column2: WASHINGTON, July 29 -- Bertha S. Adkins, assistant to the Republican National Committee chairman, issued a statement today calling attention to the fact that President Eisenhower had appointed women to twenty-seven high policy posts in his first half-year in office.

The police yesterday began distributing 40,000 more circulars in the world-wide hunt for John Mazziotta, a key suspect in the Brooklyn street slaying a year ago of Arnold Schuster, who had caused the arrest of Willie Sutton, imprisoned bank robber.
Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio, who underwent an exploratory operation at New York Hospital July 8 and took a sudden turn for the worse Tuesday, was reported yesterday to be "somewhat improved."

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- An arrangement under which small manufacturers will be eligible to bid on a portion of future purchases of jute twine has been worked out by the Small Defense Plants Administration with the Post Office Department, it was announced today.
KALAMAZOO, Mich., July 29 (AP) -- Five upsets marked the third round of the national junior tennis tournament today, but seeded players advanced in the national boys' event.

Stock prices made a gradual but sustained advance yesterday under the leadership of steels, motors, oils, utilities, electronics and the Denver and Rio Grande Western Railway, which leaped to a new 1953 high of 92 1/4 and closed 2 7/8 points higher at 91 3/4.

As a member of the Committee on Labor and Social Security Legislation of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York I want to commend you for your two excellent editorials on the majority and minority reports of the committee on amending the Taft-Hartley Act.

Two of the best instrumentalists anywhere around -- Isaac Stern and Gregor Piatigorsky -- made music singly and together last night at Lewisohn Stadium. Attracted by this stellar sequence, an audience of some 14,000 turned out. It was a most gratifying attendance for a Wednesday concert.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., July 29 -- Gordon Stott of the Nassau Country Club fashioned a 38, 34 -- 72 to gain a tie with Bertrand Kohlmann, Inwood, 36, 36 -- 72, for the qualifying medal record as a field of 123 played in the first round of the Long Island Golf Association amateur championship at the Sands Point Club today.
HAVANA, July 29 -- Ernesto de la Fe, the Minister of Information, tonight announced the capture of two motor vessels in waters off Pinar del Rio Province today.

WASHINGTON, July 29 (UP) -- The Senate passed and sent to the White House today a compromise bill creating a new small business lending agency to replace the frequently-cticized Reconstruction Finance Corporation.

SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, July 29 -- The Southern Rhodesia, police is intensifying its campaign to hunt down Negroes fleeing from their masters. The Farmers Union, which recently met here, adopted a formal resolution directing the attention of the authorities to the crime of desertion.

SAIGON, Vietnam, July 29 -- An attempt by a French and Vietnamese force estimated at close to 12,000 men to encircle and destroy two battalions of Communist-led Vietminh troops in a coastal strip of central Vietnam was reported authoritatively today to have failed.

Sales, ingot production and shipments of the Inland Steel Company, the nation's eighth largest steel producer, set new highs in the quarter ended on June 30, the company reported yesterday. The net profit was the best for any quarter since the last three months of 1951.

St. Barnabas House will be the beneficiary of the performance of "Sherlock Holmes," with Basil Rathbone, on the night of Nov. 5 at a theatre yet to be announced, instead of the night of Oct. 27, as had been announced previously. Mrs. Henry W. de Forest is chairman of the benefit committee. An encouraging sale of tickets has been reported.

A decrease last week of 374,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end they amounted to 143,446,000 barrels, compared with 143,820,000 a week earlier and 118,285,000 a year ago.
What business can do to keep the national economy sound was outlined yesterday by John S. Sinclair, president of the National Industrial Conference Board, in his annual report.

HONG KONG, July 29 -- As the Korean armistice paved the way to the exchange of military prisoners, thirty-four American civilians remained in jail today on the Chinese mainland with no indications as to their future. They include twenty-three missionaries, four businessmen, three students, two newspapermen, a merchant marine captain and an airline official.

SEOUL, Korea, July 29 -- President Syngman Rhee of the Republic of Korea said today it was "inconceivable" that the United States would fail to reopen the Korean war if the Communists refused to agree to the unification of this country.

Alexander Schneider is a musician who believes in spreading the evangel of good music by deeds, and his latest achievement in this line is to arrange for two evenings of free chamber orchestra concerts in Washington Square Park.

LONDON, July 29 -- British Government securities and South African gold mining shares were out standing for their firmness in the stock markets here today. Although business dwindled further other sections maintained a confident tone.

Middletown, Ohio, sold yesterday $4,500,000 of sewerage revenue bonds due from 1955 to 1984 to a banking syndicate headed by Glore, Forgan Co. at an interest cost of 3.34 per cent. The bid on which the issue was awarded was 98.04 for interest rates of 4 per cent, 3 per cent and 3 1/4 per cent.
ST. LOUIS, July 30 (UP) -- A five-run sixth inning, including a homer and Red Schoendienst's pinch double, gave the Cardinals a 10-4 victory over the Pirates today at Busch Stadium.

I have just learned that in your issue of July 23 the report of the hearing of Bishop Oxnam by the House Committee on Un-American Activities records that my name was entered in the record as one of two Methodist clergymen cited in "previous testimony taken secretly at New York hearings * * * as having been active members of the Communist party."

HAVANA, July 30 -- The United States Embassy has requested information from the Cuban Government concerning vessels captured by the Cuban Air Force and Navy yesterday in waters off the western tip of the island, an Embassy aide said this afternoon.

In his budget message last winter Governor Dewey said: "We should make a comprehensive reappraisal of the whole field of our fiscal operations, including the state's capital construction needs and methods of planning and paying for them, its tax stabilization reserves, its system of local assistance, and its tax system."

Frank Leahy, football coach at Notre Dame, will conduct a program of sports commentary over the A. B. C. television network on Saturdays from 9:45 to 10 P. M., beginning Sept. 26. Effective the same date, the network will begin its series of filmed telecasts of all Notre Dame home football games.

Rationing of transit tokens was liberalized yesterday by the New York City Transit Authority. Station agents of the subway and elevated lines were authorized to sell ten instead of five tokens at a time to passengers beginning at 7 A. M. today.

CHICAGO, July 30 (UP) -- Marty Furgol, winner of only two tournaments in eleven years as a pro, slashed six strokes off par at Tam O'Shanter today with a 66 to take the lead by one stroke in the All-American open.
WASHINGTON, July 30 -- During the week ended July 29, member bank reserves decreased $213,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

An appeal to the public to cooperate in meeting the many problems facing the nation's educational system was made yesterday by superintendents and administrators representing thirty-eight communities in the country. They felt they were helpless to proceed without community support.

WASHINGTON, July 30 (AP) -- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee gave quick approval today to President Eisenhower's nominees for delegates to the United Nations General Assembly session in September. The nominations now go to the Senate for expected confirmation.
A special Federal grand jury here yesterday indicted three officials of a stevedoring concern on charges of income tax evasion.
Net income reported yesterday by the Standard Oil Company of California rose to $91,373,736 in the first half of this year from $87,159,717 earned in the corresponding period of 1952.

Acting Postmaster Harold Riegelman, who ordered his employes to spruce up last week, has provided for them a spruced up "swing room" -- a locker and recreation room cheerfully painted, brightly lit and as tastefully furnished as ordinary government supplies and ingenuity permit.

The Yankees soared over the million mark for home attendance at the Stadium yesterday, but they didn't clear anything else despite valiant efforts to make Casey Stengel's sixty-third birthday a memorable one.
The State of Oregon has designated Aug. 7 as the sale date for its projected offering of $32,000,000 of highway bonds. The bonds will mature serially from Sept. 1, 1954 to 1966.

After almost a week of indecision, the International Longshoremen's Association, A. F. L., finally sent an administrator to Brooklyn yesterday to take over Local 327-1. However, he soon retreated to the friendlier shores of Manhattan, leaving the local still very much under the thumb of Anthony (Tough Tony) Anastasia.

WESTBURY, L. I., July 30 -- S. A. Wathen's 5-year-old bay horse Chuck Volo, with Wendell Wathen driving, set a world record of 3:05 3/5 for the mile-and-a-half route on a half-mile track tonight in winning the $50,000 Nassau Pace at Roosevelt Raceway.
PARIS, July 30 -- Enormous separate cape collars were one of many ways that Lanvin-Castillo gave new importance to shoulders in a showing today.

LONDON, July 30 -- What do British and European broadcasting offcials really think of American video? The answer may come as something of a surprise. Almost unanimously they think our big mistake may not be so much the more publicized intrusion of commercials as the long range social consequence of Simply having too much television.

WASHINGTON, Friday, July 31 -- Conferees for the Senate and House of Representatives agreed early this morning on a Mutual Security appropriation of $6,652,422,390 to provide President Eisenhower with a substantial margin of victory over Congressional economy advocates.

UTRECHT, the Netherlands, July 30 -- The first post-war International Parapsychology Conference opened here today with delegates from twelve countries agreeing on little more than the existence of a field they thought it would be fruitful to discuss.

BONN, Germany, July 30 -- The anti-Communist West German Trade Union Federation entered the general election campaign today with a statement to its 6,000,000 members attacking Chancellor Konrad Adenauer's coalition Government.
NORTH KINGSTOWN, R. I., July 30 (AP) -- Bell ringing Internal Revenue agents began a house-to-house canvass of Washington County today and they had a good many doors slammed in their faces.

The time is "overripe" for a tactful yet resolute confrontation of the problem of racial discrimination within the Roman Catholic Church, the Rev. John LaFarge, associate editor of the Jesuit weekly, America, said yesterday.

DOVER, England, July 30 -- Work has begun here on an experiment aimed ultimately at tieing the electric grid system that distributes light and power in Britain to the great Continental grid that extends from Scandinavia down through Europe to Spain and Italy.

WASHINGTON, July 30 (AP) -- The Federal Power Commission consolidated proceedings today on suspended wholesale natural gas rate increases of two subsidiaries of the Columbia Gas System and set a hearing here Aug. 17.

The first session of the Eighty-third Congress, like any session of any recent Congress, began at a leisurely pace and moved with increasing speed as the hoped-for day of adjournment approached. This is American, Congressional and human. At first there seems endless time ahead. Weeks go by. Little is done.

Some disappointment has been reported from both India and Pakistan over what are regarded as the meager results of the conversations between Prime Ministers Nehru and Mohammed Ali. Perhaps this is the inevitable letdown after too high hopes. The hopes were fostered, in part, by the very warmth of the reception that was accorded to Mr. Nehru in Pakistan.
WASHINGTON, July 30 -- President Eisenhower asked Congress today for a $15,000,000,000 increase in the statutory ceiling on the national debt.

SCARBOROUGH-ON-HUDSON, N. Y., July 30 -- With sub-par golf predominating, Bob Kuntz of Bonnie Briar, the defending titleholder, gained the semi-finals of the Westchester amateur championship along with Paul Kelly of Sleepy Hollow, Jerry Cole of Fenway and Ken McAleenan Jr. of Westchester Country Club.

A one-family dwelling containing eight rooms and occupying a lot 17 by 100 feet at 448 Sixth Street was sold by John Mullen to Michael De Stefano in a deal negotiated by the Charles Partridge Real Estate Company, brokers, who also sold a two-family house at 453 Sixth Street for William Woods to Josephine De Stefano.

BALTIMORE, July 30 -- In one of the peak performances of his career, Straight Clark of Pasadena, Calif., defeated Mervyn Rose of Australia today in the Middle Atlantic grass court tennis championships at the Baltimore Country Club.
Directors of the Burlington Mills Corporation have elected Henry E. Rauch a member of the board, Charles F. Myers Jr., treasurer and R. E. Osmer assistant treasurer.

It is indeed a neighborly gesture that the business associates of the late Hans Isbrandtsen should continue the noonday band concerts on Bowling Green in his honor. Those who work on lower Broadway are happy to share the tribute to his memory and are grateful also to the Park Department, Station WNYC and the other city officials who help in the arrangements.

PURCHASE, N. Y., July 30 -- A newcomer to a championship final, Mrs. Joseph A. Nesbitt of Westchester C. C., will meet Mrs. Allison Choate of Apawamis, the defending champion, in the thirty-six-hole match for the Edith R. Limburg Trophy over the Old Oaks course tomorrow.
Heavy construction contract awards reported in the week ended /fonday totaled $297,471,000, The Engineering News-Record and The Construction Daily reported yesterday.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 30 -- The United Nations has completed arrangements for the Columbia University Press to run the organization's bookshop, a favorite browsing place for thousands of tourists.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 30 -- Considerable support is developing for an expected Soviet proposal that the United Nations General Assembly invite Communist China and North Korea to send representatives when the Assembly reconvenes Aug. 17 to call the post-armistice political conference on Korea.

CHICAGO, July 30 -- Further price advances were made in wheat futures here today on the basis of black rust damage reports. The fact that wheat futures in the Minneapolis market climbed 3 1/4 to 4 5/8 cents gave weight to the rust reports, and the Minneapolis cash wheat market made even a greater advance than the futures.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- A bill authorizing New York and New Jersey to establish a bi-state commission to curb crime and racketeering on the New York waterfront was passed by the House of Representatives today and sent to President Eisenhower for his signature. The Senate passed the bill on July 16, two days after it was introduced.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, July 30 -- The formation of a predominantly Leftist Government was announced tonight by President Sukarno. Indonesia had been without a Government for fifty-eight days.

Elixir proved bad medicine for the favorite players in the feature race at the Saratoga-at-Jamaica meeting yesterday. Conceded next to the least chance against such highly regarded opponents as Mohammedan and Hyphasis, the 5-year-old son of Bleu d'Or made a fine closing bid to take the victory by a length and a half.
MOSCOW, Friday, July 31 (Reuters) -- Following is the text of the Soviet note to the United States on an air incident off Siberia, as published in Moscow newspapers today:

TRENTON, July 30 -- Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll accused the United States Air Force today of bidding up the price on a 100,000-acre tract of land the state wants for a watershed, and he threatened to take over the land by condemnation.

The word from Coney Island is that the annual Mardi Gras, which had been discontinued for the last four years, will be resumed come Labor Day. Sponsors of the lavish program already have sent assurance that the seasonal highlight down at the oceanside will have much of the pomp and glitter that have marked most of the spectacles since the Mardi Gras was inaugurated in 1902.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- Department store sales in the week ended July 25 were 5 per cent above sales in the corresponding week of last year. This was reported today by the Federal Reserve Board, which listed the following percentage changes from like periods of 1952:

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- The Senate Special Committee on Small Business will recommend tomorrow that the Civil Aeronautics Board drastically liberalize regulations that now curtail the operations of nonscheduled airlines. The committee attacked the board for "pressuring" small airlines out of business.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., July 30 -- Mal Galletta of North Hills, 1946 titleholder, led the way into the quarter-final round of the twenty-ninth Long Island Golf Association amateur championship by defeating Frank Strafaci of Connequoit, a five-time winner of the event, 3 and 2, in the second round over the Sands Point club course today.

TEHERAN, Iran, July 30 (AP) -- A meeting of opponents of Premier Mohammed Mossadegh last night ended in a fist, stick and knife battle. Four persons were sent to a hospital for treatment of injuries. One of them was reported seriously hurt.

Overshadowed by the Korean armistice developments an event has taken place in Europe which represents a blow both to democracy and to European unity. This is the overthrow of Premier De Gasperi's new Government in Italy.

A new rise in the illegal use of narcotics by adolescents, and particularly by young women, was announced yesterday by the Welfare and Health Council's Committee on the Use of Narcotics Among Teen Age Youth.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on July 25, 1953, totaled 780,705 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 10,709, or, 1.4 per cent fewer than for the preceding week, 173,515 or 28,6 per cent more than for the corresponding week of last year and 39,771, or 4.8 per cent fewer than during the corresponding week two years ago.

The last hope of a break that would prevent a near-automatic price increase for coffee at retail disappeared yesterday. Most big roasters had increased their wholesale prices about 3 cents a pound on July 10 as a result of heavy frost damage to the Brazilian crop.

RANGOON, Burma, July 30 -- Burma will ask the United Nations to brand Nationalist China an aggressor and move to unseat the Taipei Government from the international body if it fails to withdraw its forces from Burmese soil, U Ba Swe Defense Minister and "strong man" of the Dominant Nationalist party, said here today.
NEW DELHI, India, July 30 -- Prime Minister Jawalharlal Nehru reiterated today that India would oppose the oppression of racial minorities with every measure "short of war."

The 23,598-deadweight-ton tanker Phoenix, which was recently declared a total constructive loss after a collision and resultant fire, may yet escape the shipbreakers' hammers and return to the seas she ruled for four years as the largest tanker afloat.
WASHINGTON, July 30 -- Industrial production began to taper off this month in its usual summer decline, the Federal Reserve Board said today in its monthly summary of business conditions.

Last night's program at Lewisohn Stadium, conducted by Thomas Schippers, was devoted to the music of Gian-Carlo Menotti. Of greatest interest was a performance by Tossy Spivakovsky of the Violin Concerto in A minor, a work that has not yet entered the active repertory as have so many other Menotti compositions.

WASHINGTON, July 30 (AP) -- The number of new cases of infantile paralysis continued to rise last week, but, for the first time since Jan. 1, the total for the year dropped below that for the corresponding period of 1952, which was a record year.

BERLIN, July 30 -- The rush of East Germans to obtain free food in West Berlin swelled to such proportions today that it was probable those benefiting by the program would pass the million mark this week-end, thus accomplishing in less than one week what the West Berlin and Bonn Governments had planned to do in a fortnight.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- The Senate unanimously authorized $200,000,000 today toward the rehabilitation of South Korea but powerful members were aghast at President Syngman Rhee's argument that the United States must reopen the war if Korean unification failed.

WASHINGTON, July 30 (AP) -- The Department of Commerce said today that manufacturers' shipments in June totaled $25,800,000,000, about $500,000,000 higher than in May and about one-fifth more than in June, 1952.

WASHINGTON, July 30 (AP) -- The House Agriculture Committee instructed its chairman today to introduce a bill to provide for a twenty-two and half million acre cotton allotment next year, with no state to be cut more than 29 1/2 per cent from 1952 plantings.

LONDON, July 30 -- Prices continued to improve in a slightly busier stock market here today. Almost all groups rose, with British Government securities and South African goldmining shares again in the lead and oil and copper shares coming also into the limelight.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- Dr. Leonard A. Scheele, Surgeon General of the Public Health Service, Department of Health, Education and Welfare, announced today a nation-wide cooperative research effort to measure how much gamma globulin reduces the severity of paralysis in poliomyelitis.

TOKYO, Friday, July 31 (AP) -- The Air Force said today it had abandoned the search for sixteen missing crewmen of a B-50 bomber that went down Wednesday off the coast of Siberia, where speedy Russian jet fighters are based.
Nursing and the many people who use nursing services each day lost a leader and a friend recently with the death of Mrs. W. Randolph Burgess.

JACKSON, Miss., July 30 (UP) -- Gov. Hugh White today ordered a Negro prisoner freed from Parchman Penitentiary who had served nine years for a crime that authorities are now convinced he did not commit.

An appeal to all nurses here, whether practicing their profession or not, to enroll for training and assignment in Civil Defense was issued yesterday by Grover A. Whalen, chairman of the City Civil Defense Commission, at the request of Dr. Marcus D. Kogel, Commissioner of Hospitals.

CINCINNATI, July 30 (UP) -- Mae Murray, the 1950 runner-up from Rutland, Vt., rallied on the last nine today to defeat the defending champion, Polly Riley of Fort Worth, Tex., 1 up, in the quarter-finals of the Women's Western amateur golf tournament.

CAIRO, Friday, July 31 -- British and Egyptian representatives responsible for seeking a solution of the long-standing dispute over control of the Suez Canal zone met face to face last night for the first time since May 6 when direct negotiations on the issue were broken off.

ROCK ISLAND, Ill., July 30 -- Representatives of a local of the International Typographical Union, A. F. L., on strike against four quad-city newspapers, were accused today of resorting to bombing the automobiles and homes of the of the newspapers' nonstriking employes only because it cost too much to hire someone to blow up the newspaper plants.
Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio was in a coma early today at New York Hospital, and was reported sinking rapidly.

A series of stained glass panels shown at the Rambusch Studios yesterday would make unusual wall decorations for a contemporary room. The results of a project sponsored by the American Federation of Arts and the Stained Glass Association of America, they will go on view to the public at the Grace Borgenicht Gallery, 61 East Fifty-seventh Street, on Sept. 8.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- The Reconstruction Finance Corporation, controversial Government lending agency, went out of existence with a stroke of President Eisenhower's pen today. He signed a bill that established instead the Small Business Administration.

The luxurious Rockefeller Apartments at 17-23 West Fifty-fourth Street and 24-36 West Fifty-fifth Street, erected in 1936 by John D. Rockefeller Jr. as a residential adjunct to Rockefeller Center, are "going cooperative."
Lucy Monroe made a plea yesterday on behalf of the United Nations troops in Korea for stars from the entertainment world to visit them.

SAIGON, Vietnam, July 30 (AP) -- French authorities said today they inflicted 600 casualties on the Communist-led Vietminh and chased them out of a series of fortified villages on the Central Indo-China coast.

ROCQUENCOURT, France July 30 -- The extensive studies that Supreme Allied Headquarters here is making on atomic weapons indicate that the North Atlantic Treaty forces will need all "conventional" arms they can get during the first ninety days of any future war.

When Soviet citizens opened their newspapers yesterday morning they found the front pages dominated by a large picture of Lenin. Only Pravda, among the Moscow papers, carried a picture of Stalin and this was a small photograph of Lenin and Stalin printed almost inconspicuously on an inside page.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- The Atomic Energy Commission reported today that it had started to develop an advanced type of nuclear power plant for a submarine to have "significantly higher speed" than the two nuclear-powered undersea craft already under construction.
TOKYO, Friday, July 31 -- The United Nations and Communist armies that fought the three-year Korean war completed their withdrawal from the 155-mile battle-front last night.
STORIES you hear in the immaculate five-story house at 69 St. Mark's Place where the Rev. Walter D. Britt takes in the broken homeless are apt to tighten your throat a bit.

Four hundred and eighty pounds of capsules for tuberculous and under-nourished Koreans, the first of a series of shipments totaling 20,000 pounds of emergency medical supplies donated by American pharmaceutical houses, left New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- The Rev. Jack Richard McMichael, 36-year-old Georgia-born pastor of a small-town California Methodist Church, swore before the Committee on Un-American Activities of the House of Representatives today that he was not now and never had been a member of the Communist party.

The Federal Government should maintain a "hands off" policy on credit controls until it is determined whether deflation or inflation lies immediately ahead, it was decided yesterday by participants in a consumer credit management program. They had just finished a four-day forum discussion of the topic sponsored by the School of Business of Columbia University at Arden House, Harriman, N. Y.
The New York Stock Exchange list showed gains of fractions to 4 points at the close of yesterday's market which saw prices at the best levels since July 9 and net gains the best since June 17.
HARTFORD, Conn., July 30 -- Charles F. Kelley, Connecticut's Motor Vehicle Commissioner, warned New York automobile drivers today about passing on the right on highways in this state.

CAMDEN, N. J., July 30 -- A wage agreement between the New York Shipbuilding Corporation and Local 1, Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers of America, A. F. L., calls for an average 16 1/2 cents an hour wage increase for 5,000 employes of the yard here.

PHILADELPHIA, July 30 (AP) -- Lacking $175,000 in bail, six men identified by the Federal Bureau of Investigation as among the top leadership of the Communist party here were held in Moyamensing Prison today on charges of conspiring to teach and advocate the overthrow of the United States Government by force and violence.

WESTBURY, L. I., July 30 -- The Farmington (Conn.) poloists led the way into the final round of Hempstead Cups 12-goal tournament with a 11-2 victory over the Hurricanes on Whitney Field at the Meadow Brook Club today.
LONDON, July 30 -- The Soviet Union's apparent bid for a resumption of four-power discussions of an Austrian treaty was received by diplomatic quarters here today with considerable wariness.
THE horses will soon be going to Saratoga. Soon, indeed! Why, they'll be running at the Spa on Monday, and they'll continue to do the same there every racing day through Aug. 29.
SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, July 30 -- The Government here is trying the experiment of having the white man regularly till the soil with his own hands instead of having the Negro do it for him.

At the risk of dampening the enthusiasm of many New Yorkers, including yourselves, may I question for a moment the wisdom of the "largest commercial building project to be erected in Manhattan since Rockefeller Center," as announced in THE TIMES on July 23 and commented upon in your editorial of July 24.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 30 -- Prof. Sergei Alexandrovich Golunsky, the International Court of Justice's long-missing Russian judge, has resigned, leaving a vacancy that will be filled in the fall by the eighth session of the General Assembly.

The six-story building with thirty-two apartments and three stores at 1103 Washington Avenue in the Bronx, has been purchased by Seymour M. Tannenbaum, operator, from the 1103 Washington Avenue Corporation through Curtis Solove, broker.
LONDON, July 30 (AP) -- The London Evening News tonight said, "The real power in Russia has passed to a military triumvirate led by the famous wartime hero Marshal Georgi K. Zhukov."
ROME, July 30 -- The Communist leader, Palmiro Togliatti, conveyed to President Luigi Einaudi today his party's demand to be included in the next Cabinet no matter who is to head it.

Record production, shipments and net billings for both the June quarter and the first half of this year were reported yesterday by the Bethlehem Steel Corporation. Its net income of $59,495,136 for the six months to June 30 was the best for any first half in the company's history.
BOSTON, July 30 (UP) -- The White Sox handed the Boston Red Sox their worst defeat of the season, 17 -- 1, today to sweep a three-game series.

Percy and Harold Uris, builders of the twenty-five-story office building at 575 Madison Avenue, the blockfront from Fifty-sixth to Fifty-seventh Streets, have purchased the land from the William Waldorf Astor Estate. The property is assessed at $9,500,000, of which $2,750,000 is land value.

After reading that the executive committee had chosen candidates for the November election, I went to my party's County Committee headquarters to find out the names of persons on the executive committee.
I note the communication from Harry N. Haight regarding migrant labor in New York State.

Steamship passenger travel between this country and Canada and European or Mediterranean ports probably will reach record proportions this year, but, on the basis of the movement during the first half year, will fall far short of the 1,000,000-person mark so freely predicted by passenger officials in January.
In French a matelote can denote a sailor's wife, a sailor's dance or a fish stew. It is with the last meaning of the word that we are concerned today.

PARIS, July 30 -- An appeal "on bended knee" to recover Robert and Gerald Finaly from Israel was made today to President Vincent Auriol by Mlle. Antoinette Brun, former Roman Catholic guardian of the two Jewish war orphans.

LONDON, July 30 -- The Labor Opposition in both Houses of Parliament laid down a barrage of criticism today on John Foster Dulles, United States Secretary of State, because of his statement last Tuesday at a press conference that the United States had promised to walk out of the Korean peace conference if it got nowhere within ninety days of its start.

LONDON, July 30 -- Oliver Lyttelton, British Colonial Secretary, welcomed nineteen delegates from Nigeria who assembled here today to draw up a new constitution for the British West African dependency which has been torn by internal political dissension. The delegates responded with promises of cooperation.
The New York International Airport at Idlewild, Queens, is observing today the fifth anniversary of its formal dedication, although the occasion may go unnoticed by many New Yorkers.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- The House of Representatives approved today a joint resolution authorizing the creation of a United States commission to cooperate with Columbia University in the observance next year of the 200th anniversary of its founding.

TEL AVIV, Israel, July 30 -- A spokesman of the Minorities Department of the Ministry of the Interior denied today the validity of complaints submitted to Parliament by the Society for Defense of the Rights of Arabs in Israel alleging that Arabs were arbitrarily deprived of democratic municipal government.

Buoyancy in bank stocks has been increasingly noticeable ever since the bond market reversed its downward drift with the relaxation of Federal Reserve credit policy. The increment in deposits stemming from the reduction in statutory bank reserve requirements, the abrupt recovery in gilt-edged bond prices, and the better rate of return on loan transactions have all contributed to the "new look" acquired by most bank stocks during July.
CHICAGO, July 30 -- Six men, followers of an excommunicated former Roman Catholic priest, were arrested today after they had forced their way into the office of Samuel Cardinal Stritch here.
WASHINGTON, July 30 (UP) -- Jim Busby's bases-loaded triple in the fifth inning proved the big hit !today as the Senators defeated the Tigers, 7---4, behind the six-hit pitching of Chuck Stobbs.
WASHINGTON, July 30 -- It seems that President Eisenhower went in for vegetable gardening in his spare time during his military career.

While Hawaii was losing what seemed to be a fair chance to advance toward statehood at this session of Congress and Alaska was left out in a more than Arctic cold, Puerto Rico was going ahead under its so-called "Commonwealth" Constitution and making very good weather of it. A commonwealth is something new in our American system in the sense in which Puerto Rico has that status.
WASHINGTON, July 30 (AP) -- A Senate Commerce subcommittee today ended, for this session in Congress, its hearings on what the size and composition of the American merchant marine should be.

THE shooter, whether he is hunting, punching holes in a target, or merely plinking, wants as much accuracy as he can get, and Marlin has now come forward with a new rifle barrel that reputedly will increase accuracy by about 20 per cent, at least in smallbore shooting.

In behalf of the Manhattan School of Music, officers and members of the school's board of trustees have taken over the performance of "Late Love," a new comedy by Rosemary Casey, with Arlene Francis, John Loder and Lucile Watson in the leading roles, on the night of Oct. 15 at a theatre yet to be announced. Mrs. Hayden N. Smith is president and Mrs. John Hubbard, honorary president of the board.

HONG KONG, Friday, July 31 -- After having traveled almost enough sea miles to circumnavigate the globe -- and gone nowhere in the process -- passportless Michael Patrick O'Brien, who has lived the life of a human shuttlecock for more than ten months, ended his yo-yo voyaging yesterday. He landed in Hong Kong and may be headed for Brazil.

NEW DELHI, India, July 30 -- In planning the forthcoming political conference on Korea, the United Nations General Assembly must consider the views of the Communist Chinese and North Korean Governments "and their friends whoever they may be," Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru declared today.

TRENTON, July 30 -- Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll, under fire from both the Republican and Democratic candidates for Governor, said today he would ask for a review of the recent $2 cut in the state's monthly food allowance for needy families.

The police were studying last night the possibility that a homicidal maniac who killed two truck drivers on the Pennsylvania Turnpike within the week also might be the murderer of Michael J. (Barney) Prendergast, the New York tavern owner found slain in Fort Washington Park Wednesday morning.

Helen Hayes, president of the American Theatre Wing, has set up in memory of her daughter the Mary MacArthur Scholarship to provide funds for a young dramatic or musical comedy actress to study for a year in the Wing's professional training program.

Trading slowed in almost all commodities on the New York exchanges yesterday. Prices were generally lower as profit taking weakened those items that had been showing steady advances. Coffee, cocoa, potatoes, lead, zinc, tin and hides were lower; sugar, cottonseed oil, wool and copper mixed, and soybean oil and rubber higher.

CINCINNATI, July 30 (UP) -- The Phillies, beaten, 17 -- 7, by Cincinnati last night, turned the tables today to down the Redlegs, 17 -- 8, as Del Ennis connected for his twenty - first and twenty - second homers of the season.

Crippling damage to a basic American skill -- the technique of building ships -- is in serious prospect throughout the country as a consequence of the contraction in the shipbuilding industry. Qualified persons concerned for America's manpower requirements have expressed worry about the future of a profession that dates back on these shores to the launching of the thirty-ton Virginia on the Kennebec River in Maine in 1607.
HARTFORD, Conn., July 30 (AP) -- Connecticut had today its first woman Governor.

The Aluminum Import Corporation, a subsidiary of Aluminum, Ltd., announced yesterday it would apply to the United States District Court here and seek to be made a party in the case arising from a petition filed by the Department of Justice on July 20.

CHICAGO, July 30 (UP) -- The National Safety Council reported today 470 more auto deaths in the first half of 1953 than in the first six months of 1952. The six-month total for this year was 17,300, a 3 per cent increase over the 16,830 fatalities in 1952.
WASHINGTON, July 30 (AP) -- Following is the text of President Eisenhower's special message to Congress asking an increase of $15,000,000,000 in the statutory ceiling on the national debt:

BERLIN, July 30 -- Walter Ulbricht, active leader of East Germany's Communists, said in a speech published today that although the East German Government was slowing down its program it was not halting its movement toward collectivization and the creation of an army.

The three-minute headway on all Long Island Rail Road trains entering and leaving the Pennsylvania Station must be maintained to cope with the automatic speed control equipment that was completed last spring, J. Frank Doolan, chief operating officer of the railroad declared yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- A subcommittee report criticizing an arrangement that would have allowed the New York City Police Department to bypass the Federal Bureau of Investigation in civil rights brutality cases involving New York policemen is awaiting the approval of the full House Judiciary Committee.
Trading was dull on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday and closing prices were 8 to 10 points net lower on active months than on Wednesday.
WASHINGTON, July 30 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission authorized the country's railroads today to continue to add a 15 per cent surcharge to freight bills until Dec. 31, 1955.

FAIRFIELD, Conn., July 30 -- Lois Hallager of Scarsdale G. C., tournament chairman of the Women's Westchester and Fairfield Golf Association, posted a 43, 44 -- 87 to win the low gross honors in the organization's weekly one-day competition at the Country Club of Fairfield today.

BUENOS AIRES, July 30 -- Making his reappearance as a newspaper columnist, President Juan Peron today declared: "Let us thank God the United States has a President." This morning's edition of the semi-official newspaper Democracia carried a front-page article by Descartes, President Peron's nom de plume, praising President Eisenhower's decisions in the Far East and South America.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 30 -- June Allyson, now finishing "The Glenn Miller Story" at Universal, will be going back to the studio next January for another production. Aaron Rosenberg, now producing the biography of the orchestra leader, has signed Miss Allyson to appear in "Foxfire," which he will supervise also.

It is unfortunate that the Administration, faced with the need for a higher legal limit on the federal debt, did not ask for the enabling legislation before this, when it would have been treated as the routine matter it is. Somehow the notion seems to have got abroad in Congress in the last few days that a matter of economic or political principle is at stake here and that the President's action should be challenged.

John S. Sinclair, chairman of New York Chapter, American Red Cross, appealed to New Yorkers yesterday to step up blood donations for processing into gamma globulin for the fight against infantile paralysis, or poliomyelitis.
VIENNA, July 30 -- The Soviet Government told the Austrian Government here today that it would pay its own occupation costs in Austria after Aug. 5 as the United States has done since July, 1947.

MILWAUKEE, July 30 (UP) -- Secretary of Agriculture Ezra Taft Benson labeled "preposterous" today charges that the Administration was "scuttling farm programs" or that the "rug is being pulled out from under the farmers."

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., July 30 (AP) -- A Schenectady automobile dealer bid $15,000 today and gained tentative ownership of the Piping Rock Club, one-time elaborate gambling establishment in this horse-racing spa.

MOSCOW, Friday, July 31 -- The Soviet Union, in identical notes to the United States, Britain and France, has proposed that the Western powers withdraw the so-called short draft treaty for Austria to facilitate new conversations designed to lead to the signature of an Austrian treaty.

One phase of the truck drivers' strike that has brought unemployment to 100,000 building trades workers and halted construction costing $600,000,000 was settled yesterday when 900 dump truck drivers accepted a wage offer from employers.

WASHINGTON, July 30 (AP) -- Following is the 45 -- 43 roll-call vote by which the Senate tonight passed and sent to the White House a compromise bill authorizing Federal development of the submerged lands in the outer continental shelf, but minus a provision earmarking the revenues for education:

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- Theodore C. Streibert, radio executive of Locust Valley, L. I., was nominated by President Eisenhower today as director of the new United State Information Agency, which will take over all the controversial State Department libraries and information units, including the Voice of America.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., July 30 -- The Town Board of Health finally mustered today the courage to take action against a couple of hundred peacocks whose noisy mating cries had aroused a cluster of protesting citizens, incluuding two members of the Wesleyan University faculty unable to concentrate on their studies.

SAIGON, Vietnam, July 30 -- France's pledge of greater independence for the Indo-China states has produced new stirrings of domestic political activity in Vietnam, largest of the three. Vietnamese political personalities are beginning to consider the problems connected with creating a definitive form of government for their country and deciding who the government leaders should be.

Development of an external third speaker for its high-fidelity phonograph to produce "three-dimensional sound effects" was announced yesterday by Columbia Records, Inc., a subsidiary of the Columbia Broadcasting System.
A further midsummer settlement in the business loans of the New York City banks took place in the week ended on Wednesday, according to the Federal Reserve Bank here.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, July 29 A method for the isolation of lignin from wood, the result of several years of experiment at Fordham University, New York, was described here today in a paper read before the Thirteenth International Congress of Pure and Applied Chemistry by Dr. Friedrich F. Nord, Professor of Organic Chemistry at Fordham.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 30 -- Gen. Mark W. Clark came "home to San Francisco" today to a warm civic welcome during which he counseled repeatedly against letting the Korean armi stice relax the guard of the free world against Communist aggression.

CARLE PLACE, L. I., July 30 -- Four hundred union stewards from the Sperry Gyrosdope Company's plant at Lake Success staged a demonstration here today outside the strike-bound Army Corporation's plant at Roosevelt Field, cheered by 2,000 picketing Arma employes.
The case of the noisy air conditioner was settled in Flatbush Magistrate's Court yesterday in favor of science, progress and at least one kind of human comfort -- a cool bedroom for summer sleeping.

MOSCOW, Friday, July 31 -- The Soviet Government, in a note delivered to the United States Embassy yesterday, charged that a United States B-50 bomber had violated Soviet frontiers in the region of Cape Gamova and flew over Askold Island, not far from Vladivostok.

Books by the Chute sisters, B. J. (Beatrice Joy) and Marchette, are on button's list for publication this season. B. J. Chute's book to be published Aug. 24 is a novel, "The End of Loving," that concerns an incompatible marriage. A husband's love for another woman, an unmarried girl's love for a married man and a wife's struggle to win a second chance to convince her husband of her real love constitute the story's theme.

A custom smelter which had been quoting refined copper at 29 3/4 cents a pound since April 23 trimmed its price 3/4 cent yesterday to 29 cents. Other major sellers, including the big mine producers, took no action immediately to alter their price of 30 cents, quoted since late March.

A high percentage 0f the country's largest exhibitors in trade shows favors uniform attendance reports for such exhibits, according to a survey by the lational Industrial Advertisers Association and the Association of National Advertisers.

LONDON, July 30 -- By a newly signed treaty submitted to the House of Commons today Britain has obtained 20-year rights to maintain military establishments in Libya in return for financial aid to the North African kingdom.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- The Senate approved tonight, 45 to 43, a bill for Federal development of the natural resources of the outer Continental Shelf without any provision that revenues be devoted to aid to education.

PHILADELPHIA, July 30 (AP) -- Marion Fricano pitched a smooth eight-hitter and his Philadelphia team-mates banged St. Louis hurlers for five runs in the second inning-- including Gus Zernial's twenty-third homer of the year-- as the Athletics defeated the Browns by 5--3 tonight.

Sliced bacon is selling at peak prices in New York, the City Department of Markets reports. Averaging 69 cents a pound a year ago, it has advanced to 98 cents in many stores and in some is as high as $1.06.

WASHINGTON, July 30 (UP) -- The armed services said today they would drop about 27,000 Reserve officers from active duty by next July 1 because of budget ceilings. This is in addition to the number normally expected to be dropped during that period.

Dr. David M. McQueen has been appointed director of research of the chemical department of E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., and Dr. Robert M. Joyce Jr. has been named assistant director of research. Dr. Gerald M. Whitman was appointed laboratory director.
Criminal informations charging conspiracy to violate bookmaking and lottery statutes were returned yesterday against twenty-eight defendants as a result of the widespread gambling raids on July 7.

SOUTHAMPTON, L. I., July 30 -- Top-seeded players scored double victories to move into the quarter-final round of the sixty-fourth annual Meadow Club men's tennis singles tournament which started today and will continue through Sunday.

Although Gilbert Miller said yesterday in London, where "The Living Room" has established itself, that he had made "no deal yet" to buy the Graham Greene play, Mr. Miller did acknowledge that he was still pitching for it. He added there was no hope of New York getting the attraction this season because of its enormous popularity.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 30 -- Cambodia's intention of launching a five-year program of economic development is reflected in two agreements -- one basic and one specific -- signed in Phnompenh between the Royal Cambodian Government and the technical Assistance Administration of the United Nations. An announcement today explained that the basic document defines the general terms of the relationship that will govern the provision of technical assistance.

LUBBOCK, Tex., July 30 -- Charges that wealthy cattle producers, including some who operate ranches as a "sideline," were taking advantage of the Federal drought aid program to buy feed at bargain prices were being heard today in the Southwest.

End - of - the - month attendance figures now being compiled at the Brooklyn Museum confirm what many a mother of youngsters "at home" for the summer knows very well -- that hot weather is a fine time for taking children to museums.
CHICAGO, July 30 -- Brooklyn's winning streak ended at five games today when the Cubs handed the Dodgers a going-away defeat, 3 -- 2, behind the seven-hit pitching of Bob Rush.
Twelve of the thirty-five Tammany Assembly District leaders from ten of the sixteen Manhattan districts announced yesterday their support of Mayor Impellitteri and his running mates.

MILWAUKEE, July 30 -- Monty Irvin's name went into the record book today as the Giants were blanked, 5 -- 0, by Lou Burdette of the Braves. However, the distinction is one Irvin would like to forget, for by grounding into three double plays, the leading hitter of Leo Durocher's outfit tied a National League record now shared by twelve men.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- Rent increases averaging 10 per cent can be expected in the communities where Federal rent controls will die tomorrow at midnight, William Barr, Deputy Chief of the Office of Rent Stabilization, said today.

Charges that President Fulgencio Batista of Cuba had formed an alliance with Communist elements that had restored them to strength in labor unions and in his Government were denied on his behalf yesterday.

MARION, Mass., July 30 -- The final sailing contests of the New York Yacht Club cruise on this side of Cape Cod Canal brought a third straight triumph to George R. Hinman's yawl, Sagola, from Manhasset Bay. Tomorrow the squadron races to Boothbay Harbor, Me.

Pete II has been named by the Bronx Zoo to fill the vacancy caused by the death of Pete, the Methuselah of the hippopotamus world, that died Feb. 1 at the world's record age -- for hippopotamuses -- of almost fifty years.

FONTAINEBLEAU, France, July 31 -- More than 1,800 combat aircraft from nine of the North Atlantic Treaty nations, plus a visiting Meteor jet squadron from Australia, ended today a ten-day maneuver over West Europe, one of the most far reaching and complicated that had been held since the Allied nations pooled their airpower two years ago.

WASHINGTON, July 31 -- A Democratic-led movement to delay a decision on raising the national debt limit until September or October left the door open, if narrowly, today for Congress to adjourn its regular 1953 session tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, July 31 -- Gen. Peyton C. March, Chief of Staff of the Army during World War I and still erect despite his 88 years, stood before President Eisenhower today and heard the praise of Congress for his counsel in matters of national security.

Summer has just a few more weeks to go. But for many children, however, summer -- with the traditional going-away to camp, the country, or the seashore -- hasn't yet begun. They include youngsters who face life with two strikes against them. They are the unlucky ones -- the children from broken homes, the hurt and the troubled, the sick and the undernourished.

PARIS, July 31 -- For stepping out on an autunm day Maggy Rouff's collection featured separate fur-trimmed cape collars to companion youthful princess frocks flaring into a moderate bell at the knee level and shortened to about fourteen inches.

LONDON, July 31 -- Since last May Britain and the main trading nations of Western Europe have been discussing proposals to extend to a much wider area the measures employed by the European Payments Union to liberalize international trade and payments.

WASHINGTON, July 31 (AP) -- The political team of "Bob and Martha" is ended, after many a year of triumph and disappointment. When Senator Robert A. Taft died in a New York hospital today his wife, who had helped him in his political campaigns, was not able to be with him because of her own illness. She suffered a stroke three years ago and has since then been in a wheel chair.

Some cigarettes will be made available in New York and New England by the R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company at bargain prices within a week or two. Smokers in these localities will be able to buy a tin of 100 king-size Cavaliers for about 79 cents. This represents a savings of about 8 cents a pack.
BAYONNE, N. J., July 31 -- As every sensitive cook knows, there are two ways to prepare food for human consumption by the method known as "boiling." They are:

There must have been hardly a dry eye in the house as a hardy dozen of the thirty-five Tammany Assembly District leaders of Manhattan marched through the City Hall doors to repent of earlier mistakes and throw their support to Mayor Impellitteri for the Democratic nomination in the September primary.
A brief in support of William W. Remington's appeal from a conviction for perjury was filed in Federal Court yesterday by counsel for the former Government economist.

WASHINGTON, July 31 (AP) -- The Federal Government announced today the settlement, for $300,000, of a patent infringement claim filed on behalf of seven atomic scientists. Among them was Bruno Pontecorvo, Italian-born scientist who disappeared in September, 1950.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, July 31 -- "Despair" among native Africans was found by Dr. Frank S. Loescher, head of the Philadelphia Commission on Human Rights who has just completed a six months' scientific study of the racial situation in South Africa.
NEWARK, July 31 -- An estimated 2,000 New Jersey landlords who received permission this month from Federal authorities to raise rents found out today that the state would not let them do it.

The group of "gyp linen shops" on Fifth Avenue has had a record summer season defrauding the public, according to the Fifth Avenue Association. The association, which receives most of the complaints about the shops even though it cannot do much about them, says that it has heard from more irate shoppers during the last few months than ever before.

WASHINGTON, July 31 -- Last year, for the first time, television network time sales surpassed those of radio networks, the Federal Communications Commission revealed today in a report containing financial data on the operations of the television broadcast industry.

There is considerable misconception among many regarding British trade with the Communists. Much of this misconception is fostered by those who are always prepared to create discord between the British and American peoples. And the report of the Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations has added considerably to this.

Twenty-five Japanese post-graduate students who were about to discontinue their studies here for lack of funds have been enabled to pursue them through the award of grants-in-aid by Japan Society, Inc. Announcement of the awards was made yesterday by John D. Rockefeller 3d, the society's president.

The Ford Motor Company is entering the farm-machinery field on a wider scale. Henry Ford 2d, president, said the company's farm-machinery line will be one of the most complete in the industry, offering more than 100 major implements.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 31 -- Americans working for the United Nations cannot get passports for personal travel abroad until they have gone through the loyalty investigations ordered by Washington for all United States citizens on the organization's payroll.

Trading on the New York Stock Exchange dropped last month to the smallest since last August and was the dullest of any July since 1949 despite the half-hour extension of the business day. Sales exceeded the 1,000,000-share mark in only nine sessions, the largest of which was 1,318,679 shares, yesterday.
New financing in July showed a marked decline. Flotations of new bonds were the smallest in four months; stock offerings the least since December.

Greater sales and increased income from other sources lifted the net income of E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., to $114,758,444 in the first six months of this year from $101,708,123 in the corresponding period of 1952.

Your editorial "Tax Relief for the Movies?" is predicated on the assumption that the elimination of theatre admissions taxes "would involve a complete reversal of Government policy by placing relief of inequities ahead of budgetary considerations (and this at an estimated annual cost of $100 millions )."

CINCINNATI, July 31 (AP) -- Two school teachers, 29-year-old Claire Doran of Cleveland and 25-year-old Jane Nelson of Indianapolis, today reached the final of the 53d women's western amateur golf championship.

WASHINGTON, July 31 -- The death of Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio has shaken the Republican party as it has not been shaken in half a lifetime. It has removed the one real bridge between the East and Midwest in the Eisenhower Administration.

TOKYO, Saturday, Aug. 1 -- Capt. John Roche of Washington, D. C., co-pilot of the RB-50 shot down by Soviet fighter planes Wednesday off the Siberian coast, said here today there was no chance the plane could have flown over Soviet territory.
CHICAGO, July 31 -- Marshall Field Co. today reported sharp rises to net income and higher sales in both the quarter and six months ended on June 30 from corresponding periods a year ago.

OCEANPORT, N. J., July 31 (AP) -- L. R. Troiano's King Commander won the hurdle championship at Monmouth Park today by scoring a nose victory over Sanford Stud Farms' Mackville in the $10,000 added Midsummer Hurdle Handicap. A crowd of 18,354 attended the races.

CINCINNATI, July 31 -- This was a big night for Sam Calderone, the third-string catcher of the Giants. Receiving his first chance to start behind the plate this season, Calderone smashed a 3-run double in the fifth inning and helped make it easy for Larry Jansen to beat the Redlegs, 9 -- 2, before 11,497 fans at Crosley Field.

When Robert A. Taft, son of President William Howard Taft, was first elected Senator from Ohio in 1938, it marked the second time in United States history that a President's son had been chosen for the Senate. The only other son of a President to gain that office had been John Quincy Adams, whose father, John Adams, had been the second President.

BOSTON, July 31 -- The Internal Revenue Services door-to-door canvass in New England has flushed out more than 350 persons who had failed to file income tax returns, in the first two days, according to Wilber A. Gallahan, regional commissioner.

WASHINGTON, July 31 (AP) -The new United States delegation to the United Nations, including Gov. James F. Byrnes of South Carolina, whose selection had stirred up some differences among Democrats, won Senate confirmation today without discussion on the floor.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., July 31 -- A proposal for a new banking merger and expansion in Westchester County that would have financial support of the John D. Rockefeller Jr. family of Pocantico Hills was under discussion today.

An 80-year-old man was found hanged by a clothes line yesterday from a basement beam of a Jackson Heights, Queens, home in an apparent suicide. His wife, also 80, had died of natural causes a few hours earlier.

In the name of all Ukrainian exiles I should like to formulate certain objections to the use of the term "Soviet minorities" in speaking of the non-Russian peoples of the U.S.S.R. The word "minorities," as used in international law in the treaties of 1919, brings to mind small and scattered groups, usually living in a frontier zone, and cut off from the main body of their people.

A decision is expected next week on the opening date here for the musical, "Carnival in Flanders." The attraction, which begins an engagement on Monday at the Curran Theatre in San Francisco, is tentatively scheduled to open in New York on Sept. 8 at the Century Theatre.

Over-cautiousness by retailers or consumers in the next sixty days can bring market price "weakness" broken retail stocks, lost sales and devalued inventories, according to Bernard G. Cohn, president of the Independent Retailers Syndicate, New York resident buyers office.

VIENNA, July 31 -- Chancellor Julius Raab thanked the Soviet Union today for announcing it would pay its occupation costs in Austria, but took the occasion to deny that his Government in accepting such concessions was pursuing a Russophile policy.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 31 -Gov. Frank J. Lausche, a Democrat, maintained a firm silence today on the appointment of a successor to Senator Robert A. Taft, Republican of Ohio, who died earlier in New York.

WASHINGTON, July 31 -- Judge Henry A. Schweinhaut dismissed in the Federal District Court here today an application by the North American Airlines group of unscheduled flight operators for an order to restrain the Civil Aeronautics Board from holding a hearing on charges involving violations of its regulations.

The Atlantic and Gulf district of the Seafarers International Union, A. F. L., has notified eighty-four companies of intention to modify existing agreements, Paul Hall, secretary-treasurer of the district, said yesterday.

LONDON, July 31 -- A spokesman of the British Foreign Office said today the Soviet note calling upon the three principal Western powers to withdraw their abbreviated draft for a peace treaty with Austria was "rather disappointing."

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., July 31 (AP) -- The uncle and aunt of Carita Esther Bird Plunkett of Stamford started a new attempt today to prevent her $400,000 estate from going to her husband, who is serving a prison term for killing her.

WASHINGTON, July 31 -- The Department of Justice announced today that it had seized in San Francisco a liberty ship, the Lewis Emery Jr., on the ground that it had been illegally acquired from the Federal Government by a corporation controlled by aliens.

The third concert of the Naumburg Symphony Orchestra summer series took place on the Mall in Central Park last evening under the direction of Joseph Hawthorne, conductor of the Chattanooga Symphony. Joan Radley, 'cellist, was the soloist.

WASHINGTON, July 31 (AP) -- Bob Porterfield's sixth shut-out, a three-hit effort, stopped the White Sox, 2 -- 0, tonight as the Senators snapped Virgil Trucks' string of victories at eight. The loss dropped the Chicago team five and one-half games back of the league-leading Yankees.

A lone hold-up man, evidently impatient and amateurish, was critically wounded yesterday by a burst of fire from the pistols of six policemen when he attempted to hold up the Witty Brothers clothing store, 1384 Broadway, at Thirty-eighth Street.

WASHINGTON, July 31 (UP) -- Lewis L. Strauss, the chairman, said today the Atomic Energy Commission hoped to have recommendations ready by the end of the year for industrial development of atomic power.

LONDON, July 31 -- Duncan Sandys, Minister of Supply, reiterated today Britain's willingness to exchange atomic information on a reciprocal basis with the United States. He told the House of Commons that Britain's second explosion of an atomic bomb would take place in Australia in October and said that the British Government had made sure that the United States Administration "is well aware of our extreme readiness to have a frank exchange."
WASHINGTON, July 31 (AP) -- Following is the text of a United States note landed to the Soviet Government today by Ambassador Charles E. Bohlen on the downing of a B-50 plane off Siberia:

GUATEMALA, July 31 -- To an observer revisiting Guatemala after six months, the overriding factor in the political situation is the disintegration that has occurred among the organized opposition to the Government of President Jacobo Arbenz Guzman and his Communist allies.

The suggestion of Raymond W. Ehrenberg in his letter published July 29 that parades take place in Central Park instead of on main thoroughfares is one which I have had in mind for a long time. It is gratifying to note that it has occurred to others.
HAVANA, July 31 (UP) -- President Fulgencio Batista promoted, dismissed or transferred a dozen officials today in a long-expected shake-up of the Cuban Government.

CASABLANCA, French Morocco, July 31 (AP) -- The United States Army announced today a new contract arrangement with Atlas Constructors that, it said, would bring down to $32,400,000 the cost of completing work on three giant air bases here.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 31 -- Robert Aldrich was assigned today to direct "Bronco Apache" for Norma Productions.

LONDON, Saturday, Aug. 1 (AP) -- A Soviet note, broadcast by the Moscow radio, today charged that American fighter planes brought down the Soviet passenger plane as it was flying from Port Arthur, Manchuria, to the Soviet Union.

MORRISBURG, Ont., July 31 (AP) -- A bus bound from Toronto for Montreal crashed into the rear of a stalled truck near here before dawn today and plunged with sleeping passengers into the Williamsburg Canal. Twenty persons were dead -- probably all of them drowned.

SEOUL, Korea, July 31 -- United States fighting men in Korea are about to embark on a different kind of soldiering: manning new positions beyond the neutral zone, combat training, civilian schooling and just plain having a good time.

KALAMAZOO, Mich., July 31 (AP) -- John Lesch, 17, of Los Angeles, sprang the biggest upset of the national junior tennis championships today by putting out top-seeded Jon Douglas of Santa Monica, Calif., 4 -- 6, 10 -- 8, 6 -- 4, in the quarter-final round.

TEHERAN, Iran, July 31 -- Dr. Mohammed Nasiri, governor of the Bank Melli (Iran's national bank), today denied charges by opposition politicians that money circulation had been increased without an accompanying increase in gold backing.

PITTSBURGH, July 31 -- For the third time in the last ten days a truck driver was shot today, but unlike the two others he is still alive. Because the pattern of the shootings was so similar -- the first two on the Pennsylvania Turnpike, today's fifteen miles west of its western terminus -- the police believed all were the work of the same man, whom they described as "a maniac loose on the Turnpike."

Arrangements have been concluded for the installation of CinemaScope, Twentieth Century-Fox' new wide-screen process, in more than 100 theatres in Mexico, it was announced yesterday by Spyros P. Skouras, company president.

PURCHASE, N Y., July 31 -- Mrs. Allison Choate of Apawamis won the ninth annual women's Tri-County Golf Association championship by defeating Mrs. Joseph A. Nesbitt of the Westchester C. C., 6 and 5, in the thirty-six-hole final over the Old Oaks course today.

HAWTHORNE, N. Y., July 31 -- It is still illegal to pass an automobile on the right on any of the sixty-five miles of park-ways of the Westchester County Park Commission, Chief Orville Perry of the parkway police said this afternoon.

BONN, Germany, July 31 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer indicated today that the West German anti-Communist front represented by the Trade Union Federation of 6,000,000 members might be split as a result of the federation leaders' implied decision to line up with the Social Democrats against the Government parties in the general election Sept. 6.

Mayor Impellitteri announced yesterday at City Hall the official designation of Aaron Frank, Third Deputy Police Commissioner, to run on his ticket as candidate for the Democratic nomination for Borough President of the Bronx. Mr. Frank will oppose Borough President James J. Lyons in the primary election on Sept. 15.
BERLIN, July 31 -- Western officials here have evidence that the Soviet Union is reducing its reparations demands on East Germany, possibly on a substantial scale.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 31 -- United Nations delegates expect Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold to act as a link between the East and West in trying to work out an agreed formula for the composition, agenda and site of the high-level political conference on the Far East.
The following is a roundup of new products that may be of interest to the homemaker who plans to travel this month:
Senator Robert A. Taft died here yesterday of malignant tumors, and President Eisenhower led the nation in mourning.

JACKSON, Mich., July 31 -Cancellation of $3,500,000 in Air Force contracts for F-86 Sabre jet gunchargers was announced today by John J. Smith, president of the strike-closed Sparks-Withington Company.

TRENTON, July 31 -- The New Jersey Racing Commission received two applications today to conduct a running horse race meeting with pari-mutuel betting on a proposed site near Secaucus. A third application for approval of a trotting track to be situated at Pine Brook in Morris County was also filed with the commission.

CAIRO, July 31 -- Maj. Salah Salem, Egyptian Minister of National Guidance (Propaganda), said tonight that Egypt had never been informed officially of any discussion on the future of the Suez Canal Zone at the recent Washington meeting of the foreign ministers of France, Britain and the United States.

SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, July 31 -- The leader of the Rhodesian race separation movement, Denny Young, in a declaration published today called for "the just apportionment of the territories between the European and the native with an over-all federal authority and development of both races in partnership, cooperation and mutual trust."

Net earnings of the Texas Company and its subsidiaries are estimated at $85,980,121 for the six months that ended June 30, it was reported yesterday in the semi-annual statement issued by J. S. Leach, chairman of the board. The earnings, which equal $3.13 a share, compare with $83,768,366, or $3.05 a share, for the corresponding half of last year.

WASHINGTON, July 31 -- Senator Wayne Morse, Independent of Oregon, made it clear today that if and when a Democratic challenge was made to continued Republican control of the Senate, he would vote with the Republicans to maintain their thin and nominal majority.

Abraham E. Glick's letter published July 27 suggests possible disadvantages in the mortgage-and-insurance plans offered by some life insurance companies. Through such plans the insurance company takes over a mortgage, usually held by a bank, and also issues insurance on the life of the owner.

Five institutes will be conducted by the National Council of Catholic Women this month and next to train leaders for the promotion of a liaison among diocesan and parish groups of the Roman Catholic Church in this country. The first will be held from Monday through Friday at the Manhattanville College of the Sacred Heart in Purchase, N. Y.

The Browns, whose mission in life seems to be the curing of such ills as may befall the other seven American League entries, moved into the Stadium yesterday and forthwith set everything right for the Yankees.

WASHINGTON, July 31 -- Secretary of State John Foster Dulles and his party will leave by Air Force plane for Korea Sunday morning but he will not be accompanied by the bipartisan delegation of four Senators.
ST. LOUIS, July 31 -- Behind another magnificent pitching job by Carl Erskine, the Dodgers tonight beat the Cardinals, 2 -- 1, for their first victory in Busch Stadium this season.

RABAT, French Morocco, July 31 -- The trouble attending the construction of the air bases in French Morocco apparently has not prevented the United States Air Force from making good use of the facilities here.

The nation's securities distribution machinery will be occupied principally next week with a big secondary offering of common stock of the Dow Chemical Company. The offering, which will run to 400,000 shares, represents holdings of the estate of Grace A. Dow.

Robert Alphonso Taft, son of a former President and Chief Justice of the United States, was himself a brilliant politician and one of the most influential Republicans in the country. He was to become in his later years the spokesman for the majority of Senate Republicans on international affairs as he had been for a long time on domestic issues.

Homemakers with the "do-it-yourself" urge can learn to upholster chairs in foam rubber by following the instructions illustrated on this page. Those with a mind to do repairs, use a paint brush or make rugs, lampshades and the like, will find a wealth recently published material available.

BANGKOK, Thailand, July 31 -- Gen. Li Tse-fen, field commander of Chinese Nationalist troops in Burma, has left Bangkok for Formosa to confer with Nationalist authorities. His departure is the latest development related to efforts being made here to get the refugee Nationalist forces to evacuate Burma and go to Formosa.
WASHINGTON, July 31 (UP) -Congress completed action last night on a compromise bill to sell the Government's synthetic rubber factories to private industry.
A new issue of $1,500,000 of school district bonds of Clark County, Nev., due from 1956 to 1966 has been sold to a syndicate headed by John Nuveen Co.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., July 31 -- Progress toward better self-understanding was considered the principal gain parents derived from a special child development workshop that ended today at Adelphi College, according to Dr. Dorothy Disher, psychology director at the college and head of the workshop staff.

Hope for an early end to the strike of 1,800 sand, gravel and concrete truck drivers declined yesterday and it appeared that the stoppage, which has crippled New York's construction industry, would drag through next week.

A special panel of inquiry set up last March by State Industrial Commissioner Edward Corsi to end a bus strike in Nassau County announced yesterday a formula by which drivers for two companies eventually will get a five-day week without loss of average take-home pay.

HECHINGEN, Germany, July 31 -- Thieves broke into Hohenzollern Castle Museum last night and stole some of the fabulous jewels of Germany's former rulers, including gifts from Britain's Queen Victoria to Kaiser Wilhelm II.

Leaders in Government, labor, industry and the church, including those who had opposed Senator Robert A. Taft bitterly in the political and legislative arenas, joined yesterday in expressing regret at his death.
CHICAGO, July 31 (AP) -- The $90,500 Arlington Handicap, which tomorrow ends the Arlington Park season, may wind up more aptly titled "the revenge of Hill Gail."

MOSCOW, Saturday, Aug. 1 -- The Soviet Government insisted in a note to Turkey today that its interests in what it called the increasing frequency of visits of foreign warships to the Dardanelles "is fully natural for normal relations between two neighboring states."

The striking employes of the Arma Corporation at a mass meeting last night in Manhattan Center unanimously ratified an agreement with the company to maintain peaceful conditions during the future of the strike, which began a week ago, in the hope that this would pave the way for the resumption of negotiations and the eventual settlement of their contract dispute.

WASHINGTON, July 31 -- The Office of Defense Mobilization acted today to insure the most effective use of idle Government-owned machine tools and production equipment in support of present and future mobilization production requirements.

Robert A. Taft had been a member of the United States Senate for fourteen years, and first held public office in 1917. The son of President and Chief Justice William Howard Taft, he lived and loved politics. While many contested his right to the title "Mr. Republican" no challenger emerged with a more convincing claim to it.
WESTBURY, L. I., July 31 (AP) -- Red Sails, owned by H. T. King of Lynn, Ind., scored a two-length victory tonight in the $6,000 Bay Shore Pace at Roosevelt Raceway.

NEWARK, July 31 -- David Ehrlich, a lawyer here, was flattered to hear that he had been endorsed for the Essex County Freeholder nomination on the Democratic ticket. There was one drawback, however -- he has been a Republican for twenty years and intends to go right on being one.
CHICAGO, July 31 -- Wheat was further affected by black rust news in the early part of today's trading but encountered hedge selling and week-end evening-up later and closed lower for the day.

WASHINGTON, July 31 -- The Soviet Union charged today that four United States fighter planes "invaded" the frontiers of Communist China and shot down a Soviet passenger plane, killing fifteen passengers and a crew of six.

WASHINGTON, July 31 -- A Government spokesman said today that the policy on passports under which applications of United States employes in the United Nations were screened had been in operation since January and stemmed from the loyalty investigation directive.
WASHINGTON, July 31 (AP) -- The Export-Import Bank and a special Brazilian financial mission reached an agreement today on revised terms of a $300,000,000 loan to Brazil.

Seven police radio cars converged on an all-night Brooklyn diner early yesterday morning, looking for a hold-up man. All they found was a crowded counter, with ham and eggs being consumed at an inordinate rate, and everybody drinking milk.

CHAMPAIGN, Ill., July 31 -- The record of Dr. George D. Stoddard, who resigned as president of the University of Illinois last Friday after the Board of Trustees voted, six to three, that it had no confidence in his administration, was applauded today by two groups of professors.
WASHINGTON, July 31 (AP) -- The United States Air Force today made public the names of the crew aboard the RB-50 bomber shot down by Rssian fliers off Siberia Wednesday.

The American Export liner Exeter brought in recently the first shipment of kasseri cheese to reach this country from Greece in sixteen years. It swelled the small number of ewe's milk cheeses available here, and so should interest cheese lovers who like the characteristic taste of this milk, used most notably in Roquefort.

SAIGON, Vietnam, July 31 -- Bao Dai, Chief of State of Vietnam, arrived here today en route to France, where he will start negotiations with the French Government for greater independence for his country. He will leave here by plane tomorrow and is scheduled to arrive at Nice, Sunday.
