The State Liquor Authority announced yesterday the dismissal of Joseph Hartzberg, an investigator for two years in its Buffalo office, following his refusal to testify to his superiors in regard to possible past or present affiliation with the Communist party.

THE pleasures of reading other people's mail are excellently renewed in The Great Letters Series, supervised by Louis Kronenberger, general officer commanding, with a posse of learned lieutenants who have been industriously rifling the files of the illustrious. The latest pouch is well filled by Jacques Barzun with "The Selected Letters of Lord Byron,"* whose story is better told in his own words than it has ever been told by any of his swarming biographers.

WASHINGTON, July 31 -- The use of balloons and other media to carry messages from the free world to the people inside Czechoslovakia confirms that the Czechoslovak Government has created a barrier interfering with free communication, the United States said today in a blunt note to the Czechoslovak Foreign Ministry.
BALTIMORE, July 31 -- Gardnar Mulloy had one of the and narrowest and luckiest escapes of his thirty-nine years today.

MAPLEWOOD, N. J., July 31 -- Mrs. Pat Tyler teamed today with Marty Tolomeo, Twin Brook pro, to win a state P. G. A. pro-woman tournament at the Maplewood Country Club with a 33, 30 -- 63. In second place were Mrs. Theron U. Lyman and Fred Baker, the home pro, who had a 32, 32 -- 64.

TOKYO, Saturday, Aug. 1 -- The official Communist Chinese radio said today that all non-Korean sick and wounded prisoners of the Korean war would be included in the first group of captives to be returned when the exchange operation was begun at Panmunjom Wednesday.

WASHINGTON, July 31 -- One of two baseball machines patented this week pitches and the other calls strikes and balls. It is doubtful that the two will ever appear on the same diamond, however. The robot pitcher is so accurate that it would throw nothing but strikes, and the robot umpire could never tell anybody to walk.

WASHINGTON, July 31 -- The Rev. Jack Richard McMichael, Georgia-born pastor of the Community Methodist Church at Upper Lake, Calif., was confronted today by three persons who had sworn that he either had been a member of the Communist party or had followed that party's policy through long participation in activities that were Communist-hatched-and-dominated.

SOUTHAMPTON, L. I., July 31 -- Jack Tuero, former national intercollegiate champion from Tulane and ranked No. 2 here, eliminated Bill Tully, 6 -- 3, 4 -- 6, 6 -- 4, in the quarter-final round of the men's singles in the sixty-fourth annual Meadow Club tents tournament to day.

MILWAUKEE, July 31 (AP) -- Heavy rain plus thunder and lightning broke up a scoreless pitching duel between Bob Miller and Max Surkont in the eleventh inning of the second game of a twilight-night double-header tonight after Philadelphia had beaten Milwaukee, 5 -- 1, in the opener for Robin Roberts' eighteenth victory.

"I have seen the hippopotamus, both asleep and awake; and I can assure you," wrote Thomas Babington Macaulay in 1850, "that awake or asleep, he is the ugliest of the works of God." Such a very ugly ugliness must have been in the eye of the beholder, because millions of visitors who gazed into the placid, dignified visage of Peter the Great, the late resident hippo at the Bronx Zoo, found him enchanting.

WASHINGTON, July 31 -- Official Washington was saddened today by the death of Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio. In his old special home and forum, the Senate, the deep grief was accompanied by a sense of historic loss.
LONDON, July 31 (AP) --Following is the text of the Soviet note to the United States charging the shooting down of a Russian plane:
TOKYO, July 31 (UP) -- Katsuji Yamashita, 18, of Japan upset the Olympic champion, Ford Konno of Honolulu, tonight in the 1,500meter free-style final of the Japanese national swimming championships.

TRENTON, July 31 (AP) -- Jackie Cusick, former big league short-stop, of 3338 Park Avenue, Weehawken, was one of forty-six recruits graduated today as State Troopers. They were the only ones left of 735 applicants, the others failing one test or another.

WASHINGTON, July 31 -- President Eisenhower's request for a $15,000,000,000 increase in the statutory ceiling on the national debt was approved by the House of Representatives tonight, but new doubts arose over the prospect of Senate action.

RYE, N. Y., July 31 (AP) -- Maureen (Little Mo) Connolly and Doris Hart, playing in her eighth series, drew the top singles assignments today for the task of defending the Wightman Cup from the young British invaders.
The cotton futures market closed barely steady here yesterday and final prices on the New York Cotton Exchange were 3 to 9 points lower than on Thursday.

A run of losing favorites was ended at Jamaica yesterday in the feature race when the Belair Stud's Sabette, a 13-to-10 proposition, caught the Companas Stable's Ros Clag in the final yards and scored a three-quarters-of-a-length decision.

LENOX, Mass., July 31 -- The Berkshire Music Festival moved into high gear tonight when the full Boston Symphony Orchestra gave its first concert in the great shed at Tanglewood. The program began the major innovation of the festival -- Friday night concerts.

LONDON, July 31 -- The stock markets here were stimulated today by Wall Street's advance yesterday and by the decision to relax overseas credit control. Prices in virtually all groups rose in trading which was well maintained in volume despite the nearness of the long August week-end holiday.

LONDON, July 31 (Reuters) -- Bob Berry, 27, Lancashire left-arm slow bowler, today took all ten Worcestershire second-innings' wickets, the first time the feat has been accomplished in first-class English cricket since 1949.

ROME, July 31 -- President Luigi Einaudi concluded today his "consultations" with party leaders and other men prominent in the political world for a solution of the crisis brought about by the defeat of the eighth Cabinet of Premier Alcide De Gasperi Tuesday.
WASHINGTON, July 31 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture reported today that the general level of prices of farm products had held steady between mid-June and mid-July.

RIO DE JANEIRO, July 31 -- Opposition circles, and most of Brazil's newspapers, are accusing the Vargas Administration of trying to crush freedom of the press through economic pressures. Today they rejoiced at the apparent defeat of a bill to let the Government regulate journalists' salaries, which was considered the most dangerous current threat.

A letter from Bozena David published in these columns on July 18 declares that the patronage of a Communist's work in whatever field is tantamount to financial support of the Communist party. This is a dangerous argument which, however one may oppose the employment of Communists in sensitive positions, constitutes an invasion of the individual person that is repugnant to the humanist traditions of Western civilization.

Dr. Milton Eisenhower, the President's brother, was speaking a literal truth when he said in Washington this week that friendly relations between the United States and the South American republics were "critically important in the world-wide struggle for the winning of men's minds and allegiances."

When France announced her readiness to modify the pacts with the Associated States of Indo-China in the direction of broadening the base of independence she touched off, necessarily, a group of reactions. In Cambodia there was a demand for an early declaration of a complete transfer of sovereignty.

SCARBOROUGH-ON-HUDSON, N. Y., July 31 -- Paul Kelly of Sleepy Hollow, a 22-year-old Rutgers senior, won the Westchester amateur golf championship on his home course today by defeating Bob Kuntz of Bonnie Briar, 6 and 5.
LOS ANGELES, July 31 -- The complete costume look was the leading theme in the collections shown fashion editors at Fail Press Week here.

The city transit system is continuing to lose passengers under the 15-cent fare with the decline as high as 22.1 per cent on some surface lines compared with traffic a year ago, when the fare was 10 cents, the New York City Transit Authority reported yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, July 31 (UP) -- Wally Westlake collected five hits tonight, including a homer, and bated in four runs as the Indians trounced the Athletics, 12 -- 6, to end a Philadelphia three-game wining streak.
WASHINGTON, July 31 (AP) -The death of Senator Robert A. Taft led politicians to speculate today on what might have been.
WASHINGTON, July 31 -- The White House announced today that President Eisenhower would swear in tomorrow three members of the National Security Training Commission.

WASHINGTON, July 31 -- With the drive for adjournment under way on Capitol Hill, President Eisenhower called on Congress today to give some thought to the development of natural resources policy during its vacation.

WASHINGTON, July 31 -- The House of Representatives voted 237 to 156 today to pass a compromise Mutual Security appropriation of $6,752,422,390 after narrowly beating a last ditch attempt to cut another $211,000,000 from the foreign aid money bill.

WASHINGTON, July 31 -- The good nature of Representative Louis E. Graham, Republican of Pennsylvania, served today to inject a happy note into the wind-up of Congressional consideration of the Administration's program for offering to refugees a haven in this country.

Eight years after the end of the Second World War in Europe Austria remains occupied territory. Two hundred and sixty meetings of the four-Power deputies have resulted in nothing except the tedious consideration of one long treaty draft and one short treaty draft.
LONDON, July 31 (Reuters) -- A British salvage vessel, the Help, was reported today using heavy explosives in the North Atlantic roughly over the spot where the Titanic sank in 1912.

Electric Energy, Inc., which is building a 935,000-kilowatt plant at Joppa, Ill., to supply about 38 per cent of the power requirements for the Atomic Energy Commission's new development at Paducah, Ky., announced yesterday it was terminating its contractual arrangements with Ebasco Services, Inc.

With motors, oils and rubbers in the lead and almost every other industrial group on the New York Stock Exchange following, stock prices moved strongly upward yesterday. The advance, in which aircrafts were the most conspicuous hold-out, brought gains of fractions to 2 points.

CHICAGO, July 31 (AP) -- Lloyd Mangrum dropped an 18-foot birdie putt on the seventeenth green today that paid off for a second-round 68 and shot him into a one-stroke lead with 137 at the end of thirty-six holes in the $25,000 All-American golf tournament.

Lumber production for the week ended on July 25 was 4.3 per cent below the like week last year according to reports wired yesterday to THE NEW YORK TIMES by regional associations. Shipments were 0.4 per cent above those of the comparable week of last year and orders were down 5 per cent. Following are the weekly statistics in thousands of board feet:
Patrolman Charles Mend, attached to the West 100th Street station, who was involved in an argument with a police lieutenant in a West Side night club Saturday night, was suspended yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 31 (AP) -- The Office of Defense Mobilization announced today that since hostilities had ceased in Korea it was closing fifteen defense blood collection centers and ending contract arrangements with seventeen cooperating community blood banks.
Plans for a housing development and shopping center in Great Neck, L. I., have been announced in connection with the sale of ten acres of land in the vicinity of East Shore Road and Colonial Road.

Volume on the New York commodity exchanges was unusually heavy yesterday, with four items registering the largest number of trades for the month. Cocoa had the second highest volume of the year, rubber the greatest activity since May 24, lead since June 26 and the domestic sugar contract since June 16. Dealings in wool and coffee also were exceptional.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., July 31 -- William G. Holloway of Meadow Brook and Dick Fales of Nassau advanced to the final of the twenty-ninth annual Long Island Golf Association amateur championship at the Sands Point Club today.
ALBANY, July 31 (AP) -- Gov. Dewey today appointed Lieutenant Albin S. Johnson of Hawthorne the State Police Superintendent to succeed Capt. John A. Gaffney, who is retiring.

EXCEPT for the consistently good bottom fishing, and fair bay fishing, the salt water is not producing much in the way of excitement for Long Island anglers, although a number of good catches of bluefish are reported from the Sound in the Plum Gut and Race areas.

Summer belongs to the young. A few of the less fortunate may struggle in he toils of summer school, but for the great majority of youth summer is a glorious holiday in which dates on the calendar become meaningless and even the days of the week become blurred.

PHILADELPHIA, July 31 -- Two more Philadelphia area men were arrested and held in $25,000 bail each today on charges of conspiring to overthrow the United States Government by force. The arrests, made by agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation in Atlantic City, brought to eight the number of alleged Communist sympathizers seized in this area in two days.

A new type of eye chart, which replaces the usual letters and numerals with universally known symbols, is being developed for the benefit of children and adults who cannot tell a P from a Q, but who can recognize a fish or la flower when they see one.
WASHINGTON, July 31 -- Herbert Brownell Jr., the Attorney General, may go to California next month to make a personal study of the "wetback" situation, a Department of Justice source disclosed today.
A series of disheartening developments yesterday tended to dampen the best police theories on the killing Wednesday morning of Michael J. (Barney) Prendergast, New York tavern owner.

GENEVA, July 31 (AP) -- Dag Hammarskjold, secretary-general of the United Nations, disclosed today that Mrs. Alva Myrdal, United Nations official who had difficulty with United States immigration authorities earlier this year, had been granted "unimpeded access" to the United States.
STAMFORD, Conn., July 31 -- A 9 o'clock curfew for boys and girls under 15 years old was invoked here tonight by local police, on orders of Leonard De Vita, city court prosecutor.

The New York Shipbuilding Corporation received stockholders' approval yesterday to increase the number of authorized shares of voting stock, thereby permitting the company to issue additional stock in the event it should want to acquire other concerns. Last May the company acquired a 120,000-share interest in Nesco, Inc., which manufactures kitchen utensils.

WASHINGTON, July 31 (AP) -- The House passed and sent to the Senate today a compromise bill amending the formula for allocating cotton quotas to prevent a cutback of more than 29 1/2 per cent in acreage in any state next year.

CENTURIES ago avocados were savored by the Mayans in Guatemala, the Incas in Peru and the Aztecs in Mexico. Our taste for this semi-tropical fruit with the rich, nutty flavor, though acquired more recently, is equally enthusiastic.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 1 (AP) -- In one of the keenest finishes the fifty-three-year-old tournament has ever witnessed, Claire Doran of Cleveland today defeated Jane Nelson of Indianapolis, 1 up, in thirty-six holes, for the women's Western amateur golf championship.

REGULAR followers of David C. Cooke's annual BEST DETECTIVE STORIES OF THE YEAR (Dutton) will notice three departures from past tradition in the 1953 volume: it's out about two months earlier than usual; it's priced at $2.95 instead of the former $2.75; and it's somewhat longer than previous volumes -- same number of stories (twelve) but greater total wordage.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- Democrats faced a double-barreled finale this week with a general sense of well-being and optimism.
Now that a truce is in effect in Korea and a slowing of the military effort is believed in the offing, the nation's railroads may be hard pressed to maintain their present volume of traffic.

Turnstiles of the city's subway and elevated lines are being adjusted to mutilate as well as reject all slugs as a further deterrent to unscrupulous passengers who may try to avoid using the official 15-cent token, Sidney H. Bingham, general manager of the New York City Transit Authority, disclosed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- President Eisenhower sent to Congress today a blueprint for extending Federal Social Security coverage to about 10,500,000 additional citizens and asked that the program be adopted at the next session.

HANOVER, N. H., Aug. 1 -- Charles Dickens' annotated copy of "Pepys' Diary" has been acquired by the Baker Library at Dartmouth College. The four volumes, published in 1828, and a volume of selected Pepys correspondence are the gift of Ralph E. Samuel of New York, a member of the Dartmouth class of 1913, on the occasion of his fiftieth class reunion.

The gangs that have turned New York's lush waterfront into a vulture's nest of murder, theft and labor exploitation served grim warning last week that they did not intend to surrender their power without a fight.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- The three new members of the reconstituted National Security Training Commission took the oath of office this morning before President Eisenhower at the White House.

THE British author and journalist, James Cleugh, has written a one-man symposium on Spain with all the virtues and vices of the conglomerate book. Here we have every possible subject from geography to finance, from the Phoenicians to the Falangists, from internal politics to relations with every single country of Europe and the Western hemisphere.

The fall of the De Gasperi Government within two weeks of its formation indicates popular demand for more aggressive policies to meet Italy's economic and social problems, Peter G. Treves, editor of Economic News from Italy, who recently returned from an annual visit to that country, said yesterday.

SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, Aug. 1 -- Football has entered into politics here. The press continues to be thoroughly wrought up at the slap in the face given to the Rhodesias by the South African Union's Rugby Football Association, which is commonly said to insist that the rest of Africa shall toe its color line.

The recent action of Lever Brothers Company in changing the odor as well as the color of Lifebuoy soap brings out an important problem faced by manufacturers generally. That is, to make a product that will not be offensive to the olfactory senses of the consumer.

By yesterday the record of the first Eisenhower Congress was all but in. There remained only a few odds and ends of legislation. Adjournment -- or recess -- was held up by the President's last minute request for an increase in the debt limit. The prospect was that Congress would go home this week.

A COMBINATION of uninspiring reports from several angling fronts, and the recent announcement of the season dates for scoter shooting, would seem to make this a good time for a discussion of the widely ignored "coot" shooting possibilities along the coast.
Despite great uncertainty about lasting peace, Korea must now go ahead with development of trade and economic recovery as if a return to normal conditions was assured.

SEOUL, Korea, Aug. 1 -- Even before the armistice was signed at 10 A. M., Monday, on the flat plain at Panmunjom, heavy engineer equipment was moving up the narrow dirt Korean roads in the vicinity of Munsan, fifteen miles to the rear.

THIS summer, in the midst of Hollywood's quivering year of decision and in the face of such competition as a three-dimensional Western, Cinerama, and Martin and Lewis on giant screen with stereophonic sound, a plain old-fashioned flat-screen musical called "The Bandwagon" opened in New York and across the country to the kind of box-office joy that hasn't been registered for ages.
Popular unrest and opposition to the Soviet-controlled Albanian Government were reported yesterday to have reached new levels.

THE output of 16-mm., non-theatrical motion pictures, by-passing the midsummer doldrums, continues steadily, ranging in variety and professional approach. The following cross section, touching on such diversified subjects as travel, education, psychology, industry, history and finance, should serve to illustrate that the field, far from wilting in the seasonal sun, is, instead, flourishing.

MILWAUKEE, Aug. 1 -- An infield bounder, beaten out by Richie Ashburn in the fourth inning, cost Warren Spahn a perfect no-hit game today as the Braves' southpaw tossed his second shut-out of the week to beat Philadelphia, 5 -- 0, and score his fourteenth victory of the season.

THIS morning, as anyone can tell by looking at the calendar, marks the approximate mid-way point in the doldrums that have been hanging over Broadway. Henceforth the scene should begin getting brighter, the telephones in agents' offices ringing more insistently and the aspiring candidates for assorted roles in forthcoming productions bustling around and about Shubert Alley in greater numbers.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 1 -- The United Nations Security Council, once billed as the most powerful international body in the world, virtually vanished from the international stage in the first seven months of 1953.

THOUGH its title suggests that it might be about some sect of epicurean philosophers, Robert L. Heilbroner's book is really an account of the great economists and their doctrines. Yet the title is a shrewd and entirely justifiable one -- and in breadth and generalizing intelligence the book lives up to it.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- President Eisenhower's request for a $15,000,000.000 increase in the statutory ceiling of the national debt was pigeon-holed by the Senate Finance Committee tonight, 11 to 4.

America's zenith of speed boat excitement, the annual Gold Cup race, will have its forty-sixth running next Sunday at Seattle. Indeed, this is the top race in international speed boating circles in all the years when no Harmsworth event is held.

It's August. The cicada's insistent note quivers the hot afternoon air. Daisies whiten fence corners and brown-eyed Susan spreads brassy yellow petals at the pasture's edge. Blue vervain lifts its purplish spikes in damp meadow margins to the delight of bumblebees.
A DESIGN competition and an exhibition and public sale of prints by American artists under 35 are among the events on the calendar of the Museum of Modern Art for the autumn and winter season.

The Long Island Sound Yacht Racing Association championship schedule headed into the post-Larchmont Race Week home-stretch yesterday when the Echo Bay Yacht Club was host for the first of seventeen remaining regattas.

BUSINESS will find itself still operating in a defense economy, despite the truce in Korea. But the months ahead hold a real challenge if employment, national income and gross product are to be maintained at their current levels.

It comes as a direct sequel to a major political event -- the anti-Communist riots, staged in East Berlin on June 17, which have given rise to seething unrest throughout East Germany.

IN English it's "Carnival," in German it's "Rummerplatz" -- but Munich's burghers have found the film now being produced here by the King Brothers of Hollywood a king-sized circus come to town. For the carnival spirit has pervaded the Gastelgasteig studio for the past few weeks as the two versions of the drama were being shot simultaneously in color and for wide-screen usage.

WINSTED, Conn. -- An unpretentious establishment in this northwestern Connecticut town is observing its first anniversary this summer as an exhibit room and sales outlet for the handmade products of skilled artisans who are members of an eighteen-year-old, nonprofit organization, which is known as the Society of Connecticut Craftsmen.

WASHINGTON, AUG. 1 -- Mrs. Oveta Culp Hobby Secretary of the Department of Health, Education and Welfare, has added to her staff a consultant on special institutions to look out for five ventures of the Government that have been gathered under her administrative wing.

BOOTHBAY HARBOR, Me., Aug. 1 -- There were times when men of determination and courage working in the bows were waistdeep in green water, made black by night. It was one hand for the ship, one for the man. Steel rigging strained till it sang. Sails were hard as iron with wind.

MOSCOW, Sunday, Aug. 2 -- The Soviet press published today a Tass communique and a map of North Korea and Red China, which it declared clearly supports the Soviet version of the shooting down of the Soviet transport plane last Monday.

Probably Casanova is not as "primly reticent by some flagrant modern standards" as Charles Poore believes in "Close-Up of Casanova," (July 26). LONDON, Aug. 1 -- Francisco (Pancho) Segura, Ecuadorian tennis star and United States professional tennis champion in 1950 and 1951, said tonight he had been refused a visa for a tour of South Africa.

Orders for fall continued in a normal ratio to sales in the wholesale market here last week, indicating that the truce in Korea has had no effect on buying, according to Kirby, Block Co., Inc., resident buying office. Reorders were heavy.

A five-year training program designed to make the elementary school teacher as efficient on the playground as she is in the classroom will be inaugurated by New York University's School of Education this fall. Formulated and sponsored by the elementary and physical education staffs of the school, the new program will be directed by a team of faculty members from both departments.

A REPORT current in certain circles of New York the other day was that Bennett Cerf recently had five minutes in a row free. For a man who is a publisher-author-lecturer-columnist - anecdotist - and - radio - and-television-panelist, to give his occupations only as of 2:31 P. M. the Wednesday before last, a twelfth of an hour is an awfully long time to be unemployed.

OFFHAND the psychology of C. G. Jung would seem singularly ill-suited for survival in an age which daily grows more industrial, more political, more warlike. His thought is frankly aristocratic and esoteric -- a Platonic Academy in the midst of a radioactive battlefield surrounded by jet strips, tank plants, demagogues, tax-gatherers and secret police.

HONG KONG, Aug. 1 -- Far from producing an atmosphere of general jubilation, the Korean armistice has left this area in doubt about the future. Aside from those pro-Nationalist Chinese who are frankly disappointed by developments in Korea, many others here are asking the same key question that is being asked elsewhere:
CHICAGO, Aug. 1 (AP) -- John F. Cuneo, wealthy Chicagoan, said today a painting he had bought for $1,000 had been identified as a masterpiece that might be valued at more than $250,000.

Trade in the department stores was disappointing last week and observers estimated that volume would show a decline of 3 to 5 per cent from the 1952 period. It was pointed out that the week ordinarily is "draggy," marking the summer's midpoint.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- A plan, endorsed by President Eisenhower, by which United States military forces in Korea would be used as labor battalions to build South Korean roads, schools and hospitals was revealed by Secretary of State John Foster Dulles today to Ambassadors representing nations allied with the United States in the Korean war.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- Economy advocates who thought a Korean truce might pave the way for multi-billion-dollar savings in the defense and foreign aid programs are due for a sad awakening if the men who dig up the facts for President Eisenhower are any judge of its consequences.

NO Eskimo worth his salted walrus steak would claim there are right now crowded conditions aboard the Arctic ice-flows, but some time during the next year or eighteen months there will be a mild form of aerial congestion over the North Pole when the international airlines begin flying in the region of 90 degrees north latitude.

RYE, N. Y., Aug. 1 -- The American Yacht Club's annual cruise on Long Island Sound, a six-day event, started at noon today. On signal from the race chairman, Sam Barton, aboard the power-cruiser Dalou, the fleet headed out from Scotch Caps in a light southerly for an overnight run -- new to the cruise -- of seventy-nine nautical miles to South Dumpling in west harbor at Fishers Island.

AN electronic flash dry battery unit that weighs only thirty ounces but packs 480 volts and can be carried suspended from a waist belt, was announced last week by Speedlight Center, 128 West Thirty-second Street. The pack is designed for use with the company's Mighty Midget Speedlight or Swifty Speedlight.
The role of private capital in financing undertakings of wide social or industrial scope is growing, and that of the Federal Government is shrinking.

SHREVEPORT, La., Aug. 1 -- Controversy over Louisiana's offshore boundary, an issue affecting oil and gas lands in the Gulf of Mexico, is likely to continue for some time despite this year's Federal legislation returning to the states the ownership of submerged lands within their historic boundaries.

A manuscript copy of two stanzas of the song "America," commencing with "My Country 'Tis of Thee" and "Our Father's God to Thee," written by the author, Samuel Francis Smith, will make its permanent home at the Roosevelt School, Stamford, Conn. The historic document will be presented to the school this afternoon by Col. Arthur Levitt, member of the New York City Board of Education.

A small group of friends of England, mostly literary, have given token assistance to the restoration and reproduction of landmarks with literary, historical and sentimental significance in England that were destroyed or damaged during the war.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- The United States rejected today a protest by the Soviet Union charging the shooting down by United States Air Force fighter planes of a Russian passenger plane in which fifteen passengers and six crew members were reportedly killed.

A rotary pre-loaded door has been devised to facilitate the release of bombs and rockets from planes at high speeds. The door rotates 180 degrees just before a bomb is launched. No open bomb-bay is left for buffeting winds. A jet bomber traveling at high speed is just as stable a platform as one flying at World War II speeds.

AT 19, a year-after he landed his first staff job as a news photographer, George H. Hill was in the "big time." A stunt did it -- the first air view of a football game, the Harvard-Yale match in Cambridge in 1919.
THE dry titles of Jacquetta Hawkes' books on archaeology have too well concealed their author's passion for the poetry of history and her power to make dead things come alive.

PARIS, July 29 -- Exiles of Eastern and Central Europe who have gathered in Paris have regained hope that change of Soviet policies in satellite countries may become a prelude to a relaxation of the Soviet dominion that has gripped these states.

ANKARA, Turkey, Aug. 1 -- Following receipt yesterday of the third Russian note in two months of questions concerning the Straits diplomatic quarters here are increasingly convinced the Soviet Union is seeking to make the Straits a major international issue in the hope of diverting attention from more embarrassing European questions such as Germany and Austria.

EVERY once in awhile somebody comes along with an explosive discovery. It has for its objective the demolition of most any popular belief, such as that Columbus stumbled upon America in 1492, or Shakespeare, unlike Babe Ruth, wrote his own stuff.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 1 (UP) -- An official of the Pirates said today he was awaiting clarification from Ralph Kiner and George Metkovich regarding certain items submitted in their request for moving expenses to Chicago.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (UP) -- The Senate approved today and sent to the White House, with a flare of wit, legislation to admit Ohio to the Union.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (UP) -- President Eisenhower today signed a measure extending the international wheat agreement for three years.
TOKYO, Sunday, Aug. 2 -- Red Cross teams will enter North and South Korea tomorrow to begin their work of comfort and relief among prisoners of the three-year Korean war.

THE, formal appearance of the tree rose suggests a beautiful bouquet of roses mounted on a tall, slender pedestal. Although only a limited number of varieties is available, the tree rose has found an important place for itself in the garden as an accent plant.

NORTH CONWAY, N. H., Aug. 1 -- Delegates to the third annual North Conway conference on alcoholism on Sept. 28 and 29 will discuss "The Prevention of Alcoholism Through Education." The New Hampshire Council of Churches and the division on alcoholism of the State Department of Health are the sponsors.

CHICAGO, Aug. 1 -- Seventy eviction suits were filed in Municipal Court today -- the first day after the end of Federal rent controls. This compared with an average of twenty eviction cases filed on Saturdays earlier this year.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Aug. 1 -- W. G. (Beegee) Holloway Jr. of Meadow Brook won the Long Island Amateur golf championship today at the Sands Point Golf Club by defeating Dick Fales of Nassau, 1 up, in the 36-hole final.

Yesterday was the first day in nearly a quarter of a century that Vladimir P. Ananieff wasn't worrying about whether the channel was deep enough in Santa Marta for the liner Britannic or whether there were enough taxis and buses in La Guayra to accommodate the Caronia's cruise passengers for a day's land touring.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (UP) -- The Senate voted today to pay a reward of $16,119 to a steamship line employe whose tip to customs officials prevented an illegal shipment of gold bullion abroad. It approved and sent to the House a bill to pay the reward to Matthew J. Berckman of Jersey City, an employe of the Cunard Steam Ship Company.

Leaders of the shipping industry here are divided sharply in their views on the projected plan for eliminating the heavy lift charges in this port, and a real fight is in prospect for the next meeting on the plan scheduled for Aug. 18.

It has already been established that there will be no attempt to reorganize the Senate in the near future as the result of the death of Senator Robert A. Taft. Even the appointment of a Democrat from Ohio would leave the balance at 48-47 for the Democrats and the one Independent, Senator Morse, has stated that in the case of reorganization he would vote with the Republicans.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- A state funeral will be held here on Monday for Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio in the second-floor rotunda of the Capitol of the United States and the highest personages of the United States, led by President Eisenhower, will be there.

OCEANPORT, N. J., Aug. 1 -- Landlocked remained at the head of the pack every step of the way to win the $38,850 Choice Stakes at Monmouth Park today. The 3-year-old soft of Priam II, enjoying the benefit of Jimmy Stout's presence in the saddle, took the mile and a furlong event by a length, with the long-priced Ride M Cowboy finishing second.

THERE are few better known historians and teachers of Christianity than Kenneth Scott Latourette, who recently retired as Professor of Missions and Oriental History at Yale and is now serving as president of the Japan International Christian University Foundation.

AMID all the mystery surrounding the purge of Lavrenti P. Beria, one central fact seems clear: the victorious anti-Beria faction had the support of key leaders of the Soviet armed forces. If Beria, on the other hand, had succeeded in winning full military support, he would have been the purger rather than the chief victim.

LAUSANNE, Switzerland, Aug. 1 (AP) -- There will be no equestrian sports in the 1956 Olympic Games at Melbourne because of Australian quarantine laws, the International Olympic Committee reported today.

ROME -- Now that the guided tours in Rome have made Via Vittorio Veneto a definite stop like the Forum or the Colosseum, the street can be said to have arrived. Although for thirty years it has been the center of Rome's elegant set, not till the post-war American invasion did it become well known as one of Europe's famous arteries.
KALAMAZOO, Mich., Aug 1 -- (UP) -- Myron Franks and John Lesch made it an all-Los Angeles final for the junior singles title in the National junior and boys' tennis championship today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (AP) -- The House of Representatives Judiciary Committee in a final report today on its eighteen-month investigation of the Justice Department, charged there had been "shocking inefficiency" in past Administrations.

GENEVA, Aug. 1 (AP) -- The United Nations Economic and Social Council unanimously expressed its confidence today that the differences between the United States and the United Nations over access to United Nations headquarters in New York would be solved "satisfactorily and expeditiously."

ANKARA, Turkey, Aug. 1-- Turkey dedicated today her first completely modern international air terminal at San Stefano (Yesilkoy), on Istanbul's European shore. The new facility has more than 1,200,000 square feet of concrete runway and can handle up to 400 military or civilian air movements a day.

NOW that the gardener has time to lift his eyes above ground level and take an over-all look at his handiwork, he may note that, although the plants in the garden seem to be in pretty good shape, the non- growing elements -- fence or trellis, garden bench, metal table or cement floor of the terrace -- need a little refurbishing.
Ever since the first Wall Street brokers congregated under a buttonwood tree, those that have tried to figure out why the stock market acts as it does have run into more paradoxes than axioms.

The expert hand tailor is going the way of the buffalo, nickel beer and the dime subway fare. The fall-off in immigration and the disinclination of American youth to spend five to eight years learning how to cut and sew has caused a shortage of skilled tailors in every major city.

Three Brooklyn men alleged to have committed fifteen armed holdups in the last year netting $35,000 in cash and $15,000 to $20,000 in jewelry were booked by the police last night on charges of assault and robbery.

RABAT, French Morocco, July 27 -- Beneath its midsummer torpor, Morocco remains a land of unresolved tensions. Although some of the protagonists have fled the scorching heat of the African sun, the lines of conflict are more sharply drawn than ever before.

Restrictions on Jews in Iran and Afghanistan, and the low level of their living conditions, are detailed in a report analyzing the social, economic and politcal status of the Jewsh communities in both countries, made public yesterday by the World Jewish Congress. The report was prepared' by Dr. Nehemiah Robinson, director of the Congress' Institute of Jewish Affairs.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Aug. 1 -- When Gunnar Gustafsson was doing military duty aboard the Swedish pocket cruiser Goeta Lejon he threw a bottle over the side into the North Sea with a message thanking the British people for the hospitality enjoyed by the Swedish cruiser's crew during the coronation naval review at Spithead.

THE recent action of Congress in voting legislation that would remove the 20 per cent Federal tax on movie tickets has pointed up two things, at least, whatever may be the ultimate destiny of this surprising concession on Congress' part.

SHORT CREEK, Ariz., Aug. 1 (UP) -- Arizona authorities evacuated some 200 women and children from this isolated polygamous community today to thwart any attempt by male polygamists to reclaim their families.

A fire caused by the overheated motor of a special two-car money-and-mail collecting train of the I. R. T. stalled at the Times Square station of the Queens line interrupted subway service early today between the Manhattan end of the line and the Hunter's Point station in Queens.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- The American Red Cross said today that nine of its workers would go into North Korea to help Allied war prisoners back to neutral territory and twelve of its workers would accompany released American prisoners on the trip home.
BONN, Germany, Aug. 1 -- The major democratic parties and West Germany's five radio networks have reached an agreement on allocation of radio time during the general election campaign.
EVANSVILLE, Ind., Aug. 1 (AP) -- A hand grenade tossed into a rough-and-tumble brawl outside a barbecue stand early today left one man dead and at least seventeen other presons wounded.

St. Michael's College, Winooski, Vt., will introduce this fall a fundamentally reorganized educational program. The major objectives of the plan will be a more carefully integrated four-year liberal arts curriculum and a new two-year terminal program in general education.

Operators of barber shops, beauty salons, chicken markets and veterinary hospitals were surprised recently when a chubby, young-looking man with horn-rimmed glasses came in and asked them to save for him their waste hair, feathers and clippings.

EMYR HUMPHREYS' sensitive portrayal of a middle-aged English schoolmaster, caught in the conflict between duty and desire, is both rewarding and disappointing. The reward is in the firm but supple prose, the warmth and tenderness of Mr. Humphreys' observation.

NEWARK, Aug. 1--A device that resembles an office water cooler but in reality is a new gadget for transmitting coast-to- coast calls electronically was exhibited here recently by the New Jersey Bell Telephone Company.

ROME, Aug. 1 -- The West has become accustomed in the last five years to a well-ordered Italy with a stable Government so committed to cooperation with the Western democracies and to European integration that it considered any sacrifice worth while if it advanced those ideas even a little.

MUNSAN, Korea, Aug. 1 (AP) -- The Communists informed the Allies today that they planned to hand over 400 United Nations captives daily beginning at 9 A. M. Wednesday [8 P. M. Tuesday, Eastern daylight time]. They said they would deliver the prisoners in groups of 100 each hour for four hours each day.

THE recent action of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee in approving a bill which would authorize a study of the possibility of trans-Atlantic television points up the appalling lack of understanding in the United States of both the immediate realities and opportunities of international video.

RYE, N. Y., Aug. 1 -- The anticipated American sweep of the seven-match Wightman Cup series with England was still in prospect today as the United States took the first three engagements on the grass courts of the Westchester Country Club.

IN about 1884, Benito Perez Galdos wrote "Torment" in Madrid -- a novel with a diversity of characters reminiscent of Dickens and Balzac. Each of the characters vies for first place in the reader's imagination. The competition is won by two "objectionable" lovers; a neurotic priest and a young orphan girl of passionate and nevertheless vacillating character.

VIENNA, Aug. 1 (AP) -- Communist Czechoslovakia's President, Antonin Zapotocky, admitted today that the Soviet system of collective farming had failed to yield sufficient food for the 12,000,000 Czechoslovaks.

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Aug. 1 Emil Mosbacher Jr. sailed his International Class craft, Susan, to her eighth triumph of the season in the twentieth Yacht Racing Association championship regatta on Long Island Sound today.
Ercole (Herkie) Ercolano, the object of a police search for two years, was seized by Federal narcotics agents at 3 A. M. yesterday and charged with possession of 100 ounces of heroin.

The Police Commissioner's confidential squad swooped down on a secluded private house in the Bronx yesterday and broke up what they described as the bookkeeping headquarters for a multimillion dollar East Harlem policy numbers ring.

Kings County Judge Samuel S. Leibowitz, the City Fusion party's candidate for Mayor, withdrew from the Mayoralty race yesterday. In announcing his withdrawal, Judge Leibowitz said he did so because he was unable to raise the $1,000,000 he felt would be needed to make a winning campaign as an independent candidate.

Because it had been expected and discounted during the protracted period of negotiation, the signing of a truce in the Korean war exerted only a mild influence on financial and commodity markets last week. Prices gave ground initially, but by midweek the moderate selling pressure had spent its force and a recovery movement started.

" A BOOK for everyone and for no one" -- with these words Nietzsche prefaced his "Zarathustra," thus expressing his apprehension at having no readers and his hope for universal success. Though Stendhal alleged that he wrote "for the happy few," he still wished that his works might find a receptive market.
LONDON, Aug. 1 -- A British track team, anchored by Roger Bannister, set a world record of 16 minutes 41 seconds for the four-mile relay today on a rain-soaked track at the White City Stadium.

There has been a generous response thus far to the efforts of the American-Korean Foundation to obtain additional funds for its program of assistance to Koreans, but there is reason to be apprehensive because many persons may feel that action on the part of our Government to aid in Korean rehabilitation could make private gifts unnecessary.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (AP) -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, said today he had a tape-recorded, detailed report of waste in United States propaganda operations in Indo-China that might amount to many millions of dollars.

BERLIN, Sunday, Aug. 2 -- As deliveries of free food rations from West Germany for the eastern zone passed the 1.000,000 mark today, the East German Government took its first concerted step against the program by forbidding the sale of railroad tickets to Berlin.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- President Eisenhower will fly to Seattle Monday to address the conference of Governors. He is to leave after attending the state funeral here of Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio and is to return in time for his daily schedule of work Wednesday.

THE sight-seeing cruise around Manhattan has a reputation for being not only the best means of seeing the skyline but also an efficacious cure for frazzled nerves. Yet recently one of the vessels that make this tour ran aground in Spuyten Duyvil.

Lack of adequate community resources to treat the social and emotional maladjustments of youth in the city's areas of high delinquency was held yesterday to be an important contributing factor in the recent sharp increase of children's court cases.

Slender, silver-haired John Lyon Collyer pulled many an oar in his day. When he entered Cornell University in 1913 he took a major part in student activities. In a short time he was made president of his class; rowed stroke oar, and was elected captain of the varsity crew. In his senior year he served as head coach of the Cornell crews.

FOR anyone who loves New York deeply and unself-consciously, a midsummer night in this city is the sum of everything and can be compared to nothing in the world. It is hardly possible not to be touched by it, even with the price of a week-end somewhere else.

FOR the first time in some ten years, the U. S. S. R. is showing interest in acquiring American movies for exhibition in Russia, a move that may be an augury of a change in film relations between the U. S. S. R. and the United States.

MAO TSE-TUNG is a typical Chinese "hero of the grass wilderness," a shrewd but roughhewn rural Robin Hood. Influenced on the one hand by Chinese history, politics and society, and on the other by the revolutionary thought of the twentieth century, he has a mind in which Chinese monarchical concepts, Marxist-Leninist ideas and dreams of glory exist side by side.

SOUTHAMPTON, L. I., Aug. 1 -- Charles Masterson of Sea Cliff, former Eastern titleholder, and Jack Tuero of Roslyn, who was the national intercollegiate champion at Tulane several years ago, gained the final bracket of the sixty-fourth annual Meadow Club tennis tournament today.

Albert Einstein announced three and a half years ago that after two decades of effort he had at last evolved a unified field theory. By this he meant that he had invented a mathematical system in which a single set of equations linked gravitation and electromagnetism together.

A BOOMING development in the travel world is the credit-card plan, a special charge-account service for business men as well as vacationists which makes it possible to take extended trips without carrying along great sums of money or, in the case of Europe, without bothering with currency regulations or exchange rates.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (UP) -- The Secretary of Agriculture, Ezra Taft Benson, today outlined "what is probably the biggest coordinated effort ever made to get a voluntary democratic evaluation of farm programs."

WORD comes from Jonas Hallgrimsson in Reykjavik that Iceland has in preparation a series of stamps with design themes based on the historic "Icelandic Manuscripts" which are currently in the University of Copenhagen and which Denmark refuses to restore to Iceland.

A new course of study leading to the degree of Doctor of Philosophy in Social Psychology will be offered by Columbia University beginning in the fall, Dr. Edgar G. Miller Jr., dean of the graduate faculties, announced yesterday.
ROME, Aug. 1 (AP) -- Premier Alcide De Gasperi appeared to have been persuaded at the last minute tonight not to walk out on Italy's Government crisis.

LJUBLJANA, Yugoslavia, July 21 -- Nine young men and women from as many places in the United States and a college professor from Tacoma, Wash., who is the official leader, are living here with Yugoslav families, having a wonderful time.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (UP) -- John L. Lewis passed up an initial opportunity today to serve notice on the soft coal industry that he wanted to bargain for new contracts with higher wages for members of the union of which he is head.
Willford King's reply in your issue of July 26 to the earlier letter from the Commission on Academic Freedom seems to me the product of some lamentable confusions.

SANTIAGO, Cuba, Aug. 1 (AP) -- Cuban Army authorities announced today that Fidel Castro, 30-year-old student leader at the University of Havana, had confessed directing the unsuccessful rebellion Sunday against the Government of President Gen. Fulgencio Batista.

Dr. J. A. Allen made history in the summer of 1952 by transporting forty-four pounds of automatic recording instruments to an altitude of 270,000 feet (eighty kilometers). The apparatus was carried by a small rocket, which was lifted by a large plastic balloon.

ALIVERION, Greece, Aug. 1 -- Ceremonies attended by King Paul, members of Premier Alexander Papagos' Government and officials of the United States Mutual Security Agency marked today inauguration of the electric power works here that, when further devolped, may contribute decisively to Greece's industrialization.

A dozen detectives, seeking clues to the murder of Michael (Barney) Prendergast, joined the hundreds of mourners and curious persons yesterday at the funeral service for the tavern owner who was found shot dead Wednesday morning in Fort Washington Park.

THERE are various ways of producing operas. Two of them were shown, in highly illuminative fashion, by the productions of Nicolai's "Merry Wives of Windsor," the "Singspiel" after Shakespeare, and Bizet's "Carmen," at Colorado's Central City.

George Saleeby, a 43-year-old machine operator who has been in and out of mental institutions for twenty years, told the police yesterday that he had shot three men since last Monday, including one who was officially declared dead from natural causes.

THESE pictures are illustrations for a story that has gone through several hundred editions in the first four centuries of its immortality. They are scenes from the tremendous adventures of Gargantua and Pantagruel by Francois Rabelais, who was born about the time Columbus was making other discoveries, and who probably died, the savants tell us, in one sense, in 1553.

NOROTON, Conn., Aug. 1 -- Connie Neher, representing the Indian Harbor Y. C. of Greenwich and sailing Double Trouble, took the lead for the Long Island Sound Lightning Class championship as the first two races of the new series for the Noroton Challenge Trophy were completed today.

SARATOGA SPRINGS -- They will be thundering down the homestretch today and tomorrow morning, the devoted followers of the pari-mutuel machines, racing to get here before the daily double window closes at 2:20 P. M. tomorrow for the first race of the 1953 meeting at the big track.

TEHERAN, Iran, Aug. 1 -- Ayatollah Sayed Abolghassem Kashani, Moslem religious leader and Premier Mohammed Mossadegh's bitterest political enemy, placed today a stern religious boycott on the referendum scheduled to begin Monday, in which Dr. Mossadegh seeks popular approval for the dissolution of what remains of the Majlis, lower and sole existing house of Parliament.

BOSTON, Aug. 1 (UP) -- Jim Delsing, who reached base each of the five times he appeared at the plate today, hit into a force-out and drove in the winning run in the tenth inning as the Tigers rallied to beat the Red Sox, 4 -- 3, and extend Boston's losing streak to six games. The string of setbacks was the longest of the season for the Red Sox.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Aug. 1 -- During the past two weeks the Israeli Foreign Ministry has been sitting determinedly in Israel's capital of Jerusalem and persistently inviting the diplomatic representatives of twenty-five foreign powers to call. The Ministry hinted that it hoped callers would stay for a long time.

SINGAPORE, Aug. 1 -- A Malay regiment officer has killed the terrorist who on June 26 murdered Cyril A. Grey, British manager of the Mentakab estate in Pahang, a Federation communique tonight announced.

An extraordinary exhibition of mound craft by the venerable southpaw, Harry Brecheen, and a three-run homer by Don Lenhardt in the eighth inning combined to produce a most startling effect at the Stadium yesterday before a Ladies' Day gathering of 15,499.

The ozone layer in the earth's atmosphere screens out much of the sun's ultraviolet radiation. If it were not for this screening we should all be blinded. Ever since rockets freighted with spectrographs were introduced it has been possible to photograph more of the spectrum of the sun.
Three years, one month and two days of shooting war in Korea began to fade into history last week. On Tuesday the final U.N. communique recorded the end in these words: ...

One big union, one of whose aims is the abolition of the traditional serang system of hiring Asian seamen, has been formed from twenty-one Indian seafaring unions long split on questions of nationality, religion, employment and geography.

KATHARINE MORRIS feels the bond between man and his land so deeply that her novels are illuminated with the glory of Nature worship. "Country Dance," like its predecessor, "The Vixen's Cub," shows human nature responding to the influence of the earth, the season, the laws of recurrent death and rebirth, as simply and inevitably as do the hills and valleys and forests.
The need for blood will not decrease here in the next few months, John S. Sinclair, chairman of the New York chapter of the American Red Cross warned yesterday.
WALDEMAR KAEMPFFERT, in his review of "Cardano" by Oystein Ore, writes: "It was natural for the injured Samson Carrasco in Cervantes' 'Don Quixote' to send for an algebraist to heal his bruises."

Priscilla Inscho, 32 years old, was arrested early yesterday after a fifty-block, sixty-mile-an-hour chase by a radio patrol car. Held in $3,600 bail, she was accused, among other things, of attempted felonious assault.

When each of the nearly 150,000 international travelers enters the Port of New York this peak month of August, he will spend an average of less than fifteen seconds with a public health officer of the Foreign Quarantine Service of the United States Public Health Service.

NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 1 -- The American Alpine Club expedition of Mount Godwin Austen, highest unclimbed peak, was halted for some time at 20,700 feet by a blizzard that broke on July 12 and confined the party to tiny tents on the high slope for thirty-six hours, according to delayed reports from the mountain today.

THE seasonal rash of state fairs is about to break out in the majority of our forty-eight states. North Dakota, which traditionally starts off the procession, held its big fair at Minot last week. Starting tomorrow and running through Saturday Montana will stage its annual exposition at Great Falls.

HAVANA, Aug. 1 -- The revolt that flared last Sunday in Oriente Province spotlighted the iron hand of the military force on which Cuba's President Fulgencio Batista greatly depends to keep himself in power. This force, however, is usually so camouflaged under the velvet glove of General Batista's political astuteness that the Cuban people sometimes appear to be unaware of the regime's authoritarian basis.

Two brothers were killed at 2:45 P. M. yesterday when their single-engined Fairchild primary trainer crashed five minutes after a take-off from Rockaway Airport at Fifty-fifth Street and Beach Channel Drive, on the Rockaway peninsula in Queens.
MEXICO CITY, Aug. 1 (AP) -- William O'Dwyer, former United States Ambassador to Mexico, said today he planned several lengthy visits to the United States, including New York City.

A NEW high-speed 35mm film for television productions, which may later become available for 35mm still cameras as well, has been tested by Time-Life Photo Labs in a comparison test with four high speed 35mm films already on the market.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 1 -- An unearned run in the thirteenth inning gained a 10-9 victory for the Redlegs over the Giants at Crosley Field today. With the bases loaded and two out, Andy Seminick smashed a single that scored Gus Bell with the run that ended the 3-hour 49-minute contest.
SALEM, N. H., Aug. 1 (UP) -- Algasir, a 7-year-old gelding, made a gallant run through the Rockingham Park stretch today to win the $8,000 Raceland Handicap by two and a half lengths.

HOMER FOLKS, one of America's pioneers in child welfare and public health, once observed that if we knew the 10-year-old lad who would be President of the United States forty years hence, we would make every effort to see to it that he had the moral and physical surroundings and quality of care that would prepare him adequately for his future responsibilities.
WASHINGTON, Aug 1 (AP) -- The last four of President Eisenhower's ten Government reorganization plans took effect today, giving him a record of full success on such proposals in this Congress.
Representatives of the Women's Swimming Association captured four of the five titles in the metropolitan senior Amateur Athletic Union meet at the Flushing Meadow Pool in Queens yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (AP) -- A $70,100,000 fund to aid school construction in areas crowded by defense workers was added tonight to a catch-all appropriation bill.

Railroads serving fertilizer terminals in Baltimore have agreed to absorb certain handling costs that had threatened to put the port out of competition with other terminals on the Delaware River and in Hampton Roads.

IT is no accident' that James C. Petrillo, head of the American Federation of Musicians, used to be an important park official in this city. Music here seems to come with the park benches and is just as free under an ambitious outdoor music program that works in everything from symphony orchestra to Scandinavian songfest.

DEBUSSY wrote relatively little absolute music, but toward the end of his life, when he was already mortally ill and greatly distressed by the German invasion of his beloved France, he planned a series of six sonatas for various combinations of instruments.

The Eighty-third Congress, so far, has not been historic either for its accomplishments or for its failures. It stands out because it represents a shift -- however precarious -- in party control under a new Administration for the first time in twenty years. And yet, while under our political system party lines are rigidly formal, party doctrine is not.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (AP) -- Investigators of the House of Representatives reported today they had turned up evidence of "appalling violence" and "gangster tactics" in a labor dispute in Kansas City. The House group recommended that the Federal Government study the record for possible criminal prosecution.
PUSAN, Korea, Aug. 1 (AP) -- South Korean Premier Paik Too Chin said today that "no reasonable result" could be expected from a post-armistice political conference to settle Korean problems.

HONG KONG, Aug. 1 -- Gen. Chu Teh, commander in chief of Communist China's armed forces, observed the twenty-sixth anniversary of the People's Liberation Army in Peiping today with a speech in which he declared that "not one minute" should be allowed to slip by without further reinforcing China's defense strength.

Santha Rama Rau's "Life Goes on Under the Mau Mau's Shadow" (July 19) is most revealing in its clarity. One sees a landed aristocracy, protected by the authority of government, presiding over the labor of thousands of blacks who have little or no protection save those regulations that speak only restriction.

From the Scripps Institution of Oceanography of the University of California comes the news that the highest waves in the ocean are never seen. Sometimes they reach a height of 300 feet (almost a third the height of the Empire State Building). The waves that awe passengers on transatlantic liners are never more than a third as high, despite all the talk about "mountain-high'' waves.

WESTBURY, L. I., Aug. 1 -- Thunderation, a 5-year-old bay gelding owned by Parker R. Whiting, came up through the middle in the stretch to beat Gene Mac, the 7-to-2 second choice, by half a length in the feature Babylon junior free-for-all trot at Roosevelt Raceway tonight.

As for his other point that Daniel was an actual person in the sixth century, and that Solomon wrote the "Song of Songs" -- if Mr. Weinreb were at all familiar with the abler scholarship, he would know that both suppositions were abandoned long ago.

George Galloway's statement. "There is at present no organized group in American society that is primarily interested in the performance of Congress as an institution," fails to consider the National Committee for an Effective Congress, 680 Fifth Avenue, New York.

Leaders of nine anti-Communist organizations of Soviet exiles have been given an ultimatum that they either end the recent major split in their ranks or have the moderate subsidies they now receive for anti-Communist propaganda withdrawn beginning next month.

FOR about five million, or one out of thirty, Americans, mid-August means the beginning of the sneezing season. These are, of course, the hay fever sufferers, victimized by ragweed, timothy, orchard grass, cocklebur, marsh elder, wild rice, amaranth, poplar, white oak, white ash, pignut, hickory and birch.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (AP) -- Six years before Pearl Harbor, former Ambassador Joseph C. Grew, foresaw the possibility of a great clash in which Japan would be crushed by the Western powers but he predicted that she would rise again in one or two generations.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Aug. 1 -- Rebellions among Republicans in scattered communities of Westchester threatened today to harass the Republican County Committee on Sept. 15 with the largest number of primary contests it has faced in forty-five years of entrenchment as the dominant politiical power.
CAMP RIPLEY, Minn., Aug. 1 -- Former President Harry S. Truman paid his first visit as a civilian today to the Thirty-fifth Infantry Division, his World War I outfit.

A GENERATION ago young readers considered biography a dull subject -- in a class with homework at best. A half-dozen "Boys' Lives" probably wouldn't have equaled one Tom Swift adventure on the swapping block.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 1 -- Contract bridge stars and relative unknowns from all parts of the United States and Canada met at the Jefferson Hotel here today for the summer session of the twenty-sixth annual National Contract Bridge Championships, most important meet in the American Contract Bridge League's tournament schedule.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 1 (UP) -- Los Angeles and San Francisco baseball fans and civic officials have given up hope that the Pacific Coast League will ever become the so-called "third major league" and are going all-out to attract major league franchises.

The Eastern Lawn Tennis Association senior team defeated the Middle States Association seniors, 5 -- 4, yesterday at the West Side Club, Forest Hills, Queens, but lost possession of the Bruneau Cup to the players from the Philadelphia area.

A program of fellowships, scholarships and study awards in adult education has been inaugurated by the Ford Fund for Adult Education. These awards are the beginning of a continuing effort to help meet the need for additional highly skilled leaders in adult education.

MEXICO CITY, July 30 -- The wastes of misery behind the shining, sunny facade of modern Mexico have been coldly charted in the first partial breakdown of the 1950 national census, to be published in a fortnight.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- As the appointed hour of adjournment nears, a lot of business in Congress is conducted on faith. That faith sometimes is misplaced and out of it comes the legislative sleeper.

OF all the diseases that attack human beings, constant hunger weakens more people than any other on earth. And two-thirds of the world's population -- some 1,600,000,000 persons -- are sick with it all the time. Two-thirds of the world will go to bed hungry tonight. Except for some in extremely acute areas, they will not starve.

AN exhibition of industrial photography representative of the work in this field being done by Cities Service Photo Library photographers has been placed on display at the library, 70 Pine Street, for an indefinite period.

YONGDUNGPO, Korea, Aug. 1 -- With sullen, defiant hatred still burning in their eyes, North Korean Communist prisoners who will be exchanged at Panmunjom on the first day of Operation Big Switch sit here quietly passing the hours.

ITHACA, N. Y., Aug. 1 -- The broad "a" as pronounced in Boston, and sometimes regarded as the mark of an expensive Eastern education or aristocracy, originated among the lower classes of London and was brought here by New England business men who had commercial dealings in old England, Prof. C. K. Thomas of the Cornell University speech department says.

IN the cool of late evening a family sat about playing word games. One large lamp on a table lit the scene. Suddenly through the open window of the high-up apartment, a large brown moth flew in, hitting the lampshade with a smack.

STAMFORD, Conn., Aug. 1 -- City authorities decided today to resume the weekly Board of Recreation program after a one-week cancellation. The decision was reached at a meeting in Mayor Thomas F. J. Quigley's office, in which heads of the Police Department and the Board of Recreation discussed the recent outbreak of teen-age gang fights.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 1 -- A season's record crowd of 32,471 at Busch Stadium saw the Dodgers batter the Cardinals again tonight by a score of 11 -- 4, with Preacher Roe breezing to his seventh triumph and sixth straight.

Ted Atkinson, with what appeared to be an unworried move -- it certainly was an unhurried bit of business -- scored a smack-on-the-wire victory with Greentree Stable's 13-to-20 One Hitter in the $27,150 Merchants' and Citizens' Handicap at the Jamaica track yesterday.

The Greater New York Safety Council reported yesterday a decline in fatalities here in every major category of accident during the first six months of this year as compared with the like period last year.

IN a previous article I pointed out the need for classes in established repertory, particularly in the modern field, to help the young dancer bridge the gap between technical classes, where he is usually bred only on exercises, and the performing theatre, where, without preparation, he is supposed to be skilled in dramatic movement, characterization and a dozen other accomplishments required of the professional dancer.

CHICAGO, Aug. 1 (UP) -- Tenants in most affected cities had their rents raised an average of 10 to 15 per cent as Federal controls died yesterday, but some tenants reported increases today of more than 100 per cent.

CHICAGO, Aug. 1 -- Oil Capitol, a gray 6-year-old owned by Hasty House Farms and Mrs. Harry Trotsek, won the twenty-fourth running of the $84,500 Arlington Park Handicap today with a stretch drive which gave him a half-length victory over Dixiana's Sub Fleet.

KITIMAT, B. C., July 22 -- The vast project of the Aluminium Company of Canada -- reservoir, tunnels, underground powerhouse, transmission lines, smelter, townsite and all -- is running just about on schedule. Costs will be tens of millions of dollars above the $245,000,000 estimate for the initial expenditures, but this is a complaint one hears everywhere in Canada at the many places where mines and industries are mushrooming.

After the outbreak of the Korean War three years ago the Truman Administration embarked on a program of "guns and butter," designed to provide adequate armament in the event of full-scale war, in addition to full-scale production of civilian goods.

LITTLE FALLS, Minn., Aug. 1 (AP) -- A Minneapolis woman died in a hospital late today, bringing to ten the number of persons who lost their lives in an auto collision during a pouring rain this morning. It was the second worst highway crash in Minnesota history.

William S. White's article in THE TIMES of July 23 contains a statement by the President on why he prefers Senator Knowland's proposed amendment to the Constitution rather than the one Senator Bricker has suggested to protect our internal life against domestic government by treaty.

NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 1 -- India's National Planning Commission tackled the dismaying and growing unemployment problem today, offering an eleven-point plan that seeks to change traditional Indian thought in several important directions.
CHICAGO, Aug. 1 (UP) -- Frank Thomas drove in five runs with single and a homer today as the Pirates won their second straight from the Cubs, 10 -- 3.

SEATTLE, Aug. 1 (AP) -- Brayton Norton, the trim athlete from Occidental College at Los Angeles, won the national pentathlon championship today for the third year in a row but failed in his bid for a scoring record.

FLAGSTAFF, Ariz. -- Many of the most interesting of the smaller national parks and monuments of the country are passed up unnoticed by the hurried motorist beguiled by the roadside rattlesnake and cobra dens whose many signboards desecrate the Western landscape.
SOLINGEN, Germany, Aug. 1 (AP) -- America's touring track and field stars dominated an international meet here today, winning nine of the dozen events on the program before a crowd of 8,000.

ONE of Arnold Schoenberg's last works, A Survivor From Warsaw, has recently been recorded by Columbia. It raises the question of the point where sound effects take precedence over music. Schoenberg's idea was to point up the text that he himself wrote about the unfortunate Jew confronted with Hitler's reign of terror.

THE Victorians gazed upon world with innocent eyes, unclouded with our modern sense of guilt, our incomprehension and our inadequacy. And if we feel, as we read them, that they were a little like babes in the wood, at least they were cheerful babes and they possessed the singular advantage of knowing where they thought they were going.

An all-Caruso program will be presented tomorrow between noon and 2 P. M. in Bryant Park by the New York Public Library in commemoration of the thirty-second anniversary of the great tenor's death. Twenty recordings made from 1904 to 1920 have been selected for the program, the third observance of the anniversary, by Philip L. Miller of the Music Division.

THE remarks in this corner a fortnight ago about the problems of the adult beginner in music have induced a wide variety of reactions from readers. Most of the letter writers wish to bear witness, out of their own experience, that the study of a musical instrument, even if taken up in maturity, can be both rewarding and fun.
The struggle for the world entered a completely new phase last week as the guns were silenced in Korea.

A MILESTONE in conservation history has been passed with the approval by Congress of a $5,000,000 appropriation for a pilot program of small-scale watershed developments. The first sum Congress has ever voted for the purpose, it was included in the final version of the Agriculture Department appropriation bill only after it had been eliminated by the Senate and restored in conference.

WITHOUT the usual melodrama of brutality and violence, this story of prison life effectively indicts our penal system by describing our failure to solve the nation's crime problem -- because we will not attack it at the roots.

HAMBURG, Germany, Aug. 1 (UP) -- Budge Patty of Los Angeles and Fausto Gardini of Italy gained the singles final today in the German international tennis championships and will meet tomorrow for the title.

MANILA, Aug. 1 -- The Philippine Supreme Court stepped into the explosive local political picture today with an injunction to prevent the arrest of four Nacionalista party leaders on charges of rebellion and murder.
TULSA, Okla., Aug. 1 (AP) -- Rex Baxter, Amarillo, Tex., won the United States Golf Association's sixth annual junior amateur championship today from George Warren III, Hampton (S. C.) 16-year-old.

WHEN Metro - Goldwyn - Mayer decided to turn Cameron Hawley's novel, "Executive Suite," into a motion picture it didn't reckon with the casting problems of this "Grand Hotel" of big business. WITH the Police Department studying ways and means of having many school crossings in this city protected by a trained, part-time adult, civilian personnel, including a corps of women, consideration is being given to similar projects in other communities.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (AP) -- President Eisenhower told Congress today that Britain and three other free world nations would continue to get United States military aid even though they had sent strategic goods to Iron Curtain countries.
LONDON, Aug. 1 (Reuters) -- Middlesex, the county cricket leader, made a good start today against Sussex.

THE Du Mont television network is negotiating with the Chicago Symphony Orchestra in the hope of presenting a one hour weekly symphonic program in the fall. A network executive, optimistic that the program might materialize, said last week that the pending deal was "75 per cent firm."

DURHAM, N. C., Aug. 1 (UP) -- A textile concern that migrated here from Massachusetts two years ago prepared today for a legal battle against a Government order to rehire 700 Massachusetts workers, pay $4,000,000 back wages and move them down here if they wished to come.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- Occasionally the Eisenhowers give the White House kitchen a rest and, faithful to an old Chinese restaurant, send out for chicken chop suey with all the trimmings.

WOOD-RIDGE, N. J., Aug. 1 -- The dual goal of preserving a historic landmark and establishing a library as a war memorial is the aim of the Borough of Wood-Ridge in hiring an architect to convert the old Brinkerhoff house here.

MOSCOW, Sunday, Aug. 2 -- Mao Tse-tung. leader of Communist China, and his Premier and Foreign Minister, Chou En-lai, in a joint message to Premier Georgi M. Malenkov and Foreign Minister Vyacheslav M. Molotov assured the Soviet Union today that China would always be firmly beside Russia in seeking peace in the Far East and the whole world.

CHORE FOR THE WEEK: Start seed of biennials such as pansy and of perennials such as columbine for bloom next year. Prepare soil in a coldframe and sprinkle seed in rows, or sow seed in a pot that is kept in the frame. Water daily and shield from the sun until seeds sprout. Transplant seedlings when they have their second pair of true leaves.

NEWARK, Aug. 1 -- Newark's five-member Charter Commission, elected May 12 to study the local government, issued today a preliminary report in which it contends that the "city commission form of government should be abandoned at the earliest possible date."

One by one the Southern States have been abandoning corporal punishment of their prisoners and ending the use of chains in road camps. In Richmond the Virginia State Board of Welfare and Institutions announces that it has struck the last chains from offenders serving their time in the state road camps.

AT first glance, the title of this delightful collection of literary essays may seem a little strange. Sir Desmond MacCarthy, one of the best loved English men of letters, was 75 when he died last year. His memory goes a long way back, but surely, one thinks, he did not remember Walt Whitman and Walter Savage Landor, who are among the writers here discussed.

GROWING oriental poppies is one of my special enthusiasms. Part of this probably stems from the fact that with virtually no assistance from me oriental poppies fill my border with dazzling color from late May through June.

WINDOW ROCK, Ariz., Aug. 1 (AP) -- The horse, once a symbol of prosperity among the Navajo Indians, today can mean the poor house. The Navajo Tribal Council has allocated $25,000 a year to rid the range of about 15,000 horses roaming freely. They eat and tramp the grass and drink the limited water supply on the arid reservation.

AN English girl of good birth and breeding lands at Annapolis just before 1776, in chains and an iron collar -- and facing seven years of servitude. The young planter whistling "Greensleeves" so spiritedly on the docks that morning has his troubles too -- a wife with hypochondria, a sister-in-law who bosses and harries the plantation folk, and sore indecision over whether to go along with this frightening revolt against George III.

LONDON, Aug. 1 -- Britain and the United States again demonstrated this week their remarkable capacity for misunderstanding each other while remaining the best of friends and allies. T. change agent at the Crescent Street, Brooklyn, station of the Fulton Street elevated line, was stabbed several times in the chest and neck and cut on one hand at 8:15 A. M. yesterday by a hold-up man who later stabbed himself when cornered by the police.
