The question of how to improve the quality of teachers in American colleges has long troubled administrators and others interested in higher education. A five-year experiment, sponsored by the Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching, shows promise of constructive results.

NEWARK, N. J., Aug. 1 (AP) -- Local Essex County trafic will be permitted free use of the six county-situated express lanes of the Garden State Parkway, Bayard L. England, acting chairman of the State Highway Authority, announced tonight.

THE HAYDN SOCIETY of Boston, originally founded to record the complete works of Haydn but constantly broadening its scope, this week offers an interesting if non-Haydnesque project, Music of the Pilgrims.

The men's hosiery industry is undergoing a revolutionary change, one of the most radical in twenty years. Manufacturers, retailers and consumers are swinging toward stretchable hose, the construction of which permits them to fit almost any size foot.

PITTSBURGH, August 1 -- A symposium on social work practice in the field of tuberculosis came to a close here today with the sixth daily panel discussion of the multiple problems involved in the treatment and rehabilitation of tuberculosis patients.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Aug. 1 -- President Sukarno invested Indonesia's new Cabinet today during a brief palace ceremony and instructed the First Vice Premier, Dr. Wongsonegoro, to head the new Government until the arrival from Washington next Thursday of Premier Ali Sastroamidjojo.

THE New York State Thruway, which has been in the works since 1948, has now reached the point where travelers on parallel free roads between New York and Buffalo can catch glimpses of many completed, or nearly completed, sections.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 1 (AP) -- Bob Feller survived a ninth-inning scare today to lead the Indians past the Athletics, 5 -- 2.

ALBANY ,Aug. 1 (AP) -- Governor Dewey today appointed three Westchester business men and a housewife to the board of the new Westchester County Community College at White Plains. Five other trustees on the nine-member board will be appointed by the county board of supervisors.

CHICAGO, Aug. 1 -- Mrs. Mildred (Babe) Zaharias came back with a spectacular 34, after soaring to 44 on the first nine for a third round 78 today to share attention with big-name men pros battering par in the All American golf jamboree at Tam o' Shanter.

THE most distinguished of all readers of Western fiction is now living at 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue, Washington. Captain Butcher, his naval aide during the war, has told us that the general turned to golf, bridge and Western fiction as relaxation from his duties as Supreme Commander.

THE principal national championship tournament of the American Contract Bridge League is getting under way today in St. Louis. For some of the players assembled there -- which players it is not yet known, for they must survive elimination rounds -- it will last through Wednesday, Aug. 12, making eleven solid days of bridge playing, nine or ten hours a day.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- Connie Johnson, 31-year-old Negro rookie right-hander, pitched the second-place White Sox within four and one-half games of the league-leading Yankees tonight by defeating Washington, 4 -- 0. Johnson held the Senators to eight hits and struck out ten.

ALBANY -- The hotel fire at Rosendale, near Kingston, which brought death to four vacationists in the Catskill Mountains last week, is being used by the Joint Legislative Committee on Housing and Multiple Dwellings to point up the need for stringent enforcement of New York State's fire safety code for resort hotels, tourist homes and inns.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- W. J. McNeil, Assistant Secretary of Defense in charge of the budget, cautiously predicted today a $1,000,000,000 reduction in defense spending during the next eleven months but emphasized that the forecast was based on the assumption that the Korean truce would hold up.

American corporations spent more for the welfare of their employes last year than ever before. Contributions for pensions and other welfare programs reached new high levels. Only payments for unemployment insurance were smaller than in 1951.

I should like to add a few thoughts to the letters of Robert P. Skinner and Senator Anderson regarding wheat surpluses. To Mr. Skinner's example of Italy's consumption I should like to add that people in Italy consume so much wheat products -- the cheapest food -- perhaps because they can ill afford to buy anything more expensive.

BERLIN, Aug. 2 (AP) -- Wes Santee, Kansas' great miler, was beaten by Germany's Werner Lueg today, but American track and field stars dominated an international meet on the rain-soaked Olympic Stadium track.

BOSTON, Aug. 2 (AP) -- Detroit's improving Tigers swept a double-header with Boston's skidding Red Sox today, rallying to win the second game, 9 -- 6, after Right-hander Ned Garver had beaten Willard Nixon, 2 -- 1, in the opener. Detroit completed a sweep of the four-game series and increased Boston's losing streak to eight.

PITTSBURGH, Aug 2 -- The full week of truce in Korea showed no change in the steel order pattern. As expected, there was no rush of cancellations, but a few minor changes are predicted for the coming months.
CHICAGO, Aug. 2 (AP) -- Heavy rains today washed out the final round of the $30,000 Tam o'Shanter All American golf tournaments and the windup was re-scheduled for tomorrow.

NOROTON, Conn., Aug. 2 -- The host club's Waily Crump of the Noroton Yacht Club, captured the new Long Island Sound Lightning Class championship as the threerace series wound up with a sevenmile race off Long Neck Point today.

CHICAGO, Aug. 2 (UP) -- Ransom Jackson hit a home run in the last half of the eleventh inning with two out today to enable the Cubs to gain a 7-to-6 victory over the Pirates in a game that lasted three hours and was delayed an hour and a half by rain.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, Aug. 2 (AP) -- Oil-rich Rumania, the Soviet Union's most strategic East European satellite, today put on a spicand-span apron of whitewash and colors to impress thousands of West Europeans attending the Communist-sponsored "Fourth World Youth Festival."

Robert F. Wagner Jr., TammanyBronx candidate for the Democratic nomination for Mayor, declared yesterday that, if elected, he would do all in his power "to root out those few people in Tammany who have connections with the underworld."

CINCINNATI, Aug. 2 -- Harry Perkowski and Fred Baczewski of the Redlegs had too much for the Giants today at Crosley Field. The former blanked the Polo Grounders, 5 -- 0, and Baczewski downed them, 3 -- 1. Leo Durocher's outfit left this town, where they dropped three out of four to the Redlegs, in fifth place, a length-and-a-half behind the Cardinals.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (AP) -- Educational television leaders said today "there is no conflict of interest" between their aims and those of commercial telecasters.

The 18,000 persons who attended the Saturday evening concert at Lewisohn Stadium -- the final event of the season -- brought the total attendance for the six-week series just a little above last year's. Salvatore Dell' Isola conducted the Rodgers-Hammerstein program, and the soloists were Annamary Dickey, Claramae Turner, Thomas Hayward and Robert Weede.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 2 -- Runner-up to Victor Seixas in the Pennsylvania state tournament last week, Tony Trabert won the Middle Atlantic grass-court tennis championship today at the Baltimore Country Club.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 2 -- Today the weather continued hot but the Dodgers didn't. In a temperature of around 110 degrees on the field, the beleaguered Cardinals turned on the Brooks and beat them, 10-1, behind the fine six-hit pitching of Harvey Haddix, with 29,013 sweltering fans watching the fun.
NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 2 (AP) -Gen. Mark Clark, in New Orleans for his son's wedding, said today he hoped to "take off my shoes and rest a while" before returning to his United Nations command in Tokyo.

TOKYO, Aug. 2 (UP) -- Ford Konno of Honolulu and Ohio State scored a revenge triumph tonight over his 1,500-meter conqueror, Katsuji Yamashita of Japan, as he won the 400-meter free-style event in the finals of the four-day Japanese national swimming championships.

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Aug. 2 -- The seas ran heavy before a stiff easterly wind on Long Island Sound today as the Echo Bay Y. C. concluded its forty-third annual regatta and the second successive day as sponsor of the Yacht Racing Association championship competition.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 2 (AP) -- The Indians, backing the strong-arm hurling of Early Wynn and Bob Lemon with hits in bunches, took both ends of a double-header from the Athletics today, 10--1 and 7--1, to sweep the four-game series.

Lewis A. Lapham will take up his duties with the Grace Line today in the newly created position of executive vice president and also as a director. He resigned on Feb. 25 as president of the AmericanHawaiian Steamship Company, a position he had held for six years, to join the Grace organization.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- Only nine of the 429 successful applicants for television stations have turned their licenses back to the Federal Communications Commission since the commission lifted its "freeze" on new stations in April, 1952. Of the 429 licenses granted 269 are for ultra high frequency service.

ZURICH, Switzerland, Aug. 2 -- The decision to hold the Fourth International Congress of Astronautics in the Technische Hochschule here, an institution comparable with the California Institute of Technology and the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, has given official status, in Europe at least, to the seventeen societies throughout the world that believe in the imminence of extraterrestrial flight.

PARIS, Aug. 2 -- Chinese prints are the leading note of de Givenchy's collection. On satin, though modern and softly blurred, designs stem from Chinese porcelains, as well as the shades of jade, amber, rose quartz and lapis lazuli.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (UP) -The Federal Bureau of Investigation said today its practice of listing the "ten most wanted" fugitives had proved to be "an effective instrument in eliminating vicious criminal fugitives."
The public assistance caseload here declined by 3,135 persons from May to June, with costs decreasing from $11,289,286 to $11,248,397, Henry L. McCarthy, Commissioner of Welfare, reported yesterday.

SEATTLE, Aug. 2 -- Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll of New Jersey said today it was quite obvious that the new self-reform movement of the International Longshoremens Association would not solve the problem of crime and corruption on the New York and New Jersey waterfronts.

KABUL, Afghanistan, July 22 -The scarred earth left in the wake of the Mongol invasion of Afghanistan 800 years ago is being reclaimed for nomadic tribes who will settle on 640,000 acres west and south of Kandahar, the nation's second largest city.

A quiet steady undertone prevailed throughout the foreign exchange market during the past week. Activity in the pound sterling slackened off considerably while business in the Canadian dollar picked up in volume. The signing of the Korean truce, long expected, had no material effect on the market.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- The public paid its respects today to Robert A. Taft on his last visit to the Capitol. Upward of 30,000 persons, many in shirt-sleeves and carrying infants in arms, filed by the coffin under the dome of the Capitol before the chamber was closed at 9 o'clock tonight.

WISSANT, France, Aug. 2 (AP) -Egyptian swimmers established two new English Channel records today, but Florence Chadwick, 33year-old San Diego, Calif., typist, who twice has conquered the testing twenty-five miles, failed in her third attempt.

A variety of adjectives, such as dull, indifferent, quiet and slack, were used over the week-end by ship brokers and agents to describe last week's activity, or lack of it, in the steamship chartering industry.

WASHINGTON, Aug 2 (UP) -The American housewife will not buy more butter this year than she did last even though a greater supply is available and the average price is lower, the Department of Agriculture's Bureau of Economics said today.
LONDON, Aug. 2 (UP) -- Adlai E. Stevenson refused today to confirm or deny a report he had said he would run again for President if asked.

LENOX, Mass., Aug. 2 -- Pierre Monteux conducted his one concert of the Berkshire Festival this afternoon. It consisted entirely of familiar works by Tchaikovsky, but such is the conductor's power to make all music fresh that the program had the quality of sunlight.

TOKYO, Monday, Aug. 3 -- Red Cross teams representing the United Nations and the Communists agreed late yesterday to start moving into North and South Korea tomorrow morning, instead of today as originally planned, to take assistance and comfort to prisoners of war awaiting return to their homes or other disposition.
PARIS, Aug. 2 -- President Vincent Auriol's Bastille Day pardon measures on July 14 resulted in the release today of a number of Communists and former Vichy Government members and sympathizers.

LANCASTER, Pa. -- The epicure who visits this region will find himself richly rewarded, but he is likely to be surprised to learn that the substantial Pennsylvania Dutch dishes for which the region has become famous are now a not too common specialty.

The Jewish Theological Seminary of America, celebrating the fiftieth anniversary of its incorporation, will conduct a Conference on Moral Standards, Sept. 13-15, Dr. Louis Finkelstein, chancellor of the seminary, announced yesterday at a special meeting of conference leaders in the Astor Hotel.

CHAMPAIGN, Ill., Aug. 2 -- Dr. George D. Stoddard, whose resignation last week as president of the University of Illinois was forced by the board of trustees, issued today a point by point rebuttal to eleven major and three lesser charges made against him by Park Livingston, president of the trustees.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (UP) -Senator Edwin C. Johnson, Democrat of Colorado, tonight called Dr. Karl T. Compton "enemy number one of the people of the United States" for favoring Universal Military Training.

BERLIN, Aug. 2 -- The East German Government launched today an all-out offensive against the West's free-food project, barring rail travel to Berlin and seizing the gift parcels of those who sneaked through and headed home again.

TEHERAN, Iran, Aug. 2 -- The cheers and speeches of curb-side rallies and political processions resounded in the streets of this capital tonight as preparations were completed for the first referendum -- on the dissolution of the already helpless Majlis, lower and sole existing house of Parliament -- in Iran's forty-seven years of constitutional Government.

STAMFORD, Conn., Aug. 2 -Michael Memmoli is coming to court here tomorrow to be tried for breaking and entering and for illegal registration of an automobile. The police hope that it means he will be out of their hair a while, for Memmoli has been very, very trying.

In recent months several books by missionaries dealing with their lives as prisoners of the Chinese Communists have been published. These were written by men. On Sept. 24 McGraw-Hill will publish a book by a nun, a Maryknoll missionary, Sister Mary Victoria.

STOCKHOLM, Aug. 2 -- The present oversized national and municipal expenditure constitutes a threat against Sweden's economic stability and may unleash a fresh wave of inflation, warns the Swedish Bankers Association in a letter to the National Bank of Sweden.

Yesterday's water main break stopped the water supply in an area between Thirteenth and Thirtieth Streets, east of Fifth Avenue, from 2 P. M. until about 5:30 P. M. The only other utility affected was the telephone system.

LONDON, Aug. 2 -- In spite of the severe Labor party criticism in Parliament last week the British Foreign Office is quite understanding and even sympathetic toward the ninety-day limit the United States Secretary of State, John Foster Dulles, has set for the Korean peace conference to prove it is not a sham.

TOKYO, Aug. 2 -- A firm military alliance between North Korea and Communist China is now at least in the cards as a result of Korean armistice developments, some well informed Japanese and diplomatic observers here believe.

PARIS, Aug .2 -- Certain experts of the European Payments Union will attend the meeting of the Bretton Woods organization in Washington six weeks from now with the special intention of raising the question of convertibilty with the International Monetary Fund.

Sales and earnings of the Packard Motor Car Company in the first six months this year were approximately double those of the similar period last year. James J. Nance, president, revealed in the semi-annual report, released today.

The Bethlehem Steel Company's Twenty-seventh Street shipyard, Brooklyn, remained idle yesterday as its working force observed picket lines set up last Wednesday by the Seafarers International Union, A. F. L., and maintained since before the yard's entrance.

A sound and vital idea underlies "Economics for the Citizen"* by Alfred R. Oxenfeldt. This City College pedagogue had hooked economics into "the current issues of greatest general interest" and has omitted "the academic trappings that have possibly contributed somewhat to intellectual rigor."

CHICAGO, Aug. 2 -- Feed grains and soybeans forged ahead in the grain market last week, but rye futures were distinctly weak and wheat made feeble response to crop damage news from spring wheat states. There was a lot of black rust news last week, indicating that infestation of the disease was general in the Northwest, but reports of actual damage were not so numerous. Durum wheat mostly has been hurt.

In the midst of the turmoil in Congress last month over the excess profits tax, Representative Reed of New York introduced a bill bearing directly on the problem of the budget that attracted less attention, perhaps, than it merited. This was a proposal, offered on July 15, calling for the repeal of the so-called "Mills provision" in the 1950 Revenue Act.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (UP) -Senator John L. McClellan, Democrat of Arkansas, who led a Democratic walkout from Senator Joseph R. McCarthy's Permanent Senate Subcommittee on Investigations, indicated today that he intended to try to curb some of Mr. McCarthy's power at the next session of Congress.

Prompt reappointment of City Magistrate Morris Ploscowe by Mayor Impellitteri was urged yesterday by a committee headed by William Dean Embree, former president of the New York County Lawyers Association and vicepresident of the National Probation and Parole Association.

ROME, Aug. 2 -- Vice Premier Attilio Piccioni, a member of the Christian Democratic party, accepted from President Luigi Einaudi today the task of trying to form a new government to replace the one headed by Alcide De Gasperi that resigned last Tuesday.

BOSTON, Aug. 2 -- Mrs. Gardiner was born in Newton, Mass., a sixth generation descendant of Dr. Sylvanus Gardiner, one of the proprietors of the Kennebec Purchase and Oaklands, the stone castle and estate in Gardiner that has been the property of the Gardiner family since 1754.

DORTMUND, Germany, Aug. 2 (UP) -- Heinz Neuhaus of Germany successfully defended his European heavyweight boxing championship for the third time tonight when he scored a 15-round decision over Karel Sys of Belgium in Dortmund's outdoor stadium before a crowd of 30,000.

EAST HAMPTON, L. I., Aug. 2 -- Gilbert Petermann, a Long Island boat builder from Malverne, today was the high point pilot on what has become an annual fixture on Three Mile Harbor, the yachtsmen's favorite anchorage off Gardiners Bay north of this village.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (UP) -The Interstate Commerce Commission is getting set to reorganize itself gradually, J. Monroe Johnson, the agency's chairman, said today.

George Saleeby, a 43-year-old former mental patient who told the police on Saturday that he had shot three men in one week, including one who had been officially declared dead from natural causes, was arraigned in Felony Court yesterday.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Aug. 2 (UP) -- The polygamous town of Short Creek, Ariz., was turned into a ghost town today when thirty-eight mothers and 154 children were brought here by authorities who feared husbands released on bail would lead mass escapes to Utah and Mexico.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Aug. 2 -- Equestrian events will be held at the 1956 Olympic Games in Australia if entries are received from six countries, the acting chairman of the games' Organizing Committee, Lewis Luxton, said tonight.

Despite the 8,000,000-ton sugar quota for this country, an effective sugar supply of only 7,650,000 short tons exists in the market, according to B. W. Dyer Co., sugar economist and broker. The consumption for the country is estimated at 8,200,000 tons, leaving 550,000 tons to be made available by deficit prorations, quota increases or Puerto Rican 10 per cent retention releases.

It is very high-minded of you to praise the new Transit Authority for the ease with which the change-over of coin boxes has been made, as you did in your editorial of July 28. Nevertheless, a little imagination plus efficiency might have foreseen the use of slugs and toy coins, and so-called adjustment of the boxes made at the time of the change-over.

GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 2 -- A national campaign for a coast-to-coast clean-up and the removal from the American urban landscape of such familiar old friends as apple and tulip trees, horse chestnuts, catalpas, willows, poplars and certain elms, on the theory that they are messy, unmanageable, brittle or sickly, has been quietly started here by Tree Warden Joseph A. Dietrich.

AMSTERDAM, Aug. 2 -- Holland, after a long post-war period of social peace, may soon witness the beginning of social unrest. The four employers associations last week put the cat among the pigeons by a joint declaration that after next year they refuse further cooperation in any new general wage rounds except in that resulting from the forthcoming rent increase.
TRENTON, Aug. 2 -- A general alarm was sent out tonight to all New Jersey state police to be on the lookout for a Mexican Air Force plane missing with five officers aboard.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 2 -William Goetz will give up his position as head of production at Universal-International tomorrow, but will remain at the studio until Nov. 12 when his contract terminates.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- Civilian and Navy scientists seeking in the upper atmosphere of the Arctic regions the solution to the mysteries of cosmic rays "captured" the particles last week sixty miles above the earth's surface.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 2 -- The first championship event in the summer session of the twenty-sixth annual National Contract Bridge Championships got under way this afternoon at the Jefferson Hotel with eighty-three teams competing the first of three sessions of the master mixed team of four championship.

Athens of the first century with its "cafe society" of "intellectual and spiritual dilettantes" might be compared with America today where "countless thousands have their own altars to an unknown god," the Very Rev. Sturgis Lee Riddle, Dean of the American Pro-Cathedral Episcopal Church of the Holy Trinity, Paris, declared yesterday.

NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 2 -- A three-point plan for ameliorating the political and economic difficulties in Kenya that have culminated in the bloody Mau Mau uprising there will be presented to the Colonial Office in London by Joseph Murumbi, general secretary of the Kenya African Union, Mr. Murumbi said today.

Rockefeller Center Inc., has announced its purchase of a plot of land covering 60,000 square feet in midtown Manhattan for investment. The plot has a frontage of 305 feet at 103-131 West Fiftieth Street and runs through the block to an equal frontage on Fifty-first Street between the Avenue of the Americas and Seventh Avenue, and was bought from the All-Continent Corporation.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (UP) -America's share of the guaranteed world wheat market in the next twelve months will be between 190,000,000 and 249,000,000 bushels, Under Secretary of Agriculture True D: Morse said today.

Theodore H. Coogan, in his letter published on July 27 upholding McCarthy, tips his hand -- or perhaps I should say his mind -- in his closing statement. He says, regarding McCarthy, "* * * he deserves the admiration and support of every loyal American, which I believe he has."

CAIRO, Aug. 2 -- Lieut. Col. Gamal Abdel Nasser, Egypt's Deputy Premier, today told the citizens of Ismailia -- a recent point of friction in the British-Egyptian dispute over the Suez Canal zone -that the Government would never slacken its effort to end the British occupation.

FREEDOM VILLAGE, Korea, Monday, Aug. 3 (AP) -- The 3,313 United States prisoners of war whose release will start here Wednesday will receive $150 in cash each and the rest of their back pay in a United States Treasury check.

TELEVISION station WNBT is having another go at the late evening, informal variety program. Two new ones are at hand -- the Steve Allen show Mondays through Fridays from 11:20 to midnight, for which there is limited hope, and the Morey Amsterdam show on Saturdays from 11:15 to midnight, which is not likely to revolutionize the established habits of Saturday night pleasure seekers.
Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt returned from a round-the-world tour of two and a half months yesterday with a discouraging report on American prestige abroad.

Despite the truce in Korea, millions of our young men and women will still be called upon to serve in the armed forces here and abroad, far from their families and friends. Millions of persons still will be on the move as a result of the demands of the national security.

The National Newspaper Week Committee is now cutting the fuses for the barrage it will lay down beginning Oct. 1. In accordance with previous custom, proven successful by heavy participation of daily and weekly newspapers, it has redesigned the traditional logotype, "Your Newspaper Lights the Way to Freedom," and added the special slogan for 1953, "An Informed Press Means an Informed People."

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 2 -- An expansion program has been started at a "push button" engineering and maintenance base at which United Air Lines does major overhaul work on its fleet of more than 150 planes.

BOOTHBAY HARBOR, Me., Aug. 2 -- The New York Yacht Club squadron was lying in the harbor here today licking its wounds and relieved of racing until it heads farther to the eastward tomorrow. Code flags fluttered from bow to masthead to stern for a picture that this resort port has rarely seen.

Even if there is a recession in business activity this year, it is likely to be slight, according to the August letter of the National City Bank of New York. Most so-called bearish influences, it finds, have been exaggerated in the popular mind.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (AP) -Walter Masterson dropped the White Sox five games back of the idle Yankees today when he pitched the Senators to a 1-0 victory. Masterson permitted six hits in posting his seventh victory and fourth shut-out.

CUMBERLAND, Wis., Aug. 2 (AP) -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, questioned today the wisdom of President Eisenhower's decision to continue military aid to Britain and three other free world nations that have sent strategic goods to Iron Curtain nations.

Declines in sales and production of military wool goods in the first five months of 1953 were offset by gains in civilian wool apparel fabrics, it was announced yesterday by the National Association of Wool Manufacturers.

Sir Alexander Korda, British film producer, has been named winner of the first Golden Laurel Trophy, which will be presented each year by David O. Selznick to the European movie-maker selected by an American jury for contributing most to international goodwill and mutual understanding through motion pictures.

With a widened policy to study political and social forces as well as basic economic issues, the Twentieth Century Fund announced yesterday that it had spent $624,174 in 1952, but had found its assets increasing even more -- by $996,260, to $10,875,758.

LONDON, Aug. 2 -- Prime Minister Sir Winston Churchill motored this evening from Chequers, his official country residence, to the Royal Lodge at Windsor where he had a forty-five-minute audience with Queen Elizabeth II.

TULSA, Okla., Aug. 2 (AP) -World and United States crude oil production in May dipped slightly below the previous month's output, but both increased over May, 1952, the Oil and Gas Journal reported today.
" What mankind needs today is not more food, finer art, vaster industry -- it is God," the Rev. Dr. James W. Clarke, pastor of the Second Presbyterian Church in St. Louis, said yesterday morning.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (AP) -The Defense Department today identified 444 Korean war casualties in the second daily list issued since the fighting ceased in the Far East.

Emanating from the grapevine is a report that the Avon may revert to the legitimate fold, after a gap of sixteen years, with "Escapade," the London comedy hit due here the week of Nov. 2 with Roger Livesey and his wife, Ursula Jeans, starred The intimate house, seating 740, was purchased recently by Abraham Dreier and his son, Frederick, from the Columbia Broadcasting System.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (UP) -- A spokesman for the Republican Congressional Committee commented that a film on national defense was being prepared for television use, but said it was "completely nonpartisan" and would be made available for G.O.P. House and Senate members for use on local stations on a public service basis.
SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 2 -- Sixty Augusts ago, when the Flash Stakes for 2-year-olds was run for the twenty-fifth time, Jim Fitzsimmons rode the horse that finished second.

MILWAUKEE, Aug. 2 (UP) -The Phillies and the Braves fought to a stalemate today in their battle for second place in the National League as the Phils won the opener of a double-header, 4 to 1, and the Braves took the second game, 6 to 1.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- Final votes on four major bills, each already thoroughly debated, were all that stood tonight between Congress and adjournment.

Preliminary steps toward abandoning service on the Third Avenue elevated in Manhattan and demolishing the seventy-sixyear-old structure -- possibly by the end of the year -- have been taken by the New York City Transit Authority.

FISHERS ISLAND, N. Y., Aug. 2 -- Harold M. Lane's Doris III, an ocean-racing yawl, today was the Division I and over-all victor among the Cruising Club rule yachts on the first leg of the American Yacht Club's annual cruise.

May I point out the inconsistency in the utterances of Walter White about race relations and Soviet Russian criticism of the United States. In THE NEW YORK TIMES of July 28 Mr. White states that he is "shocked and dismayed" over the selection of Governor Byrnes of South Carolina as a member of the United States delegation to the United Nations.
Children's playgrounds over the country may begin having their faces lifted within the next few years if a competition for designs of new playground equipment has the results its sponsors hope for.

That this maxim is again being applied seems the most likely explanation for the Soviet charge, now being repeated by the Chinese Communists, that American planes shot down a Russian transport flying over Chinese territory.

Net income of the Electric Bond and Share Company for the twelve months ended on June 30 of this year amounted to $6,427,437, the highest in twenty years, George G. Walker, president, announced yesterday. These earning were equal to $1.22 a share on the company's outstanding common stock and are 16 cents a share more than in the previous twelve-month period.

LITERARY annals do not record who was the first to think of it -- perhaps some enterprising contemporary of Fanny Burney -- but hundreds of young women have written entertaining books according to the same reliable formula. In its simplest form it goes like this: Marry a husband outside your familiar social circle, the farther outside the better, and write a book about your humorous and interesting experiences getting adjusted to his way of life.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 2 -- On the last day of the race meeting here last year there was a gaudy-odds winner in the first race, and a man from the press box went to the paddock to ask the trainer, Jack Lawrence, if there was a reasonably fascinating tale of the turf connected with his horse. There was.

LONDON, Aug. 2 -- The signing of the armistice in Korea, although an event of the highest importance in international affairs, has produced scarcely a ripple in the financial markets. Its effect, too, on commodity, markets has been equally slight.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- The votes of the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on the major roll calls in Congress during the period July 25 through July 31 are given in the appended tabulation:

SEATTLE, Wash., Aug. 2 -Three Republican Governors from New Jersey, Wisconsin and Washington agreed today a balanced Federal budget was more important to the country than the promised reduction in taxes next year.

The Korean truce had little effect on trading in cotton futures in the domestic market last week. While prices were somewhat lower, there was no indication of selling pressure at any time. Cotton brokers said the decline stemmed from other causes and that the impact of the truce had been discounted some time ago.
SEOUL, Korea, Aug. 2 -- Dr. Syngman Rhee, South Korean President, warned members of the United Nations tonight against a course of appeasement toward communism.

It is fairly easy to see why the Senate Finance Committee shelved the President's request for a rise in the debt limit but it is hard to see what good can come of the action. The Senators obviously want to place themselves on the record as "economy-minded" and opposed, at every turn, to runaway federal spending.

CHICAGO, Aug. 2 (UP) -- The American Medical Association and other professional groups voiced strong opposition today to President Eisenhower's plan to bring their members into the Federal Social Security program.

LONDON, Aug. 2 (AP) -- Albania's People's Assembly gave rubber stamp approval last night to sweeping Government reorganization and dropped Dr. Omer Nishani from his figurehead post as President of the Presidium.

RYE, N. Y., Aug. 2 -- Enjoying a 3-0 lead, the American players were forced to wait another day as the second portion of the seven-match Wightman Cup series with the British team at the Westchester Country Club was postponed because of rain today.

NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 2 -While India and Pakistan are preparing renewed negotiations on the future of the disputed State of Kashmir, there has been a serious political division in the Kashmir Government, headed by Sheikh Mohammed Abdullah, that hitherto had been considered to be stanchly pro-Indian.
GUATEMALA, Aug. 2 -- Stronger than ever and with confidence born of an unbroken series of successes, Guatemala's Communists have given public warning of their immediate political aim.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Aug. 2 (AP) -The Who Dat, piloted by Don Wilson of Dearborn, Mich., won the 135-cubic-inch national speed boat championship today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (UP) -- The Nationalists and the Federalists chose their Presidential candidates today, but President Eisenhower need not worry about his lease on the White House.
PARIS, Aug. 2 -- Arriving at Nice to superintend the negotiations with France, Bao Dai, Chief of State of Vietnam, said today that he would ask for complete independence for his Indo-Chinese country.

A thirty-six-inch water main broke in East Fourteenth Street yesterday, flooding the Union Square subway station and causing an explosion that ripped up the sidewalk outside Luchow's restaurant and sealed its doors with a seething column of steam forty stories high.
RAVENSBURG, Germany, Aug. 2 (AP) -- West German Chancellor Konrad Adenauer today assured German refugees that they would one day get back their homes in the East.

ATLANTIC HIGHLANDS, N. J., Aug. 2 (AP) -- Ed Waters of Red Bank's Monmouth Bloat Club sailed Revenger through the choppy waters of Sandy Hook Bay to the Atlantic Coast Lightning class championship today.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Aug. 2 -- Nine American television artists and technicians, including the actress Maria Riva, who spent two months in Israel preparing to produce a series of television shorts, are leaving the country after the sudden termination of the project.

CAMBRIDGE, Md., Aug. 2 (AP) -Robert (Bud) McAllister of Ventnor, N. J., broke his world record in the one-mile time trials and set a competitive five-mile world mark for 44-cubic-inch runabouts in the seventeenth annual Cambridge Yacht Club regatta here today.

The four-story building containing two stores and eighteen apartments on lot 41 by 100 feet at 1254 Stebbins Avenue, the Bronx, was sold by Jeannette H. Foss to Samuel Hurwitz in a deal negotiated by Morris Balaban, broker. It is at East 169th Street and is assessed at $47,000.

The years pass and some things change, but nothing ever happens to take New York City's jumbo-size taxicabs off the crowded streets. Common observation, supported by occasional surveys, suggests that the average taxicab on its appointed rounds carries one passenger or two.
Today's patterns are dedicated to the college girl. At our request, Emily Wilkens, the designer, specially created the styles offered here.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- Secretary of State John Foster Dulles, leaving for talks with South Korea's President Syngman Rhee, assured the United States' other Allies today that there would be full consultation with them on the future of Korea.

CRAFTSMEN in the slowly vanishing silk-hat and opera-hat trade are grateful that the United Nations set up New York headquarters and that Latin-American diplomats cling to strictly formal headgear for public appearance.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 2 -- An unqualified accusation that "elements closely tied to the President of the Republic are trying to persuade a general of the Army to take over the Ministry of War and carry out a sudden change in key commands for a coup" was made today by the generally responsible newspaper Diario Carioca.

The arrival in Korea of New York engineers as a result of the program of the United Nations Korean Reconstruction Agency to proceed with the preliminary work necessary for the construction of a commercial nitrogenous fertilizer plant brings new economic hope to the people of the Republic of Korea.

We have had occasion to assail the "apartheid" policy of Prime Minister Malan and his South African Government on moral grounds. We oppose, on those grounds, the concept of racial superiority on which it is based. We also have criticized the policy on political grounds.
MILWAUKEE, Aug. 3 -- Russ Meyer pitched and batted the Dodgers to a 1-0 victory over the Braves tonight in a game that was called in the bottom of the eighth inning because of rain.

Active cotton futures rose 7 to 16 points here yesterday. Prices on the New York Cotton Exchange opened unchanged from Friday's close to 3 points lower on Southern and local selling but recovered on trade support.

A Rudolph Valentino silent movie, vintage 1924, which had been put to uses the great Latin lover never foresaw, led last night to the arrest of the proprietor of an East Side bar and a motion picture operator.
The Philco Corporation in the first half of this year achieved the highest sales for any such period in its history, lifting earnings from operations to $6,900,000 from $4,289,000 a year earlier.

SEATTLE, Aug. 3 -- Gov. John S. Fine, Pennsylvania Republican, and Gov. John S. Battle, Virginia Democrat, joined today in a public attack upon the Federal Bureau of Investigation, asserting that it had invaded the police powers of the states.

A study of the Ukraine and its people and their outlook for checking "the Soviet paralysis of civilization" will be issued by Bookman Associates on Aug. 19 under the title "Ukraine Under the Soviets." The author is Clarence A. Manning, associate Professor of Slavic Languages at Columbia University, who had the help of a group of Ukrainian professors now living in western Europe.

THE NEW YORK TIMES' story, "Auto Industry Sees a Decline," published in the July 20 issue, indicates that this newspaper has relaxed the scrutiny of its staff members' judgment on this particular estimate of what is fact and what appears to be fact.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- A move among Republican Senators to delay, and perhaps prevent, the expected election of William F. Knowland of California to the post of majority leader to replace the late Senator Robert A. Taft was temporarily blocked late today.

WEST TOWNSHEND, Vt., Aug. 3 -- The old Taft homestead, high atop Taft Hill, where the family of the late Senator Robert A. Taft made its home 100 years ago before moving to Ohio, was visited Yesterday by more tourists than at any other time.
Justin Lane has become associated with the New York Stock Exchange firm of Pyne, Kendall Hollister.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 3 (AP) -- Joe Nuxhall blanked the last-place Pirates on five hits tonight for a 5-0 Cincinnati victory. The triumph was the fourth in a row for the Redlegs, all won by left-handed pitchers:
In your issue of July 22 you published a report by Kennett Love, your special correspondent in Teheran, regarding the demonstrations on July 21.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (AP) -- The Government announced today a new contract under which domestic production of titanium sponge will be increased by 6,000 tons annually.
A woman and a minister were slashed yesterday by a razor-wielding assailant who snatched the woman's pocketbook but was captured after a mile chase by the minister and a Columbia University student.

WESTBURY, L. I., Aug. 3 -- Newport Chief, owned by the Newport Stock Farm of South Plainfield, N. J., and driven by Del Cameron, scored a one-length victory over Torrid in the $30,000 Village Farm Stake No. 18 for 3-year-old pacers in 2:02 2/5 at Roosevelt Raceway tonight.

BONN, Germany, Aug. 3 -- The Social Democratic party published today an analysis of the West German economic situation that sought to prove that this country's phenomenal post-war recovery was based on Government policies of making the rich richer and the poor poorer.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- William S. Lasdon, president of a Yonkers, N. Y., chemical company, told a Ways and Means subcommittee of the House of Representatives today that he had paid Judge Welburn S. Mayock, a Washington tax lawyer, $65,000 in cash to obtain a ruling from the Bureau of Internal Revenue that saved his family something like $1,500,000 in taxes.

The multi-price situation in the zinc market was confused further yesterday when one of the largest suppliers announced it would continue to sell zinc on the traditional East St. Louis basing point system -- but would absorb any freight charges in excess of 50 cents a hundredweight.

RANGOON, Burma, July 23 -- During the fiscal year beginning next October, the Government of Burma will initiate economic rehabilitation projects for large-scale production of hydroelectricity, thermal power, fertilizers, paper, jute goods and cement.

Stocks hit their best levels since June 1 at the high point of a broad but moderate upward movement yesterday. Forebodings over Congressional refusal to raise the debt limit were not translated into market action. Steels, motors, oils and rails pushed forward early in the session and trimmed their gains later but electronics and some of the rubbers were showing strength at the close.

OCEANPORT, N. J., Aug. 3 (AP) -- Jockey Sammy Boulmetis, who appears certain to gain the riding honors at Monmouth Park this season, scored his forty-fourth victory of the meet today as George D. Widener's gelding Scent beat favored Skipper Bill by two lengths in the feature purse.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- Eight Senators and twenty-four members of the House of Representatives introduced legislation today to recodify again the country's immigration and naturalization laws to replace the controverted McCarran-Walter Act of 1952 This statute was enacted over a veto invoked by Harry S. Truman, who then was President.

Alexander Schneider, a noted musician and teacher with a particular fondness for chamber music, thinks that too few New Yorkers get to hear that musical genre. The best way for them to hear it, he reasoned, would be to play it for them. What better place than Washington Square Park?

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (AP) -- The Senate today sent to President Eisenhower the $6,500,000,000 foreign aid bill which, although cut sharply below the original request, was considered an Administration victory.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- Advice is given to the parents of the pre-school child who is blind in a booklet issued today by the Children's Bureau of the Department of Health, Education and Welfare.
The Greek Line has decided to call its new 24,000-ton flagship, now being completed in Scotland, the Olympia.
ANKARA, Turkey, Aug. 3 -- Thirty-three men went on trial today in connection with the attempted assassination of Ahmet Emin Yalman, liberal Turkish newspaper editor on Nov. 22, 1952.
Aaron Frank, candidate for the Democratic nomination for Bronx Borough President against James J. Lyons, the incumbent, resigned yesterday as Third Deputy Police Commissioner.

The awards of the Christophers, 18 East Forty-eighth Street, for the second quarter of 1953 will go to a journalist, two cartoonists, an actor and others for their works reflecting "the God-given talent that can be exerted by one individual in the literary and entertainment fields," the Rev. James Keller, director, announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (AP) -- The Department of Defense said today that the International. Harvester Company will be the sole producer of five-ton military trucks after Jan. 1. They will be produced at Harvester's Fort Wayne, Ind., plant.

Two issues of Atlas Plywood Corporation's securities totaling more than $6,775,000 are being offered publicly today. Van Alstyne, Noel Co. heads two groups of underwriters in the distribution of $5,000,000 of the corporation's 5 per cent sinking fund debentures due in 1968 and 150,000 shares of its common stock.
BALTIMORE, Aug. 3 (AP) -- The Maryland Jockey Club, hoping to bring about a Native Dancer-Tom Fool meeting in the Pimlico Special, today set the date of the race for Oct. 24.

ZURICH, Switzerland, Aug. 3 -- Three rocket societies in the United States failed to answer the roll-call at the delegates' meeting of the International Astronautical Congress here today. They were the Reaction Research, the Pacific and the Detroit Rocket Societies.

A Mexican Air Force plane carrying five persons, which had been sought by the Civil Air Patrol after vanishing Sunday on a flight from Maxwell Field, Ala., to Linden Airport, New Jersey, landed safely at Hadley Field, N. J., ten miles from its destination. Hadley Field was closed at the time.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- The White House denied today that there were any plans to use United States combat troops in Korea to help rebuild the war-torn country. The statement followed several sharp attacks on the Senate floor by both Republicans and Democrats over a plan attributed to John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- Secretary of the Treasury George M. Humphrey offered today to exchange $2,881,576,000 in maturing 2 per cent certificates of indebtedness for new one-year certificates bearing 2 5/8 per cent interest.

JOE HORGAN often was called golf's dean of caddies. But the man who passed on to greener fairways last week preferred to consider himself the best-known caddy in the land. In many respects he was right.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Aug. 3 -- The Westchester Professional Golf Association pro-amateur tournament at the Ridgeway C. C. today drew eighty-six teams for best-ball and nine shared the lead with 67 six-under par.
SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., Aug. 3 -- The strongest field of the season began play today in the Eastern grass court championships at the Orange Lawn Tennis Club.

A jurisdictional dispute involving one deep-sea ship, two seamen's unions, a harbor workers' union, a shipbuilders' union and two companies entered its fifth day yesterday with six tugboats and ten barges being tied up.
A night club on Fifty-second Street was raided at midnight last night by a special police squad, which seized the cabaret's books and the permits of fifteen employees including eight entertainers.

PANMUNJOM, Korea, Tuesday, Aug. 4 -- The Communists said today that seventy Americans would be among the 400 United Nations captives to be released tomorrow in the start of the exchange of war prisoners.

BERLIN, Aug. 3 -- The official East German press confirmed today reports that many persons fought yesterday's effort by the Communists to prevent East Germans from collecting the gift food parcels distributed in West Berlin. Nevertheless rumors of mass violence could not be corroborated.

Supermarkets have no objection to selling brand name soft goods lines and in holding the price on those brands. This conclusion developed yesterday at an all-day panel discussion sponsored by McCall's magazine, in the Waldorf-Astoria. The supermarkets insist, however, that the items be those that are right for their purpose.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 3 (AP) -- Manager Eddie Stanky of the Cardinals, in solid with the owner even though his clubhas faltered in the pennant race, today was given a contract extension running through 1956.

SEATTLE, Aug. 3 (AP) -- Tod Morgan, Seattle boxer who held the world junior lightweight title from 1925 to 1929, died today after a long illness at the age of 50. His real name was Albert Pilkington. He was born at Sequim, Wash.

It is of interest to the general public -- not alone to the medical profession -- that the National Fund for Medical Education has announced grants totaling $1,944,151 to enable seventy-nine medical schools throughout the country to help meet the constantly rising demand for more doctors.

THE old man with the leathery face said you couldn't catch bass in the middle of the day. It was too hot and they went for the deep, cool water. Besides, anybody should know that the best time was in the early morning, or during the short twilight hours.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Aug. 3 -- More than 200 golfers teed off today in the opening day of the twentieth annual World-Telegram and Sun hole-in-one tournament, and a 16-inch shot by John Norton of Yonkers led the field.

Delegates to the sixty-eighth convention and trade show of the National Association of Retail Meat and Food Dealers at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday received enthusiastically demands that all Government controls of food production and distribution be removed.

Failing in only one of twelve matches, the Long Island tennis team defeated Westchester and Metropolitan New York squads in the junior Davis Cup competition yesterday at the West Side Club, Forest Hills, Queens.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 3 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold told the members of the United Nations that they were too slow in translating some of the basic purposes and principles of the organization into political reality.

ATHENS, Aug. 3 -- Nicholas Ploumbides, who had been on trial before the Permanent Military Court for high treason and espionage for more than a week, was sentenced to death today on two separate charges of supplying a foreign power with military, political and economic information over an illegal radio transmitter.

With windowbox air-conditioners becoming almost as common in homes as radios and television sets, and with an increasing interest shown by the public toward air-cooling and refrigerating units of all kinds and sizes, it is appropriate that the city should consider legislation governing the installation of such equipment.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- A draft of a message President Eisenhower had planned to send to Congress proposing revisions in the Taft-Hartley Law was weighted heavily with concessions to labor.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Aug. 3 -- Southern Africa, from Johannesburg to the Belgian Congo, and in particular this new-born Federation of Central Africa, is concentrating with increasing apprehension on the trend of events in the Wall Street district of New York.

CHICAGO, Aug. 3 -- The Standard Oil Company of Indiana today reported sales and operating revenues in the six months ended on June 30 had reached a new high for any six months in company history. They were $834,823,956, compared with $766,718,420 a year earlier.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (UP) -- Ferris Fain, Chicago White Sox first baseman, was named in a $50,000 damage suit today as the result of a fist fight reported to have occurred last night when someone tried to cut in on his dancing partner.

The 1954 military appropriations bill, passed by Congress last week, provides $34,371,541,000 for the armed forces, some $6,000,000,000 less than President Truman had requested and $1,500,000,000 less than President Eisenhower had asked.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- Marriner S. Eccles, for seventeen years a member of the Federal Reserve Board, in an analysis made public here today, declared the major monetary and credit policies of the Eisenhower Administration to date had been unjustified, too extreme, and unrealistic.

A group of educators, headed by John D. Rockefeller 3d, has formed a non-profit corporation, to be known as The Population Council, Inc., to encourage research and education concerning the relationship of the world's population to its material and cultural resources, it was announced yesterday by the board of trustees.

City-owned subway, elevated and surface transit lines showed a loss of 10.4 per cent in riders in the first week of the 15-cent fare as compared with the same week a year ago, when the fare was 10 cents, the New York City Transit Authority reported yesterday.

BOSTON, Aug. 3 (UP) -- Tony De Marco, a free-swinging lightweight from Boston, gained a technical knockout over Terry Young of New York in the fifth round of a scheduled ten-rounder at Mechanics Building tonight. De Marco weighed 140 1/3 and Young 139 3/4.

Five hundred Air Force reservists of the 8709th Pilot Training Wing have just moved into Floyd Bennett Field, Brooklyn, for a two-week annual refresher course in military flying, teaching cadets to fly and repairing planes.
York exchanges closed generally lower yesterday.
An automatic garage that provides a system of mechanical parking for cars instead of turning them over to strange hands for gear-straining storage will be put up here soon.

The extraordinary news from Berlin these past few days testifies eloquently that the men in the Kremlin have made another in their series of miscalculations regarding German policy. When Soviet troops put down East German resistance after last June 17, Moscow apparently thought that this display of force, together with the concessions announced by the Grotewohl regime, would be adequate to pacify, or at least to cow, German anti-Communist sentiment.

The municipal Department of Housing and Buildings has bought four electronic letter-writers which, it hopes, will keep up with the flood of tenant complaints that have developed since the 15 per cent rent increases permitted by the Legislature went into effect May 1.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (UP) -- The Senate completed Congressional action tonight on the final money bill of the session -- a supplemental bill authorizing a $200,000,000 start on President Eisenhower's South Korean reconstruction plan.
CINCINNATI, Aug. 3 -- Two simultaneous memorial services will be held for Senator Taft here in his home city at noon tomorrow.

MOSCOW, Aug. 3 -- Announcement has been made by the Georgia Council of Ministers of the appointment of Mikhail Aleksandrovich Zapevalin, a veteran internal affairs officer, as First Deputy Minister of Internal Affairs in Georgia.

The fact, reported here last week, that designers have come to the realization that the college girl possesses the same sound fashion sense as her career girl counterpart, was re-emphasized yesterday. College clothes, equally appropriate for the working girl, were presented at Abraham Straus and Arnold Constable to illustrate the highlights of the coming season.

For the eleventh successive year dividend payments on New York Stock Exchange stocks have established a new record, according to The Exchange, magazine published by the institution. The increase for for the first half of 1953 was reported at 4.2 per cent and the aggregate was $2,752,663,230.

So long as Congress is composed of ordinary mortals it will no doubt reflect the faults of ordinary mortals, including that of procrastination. The first session of the Eighty-third Congress, just ended, was no exception to the dismal rule. Trying to meet an arbitrarily established adjournment deadline, Congressmen found themselves snowed under during these past few days with decisions that warranted much more careful consideration than they received.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Aug. 3 -- Reports reaching here indicate a growing concern in Southeast Asian capitals over recent new declines in the value of exports from the area. Export prices have been slipping steadily for two years and the downward trend has been accentuated since the end of the Korean fighting.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- President Eisenhower, other civil and military leaders of the United States and men of the world's diplomacy mourned Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio today in a national memorial service in the rotunda of the Capitol.
MOUNT HOLLY, N. J., Aug. 3 -- A state trooper was killed today when a tractor-trailer hit him as he was checking a car on the New Jersey Turnpike six miles south of here.

UNION CITY, N. J., Aug. 3 -- Two youths, one of whom was driving an automobile while he had one arm around a girl, faced a series of charges in Municipal Court here Wednesday because they fled early today when a patrolman attempted to caution the operator of the car about one-arm driving.

MUNSAN, Korea, Tuesday, Aug. 4 (AP) -- Within minutes after the first Allied prisoners of war since the truce was signed are returned to United Nations hands at 9 A. M. tomorrow [8 P. M. Tuesday, Eastern daylight time], their names will be flashed around the world.

A portion of the Veterans of Foreign Wars convention parade in Milwaukee will be televised from 4:30 to 5 o'clock this afternoon over Channel 4. James W. Cothran, national commander, and Mayor Frank O. Zeidler of Milwaukee will speak briefly during the program.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (AP) -- Senator A. Willis Robertson, Democrat of Virginia, called on the nation's business men today to "liberally endow" United States medical schools for cancer research.

PARIS, Aug. 3 -- Walter Reuther, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, criticized French employers and Government today as being unwilling to give French workers a greater share of industrial profits than they now got.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- Tracy S. Voorhees, New York attorney and former Under Secretary of the Army, was named today a special representative in Europe for the Department of Defense.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Aug. 3 -- A land transfer that will result in Westchester's receiving from the State Thruway Authority a $1,500,000 improvement for the Cross County Parkway in Yonkers was approved this afternoon by the County Board of Supervisors. The vote was 34 to 4, some Yonkers Supervisors protesting that the plan was a "surprise" and "inadequate."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (AP) -- President Eisenhower thanked the House of Representatives tonight for its "constructive and worthwhile" record. In a letter to Speaker Joseph W. Martin Jr., read in the House, similar to one sent to Vice President Richard M. Nixon and read to the Senate the President said:

In recent months there has rightly been increased public concern About many appalling housing conditions in the city, stressing the need for better enforcement of our housing laws. In this connection there appeared some days ago a small news item which many people may have missed.
The Citizens Union announced yesterday its opposition to the proposed amendment to the State Constitution providing for the election of the Governor and Lieutenant Governor by a single vote.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (UP) -- Congress completed action tonight on a bill to plug a tax loophole that permitted movie actors and others with large incomes to escape United States income taxes through extended residence abroad.
MALMO, Sweden, Aug. 3 (AP) -- Americans won six of nine events in a track and field festival tonight, but left the crowd of almost 5,000 disappointed because Mal Whitfield didn't show up.

Wherever movements for personal dictatorships develop they usually aim for control through the military and through the workers' organizations. Whatever the actual situation may be in Brazil, the report of a plan for a possible coup published by responsible, conservative newspapers in Rio de Janeiro cannot be ignored.

A new electronic device about the size of a match head opens the way to operating telephone systems and computers with a speed 1,000 times faster than that of mechanical switches now in use, it is reported by the Bell Telephone Laboratories, which has developed the apparatus.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (UP) -- Senator Margaret Chase Smith, Republican, of Maine, tonight blocked permission for Senator Joseph R. McCarthy's Permanent Senate Subcommittee on Investigations to file reports while Congress was gone, unless the reports were approved by a majority of the Government Operations Committee, the parent group.

WOODBRIDGE, N. J., Aug. 3 -- Conditions were quiet in the New Jersey State Prison Farm here today after an hour-long noisy demonstration last night against the institution's superintendent, R. William Lagay, and the State Parole Board. The prisoners hammered on cell doors, shouted and whistled.

Steel operations slipped back slightly last week but are expected to rebound sharply this week. The industry's rate last week was 92.6 per cent, down 1.8 points from the preceding week, and production was 2,087,000 tons, a drop of 41,000 tons from the week before, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

College clothes follow this year's fashion trend toward simplicity and straight lines. The styles often are adapted from big or small brother's garb, but accessories soften the boyish lines and add feminine touches.

TEHERAN, Iran, Aug. 3 -- Premier Mohammed Mossadegh won about 99.9 per cent of the votes cast today in the first phase of a plebiscite to express the "will of the people" as authority for dissolution of the Majlis (Parliament). The proportions of the victory surprised few.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Aug. 3 -- The contract bridge team of Mrs. Ann Burnstein and Harry Harkavy of Miami Beach, with Mrs. Edith Kemp of New York and Alvin Roth of Washington, D. C., today continued to lead a field of eighty-three teams in the 1953 mixed team-of-four championship.

The regional Red Cross blood program began work yesterday toward meeting its August quota of 15,000 pints. Despite the truce in Korea, the local quota for this month is the same as that for August of 1952.
CHICAGO, Aug. 3 (AP) -- Lloyd Mangrum pocketed the All-American golf crown today with a last round of 67. His 72-hole total of 275 was thirteen strokes under par for the 6,915-yard layout.

PARIS, Aug. 3 -- United States dollar aid to France last year was several times greater than France's deficit in payments to the dollar currency area, according to figures on the balance of payments with foreign countries issued here today.

HONG KONG, Aug. 3 -- Communist China's supervisory agencies have been authorized to appoint "people's supervisory correspondents" in government organs, civic bodies and neighborhood associations to check on "all delinquencies, violations on law and trespassing on the rights of the people or the state."

PARIS, Aug. 3 (AP) -- A French pilot brought his disabled Air France Constellation down on a beach in southwest Turkey today, saving the lives of thirty-eight of the forty-two persons aboard, including those of an American mother and her child.

Two school teachers who exchanged jobs for the last year -- one from Moultrie, Ga., the other from a London suburb -- met for the first time yesterday and after comparing experiences agreed that it was just too bad they could not be in two places at the same time. Each said that she liked the other's job almost as much as her own.

In the July 20 issue of THE NEW YORK TIMES there was a letter by Ferenc Nagy, former Hungarian Premier, on the recent political shift in Communist-dominated Hungary. It is understandable that Mr. Nagy, distinguished leader of the Hungarian peasant movement, limited himself to analyzing the anti-Communist peasant opposition.
MOSCOW, Tuesday, Aug. 4 -- The Supreme Soviet, the highest legislative body in the Soviet Union, will meet tomorrow in the Great Hall of the Kremlin, it was announced today.

Operating revenues of the Transcontinental Gas Pipe Line Corporation reached $55,849,096 and net income was $6,917,105 or $1.56 a share in the twelve months to June 30, Tom P. Walker, president, reported yesterday.
TOKYO, Aug. 3 -- Secretary of State John Foster Dulles will stop in Tokyo later in the week en route home from Korea and he is not likely to like what he finds here.

Mass production at volume prices is scheduled for the world's smallest rate gyroscope, a device used in guided missiles, fire control systems, aircraft instruments, radar antenna stabilization and a host of other applications.

LENOX, Mass., Aug, 3 -- The institution of Tanglewood is like a medal. The professional side, which consists of the Berkshire Festival, was turned to a vast public over the week-end. Tonight the other side, the work of the students of the Berkshire Music Center, was shown to the 1,200 "friends" of the center who filled the theatre-concert hall.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (AP) -- The Senate confirmed today the nomination of Theodore C. Streibert of New York, former chairman of the board of the Mutual Broadcasting System, to be director of the new United States Information Agency.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (UP) -- Republicans and Democrats bestowed glowing praise on their own and each other's floor leaders tonight as the Senate wound up its session in a blaze of oratory.

THERE was once a tribe of hunters and fishers and warriors who lived in the dim long ago. They did not know how to read or write, but they loved to listen to stories and they greatly honored those who told the best ones. To be a storyteller was a fine thing. It meant the choicest marrow bones and the best place by the fire. But there were certain risks.

BIDDEFORD, Me., Aug. 3 -- Craig Colgate, a retired Wall Street broker who led 100,000 canvassers in a huge Liberty Loan campaign during World War I, died today in Webber Hospital after a long illness. His age was 78.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 3 (AP) -- The Cardinals, successful with an early inning attack, stopped a ninth-inning drive to gain an 8-3 decision over the Phillies tonight. Vinegar Bend Mizell went into the ninth with only three hits against him but Connie Ryan spoiled his shut-out with a two-run pinch-hit home run.

A chromium and nickel-plated steel food grater comes to this country from Switzerland. It is a simple sturdy device easy to use, does no damage to a manicure and gives a fluffy, dry product. It was designed by a physician at the Bircher-Benner Sanitarium at Zurich for the shredding of raw vegetables for patients on special diets.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 3 -- Unless prompt attention is given to programs designed to counteract conditions arising from simultaneous increases in unemployment and in population Asia is in danger of wasting its "most precious resources" -- its youth, the International Labor Organization said today.
KINGSTON, N. Y., Aug. 3 (UP) -- Supreme Court Justice Harry E. Schirick issued an injunction today restraining picketing of one of the Catskill Mountains' largest resort hotels.

WASHINGTON, Tuesday, Aug. 4 -- The first session of the Eighty-third Congress came to a close at 12:39 A. M. today as the Senate quit for the year a full hour and thirty-two minutes after the House of Representatives.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- The Senate completed Congressional action today on the long-stalled bill for renewing the Reciprocal Trade Agreements Act and creating a special commission to study the country's entire foreign economic policy.

Doing business in outmoded, century-old Washington Street Market adds 35 to 50 cents more to the cost of a box of carrots or lettuce, 15 to 20 cents on a bushel of string beans and 35 to 40 cents on a case of eggs, the New York State Temporary Commission on Agriculture was told here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- The personnel of the new Grain Administration Committee, established to resolve the problem of rodent and weevil infestation of wheat for human food consumption, was announced today by the Department of Agriculture, and the Department of Health, Education and Welfare.

Joseph P. Ryan, indicted lifetime president of the International Longshoremen's Association, A. F. L., declared yesterday that he had no intention of resigning despite reports that there would be strong pressure for him to do so when the executive council of the American Federation of Labor meets next week in Chicago.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 3 -- Eight men, identified by the Federal Bureau of Investigation as Communist leaders in this area, were indicted by a Federal grand jury here today on charges of conspiracy to teach and advocate the overthrow the United States Government by force.
The Army Corps of Engineers is expected to begin soon the deepening of two congested parts of New York harbor with funds allocated by the Government last week.
Casey Stengel, who has an excellent memory, couldn't recall when he last enjoyed a more pleasant afternoon than that at the Stadium yesterday.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 3 -- Following is the text of Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold's introduction to the annual report to the United Nations General Assembly on the work of the organization, written July 15 and submitted today:

TOKYO, Tuesday, Aug. 4 -- The Neutral Nations Commission that will supervise behind the lines in the armistice in the Korean war has set Saturday for dispatch of its inspection teams to airfields and ports of entry north and south of the Thirty-eighth Parallel. The teams will seek to insure against a military build-up during the cease-fire.

CHICAGO, Aug. 3 -- Grain futures trading was moderately active here today, with irregular price swings. Corn reversed its decidedly strong trend of last Friday and at times was as much as 2 cents lower. Wheat started out on a fractionally higher basis but reacted from the early tops, the rust news from the Northwest being somewhat less alarming than it had been late last week.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (AP) -- Billy Pierce, surviving a ninth-inning threat, pitched a two-hitter tonight to give the White Sox a 1-0 victory over the Senators. Pierce fanned nine in winning his thirteenth game and took over the major league strikeout lead from the Phillies' Robin Roberts with 124.

TOKYO, Aug. 3 -- A Socialist-sponsored no-confidence motion against Foreign Minister Katsuo Okazaki, which probably would have toppled Japan's conservative Government, was defeated in the House of Representatives today by 193 to 133.

INCHON, Korea, Tuesday, Aug. 4 -- The Allied armed forces have everything ready to give a warm welcome to the 12,763 Allied prisoners of war, 3,313 of them Americans, who will be brought to Panmunjom and exchanged there for Communist prisoners of war.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (UP) -- Willard L. Beaulac of Rhode Island, a career official in the Foreign Service, was nominated by President Eisenhower today to be United states Ambassador Extraordinary and Plenipotentiary to Chile.

Pyromaniacs, persons who set fires without having rational motives for doing so, are probably the most difficult criminals to apprehend and bring to justice, Martin Scott, chief fire marshal of the City of New York, said yesterday.

RYE, N. Y., Aug. 3 -- Shirley Fry of Akron, Ohio, clinched the honors for the United States today with an early triumph over Mrs. Jean Quertier Rinkel as the Americans turned back England for the seventeenth straight time in the twenty-fifth series for the Wightman Cup.

A statement that Aloysius Cardinal Stepinac of Yugoslavia is suffering from an ailment that "can have fatal consequences" was issued yesterday at the Roosevelt Hotel over the names of two American doctors who told of interviewing and examining the prelate in Yugoslavia.

Sales in eleven New York and Brooklyn department stores in July averaged 4 per cent above those of July, 1952, according to a survey made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES. It was the second month in succession in which there had been a rise.

CAIRO, Aug. 3 -- An Egyptian spokesman announced early this morning at the end of a joint meeting between the Cabinet and the ruling Military Revolution Council that unless the British brought new proposals satisfactory to Egypt for a solution of the Suez Canal dispute to a meeting of the two sides tomorrow "no more meetings will take place."

MEXICO CITY, Aug. 3 -- The Guatemalan Government's squeeze on the three large United States corporations operating there has been tightened recently with a series of moves directed against the Electric Company of Guatemala, the country's main producer of power. Company officials said the moves represent a major effort to put the company in an untenable economic position.
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 3 (AP) -- The Cardinals today sold First Baseman Dick Sisler to Columbus (Ohio) of the American Association, where his brother, George Jr., serves as general manager.

DIYARBAKIR, Turkey, July 29 -- On the outskirts of this ancient crossroads town of southwestern Asia, United States Air Force instructors are helping Turkey forge the most powerful jet air force in the Middle East.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa -- (UP) -- Jack Kramer, United States professional tennis star, was refused a South African visa today by the same authorities who earlier barred his teammate, Francisco (Pancho) Segura.

A member of the choral group with "Porgy and Bess" will have an opportunity to appear here in a leading role when she goes on this evening at the Ziegfeld Theatre in the first of a series of assignments in the role of Bess.
TENANTS HARBOR, Me., Aug. 3 -- Joseph Santry's Pleione, a converted New York Fifty, found the light to moderate airs of today's run in the New York Yacht Club cruise just to her liking.
Stones from holy places in 100 countries will adorn the shrine to Our Lady of Fatima at the proposed Roman Catholic chapel at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 3 -- James Mason, now playing the dual role of the Black Knight and Sir Brack in "Prince Valiant" for Fox, will step into the shoes of a modern nobleman in Joseph L. Mankiewicz' first independent production, "The Barefoot Contessa."

LONDON, Aug. 3 -- Publication today of the preliminary agenda for the eighty-fifth annual meeting of the Trades Union Congress, which is to be held on the Isle of Man next month, made it apparent that the delegates were in for some lively battles.

HOLLYWOOD, Aug. 3 (UP) -- The Pacific Coast League president Clarence Rowland, today fined five Hollywood and Los Angeles players a total of $300 for fighting during the teams' hotly contested series.

GENEVA, Aug. 3 -- The Soviet Union and the Communist countries of Eastern Europe have "evinced no interest in, and far less sympathy with," the claims of the Jewish people for restitution of property and reparation for losses suffered while those countries were under the Nazis, the World Jewish Congress charged in a report published here today on the eve of the third plenary assembly of the organization.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Aug. 3 -- The Government will introduce tomorrow a native labor (Settlement of Disputes) bill.

Color and new materials dominated what was described as the most successful show yet held by the Luggage and Leather Goods Manufacturers of America, which got into full swing at the New Yorker Hotel yesterday.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 3 -- Greentree Stable, which enjoys great success nearly every year in this theatre of turf operations, sent out the winner of the seventy-ninth running of The Flash Stakes as the Saratoga Association opened its eighty-fifth race meet today.

Pneumatic drills beat a rat-rat-tat in East Fourteenth Street yesterday and engineers picked their way amid the underground crisscross of pipe as they sought to repair the jagged break in a thirty- six-inch water main that had flooded Union Square Sunday.

Robert Moses, City Construction Coordinator, said yesterday that New York could not provide free automobile parking space near the Battery for visitors because there were more serious traffic problems that pressed for solution.

The nine-month-old Armed Services Textile and Apparel Procurement Agency, which handles the clothing and equippage purchases for the armed services, will be terminated before the end of September, it was learned yesterday.

It is not good news that three kinds of cockroaches hitherto strangers to these shores have been found here. There are more than a thousand species of cockroaches and therefore perhaps the discovery -- announced the other day by the alert Smithsonian Institution -- of three of these in the United States, where they have not been in numbers before (and have no business being at all), suggests, at first glance, no cause for concern.

CHICAGO, Aug. 3 (AP) -- Buyer resistance continued in the hog market today. Supplies were not immoderate for a Monday, but clearance was not obtained until price cuts of 25 to 50 cents a hundred pounds were placed in effect.

CHICAGO, Aug. 3 -- A sound liberal education is the basis for good teaching, Samuel Cardinal Stritch, Archbishop of Chicago, told 750 Roman Catholic audio-visual educators at their second annual meeting today.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Aug. 3 -- Francis Cardinal Spellman, Roman Catholic Archbishop of New York, received the Bernard M. Baruch Distinguished Service Award, the highest of the Veterans of Foreign Wars, at a dinner tonight on the opening day of the V. F. W.'s fifty-fourth annual encampment.

GREAT RIVER, L. I., Aug. 3 -- Variable winds played tricks with the sails today as the Great South Bay Yacht Racing Association's annual race week got under way. With the wind not compromising enough, there were two postponements and the course for the bigger boats was cut in half. It was wise judgment on the part of the committee considering the elements.

TOKYO, Aug. 3 (UP) -- United States Army Reserve commissioned and warrant officers in certain categories will be released from active duty as a result of the Korean armistice, the Army announced today.

A hidden assumption underlies Rev. Daniel A. Poling's insistence in THE NEW YORK TIMES of July 29 that clergymen should "purge" themselves of former connections with Communist-sponsored petitions or programs.
