The assumption is that a citizen should not associate himself with efforts aimed at justice or social betterment unless he can approve not only of the specific action contemplated but also of the persons who sponsor the action.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (AP) -- Senator Leverett Saltonstall, Republican of Massachusetts, said today that Secretary of Defense Wilson had decided to withdraw an informal request for the appointment of Col. W. F. Rockwell of Pittsburgh as an Assistant Secretary of Defense.

GENEVA, Switzerland, Aug. 3 (AP) -- Britain turned out crude steel at the record-breaking annual rate of 18,500,000 tons during most of the second quarter of 1953, the Economic Commission for Europe reported today in its quarterly bulletin of steel statistics.

A plebiscite more fantastic and farcical than any ever held under Hitler or Stalin is now being staged in Iran by Premier Mossadegh in an effort to make himself unchallenged dictator of the country. Technically the question submitted to an ostensibly popular vote is whether Parliament shall be dissolved.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- Congress has compiled a record of modest achievement in its 1953 session and has left itself a heavy load of work for next year.

GLEN COVE, L. I., Aug. 3 -- Jean Laird of Modesto, Calif., unseeded, reached the third round as the Girls Eastern grass court tennis title tourney started today at the Nassau Country Club. Miss Laird eliminated fifth-seeded Mary Blair of Oyster Bay, L. I., the Eastern and New York State clay court titleholder, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 3, after each player had drawn a first-round bye.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (AP) -- The National Association of Manufacturers laid before Congress today a plea for a national sales tax as the first step on "a firm road to fiscal security."

Decatur, Ill., Sanitary District, sold $4,200,000 of bonds yesterday due from July 1, 1954 to 1972 to the First National Bank of Chicago and associates at a bid of 100.056 for 2 1/2's and 2 1/4's for a net interest cost of 2.471 per cent. The issue was reoffered at yields ranging from 1.65 per cent to 2.55 per cent.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 3 -- Through its acting Premier, Fethi Kekhia, the Government of Libya has transmitted to the United Nations Economic and Social Council for consideration, a detailed outline of projects included in the five-year development program now in prospect.

LAKE RONKONKOMA, L. I., Aug. 3 -- A moment after he had fatally wounded the woman whose affection he had long unsuccessfully sought, Julio G. Gomez, 52 years old, a waiter, of 30-26 Thirty-fifth Street, Astoria, Queens, was himself shot dead here at 2 A. M. today by an off-duty Brookhaven Town policeman, who had narrowly missed being a victim of one of Gomez' bullets, according to Brookhaven Town police.
TEHERAN, Iran, Aug. 4 (AP) -- Flash floods sweeping into a valley of the Elburz mountains wiped out the village of Vaz late last week and drowned about 265 persons, Teheran newspapers said today.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 4 -- In an atmosphere of mourning that hung over the entire city, his native Cincinnati paid her final respects to Senator Robert A. Taft today at two services, one private, the other public.

TOKYO, Wednesday, Aug. 5 -- Secretary of State John Foster Dulles drove to President Syngman Rhee's hillside residence in Seoul this morning for his first conference with the aging South Korean leader, designed to work out a common policy in the political conference expected to be held within three months to consider over-all peace problems regarding Korea.

VALDOSTA, Ga., Aug. 4 (AP) -- Monday's sales figures in the Georgia-Florida flue-cured tobacco belt strengthened earlier estimates that the auctions have a good chance of producing new records both in average price and in cash yield.

The nation's concern over the victims of the great Southwestern drought was well expressed by the action of Congress in voting $150,000,000 in emergency relief. Help had to be extended; and from New England to California Americans are determined that their fellow-Americans in the parched areas of this land shall receive that help.

MINEOLA, L. I., Aug. 4 -- Sixty-two bathing places in Nasau County now have permits issued by the Nassau County Department of Health, while five applications have been denied, according to the final official 1953 rating of bathing waters issued here today.

The Stanley Warner Corporation yesterday filed in Federal Court here a notice of motion for approval of an agreement under which it would produce Cinerama wide-screen films and operate theatres to show them.

SEATTLE, Aug. 4 -- Gov. Frank G. Clement, Tennessee Democrat, told President Eisenhower today that the people of the Tennessee Valley regarded the Administration's policy on the Tennessee Valley Authority as unsatisfactory and uninformed.
Elegance is the keynote of the custom-made bridal collection that was presented yesterday by Jay-Thorpe. It was designed by Josephine Oro.

SEATTLE, Aug. 4 -- President Eisenhower declared today that the situation in Asia was "very ominous for the United States," and warned the Kremlin that this Government was determined to block Communist conquest of Indo-China.

AMHERST, Mass., Aug. 4 -- A vocal segment of New England's farmers expressed strong opposition today to mandatory high price supports of the region's billion-dollar industry at a public hearing conducted by the House of Representatives Agriculture Committee at the University of Massachusetts.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 4 -- The 1953 mixed team of four contract bridge championship was won today by the defending titlists, Mrs. Ann Burnstein and Harry Harkavy of Miami Beach, with Mrs. Edith Kemp of New York and Alvin Roth of Washington.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- Senator William F. Knowland of California was chosen unanimously today by his party colleagues to be Republican floor leader of the Senate, succeeding the late Robert A. Taft of Ohio.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (AP) -- The Bureau of Mines reported today that the motor gasoline sold at service stations last winter had been the best in the history of the petroleum-refining industry from the standpoint of high anti-knock ratings.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- Americans for Democratic Action declared today that "the failure of the majority party in Congress to assess its electoral victory in terms of public responsibility rather than political expediency is the outstanding characteristic of the just concluded session."
The Hellenic Lines, Ltd., announced here yesterday the purchased of the British cargo ship Empire Patrai.

Your story on July 26 of McCarthy's plans to shift his inquiries from investigations of various Eisenhower appointees and other existing Government agencies to corruption in the Truman Administration is a report that should cause more than a little consternation among people who still hold out hope for integrity and honesty in our present Government in Washington.

HYDE PARK, N. Y., Aug. 4 -- One hundred young men and women, from all parts of this country and Hawaii, who are taking part in an unusual citizenship education program, received some pointers today from one of the nation's foremost citizens, Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt.

Aug. 10 has been set aside by the United States Merchant Marine Academy at Kings Point to celebrate ten years of successful operation. The academy came into being in 1943 when the need for merchant marine officers became so desperate that it was rightly felt that some federal academy should be set up to supply that need.

GENEVA, Aug. 4 -- The most pressing responsibility of Jews and Jewish organizations throughout the world is to help the state of Israel become firmly established, Dr. Nahum Goldmann, acting president of the World Jewish Congress, said today at the opening meeting of third plenary assembly of the congress.

SOME of the more burning issues of the day are pinpointed in a new discussion program conducted by Martin Agronsky over the A. B. C. television network on Sundays from 9 to 9:15 P. M. Entitled "At Issue," its contents have been absorbing and penetrating.
THE HAGUE, The Netherlands, Aug. 4 -- World mine production of tin during May was 14,900 long tons against 14,600 tons in April, the International Tin Study Group reported here today.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 4 (AP) -- Danny O'Connell's eighth-inning triple drove in two runs for the Pirates tonight as Pittsburgh scored a 2-1 victory over the Red-legs and ended Cincinnati's four-game winning streak.

The Temporary State Commission on the Courts announced yesterday that its inquiry would deal first with court calendar congestion and delays, the costs and expenses of litigation and appeals, the establishment of an administrative agency to free judges from routine administrative work and the procedure, rules of practice and general reorganization and unification of the courts.
Detectives were investigating yesterday the disappearance of jewelry valued at $32,500 from the home of Robert Armstrong at 875 Fifth Avenue.

MUNSAN, Korea, Aug. 4 (AP) -- As he steps across to freedom, every United Nations prisoner of war will get the news that Premier Stalin is dead and General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower has moved into the White House.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Aug. 4 (UP) -- South Africa's Interior Minister, Dr. T. E. Donges, said today that tennis professionals Jack Kramer and Pancho Segura had been refused visas because of currency regulations and not racial discrimination.

The Sinclair Oil Corporation and its subsidiaries had a record gross operating income of $448,685,921 in the first six months this year, an increase of $33,053,990 over the initial half of 1952. Sales also expanded by more than 11 per cent. Net income, however, was reduced by higher costs arising principally from crude oil producing activities and larger taxes.
LONDON, Aug. 4 -- The actual process of restoring the nationalized British iron and steel industry to private ownership has begun -- in a small way.

More aggressive promotion by retailers to capitalize on record back-to-school sales potentials was urged yesterday by Edward H. Burgeson, director of the retail department, Bureau of Advertising, American Newspaper Publishers Association.

READING, Pa., Aug. 4 -- The pilots of the 107th Fighter Interceptor Wing of the New York Air National Guard anxiously marked time today as bad weather interrupted their quest of a record number of hours flown during a summer encampment.
SEATTLE, Aug. 4 (AP) -- Following is the text of President Eisenhower's address at the forty-fifth annual Governors' Conference:

CHICAGO, Aug. 4 -- A combination of the Cubs and krilium beat the Giants, 5 -- 3, today at Wrigley Field. The Cubs, who need no identification, did all the playing behind Bob Rush, Krilium made it possible. Before anyone ask "Who is krilium?" it is pertinent to note that the "who" is a "what."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, chairman of the Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations, accused Allen W. Dulles, director of the Central Intelligence Agency, today of doing "tremendous damage" to the top-secret national security organization he heads by "covering up" information concerning one of its high-level aides.
Charles H. Commons Jr. has been appointed head of the ceramic division of the research and development department of Foote Mineral Company, Philadelphia.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 4 -- The Saratoga Association ran its first nine-race program today. In addition to the usual eight events with the mutuel windows open, there was one -- the two-horse Wilson Stakes -- on which there was no betting.

BIG SPRING, Tex., Aug. 4 -More than half the cattle in six counties surrounding this trading center have been moved to early slaughter or better range lands to the north and west. Federal estimates place the number of cattle transported at 65 to 85 per cent of the normal animal population.

A New York investor has purchased the seventeen-story and penthouse apartment building at 50 Park Avenue, northwest corner of Thirty-seventh Street, from the Cowan interests, who erected the house in 1940.

PANMUNJOM, Korea, Wednesday, Aug. 5 -- The great Korean war prisoner exchange began today with a note of chill foreboding. The first American officer released reported that the Communists only two days ago sentenced some United States officers to long prison terms for "instigating against peace."
A taxpayer building with five stores at the northeast corner of Jericho Turnpike and White Road in Mineola, L. I., has been sold by Louis Heller and Joseph Schneider, builders, to an investor.

With only 168 pints of blood donated Monday at the Manhattan and Brooklyn centers, officials of the regional Red Cross blood program were apprehensive that the August quota of 15,000 pints might not be met. Monday's contributions were among the lowest of the summer.
BOSTON, Aug. 4 -- An "armchair" iron lung that enables polio patients to sit up and look the world in the eye is being tested at a unit of the Children's Medical Center.

Father Knickerbocker found himself yesterday up against the knotty problem of establishing a fair assessment principle for certain types of cooperative apartment houses. A flood of protests from owners constituting solid occupancy of one type of cooperative indicated that a satisfactory formula had not been found.

The Association of the Bar of the City of New York issued a statement yesterday declaring that judges who are candidates for non-judicial offices in the coming primaries are in violation of the canons of judicial ethics of the association.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- A Senate Monopoly subcommittee said today that the motion-picture exhibitor was operating in a "sick" industry, and proposed some remedies.
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 4 (UP) -- Robin Roberts of the Phillies pulled to within a victory of the charmed 20-game circle tonight, winning a five-hitter, 8 -- 1, from the Cardinals.

MEXICO CITY, Aug. 4 -- The final authority in Guatemala, as in most Latin-American countries, is the Army. The overwhelming weight of available evidence is that the Army remains completely loyal to President Jacobo Arbenz Guzman and apathetic to Communist overtures.

A burglary suspect was shot and wounded fatally in Brooklyn yesterday afternoon by a young man who saw him enter a neighbor's apartment through a second-story window. The police said no charge would be made against the man who fired the shot.

BULAWAYO, Southern Rhodesia, Aug. 4 --The biggest theatrical airlift in the history of the stage -- the transporting of the Covent Garden Opera to this city in the heart of Africa -- appears to be the artistic highlight of the Rhodes Centennial Central African Exhibition here.

BONN, Germany, Aug. 4 -- Preliminary skirmishes in the general election campaign have made it clear that three parties constituting the Government coalition are relying entirely on the great prestige and indefatigability of 77-year-old Chancellor Konrad Adenauer to win for them Sept. 6.

Hein Ten Hoff of Hamburg, Germany, scored a technical knockout over Big Bill Wilson of Charlotte, N. C., in 2:58 of the first round of a scheduled ten-round heavyweight fight before 2,930 fans at Ridgewood Grove, Brooklyn, last night.

MOSCOW, Aug. 4 -- M. Chkhikvadze, third secretary of the Communist party of Georgia, has sharply attacked Lavrenti P. Beria's booklet on the "History of the Bolshevik Organizations in the Trancaucasus." He described the booklet as "anti-Marxist" and the source of "profound harm" in ideological work and particularly in the development of historical science in Georgia.

The two-story air-conditioned office building on lot 48 by 130 feet at 238 to 288 Broadway, in the Williamsburg Bridge Plaza section of Brooklyn, has been sold by the Consolidated Edison Company to a client of Walter Scott Co., brokers.

A 10-year-old boy from Des Moines, Iowa, whose throat muscles have been paralyzed since he had bulbar poliomyelitis a year ago, arrived in New York yesterday to see if doctors could help him to swallow again.

Not so long ago Edna Ferber spoke about the untidy condition of the parks, streets and sidewalks of New York. A trip about New York will convince any impartial citizen who likes the Big Town that the streets and sidewalks are still far too dirty and that in certain sections they are downright filthy.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- The heads of six Arab diplomatic missions here presented a statement today to Walter Bedell Smith, the Acting Secretary of State, denouncing Israel's transfer of its Government from Tel Aviv to Jerusalem.

GENEVA, Aug. 4 -- Of two laws passed by the United States Eighty-third Congress in the closing days of its first session that affect American trade, that on customs simplification is regarded by European business men and government officials as very much the more important and more encouraging. The other is the renewal of the Reciprocal Trade Act.
MOSCOW, Wednesday, Aug. 5 (AP) -- Following is the text of the Soviet note to the United States, Britain and France on the calling of a Big Four foreign ministers conference:
NEWARK, Aug. 4 -- Raymond DelTufo Jr., a member of the Newark Charter Commission, was named first assistant United States Attorney for New Jersey today by United States Attorney William R. Tompkins.

Russeks thinks of the college girl as a person of highly individual taste. For its showing yesterday the store combed the market for designs which, though expressing the season's leading trends, did so with fresh flair.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- Point Four technical assistance funds totaling $118,243,500 were provided in the $6,500,000,000 mutual security appropriation bill sent to the White House from the Senate last night. President Eisenhower had requested $140,234,500 in new money and reappropriations.

Trading was slow in almost all commodities on the New York exchanges yesterday and prices were generally lower. Tin, copper, rubber, cottonseed oil and soybean oil were off; sugar, coffee and zinc mixed, and potatoes, hides, lead and cocoa higher.

Harold Riegelman announced yesterday his resignation as Acting Postmaster of New York and said he would decide finally by tomorrow afternoon whether he would accept the Republican designation for Mayor, which has been offered to him by the five Republican county leaders.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 4 -- The Philadelphia Orchestra is planning to seek state unemployment compensation coverage for its 104 musicians, it was disclosed today.

PANMUNJOM, Korea, Wednesday, Aug. 5 -- The international character of the army that fought in defense of South Korea showed clearly in the first contingent that came home to freedom today from Communist prison camps.

MOSCOW, Wednesday, Aug. 5 -- The Soviet Union accepted today the Western Big Three proposal for a four-power foreign ministers meeting on the German question but coupled the acceptance with a strong plea for a discussion of measures to lessen the international tensions and for a seat for Communist China at a great power conference table.

A 19-year-old unemployed laborer was arrested last night and charged with the first-degree murder of Michael J. (Barney) Prendergast, New York tavern owner found slain last Wednesday in Fort Washington Park.

The American people will eat 24,000,000,000 pounds of meat and meat products this year, H. K. Davison, executive secretary of the American Meat Institute, told the convention of the National Association of Retail Meat and Food Dealers at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday.

LONDON, Aug. 4 (Reuters) -- A stand of 125 by Glamorgan's captain, Wilf Wooller, and Len Muncer saved the Welsh County from almost certain defeat by the touring Australian cricketers today and Glamorgan emerged with a draw.

A former credit manager for a commercial loan company was charged yesterday, in Special Sessions Court with having solicited and accepted $20,000 in bribes from dealers in television sets and electrical appliances.

Supreme Court Justice Samuel M. Gold reserved decision yesterday on a motion brought by Robert Payson Hill, concert pianist, to vacate a subpoena issued by William Lyman, President Justice of the Municipal Court, after Mr. Hill, in a letter printed June 30 in THE NEW YORK TIMES, criticized the court and one of its justices.

William Esslinger in his recent letter to THE NEW YORK TIMES puts forward his opinion that it would be wrong and dangerous to undertake now an all-out psychological offensive against the Soviet domination of the satellite states in Central and Eastern Europe. He holds out as the only hope for an opportunity to work peacefully for the liberation of the enslaved peoples a possible future revision of the United Nations Charter.

Wagon wheels were a-turnin' yesterday, and bicycle, tricycle, scooter and roller skate wheels too, as the Children's Aid Society staged its fifteenth annual "Anything on Wheels" derby on East Sixth Street between Avenues B and C.

BOSTON, Aug. 4 (UP) -- Floyd Baker hit a pinch double to left center with the bases filled in the eighth inning to enable the Red Sox to defeat the Browns, 6 -- 2, and snap an eight-game losing streak before a Ladies' Night crowd of 19,003 at Fenway Park.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- Representative Charles A. Halleck, Republican leader of the House of Representatives, singled out the Korean truce today as the major accomplishment of the first session of the Eighty-third Congress.

The passing of Senator Taft has caused comment on the fact that many of our Vice Presidents who have succeeded to the Presidency on the death of the President have not been of the mature caliber that we would have elected President.

LONDON, Aug. 4 -- The stock market here opened cheerfully today after the three-day Bank Holiday. Fresh gains registered in most sections were attributable to yesterday's rally on Wall Street and news of a further increase in the country's gold and dollar reserves.

The fourth Queens sewer expose within a year broke yesterday when Borough President James A. Lundy announced he had condemned as faulty and as a health menace the major part of a three- year-old installation at Laurelton.

PACK UP your gears, fellows, and make tracks for Montauk; the blues are running! Stripers are begging for troll lines along the beaches in the cool of the evening. And the first giant tuna of the season has been boated there.
Harry J. Klinger, vice president and a director of the General Motors Corporation, has been appointed a director of the Grand Trunk Western Railroad.

Harris J. Klein of Brooklyn, a lawyer closely identified with the motor trucking industry, was appointed yesterday by Mayor Impellitteri as a member of the New York City Transit Authority. He made known immediately that he felt that the new 15-cent fare was "too much."

SUMMIT, N. J., Aug. 4 -- Mother Mary Imelda of Jesus, O. P., a founder of the Monastery of Our Lady of the Rosary Shrine here, celebrated today her golden jubilee as a Dominican cloistered nun at a pontifical mass in the monastery chapel.

MARRAKESH, French Morocco, Aug. 3 -- Hadj Thami el Mezouari el Glaoui, Pasha of Marrakesh, said in an interview at his palace here today that he would not rest until Sultan Sidi Mohammed Ben Houssef had been driven from the throne of Morocco.

James C. Petrillo, short and snappy president of the American Federation of Musicians, A. F. L., bounced down the gangplank of the liner United States yesterday and soon thereafter delivered in rapid-fire fashion a series of pronouncements on such diverse subjects as exchanging bands with Great Britain and the approaching crisis for the International Longshoremen's Association.
I was distressed to note in THE TIMES of Aug. 3 that the Transit Authority contemplates demolishing the Third Avenue El.

MONTREAL, Aug. 4 (Canadian Press) -- The English Electric Company, Ltd., of London has purchased control of the Canadian Marconi Company of Montreal, it was announced today. The announcement was made jointly by Sir George H. Nelson, chairman of English Electric; Maj. Gen. L. B. Nicholls, chairman of Cable and Wireless, Ltd., of London, and Stuart M. Finlayson, president of Canadian Marconi.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Aug. 4 -- Now is the time for this country and its Allies to develop an overall strategy for peace, Bernard M. Baruch told the national encampment of the Veterans of Foreign Wars today.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Aug. 4 -- The retirement of Laurence G. Tighe, Yale treasurer and former acting director of athletics, was announced today by Dr. A. Whitney Griswold, president of Yale University. The retirement, on the advice of physicians, will be effective Oct. 1.

The Eastern Municipal Water District of Riverside County, Calif., sold yesterday $4,300,000 of series B general obligation water bonds due from 1959 to 1981 to the Bank of America National Trust and Savings Association and associates at a bid of 100.29 for 5's and 4 1/2's for a net interest cost of 4.504 per cent.

Stock prices retreated in early trading yesterday for the first time in four days. But the selling did not gain momentum and bids firmed as the session wore on. As a result closing prices showed a plus sign for every minus sign.

GLEN COVE, L. I., Aug. 4 -- Pat Shaffer, a 15-year-old player from St. Petersburg, Fla., reached the quarter-finals of the girls' Eastern grass court tennis championships today by upsetting third-seeded Jacqueline Johannes of Dallas, 3 -- 6, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 2, in a third round test at Nassau Country Club.

Mayor Impellitteri converted his special citizens committee in the concrete truck drivers strike into a fact-finding group yesterday and ordered it to make recommendations for ending the month-long dispute.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 4 -- Word today from Washington that Congress before adjournment approved in its entirety the $9,814,000 requested for 1953 for the United Nations International Children's Fund spread cheer through the offices of the agency here.

PARIS, Aug. 4 -- International communism is now trying to convince the peoples of satellite Europe that the ideology that dictates to them is more concerned with butter than with guns and earnestly seeks to improve their living standards.
Twenty-one local housing authorities have borrowed $188,435,000 for temporary financing of Federal aided low-rent projects bearing the contractual backing of the Public Housing Administration.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (UP) -- The Joint Congressional Atomic Energy Committee closed today the case of Republican Robert L. Condon, Democrat of California, who was barred from a recent atomic weapon test in Nevada.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was somewhat irregular yesterday, and closing prices were 3 points lower to 18 points higher than on Monday.

DETROIT, Aug. 4 (AP) -- Former United States Senator Blair Moody, ex-Detroit newspaper man and Washington political writer, announced today that a syndicate headed by himself had signed a contract to lease a Detroit printing concern.

CHICAGO, Aug. 4 -- Wheat and corn again were weak, influencing other grains as well as soybeans. Oats futures showed relative strength as unfavorable reports were received from Iowa and other sections. But is was difficult to stir up buying activity in any pit.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (AP) -- Race segregation in public schools will be reargued before the Supreme Court starting next Dec. 7 instead of Oct. 12 as previously announced.

A large and important acquisition of nineteenth and twentieth century books, letters and documents from the library of Mrs. Olga Hirsch Guggenheim, widow of Simon Guggenheim, industrialist and one-time Senator from Colorado, was announced yesterday by the New York Public Library.

SHELTER ISLAND, L. I., Aug. 4 -- Nebula, a 28-foot ketch owned by J. T. Chatman, won the Rule Division in the corrected time of 0:59:50 as the American Yacht Club finished the third leg of its Block Island cruise today.

A baby biscuit of sound nutritional value is coming in for the first time from Holland, where Liga Fabrieken has been making it at Roosendaal for more than a quarter of a century. It is a fairly thick, medium firm cracker, something like our graham crackers in flavor, neither excessively bland nor excessively sweet.

CENTRE ISLAND, L. I., Aug. 4 -- Ted Sheldon's Coquette from the Riverside Yacht Club led with 40 points during the three qualifying races for the midget championship of the Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound in Oyster Bay Harbor off the Seawanhaka-Corinthian Yacht Club today.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 4 (AP) -- Virgil Trucks firebailed a fourhitter at the Athletics tonight as the White Sox came through with a six-run Splurge in the fourth inning to cushion the way for an 8-3 triumph.
HARRISBURG, Aug. 4 (AP) -- A report on surveys made on possible routes for a proposed extension of the Pennsylvania Turnpike through the anthracite regions may reach Gov. John S. Fine this month.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (AP) -- The Department of Defense has identified additional casualties in the Korean fighting which ceased July 27. The following names were listed for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut:

OCEANPORT, N. J., Aug. 4 (AP) -- Bertrando Brothers' Cobber, a 5-to-1 shot, showing sparkling speed in the stretch, scored a two-length victory over Kay-Gee Stable's Ardoch in the Silverdale Purse at Monmouth Park today.

There were times, in recent weeks, when the Administration's foreigntrade plans were floundering badly in Congress. But if the ship didn't come home with a full cargo, it was far from being in ballast, and it came in under its own steam.

Big Vic Raschi had a most important score to settle with the Tigers last night, and the right-hander squared accounts in most convincing fashion. Although he was removed for the purpose of rest after six innings, Vic set a major league runs-batted-in-record for a pitcher by driving across seven markers in the Yankees' 15-0 drubbing of Detroit at the Stadium.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- Dr. Milton S. Eisenhower said tonight that all of the South American republics were undergoing a "tremendous development" reminiscent of the industrial expansion in the United States in the Nineteenth Century.

Trustees for the Marine Aircraft Corporation, makers of "highly classified" aviation materials, were appointed yesterday by Federal Court Judge Edward J. Dimock at the company's request. The concern is seeking reorganization under the bankruptcy act.
With sales up more than 35 per cent, the Celanese Corporation of America lifted its net income in the first six months this year to $6,438,296 from $1,159,896 in the corresponding period last year.

WESTBURY, L. I., Aug. 4 -- J. S. Turner's Adios Boy, a bay colt by Adios, was driven to a new world record of 2:03 tonight in the second division of the Village Farm Stake No. 19 for a purse of $29,437.50 for 2-year-old Pacers by 23-year-old Howard Camden, at Roosevelt Raceway.

While easier repayment terms on a $300,000,000 Export-Import Bank loan will prolong "economic austerity" for Brazil, export and banking sources here were hopeful yesterday that the development would lead to better private investment prospects in that country. Moderate relaxation of the loan terms was announced last Friday in Washington by the bank.

LONDON, Aug. 5 -- The United States Air Force said about twenty-five American airmen abroad a huge RB-36 reconnaissance bomber were forced to leap from the blazing plane early today into the Atlantic Ocean, 500 miles west of England.
PARIS, Aug. 4 -- Amid the hue and cry of the great skirt length controversy, Gres, Madeleine de Rauch and Jacques Heim showed collections distinguished for line and fabric.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- Senator H. Alexander Smith, Republican of New Jersey, chairman of the Senate Labor Committee, said today that President Eisenhower's planned Message to Congress on Taft-Hartley law revisions was still in the "working paper" stage and he hoped it would cover many points that are not included now.
I should like to reply to Allen Gordon's communication published on July 27.
The price of copper was reduced 1/2 cent a pound yesterday to 28 1/2 cents by the same large smelter which had trimmed the price 3/4 cent last Thursday.

Dock workers of the International Longshoremen's Association struck the Moore-McCormack Lines passenger vessel Argentina yesterday in a dispute over hiring. Two hundred thirty-five passengers were forced to help handle their own luggage.

BERLIN, Aug. 4 -- Crowds estimated by the West Berlin police to total 5,000 sought today to disrupt the program of food gifts to East Germans at two West Berlin distribution centers. It appeared to be the Communists' first attempt to disrupt the plan by direct action.

The current one-year extension of the European Payments Union is not likely to face any serious difficulties since the organization's reserves are stronger now than a year ago and may even continue to rise moderately.
BOSTON, Aug. 4 -- The Massachusetts Turnpike Authority an nounced today the route of the proposed $200,000,000 toll highway from West Stockbridge, Mass., to the outskirts of Boston.

DARK HARBOR, Me., Aug. 4 -- Finn MacCumhaill, a twenty-nine-foot water line Class C cutter owned by Robert Coulson of Marblehead, Mass., played a David and Goliath role today through an outstanding performance on the New York Yacht Club cruise.

The Solar Aircraft Company announced it has put into operation at San Diego, Calif., what is believed to be the nation's first conveyorized, mass-production facility for applying high-temperature ceramic coatings to alloy steel components.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- More than 25,000 uniformed military personnel and civilian employes of the Pentagon were requested today to keep their mouths shut while eating.

When speaking of Moroccan nationalism it would be well to make a distinction between it and the Istiqlal party, which El Mehdi ben Aboud, whose letter you recently printed, represents in the United States.

TRANSIT Authority engineers and anthropologists have done a lot of figuring in an attempt to make subway strap-hanging tolerable for the town's short folk, but in spite of their best, complaints keep coming in.

PARIS, Aug. 4 -- On the eve of a Cabinet meeting to be held tomorrow at President Vincent Auriol's summer residence at Rambouillet, thirty-five miles southwest of Paris, the French Administration was more optimistic on the possibilities of an early opening of negotiations with the Associated States of Indo-China.

SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., Aug. 4 -- The feat of Pablo Eisenberg in taking a set from Kenneth Rosewall of Australia and Allen Morris' strong challenge to Hamilton Richardson marked the play in the Eastern grass court championships at the Orange Lawn Tennis Club today as all but one of the favored group survived their second round matches.

ZURICH, Switzerland, Aug. 4 -The possibility that man-made extra-terrestrial missiles or "space ships" eventually might travel at enormous velocities approaching that of light by the employment of photons or light particles as a propellant was put forward at the first technical meeting of the International Astronautical Federation here today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (AP) -- Patricia Ann Vincent, 16 years old, of Norfolk, Va., and Dorothy Eleanor Johnson, 17, of Newton-ville, Mass., tonight were elected president and vice president of Girls' Nation.

The first New York soldier released at Panmunjom in the prisoner of war exchange is facing a sad postscript to his long imprisonment; both his mother and father have died since his capture more than two years ago and the news has been kept from him.

Complaints that parking charges in the area under the West Side Highway had been increased from $1 to $1.50 for all-day parking and differed from the amended schedules on file at the License Department were heard yesterday by Acting Commissioner Thomas M. O'Neill. The decision was reserved.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- Representative Albert Rains, Democrat of Alabama, demanded a Congressional investigation starting next January of "a plan to wreck" the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation. The plan is headed by large New York banks, he charged in a statement in The Congressional Record today.

Merger of two of the city's oldest paper merchants, the Lathrop Paper Company, Inc., and the Vandewater Paper Company, into the Lathrop Vandewater Paper Company, a division of Chesapeake Industries, Inc., was announced jointly yesterday by Edward D. O'Brien, president of Vandewater, and Thomas Lathrop, president of Lathrop.

When a dime operated a subway turnstile most passengers used forethought and saw that they had dimes available without going to a change booth. Now, with a 15-cent token necessary, most passengers have to visit a booth, and the result is queues. This will continue unless a way can be found to encourage spread of the tokens to business counters everywhere.

Two new films will open at first-run theatres this morning. "From Here to Eternity," Columbia's adaptation of the James Jones novel of Army life, with Burt Lancaster, Montgomery Clift, Frank Sinatra, Deborah Kerr and Donna Reed in the principal roles, is at the Capitol.

Those big electronic computers that are able to solve such problems as what goes on inside an atom are limited only by their ability to remember the details of each partial answer en route to the $64 one.

The Atlas Corporation one of the country's largest closed-end investment trusts dealing in "special situations," had a net asset value on June 30 of $38.04 a common share, Floyd B. Odlum, president, reported yesterday in the company's midyear letter to stockholders. This compared with $38.67 a share on June 30, 1952.

The armistice that ended the fighting and the dying in Korea was concluded ten days ago, but for 12,763 United Nations soldiers, including 3,313 Americans, the war did not really begin to come to an end till 8 o'clock last night New York time. At that hour, which was 9 A. M.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (UP) -- Mike Garcia pitched a five-hitter to score his thirteenth victory of the season tonight as the Indians beat the Senators, 3 -- 0, for their sixth consecutive triumph.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- A State Department spokesman said today that Secretary of State John Foster Dulles "neither said nor implied that troops would be used in any sense as 'labor battalions' in Korea."

WHY do some folks -- and you'd be surprised to know how many there are -- insist on likening Leo Durocher to the late John J. McGraw when, in a major conception of how a pennant campaign should be conducted, Leo the Lip differs so vastly in his methods from those employed by his illustrious predecessor as manager of the Giants?

TEHERAN, Iran, Aug. 4 -- Premier Mohammed Mossadegh said in a nation-wide broadcast tonight that the results of yesterday's plebiscite favoring the dissolution of the Majlis (lower and sole existing house of Parliament) had strengthened Iranian democracy and would insure future Majlis that embodied the people's aspirations.

Strong pleas for rebuilding the congested old Washington Street Market in its present area were voiced here yesterday by the West Side Association of Commerce and the Commerce and Industry Association.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Aug. 4 -- Republican leaders in the Ohio Legislature have decided against attempting to change state election laws that would take away the right of Democratic Gov. Frank J. Lausche to appoint a successor to Senator Robert A. Taft until Dec. 15, 1954.
A recent trip to Mexico carried me through several states. In every city that I visited I was greatly impressed by the courtesy and kindliness extended to me as a young woman traveling alone.

With the issuance today of the midyear edition of "Investment Facts About Common Stocks and Cash Dividends," distribution of that booklet will top the 3,300,000 mark. The booklet, published by members and member firms of the New York Stock Exchange, is the twelfth edition. The first made its appearance in October, 1949.
LONDON, Aug. 4 -- The question, "What is happiness for a hen?" is becoming a major public issue in Britain.
FORT DEVENS, Mass., Aug. 4 -- One of three charges against Lieut Sheppard C. Thierman was dropped today at the Army doctor's general court martial.

JERSEY CITY, Aug. 4 -- Dr. Benjamin Potter, medical director of the Dr. Berthold Pollak Hospital for Chest Diseases, a Hudson County institution, has been dismissed, the hospital's Board of Managers announced today. The board said the action was the result of an investigation of the "cleavage" between him and Thomas Finn, civilian superintendent of the hospital.
The need to build international goodwill by individual-to-individual aid to the people of Korea was stressed yesterday by Dr. Richard P. Saunders, president of the Save the Children Foundation.

Perry Miller, Professor of American Literature at Harvard University, who is author of three books about colonial New England, has two works on publishers' lists for issue soon. On Aug. 21, Harvard University Press will bring out his "The New England Mind from Colony to Province," an analysis of the first century of the Puritan "adventure" showing the impact of their American experience on the theory of the universe the colonists brought with them.
Please accept my sincere congratulations on the appraisal by your excellent correspondent in Washington, Arthur Krock, of the late Senator Robert A. Taft in your issue of Aug. 2.

DEAL, N. J., Aug. 4 -- Essene DeCozen, young Montclair club star, fired a 40, 38 -- 78, five over par, to take a three-stroke lead today in the first round of the New Jersey Women's Golf Association's Shore Tournament at the Deal Club course.

GREAT RIVER, L. I., Aug. 4 -- Ralph Cameron of Larchmont gave the Great South Bay Star Boat skippers a lesson in rough weather sailing when he sailed his Shimmy-She-Wabble to victory in the first race of the Corry Trophy series being run off here in conjunction with the Great South Bay Yacht Racing Association's annual race week.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (AP) -- Senator Homer E. Capehart, Republican of Indiana, said today the Senate waterfront racketeering subcommittee would hold hearings in San Francisco and Seattle in the fall. They are set tentatively for late September and early October.

The Carbide and Carbon Chemicals Company, a division of the Union Carbide and Carbon Corporation, has perfected a method for "dope-dyeing" its dynel textile fiber, it was announced yesterday by Carl A. Setterstrom, general manager of the company's textile fibers department.

Enterprising officials of Washington's 247-seat Arena Stage discussed a matter of major importance to them with Tyrone Guthrie, who staged the Stratford (Ont.) Shakespearean Festival with eclat, before the British director returned to London.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 4 -- Although Wallis-Hazen Productions disbanded late in June as a corporate entity, it is beginning to lok as though Hal Wallis and Joseph Hazen will continue to be identified with Paramount Pictures, with which their company had a distribution agreement.

MOSCOW, Wednesday, Aug. 5 -- The Soviet Government has rejected as "lacking in foundation" a United States note which contended that an American RB-50 was attacked by Soviet fighters While making a routine flight over the Sea of Japan.

MUNSAN, Wednesday, Aug. 5 (AP) -- Following is a complete list of Americans among Allied prisoners of the Korean war returning today in the exchange of prisoners, as officially announced. Numbers listed after names are the serial numbers of the services to which the men are attached:

MILWAUKEE, Aug. 4 -- As an aftermath of the incident in last night's game between Brooklyn and the Braves, in which Roy Campanella tried to attack Lew Burdette for twice having knocked down the Brooklyn catcher with close pitches, Walter O'Malley, the Dodger president, may introduce a new "bean bail" rule at the next major league meeting.

LONDON, Aug. 4 -- The British Government and financial circles are apprehensive that the sharp reduction in economic aid voted by Congress will cause a recurrence of Britain's balance of payment difficulties and possibly curtailment of her defense effort.

A boy's best friend may not be his mother, nor a girl's her father. According to four studies summed up in the current issue of The American Sociological Review, offspring who think their parents are happily married tend to love mother and father equally.
TAMPA, Fla., Aug. 4 (AP) -Two Air Force B-47 jet bombers that set speed records last week on flights to England returned to this country today, one of them setting a non-stop distance record.

In fires, as in everything else, New York City has its ups and downs. Last year, according to the Fire Department's 1952 annual report recently made public by Commissioner Grumet, was certainly a year for the ups. There were 52,741 fires, or 8,701 more than in 1951.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- Welburn Mayock, a Washington lawyer, acknowledged to a Ways and Means subcommittee of the House of Representatives today that he had collected $65,000 from William S. Lasdon, a New York chemical manufacturer, to obtain from the Treasury Department a favorable ruling in a tax case.

JOPPA, Ill., Aug. 4 (AP) -- Electric Energy, Inc. announced today that the Bechtel Corporation of San Francisco had been appointed general contractor for completion of its $159,000,000,000 power plant here. The power company, jointly owned by five Midwest utilities, cancelled its contract last week with Ebasco Services, Inc., New York construction concern, to reorganize the half-completed Joppa project.

A new type of sink that can be used in custom-built kitchens will be available to dealers in a few weeks, it was announced last night by Samuel Weiss, president of Weiss Besserman Company, Inc., wholesale distributor of Youngstown Kitchens.
ELMSFORD, N. Y., Aug. 4 -- James B. Lowery, a 48-year-old Manhattan advertising man, scored an ace today in the World-Telegram and Sun Hole-in-one tourney at the Knollwood Country club.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Aug. 4 -- Prime Minister Daniel F. Malan's system of racial discrimination called apartheid is now to be enforced virtually everywhere -- at sea, in the air on transport and public premises -- even where unequal facilities are provided for different races.

TOKYO, Wednesday, Aug. 5 -- The Communists sent back to freedom today the first 400 United Nations prisoners of the Korean War liberated by the armistice, some of them after three years behind barbed wire in desolate North Korean stockades.

One of the best things about a wisely spent vacation is that old clothes may be worn then. Perhaps this should be set down in reverse, for it is, of course, the wearing of old clothes which determines the wisdom of the vacation.

Eddy Gilmore, for eleven years chief of The Associated Press bureau in Moscow, said upon his return home yesterday that he looked for the Russians to ease up on anti-foreign restrictions and that the country might be opened to tourist trade again, "probably next summer."

NEWARK, Aug. 4 -- Superior Court Judge Alfred C. Clapp refused today to dismiss a complaint attacking as illegal and discriminatory the assigning of departments by the majority on the City Commission of Jersey City. The suit was instituted by Frank Hague Eggers, Public Work Director; Joshua Ringle, Parks and Public Property Director, and three taxpayers.

Show cause orders were served yesterday on the two American Federation of Labor unions involved in the dispute that has halted operations at the Bethlehem Steel Company's Twenty-seventh Street, Brooklyn, shipyard since last Wednesday. Both actions are returnable tomorrow.

HANKOE, Norway, Aug. 4 (AP) -- The four-man United States sailing team from the Manhasset Bay (L. I.) Yacht Club today won the third and deciding regatta in a meet with the Royal Norwegian Yachting Club at this seaside resort in the Oslo fiord.

JERSEY CITY, Aug. 4 -- Four men, including three employed by Hudson County, were held here today for grand jury action on charges of conspiracy to falsify a public record. They were accused of having issued and circulated hundreds of fraudulent birth certificates over a period of several years to aliens seeking employment on the waterfront or in defense plants.
The number of deaths caused by snipers has been increasing throughout the country, a New York police official warned yesterday at a conference on modern methods in law enforcement.

ORADELL, N. J., Aug. 4 -- J. Henry Attas of Aldecress toured the Hackensack Country Club course in 39, 35 -- 74 today to pace a field of seventy-five in a Metropolitan Golf Association one-day tournament.
Vigil was kept last night beside radio and television sets across the nation by the families of fighting men who had been reported captured or missing in action in Korea.

CAMDEN, N. J., Aug. 5 -- The Campbell Soup Company has accepted $175,000 to settle its damage suit against the South Jersey Port Commission for loss of a $460,000 shipment caused by the collapse of a pier.

Mayor Impellitteri announced yesterday that he would ask the Board of Estimate to take the necessary steps to make the benefits of the Federal Social Security Act available to city em ployes who do not belong to any municipal pension system.

Election of the following officers has been announced by directors of the Ullman Company, manufacturer of plastic products: Rodney D. Morgan, chairman; Jerome M. Ullman, president; David V. Morgan, executive vice president; Leonard K. Ross, vice president; Martin C. Poppe, treasurer, and Jules H. Lester, secretary.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- The railroads are expected to refuse to bargain on two demands made by the unions on the ground that they are not properly negotiable. These demands call for health and welfare benefits and free transportation.

LONDON, Aug. 5 (Reuters) -- An opening partnership of 143 by T. C. Gardner and N. F. Horner sent Warwickshire off to a good start against the Australians today and at the close of play the home team had 225 for the loss of four wickets. Rain restricted play.

SPOTSWOOD, N. J., Aug. 5 -- Picketing at the Peter J. Schweitzer Company, a paper manufacturing concern, by residents of Old Bridge in protest over aerial and water pollution ended today as Alex Eber, Middlesex County Prosecutor, announced that he would ask for grand jury action unless the offenders acted to end the condition.

The Duquesne Light Company, which recently became an independent operating utility serving Pittsburgh and surrounding territory, has formulated plans for the sale next month of 150,000 shares of new common stock, 100,000 shares of new $50 par preferred stock and about $12,000,000 of bonds.

Entin Industrial Terminals, Inc., Sol Entin, president, started work yesterday on the second unit of the Entin Industrial Terminal, a $5,000,000 development with frontage on the Passaic River at River Road and South Parkway in Clifton, N. J. Mr. Entin said plants in the project would employ about 2,000 persons.

Fountain House, located at 412 West Forty-seventh Street in New York City, is the only community center of its kind in the United States for former mental patients. Nowhere except at Fountain House may a person released from a mental hospital join with others with similar problems in healthful and constructive recreational and social activities.

PARIS, Aug. 5 -- Marshal Alphonse-Pierre Juin of France, who was recently named Commander in Chief of the North Atlantic ground, air and sea forces in Central Europe, will take over his new assignment Aug. 20, the French Government announced today. Hitherto Marshal Juin has commanded only the Allied ground forces.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (UP) -- The incomplete list of United States Korean battle casualties climbed to 141,705 today and the Department of Defense said final reckoning might take months or even years.

Harris J. Klein, the Mayor's newly appointed member of the New York City Transit Authority, wasted no time in making up his mind about the 15-cent fare set by the authority after some weeks of study. He didn't even wait to be sworn in by Mayor Impellitteri before declaring his opinion that it was "too much."
The B. F. Goodrich Company achieved a new high in sales and increased earnings by 13.2 per cent in the first six months this year, according to semi-annual results announced yesterday.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 5 -- As of this writing, the Greentree Stable horses, trained by the devoted rooter for the Giants, John Gaver, have an .833 batting average at the Saratoga Association's eighty - fifth race meet.

Although an old and wise French proverb says that comparison is not an argument, one may accept the historical parallel made in your Topics of The Times on July 26 between the Russian Empire of Nicholas I and the present Communist state.

In a ceremony observed by 200 persons, Robert W. Dill, a New York stockbroker, was sworn in yesterday as the fortieth Collector of Customs here. Judge Webster J. Oliver, presiding judge of the United States Customs Court, administered the oath in the presence of customs staff members and friends of the new collector.

BIG STONE GAP, Va., Aug. 5 (AP) -- The body of Mrs. Ballard Lane, 35 years old, was found today entangled in a fence that she and her husband had electrified to keep boys out of their garden, Harold Fleming, Wise County sheriff, reported.
CINCINNATI, Aug. 5 (UP) -- Senator Robert A. Taft wrote his will leaving his entire estate to his family two days after New York physicians told him he was hopelessly stricken with cancer.

LONDON, Aug. 5 -- The net impression created in London today by the Soviet reply to the Western Powers' proposal for a foreign ministers' meeting was that the Soviet note was most unlikely to lead to an early East-West conference.
The bill to admit 214,000 refugees and persons from overcrowded areas was finally cleared in conference last week and sent to the White House for the President's signature.

Since it is my belief that the point of view of the common man ultimately influences national and international policy and relationships, may I give you some brief impressions formed during a recent visit to America.
A new national organization initiated by leading business executives and aimed at carrying out a vigorous campaign in favor of more liberal trade policies is being formed, it was learned yesterday.
ZURICH, Switzerland, Aug. 5 -- North American rocket men assumed virtual command today of the International Astronautical Federation now in congress here.
As part of the Government's drive to rid the country of alien-born racketeers, Joseph Doto, alias Joe Adonis, was ordered yesterday by Attorney General Herbert Brownell Jr. to be deported to Italy.
MUNSAN, Korea, Thursday, Aug. 6 (AP) -- Following is the official list of war prisoners from the United States freed in today's exchange (numbers after the names are service serial numbers):

The first series of Spanish-language story hours, arranged by the New York Public Library, was held yesterday in the children's room at the Aguilar Branch, 174 East 110th Street. The stories were told by Miss Nora McCarthy, a visiting student from Argentina, who is working for a degree in library science.
CHICAGO, Aug. 5 (AP) -- Louis L. Haggin's Homestake, a 13-to-1 shot, gained a half-length victory in the $18,000 George Woolf Memorial at Washington Park today.

BONN, Germany, Aug. 5 -- Speaking at an election rally in Trier, Chancellor Konrad Adenauer said tonight the Soviet notes in reply to a United States-British-French proposal for a Big Four foreign ministers' conference evaded four important issues that would have to be clarified if international relations were to be improved.

A bluntly worded letter suggesting six changes that the Health Insurance Plan of Greater New York might make to gain official approval by the Kings County Medical Society was mailed Monday night to Dr. George Baehr, president of the insurance plan, spokesmen for the county society said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- The Eisenhower Administration was reported tonight to be eager to inaugurate the special-quota immigration program set up for refugees in order to give a psychological lift as soon as possible to persons battling Communist rule behind the Iron Curtain.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 5-- Vice President Richard M. Nixon was chiefly instrumental in stopping a White House message on Taft-Hartley law revisions before it was sent to Congress.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- Representative Jacob K. Javits, Republican of Manhattan, urged today that Secretary of Agriculture Ezra Taft Benson announce to consumers the principles the Eisenhower Administration intends to follow in recommendations on farm price support policy, to the next session of Congress.

IF you want to catch tuna, go to Cape Cod. From the canal all the way to Provincetown come reports of the greatest bluefish season in the memory of the oldest Chamber of Commerce secretary. And some of the anglers up there will tell you there's one who remembers the day in 1620 when Capt. Miles Standish found the first Indian corn on what is now known as Corn Hill, in the Truros.

FREEDOM VILLAGE, Korea, Aug. 5 -- The first prisoners of the Korean war to be exchanged in Operation Big Switch were relaxing in their new-found freedom today. In general it was agreed these returned soldiers were adjusting to it much more readily than those who had been received here during the earlier exchange of sick and injured.
For a few hours yesterday there was considerable confusion between the higher and lower echelons of the Department of Sanitation as to what constituted litter and the littering of streets.

RUMSON, N. J., Aug. 5 -- Mrs. William Tracy of Glen Ridge scored 41, 36 -- 77 today and took the lead in the second round of the annual Women's New Jersey Golf Association's Shore Tournament at the Rumson Golf Club.

GREAT RIVER, L. I., Aug. 5 -- The wind was still blowing in near-gale proportions on Great South Bay today and shortly after noon Racing Chairman Lewis L. Delafield ordered cancellation of all sailing in the third day of the Great South Bay Yacht Racing Association's week-long regatta.

Walking ninety-six miles to work was only one of several unusual chores connected with a job in India from which Mrs. Betty Willis has just returned. She was sent by the Technical Assistance Administration of the United Nations to work with the state of Uttar Pradesh on the development of native Indian handicraft products, which as a result may in the future decorate American homes.

LONDON, Aug. 5 -- The price of copper dropped far below the Government-controlled level as free trading in the commodity was resumed on the London Metal Exchange today after fourteen years of Government restrictions.

PARIS, Aug. 5 -- After hearing a warning from Premier Joseph Laniel yesterday that the Government would not yield to special interests in its quest for financial stability, two of these groups, postal workers and winegrowers, went into action today or prepared to do so to fight his policy.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- Appointment of Mrs. Ruth Caston Mueller of New York, a leader in Negro organizations, as an assistant to Miss Bertha S. Adkins, assistant to the Republican National Committee chairman, was announced today by the committee.

MOSCOW, Aug. 5 -- The Soviet Union announced tonight a 110,200,000,000-ruble national defense budget for 1953, a reduction of 3,600,000,000 rubles from the budgeted figure for last year. At the official rate of four rubles to the dollar the new defense budget would total $2,7,550,000,000.

When the task of putting in place 1,800 prefabricated panels on the new building at 99 Park Avenue was started on July 28, the General Bronze Corporation, manufacturer and installer of the sections, estimated that the structure would be enclosed in twelve working days.

CHICAGO, Aug. 5 (AP) -- Hog prices sank to the lowest since April in a dull session at the stockyards today. Depressed wholesale pork marketing was a downscaling factor. Another was the overrun of 1,000 head which failed to clear by the close of trading.

NEW DELHI, Aug. 5 -- Inching their way through a vertical ice fissure or "chimney" nearly 500 feet long, the American-led expedition on 28,250-foot Mount Godwin Austen, or K-2, the second highest mountain in the world, has succeeded in establishing a camp at 22,000 feet on the windswept slope, according to a report from Skardu, in Western Kashmir, the nearest town to the base of the majestic, unclimbed peak.
The "mess" inherited by Eisenhower is like a morass, a dismal swamp where each step makes it more difficult either to advance or withdraw.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- Congressional leaders will meet with President Eisenhower about Sept. 25 to consider whether a special session will be necessary before Congress' scheduled return here on Jan. 6.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- An Israeli Embassy spokesman said today the establishment of his Government's Foreign Office in Jerusalem was merely a move toward restoring the status of May, 1950, when Jerusalem was functioning as the capital of Israel.
The first raids to enforce the Federal gamblers' tax law, on the books for two years, were carried out in Harlem yesterday by twenty-five Treasury agents.
The police posted a 'round-the-clock guard yesterday at the home of Anthony (Tough Tony) Anastasia, Brooklyn waterfront boss, after an underworld tip that he had been marked for murder.

FREEDOM VILLAGE, Korea, Aug. 5 (AP) -- An American who survived the terrible Bataan death march in the Philippines in World War II and an agonizing mid-winter death march as a prisoner of the Communists in Korea came back to liberty today.

Policemen generally have an unwritten agreement that permits motorists to speed at ten miles an hour over the limits for open highways, and five miles an hour in excess of the limit set for city streets, a state safety official said yesterday at a New York University institute on modern methods in law enforcement held at the Washington Square Center.

Sales and earnings of the Columbia Broadcasting System, Inc., and its domestic subsidiaries in the first six months of 1953 were the largest for any half year in the system's history, Dr. Frank Stanton, president, reported yesterday.

Though it includes several significant measures obviously aimed at reducing internal discontent, the 1953 Soviet budget leaves unchanged the fundamental Soviet policies of high military preparedness and rapid expansion of military-economic potential through heavy capital investment.

The discovery of a highly imaginative international ring of automobile traffickers accused of disposing illegally in the New York City area of fifty or more new automobiles belonging to Toronto dealers was announced here last night by the police. The retail value of the cars was put at $150,000.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 5 -- Leonard Goldstein, who produced the "Francis" films for Universal, has a story about a wily parrot and is hoping the bird will turn out to be as sturdy a bread-winner for his new company, Panoramic Productions, as the talking mule proved to be.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- Signing the first of 208 bills left for him by Congress, President Eisenhower began today a busy week that probably will wind up with his departure for Colorado for a long period of recreation and work.

MEMPHIS, Aug. 5 (AP) -- One of the Navy's famed "Blue Angels" told the story today of how he had exploded himself from the cockpit of his stricken jet plane while traveling faster than the speed of sound.

FREEDOM VILLAGE, Korea, Thursday, Aug. 6 (UP) -- Lieut. Col. Thomas D. Harrison, a cousin of chief Allied truce negotiator Lieut. Gen. William K. Harrison Jr., said today he had been "beaten with clubs and sticks" and tortured with the "water treatment" by Communist North Koreans.

MILWAUKEE, Aug. 5 -- The Braves, who had not beaten the Dodgers here this year and had lost six straight to them, turned on their Brooklyn tormenters today with a three-run uprising in the eighth inning to win, 5 -- 3.
CHICAGO, Aug. 5 (UP) -- Lower pork prices were forecast today as the hog market dropped to its lowest level in more than three months.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, chairman of the Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations, disclosed today that he had invoked a legal technicality in an attempt to prevent a key official of the Central Intelligence Agency from leaving the country.
The New York Red Cross Regional Blood Program received blood donation pledges from 250 persons at a rally at 655 Madison Avenue, near Sixtieth Street, yesterday afternoon.

BROWNFIELD, Tex., Aug. 3 -- All over this Western country, some of which is entering its fourth consecutive year of drought, cotton farmers say that "it's worse just south of here." Yet around them they see great stretches of loose soil, their second and third plantings withered or blown out, and even in irrigation areas barely enough water to pump across what is left of the cotton.

FORT DEVENS, Mass., Aug. 5 -- An Army court-martial today acquitted First Lieut. Sheppard Carl Thierman of charges of perjury and obtaining a commission fraudulently by concealing membership in the Communist party. It took the nine officers comprising the trial board three hours to return the verdict.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- President Eisenhower decorated three of the retiring members of the Joint Chiefs of Staff today and expressed the hope that their final reward would be the realization that they helped develop policies that would make war impossible.

OCEANPORT, N. J., Aug. 5 (AP) -- William Ziegler Jr.'s Bit o' Fate tied the track record of 1:43 2/5 for the mile and a sixteenth at Monmouth Park today and took the $15,000 added Long Branch Handicap after William H. Foales' 7-5 favorite, Scobeyville, had set a sizzling pace before breaking down.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 5 -- The Soviet Union made a spectacular entry into South American commerce today by signing an agreement with Argentina calling for a trade interchange of $150,000,000. At the same time the Soviet Union agreed to extend a credit of $30,000,000 for the development of Argentine heavy industry.
Little Toni Kaftol is expected to celebrate her second birthday in her home at 2810 Avenue Y, Brooklyn, on Saturday, without the pain and nausea that often accompany anti-rabies injections.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 5 (UP) -- Ferris Fain, first baseman for the White Sox, suffered a broken left hand in his night club fight at Colmar Manor, Md., last Sunday night, X-ray examinations showed today.

Three young hoodlums, accusing one another of murder, were charged with homicide and held without bail yesterday as gratified police officials wound up a seven-day investigation of the slaying of Michael J. (Barney) Prendergast, New York tavern owner.

MINOT, N. D., Aug. 5 -- American Indians are putting to use their traditional skill at making things with their hands in modern industrial plants at Rolla, N. D., near Turtle Mountain Reservation about ninety miles north of here, and also at Lac du Flambeau Reservation farther east, in northern Wisconsin.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 5 (AP) -- Bob Miller yielded a two-run homer to Stan Musial in the first inning, but pitched the Phillies to a 7-3 victory over the Cardinals tonight. The victory extended the Phillies' third-place advantage to two and one-half games over the Redbirds.

LONDON, Thursday, Aug. 6 -- While ships searched expanses of the North Atlantic last night directed by planes circling above the wreckage of a United States Air Force RB-36 bomber that crashed in the sea before dawn, sixteen members of the twenty-three-man crew were still missing.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (AP) -- Actors, theatre owners, play producers and managers joined tonight in asking the House Ways and Means Committee to remove or reduce the 20 per cent admission tax on legitimate theatres.

SEATTLE, Aug. 5 (AP) -- Gov. Hugh Gregg of New Hampshire today listed eight men -- including himself -- he said were among those under consideration to fill the Senate seat vacated by the death of Senator Charles W. Tobey.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- The United States requested from the Soviet Union yesterday "appropriate compensation" for the loss of the RB-50 plane shot down by Russian MIG fighter planes over the Sea of Japan July 29.
BOSTON, Aug. 5 (AP) -- A right-hander, Ben Flowers, making his first major league pitching start, kept eight Browns' hits well scattered today while registering a 5-0 shutout for the Red Sox.

The most impressive thing about Nellie Don clothes is their good quality in both fabric and design, combined with a low price. This was apparent again yesterday morning when a well-selected collection of these Kansas City styles was presented at a breakfast at the Pierre Hotel. All items are available at McCreery's.

The slaying of an 85-year-old grandmother in her lower East Side apartment two months ago was believed solved yesterday through the painstaking effort of a Spanish-speaking detective who searched East Harlem for leads to the assailants.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 5 (UP) -- Art Aragon, engaging in one of the bloodiest battles of his checkered career, scored a tenth-round technical knockout over Henry Davis tonight.

A rare oriental bird took a flyer in Wall Street yesterday and left hundreds of persons gaping as it repeatedly escaped the nets of would-be captors who pursued it from one skyscraper to another among the canyons of the country's financial center.
Directors of the Bechtel Corporation have elected three new vice presidents, S. D. Bechtel, president of the engineering and construction firm, announced yesterday.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., Aug. 5 -- Mrs. Reinert M. Torgerson, Cherry Valley, and Mrs. William 'R. Kirkland Jr., Piping Rock, scored 34, 35 -- 69 to win the Women's Long Island Golf Association best ball tournament by one stroke at Cherry Valley today.
CINCINNATI, Aug. 5 (AP) -- Three of Cincinnati's six hits today were homers, but they were not enough to defeat the Pirates, who triumphed, 6 to 4.

DARK HARBOR, Me., Aug. 5 -- Northeast winds up to thirty-five miles an hour outside the harbor caused the cancellation of the New York Yacht Club cruise run to Bucks Harbor today. The cancellation was made after a morning consultation between Commodore John Nicholas Brown and Alexander P. Gest, chairman of the race committee.

The captain of the Royal and Ancient of St. Andrews, the ruling body of British golf, says his country and ours may adopt a uniform golf ball in the next two years, probably the larger American version.

" Brother to Dragons," Robert Penn Warren's narrative poem, will be published Aug. 21 by Random House. The basis of Mr. Warren's story is an episode in the life of Thomas Jefferson that involves his sister and her family. The author found the original documents in the case in the courthouse at Smithland, Ky., and these are reproduced in the book.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 5 (AP) -- United States District Judge Allan K. Grim put off today for another week arraignment of eight alleged Communist leaders when it developed that they had been unable to obtain counsel.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- Well-posted sources said today that President Eisenhower would veto the bill to exempt motion-picture theatres from the 20 per cent Federal admissions tax.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 5 -- Late this afternoon, fifteen hours after the finish of the men's pair championship, the contract bridge pair of Harry Harkavy and Bill Root were declared winners of the event by .15 of a match point. Second in the photo finish were John R. Crawford of Philadelphia, and Waldemar von Zedtwitz of Miami.

MILWAUKEE, Aug. 5 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon asserted today that expenditures to maintain friendship of foreign allies were just as important to the United States as appropriations for national defense. Without allies, he told the fifty-fourth annual encampment of Veterans of Foreign Wars here, the United States could not maintain the offensive against world communism that has already produced unrest in Soviet satellite countries.

The Mayor's mediation committee that is seeking to end the sand and concrete truck drivers' strike that has halted most construction activity here since July 3 recommended yesterday a formula for settling the costly walkout.

STONINGTON, Conn., Aug. 5 -- Carl Hovgard's 45-foot sloop, Viking, arrived here today from Dering Island, L. I., a twenty-one-mile run, to win the fourth leg of the annual American Yacht Club's cruise to Block Island.

THE only good thing about growing old is that your chances of driving a Hambletonian winner are improved. A stripling of 34 won in 1934. Dr. Hugh M. Parshall, a veterinarian, remains the youngest ever to turn the trick in the world's foremost trotting stake.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 5 -- Iraq is urging the Arab members of the United Nations to demand a General Assembly condemnation of Israel for moving her government offices to Jerusalem.

The fifty-two-family apartment house at 1695 Hoe Avenue in the Bronx has been sold by the M.G.M. Trading Company, an operating firm headed by Bernard Gordon, to Morris Adler for cash above mortgages totaling $104,500. Gerard M. Bloomfield, lawyer, represented the sellers, and Jack Weiner was attorney for the buyer.

NEWARK, Aug. 5 -- On July 24, 1952, just before 5 P. M., Leon Clark, office manager of the Personal Finance Company at 17 Academy Street, in downtown Newark, received a note from a neatly dressed young man who displayed a pistol.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (AP) -- Maj. Gen. Glen E. Edgerton took office today as managing director of the Export-Import Bank, putting into effect a reorganization plan that abolishes its bipartisan board of directors.

FREEDOM VILLAGE, Korea, Aug. 5 -- The head of the hospital at this receiving center for returned prisoners reported today doctors had found a high percentage of tuberculosis and other lung diseases among liberated United Nations prisoners of war and said "I am not sure they will all recover."

Even mere acquaintances, not to say those who have spent a convivial bierabend with him, know that James Caesar Petrillo, president of the American Federation of Musicians, has strong convictions which he will defend at the drop of a sliphorn. And yet, returning from a visit to Europe, he seems to have changed his tune on some of his most stubbornly held opinions.
LONDON, Aug. 5 -- Early hesitancy caused by yesterday's weakness in Wall Street was soon thrown off in the stock market trading here today and fresh gains were registered in almost every section.
ELSTREE, England, Aug. 5 (UP) -- Bonar Colleano, screen actor, who fell and smashed his face halfway through a film came back to the set today, his features restored by plastic surgery.

OTTAWA, Aug. 5 -- This, the final week of Canada's first general election in four years, found both of the country's major parties concentrating their battle for votes in the heavily populated provinces of Ontario and Quebec were the Liberal Government enjoys the advantage but where the Progressive Conservatives still have hopes.
The cotton futures market here closed barely steady yesterday, unchanged to 9 points lower than on Tuesday.

The libretto for the musical "Can You Dance?," scheduled for production here this season by Elizabeth Miele, will be adapted by Russell Medcraft, who was co-author of the farce comedy hit of 1925, "Cradle Snatchers."

In a report appearing in the July 9 issue of THE NEW YORK TIMES I am quoted as having testified before a House Judiciary subcommittee that I "advocated extension of the wiretapping method to obtain evidence in such crimes as kidnapping and extortion."

NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 5 -- The removal of untouchability, age-old curse that afflicts more than 50,000,000 Indians, will be a long-term task because of "deep-rooted prejudices, deeper than the ones against the Negroes in America," according to a report placed before Parliament today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (AP) -- The Congressional junketing season is under way and before it ends next January the American Congressman probably will be a familiar figure from the Congo to California.

SEATTLE, Aug. 5 -- Gov. James F. Byrnes of South Carolina asserted today that the people from the Potomac River to the Gulf of Mexico had broken their solid ties with the national Democratic party and had declared their continuing political independence.

Plans for altering the four-story private dwelling at 120 East Seventy-second Street into apartments were announced yesterday in connection with the sale of the house by the Masten Construction Corporation in a deal negotiated by H. S. Reis Co. and George E. Maran, brokers.

The Wool Associates of the New York Cotton Exchange, Inc., yesterday adopted a new wool contract, in which trading will start today. The revised contract permits a maximum premium of 11 per cent on the finer grade and a maximum discount of 11 per cent on lower grade, compared with a premium of 6 per cent and a discount of 6 per cent under the present contract.

MEXICO CITY, Aug. 5 (AP) -- Spokesmen for the New Orleans Junior Baseball team told the United States Embassy today that a Mexican general had pointed a pistol at a team member when the boys were walking through a hotel hallway last night.

FREEDOM VILLAGE, Korea, Aug. 5 -- Returned American prisoners gazed upon the Star Spangled Banner for the first time in many months on their return from North Korea today and rejoiced. However, their gratitude and joy were tempered by worry over buddies they had left behind in North Korean prison camps.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Aug. 5 -- The death of the Southern coal industry is conceivable because of its regional disadvantages in the face of an increasingly competitive fuels market, Joseph E. Moody, president of the Southern Coal Producers Association, said today.
The weatherbeaten old man leaned back in his wooden chair and surveyed the expanse of empty tennis courts with a touch of remorse.
The State of Washington will accept bids until Aug. 18 for $27,000,000 of motor vehicle fuel tax revenue bonds due from 1954 to 1976. Bids are not to exceed a 6 per cent interest rate.

MANORHAVEN, L. I., Aug. 5 -- The Nassau County police started grappling in Manhasset Bay today for the body of a 52-year-old Albertson, L. I., service station owner, whose thirty-eight foot sailboat was found drifting off Oyster Bay tihs morning.

Without $32,500 worth of jewelry stolen Tuesday from their apartment at 875 Fifth Avenue, Mr. and Mrs. Robert T. Armstrong sailed for Europe yesterday aboard the French liner Ile de France. Mr. Armstrong, a retired Flint, Mich., automobile spring manufacturer, and his wife were among 1,100 passengers bound for Channel ports.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (AP) -- The Department of Commerce reported today personal income rose $1,600,000,000 in June to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $286,000,000,000.

SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., Aug. 5 -- Kenneth Rosewall and Lewis Hoad of Australia took their places in the quarter-finals of the Eastern grass court tennis championships today with Tony Trabert of Cincinnati and Gardnar Mulloy of Miami.

It is too bad that President Eisenhower -- because of Vice President Nixon's intervention or for other reasons -- did not pursue his plan to send to Congress before adjournment a message embodying his proposed revisions of the Taft-Hartley Law.
