He evidently changed his mind at the last moment, for copies of his proposed recommendations had already been sent confidentially to key men on the Senate and House Labor Committees.

I have read your excellent editorial "Kremlin Miscalculations" in your issue of Aug. 4. In it you suggested that our tactics in the whole struggle against world communism must not be limited to Germany alone -- a statement which deserves much attention and should be more extensively elaborated.

TOKYO, Thursday, Aug. 6 -- The Communists sent back to freedom today the second group of United Nations prisoners of the Korean war to be repatriated as a result of the armistice -- among them some of the most miserable cases to be returned since the exchange began with the repatriation of the sick and wounded three months ago.
THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Aug. 4 -- Harold J. Adonis, indicted for bribery by a Bergen County grand jury last November, is to leave the Netherlands tomorrow for New Jersey.

The Industrial Home for the Blind, at 520 Gates Avenue, Brooklyn 16, is giving its necessary services to more than 1,600 sightless persons. It operates not as an alms-giving organization but as one that strives always to encourage its clients to help themselves.

PARIS, Aug. 5 (Reuters) -- Dr. Luther Evans of the United States, director general of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization, said here today that membership of the Communist party was not automatically a bar to employment with UNESCO.

SEATTLE, Aug. 5 (AP) -- A flailing driveshaft, ripped loose by a snapped propeller tore out rear bottom planking of the speed boat Slo-Mo-Shun V at 170 miles an hour today, but Owner Stan Sayres said, later, he was sure his craft could be repaired in time for Sunday's Gold Cup race.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (AP) -- Bob Porterfield pitched his second successive shut-out and his seventh of the season tonight as the Senators routed the Indians, 11 -- 0, with seventeen hits. The defeat dropped the third-place Indians eight and one-half games back of the league-leading Yankees as Porterfield held Cleveland to six hits.
A TRUCULENT gourmet's a terrible sinner: He can't quite enjoy the most excellent dinner Unless he can talk about knavish plebeians
Stocks gave an impressive performance yesterday afternoon, recovering early losses and making a gain of 0.41 point in THE NEW YORK TIMES combined average. The close was the highest since May 29.

With hoist and pulley, two men spent most of yesterday assembling a huge figure in plaster in a street-floor studio at 159 East Thirty-fifth Street. A model for a work in bronze, the towering figure, when cast, will be the focal point of a war memorial at the United States Military Cemetery at St. Laurent-Sur-Mer, overlooking Omaha Beach in Normandy, stormed by Allied forces on D-Day, June 6, 1944.

Professing a desire to take advantage of the favorable conditions created by the Korean armistice to ease international tensions, the Soviet Government has now replied to the Western proposal for a Big Four Foreign Ministers conference on Germany and Austria with a counter-proposal which is so vague as to require further elucidation before its exact meaning can be ascertained but which, on the face of it, offers little hope for progress.

SEOUL, Thursday, Aug. 6 (UP) -- Secretary of State John Foster Dulles and President Syngman Rhee have reached agreement on some minor points but it is doubtful that they can reach a final accord on Dr. Rhee's demands for a unified Korea, reliable sources said today.
CLIFFSIDE PARK, N. J., Aug. 5 -- The popular old Tunnel of Love is losing its appeal, according to amusement park owners, who believe this is a sign that old-fashioned romancing has disappeared.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- Governor Dewey expressed the view, in a letter made public here today, that the Federal Government might well vacate certain fields of taxation in order to enable the states to abolish their income taxes, thus solving the problem of taxing each other's citizens.

BULAWAYO, Southern Rhodesia, Aug. 5 -- William H. Ball, the American business man sent by President Eisenhower as special delegate with the rank of Minister to the Bulawayo Rhodes Centennial Central African exhibition, said shortly after his arrival here today that he favored equal pay for equal work, irrespective of race.

CHICAGO, Aug. 5 -- Moderately bullish private crop estimates stimulated early buying of grain futures, but unfavorable developments in the Northwest which caused a lowering of forecasts failed to bring outside support and all markets receded sharply from initial bulges.

Twenty-four well-known lawyers practicing in New York, Connecticut and Vermont yesterday urged President Eisenhower to fill vacancies in the Court of Appeals, Second Circuit, by the promotion of United States District Judges.

LONDON, Aug. 5 -- Since World War II Britain has built nearly three times as many houses as were destroyed or made unfit for occupancy by enemy action, a Ministry of Housing and Local Government White Paper showed today.

GENEVA, Aug. 5 -- President Izhak Ben-Zvi of Israel, in a message read today to the World Jewish Congress assembled here, said that Jews inside and outside Israel must join forces to advance both the rights of Jews outside Israel and the strength of the State of Israel.
The housewife might have found reason to cheer at yesterday's session of the National Association of Retail Meat and Food Dealers at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
Two of four men under indictment in a gangster killing of eighteen years ago were arraigned yesterday in Kings County Court on an indictment charging first-degree murder.

HANOVER, Germany, Aug. 5 (UP) -- Mal Whitfield, George Brown and Joseph Culbreath each scored two victories tonight as American track and field stars swept the eleven events they entered during an international meet before a crowd of 15,000.

Not very long ago the job of an executive in charge of a business was merely to make, a profit and thereby stay in business. Now his work is considerably more than this; he must further the interests not only of the stockholders but of the public on a world basis.

BRANTFORD, Ont., Aug. 5 (AP) -- The Koehring Company of Milwaukee, manufacturer of construction equipment, has offered $14 each for the 37,950 Class A shares and 99,475 common shares of Waterous, Ltd., here.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (UP) -- Assistant Secretary of State Robert D. Murphy said tonight that the United States "will not resume" hostilities in Korea simply because of failure to reach agreement during the ninety-day post-armistice political conference.

CHICAGO, Aug. 5 -- Victory continued to elude the Giants today at Wrigley Field, where they bowed twice to the Cubs, 9 -- 6 and 7 -- 6, losing the second game in ten innings. At the moment, Leo Durocher's club is weighted down with a six-game losing streak, its longest of the season.

WESTBURY, L. I., Aug. 5 (AP) -- Fiesta Hanover, owned by Patricia Sheppard of Hanover, Pa., scored a one-length victory in the $8,700 David H. McConnell Trot for 3-year-old fillies tonight on the Grand Circuit card at Roosevelt Raceway.

BERLIN, Aug. 5 -- The East German Government appeared today to have quietly lifted its restriction on travel to West Berlin as thousands reached the Western sector of the city from remote parts of the country to collect the West's food gift parcels.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (UP) -- Senator Estes Kefauver asked the Internal Revenue Service today to take away the tax exempt status of the American Council of Christian Laymen for lobbying against the Tennessee Valley Authority.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Aug. 5 -- Traffic on the New Jersey Turnpike for the first six months of 1953 was ahead of the volume engineers had forecast for 1971, the Turnpike Authority reported to bondholders today.

ATLANTIC CITY, Aug. 5 -- Alarmed by increasing complaints from resort visitors about "gouging" by some parking lot operators, city officials turned over to the Police Department today the task of cracking down on violators.
Steel, Berse Co., Inc., a textile converting company, has developed a sales technique which, officers of the company say, carries the answer to price competition from vertically integrated producers.

The election of Senator William F. Knowland as majority (or floor) leader to succeed the late Senator Taft is significant mainly in that it was accomplished without the revolt threatened by the restive right-wingers within the G.O.P.

Parents of mentally retarded youngsters may enroll now for two free courses which the Association for the Help of Retarded Children, 323 Fourth Avenue, will conduct this fall in the New York area. One is a lecture-discussion series dealing with such factors as the causes of mental retardation, speech problems, home and vocational training. The other, for mothers of preschoolers, will be devoted to study of early home training techniques.
Trading continued slow on the New York commodity exchanges yesterday. Prices were slightly higher.
The Cargocaire Engineering Corporation enters its nineteenth year today with the promise of a "revolutionary" but still undisclosed new technique to protect ship-borne cargo.

Twenty cheese manufacturers have applied to the Food and Drug Administration for permits to use a new chemical mold inhibitor, sorbic acid, on wrappings of natural and processed cheese. It is expected that within a year consumers will be eating products packed with sorbic acids.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- Charles W. Crawford, Commissioner of the Food and Drug Administration said today that in his opinion the Durham-Humphrey law curbing the sale of sleeping pills was not enforceable under the new food and drug inspection bill.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 5 -- A policeman is not a book censor and lacks the authority, on his own, to decide what books are obscene and to stop their sale under threat of arrest, Federal Judge Charles J. McNamee ruled today in granting an injunction to New American Library of World Literature, Inc., New York publishers of paperbound books, against Edward J. Allen Jr., police chief of Youngstown, Ohio.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended July 29, the Federal Reserve Board reported today:

The American Natural Gas Company announced yesterday that it planned to form a subsidiary to build and operate a new 1,000-mile natural gas pipeline to supply the system's markets in Michigan and Wisconsin. The company has filed an application with the Securities and Exchange Commission for permission to form the subsidiary, to be known as the American Louisiana Pipeline Company.

If the electrical industry will give the same promotional attention to home lighting that it has to industrial and commercial lighting it can raise residential power consumption considerably, it was asserted yesterday by William H. Robinson Jr., manager of advertising for the lamp division of the General Electric Company.
GENEVA, Aug. 5 -- Bitter Russian and Polish attacks on the Federal Republic of Germany marked the closing hours of the sixteenth session of the United Nations Economic and Social Council here today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- A State Department spokesman said today that the United States Government felt the Soviet Union had left the door open for a four-power foreign ministers' conference.

A decline of only 23,000 barrels last week in the nation's gasoline stocks was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end, supplies were 143,423,000 barrels, compared with 143,446,000 a week earlier and 116,243,000 a year ago.
Sales of home sites in the Belle Harbor section of Rockaway Beach, Queens, were reported by W. F. Brunner, Inc., broker.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (UP) -- The price of frozen orange juice is going up because Americans are drinking it faster than it can be processed, an Agriculture Department spokesman said today.
PARIS, Aug. 5 -- For France, the Soviet Union's note proposing a conference including Communist China offers a tempting opportunity to bring the Indo-China problem up for international discussion.

By correctly identifying nineteen out of twenty numbers played by the Goldman Band in Central Park last evening, Nicholas J. Eberhard of 3209 Park Avenue, the Bronx, won a bronze medal but lost the right to participate in future music memory contests conducted by the band. Winners are not permitted to re-enter.

CENTRE ISLAND, L. I., Aug. 5 -- The American, Noroton and Huguenot Yacht Club entries were all tied with seven points at the end of the first two round-robin sailing events to decide the midget championship of the Long Island Sound Yacht Racing Association in Oyster Bay Harbor off the Sewanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club today.
MILWAUKEE, Aug. 5 -- Not even a matter of $30,000 could make Manhattan war veterans miss a chance to see the Brooklyn Dodgers play the Milwaukee Braves -- on the cuff.
The stretch-out in tank production, part of the general defense budget revisions for the current fiscal year, has not altered the numbers or types of tanks to be procured by the Army.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (AP) -- The Government went $2,759,000,- 000 into the red during July, the first month of the new fiscal year, although it spent $674,000,000 less than in July, 1952.

JERUSALEM, Aug. 5 -- The Acting Minister of Defense, Pinhas Lavon, warned Israel's Arab minority today that their loyalty as citizens would be judged by the active assistance they rendered against murders and "bloody excesses" by Arab bands.

CHICAGO, Aug. 5 -- Attorneys representing the National Electronic Distributors Association, Chicago, and its 350 distributor members and Federal Trade Commission attorneys reached agreement late today on a consent settlement of F. T. C. charges that the association and its members carried on illegal trade practices.

Every weekday some 20,000 improvers of the breed click through the turnstiles of Aqueduct, Belmont or Jamaica race track, and at night nearly as many watch the harness horses compete under the lights of Roosevelt or Yonkers Raceway.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- Two New York business men who had been accused by Welburn Mayock, a Washington lawyer, of splitting fees with him in a tax case denied before a Ways and Means subcommittee of the House of Representatives today that they had ever received a cent from him.

There is no doubt in the minds of officials of the United States Rubber Company that a stock split will broaden demand for a corporation's securities. The company announced yesterday that since January, 1952, when directors first disclosed their plans for splitting the common stock three for one in April, 1952, the number of investors holding its shares has increased 6,497, or 39 per cent, over the 16,362 on record at the end of 1951.

Thomas K. Finletter, Secretary for Air in the Cabinet of former President Harry S. Truman, announced yesterday his endorsement of Borough President Robert F. Wagner Jr. for the Democratic nomination for Mayor.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 5 (AP) -- Sam Mele lined a home run into the left field stands with a man aboard in the fourteenth inning tonight to enable the White Sox to gain a 9-7 victory over the Athletics.

The interunion dispute that has tied up operations at the Bethlehem Steel Company's Twenty-seventh Street shipyard in Brooklyn for eight days took on additional legal complications yesterday as the company filed suit for damage of $300,000.

That happy faculty of collecting an extra-base hit at the opportune moment continued to pay off yesterday for the world champion Yankees. Yogi Berra's double to right in the seventh enabled the Bombers to top the Tigers, 5 -- 4, before 10,578 paying fans at the Stadium.

BONN, Germany, Aug. 5 -- The ultranationalist German Reich party announced today that Dr. Werner Naumann, former state secretary in the Nazi propaganda ministry had agreed to be a candidate in the Sept. 6 elections.

A strike of longshoremen against Moore-McCormack Lines over a job dispute involving one dock worker caused the withdrawal yesterday of the company's 20,000-ton passenger liner Argentina from a scheduled voyage. The ship was slated to leave on Saturday for East Coast ports of South America with 235 passengers.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 5 -- In conformity with the establishment of Puerto Rico as a commonwealth, under the new Constitution that became effective July 25; the United States mission submitted to the United Nations today its final report on the island as a non-self-governing territory.

SEATTLE, Aug. 6 -- Governor Dewey of New York said today he had not made up his mind whether to seek re-election and probably would not make a decision for nine or ten months. He added he was busy tackling the "tough problems all the others were not willing to handle."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- During the week ended Aug. 5, member bank reserves increased $85,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. The principal changes supplying reserves were decreases of $381,000,000 in Treasury deposits with Federal Reserve banks and $11,000,000 in other deposits with Federal Reserve banks.
In your splendid editorial on the Russian regime, entitled "Utopia: 1917-53," you discuss the deliberate perversion of the words democracy, peace, brotherhood, etc.

R. H. Macy Co., Inc., will build a major regional shopping center in Bergen County, N. J., at the intersection of Routes 4 and 17, it was announced yesterday by Jack I. Straus, president. Macy's decision to proceed with the development, he said, was made after termination of negotiations with Allied Stores Corporation for a joint venture in that area.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- Senator H. Alexander Smith declared today that he was "confident" that members of the Senate would still be glad to go to Korea if it seemed important for them to participate in any further United States discussions with President Syngman Rhee.

MOSCOW, Aug. 6 -- The Soviet Government has launched a program designed to encourage peasants to own their own livestock and to increase the productivity and profits of the peasants' individual farming plots.
I was delighted to read the editorial in your issue of Aug. 3 urging that smaller taxicabs be substituted for the present "jumbo size" taxis which crowd our streets so unnecessarily.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 (AP) -- Plans for a sweeping investigation of Communist influences in labor unions were laid down today by Senator John Marshall Butler, Republican of Maryland, head of a special task force of the Senate Judiciary Committee.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 (AP) -The Federal Communications Commission today authorized the Columbia Broadcasting System to conduct public tests of a color television system that now is being proposed by the TV industry generally.

President Eisenhower has vetoed the bill, sponsored by Representative Noah M. Mason, Republican of Illinois, which would have repealed the 20 per cent emergency excise tax on admissions to the movies. The action amounts to a "pocket veto," since Congress is not in session, and so cannot vote on the question of overriding it.

MILWAUKEE, Aug. 6 -- A two-out triple by Harry Hanebrink off Russ Meyer with the bases filled today gave the Braves a ninth-inning, 3-2 triumph over the Dodgers in the second game of a double-header. The Brooks won the opener in eleven innings, 4 -- 3, on a two-out single by Pee Wee Reese off Warren Spahn, the only pitcher of the day to go the distance.

SEATTLE, Aug. 6 -- Approximately forty-four state and territorial Governors unanimously rejected today proposals by Gov. J. Bracken Lee, Utah Republican, calling for drastic changes in the United Nations to impose greater obligations upon America's Allies in resisting aggression.

HYDRO, Okla., Aug. 6 (AP) -- A Greyhound bus and an automobile, rushing the same way down an incline toward a narrow bridge, locked together at dawn near here today and plunged off United States Highway 66 into a creek, killing six persons.
" Here is the chance," said Vincent R. Impellitteri during his 1950 campaign as an "independent" for Mayor, "to assure * * * a nonpolitical administration."

Foremost Dairies, Inc., has acquired the Marin Dairymen's Milk Company, Ltd., and Dairymaid Creameries, Ltd., of California, bringing to about 100 the number of communities that Foremost is serving in eighteen states, in addition to overseas operations in Hawaii and the Far East.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- President Eisenhower told the nation tonight in a review of the domestic and foreign policy achievements of his administration, that the Korean truce demonstrated the determination of the free world to resist aggression anywhere.

In a day of larger volume, prices on the New York Stock Exchange pushed forward yesterday, making relatively small gains on a wide front. The market, broadest in a month, saw 1,092 issues traded, with 553 rising, 252 falling and 287 closing without change from the day before.

TOKYO, Friday, Aug. 7 -- Foreign Minister Katsuo Okazaki said yesterday the United States and Japan had agreed on nine points of a mutual security aid accord, including standardization of arms for this country's defense forces.

Robert F. Wagner Jr., Manhattan Borough President, aroused the ire of Traffic Commissioner T. T. Wiley yesterday by closing a four-block stretch of New Chambers Street from South Street to St. James Place. Mr. Wiley called the action "untimely" and said it tended to complicate traffic in the vicinity of the Alfred E. Smith Houses.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- Sam Rayburn of Texas, Democratic leader of the House of Representatives, asserted today that the Republicans in the session of Congress just ended had succeeded primarily only in making money "harder to get."
BALTIMORE, Aug. 6 (AP) -- Elpidio Quirino, President of the Philippines, called his acting National Defense Secretary to the United States today.
Trading volume was small on the New York commodity exchanges yesterday and prices were little changed.
The American-Korean Foundation, a private aid organization, said yesterday it was sending a second mission to South Korea to help plan the Republic's social and economic reconstruction.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- Dr. Robert P. Fischelis, secretary of the American Pharmaceutical Association, challenged today a statement made yesterday by the Food and Drug Commissioner, Charles W. Crawford, to the effect that the new food and drug inspection act needed prescription-inspecting powers to control the sale of sleeping pills.

BRIDGEHAMPTON, L. I., Aug. 6 -- Near the spot where two children of migrant farm workers burned to death in an abandoned chicken coop used as a dwelling three years ago, a spic-and-span day nursery was opened today. The two-story stucco building, formerly a doctor's home, will take care of twenty children of the migrants now picking potatoes and cucumbers in this community.
Boats, tobacco and records figured in educational programs announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- With an eye on the plans for an increasing output of jet engines, the Office of Defense Mobilization today ordered a 3,000-ton expansion in the capacity to produce titanium "sponge," the pure metal made from titanium ore and from which titanium products are fashioned. The new goal, which the O. D. M. expects will be attained by 1956, calls for an annual output of 25,000 tons of the pure metal.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 6 (UP) -- President Juan Peron received today a group of eleven leading members of the local United States business community. The group was headed by John B. Arnold, general manager in Argentina for the National City Bank of New York.

Modernization of 300 subway cars with posture seating, new paint and brighter lights, cleaning up and repainting stations and increased service on the White Plains Road line in the Bronx and the Lexington Avenue line in Manhattan will be among the first returns subway riders will get for the recent fare increase, it became known yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- Gen. Mark Wayne Clark, renowned officer of World War II and, for the past fifteen months, the United Nations commander in the Far East, saved the announcement that he would give up his command in the near future and retire from the Army for the close of his press conference at the Pentagon today.

SEOUL, Korea, Friday, Aug. 7 (AP) -- Secretary of State John Foster Dulles conferred this morning with President Syngman Rhee on the explosive question of unification for Korea and scheduled another meeting in the afternoon.

SEABRIGHT, Southampton and Newport, from the early days of the game, were magic names in lawn tennis. Next to the national championship, the invitation tournaments associated with these three water resorts were the blue-ribbon events of the grass court season, attracting the foremost players from the world over.

" Late Love" has found a haven. Beginning Oct. 13, the Forty-eighth Street will shelter Michael Abbott's initial Broadway venture. To mark the occasion with a handsome flourish, Mr. Abbott has allotted stellar billing in the Rosemary Casey comedy to Arlene Francis, Lucile Watson and Neil Hamilton, who will have the role previously announced for John Loder.

BERLIN, Aug. 6 -- After having tried a series of other forgeries to disrupt West Berlin's food gift distribution, the Communists were reported today to have sent bogus letters to the West Berlin unemployed telling them to go to their local borough offices to pick up free food parcels.
The New York Shipping Association's campaign for waterfront safety has resulted in a definite downward trend in the percentage of accidents, John V. Lyon, chairman, said yesterday.

Oliver La Farge, president of the Association on American Indian Affairs, hailed yesterday the repeal by Congress of the century-old "Indian liquor law" as the end of discriminatory Federal legislation against American Indian citizens.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Aug. 6 -- The Israelis requested today the suspension of all investigations in Jordan's territory by the Mixed Armistice Commission, saying they had evidence that the Jordanians had been tricking the United Nations investigators.
LUBBOCK, Tex., Aug. 6 -- The Republican Administration appeared today to have passed its first major test on the farm front through its drought relief program.

ANKARA, Turkey, Aug. 6 -- Turkey may find it increasingly difficult to earn the needed dollar exchange for her capital improvement program if the present decline in the price of chromite, one of this country's most important exports to the United States, continues.
Of four textile companies that issued periodic financial statements yesterday only one -- the Burlington Mills Corporation -- showed profitable operations.
PARIS, Friday, Aug. 7 -- France's biggest employer, the Government, was facing today an avalanche of strikes called by its employes to fight economy measures it was preparing.

Commissions for transactions on the New York Stock Exchange are not to be increased. Keith Funston, president, announced yesterday that the members had rejected the proposed 15 per cent average advance by a vote of 573 to 532.

TEHERAN, Iran, Aug. 6 -- The Teheran District Governorate published today an official count of the ballots cast last Monday in the plebiscite in which the Government sought popular approval of the dissolution of the Majlis (lower and sole remaining house of parliament).

A .22 caliber bullet was found yesterday in the skull of a man who, it had been declared by an assistant medical examiner, had died of natural causes. The autopsy was ordered after a confessed sniper said he had shot the victim outside 206 West Eighty-second Street on July 27.
Sixty angry women brought to a halt yesterday the demolition of empty buildings at the Manhattan Beach veterans' housing project in Brooklyn.

LONDON, Aug. 6 -- Although hampered by rain, poor visibility and rough seas searching vessels today found the bodies of two more crewmen from the United States Air Force RB-36 reconnaissance bomber that crashed in the North Atlantic before dawn yesterday.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Aug. 6 (AP) -- Ohio Republicans today decided to pass up any attempt to change the state's election laws to permit a quick special election for naming a successor to the late Senator Robert A. Taft.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- A Ways and Means subcommittee of the House of Representatives was told today that a policy had been changed and technical officials of the Treasury Department had been overruled to give the Monsanto Chemical Company favorable consideration in a tax case after John W. Snyder, Secretary of the Treasury at the time, had shown a personal interest in the case.

Emphasizing the importance college girls place on separates, Ohrbach's devoted almost its entire showing of college fashions yesterday to these designs. Far from monotonous because of their almost endless variety and imaginative handling, the slim pants, weskits, Bermuda shorts, blouses, skirts and jackets were worked out in groups repeating such campus favorites as the camel tones, leather trims, print corduroy and jersey.

In your editorial of Aug. 3 "The Segura Episode" you mentioned that THE NEW YORK TIMES has often had occasion to criticize the policies of the South African Government. But, surely, never has THE NEW YORK TIMES, nor for that matter any other responsible newspaper, based its criticism on such an unfounded and totally inaccurate presumption as that on which the Segura editorial was written.
COWES, Isle of Wight, Aug. 6 (UP) -- The main contest in the sixth day of the Cowes Regatta was tentatively won by a United States yacht, Gesture, which crossed the line first today.

June shipments of hosiery totaled 12,316,390 dozen pairs compared with 12,629,912 dozen pairs in the corresponding month of 1952, it was announced yesterday by the National Association of Hosiery Manufacturers.

Forced to yield to the pressure of their hungry millions, the Russians and their East German puppets are apparently lifting the travel restrictions on Soviet zone inhabitants trying to get American food packages from West Berlin, and the second Berlin blockade appears to have been broken by the Germans themselves.

NORFOLK, Va., Aug. 6 (UP) -Thirty fathers and sons on an outing of the Young Men's Christian Association from Canton, Ohio, were rescued by an Air Force crash boat today from a sailing yacht driven aground by strong winds in Chesapeake Bay.

As many as one-third of the Pentagon's safes, some containing top secret papers, were found by security investigators in World War II to be either unlocked or improperly closed after the responsible officers had gone for the day, a former major in the Military Police said yesterday.

NORTH HAVEN, Me., Aug. 6 -- A light weather run from Dark Harbor today produced class victories for John N. Matthews' twelve-meter Vim, William Ziegler 3d's cutter Spookie, DeCoursey Fales' Nina and Edmund S. Kelley's cutter Departure in the New York Yacht Club cruise.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 (AP) -- The Coast Guard today blamed Capt. Albert Stiglin of Vermillion, Ohio, for the sinking of his ore carrier last May during a Lake Superior storm and said steps would be taken to strip him of his license.

CHICAGO, Aug. 6 -- An agreement to sell Hertz-Driv-Ur-Self System, Inc., car and truck rental, a subsidiary of General Motors Corporation, to Omnibus Corporation of Chicago has been made by General Motors and Omnibus, Harlow H. Curtice, G. M. president, said today.

At a time when American-Italian relations are driving toward a crisis we have considered it the part of wisdom to cripple our information services in Italy. We have terminated our short-wave broadcasts, the medium-wave relays via Munich and Tangiers and the rebroadcasts via Radio Trieste I.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 (AP) -- The father of a cerebral palsied child today proposed tax law changes which would make it easier for parents to provide lifetime care for their permanently disabled children.

As a culmination of federal legislation passed in 1950 and a state law enacted earlier this year Mayor Impellitteri is proposing that city employes not otherwise covered by retirement pension plans be brought into the federal Social Security system. It is estimated that this will cost the city perhaps as much as $2,000,000 a year for protection of 40,000 or more employes.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 (AP) -- The United States Court of Appeals upheld today the Civil Aeronautics Board's action to curtail directorships of the partners of Lehman Brothers, investment banking firm, in airlines.

Determined to lose no ground on the eve of their clash with the runner-up White Sox, the Yankees yesterday achieved a clean sweep of their three-game series with Freddy Hutchinson's Tigers by deftly upending the Bengals in the finale at the Stadium, 5 to 2, before a gathering of 9,852.
Forty-one seamen arrived here by air yesterday to man the latest addition to the growing Indian merchant fleet.
Earl W. Clark has been elected president of the New York and Cuba Mail Steamship Company (Ward Line), succeeding C. H. C. Pearsall, who has been named vice chairman of the board of directors.

LAKE FOREST, Ill., Aug. 6 -- William Ellsworth Clow Jr., 68 years old, a Chicago manufacturer, was found fatally shot on his estate here tonight. Members of his family said he apparently had been the victim of a hunting accident.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 6 -- This afternoon 228 contract bridge pairs, playing here at the Jefferson Hotel, completed the second and final qualifying session in the blue ribbon masters pair event of the twelve-day national championship meet. Only the ninety-six top pairs are eligible for the three remaining sessions. As the field narrowed many of the name players fell by the wayside. Those who qualified will play the remaining sessions without further elimination.

HAVANA, Aug 6 -- President Fulgencio Batista decreed today drastic measures to supress attacks "against the national dignity, peace, public confidence, stability of the Government, the economy and the credit of the nation."
The statement of Harold Riegelman yesterday accepting the Republican designation for Mayor follows:
WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 (UP) -- The Government today ordered Thomas Marino, Brooklyn racketeer, deported to his native Italy as part of its drive against foreign-born underworld figures.

THE National Broadcasting Company is certainly putting on some very specialized television programs this summer. On Sunday nights at 7 o'clock it has a new opus entitled "Operation Neptune," all about an undersea kingdom whose ruler hates surface people and sets out to destroy them.

Symptoms of a bright future for the Avenue of the Americas appear with encouraging frequency. Announcement over the last week-end of plans for a 35-story air-conditioned skyscraper to be built in the blockfront from Fifty-first to Fifty-second Street is the latest evidence that investors are beginning to see this as a street of new opportunity.
BRANCHVILLE, N. J., Aug. 6 -- Riders from this area did well today at the annual Sussex County Horse Show which attracted entries from as far west as California.
WESTBURY, L. I., Aug. 6 (AP) -- District Attorney, owned by Dr. S. M. Damren of Portland, Me., scored a length victory tonight in the Brentwood Pace Grand Circuit feature at Roosevelt Raceway.

SEATTLE, Aug. 6 (AP) -- The old queen of the speedboats, Slo-Mo- Shun IV, qualified today for her defense Sunday of the Gold Cup at an average speed of 107.5 miles per hour, the fastest qualifying time in the history of the race.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 (AP) -The Federal Power Commission ended today a five-year battle for the New England natural gas market, dividing it between the Northeastern Gas Transmission Company and the Alonquin Gas Transmission Company along lines of its original decisions of 1950-51.
LONDON, Aug. 6 -- For the first time since food rationing was introduced during World War II, British housewives will be able to buy as much bacon as they desire after Aug. 16.

Nicholas Lana, 75-year-old laborer who lost his job with the Department of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity after forty-five years' service when the Municipal Civil Service Commission learned he had been working under an assumed name, was in a cheerful frame of mind yesterday after hearing Assistant Corporation Counsel Victor Herwitz express the hope that Mr. Lana would win his case.

NEW YORK'S subways support 11,700 vending machines, a sub-asphalt copper mine that yields 1,167,000 pounds of pennies each year, the largest operation of its kind on earth. The combined railroad stations of the United States support fewer than 10,000 machines.

Beef chuck, pot roasts and smoked beef tongues are among the most economical beef buys at this time. Unfortunately, the long slow simmering necessary to produce tenderness in these cuts fills the kitchen with steam and discourages their use in summer.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- President Eisenhower rejected today the bill for exemption of motion picture theatres from the 20 per cent Federal admissions tax, but promised to recommend reduction of the tax in January.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 6 (UP) -- The White Sox exploded with five runs in the eighth inning today to defeat the Athletics, 6 -- 4, for the A's seventh straight loss.

GENEVA, Aug. 6 -- American Jewish representatives roundly denounced an effort made today by a left wing member of Israel's Parliament to bring the execution of Julius and Ethel Rosenberg before the World Jewish Congress as a case involving anti-Semitism.

FREEDOM VILLAGE, Korea, Friday, Aug. 7 (UP) -- Six Americans and a British prisoner "stayed behind with the Commies" when their Yalu River camp was emptied for the prisoner exchange, two repatriated Americans said today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- The White House announced today that President Eisenhower would depart Saturday morning for his Colorado vacation.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 (AP) -- The Department of Justice announced today that a denaturalization proceeding against Mrs. Sophie Gerson, 43 years old, of Brooklyn, would be filed in Federal District Court there.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 (AP) -- In a White House ceremony today Webster B. Todd of New York was sworn in as director of Economic Affairs in the new United States Mission to the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and European Regional Organizations.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- The United States Court of Appeals ruled today in the case of Morris Mendelsohn, a former resident of New York, that the desire to remain at the bedside of his sick wife in Israel constituted an involuntary failure to return to the United States in time to preserve his American citizenship.

FREEDOM VILLAGE, Korea, Aug. 6 (UP) -- More than 2,000 United States prisoners froze or starved to death in the notorious "death valley" of North Korea during the Arctic winter of 1950, a returning officer reported today.

MEXICO CITY, Aug. 3 -- To the surprise and bewilderment of the Americans involved, Mexico has rejected 500,000 pounds of United States surplus powdered milk offered as a gift by Cooperative for American Remittances to Europe, Inc., a private charitable organization.

GENEVA, Aug. 6 -- The International Committee for Migration From Europe is ready to start at once helping United States authorities to carry out provisions of the new law providing for the espcial immigration of 214,000 persons, Hugh Gibson, director of the committee, said here today.
Friends of Mayor Impellitteri said yesterday, without giving any supporting data, that they expected Carmine G. DeSapio to be out as leader of Tammany within two weeks.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Aug. 6 -- A fight over the proposed Bricker amendment to the Constitution, which would limit the treaty-making powers of the President, developed at the national encampment of the Veterans of Foreign Wars today.

MUNSAN, Korea, Friday, Aug. 7 (AP) -- The United Nations Command's official list of United States prisoners of war freed today in the Korean armistice exchange (numbers after names are service serial numbers):
The cotton futures market was barely steady yesterday and closing prices were down 6 to 11 points net.

DEAL, N. J., Aug. 6 -- Mrs. William Tracy of Glen Ridge rallied on the last nine today at the Hollywood Golf Club to win the Women's New Jersey Golf Association's three-day shore tournament with a fifty-four-hole total of 240.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 (AP) -- The Federal Reserve Board said today lending by its member banks rose $5,161,000,000, or nearly 10 per cent, in the year ending June 30.

BOSTON, Aug. 6 (AP) -- Blistered hands most likely prevented Ted Williams from making a dramatic return to competitive baseball today as the Browns outfought the Red Sox for an 8-7 victory in ten innings.

A study of the political and diplomatic history of the period of crisis from September, 1940, to the attack on Pearl Harbor will be published Sept. 2 by Harper under the title "The Undeclared War." The volume covers the response of President Roosevelt and his Cabinet to the needs of Britain, our diplomatic tangles with Vichy, our attempts to alert Russia to the designs of Hitler and the breakdown of relations with Japan.

ZURICH, Switzerland, Aug. 6 -British rocketeers at the astronautical congress here discussed today the best place on earth to blast prefabricated pieces of an interplanetary orbital vehicle up into the sky with the aid of carrier rockets.

OSLO, Aug. 6 (AP) -- Mal Whitfield, former Ohio State star, defeated Wes Santee of Kansas by a yard tonight to win the 800-meter run in an international track and field meet at Olympic Bislet stadium.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- Senator Irving M. Ives, Republican of New York, to whom some persons give credit for taking labor legislation out of partisan politics when he was the Majority Leader in New York's State Assembly, may become the Senate's key figure on labor measures.
LONDON, Aug. 6 -- Prices of a broad variety of stocks continued to advance on the markets here today under the lead of British Government securities, which gained as much as one-quarter per cent.

SAIGON, Vietnam, Aug. 6 -- A warning tonight by Gen. Henri-Eugene Navarre of the possibility of open intervention in Indo-China by Chinese Communist troops was interpreted as directed at the United States as well as to the Associated States of Indo-China.
Plans for a gigantic shrine where the history of the United States will be carved in figures and words on enduring granite were announced here yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- It's Two-Gun Eisenhower now. The President received a pair of pacifiers, modern style, today, and he told the donors he may take them to Colorado on his vacation.

The fact that we knew all along, almost subconsciously, that U. N. soldiers made prisoner by the Communists in Korea must be having a bad time of it does not mitigate the shocks that we get now. They are bringing out a horror story that seems to belong to a different world entirely.

The rufous-necked hornbill that has been having a high time around Wall Street skyscrapers since it escaped from its cage Wednesday morning called it quits late yesterday and waddled wearily into a comfortable pigeon loft atop a tenement.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 (UP) -- All foreign aid soon will be going abroad under a new label denoting comradeship and friendship.

Harold Riegelman announced yesterday his acceptance of designation for the Republican nomination for Mayor. As he has no opponent, his nomination at the primary election Sept. 15 is scheduled to follow.
TOKYO, Aug. 6 -- Every year since the end of World War II the Japanese have set aside this day to remember the dropping on Hiroshima of the first atomic bomb.

The showing of college clothes presented yesterday morning by Peck Peck re-emphasized that college girls have tastes of their own when it comes to the clothes they will wear when they go to their various campuses this fall. The styles, as decreed by them, are good-looking and appropriate to American college life.

Public utility financing accounted for more than half of an $82,000,000 rise in business loans from New York banks during the week ended on Wednesday. The advance followed declines in the two previous weeks and was the largest to be registered since the week ended June 17.

Sales of the Chrysler Corporation and its wholly owned United States subsidiaries in the first six months of 1953 were the highest for any half-year period. And although taxes were $13,750,000 larger, net income increased to $44,136,903 from $43,689,486 a year ago.

The Cities Service Company, one of the nation's largest petroleum and gas companies, reported yesterday that its consolidated net income for the first six months of this year amounted to $28,384,862 after all expenses, taxes and other charges, compared with $27,120,714 in the first half of 1952.

Today's new film is "City That Never Sleeps," a Republic melodrama with Gig Young, Mala Powers, William Talman, Edward Arnold, Chill Wills and Marie Windsor in the principal roles, at the Palace. Steve Fisher wrote the scenario and John H. Auer served as associate producer-director.
In the Korean prisoner-of-war exchange reported last night five of New York's sons turned up among the eighty-one newly freed Americans.

On a day so hot that even the fireweed was drooping the head of the house decided to paint the place. This was midsummer, mind; this also was the clearest recorded case of seasonal madness, since painting the outside of the house had never before occurred to him.

ANGLERS of the New York Athletic Club, spurred by Mrs. Russell MacGrotty's 646-pound giant tuna catch off Nebraska Shoal last Tuesday from her own boat, the Tumult, are burning the wires to Trip Chairmen Lewis Iandoli and Bill Zehner making reservations for the club's tuna and marlin expedition to Montauk Point next week.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 (AP) -- Senator Edwin C. Johnson, Democrat of Colorado, assailed today a report by the Senate Small Business Committee on the problems of nonscheduled airlines. He said those airlines "killed over seven times as many passengers per passenger mile as did our certificated carriers."

Bradbury, Sayles O'Neill, Inc, publishers of college yearbooks, floor in 219 E 44th St through Robert Joseph Co, Inc; Nichols Associates, Inc, real estate brokers, in 441 Lexington Ave; American Machine Foundry Co, additional space in 511 5th Ave -- Cushman Wakefield, Inc, brokers.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 6 (AP) -- Dick Haymes was arrested today for deportation to his native Argentina. The 34-year-old singer was accused by immigration authorities of illegal re-entry into this country June 1.
The shoe was on the other foot for a change yesterday when a commuter -- and not the Long Island Rail Road -- caused a delay.
DES MOINES, Aug 6 (AP) -- A plan which will put the Misco Precision Casting Company, which makes small castings, into the soap business, was approved today by Federal District Judge William F. Riley.

The Western Union Telegraph Company had a net income of $4,417,378, or $3.59 a common share, in the first six months of this year, after provision of $4,773,000 for Federal income taxes, Walter P. Marshall, president, reported yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 (UP) -- Frank (Spec) Shea gained his ninith victory of the season today when he pitched a steady six-hitter as the Senators beat Cleveland's Bob Feller, 4 -- 1.

CHICAGO, Aug. 6 -- All through the Giants' losing streak, Leo Durocher insisted that one little break would straighten things out. That break was a long time coming, but when it materialized in the eighth inning against the Cubs at Wrigley Field today, the longest string of reversals by the Giants this season was snapped with a 12-6 triumph over the Windy City outfit.

CHICAGO, Aug. 6 -- Concern over the increasingly disturbing rust reports from the Northwest -- and the announcement late yesterday that the Government would relax its loan requirements for lightweight spring wheat damaged by rust -- started wheat off on a fractionally higher basis here today.

In the peace and beauty of the Berkshire Hills at Canaan, N. Y., a new way of life, rich in interest and in promise, opens up for troubled boys through the work of the Berkshire Industrial Farm. For sixty-seven years the Farm has helped hundreds of boys from broken homes or otherwise in need of aid to find their way to rewarding, useful citizenship.

Portfolios of prints of famed monastery paintings in Japan, which were largely destroyed by fire in 1949, have been received by 240 universities, colleges and schools here, the gift of 220 Japanese institutions of higher education.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Aug. 6 -- A two-day southwest rain has brought death and misery among 75,000 homeless refugees in this seaport capital city and disrupted the life of its 2,000,000 inhabitants.

Iron gates at both ends of Ardlea Court, Fifty-first Street and Third Avenue, soon will clang shut for the last time and a quaint byway with the charm of Dickens' London will be replaced by a modern garage.

Alexander Smith Sons Carpet Company has sold thirteen buildings in its plant in Yonkers, N. Y., to the Larno Realty Corporation of New York, whose principals are Martin Fleishman, manufacturer of advertising displays, and Morris Posner, realty operator.

A troubled conscience over damage done to city lifeguard boats at Jacob Riis Park in the Rockaways, Queens, caused two new $100 notes to be added to the municipal coffers yesterday. It was the largest single "conscience" contribution anyone on the Municipal Building staff of City Collector Alexander E. Frontera could remember.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- The State Department notified Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, chairman of the Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations today that it was issuing a passport to William Putnam Bundy, an official of the Central Intelligence Agency, to permit him to spend a vacation abroad.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- Theodore C. Streibert assumed direction of the new United States Information Agency today, and, according to an aide, would like to build up the confidence of Congress and the public in the project.

SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., Aug. 6 -- Mervyn Rose of Australia was eliminated from the Eastern grass court tennis championship today and Victor Seixas lost the opening set to Gilbert Shea before he was able to win at 2 -- 6, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 3 in a bitterly close fight almost to the end.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 6 -- Significant shifts in the pattern of world trade since 1937, detailed in a series of tables in the August edition of the United Nations Monthly Bulletin of Statistics, released today, reveal a drop in exports from the rest of the world to Communist China, despite rises registered in its trade with a number of countries.
CINCINNATI, Aug. 6 (UP) -- Mike Sandlock, dropped to ninth in the Pirates' batting order, today scored a key run in the eighth and sent home the winning tally in the ninth beat the Redlegs, 4 -- 3.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 6 -- Out of the conferences just concluded between studio and New York executives of Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer has come a decision to cut back on the company's production of so-called "in between" pictures, made at a moderate price, and to concentrate on the making of potential blue chip winners.

William A. Kielmann, chairman of the executive committee and a director of Meadow Brook National Bank, has resigned, effective Dec. 1, it was announced yesterday by August B. Weller, president of the Nassau County, L. I., institution.

MAMARONECK, N. Y., Aug. 6 -- Leading the field of one hundred duos today in the seventeenth annual John G. Anderson Memorial golf tournament were the teams of Don Cherry, 1953 Walker Cup squad member, and Frank Strafaci, representing Garden City Country Club, and Lloyd Ribner and Bill Mangin of Aldecress.

BLOCK ISLAND, R. I., Aug. 6 -- Viking, Carl Hovgard's 45-foot sloop; Thirsty Major, Edward Harrington's staysail schooner, and Sprill, William Booth's thirty-square meter were the over-all winners as the American Yacht Club's annual invitation cruise ended today.

An amicable settlement of the dispute that has halted work in the Bethlehem Steel Company's Twenty-seventh Street, Brooklyn, shipyard for nine days appeared possible yesterday as injunctive proceedings were postponed.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- President Eisenhower returned to independent status today the Farm Credit Administration that Congress revamped in legislation designed to give farmers more control and more ownership of their credit institution.

We are all quick to denounce the Police Department when some bad apples are found in it. Police Commissioner Monaghan can point with justifiable pride these days to some excellent police work in cracking three recent murder cases. Two of these crimes were solved within a few days.

NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 6 -- The House of the People (Lower House of Parliament) today gave unanimous approval to legislation empowering the central Government to collect statistics from foreign-owned and foreign-controlled firms on the employment of Indian personnel and on trade with outside countries.

The price of spot copper on the London Metal Exchange closed yesterday at 217 1/2 a long ton asked, equal to about 27.19 cents a pound, compared with 212 1/2 or 26.56 cents on Wednesday, the first day of free copper trading since Aug. 31, 1939. Volume fell to 975 tons from Wednesday's 3,100.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 6 -- Sun Shower, a horse that hadn't won since he ran with a $5,500 claiming tag on him last August, bobbed up as the No. 1 cash-collector in the $8,925 Shillelah Steeplechase at the Saratoga race track today.

ROME, Aug. 6 -- In a pontifical letter addressed to Stephen Cardinal Wyszynski and to all other Polish Archbishops and Bishops, Pope Pius XII urged them and their faithful to remain united and steadfast in the face of the persecutions of which they are victims.

Walter Berger and Leo Bercow, operators, have purchased the six- story building with fifty-five apartments and eleven stores at 1229 Franklin Avenue in the Bronx from Sanford Chobol and James J. Navone, who acquired it in a court sale last February.

TOKYO, Friday, Aug. 7 -- The Communists indicated today that they might not return all of the 12,763 United Nations prisoners they had disclosed they were holding for exchange at Panmunjom under the Korean truce agreement.

For those who live on salads when the temperatures go up, shrimp is a good taste-tempter. The Fishery Council reports that in one day this week more than 100,000 pounds of shrimp were received at local markets. Added to the nearly 1,000,000 pounds of frozen shrimp already purchased for retail distribution, the new shipments offer an abundance of the shellfish.
STAMFORD, Conn., Aug. 6 -- Life begins at 80 in more ways than one for Stamford's Fire Chief, Victor Veit.

The Federal Bureau of Investigation and the New York State Labor Department began investigations yesterday of complaints that twenty-two adolescent boys had been virtually abducted from Brooklyn to harvest crops in upstate New York under peonage conditions.

TOPEKA, Kans., Aug. 6 -- Harold R. Fatzer, Attorney General of Kansas, said today he had decided "not to prosecute C. Wesley Roberts for failing to register as a lobbyist for Cities Service Gas Company during the 1951 session" of the Kansas Legislature.

The Citizens Union announced yesterday its approval of the proposed amendment to the State Constitution increasing the limit on taxation of real property in New York City from 2 to 2 1/2 per cent. Though the amendment does not affect the rest of the state, it must be adopted by a state-wide vote.

GREAT RIVER, L. I., Aug. 6 -- Ralph Cameron's. Shimmy-She-Wabble made it two in a row today in the Star Class competition for the Corry Trophy. The Corry series is being run as a part of the Great South Bay Yacht Racing Association's thirty-eighth regatta off Timber Point here.
