In an unusual gesture of cooperation between private business interests and the city government, the merchants and other commercial groups along the Avenue of the Americas are raising a fund of about $50,000 to install a new lighting system along twenty-five blocks of their avenue.

Claude G. Bowers, diplomat and scholar, who has been United States Ambassador to Chile since 1939 and served with distinction as Ambassador to Spain for six years before that, is about to retire from the diplomatic service. His successor in Santiago has just been named, and Mr. Bowers will return soon from the lovely capital where he was nearly as well known as the Chilean President himself.

Louis J. Glickman, who took title to the office building at 42 Broadway, near Morris Street, as the result of a recent purchase from Charles F. Noyes and Duncan M. Findlay, announced yesterday that he had resold it to an investor in a deal negotiated by L. V. Hoffman Co., brokers.

E. F. O'Callaghan has been appointed eastern district sales manager of Devoe and Raynolds Company, Inc., paints, and Charles B. Moore has been named manager of the industrial maintenance division in Louisville, Ky.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended Aug. 1 totaled 793,754 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.

Chief Magistrate John M. Murtagh imposed yesterday a thirty- day workhouse sentence and a $1,000 fine on a Bronx butcher who had failed to answer summonses for twenty traffic violations, one dating from 1948.
No doubt Joseph A. Dietrich, Greenwich's tree warden, is right to have hazardous trees removed and pruned, as reported in THE TIMES of Aug. 3.

CHICAGO, Aug. 6 (AP) -- Lew (The Chin) Worsham of Oakmont, Pa., pitted Tam O'Shanter's rain-softened greens with deadly approaches today to score a seven-under-par 65 and flash to the front in the first round of the $75,000 "world" golf championship, the richest tournament in history.

SEATTLE, Aug. 7 (AP) -- Don Cockell of London, bleeding and apparently on the road to defeat, suddenly found the target in the ninth round tonight and smashed Harry (Kid) Matthews of Seattle to the canvas three time to win a ten-round split decision.

President Eisenhower in his "Report to the Nation" did two somewhat different things. He summarized what he regarded as the major accomplishments of the first six months of his Administration and put them into proper perspective. He also repeated his firm declaration of principles, and in so doing he was not merely reporting to his own fellow-citizens but also addressing the whole world.
The cotton futures market here closed barely steady yesterday, 6 to 12 points lower than on Thursday.

ANCHORAGE, Alaska, Aug. 7 -- The Alaska Railroad, owned and operated by the Department of the Interior, runs nearer the Arctic Circle than any other American railroad. It is the department's only line -- except for five miles of track on an Illinois game refuge -- and it has no competitors in its service terrain.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- At the request of the Treasury Department, Attorney General Herbert Brownell Jr. has ordered the Federal Bureau of Investigation to look into the payment of a $65,000 fee by William E. Lasdon of Yonkers, N. Y., to Welburn Mayock, a Washington lawyer, for getting a favorable ruling in a tax case.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (AP) -- Federal agents have been struggling for more than a year to dam a persistent flow of narcotics from Communist China to the United States West Coast via Hong Kong.
Trading volume continued light on the New York Commodity Exchange yesterday and prices were mixed.

Everywhere, it seems, the hapless pedestrian is admonished to "cross crossings cautiously" and to take extreme care in jousting with onrushing traffic in the roadways, but only once in a while is the citizen on foot told exactly what he should do. Now the city, we are pleased to note, is working on a project designed to give the pedestrian more tangible help.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 7 (AP) -- Alex Kellner pitched the Athletics to a seven-hit, 3-1 victory tonight over the Tigers at Connie Mack Stadium.

BONN, Aug. 7 -- The United States High Commissioner's Office in Germany announced today that it would reduce immediately the strength of American personnel from 950 to 775 and the strength of German personnel from 5,400 to 4,700. The reduction, it was said, was the result of the Congressional cut of $7,200,000 in the Government of occupied area's budget for the current year.

Letters from home are more important than ever, to prevent sagging of morale among service men and women anticipated in the wake of the Korean truce, speakers said yesterday at a "Note From a Neighbor" luncheon at the Stork Club.

A fast-moving bandit, who is alleged to have held up four hotels in thirty-five minutes by speeding up and down Broadway shortly after 5 A. M. yesterday, was arrested when he pressed his luck too far.

Thirty-four large forgings, some of them weighing as much as twenty-six tons, are being produced in the Bethlehem, Pa., plant of the Bethlehem Steel Company for the 60,000-ton aircraft carrier Saratoga, it was announced by the company yesterday. The forgings include three main propeller shafts, sixty-seven feet long and about a foot in diameter, other shafts, spacers, inboard couplings, collars, and nuts.

Since Carl Ross in his letter published on Aug. 2 introduced into the discussion of agricultural surpluses his observation of West German problems, I think that a consideration of Canadian experience, more closely related to the American scene, seems to be appropriate.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 7 -- Ninety-six finalist contract bridge pairs, out of a starting field of 228, this afternoon played the first of three final sessions for the 1953 national masters pairs championship. Play in the event will continue for two more sessions here.

SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., Aug. 7 -- On a day of disaster for United States tennis, Victor Seixas suffered his first defeat today since his crowning at Wimbledon as the three top Americans were engulfed in an Australian sweep in the Eastern grass court championships.

OCEANPORT, N. J., Aug. 7 (AP) -- Jockey Sammy Boulmetis, leading rider at Monmouth Park this season, completed a consecutive triple today by booting home George D. Widener's 17-to-10 Scent in the Park Ridge Rotary feature purse before a crowd of 24,248. The wagering totaled $2,226,816.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 7 -- Maybe, if all goes well, the horse race of the year -- Greentree Stable's Tom Fool vs. Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt's Native Dancer -- will be run at Belmont Park over the one-mile course on Sept. 26. That's the No. 1 item of turf news from Saratoga today.

BEDMINSTER, N. J., Aug. 7 (AP) -- State Senator Malcolm S. Forbes, Republican of Somerset, and four others from New Jersey have bucked rain, fog and rough seas to complete what they believe to be the first cruise to Labrador in a forty-two-foot pleasure craft.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- The new Select Committee that the House of Representatives recently created to make a second investigation within two years into expenditures by tax-exempt educational and philanthropic foundations, met today.

PARIS, Aug. 7 -- Massive reductions in the national deficit will be necessary to save French economy and to prevent a new decline in the standing of French currency, Wilfrid Baumgartner, Governor of the Bank of France, declared in his annual report to President Vincent Auriol today.

A plan to move butter out of the warehouse and onto the table was advanced yesterday by a dairy industry group. Their proposal, to be presented on Monday before a Department of Agriculture "task force conference'' in Washington, calls for the Government to continue buying butter at the present market support price of about 67 cents wholesale, but to sell it to wholesalers and distributors at 50 to 52 cents a pound.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- The American Civil Liberties Union urged President Eisenhower today to veto a bill that would confer upon five states jurisdiction over Indians in criminal and civil actions arising on Indian reservations in the states.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 7 (AP) -- The president of Studebaker Corporation says the 6,000,000 cars the auto industry expects to produce this year can be sold, but salesmen will have to use "pre-war initiative" to do it. The car market is getting back to normal and the day of telephone sales is over, H. S. Vance told a group of his sales executives here yesterday.
OTTAWA, Aug. 6 -- All over Canada's northern wastes thousands of Eskimo families will be on the move this week-end in an unusual migration.
TOKYO, Saturday, Aug. 8 -- The fourth day's exchange of United Nations and Communist prisoners of the Korean war was carried out in a smooth routine at Panmunjom today.

LONDON, Aug. 7 -- A long step toward agreement was taken unexpectedly today at the conference of delegates from the British West African colony of Nigeria who have been meeting here since last week to draft a new Constitution for their country.
PARIS, Saturday, Aug. 8 -- Almost every public service in France was still crippled today by one of the most effective strikes in recent French history.
The following is a round-up of new products for children that may be of interest to homemakers:

LONDON, Aug. 7 -- After four days of steadily rising prices, the stock market here finished the week on a less buoyant note today. Some profit-taking sales caused fluctuations in issues that recently have been in strong demand. However, apart from British Government securities, which recorded slight declines, losses were generally wiped out by the close and modest gains predominated.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (AP) -- The Association of American Railroads today estimated the net income of Class 1 carriers at $418,000,000 for the first six months of this year, $108,000,000 higher than in the same period last year.

MILWAUKEE, Aug. 7 -- The Veterans of Foreign Wars, ending their fifty-fourth annual encampment here today, elected Wayne E. Richards of Arkansas City, Kan., commander in chief. He was unopposed, as was Merton B. Tice, a Municipal Judge in Mitchell, S. D., who was elected senior vice commander to succeed him.

With 53,000,000 American consumers now over 40 years of age, and the greatest population increase during the next ten years expected in those over 60, advertising people are beginning to take notice of more than just the well-publicized youth market. This is the word from Lifetime Living magazine, which has initiated a new campaign calling attention to the "Mature Third" of America.
OLD SAYBROOK, Conn., Aug. 7 -- A new ferry service across Long Island Sound between the Connecticut and Long Island shores will be inaugurated tomorrow with civic ceremonies here.

Cheered by President Eisenhower's clear indication in his achievement repot that he would sign the Customs Simplification Bill, importers here prepared yesterday for the new procedure covering entry of foreign goods.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 7 -- Lieut. Gen. H. S. Aurand, retired former commander of the United States Army in the Pacific, proposed the following rule today to guide diplomats in wartime:

ZURICH, Switzerland, Aug. 7 -- Calculations made in the United States "show definitely that rockets can be shot into the satellite orbit using propellent combinations which are not only available but which have been thoroughly tried on the test stand." Members of the American Rocket Society announced today in a paper presented to the final session of the Astronautical Congress.

OSLO, Aug. 7 (UP) -- America's touring track and field stars won seven of ten events tonight to finish with fourteen victories in the eighteen contests of a two-day meet among athletes from seven countries. The United States trackmen won seven of the eight events yesterday.

TRENTON, Aug. 7 -- Chester K. Ligham, Director of the State Office of Rent Control, urged county rent agencies and review boards today to expedite processing of all applications on which the Federal Office of Rent Stabilization had failed to complete action before it went out of existence.
There were no decisive steps yesterday in the direction of settling the long strike of concrete truck drivers but two developments raised hopes somewhat that an agreement might come next week.

Objects made in Denmark, a country noted for its contributions to contemporary design, are included in the many additions to a group of European, Victorian-age home accessories on view at Bamberger's in Newark.

BOSTON, Aug. 7 (AP) -- Although he battled in three runs himself, Lefty Mel Parnell needed almost a baseball miracle to gain his first Fenway Park decision over the Indians in almost four seasons tonight by a 4-2 margin. A brilliant relief stint by Ellis Kinder and a spectacular defensive play by right fielder Jim Piersall insured Parnell's fifteenth victory against seven losses.
The annual hymn sing of Christ Church on Quaker Hill, Pawling, N. Y., will be conducted at 5 P. M. tomorrow in Akin Hall on a crest overlooking the Harlem Valley.

The recent controversy with respect to trading with our enemies in Communist China on the part of Great Britain, as well as the indignation that this event has aroused in the Senate, brings to mind an episode in our own history that may be illuminating.

GENEVA, Aug. 7 -- Dr. Nahum Goldmann, acting president of the World Jewish Congress, issued a statement here today clarifying his position on the relationship of Jews outside Israel to the state of Israel.

Depending on who was talking, there was a complete difference of opinion yesterday on whether Anthony (Tough Tony) Anastasia, Brooklyn waterfront boss, had agreed to turn over the books of his Local 327-1 to the parent International Longshoremen's Association, A. F. L.

PANMUNJOM, Saturday, Aug. 8 (UP) -- Ninety jubilant American soldiers came through Freedom Gate today. Twenty-five hale and hearty British soldiers, thirty-five Turks and 250 South Koreans also passed from captivity through the exchange machinery at this buffer zone village.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (AP) -- The Reconstruction Finance Corporation announced today it will close twenty-four branch offices on Sept. 28.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- Average primary market prices declined 0.2 per cent during the week ended on Tuesday, to 110.3 per cent of the 1947-49 level, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 7 -- perceptible upturn in actual filming of pictures here, as distinguished from preparation of screen plays for future use, is now in evidence. Barring unforeseen delays, and counting some carry-over filming activity from last month, a total of forty-four features will be "on camera" during August.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (AP) -- A Senate Armed Services subcommittee will visit Spain next month, thus furnishing what is considered another indication that the United States may be close to an agreement for the building of air bases on the Iberian Peninsula.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- Attorney General Herbert Brownell Jr. said today that he would go to California next week to study the "wetback" problem.

It is understandable why a great institution like THE TIMES views with pain the transformation of Times Square into a honky-tonk row. But are you not sighing over changes bound to occur in a metropolis so vast ?

PORTLAND, Ore., Aug. 7 (AP) -- Carolyn Green, 19-year-old University of Miami student, broke the world record for the mile tonight in winning that event at the women's National Amateur Athletic Union outdoor swimming championships.
MUNSAN, Korea, Saturday, Aug. 8 (AP) -- The United Nations Command's official list of United States prisoners of war freed today in the armistice exchange:

Why is "The Compleat Angler" still read three centuries -- to the year -- since that quaint and often prosy book first appeared? To tell the truth, many a reader -- angler or not -- has failed to get by "First Day," chapter one of this work, and has gone through life wondering why the book and the name of its author have survived three hundred years.

FREEDOM VILLAGE, Korea, Saturday Aug. 8 (AP) -- A released American war prisoner said today he felt the Chinese Communists encouraged the use of a weed, possibly marijuana, to win over some captives to Communism.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 7 -- Stockholders of Flying Tiger Lines, Inc., and Slick Airways, Inc., the two largest air freight carriers, at separate special meetings here yesterday approved the merger of the two companies, according to announcements by Robert W. Prescott, president of Flying Tigers, and Thomas L. Grace, president of Slick.

Parents of 10 to 12-year-old children attending the Lake Play School at Public School 19 in Corona, Queens, were entertained this week at a luncheon prepared and served at the school by their youngsters.

Tammany Assembly District leaders supporting Mayor Impellitteri for the Democratic nomination for Mayor asserted yesterday they had obtained the signatures of more than a majority of the district leaders to a petition calling for a meeting of the Tammany executive committee.
Paul Richards and his White Sox came charging into the Stadium yesterday determined to make a stand of it in the American League flag race. But they did not remain erect for long.
Hume Cronyn, who starred with his wife, Jessica Tandy, in "The Fourposter" for a total of seventy-seven weeks in New York and on the road, is considering two directorial assignments for this season.

BLOOMFIELD, N. J., Aug. 7 -- The one-foot shot fired yesterday by Al Ross, a 32-year-old machinist, won New Jersey division honors in the twentieth annual World-Telegram and Sun hole-in-one tournament, which concluded today at the same Forest Hill Field Club after a breezy day of hitting by 148 contestants.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (AP) -- The Chilean Government has formally asked the United States to buy about 65,000 tons of its copper for this country's strategic stockpile at the world market price. Chilean Ambassador Anibal Jara announced that the offer had been made to the Department of State.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Aug. 7 (AP) -- The Ohio Turnpike Commission approved traffic and engineering studies today of a proposed new $400,000,000 turnpike to run from Cincinnati to northeast Ohio and a juncture with a New York-Pennsylvania superhighway.
Two hold-ups in Brooklyn yesterday netted $10,200 for pistol-toting thugs who escaped in waiting automobiles.

LENOX, Mass., Aug. 7 -- Charles Munch and the Boston Symphony Orchestra began tonight their second week-end of Berkshire Music Festival concerts with a performance of Berlioz' dramatic Symphony, "Romeo et Juliette:"

The Municipal Civil Service Commission's reclassification unit is now sending out multi-page questionnaires to employe groups and bureau heads. I should like to sound a note of warning concerning this questionnaire.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (AP) -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon today named ten Senators as members of two major study commissions set up at the 1953 session of Congress.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., Aug. 7 -- Jack Brittain Sr. of the Hempstead Golf Club scored 40, 38 -- 78 to win the low gross prize in the Long Island Senior Golf Association one-day medal play tournament at the Garden City Country Club today.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 7 -- The 550 striking ready-mix concrete truck drivers, whose twelve-week walkout has tied up $75,000,000 worth of construction and has forced about 24,000 other American Federation of Labor craftsmen into idleness, voted today to reject arbitration of their labor dispute.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (AP) -- President Eisenhower signed today a bill creating a commission to study the question of salary rises for members of Congress and Federal judges.
We do not have the habit of writing to papers, but in these difficult moments you will perhaps be interested in what the feeling is here.

LINDEN, N. J., Aug. 7 -- Management representatives of the Linden division of General Motors Corporation and leaders of Local 595, United Automobile Workers, C. I. O., reached a tentative agreement at 6 o'clock tonight on a production - standards dispute, which for a time threatened another strike at the huge assembly plant.

The strike of dock workers of the International Longshoremen's Association, A. F. L. against ships of Moore-McCormack Lines, Inc., continued yesterday, its fourth day, without any prospect of settlement.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- President Eisenhower signed a bill today extending the reciprocal trade program to next June 12 and said that it would "provide a breathing space" to develop a more adequate policy.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- The State Department has approached approximately sixteen or seventeen countries on the subject of a state visit by Vice President Nixon, as a personal representative of President Eisenhower. His tour is expected to start after Oct. 1.
NORFOLK, Va., Aug. 7 (AP) -- The Pentagon got an unexpected dunking the other day.

MAMARONECK, N. Y., Aug. 7 -- While the co-medalists were winning, the chief upset of the two rounds of the seventeenth John G. Anderson memorial tourney at the Winged Foot Golf Club today was being scored by Art Lynch and John J. Smith of the home club.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 7 (UP) -- The Monsanto Chemical Company said today that a tax arrangement involving the rebuilding of its Texas City, Tex., plant "constituted compliance, absolute and literal" with United States Treasury regulations.
SALEM, Mass., Aug. 7 (UP) -- A retired Army officer and big-game hunter has bequeathed $700,000 to the Boston Museum of Science on the condition that it exhibit his weapons and trophies.
Twenty emergency freighters now in service for the Military Sea Transportation Service are to be returned to lay-up status, it was announced yesterday.
CHICAGO, Aug. 7 (AP) -- A new "deep sleep" treatment for epilepsy that worked when standard therapy failed was reported by two California physicians.

MILWAUKEE, Aug. 7 (AP) -- Vern Bickford tossed a five-hitter tonight in his first start since June 24 as the Braves beat the Pirates 9 -- 2, and stayed seven and a half games behind Brooklyn in the National League race.

Plans for a new housing development called Bruce Village in Westwood, N. J., were announced yesterday in connection with the purchase by Michael Montalbano, builder, of land on Emwood Avenue, near Lincoln Boulevard and Fourth Avenue. The buyer intends to erect twenty dwellings, ten of which will comprise the first Section.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 7 (UP) -- The Secretary of Labor, Martin P. Durkin, today predicted Congressional approval of "substantial" changes in the Taft-Hartley act that would be "more likable to representatives of organized labor."

TRIESTE, Aug. 7 -- Demonstrations and hints of violence against two more Yugoslav Roman Catholic bishops have been reported in the Government's drive to set up the Patriotic Priests Associations in Croatia.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- A humanitarian device patented this week enables a dental patient to signal "Ouch!" even though his jaws are propped open and his mouth is filled with cotton and machinery. With a push on a switch, he at once cautions the dentist and shuts off the drill.

A one-story dwelling at 27-09 Little Neck Boulevard, in Bayside, Queens, has been sold by Peter Perpignano to John Karnig, who insured title with the Title Guarantee and Trust Company. The Tortora Agency was the broker.
ROME, Aug. 7 (AP) -- Italians have more money put away in savings and checking accounts now than at any other time in the nation's financial history.

Sterling Drug, Inc., and its subsidiaries attained the highest sales for a half-year period in the first six months this year and increased earnings 17.1 per cent over the corresponding period of 1952, according to the report issued yesterday by James Hill Jr., chairman and president.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (AP) -- Chairman Jesse P. Wolcott, Republican of Michigan, of the House Banking Committee, said today the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation is stronger than ever before -- and the nation's banking system "never has better served the credit needs of our driving economy."

The cabaret license of the Three Deuces Club, 72 West Fifty-second Street, was suspended yesterday by fourth deputy Police Commissioner George P. Mitchell, pending a hearing Tuesday afternoon of charges involving violations of police regulations.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 7 -- President Getulio Vargas today held the first full meeting of his Cabinet as reorganized in June. At its close a communique was issued to reassure the Brazilian people of the Government's intention to maintain the present regime and to abide by the Constitution.
CHICAGO, Aug. 7 (AP) -- The Phillies needed just two big innings to defeat the Cubs for the thirteenth time in fourteen games, 5 -- 4, before 4,499 today.
Emil A. Mesics has been appointed director of personnel of the RCA International division of Radio Corporation of America.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (AP) -- Chico Marrero held the Browns to three hits tonight as the Senators blasted three pitchers for a 12-0 victory on an eleven-hit attack that included Clyde Vollmer's seventh homer.

ANKARA, Turkey, Aug. 7 -- The captain of a Greek gunboat and his radio officer, arrested Wednesday by Turkish authorities at Fethiye for allegedly having dishonored the Turkish flag, have been released and have returned to the island of Rhodes.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Aug. 7 -- Claims by Danes to be the first to scrape primitive forms of life from the marine floor of the world, a feat they accomplished six miles down in the Philippine Trench of the Pacific, have been challenged by Russian oceanologists present at the International Congress of Zoology here.

New York State's law on sex were termed "ridiculous" and "unenforceable" by a lawyer who told a New York University institute on modern law enforcement methods law enforcement methods yesterday that "antiquated" statutes were undermining efforts of authorities to control offenders.

The role of the Roman Catholic Church in secular, political and social movements is the subject of an anthology scheduled for Sept. 21 publication by Arts, Inc. The volume will be titled "Church and Society: Catholic Social and Political Thought and Movements, 1789-1950."

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 7 -- Gen. Mark W. Clark said today that any formal demand for an investigation of the fate of United States prisoners who may be illegally detained by the Communists must wait until the current prisoner exchange is completed.

Sound-proof parkways and expressways, with nerve-racking traffic noises reduced to harmonious undertone in adjacent residential areas, were envisioned yesterday from research data supplied by Robert Moses, City Construction Coordinator, and Wilbur H. Simonson, Bureau of Public Roads, United States Department of Commerce.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- President Eisenhower signed into law today the appropriation bill providing $6,652,422,390 for military, economic and technical assistance in the current fiscal year to help free governments in resisting Communist aggression and subversion.

" THREE GREAT IRISHMEN,"* by Arland Ussher, is a brilliant triple-portrait of James Joyce, George Bernard Shaw and William Butler Yeats. Having beer educated at Trinity College, Dublin, and Cambridge University, England, Mr. Ussher now lives in Dublin, where his Ascendancy family is rounding out the first thousand years of its Irish visit.

MONTAUK, L. I., Aug. 7 -- In the old days, nearly everybody in almost every little town went to the railroad station to see the evening train come in. Perhaps they still do in some places. But, here in Montauk, everybody goes down to the docks to see what the fishing boats have brought. How many and what kind and how big.

A new laudable social welfare enterprise in Brooklyn -- a group to be known as the Brooklyn Association for Rehabilitation of Offenders -- will seek to provide facilities for the study, treatment and rehabilitation of offenders, to conduct research toward the prevention of crime and delinquency and to train psychiatrists, psychologists, social workers and other personnel in the technique of treatment of offenders.

TOKYO, Saturday, Aug. 8 (UP) -- The Pyongyang radio in its account of the "purge trial" alleged that the accused officials had been directed in their "spying" by a United States State Department man in South Korea named "Noble."

KNOB LAKE, Que, Aug 2 -- Some freak of nature duplicated Minnesota's Mesabi Range up here in the grim wastes of the Labrador-Quebec line, and such is now the insatiable thirst for iron ore that Canadians and Americans have come here to get it.

ANKARA, Turkey, Aug. 7 -- Foreign trade officials here are highly gratified by results of the prolonged trade negotiations with West Germany that resulted in the signing last night in Bonn of an agreement calling for the export of $140,000,000 worth of Turkish cereals, tobacco, cotton, dried fruits and minerals in the coming year in return for an equal value of German machinery, industrial equipment and other manufactured goods.

Earnings of the New York Telephone Company, largest operating unit in the Bell System, were $2.21 a common share in the second quarter of 1953, a decline of 41 cents from the $2.62 a share earned in the second quarter of last year, Keith S. McHugh, president, announced yesterday.

LONDON, Aug. 7 (Reuters) -- The Australian cricket tourists, left with 170 minutes to score 166 runs for victory, were forced to play defensively and hit only 53 for the loss of five wickets against Warwickshire today.

Howard Reed, Allan Kosh and Irving S. Schwimmer are among the latest buyers of homes at Stratton Heights, a new community of private dwellings being erected by Ben Okun Associates, builders, at Baraud Road and Puritan Drive, in the Wilmot Woods section of New Rochelle, Westchester County.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (UP) -- Industry leaders said they hoped to get color TV sets into mass production in six to nine months and the National Broadcasting Company and Columbia Broadcasting System said they planned to start color broadcasts "right away" after the F. C. C. ruling was final.

Winter cottons are the newest of the "old" fabrics for fall. In the fashion world, where last season is as remote as Caesar, year-round cottons are not new, being about four years old. But the imagination and styling that many cotton houses are bringing to this established fiber give it a life and vitality that would not be expected of a fabric as old as history.

Immigration authorities, acting on orders by the Department of State, revoked the passport of Joseph Starobin, European editor of The Daily Worker, Communist newspaper, on his return by plane from Europe Thursday to New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens.
The experience of your correspondent Helen P. Long must indeed have been exceptional to have caused her to write to you so disparagingly of the manners of New Yorkers.

CHICAGO, Aug. 7 -- Drastic declines in wheat futures marked trading here today. Heavy selling followed reports that the nation's wheat growers might not ratify the market quota plans for 1954 which will be voted upon next Friday.

With hardly a single security group moving concertedly in one direction, the New York Stock Exchange churned quietly yesterday. THE NEW YORK TIMES averages registered a minor recession -- only the second since July 27 -- but more stocks rose than fell by a small margin.

The State of Oregon sold at public bidding yesterday $32,000,000 of state highway, series B, direct obligation bonds due from 1954 to 1966 at a net interest cost of 2.3202 per cent. A group headed by Kuhn, Loeb Co. and Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., submitted the winning bid of 98.517 for a combination of 1 1/2's, 1 3/4's, 2's and 2 1/4's.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7, (AP) -- Following is the text of a statement by President Eisenhower in connection with the signing of a bill to admit 214,000 refugees and other aliens during the next three years:

SEATTLE, Aug. 7 (AP) -- Paul Sawyer, Rochester, N. Y., speedboat driver who was discharged this week as pilot of the world record-holding Slo-mo-shun IV today sued Stanley S. Sayres, owner of the Slo-mo, for $12,000.

HAGERSTOWN, Md., Aug. 7 (AP) -- Representative Clare E. Hoffman, Republican of Michigan, was found guilty today of speeding east of Hagerstown April 2 and fined the minimum of $10 and costs by Magistrate William E. Kreykenbohm.

BERLIN, Aug. 7 -- The Government of East Germany, grappling with widespread unrest and with the Western program of distributing food gifts to its residents, has rejected a West German offer to sell it $6,000,000 worth of food on the ground that the terms of sale were unacceptable.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (AP) -- Following are the texts of the draft of the mutual defense treaty between the United States and the Republic of Korea, initialed in Seoul, and of the Dulles-Rhee statement:
ARDMORE, Okla., Aug. 7 (AP) -- Tom Frost, who started sailing a year ago, today won the senior trophy in the national championship Snipe Regatta to give him a sweep of the races.
CINCINNATI, Aug. 7 -- Neither the rain nor the Redlegs could stop the Dodgers tonight, the Brooks taking the series opener by a 9-4 score before 13,756 damp customers at Crosley Field.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 7 -- The Japan Transport, a 12,490-ton cargo-liner recently acquired by Pacific Transport Lines, is scheduled to leave tomorrow on her first trip to the Orient. The ship, of 3-C design and built in the Bay area by the Moore Dry Dock Company at a cost of more than $3,000,000, increases Pacific Transport's privately owned fleet to six 12,000-ton cargo-liners.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (AP) -- Senator Herbert H. Lehman, Democrat of New York, declared today that the record of the Republican-controlled Eighty-third Congress in the session just completed was a total blank on civil rights legislation.

NORTH HAVEN, Me., Aug. 7 -- Nimrod V, a 55-foot cutter belonging to Robert L. Hall of Huntington, L. I., came alongside the committee boat in the early evening while homeward bound with a question, "How did we make out today?"

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Aug. 7 -- It has often seemed in the last thirteen months that this city, founded by the French Huguenots on land acquired from Sir John Pell, would fail in the 1688 promise to deliver a "fatt calfe" to Sir John's descendants each spring as perpetual payment for the property.

DETROIT, Aug. 7 (AP) -- General Motors today moved to enter the off-the-road heavy truck field by authorizing an exchange of its common stock for all outstanding preferred and Class A stock of the Euclid Road Machinery Company.

GLEN COVE, L. I., Aug. 7 -- Unseeded Darlene Hard of Montebello, Calif., made her first tournament in the East a winning one by defeating first-seeded Mary Ann Eilenberger of San Diego, Calif., 8 -- 6, 7 -- 5, in today's final of the girl's Eastern grass court championships at the Nassau Country Club.

RANGOON, Burma, Aug. 7 -- U Tun Pe, Burma's Minister for Culture, has resigned effective next Wednesday because of differences with the Cabinet over the expenditure of $6,000,000 earmarked for holding the sixth Buddhist Synod in May, 1954.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (AP) -Senators James H. Duff and Edward Martin, both Republicans of Pennsylvania, today urged Army reconsideration of a gas mask contract they feel was awarded to the wrong company.

NAIROBI, Kenya, Aug. 7 (Reuters) -- Gen. Sir George Erskine, British commander in the fight against Kenya's anti-white Mau Mau terrorists, said today the time has come for the Kikuyu natives to "get off the fence" and choose sides.

Work was resumed yesterday afternoon at the Bethlehem Steel Company's shipyard at Twenty-seventh Street, Brooklyn, after a ten-day halt. An arrangement was reached between counsel for the Seafarers International Union, A. F. L., and the Valentine Chemical Corporation.

LOS ANGELES, Calif., Aug. 7 -- An offer to acquire the remaining outstanding common stock of Milliron's downtown Los Angeles department store, and at least 38,360 shares or 50 per cent of the outstanding preferred stock, has been made in a letter to stockholders by J. K. Ohrbach, president of Ohrbach's Inc., here today.

CHICAGO, Aug. 7 (AP) -- Ed (Porky) Oliver, shooting a 5-under-par 67, captured the halfway lead in the $75,000 "world" pro golf tourney today by two strokes at 135. Lew Worsham was next after posting three one-over-pars between the fourteenth and seventeenth holes for a 72 after yesterday's pace-setting 65.

SEOUL, Korea, Saturday, Aug. 8 -- John Foster Dulles, United States Secretary of State, and Pyun Yung Tai, South Korean Foreign Minister, initialed this morning the draft of a mutual defense agreement between South Korea and the United States.

The Soviet Government's new, more favorable attitude toward collective farmers' garden plots announced in Moscow last Wednesday appears to be the most significant shift in economic policy enunciated during the first five months of the post-Stalin regime.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- Officials of Federal agencies dealing with food and technical assistance forecast a further decline in agriculture productivity of the Soviet zone of Germany. The area has been gripped by unrest and is the object of an extensive campaign of food gifts from the West.

BADEN-BADEN, Germany, Aug. 7 -- The foreign ministers of the European coal and steel community nations convened here this afternoon in this once fashionable resort to continue their work of trying to create the machinery for a European political community.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- Frank E. Kalbaugh, superintendent of the Salt Lake Division of the Southern Pacific Railroad, today was named manager of the Alaska Railroad by the Department of the Interior.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (UP) -- The Air Force tonight disclosed the first non-stop jet flight across the Pacific and said the 1952 Mackay Trophy would be awarded to the commander of the plane.

TRENTON, Aug. 7 -- Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll, in a surprise move, has directed the heads of all state departments in New Jersey to see to it that all of their employes sign a long loyalty and anti-Communist oath as prescribed by a 1949 statute.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 7 -- Vinegar Bend Mizell, the Cardinals' lefthander, outpitched Ruben Gomez as the Giants dropped a 2-1 decision to Eddie Stanky's Redbirds tonight at Busch Stadium. Most times, the 7-hitter hurled by Gomez might have won, but tonight it was not quite good enough.

A plea for a new type of "churchmanship" that will extend its ministry to people "because they are people, rather than because they are black or white or yellow or rich or German or Swedish," was voiced yesterday by the Rev. Dr. William J. Villaume, executive director of the department of the urban church of the National Council of the Churches of Christ in the U. S. A.
The Raytheon Manufacturing Company plans to increase its authorized $5 par common from 3,000,000 to 4,000,000 shares, subject to stockholder approval at a special meeting called for Sept. 17.

NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 7 -- India and the Soviet Union have agreed in principle on a barter deal for exchanging Indian commodities for Russian wheat, Rafi Ahmed Kidwai, Minister of Food, announced in Parliament today. The agreement is to run for three years.
Blood collections in the city during the first four days of this month yielded only 1,120 pints toward the August quota of 15,000 pints set by the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (UP) -- S./Sgt Barbara O. Barnwell, a Marine who saved a fellow Leatherneck from drowning, received the Navy-Marine Corps Medal for Heroism today. She was the first woman to win the award.

In the chapel of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Incarnation yesterday afternoon, Miss Mary Louise Drechsel, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William E. Drechsel of 21 East Eighty-fourth Street was married to Lieut. Edwin Warfield Gramkow, U. S. A. F., son of Mrs. Emma Warfield McCormick of Oakhill, Glenwood, Howard County, Md., and the late Frank E. Gramkow of Wellesley, Mass.
The question of retirement can be linked with employment and should be an important concern of our Government.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (UP) -- President Eisenhower signed legislation today reaffirming the Federal Government's ownership of offshore oil lands in the outer Continental Shelf. The law establishes legal machinery for the Federal Government to lease these submerged lands to private industry.

LONDON, Saturday, Aug. 8 -- The Moscow radio announced today that death sentences had been imposed on ten top North Korean officials accused of plotting armed rebellion and spying for the United States and the South Korean Government of President Syngman Rhee.

When Gen. Mark W. Clark, just returned from signing the Korean armistice, faced the reporters at a news conference on Thursday he had had nearly forty years in the Army. At the relatively early age of 57 he had set next Oct. 31 as the date for his retirement.
NEWARK, Aug 7 -- A state-wide group of New Jersey business and professional leaders is being formed to support Paul L. Troast, Republican candidate for Governor.

New Yorkers who can't get away from the city for more than a short time this summer will find much to enjoy in the facilities provided right at home by the Department of Parks. During the hot and muggy dog days the more than sixteen miles of sandy public beaches and the seventeen outdoor swimming pools are most attractive.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- The Federal Communications Commission announced plans today to authorize a new compatible color television system that can be received in black and white on existing sets. Unless major objections are registered with the commission, it was said, the orders can be promulgated by the year's end and the system can be in operation conceivably by mid-1954.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (AP) --A new and expanded United States parole board of seven members was sworn in today at the office of Attorney General Herbert Brownell Jr.

BOSTON, Aug. 7 -- The Nursery Training School of Boston completed this week, as part of its summer school program, a workshop seminar for experienced teachers in the guidance of the handicapped child.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (AP) -- President Eisenhower made it official today: Ohio is a full-fledged member of the Union.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (UP) -- The Department of Justice said today it is conducting a "careful" investigation to determine whether gasoline companies violated anti-trust laws in a recent price increase.

MONTREAL, Aug. 7 (AP) -- Canada breezed through the opening Davis Cup singles against Cuba today, Henri Rochon and Lorne Main setting up a 2-0 lead with victories over the Garrido brothers, Reynaldo and Orlando.
SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., Aug. 7 (AP) -- The undercurrent of unrest in American tennis gained momentum today with a sharp split between the two young men the nation expects to bring back the Davis Cup.

GREENSBORO, N. C., Aug. 7 (UP) -- North Carolina State, one of the nation's top basketball powers, was placed on one year's probation today by the new Atlantic Coast Conference, which barred fourteen athletes permanently from intercollegiate competition.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 7 -- Following is the foreword to a special report of the Unified Command to the United Nations, transmitted to Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold by the United States Delegation to the United Nations:

EAST RUTHERFORD, N. J., Aug. 7 -- Four persons, including two small children, were seriously injured and several others required first aid this afternoon when a bus bound from New York City to Paterson, N. J., went out of control and crashed head-on into three cars.

Red beans and rice, that Southwest favorite, is a good summer week-end dish that calls for no exact timing in cooking and stays hot during an outdoor meal if presented in a heavy casserole. A receipe for it comes to us from a reader in, of all unlikely places, Middlebury, Vt.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (AP) -- The Federal Power Commission today allowed United Fuel Gas Company, Charleston, W. Va., a wholesale natural gas rate increase of about $10,000,000 annually.

TRENTON, Aug. 7 -- Captain Video, Gene Autry, the Lone Ranger and sundry other characters have been replaced overnight as the heroes of the hour to local youngsters by Trenton's philosophical City Counsel, Louis Josephson.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 7 -- The sixteen countries that fought under the United Nations flag in Korea have pledged themselves to take up arms against any new Communist aggression there and have warned the Communist world that if aggression is renewed the war probably will spread beyond Korea's borders.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- C. Tyler Wood, deputy to Harold E. Stassen, director of the Foreign Operations Administration (the former Mutual Security Administration), today was named economic coordinator for the relief and rehabilitation program in Korea.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (AP) -- Uncle Sam sold 251,142,000 bushels of wheat and flour abroad during the year ending July 31 at cut-rate prices averaging about 55 cents a bushel below those paid by domestic users.

OTTAWA, Aug. 7 (Canadian Press) -- Grain producers in Canada's bulging bread basket delivered record quantities of prairie grain during the crop year ended on July 31, the Trade Department said today.

GOSHEN, N. Y., Aug. 7 (AP) -- Tom Berry, 71-year-old harness driver who has one of the favorites for the Hambletonian here next Wednesday, was thrown from his sulky during a workout at Good Time Park today and suffered a back injury.

ATHENS, Aug. 7 -- A Government-sponsored law designed to reduce tax evasion was passed early this morning by the Parliamentary Recess Committee. On general lines, it complies with the recommendation of the United States Aid Mission.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 7 -laj. Gen. George A. Horkan, the Army Quartermaster General, said today that George lV[. Mardikian, restaurateur of this city, would leave with him on Sunday to inspect Alaskan installations, and offer recommendations for improving food procurement for Army units there in the interests of economy.

A dispatch from London to this newspaper, observes that Government and financial circles are apprehensive that the reduction in economic aid voted by Congress might cause a recurrence of Britain's balance of payments difficulties. Almost as if it were intended to answer this plaint from London was a dispatch under the same date from Michael L. Hoffman, correspondent for this newspaper, from Geneva.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- The President and Mrs. Eisenhower will start at noon tomorrow for a Colorado vacation. They may be away three weeks or more.

CHICAGO, Aug. 7 (AP) -- Cooler weather in the major pork consuming areas improved demand for the live product enough today to recoup 25 cents to $1.00 of recent price losses. Cattle were steady to 25 cents up but lambs were 50 cents to $1.00 off.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 7 -- The Committee on Civil Rights of the Philadelphia Bar Association will meet Monday to consider the problem of providing counsel for seven of the eight Communist leaders indicted on charges of conspiracy to overthrow the Government by force.

What is behind all the market activity in the common stock of the RKO Pictures Corporation? Trading in the shares aggregated 20,200 yesterday and 26,400 shares changed hands on Thursday. That is almost as much stock as was traded in the previous month.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (AP) -- President Eisenhower's signature on a military construction appropriations bill today gave the Air Force authority to spend an additional $9,534,000 on the projected Plattsburg, N. Y., bomber base. The Air Force already has received an appropriation of $28,500,000 for the base. Eventual cost is estimated at more than $70,000,000.

WESTBURY, L. I., Aug. 7 (AP) -- Direct Rhythm, owned by W. G. Reynolds of Louisville, scored a half-length victory over Prince Jay tonight in the $10,000 Jericho Pace on the Grand Circuit card at Roosevelt Raceway.

OTTAWA, Aug. 7 -- Charges that Prime Minister Louis St. Laurent's Liberal Government aims at dictatorial powers and appeals to the electorate to save the two-party system by turning the Liberals out, marked the closing phase of Canada's first national election campaign since 1949.
MILWAUKEE, Aug. 8 (UP) -- Ed Mathews and Joe Adcock hit homers to spark the second-place Braves to a 7-to-4 victory over the Pirates today. Mathews' four-bagger was his thirty-fifth of the season.

The new law permitting the admission of 214,000 extra immigrants will "work out all right" if it is properly administered, Senator Pat McCarran, Democrat of Nevada, declared yesterday before sailing for Bermuda aboard the Furness liner Queen of Bermuda.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 8 -- A threat that San Francisco landlords might be confronted with the "most rigorous" rent control ordinance in the city's history was heard late this week.

BACH'S great cantata for the third Sunday after Easter, Wir muessen durch viel Truebsal in das Reich Gottes eingehen, makes its first appearance on LP this week in a performance by the Bach Guild Choir and the Vienna State Opera Orchestra, Felix Prohaska conducting (Bach Guild).

GREAT RIVER, L. I., Aug. 8 -- Failure to hear the recall signal in this afternoon's race proved costly to Ralph Cameron's boat in the Corry Trophy series for the Star class as competition ended in the annual Race Week of the Great South Bay Yacht Racing Association.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- Premier Georgi M. Malenkov's announcement that the Soviet Union had mastered production of the hydrogen bomb was received calmly and with some skepticism here today.

TOKYO, Aug. 8 -- A fresh crop of problems involved in the Korean truce will come to light this month when the United Nations General Assembly meets to tackle the formulation of conditions for the international political conference recommended by the high commands of both sides to settle basic questions of the Korean problem.

The establishment in 1952 of communications systems for several divisions of the Office of Civil Defense, including public works, water supply and medical, has placed New York City "far ahead of any other municipality in the United States in its civil defense communications," Mayor Impellitteri was told yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 (UP) -- Nothing pleases a Congressman so much as to go home and have the folks send him back to Washington. So, for those constituents who cannot come to the capital to observe the scenes in which they labor, the members are planning to bring the scenes to them.
Passengers on the United States Lines superliner United States ate nearly 3,000 tons of food last year.

SINGAPORE, Aug. 8 -- Malayan security forces released today the "bad" village of Broga in Selangor State after nine days of mass detention and lifted a night curfew imposed on it. Other penalties, including closing of all coffee shops and eating houses and all shops except a government-approved store, remain in force.

LONDON, Aug. 8 -- Gordon Pirie, who usually runs anywhere from three to six miles in track meets, ran only one today but he did it in 4:06.8, fast enough to defeat weary Wes Santee of Kansas, in what had been billed as "the mile of the century."
Premier Georgi M. Malenkov's claim that the Soviet Union had "mastered" the hydrogen bomb must be treated seriously whether it represents fact or fiction.

NEW YORK AIRWAYS completed its first month of flying passengers by helicopter between the three major airports in the metropolitan area when its daily schedule was ended at dusk last Wednesday and now the company is planning an expansion of its passenger flights. However, the added trips will be made over its present routes linking La Guardia, New York International and Newark Airports.

Pedro Vaszquez, 50 years old, a handyman, shot and killed his seriously ill wife, Francisca, 33, while she slept Friday nightt in their apartment at 16-18 West 101st Street, and then shot himself, the police reported yesterday. The bodies were discovered yesterday at 10:30 A. M. by a 3-year-old nephew, George Pagan, who lives in the same apartment.
POINT PLEASANT BEACH, N. J., Aug. 8 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon, with his wife and two little daughters, reviewed a community parade at this seashore resort today.
KANSAS CITY, Aug. 8 (AP) -- Saul N. Yarmak, 19, Passaic, N. J., won the unior national chess championship in the week-long tournament which ended here today.
SUDENTS of recent trends in contemporary music have often wondered why the immense possibilities of the film sound track and recording tape have not been put to fuller use by composers.
GOOD cooks today give recipes for their favorite ways of presenting chicken in cold dishes. The bird is plentiful and inexpensive.

ATHENS, Aug. 8 -- Minister of Coordination Spyros Markezinis announced today that the budget for fiscal 1953-54, to be presented soon to the Parliamentary recess committee, would amount to the equivalent of $300,000,000. Expenditures will total $290,000,000, which would mean that a surplus of $10,000,000, called the first in recent years, could be used to supplement the allocation already in the budget for various investment projects designed to increase Greece's productivity.

In the last-day rush of legislation Congress passed a bill which seems to have been overlooked in the headlines but which has deep significance for America's standing throughout the world. I refer to the legislation authorizing the President to use $100,000,000 worth of United States farm surplus foods for foreign relief.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- Three ships carrying cotton for cloth for the backs of South Korean citizens and barley and rice for their stomachs will leave the United States next week as the Government's program of relief and rehabilitation of the war-ravaged nation goes into full operation.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 (AP) -The Interstate Commerce Commission advised Senator George A. Smathers, Democrat of Florida, today that a proposed ban on return-trip leasing of trucks hauling livestock, fish, agricultural or horticultural commodities to market would not go into effect until March 1.

" A MAN'S life of any worth," wrote Keats, "is a continual allegory. * * * Lord Byron cuts a figure -- but he is not figurative." But Keats, as both Jacques Barzun and G. Wilson Knight reveal in their different ways, was unjust to Byron.

CHAIRMAN of Long Island University's Department of English, James R. Foster is a literary folklorist with a nice sense of balance between literature and lore, between the art and the science of folk literature. Designed frankly for entertainment these ninety folk tales chiefly from European sources, with a few from Egypt and India, will divert and delight the imaginative reader.

CAIRO, Aug. 8 -- British and United States diplomats called on the Egyptian Foreign Minister, Dr. Mahmoud Fawzi, today to discuss the current efforts to reconcile the conflicting British and Egyptian claims on the Suez Canal Zone and matters affecting the agreement between the two states to end the condominium of the Sudan.

TRENTON, Aug. 8 -- Faced with some of the worst slum conditions in the East, this historic city is engaged in an all-out campaign to redevelop its most blighted areas and wherever possible to replace buildings beyond repair.

There has been a trend in recent years away from the traditional method of awarding college scholarships in amounts equal to the tuition. The new approach is to fit the scholarship to the individual need. It may be as low as $100, or it may reach $1,500. But, whatever the amount, it comes closer to the student's actual requirements than the so-called tuition method, which many educators consider impractical and at times unfair.

President Eisenhower yesterday followed Congress -- out of Washington. For most of the next month, unless recalled by urgent state affairs, he will be in Colorado. The first ten days he and Mrs. Eisenhower will spend in Denver with her mother, Mrs. John S. Dowd.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 (UP) -- A House of Representatives subcommittee reported tonight that Government employment still was burdened with "outmoded policies and antiquated practices."

NEW DELHI, India, Sunday, Aug. 9 -- Sheikh Mohammed Abdullah, Prime Minister of the Indian-held part of the state of Kashmir, was dismissed this morning by Prince Karan Singh, Governor of the state, in the wake of rumors that the Sheikh was about to repudiate the state's accession to India. Bakshi Ghulam Mohammed, the Deputy Premier, was installed in his stead.

In regard to Irving Glssman's recent letter about the current movie, "The Band Wagon," I must admit that I do agree with him in part and I cannot, either, understand why the motion-picture critics went so wholeheartedly out of their minds when reviewing this picture.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug 8 -Greentree Stable's Tom Fool, in a two-horse race on which there was no betting, and Mrs. Claude H. Johannsen Jr.'s Wise Pop, in a four-horse sprint with the show windows closed, were the winners of the stakes contests that headed the Saratoga Association's nine-race program today.

Gil Turner, welterweight contender from Philadelphia, will continue his bid for another title shot when he faces Ramon Fuentes, Los Angeles battler, in the ten-round feature bout at Madison Square Garden Wednesday night.

INCHON, Korea, Aug. 8 -- A young soldier made a plea today for the body of his closest friend. He asked the world to help him take it from the banks of the Yalu River and lay it to rest near people his friends loved in Alabama.

LAUSANNE, Switzerland, Aug. 8 (UP) -- Otto Mayer, Chancellor of the International Olympic Committee, said today the 1956 Olympic equestrian events may be held after all, but in a different place from Melbourne.

It was encouraging to read in THE TIMES of Aug. 2 that President Eisenhower has forwarded recommendations to Congress for extending Social Security coverage to millions of people in the United States, even though there is little likelihood of any action being taken at this session.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- President Eisenhower left Washington today at 12:13 P. M., Eastern daylight time, aboard his private plane the Columbine for a Colorado vacation expected to last three to four weeks.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Aug. 8 -- With the same thrill that folk the world over feel when a band goes marching by, thousands of proud Pakistanis lined three miles of muddy streets today during the dress rehearsal of the "biggest parade" in this capital city's six-year history.

MONTREAL, Aug. 8 -- Canada took the semi-final round of the North American Davis Cup tennis competition against Cuba today by winning the doubles match, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 2, for an unsurmountable 3-0 lead.

The twenty-eighth championship tournament of the women's Westchester and Fairfield County Golf Association, opening tomorrow at the Scarsdale Golf Club, Hartsdale, N. Y., has drawn an entry of sixty-two members including two former champions, other standout performers within the area, but not the reigning title-holder.
LONDON, Aug. 8 -- The British people set out on their annual August vacations this week in probably a happier and more secure frame of mind than they have known since the end of the second World War.

THE sixth annual American Dance Festival, which will consist of five performances in the Palmer Auditorium of Connecticut College in New London Aug. 20-23, will concern itself largely with the first presentations of new works. On the schedule are five new ensemble compositions and six smaller pieces.

LAST fall, a college group, The Columbia Players, requested permission to produce William Saroyan's "Slaughter of the Innocents." The playwright refused on the ground that he no longer could afford to have his plays produced by amateurs.

WEST POINT, N. Y., Aug. 8 -The colors of the nation's second-oldest, regular Army infantry regiment were presented to the United States Military Academy today at a review of the First Regiment of the Corps of Cadets on the plain at the academy.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 8 -- The Great Lakes ore fleet, augmented by two new bulk freighters, will continue its record feats this month if weather conditions remain favorable, officials of the Lake Superior Iron Ore Association predicted today.

BEES have an important part to play both from the gardener's and the farmer's viewpoint. They pollinize fruit and other crops and for the same reason are valued in regions where seed is grown for gardens. (One hive per acre is the average for purposes of pollination.)

THERE is an ever-growing group of fans who are beginning to feel, as they examine the types on these pages, that they are among friends. For these monsters, ghouls and vampires have chilled an adoring public for years and today are proving more popular than ever.

Robert F. Wagner Jr., Manhattan Borough President and candidate for the Democratic nomination for Mayor, announced yesterday the appointment of Adrian P. Burke, lawyer, as campaign manager for himself and his running mates, Lawrence E. Gerosa, candidate for the nomination for Controller, and Abe Stark, candidate for the nomination for President of the City Council.

The Yankees, behind the brilliant pitching of Whitey Ford and Bob Kuzava, shut out the White Sox twice yesterday, 1 -- 0 and 3 -- 0, to increase their American League lead to eight games. Kuzava had a no-hitter until one out in the ninth inning of the second game when Bob Boyd.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- The Republicans are now attempting to rally from the profound blow of the death of Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio.

MAMARONECK, N. Y., Aug. 8 -Don Cherry, a member of the 1953 Walker Cup team, and Frank Strafaci, former Metropolitan amateur champion, gained the final of the John G. Anderson Memorial golf tourney at the Winged Foot Club today.

A trailer truck overturned yesterday afternoon when it made a mistaken turn into an approach from the George Washington Bridge to the West Side Highway. Traffic was diverted to other approaches while a police emergency crew righted the truck and firemen flushed away spilled gasoline.

The first hint that the Soviet Union would claim attainment of the hydrogen bomb was given by the Soviet Government newspaper Izvestia on Aug. 1 when it revealed that a key component of the hydrogen bomb, deuterium or heavy hydrogen, was available in the Soviet Union in sufficient quantity to be used for non-military experimentation.

GENEVA, Aug. 8 -- Emulating their French neighbors, fruit farmers in the Canton of Valais, Switzerland, stopped trains, barricaded rails and set fire to some cars yesterday in protest against the conditions for the sale of their apricot crop. The farmers were incensed by the Swiss Federal Council's refusal to ban imports of peaches as a means of forcing Swiss housewives to buy apricots.

TOKYO, Aug. 8 -- John Foster Dulles, United States Secretary of State, arrived in Japan today bearing gifts for the increasingly restive people of this country.

USUALLY there is a great deal of knee-shaking in a motion-picture studio when the man, or combination of men, who have been running the show, step aside and new hands take hold of the production helm. Last Monday morning Edward Muhl, 46-years-old and a twenty-six-year veteran of Universal-International Pictures, took full command of the studio with the title of vice president in charge of production.

THEY'RE coming home again, this time from the Korean war, only this time they aren't getting the veteran's gold-plated duck. They have fought in an international war that has defeated Communist aggression, a war that must go down among the decisive struggles in world history, yet if you gave them a discharge pin for their part in that three-year nightmare they probably wouldn't wear it.

Each occasion is too nearly unique to allow us to find a profitable pattern of it in the past.

THE situation in South Africa becomes ever more tense as Prime Minister Daniel F. Malan presses on with his program of Apartheid -- racial separation. What motivates Malan? It is important to know because Apartheid is rending his own country and is being watched with intense concern throughout Africa and much of the world.

LOS ANGELES -- A record attendance of more than 2,000 photographers from several parts of the country made the twentieth convention of the Photographic Society of America, held here last week, the largest in the society's history. The count of one-day visitors, not yet completed, was expected to increase this figure considerably by the end of the week.
Despite various prophets of doom, the alcoholic beverage industry in all its branches seems destined to survive the vicissitudes it has been fearing.

Just before his recent departure for the Far East, Secretary of State John Foster Dulles announced a plan whereby American troops remaining in Korea would be used to help that war-devastated nation in its reconstruction program. Mr. Dulles also urged the Ambassadors of the fifteen nations allied with us in the Korean war to do the same.

IN her foreword to "A Puffin Book of Verse" Eleanor Graham says: "I have had a simple standard in compiling this anthology for children -- namely, to find verses which sing in the ear and catch in the mind." That is as good a standard as I can think of for such a collection -and well met.

TOPEKA, Kan., Aug. 8 -- Scott McLeod, the State Department's chief of security and personnel, said today that 4,000 persons were being investigated to weed from the State Department any employes of "doubtful security potential."

Undoubtedly there are many whose reaction will be one of disbelief, and certainly skepticism is not entirely unjustified in the absence of independent evidence to support the Soviet assertion.

The second annual New York Knickerbockers-College All Stars basketball game for the benefit of the Milk Fund will be played at Madison Square Garden, Saturday night, Oct. 24. The game will mark the opening of the eighth professional season locally as the Boston Celtics meet the Syracuse Nationals in the other game of the double-header.

ATLANTA, Aug. 8 -- Retailers in the Southeast relied more upon bank borrowings in the first half of this year than in the corresponding period last year, the Sixth Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta reported this week. Between Jan. 1 and the end of June, retail trade loans outstanding at twenty-two weekly reporting member banks in leading cities of the area rose $12,000,000.

LONDON, Aug. 8 -- When Selwyn Lloyd, Minister of State, leaves London for New York Monday night he will carry a brief that, British officials hope, is as well prepared as is humanly possible to anticipate and prevent any friction with the United States at the United Nations General Assembly session on the Korean peace conference.

Spectacular signs -- "signs that cover more than a 1,000 square feet and employ special effects" -for advertising purposes have come more and more into use in the last twenty years and are gaining acceptance in cities throughout the United States, far from Times Square.

VANCOUVER, Wash. -- The two seacoast states of the Pacific Northwest, rich in scenery but often hard-pressed to thread adequate roads over vast and mountainous areas, are appropriating millions of dollars this year to improve their highway systems for the local resident and the motoring wayfarer alike.

THE seventh volume of this extraordinary edition of the papers of an extraordinary man covers a year in Jefferson's long and incredibly fruitful life. It completes his career in the Continental Congress (his final legislative service) and takes him to France as a Minister to negotiate treaties of commerce, in conjunction with Franklin and John Adams, ending with a letter in which his likely appointment to succeed the former at Versailles is reported.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 8 -- A press conflict of extraordinary bitterness reached such a pitch here that the police put a special guard on the office and person of a prominent, editor, Carlos Lacerda, last night because of reported threats of violence.

HORNELL, N. Y., Aug. 3 (AP) -- A labor contractor told The Hornell Tribune here today that he had hired twenty-two Brooklyn boys to work on a Livingston County farm near Wayland and that the boys had known they were being recruited for work upstate.

The dieselization program undertaken by the nation's railroads after World War II is approaching completion. Orders for new diesel locomotives have declined to the point where most diesel builders have had to curtail operations.

LONDON, Aug. 8 -- Heirlooms and curios worth thousands of pounds were stolen last night from Inverary Castle, the eighteenth century home of the Duke and Duchess of Argyll in Argyllshire, Scotland. One of the items taken was the baton that the Duke carries as hereditary master of the royal household in Scotland.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 (AP) -- The Defense Department today identified 273 additional casualties in the Korean fighting that ended July 27. The new list included twenty-seven killed, 180 wounded, fifty-four missing in action and twelve injured in combat zone accidents.

THE story of Chinese intellectual development from the earliest times to the present is unfolded here in a brief book by H. G. Creel, Professor of Early Chinese Literature at the University of Chicago. More than two thirds of his "Chinese Thought" deals with the period from Confucius to the violent intrusion of the West in the nineteenth century.

The Swiss merchant marine, born in 1941 of the war-time necessity of supplying the small, entirely landlocked republic, is now a thriving and growing enterprise, but Swiss shipowners are perturbed that only one-fourth of the thousand men sailing their ships are nationals of the country.
SAN DIEGO, Calif., Aug. 8 (UP) -- The Los Angeles Rams boasted a scoring record after crushing the Navy-Marine All-Stars, 72 -- 19, before 18,000 fans in Balboa Stadium last night.

TWO Ascor electronic flash units, products of American Speedlight Corp., are being handled through Peerless Camera Stores; 415 Lexington Avenue, the latter announced last week. Both will operate from rechargeable batteries or AC outlets.

The article by Gertrude Samuels "Their Hunger -- And Our Surplus" (Aug. 2) was, in my opinion, a stirring report of what can be one of America's wisest acts. Giving our surplus stocks to countries needing them will, in the first and most important place, save lives, fill out bodies and help ordinary and unknown neighbors.

RYE, N. Y., Aug. 8 -- Ted Sheldon of the Riverside Yacht Club, sailing his Coquette, took the lead for the Western Long Island Sound District Lightning Class championship off the American Yacht Club today by winning the first of a three-race series. Twenty-eight sloops started.

MONMOUTH, Me., Aug. 8 -- The chance opening of the Monmouth Town Hall door last spring by a Gilbert and Sullivan opera company looking for a summer location has focused attention on this village of 1,600 as an example of what visiting economists often overlook in attempting to survey the New England economy.

The increasing amount of time school-age children are spending in front of television sets has prompted worried parents and teachers to seek new diversions for the youngsters on and off the screens. The objectives seem to be more appropriate programs and especially those that would encourage outside reading such as dramatizations of colorful books.

LOS ANGELES -- Paul Arnold of Binghamton and Arthur M. Underwood of Rochester led a list of eighty-nine recipients of honors announced here last night at the annual Honors Awards Banquet of the Photographic Society of America. Both received Honorary Memberships in the society.

In the second scheduled test for this year, the city's 578 air raid warning sirens will be sounded on Tuesday at 11 A. M., Herbert H. O'Brien, director of the New York City Office of Civil Defense, announced yesterday. The public will not be asked to seek shelter during the test, which is to check the sirens for mechanical defects.

One of the great price barometers of the world metal markets went back into action last week after a lapse of nearly fourteen years -- and the initial readings indicated some squally weather ahead for copper producers.

FOR the fourth anniversary of the "Patto Atlantico" (Atlantic Pact) Italy has issued 25-lire yellow and green and 60L red-violet and blue stamps in a symbolic design. A rainbow, a white star at its center, spans the Atlantic between outline maps of the New and Old Worlds. Inscribed along the bottom border is "Pace-Forza-Liberta" (Peace-Strength-Liberty).

LONG ago Pearl Buck staked out China as her literary province. Occasionally she has written of other Asian countries, but "Come, My Beloved" is her first novel with an Indian background. This daring and dramatic journey demonstrated beyond any doubt that the pre-European inhabitants of South America could have reached Polynesia.
