AT the same time that the Earl Jowitt's book, "The Strange Case of Alger Hiss," was coming out over here, Whittaker Chambers' book, "Witness," was coming out over there. Mr. Chambers' personality, perspicacity and prose had the English critics doing flips, though all were agreed that here was no persiflage.

BERLIN, Aug. 8 -- As West Berlin's presentation of gift food parcels to the East Germans and East Berliners neared the 2,000,000 mark, the city's Council of Elders decided against a distribution of food to the city's own needy.

A demonstration protesting what they termed "a reign of terror" in their neighborhood was staged yesterday morning by seventy-five residents of Ocean Hill section of Brooklyn who live near Atlantic and Howard Avenues.

EACH time one revisits the remarkable survey of twentieth-century sculpture at the Museum of Modern Art one is impressed anew with the great diversity of styles and materials and with the wide range of fundamental concepts underlying the work.

A HAND shoved a 50-cent piece through the window of a subway booth at Times Square. The man in the booth, with a deft triangular flick of his hand, slid three tokens and a nickel back into the hollow hewed in the apron outside the window by so many nickels and dimes that have gone there before.

ST. PETER, Minn., Aug. 8 (UP) -- Paul Douglas, former University of Illinois star who developed his baseball-style kicks by playing soccer, has introduced his "knuckle-ball" and "slider" to the New York Football Giants' camp.
Plans for the establishment of an organization to improve secondary-school education and to promote wider knowledge of the nation's free enterprise economy were announced yesterday.

THE publishers describe this picture book as "a simple lesson in international understanding." Sometimes little homilies on tolerance undo their earnest purpose by raising disturbing questions in the minds of very young children.

CHORE FOR THE WEEK: Regular spraying or dusting throughout summer is essential to control red spider, various kinds of beetles, leafhoppers and diseases such as mildew. Dust plants susceptible to mildew with sulfur. Spray annual verbena and perennial phlox as well as any shrubs that have red spider with a miticide.

CHICAGO, Aug. 8 -- John W. Snyder, Secretary of the Treasury under President Harry S. Truman, defended his actions in expediting tax settlements and said he was willing to go before a Congressional committee "at any time" to clarify any questions about tax matters during his term of office.

IF a Martian or a Flying Saucerer (he would be a tourist) fell suddenly and from the skies and into a Paris street (it would be the Champs-Elysees) the probability is high that, as he surveyed the rows upon rows of banks after banks of sitting people, he would exclaim: "What sort of theatre is this?" He would, of course, be responding to the spectacle of the sidewalk cafe.
A fight to the death between two six-foot brothers, watched by 200 persons in Harlem yesterday, ended in the fatal slashing of one of them and the arrest of the other on a homicide charge.

CHICAGO, Aug. 8 -- Four seasoned players today tied for the 54-hole lead of the $75,000 "world" professional golf championship. Tomorrow's final round for the $25,000 first prize looms as the tightest finish seen in the Tam o'Shanter tournaments.

MAY I be allowed to comment on your excellent piece, "Money for Movies." It is true that the motion picture industry and theatres have been hard pressed for several years, particularly since the advent of television. However, even a child could recognize that the industry's cry of imminent collapse if not granted removal of the 20 per cent excise tax was greatly exaggerated purely for the occasion.
Blind since birth, 5-year-old triplets stopped at La Guardia Airport yesterday on the way from a Boston school to Cincinnati and their first reunion with their family in two years.

Brooklyn, with its 100 miles of waterfront, its manufacturing plants and skilled manpower, has played a major role in the economic welfare of the nation and the world, according to Borough President John Cashmore.

HARRISBURG, Aug. 8 -- The Pennsylvania Turnpike Commission expects surveys to be completed in "about ten days" of alternate lines for the proposed 125-mile northeast extension of the superhighway from Philadelphia through the anthracite region to the New York State line, a spokesman said today.

Following a recently instituted plan of presenting an opera in full during a week of concerts, the New York Public Library will bring to listeners in Bryant Park, beginning Tuesday, Verdi's "La Traviata."

SPEAKING of poets is a rash occupation, especially when the poets are still alive and can answer back or, as is more usual, answer behind one's back sideways. On the other hand, no poet should be mealy-mouthed about poetry.

WHILE extensive progress has been made in motor vehicle improvement and highway design, the average motorist has not advanced much beyond the two-wheel-brakes and crowned-roads era, according to Dr. Herbert J. Stack, director of the Center for Safety Education at New York University.

STONY BROOK, L. I., Aug. 8 -- A silvered harness, ordered by a king who lost his throne before the trappings for his eight-horse team were finished, has been put on display in the Carriage House of the Suffolk Museum here.

Walter Dayton of the home club brought his rebuilt 17-year-old Dutchess back to the races for the first time this season yesterday, and won the opening race of three among the Comets in the fifteenth annual invitation regatta of the Bayside Yacht Club in Little Neck Bay, Queens.

OLD SAYBROOK, Conn., Aug. 8 -- A new ferryboat link in the transportation chain across Long Island Sound was inaugurated today between Long Island's North, Fork and Saybrook Point, Conn. This service, designed to cut travel time almost one-half hour between Eastern Long Island and New England, is an extension of the Orient Point-New London service, which has been operated since 1948 by the New London Freight Lines.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- The executive-legislative stalemate over a proposed increase in the legal limit on Government debt has left unanswered the vital question of how good is the credit of the United States, or how big a debt can we stand.

CHICAGO, Aug. 8 (AP) -- The Cubs batted ace hurler Robin Roberts all over the lot today and defeated the Phillies, 4 -- 1, before 19,886 fans in Wrigley Field. The Cub attack thwarted Roberts in his effort to become the first 20-game winner in the majors this season.
PORTLAND, Ore., Aug. 8 -Three more American records fell in the women's National Amateur Athletic Union outdoor swimming championships today.

I recently came across what I thought was a very sensible remark by actor Ronald Reagan to the effect that what Hollywood needs most is good writers and good stories. There is nothing new about this theory; I think most of Hollywood's intelligent producers have always had the same idea.

THE Wadsworth Atheneum at Hartford has recently been fortunate enough to acquire a splendid portrait by Ingres which also happens to be of considerable historical interest. It represents Ferdinand, Duc d'Orleans, the eldest son of Louis Philippe, who was tragically killed in a carriage accident in 1842.

WE do not have anything in London which quite corresponds to the New York shutdown of theatres in the summer. We don't always get the summer, as this year has been trying to remind us, and even when we do, London is a long way farther north than New York and can naturally reckon on being that much cooler.

IT was astonishing and refreshing to get from Louis Kronenberger -- perhaps the sternest book critic of our day -- an article praising the art of appreciation. * * * However, his own very sharp and usually very just remarks about literary works over a period of many years are in themselves proof that the severe observer can be stimulating and constructive as any other type.

Making satisfactory emotional and vocational readjustments is an important problem for the discharged tuberculosis patient. In the ten years that the New York Tuberculosis and Health Association's rehabilitation division has been concentrating on this work, 2,216 persons have received its free individualized service.

In France last week a complex budgetary problem which has bedevilled parliamentary life for the past year was thrust into sharp public focus. The thrust was a wave of protest strikes in Government services and nationalized industries that threatened to bring the whole economy to a standstill.

STOWE, Vt. -- Vacation travel trends take off at times on strange and sudden tangents; old resorts are deserted and new ones developed. But sometimes the curve is one which slowly and steadily describes a full circle. Such is the ease with Stowe, the Vermont township spread so prettily at the foot of Mount Mansfield, highest peak of the Green Mountain range.

Chet Sanok, Upper Montclair star who last September gained the distinction of being the first amateur to win the metropolitan open championship in thirty-seven years of competition, officially reigns as the top amateur golfer hereabouts. This was indicated yesterday as the Metropolitan Golf Association issued its handicap list for 1953.

OSLO, Norway, Aug. 8 -- The announcement by Premier Georgi M. Malenkov today that the Soviet Union had mastered the production of the hydrogen bomb will come as no surprise to the inner circle of atomic scientists closely associated with the United States hydrogen bomb project.

SEATTLE, Aug. 8 (AP) -- The wild men of the waters will hold their annual Gold Cup convention tomorrow on Lake Washington, and any delegate who catches the sturdy old Slo-Mo-Shun IV will at once become high chief of the speed boat world.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 8 -- The index of industrial activity in Pennsylvania in June stood at 232, compared with 209 for the corresponding month of 1952, when the steel strike cut production. The Bureau of Business at the Pennsylvania State College noted that the 232 figure was only 2 points below the record set in April.

Swimming crew members from the French liner Ile de France out-distanced their competitors in the International Seamen's Swimming Trials that ended last week at the Seamen's House Young Men's Christian Association, 550 West Twentieth Street.

HARTFORD, Conn., Aug. 8 -- Strife in the Republican party in Connecticut may break out soon over reported efforts by Gov. John Davis Lodge to oust Fred R. Zeller of Stonington, as the party's nominee for state controller in the 1954 state election.

TOKYO, Sunday, Aug. 9 -- Communist women prisoners of the Korean war staged scenes of hysteria today when the United Nations Command sent them with their children across the armi stice line at Panmunjom to homes behind the Iron Curtain.
HONG KONG, Aug. 8 -- The China trade question has become a hotter and more complicated issue now that the Chinese "volunteers" are no longer shooting at United Nations troops in Korea.

BOSTON, Aug. 8 (UP) -- Sid Hudson's brilliant six-hit relief pitching for eight and a third innings, backed by the booming bats of Tommy Umphlett and Sammy White, gave the Red Sox a 5-4 victory over the Indians today. It was Boston's second consecutive triumph over the Indians and their twenty-fourth 1-run triumph in thirty-six decisions.

HONG KONG, Aug. 8 -- Gen. Li Tse-fen, deputy commander of Chinese Nationalist guerrilla operations in East Burma passed through Hong Kong today en route to Bangkok after conferring with Nationalist authorities in Formosa. He told reporters here that only about 1,700 Nationalist troops could be evacuated from Burma.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Aug. 9 (Reuters) -- Sam Goldwyn said here today he wanted his movie "Hans Christian Andersen" shown in Denmark, home of the storyteller, even if it runs at a loss. Denmark has not yet seen the film, although crowds of Danes have been flocking to Sweden to see it.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 (UP) -- The Navy, under prodding from the White House, is ready to move toward elimination of segregation among civilian employes at its bases in the South, Pentagon officials said today.

TRIESTE, Aug. 9 -- An atmosphere of frustration hangs over this pleasant city. Today the Adriatic is unbelievably blue and the sunlight casts the same golden glow on the curving coasts of Zone A and Zone B. But only the sun is impartial.
The Seafarers International Union, A. F. L., has announced that it will place its own library of fifty books on every ship sailing under contract to the union.

ANKARA, Turkey, Aug. 8 -- The Soviet Union is cooperating with Turkey in a joint study of the problem of irrigating the fertile Igdir Plain, which extends from northeastern Turkey into the Armenian Soviet Republic, it was revealed today.

SEATTLE, Aug. 9 (AP) -- The Slo-Mo-Shun IV won the Gold Cup speedboat race for the third time in four years today, placing first in all three of the 30-mile heats. Only two other boats finished, Gale II placing second and Such Crust III, third.

Organizations representing real estate taxpayers have begun an intensive study of the possible impact of a separate county real estate tax after Jan. 1, 1954, in case the voters of the state reject the proposed constitutional amendment enlarging the city's over-all power to tax real estate on a citywide basis.
DENVER, Colo., Aug. 9 -- Secretary of State Dulles will arrive here tomorrow morning and report to President Eisenhower on the Korean trip and talks with President Rhee.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 9 -- Herbert Hoover will celebrate his seventy-ninth birthday tomorrow, quietly, with plans for only a small dinner with friends here.

Frank Miller, first 'cellist of the N.B.C. Symphony Orchestra, conducted his colleagues yesterday afternoon when the group, going by the seasonal name of the N.B.C. Summer Symphony, made an hour-long Sunday afternoon broadcast from a studio in Rockefeller Center. It was his second local conducting appearance, for he also led the orchestra last summer.

TOKYO, Aug. 9 -- Secretary of State John Foster Dulles left here for Washington yesterday convinced that he had made substantial progress in Korea but was not so sure about Japan. Mr. Dulles had some difficult moments with both President Syngman Rhee of South Korea and Premier Shigeru Yoshida of Japan, but went away feeling that he had clarified United States relations with both countries.

OTTAWA, Aug. 9 -- From 9 A. M. until 7 P. M. tomorrow, Canadians from towns, farms and cities in the populous provinces of Quebec and Ontario, from the Maritimes and the prairies, and in the frozen tundra of the north, will be trekking to the polls to choose a Government.

In tone and content, Premier Georgi M. Malenkov's speech to the Supreme Soviet Saturday suggested that he had become the strongest among the members of the "collective leadership" ruling the Soviet Union since the death of Stalin.

STATE COLLEGE, Pa., Aug. 9 -- The disappointment, confusion and irrational guilt often felt by parents when a child is born handicapped may be perfectly natural" but such feelings can cause real trouble unless the parents are helped to understand them, according to Dr. Eugene T. McDonald, director of the speech and hearing clinic at Pennsylvania State College.

If any further proof were required of the bankrupt leadership of President Joseph P. Ryan of the International Longshoremen's Association, it can be found in the dispute over the employment of a single dock worker which has led to a strike against the Moore-McCormack Lines and the tie-up of two ships.

CHICAGO, Aug. 9 -- The reign of Joseph P. Ryan as president for life of the International Longshoremen's Association, A. F. L., and the days of the pier union as a member of the Ameri can Federation of Labor family were drawing to a close here today.

MOSCOW, Aug. 9 -- For the first time since its Five-Year Plan was instituted in 1928 the Soviet Union is going to shift the weight of its economy from the production of capital goods to increasing the output of consumer goods, a study of the speech of Premier Georgi M. Malenkov to the Supreme Soviet Saturday clearly indicates.

James Lane, who had a job but no work, snatched a great-grandmother's purse that contained only 4 cents. Surpless reduced bail on a larceny charge from $5,000 to $500.

As a trial lawyer who has pleaded in the courts for some years I am intrigued by the fact that political parties sometimes nominate and elect judges whose knowledge of both substantive law and procedural practice is extremely limited. The result is that such judges are obliged to begin in the kindergarten to learn the A B C's of the law.

PARIS, Aug. 9 -- The public service strikes that have complicated life in France for the past two days subsided today. But the civil servants' unions tonight called for meetings to decide on a resumption of the strike wave if the governmental economy decrees, adopted during the day by the Cabinet of Premier Joseph Laniel, should be found unacceptable.
CLEARFIELD, Pa., Aug. 9 (AP) -- Carl Steinfeldt of Rochester, N. Y., built up a 79.1 ringer percentage as he successfully defended his Eastern horseshoe title in a two-day tournament.

Two sources indicated yesterday substantial increases in newspaper advertising so far this year. Linage figures for the seven New York dailies showed a total of 87,233,798 lines for the first seven months of 1953, an increase of 2.98 per cent over the comparable 1952 period.

The apathy that has characterized the charter market over the last three months continued through last week, with little or no fluctuation in the present low rates and few vessel contracts consummated, according to a survey of charter brokers here.
LONDON, Aug. 9 -- The business event of greatest importance and interest last week was the resumption of free dealings in copper on the London Metal Exchange after nearly fourteen years of controls.

Pacific Western Oil Corporation and its subsidiaries reported net earnings of $7,342,385 for the first half of 1953, against $5,289,845 for the same 1952 period. After preferred dividends, the common stock earned $1.47 a share, against $1.17 the year before.

The first session of the eighty-third Congress was marked by considerable activity on maritime matters, with action completed on eight major bills of particular interest to American shipping and preliminary steps taken on eleven more that will probably come before the second session for final consideration.

NORWALK, Conn., Aug. 9 -- A dismal collection of obsolete, tumbledown houses, some of them more than 100 years old and all of them heavy with violations of the city's building, health and fire codes, is being eliminated from the heart of Norwalk in a novel experiment with fast-moving, hard-hitting official squads.

BERLIN, Aug. 9 -- Visitors seeking West Berlin's giveaway food parcels fell to a new low today as the Communists intensified their efforts to block rail travel to Berlin and discourage those who might seek to take advantage of the food offer.

DENVER, Colo., Aug. 9 -- President and Mrs. Eisenhower went to church this morning, but otherwise spent a quiet day at home with Mimi, which is the family's familiar name for Mrs. Eisenhower's mother, Mrs. John S. Doud.

ADAIRSVILLE, Ga., Aug. 9 (AP) -- More than 200 men used bloodhounds and planes today in a hunt for two prisoners who killed a United States deputy marshal and escaped with a second guard as a hostage.

PORTLAND, Ore., Aug. 9 (AP) -Gail Peters, 24-year-old Government worker from the Walter Reed Swim Club of Washington, set her third record in the women's National Amateur Athletic Union outdoor swimming championships today.

FREEDOM VILLAGE, Korea, Aug. 9 -- Frank (Pappy) Noel, The Associated Press photographer who was released by the Communists after two years and nine months as a prisoner, told today the story of his ordeal.

SAYVILLE, L. I., Aug. 9 -- Jack Danes' Pursuit, a Star Class boat captured the annual Queen-of-the-Bay race sailed in Great South Bay today. Danes will have to wait until the Great South Bay Yacht Racing Association rules on eligibility restrictions before he receives the Growtage Memorial Trophy.

John D. Morris, of the Washington staff of THE TIMES, writing last week on the record of the first session of the Eighty-third Congress, offered what was a fairly typical summary of its performance. As he put it, "it (the session just adjourning) has compiled a record of modest achievement, and has left itself a heavy load of work for next year."

GROSSINGER, N. Y., Aug. 9 -- The lack of regular sparring partners today hampered heavyweight champion Rocky Marciano's four-round work-out in preparation for his title fight with Roland La Starza at the Polo Grounds on Sept. 24.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 (AP) -- It will be a little more difficult next year for farmers to get a slice of a 195-million-dollar subsidy the Government is offering them for conserving soil and water.

GENEVA, Aug. 9 -- In the first quarter of 1953 the dollar deficit of Europe arising from current trade and financial transactions reached "virtual extinction," the Economic Commission for Europe reported in its quarterly bulletin published in Geneva today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 -- This country produced goods and services in April, May and June at a record rate of $372,400,000,000 a year, measured in current prices. In the first three months of the year the rate of the gross national product was $362,000,000,000.

TOKYO, Monday, Aug. 10 -- The United Nations and Communist commands staged the sixth day's return of prisoners of the Korean war this morning amid new charges that the Chinese and North Koreans had withheld men entitled to repatriation.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 9 -- The steel industry in recent weeks has been unable to reach the operating levels set up by estimating departments. This failure to meet bogies has been caused by vacations, product mix and to some extent the weather.

OTTAWA, Ont., Aug. 9 -- Although women constitute 51 per cent of the Canadian electorate and conceivably could sway results of tomorrow's Federal election, the accent in the campaign still is heavily on the male.

WIESBADEN, Germany, Aug. 9 (UP) -- The big C-119 transport "ditched" for undetermined reasons and the survivors were picked up by a United States amphibian rescue plane based at Bordeaux, France. The brief rescue flash received here did not identify the survivors or mention their condition.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 9 -- One of the saddest Western trips ever taken by the Giants ended today at Busch Stadium where the Cardinals, completing a sweep of the three-game set, downed the New Yorkers, 6 -- 2. The setback was the Polo Grounders' twelfth in the fifteen-game tour.

Roman Catholics in the United States willingly "sacrifice" to maintain a Catholic school system because "the purpose of Catholic education is inseparably involved in our concept of Christ, in our grasp of the Incarnation and its consequences," Msgr. Edward J. Waterson declared yesterday.

BOSTON, Aug. 9 (UP) -- Pinch-hitting Ted Williams, appearing at bat for the second time after returning from Korea, crashed a home run in the seventh inning today but the Indians salvaged the finale of a three-game series with the Red Sox and won, 9 -- 3.

The Canadian dollar was active and higher last week as a steady demand brought the currency to its highest premium since early May. A strong undertone marked limited activity in the British pound sterling.

CHICAGO, Aug. 9 (UP) -- Bill Serena punched a pinch single with the bases filled and the score tied in the ninth inning today to win the finale for the Cubs, 6 -- 5, after the Chicagoans had bowed to the Phillies, 7 -- 0.

SOUTH MANTOLOKING, N. J., Aug. 9 -- The charred bodies of Rosemary Angela Cosgrove, 3 years old, and her sister, Rhomelia Ann Cosgrove, 7, were found today in the garage of their summer home, which was destroyed by fire last night.

Mayor Impellitteri lamented yesterday the refusal of Carmine G. DeSapio, the Tammany leader, to back his candidacy for re-election and implied clearly that Mr. DeSapio's position was divisive of Italian-American solidarity.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Aug. 9 (AP) -- Fred M. Warner of Birmingham, Mich., drove his powerful Allard J2X over the twisting 3.5-mile Lockbourne Air Force Base track today to win the featured fifth race of the national sports car meet.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 -- The United States public may be brought to a greater awareness of the dangers of an atomic attack on the United States because of the announcement yesterday in Moscow by Premier Georgi M. Malenkov, indicating that the Soviet Union had learned the secret of the hydrogen bomb.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 (UP) -- Senator Paul H. Douglas, Democrat of Illinois, said today that passage of a bill admitting 214,000 refugees was the Administration's only "major" legislative achievement of the Congressional session that has just ended.

The sale of Radio Station WINS, 50,000-watt New York broadcasting installation, to Western interests, subject to the approval of the Federal Communications Commission, was announced here yester- day. The proposed purchase price is $450,000.

Net income of the C. I. T. Financial Corporation for the first six months this year increased to $16,391,130, equal to $1.70 a common share, from $14,524,014 or $1.51 a share for the initial half of 1952.

Cotton futures prices in the domestic market continued to hold to a narrow trading range last week, showing only small irregular net changes at the end. At the close of trading on the New York Cotton Exchange on Friday, final quotations were 45 cents higher to $1.25 lower a bale, or up 9 points to off 25 points.

ANCHORAGE, Alaska, Aug. 9 -- Work is progressing rapidly on a large four-mile tunnel being bored through Goat Mountain thirty-three miles north of here at the Federal Bureau of Reclamation's Eklutna power project.
Quick thinking by a playmate saved the life last night of a 10-year-old boy who had fallen across the power rail of the New York Central Railroad tracks on the West Side.

SAN FRANCISCO -- For a full and richly publicized century, San Francisco has been evolving her tradition of cookery. It has been celebrated profusely in literature and in journalism alike. Yet, it is a cosmopolitan thing, borrowed and adapted from kitchens the world around and owing little to local genius.

MAMARONECK, N. Y., Aug. 9 -- By winning the last two holes of the match, Don Cherry, member of the 1953 United States Walker Cup team, and Frank Strafaci, former metropolitan amateur and national public links champion, captured the final of the John G. Anderson Memorial tournament at the Winged Foot Golf Club today.

Detailed plans for beautifying the Columbia University campus in preparation for the university's bicentennial next year were announced yesterday by Dr. John A. Krout, vice president and provost of Columbia. The improvements, upon which work was started last week, were made possible by the acquisition of 116th Street between Broadway and Amsterdam Avenue. a vast greensward. It is expected the project will be completed before the beginning of the bicentennial observance in January.

A 63-year-old man, bitten by a pet rattlesnake, battled for his life early today at St. Elizabeth's Hospital with the help of a scarce, life-saving serum obtained after a desperate search of the metropolitan area.

Increasingly the city seems to have adopted a "try and get it" policy in connection with partial tax exemption for middle-income housing projects built by private enterprise. Partial tax aid is the only device which has produced such housing since the war -- except in outlying areas.

OLD WESTBURY, L. I., Aug. 9 -- Led by Al Parsells, the Westbury poloists rallied to score three goals in the final two periods to gain a 9-6 decision over the Hurricanes in the rain on Bostwick Field today.

NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 9 -- Sheikh Mohammad Abdullah, dismissed early this morning as Prime Minister of the state of Jammu and Kashmir, was under arrest today, along with his Revenue Minister, Mirza Afzal Beg.

ROCQUENCOURT, France, Aug. 9 -- Although propaganda winds have been blowing peace offensives and counter-offensives across Europe this spring and summer, the task of Allied military planners remains substantially unchanged.

One of every sixteen children in the public elementary schools of New York City -- 38,777 of a total of 585,334 last term -- fails to get a full day's schooling because his school is too crowded. For the same reason, 15,935 attend classes outside of the normal 9 A. M. to 3 P. M. session, as of last term's count.

SPRING LAKE, N. J., Aug. 9 -Vice President Richard M. Nixon was forty minutes late for a golf appointment this morning because he got lost driving the ten miles to the Spring Lake Golf and Country Club from the cottage his family is occupying this month at Mantoloking.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 9 -- The 1953 masters pairs championship was won this afternoon by the youthful Chicago contract bridge players, William A. Rosen and Milton M. Ellenby. At the close of today's fifth and final session at the Jefferson Hotel the winners were well ahead of the ninety-six-pair finalist field.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 (UP) -- The Senators rapped three pitchers for thirteen hits and a 12-3 victory in the second game of a double-header today after Duane Pillette and Satchel Paige had combined to give the Browns a 3-0 triumph in the opener.

CHICAGO, Aug. 9 (AP) -- In one of the most spectacular finishes in golf history, Lew Worsham today sank a 140-yard approach shot on the final green for an eagle 2 to beat Chandler Harper by one stroke in the "world" professional tournament at Tam o' Shanter and collect $25,000, the richest prize in the game.
Former Maj. Sahiba Gokcen, who was Turkey's first and only woman air force pilot, said here yesterday that all air forces should have women combat fliers.

ROME, Aug. 6 -- Italian boutique designs, one of the most widely copied and exported items of the Italian fashion industry, continued inventive this year. Many buyers in Florence to view the recent Italian Fashion Show at the Pitti Palace felt that boutique and sportswear should have received foremost place in the exhibition, surpassing "alta moda."

GENEVA, Aug. 9 (AP) -- The World Jewish Congress debated in committee today a resolution that would urge Germany to take effective measures "to suppress and eradicate any attempt to revive Nazi doctrines menacing democracy."

NEWPORT, R. I., Aug. 9 -- The thirty-fourth annual tennis week in Newport, opening tomorrow, will be marked by the debut of Miss Melba Colt, daughter of Mrs. Boswell C. Colt of Bristol, who is at Lilac Cottage for the summer. Mrs. Colt is giving a dance at Bailey's Beach Wednesday evening to present her daughter.
COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Aug. 9 -- Five hundred members of the International Congress of Zoology, now in session here, took time off this week-end for informal discussions.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 (AP) -- The Defense Department today identified 117 additional Korean battle casualties in the fighting that ceased July 27. The new report listed seventeen killed, eighty wounded, sixteen missing and four injured. Casualties from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut follow:
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 9 -- Gene Markey, after a long absence from movie work, is reactivating his independent company, Markfilms, to produce a film of his current novel, "Kingdom of the Spur."

It's time to chalk up a few ideas for back-to-school togs. Mothers, get busy! Think about the type of dress you are going to make for Mary, Jane or Barbara to sally forth in when the school bell begins to ring.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 (UP) -- The American Civil Liberties Union today defended federal investigations of civil rights violations in the states. It said the Federal Bureau of Investigation usually stepped in after the state agencies had failed to act.
SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., Aug. 9 -- Lewis Hoad today won the Eastern grass-court tennis championship, the most important prize to fall to him in this country.

While sitting around during melancholy evenings groups of parents are certain sooner or later to begin again a discussion which originated far, far back. This is, at what age are children at their worst? As a topic for conversation it must go back to the twilight talk on the terrace before the first habitable cavern when mothers, dressed in leopard-skin peasant blouses, waited for the children to come home from the neighborhood picture cave.
CINCINNATI, Aug. 9 -- A grandslam home run by Duke Snider off Southpaw Joe Nuxhall in the fourth inning paced the Dodgers to a 9-1 victory over the Redlegs at Crosley Field today before 19,938 fans.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, who had one book, "India and the Awakening East," published by Harper on July 22, has another on the concern's October list. Written in collaboration with William A. DeWitt, "U. N.: Today and Tomorrow" is a story of the world organization in which Mrs. Roosevelt was an American representative for seven years.

New York City has many problems, but surely none of them is more important or less susceptible of early, satisfactory solution than the need for good housing and adequate public schools. The second installment of the series of articles in THE TIMES on the city's plant appears today, and deals with the inadequacies in these fields.

The Knox School of Cooperstown, N. Y., has purchased the La Rosa estate, a sixty-acre property at Smithtown in Suffolk County, L. I. The school, a preparatory institution, will celebrate its fiftieth anniversary next year when it will move to the Smithtown property.

A large advance subscription has been reported for the Sept. 22 benefit performance of the Sadler's Wells Ballet Company to aid the scholarship fund of the Institute of World Affairs, Inc. Mrs. Alexander M. Hadden is president of the organization.

The luxury trades indicated no slump as the American National Retail Jewelers opened a display of products worth about $10,000,000 in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday. W. Waters Schwab, president of J. R. Wood and Sons, Inc., engagement and wedding ring maker, said a coast-to-coast tour indicated most jewelry retailers expected an increase of about 25 per cent in business this year.

ZURICH, Aug. 9 -- By submitting to Congress a bill proposing "complete return of all West German private property vested in the United States during World War II," Senator Dennis Chavez, Democrat of New Mexico, whose initiative was endorsed by Senator Pat McCarran, Democrat of Nevada, changed the outlook for Europe so profoundly at one stroke that Swiss authorities hastened to examine the changes that would be wrought on European economy as a whole.

STAMFORD, Conn., Aug. 9 -- While the Internationals were "washed out," Warner M. Willcox scored his fourth straight triumph and ninth of the season with the Twister in Class S in the Rocky Point Sailing Club's regatta today, a joint event staged by the Stamford Yacht Club and Rocky Point.

ROME, Aug. 9 -- Attilio Piccioni, Christian Democratic Premier-designate, called on President Luigi Einaudi this morning and definitely undertook to form a new Government to replace the one headed by outgoing Premier Alcide De Gasperi, who resigned July 29.

TEHERAN, Iran, Aug. 9 -- Nine Opposition deputies who have taken asylum in the Parliament building sent a 350-word cablegram today to Dag Hammarskjold, United Nations Secretary General, accusing Premier Mohammed Mossadegh's "rebel" Government of violating the human rights declaration and of driving freedom from Iran with a plebiscite designed to establish a dictatorial regime.

Though attention in this country has been centered largely on Premier Malenkov's remark about the hydrogen bomb, the feature of his speech last week-end which will appeal most to Soviet citizens is its at least verbal emphasis upon increasing the standard of living.

LENOX, Mass., Aug. 9 -- Charles Munch and the Boston Symphony Orchestra concluded this afternoon a week-end of music-making at Tanglewood with a concert featuring Gregor Piatigorsky, 'cellist, as soloist.

The five-story apartment house at 1745 Broadway, in Brooklyn, has been purchased by the Estate Securities Company, operators, from Frank J. Fitzgerald, plumbing contractor, in a deal negotiated by George Brezel, vice president in charge of apartment house sales of Sydney M. Siegel Co., Kew Gardens brokers, who recently sold two apartment buildings at 1738 and 1742 Broadway in the Williamsburg section of the borough for Mr. Fitzgerald.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 (UP) -- The A. F. L. Plumbers Union, in its official publication, is attacking the Eisenhower Administration while its president-on-leave, Martin P. Durkin, sits in the Cabinet as Secretary of Labor.

Despite all the obstacles confronting it, the cause of European unification advanced another hopeful step when the foreign ministers of six European nations unanimously agreed not only on the desirability but on the absolute necessity of creating a supranational European political community based on a common economy and common defense.
Since the turn of the century, with the exception of the war years, a metropolitan rowing championship regatta has been held annually.

The official list of decrees issued since the March 15 meeting of the Supreme Soviet and approved at last week's meeting in Moscow did not include the amnesty for minor crimes announced late in March. The Soviet press has indicated that at least some persons have been freed under the amnesty, and it was thought unlikely that the failure to ratify the move would change the status of those released.

ROME, Aug. 9 -- A United States Air Force C-119 Flying Boxcar with twenty-four persons aboard crashed into the Mediterranean off Tripoli today. Scattered reports said five survivors had been picked up.

Ray Bolger, dance comedian and satirist, will be presented regularly over the A.B.C.-TV network Thursdays at 8:30 P. M., beginning Oct. 8, under alternate weekly sponsorship of the American Tobacco Company and the Sherwin-Williams Company. The show will be produced from special films made in Hollywood.
MILWAUKEE, Aug. 9 (UP) -- The Braves swept a double-header from the cellar-dwelling Pirates today, 7 to 4 and 10 to 3, to run Milwaukee's victory string to five in a row.
INDIAN RIVER, Mich., Aug. 9 (AP) -- One of four winners in the fifth annual top o'Michigan out-board motor marathon was disqualified today before the prizes could be awarded.

MOSCOW, Aug. 9 (Reuters) -- The Soviet Unions annual air show to mark National Air Force Day was postponed today as winds and low hanging clouds swept over the capital a few hours before the celebrations were due to begin.

HONG KONG, Monday, Aug. 10 (Reuters) -- Charges that prominent North Koreans had plotted with United States authorities in South Korea from shortly after the end of World War II to overthrow their Communist regime were made today by the official Communist New China News Agency.

GOSHEN, N. Y., Aug. 9 (UP) -The annual pre-Hambletonian tension began mounting at Good Time Park today as the time drew near for owners to pay the $1,000 starting fee that will make their horses eligible for the richest event in harness racing history on Wednesday.

THE familiar routine of television programs asserting that they have access to the "confidential" files of various governmental agencies has now extended to the United States Army and reportedly soon will involve the State Department. It is time that the Federal Government got out of the business of giving its endorsement to commercially produced detective shows.

CHICAGO, Aug. 9 -- In point of volume wheat futures were again the most active on the Board of Trade last week. Oats trade was larger than the previous week while corn, rye and soybeans business for the week was smaller than the preceding period.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 (AP) -- The international monetary fund announced today it had deviated from established policy to give Turkey a helping hand over an economic rough spot, perhaps signaling more liberal future policies by the agency.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 9 (UP) -- President Elpidio Quirino of the Philippines declared today that he had recovered from stomach surgery and intended to stay in his country's Presidential race as the candidate of the Liberal party.

LONDON, Monday, Aug. 10 -- The statement by Soviet Premier Georgi M. Malenkov that the United States no longer had a monopoly of the hydrogen bomb, has been received in London with seemingly at least equal skepticism and with perhaps less apprehension than in Washington.

THE melancholy dull-red brick schoolhouse on the south side of Thirteenth Street east of the Avenue of the Americas was hailed as "the perfection" of what a schoolhouse should be when it was opened in 1847 as Ward School 35.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 (AP) -- Small Business Administrator William D. Mitchell announced today he will start a series of meetings this week with "all segments" of private industry and finance "on plans for expanded Government aid to small business."

Somebody always seems to be taking a dig at the Long Island Rail Road. The line, which is fighting to keep out of the red, complained yesterday that it has lost new ground -- specifically five baskets of it.

TEHERAN, Iran, Aug. 8 -- This troubled capital could hardly contain its feelings of delight and relief today over Soviet Premier Georgi M. Malenkov's statement that he hoped for a settlement of Soviet-Iranian border disputes and "common financial claims."

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 9 (UP) -- The Athletics, aided by a grand-slam homer by Gus Zernial, rallied to tie the Tigers, 8 -- 8, in ten innings today after a pinch single by Ray Murray won the ten-inning opener of a double-header for the Athletics, 4 -- 3.

Pay no attention to those reports about Richard Rodgers and Oscar Hammerstein 2d having a new show on the boards this season, advises Mr. Hammerstein. To bolster this assertion, Mr. H. says the team has a crowded agenda ahead of them.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 -- The members of Congress who remained in Washington after the first session of the Eighty-third Congress adjourned early last Tuesday morning still seemed to be occupied today with the problems of taxes, budget balancing and anti-subversive activities.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 (AP) -- The first issue of The Democratic Digest, the new monthly magazine published by the Democratic National Committee, sold more than 100,000 copies, party headquarters said today. One-and two-year subscriptions to the pocket-sized publication were reported to have passed the 30,000 mark.
DORTMUND, Germany, Aug. 9 (AP) -- The third world university games were opened in the huge Rote Erde Soccer Stadium today.
Truck loading, the perennial bugaboo of pier superintendents in the Port of New York, has been largely brought under control by the Holland-America Line at its Hoboken terminal.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 (AP) -- Two major unions of the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations announced a "no raiding" agreement today in which each pledged to respect areas already organized by the other.

The Rev. Dr. James Gordon Gilkey, minister of the South Congregational Church, Springfield, Mass., preaching yesterday morning at the Riverside Church, 122d Street and Riverside Drive, on "What It Means to Trust in God," listed "basic facts about human beings" to remember in this connection.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Aug. 9 -- Pakistan's reaction to the dismissal of Sheikh Mohammad Abdullah as Prime Minister of India-held Kashmir was one of long-range optimism. While neither Prime Minister Mohammed Ali nor Ghulam Mohammed, the Governor General, would comment tonight, I. H. Quersyi, the Minister for Kashmir Affairs, said he was "not surprised at the announcement."

RYE, N. Y., Aug. 9 -- Jim McCulloh of the American Yacht Club, sailing his Lagniappe, won the Western Long Island Sound district championship of the Lightning Class as the two-day series wound up in heavy weather off the American Y. C. today.

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, Aug. 9 -- The Netherlands Bank has decided upon further important liberalization of foreign exchange by abolishing a decree that all foreign exchange claims must be turned over to it.

CHICAGO, Aug. 9 -- Bullish reports on rust developments in the Northwest failed to cause more than temporary rallies in wheat and the high cash prices prevailing at outside markets also failed to inspire buying of consequence last week.

SEVEN ISLES, Que., Aug. 3 -- This booming port will be the outlet for the iron ore which will start coming down next year from the Hollinger-Hanna mines at Knob Lake, 360 miles to the north. The so-called Ungava mines are expected to produce up to 20,000,000 tons annually and help replace the high-grade iron ore which is going to run out in a matter of decades at Minnesota's Mesabi Range.

HONG KONG, Aug. 8 -- About 1,700 Chinese have entered suits in various United States district courts seeking declaratory judgments in support of their claims to United States citizenship, according to the United States Consulate General here.

The Rev. Dr. James Gordon Gilkey, minister of the South Congregational Church, Springfield, Mass., preaching yesterday morning at the Riverside Church, 122d Street and Riverside Drive, on "What It Means to Trust in God," listed "basic facts about human beings" to remember in this connection.
CUSTER, S. C., Aug. 10 -- A thorough overhauling of state lobbying laws was urged today by Harold R. Fatzer, Attorney General of Kansas and president of the National Association of Attorneys General.

Mrs. Julia Kiene, director of the Westinghouse Home Economics Institute, has had wash-day worries for ten years, the period of time she has spent in a continuing research into the washability of man-made fibers.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Aug. 10 -- After wrangling for six hours today the delegates at the International Congress of Zoology here managed to unravel a complicated knot that has hog-tied zoology for more than half a century.

OCEANPORT, N. J., Aug. 10 (UP) -- J. C. Brady's Artismo won the featured $41,050 Sapling Stakes for 2-year-olds today as Monmouth Park lowered the curtain on its fifty-day summer session with records for attendance and total mutuel handle.

HONK KONG, Aug. 10 -- The 3,388-ton Heinrich Jessen, a Danish-operated coastal steamer that plies regularly between Hong Kong and Tientsin, was fired on and intercepted by an unidentified gunboat about 11:30 A. M. yesterday off Amoy, in the Formosa Strait, according to messages received from the ship.

Civil air cadets from sixteen European and Latin-American countries completed a three-day visit to New York and a three-week visit to the United States by sight-seeing here yesterday. The 120 young men were impressed by the city and the United States. And their hosts, the Civil Air Patrol and the Air Force, were impressed by the visitors, many of whom are already rated pilots.

TRENTON, Aug. 10 -- The Arnold Constable Corporation has taken a ninety-nine-year lease on property with a 150-foot frontage on East State Street, the main business thoroughfare here, and will erect a modern branch store on it soon, it was learned today.

CAIRO, Aug. 10 -- The Egyptian Government continued its offensive against domestic communism today with the arrest of fifty-one party workers, but displayed more tolerance for the international variety in a Foreign Office trade report listing the Soviet Union and its satellites as the most likely source of arms for the nation's forces.

Dr. Edward M. Weyer Jr., anthropologist and editor of Natural History magazine, has returned from the interior of Brazil, where he succeeded in spending two months with one of the most primitive Indian groups in the world, Dr. Harold E. Anthony, deputy director of the American Museum of Natural History, said here yesterday.

DENVER, Colo., Aug. 10 -- John Foster Dulles, the Secretary of State, declared today that the United States would not repatriate some Communist prisoners of war if the Communist authorities in North Korea hold back any Americans.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 (AP) -- A special report to President Eisenhower made public today said Korea needed four to five years of American help, plus large-scale financial reforms at home, to rebuild

Mayor Impellitteri's remarks at a Harlem political rally do not make good reading. They state or imply a conviction that Americans should vote according to national origin, or perhaps according to color of skin, rather than simply as Americans. Our news columns yesterday reported that the Mayor lamented the refusal of Carmine G. DeSapio, Tammany leader, to back the Mayor for re-election, and "implied clearly that Mr. DeSapio's position was divisive of Italian-American solidarity."

KARACHI, Pakistan, Tuesday, Aug. 11 -- In a new effort to end the long-standing friction between Pakistan and India over the disputed State of Kashmir, Prime Minister Mohammed Ali yesterday asked Jawaharlal Nehru, the Indian Prime Minister, for an immediate meeting in New Delhi.

Primary aluminum production in this country set records in both the June quarter and the first half of this year, and the industry's average daily production in June was at a new peak of almost 7,000,000 pounds, the Aluminum Association reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, chairman of the Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations, reported today that his group had received new evidence indicating that at least one member of the Communist party had access to secrets of the military establishment, the Atomic Energy Commission and the Central Intelligence Agency.
The Eisenhower Administration is making solid advances to better times, Secretary of Commerce Sinclair Weeks asserted last night.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 10 -- Rain drummed on Saratoga roofs last night and, after a clearing in the morning, there was an assortment of showers -- some light, some heavy and some in between -- during the afternoon. So the race track was deep in mud, and the customers were looking for horses that have what is known in the trade as "mud figures."

SCRANTON, Pa., Aug. 10 -- Scores of apparel and lingerie plants in northeastern Pennsylvania were closed today by a strike of about 10,000 members of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, A. F. L.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 10 -- Maj. Gen. Vagn Bennike, the Danish military officer in charge of the United Nations Truce Supervision Organization in Palestine, said today that because of mounting tensions between Israel and the neighboring Arab states, he would ask for additional military observers to be assigned to watch the troubled frontier lines.

Stocks held their ground well under the bearish influence of lower wheat and cotton prices and gave up little ground yesterday. Volume on the New York Stock Exchange rose to 1,090,000 shares, from 950,000 on Friday.
BONN, Germany, Aug. 10 -- Georges Bidault, French Foreign Minister, visited Bonn today and lunched with Dr. Konrad Adenauer, West German Chancellor.

CHICAGO, Aug. 10 -- Benjamin Schwartz, Assistant Attorney General of Illinois, filed a forty-six-page brief today in Federal District Court here, denying allegations by Roger Touhy, now in Stateville Penitentiary, that local and Federal law enforcement officers illegally had conspired to put him in jail.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- Addressing an audience of 350 schol ars, Government officials and others meeting to consider "the problem of Soviet imperialism," Mr. Kennan and other speakers stressed that the Soviet challenge was likely to continue for an indefinitely long period.

CROTON-ON-HUDSON, N. Y., Aug. 10 -- Irked by the state's continued failure to eliminate Sunday traffic congestion on the Albany Post Road here, village officials carried the fight today to motorists themselves to see if they couldn't do something about it.
PANMUNJOM, Korea, Tuesday, Aug. 11 (AP) -- Cpl. Henry Price of 511 Baltic Street, Brooklyn, volunteered at the start of the Korean prisoner-of-war exchange to drive correspondents to Panmunjom.

NOW is the month when the college football coach sets himself to his bread-and-butter letter writing, and it's no polite thank-you note for a lovely time he is sending off. In a few weeks his squad assembles for fall practice and there is much he has to say to each member, reviewing the 101 details of playing his position properly and cautioning him to report back a hundred per cent fit.
PARIS, Tuesday, Aug. 11 -- The threat of an unlimited general strike in public services, railroads, mines and other nationalized sectors hung over this country today.

Late last year Robert Rossen confidently set about to acquire the dramatic rights to Colette's novelette, "Julie DeCarneilhan," so he could adapt it for his long-desired return to the Broadway stage. After many months of protracted negotiations, the writer-producer-director of the Academy Award winner, "All the King's Men," admitted the other day that the deal finally had been secured.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 (UP) -- Frances E. Willis was sworn in today as a United States Ambassador -- the first career woman diplomat ever to advance to that post in the Foreign Service.
The Moore-McCormack Lines called for the "fullest state and city Government action" to end a strike that has made the company's North River pier idle for the last seven days.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 (AP) -- George Kennan, former United States Ambassador to Moscow, predicted today that a revolution would break out eventually "in the Soviet orbit" and he pictured Russia's danger to the outside world as probably on the wane.

Mr. Malenkov may have been lying, and he may not, when he said that Russia now has the hydrogen bomb. However the case may be, the only safe course for the free nations to pursue is to act as though Russia already had the bomb. Some day she will have it, and then we must face destiny's tragic question: Is the continued freedom of the free world worth its possible cost?

GARDEN CITY, L. I., Aug. 10 -- Korean-tested know-how in troop carrier operations, air evacuation and air supply was demonstrated at Mitchel Air Force Base here today for reserve officers and airmen of the 514th Troop Carrier Wing encamped at the base for their annual fifteen-day training period.

A trainer was talking about Apprentice Charles Albert O'Brien. "Horses run for him," the trainer said. In the first race Charles Albert succeeded in getting W. E. Schlusemeyer's Fiddler's Girl rolling in the late stages, and the filly rolled home at $48.70.

The twelve-month extension of the Reciprocal Trade Agreement Act, as enacted by Congress, represents "an unavoidable compromise of the political and economic issues inherent in the United States at this time."

Mayor Impellitteri described as a hoax yesterday reports that Carmine G. DeSapio, leader of Tammany, had been threatened with physical violence for continuing to back Borough President Robert F. Wagner Jr. of Manhattan for the Democratic nomination for Mayor.
OTTAWA, Aug. 10 (Canadian Press) -- Canada may turn out an above-average volume of wheat this year, the experts say, but the crop may be late and the quality questionable.

NORFOLK, Va., Aug. 7 -- Improvement in shipboard living conditions and a restudy of ship complements and ship missions can lead to an approximate 10 per cent reduction in the number of men assigned to naval vessels. The resultant saving can be perhaps $100,000,000 annually for the Atlantic Fleet alone.

Confirming recent indications, the Economic Commission for Europe reports that during the first quarter of this year the traditional and troublesome European dollar deficit, better known as the "dollar shortage," has reached "virtual extinction," and that the European central banks are now increasingly able to build up their gold and dollar reserves.

Yesterday's showings of back-to-college fashions, with their now familiar theme that college girls share the same taste in clothes as their career girl contemporaries, were enlivened by many new amusing ideas.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Aug. 10 -- Harry Dee, professional at the Dellwood Country Club in New City, and Max Feinberg of the same club, the one-time Westchester junior titleholder, captured the Westchester County Golf Association's pro-amateur championship by combining for a gross best-ball round of 33, 32 -- 65 at the Knollwood Country Club today.

TEHERAN, Iran, Aug. 10 -- An agreement has been concluded with the Soviet Union to hold high-level negotiations here to iron out "all differences," including financial and territorial disputes, the Iranian Government announced today.
NEWPORT, R. I., Aug. 10 -- The seventy-second annual Newport tennis tournament began today on the turf courts of the Casino where the national championship was first held.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture forecast this year's cotton crop today at 14,605,000 bales of 500 pounds gross weight -- a figure which virtually assures production controls on next year's crop.

Disturbing cost-profit trends in the wholesale drug distribution field, as highlighted in a report for 1952 just issued by the National Wholesale Druggists Association, show this billion-dollar industry is faced with after-tax profits below depression levels.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development reported today a net income for the fiscal year ended on June 30 of $18,485,411, compared with $15,872,883 in the preceding fiscal year.

OTTAWA, Tuesday, Aug. 11 -- The Liberal Government that has governed Canada since 1935 was returned safely to power yesterday, winning its fifth national election in the last eighteen years. Louis St. Laurent, the dynamic French-Canadian who took the mantle of the late Mackenzie King, was re-elected from his own district in Quebec and will be the next Prime Minister.

The third article in THE TIMES series on New York City's governmental plant provides an insight into a number of departments and crosses bureau lines in a study of methods used in maintenance of automotive equipment. It is clear that no single, consistent standard governs such maintenance.

A new foreign exchange policy in Brazil sent coffee futures prices to the maximum daily decline of 200 points (2 cents) here yesterday but elsewhere on the New York commodity exchanges trading was light and prices were only slightly lower.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- Joseph W. Martin Jr., Speaker of the House of Representatives, appointed four members of the House today to serve on a special commission to help observe the bicentennial of Columbia University.
CHICAGO, Aug. 10 -- Joseph P. Ryan asked the American Federation of Labor today for one last chance to clean up his racket-ridden International Longshoremen's Association.

THE tremendous increase in the number of bow and arrow experts over the last few years has prompted the New Jersey State Fish and Game Council to announce an extra week of deer hunting this year. A season for the archers extending from Nov. 21 to Dec. 12, inclusive, has been proposed and its adoption is expected following a public hearing in Trenton on Aug. 20.

LONDON, Aug. 10 -- British Government securities and leading industrials responded to small but persistent demand on the stock market here today, with gains up to one-eighth per cent for the gilt edge stocks and as much as one shilling (fourteen cents) for the industrial equities.

SOREL, Que., Aug. 6 -- Titanium has been called "the metal of the future," and if it ever fulfills its promise the new industry will largely have to thank the pilot smelter here on the St. Lawrence River which is learning how to produce titanium slag the hard way.

NOROTON, Conn., Aug. 10 -- Alexandra (Sandy) Widmann, 17, of the host Noroton Yacht Club, won the first two races, then placed second, to lead the qualifiers with 41 of a possible 42 points as the preliminaries of the Long Island Sound junior sailing championship were completed today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 10 -- Glenn Ford's pet project, a film based on the life of Patrick Henry, is taking shape and may well be his next undertaking. The actor, now in Brazil making "The Americano" for Robert Stillman, has interested the producer in the subject, which has been a long time aborning.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- United States experts on the Soviet Union expressed belief today that a 25 per cent increase for military expenditures was concealed in the new Russian budget, and said they thought most of it would go for increased development of atomic and hydrogen weapons.

The sales and earnings of the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company and its subsidiaries in the first half of 1953 were higher than in any previous comparable period, P. W. Litchfield, chairman, disclosed yesterday in his semi-annual report.

The first session of the Eighty-third Congress, like that of the Eighty-second, has failed to debate, let alone enact, a major civil rights bill. The only law adopted even resembling a civil rights measure was one that repealed a 100-year-old restriction against the sale of liquor or firearms to Indians.

BERLIN, Aug. 10 -- West Berlin officials announced tonight that 70 per cent of the residents of the Soviet sector of Berlin already had obtained gift food parcels. Consequently they said a new program would begin Aug. 27 in which visitors to West Berlin would get second helpings.

The North American Zone Davis Cup tennis final between the United States and Canada will be held at the Mount Royal Tennis Club in Montreal. Sept. 11 to 13, it was disclosed yesterday by Alrick H. Man Jr., chairman of the United States Davis Cup Committee.

SPRINGFIELD, N. J., Aug. 10 -- Despite some erratic golf on the back nine, Mrs. Theodore Hawes of Baltusrol took the lead after the first round for the Clara Rossin Trophy today in the women's Metropolitan Association senior championship over the Baltusrol Country Club course.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- As the Ways and Means Committee of the House of Representatives continued its day-and-night hearings preparatory to widespread revision of all taxation laws, a spokesman for the Bell Telephone System, Mark R. Sullivan, denounced excise levies on phone calls tonight as being so discriminatory as to discourage the use of the phone.
Norman B. Boothby has been named dean of the Parsons School of Design and Miss Shirley M. Carson has been made registrar and director of placement.

Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., heads a syndicate that is offering a $7,650,000 issue of Louisville and Nashville Railroad 3 1/4 per cent equipment trust certificates today. The certificates, the first installment of a proposed issue of $9,645,000, are priced to yield 2.90 per cent for the Aug. 15, 1954 maturities, and 3.35 per cent for the longer maturities ending in 1968.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., Aug. 10 (AP) -- An official of the state labor department said today the investigation of the alleged exploitation of twenty-two Brooklyn boys would continue, but he explained that the department had no basis for action at this time. The boys, ranging in age from 14 to 17, said they were taken to an upstate farm and put to picking beans and berries for almost nothing.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 10 -- National Theatres, Inc., one of the major movie house networks and the first to report on its financial status since President Eisenhower refused to sign the movie tax relief bill, today announced consolidated net income totaling $1,873,521 for the thirty-nine weeks ended last June 27.

The New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program will send four mobile units to various parts of the city today to help spur lagging donations to the August quota of 15,000 pints. Last week only 1,295 pints were contributed.
A capacity crowd of 50,000 is anticipated tonight when the Giants and Dodgers square off in the first of a three-game series at the Polo Grounds.

NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 10 -- Three persons were killed by police fire in Srinagar yesterday and one person was injured in the violent protest demonstrations that followed the summary dismissal of Sheikh Abdullah.

GENEVA, Aug. 10 -- The World Jewish Congress began discussion today of a series of resolutions designed to express the position of the Jews of the world on a wide range of problems of current importance.

The present heads of the New York State Department of Mental Hygiene are able men and are striving to achieve a high level of care and treatment of patients in the New York State mental hospitals. It is possible to concede this much now, though a similar concession could not have been made several years ago.

TEHERAN, Iran, Aug. 10 -- Premier Mohammed Mossadegh again won more than 99.9 per cent of the votes as balloting in the provincial cities and towns throughout Iran was completed today on a plebiscite on whether the Majlis, lower and sole existing House of Parliament, should be dissolved by the "will of the people."

In a realignment of executives of Eastern Air Lines, Inc. which this year is celebrating its twenty-fifth anniversary, Captain Eddie Rickenbacker yesterday became the first chairman of the board of directors of the company, and Thomas F. Armstrong succeeded him as president.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- The "Census Clock," an electrically driven United States population recorder in the lobby of the Department of Commerce Building, hit the round figure of 160,000,000 at two minutes and seven seconds after 11 A. M. today.

Signs reading "Baby Carriages and Shopping Carts Prohibited" have been painted in six-inch letters on the sides of the 873 buses of the Surface Transportation Corporation in an effort to avoid accidents. The vehicles are operated in Manhattan and the Bronx and carry an average of 27,000,000 passengers a month.
New accessories for the home that are decorated with motifs inspired by sports are in a large collection now available at the Crossroads of Sport, Inc., 15 East Fifty-fourth Street.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 10 -- Walter O'Malley, president of the Dodgers, appeared unexpectedly here tonight after flying out from New York and his presence promptly stirred speculation that he was about to discuss a new contract with Manager Chuck Dressen.

Three new films open at first-run theatres today. At the Normandie is 'So This Is Love," a Warner Brothers Technicolor musical of the life of Grace Moore, starring Kathryn Grayson, Merv Griffin, Joan Weldon and Walter Abel. John Monks Jr. wrote the screen play, Gordon Douglas directed and Henry Blanke produced.

No one would criticize Herbert Hoover if he rested on his laurels on his California hilltop at the age of 79, which he reached yesterday. He has done his fair share of unselfish work in the world from the days when he directed Belgian relief down through his career in the Presidency and in the labors of his later years in the field of governmental reorganization.

NEWARK, Aug. 10 -- A heavyset, middle-aged woman walked into the United States Savings Bank at 772 Broad Street this afternoon and, without arousing the suspicions of twelve patrons, handed a teller a note demanding $250. The teller, Miss Fay Biunno, of 10 Thirty-eighth Street, Irvington, gave the woman two $100 bills and a fifty.

MILWAUKEE, Aug. 10 (AP) -- Warren Spahn coasted to his fifteenth victory tonight as the Braves batted around for five runs in the second inning and downed the Cards, 8 -- 2, before 34,950 fans. The victory cut Brooklyn's National League lead to six and one-half games over the runner-up Braves.
Cotton prices were easier on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday and the close was 5 to 21 points net lower than on last Friday.

MILWAUKEE, Aug. 10 -- Nearly every state in the Union was represented among the players who registered today for the fifty-fourth annual open championship of the United States Chess Federation. The tournament, which drew 182 entries, is being sponsored by the Milwaukee Chess Foundation and the Municipal Recreation Department.

Lulu Perez, 125 1/2, Brooklyn featherweight, stopped Frankie Sodano, 124 3/4, Philadelphia, in 2:36 of the fifth round in a scheduled ten rounder at Eastern Parkway, Brooklyn, last night. A crowd of 1,200 saw Referee Harry Kessler halt proceedings to save Sodano unnecessary punishment.

CHICAGO, Aug. 10 -- Stop-loss selling of wheat prompted by fears that the nation's wheat growers would reject Federal marketing quotas in the referendum next Friday caused semi-panicky conditions in the wheat pit here today. Declines for the session were 9 1/4 to 10 cents, with March off the 10-cent daily limit.

LONDON, Aug. 10 -- Selwyn Lloyd, Minister of State, embarked at London Airport tonight for New York where he is to head Britain's delegation to the United Nations special assembly on Korea, which opens Aug. 17. In the interim he intends to consult with United States officials and consolidate the Foreign Office's preliminary understanding with the State Department on the two nations' efforts at the session.

The tenth anniversary of the dedication of the United States Merchant Marine Academy at Kings Point, L. I., was celebrated yesterday when 143 men were commissioned ensigns in the Naval reserve at graduation ceremonies. The new officers represented forty-four states, the District of Columbia and Puerto Rico.
WESTBURY, L. I., Aug. 10 (AP) Major Camp, owned and driven by Eddie Cobb of Washington Court House, Ohio, made a strong stretch drive to win the Port Jefferson Pace tonight at Roosevelt Raceway.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 (UP) -- The Fish and Wildlife Service today issued liberalized migratory waterfowl hunting rules for the 1953-54 season and said hunters may shoot until sunset in all flyways.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 (AP) -- Bob Porterfield, the major leagues' shut out king, made it eight white-washings for the season tonight with a blazing one-hitter against the Red Sox as the Senators squeezed out a 2-0 victory before a Red Cross benefit crowd of 13,631.

HARTSDALE, N. Y., Aug. 10 -- Mrs. Harry J. Nevil Jr. of Hudson River carded 44, 37 -- 81 over the Scarsdale Golf Club's par-75 layout of 6,190 yards today to repeat as medalist in the Women's Westchester-Fairfield Golf Association championship.

The first troopship to arrive here from Korea since the truce was signed docked yesterday at Pier 10, Army Base, Stapleton, S. I. She was the 17,500-ton Navy transport Marine Carp and she brought back 1,382 troops and seventy-five officers from the fighting area, a total of 1,457. One hundred and thirty-two of the veterans are from New York.

SEOUL, Korea, Aug. 10 -- President Syngman Rhee told the Koreans once again today that the achievement of unification of their country had only been postponed and that if a political conference failed to unify Korea after three months "sixteen United Nations, including the United States, will join us in an effort to achieve our unification by other means."

The city's collection of between 3,000 and 5,000 recordings of historic events here, including City Hall receptions of the last twenty years and all the Mayoral speeches of the late Fiorella H. La Guardia, William O'Dwyer and -- to date -- of Vincent R Impellitteri, will be put into new permanent archives in the Raymond V. Ingersoll Memorial Library in Brooklyn.

The story of its Avcoset program for quality control of washable rayon fabrics will be told by the American Viscose Corporation to the consumer this fall in national magazines. Hirshon-Garfield, Inc., is the agency for the program, which includes an extensive merchandising effort.
New York collected $25,012,842, half of the nation's total customs receipts for July, Robert W. Dill, Collector of Customs here, announced in his first monthly report yesterday.

LUSAKA, Northern Rhodesia, Aug. 10 -- The great body of organized native African labor south of the Equator is engaged here in a trial of strength with the management of Northern Rhodesian copper mines, which is wavering on the edge of developments that could close down three-fourths of the copper industry, the third largest in the world.

John J. (Gene) Sampson, who as business agent of the traditionally insurgent Local 791 of the International Longshoremen's Association, A. F. L., has been labor boss of Chelsea's waterfront for many years, was ousted from his job last night at a mass membership meeting.
A parked truck containing packages of furs valued at $50,000 was stolen yesterday on West Thirty-first Street while the driver was making a delivery in a near-by building.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 (AP) -- Despite the halt in Korean fighting, the burden of required military service on the nation's young men has not changed.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, Aug. 10 -- Grigoire Preoteasa, Deputy Foreign Minister, said today that Ana Pauker, former Rumanian Foreign Minister who had been purged, had not been arrested and was living in Bucharest.

MEXICO CITY, Aug. 10 (AP) -- The morning newspaper Excelsior, in a copyrighted story, will say tomorrow that Sloan Simpson O'Dwyer by-passed Roman Catholic Church approval and obtained a Mexican civil divorce from William O'Dwyer, former New York City Mayor and former Ambassador to Mexico.

MOSCOW, Aug. 10 (UP) -- The Supreme Soviet formally approved today the ouster of Lavrenti P. Beria, Minister of Internal Affairs, from the Government and the Communist party and ordered him tried by the Supreme Court.

The increasing volume of books available for reading in this year of 1953 makes one realize the shortness of life and the difficulty each new generation faces in choosing those which will endure. Seneca, in the first century A. D., observed that "a multitude of books distracts the mind."

Referring to the article "Of Old Clothes" in Topics of The Times of Aug. 5, on the wisdom of a man wearing old clothes for a vacation, there is another side to the question. A vacation may be an opportunity to experience the advantages of the many new styles and fabrics in clothing, some of which are more suited to vacation needs than old clothes.

Operations in the nation's steel mills were at a slightly higher rate last week than a week earlier, and were expected to pick up a little more this week. The industry operated at 94.0 per cent of theoretical capacity and turned out 2,119,000 tons of ingots and steel for castings last week, compared with 92.6 per cent and 2,087,000 tons the week before, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

Seventy-one-year-old Joseph Morris, described in the police line-up yesterday as having "buried practically every detective who ever arrested him," faced the prospect of spending his last years in jail because of his latest apprehension.

There are only two books published today. One is Joseph Foster's novel "Stpeet of the Barefoot Lovers" (Duell, Sloan Pearce, $3.75), which i reviewed today. The other is a collection of Frank Sullivan's humorous magazine pieces entitled "The Night the Old Nostalgia Burned Down."
DENVER, Aug. 10 -- President Eisenhower, faithful to old custom, is living with his mother-in-law, Mrs. John S. Doud in her home at 750 Lafayette Street, during his stay in Denver.

TOKYO, Tuesday, Aug. 11 -- The Communists angrily charged yesterday that the United Nations Command had permitted agents of the Chinese Nationalist Government of Generalissimo Chiang Kaishek to indoctrinate and coerce Chinese prisoners of the Korean war in South Korean camps. The Communists demanded that stockades where captives who refused repatriation are held be turned over to Indian control.

NEWARK, Aug. 10 -- Paul L. Troast, Republican candidate for Governor, said today that he had written to all members of New Jersey's Congressional delegation voicing his approval of a Constitutional amendment that would relieve New Jersey commuters of paying New York state income and Philadelphia wage taxes.

Every 2,000 miles, the ninety-one automobiles maintained by the Public Works Department are rolled up on a chassis dynamometer. On this apparatus a car can be operated as if in motion, while connected to various testing devices for preventive check-ups.
Greater cooperation between American business and the seventy-nine medical schools of the nation was urged yesterday in a report issued by the National Fund for Medical Education.
A special anniversary dinner and a retreat parade yesterday marked the thirty-fifth anniversary of the First Army, whose headquarters is on Governors Island.

A syndicate of investors represented by Leon Schreiber has purchased 220 Wadsworth Avenue, a six-story apartment building occupying the blockfront on the west side of the avenue from West 184th to 185th Streets. The property, which is assessed at $180,000, was sold by Leo Bercow and Walter Berger, operators, who were represented by Charles H. Kelman attorney.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 (AP) -- New appeals were made today to President Eisenhower to veto a bill that would give to five states civil and criminal jurisdiction over Indians.

Despite scattered reports that the Madeira cockroach, which is common to the West Indies, might have established a foothold with the increase in the number of Puerto Rican families arriving here, it appeared yesterday that colonies of the insects here are rare indeed.

THAT modern Western civilization is subject to serious ills is a truth that only the blindly complacent or sublimely ignorant can deny. And one of its minor ailments, it seems to me, is the fashionable search of some writers for truer values in unlikely quarters. Life is not necessarily better because it is lived primitively nor are people necessarily finer in character and more Joseph Foster spiritual because they are unfortunate.

INCHON, Korea, Aug. 10 -- Shortly before 6 P. M. today, 328 repatriated American prisoners of the Korean war boarded the military transport Gen. Nelson M. Walker for a voyage to San Francisco. The ship will leave tomorrow morning and is scheduled to arrive Aug. 24.

ROCQUENCOURT, France, Aug. 10 -- The visit of Harold Talbot, United States Secretary of the Air Force, at Supreme Allied Headquarters here highlights the important behind-the-scenes steps being taken to coordinate and improve the still insufficient air forces of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

TRENTON, Aug. 10 -- William F. Tompkins, United States Attorney for New Jersey, disclosed today that he had reached an agreement with Bergen County authorities on the seizure of Harold John Adonis, fugitive now en route to Hoboken aboard the Holland-America liner Veendam.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 (UP) -- If housewives are spending more at the grocery store these days they have only themselves to blame, according to Agricultural Department statisticians.

Foreign students who recently expressed the opinion that having the privilege of conducting unchaperoned romances was their favorite American freedom may or may not have realized that our mode of courtship is not an open pathway to marital bliss.

Repeatedly I read letters in the various metropolitan dailies expounding on the unbearable noise and inherent dangers from airliners flying to and from our three airports. Little has been said on behalf of the pilots who are doing their utmost to cut down on the noise from the engines over residential areas.

Construction of an earthen embankment to replace the burned] trestle of the former Rockaway line of the Long Island Rail Road across Jamaica Bay will start today under a contract let by the New York City Transit Authority.
