Rapid transit service to the Rocksways is planned when the work is completed in about t]ree years.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 (UP) -- Representative Joseph W. Martin Jr., Republican of Massachusetts and Speaker of the House of Representatives, appointed today five members of the House to a special commission to study United States problems on foreign trade.

GOSHEN, N. Y., Aug. 10 (AP) -- The names of twenty-three horses were dropped into the entry box today for the twenty-eighth Hambletonian Stake, making the world-famous trotting test the richest in history with a gross value of $117,117.98.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- Lawrence E. Gooding, chairman of the Wisconsin Employment Relations Board for many years, is reported to be the White House choice for appointment to the National Labor Relations Board to succeed Paul L. Styles, resigned.
WIESBADEN, Germany, Aug. 10 (AP) -- All twenty-four men aboard a United States Air Force C-119 were safe tonight after parachuting from the big transport plane over the Libyan desert late Saturday.

The natural gas industry generally welcomed the news yesterday that the Federal Power Commission had granted to the United Fuel Gas Company rate increases calculated to give the company a 6 1/4 per cent return. The company's request for approval of the new rates had been pending for two years.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- Joseph W. Martin Jr., the Speaker of the House of Representatives, asserted tonight that President Eisenhower and the Republican Congress had made "a great start" toward reversing "the world-wide trend toward total statism."

The protests of Governor Fine of Pennsylvania, Battle of Virginia and Dewey of New York against what they term the "invasion" of state sovereignty by the F. B. I. are worth rather more than a passing glance.

BLOOMFIELD, N. J., Aug. 10 -- Walter H. Freygang, president of two strike-bound manufacturing companies, was held for the grand jury today on a charge of atrocious assault and battery with an automobile. Mr. Freygang, 62 years old, last Tuesday tried to drive his car through a massed picket line of 100 strikers to reach his plant.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Aug. 10 -- The last and most important event of the twenty-sixth annual National Contract Bridge Championships continued this afternoon here at the Jefferson Hotel with eight teams playing the third of seven round-robin matches for the United States 1953 team-of-four championship.
CHICAGO, Aug. 10 (AP) -- A Chicago liquor concern today sued for $600,000 treble damages against two distilleries, charging they conspired to remove Old Prentice whisky from the market.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- The National Federation of American Shipping reported today that more than 82,500 seamen were now employed on ocean-going ships of the American Merchant Marine.

The evening performance of the new F. Hugh Herbert comedy, "A Girl Can Tell," on Nov. 12, at a theatre yet to be named has been taken over by the trustees and women's board of the Kips Bay Boys Club as a benefit for that organization.
CHICAGO, Aug. 10 (UP) -- The nation's wheat farmers vote on Friday to decide whether the Government should clamp marketing quotas on next year's wheat crop.

The Department of Traffic expects to cut the cost of signs and related equipment for controlling traffic by $250,000 and at the same time to improve the quality of the traffic, it was made known yesterday.
SYDNEY, Aug. 10 (AP) -- General Motors-Holden Ltd., earned last year the highest net profit ever recorded by an Australian company -- yet did not declared an ordinary dividend.

The strikes in France come as a great shock because they must be taken as symptomatic of a profound unrest among a wide field of the working classes. The core of the discontent in the present instance is in the P. T. T. (Post Office, Telephone and Telegraph services), but the impressiveness of the movement lies in the widespread support these civil servants got from many other employes in the Government services and nationalized industries.

TOKYO, Aug. 10 -- Japan's Diet (Parliament) concluded today its sixteenth postwar session after eighty-five days of bitter debates, occasional fist fights and several major legislative accomplishments.

That religious group knows as the Shakers, once numbering thousands and now only a handful, put their imprint not only on American handicrafts but also on our food and cooking. A new volume, "The Shaker Cook Book: Not By Bread Alone" (Crown, 283 pp.), traces the culinary influence of this high-thinking people who, dwelling in communities, had excellent standards in every department of daily living, including eating.

LONDON, Tuesday, Aug. 11 (AP) -- The Moscow radio interpreted today the pledge of prompt resistance to any new Communist aggression in Korea -- signed by the United States and its fifteen Allies in the war -- as giving President Syngman Rhee of South Korea a green light to scuttle the truce.

CHICAGO, Aug. 11 -- The wheat market held a choppy price course today, with a lot of short profit-taking but with general buyers still inclined to stand pat pending the referendum on Friday on next year's marketing quota.
Donations of blood to the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program totaled 123 pints on Monday -- one of the smallest collections of the summer. The low was 116 pints, taken on July 3.

Brazil's easing of foreign exchange regulations on cocoa, of which the trade learned yesterday, failed to have the depressing effect on futures here that the similar action on coffee had had on Monday.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 11 -- A nation-wide organization of attorneys specializing in personal injury claims and working with doctors who specialize in courtroom testimony are costing every bus, streetcar, train and automobile rider, money, it was charged today at the American Transit Association's annual convention.
HONOLULU, Aug. 11 (UP) -- Seventeen ill American soldiers freed from Communist prison camps leave tonight on the last stage of their flight home.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- Martin P. Durkin, Secretary of Labor, defended the Administration today against an attack by the man who is acting in his former post as president of the Plumbers' Union, A. F. L. He declared that if he had not been satisfied with President Eisenhower's record in labor matters he would have resigned from the Cabinet.

With roughly 10 per cent of the issues traded selling ex-dividend, stock prices drifted irregularly lower yesterday. Motors and rails were softest, while utilities continued to hug the upside, as they have for several trading sessions.

The Citizens Non-Partisan Committee voted last night to disband because of its failure to reach agreement with Liberal and Republican party leaders on a coalition candidate for Mayor to rid the city of machine politics.
The strike of union dock workers against the Government-owned liner Argentina moved into its second week yesterday as state mediators took steps to get the men back to work.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- The Senate's Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations heard a second group of witnesses whose identities it guarded in a closed session today, in a move to determine whether secret documents passing through Government printing plants were accessible to persons who might use them against this country.

GREAT NECK. L. I., Aug. 11 -- Roslyn (Cookie) Swift, the youngster from Glen Oaks who holds four golf titles including the state championship, shot 39, 37 -- 76 to take gross honors today in the women's Cross County Golf Association medal play tournament at the Deepdale Club.

GENERATION of criminals and neighborhood topers have left whimsical or embittered thoughts in writing on the walls of long-abandoned, windowless cells in old East Thirty-fifth Street police station with outlaws' scorn for city property.

After long years of agitation by Rockaway residents for municipal rapid transit, the city began yesterday a mechanical agitation that is to lead to a tie-in of the peninsula communities with the IND subway division in two and one-half years.

The recently formed United Merchant Marine Officers Association, an independent organization of deck and engineer officers with headquarters at 15 Moore Street, has had rough sailing since its new officers were announced on July 29. It has lost both its president and second vice president.

Harry L. Smith Jr. of Pittsburgh, staff manager of product sales for the Aluminum Company of America, will be sworn in today in Washington as director of the aluminum division of the National Production Authority, it was announced yesterday.
A group of "little wedding gowns," whose length was a happy compromise between ballerina and waltz, was shown along with full-length bridal dresses by the Rosette Pennington Shop yesterday.

MOSCOW, Wednesday, Aug. 12 -- The Soviet demand for compensation was submitted to Mr. Bohlen by Andrei A. Gromyko, Deputy Foreign Minister, in connection with the presentation to Mr. Bohlen of new details of a Soviet investigation into the attack on the plane.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was quiet yesterday, and closing prices were 3 points lower to 9 points higher than on Monday.

FREEDOM VILLAGE, Korea, Aug. 11 -- The United Nations began getting back today some of the "bad boys" of the North Korean prisoner camps, the ones who, despite repeated punishment, kept causing the Communists a great deal of trouble during their years of captivity.

The article published today in THE TIMES series on city plant and related problems reveals that the path to governmental economy is a rocky one. Home care for many indigent patients who might otherwise be occupying expensive hospital bed space is proving a sound and highly beneficial method.

NAZARETH, Israel, Aug. 11 -- -- The highest Moslem religious authority in Israel, Sheikh Taher el Tabari of Nazareth, demanded today that Arabs in Israel and Jews in Arab countries be given the right to leave the countries in which they now reside.

Best Co. upheld the cause of good fashion classics that have weathered many a season in its showing of back-to-college designs yesterday. In addition there were many fresh and new looking interpretations of the season's top fashions, and for extra news and excitement such items as a real vicuna sweater at about $80 -- a price that would wreck havoc with a college girl's allowance.

It was no surprise that the Liberal party should have won the general election in Canada on Monday. However, almost everybody in that country seemed to believe that, while the Liberals would be returned to power, they would have a reduced majority. As it happened, they won 171 seats in Ottawa's House of Commons out of 265.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 11 -- In a summary of general trends in territories under its jurisdiction the United States reported to the United Nations today that native participation in legislative responsibility for economic, social and educational advancement was widening in Alaska, Hawaii, the Virgin Islands, American Samoa and Guam.
MANCHESTER, Mass., Aug. 11 (AP) -- Eight seeded stars advanced and an unseeded player scored a minor upset in the opening round of the Essex County Club women's tennis tournament today.

MAJOR league baseball is a professional sport played by talented and highly specialized artisans who rise to the upper levels only after having been carefully screened and developed through a graduated, well-organized system of minor leagues. It is, therefore, and by reason of its long, 154-game schedule, which reduces to a minimum the value of flukish victories, a sport that runs closer to form than most any other.

In the lobby of the Commerce Department Building in Washington there is a large electric population calculator geared to add this country's births and new arrivals and to subtract her deaths and departures. Last Monday the number 160,000,000 flashed on the board and stayed there for a few seconds.

The equivalent of more than $50,000,000 in new hospitals is being made available to the city's sick poor by just one of several "decompression devices" that the Hospital Department reports it is using to stretch municipal resources and to reduce hospital overcrowding.

In your editorial on the Fire Department's Annual Report you refer to its omission to mention certain recommendations by the Mayor's Committee on Management Survey, and particularly the recommendation for the reduction of the number of fire companies suggested by A. C. Hutson.

The apartment building containing fifty-two suites and occupying a plot 100 by 100 feet at 30 Copper Street, south of 204th Street, in the Dyckman section of Manhattan, has been sold by Walter L. Rothschild to an investing client of E. J. Stark.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., Wednesday, Aug. 12 (AP) -- The nine-day-old strike of the 13,000 southern New England truck drivers was settled this morning. Arthur W. Devine, State labor director of Rhode Island, announced this morning that American Federation of Labor Teamster Union negotiators and representative sof the commercial haulers had reached an agreement for ending the strike.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (AP) -- The Department of Defense today identified 225 additional casualties in the Korean war prior to the truce of July 27. The new list reported 57 killed, 113 wounded, 45 missing in action and 10 injured. The following names were listed for New York and New Jersey (none from Connecticut):

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 11 -- Leading Western delegates, arriving in New York today for the General Assembly session opening Aug. 17, were agreed on trying to keep the meeting limited to arrangements for a Far Eastern political conference and were waiting for a sign of Soviet intentions.

Thousands of independent fabricators in the United States would be deprived of aluminum they need to keep their plants going if the Department of Justice succeeds in preventing the Aluminum Company of America from purchasing 600,000 tons of Canadian aluminum.

HANOI, Vietnam, Aug. 11 -- Gen. Rene Cogny of the French Union forces announced today that the French air base at Nasan, in the Thai hills of North Vietnam (Tonkin), was being evacuated in the largest air operation ever attempted in Indo-China.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 11 -- A timely reminder that greatness in cinematic expression, no matter what shape the screen itself may have in the future, will determine the success of the motion-picture business was sounded last night by Y. Frank Freeman at the monthly board meeting of the Screen Producers Guild.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Aug. 11 (UP) -- Mal Whitfield, American middle-distance runner, again came within a tenth of a second of equaling the world record for 1,000 meters tonight when he won the event in 2:21.4 as United States track and field stars took eleven out of thirteen events in an international meet.

Permit me to thank you for your editorial of July 30 regarding the proposal submitted to the United States Government by the Philippine Government for a revision of the present trade agreement as provided in the Philippine Trade Act of the United States Congress of 1946.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- A Senate Armed Services subcommittee reported today that enough ammunition was on hand in Korea to meet any emergency there but that the supply of all the Western Allies combined was "inadequate for an all-out war."
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 11 (UP) -- John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers, called today for a reorganization of labor so that it could more properly exert its strength and influence.

PARIS, Aug. 11 -- Unlimited strikes on the railroads and in the public services and mines began today as French labor continued its offensive against the Government and, by the same token, threw the economic life of the country into a state of nervous confusion.
SHENANDOAH, Iowa, Aug. 11 (AP) -- A majority of those participating in a Midwest Livestock Feeders Association informal poll indicated today they favored cost-of-production farm program.
MEXICO CITY, Aug. 11 -- Former Ambassador William O'Dwyer said today that he did not recognize the civil divorce obtained June 3 in Cuernavaca, Mexico by his wife, the former Sloan Simpson.

WESTBURY, L. I., Aug, 11 (AP) -- Slipping through on the rail in the backstretch, Mr. Primrose, owned by Arch McDavid of Inglewood, Calif., went on to win the Setauket Pace tonight at Roosevelt Raceway by a half length.
CHICAGO, Aug. 11 (AP) -- Hogs are the scarcest at the stockyards this week since a packinghouse workers strike in March, 1948, and today prices rose another 25 to 75 cents a hundred pounds.
Renato Salem from Bologna pointed out correctly, in his letter published in THE NEW YORK TIMES on Aug. 8 last, that "the Ljubljana plain is the door to Italy and to the Western system of defense."

SPRINGFIELD, N. J., Aug. 11 -- Mrs. Theodore Hawes of the home club won the Women's Metropolitan Seniors Golf Championship today when she scored 45. 42 -- 87 for a 36-hole gross of 173 at the Baltusrol club course.

TEHERAN, Iran, Aug. 11 -- Wine jugs all over this land of Omar Khayyam were tilted today in celebration of the news that Premier Mohammed Mossadegh had decreed the postponement of prohibition for one year.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Aug. 11 -- Prime Minister Daniel F. Malan today attacked India and the United Nations and warned Britain that South Africa's patience was becoming exhausted on the question of incorporation of certain British protectorates into the South African Union.
LONDON, Aug. 11 (UP) -- The Soviet Union was reported today to be buying large quantities of butter throughout the world in line with Premier Georgi M. Malenkov's promises of more food.
LONDON, Aug. 11 -- It was a historic occasion for ballet lovers at the Royal Opera House in Covent Garden tonight.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- Creation of "pools of capital" from which small business enterprises can borrow funds they need was described as the major objective of the Small Business Administration today by William D. Mitchell, head of the new agency.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (AP) -- The Atomic Energy Commission announced today the award of forty-seven contracts totaling $2,183,144 all to universities and private institutions for non-secret research associated with Atomic energy.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Aug. 11 -- Petitions filed today with the Westchester Board of Elections for the Sept. 15 primaries set up the largest number of Republican contests in the forty-five years the party has been the dominant political power in the country.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 11 (AP) -- Curt Simmons, Phils' southpaw, blanked Pittsburgh, 3 -- 0, on six hits -- all of them singles -- tonight after the Pirates had whipped the Philadelphians, 7 -- 4, in a suspended game preceding the regular contest.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Aug. 11 -- Internationally famous bug specialists at the International Congress of Zoology disclosed here today how wasps were forced to fly in wind tunnels so that man might not lose an estimated 20 per cent of his crops to creatures of six and occasionally eight legs that fly, jump, crawl, suck or pollute potential foods as they do at present.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- A spokesman for the Department of Defense said today that military authorities in Korea handling the prisoner exchange expected to find, as they had in the April-May return of United States soldiers, some who had succumbed to Communist propaganda.

The nation's steelmakers produced 9,284,000 net tons of ingots and steel for castings last month, a new July high. The output for the first seven months of this year, at 67,229,936 tons, was larger than that of any comparable period.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (AP) -- The Democratic Digest said today that Democratic cooperation with President Eisenhower so far had made "all the difference between success and failure for his Administration."
I am astonished to read many articles speculating on the cause of Beria's downfall and assuming the diminution of Soviet terror.

HEAVEN forbid that anyone should try to find another trend in television programming, but strange things seem to be happening. To look at video on many evenings recently, it would seem as if the TV screen had become a roost for nothing but unpleasant and unattractive characters concocted by dramatists in desperate need of psychotherapy.
CHICAGO, Aug. 11 (AP) -- Seven hundred and fifty policemen were assigned today to patrol the area around a public housing project on the southeast side.

ATHENS, Wednesday, Aug. 12 -- Survivors reaching this city today said the death toll from a series of earthquakes in the remote Ionian Islands would pass 400 by the time all victims were dug out from heaps of rubble. The official count, however, remained at 150.
A sharp quarrel, with a heavy seasoning of sarcasm and indignation, has broken out between the United Nations and New York City on the parking of cars in and around the world capital.
Those with a taste for smoked fish and the energy to seek it out might make their way to Russ and Daughters, a famous little shop at 179 East Houston Street.

JERUSALEM, Aug. 11 -- Universities and secondary schools throughout the world were called upon to strengthen, or institute, the teaching of the history of science in a resolution adopted today near the close of the seventh International Congress for the History of Science.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 11 (Reuters) -- The Central Committee of the Yugoslav Communist party today rebuked members for drifting away from Marxism and "ceasing to be revolutionary."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture forecast today this year's corn crop at 3,330,418,000 bushels and the wheat crop at 1,202,829,000 bushels. The corn estimate is 6,083,000 bushels less than last month's forecast of 3,336,501,000 bushels, and the wheat figure 28,121,000 bushels more than the previous estimate at 1,174,708,000.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (AP) -- An Interstate Commerce Commission examiner said today railroads serving Newport News and Norfolk, Va., should be permitted to cut their freight rates on shipments of imported iron ore to the Great Lakes.

The Metropolitan Rapid Transit Commission was sharply criticized yesterday by City Planning Commissioner Goodhue Livingston Jr. for "dragging its feet." Mr. Livingston indicated that the transit agency, set up by the Legislature in 1952, had been stymied by Governor Dewey. He accused the Governor of "lack of boldness and vision in the field of metropolitan transportation."

CLEVELAND, Aug. 11 (AP) -- Minnie Minoso's three-run homer featured a five-run uprising in the seventh inning tonight as the White Sox drove Bob Lemon from the box and scored a 6-2 victory over the Indians.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- The Soviet Union demanded today that the United States pay compensation for the shooting down July 27 of a Soviet IL-12 passenger plane in which it was alleged fifteen passengers and a crew of six were lost.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Aug. 11 -- Claude Harmon of Winged Foot, played the second nine of the Knollwood Country Club course in thirty-one strokes for a five-under-par 66 to lead the field in the initial round of the Westchester open golf championship today.

CHICAGO, Aug. 11 -- The complete text of the letter from George Meany, president of the American Federation Labor, to the International Longshoremen's Association, recommending suspension of the pier union from the federation, follows:

The Executive Council of the American Federation of Labor decided yesterday to recommend that the A. F. L. Convention in St. Louis on Sept. 21 suspend the charter of the International Longshoremen's Assocation until it removes officers with criminal records, eliminates racketeering and does away with the shape-up system of hiring.

CUSTER, S. D., Aug. 11 -- Attorney General Herbert Brownell Jr. predicted today that the Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act, passed by the Eighty-third Congress, would become generally accepted as a principle of international law and that it would speed the orderly development of natural resources by the Federal Government without infringing on the rights of states.
The model of a boat built especially for women drivers, including one back-seat driver, has been placed on exhibition at the Seamen's Church Institute of New York.

The ousting of John J. (Gene) Sampson as business agent of Local 791 of the International Longshoremen's Association, A. F. L., on Monday night brought no immediate repercussions along the Chelsea waterfront yesterday. But informed observers said the ouster indicated that control of the local had been taken over by a group of "young Turks" known as the "Scanlon mob."

THE old house called Dunmeade was the show place of Newtown. Strangers looking through the gates were always surprised by its vaguely Spanish architecture when they had naturally expected white pillars. The Chadleys were the wealthiest family in Newtown; but they hadn't built Dunmeade. A mysterious Spaniard had done that before the War Between the States.
MUNSAN, Wednesday, Aug. 12 (AP) -- The United Nations Command's official list of United States prisoners of war freed today in the eighth day of the Korean prisoner-of-war exchange:

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 11 -- As play in the National Bridge Championships neared its close it appeared here today that five teams would be locked in a tie in the eight-team round-robin struggle for the 1953 United States team-of-four contract bridge supremacy.

LONDON, Aug. 11 (Reuters) -- The Australian touring cricket team defeated Lancashire by seven wickets at Manchester today to gain its first victory in England since early July. The team's last six games have ended in draws.

ROME, Aug. 11 -- Sixty-nine-year-old Prof. Auguste Piccard, who soared 55,000 feet into the stratosphere in a balloon in 1932, today made the first test of a new "bathyscaphe" in which he hopes to establish a new world record by diving to a depth of 10,000 feet into the Mediterranean Sea.

TRENTON, Aug. 11 -- The Appellate Division of the New Jersey Superior Court ruled today that secondary picketing of products rather than persons was legal. Accordingly, it declared void a lower court injunction.
MILWAUKEE, Aug. 11 (UP) -- The Cardinals scored a run in the ninth inning tonight to end the Braves' winning streak at six games, with a 4-to-3 victory, before 34,436 fans.

TOKYO, Aug. 11 -- Even before he is well established as chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff in the United States, Admiral Arthur W. Radford has become a figure of great interest and influence throughout East Asia.

MOSCOW, Aug. 11 -- Soviet consumers this year are to get 36,000,000 pairs of shoes more than they received in 1950. Of this quantity 7,000,000 pairs will be women's wedgies and 34,000,000 pairs will have sponge rubber soles.

The gradual evolution of the modern chair over the last century is traced in a small but interesting exhibition opening today to the public at the Museum of Modern Art. Devoted to the production of one company, Thonet Brothers, Inc., a pioneer in chair designs, the display includes thirteen chairs designed and made between 1836 and 1952, and much supplemental photographic material showing these chairs and other Thornet furnishings in use.

Plans for a $5,000,000 shopping center in Edmonton, Alberta, to be built by a group of United States investors, were announced here yesterday. The projected center, covering thirty acres in a rapidly-growing section of the Alberta capital, would be the largest of its kind in Canada, it was noted.

Walter P. Reuther, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, who returned from six weeks in Europe yesterday on the liner America, labeled as "sheer nonsense" recent speculation that the C. I. O. was disintegrating and asserted that his organization was in a "stronger position than ever."

TOKYO, Wednesday, Aug. 12 (AP) -- The Pyongyang radio announced last night a drastic shake-up of the North Korean Communist party and the "suicide" of Hukaii, a former Vice Premier, close on the heels of a purge of the Red regime.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 11 -- There was a rousing finish in the $5,000-added handicap that topped the Saratoga Association's racing program today. Heads apart at the end of the run of a mile and a furlong over a muddy track were (1) C. V. Whitney's Fly Wheel; (2) Ogden Phipps' Great Captain, and (3) the favorite, Mrs. Widener Wichfield's French-bred Guardian II.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (AP) -- President Eisenhower has tentatively decided to name David J. McDonald, president of the United Steelworkers of America, C.I.O., to the seventeen-member Commission on Foreign Economic Policy, it was reported today.

Supreme Court Justice Samuel M. Gold dismissed yesterday a petition for reinstatement of former Patrolman Meyer E. Rubenstein, who was discharged from the Police Department May 12 for lying about his communistic connections at an official department inquiry.
LONDON, Aug. 11 -- Prices continued to advance in nearly all markets today, with selected domestic industrials, particularly store shares, making the best shouting.

BERLIN, Aug. 11 (AP) -- Walter Ulbricht, leader of the East German Communist party, struck down Red party leaders in four big industrial cities today. He accused top Communist officials in Dresden, Magdeburg, Halle and Karl Marx Stadt (Chemnitz) Chemnitz of treason in connection with the June 17 revolt.

OTTAWA, Aug. 11 -- Staggered by the extent of their party's defeat in yesterday's general election, members of the Progressive Conservative party were talking today of the need for a general renovation.

A suggestion that the time had arrived for Burton Lane, who is remembered as the composer of "Finian's Rainbow," to be redeemed from Hollywood and to furnish the melodies for "By the Beautiful Sea," starring Shirley Booth, has been acted upon.

The Texas Eastern Transmission Corporation, operator of a gas pipeline system, reported yesterday a net income of $4,332,021 in the first six months of this year, after all expenses, including preferred stock dividends. This was equal to 79 cents a common share, and compares with a net of $5,490,794 or $1 a share in the first half of 1952.

Bernard Lamstein, 36-year-old Brooklyn landlord, was forced yesterday in Kings County Court to repay to eighty-four present or former tenants nearly $30,000 he had admitted receiving in bonuses and illegal rent increases.

NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 11 -- Some surprise was evident in official circles here today at an urgent communication received by Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru from Pakistani Premier Mohammad Ali requesting an early meeting to discuss the latest developments in Kashmir.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- Atomic war by the Soviet bloc against the United States is "highly probable," though it cannot be proved inevitable, Jules Menken, a leading British student of Soviet affairs, said today at the second day's session of a conference on Soviet imperialism.

New York's air raid warning sirens wailed yesterday morning with slight reaction from the city's millions. The third mechanical test this year of the 578 sirens prompted only eighty-one Manhattan dwellers to telephone to the police, but not a single inquiry was made at the Police Information Booth at Broadway and Forty-third Street.

HONG KONG, Aug. 11 -- Gen. Peng Teh-huai, commander of Chinese Communist troops in Korea, arrived in Peiping today and was given a hero's welcome by a large delegation that met him at the railway station, according to the Peiping radio.

BRIONI, Yugoslavia, Aug. 11 (AP) -- President Tito pledged today that Communist Yugoslavia never would return to Russian domination, predicted that Communist China eventually would pursue an "absolutely independent policy," and said prospects for avoiding a third world war look better now.

Juvenal Marchisio, a Domestic Relations Court justice - from Brooklyn, withdrew yesterday as the candidate for President of the City Council on the Liberal party ticket headed by Rudolph Halley, the present President of the City Council who is running for Mayor.

Three books about Africa and its problems are scheduled for issuance in a period of one month. On Aug. 28, the British Book Centre will release a new edition of "Facing Mount Kenya: The Tribal Life of the Gikuyu," by Jomo Kenyatta.

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Aug. 11 -- Flags waved in front of City Hall at noon today, military "brass" stood at attention, shoppers queued to cheer, Main Street traffic slowed and a motorcycle policeman led a frightened heifer the wrong way on a one-way street as New Rochelle complied for the first time with a 1688 agreement to give a "fatt calfe" each year to descendants of Sir John Pell.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 11 (AP) -- Scoring four runs in the first inning, mainly on Don Lund's three-run homer, the Tigers defeated the Browns, 9 -- 3, in the second half of a twilight-night doubleheader tonight after the Browns had taken the first game, 5 -- 2.

A store building built by the Tishman Realty and Conctruction Company for its 800-family Rego Park apartment development on Woodhaven Boulevard in Rego Park, Queens, has been sold by the builders to Samuel Barkin Sons and Sidney Weiderman.

MILWAUKEE, Aug. 11 -- With the notable exception of Max Pavey, champion of the Manhattan Chess Club, New Yorkers were invariably successful in the first round of the fifty-fourth annual tournament for the open championship of the United States Chess Federation being played at the Eagles Club here.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 11 -- The Brazilian Government's new move to spur exports by relaxing foreign exchange controls, effective yesterday, had the immediate effect of strengthening the cruzeiro. The United States dollar that would buy as much as forty-nine cruzeiros at one point in June and forty-one a week ago was worth only thirty-eight and a half this afternoon.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (AP) -Airman First Class Henry Brady, third generation in a line of United States fighting men, became an American citizen today. The ceremony took place in United States District Court, with Judge Walter M. Bastian administering the oath of allegiance.

KUALA LUMPUR, Malaya, Aug. 11 -- The British Government will give new financial assistance to the Federation of Malaya to help meet the costs of combating the Malayan Communist insurrection, it was announced here this afternoon.

Thousands of workers and visitors in the Wall Street area enjoyed a performance yesterday by a United Service Organizations Camp Shows troupe that will depart next Monday for a tour of the Far Eastern Command.

ELIZABETH, N. J., Aug. 11 -- Union County Judge Milton A. Feller dismissed today seven 1950 indictments against seven prominent Democrats in near-by Rahway on charges of vote registration irregularities at the 1940 general election.

Harassed by staff shortages and their own vacation schedules, immigration and customs officers strove to clear 6,848 passengers and their luggage ashore from seven liners that docked here within a two-hour period yesterday morning.

An agreement that may provide Federal old-age and survivors' insurance protection to about 100,000 state and local Government employes was reached yesterday in the office of State Controller J. Raymond McGovern at 270 Broadway.
QUITO, Ecuador, Aug. 11 (AP) -- Ecuador's President has hailed the United States as an "efficient dam against Soviet totalitarianism."

An improved waterproof fabric will be available soon for the rainwear, sportswear and outerwear apparel trades, it was learned yesterday. Developedl by a textile expert who is a civilian employe for the United States Navy, the cloth has been placed in production and will be used this fall for children's snowsuits, windbreakers and men's and women's rainwear.

Copper prices on the London Metal Exchange have climbed a little higher in each trading day since their initial drop last Wednesday when private copper dealings were resumed. Yesterday's closing asked price of 232 1/2 a long ton for spot metal was equal to about 29.06 cents a pound and compared with the final quotation on the opening day of 26.25 cents.

HARTSDALE, N. Y., Aug. 11 -- Mrs. Allison Choate of Apawamis, seeking her third women's Westchester-Fairfield Golf Association crown and retirement of the championship bowl, defeated Mrs. Richard Hellman on the nineteenth hole in the first round of match play in the twenty-eighth title-tourney at the Scarsdale Golf Club today.

Lockheed Aircraft Corporation reported yesterday a backlog of $150,000,000 in orders for its Super-Constellation transport powered with Wright turbo-compound engines. It is the largest commercial backlog in the company's history. For the first six months of the year Leonard K. Schwartz, director of commercial sales, reported a sale of one $1,700,000 Super-Connie every ten days.

Fortnightly meetings are being held by committee members at their homes here and in near-by country places to perfect plans for the fourth annual dinner dance for the benefit of the Hemophilia Foundation, that will take place Oct. 13 in the ballroom of the Pierre.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (UP) -- The Defense Department announced tonight that the Communists had identified 1,022 American G. I.'s "purported to have died" in Red prison camps in Korea.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Aug. 11 -- France has bowed to the Indo-Chinese kingdom of Cambodia and agreed to give it immediate control of its own army, police and judicial system, Cambodian Premier Penn Nouth said today.

There'll be a new, but familiar face in the New York Rangers' line-up next winter. Brig. Gen. John Reed Kilpatrick, president of Madison Square Garden, yesterday revealed that the Broadway Blues had acquired Max Bentley, one of the most consistent scorers in the National Hockey League, in "a straight cash" deal with Toronto.

CHICAGO, Aug. 11 -- The executive council of the American Federation of Labor decided today that the gang-dominated International Longshoremen's Association had not cleaned house as ordered and so recommended its suspension. The long-awaited action was in the form of a letter from George Meany, A. F. L. president, to the top command of the dock union.

The action of Congress in voting that corporations must wait another six months for relief from the excess profits tax, thus placing them on the same time schedule as the citizen who pays a personal income tax has, as most people know, caused the heart of New York's Representative Daniel A. Reed to bleed copiously and protractedly.

OSLO, Norway, Aug 11 -- More than one hundred workers in the field of application of atomic energy for industrial power met here today at the first International Atomic Power Conference held under the auspices of the Atomic Energy Institute.

Sales and earnings of the International Paper Company and its subsidiaries for the quarter and six months ended with last June were substantially larger than those of the corresponding periods last year, the semi-annual report disclosed yesterday.

TRENTON, Aug. 11 -- The Legislative committee that investigated the dismissal in January of former Deputy Attorney General Nelson F. Stamler met in closed session at the State House here today and decided to serve a subpoena on Harold J. Adonis as soon as he set foot in the United States.

Carl Erskine, a previous non-winner at the Polo Grounds, shut out the Giants on two singles last night as the league-leading Dodgers teed off on Sal Maglie and humbled the skidding New Yorkers, 4 -- 0, before a banner throng of 45,604 paying spectators, the second largest crowd of the National League season.

An official of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, A. F. L., announced last night agreement has been reached with a manufacturers group. He said a strike of Pennsylvania dress workers should end by Thursday.
Cleveland, Ohio, sold at public bidding yesterday $10,150,000 of various purpose bonds at a net interest cost of 2.5528 per cent.

VIENNA, Aug. 11 -- Although Austria is a wedge thrust into the Soviet bloc and although Vienna is about the only place where the four Powers still exercise joint control, the first thing that strikes a visitor is that Austrians know as little of what is in the Russian mind as people half a world away.

The big city proved to be too much yesterday for a 13-year-old boy who ran away from his home in Florida five months ago and worked his way to New York by way of Texas by caddying, sleeping at bus terminals and hitch-hiking rides from friendly motorists.

Vim Television and Appliance Stores remains outside the circle of dealers in large household appliances franchised by the General Electric Company, G. R. Brownback declared yesterday. He is manager of General Electric Appliances, Inc., a wholly owned General Electric subsidiary that distributes the company's refrigerators and other major appliances in nine key markets, including the metropolitan area.

GOSHEN, N. Y., Aug. 11 -- All was in readiness today for tomorrow's twenty-eighth Hambletonian, the Kentucky Derby of harness racing. Fair and warm weather has been forecast, the kite-shaped mile course will be fast and arrangements have been completed for the handling of 20,000 followers of the sport.
ALONG with the fish, which are abundant in all sizes and in many species, there's lots of hospitality -- Southern variety -- to be found out on the eastern end of Long Island.

Mrs. Oksana Stepanova Kasenkina, former Russian school teacher whose dramatic leap to freedom from the Soviet Consulate here five years ago today won world attention, avowed yesterday a wish to help the cause of peace without being "pushed around."

PARIS, Aug. 11 -- Harold E. Talbott, United States Air Secretary, said here today that the United States Government had no intention of cutting into the "bone and muscle" of the North Atlantic alliance's air power either by reducing the number of United States air wings assigned to defend Europe or by stretching out the program of future air reinforcements.

TOKYO, Wednesday, Aug. 12 -- Organized Japanese workers at United States military bases throughout Japan left their jobs this morning in a forty-eight hour strike. They demand revision of labor contracts with the United States security forces.

GLEN ROCK N. J., Aug. 11 -- Bruce Alan Miller, 29-month-old son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Miller of 76 Brookfield Avenue, who had been missing since 5 P. M. yesterday, was found about two miles from his home near an apartment building in Fair Lawn at 9:45 o'clock this morning.

TOKYO, Wednesday, Aug. 12 -- The exchange of prisoners of the Korean war today went into its second week as returning captives, both Americans and British, told bitter tales of collaboration by some of their number with Communist guards in prison stockades along the Yalu River.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (AP) -The Treasury announced today that holders of 96.5 per cent of nearly $3,000,000,000 worth of maturing certificates of indebtedness accepted the Treasury's offer to exchange them for new certificates paying a higher interest rate.

In the closing days of this session there was mysteriously sneaked through Congress a bill that could do great wrong to the American Indian population of many states, a bill that President Eisenhower in simple fairness to the Indian ought to veto.

A $15,000,000 issue of The Chesapeake and Potomac Telephone Company of Baltimore City thirty-one year 3 1/2 per cent debentures is being offered publicly today by Harriman Ripley Co., Inc., and associates at 101.52 per cent and accrued interest to yield 3.42 per cent.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Aug. 11 (AP) -- Nino Valdes, Cuban heavy-weight champion, tonight scored a stunning upset by taking a unanimous ten-round decision over the former heavyweight champion Ezzard Charles, at the Miami Beach Auditorium.

OAKLAND, Calif., Aug. 11 -- A cargo ship proclaiming on massive red, white and blue banners that it carried a "United States Government Shipment for Korean Recovery" was maneuvered out of an Oakland berth this afternoon as the Sixth Army band played "The Star-Spangled Banner."

NOROTON, Conn., Aug. 11 -- Frank P. (Skip) Raymond of the Norwalk Y. C. won two races and was second in the other to take the lead for the junior sailing championship of Long Island Sound with 14 points today at the Noroton Y. C.

A new one-story building on plot 165 by 150 feet at 612-34 Eighty-sixth Street, in Brooklyn, has been purchased for investment by Jacob L. Rosenthal, who was represented by the Kreisel Company, brokers. It is leased on a net basis to Robert Hall Clothes, Inc., for twenty years.

NEWPORT, R. I., Aug. 11 -- Extra-set matches were the order of the day for most of the ranking contenders in the Newport invitation tennis tournament at The Casino today as the field was reduced to sixteen players.
William Reid, chairman of the board and president of the Hudson Manhattan Railroad, has been elected to the board of trustees of The Prudential Savings Bank, Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- The Yankees, who were smothering the opposition with quite a display of superlative pitching until Chicago's Billy Pierce shut them out at the Stadium last Sunday, had a little more of it spread on them tonight.
CHICAGO, Aug. 11 (AP) -- Paul Minner needed just one second-inning run in pitching the Cubs to a three-hit 1-0 victory over Cincinnati in the opener of a four-game series before 7,322 today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- A Congressional investigating subcommittee expresses "grave concern" today over what it called "reckless and heedless" attacks on armed services exchanges, commonly known as P. X.'s and Ships' Stores.

Representatives of the striking sand and concrete truck drivers and their employers are scheduled to meet at 2 P. M. today in City Hall for their first joint session since the walkout began on July 3.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug 11 (AP) -- The Red Sox halted late-inning rallies by the Athletics twice tonight to sweep a double-header, 7 -- 6 and 7 -- 5.
RANGOON, Burma., Aug. 11 -- The Burmese secret service today accused two American-owned concerns of supplying arms and ammunition to Chinese Nationalist irregulars in Burma.

TRENTON, Aug. 11 -- The New Jersey Parole Board announced here today that it had granted a parole to Ralph Cooper, the last remaining defendant in the "Trenton Six" murder case. He will be released from the New Jersey State Prison here in November.

V. Murphee, president of the research organization.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- Secretary of Agriculture Ezra Taft Benson raised the possibility today of rigid Federal controls on the 1954 crop of corn--the raw material for meat and dairy products. WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (AP) -- Wholesale prices as measured by the Government reached their highest level of the year last month.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- Liquor control authorities from the states joined representatives of the industry and labor union spokesmen tonight in urging Congress to reduce Federal excise (sales) taxes on alcoholic beverages.

DENVER, Aug. 11 -- President Eisenhower directed all Federal departments and agencies today to begin a new attack on current spending in an effort to keep the public debt from crashing through the $275,000,000,000 legal ceiling. His aim is to avoid calling Congress back into special session to raise that limit.

BERLIN, Aug. 11 -- Almost 3,000 East German farmers who fled to the West have returned to East Germany in recent weeks to claim their abandoned farms, according to Paul Scholz, a deputy East German Premier.

CAIRO, Aug. 11 -- British and Egyptian representatives met for the third time today in the current effort to find a basis for agreement on the future of the Suez Canal zone military base, notably on the conditions under which the base would be reopened to Western forces if the present British garrison is withdrawn.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 12 (AP) -- The Red Sox tonight defeated the Athletics, 3 -- 2, in a ten-inning game.

CHICAGO, Aug. 12 -- Trade in wheat futures was at a much slower pace today, but there were wide fluctuations, with traders inclined to go slow until after the referendum on Friday on the Government's marketing quota plan.

TOKYO, Thursday, Aug. 13 -- Neutral nations representatives charged with policing the Korean armistice took up their duties in North and South Korea today while the United Nations and Communist commands pressed ahead with the exchange of prisoners of war, now in its second week. Seventy-five Americans came back today.

RANGOON, Burma, Aug. 12 -- Kachin State, the broad strategic wedge of Burmese territory between Yunnan Province in China and Northeast India, is agitated following a month-end change of ministers which saw Duwa Sinwa Nawng, head of the state since Burmese independence in 1948, go out of office and Duwa Zaw Lawn, his life-long rival, installed.

CHICAGO, Aug. 12 -- The 822,500-member United Brotherhood of Carpenters withdrew unexpectedly today from the American Federation of Labor in protest against a proposed no-raiding agreement between the A. F. L. and the Congress of Industrial Organizations.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (UP) -- American savers and investors have bought $173,000,000 more series "E" and "H" Savings Bonds than they have cashed in since Jan. 1, the Treasury announced today. The seven-month record is the best since before the start of the Korean war in June, 1950.
TOULON, France, Aug. 12 (UP) -- The Navy announced tonight that two French officers set a world record by diving 1,550 meters (5,084 feet) in a bathyscaphe today.

BERN, Switzerland, Aug. 11 -- Swiss diplomacy now is cautiously seeking to capitalize on the country's traditional position of neutrality by facilitating exchanges of contact between the Eastern and Western ideological blocs and encouraging any tendency toward world detente, or easing of tension.

PARIS, Aug. 12 -- Summoned from the vacation cure he had been taking in Morocco, Lieut. Gen. Augustin Guillaume, the Resident General, conferred today with Premier Joseph Laniel and then returned by air to Rabat, the Moroccan capital, with firm Government instructions to take measures to insure that order should be safeguarded in Morocco.

CHICAGO, Aug. 13 (UP) -- Bob Rush scattered nine hits and struck out ten today as the Cubs nipped the Redlegs, 3 to 1, after Cincinnati beat the Cubs, 10 -- 6, on Andy Seminick's grand slam home run in the first game.

Three apartment buildings at 1011-19 and 1029-35 Freeman Street and 1312-20 West Farms Road in the Bronx have been sold by Alvin M. Greenstein and Herbert S. Goodman to an investor, represented by Lawrence I. Gerber, lawyer.

A decline last week of 104,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end, total supplies were 143,319,000 barrels, compared with 143,423,000 a week earlier and 116,930,000 a year ago.

MILWAUKEE, Aug. 12 (AP) -- Jim Pendleton doubled down the right field foul line to drive in the winning run in the eighth tonight as the Braves nipped St. Louis, 5 -- 3, in the second game of a twilight-night double-header after downing the Cardinals, 8 -- 2, in the opener.

HARTFORD, Aug. 12 -- Connecticut Republican leaders said today they had been asked by the Eisenhower Administration to "clear" the appointment of Judge Thomas W. Swan of Connecticut, who retired on July 1 as a Judge of the United States Circuit Court of Appeals, to the War Crimes Clemency Board in Germany.

CHICAGO, Aug. 12 -- George Meany, president of the American Federation of Labor, made it clear today that before the suspended International Longshoremen's Association could hope to be reinstated it would have to get rid of its present leadership, including Joseph P. Ryan, lifetime president.

TOKYO, Thursday, Aug. 13 -- The Peiping radio today said the Geneva Convention governing treatment of war prisoners gave the Communists the right to hold American and other Allied war prisoners awaiting Communist trial or already serving prison sentences, but hinted they might all be released.

TEHERAN, Iran, Aug. 12 -- Iran and the Soviet Union opened diplomatic talks today on the longstanding border and financial disputes. They hope to inaugurate an era of mutually profitable and amicable relations.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- Secretary of State John Foster Dulles said today that failure to return United Nations prisoners of war because they had been convicted by the Communists of crimes would be a violation of the armistice terms and would be resisted by the United States and her allies.

JERUSALEM, Aug. 12 -- Ideological trends in elementary education, which were carried over by the State of Israel from the British mandatory era, will be abolished next term following approval of the state education law by the Knesset (Parliament) tonight.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (UP) -- The National Foundation for Consumer Credit accused the Government today of using false propaganda in an attempt to gain public and Congressional support for permanent controls over installment credit.

Shipments of rayon and acetate yarn and staple in July totaled 108,000,000 pounds, 3 per cent less than shipments in July, 1952, it was announced yesterday by the Textile Economics Bureau, Inc. For the first seven months the shipments were 726,900,000 pounds or 14 per cent more than was shipped in the corresponding period of 1952.

HAIFA, Israel, Aug. 12 -- Archbishop George Hakim of the Greek Catholic Church said today that in spite of recriminations and friction, relations between the Israelis and 175,000 Arabs who live in Israel were improving.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 12 -- The Canadian-bred Canadiana, a 3-year-old filly that won the 1952 horse-of-the-year title in the Dominion, ran off with horse-of-the-day honors at the Saratoga track this afternoon. She led from shortly after the start of the $17,125 Test Stakes, and finished two lengths in advance of the runner-up.

FAIRFIELD, Calif., Aug. 12 -- In a quiet home coming seventeen Americans freed from Communist prison camps in Korea were carried off a hospital plane of the Military Air Transport Service on litters today at Travis Air Force base in northern California. Too ill to make the long trip by ship, they became the first former prisoners of war to reach the mainland since the signing of the armistice.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 12 (UP) -- Eight alleged Communist leaders charged with conspiring to teach and advocate violent overthrow of the Government won reduction of their bail today after having charged it was excessive and unfair.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- Dr. Chester Scott Keefer, on leave from his post as physician in chief of the Massachusetts Memorial Hospital and Professor of Medicine at Boston University, was sworn in today as special assistant for health and medical affairs to the Secretary of Health, Education, and Welfare.

Major New York civic groups united yesterday at a City Hall hearing in urging the City Planning Commission to approve as a major traffic improvement plans of the 10-42 Corporation to build a $4,000,000 airlines terminal at Tenth Avenue and Forty-second Street.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Aug. 12 -- With a record equalling score of 206. Claude Harmon of Winged Foot won the Westchester open golf championship at the Knoll-wood Country Club today by a margin of four strokes.

Alex Lewyt, who sells vacuum cleaners, told Eastern regional distributors of his company yesterday that the current buyers market is not the "disease" some manufacturers and leaders hold it to be. The head of the Lewyt Corporation said a market in which manufacturers, distributors and dealers have to exert sales effort is a healthy one and need not lead to a depression.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (UP) -- The Army said today that it had settled a controversy over where to buy gas masks by buying no gas masks at all.

Astor Court, an apartment development for 144 families occupying the blockfront on the east side of Broadway between Eighty-ninth and Ninetieth Streets, has been resold after an ownership of two and one-half years by Myron and Ira Hechler.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- Spokesmen for leading organizations of doctors, lawyers, accountants, salesmen, writers and farmers joined today in urging Congress to provide income tax deductions on contributions to private pension funds.

Yesterday the $5-par-value common stock of E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co. closed on the New York Stock Exchange at 102 3/8, a shade below the high since the 1949 four-for-one split. There have been other splits in du Pont. Without going back into the history of its predecessor, the E. I. du Pont e Nemours Powder Company, the researcher finds a two-for-one split in 1926 and a three-and-a-half-for-one split in 1929.

BONN, Germany, Aug. 12 -- Erich Ollenhauer, Social Democratic party leader, said today in his first major speech of the campaign for the general election Sept. 6, that the United States Government and Chancellor Konrad Adenauer were trying to "square the circle" in attempting to reunify Germany while unifying Western Europe.
While one public dock loader escaped a prison term yesterday in Federal Court for extortion, two others were arraigned on an income-tax evasion indictment.

MINEOLA, L. I., Aug. 12 -- One of Long Island's worst summer traffic bottlenecks is scheduled to be eliminated with the construction of a new "twin" bridge across Reynolds Channel from Island Park to Long Beach.

GOSHEN, N. Y., Aug. 12 -- Just when it appeared that a fourth heat would be needed today to determine the winner of the twenty-eighth Hambletonian, Kimberly Kid went off stride and along came Helicopter, a previously unheralded brown filly, with her second victory of the day.

Robert Payson Hill, a concert pianist, who, after serving as a juror in the Municipal Court, complained about the "sanitary conditions and the intemperate nature of one of the judges who sat there," lost his fight yesterday to avoid giving further testimony.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 12 -- The United States was reported today to be arguing against including India in the political conference on Far Eastern problems agreed upon under the Korean armistice. Sixteen nations with troops committed to the United Nations side in Korea met tonight to talk over the who, where and when of the conference. The question of India was a main topic.

Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange, in more active trading, closed yesterday within 1 to 3 points of the extreme lows of the day and 3 to 14 net lower than on Tuesday, with the December position weakest.

In a complicated deal rounding out its holdings of land upon which Rockefeller Center was created, Columbia University has purchased from the Rockefeller interests virtually all of the frontage along the east side of the Avenue of the Americas between Forty-eighth and Fifty-first Streets, for which it paid $5,500,000.

LUSAKA, Northern Rhodesia, Aug. 12 -- Sir Roy Welensky, with Prime Minister Sir John Huggins of Southern Rhodesia the principal architect of the new Central African Federation, stated in an interview here today that the great issue of the relations of others with the Negro population in this part of the world provided an opportunity for progress.

PARIS, Thursday, Aug. 13 -- The strikes in the railroads, communications, mines and other public services took an ominous turn last night by spreading to private industry, while Premier Joseph Laniel told the country by radio that the Government would not yield to the strikers and would take every measure to nullify the effects of the strikes.
LONDON, Aug. 12 -- Sir Winston Churchill paid his first visit today to the Prime Minister's official London residence at 10 Downing Street since his doctors ordered him to rest at the end of June.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Thursday, Aug. 13 -- Pakistani officials pondered today the reply by Jawaharial Nehru, India's Prime Minister, to the urgent request of Prime Minister Mohammed Ali for an immediate meeting in New Delhi to discuss settlement of the Kashmir issue.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt came to Washington today to help launch what she termed an educational campaign to curb reactionary forces abroad and a contracting economic policy at home.

By fanning and fulfilling the world's desire for better products, better health and a better life, this country can meet a great challenge as well as take advantage of a great opportunity, it was said yesterday by Will C. Grant, president of Grant Advertising, Inc., Chicago.

ROME, Aug. 12 -- A last-minute veto by the Right-Wing Socialist party against the inclusion of Premier Alcide De Gasperi as Foreign Minister in the new Cabinet and against the "Atlantic policy" that he represents caused the collapse today of Premier-designate Attilio Piccioni's efforts to form a new Government.

Palmer N. Pigot of Cherry Valley won the Long Island division of The World Telegram and Sun twentieth annual hole-in-one tournament, which ended at Bayside Links, Queens, yesterday. Pigot had landed a shot 5 inches from the pin on Monday, first day of the three-day Long Island competition.

SEOUL, Korea, Aug. 12 -- About 2,000 relatives and friends of the 130,000 South Korean civilians taken prisoner by the Communists when this city fell in June, 1950, met in Duk Soo Palace here this morning to make a plea for their release. Leaders of the meeting termed the missing the "forgotten men," because neither South Korea nor the United Nations has raised the question of their fate.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (UP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission reported today that Electric Energy, Inc., has asked for authority to borrow up to $30,000,000 from five New York and St. Louis banks.

NOROTON, Conn., Aug. 12 -- Frank P. (Skip) Raymond won the Long Island Sound junior sailing championship as the three-day series ended at the Noroton Y. C. today. He took the Pequot Cup to the Norwalk Y. C.

NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 12 -- While expressing his willingness to meet Mohammed Ali, the Prime Minister of Pakistan, soon if he so wished, Jawaharlal Nehru, the Indian Prime Minister, has told him recent developments in Kashmir, culminating in the dismissal of Sheikh Mohammed Abdullah's Cabinet, were purely a Kashmir affair and would in no way affect the projected negotiations between India and Pakistan.

Today's new film is "The War of the Worlds," Paramount's Technicolor version of the H. G. Wells novel, at the Mayfair. Gene Barry, Ann Robinson and Les Tremayne are starred in the science-fiction thriller. Barre Lyndon was the scenarist and the production was directed by Byron Haskin. George Pal produced.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 12 -- A way of increasing the production of cortisone and related hormones through the use of a breed of microbes was reported to the annual meeting of the Society of American Bacteriologists today by a group of scientists from Mexico.
CARTERSVILLE, Ga., Aug. 12 (UP) -- Two convicts who escaped by shooting to death a Deputy United States Marshal and kidnapping a guard were captured today by a patrol of the Georgia National Guard.
A survey of the 1952 shipping season in Hudson Bay has been published by the Commonwealth Shipping Committee to coincide with the opening of the icy Canadian region for navigation this year.

Substantial progress by the Internal Revenue Service in reducing operating costs as well as in improving efficiency was reported here yesterday by Commissioner T. Coleman Andrews on a visit to the regional tax offices in the city.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (UP) -- If any Army private wants to shell out a month's pay, he now can dress as snappily as his company commander -- or almost as sharply as a Marine.

WITHIN ten days a band of British amateur golfers will reach Canada as part of the trip that will bring them to the United States for the Walker Cup series. If the route seems devious, there is no doubt concerning the ultimate object of the visit. It is to try to interrupt the succession of American triumphs that has dominated the matches since 1922.

Hundreds of apartments designed and equipped specially to make living easier for the physically handicapped will be available by next March in state-aided public housing projects, State Housing Commissioner Herman T. Stichman reported yesterday.

ATHENS, Aug. 12 -- Four hundred persons were reported to have been killed and scores more injured tonight as one of the worst earthquakes in Greece's history continued to ravage the three Ionian islands of Cephalonia, Zante and Ithaca, the home of Odysseus.

The current celebration throughout the Western Hemisphere of the 170th anniversary of the birth of Simon Bolivar, the apostle of Latin-American union, provides an appropriate occasion to appraise the significance of the first meeting of the Ministers of Foreign Affairs under the auspices of the Organization of Central American States (ODECA).

New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program officials appealed yesterday to New Yorkers to prevent a critical shortage of blood by giving blood before going on summer vacations. Although there was an upswing Tuesday in blood collections, which amounted to 467 pints, bringing the total this month to 1,785 pints, this number was much less than the 4,324 pints collected in the like period last month.

A method for striking back at jewelry price cutters was outlined to the trade at the convention and trade show of the American National Retail Jewelers Association at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday.

A guide to "Doing Business Abroad," designed to induce additional American business men and corporations to extend operations to foreign countries, was issued yesterday by the United States Council of the International Chamber of Commerce.

ELIZABETHTOWN, N. Y., Aug. 12 -- Judge Augustus N. Hand of the United States Court of Appeals gave permission yesterday for Cinerama, the three-dimensional movie process, to increase its production through the Stanley Warner Corporation.

Nineteen of the thirty-four district leaders who constitute the executive committee of the Tammany Democratic organization face primary contests for continuance in office, records of the Board of Elections disclosed yesterday.
The United States Atomic Energy Commission will install a production facility at the Lake Ontario Ordnance Works twelve miles from Niagara Falls, it was announced here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (AP) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission said today that national defense factors played an important part in its recent decision to continue present freight rate levels through 1955.

Sherrill, N. Y., City School District sold $2,290,000 of bonds dated June 1, 1953 and due from Dec. 1, 1954 to 1982, to the Marine Trust Company of Western New York and associates at a bid of 100.1749 for 3's.

MANCHESTER, Mass., Aug. 12 (AP) -- Mrs. Margaret Osborne du Pont of Wilmington, Del., unseeded though a three-time Essex champion, today scored the only break in seedings to join seven favorites in quarter-finals of the Essex women's tennis tournament.
WESTBURY, L. I., Aug. 12 (AP) -- Harvey Pointer, owned and driven by Jack Brown of Macon, Ga., scored a half-length victory tonight over Henry's Mc in the Huntington Pace at Roosevelt Raceway.

LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., Aug. 12 -- Mrs. Melvin Scharf and Dan Scharf, a 14-year-old student at Great Neck High School, playing from Glen Oaks, scored 39, 39 -- 78 to win the low gross prize and the championship in the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association mother-and-son tournament at the Creek Club today. There were forty teams in the field.
Levi Hestdalen, his wife, and their five children arrived in New York last Friday with all their worldly goods on their way to a new job, new home and a new life in British Columbia.

Two of New York City's most important resources are emphasized today in the fifth article in THE TIMES series on problems of the city's plant. These are the city-owned piers and the transit system. Both are the victims of long neglect. Each requires many millions of dollars for modernization.

CAIRO, Aug. 12 -- A series of violent incidents in the Suez Canal Zone, culminating in the killing of two British soldiers and the wounding of two other British military personnel and three or four Egyptians since Saturday, has produced an atmosphere of tension threatening to disrupt the current, informal efforts to end the British-Egyptian dispute over the canal zone.
MIAMI, Fla., Aug. 12 (AP) -- Mrs. Ann Davison, British widow, docked here today to complete a fifteen-month voyage alone from England aboard her 23-foot sailboat, Felicity Ann.

HARMONY, N. J., Aug. 12 -- Law enforcement in this state was the primary topic of discussion tonight as the three leading candidates for Governor appeared together for the first time on the same platform.
MIAMI, Fla., Aug. 12 (AP) -- A growing hurricane, with winds up to 100 miles per hour, moved slowly up the Atlantic tonight and threatened to lash the North Carolina coast with gales tomorrow.

AN unusual run of white marlin -- seventy, eighty and 100 pounders -- is reported off Beach Haven, N. J. Charter boat skippers operating from the yacht club docks there say they have not caught so many in years.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 12 (AP) -- The Indians came from behind with four runs in the eighth inning tonight to defeat the White Sox, 7 -- 4, in a wild affair in which two players were ejected and two others nearly came to blows.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- Secretary of State John Foster Dulles said today the United States Government accepted with skepticism the implication by Soviet Premier Georgi Malenkov that the Soviet Union had the hydrogen bomb.

GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 12 -- Mrs. T. Arthur Menzel, a former champion, headed the field in today's one-day tournament of the low-handicap Women's Tri-County Golf Association by carding 38, 39 -- 77 at Round Hill Club. Mrs. C. T. Chadsey Jr., on her home. par-74 course, scored 41, 38 -- 79 for second.

Henry Siegel, builder and operator, sold the new one-story taxpayer building at 178-21 Hillside Avenue in Jamaica, Queens, to a client of Rudolf Birnbaum, lawyer. Thomas Roulston, Inc., and the Electrolux Corporation have stores in the building.

CUSTER, S. D., Aug. 12 -- The National Association of Attorneys General agreed today to begin a nation-wide study of lobbying practices in an effort to strengthen the "inadequate and ineffective" laws now governing them.
LONDON, Aug. 12 -- The stock markets here today lost some of their buoyancy of the last few days. While the undertone remained firm, several domestic issues previously in brisk demand closed lower.

New minimum wages ranging from 65 to 75 cents an hour have been recommended for New York State's retail trade industry in a report to Industrial Commissioner Edward Corsi by the wage board for the industry.

DENVER, Aug. 12 -- President Eisenhower signed today the bill that will enable New York and New Jersey to create a waterfront commission designed to knock out criminal and Communist control of stevedoring and other pier operations in New York harbor.

An old colonial home on Pound Ridge Road in Bedford Village, N. Y., has been sold by Mrs. Emily F. Spear to Evelyn Scott. The house, formerly the farmhouse of Indian Hill dairy farm, was bought by Mrs. Spear about six years ago. She modernized it and added three accessory buildings to the place.

The leading production area in the East for lima beans is Suffolk County, where the sandy soil of Eastern Long Island has been favoring commercial cultivation of the delicious, meaty vegetable for more than half a century.

Carmine G. DeSapio declared himself yesterday in favor of a "wide open" Democratic primary and announced that the Tammany organization, which he heads, would make no attempt to disqualify those seeking nominations for Mayor or other places on the Board of Estimate on legal or technical grounds.

Coffee and cocoa prices closed higher on increased volume yesterday following the announcements earlier this week of the easing of foreign exchange regulations by Brazil on both items. Elsewhere on the New York commodity exchanges, trading was also more active generally but prices were mixed.

Authorized to spend $500,000 in the field to meet pressing needs, six members of the American-Korean Foundation, headed by Dr. Howard A. Rusk, will leave for Korea today to assist the United Nations, United States, and Republic of Korea officials in planning economic and social reconstruction for that nation.

Operations of the International Nickel Company of Canada, Ltd., and its subsidiaries in the first six months of this year resulted in net earnings of $29,205,595, equal to $1.93 a share of common stock. They compare with $25,353,055, or $1.67 a share, for the previous six months and with $33,538,227, or $2.23, for the initial half of 1952.
NEWPORT, R. I., Aug. 12 -- Kurt Nielsen of Denmark, finalist against Victor Seixas at Wimbledon, was eliminated from the Newport invitation tennis singles today at The Casino.

Gil Turner, second-ranking welterweight contender, knocked out Ramon Fuentes of Los Angeles in 2 minutes 49 seconds of the fifth of the main bout listed for ten rounds at Madison Square Garden last night.

ST. LOUIS, Aug 12. (AP) -- Ike Boone's hex on the Browns' pitchers was in operation again tonight as the Tiger infielder clouted his fourth grand slam home run of the season against St. Louis to break up a 3-3 game in the ninth inning for a 7-3 Detroit victory.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, said emphatically today that political tests were not being applied for employment in the Department of State.
Settlement of the three-day strike of several thousand dress-makers in eastern and central Pennsylvania was announced in New York yesterday.

When the Giants jumped away to a five-run lead over the Dodgers in the first two innings yesterday, it appeared to the 23,328 observers at the Polo Grounds that the New Yorkers might at long last be snapping out of the slump that had dropped them from pennant contention.

PALO ALTO, Calif. Aug. 12 -- Perfection of "the most powerful microscopic equipment ever built" and its yielding of a series of startling facts about the nucleus of the atom were announced today at Stanford University.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- The Yankees tonight let the Senators have all the barrels as they cut loose with their heaviest offensive of the year, a 28-hit barrage to butcher Bucky Harris' Nats, 22 to 1, in the second encounter of the current three-game series.

Directors of Flour Mills of America, Inc., in a letter to stockholders yesterday, announced they would accept the resignations of two top officials of the company at a meeting in Kansas City this morning. The letter also disclosed that the concern suffered a loss of about $3,000,000 in the fiscal year ended May 31.
DANBURY, Conn., Aug. 12 -- The board of trustees at Danbury Hospital was completed today for the first time since a 1952 controversy depleted its ranks.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- A special committee of the American Society of Newspaper Editors reported today that its eleven members had been unable to agree whether freedom of the press had been threatened in the questioning of James A. Wechsler, editor of The New York Post, by Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, at closed hearings April 24 and May 5.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Aug. 5, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

OSLO, Norway, Aug. 12 -- Delegates from nineteen countries in Europe, Asia, the Americas and the Middle East, attending the first International Conference on Atomic Power for Industrial Uses, saw today for the first time what leaders in the field regard as the atomic power plant of the future.

To the surprise of many baseball followers, who thought Leo Durocher's days as manager of the Giants were numbered in view of the current collapse of the Polo Grounds team, the controversial skipper was signed yesterday to a new two-year contract that will carry him through the 1955 campaign.

A new housing development for the east side of Manhattan, designated as the New York University-Bellevue project, moved a step nearer realization yesterday when the City Planning Commission voted its approval of proceedings to begin acquisition of title to the property.

Probably $45,000,000 and more in improvements have been made on port facilities, public and private, in the five boroughs since World War II. Despite the furor over waterfront problems, the Port of New York, including the New Jersey shores, may now be han

HARTSDALE, N. Y., Aug. 12 -- Upsets were the order of the day as the quarter-finals of the twenty-eighth Women's Westchester-Fair-field Golf Association championship were played at the Scarsdale Golf Club today.

CHICAGO, Aug. 12 (AP) -- A dead-heat finish for first between Queen Hopeful and Greek Lady followed a seven-length triumph by Spy Magic in the two-division running of the Mademoiselle Stakes at Washington Park today. Each race for 2-year-old fillies had a gross value of $22,837.50.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 12 (AP) -- Robin Roberts, the Phillies' ace right-hander, batted across three runs with an infield out and a triple in beating the Pirates, 8 -- 4, tonight for his twentieth victory of the campaign. Roberts is the first pitcher to win twenty games in the major leagues this year.

OTTAWA, Aug. 12 -- The Ministry of External Affairs revealed today that Canada had received a reassuringly conciliatory reply from the United States State Department to its latest expression of concern over the possible extension of import restrictions.

President Eisenhower will interrupt his vacation next Tuesday night to make an overnight flight from Denver to New York, where he will attend the dedication of a slum-clearance housing project next Wednesday after registering with the Board of Elections so he can vote in the city election on Nov. 3.
MUNSAN, Korea, Thursday, Aug. 13 (AP) -- The United Nations Command's official list of United States prisoners of war in today's armistice exchange:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- A 42-year-old bookbinder machine operator in the Government Printing Office took the spotlight today in an offstage battle between his attorneys and the Senate's Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations, headed by Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin.

LONDON, Aug. 12 (Reuters) -- British and Dutch associated oil companies have made up from other sources 14,000,000 of the 30,000,000 tons of annual oil output they lost when Iran's Prime Minister Mohammed Mossadegh seized the Iranian oil fields in 1951, it was disclosed today.

KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, Aug. 12 -- Despite evidence in several directions of financial stringency and business retrenchment, competent observers here do not regard the present economic situation in Malaya as representing a major slump.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (UP) -- The official toll of United States battle casualties in Korea rose to 142,294 today and Department of Defense officials indicated this may be close to the final cost of resisting Communist aggression there.

" North: The Nature and Drama of the Polar World," by Dr. Kaare Rodahl, combines personal adventure and history. It will be published Sept. 2 by Harper. Dr. Rodahl, an expert on Arctic medicine and nutrition, writes of the early heroes in search of the absolute North.
