SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 12 -- Barring unforeseen incident during the rest of the year the Matson Navigation Company's operating results for 1953 should be the best of any year in the post-war period, Randolph Sevier, the president, informed stockholders today in an interim report.

A new two-story taxpayer building at 6717 to 6735 Fourth Avenue, in Brooklyn, has been sold by Harry Siegel, builder and operator, to an investing client of Dreyer Traub. Tenants include an A. P. market, the John Hancock Life Insurance Company and the Electrolux Vacuum Cleaner.

In an effort to provide better educational services for children with cerebral palsy, sixteen teachers from seven states and Norway are taking part in a special workshop at Teachers College, Columbia University. The program, which began July 6 and will end tomorrow, is under the auspices of the college's Department of Special Education in cooperation with the United Cerebral Palsy Association, Inc.
The important new trends in fall daytime dress designs are not numerous but are so strong that the entire market reflects them.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 12 -- The Israeli Foreign Office has appointed one of its top diplomatic technicians to prepare specific plans for settlement of some of Israel's disputes with the Arabs, against the day when agreement seems near.

Reflecting a sharp rise in shipments, two concerns engaged in manufacture of aircraft or aircraft accessories reported yesterday a substantial increase in earnings for the first half of this year over those of the corresponding period of 1952.
Karl Heinz Pfeiffer 2O-year-old stowaway, was saved yesterday from the fate of Michael Patrick O'Brien -- at least temporarily.

Sales of leading chain stores and mail order companies showed an aggregate gain of 4.5 per cent in July over those in the same month a year ago, according to a compilation of forty-three companies made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES.

HARRISON, N. J., Aug 12 -- A total of 1,170 production and maintenance employes of the Crucible Steel Company's Spaulding Works here staged a wildcat strike today, halting work on Government and private contracts. The dispute involves the dismissal of seven employes.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 12 -- A dramatic story spun to its conclusion this afternoon here when the youthful, relatively untried contract bridge team of William A. Rosen and Milton M. Ellenby, both of Chicago, Douglas Steen of Los Angeles, Donald Oakie of San Francisco, and Clifford Bishop of Detroit, clinched the 1953 United States team-of-four championship.
The Communication from City Planner Richard May Jr. about the proposed Socony-Vacuum building on East Forty-second Street deserves the attention of all thoughtful New Yorkers.

The magical box-office lure of "Oklahoma!" appears to be holding as strongly as ever. The response to a mailing campaign for a limited engagement of the fabulous musical at the City Center has proved "so overwhelming," in the words of Richard Rodgers and Oscar Hammerstein 2d, that they have decided to extend the attraction's stay at the civic playhouse from the original three weeks to five.

EDINBURGH, Scotland, Aug. 12 -- Twelve hundred delegates from forty-four countries assembled here today for the eighth International Congress on Home Economics, a world-wide movement dedicated to the study of the home as the keystone of communal life and the advancement of ideas designed to contribute toward its smooth running.

After a gentle sell-off in the morning hours, stocks began a slow recovery in the noon hour that gathered strength and volume toward the close yesterday. Chrysler, selling ex-dividend and weak at the start, won back its dividend and ended with a gain of an eighth.

FREEDOM VILLAGE, Korea, Aug. 12 -- A bitter picture of the hatred harbored by prisoners of war for fellow-prisoners who they said, "squealed" on them to the Communists emerged at press interrogations here today.

As everyone must know by now, the human will is a sorry thing. This is shown no more clearly than upon those occasions when it should urge some definite action about things it finds deplorable or otherwise unfortunate.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (UP) -- The Department of Agriculture imposed planting controls on domestic sugar cane producers today for the first time since before World War II, and immediately cut the 1954 sugar cane acreage allotments 7.8 per cent below this year's planting.

BERLIN, Aug. 12 -- Hermann Streit, head of East Germany's crop collection agency is prodding farmers on the delivery of their quotas and is attacking those who he said were urging peasants to withhold their produce for higher prices.

There has been understandable confusion and several accidents since New York State amended its Motor Vehicle Code on July 1 to permit passing on the right under the following conditions: if the car ahead is making a left turn; if the overtaking car is on a four-lane two-way road with no parking, or if the overtaking car is on a two-lane, one-way unobstructed road.

The inquiry last spring to which Senator McCarthy subjected James A. Wechsler, editor of The New York Post, was characterized by this newspaper at the time as "an attempt to harass and intimidate Mr. Wechsler" because of the latter's outspoken and vigorous opposition to Mr. McCarthy.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- The possibility that the Soviet Union will be able to knock out the industrial potential of the United States through a surprise all-out atomic and hydrogen bomb attack cannot be discounted in any effort to appraise the Russian menace of the future, two speakers warned today at the symposium of approximately 400 students of international affairs here.
Though New York strikes most Western Europeans as fascinating, bracing and so much nicer than expected, its manners seem to them appalling.

The Port of New York, frequently reported by critics to be losing its dominance in ocean trade to other ports, actually increased its share of the nation's foreign trade in 1952, according to a statistical analysis made public here yesterday.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Aug. 12 -- The resignation of all five members of the state committee f the Federal Production and Marketing Administration, because of a change in the national administration and its views on farm crop controls, was announced today by H. Earl Propst, administrative officer of the State Production and Marketing Administration.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 12 -- Hopes rose at the United Nations today for a negotiated settlement of the world organization's parking-space war with New York City officialdom.

BOSTON, Aug. 12 -- The American Bar Association standing committee on judicial selection, tenure and compensation says that unless Federal judicial salaries are increased substantially, future selections for the bench will be limited chiefly to independently wealthy lawyers or those so unsuccessful in private practice that they could not earn even as much as Federal judges are paid now.

MILWAUKEE, Aug. 12 -- After two rounds of the fifty-fourth annual open championship tournament of the United States Chess Federation at the Eagles Club here, the United States champion, Larry Evans, Nicholas Rossolimo of Paris, Herman Steiner of Los Angeles, and Arthur B. Bisguier and James T. Sherwin of New York have 2-0 scores.

LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., Aug. 13 -- Mrs. F. F. Adel and Mrs. Reinert M. Torgerson of the Cherry Valley club scored 42, 43 -- 85, to tie with Mrs. Charles Stillman, Glen Head, and Mrs. Saul Weinsier, Fresh Meadow, 44, 41 -- 85, for the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association mother-and-daughter championship at The Creek Club today.

TEHERAN, Iron, Aug. 13 -- Fifty shawl-wrapped women, many carrying babies, occupied the telegraph office here for several hours tonight in a protest of the banishment or imprisonment of their husbands for activity during strikes in the Government tobacco factory and grain elevators three months ago.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 13 -- An American Transit Association spokesman's infeenrce that there is widespread collusion between doctors and lawyers in transit injury claims brought a vigorous denial today from the National Association of Claimants and Compensation Attorneys.

CHICAGO, Aug. 13 -- The executive council of the International Longshoremen's Association has decided to take action against corrupt union officials, it was reported here today, but the fate of Joseph P. Ryan, the union's president, was not clear.

An attempt by the Commerce and Industry Association to have the city revoke its permission to the Hearn department stores strikers to collect funds on the streets was rejected yesterday by Welfare Commissioner Henry L. McCarthy.

ROME, Aug, 13 -- As the Italian Cabinet crisis entered its forty-fifth day this afternoon, Giuseppe Pella, 51 years old, who was Minister of Finance in all of Premier Alcide De Gasperi's Cabinets since 1947, undertook to try to solve it by forming a "business government."

The National Football League will usher in its thirty-fourth campaign on Sunday, Sept. 27, with a complete program of six contests in Baltimore, Milwaukee, Los Angeles, San Francisco, Detroit and Chicago, according to the official schedule released yesterday by Bert Bell, league commissioner.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Aug. 13 -- Mohammed Ali, the Pakistan Prime Minister, will leave Sunday for New Delhi where he will confer "as long as necessary" with Jawaharlal Nehru, the Prime Minister of India, on a solution of the critical Kashmir problem.

BERLIN, Aug. 13 -- Britain and France, alarmed at the possible implications of a new giveaway food program in Berlin, have urged that the West Berlin Government "hold everything" until the project can be approved by the Western High Commissioners in Bonn. Such approval now seems assured.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 13 (AP) -- Rufus, the restless hornbill that took a flyer on Wall Street, is just another character now in the St. Louis Zoo birdhouse and is likely to have an uncomfortable time resting on its laurels.

MOREHEAD CITY, N. C., Aug. 13 (AP) -- A hurricane screeched across this coastal vacation land tonight. Top winds were estimated at 95 miles an hour. One man was blown from a fishing pier and swept out to sea. Four marines were reported injured, none seriously, at the Cherry Point Marine Base. A Coast Guard petty officer was hurt in rescue work.

MILWAUKEE, Aug. 13 -- Third-round results of the open championship tournament of the United States Chess Federation today found four players with scores of 3 -- 0. Two are New Yorkers -- Larry Evans, United States champion, and James T. Sherwin, 1951 New York State champion.
The search for John Mazziotta, wanted for questioning in the slaying of Arnold Schuster, the tipster who turned in William F. Sutton, the bank robber, now centers on the Midwest.

LONDON, Aug. 13 -- Two of the nineteen delegates to the current London conference for a revision of the constiution of Nigeria walked out today in protest against what they called the "futility" of making the Nigerian Federal Government "entirely dependent on the three regional governments" of the British West African dependency.
ROCQUENCOURT, France, Aug. 13 -- Gen. Alfred M. Gruenther, Supreme Allied Commander, plans to visit Denmark and Norway for a week beginning Tuesday, Aug. 25.

What's wrong with New York? The answer is not simple, as readers of THE TIMES know if they have been following the articles this week on city problems. One possible reaction to this series, concluded today, might be that there is not much wrong that a few billion dollars wouldn't fix. Another might be to ask what's right with New York?
LONDON, Aug. 13 -- The most celebrated aspect of life in Britain for more than a decade -- austerity -- has almost disappeared this summer.

The evening performance of the comedy "Sabrina Fair," starring Barbara Bel Geddes and Joseph Cotten, on Nov. 2 at the National Theatre has been taken over by the board of directors of the West Side Day Nursery for its autumn benefit.

The city Board of Responsibility, meeting yesterday in the Municipal Building, disqualified the San Martino Construction Company of 81-42 Baxter Avenue, Jackson Heights, Queens, from future sewer construction work in the five boroughs.
PARIS, Aug. 7 -- Soft, luxurious fox, mink and beaver, were prominent among the furs that appeared in unexpected places on clothes shown this week in the fall collections.

The political crisis in Italy has turned into a major setback for the cause of Western strength and unity. If it had resulted in nothing more than the eclipse (a temporary one, it is hoped) of Alcide De Gasperi it would still represent a watershed in contemporary Italian history.

New York City, at 300 years of age, is still a young city as the world's metropolises go and its leaders believe the municipal enterprise, with its $12,000,000,000 physical plant, can improve its running. They think it needs good men in key places with some better management tools and certainly a zeal for reform.
A tax snag is hindering the progress of the Lively Arts Foundation, Billy Rose's philanthropic gesture encompassing "contemporary art forms."

The final step in a year's study for a fourth Hudson River crossing was authorized yesterday when the Port of New York Authority ordered a new origin-and-destination count of New York-New Jerey traffic using its six toll facilities.

Efforts to obtain from the Internal Revenue Bureau a uniform and more liberal definition of what constitutes "traveling expenses" will be made this year by traveling salesmen in the apparel trades. The proposal is part of the legislative program adopted yesterday by the executive advisory council of the National Association of Women's and Children's Apparel Salesmen at its midyear meeting in the New Yorker Hotel.

LENOX, Mass., Aug. 13 -- The annual five-ring musical circus known as "Tanglewood on Parade" went on display here today for a one-day stand. The 400 students of the Berkshire Music Center, the full membership of the Boston Symphony Orchestra led by Charles Munch and Leonard Bernstein, and guest artists Isaac Stern, Leontyne Price and William Warfield provided an afternoon's and evening's entertainment in different areas of far-flung Tanglewood.
R. S. Quint has sold his home on River View Road in Irvington-Hudson to a client of E. R. Littler, broker. The property consists of a seven-room air-conditioned ranch house and a half acre.

Despite a sharp increase in sales, the consolidated net profit of Aluminium, Ltd., declined to $9,498,796 in the first half of this year, equal to $1.06 a common share, from $10,906,058 or $1.21 a share for the same period last year.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- American wheat growers will decide tomorrow whether to accept strict Federal controls on their 1954 crop.

LONDON, Aug. 13 (AP) -- The International Sugar Conference has tentatively raised its 5,000,000-ton limit on world sugar exports by 350,000 tons to meet pressure by individual producers for larger quotas.

Efforts of Federal mediators to settle the strike of 5,000 employes at the Brooklyn and Garden City, L. I., plants of the Arma Corporation received a new setback yesterday when company negotiators walked out of a session at the offices of the Mediation and Conciliation Service, 341 Ninth Avenue.

PIERMONT, N. Y., Aug. 13 -- The police here, the Coast Guard and representatives of the Rockland County District Attorney's office are looking for river pirates who, in the last three nights, have stolen an outdoor motorboat and taken valuable gear from pleasure craft moored in the Tappan Zee, a three-and-a-half-mile-wide bay that is part of the Hudson River.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- The essential difference between the old and the new committees is that the new unit will have definite operating functions.
RICHMOND, Va., Aug. 13 (UP) -- An abandoned wooden ice box yielded the bodies of four adventurous barefoot boys today only a few hours after five children had died in a similar tragedy in Arkansas.

PARIS, Aug. 13 -- Premier Joseph Laniel's appeal to the strikers last night to return to their jobs in the interest of the nation went largely unheeded today and stop-pages continued in communications, public services, government offices, railroads and mines.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 13 (AP) -- Virgil Trucks came up in the tenth inning today with a game-deciding single that propelled the second-place White Sox to a 7-3 victory over the Indians. It was the rubber game of the three-game series and left the Tribe five lengths behind the Sox.

Housewives, who regard the daily round of housekeeping chores as part of "woman's lot," may derive some satisfaction from the fact that the sterner sex manages the housework on such big floating residences as the luxury liner America.
IF you ask Col. Duncan Macaulay, the greatest woman player to set foot on a tennis court was Suzanne Lenglen.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, Aug. 13 -- The one-day strike yesterday sponsored by Ceylonese Communists because of the Government's decision to reduce the rice subsidy was called off today, but the violence that began with the strike continued with incendiarism, looting and terrorist activities.
KUALA LUMPUR, Malaya, Aug. 13 -- Communist insurgents are going through the grimmest period they have yet experienced in their five-year-old jungle war for control of the Malaya Peninsula.
DETROIT, Aug. 13 (UP) -- Widespread layoffs in the automotive industry were predicted by officials today as a result of the $70,000,000 fire at the General Motors Livonia plant yesterday.

Week-end shoppers will find that lamb has dropped somewhat in price. Loin chops show a 4-cent decrease, and are now at a general price of $1.25 a pound, according to the consumers' service division of the New York City Department of Markets. Shoulder chops average 89 cents a pound, which is 6 cents less than last week.

The New York City Transit Authority increased yesterday by $11,273,700 the operating budget of the publicly owned transit lines to a new total of $261,458,000 for the 1953-54 fiscal year. The authority also thwarted an attempt to defraud it of 50,000 15-cent brass tokens worth $7,500.

CAIRO, Aug. 13 -- Robert Hankey, British Charge d'Affaires in Cairo, called this morning on Dr. Mahmoud Fawzi, Egyptian Foreign Minister, and, according to British sources, received assurances that the Egyptian Government would continue to do all that lay in its power to maintain order in the Suez Canal zone.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 (AP) -- Infantile paralysis cases continued to increase last week, but not as rapidly as in the preceding week, and showed a decrease of nearly 30 per cent, compared with the corresponding week a year ago.

DENVER, Aug. 13 -- Following is the text of the President's Executive Order establishing the Government Contract Committee to supervise compliance with Federal Government fair employment policy practices in the performance of Government contracts:
PITTSBURGH, Aug. 13 (UP) -- The Pirates came from behind three times to edge the Phils, 4 -- 3, today and break a five-game losing streak.

Your editorial "The Ultimate Weapon" asserts but inspires little hope that man's determination to be free will triumph over the hydrogen bomb. For it cannot in reasonableness happen that if the dictators in Moscow "take the sword, the men of the free world will certainly see to it that they and their system perish by the sword."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 13 -- Philip Yordan has sold a science-fiction story titled "The Men From Earth" to Milton Sperling, head of the United States Pictures unit at Warner Brothers. The author also has been hired to write his own screen play.

In the appalling highway slaughter the failure of the machine is now very seldom a factor. Automobiles have reached such a state of reliability that more and more the truth of the old quip is apparent that there is just one thing wrong with the car of today -- namely, the fool behind the wheel.

Cross-currents swayed the stock market yesterday, but when the excitement ended changes were almost negligible. The market began with a continuation of Wednesday's closing rally, checked itself and dipped when wheat prices cracked in Chicago, and then staged a minor recovery as wheat rallied.

In his annual report to Mayor Impellitteri for 1952 the director of WNYC, Seymour N. Siegel, has placed great emphasis on emergency preparations that, in his opinion, have made the Municipal Broadcasting System "the key to civil defense communications."

The International Boxing Club completed arrangements yesterday for a world middleweight championship bout between Randy Turpin of London and Carl (Bobo) Olson of Honolulu at Madison Square Garden on Oct. 21. This be the second of two title fights to be staged here within a month, the other matching Rocky Marciano, heavyweight ruler, and Roland La Starza at the Polo Grounds on Sept. 24.

Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed yesterday with losses of 6 to 10 points on the day and at the extreme lows of the current reaction. An increasing volume of hedges was the basic factor in the late setback.

The New York City-United Nations controversy over automobile parking around United Nations headquarters entered Phase 3 yesterday when Robert Moses, City Construction Coordinator, announced he had accepted the invitation of Dag Hammarskjold, Secretary General of the United Nations, to meet for lunch.

The fifty - five - year - old former trolley power station occupying the block bounded by Ninety-fifth and Ninety-sixth Streets, First Avenue and Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive, was just a gaping shell of three walls yesterday, looking down on a litter of bricks.

The editorial appearing in THE TIMES on the "Hall of Our History" jarred my faith in intelligent journalism. How can you say we "need reminders in granite and bronze of the pains endured and the sacrifices made by men and women" when we have those reminders written on the pages of our literature, on our tombstones and on the minds of our generation.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 (UP) -- Robert R. Nathan, a spokesman for Americans for Democratic Action, said tonight that President Eisenhower's new economy order was a move to avoid the "political embarrassment" of calling Congress into special session.

CHICAGO, Aug. 13 (AP) -- The Cubs made three straight errors in the third inning today as the Redlegs scored five unearned runs to tag the seventh-place Bruins for a 10-2 rout before a Ladies' Day crowd of 16,069.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended last Saturday totaled 785,349 cars, the Association of American Railroads reported today. This was 8,405 cars, or 1.1 per cent, fewer than for the preceding week; 3,701 cars, or 0.5 per cent, more than for the corresponding week last year, and 24,016 cars, or 3 per cent, fewer than in the corresponding week two years ago.
Prices on the New York commodity exchanges were mixed yesterday in fairly active trading.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- The United States is resisting, alone thus far, proposals among its major Allies in the United Nations that the post-armistice Korean conference be broadened into a general effort to settle Asian problems rather than be confined to Korean war issues alone.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today approval of purchase by the Portsmouth Steel Company, Cleveland, of all the common stock now held by the Alleghany Corporation in the Cleveland-Cliffs Iron Company, Cleveland.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- A recommendation that the Department of Justice appeal to the United States Supreme Court for a review of the Federal Reserve Board's action against the Transamerica Corporation was sent to the Department today by the board.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 (AP) -- Secretary of State John Foster Dulles has the final word on the dismissals of State Department employes found to be "'security risks," under a new set of rules disclosed today.

A resolution expressing "grateful appreciation to all those who assisted in bringing about the enactment of emergency legislation" that will permit the entry into this country of 214,000 displaced persons and refugees from Communist - dominated countries was adopted yesterday by the National Catholic Resettlement Council and the American Committee on Special Migration.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 (UP) -- A former member of the Italian and French Communist parties said today the Kremlin planned to conquer Western Europe by infiltration and subversion rather than outright war.
NAZARETH, Israel, Aug. 13 -- Times are bad in this little town where, according to the Christian faith, the Angel Gabriel appeared to Mary and announced to her that she would bear the child Jesus.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- Continuing its program of easing export restrictions as rapidly as possible, the Office of International Trade of the United States Department of Commerce today created a new and more flexible type of export license.
WASHINGTON, Aug 13 (AP) -- Following is a list of the first 121 names, released by the Army today, of the 1,022 United States soldiers reported by the Communists to have died in Korean prison camps:

Dr. Alfred P. Ingegno's letter to the Health Insurance Plan as described in THE TIMES of Aug. 6 must have aroused considerable concern among those for whom any serious illness is generally tantamount to personal bankruptcy.

Loans to business by New York City banks rose $51,000,000 during the week ended on Wednesday, registering the second successive weekly advance, according to data issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 13 -- The change-of-equipment listing in the program was the tip-off on the winner of the $8,850 North American Steeplechase at the Saratoga track today. Under the names of the horses was the notation: The Mast -- blinkers on, spurs on.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 13 -- Henry Cabot Lodge Jr., the United States representative, said tonight it would be "chaotic, maybe catastrophic" for the United Nations General Assembly to invite nonbelligerents in the Korean war to participate in the post-armistice political conference. Mr. Lodge insisted the armistice agreement provided only for the participation of "countries concerned" and that this applied only to belligerents.

CHICAGO, Aug. 13 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission announced here today that the suspension of trading in common stock of Flour Mills of America, Inc., of Kansas City, Mo., on the Midwest Stock Exchange will be extended an additional ten days to allow time for further investigation.

The public interest is vitally involved in negotiations which have been resumed to settle the strike of 1,100 sand, gravel and concrete-mix truck drivers. This strike, which has been in effect since July 3, is a major calamity. It has already forced 100,000 construction workers into idleness and is holding up $600,000,000 worth of building contracts.

HARTSDALE, N. Y., Aug. 13 -- Two players from the Siwanoy Country Club, 21-year-old Diana Bourne and Mrs. Philip Conway, gained the final of the Women's Westchester-Fairfield Golf Association championship at the Scarsdale Golf Club today.

A sharp reversal in the downtrend of whisky sales was predicted here yesterday for at least one brand. Harry G. Serlis, vice president of Schenley Distributors, Inc., at the concluding meeting of a two weeks' series of groups of distributors at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel said orders already placed for Schenley Reserve indicate business in the September-December period greater than the record levels for the same period in 1948.

EDINBURGH, Scotland, Aug. 13 -- Women of forty-four nations, meeting here as delegates to the eighth International Congress on Home Economics, began today an exchange of ideas on a universal theme -- the art and science of running a home.

About 300 men-of-war from nine North Atlantic Treaty Organization nations will participate in September and October in Exercise Mariner, an international training exercise that will range across the North Atlantic from Iceland to Gibraltar.

The untimely death of Senator Taft should focus attention on the greatest flaw in our elective system -- disregard of the physical fitness of candidates nominated to the highest office in our country.

HEWLETT, L. I., Aug. 13 -- W. R. Howe and John J. Humm, Rockville, fired a 34, 35 -- 69, three strokes under par, to take the qualifying lead in the nineteenth Arthur Mann Memorial invitation member-guest tournament at the Seawane Harbor Club today.

LONDON, Aug. 14 (Reuters) -- A report published today shows transactions of the International Wheat Agreement are far lower than last year. Up to Aug. 7 sales under the agreement totaled only 530,000 metric tons.

Senator Herbert H. Lehman, Democrat of New York, made public last night a letter in which he strongly dissented from the view that Americans of the Jewish faith should regard Israel as their homeland.

PARIS, Aug. 13 -- More than 100 Berber pashas and chieftains and other leaders from all parts of Morocco were gathered in tribal conclave in their holy city of Marrakesh tonight around their leader, Hadji Thami el Mezouari el Glaoui, the Pasha of Marrakesh, awaiting a decision on the future of the Moroccan State.

Hope that work would be resumed at Pier 32. North River, was crushed yesterday morning as longshoremen refused to accept a Moore-McCormack Lines proposal that the dispute involving the discharge of a safety employe, James Garvey, be submitted to arbitration.

LIBERACE, a piano player in Hollywood, has been described as the "Casanova of the keyboards" and, according to assorted reports, makes some feminine hearts go flutter flutter. This corner can only withdraw any unkind remarks previously made about the Continental.

The West Germans will build two passenger-cargo ships for the trans-Atlantic run of the Zim Israel Navigation Company as part of Israeli reparations, it was announced by the line here yesterday. The vessels will be completed in 1955.

GOSHEN, N. Y., Aug. 13 (AP) -- Bi Shively drove Sharp Note, 1952 Hambletonian winner, to a staight-heat victory in the $5,800 Trotting Derby today as the 1953 Grand Circuit harness race program closed at Good Time Park.
The Federal Government was chided yesterday on its failure to follow the example of state and local authorities in the treatment of sewage flowing into the waters around New York.

The city was asked yesterday by Public Works Commissioner Frederick H. Zurmuhlen to provide immediately $8,221,531 to permit a start on construction by the end of this year of the long-projected improvements to the Queensboro Bridge. Plans call for a new upper-deck roadway with approaches.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- The Air Force was ordered by Federal Judge Walter M. Bastian today to bring Robert W. Toth, a former sergeant charged with murder of a South Korean civilian, from Korea to Washington by Sept. 1. On that date a final order is expected in habeas corpus proceedings brought by Toth's attorneys.
PARIS, Aug. 13 (AP) -- Nearly every country in Western Europe reports bumper grain crops for 1953.

MANCHESTER, Mass., Aug. 13 (AP) -- It was strictly routine action in quarter-finals of the Essex women's tournament today, the Americans beating England's Wightman Cup players, as they have been doing since 1930.

Pakistan today is observing its "Independence Day," the sixth anniversary of the withdrawal of British sovereignty. The Indians have usually chosen Aug. 15. In either case it is the anniversary of the partition of the Indian subcontinent and the emergence of two independent nations within the Commonwealth framework.

Today's new film is "Glory Brigade," a Twentieth Century-Fox drama with a cast headed by Victor Mature, at the Palace. Robert D. Webb directed and William Bloom produced from a screen play by Franklin Coen. Among the supporting players and Alexander Scourby, Lee Marvin, Richard, Egan, Nick Dennis by Roy Roberts.

MOSCOW, Aug 13 -- There has been a considerable increase in travel in the Soviet Union by foreign diplomats and service attaches, including Americans, since the removal in mid-June of restrictions on travel to most of European Russia, the Ukraine, the Caucasus and central Asia.

OTTAWA, Aug. 13 -- Lester B. Pearson, Secretary of the Canadian Ministry of Foreign Affairs, said before leaving today to preside over next week's United Nations General Assembly that the Soviet Union and probably India would have to participate in the political discussions on the future of Korea.

This photograph is a copy of Page 1 of last Sunday's issue of the Moscow newspaper Izvestia, received here yesterday. It shows Premier Georgi M. Malenkov of the Soviet Union as he addressed the Supreme Soviet last Saturday, when he announced the United States no longer had a monopoly on the production of the hydrogen bomb.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- Dr. Lee M. Thurston, Federal Commissioner of Education, said today that the funds voted by Congress for the Office of Education enabled it to recall notices of reduction in staff and continue all programs.
WESTBURY, L. I., Aug. 13 (AP) -- Queen's Joy, owned by Mrs. Catherine Peters of Schuylkill Haven, Pa., staged a stretch drive to win the Lindenhurst Trot tonight at Roosevelt Raceway.

The Comet Chemical Company, Inc., has completed its new factory, laboratory and offices at 410 Adams Street, Newark, replacing the plant destroyed by explosion Feb. 21 last, and all operations are under way there.

With the approach of mid-August -- when the pollination of ragweed brings the worst season of the year for hay fever sufferers -- the Health Department announced yesterday the destruction of 1,748 acres of the obnoxious growth since June 10.

Reflecting the record peacetime sales achieved in the quarter and six months ended on June 30, Olin Industries, Inc., increased earnings over the corresponding periods of last year despite substantially larger taxes.
The annual luncheon and fashion show of the American Women's Voluntary Services will be given on Oct 14 in the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria under the chairmanship of Mrs. Ogden L. Mills.

The Procter Gamble Company and its subsidiaries had a net profit of $42,031,863 after all charges, including $46,499,097 provision for taxes, the report for the year ended June 30 disclosed yesterday. The profit is equal to $4.35 a common share and compares with $41,715,757, or $4.32 a share, earned in the previous year, when taxes took $50,636,122.

A guilty conscience prevailing upon him, a young painter surrendered to the police yesterday afternoon and confessed that he had robbed a West Side bank of $950 fourteen months ago to pay off debts and further his art career.

NEWPORT, R. I., Aug. 13 -- Victor Seixas and Tony Trabert gained the semi-final round of the Newport invitation tennis tournament today and between them they were on the center court of the Casino from 11:45 in the morning until 5:15 in the afternoon.
LONDON, Aug. 13 -- Britain's exports to the United States were at the high level of $42,560,000 during July.

Gale warnings for the New York area went out last night from the Weather Bureau in a 7 o'clock bulletin predicting sharp lashes of wind and rain here today from the fringes of the hurricane that struck across the Atlantic Coast yesterday.

CHICAGO, Aug. 13 -- Wheat futures priced dropped here today to the lowest level since June, 1947, the September contract hitting the $1.75-a-bushel mark before recovering. After a steady opening the market went into a dive which carried prices down as much as 8 cents.

OSLO, Norway, Aug. 13 -- The first international conference on atomic energy for industrial power voted unanimously at its closing session today in favor of establishing an international nuclear energy association, open to nuclear scientists of all the nations of the world, including the Soviet Union and other countries behind the Iron Curtain.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 (UP) -- The Department of Defense released today the names of the first of 1,022 Americans listed by the Communists as having died in Korean prison camps.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- The separation of 1,109 employes of the State Department under the new Administration's economy program will have been practically completed by Nov. 1. The personnel cut represents a reduction from 11,198 positions to an authorized 10,089 positions.

TOKYO, Friday, Aug. 14 -- The Communist Chinese Peiping radio charged today that the United Nations Command was "secretly withholding" 129 prisoners of the Korean war who had been removed from South Korean stockades and separately detained.
DENVER, Aug. 13 -- President Eisenhower created a new fourteen-member Government committee today to prevent discriminatory employment practices in companies with Federal contracts.

Oil from Russia and the satellite countries appears to be seeking an outlet in increasing amounts in world markets. So far, the volume is "not great." according to international oil circles, but they say the movement has reached such proportions that it will bear watching.

CHICAGO, Aug. 13 (AP) -- The Detroit Lions, champions of the National Football League, and the best new college graduates tangle in the twentieth All-Star game at Soldier Field before 90,000 tomorrow night.

The New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program will send a bloodmobile today to La Salle Military Academy, Oakdale, L. I., to collect blood donations from Christian Brothers, mainly from Manhattan College, on a summer retreat there.

Construction contracts for two specially designed Navy refrigerator ships have been awarded to the Ingalls Shipbuilding Company of Mississippi, it was announced yesterday in Washington by Louis S. Rothschild, chairman of the Federal Maritime Board.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- The Yankees came up with only eleven blows tonight, scarcely an echo of their explosive twenty-eight-hit outburst last night.

MONSTERS are awake in the deep! None of those pink hallucinations, but blue-finned giants of the tuna family and among them probably the world record fish which all the sports fishermen along the Atlantic Coast are hoping to catch.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- Department store sales in the week ended Aug. 8 were 2 per cent above sales in the corresponding week of last year. This was reported today by the Federal Reserve Board, which listed the following percentage changes from like periods of 1953:
MUNSAN, Korea, Friday, Aug. 14 (AP) -- The United Nations Command's official list of United States prisoners of war freed in today's armistice exchange:

LONDON, Aug. 13 -- In the quietest trading this week prices of many domestic industrials showed small declines on the stock market here. However, British Government securities continued their advance, with gains up to one-eighth per cent and several of the leading equities were in demand.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy said today that sworn testimony in the records of his Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations indicated that an employe of the Government Printing Office, who had been accused under oath of being a Communist, had access to top secret data concerning both the atomic and hydrogen bombs.

Park Commissioner Robert Moses is right when he says that not many of this city's visitors would agree with Frederick R. Koppen of 1 Wall Street that New York is "an awfully cold burg." As Mr. Moses points out, the city has amply demonstrated the cordiality of its welcome for visitors by letting them parade through business streets and by handling the more boisterous ones in tactful fashion.
KINGMAN, Ariz., Aug 13 (UP) -- Six women members of the Utah polygamous colony, held here today after extradition by Utah authorities, refused to tell the whereabouts of their spouses and children.

ATHENS, Aug. 13 -- United States Navy and Air Force units labored beside Greek, British and Israeli disaster relief forces in the Ionian Islands today as the tide of casualties from the worst earthquake in modern Greek history mounted steadily.

MAYS LANDING, N. J., Aug. 13 (AP) -- Again II, an Argentine-bred horse owned by John S. Kroese, received a powerful ride by Charlie Burr at the Atlantic City track today to take down the winner's share of the $5,000 Seaside Purse.

In Youngstown, Ohio, last winter a zealous police chief embarked on a "clean-up" campaign of the city's newsstands and attempted through threat of arrest to stop the sale of certain books and magazines he deemed obscene. No court order was involved; the forbidden items were simply those which the police authorities decided came under a Youngstown ordinance banning sale of publications of an "obscene or immoral nature."

Five Army and Marine veterans of Korea joined Mayor Impellitteri last night in Times Square to start a nation-wide program to encourage the folks at home to write more letters to United States service men and women stationed throughout the world.
Albuquerque, N. M., will open bids on Aug. 25 on $2,400,000 of sewer and water revenue bonds maturing from 1969 to 1983.

ONE day in June sixty years ago Dr. William Hallock Park of the municipal Health Department's Bureau of Laboratories got a cablegram from Budapest. It said: "Start the horses. Antitoxin great success."

CHICAGO, Aug. 13 -- Dave Beck, president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, one of the country's largest unions, was elected today to the executive council of the American Federation of Labor. By this unanimous action of the council he became the Thirteenth Vice President of the federation.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- During the week ended Aug. 12, member bank reserves decreased $21,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

OTTAWA, Aug. 13 -- The Canadian Ministry of Immigration revealed today that an escaped German prisoner of war, accompanied by his Austrian-born, naturalized wife and 3-year-old son, walked into headquarters yesterday and gave himself up, asking for legal entry into the country.

With Leo Durocher simmering in the dressing room, the Giants blew a third straight decision to the Dodgers, 9 -- 8, in ten innings, before 30,931 spectators at the Polo Grounds last night. As on Wednesday, the New Yorkers frittered away a five-run lead, and, again as on Wednesday, Clem Labine was the winning pitcher and Hoyt Wilhelm the loser.

Manhattan Borough President Robert F. Wagner Jr., the Tammany-Bronx candidate for the Democratic nomination for Mayor, promised yesterday to invoke the full powers of the city government to put a stop to rent gouging if he is nominated and elected.

BONN, Germany, Aug. 13 -- The Social Democratic party headquarters issued today a Yellow Book containing sixty-three documents purporting to prove that leading industrialists and business men in West Germany had raised a multi-million dollar campaign fund to re-elect Chancellor Konrad Adenauer's three coalition parties in the election Sept. 6.

DENVER, Aug. 13 -- That man Eisenhower has poise. He consented to let photographers shoot him while he played golf today. He had photographers prone in front of him, photographers kneeling behind him, photographers squatting on the flanks and photographers in his hair.
MONTCLAIR, N. J., Aug. 13 -- Outscoring the strong field by a stroke, Mr. and Mrs. Gordon S. Park won the Metropolitan Golf Association mixed-foursome event today over the Montclair Golf Club course.

FORT WAYNE, Ind., Aug. 13 (AP) -- Marty Furgol of Lemont, Ill., and Dick Knight of Honolulu led the field with a nine-under-par 63's in the first round of the $15,000 Fort Wayne open golf tournament today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- The Administration's intensified drive to curb Federal spending serves to emphasize the imminence of a fiscal predicament that goes much beyond the immediate problem of staying within the legal national debt limit this year.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 13 -- Plans for building a downtown airlines bus terminal as a means of getting airlines operations out of the crowded Union Square district were announced today.

Negotiators for 1,100 sand and concrete truckers agreed last night at City Hall to let their union membership vote in secret Tuesday on an industry offer for settlement of their seven-week strike. The tie-up has halted $600,000,000 in construction, including work on several school buildings, in this city and on Long Island.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 13 (AP) -- O. DeG. Vanderbilt, president of the 211-year-old Taylor-Wharton Iron and Steel Company, said today directors have approved sale of the company's principal assets to Eastern financial interests. The deal was reported to involve more than $5,000,000.

Thirty per cent of the money invested by the nation's life insurance companies in the first six months of this year was used for mortgage loans on homes, farms and other properties, according to the Institute of Life Insurance.

A syndicate represented by David Rapoport has purchased the six-story store and office building occupying the block bounded by Astor Place, Fourth Avenue, Ninth Street and Third Avenue, a landmark called Bible House. The sale was the first since the building was erected and was negotiated by Carstens Linnekin, brokers, with Gilbert Darlington, treasurer of the American Bible Society, and Harry Frankel, of the Astor Place Real Estate Company, represented the seller.

TOKYO, Friday, Aug. 14 (AP) -- The Peiping radio complained today that Chinese and North Korean Red Cross workers visiting the Allied prisoner island of Koje had been prostrated by tear gas last Sunday.

MUNSAN, Korea, Aug. 13 -- At least nine more American soldiers who have chosen Communist China over the United States as a homeland were identified today by newly freed G. I.'s passing through Munsan.

WASHINGTON, Aug 13 -- Walter Thomas Grow, a First Classman at the United States Military Academy, West Point, N. Y., died in a burning bedroom of his home in nearby Falls Church, Va., early today, despite the efforts of his father, Maj. Gen. Robert W. Grow, to save him. He was 21 years old.

The abundant supply of fresh vegetables, largely from near-by areas, suggests their generous use in week-end meals. Some of those recently classed as "budget buys" are eggplant, peppers, celery and summer squash. Coming into seasonal prominence now are broccoli, cauliflower, lima beans and corn. Cabbage, onions and carrots still remain the lowest priced selections in the market.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 13 (AP) -- Joe Coleman pitched a three-hitter tonight as the Athletics defeated the Red Sox, 1 -- 0. It was the first victory for Coleman this season and his first completed game in more than two years.

Not too many books (of the thousands that are published each year) are published in the summer. It is the slow season. It is the time when most people make elaborate plans to do nothing. It is, however, also the time when would-be authors work very hard.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 13 (AP) -- Vern Stephens, who failed in three earlier clutch batting opportunities, redeemed himself today by driving in Vic Wertz with an eleventh inning single to give the Browns a 1-0 triumph over the Tigers before 980.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 (AP) -- Leland Olds, former chairman of the Federal Power Commission, urged Congress today to keep atomic power under Government control as "a resource of the people, a part of the public domain."

PURCHASE, N. Y., Aug. 13 -- A traffic ticket will disqualify a contestant and a new dent in his fender will cost him five demerits in the 1953 "International 1000," a long distance sports-car motoring contest to be run through parts of New York, Canada and Pennsylvania beginning Aug. 26.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 (UP) -- Senator John W. Bricker, Republican of Ohio, said today that the Senate Commerce Committee, of which he is chairman, probably would postpone an investigation of professional and amateur athletics until Federal court cases involving football and baseball were decided.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 (UP) -- The Veterans Administration announced today it is suspending G. I. loan gratuity payments after Sept. 1, in compliance with a law recently passed by Congress.

GUATEMALA, Aug. 13 -- The Guatemalan Agrarian Department notified the United Fruit Company today that 173,949 acres of its Atlantic holdings would be expropriated. This means that all but 87,000 of its approximate 260,000 acres in the Atlantic holdings are affected by the Agrarian law.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Aug. 13 -- Outstanding progress in nomenclature, or the naming of things, the highly disputatious A B C of zoology, was reported at the final plenary session of the fourteenth International Congress of Zoology that came to an end here today.

CAMBERLEY, England, Aug. 13 (Reuters) -- British Commonwealth military leaders have decided the guided missile is a better weapon for tactical atom warfare than the United State's atomic cannon, it was announced here today.

Hotels Statler, Inc., announced here yesterday the awarding of a contract to erect an eighteen-story Statler hotel in Dallas, Tex., to Robert E. McKee General Contractor, Inc. Arthur F. Douglas, president of the Statler group of hotels, said the proposed building would contain 1,000 rooms and would represent an investment of about $15,000,000, including the cost of the land.

As Actors Equity Association considered charges of insubordination filed against Ronny Graham because of his sudden withdrawal from "New Faces of 1952," now playing in Chicago, the actor-writer issued a statement yesterday attributing his action to an extended siege of illness.
Trading on the New York commodity exchanges was light yesterday and prices were mixed.

At their annual meeting in San Francisco yesterday stockholders of the Crown Zellerbach Corporation voted to amend the articles of incorporation to permit an increase in authorized common shares from 7,500,000 to 15,000,000.
An octagonal chapel for the Benedictine Order of the Roman Catholic Church will be blessed in honor of Our Lady of Peace tomorrow morning on a 500-acre farm site west of Elmira, N. Y.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 14 -- The Yankees' grand march on their fifth straight pennant stalled a bit tonight when rain washed out the opener of their five-game series with Jimmy Dykes' sixth-place Athletics.

Election of Irving B. Babcock as president of the Dearborn Motors Corporation and the Dearborn Motors Credit Corporation, Birmingham, Mich., was announced yesterday by the board of directors. He succeeds Thomas A. Farrell, who resigned both offices to become a vice president of the Ford Motor Company and general manager of its newly formed Ford tractor division.

LONDON, Aug. 14 (Reuters) -- A British flight lieutenant who was shot through the heart with a .303-caliber rifle bullet is alive and well, thanks to a new arterial transfusion process, the British Medical publication, The Lancet, reported today.

ROSLYN, L. I., Aug. 14 -- The operations and control center of the Twenty-sixth Air Division, whose responsibility it is to protect the Eastern Seaboard from enemy air attacks, was shown to the press today for the first time.

CONCORD, N. H., Aug. 14 -- Robert W. Upton, 69 years old, a lawyer of Concord and a lifelong, stanch Republican, was appointed today by Gov. Hugh Gregg of New Hampshire to fill the vacancy caused by the death of Senator Charles W. Tobey, also a Republican.
OTTAWA, Aug. 14 (Canadian Press) -- The Trades and Labor Congress of Canada, backtracking on an earlier attitude, today took a step toward a single labor body for Canada.

PARIS, Aug. 14 -- While strikers in public services, transport and communications continued to maintain a solid front, with the important exception of Paris subway workers, the first signs of a groping toward a solution of the present crippling situation appeared today.

MILWAUKEE, Aug. 14 -- Larry Evans and James T. Sherwin, both of New York, kept pace with Nicolas Rossolimo of Paris by winning their fourth straight games in the fourth round today in the annual tournament for the United States Chess Federation open championship.

The Health Department obtained a special allotment of gamma globulin yesterday from state health authorities for children who returned to the city on Aug. 6 from Camp Wyandot, at Mount Tremper in Ulster County, where three cases of poliomyelitis, one of them fatal, have occurred.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- Tariff agencies representing motor carriers told the Interstate Commerce Commission today that they would add the weight-distance tax on motor vehicles operated in or through New York State to their present rates before the end of the year.

NEWPORT, R. I., Aug. 14 -- Kenneth Rosewall, Australian champion, reached the semi-final round of the Newport invitation tennis tournament today and Lewis Hoad, his team-mate, was leading Hamilton Richardson of Baton Rouge, La., by 2 sets to 1 when rain interrupted play at the Casino.

The Public Service Commission asked the Long Island Rail Road yesterday for a report of the facts in a complaint by a commuter that he and eight other passengers were stranded in the Jamaica station early Wednesday because of inaccurate information given to them by railroad employes.

When a man dies it is right that those who survive should regard again his accomplishments, especially if he has contributed conspicuously to work of public value and public interest. Consequently, the tributes paid to George McAneny in the press reminded his many friends of his good work.
INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 14 (AP) -- Ford Konno of Honolulr, Olympic 1,500-meter swimming champion, won his specialty in the national A. A. U. title meet today.

Forty-eight business executives from most sections of the United States and from three foreign countries will arrive tomorrow at Harriman, N. Y., to begin work in the third session of the Executive Program in Business Administration, conducted by the Columbia University Graduate School of Business.

FORT WAYNE, Ind., Aug. 14 (UP) -- Dr. Cary Middlecoff, Memphis dentist, blazed to a competitive course record today to tie Marty Furgol for the halfway lead in the $15,000 Fort Wayne open golf tourney with 131 -- 13 under par.

The massive New York Cathedral (Cathedral of St. John the Divine) for more than half a century a solemn haven for worshipers and awed sightseers, is now playing host to a summer day camp, the members of which play softball at its north side and Scrabble and nok-hockey in the crypt.
WASHINGTON, Saturday, Aug. 15 -- The nation's farmers have overwhelmingly approved strict Federal controls on the 1954 wheat crop in return for high Government price supports.

LENOX, Mass., Aug. 14 -- The final week-end of concerts at the Berkshire Festival began here tonight in the stately music shed at Tanglewood with a performance of a big work for chorus, soloists and orchestra -- Brahms' "A German Requiem."

An armed thug who had just robbed a business man of $1,300 in an elevator, deliberated yesterday how to escape while he rode up and down four times in a twelve-story building at 12 West Thirty-first Street. He finally alighted at the second floor and fled.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 (AP) -- Under the law, the commission has thirty days to act on the rehearing petitions. If it takes no action, they are deemed automatically denied at the end of thirty days. Filing of such petitions is a necessary step to a court contest on the F. P. C.'s order.

The world has so many trouble spots these days that one is apt to pass over the odd one here and there to preserve a little peace of mind. It would be well, however, to keep an eye on Iran, where matters are going from bad to worse, thanks to the machinations of Premier Mossadegh.
Supreme Court Justice Samuel M. Gold granted a motion yesterday reducing the rents of seven tenants at the Gansvoort Apartments, 95 Christopher Street.

PATRAS, Greece, Aug. 14 -- Vice Admiral John H. Cassady arrived here today with six transport ships and more than 1,000 Marines from the United States Sixth Fleet to aid victims of the disastrous earthquakes that continued to be felt in the Greek Ionian Islands, Cephalonia, Zante and Ithaca. The quakes began last Sunday.

TOKYO, Saturday, Aug. 15 -- The United Nations Command formally demanded yesterday that the Communists return all prisoners of the Korean War who chose repatriation, regardless of sentences imposed on them for real or fancied breaches of discipline in the North Korean stockades.

PARIS, Aug. 14 -- Assembled around their leader, Hadj Thami el Mezouari el Glaoui, the Pasha of Marrakesh, about 300 caids, sheikhs and tribal chieftains from all parts of Morocco decided today to depose their Sultan, Sidi Mohammed Ben Youseff, and to enthrone the Sultan's uncle, Moulay Mohammed Ben Arafa, in his place.

VIENNA, Aug. 14 -- The Allied Control Council held its 200th session today. The meeting was livelier and more genial than usual because the Russians were in a conciliatory mood and the Western High Commissioners felt the decisions marked a step forward in the position of occupied Austria.
MANCHESTER, Mass., Aug. 14 (AP) -- Mrs. Margaret Osborne du Pont, a 34-year-old mother from Wilmington, Del., continued in her bid for the comeback of the year in women's tennis.

EVER since the Neanderthalers invented writing or a predecessor of it men have worked overtime to charm their fellows with words. Ever since Joe College became a recognizable type, writing courses have mushroomed on all sides, following the unsound assumption that anything, including creation, can be learned from a book, provided that the student is willing and

Glass or crystal containers seem to double their usefulness in summer, their clear or frosty-colored sides giving a cool look to their contents as well as to the room. Vases, beverage containers and accountrements for serving a meal are some of the new containers that display fresh shapes, colors or decorations.

TRENTON, Aug. 14 -- The Public Service Coordinated Transport Company today asked the State Public Utility Commission for the right to raise the fares on its buses operating to New Jersey race tracks and to some shore resorts.

UTICA, N. Y., Aug. 14 (AP) -- At least eighteen persons were injured and ten railroad cars were derailed today when a New York Central eastbound passenger express, the Missourian, crashed into a huge highway construction roller stalled on the tracks near here.

NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 14 -- Such wide publicity is being given to reports of United States interference in Kashmir that the American Embassy here issued today a statement categorically denying the allegations.

PARIS, Aug. 10 -- A retrospective look at this fall's openings discloses Dior's skirts are not as short as they seemed at first glance. His coats are about seventeen inches from the floor, dresses a half inch shorter, which on most women means they reach the top of the calf.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 (UP) -- Representative Augustine B. Kelley, Democrat of Pennsylvania, told the Army today he wanted the "full facts" on why it was dropping a gas mask procurement program.

LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., Aug. 14 -- Maureen Orcutt of White Beeches and her brother, Bill, from the Pine Brook Club of Gloversville, N. Y., won the nineteenth sister-brother golf championship with a four-over-par, 37, 39 -- 76 over the rain-soaked Creek course today.

CHICAGO, Aug. 14 -- Wheat trading again monopolized pit activity today, prices moving up sharply and continuing the recovery which was started yesterday. Trade opinion was that long liquidation had been completed with heavy stop-loss sales yesterday.

LONDON, Aug. 14 -- Prices of domestic industrial issues advanced on a broad front today. The brighter trend, which reversed yesterday's movements, was attributed mainly to the improved July trade returns which were issued too late yesterday to affect the markets.

Larry Sullivan, a longshoreman employed by the United States Lines on Pier 61, was elected president of Local 791 of the International Longshoremen's Association in a day of voting yesterday under the auspices of the Honest Ballot Association.
CHICAGO, Aug 14 -- Dave Beck, president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, has assured the American Federation of Labor that he intends to stay in the federation, it was learned today.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Aug. 14 -- The 125-year-old Java Bank, renamed the Bank of Indonesia in July when Parliament converted the former private Dutch institution into a Government corporation, has issued its last annual report with the warning Indonesia is living far beyond her financial strength.

SCOTT AIR FORCE BASE, Ill., Aug. 14 (AP) -- Eight ailing former prisoners of war were delayed here today in their flight from Korea to hospitals near their homes by hurricane warnings on the East Coast.
LONDON, Saturday, Aug. 15 (AP) -- Following is the text of a statement from Prime Minister Churchill's office today on Britain's post-armistice commitments on Korea:

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Aug. 14 -- The Riksdag (Parliament) is not placing funds at the Navy's disposal fast enough to maintain the $128,000,000 naval building program approved by the Riksdag last year. The plan, already delayed by Riksdag insistence that the payments be spread over seven instead of six years as asked by the navy, will now be delayed two years more for completion in 1961.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 14 -- A reading room in the United Nations library building has been set aside as a memorial to Abraham H. Feller, former general counsel to the world organization and one of the top-rank officials connected with its early years.

EDINBURGH, Aug. 14 -- The twelve hundred women delegates attending the International Congress on Home Economics here acclaimed with prolonged applause today a plea by a British expert that the study of home economics be raised to university status and graduates in this subject be given the accolade of degrees.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 14 -- Dag Hammarskjold, Secretary General of the United Nations, declared today that he would not try to prove who was right or wrong in the tiff with New York over parking near the headquarters site.

In his proposals to the City Planning Commission for the expenditure of capital funds on the construction of public projects Public Works Commissioner Zurmuhlen has shown restraint. Of the $85,266,390 recommended for 1954 construction, only $1,265,000 is for new projects, the remainder being proposed as renewals of planning and construction funds for current projects.

Three bond issues totaling $2,800,000 were sold yesterday by Anchorage, Alaska, and 'the Anchorage Independent School District to a group headed by Foster Marshall of Seattle, Blyth Co., Inc., of Seattle, and Allison-Williams Company of Minneapolis and associates.

BERLIN, Aug. 14 -- The dismissal of Anton Ackermann, East Germany's acting Foreign Minister, was considered likely today, after it had been announced he had been ousted as head of East Germany's leading Marxist academy.

AMHERST, Mass., Aug. 14 (UP) -- Championship competition of the National Archery Association ended today with the Springfield (Mass.) archers winning the national team prize by seventeen points over the Essex, N. J., squad.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 14 -- This hardly comes under the heading of stop-press news, but Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt's Native Dancer, the 3-year-old colt with the sixteen - for - seventeen record, is a 1-to-2C proposition in tomorrow's eighty-fourth Travers.

WEST POINT, N. Y., Aug. 14 -- Battle-tested veterans of the Korean War and cadets of the United States Military Academy's Third Class engaged in realistic combat maneuvers here today under the direction of the academy's Department of Tactics.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 14 -- J. A. (Jango) Goulart, young Labor Minister who has been the most controversial figure in Brazil in recent weeks, defined his policy today and denied vehemently he had any "peronista" leanings.

DETROIT, Aug. 14 (AP) -- Motor vehicle output in the United States this week will total 150,920 units. Ward's Automotive Reports said today. The agency counted 125,959 cars and 24,961 trucks in this total.

It was Odysseus, the one "of many wiles," who described his native Ithaca as "a rugged isle, but a good nurse of young men." Now Ithaca and its neighbors of the Ionian Sea -- more familiar to the mariners of antiquity than to most of us today -- have been laid low by a devastating earthquake, the worst they have suffered in modern times.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- Oveta Culp Hobby, Secretary of the Department of Health, Education and Welfare, today announced the organization of a departmental council of top-echelon office holders with a full-time secretary.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- Whatever differences there may have been between the British and French over the United States Government's food program in East Germany, have been ironed out by now, a State Department spokesman said today.

VIENNA, Aug. 14 -- The Allied Council abolished today four-power censorship of letters, telegrams, telephonic and teletype communications in Austria and agreed to remove all restrictions on travel throughout Austria for members of the Allied Commission, the staffs of the Allied Embassies and their families.

MINEOLA, L. I., Aug. 14 -- Two Nassau boys who left Woodmere yesterday for a leisurely sail to Bay Shore were rescued today from their grounded twenty-five-foot cabin cruiser, Sweet Ethel, two miles east of the Jones Beach water tower. They had spent the night aboard the disabled craft.

Charles Olla, a 45-year-old hair-dresser of Union City, N. J., who recently has become a food manufacturer, says it is his formula and his method that are responsible for quite the best bottled tomato sauce we have tasted in recent memory. It is thick and mellow, so like the freshly cooked in flavor that the most experienced Italian-American palate would miss out, we think in identifying it as a heat-and-eat food.

The eleven-day walkout of longshoremen employed at Pier 32, North River, which has paralyzed the operations of the Moore-Mc-Cormack Lines since Aug. 4, ended yesterday afternoon, when the steamship company capitulated on the single issue involved.

LUANG PRABANG, Indo-China, Aug. 14 (UP) -- Patrol fighting between French Laotian troops and Communist rebels has broken out in many parts of Laos, remote Indo-China kingdom, French headquarters announced today.

Rails and motors were hammered on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday and the general level of prices had the widest loss this month but the market was studded with strong points. Electrical equipments, aircrafts and rail equipments moved higher.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- An unidentified woman witness flown here from the West Coast was reported by Senator Joseph R. McCarthy today to have sworn before his Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations that she saw a fellow employe at the Government Printing Office pocket highly classified data, including "a secret code," and take it out of the plant.

MOUNT HOLLY, N. J., Aug. 14 -- The New Jersey Racing Commission took under advisement today an application of the Jersey Raceway Association for a permit to construct a harness racing track with pari-mutuel betting at near-by Springfield Township.
HERE is that striped-bass fellow again! We mean Ray Garceau from out on Block Island, who spends all his free time breaking his own world records.
CHICAGO, Aug. 14 (AP) -- Notre Dame is scheduled to be disciplined by the National Collegiate Athletic Association for football recruiting irregularities, an authoritative source said today.

The crews that will represent the United States in the International Lifeboat Race, to be held on the Hudson River on Sept. 12, were chosen yesterday despite the ugly weather that kept transportation to a minimum,

There are more apartments in Manhattan than in the other boroughs of the city, though it has only 14 per cent of the city's population, according to a survey of apartment construction here in the last fifty years just completed by the Real Estate Board of New York.

" Our conception of the United Nations is that of a family of nations and not an anti-Communist alliance." This was said by Acting Prime Minister Richard A. Butler in the House of Commons on July 30 in advocacy of the admission of Communist China to the United Nations.

PATERSON, N. J., Aug. 14 -- Clarence (Red) Mosley, the Air Force's only quadruple amputee, arrived at his home here today and announced that he just wanted to "relax, think things over and get used to being Mr. John Q. Civilian."

TEL AVIV, Israel, Aug. 14 -- The first goods from West Germany shipped under the $714,000,000 reparations agreement between West Germany and Israel were unloaded today in Jaffa. The Israeli freighter Ethrog carried the cargo, which consisted of iron and caustic soda from Hamburg.
Deliveries of refined copper to fabricators in this country dropped sharply last month to 104,593 tons from the 139,520 tons shipped in June, the Copper Institute reported yesterday.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 14 (AP) -- Roy McMillan's single scored Ted Kluszewski in the eleventh inning tonight to give the Redlegs a 2-1 victory over the Cardinals. Kluzewski hammered in the initial Redleg run in the fourth and doubled to spark the victors in the second extra inning.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Aug. 14 -- Mohammed Ali, Prime Minister of Pakistan, was reported today to be considering a major concession to Jawaharlal Nehru, the Indian Prime Minister, on the number of troops to be maintained by each country on a cease-fire line in Kashmir.

PLAINFIELD, N. J., Aug. 14 -- Betty Park of Glen Ridge, finishing in a downpour, carded a 37, 43 -- 80, to win the Women's New Jersey Golf Association one-day tournament at the Plainfield Country Club today. Miss Park paced a field of forty-four.
LIVERPOOL, England, Aug. 14 (Reuters) -- Rates for the use of the Port of Liverpool are to go up by 12 1/2 to 66 2/3 per cent beginning Sept. 7.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 (UP) -- The Customs Bureau disclosed today that it planned to impose fees ranging from $25 to $100 for some types of service it now provided free.
The Pure Oil Company and its subsidiaries reported yesterday a net profit of $11,297,000 for the first half of this year, as against $13,816,000 earned in the initial six months of 1952.

DENVER, Aug. 14 -- It's a happy day for William Urban Maloney of Curryane, Swinford, County Mayo, Ireland. The Eisenhower Administration has decided to forgive and forget that bit of a tangle he got into with the London Bobbies.

CHICAGO, Aug. 14 (AP) -- A week in which salable receipts were the fewest for hogs in more than five years ended with prices going still higher today. A steady to 25 cents higher trend placed them at new high levels for the month to date.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 (AP) -- Discovery of active oil seepages in the little-known Malaspina Glacier area of southern Alaska was announced yesterday by Secretary of the Interior Douglas McKay.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- Average primary market prices declined 0.1 per cent in the week ended on Tuesday to 110.6 per cent of the 1947-49 base, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

The city Public Works Department made known yesterday that it had received bids on the first construction contract for the new $9,666,214 Brooklyn City Prison and Remand Shelter, designed to accommodate 817 prisoners.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- Four separate objectors today moved to halt the Federal Power Commission in its plan to authorize the New York State Power Authority to participate in the hydroelectric development of the St. Lawrence River.

Admiral Arthur W. Radford takes over from General Bradley today the post of Chairman of our Joint Chiefs of Staff. By Monday he will have the new team in full operation. General Twining has already been sworn in as the Air Chief and on Monday General Ridgway and Admiral Carney will take their places of Chiefs for the Army and the Navy.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- Secretary of State John Foster Dulles left Washington by commercial airliner today for Watertown, N. Y., and his lodge on near-by Duck Island, Lake Ontario, for a week's vacation. He will not attend the opening session of the General Assembly of the United Nations Monday.

The latest addition to the druggists' bag of merchandising tricks is the use of animation in the conventional shelf strips in self-service drug stores it was reported yesterday by J. N. Cooke, director of marketing of Sterling Drug, Inc.

Eight months after its adoption, the New York Stock Exchange Seat Retirement Fund swung into action. The committee charged with its operation bought a Stock Exchange membership for $45,000, down $1,000 from the previous transaction.

HEWLETT, L. I., Aug. 14 -- Although twenty-eight teams battled the elements during the second half of the qualifying round in the nineteenth annual Arthur Mann Memorial member-guest golf tournament at the Seawane Harbor Club today, only two were able to earn places in the championship flight that will start match play tomorrow.

It was a happy inspiration that led President Eisenhower to plan a break in his vacation next week by flying 1,600 miles from Denver to New York in order to dedicate one of this city's great slum-clearing and low-rent housing projects built with aid of the Federal Government.
DENVER, Aug. 14 -- Clarence B. Randall, chairman of the board of the Inland Steel Company, was appointed by President Eisenhower today to be chairman of the new Commission on Foreign Economic Policy.

LONDON, Aug. 14 -- The Labor party attacked the Government tonight for joining with the fifteen other nations fighting in Korea in a warning to Communist China that said that a breach of the armistice would probably lead to hostilities beyond Korea's borders.

TRENTON, Aug. 14 -- Fifty employes of the State Division of Employment Security received dismissal notices today and 550 other employes, or 25 per cent of the division's total personnel, faced the loss of their jobs within the next six weeks as a result of a cut-back in Federal funds.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 (AP) -- Representative Daniel A. Reed, Republican of upstate New York, said today a comprehensive revision of income tax laws, benefiting millions of taxpayers, will be the first order of business for the Ways and Means Committee of the House of Representatives at the session of Congress starting Jan. 6.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed yesterday at about the day's best levels and with net gains of 2 to 11 points, with the firmness developing in the last minutes of trading.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 (AP) -- The Federal Reserve Board said yesterday the nation's non-farm home owners increased by 5,000,000 in the past five years, with demand for houses still apparently strong.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Aug. 14 -- The long-awaited bilateral air treaty between the United States and Venezuela was signed here today. The signing marks the settlement of differences that began in 1950 and means a signal step forward in the relations between the two countries. The treaty goes into effect in eight days.

CHICAGO, Aug. 14 (AP) -- A record-breaking passing attack catapulted by Bombing Bobby Layne swept the Detroit Lions to a 24-10 victory over the College All-Stars before 93,818 at Soldier Field tonight.

RANGOON, Burma, Aug. 14 -- Burma may cut adrift from the British security system in Southeast Asia as a result of negotiations initiated recently for the replacement of the five-year-old British-Burmese defense agreement.
DETROIT, Aug. 14 (AP) -- Billy Pierce ran his scoreless streak to thirty-four and two-thirds innings tonight in pitching the White Sox to a 7-0 victory over the Tigers before 31,101 fans.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 (AP) -- Ernest O. Thompson, chairman of the Texas Railroad Commission, told Congress today the United States does not have half enough ready reserves of oil producing capacity for national security.

The cabaret license of the Three Deuces Club, 72 West Fifty-second Street, was revoked yesterday by Fourth Deputy Police Commissioner George P. Mitchell after the owners refused to contest the charges of violations raised by the Police Department.
