The Buckhorn Association, which is celebrating its fiftieth anniversary, has taken over the night of Nov. 11 at the play, "Gently Does It 'A Study in Murder,'" an English mystery, starring Brenda Do Banzie, the original London lead, and an all-English cast, at the Playhouse Theatre, for its autumn benefit.

ELISABETHVILLE, Belgian Congo, Aug. 14 -- The director of the economic service of Katanga Province, a mineral storehouse and industrial center in the Congo about the size of France, stated today the future of this part of Africa depended upon raising the purchasing power of the Congo's 11,000,000 Africans.

The cordial relations that have long existed between Columbia University and the City of New York are once again symbolized today as title to the one-block length of 116th Street between Broadway and Amsterdam Avenue passes from the city to the university.

The Federal Reserve Bank of New York hopes to promote greater skill and accuracy in reading numbers and sorting checks by its employes under a new speed reading program now being developed at the bank. A test group of fifteen proof machine operators took a special course in visual perception some time ago and follow-up studies indicated successful reults.

An investor has purchased from Chobol Navone, operators, the four-story apartment house for thirty-eight families on plot 100 by 100 feet at 1149 Sixty-third Street, between Eleventh and Twelfth Avenues, in Brooklyn, in a deal negotiated by Rubin Nason, brokers. The property is assessed at $95,000 and was sold for cash over mortgages amounting to $80,000.

GARFIELD, N. J., Aug. 14 -- An Austrian sporting goods manufacturer who had served in the underground and then was held in a concentration camp for three years killed his wife, his daughter and himself here early this morning.

HONG KONG, Aug. 14 -- Assembling under the leadership of their Communist party members, branch units of the Chinese-Soviet Friendship Association have been holding local meetings in Communist China on the ways and means to strengthen Chinese "emulation of the Soviet Union" and the "education of internationalism based on Chinese-Soviet friendship."

TEHERAN, Iran, Aug. 14 -- Premier Mohammed Mossadegh broadcast his thanks today to the Iranian people for their plebiscite vote dissolving the seventeenth Majlis (lower House of Parliament) then accused "some world statesmen" of misinterpreting and distorting events in Iran.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 (UP) -- The Agriculture Department said today that western railroads had cut rates 50 per cent on round-trip shipments of livestock from southwestern drought areas to temporary grazing areas.

SEOUL, Korea, Aug. 14 -- President Syngman Rhee said today that the only measure for judging the success of the forthcoming political conference called for under the armistice was whether it would serve to unify Korea and that this aim would have to be achieved within ninety days.

OTTAWA, Aug. 14 (AP) -- The Board of Transport Commissioners rejected today an appeal by Western Canadian lumber manufacturers against a freight rate increase of $1,000,000 a year on West Coast lumber shipped to Toronto, Montreal and other Eastern Canadian markets.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 14 -- Dag Hammarskjold, United Nations Secretary General, suggested here today that the General Assembly open its annual session in the spring instead of September to avoid the interruption of a recess at Christmas time.

HARTFORD, Conn., Aug. 14 -- A move by William A. Purtell, junior United States Senator from Connecticut, to heal a growing breach within the Republican party in this state was greeted today by dissident party leaders as a step toward harmony.

HARTSDALE, N. Y., Aug. 14 -- Diana Bourne, 21-year-old Siwanoy Country Club titleholder, won the Women's Westchester-Fairfield Association championship today by rallying in the rain at the Scarsdale Golf Club.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 14 -- Edmund Purdom, young English actor under contract to Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, has been chosen to play the title role in "The Student Prince." The film will utilize the voice of Mario Lanza, who had recorded the film's score before becoming involved in a dispute with Metro that ended in the termination of his contract.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 14 -- A mission of the American-Korean Foundation passed through this city today enroute to the Far East with both short and long-range objectives.

WINNIPEG, Aug. 14 (Canadian Press) -- Grain officials in Winnipeg said today Canadian farmers face the prospect of the worst grain tie-up since World War II as they prepare to harvest another bumper crop.

The election of a Negro to the Board of Estimate, top city governing agency, for the first time was virtually assured yesterday by the withdrawal of the last two white candidates for party nominations for Borough President of Manhattan and their scheduled replacement with Negroes.

Hurricane Barbara veered sharply to the open sea early today, after side-stepping the city and the exposed flanks of Long Island and northern New Jersey. Gusts of wind up to forty-four miles an hour, however, buffeted the metropolitan area during the night.

CHICAGO, Aug. 14 -- The twenty-first annual convention of the Military Order of the Purple Heart here today adopted a resolution demanding that if the Communists hold back any United Nations prisoners, as reports from Korea indicate they are doing, the Eighth Army Command should retain a like number of Communist prisoners.

As if the recent going had not been rough enough for the Giants, along came yesterday's rain to cause postponement of last night's scheduled encounter with the Phillies at the Polo Grounds. It will be contested as part of a doubleheader here on Monday, forcing Leo Durocher's club to play three successive twin bills -- all against the Phillies -- in as many days.

PLYMOUTH, England, Aug. 14 (AP) -- The British yacht Favona, owned by Sir Michael Newton, was declared the winner of the 605-mile Cowes-Fastnet Rock - Plymouth Challenge Cup race today on the basis of corrected time.

CHICAGO, Aug. 14 (UP) -- Bill Serena slammed a pinch home run with the bases filled in the sixth inning today as the Cubs routed the Braves, 11 to 4. This was the third straight pinch hit by Serena, his eighth homer of the year and the first grand slam home run of his major league career.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Aug. 14 -- The financial stringency in South Africa is being used by the Nationalist party as a lever to get for Prime Minister Daniel F. Malan what two years of bitter constitutional struggle failed to give him: the right to purge the white register containing 1,600,000 names of 47,000 mixed-blood voters called Coloreds.

Pak Heun Yung, purged Vice Premier and Foreign Minister of North Korea, was not among ten Communist officials recently sentenced to death by the Pyongyang regime, a dispatch on the purge in Pravda, the Soviet Communist newspaper indicated.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 (UP) -- A former top State Department official proposed today an increase of up to $3,000,000,000 in air defense spending "over a period of years" to guard against possible "overwhelming atomic attack" by the Soviet Union.

KUALA LUMPUR, Malaya, Aug. 14 -- The influental Malayan Chinese Association and Gen. Sir Gerald Templer, British High Commissioner in Malaya, are involved here in a controversy that is likely to have far-reaching importance in the evolution of Malayan politics.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- An improved stingless beehive that the keeper can rob of honey without danger to his fingers or face was patented this week by Charley A. Garrett of Gainesville, Tex. The bees deposit the honey in glass jars. When one is full, the bee farmer merely pulls it out, recaps it and sends it to market.

INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 14 -- American newspapers were praised and Russian papers assailed today by Maj. Gen. Julius Ochs Adler, vice president and general manager of THE NEW YORK TIMES, in an analysis of journalistic techniques of the United States and the Soviet Union.

Rounding out its services to offer the facilities of a complete medical center, St. Vincent's Hospital announced yesterday plans for a $2,500,000 addition to be devoted entirely to psychiatric treatment. The plans were filled with the Department of Housing and Buildings.

ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L. I., Aug. 15 -- An influential group of business men here rebelled this week against assessment methods being used to finance the building of three off-street parking lots for shoppers and commuters.

The adjustment from an inflationary to a sound fiscal policy cannot be made without interruption, according to the view expressed by Henry H. Heimann, executive vice president of the National Association of Credit Men, in his Monthly Business Review, being released today.
Fire swept through the New York Central Railroad's Wakefield Station in the Bronx yesterday afternoon and caused a two-hour suspension of train service on the line's Harlem division.

WHEN Andre Gide received the Nobel Prize in 1947, only eleven of his more than fifty works had appeared in the United States, and only a few of these were then readily available. Since that time about fifteen volumes, constituting a large and representative selection of his writings, have been newly published or reissued.

THE Sculpture Center's attractive but overly dark premises are constructed on the iceberg principle. That is, the main gallery leading straight off the street is no more than part of the building, the rest of which is a workshop and studios for member and guest artists.

SINCE geography has made England a maritime nation whose sailors and ships have kept her shopkeepers safe and in business, it is only natural that her film-makers have been able to cull rich source material from the sturdy vessels and doughty and intrepid men who guarded her sea lanes in time of war.

PANMUNJOM, Korea, Sunday, Aug. 16 (AP) -- Truckloads of happy American and British captives and exuberant South Koreans rode out of the Communist northland into this big prisoner exchange center today in the Russian-built Molotov trucks.
DETROIT, Aug. 15 (AP) -- Woodruff Randolph, president of the International Typographical Union, prepared today for a showdown with harsh critics of his union's venture into the publishing business.
BERLIN, Aug. 15 (AP) -- The Soviet zone mustered its provincial Communist press today in a drive to shame East Germans who come to West Berlin for United States food parcels.

SALT LAKE CITY, Aug. 15 -- Following a simple ceremony likened in significance to the driving of the golden spike on the nation's first transcontinental railroad, gasoline and other refinery products flowed this week through the $8,300,000 eight-inch transmission line of the Pioneer Pipe Line Company across 290 mountainous miles from Sinclair. Wyo., to North Salt Lake City.

A new approach to the delicate problem of religion in education is about to be undertaken by the American Association of Colleges for Teacher Education. The plan, brought down to its essence, is to develop "religious literacy" among prospective teachers.

After snapping their six-game losing streak by beating the Phillies, 4 -- 1, behind the six-hit pitching of Marv Grissom, the Giants relapsed into ineffectiveness and bowed to the Philadelphians, 5 -- 2, yesterday.

LARRY STORCH, Jackie Gleason's summer replacement on the Columbia Broadcasting System television network on Saturday evenings at 8 o'clock, is a serious young fellow, and for a lazy man he's one of the hardest workers in his field.
A new Congressional committee is about to study the Reciprocal Trade Act and to make recommendations on the basis of its findings. Our trade policy has been frequently investigated in the past.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 15 -- Divergent views of Britain and the United States as to the composition of the Far Eastern political conference that will take place this fall under terms of the Korean truce agreement appeared to have been brought closer together today.

WESTBURY, L. I., Aug. 15 -- Pronto Don, under the brilliant handling of Benny Schue, increased his life-time earnings to a record $255,236.46 tonight by capturing the featured Wyandanch Trot at Roosevelt Raceway before 35,048 fans, a world night-time harness racing attendance mark.
MEXICO CITY -- As the result of an immense dam and development project, the interior of southeastern Mexico has now been opened to comfortable travel for the first time.

The late David Shirr Jordan, Leland Stanford University and ichthyologists of two continents, figure in a puzzling case now awaiting disposition by the New York office of the Food and Drug Administration.

Dr. Robert Hofstadter, graduate student Harry R. Fechter and John A. McIntyre of Stanford University have devised the most powerful apparatus ever built to probe deeper into the nucleus of an atom than physicists have ever probed before. Some astounding discoveries have been made.
CINCINNATI, Aug. 15 (UP) -- Harvey Haddix gained his fifteenth victory of the year tonight as the Cardinals pounded out fifteen hits to rout the Redlegs, 10 -- 4.

QUENTIN, Pa., Aug. 15 (AP) -- Charles Dennehy Jr., a Lake Forest, Ill., youth who celebrates his twenty-first birthday Wednesday, turned in the only perfect ride in today's first half of the final competition to choose the 1953 United States equestrian team.

WITH only three weeks left of the official summer season, many resorts are calling attention to the fact that hotels do not slam shut and the scenery is not packed away with the advent of Labor Day. From various parts of the country come assurances of good weather and plenty of activities in September and October, along with the bonus of off-season rates.

INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 15 -- Burwell Jones of Detroit, chased by familiar twin Scotsmen, broke his own American record today in the 300-meter individual medley and won his sixth national amateur Athletic Union championship in the combination back-stroke, breast-stroke and free-style event.

ELISABETHVILLE, Belgian Congo, Aug. 15 -- Probably the most striking proof of the difference between the white man's mentality in South Africa and British Africa and the attitude of the Congo is the drive that now is being made here to get Africans to join the white settlers' federation.

UNTERWASSER, Switzerland -- Unterwasser is not the name of a regional Swiss liqueur. It is a hamlet, a thinly populated green speck that rests serenely in the valleyland that separates Churfirsten and Santis Mountains in eastern Switzerland.
PARIS, Aug. 15 -- Breaches appeared in the strike front today. That together with the resumption of contacts between the Government and non-Communist labor encouraged the belief that a ...

TEHERAN, Iran, Aug. 15 -- The Iranian Majlis, the lower house of Parliament, which last month threatened to oust Premier Mohammed Mossadegh with votes of no confidence, was declared today to have been dissolved as the result of the referendum completed this week, in which 99.94 per cent of the voters using non-secret ballots took the Premier's side in his quarrels with the chamber.

A group of factory and office workers from Fort Wayne, Ind., returned yesterday from a three-week tour of Europe and reported that Pope Pins XII had obligingly stood up on a chair -- at the request of one of the women.
ANTI-WAR and anti-American films are making news and money in Japan. Written and directed by purged Reds, the pictures are setting new boxoffice records and leaving a nationalistic after-taste.

LOS ANGELES -- West Coast photographers took the lead in the widely varied twentieth - anniversary program of the Photographic Society of America convention held here recently. Although, as in previous years, the pictorialist influence continued to dominate the meeting, the growing interest in other aspects of photography, particularly in color and stereo, appeared to challenge pictorialism's one-time leadership as the principal amateur activity.
Don't jinx us!"

One of the most cherished possessions of a manufacturer is his trade-mark. For some producers, loss of such symbol is tantamount to going out of business, while for all trade-mark owners such a loss means decreased sales.

PARIS, Aug. 15 -- Long-simmering labor discontent boiled up in France this week with such suddenness and force that it disrupted the country's entire economy and created genuine concern for the safety of the republican regime.

LONDON, Ont., Aug. 15 -- Barbara Romack, 20-year-old Sacramento, Calif., blonde, today won the Canadian women's open golf championship, defeating the British open champion, Marlene Stewart of Fonthill, Ont., 2 and 1, in the final.

DAG HJALMAR AGNE CARL HAMMARSKJOLD, the Secretary General of the United Nations, and a practicing, unashamed intellectual, is a man who cannot find it in him to make flat, pontifical statements; for him the-other-side-of-the-coin is not a cliche but a way of life.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- One of the first items on the Congressional agenda next year will be a general overhaul of the Federal tax structure -- something that has not been attempted in modern history and a project, as it is now shaping up, of back-breaking proportions.

SIX new all-bedroom cars costing more than $1,000,000 have been put in service by the Illinois Central on its Panama Limited and City of Miami trains. The new cars are noteworthy because they are the first of their kind to be built by the Pullman Standard Car Manufacturing Company.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- Eisenhower Administration farm leaders hailed today approval by American wheat farmers of rigid controls on their 1954 crop, a decision that will have an important bearing in shaping future farm policy.

DENVER, Aug. 15 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon was appointed by President Eisenhower today to be chairman of the new Government committee to fight discrimination and other unfair employment practices in plants working under contract for the Government.

RIVERSIDE, Conn., Aug. 15 -- Fourteen skippers started the men's sailing championship of Long Island Sound at the Riverside Yacht Club today. With favorable westerly breezes the four-race preliminaries were completed before darkness set in, despite time lost in replacing one boat damaged in an accident.

TEANECK, N. J., Aug. 15 (AP) -- The International Business Machines Country Club team from Poughkeepsie, N. Y., topped the firing today in the match for organized pistol club four-man teams in the twenty-second annual International Police Pistol Tournament.

With a total of $400,000 in purse offerings at stake. Yonkers Raceway opens its twelve-night summer meeting tomorrow night. As a result, followers of the light harness racing sport will be able to watch the standard-breds on two fronts, since programs also will be continued at Roosevelt Raceway in Westbury.

THE detective story may be 112 years old, but (despite its harsher critics) its possibilities are not yet exhausted. And I don't mean just its constantly widening literary possibilities, but the pure structural element of plot-trickery.

THE theatrical phenomenon of Australia and New Zealand ever since the war has -- been a revue company which does not have one girl in it. It is still playing to capacity houses after eight years and is now planning a world tour.

WHENEVER news of television slackens off, as it usually does during the summer dog days, it is reasonably certain that someone will rush to the rescue with a report that either "live" programs are enjoying a new vogue or the trend in TV is toward film.

Radiation safety will be outlined in a course to be given by the Department of Industrial Medicine of the New York University Post-Graduate Medical School in cooperation with the United States Atomic Energy Commission. Designed to acquaint present and potential users of radioisotopes and X-ray equipment with safety precautions, the course will be given once a week for fifteen weeks at the Institute of Industrial Medicine, 325 East Thirty eighth Street, beginning Sept. 23.

I found Albion Ross' "The Forces That Drive Malan On" (Aug. 9) more of an apology for Malan and what he stands for than an impartial account of the forces that are shaping South African policies. * * * In one place. Ross writes, "His speeches are like a mathematical equation."

NOT in more than twenty years has there been such a result in a national bridge tournament as the one at St. Louis last week, when an "unknown" pair won both the masters' pair and masters' team championships.

CHICAGO, Aug. 15 -- These are paradoxical times for the American labor movement. Union treasuries are full. The American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations are courting again after eighteen years of divorce.

On July 29 one of the weakest resolutions ever proposed on disarmament was adopted in the Senate by men who had just recently approved one of the strongest resolutions. It was introduced by Senator H. Alexander Smith of New Jersey as Senate Resolution 150 and was amended to become Senate Concurrent Resolution 46.
BONN, Germany, Aug. 15 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer charged tonight that certain Social Democratic district leaders had received campaign funds from East Germany.

TOKYO, Sunday, Aug. 16 (AP) -- The third devastating flood to hit Japan in less than a month today left hundreds dead, missing or injured and scores of thousands driven from inundated homes in the narrow Kizu River valley.
DENVER, Aug. 15 (AP) -- President Eisenhower today signed a bill liberalizing Government insurance of private loans for ship construction.

BACK in 1947 the Citizens Committee on Children of New York City published a pamphlet called "The Group Living of Children." In it leading specialists in health, education and welfare defined the essentials for all-round good care of children in groups outside their own homes.
MILWAUKEE, Aug. 15 (UP) -- Tuzo Portuguez of Costa Rica upset Jesse Turner of St. Louis when he boxed his way to a unanimous ten-round decision tonight at the Milwaukee Auditorium.

The pictures on these pages illustrate an oft-forgotten truth of war: the fighting may end, but soldiering goes on. This is most especially true for the troops in Korea, few of whom can expect shipment home as a result of the armistice, but who must now stand by to see what happens next.

Dr. Leonell C. Strong, research associate in anatomy at Yale's School of Medicine, finds that the age of the mother at pregnancy may endow the offspring with many characteristics, including either a susceptibility or a resistance to cancer. He has worked with inbred strains of mice but believes that his findings hold good for man and for higher animals in general.

THE blue hydrangeas which sometimes become pink, and the hydrangeas that were pink in the nursery but changed to blue in the garden, are always perplexing problems to the home gardener. This is not the fault of the nurseryman.

WASHINGTON -- For the long-distance motorist traveling north and south along the Atlantic Seaboard, the Chesapeake country still has more obstacles than any other comparable stretch of territory from Maine to Florida.

MIKE McGONNIGLE wants to retire. Turning his covered wagon southward, the old prospector heads for Frog Lake, hoping to settle in peace and seclusion. A swindling real estate dealer and a vicious neighbor almost drive him away, until Jo and Jerry, two young town children, help him outwit the two schemers.

Congress adjourned a fortnight ago without acting on the request of the Administration to raise the ceiling on its debt-making power. At the moment, therefore, the Federal Government is, technically speaking, in the position of a municipality which faces the possibility that it may have to raise additional funds but cannot obtain the necessary enabling legislation for the purpose.

THE digestive process of journalism is coarser than that of art, and we have lived through a period when a coarse digestion became indispensable. The journalist has had the task of accommodating violence to the private stomach and of domesticating the religious, revolutionary and national wars in the private conscience.
TORONTO, Aug. 15 -- A little Polish girl was rescued today by the stroke of a President's pen and a man named Eisenhower became her "best friend."
HEIDELBERG, Germany, Aug. 15 (UP) -- Two United States officers landed their light plane by error in the Soviet zone yesterday and are presumed be held by the Russians, it was announced today.

J. BRONOWSKI, a British scientist educated at Cambridge University, is something of an iconoclast. Not only does he believe that as a scientist he has the social obligation to explain science, so that a general public that knows hardly anything of its technical procedures will understand it, but he practices his belief.

Daniel J. Reisner, secretary of the New York County Republican Committee and deputy clerk of the State Assembly, was designated yesterday as campaign manager for Harold Riegelman, Republican candidate for Mayor.

The International Longshoremen's Association last week entered the crisis period in a sickness that has brought it to the point of disintegration. Joseph P. Ryan, lifetime president of the 60,000-man dock union that controls waterfront work along the Atlantic and Gulf Coasts, was notified that the executive council of the parent American Federation of Labor had voted to suspend the I. L. A. for labor racketeering and for failure to clean house.

The Air Force, which is seeking civilian engineers to work at overseas installations, will interview applicants at the professional office of the State Employment Service, 1 East Nineteenth Street, from tomorrow through Friday this week, between noon and 8 P. M.

HAVANA, Aug. 15 (UP) -- Three top leaders of the Popular Socialist (Communist) party go on trial Tuesday on charges of being involved in the abortive revolt at Santiago last July 26, it was announced today.

AMERICAN sports-car society is a cultural phenomenon which has now become sufficiently stratified so that its members may be identified, like Yale men, Kwakiutl Indians or followers of Madame Blavatsky, by their unique markings, distinctive cries and recherche ways.

MOST primroses require division and replanting every two or three years, if they're to retain their vigor and produce an abundance of flowers of maximum size in spring. Division of the plants can be accomplished any time from now until early October.

PRINCIPLES and "know-how" of road construction and maintenance developed in this country will be reported to Brazil by six top-flight highway engineers from that country now studying the highway networks of the forty-eight states. Particular attention will be given to procedures in the building of the New York Thruway, where the South American observers will learn ways of conquering terrain difficulties that will be applicable to corresponding districts in their country.

GLEN COVE, L. I., Aug. 15 -- Junius S. Morgan of West Island, elder son of the late banker, J. P. Morgan, is expected to take the next step in the long-standing controversy with the City of Glen Cove over beach fishing rights along Dosoris Creek and the Long Island Sound waterfront adjoining his estate.

NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 15 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru today appealed to the people of India, and especially to the citizens of New Delhi, to accord a warm welcome to ohammed Ali, Prime Minister of Pakistan, who will arrive here tomorrow to discuss the Kashmir dispute.

Leonard W. Mayo's article, "2,000,000 Reasons to Help South Korea" (Aug. 2), brought the attention of many of your readers to the work that Foster Parents Plan for War Children, Inc., is doing in Korea.

THERE appears to be an increasing tendency on the part of the recording companies to revisit happy, bygone days -- or, sometimes, happily bygone days -- in their jazz releases. The nostalgic backward glance, usually confined heretofore to reissues of disks by notable stars of the past, is now peeking into a variety of corners.

EVER since 1936, when Sir Francis Drake's "Plate of Brass" was rediscovered archaeologists have been hard at work just north of San Francisco trying to locate further proof of his visit. Nothing new has been unearthed yet to determine the exact landing site, but there is no doubt that Britain's most illustrious sea dog did put into one of California's shallow bays for a hull scraping.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (UP) -- Two hundred ninety-nine ships were in use for hauling United States military cargoes all over the world on Aug. 1, the National Federation of American Shipping reported today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- E. Roland Harriman, president of the American Red Cross, asked the American people today to contribute to a fund to care for thousands of suffering Greeks, left homeless by recent earthquakes in the Ionian Islands.

FREEDOM VILLAGE, Korea, Aug. 15 -- The men passing through here yesterday on their way from the prisoner exchange point at Panmunjom to Inchon, point of departure for the homes they left long ago, demonstrated once again the destructive inroads of communism.

TRENTON, Aug. 15 -- The New Jersey Legislature will convene here Monday to receive from Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll, for possible further consideration, all the bills he has vetoed since the Assembly and Senate adjourned sine die in June.

THE House Ways and Means Committee, delving into the problem of raising more taxes to meet the Federal deficit, listened last week to dozens of witnesses but few came up with any concrete ideas for raising new revenue.

NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 15 -- Inspirational speeches throughout the country today on the occasion of India's Independence Day may call forth some pride in the achievements since this country became free on Aug. 15, 1947, but the mood of the population at large has hardly been one of joy at any time in the six years of sovereignty.

LOS ANGELES -- The highlight of the technical division talks at the Photographic Society of America convention here was the Graflex Company's demonstration of the new black model of the Graphic 70, which uses 70mm double perforated film, and the announcement that the camera would be available sometime this year.

IN the elephant camp on the Irrawaddy the riders spoke of Majda Koom, the father of all elephants, in hushed voices. Word had come that the renegade had been seen in the hills with a herd of wild elephants. Only the boy Haji, who had known Majda from babyhood, was unafraid.

One can buy a mink coat or place a bet on a horse race at a lower Federal excise tax cost, percentagewise, than would be charged against a simple but often essential telephone call or an urgent telegram to an anxious relative.

MANCHESTER, Mass., Aug. 15 (AP) -- Shirley Fry of Akron, Ohio, shook off one personal tennis nemesis today and won the right to face another, Maureen Connolly of San Diego, Calif., in the final of the Essex Women's Tournament tomorrow.

CHICAGO, Aug. 15 (AP) -- Halfback Gib Dawson of Texas, who scored a touchdown and a field goal as his collegiate mates last night lost to the Detroit Lions, 24 -- 10, today was named the game's most valuable All-Star performer by sports writers.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (AP) -- The Army made public today the names of 209 more soldiers reported by the Communists to have died in Red prison camps. With today's list, the Defense Department has identified 587 of the 1,022 men said by the Communists to have died in captivity. There's a big contrast between a Truman and Eisenhower vacation. Mr. Truman always had a sizable staff along and pretty much followed his regular routine. At Key West he would sign papers at breakfast or on the beach. He did not go in for strenuous sports and was happy with a fairly static life with his staff intimately about him.

Audiences at the Berkshire Music Center were listening last week to an old eighteenth-century French opera called "Richard the Lion-Hearted" by Andre Gretry, one of fifty-odd operas by this composer, nearly all of which are long since forgotten.

ELM, beech, oak, honey locust, maple and apple -- these and other favorite trees will come in for a good deal of attention this week with the opening of the twenty-ninth annual National Shade Tree Conference tomorrow in Chicago. The meeting is to be held at the Hotel La Salle and will continue until Friday.

IT is the garden which reinforces the illusion of being on the Mediterranean. First there had been the glimpse far below of the handsomely thumb-shaped bay of San Pedro holding an intense, staring blue sea. Then, the road zigzagging as it scales the hills past white stucco walls which were burdened with brilliant hibiscus and bougainvillaea.

EDINBURGH, Scotland, Aug. 15 -- The international development of home economics as a vital force for world peace was placed before the Eighth International Congress of Home Economics here today as a priority task.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- Miss Cissy Cooray, one of two women Senators from Ceylon, will spend next week in a rural community near Binghamton, N. Y., studying this country's agricultural extension service, including the 4-H Clubs for youth.

Harvesting in the nation's castor bean fields will begin in about two weeks, and it is estimated that the crop will be large enough this year to produce well over 15,000,000 pounds of that old-fashioned and heartily detested childhood tummyache remedy, castor oil

If officials at the Bronx Zoo read nature's signs aright, the first baby platypus ever hatched outside Australia is currently spending a somewhat overprotected infancy there in a nest of eucalyptus leaves deep in an earth-bank tunnel. At the Central Park Zoo a new-born zebra has already eyed the passers-by.

DR. JACOB KWALWASSER'S remarks quoted in your column on musical training for adults have undoubtedy brought a deluge of correspondence to your desk from amateur chamber music players like myself. But how can we keep quiet in the face of such dogmatism?

LINCOLN, Ill., Aug. 15 -- The first and what is believed to be the only town named for Abraham Lincoln before he became President will start a week's celebration of its one-hundredth anniversary Aug. 29.

OF approximately 10,800 bills introduced during the first session of the Eighty-third Congress, forty-two contained suggestions for new postage stamps. From Jan. 3 until adjournment on Aug. 1, fourteen Senate and twenty-eight House measures were offered by thirty-two legislators.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Aug. 15 (AP) -- The largest field in its history -- 223 golfers from forty-five states and several foreign countries -- will compete in the eighth annual Jaycee golf tournament next week.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 15 -- Plans for the development of the San Francisco Bay area have been answered at a lively rate in the last fifteen or twenty years and millions of words have been written and spoken in defense or denunciation of each plan.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- Top military posts of the nation changed hands today as Admiral Arthur W. Radford became Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff and Gen. Matthews B. Ridgway took over as Army Chief of Staff. The transition was achieved in brief ceremonies spaced an hour apart at the Pentagon.

After battering the coast from North Carolina to southern New Jersey, the hurricane called Barbara continued its course out to sea early yesterday, missing Nantucket by some twenty miles and spending itself ultimately in the Atlantic wastes several hundred miles east of Cape Cod.

FRIENDSHIP, Me. -- Lobster fishing, the chief industry of this and similar villages scattered along the north-eastern seaboard, is not billed as a tourist attraction, but it is providing a growing number of visitors with unexpected pleasures.

I am in full agreement with you that it is never too late to try to learn music. As a retired engineer I took up the violin. I practically beat a hole in the rug trying to learn to count correctly. Many times I decided to quit but each time I realized that at my age (55) I must keep going -- now or never.

" I DON'T know why it hurts so much to be an outsider, but it does," says Kathy Barnum looking back over her perplexing, turbulent senior year at Central High. That was the year when she suddenly became an insider and discovered that being one of the Crowd sometimes presents problems worse than loneliness.

Perhaps I am still politically naive about my native country, for I feel nothing but indignation when reading of such patriotic endeavors as exemplified by "The Hall of Our History," described by Judge Learned Hand and illustrated by drawings in THE TIMES Magazine (Aug. 9).

IT was not the call of the wild which brought us to camping, but the more prosaic fact that we have more wanderlust than money. Except for our Boy Scout son, we had not slept out or cooked farther from our kitchen than our own suburban backyard since our own youth twenty-five years ago.
EAST PATERSON, N. J., Aug. 15 -- An agreement for a wage increase of 10 cents an hour for 3,000 employes of Allen B. Du Mont Laboratories, Inc., was announced here yesterday.

IT has been clear for some time that Randall Jarrell is one of the most gifted poets and critics of his generation. The present volume, his first collection of criticism, should do much to confirm and strengthen his reputation. In it he discusses inimitably such poets as Whitman, Frost, Wallace Stevens, John Crowe Ransom, Williams, Walter de la Mare, Robert Lowell and a good many others.

With the opening of its scholastic year in September, Vassar College will inaugurate a college teacher internship program. Aided by a grant of $36,500 from the Ford Foundation's Fund for the Advancement of Education, Vassar will permit prospective college teachers to complete their graduate studies at college while they are actively teaching.

By provision of law Federal income taxes, in general, must be assessed within three years after a return is filed. Under this statute no court proceeding can be started after the expiration of such period. This is known as the "general rule" under the statute of limitation (Section 275 (a) of the Internal Revenue Code) governing the assessment and collection of income taxes.
Looking very much like young men off for a vacation, 184 Marine Corps reservists left here yesterday for two weeks of maneuvers at Cherry Point, N. C.

DESIGNS for New Caledonia's promised series for the "Presence of France" centenary have been announced. On Sept. 24, 1853, the French Rear Admiral Febvrier-Despointes, commanding naval forces in Oceania, took "solemn possession" of New Caledonia and dependencies, and his portrait is on 13-francs green and blue.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (UP) -- The nation's top teen-age drivers said today that compulsory high school driving instruction was one of the best ways to cut down highway accidents, which killed or maimed 1,340,000 last year.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 15 -- A few years ago, Andrei Y. Vishinsky had some happy words to say to the United Nations about how the Soviet Union was using atomic energy to move mountians, to say nothing of cutting paths through forests. The official text of the Vishinsky speech, released in Moscow a couple of weeks later, toned things down considerably by putting the boast in the future tense.

Diplomatic reports from Moscow last week left little doubt that for the great bulk of the Soviet citizens the big news in Georgi M. Malenkov's speech before the Supreme Soviet was not his hint of a Soviet hydrogen bomb, but his forthright promise that a better standard of living was on their immediate horizon.

IN the center of Enterprise, Ala. (pop. 7,288), there is a fountain that bears the following inscription: "In profound appreciation of the boll weevil and what it has done as the herald of prosperity." By the same sort of reasoning a medal now might be awarded to DDT in appreciation of the part it has played in the development of efficient new miticides.
EVER since Columbia Records brought out its new "360" model record-player, purchasers have been wondering why the set included a plug-in socket but nothing, apparently, to go in the socket.
CHICAGO, Aug. 15 (AP) -- Joe Adcock's two-run homer in the fourth was all Southpaw Warren Spahn needed behind his five-hit pitching today as the Braves beat the Cubs 2 -- 0.

In the current distribution of world power, France has a crucial assignment. As a European power, she is the key to Western defense of the continent. As a Mediterranean power, she is responsible for strategic stretches of North Africa. As an Asian power, she holds in Indo-China the vital southeast corner of Asia.

LONDON, Aug., 15 -- The one thing the British Government is trying hardest to avoid in the confused situation that has arisen over Korea is a vote in the United Nations General Assembly that would range the United States and Britain on opposite sides.
The United States has been losing gold at an average rate of $138,625,000 a month since last Dec. 10.

NOWADAYS Henry Clay is remembered, if at all, as a man who tried very hard -- and often -- to become President, but never quite made it. In the inconclusive popular vote of 1824, Clay ran third, behind Jackson and Adams; he lost to Jackson in 1832, to Polk in 1844.

For the past three years, Dr. Arthur C. Guyton, University of Mississippi, and his associate, Jack Crowell, have been operating a 3-D apparatus called the "stereovector-cardiograph" to study the human heart in action. The electrocardiograph is an instrument long familiar to physicians, but three - dimensional vectorcardiograms are something new.

POLITICAL scientists tell us that the worth of a governmental system depends less on the occasional presence of chiefs of genius than on the continuing existence of an able, trained and responsible secondary leadership.
New Yorkers seeking respite from the 15-cent fare, which has now been in effect three weeks, are learning new ways to travel, are walking or are staying home.

SMITHTOWN, L. I., Aug. 15 -- Mr. and Mrs. A. H. Merkel's dun gelding, Why Daddy, scored 13 points to win the jumper championship during the thirty-eighth annual Smithtown horse show for the benefit of St. Charles Hospital on Glad Acres Farm today.
Gen. Omar N. Bradley, an expert on what the military needs, is about to take over the task of helping the research and development facilities of the armed forces get what they require.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 15 -- Consumers in the Third Federal Reserve District have been buying more in department stores this year than last. Throughout the district, monthly fluctuations in dollar sales have been more pronounced than a year ago, it was reported.

LITERATURE is the place to cry havoc, as the havoc itself must be reduced, the disorder made orderly, if the cry is to be heard. The Negro in America has known this for some time. To his old cry of havoc something new, recently, has been added.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 15 -- Senator William F. Knowland of California, the Senate majority leader, bluntly warned here today that he would take immediate steps to remove the United States from the United Nations if Communist China were admitted to membership.
SAN BERNARDINA, Calif., Aug. 15 (AP) -- The United States Forest Service is testing a mechanical Paul Bunyan that fells giant trees with a few twists of the wrist.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, called on the American Society of Newspaper Editors today to investigate one of his most severe critics, J. Russell Wiggins, vice president and managing editor of The Washington Post, for "deliberate abuse and prostitution of freedom of the press."

THE tennis season is upon us and the Briton continues to write verses. Our tennis champion is a splendid fellow; but he has the impossible monicker Victor Seixas. How do we pronounce it? We found the very verse in The Observer:

MOSCOW, Aug. 14 -- Clowns, and particularly funny clowns, have almost vanished from Soviet circuses, Izvestia declared today and demanded that immediate steps be taken to train new ones and provide "gay, lively jokes for them."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- Senator Styles Bridges, chairman of the Senate Appropriations Committee, reported today that the Eisenhower Administration and Congress, working as a new Republican "team," had made "unprecedented" economies and paved the way for a balanced budget.

Philip R. Mallory, president of the Marine Historical Association, was renamed to his office for a twelfth term on Friday at the organization's annual meeting at Mystic, Conn. It was the twenty- fourth annual meeting of the group at its home site, known as Mystic Seaport, a maritime museum center.

In one of the most ambitious educational television projects yet conceived, thirty-one universities, colleges, technical institutes and medical schools of the nation are cooperating to present a series of programs intended to acquaint the general public with their most interesting aspects. The tentative date for the first of the half-hour Sunday afternoon showings is Oct. 18.

MOSCOW, Sunday, Aug. 16 -- In a message to Premier Georgi M. Malenkov, North Korea today thanked the Soviet Union for its billion ruble contribution to Korean rehabilitation and said this aid strengthened its confidence that it would achieve unity and independence.

LOS ANGELES -- An exceptionally well-planned and presented demonstration and talk on color values by Fred Bond, photographer and author, was one of the most instructive in a series of practical color programs at the Photographic Society of America's convention here recently.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- The 1954 Congressional campaign got under way in earnest this week, although the day of decision is still nearly fifteen months away.

THE value of helicopters as a vital form of transportation was stressed last week by Lord Douglas of Kirtleside, famous R. A. F. fighter commander and chairman of British European Airways, who said that rotary-winged planes will eventually be the fastest method of travel between cities within 250 miles of each other.

WHEN Obie Shane and his parents settled in deserted prairie country, they had a sod house, a pen of pigs, a crate of chickens, a cow, a horse, a Winchester rifle, and a little household equipment. The stove had been left in Ohio. It was too heavy to take in the Conestoga wagon.

BUFFALO, Aug. 15 -- In a preview today to tomorrow's national championships in two important speed boat racing divisions drivers from many states and from Canadian provinces converged on the Niagara River downstream from here off Grand Island for one of the inboard race meets made famous by the venerable Buffalo Launch Club.
Cut off the leg of a salamander and it will grow a new one. A lobster will do as much when he has lost a claw. The new leg or claw is composed of tissue exactly like that of the old.

Counsel for the Seafarers International Union, A. F. L., and the Valentine Chemical Corporation have reached an accord in a dispute involving the manning of the tanker Val Chem, and injunctive proceedings started on Aug. 4 will be dropped tomorrow morning, it was learned yesterday. No details of the settlement were available.

ROCQUENCOURT, France, Aug. 15 -- An obvious change has come over Gen. Alfred M. Gruenther, the man who "created" the Supreme Allied Headquarters here as chief of staff to General Eisenhower and Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway during the last two years and who took over as Supreme Allied Commander himself a month ago.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 15 -- The Yankees clouted three home runs today, but it still wasn't their day. In fact, the Bombers just about turned it into a nightmare for Casey Stengel by blowing the opener of their five-game series with the supposedly docile Athletics, 9 to 8, to the delight of 7,502 onlookers.

The Dodgers extended their winning streak to seven games yesterday by crushing the Pirates, 14 -- 6, with a fifteen-hit attack that included four home runs. Meanwhile, the Giants snapped a six-game losing string as Marv Grissom subdued the Phillies, 4 -- 1, in the opener of a double-header.
Jewelry valued at $44,000 was stolen from the ten-room apartment of Joseph R. Vogel, a movie executive, at 888 Park Avenue near Seventy-ninth Street, the police revealed last night.

A MILD little parable, "The Train in the Meadow" is turned with a practiced hand. The symbolic train of the title, bound for an inevitable symbolic country behind distant blue horizon peaks, has stopped for the length of the narrative in a wide, flat mountain valley, an in-between place, gray-green in color, indeterminate of season, lucid of atmosphere, and flowerless.

NO country in the world has so many foreigners write novels about it as does Mexico. Perhaps this is because the initial impact is so violent that most artists either run away -- or, staying, try prematurely to express what they feel. When Josephus Daniels was United States Ambassador there, he was visited by a young journalist who wanted to write about Mexico.

IN this novel, Patricia McGerr poses a problem few feminine readers could resist. Ellen Clement's husband, Ned, who deserted her twelve years before, suddenly returns home. Still handsome, assured and jaunty, he expects Ellen and their two children to welcome him back.
FAIRFIELD, Calif., Aug. 15 (AP) -- Nine more United States prisoners of war -- all showing evidences of their long confinement in Red prison camps -- were flown home from Korea today.

LETHBRIDGE, Alta., Aug. 5 -- The present situation of the American Indian, both in the United States and in Canada, is one of violent contrasts. The range between poverty and well-being is greater, perhaps, than in the case of any other minority group.
DAYTON, Ohio, Aug. 15 (AP) -- Jack S. King of Greensboro, N. C., broke 98 of 100 targets at a distance of 21 yards to win the handicap event today at the Grand American trapshot at near-by Vandalia.

THIS is the quietest time of the musical year. Most of the summer events are drawing to a close and the winter season will not be starting for another month or so. In New York the new season will be later than usual in getting under way.

If Michael Walsh and Raymond D. White had not tried to steal a ham in Utica, N. Y., in what was to prove the worst possible way, they probably would not be under arrest in Brooklyn, charged with having held up a jewelry manufacturer.
When an organization is described as the General Motors, the J. P. Morgan or the A. P. of its field, one may well ask:

THE visitor in the province of Harry S. Truman is impressed by nothing so much as the ease with which the former President has slipped back into his old environment. He has slipped back to the soil that nurtured him -- which is not to say that he has slipped.

A FORMER Scotland Yard superintendent, in "Fabian of the Yard," tells his story simply and with commendable restraint. The book could be a model for any ex-cop's autobiography. Robert Fabian covers thirty-one cases from his own records, each with briskness and brevity, though without skimping.

BONN, Aug. 15 -- The pattern of current Soviet policy has been considerably clarified during the past week. Both Premier Malenkov's historic speech and specific actions within the U. S. S. R.'s orbit have indicated what is to be the current tactic in the long-range zigzag of Communist strategy. It is not dissimilar from Stalin's latter-day maneuvers.
LONDON, Aug. 15 (Reuters) -- Alec Bedser and Freddie Trueman led England's attack which dismissed Australia for 275 in five and a quarter hours in the first day of the final test cricket match today.

SPARTA, N. J., Aug. 15 -- Barbara Clevely of Irvington, the 1952 American Horse Show Association saddle seat champion, captured the National Horse Show qualifying event and Good Hands horsemanship contest at the Lake Mohawk horse show today.

KARACHI, Aug. 15 -- This week's developments in Kashmir, the strategic northern state claimed by both India and Pakistan, have driven a new wedge between these two countries. Especially disappointing to the interests of this area was the fact that this happened at a time when the outlook was considered more favorable than ever before for a solution of the five-year-old dispute that at one time involved the two Asian nations in an undeclared war.

Elpidio Quirino, President of the Philippines, left the hospital at Johns Hopkins yesterday and is starting on a leisurely return to the most bitter political campaign of his life. He is seeking re-election as a vindication of his administration, which is under heavy fire from two strong opponents.

Jacob Potofsky, president of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America, C. I. O., returned from Europe yesterday and expressed hope that organic unity would be achieved by the Congress of Industrial Organizations and the American Federation of Labor within two years.

BEACH HAVEN, N. J., Aug. 15 -- It's true about the white marlin. This fighting "bill fish" is providing excellent sport for anglers working out of this community on Little Egg Harbor Bay. They are being taken on whole-squid-baited troll lines in the Atlantic Ocean about twenty miles south of here.

THE third novel by Berry Fleming since the publication of "Colonel Effingham's Raid" is a kaleidoscopic excursion into the world of the carnival. It is, however, a carnival on a cosmic scale, a symbol of man's individual search for self-meaning, directed and energized in terms of the midway.

OF all the delusions that influence human affairs, the most persistent, if not the most prevalent, is the notion that roulette wheels, dice and cards have memories -- i. e., that because a certain number comes up on one roll or turn, it is either more or less likely to come up the next time.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., Aug. 15 -- Four former United States prisoners of war, suffering from tuberculosis, were flown to Mitchel Field Air Force Base near here today on the last stage of their journey from Korea to St. Albans Naval Hospital in Queens.

BISMARCK, Germany's Iron Chancellor, called his autobiography "Thoughts and Memories." The recollections of one of his successors, Hohenlohe-Schillingsfuerst, are simply "Memoirs." Even Chancellor von Buelow, whose three-volume' autobiography mistakes charm for history, was content with writing "Memoirs."

Dr. George B. Galloway in his comprehensive article, "To Break the Congress Log-Jam" (July 26), ends on the sad but challenging thought that the Congress will make no basic changes in its ways unless we can develop a sustained campaign for reorganization of its methods.

WESTON, Conn., Aug. 15 -- Residents along the Saugatuck River are girding for battle, if necessary, with an old enemy, the Bridgeport Hydraulic Company, whose contract for control over the river's waters expires in six weeks, on Oct. 1.

DEL MAR, Calif., Aug. 15 (AP) -- Goose Khal scored an upset today to win the $10,000 San Diego Handicap at Del Mar. The 1-5 favorite, Royal Serenade, Hollywood Gold Cup winner, finished out of the money.

THE 1953 Gold Medal in the annual Concours International de Roses a Bagatelle in Paris, France, has been awarded to a new American rose, Mojave. Since this fine hybrid tea is also an All-America Selection for 1954, it now holds two of the highest honors a rose can achieve.

THE most delightful thing about reading a book of recollections is getting to know the person who is doing the recollecting. When this person also has total recall about at least fifteen other engaging persons, the whole book becomes at least fifteen times as delightful.

The urgency that was midsummer now begins to relax, and September comes in sight over the land. You see it in the trees, you see it at the road-sides where the uncut weeds begin to reach maturity, and you see it in the fields and pastures. Oat fields are stubble now, the golden grain harvested.

LOMPOC, Calif. -- At this time of year, tourists who are in too much of a hurry to make the drive between Los Angeles and San Francisco are likely to miss one of the West Coast's most colorful sights. This is the blossoming of hundreds of acres of flowers on the commercial seed farms here at Lompoc (pronounced Lom-poke) and at Santa Barbara and Guadalupe, another twenty miles or so to the north.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 15 -- It was expected that Native Dancer would have a romp in the eighty-fourth running of the Travers Stake for 3-year-olds at the Saratoga Association's horse park today. A romp it was.

MANY of the plants that grandmother used to grow are still great favorites today. One of these is oxalis, often seen in hanging baskets on a porch or as a pot plant. The reasons for its continuing popularity are not far to seek: oxalis is fairly easy to grow, new flowers appear daily and the fascinating foliage, which is cloverlike, folds up at night to reopen in the morning.

The United Nations began moving last week toward an attempt to settle the deep seated issues behind the Korean war -- issues that were brought to the forefront by the truce signed three weeks ago. The attempt will reach its climax at the political conference scheduled to convene ninety days after the signing of the armistice.
A soft-spoken Yonkers ship's chandler, who has been waging an unbending private war of propaganda against communism since 1950, is appealing to West Germans to join him in a new attack.

In deserts and villages of the Middle East, more than 70,000 Arab children are receiving the benefits of a first-class education under the guidance and sponsorship of two United Nations agencies. Most of these children are of refugee families which even in normal times could not have provided the youngsters with anything resembling the type of modern training they now receive.

DENVER, Aug. 15 -- President Eisenhower approved today a bill ending the jurisdiction of Federal courts over criminal cases involving Indians in five states. Jurisdiction was conferred on the state courts of California, Minnesota, Nebraska, Oregon and Wisconsin.

PRINCETON, N. J., Aug. 15 -- One of the fiercest political battles in this area in recent years is nearing a showdown as the voters of Montgomery and Hillsborough Townships prepare to go to the polls to determine whether to replace the present committee form of government with a council-manager system.

MAYS LANDING, N. J., Aug. 15 -- Atalanta, the 5-year-old daughter of Count Fleet purchased by the Darby Dan Farm from Brook-meade last year, again proved that seven furlongs is to her liking by winning the $18,100 Mermaid Handicap today.

I enjoyed reading Charles Poore's "Close-Up of Casanova'' (July 26) very much. The statement that the four portraits which you displayed (ostensibly of Casanova) differ very much is understandable, since the third portrait is not that of the adventurer Giacomo but of his brother Giovanni Casanova, director of the Dresden Art Gallery.

The bad weather of Friday had an adverse effect on department store volume and as a result store controllers estimated that the week would show a decline of 4 or 5 per cent from the 1952 week. That week, in turn, was off about 6 per cent from 1951.
Q. -- What is the difference between an A-bomb and an H-bomb?

A major study of this country's foreign economic policies, expected to have strong influence on future decisions of the Eisenhower Administration in this field, is scheduled to develop during the next six months.

IN Moscow's Trade Union House in the Okhotny ryad there is a hall of lofty Ionic columns, quarried from white and rose-veined Polish marble, an elegant hall with crystal chandeliers hanging over balconied loges. Once the meeting place of the Russian nobility, this Hall of Columns has for the past thirty years been the stage of the Soviet Union's most famous "show trials."

I WAS talking the other day to Henry Wiggen, the pitcher whose doings I recently helped to get into book form, and I told him what happened to a baseball which he and several other Mammoths had signed. I, with the air of a man conferring an everlasting honor, had given this ball to a neighbor boy.

THE news of the Bayreuth Festival this summer is still Wieland Wagner's "Ring;" this despite a new production of "Lohengrin" by his brother Wolfgang and a conductor crisis which has seen the departure of both Hans Knappertsbusch and Herbert von Karajan, the mainstays of the first two years of the post-war festivals.

THE departmental scholar, assiduously scrutinizing the schedule for the impending Broadway season, came up last week with the lugubrious news that for a second year in a row there is going to be a dearth of new musical productions between now and the New Year.

GARDENERS who buy nursery stock can be relatively certain that the plants they purchase will be free of serious diseases and insect pests. For this assurance, credit goes to the state experiment stations which make annual inspections of nurseries in their area.
BAGSVAERD, Denmark, Aug. 15 (AP) -- The Russians used their 165-pound coach to steer their eight-oar shell in the Helsinki Olympics but they have smartened up since then.

THE catalogue of recordings of Bach's cantatas continues to expand. And the companies are not merely reproducing a few of the most famous. Of six cantatas freshly engraved, for instance, four are works that have not been previously recorded -- at least, not on long-playing disks.

NEW DELHI, India. Aug. 15 -- The volume of India's foreign trade registered a sharp fall during the fiscal year ending March, 1953, according to an annual review of the nation's foreign trade published today by the Ministry of Commerce and Industry.

Since the supply of cotton from domestic sources this season is estimated to be just another 20,000,000 bales, the amount of the staple likely to be impounded in the Government loan may exceed 4,000,000 bales. This would be almost twice the 2,297,500 bales from the 1952 crop of which 500,000 were repossessed before the end of the season.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Aug. 3 -- The water department of the city of Tel Aviv is running a race against the contamination by subterranean infiltration of seawater of the forty-five wells from which the city derives its water supply.

The United Nations General Assembly will go into session tomorrow to make up the Korean question. This is special session called as the result of the armistice agreement and it will receive the formal notice of that agreement negotiated on its behalf by the United Nations Command in Korea.

MILWAUKEE, Aug. 15 -- Nicholas Rossolimo of Paris continued his bid for the open championship of the United States Chess Federation in today's fifth round of the fifty-fourth annual tournament when he defeated Eugene E. Warner of Seattle, who had been tied for first place with him, in a Queen's Indian defense lasting thirty-five moves.

A VISIT to the United States these days is becoming as imperative for the serious interior designer from abroad as was a period of study in Germany or France in the Twenties or a trip to Sweden in the Thirties. Several dozen designers have come within the past year to study our methods, absorb our attitudes and appraise our products.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Aug. 15 -- Prime Ministers Nehru and Mohammed Ali will meet in New Delhi tomorrow with a heavier task than they faced at their Karachi conference late in July. For this time an immense body of opinion in Pakistan, including some important Cabinet ministers, is convinced of the inevitability of war unless the Kashmir issue is settled to mutual satisfaction.

LENOX, Mass., Aug., 15 -- The Berkshire Music Center, which has been providing an intensive workshop in music each summer since 1940, ended its annual six-week session today. Although the center is not a formal school and grants no diplomas, the final concert this afternoon by the student orchestra served as a kind of commencement exercise.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- The Library of Congress will close its New York office at the New York Public Library at the end of August. A purpose of the office was to improve the Library of Congress catalogue card service by encouraging publishers to send advance copies of their books to the library for consideration by the United States Quarterly Book Review and for prompt cataloguing. Five hundred publishers are cooperating in the program.

CHICAGO, Aug. 15 -- The National Collegiate Athletic Association's powerful council was concerned with track records and football television today while speculation sizzled over the fate of three colleges expected to be penalized for athletic code violations.
OKRA may not have the picturesqueness of magnolia blossoms, the social standing of a Kentucky colonel or the allure of a mint julep, but it is nevertheless as typically Southern as any of these.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- Washington has been slowing up a bit since Congress recessed twelve days ago.

ABOUT summer reading people used to say something very much like what they said about opera versus the spoken word -- what is too silly for cold weather is just right for hot. But times have changed and a glance at the best-seller list will bear me out.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (UP) -- Max Conrad will leave here Monday for the first air tour of the forty-eight state capitals since Charles Lindbergh and his wife paid their respects to the nation's governors in 1929.
The new Swedish American liner Kungsholm has completed an unofficial test run in the North Sea to the satisfaction of her owners.

THE decadence and bankruptcy of the human spirit seem to be the main theme of most of our literary practitioners today. And with devious and sometimes lyrical prose they celebrate in wanton chorus the degradation of man and the certainty of his senseless doom upon a lost and wandering planet.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 15 -- Attorney General Herbert Brownell Jr., after a two-day tour of the Southern California-Mexico border area, declared today that the influx of illegal immigrants from Mexico presented "a serious and thoroughly unsatisfactory situation."

The best way to find out if music is an expression for you is to try. No one need aim at becoming a member of the Philharmonic, nor should a person interested in music be made embarrassed at studying because he has been told he is not musically inclined.

There are nearly as many different kinds of crude oil as there are oil fields. Some of these crudes are so liquid that they can be poured, splashed and drained into puddles like water. But others are as heavy and thick as molasses, grease or butter. Because of their stickiness, they cling to the oil-sand grains that hold them, and because of this they cannot be moved easily through underground formations into oil wells.
Bob Mathias, two-time Olympic decathlon champion and Stanford fullback, says he is giving up college football "because it is no longer a sport." The Associated Press reported.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (AP) -- Who were the two great French generals who helped win the Revolutionary War?

PARIS, Aug. 15 -- Sidi Moulay Mohammed Ben Arafa, uncle of the reigning Sultan, Sidi Mohammed Ben Youseff, was proclaimed today to be the supreme religious chief of Islam in Morocco, but no steps were taken to deprive the Sultan of his governmental or dynastic power.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Aug. 15 -- Actual collision between nuclear particles is not necessary for a nuclear reaction, laboratory research at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology has shown.

SUMMER phlox is one of the easiest of all hardy perennials to grow. It will thrive in any good garden soil in a well-drained, sunny or half-shaded location. This year, however, some gardeners have reported attacks on this phlox (P. decussata) by the few insect pests and diseases that ever trouble it.

BOSTON, Aug. 15 (AP) -- The Red Sox succeeded only in snapping Pitcher Bob Porterfield's string of twenty-nine scoreless innings today while losing a double-header to the Senators by 5-2 and 4-2 margins. Chuck Stobbs, Boston bonus discard, beat Bill Henry in the first game.

BERLIN, Aug. 15 -- Herbert Warneke head of East Germany's Labor Federation, in a speech published today called for a purge to weed out the anti-Communist underground that, he said, existed in several key East German unions.

BENNINGTON, Vt., Aug. 15 -- One hundred and seventy-six years ago tomorrow a detachment of New Hampshire militia under Gen. John Stark straggled through this town on the way to fight the British across the line in New York, but Vermont alone observes the anniversary as Bennington Battle Day.

IT rather looks, in a manner of speaking, as if Hollywood of the West had beaten us of the East to the draw. The Los Angeles Symphony Orchestra invited Sir William Walton, a foremost figure in modern English composition, to make his first American appearance as conductor of his own works at the concert scheduled for last Thursday night in the Hollywood Bowl.

CHORE FOR THE WEEK: Finish pruning spring-flowering, deciduous shrubs so that as few as possible of the buds forming for next year's bloom will be removed. Cut off at ground level thick, old canes and reduce this year's extra-long growth of young stems by as much as one-third their length. Trim off neatly long, rangy stems on evergreen shrubs.

HONG KONG, Aug. 15 -- Communist China has promised North Korea "active support and assistance" in repairing its war damage, restoring its battered economy and upholding what Premier Chou Enlai terms its "fight for the cause of peace, unity and independence."

HEWLETT HARBOR, L. I., Aug. 15 -- The medal-winning team of W. Russell Howe and John J. Humm of Rockville led the way into the semi-final round of the nineteenth annual Arthur Mann memorial member-guest golf tournament at the Seawane Harbor Club today.

THE dust cover of this book shows a man riding on a roan horse with all its four feet off the ground. The man is looking back as though he were being followed, perhaps by a band of Apaches. But that is not the kind of story this is.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- A farmer or a resort owner may some day be able to look at a chart and accurately determine certain general weather trends that will tell him years in advance about when there will be rain and about when there will be drought.

FORT WAYNE, Ind., Aug. 15 -- Jackie Burke Jr. of Kiamesha Lake, N. Y., fashioned an eight-under-par 64 today to jump in front of a closely-packed field at the end of fifty-four holes in the $15,000 Fort Wayne open golf tournament.

IN these days of deep moaning that baseball isn't what it used to be, that the day of the .400 hitter is gone forever and that there'll never be another thirty-game winning pitcher, it is refreshing, indeed, to see husky, young Robin Roberts demonstrate that if a ball player has what it takes the game still offers him ample opportunity for exploiting his talents.

The leasing of automobiles, trucks and station wagons for industrial purposes has become one of the fastest-growing businesses in the United States. And it is even possible now for corporations to lease airplanes.

" WHAT would you do if you were a small black cat named Jasper and you woke up one morning to find your tail twice as long as it should be?" That is the question posed, and the solution takes on a "Chicken Little" tone as Jasper moves from the Scotch terrier, to the rooster to the pig to the magpie to the rat for a solution.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- Competent labor sources here view the stated reason for the United Brotherhood of Carpenters' withdrawal from the American Federation of Labor this week as not the real or exclusive reason, but as a substantial rationalization.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- President Eisenhower was invited today by Senator Herbert H. Lehman, Democrat of New York, to support as part of the Administration's program the omnibus immigration bill that he and seven other Senators and twenty-four members of the House of Representatives introduced early this month.

CHICAGO, Aug. 15 -- Stan, an English-bred racer owned by Hasty House Farm and ridden by Johnny Adams, went ahead in the last eighth of a mile to win the $28,375 Grassland Handicap in a Washington Park stakes double-header today.

UP Shakespeare! To judge by bulletins from several places this summer, Shakespeare is fascinating more people than any other dramatist. Starting from nothing more substantial than a romantic idea, the Stratford, Ontario, festival of "Richard III" and "All's Well That Ends Well" has been fabulously successful.
MUNSAN, Korea, Sunday, Aug. 16 (AP) -- The United Nations Command's official list of United States prisoners of war freed in today's armistice exchange:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- Competent labor sources here view the stated reason for the United Brotherhood of Carpenters' withdrawal from the American Federation of Labor this week as not the real or exclusive reason, but as a substantial rationalization.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- President Eisenhower was invited today by Senator Herbert H. Lehman, Democrat of New York, to support as part of the Administration's program the omnibus immigration bill that he and seven other Senators and twenty-four members of the House of Representatives introduced early this month.

THIS is the week of the annual American Dance Festival, sponsored by the Connecticut College School of the Dance, at New London. Though eleven new works were originally announced, one of these has fallen by the wayside, which is a remarkably small percentage for a summer festival.

SHORTLY before her death in 1946 Gertrude Stein gave and bequeathed her papers to the Yale University Library. She was a hoarder of the written word and, besides her manuscripts, there are more than 20,000 letters in the collection, including notes from her concierge, who wrote in bad French spelled phonetically, and messages from many of the most distinguished writers and painters in Paris, London and New York.
NEWPORT, R. I., Aug 15 -- A new type of senior high school with eight separate buildings will be erected here in the spring at a cost of $2,200,000.
BUCHAREST, Rumania, Aug. 15 -- We entered Bucharest by way of Baneasa, the royal station built specially for King Carol.

THIS is the week of the annual American Dance Festival, sponsored by the Connecticut College School of the Dance, at New London. Though eleven new works were originally announced, one of these has fallen by the wayside, which is a remarkably small percentage for a summer festival.

SHORTLY before her death in 1946 Gertrude Stein gave and bequeathed her papers to the Yale University Library. She was a hoarder of the written word and, besides her manuscripts, there are more than 20,000 letters in the collection, including notes from her concierge, who wrote in bad French spelled phonetically, and messages from many of the most distinguished writers and painters in Paris, London and New York.
NEWPORT, R. I., Aug 15 -- A new type of senior high school with eight separate buildings will be erected here in the spring at a cost of $2,200,000.
BUCHAREST, Rumania, Aug. 15 -- We entered Bucharest by way of Baneasa, the royal station built specially for King Carol.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (AP) -- The Defense Department identified today 185 additional Korean war casualties. A new list covering combat prior to the armistice included twenty-nine killed, 130 wounded, twenty two missing in action and four injured. The following names were from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut:

THERE will be no shortage of family life among teleevision programs making their debuts this fall. Apparently producers agree that the hot property today is the show that features husbands and wives or some aspect of family existence.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Aug. 15 -- Leaders of South Africa's Cape Colored (persons of mixed ancestry) have warned Prime Minister Daniel F. Malan that his moves to "filch" their franchise rights from them will "create a situation that will disturb the peace of the land."

DIRECTOR Henry Koster's frank enthusiasm for CinemaScope, which will be officially launched here with the premiere of "The Robe" next month at the Roxy, was highly evident during his brief stop-over last week en route to Europe on a business-vacation trip.

DETROIT, Aug. 15 -- Al Aber, Tigers' southpaw, gave up only one hit in four and two-thirds innings of sparkling relief pitching to save a 5-4 victory over the White Sox and prevent them from gaining ground on the Yankees.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (AP) -- The Defense Department released today the names of thirty-three additional soldiers from the list of 147 reported by the Communists as having escaped from prison camps. It emphasized that in no case had the Communist reports been verified. The names follow:

CHIHUAHUA, Mexico, Aug. 15 -- Action by the Mexican Government is expected to bring to an end fifty years of ownership by the Hearst family of more than one million acres of fertile ranchland in Northern Mexico.

ROME, Aug. 15 -- The Christian Democratic Premier designate, Giuseppe Pella, announced a new Cabinet today, only two days after he had accepted the task of trying to solve the Italian Cabinet crisis. The new Cabinet, composed entirely of Christian Democrats, will seek the confidence of Parliament next week.

ONLY an author with a down-deep love and knowledge of canaries could create a personality as alive as Din Din, Lucinda's pet. In "Canary Yellow," Helen Lorraine Hultz intertwines the day-to-day existence of a rather ordinary little girl with the antics and out-of-cage adventures of a rather extra-ordinary little bird, whose addition to the family rates more attention than a new baby.

TOKYO, Sunday, Aug. 16 -- Communist prisoners rioted on their road home through the exchange point at Panmunjom and Communist armistice officials angrily protested yesterday against the United Nations Command's handling of the truce agreement in the Korean war.

ABOARD THE U. S. S. SALEM, Argostolion, Greece, Aug. 15 -- Helicopters and amphibious planes of the United States Sixth Fleet and the United States Air Force began today a dawn-to-dusk airlift, transporting to hospital centers scores of severely injured persons on the three Greek Ionian islands of Cephalonia, Zante and Ithaca.

Fall business has begun early and stores are already filling in stocks, according to the report last week by the McGreevey, Werring Howell Company, resident buyers. The company also noted that current activity in the sportswear market indicated record volume for the fall.

One or more of the vessels involved in the Moore-McCormack Lines dock strike that ended with company capitulation on Friday may be withdrawn from the seas under a replacement program now being considered.

FORT PECK, Mont., Aug. 15 -- Army Engineers seeking to control the Missouri River along its upper reaches were close to their goal this week as construction work on four large "main-stem" dams neared its seasonal peak.

The problem of the unification of Germany raises a number of related issues which sooner or later will call for solution. All these issues are related not in the sense that they reflect the needs or aspirations of Western Powers but the aspirations of German nationalism.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Aug. 8 -- Acting on a confidential up several nights ago, the Istanbul police swooped down upon a tiny, smoke-filled backroom in suburban Buyukdere. There they arrested the tenant, a night watchman, and eight men accused of using hashish, a common Eastern narcotic drug derived from hemp. Later that night the police apprehended three persons charged with trafficking in heroin.
