PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Aug. 15 -- B. Glenn MacNary's Annie captured the laurels in the International Class in the Knickerbocker Yacht Club's regatta on Long Island Sound today. A fleet of ninety-six craft raced in winds that hit twelve miles at the start and increased to more than twenty at the finish.

When the neutron was discovered in 1932 it became necessary to reconstruct the nucleus of the atom in the mind's eye of the mathematical physicist, a task performed by Werner Heisenberg. The planetary electrons revolved around the nucleus, the atomic sun, as before and also leaped from orbit to orbit in an unplanetary way, but the nucleus was regarded as a mass of neutrons and protons of uniform density.

Georgi Malenkov's claim eight days ago that Russia had mastered the secret of the hydrogen bomb startled the world. True or not, the claim indicated that Russia could take a strong stand; that Malenkov, at the very least, was the chief Soviet spokesman.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 15 -- American foreign policy, as revised by the Eisenhower Administration since it took office some seven months ago, will meet its first major test next week when the General Assembly of the United Nations reconvenes to call the Far Eastern political conference that is provided for under the Korean armistice.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- A large section of the country's civil aviation contingent is disturbed over the curtailment of air services and safety facilities dictated by Federal budget economy.

BONN, Germany, Aug. 15 -- West German concerns signed today an agreement in Bonn with representatives of the Indian Government to participate in the construction of a $150,000,000 steel mill in India.

Premier Malenkov's hint that the Soviet Union can manufacture a hydrogen bomb pointed up again the importance of a maximally effective United States intelligence service. Much policy -- and perhaps the survival of the nation -- depends upon correct evaluation of Soviet strength and intentions, one particular facet of which is the hydrogen bomb claim.

MANCHESTER, England, Aug. 15 (AP) -- Two speeding commuter trains collided head-on today on a bridge, killing ten persons, injuring fifty-eight and tossing one smashed coach eighty feet into the shallow Irk River.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- Five leading Protestant churchmen, speaking for the American Christian Palestine Committee, have taken issue with the Secretary of State, John Foster Dulles, in his views against removing the Israeli Foreign Ministry from Tel Aviv to Jerusalem.

ANEW and urgent chapter in an old debate over our defense policy -- Europe first or Asia first? -- has opened with the armistice in Korea. Which continent should receive priority in arms and equipment, money and effort?
SIMCO, Ont., Aug. 15 (AP) -- Dreams of an iron ore industry for Ontario's Norfolk County on Lake Erie have vanished -- at least for the present.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 15 -- Thousands of coal miners are idle and many operators have expressed fears that they will have to shut down additional mines because of decreased sales, but bituminous coal shipments from Lake Erie ports to the head of the lakes exhibit no sign of slumping.

There is little evidence that women have taken an active role in the prevention of war, the Rev. Dr. Homer A. Jack declared yesterday morning at the Community Church of New York, 40 West Thirty-fifth Street.

The deal, first made known in April, to film "Oklahoma!" in the new Todd-AO, 65 mm. wide-screen process, was settled Friday in Buffalo after tests made by Arthur Hornblow Jr., who will produce the picture for Richard Rodgers and Oscar Hammerstein 2d, Fred Zinnemann, who will direct and Harry Stradling, who will serve as cinematographer, the principals announced yesterday.

The Police Department has started a full-scale campaign to stop taxicab drivers from fleecing passengers by taking indirect routes or overcharging. In the last week three cabbies have lost their hack licenses, and six have been suspended for thirty days. Eleven others are awaiting trial before the Hack Bureau.

DETROIT, Aug. 16 (AP) -- Ralph Branca choked off a ninth-inning rally today as the Tigers defeated the penant-conscious White Sox, 3 -- 2. Branca hurled a four-hitter in winning his third American League game against two setbacks.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 (AP) -- A complaint has been made by a processor group that Government price supports offer farmers a "temptation and opportunity" to speculate in food crops with public funds.

ALBANY, N. Y., Aug. 16 (AP) -- Heavy rains prevalent in all central and western sections of the state last week were generally beneficial and were especially needed in the Rochester area for tomatoes, peaches and potatoes, which should now size up well.

LEOPOLDVILLE, Belgian Congo, Aug. 16 -- The white minority -- all important in Africa south of the Congo -- is engaged in a campaign here to assure itself legally a guarantee of the right to reside permanently in this Belgian colony.

The right of Congressional committees to investigate alleged subversive activities by clergymen was upheld in principle yesterday by the Rev. Dr. George H. Talbott in a sermon at the West-Park Presbyterian Church, Amsterdam Avenue and Eighty-sixth Street.

BUFFALO, Aug. 16 -- Two national speed boat championships, always grueling tests of men, engines, hulls, water, weather conditions and usually needing a fair supply of luck, changed hands this blowy afternoon on the Niagara River in the golden anniversary regatta of the Buffalo Launch Club.

Officials at Croton-on-Hudson, in Westchestcr County, may not be choosing the best way to make friends and influence people at Albany by putting up signs blaming the state for inadequacies of the Albany Post Road. But they are, in a limited way, publicizing a highway problem that deserves some state attention.

A plea for "a complete dedication and commitment" to the Christian way of life and for the courage to defend freedom of thought was voiced yesterday morning by the Rev. Dr. Ray Freeman Jenney of the Bryn Mawr Community Church, Chicago, Ill., in a sermon at the Marble Collegiate Reformed Church, Fifth Avenue and Twenty-ninth Street.

The reappointment of city magistrates should not be the responsibility of the Mayor but of some such group as the Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court, Chief Magistrate John M. Murtagh declared yesterday.

When adults get together to talk over the behavior of teen-agers today, those with children are likely to take one point of view and those without, another. A survey of the opinions of these two groups indicates, however, that parents and non-parents are not too far apart in their opinions, though they do differ slightly on significant points.

Victor Andrade, Ambassador from Bolivia, announced recently that an agreement between the Bolivian Government and Patino Enterprises provided for "full compensation" for American stockholders in the nationalized mines of his country.

President Eisenhower's No. 1 objective on the economic front, as he himself told Congress in his first State of the Union Message, is to straighten out the problem of the budget. The task is a monumental one, and the President would be less than human if there were not moments when he felt a twinge of envy for those who, for want of a more precise designation, may be called the Over simplificationists.
SUFFERN, N. Y., Aug. 16 -- The last of Rockland County's historic roadside inns, Eureka House, will close tomorrow, giving way to the Thruway between New York and Buffalo, which will cross its site.

The session of the General Assembly of the United Nations that opens today can be fateful in the fullest sense. The direction that this meeting takes may well determine if we shall lose, in the truce, that for which we fought on the battlefield. The United Nations put its stamp of condemnation on the aggression and undertook to meet it by force.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -- Two Army colonels, essaying the role of pathfinders in the tactics of atomic warfare, propose to revise Gen. Nathan Bedford Forrest's classic doctrine: "Git thar fustest with the mostest."

BONN, Germany, Aug. 16 -- Dr. Werner Naumann, former State Secretary in the Nazi Propaganda Ministry, is resorting to Hitler's beer-hall technique of the early Nineteen Twenties in his campaign for election to the Bundestag Sept. 6.

The Muscular Dystrophy Associations of America, Inc., 39 Broadway, has expanded the research program in the disease at New York Hospital and has made grants for research to three other institutions, William Mazer, national president, announced yesterday.

Some 300 visitors were barred last night from Long Island College Hospital in downtown Brooklyn as a control measure against further spread of a streptococcal throat infection epidemic that broke out among the institution's employes Saturday afternoon.

SARATOGA, SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 16 -- At 6 A. M. tomorrow, Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt's Native Dancer, who scored his seventeeth success in eighteen tries when he won the Travers Stakes yesterday, will start on a train ride for Chicago, where he's to run in Washington Park's $100,000 added American Derby on Saturday.

The Association of National Advertisers has issued a study of cooperative advertising by seventy-one of its members who have wide experience in the field. It was prepared for the use of members by a special committee headed by Walter Lowy of the Formfit Company.

An explosion in the New York Naval Shipyard in Brooklyn in a two-story frame building near the main Sands Street gate shortly before midnight last night killed one Navy man and injured at least eight others, some of them critically.
When vacations are over and there is a whiff of autumn in the air, it is time to begin planning a fall wardrobe.

In a confused and so far bloodless revolt, in which the rival moves are still unclear, Premier Mossadegh appears to have made himself the absolute dictator of Iran, who, in the Persian tradition, may be reaching for the throne itself. The Shah has fled to Baghdad, Parliament has been dissolved, and the only law governing Iran today consists of Mr. Mossadegh's decrees.
BOSTON, Aug. 16 -- The National Association of Men's Apparel Clubs, Inc., opened a four-day convention at the Parker House today in an atmosphere of optimism.

Sales and earnings of Foremost Dairies, Inc., for the twenty-eight weeks ended on July 18, were the highest in the company's history, reflecting the effect of acquisitions and greater volume in established territories.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 16 -- Signs of the coming return of a more competitive steel market were not lacking this week, according to observers here. While there is no disposition on the part of major mills to view the situation with alarm, it was reliably reported that some of the smaller producers are becoming concerned over fourth-quarter sales prospects.

BONN, Germany, Aug., 16 -- The triple strain to which the French Union is being subjected by crises in Asia, Africa and Europe is a matter of concern to the entire structure of Western democratic defense. On this continent the main Allied forces, based in Germany, rely upon strike-bound Metropolitan France for their supply lines to the main Atlantic ports.

SYDNEY, Aug. 16 (AP) -- Ever since the first automobiles spluttered along their roads. Australians have dreamed of striking oil in useful quantities in their own country. Gas has been tapped in places, but so far there's been no payable oil.

Highlighted with such exciting new ideas as needle-like heels beveled to triangular thinness, Saks Fifth Avenue's collection of fall and winter shoes, shown last week at the Savoy Plaza, was as handsome as any seen in many a season.

VIENNA, Aug. 16 -- Schattendorf is like any other village in the Austrian Burgenland. Once part of Hungary, this province was turned over to Austria as the result of a plebiscite after the First World War. Though the inhabitants are Austrian, the villages look Hungarian. The freshly whitewashed houses with their big wooden gates face on an unpaved, straggling main street.
AMSTERDAM, Aug. 16 -- Allotment on a 400,000,000 guilder 3 1/2 per cent Government loan issued at par last Wednesday will amount to only 18 per cent of the subscribers, which totaled 1,890,000,000.
NEWPORT, R. I., Aug. 16 -- Tone Trabert celebrated his twenty-third birthday by winning the Casino Challenge Cup today.

ALBANY, Aug. 16 -- The State Water Pollution Control Board announced today that it had successfully completed the first phase of a research program aimed at eliminating the pollution in the Moriches Bay drainage area on Long Island that has resulted from duck raising there.

MOSCOW, Aug. 16 -- The Soviet Government has proposed that a German peace conference be convoked within six months and that East and West Germany seek immediately to set up a temporary Government for all Germany looking toward elections and the establishment of German unity.

Cotton futures moved irregularly in a narrow trading range last week and closed moderately lower. Final prices of futures on the New York Cotton Exchange on Friday were down 14 to 21 points, or 70 cents to $1.05 a bale, from the levels of the preceding week.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 16 -- David O. Selznick, in negotiations with the Sam Jaffee agency, has reached agreement on basic terms for the purchase of "Bell, Book and Candle," the John van Druten comedy produced on Broadway in 1950 by Irene Mayer Selznick, former wife of the film producer.

Radio Station WEVD, primarily a foreign-language station operated here by the Debs Memorial Radio Fund, went off the air yesterday as the result of a strike for higher pay by nine technicians and operating engineers of Local 1212, Radio and Television Engineers Union, A. F. L.

There must be thousands of Americans who are deeply moved by the reports of suffering from the recent earthquakes in Greece and who will naturally wish to help. While the Greek representative of the Red Cross in this country has announced that he is not authorized to accept any donations, there are other channels through which gifts can be made.
The charter market last week continued the "low" trend that has marked recent months, with the only encouraging factor being a slight improvement in activity on the Pacific Coast.

CHICAGO, Aug. 16 -- Violent price fluctuations marked wheat dealings on the Board of Trade last week, sharp declines following rumors that wheat growers would refuse to endorse the Government's plan for a marketing quota for the 1954 crop.
Ship construction in this country's private yards continued its downward plunge last month and set a new low point for the last two years.
NAZARETH, Israel, Aug. 15 -- The Arabs of Israel have become more vocal during the last month than at any time since the armistice of 1949.
ROME, Aug. 16 -- The Government announced yesterday by the Christian Democratic Premier-designate, Giuseppe Pella, does not appear to have been born under an auspicious star.

A strong market for the Canadian dollar and a steady undertone in the British pound sterling continued in foreign exchange trading during the past week. Transactions were fairly heavy at times but business generally was only moderate in comparison with some previous sessions.
LONDON, Aug. 16 -- A forty-two-year-old commitment by Britain's Parliament to reform the House of Lords by minimizing the hereditary basis of membership seems likely to bear fruit this year.

This may be the year for corporations to settle all outstanding claims against them, buy off guarantees that may cost money in the future, sell -- not swap -- old machinery, set up company foundations for the usual vague eleemosynary purposes -- the law allows 5 per cent deductions for this -- and go into pension trust or profit-sharing schemes.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 16 -- Following is the text of a resolution to be introduced in the United Nations General Assembly tomorrow by fourteen of the sixteen member states that sent armed forces to defend South Korea (Luxembourg was absent and South Africa awaited authorization):

SEOUL, Aug. 16 -- Twelve frightened passengers tightened their harnesses and prepared to jump from a plane hovering in distress over this city last night. They could not possibly have known their cargo of salad oil would save them from making the frightening leap into the darkness.

TEHERAN, Iran, Aug. 16 -- Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi and his Queen fled to Baghdad, Iraq, today after an attempt to oust Premier Mohammed Mossadegh, either by a coup or by a formal dismissal, according to conflicting versions, had failed. Dr. Mossadegh appeared to be in complete control tonight, with the bulk of the Army apparently supporting him.
MOBILE, Ala. -- Foods of many varieties are offered on the Gulf Coast, but the famous seafood dishes are the big favorites of tourists and natives alike.

Thomas J. Curran, Republican leader of New York County, will confer here Tuesday with William L. Pfeiffer, state Republican chairman, on a recommendation to be made for appointment to the office of Postmaster of New York. The postmastership became vacant Aug. 4 when Harold Riegelman, acting postmaster, resigned to accept the Republican designation for Mayor.

MILWAUKEE, Aug. 16 -- Nicholas Rossolimo of Paris met Larry Evans of New York, United States champion, in the sixth round of the open championship tournament of the United States Chess Federation at the Eagles Club today and drew in a cautiously conducted King's Indian defense lasting 22 moves.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 (AP) -- A congressional investigation into "full use of the air" by civilian and commercial aviation is under way, Senator John S. Cooper, Republican of Kentucky, said today.

There can be no doubt that war prisoners in the hands of the North Koreans and the Chinese have been subjected to murderous hardships. We have seen this happen in the war with Japan. Nothing was done then and nothing since to remedy this condition, with the result that we have now witnessed thousands of men tortured and killed on a far grander scale.

Budget Director Abraham D. Beame announced yesterday that he would meet on Aug. 25 with labor leaders and spokesmen for teachers' organizations to discuss the proposed extension of Federal Social Security benefits to eligible city employes who are not members of a municipal pension system.

NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 16 -- Mohammed Ali, the Prime Minister of Pakistan, arrived here tonight and dined privately with Jawaharlal Nehru, the Indian Prime Minister, on the eve of a four-day conference in which he hopes to allay the fear of war between the two countries over Kashmir.

In the last ten years we have witnessed a revival of the Malthusian doctrine that the world's population is increasing more rapidly than its supply of food, minerals and other commodities considered necessary for the maintenance of a high standard of living. We owe this revival largely to Fairfield Osborn ("Our Plundered Planet") and to William Vogt ("Road to Survival"), who have been followed by economists, public health officials and governments with predictions of misery.

RIVERSIDE, Conn., Aug. 16 -- Cornelius Shields Jr., Warner Willcox, Arthur Knapp, Howie McMichael and Skip Purcell gained the final for the Long Island Sound men's sailing championship at Riverside Yacht Club today.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 16 -- All went well with Casey Stengel and his Yankees today as the world champions deftly upended Jimmy Dykes' apathetic Athletics in both ends of a double-header to the keen disappointment of a gathering of 24,903.

Your editorial of Aug. 8 on "City Park Vacation" is in the best Chamber of Commerce or Convention Bureau tradition, but it is nevertheless timely and much to be applauded. At the same time, as an ex-Brooklynite (if one can ever go ex-Brooklyn), that editorial lacks a uniquely Brooklynesque type of seasoning.
FORT WAYNE, Ind., Aug. 16 (AP) -- Cary Middlecoff and Art Wall Jr. carded seven-under-par 65's today to tie for first place with 265 totals in the $15,000 Fort Wayne open golf tournament.

FREEDOM VILLAGE, Korea, Aug. 16 -- The return of thousands of Allied prisoners of war from Communist camps is affording the free world a chance to give a thorough examination to Communist prison methods.

LAKEWOOD, N. J., Aug. 16 -- A light blue 1953 sedan, southbound along Route 9 five miles north of here, swung out of line as if to pass a car ahead at 6:45 o'clock this morning. But instead of cutting back safely into line, it crossed to the northbound lane and crashed into a Lakewood-New York bus, whose driver swerved vainly to the shoulder to avoid it.

A man was killed and three other persons were injured, one of them critically, early yesterday when an automobile went out of control and struck a lamp-post on the West Side Highway at Thirteenth Street. Edward Armistead, 32 years old, of 56 West 128th Street, died when he was thrown from the car.
A mild earth tremor was recorded in the metropolitan area last night and touched off a flurry of alarm in scattered parts of the city, Westchester County and New Jersey.

In a deal in the Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn, the apartment house for thirty-eight families on plot 100 by 100 feet at 1137-49 Sixty-third Street has been sold by Chobol Navone, operators, to an investing client of Alex J. Spanow.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 16 -- At 3 o'clock tomorrow afternoon, near the suburban community of San Carlos, twenty-five miles south of here, private enterprise will take up where the Voice of America left off. For three hours thereafter, and daily from 3 to 6 P. M., a regular schedule of short-wave programs, broadcast from Station KGEI, will be heard again in homes throughout Central and South America.

BOSTON, Aug. 16 -- As its first major project, the new Massachusetts State Department of Commerce is undertaking a survey of vacant industrial buildings in the Commonwealth. This was the result of a suggestion by Governor Christian A. Herter that remodeling be included in a proposal by Federal authorities to give new construction accelerated amortization in industrially "critical" areas.

A store at 36 East Fifty-seventh Street has been leased by Fay-Wynn Gowns, Inc., for a long term at an aggregate rental of $200,000 through Riker Co. and Rossbach Associates, brokers. The space will be altered from plans by Frederick Victoria, architect, and is expected to be ready for occupancy early this fall.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 16 -- Herbert Brownell Jr., Attorney General, ending his investigation of the "wetback" problem here today, said he was convinced illegal Mexican immigration was becoming one of the nation's gravest law-enforcement problems.

QUENTIN, Pa., Aug. 16 (AP) -- Three women and three men were named today to the 1953 United States equestrian team -- the first time in the forty-year history of the squad that it has had more than two women members.

Nicholas Roosevelt, journalist and diplomat, has written a personal narrative of the events in which he participated and about the notable figures he has known. His book, entitled "A Front Row Seat," covers his experiences from 1914, when he was 21, through his days with THE NEW YORK TIMES and Station WQXR in 1946.

OMAHA, Aug. 16 (AP) -- The eventual tonnage of freight carried by barge on the Missouri River "will far exceed any official or unofficial estimates ever made to Congress," Everett T. Winter of Omaha predicted last night.

That National League pennant appears to be getting closer every day for the Dodgers. Yesterday at Ebbets Field the Brooks continued to harass Fred Haney's hapless Pirates by beating the Corsairs in both ends of a double-header, 3 -- 1 and 9 -- 5.
DENVER, Aug. 16 -- President Eisenhower went from church this morning to visit a 6-year-old boy declared by his physicians to be incurably afflicted with cancer.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 (AP) -- Income payments to individuals increased 5 per cent last year in the United States as gains were reported for all except four states.
For the third time in a year Engine Company 217's only bachelor, Fire Lieut. Edward T. Dunne, answered the pleas of a panicky father yesterday -- and aided in the delivery of a baby.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Aug. 16 -- Two armed hold-up men, handkerchiefs masking their faces, robbed Hackney's Restaurant tonight and escaped with $29,000 in week-end receipts. The restaurant, which is one of the world's largest sea food houses, is located on the boardwalk in the Inlet section of the resort.

TOKYO, Monday, Aug. 17 -- North Korean Communists riding trucks toward the prisoner-of-war exchange point at Panmunjom again fought a running battle with South Korean spectators along the roadside, the United Nations Prisoner-of-War Command announced yesterday afternoon.

PARIS, Aug. 16 -- Violence resulting in more than a score of fatalities and perhaps double that many injured broke out in different parts of Morocco today between supporters of the Sultan and of the rebellious Berbers, who have proclaimed his uncle the religious head of the country.

CARACAS, Aug. 16 -- A strong campaign for the opening of new oil concessions in Venezuela -- closed since 1945 -- has begun here. It is being backed by important Venezuelans who are arguing that new oil grants are important to the well-being of the nation.

CHICAGO, Aug. 16 (UP) -- The Braves backed up Rookie Bob Buhl's three-hit hurling with a twelve-hit attack for a 6-to-2 victory over the Cubs after taking the first game of a double-header, 4 to 2, today. The second contest was called because of darkness after the eighth inning.

A LADY who lives in East Sixty-sixth Street just off Central Park noticed, two years ago, that most recreational facilities in the park were huddled at the southern end, more or less. She got to thinking that the impoverished hundreds of thousands who live beyond the park's northern border had greater need of outdoor entertainment, especially on broiling summer nights.

Two victories over the fading Phillies made it a decidedly pleasant afternoon for the Giants yesterday at the Polo Grounds. Leo Durocher's lads, who have had too few enjoyable outings in the last three weeks, upset Robin Roberts, 8 -- 1, in the opener, and squeezed past Karl Drews and Steve Ridzik, 4 -- 3, as first Jim Hearn, then Ruben Gomez went all the way, each with a six-hitter.

The Allied Singers continued their "Songs on Sunday" series with an afternoon concert yesterday in Carl Fischer Concert Hall. This group is presenting singers from the "Porgy and Bess" company, now playing on Broadway.

INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 16 (AP) -- Richard G. (Dick) Cleveland of Honolulu slapped the wall inches ahead of Olympic champion Lieut. Clarke Scholes today in a churning finish of the national A. A. U. 100-meter championship.

Four four - story apartment houses at 308 to 314 Bleecker Street, corner of Grove Street, have been sold by Helen T. Hopson and others to Lawrence Kapner and Nathan Greenberg for investment in a deal negotiated by Dwight-Helmsley, Inc., and O. A. Robertson, Inc., brokers.

The first unit of the Belgian Line's 70,000-deadweight-ton construction program, involving seven new Diesel-powered cargo liners, is scheduled for completion by the end of this year, and the remaining vessels will be finished and ready for service over the next three years, Emile Heyrman, New York representative of the line, announced yesterday.
KUALA LUMPUR, Malaya, Aug. 16 -- Food control has become the most potent weapon in the arsenal of anti - Communist warfare in Malaya.

ABOARD U. S. S. SALEM, Argostoli Harbor, Aug. 16 -- The six-nation rescue operation moved into high gear today in the earthquake-stricken Greek Ionian islands of Cephalonia, Zante and Ithaca. Official reports indicated that the immediate emergency has been overcome, although most of the islands' 118,000 inhabitants have fled their homes and many of the injured remain in isolated interior villages.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., Aug. 16 -- An Air Force staff sergeant from Detroit, who had been a prisoner of war in North Korea since the B-26 light bomber in which he was a gunner was shot down behind Communist lines May 21, 1951, was reunited with his wife here today at Mitchel Air Force Base.

LENOX, Mass., Aug. 16 -- The sun shone brilliantly on Tanglewood and on the overflow thousands on the lawns around the music shed this afternoon, and as a result the Berkshire Music Festival came to an end with a new attendance record for the season.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 16 -- The United States agreed today to support a compromise resolution under which the General Assembly, when it resumes tomorrow, would recommend the participation of the Soviet Union in a Far Eastern political conference "provided the other side desires it."

LONDON, Aug. 16 -- The stock markets continue to show a surprising degree of activity and firmness at a time when the usual experience is one of business inertia and sagging prices at the height of the holiday season.

MANCHESTER, Mass., Aug. 16 (AP) -- Maureen Connolly of San Diego, Calif., 18-year-old United States champion, today won her second successive Essex County Club women's tennis tournament with a 7-5, 6-0 victory over Shirley Fry of Akron, Ohio.
BERLIN, Aug. 16 -- The Soviet Union's new note on Germany is the bombshell that Western observers had long suspected would be exploded by Moscow on the eve of the West German elections.

" Escapade," instead of "Late Love," is going into the Forty-eighth Street, after all. Contracts were signed on Friday for "Escapade" to open Nov. 12. This was confirmed yesterday by Alfred de Liagre Jr., co-producer with Roger Stevens of Roger MacDougall's London hit.

NEWPORT, R. I., Aug. 16 -- On the beautiful lawns of the Longwood Cricket Club in Brookline, Mass., will gather tomorrow tennis players from Europe, Asia, North and South America and Australia for the national doubles tennis championships.

Secretary Dulles' suggestion that the American Army be used for Korean reconstruction seemed to this reader to reflect good heart and high vision, and at the same time an astonishing naivete regarding the temper of American public opinion in general and Army psychology in particular.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 16 (UP) -- Johnny Groth's fifth-inning single broke a 5-5 tie as the last-place Browns gained a 7-5 victory over the Indians and a sweep of their double-header today. St. Louis took the first game, 7 -- 6. It was the first double-header victory of the season for the Browns at home.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 (AP) -- Gen. J. Lawton Collins, who was succeeded yesterday as Army Chief of Staff by Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway, paid tribute to the "loyalty, sacrifice and constant devotion to duty" of his forces in a farewell message today.

DALLAS, Tex., Aug. 16 (UP) --A Marine Reserve pilot crashed through three 138,000-volt high tension wires yesterday but flew his plane 100 miles farther to make a safe landing, although part of one wing had been clipped off and the other severely damaged.

LONDON, Aug., 16 -- The darkest cloud on Britain's economic horizon, which is generally bright compared with anything most residents can remember, is the increased difficulty being met by what is known here as the engineering industries in selling their products abroad.
A detachment of officers and midshipmen from the Portuguese Navy sloop Goncalves Zarco were honored guests at solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday.

CASABLANCA, Morocco, Aug. 16 -- The situation in Morocco could only be described as ugly tonight. The Sultan still was on his throne and the pricipal cities presented an outward appearance of calm, but there were sporadic flashes of violence.
SANTA FE, N. M., Aug. 16 -- President Eisenhower's signing into law yesterday of bills designed to improve the status of the nation's Indians has evoked mixed comment in the Southwest.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 (UP) -- The Department of Agriculture predicted today that American wool growers will receive "slightly" higher prices for this season's output than last.
CHICAGO, Aug. 16 (UP) -- Kentucky and Bradley were restored to good standing in the National Collegiate Athletic Association today by the top-governing group, the policy-making council.
A Protestant Episcopal minister and a member of the House Un-American Activities Committee agreed yesterday that a "few" clergymen probably had embraced communism.

The camper has returned, needing a haircut, much browner than when he departed several short weeks ago, a little slimmer, perhaps -- although he has much to say about the good food, which he compares to home cooking to the latter's detriment -- but hardened, and with an air of self-assurance he did not have before he left.

FRANZ VON PAPEN is 74 years old now, a white-haired old gentleman who has spent most of his adult life teetering on the tightrope of political power. Often when it seemed that he was certain to fall he managed to recover his balance and bow haughtily to the crowd, assuring them by his lordly manner that he had not slipped, had been only momentarily upset by someone jerking the wire.
Between 1,200 and 1,500 policemen will guard President Eisenhower and control the crowds on Wednesday during the President's first daytime visit to New York City since his inauguration.

BOSTON, Aug. 16 (AP) -- Washington and Boston split a double-header today as Mel Parnell, Red Sox southpaw, became the American League's first seventeen-game winner by winning the opener, 4 -- 1, and Frank (Spec) Shea took the nightcap, 7 -- 4, despite Ted Williams' home run and double in his first starting assignment for Boston since returning from Korea.

A six-story building containing seventy-two apartments and occupying a plot 150 by 97 feet at 4382 Furman Avenue, the Bronx, has been sold by Louis Levinson and Sam Bressler to the Einhorn Realty Corporation for cash over mortgages amounting to $195,792.

With its gross funded debt at a new high of $3,412,752,649 as of last July 1, the city's capital outlay program for 1954 within its constitutional debt limit should not exceed $230,000,000, Controller Lazarus Joseph declared yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 (UP) -- President Eisenhower's proposals for handling Government security information drew high praise today from the American Civil Liberties Union.

Metropolitan New York's harness racing fans will divide their attention for the next two weeks between two courses, with the opening tonight of the Yonkers Raceway's summer session and the continuance of the meeting at Roosevelt Raceway on Long Island.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 16 -- Debate on the Far Eastern political conference on Korea, opening tomorrow in the reconvened seventh session of the United Nations General Assembly, is expected to last a minimum of two weeks, and may even continue until Sept. 15, the date set for the opening of the next regular session.

BAGHDAD, Iraq, Aug. 16 (Reuters) -- Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi of Iran arrived here unexpectedly today in his private plane after Iran's Premier Mossadegh had crushed an attempted military coup by officers of the Shah's Imperial Guard. With the Shah were his Queen, Soraya, an aide and a pilot.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 16 (UP) -- Ted Kluszewski hit a homer in each game to set a Cincinnati record of thirty-six four-baggers in a season as the Redlegs split a double-header with the Cardinals today. The Redlegs won the opener, 3-2, before bowing, 6-2.

GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 16 -- Joseph Dietrich, the amiable tree warden of this town, has been startled by the aggressive reaction to his suggestion a fortnight ago that the urban landscape from coast to coast could stand a long-range pruning of "weed" trees -- including many old favorites such as apples and willows, poplars and horse chestnuts and certain elms.
A grant of $50,000 has been made by the New York Foundation to help finance preparation of plans for the presentation and restoration of Colonial Richmond-town on Staten Island.

Since you reported on Aug. 6 that Governor Dewey claims that non-residents should pay New York taxes because they enjoy the amenities provided by the state, I have been waiting for somebody to remind him that this ignores the basic issue of principle -- "no taxation without representation."

LONDON, Aug. 16 -- The first phase of the largest air defense exercise ever held over Britain has shown the need for more fast interceptor planes, but on the whole the "coordinated system of warning control and fighter defense has worked efficiently," the Air Ministry said tonight.

Harold Riegelman, Republican candidate for Mayor, declared yesterday that he eventually could trim $170,000,000 a year from the present cost of running the city government and predicted that his election would result in greater state aid for the city.

Normal secular occupations offer opportunities to carry out a Christian ministry fully as well as does the vocation of a clergyman, the Rev. Dr. David A. MacLennan of the faculty of Yale Divinity School, New Haven, Conn., said yesterday in a sermon at the Riverside Church, 122d Street and Riverside Drive.

Half of all new American homes will have complete airconditioning by 1958, according to an article on that industry appearing in the current issue of Steelways, the magazine of the American Iron and Steel Institute.

BERLIN, Aug. 16 -- Two of East Germany's leading Communists were ousted from all their party posts last month because they advocated drastic policy revision whereby Communist leaders would have been replaced "from top to bottom," according to the official Soviet newspaper Taegliche Rundschau.

Four friendly zebras, one shy hyrax, five disagreeable mongooses and three vultures arrived here from England yesterday. They were brought in aboard the Cunard liner Media by Reginald T. Bloom, an Englishman who captured them in Kenya, Africa, three months ago and is taking them to the National Zoological Park in Washington.

TWO fifteen-minute musical programs have been introduced this summer by the C. B. S. television network. "TV's Top Tunes" is presented on Mondays, Wednesdays and Fridays at 7:45 P. M.; "Summertime U. S. A." is seen on Tuesdays and Thursdays at the same hour. The programs are no more similar, however, than Hopalong Cassidy and the Beast From 20,000 Fathoms.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 (AP) -- Haldore Hanson, once accused of Communist leanings by Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, will leave his post in the Foreign Operations Administration Sept. 1, Harold E. Stassen said today.

PARIS, Aug. 16 -- The French public service strikes, which have been submerged in the total shutdown during the most popular holiday of the year, the Feast of the Assumption, were scheduled to continue this week despite peace feelers from both the Government and the strikers.

BERLIN, Aug. 17 -- The East German Cabinet, in a special session today, named a delegation of fifteen consisting of virtually the entire top leadership of the Soviet zone regime to go to Moscow to discuss the Kremlin's new plan for the creation of a provisional all-German government.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture today proposed revision of the New York milk marketing order's provision on payments from "pool" funds to cooperatives for performing certain market-wide services to all producers.

A Securities and Exchange Commission hearing into the affairs of a large North Jersey meat company, Adolf Gobel, Inc., got under way yesterday with testimony on alleged juggling of $225,000 of inventory.

HONG KONG, Aug. 17 -- The British Navy announced here today that the frigate Saint Brides Bay had thwarted a Chinese Nationalist attempt yesterday to seize the British coastal steamer Nigelock after the 700-ton vessel was intercepted off the southeast coast of China.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 (AP) -- Representative W. Sterling Cole, chairman of the joint Atomic Energy Committee, declared today "there is no question that America still leads the world in atomic development."

TRENTON, Aug. 17 -- Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll, in what probably will be recorded as his last major act as chief executive of New Jersey, returned today to the State Legislature 100 bills and resolutions that he had vetoed since that body adjourned sine die in June. The Governor will retire from office in January.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- A storage use guarantee plan, designed to encourage construction of commercial storage facilities for mounting supplies of farm commodities, was announced today by the Department of Agriculture.
In a letter published in your issue of Aug. 13, Stanley I. Posner, obviously with the best intentions, discusses a Central American Union.

OTTAWA, Aug. 17 -- Canadian Arsenals, Ltd., established in 1945 to provide a reserve of specialized facilities and skills for defense, managed to meet all operating expenses and maintenance charges out of income, C. D. Howe, Minister of Defense Production, said today in reporting on the company's activities in the last year.

DUCK hunters throughout this area are lavish in their praise of the State Conservation Commission, particularly of its chief, Perry B. Duryea, on that department's success in obtaining permission from the Federal Fish and Wildlife Service to set up zones in upstate New York and on Long Island to coincide with migration.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 (AP) -- The Defense Department identified today 206 additional United States soldiers reported by the Communists to have died in enemy prison camps. The Pentagon has made public the names of a total of 794 of the 1,022 United States service men said by the enemy to have died in Communist hands. The new list, which is based solely on enemy reports, includes:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- President Eisenhower, in a progress report today to Congress on the nation's foreign aid program, declared there was need for greater cooperation among countries participating in the world-wide development of collective defense and economic stability.

DETROIT, Aug. 17 -- The General Motors Corporation disclosed today that it was in negotiation with Kaiser Motors for a lease on 1,500,000 square feet of the Kaiser plant at Willow Run in which to re-establish volume production of hydramatic transmissions.
A taxicab mechanic was murdered yesterday morning when he tried to drive a cab out of the company garage in Long Island City, Queens, during a hold-up by two men, who escaped.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- Democratic National Headquarters today issued a formal call for a meeting of the party's full National Committee in Chicago on Sept. 15 in conjunction with the "welcome home" ceremonies being arranged for Adlai E. Stevenson, the Democratic Presidential Candidate of 1952.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 (AP) -- Fred B. Lee, Administrator of Civil Aeronautics, said today that a 100-passenger American-built jet airplane might be in operation by 1955.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 (AP) -- The Defense Department identified 132 additional Korean battle casualties today. A new list on pre-armistice combat reported nine killed, ninety-seven wounded, nineteen missing in action and seven injured. The following were listed for New York and New Jersey (none from Connecticut):

Your eloquent editorial, "The Ultimate Weapon," must have roused somber reflections in us all. It is because freedom is infinitely precious to me, also, that I ask your patience with a viewpoint differing from your own in its conclusion. For to me you leave freedom's very deepest aspect still unplumbed.
A field of 159, including four ex-champions, has been listed for the fifty-third women's amateur championship of the United States Golf Association, it was disclosed yesterday.

PEORIA, Ill., Aug. 17 -- President Eisenhower sent a message today to the thirty-sixth annual convention of the American Federation of Teachers, A. F. L., urging delegates and members to "lead in the fight against those who -- through dishonesty -- would undermine our freedom and our liberty."

KANSAS CITY, Aug. 17 (AP) -- The former president of Flour Mills of America, Inc., said increasing costs of milling operations and price competition within the industry caused the $3,000,000 loss reported by the company for the past year.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Aug. 17 -- A Yale University law professor and a Supreme Court justice's clerk charged today that the United States Coast Guard port security program is unconstitutional on the ground it denies a man's right to work without due process of law.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 17 -- Columbia, it became known today, is figuring on doing an original musical film on Thai harem life a la the Rodgers-Hammerstein adaptation of "The King and I," which was based on the Margaret Landon novel about the experiences of the English governess, Anna Leonowens, who went to Thailand in the Eighteen Sixties as a teacher for the king's children.

Henry (Pappy) Gault of Spartanburg, S. C., successful in four previous title defenses, was dethroned as the North American bantamweight champion last night when he lost a split decision to sharp-hitting Billy Peacock of Los Angeles at the Eastern Parkway Arena in Brooklyn.

Bernard Lamstein, the Brooklyn landlord who last Tuesday repaid nearly $30,000 to eighty-four tenants from whom he had admitted taking bonuses and illegal rent increases, returned yesterday to Kings County Court to pay his $15,000 fine.

VANDALIA, Ohio, Aug. 17 (AP) -- Joe Hiestand, 44-year-old Hillsboro, Ohio, farmer, almost shut out in last year's Grand American trapshoot, tied today for the top spot in the 200-target, 16-yard introductory event of the fifty-fourth Grand.
FAIRFIELD, Calif., Aug. 17 (AP) -- Three more American prisoners freed by the Communists in Korea arrived here by plane today.

Futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed yesterday 2 to 11 points below Friday's close on the more active positions, and at or near the extreme lows of the current reaction. The feature was the liberal price fixing, particularly in the October position, which displayed relative steadiness.
CAIRO, Aug. 17 -- Egypt has concluded informal agreements with both the Soviet Union and Czechoslovakia that may include the purchase of arms, according to an official Government source.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Aug. 17 -- President Sukarno, commemorating the eighth anniversary of Indonesia's proclamation of independence, today called for total annihilation of the armed bands that are disturbing the countryside.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 17 -- The Yanks are still grabbing them two at a time. They swept their second successive double - header with Jimmy Dykes' Athletics tonight, this one a twilight-night affair that drew a crowd of 13,595.

The sky glowers and grumbles belligerently, and the breeze accelerates as if to escape the ominous developments portending. This is the start of a summer storm, one of nature's most impressive productions; a symphony of sound and fury punctuated by interludes of jagged lightning.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, Aug. 17 -- The strike that gripped Ceylon on Aug. 12, with accompanying violence and terrorism that resulted in the imposition of a curfew, is interpreted in political circles here is an attempt by the Communist party to wrest power from Ceylon's democratically inclined Government and to introduce a totalitarian reign.

Norman Thomas, Socialist leader, returned by air yesterday from a six-week visit abroad during which he attended the meeting of the International Confederate of Free Trade Unions and the Socialist International in Stockholm.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- Fred Sillers, a former employe of the Government Printing Office, refused to answer today on the grounds of possible self-incrimination questions of the Senate Permanent Subcommittee on investigations regarding Communist affiliations or associations.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 17 -- United Nations delegates, returning today to begin planning for the Far Eastern political conference, brought a new stir of activity and excitement to long quiet halls and conference rooms.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 (AP) -- The Department of Commerce said today that in recent years farmers have invested an average of $3,500,000,000 a year in equipment and buildings other than their homes. This was more than double the rate of farm investment from 1937 to 1941, the department said, even after allowance for virtual doubling of prices paid for equipment and building.

LONDON, Aug. 17 -- Most sections of the securities market here were quietly firm today with small rises widely distributed among the domestic industrials and British Government issues. Textile and store groups were in best demand and Standard Motors and Massey Harris both reacted to the Fergusson-Massey tractor deal with gains.
DENVER, Aug. 17 -- President Eisenhower will have a busy schedule Wednesday from the moment he arrives in New York City until he departs.

A gang of burglars broke into nine offices in a six-story Queens building over the week-end and escaped with $5,000 in jewelry and cash. The police said that the gang entered the Red Cross Building at 92-32 Union Hall Street, Jamaica, by way of a fourth-floor fire-escape and robbed offices on the third and fourth floors.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- The Administration's new council of top-level military advisers, the Joint Chiefs of Staff, was completed today with the swearing in of Admiral Robert B. Carney as Chief of Naval Operations.

A new series of model rooms at McCreery has been aptly named "A House Divided." The story behind the two living rooms, two dining areas and two bedrooms is that they duplicate similar rooms in a two-family house in Whitestone, Queens, one-half of which has been decorated in contemporary style and the other half, with identical floor plan, in traditional fashion.
BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 17 (AP) -- Sixteen golfers with scores of 87 and under today qualified for the National girl's junionr golf championship tournament at The Country Club.

The filing of architectural plans for Bay View Houses in Brooklyn was announced yesterday by Philip J. Cruise, chairman of the New York City Housing Authority. The development, which is expected to cost $20,325,000, will house 1,603 families in apartments of three-and-a-half to five-and-a-half rooms, renting at about $19 a room a month.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- The Western powers made a conciliatory gesture toward Moscow today by withdrawing their proposed "short treaty" for Austria and called upon the Soviet Union to send a deputy to London Aug. 31 to meet with the representatives of France, Britain and the United States to complete promptly a longer treaty restoring Austria's full independence and sovereignty.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 17 -- The General Assembly cleared the decks this afternoon for debate on the make-up of the Far Eastern political conference provided for in Article 60 of the Korean armistice. At a session lasting only eight minutes the Assembly decided to refer the question to its Political and Security Committee, which will start work at 10:30 A. M. tomorrow, and then adjourned.

Although some stock leaders, including several represented in THE NEW YORK TIMES industrial average, turned upward and gave that measure of the stock market an appearance of firmness yesterday, the general movement was slightly downward.

CANTON, N. Y., Aug. 17 -- Recent investigations show that 30 per cent of the country's juvenile delinquents suffer from serious emotional disturbances and that increasing numbers of these youths are coming from middle-class homes, a nationally known sociologist said here today.

NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 17 -- A spokesman for the meeting between Prime Ministers Jawaharlal Nehru of India and Mohammed Ali of Pakistan said after today's session that while the possibility of a plebiscite among the 4,000,000 predominantly Moslem population of Kashmir had not been "ruled out," it was "advisable not to be unduly optimistic."
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 17 -- The Republic of Korea has warned that it may withdraw entirely from the conference on Far Eastern problems if India is invited to participate.

PARIS, Aug. 17 -- Gen. Augustin Guillaume, French Resident General in Morocco, today blamed the Istiqlal, the Moroccan nationalist party, for yesterday's disorders and bloodshed in Morocco. He flew from Rabat today.

A mild outbreak of food poisoning struck 150 patients and sixty-seven staff members Thursday at the Veterans Administration Hospital, Fort Hamilton, Brooklyn, Dr. Abraham M. Kleinman, chief of professional services at the hospital, disclosed yesterday.

Comment on the wisdom of entering into the Korean armistice by one ignorant of the many factors bearing upon the question is out of place. What seems open to criticism, however, is the ambiguity of the language of the instruments by which the armistice is implemented. This will lead to different interpretations which are likely to plague and humiliate us in the future.

Hemphill, Noyes Co. heads an underwriting group that is offering for public sale today 100,000 shares of Combined Locks Paper Company. Class A common stock at $12.50 a share. Proceeds will be applied toward the cost of completing the company's expansion and improvement program at the plant of its subsidiary, the D. M. Bare Paper Company, at Roaring Spring, Pa.

The center of the earthquake that alarmed many residents of the metropolitan area Sunday night appears to have been about the center of Bergen County, N. J., the Lament Geological Observatory of Columbia University reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 (AP) -- Despite a slight net increase in the supply of labor in some areas between May and July -- the first since March, 1952 -- the over-all labor market situation in the nation's major centers continues to rank among the best balanced on record, the Labor Department said today.

BERLIN, Aug. 17 (Reuters) -- Following is the text of the Soviet note to the United States proposing a peace conference on the German question, as transmitted by A. D. N., official East German news agency. (Similar notes were sent to Britain and France):
LONDON, Aug. 17 -- The only significance of last night's new Moscow note on Germany is its timing, well-informed sources said here today.

Sixty-nine members of the police force will be promoted today in a ceremony at Police Headquarters, including six lieutenants who will become captains. At the same ceremony 847 probationary patrolmen will graduate and get assignments in the force.
EDINBURGH, Aug. 17 -- The Eighth International Congress on Home Economics today tackled the problem of the shortage of domestic help, a problem particularly acute in Britain and the United States.
Operating revenues and earnings of the El Paso Natural Gas Company and its subsidiaries rose sharply in the twelve months ended on June 30.

In signing a bill that authorizes all states to assume jurisdiction over the Indian tribes within their borders irrespective of the Indians' wishes, President Eisenhower clearly expressed one reason why he might have been better advised to veto it.
MILWAUKEE, Aug. 17 -- Nine players were tied for first place in the open championship tournament of the United States Chess Federation at the end of the eighth round today.

TOKYO, Tuesday, Aug. 18 (AP) -- The Korean rehabilitation mission, headed by Dr. Howard A. Rusk and the former Eighth Army commander, Gen. James A. Van Fleet, arrived in Tokyo today on its way to Korea.

Two five-story buildings containing four stores and forty-seven apartments at 634-36 Union Street in Brooklyn have been sold by the Estate Securities Company, real estate operators, to a client of Alex DiLorenzo, attorney. The property, on a plot 76 by 100 feet, is assessed at $60,000.

The Northwest Orient Airlines has leased space in the nine-story building at 537 Fifth Avenue, between Forty-fourth and Fortyfifth Streets, from the City Bank Farmers Trust Company, trustees of the Astor estate. The lease, covering the first four floors and the basement, is for fifteen years with an option to rent the remaining floors as soon as the space becomes available.

Bishop Charles K. Gilbert, president of the New York City Affairs Committee, expressed regret yesterday that Robert K. Straus, temporary chairman of the executive committee of the organization, had identified himself with the independent candidacy of Robert B. Blaikie for the Democratic nomination for Mayor. Mr. Straus announced Sunday his intention to support Mr. Blaikie.

ROME, Aug. 17 -- Giuseppe Pella became Premier of Italy at 11 o'clock this morning when he was sworn in by President Luigi Einaudi. A Christian Democrat, he succeeds Alcide De Gasperi of the same party, who held the premiership with eight Cabinets from Dec. 10, 1945, until today.

WHEN Gwen Raverat was a little girl in Victorian Cambridge her mother used to deputize her to act as chaperone for men and women in their thirties whose sedate courtship would have offended the proprieties if a third person were not always present. No other fact in Mrs. Raverat's delightful volume of childhood reminiscences, "Period Piece,"* demonstrates quite so well how much the world has changed in sixty years.

ZURICH, Aug. 17 -- Belief that removal of the last technical hindrances will enable the German Government to resume debt service soon, as provided by the London debt agreement of Feb. 27, 1953, and possibly allow resumption also of dividends on foreign-owned German shares, at least on those held continuously since August, 1931, resulted in a sudden large-scale demand for sperrmarks in Zurich last week at sharply rising prices.
In your editorial of July 21, "Sixty-One Million Jobs," I find the following:

FREEDOM VILLAGE, Korea, Tuesday, Aug. 18 (AP) -- The Communists now fly new twin-jet fighter-bombers in North Korea's skies where they never dared appear with a war on, returning prisoners said yesterday.

French difficulties in Morocco are inherent in the whole cumbrous, backward, unsatisfactory relationship between the protectorate and Paris. Morocco is now caught in a civil strife which was none of France's doing and was, indeed, much against her wishes, yet no one can say that it was unexpected or unnatural in the circumstances.

DAYTON, Ohio, Aug. 17 (AP) -- Air Force Secretary Harold E. Talbott announced today that the Air Materiel Command, Air Force logistical arm, would eliminate seven of its subordinate headquarters by Dec. 31.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 (UP) -- The General Services Administration announced a new victory today in the Government's eternal war with red tape.

Establishment of the School of World Trade at 52 Broadway was announced yesterday by its director, George S. Bosse, who was formerly supervisor of the foreign trade unit of the recently discontinued Midtown Center of the City College of New York.

SALZBURG, Austria, Aug. 17 -- Gottfried won Einem's opera setting of Franz Kafka's "The Trial," which had its premiere here tonight, is a serious approach to a problem that probably can be solved only by recourse to the medium of the motion picture.
The sensational announcement made by Malenkov about the hydrogen bomb has largely overshadowed another part of his speech.

INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 17 -- Gov. George N. Craig ordered the Clinton exchange of the Indiana Bell Telephone Company opened today and sent state troopers there "to keep it open." He also said that he had alerted the Indiana National Guard for action against further possible violence.

Where are the voices of protest at the proposed discontinuance of the Third Avenue Elevated? To many of us it will be a major calamity, especially to those like myself who are life-long residents of Manhattan.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- The United Brotherhood of Carpenters is out of the American Federation of Labor because William L. Hutcheson, president emeritus of the union, tried the walkout technique of domination once too often, "and the executive council got fed up."

OTTAWA, Aug. 17 -- A fire that has ravaged 100 square miles of timberland worth $1,000,000, according to one source, was raging tonight a bare four miles from the little town of Ste. Therese de Colombier on the north shore of the St. Lawrence River almost opposite Rimouski.

FORT WAYNE, Ind., Aug. 17 (AP) -- Art Wall Jr. of Pocono Manor, Pa., chipped and putted his way to a 2-stroke victory over Dr. Cary Middlecoff of Memphis in a playoff today, for the Fort Wayne open's top money. The 25-year-old Pennsylvanian shot a 70.

TRENTON, Aug. 17 -- New Jersey is no longer the Garden State. This may come as a surmise to the public and even to some members of the State Legislature. For the latter body recently voted to have that appellation inscribed on the next issue of automobile license plates -- a plan that Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll vetoed today.

YONKERS, Aug. 17 -- Fred C. Tobey's Frisco Fancy from Gansevoort, N. Y., with Harold Story handling the reins, won a torrid stretch duel by a head from Lonway, Billy Haughton up, in the $5,000 Carmel pacing feature tonight in 2:06 3/5.

Synthetic fibers and plastics now constitute a major part of the linens and domestics industry, manufacturers said yesterday at the fall showing of the Allied Linens and Domestics Association in the Commodore Hotel. An extensive assortment of synthetics was shown by many of the eighty-one manufacturers displaying their products at the show, which opened Sunday and will continue through Friday.

Julius Helfand, assistant District Attorney of Kings County and a candidate for President of the City Council on the ticket headed by Mayor Impellitteri, said yesterday that former Mayor William O'Dwyer had tried to "destroy" the Brooklyn inquiry into links between gamblers and the police.
MEXICO CITY, Aug. 17 (AP) -- Mexico's Foreign Minister said today relations with the United States "are very cordial although there are some problems arising from our geographical relationship."

Excellent potato crops in the major producing areas of the country are predicted for this year by the United States Department of Agriculture. The estimated total of 382,835,000 bushels is 10 per cent larger than that for 1952.

It is certain now that "A Night in Venice," moat and all, will be set up for the wonderment of our South American neighbors. Sending cigar-smoke signals from Los Angeles yesterday, Michael Todd, local impresario, revealed that he had completed plans to produce the outdoor spectacle for twelve weeks in Sao Paulo, Brazil, starting Jan. 1.

Steel-making operations were at a faster pace last week for the second week in a row and are expected to gain a little more this week. The nation's mills turned out 2,146,000 tons of ingots and steel for castings in the period ended on Aug. 15, with operations at 95.2 per cent of theoretical capacity, compared with 2,119,000 and 94 per cent the previous week, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 17 -- A 43-year-old chef confessed to the police today that eleven years ago he killed a prowler he had found in a New York hotel room and had burned his body in a vacant lot.

OAKLAND, Calif., Aug. 17 -- A measure adopted by California voters last November granting tax exemption to privately operated, nonprofit elementary and secondary schools was ruled unconstitutional today in a 2-to-1 decision of the State Superior Court of Alameda County.

The textile company of M. Lowenstein Sons, Inc., in the first six months of this year expanded sales by 20 per cent and earnings by 44 per cent over those of the corresponding period last year, the semi-annual report disclosed yesterday.

Some interesting data to which marketing men might well pay heed for evidences of a trend has been turned up by McCall's magazine in a survey of 1,000 brides of 1952. For example, more than one-third of those queried were teen-agers and fewer than one-quarter of them had been engaged for a year or more.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Aug. 17 -- The new Presidential panel set up to handle atomic labor disputes took its first action today. It recommended a wage increase of 7 cents an hour for 3,500 American Federation of Labor workers in two of the three big operations at Oak Ridge.
TAEGU, Korea, Tuesday, Aug. 18 (AP) -- A court-martial yesterday convicted Second Lieut. George Schreiber of Hollywood, Ill., of the murder of a South Korean civilian last September.
MUNSAN, Korea, Tuesday, Aug. 18 (AP) -- The United Nations Command's official list of United States prisoners of war freed in today's armistice exchange:

Rain until an hour before game time and the threat of more did not prevent the Giants and Phillies from playing and dividing a double-header at the Polo Grounds yesterday. It did, though, compel the athletes to go through the motions in comparative privacy because the weather held the crowd down to 2,885 fans, the third smallest turnout of the local season.
LONDON, Aug. 17 (AP) -- Britain's Ryder Cup selectors mixed youth with golfing experience today in the 17-man team they picked to battle the Americans at Wentworth, outside London, on Oct. 2 and 3.

The New York Rangers, still seeking to bolster the club for the coming National Hockey League campaign, yesterday announced a one-for-two deal with the Montreal Canadiens. They acquired Ivan Irwin, a defenseman, in exchange for a pair of experienced forwards, Ed Slowinski and Pete Babando.
BONN, Germany, Aug. 17 -- Dr. Konrad Adenauer, West Germany's Chancellor, categorically rejected today as a basis for peace the treaty terms suggested in a week-end note by the Soviet Union.
A three-man Navy board of inquiry was appointed yesterday to investigate the explosion in the New York Naval Shipyard in Brooklyn that killed two men and injured ten others.

The 300th and last man for the special Marine company recruited as part of the city's tercentenary celebration signed up yesterday morning. He is 20-year-old Eugene Thomas Murphy of Queens, who signed his enlistment papers at a ceremony attended by Marine officers and officials of the anniversary committee.

Trading volume on the New York commodity exchanges continued light yesterday and prices were mixed. Copper, rubber, wool and coffee advanced; potatoes, lead, sugar and cocoa were mixed, and hides, zinc, cottonseed oil and soybean oil declined.
Record sales and earnings were achieved by the Davison Chemical Corporation in its fiscal year ended last June 30, according to the annual report mailed to stockholders yesterday.

NEWARK, Aug. 17 -- Carl Holderman, state president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, said today that the New Jersey Blue Cross Hospitalization Plan would "obviously require" an increase in subscription rates. In a letter to all union locals, Mr. Holderman criticized the State Chamber of Commerce, which has said that rate changes being considered by the Blue Cross would result in "drastic increases."
J. Ross Stainton has been appointed general sales manager of the British Overseas Airways Corporation. Winston Bray will replace Mr. Stainton as North American manager.

When wheat supplies reach the point where they exceed "normal" by 20 per cent the Secretary of Agriculture is authorized, at his option, to hold a referendum of wheat growers. The growers are polled as to whether they favor a substantial cutback in the acreage they can plant and the amount of wheat they can market, or whether they favor uncontrolled planting and marketing.

CHICAGO, Aug. 17 -- The favorable vote on the marketing quota referendum inspired free buying at the start this morning, but prices reacted sharply as outside buying failed to follow the upturn. Except for the May wheat delivery, all the early gains were erased before a better demand developed.

Beauty and barber shop supply distributors throughout the country are ready to cease purchasing from manufacturers who refuse to share freight costs with them, O. C. Bottenfield, president of the Beauty and Barber Supply Institute, asserted yesterday.

PARIS, Tuesday, Aug. 18 -- The crippling strike movement in France took a grave turn last night when contact between the Government and the non-Communist unions was suddenly broken. The way is now open for a general spread of the strikes, which have all but immobilized railroads, communications, mines and important public services, to every other sector of French economy.
DENVER, Aug. 17 -- Attorney General Herbert Brownell Jr. won President Eisenhower's approval today of a three-way approach to a solution of the problem of illegal labor -- "Wetbacks" -- from Mexico.

The long controversy over the assessment of extra charges for handling heavy units of steamship cargo is expected to he resolved today, and both sides in the dispute have marshaled strong forces for a meeting this afternoon in the Maritime Exchange, 80 Broad Street. These charges have been under heavy attack here since the end of World War II.

NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 17 -- On the eve of the Indian team's return from its mission in Korea preliminary to repatriation of prisoners of war, Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru told Parliament today that the first of four ships carrying 5,000 Indian troops and Red Cross workers was scheduled to leave for a Japanese or Korean port to be announced this week.

The current meetings in New Delhi between Prime Minister Nehru of India and Prime Minister Mohammed Ali of Pakistan are of profound significance to the peace of Asia and the future relationships between the two great powers in that region. To describe these talks as critical would be an understatement. If they fail the prospect is too dreadful for contemplation.

TEHERAN, Iran, Aug. 17 -- Mobs threw down from their pedestals today the statues of Iran's two Kings of the Pahlevi line, the late Riza Shah and Shah Mohammed Riza, who fled to Baghdad yesterday after a midnight attempt to replace Premier Mohammed Mossadegh had been thwarted by the Army.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Aug. 17 -- Jack Patroni of Apawamis and Toney Tiso of Vernon Hills finished in a tie for the Westchester Professional Golfers Association championship with scores of 143 for thirty-six holes at the Fenway Golf Club today.

New York City's gross funded debt as of July 1, 1953, was $3,412,752,649, an increase of nearly $60,000,000 in a year. Debt service to amortize this debt, retire short-term debt and pay interest is an item of $293,473,522 in this year's expense budget, an increase of more than $25,000,000 in a year.

BLED, Yugoslavia, Aug. 17 -- In a vast set of economic decrees planned by the Communist leaders of Yugoslavia for promulgation early next year is one that would permit individuals to organize small business enterprises and reap the profit from them.

TOKYO, Tuesday, Aug. 18 -- The Communists increased the group of Allied prisoners returned today to 450, the largest number sent back on a single day since the transfer began at Panmunjom, but they appeared to be holding back some American captives.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- Following is the text of a note delivered to the Soviet Foreign Office by the United States Embassy in Moscow at noon (Moscow time) today:

Johnny Lindell had the Dodgers shut out with three hits going into the ninth inning at Ebbets Field last night and, with the Pirates leading, 2 -- 0, it looked as though the nine-game winning streak of the Brooks was doomed.

VIENNA, Aug. 17 -- The statement of Chancellor Julius Raab Saturday that "Austria demands peace and has no objection if a state treaty should forbid her a large army and alliances with other states" has set up lively repercussions not only in Western diplomatic circles but among some of his own supporters.

Mayor Impellitteri made his second appearance of the Democratic primary campaign in Harlem last night and, this time, pledged himself and his associates to wage a continuing battle against all forms of racial or minority prejudice and persecution.

ATLANTA, Aug. 17 (UP) -- Gov. Herman Talmadge said today that Georgia could transfer public schools to private operation in "a few days" is the United States Supreme Court banned classroom segregation.

The world's first regular trans-Atlantic passenger service in airliners powered with complex engines that combine the features of both conventional power plants and turbines has been started by K. L. M. Royal Dutch Airlines. The first commercial flight of a turbo-compound Lockheed Super Constellation between the United States and Europe was made last Saturday.

THIS is merely a look around the store to see if anything changed while this shopkeeper had his back turned. The joint looks pretty much the same with no violent disruptions among the goods on the shelves. At the time of departure the Dodgers were leading their league by three games and the Yankees were leading theirs by four.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 17 -- The knee injury that Victor Seixas sustained at Newport yesterday in his final-round match with Tony Trabert may make it necessary for them to withdraw from the national doubles tennis championships which started today on the turf of the Longwood Cricket Club.

LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., Aug. 17 -- Roslyn (Cookie) Swift and Bill Collins of Glen Oaks carded 36, 36 -- 72 and won on a matching of cards to take the low gross prize from Mrs. R. M. Torgerson of Cherry Valley and Jimmy Thomson, unattached, in the Long Island P. G. A. women-pro tournament at the Piping Rock Club today.

Radio Station WEVD continued to remain off the air yesterday as the result of a strike by nine technicians and operating engineers. The strike, involving a dispute over pay increases, was called Sunday by Local 1212 of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Wrkers, A. F. L.

VIENNA, Aug. 17 -- Four hundred delegates gathered here today for the fifth annual congress of the World Federation for Mental Health. They represented seventy-two mental health associations in thirty-eight countries and four international associations with a total membership of 1,000,000.

CHICAGO, Aug. 17 (AP) -- Notre Dame and Michigan State received a sharp slap for violations of the athletic code tonight and little Arizona State at Tempe was placed on two years' probation by the powerful policy-making group of the nation's colleges.

ATLANTA, Aug. 17 (UP) -- Gov. Herman Talmadge said today that Georgia could transfer public schools to private operation in "a few days" is the United States Supreme Court banned classroom segregation.

The world's first regular trans-Atlantic passenger service in airliners powered with complex engines that combine the features of both conventional power plants and turbines has been started by K. L. M. Royal Dutch Airlines. The first commercial flight of a turbo-compound Lockheed Super Constellation between the United States and Europe was made last Saturday.

LONDON, Aug. 17 (Reuters) -- Len Hutton and Peter May made a second-wicket stand of 100 as England scored 235 for seven today in reply to Australia's first-innings' 275 in the final cricket test match. The first four tests were drawn.

If the check book says "no" to a European trip, you can find the color and quality of far-away romantic places by visiting the yard goods departments of New York stores that are displaying imported fabrics.

A comparatively new addition to the large collection of accessories for the modern home is the contemporary version of the scatter rug, termed today as an "accent" or "area" rug. Two new groups of such floor coverings are now available.

LAKE HULEH, Israel, Aug. 17 -- Possibly 100,000 years ago a volcanic eruption raised a basalt barrier across the Jordan Valley and the Jordan River backed up into Lake Huleh and the Huleh swamp. Prehistoric man knew this lake and swamp, ancient Hebrews built towns on the cool heights above, and they were known to Jesus.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- Senator William F. Knowland of California, the Republican leader of the Senate, listed the Korean truce as the No. 1 achievement of the Republicans today.

UNITED UATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 17 -- The United States formally called today for full public debate in the General Assembly on a United Nations report that found the Soviet Union guilty of using forced labor for political and economic ends.

Washington Square experienced a new kind of entertainment last night -- a free concert by a chamber orchestra of a dozen string players. The event attracted so large a turnout that the tiny ensemble and the 550 early-comers who were lucky enough to get seats were all but engulfed in the crowd.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 17 -- Native Dancer boarded a train for Chicago early this morning, headed for Washington Park and Saturday's $100,000 added American Derby, but Eric Guerin, the young man who has been standard equipment astride the gray colt, won't be making the trip.

Manufacturers and retailers of shoes, handbags, belts, garments, gloves and other accessories from all parts of the United States, Canada, Latin America and Europe will gather at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel today and tomorrow for the annual leather show, which starts the new season for the entire range of the shoe and accessory industries. The attendance is expected to exceed 8,000.

A whole family of new Army weapons, including two strange-looking combat vehicles -- oddly named "Ontos" or "The Thing," and "Larruping Lou" -- is to be produced or further developed with funds from the 1954 military budget.

Before the Western Powers could reply to the Soviet note of Aug. 5 accepting their proposal for a Foreign Ministers' conference to deal with Germany, provided it did so on Moscow's terms, the Soviet Government has submitted a new note spelling out just what the Soviet terms are.

VIENNA, Aug. 17 -- Edgar Sanders, British executive of the former Standard Electric Company in Budapest, who was sentenced three years and six months ago on a charge of espionage, was pardoned tonight by the Hungarian Government, according to the Budapest radio.

The hard money policies recently put into effect by the Government have aggravated the normal difficulties of small business in obtaining short-term money it is said in a survey by the Standard Factors Corporation released today by Theodore H. Silbert, president.
DENVER, Aug. 17 (UP) -- Charles R. Sligh Jr., president of the National Association of Manufacturers, today urged complete elimination of the excess profits and excise taxes.

ATHENS, Aug. 17 -- The United States Sixth Fleet began withdrawing from the earthquake-stricken Greek Ionian islands of Cephalonia, Zante and Ithaca today after Vice Admiral John H. Cassady, the fleet commander, told Premier Alexander Papagos "conditions are now well in hand."

DETROIT, Aug. 17 -- Walter P. Reuther, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, predicted today "there will be no secession problems" inside the C. I. O. over the no-raiding agreement with the American Federation of Labor.

A new appeal for funds to rebuild two of the city's major properties -- City Hall and the Manhattan Bridge -- was made yesterday by Public Works Commissioner Frederick H. Zurmuhlen. He warned the City Planning Commission that unless the work was started next year, both structures would face serious deterioration.

SALT LAKE CITY, Utah, Aug. 17 -- More intensive training for pharmacists in view of the increasing complexities of their field was urged today at pre-convention sessions of the American Pharmaceutical Association, the American College of Apothecaries and the American Institute of the History of Pharmacy.
CHICAGO, Aug. 17 -- A piling up of inventories of farm machinery because farmers are buying less underlies the recent wave of production cutbacks in the industry, manufacturers said here today.
