THE NEW YORK TIMES is to be complimented for the publication of the feature article and editorial on Aug. 10 on the New York City school plant. Your staff has done an excellent and objective reportorial treatment of the status of the school facilities of our city. It is a fine public service to have

LONDON, Aug. 17 -- Head-on collisions between galaxies billions of miles out in space may be the cause of the so-called radio Signals from the stars, according to a technical assessment of the possibilities in the current issue of Nature, the British science journal.
FRINTON-ON-SEA, England, Aug. 17 (Reuters) -- Mrs. Winifred Sanders heard the news that her husband had been pardoned just as she and her three daughters were going to bed tonight.

Edward J. Flynn was the last of the old-line political leaders in New York City, and a man of unusual qualities to be and remain in such a post so long. He ruled the Democratic party in the Bronx for three decades, was a powerful and sometimes dominant influence in his party's affairs in the state for much of that time, and became the Democratic National Chairman for the Roosevelt third-term campaign for the Presidency.

TOKYO, Wednesday, Aug. 19 -- The United Nations Command was expected today to renew its demand that the Communists return all Allied prisoners of the Korean war, some of whom, returning prisoners have said, disappeared just before the exchange operation began at Panmunjom a fortnight ago.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 18 -- The Soviet Union proposed today that the impending Far Eastern political conference be made up of Burma, Poland, Sweden, India, the Soviet Union and the principal belligerents in the Korean war, the United States, Britain, France, Communist China and North and South Korea.
OTTAWA, Aug. 18 (Canadian Press) -- Carry-over stocks of Canadian grains in Canada and the United States were the second highest on record on July 31, the Bureau of Statistics reported today.

Mayor Impellitteri opened his Brooklyn primary campaign headquarters at Fulton and Willoughby Streets yesterday with a defense of his vote to lease the city's transit system to the New York City Transit Authority; he also aimed a few scattering shots at all his rivals.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 18 (AP) -- The battle of Bear Creek ended abruptly today. A construction firm began removing its equipment from the property of a scrappy, 57-year-old grandmother who had impounded it.
PIERRE - ST. - MARTIN, France, Aug. 18 (AP) -- A winch-operated wire cable pulled a French scientific cave explorer back to the surface tonight after the deepest claimed descent inside the earth.

The on-the-spot study Attorney General Brownell has been making of the "wetback" situation raises hopes that Congress may be induced at its next session to give serious attention to this growing menace. For the "wetbacks," the illegal migratory laborers from Mexico, constitute a social, economic, political and moral problem of the first magnitude.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (UP) -- The refrigeration industry organized a committee tonight to find ways of eliminating refrigerator "death traps" for children, and a Virginia member of Congress promised to introduce legislation directed against abandoned ice boxes.
LONDON, Aug. 18 -- The British are beginning to discover that having a national economy considerably stronger than your neighbor's is not all gravy.

Patricia Powell, a pretty, blonde nurse, stepped from the Seaboard Air Line Railroad's Silver Meteor at Pennsylvania Station yesterday at 11:25 A. M., looking not a bit travelweary after twelve years, nine months and 2,000,000 miles of train travel.

Record sales of $286,382,170 were made by the Eastman Kodak Company and its consolidated United States subsidiaries in the twenty-four weeks ended on June 14, resulting in a 24 per cent increase in net earnings to $22,531,833.

The statistics on crime in New York City made public yesterday offer the opportunity for the first valid comparison with a preceding period since "reform" of the recording method instituted in mid-January, 1952. They show a serious increase in crimes of violence in the first six months of 1953 as compared with the like period of 1952: 22.1 per cent in murders, 42.5 per cent in manslaughter, and 10.7 per cent in felonious assault.

YELLOW SPRINGS, Ohio, Aug. 18 -- After staging and playing seven Shakespearean productions in seven weeks, the Antioch Area Theatre actors are settling down to a relaxing routine. During the next three weeks all they have to do is act all seven plays on a nightly repertory schedule.

BONN, Germany, Aug. 18 -- The latest Soviet note on Germany has had the unexpected result of forcing Chancellor Konrad Adenauer and his Social Democratic opponents to adopt a limited bipartisan foreign policy for the first time in four years.

INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 18 -- Gov. George N. Craig today ordered the State Police to "stand by" at telephone exchanges in five more Indiana cities to prevent recurrence of violence in the twenty-eight-day-old Indiana Bell Telephone strike.

Safety of pedestrians would not be enhanced by construction of bridges at street crossings where motor traffic is heavy, as proposed by John Dattels in his letter of Aug. 2. Pedestrians will not climb up and down some sixty steps to avoid going through vehicular traffic.

WOR-TV was blacked out yesterday by a sudden strike of 160 radio and television engineers but a telecast of the Brooklyn Dodgers-New York Giants baseball game at Ebbets Field last night was transferred to another channel.

FLORAL PARK, L. I., Aug, 18 -- An armed desperado today looted the Floral Park branch of the Franklin National Bank of $191,280 in cash after he had kidnapped the assistant manager at his home and forced him to drivel them to the bank.

MILWAUKEE, Aug., 18 -- As leaders were paired in the ninth round of the tournament for the open championship of the United States Chess Federation at the Eagles Club here, the number of players tied for first place was reduced today to three.

LONDON, Aug. 18 -- All Britain went to bed tonight with the exultant hope that for the first time in twenty years the Ashes -- the mythical trophy in the England-Australia cricket rivalry -- may return to England's soil.

BONN, Germany, Aug. 18 -- The political football of West Germany's coming elections is the project for a European army. In all probability most of the voters do not fully comprehend the implications of that audacious plan.
FORESTVILLE, Que., Aug 18 (AP) -- Quebec's raging forest fires roared on out of control for the eleventh day today, but a lull in the winds slowed its spread.
DETROIT, Aug. 18 -- The ninety-fifth convention of the International Typographical Union, A. F. L., dealt today with internal matters governing the printers craft.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 18 -- President Juan Peron officially disclosed today that the Argentine Government does not intend to launch its ambitious second five-year plan until next year. Speaking before the nation's banking officials, President Peron said two years of severe crisis had forced the Government to prolong the transition period between the first and second plans to two years instead of one.
Prices were generally higher on the New York commodity exchanges yesterday on moderate trading.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (AP) -- The Government announced today it has signed a contract with the Copper Range Company, Boston, calling for delivery to the Government of 7,965,000 pounds of refined copper by Dec. 31, 1955. The price will be 32 cents a pound.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- The text of the statement by the Department of the Interior of the Eisenhower Administration's policy on electric power follows:

The New York State Congress of Industrial Organizations has decided to throw its full strength behind the walkout of 800 employes of the two Hearn department stores here and to take over direction of the three-month-old strike, Louis Hollander, president of the State C. I. O., announced yesterday.
BONN, Aug. 18 -- West Germany's gold reserves and foreign currency holdings set another postwar record in the week ended Aug. 7, according to the latest report of the Bank Deutscher Laender.
There will be four opportunities to catch a glimpse of President Eisenhower today as he travels through Manhattan and Queens over the following routes, as indicated by the arrows on the map:
Nine municipal bond issues totaling $54,066,000 were sold at public bidding yesterday.
DETROIT, Aug. 18 (AP) -- Steve Gromek of the Tigers tamed his old Indian teammates with six hits and drove in the winning run as he beat them, 3 -- 2, tonight before 33,848 fans.
SYRACUSE, Aug. 18 -- The possibility of a long-term transit tie up faced this city today as a strike stopped Syracuse Transit Company buses for the second day.
Futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed yesterday with gains of 3 to 7 points in a comparatively quiet session.

Two partners holding a winning sweepstakes ticket for $28,500 in the name of "Strange Interlude" have parted company on the deal and now neither one is able to cash in on the Irish Grand National prize.

PEORIA, Ill., Aug. 18 -- The American Federation of Teachers, A. F. L., meeting here at its thirty-sixth annual convention, voted today to ban racial segregation in its 400 local unions throughout the nation.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- General of the Army Omar N. Bradley, who stepped down last Saturday as Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, today directly challenged the wisdom of the Administration's defense budget cuts.
BERLIN, Aug. 18 -- An East German refugee was killed by East German People's Policemen today on the frontier of West Berlin.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 18 -- Maurice Schumann, French Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs, nominated Geneva today as the site of the Far Eastern political conference to be held this fall.

CHICAGO, Aug. 18 (AP) -- Eddie Arcaro, an old hand at bringing in big stakes winners, will ride Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt's Native Dancer in the $100,000 added American Derby at Washington Park Saturday.

Sales of Kimberly-Clark Corporation, paper manufacturer, for its first fiscal quarter ended July 31 were $41,463,869, an increase of 8 per cent over the like period last year, stockholders were told at the annual meeting yesterday in Neenah, Wis. Earnings on common stock were reported as down from $1.04 to $1.02 per share.

Striking concrete truck drivers rejected yesterday an industry offer for a wage rise of 40 cents an hour, thus prolonging the walkout that has stopped most construction in New York and brought idleness to 100,000 building workers.

MONTREAL, Aug. 18 (Canadian Press) -- The pulp and paper industry spent $600,000,000 on plant construction, machinery and equipment and $360,000,000 on repairs and maintenance in the postwar years in an effort to bring supply into line with ever-increasing demand.

CHICAGO, Aug. 18 -- Grain showed a firmer tendency following initial declines, commission absorption being more active on the declines, while there was less selling pressure. Many wheat traders who took profits on the early upturn yesterday were reinstating their lines.

The gravest strike wave that has hit France since the middle Thirties has now led to a complete deadlock between the Government and the disaffected workers that could have serious repercussions on France, on Europe and on the whole North Atlantic community.
A young, wan-looking Army veteran, who lives with his wife and five children in a one-room Bronx basement apartment, was arrested yesterday, charged with abandoning his 2 1/3-year-old son.
EAST LANSING, Mich., Aug. 18 (AP) -- Michigan State College was sitting on a hot griddle today pondering the question: "What happened to that missing $5,400."
WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (AP) -- Some national banks have liberalized personal loan policies "beyond the point of prudence," according to Ray H. Gidney, Controller of the Currency.

TWENTY-ONE clubs have entered squads for the eleventh annual United States Atlantic Tuna Tournament to be held off Point Judith at Narragansett, R. I., next week. The New York A. C. Anglers, the Sheepshead Bay Tuna Club and the Brielle (N. J.) Marlin and Tuna Club, each with two victories in the ten tournaments previously held, top the lists.

PARIS, Aug. 18 -- An overwhelming majority of the striking French workers defied the ultimatum Premier Joseph Laniel gave to them last night and went on with their strikes in both public services and private industry today.

QUIMPER, France, Aug. 18 -- Brittany, like other provinces of France, has been virtually isolated for nineteen days by the nationwide railway postal and telephone strike but, like Normandy, the Riviera and the Basque Coast, it nevertheless is still playing summer host to tens of thousands of French and foreign tourists.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 18 (AP) -- Robin Roberts, the major league pitcher with the most victories, trudged out of the bullpen in the seventh inning tonight to save a shutout for Steve Ridzik as the Phillies squeaked by the Pirates, 1 -- 0.
DUBLIN, Aug. 18 -- Edward J. Flynn, Democratic National Committeeman and Bronx County leader in New York, died here early today in St Vincent's Hospital. He was 61 years old.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- The new law to admit 214,000 refugees to this coutnry in the next three years is expected to require considerable legal interpretation and operational groundwork before any immigrants arrive under its provisions in New York or any other ports of entry.

The slump in stock prices yesterday caught most of the technicians in Wall Street unawares. There had been nothing in the overnight news to suggest that "squally" weather was ahead for the bulls. In fact, the opening was quiet with prices mostly unchanged, and for a while it looked as if the list might push ahead smartly.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- Senator Harry F. Byrd, Democrat of Virginia, today hailed the recent Congressional rejection of an Administration request for a higher national debt ceiling as a "milestone" in preserving the country's solvency.

Apparently the statement of four respected editors that Senator McCarthy's action in the Wechsler case constituted "a peril to American freedom" has got under the Senator's none-too-tender skin. The four were part of an eleven-man panel named by the American Society of Newspaper Editors to determine whether Mr. McCarthy's questioning last spring of James A. Wechsler, editor of The New York Post, involved a threat to freedom of the press.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 18 -- A demand for a 6 per cent wage increase in all ratings, with a similar increase in overtime and penalty pay has been laid before the Pacific Maritime Association by the Sailors Union of the Pacific A. F. L., in anticipation of an overhauling of the coastwise contract on Sept. 30.

As reported in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Aug. 12, the Prime Minister of South Africa, Dr. Malan, has again raised the question of the interrelation of problems in all African territories. He suggests the need for broad consultation to evolve "an all-Africa policy," based on "an Africa charter." These are Dr. Malan's formulations, and they are significant in their implications.

A carefree Yankee romp over the Senators developed into a hideous nightmare for Casey Stengel and his Bombers last night when Washington, teeing off on a procession of relief pitchers, came up with seven runs in the ninth inning to capture a 10-8 decision.

ROANOKE, Va., Aug. 18 -- Twelve workshop committees, composed of 110 city planning experts from fifty municipalities in fourteen Southern States, initiated developmental studies today to advance urban expansion programs for an area that is experiencing swift changes in population and economic patterns.

Following the lead given in Premier Georgi M. Malenkov's speech ten days ago, the Soviet press has made the Soviet consumer and his needs its leading propaganda theme in a thunderous campaign. An important part of this is the presentation of Premier Malenkov as the single figure behind the effort -- at least on paper -- to raise living standards.

Plans to impose new traffic regulations on the city's pedestrians next year, provided funds are made available for 200 more neon signs to help separate those who walk from those who ride at busy intersections, were reported yesterday by Traffic Commissioner T. T. Wiley.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Aug. 18 -- Embarassment has arisen here over comments by visiting United States newspaper men on the continued existence of press censorship. Visitors brought here as guests of the Government say they were promised that the censorship would be lifted.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (AP) -- Thousands of veterans, who have been promised free dental treatment by the Veterans Administration, aren't going to get it.

Removal of the asphalt pavement on Columbia University's newly acquired block of 116th Street between Broadway and Amsterdam Avenue was begun yesterday as the first step in the beautification of the street for the university's bicentennial celebration next year.
Although the children's record business is vast and lively, musically minded parents know that recordings of classical music appropriate for the young are not always easy to find.

NEW YORK is a trembling city. It quivers most when subway, bus, elevated railroad and motor traffic picks up in morning and evening rush hours. Heavy milk trains make its rocky underpinning jig before dawn. Earthquakes clear across the world can titillate it.

Only 138 pints of blood were donated on Monday to the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program. Today, with four bloodmobiles out and with the functioning of the Bronx center at St. Barnabas Hospital, 183d Street and Third Avenue, and the downtown center at Federal Hall Museum, Wall and Nassau Streets, both of which are open only on Wednesdays, it is expected that the program wil ldo much better.

RABAT, Morocco, Aug. 18 (AP) -- French and United States sources said today that, contrary to published reports, the Sultan of Morocco had not signed French decrees aimed at stripping him of his powers and reforming the Government.

A formula under which shippers of export cargo through this port would not have to pay extra handling charges on most large units of freight was overwhelmingly, defeated yesterday by the steamship lines.

The Curtiss-Wright Corporation achieved the highest peacetime sales and earnings for any initial half year period in the first six months this year, according to the semi-annual report issued yesterday.

VANDALIA, Ohio, Aug. 18 (AP) -- Fred D. Waldock Jr., 23-year-old Ohio State law student from Sandusky, Ohio, today outshot 705 of the country's finest gun pointers to win the North American clay target championship.

Removal of "Communist traitors" from police ranks and elimination of the "mess" that existed when Commissioner George P. Monaghan took office have restored public confidence in the department, Mayor Impellitteri declared yesterday at Police Academy graduation exercises.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (AP) -- The truce in Korea has had "little immediate effect" on the nation's booming business, the Department of Commerce said today.

CANTON, N. Y., Aug. 18 -- The lack of adequate community facilities to cope with the rise in juvenile delinquency has created a nation-wide need for policemen specially trained to deal with socially and emotionally maladjusted children, a former New York City police officer, said here today.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Aug. 18 -- Indonesia's three-day celebration of the eighth anniversary of the proclamation of her independence by the national government set up by the Japanese culminated today in a red-flagged procession through the heart of Jakarta by about 50,000 Communists and their sympathizers.

MONTCLAIR, N. J., Aug. 18 -- Mrs. Philip Cudone of the home club and Betty Park of Glen Ridge took the lead at the end of the first round of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's Scotch foursome tournament at the Montclair Club today.

The Ohio Edison Company and its subsidiary, the Pennsylvania Power Company, reported yesterday a net income of $18,087,528 in the twelve months to July 31. This is equal to $3.08 a share on the average number of shares during the period, and compares with $14,760,324, or $2.73 a share, in the previous year.

The Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday adjourned its hearings into alleged violation of the securities law by Adolf Gobel, Inc., Union, N. J., meat packing concern, to Aug. 31, to give the company's attorney time to prepare a cross-examination of the first witness, Ruben D. Gruber.

Three new films will open today at first-run theatres. "The Sword and the Rose," Walt Disney's romantic adventure produced by Perce Pearce and filmed in Technicolor in Britain with an all-British cast headed by Richard Todd and Glynis Johns, is at the Rivoli. Kenneth Annakin directed from a screen play by Lawrence E. Watkin.

General Mills, Inc., is pressing an aggressive research program to maintain its products in the market and develop new products in foods, chemicals and other non-food lines, Harry A. Bullis, chairman, said at the annual meeting yesterday in Wilmington, Del. He noted that flour accounted for 74 per cent of the company's sales in 1938, while in 1952 it was only 52 per cent.

Public offering of $12,000,000 of General Telephone Corporation's common stock is to be made today. Paine, Webber, Jackson Curtis, Mitchum, Tulley Co. and Stone Webster Securities Corporation jointly head a group underwriting the offering of 300,000 shares of $20 par value common, priced at $39.50 a share.

Two members of the Baruch family will be honored today at the dedication ceremonies for Baruch Houses, on the lower East Side, and of a bronze bust at the end of the near-by playground. One of these Baruchs who did so much for our city was Dr. Simon Baruch, a onetime Confederate surgeon, who practiced medicine and good citizenship here from 1881 until his death, in 1921.

LONDON, Aug. 18 -- The stock markets were confident today, industrial shares in particular making many fresh gains despite some profit taking. Textiles led the way, followed by building material issues and the stores group. However, United States issues were dull on overnight advices from Wall Street.

KEARNY, N. J., Aug. 18 --Production was halted tonight at the gas and coke plant of the Koppers Company, Inc., here when 800 employes walked off their jobs for higher wages. The plant operates 235 chemical recovery ovens that produce consumer and industrial coke principally for New Jersey customers.

JERSEY CITY, Aug. 18 -- An initial step toward construction of a $100,000,000 toll link between the Holland Tunnel here and the New Jersey Turnpike at the Newark Airport interchange was taken today when plans for the traffic artery were explained at a public hearing to municipal and county officials and representatives of business, industry and other public transportation facilities.
CHICAGO, Aug. 18 (AP) -- The White Sox gained a game and a half on the leading Yankees tonight as Virgil Trucks and Sandy Consuegra pitched a double victory over the Browns, 3 -- 2 and 2 --1.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 18 -- Two Hungarian-born conductors are among six musicians announced today as leaders of the San Francisco Symphony during the 1953-54 season, opening on Nov. 12.

ONE of the supposedly impossible labors assigned to Hercules was the cleansing of the Augean Stables. The National Collegiate Athletic Association is confronted with a task of equally herculean proportions in its efforts to cleanse the unsanitary, unsavory mess that is our intercollegiate sports structure. It is smeared with recruiting, subsidization, sharp practice, semi-professionalism, outright professionalism and hypocrisy.
JERSEY CITY, Aug. 18 -- This city's administration became the subject of a third investigation today, but this time the city fathers will investigate their own and past administrations.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (UP) -- Secretary of Agriculture Ezra Taft Benson said today that there would be no export subsidies on the 1953 cotton crop. He issued his statement in response to "many inquiries" on the possibility of a subsidy.

VIENNA, Aug. 18 -- The Ballhaus-platz, the historic Austrian Chancellery where Metternich worked, where Dollfuss died, where Schuschnigg vainly defied Hitler, is now presided over by Chancellor Julius Raab, a simple, taciturn, publicity-shy man, unknown outside of Austria until his election last spring, but who faces dilemmas as grave for his country as the fateful choices made by his famous predecessors.

Borough President Robert F. Wagner Jr. of Manhattan, a candidate for the Democratic Mayoral nomination in the Sept. 15 primary, called yesterday for a revision of the city's policy for dealing with its own employes and accused Mayor Impellitteri, his chief rival, with mishandling the city's employe relations program.

MAYS LANDING, N. J., Aug. 18 (AP) -- The Cedar Farm's Halter made it two straight victories at the Atlantic City race course when he captured the featured $5,000 Defense Bond Purse today before a record week-day crowd of 22,717. Backed down to 9-5 favoritism, Halter has turned back Arthur H. Bowen's Sweet Vermouth by a head.

Exact recipes plus production-line methods simplify the making of sandwiches in quantity. Just such a task is apt to be demanded of the home cook during this, the season for picnics. Today's column, therefore, is devoted to formulas for a variety of popular fillings.

Mayor Impellitteri will honor Richard Rodgers and Oscar Hammerstein 2d for "their long and distinguished career and their valuable contribution to our city" by designating Aug. 31 to Sept. 6 as "Rodgers and Hammerstein Week."

In the battle between two of the world's most heavily advertised commodities -- American soaps and detergents -- the detergents seem to be winning. Figures issued yesterday by the Association of American Soap and Glycerine Produceers, Inc., show sales for the first six months of the year at $365,163,000 for both, an increase of 7 per cent over the same period last year.
HELSINKI, Finland, Aug. 18 (AP) -- A small band of American track and field athletes won five of the eight events they competed in at the Olympic Stadium tonight.

HOBOKEN, N. J., Aug. 18 -- Harold John Adonis, smiling but seemingly nervous, returned voluntarily from the Netherlands today to face charges of accepting $228,000 in protection money from syndicate gamblers in Bergen County, N. J., and a Federal indictment accusing him of income tax evasion. Thus, he fulfilled a promise of many months.

Billy Loes and Allan Worthington started for the Dodgers and Giants last night at Ebbets Field. Three hours and thirty-one minutes and thirteen innings later -- long after both had left the scene -- Gil Hodges drove home Pee Wee Reese from third after a fly to right and the flag-bound Brooks gained a 4-3 victory over the outfit that Chuck Dressen recently pronounced "dead."

VIENNA, Aug. 18 -- Edgar Sanders saw his wife and three daughters for the first time in nearly four years today. Mr. Sanders, a former British officer and executive of the Standard Electric Company, a subsidiary of the International Telephone and Telegraph Company, was pardoned last night by the Hungarian Government after serving three years and six months on charges of espionage and sabotage.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- An electric power policy that places primary responsibility for supplying local power needs in local hands was laid down today by the Eisenhower Administration.

BAGHDAD, Iraq, Aug. 18 -- The Shah made a hasty unannounced departure from Baghdad by air today for Rome. He and his party boarded a British Overseas Airways Corporation plane at 7 A. M., less than forty-eight hours after their arrival in the Iraqi capital Sunday.

VIENNA, Aug. 14 -- When the Rumanian Government lifted the Iron Curtain two weeks ago to permit four United States newspaper men to enter the country for the first time in five years, to report on the World Festival of Youth and Students for Peace and Friendship, there was speculation about its motives.

RANDALL JARRELL, poet, professor of English and pugnacious critic, feels about modern poetry and those who ignore it much the same as medieval crusaders felt about Christianity and the infidels. He is shocked and outraged by those who do not share his faith. In theory he would like to convert them; but in practice he would much rather engage them in battle.
LONDON, Aug. 18 -- For the first time since June 24, Sir Winston Churchill presided at a Cabinet meeting at 10 Downing Street today.

LONDON, Aug. 18 (AP) -- Delegates to the thirty-nine-nation International Sugar Conference appeared confident tonight for the first time that an over-all marketing control agreement would finally emerge from their stormy month-long meeting.

School is not in session at the moment, and for some this is the time for carefree vacation. But not for all, alas; not for all. There were those who loitered through the winter months, who emulated the grasshopper rather than the ant; and these are now busily tutoring.

THE baseball commentary and interview program presented immediately before and after the telecasts of baseball games has become a fixture in television, but its level of entertainment lies waiting for improvement. Pre-and post-game commentators have come and gone, just like managers of losing clubs, but a viewer still must "wait until next year" for the ideal show.

FREEDOM VILLAGE, Korea, Aug. 18 -- A sandy-haired corporal came back to the free world today and from the sparkle in his blue eyes, his ready grin and effervescent humor it was apparent twenty-two months in a Communist prison camp had not broken his spirit.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (UP) -- Employes of the Foreign Operations Administration began taking intelligence tests today to determine whether they were smart enough to continue working for the Government.

VIENNA, Aug. 18 -- A survey of alcoholism in the leading countries of Europe and the Americas during the past three years under the auspices of the World Health Organization has revealed that the causes of alcoholism vary with different countries, each type requiring a specific approach.
PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Aug. 18 -- The young skippers of Long Island Sound took command today as a fleet of 136 boats competed in the start of Manhasset Bay Race Week.
Dr. Israel Goldstein, president of the American Jewish Congress, said yesterday that "Jews in all lands owe their political allegiance only to the countries of their citizenships."

BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 18 (AP) -- All three girls who tied for the medal were among the eight who gained quarter-final berths today in the fifth annual national girls' junior golf championship at The Country Club.

The change in the "Talent Scouts" format on Monday night over the C. B. S. television and radio networks resulted from a last-minute decision by Arthur Godfrey to cancel the acts he had watched in a dress rehearsal. He said they were not up to standard and singers from his other programs were substituted.
BOSTON, Aug. 18 (UP) -- Back-to-back doubles by Billy Goodman and Jim Piersall in the third inning capped a 2-1 Red Sox victory over the Athletics tonight before 28,024 Fenway Park fans.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- Edward M. Rothschild, an employe of the Government Printing Office, refused to tell the Senate's Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations today whether he was a Communist, whether he had stolen a secret code from the printing office or whether he had been engaged in espionage against the United States as late as Aug. 9.

The nineteen-story and penthouse building with 100 apartments at 565 West End Avenue has been sold by Jacob Goodman Co. to Samuel Edelman, who recently acquired the property at 530 West End Avenue. The property, on a plot 100 by 100 feet at the corner of Eighty-seventh Street, is assessed at $1,025,000.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Aug 18 -- With considerable fanfare the Government of Thailand presented today its long awaited and controversial land reform bill to its supporters in the National Assembly. The bill, which is close to the heart of Premier Pibul Songgram, has been opposed by the landlords, including some National Assemblymen.

A residential development is planned in Rye, N. Y., by the Chanin Organization, which has purchased a tract of 170 acres adjoining the Blind Brook Country Club and the Hutchinson River Parkway at the Connecticut boundary.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 18 -- Joe W. Brown's Bobby Brocato, the sixth choice in the line-up of seven 2-year-olds, and the Brae Burn Farm's War Piper, the 7-to-10 favorite, hooked up at the top of the stretch and stayed hooked for the rest of the way in the $13,825 Sanford Stakes today. The sixth choice won the duel.
The Nippon Yusen Kaisha ship Hikawa Maru will leave Seattle on Monday for the first Japanese-flag passenger sailing from this country since the end of World War II.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Aug. 18 (AP) -- Robert L. Lee, a staff sergeant at the Miami Marine Base, died tonight a few minutes after he was hit under the heart in the first round of a four-round preliminary fight tonight at the Miami Beach auditorium.
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 18 (UP) -- Rookie Harry Elliott's two-run double in the fifth inning helped the Cardinals to a 5-1 victory over the Cubs tonight.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 18 -- Donald O'Connor, who is ill, has been replaced at Paramount in the Bing Crosby-Irving Berlin musical, "White Christmas," by Danny Kaye.
If anybody is looking for a place to start a country weekly newspaper, there is a wide-open opportunity at North Pole, Alaska.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Aug. 18 -- Malayans on Cape Province are reported to be willing to barter their century-old franchise for the safety of their mosques.

The death of Edward J. Flynn, long-time Bronx Democratic leader, injected a new element of uncertainty into the Democratic primary campaign yesterday. It likewise opened the door to a new battle between New Dealish and conservative factions for domination of the party organization in the state.

HOLYOKE, Mass., Aug. 18 -- Henry H. Noel, 71 years old, a Holyoke alderman and a Republican party leader in western Massachusetts, was shot and killed today by a masked intruder who entered his home about 2:30 A. M. Mrs. Noel, 67, was a witness.
William Heller, Inc., manufacturer of jersey fabrics, will establish a production unit in Paris to meet the growing demand for lightweight fabrics by French designers, it was announced yesterday.

LONDON, Aug. 18 -- Harold E. Talbott, United States Secretary of the Air Force, said here today that he foresaw continued expansion rather than curtailment of the activities of the United States Air Force in Europe.

The United States Golf Association yesterday disclosed that it had received 1,300 entries, the second highest total in the history of the event, for its fifty-third amateur championship, which will be held at Oklahoma City from Sept. 14 to 19.

Interhandel, which has a 90 per cent stock interest in General Aniline and Film Corporation, is making a renewed effort to bring about a settlement with the Alien Property Custodian, who has been operating the property since 1942.

Extensive damage was caused yesterday to St. Monica's Roman Catholic Church, 409 East Seventy-ninth Street, just east of First Avenue, by a fire that started on its roof shortly before noon. The roof was destroyed, but the firemen succeeded in keeping the blaze confined to the upper part of the edifice, which is six stories high.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- Dave Beck, president of the Teamsters Union, was elected a vice president of the American Federation of Labor over the objections of George Meany, president, and several others, and observers see a fresh struggle for power shaping up in the federation.

ROME, Aug. 18 -- Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi of Iran and his wife, Queen Soraya, who abandoned their capital last Sunday after a reported unsuccessful attempt to oust Premier Mohammed Mossadegh, arrived in Rome by commercial plane from Baghdad early this afternoon.

PARIS, Aug. 18 -- Gen. Augustin Guillaume, Resident General in Morocco, conferred today with authorities here on the military and political actions to be taken to keep order in Morocco and to prevent strife between the opposing factions backing the Sultan and the Berber Pasha of Marrakesh.

Aubrey Menen, author of four novels, will have a work of non-fiction published by Scribners on Monday, entitled "Dead Man in the Silver Market." In part, the book is a memoir and an explanation of the shaping of the author's philosophy.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 18 -- With his injured knee encased in a heavy-laced bandage and supported by steel braces, Victor Seixas played his opening match in the National doubles tennis Championship today, paired with Tony Trabert of Cincinnati.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- A responsible Government source confirmed today the existence of a secret understanding with the Chinese Nationalist Government under which its troops based on Formosa would not undertake intensified military operations against the Chinese Communists without prior consultation with United States military authorities, who are still responsible for the defense of the island.

TEHERAN, Iran, Aug. 18 -- Policemen and soldiers swung into action tonight against rioting Tudeh (Communist) partisans and Nationalist extremists. The troops appeared to be in a frenzy as they smashed into the rioters with clubbed rifles and nightsticks, and hurled tear-gas bombs.

SCRANTON, Pa., Aug. 18 -- Sixteen coal cars slipped their brakes early today in the Carbondale yard of the Delaware and Hudson Railroad, twelve miles north of here, ran to Yatesville, in Luzerne County, a distance of twenty-seven and a half miles, traveling at sixty miles an hour at times.
KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Aug. 18 (AP) -- The college athletic world paid tribute tonight to Gen. Bob Neyland, Tennessee's retiring football coach, as a gridiron master with few peers.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 18 -- In an unusually strained atmosphere, the Committee on Information from Non-Self-governing Territories opened its fourth session today with one member nation's seat vacant and expressions of dissatisfaction from other delegates about the functions of the panel.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 18 (UP) -- Ed Mathews hit his thirty-eighth homer of the season to equal the highest total ever achieved by a member of the Braves tonight and pace Milwaukee to an 8-2 victory over the Redlegs.

BLED, Yugoslavia, Aug. 18 -- Communist China should be admitted to the United Nations, Clement Attlee, leader of the British Labor party and former Prime Minister, declared today. He said admission to the United Nations was not a privilege but a recognition of fact.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 18 (AP) -- Wanted: One baseball park of major league caliber for the Browns. That was the substance today of a sports page commotion over the possible transfer of the St. Louis club of the American League.
LONDON, Aug. 18 (Reuters) -- British exports in the first half of 1953 improved by 5 per cent in volume and average 209,000,000 sterling ($585,200,000) a month, the Ministry of Trade announced today.

WINSTON-SALEM, N. C., Aug. 18 (AP) -- A charitable and educational foundation, tentatively valued at $12,000,000, will be established under the terms of the will of Mrs. Mary Reynolds Babcock, who died July 17 in New York. She was one of two daughters of R. J. Reynolds, founder of the R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company.

NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 18 -- The Prime Ministers of India and Pakistan held their third private meeting today rooking to a solution of the dispute over Kashmir for the third successive day. Spokesman continued to offer little information on the outcome of the discussions.

MONTREAL, Aug. 18 (Canadian Press) -- Lack of buying of Canadian grains by overseas countries is reported to have plugged most grain elevators from Fort William, Ont., to the Atlantic Seaboard. One shipper said today that he had not seen anything like it in more than twenty years.

EDINBURGH, Scotland, Aug. 18 -- The Eighth International Congress on Home Economics at its closing session here today sounded the keynote of five days of discussion by spotlighting the housewife's task in the home and defining her mission.
DENVER, Aug. 18 (AP) -- President Eisenhower endorsed today an American Red Cross appeal for funds to help relieve distressed victims of the recent earthquake in Greece.

DENVER, Aug. 18 -- Clarence E. Manion, South Bend lawyer, and former dean of the Law School at the University of Notre Dame, was appointed by President Eisenhower today to be chairman of the new Commission on Intergovernmental Relationships.

With an eye to next month's school and college openings and the ever-growing career girl market, B. Altman, Saks-34th St., Martin's and Wanamaker's held fashion shows for the press and public this week.
A report emphasizing the high rank of the Scandinavian market in world trade was released yesterday by the National Foreign Trade Council.

Rumors of the formation of a new labor federation built around the carpenters, miners, steelworkers and teamsters' unions seem to have little support in fact. Nevertheless, the circumstance under which the speculation goes on Points up an important question, namely: Can union members be handled by their leaders like sheep, transferred from one federation to another at the will of the reigning labor chieftain?

NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 18 -- India's advance team that will serve on the Neutral Nations Repatriation Commission provided by the Korean armistice returned from Tokyo today after an eleven- day tour of the United Nations and Communist commands.

A sharp increase in murder and manslaughter in New York City in the first six months of this year, as compared with a like period in 1952, was reported yesterday by Police Commissioner George P. Monaghan.

There are five important trends in fall coat fashions. These are the emphasis on short er lengths, the importance of a new width and breadth in shoulders, return of the fitted silhouette, great popularity of the coat of straight fullness and revival of fur trims.

HARLINGEN, N. J., Aug. 18 -- The residents of Montgomery Township voted today to retain their long-standing committee form of government, in effect giving a vote of confidence to township officials who have indicated that they intended to rezone this residential area to make way for a quarry and granule-making plant.

Sidney Kingsley reported yesterday that his latest play, a comedy temporarily known as "Satyr Dance," should come along in the fall or winter. Mr. Kingsley's sister, May Kirshner, who gained valuable experience in the presentation of two of his plays, "Detective Story" and "Darkness at Noon," will serve as sponsor of the new work, dealing with sex and requiring a company of seven (four men and three women).

The newest steam-electric generating power plant in the seven-state American Gas and Electric Company system, the Kanawha River Plant on the Kanawha River at Glasgow, W. Va., began delivering its 200,000 kilowatts yesterday. The $46,000,000 plant is owned and operated by the Appalachian Electric Power Company, a major A. G. E. subsidiary.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- Charles E. Wilson, the Secretary of Defense, opened a sweeping overhaul of the fiscal procedures of the entire military establishment today with an eye toward making military commanders more directly responsible for the billions they spend each year.

Undaunted by the fact that the event heralded the close of the vacation season and the approach of the school year, 300 youngsters from Board of Education summer playgrounds in Manhattan presented their annual song and dance festival yesterday and demonstrated that school could be fun -- at least in the summertime.

The Chesapeake and Ohio Railway is trying a new method to get its passenger traffic salesmen better acquainted with their competititors. The railroad has called a staff meeting of its passenger traffic salesmen at Point Comfort, Va., and the travel representatives were told yesterday to start traveling there by any means except the C. O.'s own passenger trains.

The largest weekday crowd of the season at Ebbets Field, 20,559 paid and 7,861 Knothole Club kids and servicemen, yesterday saw the Dodgers rally in the eighth inning to beat the Giants, 7 -- 5, and run their winning streak to twelve games.

Buying of leather for use in manufacturing shoes and other products was described as good at the second and closing session yesterday of the annual trade show of the leather industry at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

The New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program received on Tuesday its biggest donation for this month, 661 pints, in contrast to 138 on Monday. However, the total for this month through Tuesday was 3,991, against 4,649 for the same period in August, 1952.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 19 -- The first face-to-face negotiations in the parking dispute between the United Nations and New York City officials took place here today. The informal communique issued after the meeting was that all had gone pleasantly and that another session would be held next week.
Three hundred New Yorkers who had enlisted for membership in "New York City's Tercentennial Marine Company" received a ceremonious induction into the Marine Corps yesterday noon at City Hall Plaza.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 19 (AP) -- Frank Thomas' eighteenth home run of the year put the Pirates ahead and Eddie O'Brien's single pushed across the insurance run in the eighth inning tonight as Pittsburgh defeated Curt Simmons and the Phillies, 5 -- 3.
MUNSAN, Korea, Thursday, Aug. 20 (AP) -- The United Nations Command's official list of United States prisoners of war freed in today's armistice exchange:
Spokesmen for four city agencies appeared yesterday before the City Planning Commission to ask for a total of $26,615,519 to be allocated to them in 1954 for capital projects.

WASHINGTON, Thursday, Aug. 20 -- The United States Atomic Energy Commission announced early today that the Soviet Union had conducted an atomic test Aug. 12 and that subsequent information showed it involved both fis sion and thermonuclear reactions.

DETROIT, Aug. 19 -- Delegates to the ninety-fifth convention of the International Typographical Union, A. F. L., voted virtually unlimited control over union funds today to the union's Executive Council.
MOSCOW, Thursday, Aug. 20 -- The Soviet Government announced today that it had carried out an experimental explosion of a hydrogen bomb "within the last few days."

The Moore - McCormack liner Brazil, one of the three largest passenger vessels in service between this country and the East Coast of South America, has been withdrawn from that run for the remainder of this year, the line announced here yesterday.

GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 19 -- A 16-year-old Greenwich High School student on the way to a dance in neighboring Stamford last night wound up early today in Providence, R. I., 140 miles off his destination, the kidnap victim of three escaped mental patients.

CORVALLIS, Ore., Aug. 19 -- True D. Morse, Under Secretary of Agriculture, foresaw today serious trouble ahead for some farm programs and called for a rise in the level of economic literacy "so that the people will not ask their Congressmen for things which are impossible of fulfillment or impractical."

BAGHDAD, Iraq, Aug. 19 -- Broadcasts from Teheran indicated today that the dead in the Iranian revolution included Foreign Minister Hossein Fatemi, who was "torn to pieces" in the office of his newspaper Bakhtar-e-Emruz.

Two hundred and fifty Jewish communal leaders formulated plans yesterday at the Roosevelt Hotel for celebration of the 3,000th anniversary of Jerusalem at Madison Square Garden on Oct. 20. The celebration will be under the auspices of the State of Israel Bond Organization.

One hundred and ninety-nine documentary shorts, full-length documentaries and children's films, representing thirty-four countries, have been exhibited for judging at the Venice Film Festival, Italian Film Export announced yesterday.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Aug. 19 (AP) -- Kimberly Kid, star of the All-wood Stables of Far Hills, N. J., gained revenge today for his defeat in last week's Hambletonian by beating most of the same horses in the Grand Circuit Review Futurity 3-year-old trot.

Clement V. Conole, president of the Hearn department stores, yesterday accused Louis Hollander, state president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, of trying to intimidate George Bott, general counsel of the National Labor Relations Board.

Though prompted by the highest motives, the leniency shown by Federal Judge Sidney Sugarman in the case of Thomas May, a racketeering pier loader who pleaded guilty to extortion, will discourage those who have been seeking to eradicate racketeering from the Port of New York. The freeing of May can only lead others similarly situated to believe that they too can "beat the rap."
LONDON, Aug. 19 -- After twenty years of defeat, England won today what amounts to the world championship in her own national sport -- cricket -- by defeating her Commonwealth offspring, Australia.

Establishment of local promotion campaigns to explain the meaning of VHF (very high frequency), UHF (ultra high frequency) and certain other television words and phrases to the public was suggested yesterday by Joseph J. Weed, president of Weed Television, station representatives,

NORWALK, Conn., Aug. 19 -- Ten persons were arrested here today as the Hat Corporation of America moved two truckloads of finished hats through the picket lines of striking members of the United Hat, Cap and Millinery Workers, A. F. L., to the South Norwalk railroad station.

As a first step in its major expansion program, D. A. Schulte, Inc., signed a contract yesterday to purchase the outstanding capital stock of the Stineway Drug Company, which operates twenty-two drug stores in Chicago and supplies merchandise to fourteen franchised Stineway System stores.

VANDALIA, Ohio, Aug. 19 (AP) -- Illinois shooters dominated the Fifty-fourth Grand American trapshoot today, winning three of five titles as 960 of North America's outstanding competitors decided class championships.
LONDON, Aug. 19 -- British sources indicated today a mixed optimism about the probable effect of the coup in Iran on Teheran's relations with the Western powers.
DETROIT, Aug. 19 (AP) -- The Tigers defeated-Early Wynn for the first time in three years, gaining a 4-2 victory over the Indians today before 8,053 fans.
Following are the texts of the addresses by President Eisenhower, Bernard M. Baruch and Robert Moses, city construction coordinator, at yesterday's dedication of Baruch Houses:
NEWARK, Aug. 19 -- The 2,000,000-subscriber Hospital Service Plan of New Jersey (Blue Cross) announced today two new contracts at substantially increased rates.
BOSTON, Aug. 19 -- Internal Revenue officials estimated today that they had collected $24 for every $1 invested in last month's door-to-door canvass in New England in search of delinquent taxpayers.

The eight massive concrete boxes that will serve as the foundation of the main Thruway span between South Nyack and Tarrytown will be floated into place and installed within six weeks, according to a report submitted yesterday to the Thruway Authority by the consulting engineers, Madigan-Hyland.

ROME, Aug. 19 -- In a program speech in which he presented his step-gap Government to Parliament today Giuseppa Pella, the new Christian Democratic Premier, said it intended to remain unswervingly faithful to the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and to the principle of European unity.

PARIS, Aug. 19 -- The French Cabinet, unable to reach an agreement on a policy for dealing with the dispute between the Sultan of Morocco and the Pasha of Marrakech, the dispatched Gen. Augustin Guillaume, the Resident General, to Morocco today to try to prevent an armed conflict and to protect the Sultan and French residents until the French course has been determined.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 19 -- Following are excerpts from a speech in the Political and Security Committee of the United Nations General Assembly today by Andrei Y. Vishinsky, Soviet representative, and the text of the reply by Henry Cabot Lodge Jr., United States representative:

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 19 -- Stanford University physicists reported today a doubling to 30,000,000 watts of the strength of the klystron, which already had been catalogued as the most powerful vacuum tube known to the Western World.

On reading your editorial of Aug. 13, "They Shall Not Pass," I first thought that you were perturbed by the amendments to the New York law in relation to motor vehicles which permit an overtaking vehicle to pass on the right a car making a left-hand turn, or traveling in the left-hand lane on a four-lane road with no parking, or traveling in the left-hand lane on a two-lane one-way unobstructed road.

FRESH water game fishing, with some exceptions, isn't very "hot" in the New York-New Jersey area at the moment. So, if you're planning such a trip, it would be wise to consult your sporting goods store expert. These fellows keep a close check and know the "spots."

Plans for the largest single new financing operation in corporate history were announced yesterday by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, the world's largest communications enterprise. Directors of the company authorized a new convertible debenture issue aggregating $625,000,000 and asked stockholders to approve the financing at a special meeting on Oct. 14.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (AP) -- An allocation to the forty-eight states of $16,084,516 in Federal aid funds for wildlife and sport fishery restoration and development project was announced today by Secretary of the Interior McKay.

The International Longshoremen's Association, A. F. L., and some of its units and officials have been cited for secondary boycotting, a violation of the Taft-Hartley Law, in a recommended decision by a National Labor Relations Board trial examiner, it became known yesterday.

Iran is poor in many ways but she is singularly rich in drama. The figures come and go on her stage as they play their tragic roles. Exile, imprisonment and death are the themes, and the audience -- Western democrats and Russian Communists -- are more than interested spectators.

ROANOKE, Va., Aug. 19 -- Reports and recommendations supporting a region-wide effort to coordinate education, research and legislative aid in the field of city planning were submitted today by 110 urban development experts from fourteen southern states.

An increase of almost 6 per cent in transportation costs in the last two years, this time in the operation of passenger cars, was reported yesterday by the American Automobile Association, through the Automobile Club of New York, after a country-wide survey.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 19 -- Henry Cabot Lodge Jr., United States representative accused the Soviet Union today of proposing to give the Republic of Korea a "second-class seat" at the Far Eastern peace conference and to exclude entirely thirteen of the sixteen members of the United Nations that contributed armed forces to defend the republic.

A major custom smelter which had been quoting copper at 28 1/2 cents a pound since Aug. 4 advanced the price by 1/2-cent yesterday, to 29 cents. Large mine producers continued to quote 30 cents, their price since late last March.

The Stein Blaine Building, a six-story-and-penthouse structure on lot 32 by 100 feet at 13 West Fifty-seventh Street, near Fifth Avenue, has been purchased by Romley Mason, Inc., Jerome Hoffman, president, from Stein Blaine, Inc., ladies' apparel, who leased back the store, basement and second floor for fifteen years at rentals aggregating more than $500,000.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- The appointment of Edward F. Hamm Jr. as the first managing director of the Interstate Commerce Commission was announced today by the commission.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 19 -- A match between the international lawn tennis clubs of Australia and the United States will be held Thursday, Aug. 27, on the turf of the Westchester Country Club at Rye, N. Y.

LONDON, Aug. 19 -- The ordinary shares of Anglo-Iranian Oil Company rose sharply on the stock market here today on news from Iran of the overthrow of the Mossadegh Government. Shares rose By 5/32's of a pound sterling to 7 17/32 pounds sterling.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- A preliminary total of 142,277 United States casualties in the Korean war was announced today, making it the fourth bloodiest conflict in the nation's history. Only World Wars I and II and the Civil War took a greater toll.

The Radio Corporation of America this year has beaten decisively the traditional summer slump in sales of its phonograph records, Emanuel Sachs, reported yesterday. He is vice president and general manager of the record department of the company's RCA Victor division.

A new one-story building owned by the Malem Realty Corporation at 14-35 Thirty-first Avenue in Long Island City has been leased by the Brennan Steel Corporation through Queens Industrials as broker. The building will be used by the lessee for executive offices and as a warehouse.

TOKYO, Thursday, Aug. 20 -- The United Nations Command told the Communist Command yesterday that representatives of the Chinese and North Korean national Red Cross organizations working among prisoners of war held by the Allies in South Korean camps had attempted to engage in activities beyond their humanitarian mission.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 19 (AP) -- Andy Pafko blasted a home run in the ninth inning today to enable the Braves to gain a 3-2 victory over the Redlegs. Pafko's wallop extended his hitting streak to seventeen games.

With chemicals and coppers standing out against the rest of the list, the stock market yesterday recorded its widest losses since July 13 and touched the lowest level since July 29. Volume rose to 1,400,000 shares, the largest since June 10.

CONSIDERING the fact that they'd been up rather late the night before while wresting a thirteen-inning thriller from the Giants, the Dodgers were surprisingly frisky and bright-eyed when they arrived at Ebbets Field yesterday morning. The Giants had been up just as late but they were neither as frisky nor as bright-eyed.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- The Selective Service system announced today that draft registrants who expected to claim exemption as fathers must do so by next Tuesday.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, Aug, 19 -- Documentary evidence of Communist plans to make another Malaya out of Ceylon, this rubber and tea-growing island dominating important sea lanes to India, Southeast Asia and Australia, has been discovered by the police. The discovery came in the wake of the Communist-led disturbances that briefly threatened to paralyze this dominion a week ago today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- The Southern Bell Telephone Company, of Atlanta, Ga., today applied to the Securities and Exchange Commission for authority to market $30,000,000 worth of twenty-four year debentures. The securities, which will be offered for sale at public bidding, will mature in September, 1977.
To please package-minded Americans, and in so doing obtain some of their dollars, European manufacturers are developing new labels and containers for the foods they ship to the United States.

MILWAUKEE, Aug. 19 -- While drawn games were recorded by three of the leaders in the United States Chess Federation open championship, Curt Brasket of Tracy, Minn., won in fifty-six moves today and entered a four-way tie for first place with a score of 8 -- 2.
CHICAGO, Aug. 19 -- Continued long liquidation caused a further drop in wheat prices here today. Local operators also worked on the selling side as they noted the absence of any aggressive support.

MOUNT CARMEL, Conn., Aug. 19 -- The use of flame throwers and the off-season cultivation of huge sunflowers to increase the productivity and improve the soil condition of New England farms were suggested here today at the thirty-seventh annual field day of the Connecticut Agricultural Experiment Station.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Aug. 12, the Federal Reserve Board announced today.

Dr. Buell G. Gallagher, president of City College and American chairman of the World University Service, returned from a two-month trip to India, Turkey and the Mediterranean yesterday aboard the American Export liner Excambion.

Samuel D. Freeman, in his letter published on Aug. 14, commented on certain proposals for changes in the Health Insurance Plan which I have suggested as a basis for discussion between HIP and Kings County Medical Society representatives.
The State of North Carolina sold at public bidding yesterday $14,250,000 of permanent improvement bonds at a 2.30499 per cent net interest cost for a combination of 4s, 2s and 2 1/4s.

Arrangements were made yesterday for the transfer of Brooklyn Dodgers baseball telecasts for the remainder of the season from WOR-TV, which is undergoing a strike by engineers, to WABC-TV, the local station of the American Broadcasting Company.

The great exodus of city children that took place in early July will be reversed next week as the first among thousands of youngsters who spent two months at summer camp return to their homes. A great deal has been written on handling the leave-taking; not so much has been said about the return.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 19 -- A consolidated net profit of $12,600,000, or $1.28 a share, was reported today for the Transamerica Corporation for the first six months of 1953 by Frank N. Belgrano Jr., president. This compares with $11,600,000, or $1.18 a share, a year earlier.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 19 -- The Belair Stud's Sabette, the $7.30-for-$2 favorite, scored with ease in the $16,675 Diana Handicap at the Saratoga track today and gave 79-year-old Jim Fitzsimmons, who has been training winners for more than half a century, his third successive triumph in the filly-and-mare stake.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- Fred G. Aandahl, Assistant Secretary of the Interior, said today he had found wide acceptance in all sections of the country except one of the principle that local communities should develop their own power resources.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Aug. 19 -- Seven of the Long Island Sound Yacht Racing Association's junior skippers scored victories for the second day in a row virtually to clinch championships in the fifth annual Manhasset Bay regatta today. Blue skies, with billowy white clouds, and winds to fifteen knots made perfect sailing weather.

Additional clinical facilities for an estimated 3,600 patients or 20,000 visits annually will be available on Monday in the Tower Memorial Building of Roosevelt Hospital on Ninth Avenue between Fifty-eighth and Fifty-ninth Streets.

CHICAGO, Aug. 19 (UP) -- The Browns ended Billy Pierce's string of scoreless innings with two runs in the sixth today and went on to defeat the slim southpaw with two more in the tenth for a 4-to-3 victory over the White Sex.

A syndicate represented by David Rapoport has contracted to buy 21-25 East Twenty-sixth Street, two twelve-story and five-story office and showroom buildings on a plot of 20,000 square feet opposite the New York Life Insurance Building.

MONTCLAIR, N. J., Aug. 19 -- Mrs. Philip Cudone of the home club, State champion, and Betty Park of Glen Ridge easily captured the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's Scotch-foursom championship today at the Montclair Club.
NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 19 -- India and Pakistan have agreed to a plebiscite that will decide to which nation the 4,000,000 inhabitants of the disputed state of Jammu and Kashmir will accede.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Aug. 19 (AP) -- Frank Strafaci of Garden City, N. Y., the medalist, led a field of favorites, including three Walker Cup players, into the second round of the Western amateur golf championship today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (UP) -- The Department of Agriculture announced today a change in its method of determining, subsidy rates for sugar beet growers which will reduce average 1953 payments 2 1/2 cents a ton.

ALBANY, Aug. 19 -- The State Health Department presented evidence today that the mass gamma globulin inoculations supervised by it in two southern tier counties a month ago had paid dividends in protecting from polio the age group that had received the injections.

Now that all possible trading arguments have been wrung out of the first half earnings statements of the industrials, many of the brokerage houses are taking another look at the rails. July earnings statements for this group will be arriving in volume over the next few days and they should provide plenty of bullish statements for the market letter writers.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 19 -- Jack Palance, with three years of movie experience, will get star billing for the first time in "The Man in the Attic."

The ambitious plan of making a musical version of Gene Fowler's "Beau James," the biography of the late James J. Walker, is afoot once again. Back in 1949, it was Saint Subber who came up with the notion that he would like to do a musical based on the book.

Maj. Gen. Fazollah Zahedi, leader in yesterday's uprising in Iran against the Government of Premier Mohammed Mossadegh, will have reached the peak of an impressive military and political career if the pro-Shah forces consolidate their victory.

MINEOLA, L. I., Aug. 19 -- A novice robber with an intimate knowledge of the internal politics of the Floral Park, L. I., branch of the Franklin National Bank carried out the $191,280 hold-up of the institution yesterday, Inspector Stuyvesant A. Pinnell, in command of Nassau County detectives, asserted today.

BONN, Germany, Aug. 19 -- Something like a two party political system for West Germany may emerge from the parliamentary elections Sept. 6, if the voting forecasts of the Social Democrats prove to be correct.

VIENNA, Aug. 19 -- The Austrian Government informed the Soviet Government in a note today that, now that the Western powers had dropped the short form of treaty, Austria was prepared to accept any treaty that would establish her freedom and independence and guarantee her the right and ability to develop.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- High Government officials here made it plain today they would be unable to evaluate accurately the effects of the uprising in Iran until the whereabouts and physical condition of Premier Mohammed Mossadegh had been definitely established.

LONDON, Aug. 17 (Reuters) -- Queen Elizabeth II, on holiday at Balmoral Castle in Scotland, already is busy supervising the preparation of her wardrobe for the Commonwealth tour she will start Nov. 23.

VIENNA, Aug. 19 -- Prof. Werner Villinger, director of the Neurological Clinic of the University of Marburg, Germany, and one of Europe's leading psychiatrists, declared here today at the annual meeting of the World Federation for Mental Health that the danger that the German people would accept communism or any other totalitarian regime no longer existed.

LONDON, Aug. 19 (Reuters) -- The English soccer season opened unobtrusively tonight. Despite cricket fever sweeping the country, 750,000 soccer enthusiasts turned out to see sixty-six of the ninety-two top-league clubs in England and Wales start the thirty-eight-week season.

The Glidden Company, whose products range from paints to food, had net earnings in the nine months ended on July 31 of $4,629,251, an increase of 11.8 per cent over the $4,139,619 earned in the corresponding period of the previous year.

SEOUL, Aug. 19 (AP) -- Robert Toth, a former airman, left under guard tonight for the United States where a Federal court will decide if the Air Force had the right to bring him back to Korea to stand trial on murder charges.

President Eisenhower, who dedicated yesterday the partly built $32,000,000 Baruch Houses, defended Congressional cuts in Federal aid to public housing against criticism by City Construction Coordinator Robert Moses that "hardboiled reactionaries" had "cut in two" that and other slum clearance projects.

" Arabian Jubilee," by H. St. John B. Philby, explorer and authority on Arabia, will be published Sept. 18 by John Day. It is a biography of Ibn Sa'ud, "by the Grace of God King of Sa'udi Arabia," which combines the story of the man and that of the country he has ruled and molded.

The Eisenhower Administration emphasized yesterday that it was interested in concrete performance rather than hazy recommendations by the Government committee set up last week to prevent discriminatory employment practices in plants with Federal contracts.
The Soviet explosion of a hydrogen bomb raises questions of the first magnitude both for the United States and for the entire Western alliance of which this country is the key.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- The two officials chiefly responsible for personnel security in the Government Printing Office testified today that they had cleared Edward Rothschild, a bookbinder employed by that office, to continue work because they had not been convinced that he was a Communist and it had not been established that he had engaged in espionage or had stolen secret documents.

Although Malenkov, in his speech of Aug. 8, publicly acknowledged certain shortcomings in the economic situation of Soviet Russia, he carefully avoided mentioning the all-important question of what the economists call the wage-price relationship.

PARIS, Aug. 19 -- The Cabinet reaffirmed today the Government's refusal to negotiate with labor so long as the present strikes continued on the railroads, in the mines, in communica tions and in other services.

Borough President Robert F. Wagner Jr. of Manhattan, who is opposing Mayor Impellitteri for the Democratic mayoral nomination, called yesterday for a redivision of tax sources and governmental functions between the state and municipal governments.

An increase last week of 258,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. Supplies at the week-end were 143,577,000 barrels, compared with 143,319,000 a week ago and 115,979,000 a year earlier.

The loss of passengers on the city-owned transit system remained for the third week close to the 11.1 per cent predicted under the 15-cent fare, the New York City Transit Authority reported yesterday. The decline in riders for the five days from Aug. 10 to 14 was 11.2 per cent.

The National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis announced yesterday an increase of nearly one-third in the national pool of scarce gamma globulin available this summer to limit the spread of poliomyelitis.

BOONTON, N. J., Aug. 19 -- A New Jersey amateur golf team regained possession of the Stoddard Bowl today by turning back Westchester and Long Island in the triangular matches staged by the Metropolitan Golf Association at the Knoll Golf Club.
BOSTON, Aug. 19 (AP) -- Ted William, who less than a month ago was a Marine combat flier, today blasted a home run that sparked the Red Sox to a 6-4 victory over the Athletics.
YONKERS, Aug. 19 (AP) -- Lark Hanover, owned by Myers and Shepard of Hanover, Pa., gained wire-to-wire victory tonight in the $6,000 Broadway trot for 3-year-olds at Yonkers Raceway.

JERUSALEM, Aug. 19 -- Posthumous Israeli citizenship will be conferred upon 6,000,000 Jews killed by the Nazis in Germany and in overrun countries during World War II, according to a decision of the Knesset (Parliament) today.

It was to be expected that the debate in the General Assembly of the United Nations on the projected political conference on Korea would be a two-sided affair between the defenders of the United Nations who sacrificed blood and treasure for it and the forces which waged aggressive war against it under the inspiration of Soviet Russia.

MOSCOW, Thursday, Aug. 20 -- Premier Mohammed Mossadegh's overthrow came at a moment when Soviet policy was strongly oriented toward rapprochement with Teheran and coincided with Soviet charges that United States intrigues and finances had lain behind the earlier stages of the Shah's coup.

NEW DELHI, Aug. 19 (AP) -- India's Prime Minister Nehru and Pakistan's Prime Minister Mohammed Ali have agreed that an Asian plebiscite administrator should supervise any balloting conducted to determine the future of disputed Kashmir, reliable sources said today.

After serving sixteen years of a thirty-year sentence as a second felony offender, Fred Cianci, 45 years old, was freed yesterday by Judge Louis Goldstein in Kings County Court on the ground that his constitutional rights had been violated in that Cianci had no attorney in his first trial.

The Atlas Corporation, investment trust dealing in so-called special situations, at June 30 had $26,000,000, or 38 per cent, of its $67,900,000 assets in cash and Government securities and may wait weeks or months before it puts the money to work in corporate securities, Floyd B. Odlum, president, told stockholders at the annual meeting yesterday.
KONXVILLE, Tenn., Aug. 19 -- Suggestions for the Tennessee Valley Authority to float revenue bounds to finance future power expansions brought objections today from Chairman Gordon R. Clapp.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Aug. 19 -- Judicial action has been taken to remove from office the Bishop of the 800-year-old Strangnas diocese, fifty-seven-year-old Dick Helander. The gist of .the indictment, formally for slander, is that Bishop Helander used unfair means to achieve his election to the Episcopate last year and that by writing anonymous letters to the electors he had slandered his competitors.

Aggregate short interest on the New York Stock Exchange remained virtually unchanged in the month ended Aug. 14, dropping 17,600 shares to 1,794,752 shares from 1,812,352 shares on July 15. Both figures exclude short positions carried in the odd-lot accounts of odd-lot dealers.

WASHINGTON, Aug 19 -- Plans to name a special committee on cost justification were announced here today by Edward F. Howrey, chairman of the Federal Trade Commission, and immediately drew fire from the National Federation of Independent Business.

VIENNA, Aug. 16 -- The World Festival of Youth and Students for Peace and Friendship in Bucharest, to report which this correspondent was granted a visa by the Rumanian Government, may be remembered by the people of Rumania as the beginning of a period of plenty after one of near famine.

Another act in the "Strange Interlude" drama of the elusive winning sweepstakes ticket was being prepared yesterday as litigants withdrew action from Lower Manhattan Court and one claimant promised to carry her fight for the $28,500 prize to the Ould Sod itself.

Public offering of $20,000,000 of the Pacific Finance Corporation's 4 per cent debentures is being made today by a syndicate headed jointly by Blyth Co., Inc., and Hornblower Weeks. The debentures, due in 1959, are priced at 99 7/8 plus accrued interest from Aug. 1.
Trading volume on the New York commodity exchanges continued moderate yesterday and prices were generally lower.
TORONTO, Aug. 19 -- After nineteen years together the Dionne quintuplets are separating to live their individual lives, their father, Oliva Dionne, revealed today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- The Political Action Committee of the Congress of Industrial Organizations spent a half-day looking at the record of Congress, the Administration and Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, today and found it nearly all bad.

RABAT, Morocco, Aug. 19 -- An uneasy truce continued to prevail in Morocco today pending the return of General Guillaume. The suspense was heightened by the general uncertainty as to the possible outcome of the conflict that has pitted the pashas and kaids and their vast rural following against the Sultan and the urban nationalists.

TEHERAN, Iran, Aug. 19 -- Iranians loyal to Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi, including Teheran civilians, soldiers and rural tribesmen, swept Premier Mohammed Mossadegh out of power today in a revolution and apparently had seized at least temporary control of the country.
BLED, Yugoslavia, Aug. 19 -- A Yugoslav military delegation will leave for Washington tomorrow to confer with United States, British and French army officials on the problems of military aid.

New York's City Hall is 150 years old, from date of cornerstone laying, in this year 1953 in which we are celebrating the 300th anniversary of the incorporated city government. It is a beautiful building, of graceful line, and the structure is sound. But it has a shabby, moth-eaten appearance because of deterioration of the outside stonework.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (AP) -- A secret report made to President Eisenhower last month was disclosed today to have recommended cutting down on Voice of America broadcasts to Russia.
President Eisenhower registered yesterday to vote here in the November election. His party affiliation was no secret. He enrolled openly under the eagle emblem of the Republican party.
