SEOUL, Korea, Aug. 19 -- Fresh intelligence reports received here are serving to confirm that, following a blood purge of the Korean Communist party, dominant Russian and Chinese-trained wings of the party settled the balance of power arrangement.

CANTON, N. Y., Aug. 19 -- Political patronage in the administration of penal institutions now is the most important single cause of prison disorders, a leading criminologist declared here today at St. Lawrence University's statewide crime clinic.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 19 -- Kurt Nielsen and Torben Ulrich of Denmark were eliminated from the national doubles tennis championship today as Victor Seixas and Tony Trabert led the advance of the American contingent at the Longwood Cricket Club.

ROME, Aug. 19 -- The Shah of Iran, on confirmation of the news that Royalists in his country had overthrown Premier Mohammed Mossadegh, decided to fly back to Teheran tomorrow. His aides immediately called a British airline to charter a plane to take him back to his home, whence he fled on Sunday.

Robert B. Takewell has been appointed executive vice president of the J. M. Huber Corporation, manufacturer of carbon black, clay, ink and chemicals. A. Z. Hahn has been named vice president of the carbon black division.

The International Longshoremen's Association last night named George A. Brenner, a member of a law firm other than its regular counsel, to carry through the courts its projected legal fight against new bi-state waterfront controls.
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 19 (UP) -- Rookie Dick Schofield's error on Clyde McCullough's ground ball in the sixth inning gave the Cubs a 5-3 victory over the Cardinals tonight.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., Aug. 19 (AP) -- The Bethlehem Steel Company put a new coke oven battery into operation today, adding 1,300 tons daily to its output. But a company official said the real significance of the new battery is its relation to the over-all expansion of the company's steelmaking facilities.

PEORIA, Ill., Aug. 19 -- Carl J. Megel, president of American Federation of Teachers, A. F. L., which is meeting here in its thirty-sixth annual convention, declared today that more teachers were leaving the profession each year than the number entering.

The nation's steelmakers shipped a record 42,356,861 net tons of steel products in the first half of this year, and shipments in June to the manufacturers of guns, tanks and other military items were the largest for any month since the end of World War II.
Bernard Baruch had a wonderful time on his eighty-third birthday yesterday.
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 19 (AP) -- Bill Veeck continued his West Coast shopping tour today, looking for a new home city, complete with ball park, for the Browns.
BOGOTA, Colombia, Aug. 19 -- President Gustavo Rojas Pinilla gave orders today in the presence of visiting United States newspapermen that henceforth no outgoing press dispatches should be censored.

VIENNA, Aug. 19 (Reuters) -- Edgar Sanders, British business man, will return to his native country tomorrow for the first time after three and a half years in a Hungarian Communist jail for alleged spying.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 19 -- The controversy over India's participation in a Far Eastern political conference has developed into one of the United Nations' tightest voting contests. The decision rests with the Latin-American bloc.

DETROIT, Aug. 20 (AP) -- The Indians celebrated Manager Al Lopez' birthday anniversary with an eighteen-hit outburst today against five Tiger pitchers for a 13-7 decision that snapped a four-game losing streak.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- Lacking any sure indications of what eruptions might follow, responsible officials here were maintaining a reserved and diplomatic silence today on the counter-thrust that has ousted Mohammed Mossadegh as Premier of Iran.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 20 (AP) -- America's version of the famed British Canberra jet bomber took to the air tonight for its formal delivery to the United States Air Force.

SPORTS fishermen all along the Atlantic Coast were fearful, while riding out last week's terrific storms in snug anchorages, that the high winds and tides would chase the bigger and better fish to waters beyond their scope of operations.

ALBANY, Aug. 20 (AP) -- Plans for widening and deepening the Hudson River channel between Albany and New York have gained the approval of Army engineers, the chairman of the Albany Port District Commission reported today.

" My Promised Land," by Molly Bar-David, an account of the author's daily life in Palestine since her migration there in 1935 from Western Canada, will be issued in mid-October by Putnam's. BOSTON, Aug. 20 -- A committee of State Supreme Court Justices reported today that an increase in the use of the habeas corpus process indicated "clearly a scandalous abuse of the privilege."

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 20 -- The 53,000 nonsupervisory employes of Southwestern Bell Telephone Company's six-state system went on strike at 6 A. M. today, after all-night negotiations had failed to bring agreement on a new wage contract.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 20 -- In the midst of the United Nations debate on Korea today, the Asian and African states managed to get in a protest against France's ouster of Sidi Mohammed Ben Yousseff, Sultan of Morocco.
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 20 (AP) -- The Los Angeles Rams beat the Washington Redskins, 20 -- 7, last night in a National Football League charity exhibition,

DETROIT, Aug. 20 -- General Motors announced today that agreement had been reached with the Kaiser Motors Corporation for a lease on 1,500,000 square feet of the Kaiser plant at Willow Run, Mich., in which G. M. will seek to establish volume production of hydramatic transmission as soon as possible.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- A responsible United States source said tonight that the confirmed news of a Soviet atomic test involving "both fission and thermonuclear reactions" did not necessarily mean the Soviet Union had yet perfected a hydrogen bomb capable of being delivered by airplane upon this country.

DETROIT, Aug 20 (UP) -- The Ford Motor Company will soon begin construction of a research center to test kerosene-burning turbine engines for automobiles. Such engines would employ jet principles, engineers said.

Cotton futures prices closed yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange 2 to 7 points net higher than Wednesday on the more active deliveries. The closing was at about the day's best levels. The volume of trading was not far different from the limited turnover of Wednesday, when it was 47,500 bales.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- The State Department described India today as the crucial proving ground of freedom for all Asia, and said that the test might come "during this decade."

VANDALIA, Ohio, Aug. 20 (AP) -- Elmer Woods, 55-year-old dirt farmer from Williamstown, Ohio, broke 99 of 100 from the 19-yard line today to win the Preliminary Handicap, trapshooting's second greatest prize, at the Fifty-fourth Grand American.
PARIS, Friday, Aug. 21 -- Both non-Communist and Communist unions called their members out for forty-eight-hour strikes, beginning today, in the French metallurgical industry.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 (AP) -- The Daughters of the American Revolution proudly announced today that they had trounced the United States Navy in a fight over flags. The D. A. R. said that Old Glory "at last flies in its proper place at naval headquarters of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization in Norfolk, Va."

A hearing on a complaint by the Isbrandtsen Company, Inc., against institution of a dual rate contract system by the Japan-Atlantic and Gulf Freight Conference will be held here on Oct. 5 at 45 Broadway, it was decided at a pre-hearing conference in Washington yesterday by Federal Maritime Board hearing examiner Robert Furness.

The police here and on Long Island received yesterday three more reports that John Mazziotta, believed to be a key figure in the slaying seventeen months ago of Arnold Schuster, had been sighted in this vicinity. Mr. Schuster was responsible for the capture of William Sutton, the bank robber.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 20 -- The explosion of a hydrogen bomb by the Soviet Union calls for action on the "highest levels" in Washington and Moscow to find out if new ground exists for international atomic control, Senator Alexander Wiley, chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, said here today.
DARK is the blood of man, sombre the human heart.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 20 (AP) -- Assistant Attorney General Stanley N. Barnes said today that he was being flooded with complaints from consumers about recent gasoline price advances east of the Rocky Mountains.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 (AP) -- New talks on a pact to stabilize world tin prices were virtually assured today after the United States indicated it would take part.

SEOUL, Korea, Aug. 20 -- Gen. James A. Van Fleet returned to Korea today. He said this land was his "second home" and he always intended to return. It was the first time the former chief of the Eighth Army had revisited the Peninsula since he retired from his command last February.
A 3,400-gallon tank has been fashioned of plastic which its sponsors say is not only lighter than a similar one of steel, which it replaces, but permits considerable savings in operation.
BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 20 -- Lewis Hoad and Kenneth Rosewall reached the end of their quest for a sweep of the world's major doubles tennis titles today in one of the shocks of the year.

Production of newsprint in Canada in July amounted to 491,254 tons, with shipments to 494,212 tons, according to a report yesterday by the Newsprint Service Bureau. United States output for the month was 88,121 tons and shipments 90,755, making total North American production and shipments for July, 579,375 and 584,967 tons, respectively.

SAIGON, Vietnam, Aug. 20 -- King Norodom Sihanouk said today there had been a lull in the dispute with Paris over Cambodia's future relations with France, but he maintained his demand for what he termed "spotless sovereignty." The king said the latest French reply met Cambodian demands to some extent.

Newspapers were the -- "shock troops" in the successful battle by Seagram-Distillers Corporation to reach top sales position in the liquor field for its 7-Crown blended whisky, says George E. Moseley, head of the company's advertising and sales promotion, in the latest edition of "Advertising Facts" published by the Bureau of Advertising, American Newspaper Publishers Association.

Pakistan's Prime Minister, Mohammed Ali, says that he is, of course, "not entirely satisfied" with the accord that has been reached with Prime Minister Nehru of India on a plebiscite for Kashmir, but he welcomes the fact that a compromise has been found. The rest of the world will send up a profound sigh of relief that the explosive tension between the two countries has been lessened.

MINEOLA, L. I., Aug. 20 -- The Nassau County police and the Federal Bureau of Investigation are hampered by having only a "Mr. Anonymous Average American" description of the bandit who robbed the Floral Park branch of the Franklin National Bank of $191,280 early last Tuesday morning.

MINEOLA, L. I., Aug. 20 -- Two executives of the strike-bound Arma Corporation at Roosevelt Field were cleared on felonious assault charges today. A Nassau County grand jury failed to indict either of the men, who had been accused of running down pickets with their automobiles.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 20 (AP) -- Bob Carpenter, owner of the Phillies, today signed Steve O'Neill to a new contract as manager for 1954 amid hints that there would be some changes made in the ball club.

VIENNA, Aug. 20 -- Dr. Manfred Sakel, discoverer of the insulin therapy for all schizophrenia, most serious of all mental diseases, charged today before an international conference of leading psychiatrists that hundreds of thousands of victims of the disease were confined in mental asylums as hopelessly insane.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 20 -- Five leaders of the Communist party in this area were found guilty today of conspiring to teach and advocate violent overthrow of the United States Government. The trial under the Smith Act began in the Federal District Court March 10.

Three years of highly successful service as executive vice president of the Security Bureau, Inc., a period in which the incidence and extent of pier theft and pilferage in the Port of New York have been reduced considerably, will end for John C. Hilly on Sept. 1, when he takes up new duties with the Bush Terminal Company.

YONKERS, Aug. 20 -- Ralph L. Craig's Wilmington's Star from Urbana, Ohio, with Billy Haughton in the sulky, scored a one-length victory over the fast-closing Red Sails in the fourth annual $25,000 mile and one-half Yonkers Pacing Derby in 3:06 before 18,736 fans at Yonkers Raceway tonight.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 (UP) -- The agriculture department announced today that 1953-crop cottonseed cake and meal bought by the Government will be offered for sale at the support or market price, whichever is higher.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 (AP) -- Senate officials disclosed today that a secret inquiry into cancer drugs and treatments started by the late Senator Charles W. Tobey, Republican of New Hampshire, had been ended amid controversy.
MUNSAN, Korea, Friday, Aug. 21 (AP) -- The United Nations Command's official list of United States prisoners of war freed in today's armistice exchange:

LEOPOLDVILLE, The Belgian Congo, Aug. 20 -- Belgium's refusal to participate in the work of the United Nation's Committee on Information from Non-Self-Governing Territories is believed to be traceable to its program of gradual political and economic development of the Congo, the course of which she believes should not be changed.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended Aug. 15 totaled 807,387 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.

TRENTON, Aug. 20 -- New Jersey hospitals have spent $53,000,000 since 1946 expanding and improving facilities, and plan to spend $76,000,000 more in the next five years, it was disclosed today in a report by Sanford Bates, State Commissioner of Institutions and Agencies.

MOSCOW, Friday, Aug. 21 -- An East German Government delegation headed by Premier Otto Grotewohl and Deputy Premier Walter Ulbricht arrived yesterday and a few hours later was entertained at a reception given by Premier Georgi M. Malenkov and other Soviet leaders.
One man was killed and another burned critically yesterday by a fire and explosion in the yard of the Queen Chemical Company, 57 Vandam Street, in the Greenpoint section of Brooklyn.

Negotiations extending for nearly two years have been concluded whereby the RKO Palace will recognize the Association of Theatrical Press Agents and Managers Union, thus marking the first instance in the union's history for a chain house to do so.

Adlai E. Stevenson came back to the United States yesterday after a six-months' trip that had carried him round the world, through thirty countries. It is not on record that during all those crowded months when he was subject to the temptation to rash and impetuous speech at every turn, he ever said a thing that did not help his country, or anything that could embarrass the Eisenhower Administration.

Repayments by sales finance companies were a factor in producing a slight decline in the loans to business enterprises by New York banks last week. The $9,000,000 dip for the week ended on Wednesday followed increases in the two previous weeks, and brought the reduction in such loans since the start of this year to $379,000,000 against a drop of $286,000,000 in the similar period a year ago.

WASHINGTON, Aug 20 (UP) -- The Pan American World Airways announced today that it has submitted new evidence to the Civil Aeronautics Board in support of its plan for through air service between Northeastern United States and Latin America.

The Institute of Textile Technology, a cooperative research center for the textile industry in Charlottesville, Va., has developed a new family of cotton fibers through chemical treatment, it was announced yesterday. The new fiber, known as T-7, is produced by reaction of ordinary cotton fiber, yarn or fabric in a process called cyanoethylation, which transforms the cotton into a structurally different type of fiber.
SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 20 -- Today's assortment of news items at the Saratoga Association's cavalry post included the following:

Stay-at-home baseball fans missed the 10-to:0 slaughter yesterday of the New York Giants by the Brooklyn Dodgers when an Ebbets Field electrician refused to pull a switch that was to have provided the power for the cameras of WABC-TV.

DENVER, Aug. 20 -- President Eisenhower conferred today with Mrs. Oveta Culp Hobby, Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, and Under Secretary Nelson Rockefeller on departmental plans and policies, including the recent recommendation to extend Social Security coverage to an additional 10,500,000 persons.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 (AP) -- The Petroleum Administration for Defense said today that it was considering repeal of its order fixing a minimum on the amount of tetraethyl lead to be used in civilian domestic aviation gasoline.

FREEDOM VILLAGE, Korea, Aug. 20 -- A Nisei sergeant who spent twenty-eight months in a prisoner-of-war camp returned today and received as his reward the Medal of Honor, highest military decoration of the United States.

Prospects now are favorable for an easing of United States taxation of foreign-source income, with resultant added incentive for the increase of private investment abroad, according to views expressed yesterday by George F. James, chairman of the National Foreign Trade Council's tax committee.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- Domestic manufacturers of popular-price watch bracelets and parts lost out today in their effort to invoke the "escape" clause of the Reciprocal Trade Agreements Act and raise tariff rates on imported watch bracelets.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- United States department store sales in the week ended last Saturday were unchanged from those in the corresponding week of last year. This was reported today by the Federal Reserve Board, which listed the following percentage changes from like periods of 1952:

CHICAGO, Aug. 20 (AP) -- The sun had barely risen today when Les Murray, Native Dancer's groom entered the gray colt's stall at Washington Park. After about five minutes, Murray came out wearing at big smile.

BALBOA, C. Z., Aug. 20 -- A simulated forty - kiloton atomic bomb was exploded today five hundred yards from Miraflores Locks, the last step down to the Pacific of the Panama Canal, theoretically letting the waters of Miraflores Lake flow into the Pacific.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 (AP) -- The Government's controversial policy of giving labor surplus areas preference in the awarding of defense contracts has been suspended indefinitely, an Office of Defense Mobilization spokesman said tonight.

ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L. I., Aug. 20 -- Montreal, the defending champion, and Schenectady gained the final of the region 1 Little League baseball tournament as Johnson City and Massapequa were eliminated at Hickey Field today.

Merger of the West Virginia Pulp and Paper Company and the Hinde Dauch Paper Company, both established in 1888, was voted by their boards at separate meetings yesterday, subject to approval of stockholders.

Somewhere in New York -- and it might be Queens -- is a burglar with a powerful taste in modern music. The highbrow-music lover invaded the home of Milton Katims, symphonic conductor and violist, early yesterday morning and, out of a collection of several hundred valuable recordings, walked off with three, the works of Hindemith, Stravinsky and Roussel.

The policy statement of the Administration on the Government's role in the development of hydroelectric power represents a shift of emphasis from federal to local enterprise. Whether it represents a great deal more than that remains to be seen.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- Testimony that in 1943 Edward Rothschild, a bookbinding machine operator in the Government Printing Office, took a secret code of the United States Merchant Marine from a machine other than the one he operated was read into the record today at a hearing of the Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations of the Senate Committee on Government Operations.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- Civil Defense Administrator Val Peterson said today that a Soviet hydrogen bomb was obviously of tremendous importance to civil defense.

Adlai E. Stevenson, back from his around-the-world quest for understanding, said yesterday that the free nations were winning the "cold war" step by step, and that the danger of world war had diminished.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- The Post Office Department today dismissed a fraud order it had on its books against the producers of AD-X2, a battery additive, since last Feb. 24. The Department ruled that there existed "insufficient proof" of an intent to deceive by Pioneers, Inc., producers of the additive, or by officers of the company, including Jess M. Ritchie, president, to justify retention of the order.

YELLOW SPRINGS, Ohio, Aug. 20 -- These are comments on Shakespeare's "Coriolanus" and "Pericles," which have occupied the Antioch Area Theatre during the last two evenings. When they were originally produced more than 300 years ago, "Coriolanus" was a flop and "Pericles" a success.

Stock prices reversed a four-day downtrend yesterday and with volume fading, climbed laboriously to higher levels. In the narrowest market since July 3 only 1,002 issues were traded. Of these, 383 rose, 361 fell and 258 were unchanged.

VIENNA, Aug. 16 -- Will Rumania follows Moscow's lead in making overtures to the Western world and relaxing the rigors of its Communist regime? This question arose as part of the pattern of events that led to the admittance of Western correspondents to the recent World Festival of Youths and Students for Peace and Friendship in Bucharest.

SOUTHPORT, Conn., Aug. 20 -- Thomas I. S. Boak, sailing Delora, took the lead for the Atlantic Class national championship by winning the first event of the five-race series at Pequot Yacht Club today.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 20 -- Ashley Trimble Cole, chairman of the New York State Racing Commission, said tonight that "I do believe a new race track will be built in New York" and that "the best site I can see anywhere around the city is the site at the present Aqueduct track."

New Yorkers, who suddenly found themselves strolling down Thirty-fourth Street side by side with a group of unlikely city pedestrians, including a 3,000-pound Angus steer, crowded the sidewalk in front of the New Yorker Hotel yesterday morning to watch a preview of the 108th Dutchess County Fair.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Aug. 20 (UP) -- A giant Air Force C-99 air freighter "smashed every international cargo-handling record in existence" when it landed here yesterday after its initial trans-Atlantic flight, an Air Force spokesman said today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 (UP) -- Robert B. Anderson, Secretary of the Navy, announced today a new policy calling for "complete elimination" of racial segregation among civilian employes at forty-three naval shore stations in the South.

SALEM, Mass., Aug. 20 -- The Naumkeag Steam Cotton Company will close out its Salem operations by the end of this year, Rudolph C. Dick, president, said today. A meeting last night with city and union officials failed to develop any reason for a change in plans, he added.

NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 20 -- Mohammed Ali, Prime Minister of Pakistan, hinted at a news conference today that his country and India, the two nations with a fifth of the world's population, had laid the foundation for peace in the subcontinent.

Our national dessert is not so peculiarly ours as we may think. Pastry with apples, known in all quarters of the United States as apple pie, is a combination enjoyed in varying forms in other countries. Hungary has its apple strudel, England makes an apple custard tart, France bakes a different sort of tart and also chaussons aux pommes (like our turnovers).
Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi, who is to fly back to Teheran today to the throne of Iran, is considered to be the direct antithesis of his father, the late Shah Riza Khan Pahlevi.

CHICAGO, Aug. 20 -- Individual rights are strongly defended in a report by a special committee of the American Bar Association that attacks attempts to curb books in American libraries as inimical to the security of this country.

SALT LAKE CITY Aug. 20 -- Eli Lilly, board chairman of the drug manufacturing company that bears his name, was elected today honorary president of the American Pharmaceutical Association. The Indianapolis manufacturer, chosen by unanimous vote, succeeds Rufus A. Lyman of Lincoln, Neb.
Eight hundred and seventy pints of blood were collected by the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program on Wednesday -- the highest total for a day thus far this month.

On Aug. 12 you mentioned an item about metering water in city apartment houses. The third paragraph states that one of the most obvious and widely accepted municipal economy measures proposed is the universal metering of water use, etc. Later on appears the further statement that the fair method is to charge the user by metering water.

A record $101,560,000 new construction program for 1954 was outlined yesterday by the Board of Education at a public hearing before the City Planning Commission. The program included a 1954 capital budget request for $65,680,000 for thirty new schools and additions to accommodate 34,400 pupils.
PARIS, Friday, Aug. 21 -- Two big non-Communist unions ordered their members early today to return to work in France's postal, telegraph and telephone services.
Your editorial of Aug. 14 "India, Pakistan, Kashmir" strikes the observer as markedly partisan.

In spite of recent ups and downs in retail meat prices, consumers in the New York area are paying lower prices for beef, veal and lamb than a year ago. The only exception is pork, which is 3 to 20 cents higher a pound than in August, 1952.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- During the week ended Aug. 19, member bank reserves increased $48,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board announced today.

Chuck Dressen may not be a grammatical prophet, but he seem to be an accurate one. His airy assertion of eleven days ago that "the Giants is dead" was well supported at Ebbets Field yesterday before 24,939 spectators (17,785 paid) when his Dodgers completed a sweep of the three-game series with the Giants with a 10-0 triumph.

Lace figured importantly in a showing of fall and winter bridal designs at Best Co. yesterday. It was used to fashion entire gowns, lavishly trim satins and heavy silks, compose enchanting little jackets or bib-like capes and, glistening with iridescent paillettes, afford the daintiest applique.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Aug. 20 -- Light winds and slack sails failed to upset the form as favorites came through in every class on the final day of the Manhasset Bay Race Week fifth annual junior regatta today.

RYE, N. Y., Aug. 20 -- The Westchester Country Club's four-man golf team retained the honors in the tenth annual Hoffhine Memorial tourney with a four-under-par aggregate of 284 on the victors' course today.
RABAT, Morocco, Aug. 20 -- The Sultan of Morocco, Sidi Mohammed Ben Youssef, was banished from his empire today after armed Berber tribesmen had begun to converge on Rabat.

One of the best friends the gardener can have is a strong back. The amount of stretching, bending, twisting, heaving and pulling the average gardener goes through in the course of a season is prodigious, and a back in tiptop working condition is as essential, if not more so, as a good spade or a trowel with a non-bending handle.
Gov. Thomas E. Dewey has made an excellent choice in naming Lieut. Gen. George P. Hays as the New York member of the New York-New Jersey Waterfront Commission.
TURKU, Finland, Aug. 20 (UP) -- American track stars, flashing over a track covered with water after two days of rain, won six of nine events in an international track and field meet today.

CHICAGO, Aug. 20 -- Wheat futures showed considerable strength through most of the session here today following rather sharp initial declines, but demand faded in the late trade and the market lost its gains.
Following is the text of a statement by Adlai E. Stevenson at the Biltmore Hotel yesterday:

SIDON, Lebanon, Aug. 17 -- A twenty-three-mile coastal strip of Lebanon, stretching from here to Tyre, will be converted into a fertile farming area through United States Point Four projects in the making. The first stage is to complete the ten-foot-wide Kasmieh Irrigation Canal, to bring Litani River water from Tyre northward to irrigate nearly 2,000 acres of potentially rich farmland.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 21-- Pabco Products, Inc., reported today. total earnings after Federal income taxes for the fiscal year ended June 30 of $1,460,689, equal to ninety cents a share, compared with $1,608,500, or $1 a share, for the preceding year.
BLOOMINGTON, Ind., Aug. 20 (AP) -- Dr. Alfred C. Kinsey's scientific look at women's sex lives finds that many popular ideas are wrong.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Aug. 20 -- The old question of friction between Colombia's little Protestant minority and the Roman Catholic church has come into prominence again with fresh reports of trouble and unsuccessful efforts by Protestants to persuade President Gustaro Rojas Pintilla to take an unequivocal stand against persecution.

ROME, Aug. 20 -- The Shah and Queen Soraya were joined today by the Shah's twin sister, Princess Ashraf. She came from Switzerland, principally to act as a companion for Queen Soraya, who has been in poor health recently. Early this morning the Queen required the care of a physician, who then sent a white-robed nun as a nurse.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- David J. McDonald, president of the United Steelworkers, avowed his solidarity with the Congress of Industrial Organizations today.

LONDON, Aug. 20 -- Activity in the industrial group overshadowed nearly all others in the stock markets today. Miscellaneous leaders were especially prominent, with widespread gains. Trading elsewhere was sparse and prices generally moved irregularly slightly higher or lower.

The Central Trades and Labor Council, meeting here last night at Roosevelt Auditorium, 100 East Seventeenth Street, approved a resolution that bitterly attacked the Kings County Medical Society for its recent actions concerning the Health Insurance Plan of Greater New York.

Shelby County (Memphis), Tenn., awarded $5,050,000 of various purpose bonds due from 1954 to 1978 to the First National Bank of Memphis and associates at a net interest close of 2.5196 per cent for a combination of 2 1/2's and 2.6's.

RIVERSIDE, Conn., Aug. 20 -- Cornelius Shields Jr., known as Glit, stole the show from his illustrious yachting father, Corny Sr., as half the races in a six-way final round-robin for the Long Island Sound men's championship and the Commodore Hipkins Trophy were completed at Riverside Yacht Club today.

Your editorial "Intelligence in Economy" should be reproduced a few hundredfold and then dispatched to all those students recently released from universities, armed with degrees, a wealth of information and training ripe for use by the United States information services.
MONTREAL, Aug. 20 (Canadian Press) -- Jerry Barber of La Canada, Calif., toured Summerlea's golf layout today with a record-breaking 64 to lead the field in the first day of the $25,000 open.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 20 -- Henry Cabot Lodge Jr., the United States representative at the United Nations, announced tonight the United States would vote against the participation of India in the impending Far Eastern political conference. Before tonight he had refused to say whether this country would vote against Indian participation or merely abstain from voting.

Years of encyclopedic reading and hundreds of hours of work on a puzzle contest bore fruit -- in the form of a check for $307,500 -- for a 55-year-old Chicago man yesterday. Herbert J. Idle reached out a hand made unsteady by surprise and accepted the check from former Vice President Alben W. Barkley on the steps of Federal Hall, the former Subtreasury Building, at Broad and Wall Streets.

Mayor Impellitteri yesterday picked Jack Mintz, retired textile executive with only a very limited political experience, as the manager of his campaign for the Democratic primary nomination for Mayor.

Eddie Lopat cast his customary southpaw spell over the Senators at the Stadium yesterday as the Yankees ganged up on Bob Porterfield, the shutout leader of the major leagues, for seven runs in the fourth inning.

The Military Sea Transportation Service requested offers yesterday for two ocean tows from the American shipping industry. At the same time, the agency announced that the Hong Kong Transport, a Victory ship operated by Pacific Transport Lines, had been chartered for four months, with option for an additional four months, at a rate of $1,975 a day.
Here is a message of importance for all subway passengers from our sponsor, the New York City Transit Authority.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- Two hundred and twenty-seven of the 427 employes of the Government's huge synthetic rubber plant, at Institute, W. Va., received dismissal notices today, effective on Sept. 19. The Reconstruction Finance Corporation, which operates the plant, said the remaining 200 workers, who have helped turn out some 5,000 tons of general-purpose synthetic (GR-S) rubber a month, would be kept on to put the plant in stand-by condition.

BONN, Germany, Aug. 20 -- The police in the Baltic port of Kiel broke up an election rally that was to have been addressed today by Dr. Werner Naumann, former State Secretary in the Nazi propaganda Ministry, who is campaigning for election to the Bundestag on the ticket of the ultra-nationalist German Reich party.

A "universal" credit plan has been perfected for travelers after ten years of study and research by the hotel industry, it was announced yesterday by Arthur J. Packard, president of the American Hotel Association.

Directors of the Pacific Gas and Electric Company yesterday increased the quarterly dividend on the common stock and announced an allotment of rights to common stockholders of record Sept. 15 to subscribe for 1,946,829 common shares on the basis of one new share for each seven held.
HOUSTON, Tex., Aug. 20 -- An investigating committee has announced today that it found no evidence of subversive or Communistic affiliation, association or teaching at Texas Southern University here.

A ring of garment thieves who had been preying upon manufacturers for several months appeared to have been broken yesterday as the police recovered an estimated $100,000 worth of clothing in a Harlem raid and had eight men under arrest.

A rugged combat veteran of two world wars, Lieut. Gen. George P. Hays, was named yesterday to lead the state's drive against waterfront corruption. Governor Dewey, at a press conference at the Roosevelt Hotel, named General Hays as the New York member on the two-man New York-New Jersey Waterfront Commission.

TOKYO, Friday, Aug. 21 -- United States airmen were physically tortured in Communist prison camps in North Korea to make them "confess" they had engaged in germ warfare, American prisoners who returned to freedom at Panmunjom said yesterday.

A finely printed, large magazine-size brochure memorializing extensive United States economic aid to Austria has just been issued by the United States Austrian Chamber of Commerce. The 160-page volume, which records the benefits of American aid, first in needed food shipments and later in revival of Austrian industry and trade, was prepared as an expression of gratitude to this country, chamber officials noted.

CANTON, N. Y., Aug. 20 -- New York State's mental hospitals and institutions are severely handicapped by a lack of facilities to care for the large numbers of children and adolescents now being sent to them, Dr. Robert C. Hunt, Assistant Commissioner of the State Department of Mental Hygiene, said here tonight.

The words "room air conditioner" seem to be cropping up on more and more homemakers' shopping lists, judging from the fact that the industry, according to the Carrier Corporation, expects a sale of 600,000 such units in the United States this year.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 20 (AP) -- Winner (Vinegar Bend) Mizell won his own ball game today for the Cardinals, breaking a sixth-inning tie with a two-run double as the Redbirds scored a 5-3 victory over the Cubs.

The New York City Transit Authority decided yesterday to continue indefinitely free rides on the publicly owned transit lines for policemen, firemen, transit workers and retired employes of the system managed by the authority.

Decision was reserved yesterday by the Tax Commission after an all-day public hearing on the pleas of tenant-owners of cooperative apartments in Brooklyn and Queens for reduction of assessments on their buildings.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Aug. 20 (AP) -- Frank Strafaci of Garden City, N. Y., playing "the greatest match of my life," advanced to the quarter-finals of the Western amateur golf championship today with a remarkable display of putting.

ATHENS, Aug. 20 -- The Greek Government has informed the United States that this country's precarious economic equilibrium and hard-won currency stability will be destroyed unless Washington provides special assistance to finance an important part of the costs of reconstructing the earthquake-stricken Ionian Islands.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Aug. 20 -- Development by researchers of the Monsanto Chemical Company of a new process for increasing the production of cortisone was disclosed today in the current issue of the Journal of the American Chemical Society.
In your edition of Aug. 16 appeared an excellent letter on Central European Federation written by Anthony Palecek.

BONN, Germany, Aug. 20 -- Reorganization of the present constitutional structure of West Germany into a Presidential democracy patterned after the United States, in which the German President would be head of the Government and appoint his own Cabinet ministers, was urged today by August Martin Euhler, chairman of the Hesse branch of the Free Democratic party, one of three major parties constituting Chancellor Konrad Adenauer's coalition.
Prices on the New York commodity exchanges were mixed yesterday on slightly improved trading volume.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 20 -- Concern that the motion picture industry may be limiting rather than broadening the scope of cinematic expression by its current preoccupation with various forms of wide-screen technique was expressed today by George Stevens.
TEHERAN, Iran, Aug. 20 -- Former Premier Mohammed Mossadegh surrendered at 7 o'clock tonight to his successor, Maj. Gen. Fazollah Zahedi. He was accompanied by three of the top aides of his regime.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 (UP) -- Senator Leverett Saltonstall, Republican of Massachusetts, said today the United States would "reaffirm its traditional policy "of free fishing rights on the high seas outside the three-mile limit.

NATIVE city folk don't seem to be bothered by the oppressive embrace of brick and mortar, because they're born with skyscraper shadows across their cribs, but country folk don't breathe too well in the Great City.

PARIS, Aug. 20 -- French official quarters presented the removal of the Sultan and his family today as a measure of security to protect the ruler, possibly from death, at the hands of incensed tribesmen ready to invade the capital city from the mountains and the plains.

THE Yankees have the reputation of being much more practical and much less sentimental than either the Dodgers or Giants. But the Bronx Bombers tug tenderly at the heartstrings once each year by conducting an Old-Timers Day at the Stadium, bringing back some of the fabled heroes of the past to stir memories of yesteryear. They usually are worth bestirring.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, Aug. 20 -- Polish vessels calling here to take Ceylonese rubber to Communist China and bring back Chinese rice in exchange are thought to provide a principal channel of communication between this island's Communists and Communists abroad.

VIENNA, Aug. 20 -- Rudolf Bing confirmed in Salzburg tonight that he had been offered a contract to take over the former Berlin-Charlottenburg Opera, now Staedtische Opera in Berlin, but said he considered himself bound by the three-year renewal last June of his contract with the Metropolitan Opera.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 20 (AP) -- The president of the National Association of Margarine Manufacturers said today that the Government was considering the subsidized sale of butter in the open market to reduce its surplus stock.

RIDGEWOOD, N. J., Aug. 20 -- J. B. Matthews, ousted staff director of the Senate Investigating Committee headed by Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, canceled today his speaking date, scheduled for Sept. 17.

PEORIA, Aug. 20 -- After spirited debate, delegates to the thirty-sixth annual convention of the American Federation of Teachers, A. F. L., condemned today the practice in some areas of dismissing teachers whose only "crime" was to use the Fifth Amendment to the Constitution to protect their rights.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 20 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, asserted in an address tonight that the United States must recapture its national honor, which he said had been tarnished by the truce in Korea and the treatment accorded American soldiers by the Communists.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 20 (UP) -- The Pirates, capitalizing on loose fielding, scored all their runs in the final three innings tonight to defeat the Phillies, 5 -- 2, and stem Robin Roberts' bid for his twenty-first triumph of the season.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- Officers of the Air Force Association, expressing alarm over Air Force budget cuts and other trends in military planning, tonight proposed the creation of a permanent independent commission of leading civilians, free of military influence or pressure from any branch of the Government, to set national defense strategy.

RALEIGH, N. C., Aug. 20---Mr. Morrison was known as the "Good Roads Governof' because of a prograin of highway building begun in his 1921-25 terre as Governor. He was appointed to the'Senate in 1930 by former Gov. O. Max Gardner upon the death of Senator Lee S. Overm.

In 1837 Mrs. Caroline Kirkland, daughter of a New York publisher, set out to join her husband and settle in Pinckney, Mich., then a frontier town. As she traveled west and after settling down in Michigan, she wrote a book on her experiences, telling the truth about frontier folk and the bitter struggle of pioneer life and thereby exploding the myth of the romantic wilderness "so dear to the hearts of writers of her time."

ROCQUENCOURT, France, Aug. 21 -- Powerful telephone, radio circuits linking Supreme Allied Headquarters here with its military units over 4,000-mile "Front" have functioned at peak efficiency and without interruption during the last fortnight of nation-wide communications strikes in France.
The following is a round-up of new products that may be of interest to homemakers:

A man with a handkerchief over his mouth walked into the eighteenth floor office of Parnis-Livingston, Inc, a dress company at 530 Seventh Avenue, near Thirty-eighth Street, at 9:50 A. M. yesterday and, at pistol point, robbed a woman bookkeeper of a $4,297 cash payroll.
POTSDAM, N. Y., Aug. 21 (AP) -- A Juvenile Court judge praised modern children today as "the finest generation in our country's history."

CALGARY, Aug. 21 (AP) -- The Council of Canadian Beef Producers (Western section) reports there is an "alarming" shortage of acceptable freight cars in certain areas of Canada -- which might prevent the railways from handling any big increase in livestock exports to the United States.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 21 -- Asian and African members of the United Nations called tonight for an urgent meeting of the Security Council to take up the "unlawful intervention" of French authorities in Morocco and the overthrow of the Sultan, Sidi Mohammed ben Youssef.
BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 21 (AP) -- Millie Meyerson, 16, of Los Angeles won the national junior girls' golf title by defeating Holly Jean Roth, 16, of Milwaukee by 4 and 2 today at The Country Club.

At the dedication of the Baruch Houses this week, Commissioner Robert Moses came right to the point with his plea for "the courageous, clean-cut, surgical removal of all of our old slums." No one knows better than he that while it is desirable to encourage private capital to do as much of the job as possible, the task is simply too big and too expensive for private capital alone.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 21 (AP) -- An unofficial feeding and roosting place in this city for millions of birds is about to become official and protected. Lovers of the winged world, from bird watchers to bankers, are in on the salvage deal. Incidental, but pivotal in the situation, are the Corps of Army Engineers, the City of Philadelphia, a big-hearted oil company, a real estate deed and a spur railroad.

YOKOHAMA, Japan, Aug. 16 -- The problem of which China -- Nationalist or Communist -- should be seated in the United Nations and recognized in various capitals is being discussed in this part of the world with even more heat than in New York.

The employers' negotiating committee which has made an offer of settlement to 1,100 striking drivers of concrete-mix trucks has now properly demanded that the negotiating committee of Teamsters' Local 282 abide by an agreement to submit the proposal to a secret ballot referendum of the men.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 21 -- The Argentine Senate unanimously ap-approved today a bill designed to stimulate the influx of risk capital into the country by providing specific guarantees to foreign investors.
BOGOTA, Colombia, Aug. 21 -- The conservative newspaper El Siglo did not appear today because the editors refused to obey an order of censorship and preferred to suspend publication.

JERSEY CITY, Aug. 21 -- Henry W. (the Dutchman) Grunewald, 63-year-old mystery man of Washington tax case inquiries and political influence hearings, narrowly escaped death here early today when he and Mrs. Ann Anderson of Catonsville, Md., a 47-year-old grandmother, were found in an apartment overcome by gas.

NEW LONDON, Conn., Aug. 21 -- The second performance in the annual American Dance Festival sponsored by Connecticut College in Palmer Auditorium found Sophie Maslow and her company more or less in command tonight with the major part of the program falling to her.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Aug. 21 (AP) -- Three favorites, led by the medal-winner Frank Strafaci of Garden City, N. Y., advanced to the semi-finals in the Western amateur golf championship today, but two outsiders provided the drama at the Blythefield Country Club course.
CHICAGO, Aug. 21 (AP) -- The White Sox triumphed over the Tigers, 4 -- 1, tonight as a rookie, Mike Fornieles, turning in a five-hitter, beat Ralph Branca, one-time ace of the National League.

BLED, Yugoslavia, Aug. 21 -- Communist activity against the churches and religion in Yugoslavia appears to be increasing, as evidenced by a new rash of demonstrations not only against Roman Catholic prelates but against the leaders of the Serbian Orthodox and Moslem churches as well.

The bodies of a 53-year-old Department of Health official and his wife, 50, were found last night in their apartment at 1600 Metropolitan Avenue in Parkchester, the Bronx. They had been dead for about twenty-four hours.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Aug. 21 -- At the insistence of Prime Minister Daniel F. Malan's Nationalist Government, and with the agreement of the United party Opposition, the South African Parliament is writing into South African law the principle that all men are not equal before the law.

TOKYO, Aug. 21 (AP) -- The Communists staged two "P.O.W. Olympics" for Allied prisoners in North Korean stockades, but members of "minority groups" always won and athletic competition took a back seat to propaganda.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Aug. 21 (AP) -- Mrs. Margaret Sanger of Tucson, Ariz., founder of a birth control movement in the United States, was elected president of the new International Federation of Planned Parenthood today.

Allie Reynolds of the Yankees announced last night that the major league baseball players had hired the New York firm of Lewis and Mound as their legal representatives in dealings with the club owners.

Rabbi Norman Salit of Lawrence, L. I., president of the Synagogue Council of America, representing all branches of Judaism in this country, has announced that a national advisory committee of 100 Jewish leaders is being set up as a step to expand the council's objectives.
The experience of the Hamburg-American Line with its new "Heidelberg" class of cargo vessels has necessitated a re-evaluation of the ships and possibly new and faster schedules.

Youngsters to whom the name Lou Gehrig has only a vaguely heroic ring mingled in East Ninety-fourth Street yesterday with baseball veterans who bad been intimately associated with the great Yankee first baseman, and with a few, like Connie Mack, who were leaders in the game when Gehrig himself was a boy.

CLEVELAND, AUG. 21 (UP) -- Al Rosen hit three home runs and drove in seven runs tonight as the Indians defeated the Browns in a twilight-night double-header, 7 to 3 and 3 to 2. Bill Glynn's double in the twelfth inning of the second game off Harry Brecheen scored Bob Avila with the winning run.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- The people of the United States can be assured that the United States is and will continue to be in a preeminent position in atomic developments, Representative W. Sterling Cole, Republican of New York and chairman of the Joint Congressional Atomic Energy Committee, said this afternoon.

DETROIT, Aug. 21 (AP) -- A second attempt to kill the International Typographical Union's far-reaching Unitypo program was beaten down today in the closing minutes of the union's ninety-fifth convention.

SAG HARBOR, L. I., Aug. 21 -- A museum devoted to the typical items saved by families through the generations rather than to their works of art will go on view tomorrow along with nine private houses at the annual Open House Day tour held by the Old Sag Harbour Committee.

Because an occupational trouble of baseball players is getting beaned in the bean with what is called, logically enough, a bean ball, the chemical industry has come up with an armored answer that improves on plastic caps already in use.
CHICAGO, Aug. 21 -- Accustomed to the racing strip and acquainted with his new jockey, Native Dancer is virtually everybody's choice to take the $114,600 American Derby at Washington Park tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 (UP) -- The Voice of America is telling the world that Russia must sit on the "aggressor's side" of the Korean peace conference table because she instigated the war and supplied weapons to the North Korean Reds

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- President Quirino predicted certain victory today for his Liberal party in the November elections as a result of the withdrawal of General Romulo from the Presidential race. The President is in Washington recovering from a series of operations at Johns Hopkins University Hospital at Baltimore, Md.

MONROE, Wash., Aug. 21 (AP) -- A spokesman for the rioting inmates held in the yard of the reformatory told reporters atop the wall today that they felt the slain inmate, Walter Lyshall, 21 years old, of Seattle, was shot without justification after the peak of the riot was past.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- Average primary market prices advanced 0.3 per cent in the week ended on Tuesday to 110.8 per cent of the 1947-49 level, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. Higher prices for farm products and processed foods were responsible for the increase as the index for all other commodities remained unchanged for the sixth consecutive week.

HAVANA, Aug. 17 -- A great silence has fallen over Cuba as a result of the new so-called public-order decree issued by the Batista Government. It is a great silence, but not a complete silence. It affects political discussions, criticisms of the Government and dissemination of reports and rumors adverse to the present regime.

LONDON, Aug. 21 -- Animals in the London Zoo collection of some 5,000 suffered badly from tuberculosis during the fog year of 1952, according to a report published today by Prof. W. C. Osman Hill, the zoo's chief pathologist. The disease, he said, "has greatly increased."

There is a general tendency -- and one no doubt based upon the existing weight of evidence -- to bemoan the passage of many of the good things of life. The superhighway, for instance, and the airplane, have taken away the leisure from traveling.

After four successive month-to-month declines, commercial paper outstanding rose $21,000,000 last month to $429,000,000, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. The bank's report is based on the results of a regular monthly survey of commercial paper dealers.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 21 -- Victor Seixas threw off his shackles today and gave Tony Trabert a full measure of support in a convincing victory over Clive Wilderspin and Ian Ayre of Australia in the national doubles tennis championship.

Officials of Local 338, International Longshoremen's Association, A. F. L., one of seven locals being investigated by Kings County District Attorney Miles F. McDonald's rackets bureau, reported to the police yesterday that books and records had been stolen from their office.
PINE, Colo., Aug. 21 -- President Eisenhower presided today over a typical American fish fry and, though he caught none of the fish himself, he enjoyed himself hugely.

LONDON, Aug. 21 (Reuters) -- Charges of monopoly and high profits made against the British match industry by the Monopolies Commission last May were denied today in the annual report of the British Match Corporation.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- Administration defense leaders sought today to forestall an open break with leading exponents of air power who have been protesting that defense policies have cut deeply at this country's prime counter-attack measures against the Soviet Union.
VANDALIA, Ohio, Aug. 21 (AP) -- Raymond A. Williams of Eaton, Ohio, today won trapshooting's biggest prize, the Grand American Handicap, from a field of 1,976, largest in the event's history.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 21 -- One hundred and thirty-five longshoremen ended a two-day strike today against the Franklin Sugar Refining Company here, thus forestalling a complete shutdown of the Port of Philadelphia tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 (UP) -- A spokesman for the American Council of Education said today that fourteen colleges or universities had refused to sign a contract with the United States Armed Forces Institute because they feared it gave the Government dismissal power over teachers.

VENICE, Italy, Aug. 21 (AP) -- Hollywood chose one of its made-in-Italy products, "Roman Holiday," to open competition last night in the fourteenth annual Venice Film Festival. The Russian "Return of Vassilli Bortnikov," the first Iron Curtain entry since World War II, was offered tonight.

Since the seasonal rush is on to obtain Broadway berths and non-conflicting opening dates for incoming stage attractions, the daily theatrical dispatches are apt to dwell these days on bookings accomplished and/or schedules arranged.

FAIRFIELD, Calif., Aug. 21 (AP) -- Robert W. Toth, Pittsburgh, Pa., steelworker, arrived from Korea today under guard and said one of two Air Force members convicted of slaying a Korean citizen had "got a rotten deal."

William Holmes McGuffey, if he were living today, would know just what to say to some people who have been making mistake after mistake with a letter that left Oxford, Ohio, on June 24, headed for THE NEW YORK TIMES.

TRENTON, Aug. 21 -- Despite the fervent pleas of hunting enthusiasts and sportsmen's clubs that the shooting of bears be permitted in New Jersey, state officials turned thumbs down on the proposal early this morning. They rejected the idea even though the bear population of the state has been increasing by "leaps and splashes."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- Three New Yorkers received patents this week on a mechanical nursemaid, which, they said, is efficient and completely reliable. It holds onto the end of a perambulator, rocks it gently and steadily and does not talk to policemen.

Charley Silvera's two-out pinch single in the eleventh inning helped the Yankees score a 5-4 victory over the Athletics in a wrangle-marked contest at the Stadium last night. Philadelphia continued the game under protest after a violent ninth-inning argument that resulted in the banishment of the visiting manager, Jimmy Dykes.

Another group of building materials drivers refused yesterday to ballot on an employer offer, further decreasing the possibility of the settlement of a truck strike that has halted $600,000,000 in building and caused lay-offs for 100,000 construction workers.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 (AP) -- The Department of Justice said today it is not considering any out-of-court settlement of the long dispute over ownership of the majority stock interest in General Aniline and Film Corporation.

TOKYO, Saturday, Aug. 22 -- Maj. Gen. Blackshear M. Bryan, chief United Nations representative on the joint Military Armistice Commission, told the Communist members of that body in Panmunjom yesterday that the United Nations Command would ask the Neutral Nations Supervisory Commission to look into charges by the North Koreans and Chinese Reds that their Red Cross delegates were being restricted in contacts with prisoners at the Allies' prisoner of war camps.

If mid-city traffic is a bit more snarled than usual now, one explanation is the vast number of torn-up streets. And until the strike of sand and concrete truckers is settled pavement restoration must wait.
Zenith Radio Corporation in the six months ended June 30 reported a 75 per cent rise in sales to a new high record and an increase in earnings of 107 per cent from those of a year ago.

WESTBURY, L. I., Aug. 21 -- The No. 2 post position scored five times in a row tonight, starting with the first race and going through the fifth at Roosevelt Raceway. It was the first time that such an occurrence ever took place at the Westbury oval.
WASHINGTON, AUG. 21 (AP) -- This year's turkey crop is 8 per cent smaller than last year's.
DOVER, N. J., Aug. 21 -- Crews rescued here this morning a miner trapped six hours 1,800 feet below the surface in a cave-in at an iron-ore mine.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- Philip L. Cole, Deputy Public Printer, said today that he did not believe that any secret material had ever leaked from the Government Printing Office to any agent of an enemy of the United States. He is the security officer of the printing office.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 21 -- The Netherlands called today for a poll of members of the United Nations to find out if they wished to go ahead with a charter-revision conference in 1955, and what ideas they had for amending the organization's constitution.
PARIS, Aug. 21 -- The accession of a new Sultan in Morocco today is expected to give rise to sweeping changes in the whole Administration and in the status of the Government of the protectorate.
BAGHDAD, Iraq, (AP) -- The Shah of Iran declared tonight that Premier Mohammed Mossadegh was an "evil man."

During the first twenty days of this month, the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program collected 5,513 pints, a decrease from the total of 6,204 that was contributed by New Yorkers during the same period in 1952. This month's quota is 15,000 pints.
RABAT, Morocco, Aug. 21 -- Sidi Moulay Mohammed ben Arafa was proclaimed Sultan of Morocco today in an open air ceremony at the Imperial Palace here.
Sam Tour, general manager of Sam Tour Co., Inc., industrial consulting, research and testing concern, has been elected chairman of the metallizing committee of the American Welding Society.

The present plan for a new $2,000,000 Fulton Fish Market at Piers 17 and 18, East River, may have to be modified to provide for a project costing less than half that amount, Market Commissioner Anthony Masciarelli said yesterday at a public hearing held by the City Planning Commission.

PLYMOUTH, England, Aug. 21 (Reuters) -- Three men on a yacht will push off from here this week-end to drift as slowly as possible across the Atlantic Ocean. Their main object is to study the marine life down to the depth of ten feet.

SANTIAGO, CHILE, AUG. 21 (AP) -- President Carlos Ibanez' Government, pinched by an economic crisis, offered tonight to sell copper -- a strategic war material -- to the Soviet Union and the Soviet satellites.

Manhattan Borough President Robert F. Wagner Jr. was endorsed for the Democratic mayoral nomination yesterday by Nathan Straus Jr., who long has been identified with the New Deal wing of the Democratic party, and a group of labor union officials active in the Congress of Industrial Organizations.

MUNICH, Aug. 21 -- This is as good a place as any to seek an answer to the nagging question of effectiveness of American propaganda. Ironically enough this resurgent city, once the apple of Hitler's eye and predestined by him to be the capital of a Nazi Europe, has become the headquarters of the campaign to keep the hope of freedom alive in the Soviet empire.

WICHITA, Kan., Aug. 21 (AP) -- A Kansas judge criticised an insurance advertising campaign today as intended to influence jurors to reject damage claims, but held the advertisements did not constitute contempt of court.
A manufacturer of children's cosmetics, Helene Pessl, Inc., completed yesterday its move into a new $300,000 plant in New Rochelle, signalizing the coming-of-age of the young industry.

BERNARDSVILLE, N. J., Aug. 21 -- Chet Sanok tied the course record with a blistering 33, 33 -- 66 and teamed with Phil Dameo for a best-ball 32, 33 -- 65 that took the medal today in the qualifying round of the New Jersey Golf Association's amateur-amateur championship at the Somerset Hills Country Club.

LONDON, Aug. 21 -- The stock markets were less active today and prices moved narrowly up and down. However, British Government securities remained firm with short-medium bonds and undated loans rising slightly.

OYSER BAY, L. I., Aug. 21 -- The international six-meter boats took over the spotlight on Long Island Sound today to compete in the Old-New World Trial conducted by the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club. They were favored by excellent sailing weather. Top honors were captured by Fun, the sleek, blue-hulled craft owned and sailed by Ernest Fay of Houston.

LINDENHURST, L. I., Aug. 21 -- Hopi Indians, Winnebagos, Mohawks, Apaches and Iroquois began a three-day pow-wow tonight at the home of Princesses Blue Moon and Laughing Eyes on Glenn Street, North Lindenhurst. Also scheduled to participate in the colorful show are visitors from Mexican and Central American tribes.

Three men took a $7,000 payroll from the treasurer of a plumbing company at pistol point in Brooklyn yesterday morning. The bandits also took a .38 caliber revolver from an off-duty policeman who was accompanying the treasurer.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 21 -- Henry Cabot Lodge Jr., the United States representative at the United Nations, predicted today that India would fail to get the two-thirds majority in the General Assembly that would be required for an invitation to the impending Far Eastern political conference.

NAIROBI, Kenya, Aug. 21 (Reuters) -- Kenya Colony's bloody emergency situation showed signs of ending today, one year after white settlers had begun barricading their homes against attack by anti-white Mau Mau terrorists.

PANMUNJOM, Saturday, Aug. 22 (AP) -- Hobbling or litter-borne, white-faced American and Allied prisoners who paid with all but their lives for months in captivity, came back today from the Communist camps on the eighteenth day of Operation Big Switch.

MANILA, Aug. 21 -- Brig. Gen. Carlos P. Romulo, together with his Vice Presidential running mate on the Democratic party ticket, withdrew from the Philippine Presidential campaign tonight and announced a coalition with the Nationalist party, whose candidate is the former Defense Secretary, Ramon Magsaysay.

PEORIA, Ill., Aug. 21 -- Winding up its five-day convention, during which delegates devoted much time to defending civil liberties and assailing discriminatory practices, the American Federation of Teachers, A. F. L., went on record today as deploring the appointment of Gov. James Byrnes of South Carolina as a delegate to the United Nations.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- Unions representing seafarers are aroused by reports that the Government contemplates ending free medical care to merchant seamen.
Jefferson County, Colo., School District No. R-1, sold $3,300,000 of bonds due from 1955 to 1968 to Harriman Ripley Co., Inc., and John Nuveen Co., and associates at a bid of 96.76 for 3's.

RIVERSIDE, Conn., Aug. 21 -- Howard McMichael of Orienta Yacht Club, a boat-yard operator in Mamaroneck, N. Y., captured the Long Island Sound men's sailing championship today at Riverside Yacht Club. He won the Commodore Hipkins Trophy, emblematic of the title, by finishing the six-race final round-robin with 24 1/4 points.

District Attorney Frank S. Hogan asserted yesterday that the Rev. John M. Corridan, known as the "waterfront priest," had, in effect, retracted charges he made before a Senate committee that waterfront murders here were being "covered up" and reported by the police as "deaths from natural causes."

With reference to your excellent editorial "'Wetback' Control" in THE TIMES of Aug. 19, I should like to submit a suggestion which seems to have been overlooked so far in the discussion of how to combat this type of illegal immigration.

Officials of the State Congress of Industrial Organizations and the City C. I. O. Council asked yesterday for a meeting with the management of the struck Hearn department stores and threatened mass picketing if the company refused.

PARIS, Aug. 21 -- The Communist-led General Confederation of Labor fought hard -- in some places successfully -- to prevent the strike front in public services from breaking up today following the agreements reached between the Government and the non-Communist unions.

After more than twenty-one months of investigation, the United States Pardons Attorney's office has still not acted on a recommendation for executive clemency for a 50-year-old man who served seven and a half years for a crime committed by another.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 21 (AP) -- Southpaw Harvey Haddix blanked the Redlegs on four hits tonight to lead the Cardinals to a 4 -- 0 victory for his sixteenth triumph of the year. Steve Bilko's sixteenth homer of the season and a two-run double by Red Schoendienst drove in three of the Redbirds' runs.

Having read your Aug. 18 editorial on the wheat vote, it would seem only fair, now that the farmer has been asked whether he would rather produce a lot of wheat at low prices or less wheat at high prices, and has expressed his most astonishing preference, to ask the consumer how he feels about it.

Baseball stars of the past and present will come together today in the annual oldtimers' game, a three-inning contest that will precede the American League clash between the Athletics and the Yankees at the Stadium.

A trip to Staten Island is always a rewarding adventure for those who live in the more populous boroughs of New York, and it will become even more an occasion for reflection and relaxation as the contemplated restoration of old Richmondtown progresses. The island is rich in history, and the Staten Island Historical Society has been vigilant in guarding its treasures.

ELIZABETH, N. J., Aug. 21 -- Production was snarled today at the plant of the American Type Founders, Inc., as about 1,100 dayshift employes walked off their jobs in a dispute over wage negotiations. A. T. F., a subsidiary of Daystrom, Inc., manufacturers of presses, has been engaged in the production of guns for the Army's General Walker tanks.

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, Aug. 21 (Reuters) -- New Zealand is planning a 30-per cent increase in production of primary goods in the next twenty years, according to a Government report to be presented to Parliament today.

TEHERAN, Iran, Aug. 21 -- Tanks were deployed at strategic intersections in this capital today as the two-day-old Government of Maj. Gen. Fazollah Zahedi took precautions to keep the Tudeh (Communist) partisans underground for the first time in twenty-eight months.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 21 -- Two errors, which led to four unearned runs for the opposition cost the Giants a 7-6 defeat by the Phillies tonight at Connie Mack Stadium, and fourth place. just about the only thing left to fight for. now is seven lengths out of the New Yorkers' reach.

MONTREAL, Aug. 31 (Canadian Press) -- Jerry Barber of La Canada, Calif., retained his one-stroke lead today at the halfway point of the Labatt $25,000 golf open despite another general assault on Summerlea's par 70.
POINT PLEASANT, N. J., Aug. 21 -- "Miss Seafood Princess" was crowned here today. But it wasn't the same girl who won the title as a climax of the big Sea Day celebration on Aug. 8.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 (AP) -- J. L. Atwood, president of North American Aviation, today identified the North American F-100 as the nation's first supersonic fighter.

The passenger traffic decline predicted by the New York City Transit Authority under the 15-cent fare was 11.1 per cent, and the experience of the first three weeks of the fare rise has held remarkably close to the forecast. The decline was 10.4 per cent from the like period of 1952 in the first week, 7.84 per cent the second week, and 11.2 per cent the third week.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 (AP) -- The Army identified today forty-three additional United States soldiers reported by the Communist Command in the Korean war as having died in captivity. The Army emphasized that it was unable to verify the enemy reports and was continuing efforts to establish the facts. The names follow:

PARIS, Aug. 21 -- Two of the dominating characteristics of Sidi Moulay Mohammed ben Arafa el Alaoui, who was solemnly proclaimed Sultan of Morocco today at Rabat, are his loyalty to France over many years and his oft and sharply expressed disapproval of the Moroccan nationalist [Istiqlal] independence movement and all its works.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 (AP) -- Leaders of the air force association urged today the immediate use of atomic bombs against any future Korea-type aggression. The association's executive committee presented the recommendations in the form of a proposed statement of policy.

Dedicated this week by President Eisenhower, Governor Dewey, Mayor Impellitteri and other dignitaries, Baruch Houses on the lower East Side will house more families when completed than General Eisenhower's home town of Abilene, Kan.

RARITAN TOWNSHIP, N. J., Aug. 21 -- Carl Ballton has finally paid his month-old $2 parking fine in person -- after discovering that the United States Post Office doesn't even recognize the existence of this thirty-six-square-mile municipality.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 (AP) -- Harold E. Stassen, formerly a university president and currently chief of the foreign aid program, sat down today as grimly as any freshman and took a written examination. Three hours and a half later he took a halt -- a little dazed, but still convinced the aptitude test he had ordained for the 1,700 employee of the Foreign Operations Administration was a good idea.
MUNSAN, Korea, Saturday, Aug. 22 (AP) -- The United Nations Commands official list of United States prisoners freed in today's armistice exchange:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 (AP) -- Ted Williams blasted a three-run home run and three singles off Spec Shea to dominate Boston's 7-to-3 victory over Washington tonight in the second game of a twilight-night double-header after the Senators had won the opener, 9 -- 1.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Aug. 21 -- Mohammed Ali, Prime Minister of Pakistan, returned from New Delhi this morning after conferring since Sunday with Jawaharlal Nehru, Prime Minister of India, on a settlement of the disputed sovereignty of Kashmir. He joined his people in observance of the Moslem Day of Sacrifice.

The National Outerwear and Sportswear Association has started a campaign to circumvent demands from retailers for financial aid on advertising programs. The association condemns such demands, whether the aid asked be for a special catalogue, brochure or other medium.
THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Aug. 21 -- United States officials here are angered by what they consider a refusal by Dutch officials to inform adequately the Dutch people of United States military aid.

It is difficult to quarrel with the purely legalistic logic of the United States delegation to the United Nations concerning our position on how best to implement Paragraph 60 of the Korean armistice agreement.

THE trout is an impressionable fish, a willing, pliable, plastic sort of fellow. And that's why we have so many in New York State these days. If you'd like to have a trout believe that May 1 and not June 21 or 22 is the longest day in the year, he won't argue. It makes little difference in the life of a fish, anyway.

CAMP PERRY, Ohio, Aug. 21 (AP) -- Charles Rodgers of Phoenix, Ariz., and L. A. Wilkens of Seville, Ohio, fired perfect scores of 800 today to tie for the lead in the national small-bore rifle championship event.

A price increase of $5 a ton on kraft paperboard, a primary material for shipping and other containers, will become general next month following the lead of major producers, trade sources reported yesterday.

ANDOVER, Mass., Aug. 21 -- The Rev. William W. Lewis of Portsmouth, N. H., asserted today that delegates representing the Universalists and Unitarian Churches of the United States had received a "mandate" from local parishes to adopt a limited form of merger between the two denominations.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 21 (UP) -- Senator McCarthy opened hearings here today in an investigation which, he said, he expected "to be tremendously more important than the Hiss case." He hinted that the case involved Soviet hydrogen bomb espionage.

IT WAS Oscar Wilde (if memory serves) who once said there was no such thing as an immoral book. "Books," Mr. W. continued, "are well or badly written -- that is all." Over the years, a professional reviewer grows wary of all generalizations about writing. And yet, this yardstick seems to fit the two novels up for dissection today. One is "Galatea"* by James M. Cain, a master of the grand-guignol these many years.

LEOPOLDVILLE, Belgian Congo, Aug. 21 -- Maurice Alhadeff, a citizen of the United States with a New York office looking down into Times Square but whose principal business interests are here, has started a determined campaign to found a huge institute on the edge of Leopoldville to encourage the widespread enthusiasm for painting, sculpturing and any other art taken up by the large urban Negro populations of the Congo.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 (AP) -- Representative Burr P. Harrison, Democrat of Virginia, contends that if the Army is going to send a swarm of its detectives to parties for the big brass, it ought to pick some who do not stick out like sore thumbs and create doubt as to their fitness for the undercover assignments.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 (AP) -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, raised the issue of newspaper mail rates today in his running fight with The Washington Post and was in turn accused by the newspaper of trying to adopt "totalitarian methods of doctoring and falsifying news."

It is the responsibility of parents to avoid the danger of youngsters' being trapped in abandoned iceboxes, according to a statement issued this week by ths Institute for Safer Living of the American Mutual Liability Insurance Company of Boston.

A housewife of Lake Lincolndale, N. Y., asks how to remove "the objectionable muddy taste" that may spoil even freshly caught fresh-water fish. She raises a culinary problem of interest during the summer when so many Izaak Waltons proudly present their families with their hauls.

YONKERS, Aug. 21 (AP) -- Katie Key, owned by Pat Tuccio of Riverhead, N. Y., scored a stunning upset tonight in the $10,000 Putnam Trot as Pronto Don, the leading money-winning trotter in the world, broke stride.

MILWAUKEE, Aug. 21 -- Max Pavey, champion of the Manhattan (N. Y.) Chess Club, and Donald Byrne of Yale and Brooklyn, N. Y., won their semi-final matches today in the annual tournament for the open championship of the United States Chess Federation.
Twenty thousand pieces of Communist literature have turned up in the Bronx, and city officials admitted yesterday that they found themselves in a difficult spot.

A two-story two-family building with a four-car garage on a plot 100 by 100 feet at 4317 Atlantic Avenue in the Sea Gate section of Brooklyn has been sold by Emanuel Sanford to Jane Schachter. Ttile was insured by the Lawyers Mortgage and Title Company.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 (UP) -- The Navy has decided to send a written directive to Navy base commanders in the South to "proceed * * *toward" elimination of segregation in facilities for civilian workers.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 21 -- Dan Duryea, who last week finished a co-starring role with Audie Murphy in "Ride Clear of Diablo," signed a two-picture deal today with Universal-International. He is teamed with John Payne and Mari Blanchard in "Fort Laramie" as the first under the contract; the second picture has not been selected.

MILWAUKEE, Aug. 21 (AP) -- Eddie Mathews drilled his thirty-ninth home run, setting a club record, as the Braves tripped the Cubs tonight, 5 -- 4, for their sixth straight victory before 37,243 fans, a season high for County Stadium.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 (AP) -- The Bureau of the Census reported today the carry-over of cotton from past crops at the beginning of the 1953-54 marketing year, Aug. 1, at 5,501,942 running bales. This was described as a preliminary figure. It compared with 2,789,362 bales a year earlier.

GREAT RIVER, L. I., Aug. 21 -- Miss Peggy Mackie of Inwood and Mrs. J. B. Balding of The Creek won low gross honors in the Women's Cross County Golf Association tournament at the Connequot Country Club today. Miss Mackie carded 42, 40 -- 82 and Mrs. Balding registered 46, 42 -- 88 for a total of 170.

VIENNA, Aug. 21 -- The brain operation known as lobotomy that is widely performed on the insane in the United States has been outlawed in the Soviet Union as inhumane, Prof. Nikolai I. Oserezki, director of the psychiatric clinic of the Pavlov Institute of Medicine of Leningrad, reported here today at the closing sessions of the annual meeting of the World Federation for Mental Health.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 21 (AP) -- A wealthy New York State woman, who donated the land for the Akron Metropolitan Park near Richfield, wants all 197 acres back. She objects to plans to run the Ohio Turnpike through four acres of the park.

Acting on a tip, detectives attached to the Brooklyn homicide squad and subway transit patrolmen searched an IND subway train in Brooklyn yesterday morning for John Mazziotta, a key figure in the slaying of Arnold Schuster seventeen months ago. Mr. Schuster was responsible for the arrest of William Sutton, the bank thief.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.
