Y., Aug. 21 -- Some of the 12,458 customers stayed behind the stands, trying to pick the winner of the next race, while the $51,950 Spinaway Stakes was being run at the Saratoga track today. With only two 2-year-old fillies going after the money, there was no betting on the sixty-second Spinaway, and it turned out to be no contest from the instant George Cassidy pressed the starting button.

The United Nations will be failing in its duty if it postpones discussion of the slave labor issue, which was the subject of a special committee report last June. The report has now formally been brought to the attention of the U. N. by the United States with a request that it be debated at the next Assembly meeting, which opens on Sept. 15.

BOSTON, Aug. 21 (UP) -- Federal Bureau of Investigation agents arrested a Georgia sailor, his father and a former sailor who is now a policeman today in the 1951 burglary of $60,000 from a safe at the Quonset, R. I., Naval Air Station. A fourth man was jailed at West Palm Beach, Fla., tonight in connection with the case.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 21 -- The Dodgers' winning streak expired at Forbes Field tonight when little Murry Dickson held them to seven hits while his mates were plastering Johnny Podres and Ben Wade for nine hits, good for a 7-1 Pirate triumph.

HANOI, Vietnam, Aug. 21 (UP) -- French commandos have stormed ashore in a raid deep behind the Vietminh lines in Central Vietnam and killed eighteen rebels and captured sixty-five others, the French said today.

A group of anxious parents laid siege to the Department of Health and City Hall yesterday, demanding gamma globulin for their children, who had been exposed to a case of poliomyelitis earlier this week at Camp Delmont, near Livingston Manor, N. Y. After a six-hour wait, they were notified that the State Health Department in Albany had authorized a special allotment of the scarce blood fraction for immediate distribution.

BERLIN, Aug. 21 -- Responsible sources said today that the United States had promised the West German Government to supply all the heavy equipment necessary for its twelve divisions as soon as the European army project became effective.

CHICAGO, Aug. 21 -- The American Medical Association today announced that reports it was blocking a cancer cure and information were "vicious lies." Specifically, the A. M. A. repudiated claims favorable to a drug called "krebiozen," on which the association had reported unfavorably.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- Dr. Allen V. Astin, head of the National Bureau of Standards, consented today to remain in that post indefinitely.

CHICAGO, Aug. 21 -- Grain futures moved up in the early trade here today, offerings at the opening being light, but demand faded later and prices dropped well below yesterday's close for all grains except September corn.
This country's tariff regulations are working a hardship on the important blue cheese industry of Denmark, Robert Coe, newly appointed United States Ambassador to Denmark, declared here yesterday.

France having once again got herself into an impasse in Morocco, has solved her problem by taking the tough line. The difficulty with such "solutions," of course, is that they make matters worse in the long run.

The garage property at 4350 Broadway, owned for the past thirty-five years by the 185th Street Garage Company, has passed to new ownership in a stock sale transaction. A syndicate represented by William R. Altman, attorney, is the new owner.

Continued assistance to the nations of the Near and Middle East and "less howling about why aren't we appreciated" were urged yesterday by Dr. Buell G. Gallagher, president of City College, who returned Wednesday from a two-month trip to India, Pakistan, Turkey, Greece and Italy.
MONROE, Wash., Aug. 21 (UP) -- Prisoners ended their riot at the State Reformatory today after one had been killed and three injured.

Individual issues and groups acted independently yesterday and the stock market as a whole was virtually without tone or trend. Although THE NEW YORK TIMES averages showed an advance and more stocks rose than fell, there were only seven new highs for 1953 against thirty-three new lows.

CANTON, N. Y., Aug. 21 -- Improved diagnostic and treatment facilities must be established for actual and potential delinquents because present screening methods often were not adequate to protect the community from the juvenile killer, the sadistic killer and other dangerous aggressive individuals, a leading penological psychiatrist said here today.

Walter Sulzbach, whose letter appeared in THE TIMES of Aug. 16, suggests currency decontrol as a panacea for the European and sterling area dollar shortage. This suggestion appears to me to be nothing short of a naive proposal that the sick patient should commit suicide.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 22 -When Gov. Earl Warren comes home late next week from a vacation in Europe he will find both major political parties in California preparing for the 1954 campaign.

MOUNT VERNON, N. Y., Aug. 22 -- Stubbles of beard began to appear on the faces of 500 city officials, business men and other civic leaders today as this city of 75,000 population, on the northern rim of New York City, prepared to celebrate its 100th birthday with Madri Gras fanfare.

TOKYO, Sunday, Aug. 23 -- The Communists scheduled for completion today return of the first half of the United States prisoners of the Korean war to be repatriated under terms of the armistice agreement, with "Operation Big Switch" running well ahead of schedule.

SALEM, N. H., Aug. 22 (AP) -- O. L. Foster's Repelled, ridden by Apprentice Richard Rushworth, emerged from the pack of fourteen at the head of the stretch today to win the $15,000 Manchester Purse on Rockingham Park's closing card.
ATHENS, Aug. 22 -- While the West's attention has been focused elsewhere, progress toward an effective security system in Southeast Europe has come virtually to a dead halt.

CAMP DRUM, N. Y., Aug. 22 -The first contingents of citizen-soldiers from the New York City area began arriving at this vast northern New York military reservation early today, and before tomorrow night more than 9,000 troops of the Forty-second National Guard Division and the Seventy-seventh Reserve Infantry Division will be here to begin two weeks of summer field training.

MOSCOW, Aug. 22 (UP) -- Premier Georgi M. Malenkov attended today a reception at the East German Embassy in honor of East German Premier Otto Grotewohl. Mr. Malenkov stayed at the reception ninety minutes talking to Herr Grotewohl and other German leaders.

TAUNTON, England, Aug. 22 -- (Reuters) -- Australia's touring cricketers today gave an impressive batting display, scoring 486 all out in 5 hours 20 minutes in the first day of their three-day match against Somerset.
ORGANIZING and running a group concerned with family and child relationships is a matter of concern to parents who, come the school season, play a leadership role in their communities.

AT this moment periodicals all over the country are rushing copy into print to review, interpret, or expand some phase of the most eagerly awaited document since the Declaration of Independence. I refer, of course, to Dr. Kinsey's findings concerning sexual behavior in the human female.

BERLIN, Aug. 22 -- Both Moscow and the Western Powers renewed their diplomatic offensives in Central Europe this week. The ultimate prize of the game being played over the partitioned realms of Germany and Austria was control of the Continent and potential ascendancy in the scale of world power balances.

NO wonder the name was underlined in red on the flight list, for Eva Droumek was the Refugee Who Had Everything -- a slim figure, dark eyes under a mass of raven hair, a wistful look, the gestures of a movie star.

The belief that farmers favor less governmental interference in their operations having been disproved by the overwhelmingly affirmative vote by growers in a referendum of wheat controls a week ago, it is now apparent that the farm policy of the Roosevelt and Truman administrations will be continued with only slight variations in new legislation to be enacted at the next session of Congress.

The atmosphere at the United Nations General Assembly was tense last week. The task before the Assembly was to name the participants to the Korean political conference. Article 60 of the truce agreement says the conference shall convene ninety days after an armistice to settle "the withdrawal of all foreign forces from Korea, the peaceful settlement of the Korean question, etc."

MOSCOW, Sunday, Aug. 23 -- A joint communique was issued this morning by the Soviet Government of Premier Georgi M. Malenkov and the East German regime, announcing that the Soviet Union had agreed to forego further reparations payments from East Germany and make other economic concessions.

BOSTON, Aug. 22 -- As the United Nations General Assembly began the task of choosing representatives for the political conference on a Korean peace this week, the dividing line of opinion, pro and con, concerning the effectiveness of that organization was far from clearly defined.

RABAT, Morocco, Aug. 22 -- The trials of the deposed Sultan of Morocco stemmed almost directly from his unnatural alliance with the nationalists of the outlawed Istiqlal (Independence) party. The Sultan might conceivably have used it to strengthen his position if he had maneuvered more astutely, but when the cards were down his hand was found to be weaker than he thought.

STAMFORD, Conn., Aug. 22 -- The Little Leaguer with a major-league heart, Ronnie Sundermann, 12 years old, left his home today with his parents for Dallas, Tex., where he will receive treatment for an incurable disease of the bloomstream.

IT has been more than four years since Fred Allen quit radio, a tired man, disillusioned by the great popularity of the giveaway show and perplexed by that upstart television. In 1950 and again in 1951 he tried the video medium, but mercifully both shows were pardoned after short terms.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 -- After nearly six months of voluntary exile, Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois returned to the United States this week to resume his role as the titular head of the Democratic party and the leader of the loyal opposition to President Eisenhower's Administration.

WHENEVER a frame house needs repainting, the home owner is up against a real problem. House painters as a rule go about their work with a single-mindedness that can turn landscaping into a shambles in the space of a week.
DES MOINES, Iowa, Aug. 22 -- Most Midwesterners this week continued to regard the United Nations with respect and with some hope, even though the latter feeling was diluted by skepticism.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 22 -- Victor Seixas of Philadelphia and Tony Trabert of Cincinnati went down to defeat in the national doubles tennis championship today at the Longwood Cricket Club. Reversing the result of their meeting Sunday at Newport, Mervyn Rose and Rex Hartwig of Australia overcame the team that has been looked upon as our prospective Davis Cup combination.

ATHENS, Aug. 22 -- Field Marshal Alexander Papagos, Premier of Greece, left Athens late today to visit the Ionian Islands of Cephalonia, Zante and Ithaca, devastated since Aug. 9 by a series of disastrous earthquakes. He was accompanied by Gen. Christos Karatzenis, director of the Premier's Office, who is in charge of coordinating relief operations in the islands.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 -- When Congress quits and goes home, as it did a little while ago, it doesn't necessarily mean that David Lynn, architect of the Capitol, goes on vacation, too.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 -- The United States, to an expert observer standing with his back against the Iron Curtain, "does indeed look vulnerable," Harold E. Talbott, Secretary of the Air Force, said tonight.

YOU ask me to say something about the composition of "Brother to Dragons." I don't have much in the way of great generalization about long poems. For one thing, I reckon I am still too close to the particular problems encountered in trying to write this particular long poem. But I may mention some of those.

FAIRFAX DOWNEY gives a new twist to the story of Robert E. Lee by telling it in terms of the horses that carried the great leader in peace and war -- from Tom and Jerry, whom he rode in 1846 at Fort Hamilton, N. Y., to Traveller, who carried Lee gallantly through many of the campaigns of the Civil War.

VENICE is preparing for the yearly gathering of the film clan. In and about the spacious film palace carpenters and painters are hard at work, enormous posters spring up overnight, and many other exterior trappings that go with an event of this kind are being readied for the big show.
SOUTHPORT, Conn., Aug. 22 -- Briggs S. Cunningham of the Pequot Yacht Club, sailing his Spindrift, retained the Atlantic Class national championship as the three-day series ended at Pequot today.

IF current negotiations are successfully concluded -- and indications are that it is a foregone conclusion -- Sugar Ray Robinson, retired world middleweight boxing champion who has been performing in night clubs as a dancer, will make his debut as a television actor during the premiere showing of "Excursion," the TV-Radio Workshop of the Ford Foundation children's show, over the N. B. C. television network on Sunday, Sept. 13 from 3:30 to 4 P. M.

EASTON, Pa., Aug. 22 -- The Marquis de Lafayette's own copies of The Journal de Paris, first daily journal published in France, dating from Oct. 23, 1789, to Dec. 30, 1789, have been added to the extensive memorabilia about the marquis in the Lafayette College library.
LONDON, Aug. 22 (Reuters) -- Results of today's football games:

Another turn has been given to the intense political campaign in the Philippines. Brig. Gen. Carlos P. Romulo has withdrawn his candidacy for the Presidency and has thrown his support to the opposition Nacionalista candidate, Ramon Magsaysay. He has announced that he will not be a candidate for an elective office and the Democratic party that he headed, when he bolted President Quirino's Liberals, has made a coalition with the Nacionalistas.
PARIS, Aug. 22 -- France will withdraw from any discussion of the deposition of the Sultan of Morocco in the United Nations Security Council, it was learned here today.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 22 -- Iron ore stocks in furnace yards and on lake docks increased by 6,759,281 tons last month despite the heaviest July consumption on record, according to statistics compiled by the Lake Superior Iron Ore Association.

For the first time in several years Communist Rumania opened its doors to Western correspondents for several days earlier this month, permitting them to go to Bucharest for an international Communist rally called the "World Youth Festival." An interesting series of articles in these pages by John MacCormac recently told what these correspondents learned.

OYSTER BAY, L. I., Aug. 22 -- Postmaster John A. McGarr, who presides over the fifteen-year-old L-shaped Government Building built to replace the country office used by Theodore Roosevelt when his home. Sagamore Hill, was the summer White House, is up to his arms in mail as he sits at his desk.

At 2 P. M. last Wednesday, a citizen entered the voters' registry office on Broome Street in lower Manhattan, signed an application form thus and then signed the registry book and marked an "X" under the Republican eagle.
TOKYO, Sunday, Aug. 23 (AP) -- Japan will need more territory in a few years if the living standards of its growing population are to be maintained, a Government White Paper said today.

MAHWAH, N. J., Aug. 22 -- Eighteen young persons from ten states dispersed last night after a farewell supper here in the new community room that they had built in the course of an eight-week work camp organized by the American Friends Service Committee.
PASADENA, Calif., Aug. 22 (UP) -- Fortune Gordien, former University of Minnesota star, broke his own world record in the discus today with a throw of 194 feet 6 inches.

LONDON, Aug. 22 -- Hopes for eventual agreement upon a revised Constitution for Nigeria rose today when the Action Group, representing Western Nigeria, returned to the constitutional conference here and joined in the signing of the final report recommending amendments to the present charter.

A spokesman for the Communist party said yesterday that he had submitted a bid of $100 for some 20,000 pieces of Communist literature and several items of office equipment now in the possession of the Bronx Bureau of Encumbrances.
BLED, Yugoslavia, Aug. 22 -- Communist leaders of Yugoslavia have begun a widespread purge of their party ranks. It is still too early to tell whether any prominent persons will be affected.

LONDON, Aug. 22 -- "Remarkable advances" in the development of guided rockets for use against enemy aircraft were announced today by Duncan Sandys, Britain's Minister of Supply, on the eve of his departure for Australia to arrange this autumn's atomic tests on the Woomera range there.

Budgetary reductions in Customs Service funds have necessitated some "spreading" of personnel, but this will not materially affect its service to the public. Robert W. Dill, Collector of the Port, asserted yesterday.

SAUGUS, Mass., Aug. 22 -- Modern construction machinery is reproducing the buildings that constituted one of the nation's oldest industrial landmarks, an iron foundry dating back to 1646, in the center of this suburban residential community ten miles north of Boston.

The Athletics, with Marion Fricano and Morrie Martin on the mound, defeated the Yankees, 10 -- 4, at the Stadium yesterday. Preceding the league game, two teams of former stars played a two-inning exhibition as part of the Old-Timers' Day celebration.

No person or institution -- not even the United States Supreme Court -- can prevent the determined American shopper from buying some needed goods at a discount, several leading store executives agreed last week.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 -- The surprise in the Eisenhower Administration's statement of an electric-power policy this week was that the Department of the Interior made it a formal document. Its contents added up to what Administration officials, including the President, have long been saying, although the wording of the new statement in some instances was on the vague side and only future actions will clear their meaning.

THE first Thanksgiving, held in Plymouth in 1621, has become enshrined in an American institution. In the seventeenth century. New England observed many days of rejoicing, but none in imitation of this original; all were ordered "pro temporibus et causis," according to the manner in which providence was dealing with the land.

ELIZABETH, N. J., AUG. 22 -New apartment construction with 215 dwelling units, a shopping center, an office building, a public park and off-street parking facilities are proposed in a re-use plan the Elizabeth Redevelopment Agency approved today for its Washington Avenue project area.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (AP) -Registered lobbyists spent $2,377,000 in connection with their "legislative interests" in the first six months of this year.

Borough President Robert F. Wagner Jr., candidate for the Democratic Mayoral nomination, announced yesterday a program for improving housing conditions that he would espouse if elected. He laid stress on the development of publicly aided housing for middle-income families.

Eager to show the old boys how it's done today, Casey Stengel's Yankees of 1953, apparently headed for an almost surefire fifth straight pennant, put on a performance at the Stadium yesterday, which, coming as a climax to the Bombers' annual Old-timers Day, must have puzzled the stars of other years no end.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (UP) -- Federal Housing officials said today seventy cities that had asked for Federal aid for slum clearance must submit new information before their applications could be considered. Names of the cities were not given.

INDO-CHINA, with its seething nationalistic spirit and resentment against the white man (coupled with its dependence upon him and what he brings) is the locale of this interesting, fast-paced novel. Few Americans know or understand much about the conflict between the French and the Vietminh in Indo-China, except that it is (in part) a chapter in the world struggle against communism.

LONDON, Aug. 22 -- It is not at all certain that the British people, after facing economic stagnation between the wars, a period of slight recovery in the Nineteen Thirties, a wartime crisis and post-war austerity, would recognize a boom if they saw one.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 22 -- A degree of normalcy returned to Forbes Field today when the Dodgers resumed their season-long practice of beating the cellar-dwelling Pirates. The Brooks won, 5 -- 3, before 7,033 cash customers and 2,567 Knothole Club kids.

Indiscriminate criticism of banking provoked by the opponents of the Administration's monetary policies is likely to narrow the competitive breach betweeen New York's savings and commer cial banks. This is the view of savings bank executives who assert that any such attacks affect the entire banking industry since the general public usually does not differentiate between types of banking institutions.

TO a large extent, a racing driver feels about his car -- assuming they are both worthy -- the way a sailor feels about his ship. But a ship is a home, and a well-equilibrated car is a bride -- generally compliant and often inspired.

CHICAGO, Aug. 22 -- Fred T. Whiting, vice president of Westinghouse Electric Corporation and a civic leader in this city, was reported today to be missing since Thursday in a fishing accident in British Columbia. The 62-year-old industrialist was believed to have drowned.

BOSTON -- The 1953 motorist in his high-powered car whips through New England covering in an hour the distances it used to take a stagecoach two hard days of driving to cover. If the motorist will only slow down a bit as he goes, he can still see traces of the stagecoach era.

Mid-August is usually regarded as a time of relaxation, of vacations, of escape from the world of affairs, of the quiet doldrums of lazy dog days. In contrast to that conception we have just gone through one of the most fateful weeks in the post-war period. From a news point of view this has been literally a tremendous week.

In December, 1931, Karl Jansky of the Bell Telephone Laboratories was studying "static" from thunderclouds. He had a radio receiver fifty feet in diameter, mounted on wheels so that it could be turned on a brick runway. Even when there were no thunderstorms he received feeble radio signals -- hisses like the background noise sometimes heard when the volume knob on a radio set is turned up.

FOUR years ago Burt Lancaster visited Columbia studios to discuss a film job. "Let's do a typical Burt Lancaster picture," the studio heads suggested. "And what's a typical Lancaster picture?" asked the star. "Why -- 'The Killers,' of course." they replied enthusiastically.

MOSCOW, Aug. 22 -- Uvelyan Davidovich Topuridze - Sumbatov, deputy chairman of the Council of Ministers of Azerbaijan and for many years a member of the Azerbaijan Central Committee of the Communist party, has been removed from his post and relieved of his honors by action of the Azerbaijan Supreme Soviet.

NAIROBI, Kenya, Aug. 22 (Reuters) -- The East African Appeals Court upheld today the seven-year prison term awarded to Jomo (Burning Spear) Kenyatta and five other natives for managing the Mau Mau, anti-white terrorist cult of Kikuyu tribesmen.

ONE of the most disturbing things about the recent revolt in East Germany is that hardly anyone in the West expected it. The completeness of our surprise is a measure of the awe in which we stand of the Communist evil. We seem convinced that it has a boundless power to shape and crush men's souls.

PLYMOUTH, Vt., Aug. 22 (AP) -- Calvin Coolidge, a solitary, retiring figure in life, is almost lost in death. His grass-grown grave in an unkempt cemetery is hard to find without a guide. Only the Great Seal of the United States on the small headstone indicates that his life differed from those of the farmer ancestors who lie buried with him.
The article by Emily Amber (whoever she may be) about children at camp revealed hostility to camping and insensitiveness to children.

PHILADELPHIA Aug. 22 -Shabby support made it an untrue test as Sal Maglie tried his ailing right shoulder against the Phillies and failed to survive the second inning tonight at Connie Mack Stadium. The Giants' 36-year-old right-hander, in his first outing since Aug. 11, when he had to stop pitching after four innings, was the loser, 7 -- 1, in the opener of the twilight-night double-header.

Violent changes over the last year in the international trade picture have pushed the pound sterling back above par, created a "sterling gap" in some parts of the world and set the Bank of England busily to work on correctives.
AUCKLAND, New Zealand, Aug. 12 -- Novel methods and great enterprise are being used in a national drive to make New Zealand one of the world's leading home-owning nations.

LOGANSPORT, Ind., Aug. 22 (AP) -- Federal Bureau of Investigation agents today seized a man who they said was wanted for the killing of a Kansas City priest and as a suspect in recent slayings on the Pennsylvania Turnpike.

In the Topics of the Times of Aug. 16 you recall the orchestral performance of Andre Gretry's monarchist song "O Richard, O my King," at the royal dinner in Versailles on Thursday, Oct. 1, 1789. Your readers may be interested in knowing that such "royalist" operas as "Richard the Lion-Hearted" got the composer into plenty of trouble with the revolutionaries.
A new type of collapsible tank, which is able to carry bulk liquid cargo one way and dry-cargo on the return voyage, has been developed in England.
FREEDOM VILLAGE, Korea, Aug. 22 -- A soldier no one ever expected to see again came back this morning.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 22 (UP) -- Mike (Big Bear) Garcia kept his hopes for another twenty-victory season alive today by pitching a five-hitter for his fifteenth triumph as the Indians beat the Browns, 4 -- 1.

EAST HAMPTON, N. Y. -- During the past fortnight a new ferryboat service connecting Long Island and Connecticut has been put in operation, providing a third route for motorists and other sight-seers shuttling across the Sound.

Edward J. Flynn, Democratic leader of Bronx County or the past three decades, National Democratic Committeeman from New York, and National Democratic Chairman from 1940 to 1943, was the archtype of the big-city political boss. He had a simple rule of survival in the rough political game.
Hold-up men were busy early yesterday in Manhattan and the Bronx. They held up five men in four robberies in the two boroughs.

TEACHING conditions in Washington Territory in 1884 would have made the pulse of the average P. T. A. leader today flutter with outrage and indignation. For her pay of $50 a month Katherine Duncan, age 17, not only had to discipline rugged young frontiersmen older than herself, but she also was expected to help with the cooking and housework at the Carlson home, where she shared a bed with one of the 6-year-olds.

" Anything that can be measured can be controlled, and there are fewer and fewer things that cannot be measured." That is the platform of Henry F. Dever, president of the Brown Instrument division of the Minneapolis-Honeywell Regulator Company.

DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Aug. 22 (AP) -- George Stewart of Newark, N. J., won his fourth consecutive national Negro men's championship today in the thirty-sixth American Tennis Association tournament at Bethune-Cookman College by defeating Eartha Jacquert of Los Angeles, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 1, in the final.

VANDALIA, Ohio, Aug. 22 (AP) -- This peaceful village settled down for a fifty-one-week nap late today as the echo of the 1,493,800th shot in the fifty-fourth Grand American trapshoot faded across the Miami Valley.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (AP) -- The Defense Department identified 176 additional Korean war casualties today in a list that reported forty-six killed, 120 wounded, one missing and nine injured. Those form New York (none from New Jersey or Connecticut) follow:

RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 22 (AP) -- Two of Latin America's most powerful men -- President Getulio Vargas of Brazil and President Manuel Odria of Peru -- will meet here next Tuesday for talks expected to have important results both for their own nations and for the continent.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 -- The Post Office Department put the finishing touches this week on regulations under which other Government agencies and Congress will pay it for mail service.
A special wheat advisory committee appointed by Secretary of Agriculture Benson has, according to news reports, "recommended discussion of a 'two-price' marketing program for wheat."

At 2:27 this morning a despondent 23-year-old naval veteran who for thirteen and a half hours had been threatening to jump to his death from the fourteenth floor of the Brooklyn Veterans Administration Hospital gave way to the tearful pleadings of a rabbi and stepped through a window to safety.
GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Aug. 22 -- Dick Norton, a skinny youngster from Grand Rapids, and Dale Morey, a salesman, reached the final of the Western amateur golf championship today.

HONG KONG, Aug. 22 -- Vice Admiral Joseph J. Clark, commander of the United States Seventh Fleet, said at a press conference here today that the United States was not encouraging Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek's Nationalist Government in Formosa to attempt an invasion campaign against Communist China.

American dry cargo and tank vessels carried more than half of all overseas shipments of Mutual Security Program cargoes during the fiscal year ended June 30, according to a report to Congress last week by President Eisenhower.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (UP) -The Government had more than $178,000,000,000 to spend in the twelve months that ended last June 30, and up to June 1 had managed to get rid of only $65,900,000,000 of it, a Congressional committee reported today.

BOSTON, Aug. 22 -- A resolution calling for the American Bar Association to undertake a study of the "purposes, scope and procedures of legislative investigating committees," was drafted today by a Richard Wait, a past president of the Massachusetts Bar Association.

IN this latest (and apparently the last) book of the Santayana canon we have a collection of work hitherto unpublished. There are a few lyrics, some of them obviously late; some early transactions, and two verse plays:

EXCEPTING that phenomenon known as "Gone With the Wind," which not only broke all existing box-office records but reached a saturation point in pre-release publicity no other movie has quite duplicated, Stanley Kramer feels there is more public expectancy about his picturization of "The Caine Mutiny" than over any movie before or since the panoramic drama of the Civil War.

THE growing acceptance of advanced modern design by the American public is documented by the three houses illustrated here. They were designed over a four-year period by Architect Charles Goodman. All were shown as model houses at Hollin Hills, Alexandria, Va., the project that has been called by critics "the best single development in the country."

ANENT Peter Wynne's letter defending Martin Van Buren against my charge that he was a "Northern man with Southern principles." Van Buren was indeed the candidate of the Free Soil party in 1848, but this was some time after his Presidency and the Amistad case.

CHORE FOR THE WEEK: Cut dead flowers from annuals and perennials, roses and summer-blooming shrubs. This prevents seed formation, thus prolonging bloom on annuals and stimulating second bloom on many perennials. Phlox and delphinium, for example, are starting another display. And if plants in a border are crowded now, make room for better flowering by snipping out surplus or straggling branches.

First word of the earthquakes in the Ionian Islands came from Ithaca, which was immediately identified as the home of Odysseus, or Ulysses. All that has happened to Ithaca, in modern Greek Thiaki, since the days of Odysseus -- who must have lived about 1200 B. C. -- has been generally overlooked.

THE Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival, near Lee, Mass., which has only two more weeks to go, will present a mixed program this week on which Myra Kinch and her company will represent the modern dance, Yvonne Chouteau and Gilbert Reed the ballet, and the Japanese dancer, Sahomi Tachibana, the ethnological branch.

TENNIS week in Newport is no longer such an overwhelming event in itself as to exclude attractions other than those of the beach and of the Casino. At the Cushing Memorial Charles Baskerville is holding an exhibition of paintings and drawing done over the past fifteen years.
Christians were urged yesterday "to study, pray and work for a better fulfillment of the purposes of the United Nations Charter."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (UP) -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, asked the Post Office Department today to submit estimates on the cost of "subsidizing distribution" of The Washington Post, The Wall Street Journal, and The Daily Worker, a New York Communist paper.

Bishop Nikon in his letter, published on Aug. 16, thinks that victory over communism will be made easy if the Russian people are on our side. However, in order for them to be "on our side," Bishop Nikon demands that the American press cease supporting separatist nationals hostile to Russia.

VIENNA, Aug. 22 -- A decision to "raise the standard of living of the Rumanian people as soon as possible and to overcome difficulties in supply" was taken at a meeting of the Central Committee of the Rumanian Workers (Communist) party at a meeting Wednesday and Thursday, according to a Bucharest radio broadcast today.
TRENTON, Aug. 22 (AP) -- Stamford, Conn., banged out three home runs today to win the Little Bigger League World Series for the second year in a row over Burlington, N. J., 6 -- 3.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 22 -- India will not withdraw her name from consideration as a participant in the Far Eastern political conference before the test vote scheduled for next week. United Nations diplomats reported today that the instructions from New Delhi to the Indian delegation were to stay in the contest despite the public announcement from the United States that Washington would cast its vote against India's participation.

LIKE Benjamin Franklin, Alan Paton, the politician, is flying a kite into the thundery South African racial skies to draw off some, at least, of the lightning and neutralize it in his recently formed Liberal party, of which he is vice president -- a titular, not executive, office.

PARIS, Aug. 22 -- Despite continued opposition from the Communists, France's postal, telephone and telegraph services were slowly getting back to normal today as a majority of the workers abided by the decision of the non-Communist unions to end the sixteen - day strike.

IF you are unsettled by the performance of your phonograph and baffled by the cause, several of the new test records may help you pin down what ails the machine. Test records have been available for many years, but the LP revolution has transformed them, along with everything else phonographic.

Your editorial of Aug. 18 correctly points out that the latest Soviet note on Germany calls in effect for "a complete surrender of Western policies and principles and a triumph of Soviet designs for ultimate control of all of Germany." The proposal is wholly unacceptable. Yet its mere rejection will not further the cause of peace.
HAMMOND, Ind., Aug. 20 (UP) -- Almost every day for a year, John Anderson, 29 years old, has brought a snare drum with him to his job as a porter in a clothing store.
STOCKHOLM, Aug. 22 (AP) -- American and Russian star musclemen here for the world weightlifting championships on Aug. 26-30 got together in a local gym today -- and played ping pong.

The itinerary of the superliner United States has been extended to include a call at Bremerhaven, Germany, during the winter months, officials of the United States Lines said yesterday in announcing the schedules of that ship and the America for the next nine months.

FOR Susan Maynard, at 12, it was novel and exciting, after nine years in a children's home, to join her musician father. Even if her big 'cello sometimes seemed more nuisance than joy, it made Susan a Chautauqua trouper, back in the early Nineteen Hundreds.

IN his wonderfully entertaining new book, "My Uncle Louis," Robert Fontaine is so personal as to make reviewing extremely difficult. A semi-fictional account of his own boyhood, it could only have been written by the son of a French-Canadian musician and a Scotch Presbyterian housewife.
MEXICO CITY, Aug. 22 (UP) -- The imprisoned killer of Leon Trotsky has been "definitely identified" as a Spanish Communist named Ramon Mercader del Rio Hernandez, it was announced today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 -- The intransigence of the Soviet Union makes the prospect for the international control of atomic energy "dim," Gen. Walter Bedell Smith, Acting Secretary of State, has advised Senator Alexander Wiley, Republican of Wisconsin.

Gilbert Millstein's article, "Sports-Car Society" (Aug. 16), was a good explanation of the "pom-pon" set which is not representative of the sports-car field. The pompons make up a small, loud and objectionable segment.

IN "Childhood's End," Arthur C. Clarke joins Olaf Stapledon, C. S. Lewis, and probably one should add H. G. Wells, in the very small group of writers who have used science-fiction as the vehicle of philosophic ideas -- not merely ideas about the nature of future society, but ideas about the End of Man.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 -- A State Department official was authorized today to say that the United States "views with deep concern" the developments that have led to the removal of Sultan Sidi Mohammed ben Youssef of Morocco by France and "earnestly hopes" for the restoration of order in the inflamed North African territory.

ANKARA, Turkey, Aug. 5 -German influence again is predominant in Turkey's foreign commerce. The West German Federal Republic is this country's best customer and its leading supplier, already accounting for more than a quarter of both Turkey's imports and exports.

RABAT, Morocco, Aug. 22 -- The new Sultan of Morocco. Sidi Mohammed ben Moulay Arafa, arrived today amid a display of Oriental pageantry and ascended the throne left vacant by the banishment on Thursday of his predecessor, Sidi Mohammed ben Youssef.

OTTAWA, Aug. 21 -- The brown wheat is lying stacked in the flat fertile fields of the western prairies. It is another bumper crop. What to do with the embarrassment of riches until the wheat is sold and turned into cash is causing the Canadian Government some concern.

PLOT synopses can be most misleading. Say that a novel is about a kidnapping, an international dope ring, and a curious cult which mixes black magic with narcotics and sex perversion and your listener will take for granted that you refer to the latest slam-bang private-eye opus.

BERLIN, Aug. 22 -- The dissident group in East Germany's Politburo sought last month to oust Walter Ulbricht from the leadership of the party, and to install Rudolph Herrnstadt in his place, according to the official Communist newspaper, Neues Deutschland.

American industry has at last awakened to the fact that it must train men to take the top executive jobs. A great many leaders were not trained for their posts at all, but, like Topsy, "jes' growed" into them.

ANSCO announces five new camera flash outfits varying in price from $9.75 to $197.34. Designed for the Christmas trade, the outfits will become available next month. Each outfit contains a camera, a flash unit, film and flash lamps.

MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 22 (AP) -- The Green Bay Packers pooled a procession of intercepted passes and long-gaining punt runbacks to rout the New York Giants, 31 -- 7, in a charity exhibition football game tonight.

IN spite of the late, wet spring that was followed by a serious, early-summer drought in most sections of the country, gladiolus exhibitors have managed to bring to flower shows this month many spikes of excellent quality. Some growers have overcome the adverse weather conditions by irrigating their plantings; others used mulches to conserve moisture.
MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 22 (AP) -- Clyde Hippenstiel, 31-year-old San Bernardino, Calif., civil engineer, gained the final of the National Public Parks tennis tournament today.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Aug. 22 -- Objections to projected state thruway construction in Westchester have diminished until organized opposition now exists only in three or four communities, James C. Harding, County Commissioner of Public Works, reported today.

THE third book in Ralph Moody's series of boyhood reminiscences represents a continuation of the ingratiating narrative style, the rich variety of incident that characterized the two earlier books in the series.

SALT LAKE CITY, Aug. 22 -- Utah teachers, engaged in a stubborn battle for added educational funds with economy-minded Gov. J. Bracken Lee, may refuse to open public schools throughout the state in September.

THERE'S a bit of red tape, not much, for American sportsmen planning trips to Canada or Mexico this fall to hunt ducks, geese and other migratory birds. Government officials at the borders are very nice people, we find, if you have complied with all the regulations pertaining to the exportation and importation of such birds.

As soon as the Korean truce was announced someone started to spread abroad the idea that the next demand of the Chinese Communists would be for admission into the United Nations, that India would sponsor this demand, and that after all Red China should be taken in.

LUCY FREEMAN, reviewing Helen Bryan's "Inside," states that Miss Bryan had been imprisoned for refusing to name recipients and donors to the Joint Anti-Fascist Refugee Committee, adding that this group had "sent funds and medical relief to Spanish Republican refugees."

WHEN asked "why I write in verse," I have a ready answer: "Because that is easier for me." Maybe I should demonstrate by writing this article in meter. Prose, however, is better for explanation. We shall see that poetry is supreme for suggestiveness.

The Department of Parks Marionette Theatre, which has been touring parks and playgrounds in the five boroughs since June 15, will close its season with a tour of Manhattan park playgrounds, beginning tomorrow with a performance in the East River Park, Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive and Sixth Street, at 2:30 P. M.

Rodents -- and squirrels are rodents -- are to most of us typical hoarders. But many other animals, from kangaroos to birds, hoard. Worms, grass, berries, pellets of wood, snails and other things are hoarded. While we are about it, we may as well include human beings who hoard paper bags, string, chewing gum wrappers and what not.
Literature, television and advertising customs have suffered a three-way smash-up, with the title of a Rudyard Kipling novel the only victim.

BACH: Sonata in G major for 'Cello; Chorale: Herzlich Tut Mich Verlangen; BLOCH: Nigun from Baal Shem; DEBUSSY-HEIFETZ: Beau Soir and others; Pierre Fournier, 'cellist, with Ernest Lush at the piano (London). Suavely beautiful playing in a "recital" by one of the finest of living 'cellists.

ANDOVER, Mass., Aug. 22 -- A need for a "liberal" religion and "a new birth of freedom," unmatched since the decay of the Roman Empire and the rise of Christianity, was seen here today by Dr. Karl Deutsch of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 22 (AP) -- Joseph Littman of Paterson, N. J., laundryman, and Mario Balestreri, a California strawberry grower, have been convicted of being part of the nation-wide heroin syndicate of the late Irving Wexler, more widely known by his underworld name, Waxey Gordon.
A HOT dish on a hot day is an ancient East Indian custom that can be refreshing. The favorite dish in this instance is curry, named after the mixture of ground spices that gives it so fiery a flavor.

President Warren Giles of the National League criticized the major league players' idea of hiring a lawyer to represent them yesterday, while J. Norman Lewis, the players' choice, went ahead with plans to meet tomorrow with Commissioner Ford Frick and baseball's executive council.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Aug. 22 -- The newspaper El Siglo bowed to the censor's orders and appeared today with virtually the entire front page devoted to Thursday night's radio speech by Dr. Lucio Pabon Nunez, Minister of the Interior, criticizing the administration of former President Laureano Gomez, founder of El Siglo.

The enactment of the "Technical Changes Act of 1953" introduces at least one loophole-closing provision and seeks to alleviate some inequities in the Internal Revenue Code. This discussion deals with only a few of these measures.

SINGAPORE, Aug. 22 -- The holding of federal Malayan elections by 1956 was recommended today in a draft program announced by a working committee representing Mentris Besar, the Prime Ministers of the nine Malay states.

ALPINE, N. J. -- A 150-acre tract of public parkland where roadblock, poison ivy and forbidding signs discourage the general run of picnickers and hikers is drawing bird lovers and students of nature from many parts of the nation.

SUMMER has an enervating effect upon business much in the same manner that it affects people. But with all ears attuned for any possible interruption in the even rhythm of industrial activity because of the Korean armistice, there can be a tendency to confuse the seasonal letdown with the beginning of a recession despite the fact that all economic indices belie it.

IN England, the mood this summer has been one of national euphoria. The beauteous young Queen has been crowned with fairy tale pomp, and her adoring subjects see themselves as the Elizabethans of the twentieth century. Magic and hope fill the English air these days: Shakespeare's sceptered isle is being reborn.

LONDON, Aug. 22 (Reuters) -- The British Government approved the building of a "skyscraper" near St. Paul's Cathedral, and a spokesman for connoisseurs of old London cried that it would make the capital into "a kind of New York."

THE recent article by Geoffrey Brown on the deplorable state of affairs existing in the theatre sums up the situation neatly but fails to offer any solution. As a young playwright, I am only too well aware of the commercial barriers of the box office with their atrophying effect on striving creative talent.

MAUREEN CONNOLLY, at 18 the top woman tennis player in the world and the only one in history who has held all four of the world's major crowns -- American, British, Australian and French -- at one and the same time (in fact, at any time), is going after her third successive national championship this week at Forest Hills.

PRINCETON, N. J., Aug. 22 -- A comprehensive inquiry into contemporary Islamic culture will take place in a twelve-day international conference beginning at Princeton University on Sept. 8. Entitled "Colloquium on Islamic Culture in Its Relation to the Contemporary World," the conference is under the joint sponsorship of Princeton and the Library of Congress.

PAUL REYNAUD has recently said that the problems facing France today are more serious than those facing her on the eve of her Great Revolution. He is right; they are more serious, more difficult, and, paradoxically, one of them is the Great Revolution itself, and its results, both material and spiritual.

MONROE, Wash., Aug. 22 (UP) -Guards armed with submachine guns seized home-made knives and other weapons today in a painstaking search of 150 Washington State Reformatory convicts who caused $2,500,000 damage in a prison riot this week.

DAKAR, French West Africa, Aug. 12 -- The French authorities here are betting on their policy of assimilation to secure their vast West African territories against the convulsions that have made things so awkward for the British in Nigeria and the Gold Coast.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va. -- More and more tourists are discovering the fascination of Monticello, Thomas Jefferson's mountaintop mansion here. For the last five years, annual attendance records have been successively broken. As of the middle of the present month, the gate count since Jan. 1 stood at 151,165; for the same period last year it was 138,805.

WESTBURY, L. I., Aug. 22 -- Crystal Hanover, Dean Hanover mare driven by Henry Myott, turned in a new track trotting record for 4-year-old mares of 2:03 4-5 to win the $5,000 Connecticut by a length over Darn Flashy at Roosevelt Raceway tonight.

The United States All-Stars defeated the best of New York's aces, 5 -- 1, in the eighth annual Hearst Sandlot Classic at the Polo Grounds last night. The diamond test held the featured place on the unique basketball-baseball twin bill, but most of the 29,480 persons at the park were there to watch the fabulous Harlem Globetrotters.

IN Salem, in 1692, Tim Tetlow, the tinker's son, is more worried about his friends' sudden hostility than about the grownups' talk of witches. Tim's Granny and his clever, easygoing father have told him that witches do not exist.

For twenty-eight months the kingdom of Iran has been the most troubled spot in the troubled Moslem world. During these months Iran -wedged up against the Soviet border and standing at the gateway to the world's richest oil resources -- has moved steadily, under tremendous internal and external pressures, toward a closer association with Russia.

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Aug. 22 -- William H. Stanley's Bumble Bee, with Arthur Knapp at the tiller, set the pace throughout to top the Internationals in the Huguenot Yacht Club's regatta on Long Island Sound today.

MOSCOW, Sunday, Aug. 23 (UP) -- The Soviet Union called today for speedy action on a German peace treaty and creation of an all-German Provisional Government to prepare for reunification of the divided country.

TRENTON, Aug. 22 -- The annual New Jersey State Fair, to be held here from Sept. 27 through Oct. 4, will be a bigger and better exposition than ever this year, according, to its promoter. Many new features are planned and a new building is being erected on the fair grounds to house additional exhibits.

Plans for an unusual, comprehensive senior high school, to be constructed along the lines of a university campus, have been announced in Newport, R. I. The school, consisting of eight separate buildings, connected by covered walks, will meet the need for an anticipated growth in secondary school enrollment.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 22 -- Dr. Nathan Goodman, author and teacher of American History at Central High School here, plunged to his death today from the Henry Avenue Bridge over Wissahickon Creek.

SAN FRANCISCO -- About thirty California photographers, mostly amateurs and semi-professionals, met here last week at the studio of Minor White, photography teacher and writer and editor of the quarterly Aperture, to show their pictures and share experiences.

" WHERE this thin, red Saxon line has not gone man has not found. It has crossed every sea; it has traversed every desert; it has sought every solitude." Few contemporary patterns of words flame like Homer Lea's in "The Day of the Saxon" (1912).

FREEDOM VILLAGE, Korea, Aug. 22 -- Two soldiers from Staten Island returned here today and told of their narrow brushes with death. Like almost everyone of the returned prisoners they had at one time or another despaired of their own lives.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 22 (UP) -- The 75-year-old Metropolitan of Sarajevo, one of the highest officials of the Serbian Orthodox Church, received a brutal beating by a mob last Wednesday, it was reported today.

MILWAUKEE, Aug. 22 -- Donald Byrne of Brooklyn, N. Y., 23-year-old Yale senior, today won the open championship of the United States Chess Federation by half a point when he defeated Max Pavey, also of Brooklyn, after forty-two moves.

Three visiting professors from abroad will be on the staff of the College of Medicine of the State University of New York, 350 Henry Street, Brooklyn, in the 1953-54 academic year, Dr. Joseph M. Pisani, assistant dean, announced yesterday. The appointments are in line with the college's policy of inviting to the campus distinguished representatives of leading medical institutions of the world, Dr. Pisani said.

YONKERS, Aug. 22 -- Anthony Hanover, owned by T. J. Zornow of Pittsford, N. Y., scored a wire-to-wire victory tonight at Yonkers Raceway in the Tarrytown Trot, a $7,000 junior free-for-all, before 25,608 fans.

FERNANDO VALENTI is the busiest of recording harpsichord players, and from the volume of records that Westminster has been issuing, featuring his work, one can imagine him pecking away at the keyboard day and night.

FOR nearly four thousand years, many persons, male and female, of high and low degree, apparently have been dissatisfied with the plainness of the human skin in which they are clothed. To make this natural garb more interesting and also, according to Hanns Ebensten, to satisfy an urge that is largely sexual, considerable numbers of men and women have had themselves tattooed.

An appraisal of photography today, a symposium of opinion by Norris Harkness, Wilson Hicks, Arthur Rothstein, W. Eugene Smith and Frank Zachary, is the leading feature of the fourth issue of Photography Annual, just published.

ROME, Aug. 22 -- After only two days of debate, the Senate granted its confidence today to Premier Giuseppe Pella's Government, composed exclusively of Christian Democrats and independents. The vote was 140 to 86, with ten absentions.

LONDON, Aug. 22 (AP) -- At least 1,000,000 soccer fans packed forty-six stadiums today as the English League teams played their first Saturday games of the 1953-54 season. High scoring marked a number of the matches as 166 goals were scored in the four divisions of the league.

ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L. I., Aug. 22 -- A six-man committee has been appointed to study possible changes in the method of financing the purchase of land for Rockville Centre shopper and commuter parking fields.

WHILE fighting Jubal Early in 1864, Gen. Phil Sheridan became impatient with an unaggressive cavalry chief. Eventually he ordered the dilatory officer to attack and "either whip the enemy or get whipped yourself."
SEOUL, Korea, Aug. 22 (AP) -- The Eighth Army said today that it had awarded 105,625 decorations for gallantry and service to the 750,000 men who served in its ranks during the Korean war.

What a dull place the garden would be from now until frost if all the petunias were still in Brazil! For these descendants of a native South American flower come to bloom at just the right time to fill those gaping holes where earlier blossoms have finished their season's work.

WARMED by the ocean currents and moistened by gentle, misty rains, Washington (the Evergreen State) is a fairyland for a New England gardener who is accustomed to having many of his most choice varieties killed or severely injured by sudden hard freezes.

OYSTER BAY, L. I., Aug. 22 -- Llanoria, Magnus Konow's white-hulled yacht that fared so well in its European campaign last year, gained the lead over her three rivals today in the Six-Meter trials for the One Ton Cup, which got under way on Long Island Sound.

JIM SETON decided at 23 that it was time he did an adult thing -- so he decided to get married. He had known better looking girls before he met Henrietta Hildebrand, a Wave who was frankly fat, solidly stern and consciously capable.

THE smallest of a family of five kittens, Pitschi wants to be anything else but a kitten. In turn he tries to be a proud rooster, a gentle goat, a duck and a rabbit, only to learn inevitably that a kitten's life is a happy one.

DENVER, Aug. 22 -- President Eisenhower, completing today the formation of the Commission on Foreign Economic Policy, declared "the sound enlargement of commerce between nations" was essential in building up a strong and self-supporting economic system in the free world.

The forty-fourth annual Teachers Institute, sponsored by the Department of Education of the Archdiocese of Boston, will take place Aug. 25-28. Representatives of the 4,000 religious and lay teachers in the 315 elementary and secondary schools of the archdiocese will participate in the program.

MONTREAL, Aug. 22 -- Doug Ford of Harrison, N. Y., gained the lead in the $25,000 open golf championship at the Summerlea Club today with a record-equaling third-round 64 and a fifty-four-hole total of 200.
I have just finished Emily Amber's "Rules for Writing to Camp Noosa Woosa" (Aug. 9). As an ex-camp counselor I submit the following footnotes:

Peace after hostilities has in the past meant plunging prices and mine shutdowns for the domestic producers of the highly strategic metal tungsten. This time, both Government and mining companies are determined that the historic pattern will not be repeated.

NOT long before his death last winter Ben Ames Williams completed a sequel to his popular Civil War novel of a few years ago, "House Divided." That novel, he has explained, was originally intended to carry the Currain family through the Reconstruction, but it became very long -- over fifteen hundred pages -- and he cut it off after Appomatox.

KARL FREUND, an effervescent, chatty, pear-shaped man of 63, who, before becoming director of photography for "I Love Lucy" and "Our Miss Brooks," put in forty-seven years as a motion picture cameraman here and abroad, rolled into New York City from California the other day in a high state of disgust.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Aug. 12 -- Prime Minister Daniel F. Malan's system of race discrimination, called apartheid, is being applied to the whites as well as the nonwhites and is splitting the South African Army on racial lines, according to opposition elements.

CHICAGO, Aug. 22 -- Native Dancer hit with expected impact today in winning the $112,600 American Derby at Washington Park. Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt's colt further strengthened his claim to 3-year-old greatness by capturing the mile and a furlong event in 1:48 2/5, only a fifth of a second slower than the track standard.

STATE COLLEGE, Pa. THE four-acre flower garden in the northeastern corner of the campus of Pennsylvania State College is one trial plot that heads the visiting list of seedsmen and hybridists every summer. The two field days, held annually in mid-August, have made this a mecca for seedsmen who come to observe and compare the performance of their own as well as others' annuals.

MORROE BERGER states in his review of my book "World Without End: The Middle East," that the volume depends almost entirely on "secondary sources and the newspapers." A closer reading of my book will show that this is an unwarranted generalization.

Dr. Siegfried J. Gerathewohl of the Air Force School of Aviation Medicine at Randolph Field, Tex., reported at the Fourth International Astronautical Congress that at least twice U. S. Air Force experimenters have produced a no-gravity situation for jet pilots without ill effects of any consequences.

ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L. I., Aug. 22 -- Schenectady beat Montreal, 2 -- 1, with a run in the eighth inning to win the Region 1 Little League baseball tournament before 4,000 fans in the final at Hickey Field today. The victory moved the upstaters into the little world series against North Newton, Mass., on Tuesday at Williamsport, Pa.

BEFORE Vogue -- even long before Godey's Lady's Book -- our feminine ancestors learned about the new styles from dolls which literally carried the fashion news on their backs from country to country. Around one such doll Laura Bannon has written this unusual little story.

Members of the crew of the U. S. S. Antietam, aircraft carrier now tied up at the New York Naval Shipyard in Brooklyn for repairs, will start tomorrow a five-day blooddonation to the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program.

DANBURY, Conn., Aug. 22 -Like Tweedledum and Tweedledee, the Town of Danbury and the City of Danbury have "agreed to have a battle." This is the only community of its class still functioning in Connecticut under the antiquated system of overlapping city and town governments.

CONFERENCES do not, I am convinced, promote understanding. Unless the hundreds who attended the Harvard conference on the contemporary novel are considerably luckier than I, they must now be more confused than before.

BOSTON, Aug. 22 -- Among the 750 students receiving degrees at Boston University's summer commencement today were three war veterans who did most of their studying in hospitals and one who did his at home. The four received the College of Education's two-year Associate in Arts degree, but plan to transfer to full-time departments.

PANMUNJOM, Korea, Sunday, Aug. 23 -- The Communists released 150 shouting and laughing Americans from Red prison camps today and told the United Nations Command another 150 would be sent home tomorrow.

TOKYO, Aug. 22 (AP) -- A Japanese labor union, whose 107,000 claimed members are employed by the United States armed forces at bases throughout the country, notified the Japanese Government today that a second forty-eight-hour strike would be called next Friday.

IT used to be that so long as a professor could speak the vernacular of pedantry it did not matter that he couldn't write for peanuts. But pedagogy has happily kept pace with the times. This is the reflection of a reviewer after a good week in the company of the ardent humanity created by novelist Sullivan.

THE film of "The Beggar's Opera" was born in a restaurant inside a cigarette packet after supper. It was the first time I had met Herbert Wilcox, the producer, and the only thing of mine he'd seen was a production of "Romeo and Juliet" at Stratford, which got scandalous notices, almost as bad as the press for my Covent Garden ''Salome."
HERSHEY, Pa., Aug. 22 (AP) -- The Philadelphia Eagles tonight downed the Chicago Bears, 24 -- 10, in a National Football League exhibition game before 13,405.

CHARLESTON, W. Va., Aug. 22 (AP) -- Mrs. Walter E. Clark, 59-year-old principal owner of The Charleston Daily Mail, was found beaten "to death at her home here today. The chief of police announced that "it looks like murder."

DANBURY, Conn., Aug. 22 -Ten persons, including six from Brooklyn, were injured this morning in a two-car collision here on U. S. 7. Five of the injured were admitted to Danbury Hospital, two in serious condition with possible skull fractures.

FORT DEVENS, Mass., Aug. 22 -- Specialists in the feeding of large numbers of persons in peacetime will attend an intensive, three-day course in the feeding of disaster victims after a supposed enemy attack. The course will be held in this First Army area Tuesday through Thursday.

BOSTON, Aug. 22 (AP) -- The Chief Justices of forty-eight state courts today criticized Federal courts for ordering new hearings in cases where convictions had been upheld by state courts and reviews denied by the United States Supreme Court.

OTTAWA, Aug. 22 -- Canada, a country of vast spaces, a huge industrial potential and not enough people, is dipping deep into the reservoir of European manpower to meet her needs for more and more labor.

ELBERON, N. J., Aug. 22 -Services to mark the formal dedication of the new Temple Beth Miriam here will be held Friday at 8:15 P. M., with Rabbi Aaron H. Lefkowitz, spiritual leader of the temple for the last nine years, in charge.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Aug. 22 (AP) -- John Schubeck of Detroit and Jimmy Raines of Augusta, Ga., a pair of teenagers, today played to a seventy-two-hole tie for the International Junior Chamber of Commerce golf title.

Sales in the nation's department stores in the week ended Aug. 15 were unchanged from the similar 1952 period, according to data prepared by the Federal Reserve Board and listed in the table below the chart. In the preceding week the volume was 2 per cent above 1952.

FEW can rival Ludwig Bemelmans as the world's leading authority on hotels. From his latest volume we learn that he not only spent his youth in hotels ("a very lonesome life for a child"), he was born in a hotel.
MUNSAN, Korea, Sunday, Aug. 23 (AP) -- The United Nations Command's official list of United States prisoners freed in today's armistice exchange:

MAYS LANDING, N. J., Aug. 22 (AP) -- The Brookmeade Stable's Sunglow, 27 to 1, making his first start over a turf course, gained a lucky victory in the first division of the $15,000 added Boardwalk Handicap at the Atlantic City track today as attendance and mutual records continued to topple.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 22 (AP) -- Steve Bilko's seventh-inning double drove in Stan Musial from first base tonight and settled a see-saw game in which the Cardinals won their third straight by downing the Redlegs, 5 -- 4.

MILWAUKEE, Aug. 22 -- Johnny Logan slashed a single over Ralph Kiner's head in the fourteenth inning today to give the Braves a 2-1 victory over the Cubs and extend their winning streak to seven straight, their longest of the season.
FREEDOM VILLAGE, Aug. 22 -- Tired, hollowed-eyed prisoners of the Korean war continued to stream across the line to freedom this week.

Because many factories will be closed on the Labor Day holiday, stores anticipating their needs for that period have been reordering heavily, according to Kirby, Block Co., Inc., resident buying office. Fall goods have been meeting consumer acceptance and reorders have been numerous on many new items.

HOUSTON, Tex., Aug. 22 -- It would appear that United Nations stock is dropping in Texas. And if it is not dropping, then there is certainly a growing demand that the United States pause in its international relations and reconsider its position.

In reading Mr. Barrett's article, "Portrait of the Korean Veteran" (Aug. 9) I felt he had ignored one factor that may bear on his observation. Draftees now being released after having served from twenty-one to twenty-four months are still listed as members of the Enlisted Reserve for a period of five or six years.

AT one time or other the gardener is sure to have noticed a curious growth on leaves, stems or roots of many plants. Sometimes it takes the shape of a small cone, or it may look like a dried prune. This, then, is a gall; it is caused either by a parasitic fungus or an insect such as the gallfly, gall midge or certain species of aphids.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 22 -- The Grand Union Hotel Stakes and the Saratoga Handicap had their fifty-first runnings at the Saratoga track today, and the winners were James Cox Brady's second-choice Artismo in the $27,575 sprint for 2-year-olds and the Hampton Stable's thirdchoice Alerted in the $28,700 run for members of the handicap brigade.

This morning once again another group of American prisoners will be exchanged at Panmunjom and loaded into ambulances for the fourteen-mile ride to Freedom Village. Awaiting them there is an incredibly efficient processing system in which they are checked medically, fed, given new clothing and their records are brought up to date.

Two rather different notes have been struck in recent official comment following confirmation of the Soviets' claim to having exploded a hydrogen bomb. One note stresses reassurance and is typified by Representative Cole's assertion that we have and will continue to have leadership, presumably as against Russia, in atomic development.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (AP) -- Robert W. Toth, 21-year-old Pittsburgh steel worker, got a warm family welcome as he arrived by plane today to challenge the Air Force's action in arresting him and returning him to Korea to face murder charges.

TEHERAN, Iran, Aug. 22 -- Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi flew here from-Baghdad today in a triumphal return to his capital just six days after he had fled the country under threat of dethronement. The first man to greet the Shah was Maj. Gen. Fazollah Zahedi, who assumed the Premiership Wednesday after a bloody uprising by mobs and troops had overthrown the increasingly anti-monarchist Government of Dr. Mohammed Mossadegh.

With the Empire Theatre vanishing from Broadway with appropriate salutations and adieux, the stage historian may wonder a bit at the apathy of press and public in failing to grant so much as a nod to the gallant old Savoy when it fell recently beneath the wreckers' blows.

JOHN KEIR CROSS, British novelist and radio writer, is probably best known by young Americans for his tale of Martian adventure, "The Angry Planet," and his story of the Napoleonic era, "Blackadder." His new book is a curious combination of backstage vaudeville life in England and on the Continent, international intrigue and a dash of science fiction.

DANBURY, Conn., Aug. 22 -- Best in show in the fourth annual event of the Newtown Kennel Club today went to one of the smallest dogs in the competition. This was the pert white toy poodle, Ch. Wilbur White Swan.

OUT in Burbank, in the shadow of the giant movie studios, is a low, unpretentious building with a ring of offices opening onto a patio. There are no red-headed stars, no platinumed starlets, no facades of Western ghost towns nor tanks for storms at sea, no monster-like camera or microphones moving on the ends of giant antennae, no enormous crew of camera-men, property girls, wardrobe mistresses, extras and directors in canvas-backed chairs.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., Aug. 22 -- Two more men, both of Florida, have been arrested in connection with the $60,000 safe robbery in 1951 at the Quonset Point Naval Air Station, Rhode Island, the Federal Bureau of Investigation announced here today. This brings the number under arrest to four.

WE were speeding through the flat plains of Oklahoma on our way west, my wife and I. The landscape was desolate; the sun poured down relentlessly out of a lead sky. In the distance we saw a small boy standing patiently in the road, alone against the sky.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Aug. 22 -- Fifteen thousand Moslems, led by Vice President Mohammed Hatta, quietly gathered in the heart of Jakarta Thursday morning to hear Moslem leaders call for a united Islamic front against "irreligious ideologies." Tension between Communist and Moslem groups has been spreading throughout the country.
CHICAGO, Aug. 22 -- The Tigers triumphed over the White Sox, 2 -- 1, today in an eleven-inning game. The winning run was scored by Third Baseman Ray Boone, who was driven home by Walt Dropo.

A basic problem confronting citizens in large cities is how to establish a closer working relationship with the schools. In the small towns and villages this is relatively easy. Through town meetings or school committees the citizens get to know their schools and participate in school activities.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Aug. 22 -- Iowa's major political parties began an unusually early organizational drive this week in an effort to win the state's eight seats in the House of Representatives and the United States Senatorship that will be contested in the general elections in 1954.
Edwin M. Otterbourg, president of the New York County Lawyers Association, made public yesterday a list of the standing committees of the association for the year 1953-54.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, Aug. 22 -- A significant salient of the Communist battle for Asia is being fought here in the form of a clash of ideologies in the Buddhist faith, with about 200 "Red bhikkus" (monks) seeking to advance Marxism against overwhelming odds among the more than 5,000,000 conservative Buddhists of Ceylon.

The Department of Health dipped yesterday into its dwindling reserve supply of gamma globulin and distributed 1,956 cubic centimeters of the temporarily immunizing blood fraction to the parents of 140 of the 160 children and young counselors who had been exposed to poliomyelitis earlier in the week at Camp Delmont, near Livingston Manor, N. Y.

THAT ancient Variety aphorism that moviegoers in the sticks say nix to hit pix is being modified, along with several other tired concepts about audience tastes, in the small towns which are still the box-office backbone of Hollywood.

The Zionist Organization of America will open its fifty-sixth annual convention Wednesday night at the Waldorf-Astoria. Twelve hundred delegates from every section of the country are expected to attend the meetings, which will run through Sunday.

The General Electric Company announced plans yesterday to build a new metallurgical development laboratory to provide 71,000 square feet of additional floor space at its research facilities near Schenectady. Construction will begin soon and the building, the eighth of those comprising the research laboratory is scheduled for completion by the spring of 1955.

DEL MAR, Calif., Aug. 22 (AP) -- Mrs. A. W. Ryan's Apple Valley scored a stunning upset today in the running of the $15,000 added Del Mar Derby, winning in the role of outsider from Smart Barbara and Chanlea.

ABERDEEN, Md., Aug. 22 -- Many of the eastern speed boat pilots who next week-end will take part in the national championships on Lake Onondaga, Syracuse, had their final warm-up this windy afternoon in the annual Bush River Boat Club regatta on Long Bar Harbor, Abingdon, a landlocked arm of Chesapeake Bay a few miles north of Baltimore.

IF your memory stretches back a generation you probably will be interested in learning that the Forty-Eighth Street Theatre will be the haven for "At Home With Ethel Waters" the week of Sept. 21. The exact date of the premiere is to be announced shortly but, in the meantime, Herman Levin, who will be offering the nostalgic program in association with Richard Barr and Charles Bowden, is planning a six-week engagement at the house.
OMAHA, Aug. 22 -- The only thing proved by last week's wheat vote is that American farmers, being totally sane, would rather receive $2.20 for a bushel of wheat than $1.20.

IT was Old-Timers' Day at the Yankee Stadium yesterday, a day of nostalgia and sentiment as the heroes of the past came trouping back to bask briefly on the diamond they once had graced so well and with such distinction. Just seeing them was a thrill for the fan. Just being there was a thrill for the old-timers.
Referring to George Barett's article:

NEWARK, Aug. 22 -- Lieut. Gen. Willis D. Crittenberger, retired commander of the First Army, urged tonight a policy of diplomatic and military realism based on simultaneous efforts to obtain effective international control of the hydrogen bomb and to make United States armed forces "atomic-minded."

A full-time student teaching program for seniors has been launched by the National College of Education, Evanston, Ill. The move is described by President K. Richard Johnson as part of the college's plan to develop more adequate methods of preparing future elementary teachers for the nation's classrooms.

WHEN a ship vanishes at sea those who know her and her crew are reluctant to accept her doom. Young Randy Draper is deeply troubled by the circumstances surrounding the mysterious disappearance of the tuna clipper Westwind, for his best friend was a member of the crew.

MARTIN LUTHER, whose rebellion against Roman Catholicism in the sixteenth century shook Europe to its roots, is the hero of a new movie shot in Luther's native Germany by American producer Louis de Rochemont With Niall MacGinnis, British actor, as Luther, "Martin Luther" follows its central figure from his years as a monk, his rising doubts about church dogma, through his excommunication and leadership of the Protestant Reformation.

George Barett's thought-provoking portrait of the Korean veteran makes one wonder, if perhaps in addition to the ascribed causes of the laconic fatalism of these men, there could be a self-preservative tendency -- to "roll with the punches" in order to keep some semblance of balance in the international maelstrom into which they were thrown.
CLEVELAND, Aug. 22--A general wage increase of 37 1/2 cents an hour was announced today as goal to be sought for 200,000 members of the Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen.
GENEVA, Aug. 15 -- The liquidation of the International Refugee Organization will take place in September.

DAYTON, Ohio, Aug. 22 -- Only jet planes flown by military pilots will take part in the aerial events of the National Aircraft Show to be held here during the Labor Day week-end, it was announced today.

TEHERAN, Aug. 22 -- In one of his legendary adventures, Sinbad the Sailor carried an ailing old man across a stream on his shoulders. When he reached the other side, the old man refused to get off. He locked his legs around Sinbad's neck and belabored him rudely at each attempt to escape.

THERE is an increasing trend to toll roads in new highway construction throughout the country. The toll fees motorists pay equal an extra tax on motor fuel of about 18 cents a gallon, according to J. R. Crossley, vice president of the Automobile Club of New York.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., Aug. 20 (AP) -- Doak Walker's last-period touchdown and field goal gave the champion Detroit Lions a 16-13 victory tonight over the Pittsburgh Steelers in a National Football League exhibition.

The reactionary tendencies in financial markets continued last week despite highly favorable reports on economic conditions. For the second successive week, commodities and securities were under selling pressure. Although wheat was sharply lower, price fluctuations were not as wide.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (AP) -- Oswald Ryan, chairman of the Civil Aeronautics Board, celebrated the board's fifteenth anniversary -- and his own fifteenth anniversary as a board member -- today.

NEW HAVEN, Aug. 22 -- Since early summer a Yale University truck -- completely equipped to serve as a laboratory -- has been conducting intensive research into the secrets of the cosmic rays at the Brookhaven National Laboratory at Upton, L. I., under the direction of four of Yale's nuclear physicists.

For several years the Roscoe B. Jackson Memorial Laboratory, Bar Harbor, Me., has been engaged in studying animals, chiefly dogs, in order to find out the relative importance of heredity and environment, the subject of an old controversy. The latest phase of the study deals with variations in the learning ability of dogs.

PHILADELPHIA Aug. 22 -- The Blinded Veterans Association, Inc., charged today that "certain Federal employe associations" were encroaching on the privileges of blind persons to operate small business enterprises in Federal buildings.

TOURISTS were still getting about in France last week, with their difficulties arising mainly from strikes on the railroads and in communications. Although very few trains were running, most bus lines were unaffected. The big tour operators continued to send scheduled groups into France and were confident that they could be moved by bus, although changes were made in itineraries to conform with the switch in carriers.

The medical aspect of pensioning is commanding greater attention among industrial physicians, a recent study of geriatrics and retirement indicated. Steadily increasing population and pending economic and sociological changes are prompting this greater interest.
LONDON, Aug. 22 -- An international agreement designed to stabilize the world market for sugar has been completed, and will be opened for signature by interested Governments next week.
