BANGKOK, Thailand, Aug. 22 -- The Soviet Union has extended feelers here on the subject of a bilateral trade agreement with Thailand, Col. Vorakarn Bancha, Minister of Economic Affairs, announced today. A Soviet diplomatic representative broached the subject at the Ministry of Foreign Affairs this week, he said.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (UP) -- Ted Williams did it again tonight when his two singles drove in two runs as the Red Sox tripped the Senators, 4 -- 3. In the five games that Williams has started, the Sox have won four, with Ted driving in enough runs to win three.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Aug. 22 (AP) -- Jerry Pittman, a 6-foot, 16-year-old from Tulsa, Okla., won the national caddie golf championship today by defeating Frank Malara of White Plains, N. Y., 3 and 2, on the thirty-fourth hole. Pittman sank a 40-foot curling putt on the Ohio State University course to close out the match and win a $1,500 college scholarship.

WILL the cease-fire in Korea produce a recession? There is no doubt that many people believe that it will. Such fears raise the basic question of the role of "psychology" -- men's hopes, fears, expectations, or attitudes -- in producing business conditions.

There is one essential commodity, translated into terms of present-day dollar earnings, which affords the consumer an even break with the bill collector -- electricity. Last week, with electric power production topping all previous records -- more than 8,513,000,000 kilowatt-hours were required to meet the demands of the nation's consuming public -- President Eisenhower issued, through the Department of the Interior, a new electric power policy.

CAMP PERRY, Ohio, Aug. 22 (UP) -- Charles Whipple of Somerset, Pa., forged into the lead of the national small-bore rifle championship today by posting a 1,599 out of a possible 1,600 score at the half-way mark.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 22 -- Longshoremen of ten St. Louis locals asked Joseph P. Ryan, president of the International Longshoremen's Association, A. F. L., last night to resign immediately because they believed the union was entitled to "capable leadership."

THE basic idea behind this book is a good one. Anthony T. Bouscaren, Associate Professor of Political Science at the University of San Francisco, apparently sought to show that the goal of world communism is world domination and to review the forces -- within the Soviet Union and in the Communist parties throughout the world -- available to help realize this objective.

The Monsanto Chemical Company announced last week that Drs. Oliver Weinkauff, William S. Knowles, Lloyd Barkely, Martin Farrar and Harold Raffelson had developed a process for the production of cortisone with cheap raw materials instead of expensive ox bile.

A WAYWARD girl who eventually married into a respectable small town banking family has been brutally knifed to death in her home while her husband was at a poker game. The town marshal and his assistant thugs find two young men, one of them a Mexican, asleep boside a dying campfire at the edge of town.

EVEN in his novels Aubrey Menen is at his best when he is writing essays. My favorite scene in "The Prevalence of Witches," for instance, is the one in which several of his characters decide (with relatively little motive except that they all love to talk) to make speeches to each other.

PARIS, Aug. 22 -- All France's tensions, internal and external, seem to be culminating in this abnormal month of August, when frictions generally subside with the recess of the National Assembly and the departure of half of the population on vacations.

COPENHAGEN -- Foreigners who are in Copenhagen during the next two weeks will have an opportunity to share with the Danes in the distribution of one of the most tempting assortment of prizes offered anywhere when the annual Rundskuedag, or Look Around Day, festivities are in full swing here.

THE American Kremlin is no match for the granite and gold opulence of its Moscow counterpart. The national headquarters of the Communist party, in a bedraggled four-story building at the southern end of New York's bustling garment district, reflects the poverty of a party that is finding it increasingly hard to lure Americans down its devious paths.

SO much has been written and said about the trials of the orchestra musician, the problems of orchestras in big towns and small, that I think it is time to sound another tune. To be in music, -- as in any of the arts, means willy-nilly to suffer.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 22 -- Ten days ago the dispute over the participation of India in the Korean peace conference was a cloud no larger than a man's hand. Now it has placed the United States in the most serious predicament it has confronted since the United Nations began operating seven and a half years ago.

PANAMA CITY, Panama -- It is now possible to drive from New York City to Panama City, except for ninety-one miles in southeastern Costa Rica. We know, because we just did it -- with a four-wheel-drive truck, a winch and machetes.

LONDON, Sunday, Aug. 23 (Reuters) -- Mr. Malenkov in his address to the East Germans at the Kremlin, as broadcast by Tass over the Moscow radio and monitored here, said their talks had been carried on with "a complete unanimity of views and have led to important decisions."

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 22 -There is widespread support on the West Coast for the stated principles and objectives of the United Nations, but with it there is widespread complaint over the shortcomings of the global organization in action.

THE "standard" bidding methods are under fire today, as they usually, are when the best-known players lose several tournaments in a row. (There are losing streaks in tournament play as well as in rubber bridge.)

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 -- The Federal Government is stepping up its search for a low-cost method of converting salt and brackish water into fresh water for human consumption, irrigation and industrial uses.

BONN, Germany, Aug. 22 -- The note delivered to the British, French and United States embassies in Moscow early this week was addressed to the Governments of the three Western powers, but it was intended primarily to be read by the West German electorate.

BORDENTOWN, N. J., Aug. 22 (AP)-- A 17-year-old boy was ordered held without bail today after he had pleaded not guilty to arson charges growing out of a series of six barn fires in this area within twelve days.

ATLANTA, Ga., Aug. 22 -- Most people in this area remain strong supporters of the United Nations Organization although considerable division of opinion exists over its effectiveness and prospects for the future.

Failure of New York State officials to increase funds for schools to offset the effects of inflated dollar values is resulting in lasting harm to the students in many school districts, it was asserted yesterday by George Ryder of the Board of Education of Cobleskill, N. Y., and Dr. Paul R. Mort, Professor of Education at Teachers College, Columbia University.

HOT summer days make some kind of swimming pool almost a necessity instead of a luxury. Or at least, they influence thinking in that direction. The kind of pool most feasible, of course, depends on the family budget, as well as possible sites and water supply for a pool.

BONN, Germany, Aug. 22 -West Germany's Trade Union Federation, although nominally neutral in politics, has started playing an active role in the Bonn republic's general election campaign, which now has two weeks to run. Among the federation's targets are the two minor parties in Chancellor Konrad Adenauer's coalition Government.

SPEAKING of Shakespeare, as we were in this space last Sunday, the Antioch Area Theatre Festival has two more weeks of repertory to play before the vacation season is finished. Since the first of July these star-lit productions of seven Shakespeare plays have been drawing thousands of people into a country village from the neighboring cities of Ohio and all over the country.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., Aug. 22 -- Joseph Mayo, regional director of the Independent United Mine Workers Union, said today he believed he could get Syracuse buses rolling if he could meet with authorized representatives of the Syracuse Transit Corporation.

For years Irving Berlin has been dreaming of a pet project -- a show to commemorate the opening of the Music Box on Sept. 22, 1921. Mr. Berlin is part owner of the Music Box. Something always intervened, though, to check the venture.

Man's continuing rejection of Christ, little modified through the centuries since "He came unto His own and His own received Him not," was deplored yesterday by the Rev. Charles J. McManus of St. Patrick's Cathedral clergy.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Aug. 23 (AP) -- Gen. Paul de Langlade, commander of French forces in Cambodia, said today France was willing to hand over military command of all Cambodia to King Norodom Sihanouk.

BOSTON, Aug. 23 (AP) -- Following is the text of a twelve-point code on fair trial and free press, proposed today by Edwin M. Otterbourg, president of the New York County Lawyers Association, at the opening session of the National Conference of Bar Presidents:

TOKYO, Monday, Aug. 24 -- The Communists hastily dressed up their prisoner-of-war camps along the Yalu River on the border of Northwest Korea before the arrival of Red Cross teams after the armistice, returning American captives said yesterday.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 23 (AP) -- A Marine lieutenant came home from Korea today and learned officially for the first time that he had an appointment with President Eisenhower to receive the nation's highest award, the Congressional Medal of Honor.

The greatness of a country depends upon "the proportion of its cultivated citizens, its men and women of enlightenment, education and Christian character," declared the Rev. Dr. Samuel H. Prince of the faculty of Kings University, Halifax, N. S., in a sermon yesterday morning at St. Stephen's Protestant Episcopal Church, 122 West Sixty-ninth Street.

A considerable portion of Greenwich Village is scheduled to undergo a face-lifting through two redevelopment plans announced yesterday. Authorities promised, however, that the beautifying operation would in no wise mar the old neighborhood's distinctive historical and architectural contours. A total of 4,056 new apartments will be provided.

PARIS, Aug. 23 -- Strikes in the metallurgical industries in the Paris region were called off today by the Socialist Workers Force Union, one of whose leaders said that the Roman Catholic groups were taking the same action.

Net income of the American Smelting and Refining Company and its subsidiaries declined sharply in the first six months of this year to $9,204,286 from $17,237,636 in the corresponding half of 1952, according to the unaudited statement issued for publication today.
DIXMUDE, Belgium, Aug. 23 (Reuters) -- Three hundred mounted policemen today dispersed a crowd of Flemish nationalists who demanded an amnesty for convicted wartime collaborators.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 23 (AP) -- Crawford H. Greenewalt, president of E. I. du Pont de Nemours, said today he can see no signs of a depression following the Korean armistice because business "has far more to gain from a drop in Government spending than it has to lose."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (UP) -- The Defense Department, under Presidential prompting, has set the fall of 1955 as the "target date" for eliminating segregation in state-operated schools on military posts.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- The Senate Subcommittee on Internal Security reported today that the Soviet international conspiracy had accomplished a successful penetration into the United States Government to a frightening extent that had not yet been fully exposed.

PARIS, Aug. 23 -- Telegrams of congratulation were sent today to the new Sultan of Morocco, Sidi Mohammed ben Moulay Arafa, by President Vincent Auriol, Premier Joseph Laniel and Foreign Minister Georges Bidault, all of whom greeted the enthronement as a signal for a new era of confident cooperation between France and Morocco.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Aug. 23 -- The new Government installed by Lieut. Gen. Gustavo Rojas Pinilla through a military coup June 13 has brought a degree of peace and emotional calm to Colombia that is astonishing to anyone who experienced the tension and atmosphere of hate prevailing here six months ago.

CHICAGO, Aug. 23 (UP) -- Scattered sabotage was reported in the Southwestern Bell Telephone Company strike today. Picketing in the six-state area has been generally peaceful, but wire cutting was reported today at several points in Kansas.

A 23-year-old Navy veteran, coaxed from a fourteenth-floor ledge of the Brooklyn Veteran Administration Hospital after thirteen and a half hours of threatening to jump to his death, rested quietly yesterday in a screened-in room in the hospital's psychiatric ward.

The one-family dwelling on plot 90 by 115 feet at 336 Coolidge Street, was Hempstead, L. I., has been sold by Louis Purow to Max Pfeffer, who insured title with the Lawyers Mortgage and Title Company. The terms were cash over a mortgage of $15,000.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (AP) -- High official sources indicated today that President Eisenhower himself may have to decide the problem of United States economic aid to Iran.

LONDON, Aug. 23 -- Stock market business continues to run contrary to the usual experience of seasonal inactivity. An outstanding feature is the steady expansion of interest in industrial securities, although prices in most markets have been tending upward rather than downward.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 23 -- A gray transport slipped in from Korea today under a low-hanging fog and deposited 328 former prisoners of war at Fort Mason here for an emotion-packed homecoming.
LONDON, Aug. 23 (AP) -- Following is the text of the Soviet-East German communique on the negotiations in Moscow, as issued by the Tass news agency in Russian and broadcast by the Moscow radio:

A "listless" charter market, marked by too many available ships, too few cargoes and too low rates, was the general description of conditions by ship brokers and agents of maritime activity last week.

The activities of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, were denounced in a sermon yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Homer A. Jack, who argued that the Senator's activities were as harmful to the cause of freedom and American democracy as was the work of an undercover Communist.

ZURICH, Aug. 23 -- As Germany is to resume debt service in the near future, with Switzerland soon to ratify the London debt agreement, the Swiss Bank Corporation answering queries of investors has just issued an exhaustive analysis to determine whether the German Federal Republic will always be able to fulfill obligations punctually.
P. Schuyler Miller's recent letter on Panther Mountain Dam appears to be founded on three basic assumptions, all mistaken.

Thirteen-year-old Helen Gindins left the New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, yesterday to be reunited with her father, Henri Gindins, a World War II French soldier. Behind the departure was the story of the child's resolute faith that at least one of her parents was alive despite reports that they had perished during the Nazi occupation of France.

An investing client of Louis Schlesinger, attorney, bought the building containing two stores and twenty-one apartments on lot 40 by 100 feet at Ralph Avenue and Sterling Place, in Brooklyn, from 1716 Sterling Place, Inc., in a deal negotiated by the Cruikshank Company, broker.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- A network of economic experts, all known for their business acumen and objectivity in assessing local economic conditions, is being set up by the White House at key points across the country.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (AP) -- James Kerney Jr., editor of The Trenton Times, contended today that Senator Joseph R. McCarthy had endangered freedom of the press in his fight with The Washington Post and James A. Wechsler, editor of The New York Post.

RABAT, Morocco, Aug. 23 -- One of the early conclusions drawn from the reign of the new Sultan of Morocco is that the balance of power within the country has shifted away from the westernized city Arabs and now favors the feudal lords of the mountains.

The effect of the city's "gimmick" financing in the fiscal year 1952-53 upon its current budget was strikingly illustrated yesterday in a report by City Treasurer Spencer C. Young, showing that the yield from special city taxes in July was only $9,280,830, compared with $57,623,712 in July, 1952.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (UP) -- A ninth-inning double by Rookie Karl Olson scored Jim Piersall with the winning run as the Red Sox defeated the Senators, 5 -- 4, before a crowd of 12,215 today.

CHICAGO, Aug. 24 (AP) -- Eddie Arcaro, who rode Native Dancer for the first and probably last time Saturday, still thinks Alfred G. Vanderbilt's gray 3-year-old has to prove he belongs in the same class as Citation.

Business in the foreign exchange market was only moderately active during the last week. British pound sterling developed an easier tone while the Canadian dollar continued to maintain the steady strength that has been evident since early July.

Granting that the leaders of Russia are stubborn and do things that we do not want them to do, this disintegrating world cannot be put together if we act mistrustfully, the Rev. Dr. Frederick K. Stamm declared yesterday morning in a sermon, "Putting the World Together."

IF any team is less in need of reinforcements in its inexorable drive toward a fifth straight pennant than the Yankees, diligent search would fail to uncover it. And now the Bronx Bombers will have the services of Jerry Coleman for the final month of the season. It's like Rockefeller finding another oil well. Or, if you'd prefer, an equally comparable baseball simile -- like the rich Casey Stengel finding another gusher.

SEOUL, Korea, Aug. 23 -- Dr. Howard A. Rusk, a leading member of the American-Korean Foundation mission touring Korea for a study of health, housing, social welfare and rehabilitation problems, announced here today that a three-point program had been set up to become effective soon.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- Government officials here took a casual view today of the Soviet-East German communique issued last night in which it was announced that Moscow had granted major economic and political concessions to Communist East Germany.

ONE viewer couldn't believe what he saw and heard Saturday afternoon when he meant to tune in Yankee Stadium and got Rockville Centre, L. I., instead. What was Rockville Centre doing in the league? Had Bill Veeck finally transferred the Browns?

POTTERSVILLE, N. Y., Aug. 23 -- "The Treasure," a new operatic work composed by Gerald Fried from a dramatic poem written especially for the opera by Alfred D. Geto, received a premiere performance last night at Schroon Crest, near here in the Adirondack Mountains.

The Carrier Corporation is one of the nation's pioneer companies in the field of air conditioning, and its president is Mr. Claud Wampler. In an article appearing in the current issue of "Steelways" Mr. Wampler hazards the prediction that by 1958 half of all new homes in the United States will be equipped with complete air conditioning.
BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 23 -- Mervyn Rose of Australia today won the national doubles tennis championship for the second successive year, this time with Rex Hartwig.

In its fiftieth semi-annual rating of United States export markets in Latin America for credit and collection conditions, the Foreign Credit Interchange Bureau places Nicaragua in first place. Results of the survey, covering twentyfour markets, were announced over the week-end by Philip J. Gray, manager of the bureau.

Condemnation of bargaining proposals of the International Longshoremen's Association as "impossible" has been voted by the conference committee of the New York Shipping Association, the employer bargaining agency of the industry.

MOSCOW, Aug. 23 -- The Soviet Union placed before the German people today two important instruments of policy: A carefully reasoned appeal by Premier Georgi M. Malenkov that Germans unite to avoid the path toward war that has led to two national catastrophies in a half century and a broad program of financial and economic measures designed to assist East Germany.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (UP) -- Senator Wagne Morse today denounced the Administration's new power policy as a "cover-up" for "giving away" public power facilities and projects to private interests.

NAIROBI, Kenya, Aug. 23 (Reuters) -- Mau Mau terrorists who want to give up must come out of their forest hide-outs in daylight "waving green branches as a sign of surrender," the Government said today in detailing its new policy for dealing with the anti-white cultists.

TEHERAN, Iran, Aug. 23 -- Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi declared today that the five-day-old Government of Maj. Gen. Fazollah Zahedi was in "imperative need" of financial assistance, not in a matter of months or weeks, but "in a matter of days."
WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (AP) -- Mrs. James Doolittle will direct a new program to provide sympathy and help to the widows of recent Air Force dead.

A milestone was marked recently in the long and at times seemingly endless fight of Brooklyn grand juries and civic and social welfare organizations to have the often-condemned Brooklyn City Prison at 149 Ashland Place -better known by its old name of Raymond Street Jail -- torn down and replaced by an adequate, modern penal institution.

CHICAGO, Aug. 23 -- Wheat trading again came close to monopolizing the business in grain and soybean futures on the Board of Trade last week. Wheat volume was not as large as the preceding week, but purchases ran up a total of 153,594,000 bushels.

Samuel Reshevsky, America's grand master at chess, yesterday made his first definite statement that he intended to take part in the world championship challengers tournament in Switzerland. The winner will have the right to play for the title held by Mikhail Botvinnik of Moscow in 1954.
Richard Becker's Pride, William H. Stanley's Bumble Bee, Warner Willcox's Twister and Howard Walden's Que Pasa were among the victors in the Bayside Yacht Club regatta on Long Island Sound yesterday.

ROME, Aug. 23 (Reuters) -- Italian shipbuilders, who have already brought the tonnage of Italy's merchant fleet back to the pre-war level, are struggling to reach a total of 4,000,000 tons within the next two years.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Aug. 23 -- The underground organization without a name, composed of former Stern Gang terrorists, religious zealots and ultranationalist and ultraorthodox juveniles, was denounced by a military court here today in a judgment convicting thirteen of fourteen persons accused under the emergency regulations for prevention of terrorism.

OYSTER BAY, L. I., Aug. 23 -- Fun, the Bimini blue-hulled yacht owned and skippered by Ernest Fay of Houston, Tex., moved into the lead in the Six-Meter trials for the international One Ton Cup tonight when Magnus Konow's Llanoria, yesterday's winner, was disqualified.
Although enough food is produced in the world, two-thirds of the human race has a deficient diet, the Medical Geography Department of the American Geographical Society announced yesterday.

Robert B. Blaikie, independent candidate for the Democratic nomination for Mayor, advocated yesterday that the city "recapture" the municipal transit system, which since June 15 has been under the control of a state-created authority, with a mandate to make operations self-sustaining.

The General Assembly of the United Nations will return today to its debate on the composition of the delegation that is to take part in the political conference on Korea. The United States will continue to insist that the delegation should be closely limited. In this case this means a vote against the extension of an invitation to India to participate.

LEOPOLDVILLE, Belgian Congo, Aug. 23 -- The president of the white settlers' organization here, Louis Ballinger, announced today at a meeting of Europeans and Congo African natives the end of the racially exclusive white settlers' organization in the Congo and declared that in the future all organizaions shall consist of both Negroes and whites.

OLD WESTBURY, L. I., Aug. 23 -- Joe Schwartz, a 17-year-old schoolboy, and Philip Iglehart, an international star, collaborated yesterday to lead the Roslyn polo team to a 13-7 victory over Old Westbury before 1,500 fans at Bostwick Field.
CHICAGO, Aug. 23 (AP) -- Bob Boyd, a substitute first baseman, hit key blows in both games of a double-header today as the White Sox beat the Tigers, 2 -- 1 and 11 -- 6, before 22,383.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 23 -- Disconsolately, the Giants departed from this City of Brotherly Love today, beaten 6 -- 3, with a seven-game losing streak, their longest in two years. Four straight setbacks here gave evidence that the Phillies displayed little affection toward the visitors, whose hopes for a first-division finish continued to fade.

In its first change of ownership since 1850, the four-story business building at 15 North Broadway, Yonkers, N. Y., has been sold by John M. Wheeler, president of Bell Syndicate, Inc., and the North American Newspaper Alliance, to the Malamud Corporation for investment.

EDINBURGH, Scotland, Aug. 23 -- The Seventh International Festival of Music and Drama staged in the Scottish capital was opened here today by the Moderator of the Church of Scotland, the Right Rev. James Pitt-Watson, at a service in historic St. Giles Cathedral.

CAMP DRUM, N. Y., Aug. 23 -- More than 1,700 officers and men who make up part of the permanent cadre of the Seventy-seventh Reserve Infantry Division completed their nine-hour train ride from New York this morning and started the first day of their two-week summer training program.
LONDON, Aug. 23 -- Britain's biggest post - war air force exercise, Momentum, ended tonight after a day of rain and poor visibility that held operations to a minimum.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (UP) -- Nearly 30,000,000 youngsters will answer the school year's opening bell next month, and this is about 10,000,000 too many, national education officials said today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- Representative Wright Patman, Democrat of Texas, expressed "shock" today at the plans of Herbert Brownell Jr., the Attorney General, to study the Government's anti-trust laws.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Aug. 23 (UP) -- Foreign Minister Oscar Fenner said today that Chile would accept no European orders for copper while the present price negotiations with the United States were in progress.

AMSTERDAM, Aug. 23 -- Foreign trade in July showed a slight decreased with imports 750,000,000 guilders against 772,000,000 in June, and exports 627,000,000 against 628,000,000. The seven months' import surplus is 544,000,000 guilders against 384,000,000 in the same period last year. It is expected that in autumn exports again will rise due to seasonal factors.

Next week, on Sept. 1, there will open in the new Carnegie Endowment International Center the first major exhibit of Philippine painting and sculpture to be put on display in this country. There will be more than a hundred canvases by leading Filipino artists, sculptures, handicrafts, such as hand-weaving and carving, and photography.

GREAT BARRINGTON, Mass., Aug. 23 -- Champion Waterbeck Watermark, imported Dandie Dinmont terrier owned by Sarah Swift's Cliffield Kennels of Bedford Village, N. Y., and handled by Seth Campbell, was named best in show at the annual event of the Great Barrington Kennel Club today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- About 100 leaders in the fields of business, agriculture and labor, will meet here Sept. 15 with members of the Senate Banking and Currency Committee to begin a study of the financial aspects of international trade.

There is "a very good probability" that Congress will ease the tax burden on United States corporations investing abroad, according to George F. James, chairman of the Tax Committee of the National Foreign Trade Council.

MOSCOW, Aug. 23 -- The largest demonstration of Soviet jet air strength ever shown in Moscow, including the latest single-jet fighters and twin-jet bombers, was put on view today in the an nual air show before Premier Georgi M. Malenkov, top Government and military leaders and foreign diplomatic and military attaches.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 23 -- Steel sales executives here are beginning to sense a new note of caution in their customer's buying patterns. Steel buyers, maintaining that they still expect production to stay at high levels, usually say that their more cautious attitude on fourth quarter steel is primarily due to inventory correction.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 23 -- The crucial stage of debate over the composition of the Far Eastern political conference that will attempt to write peace terms for Korea begins tomorrow in the Political and Security Committee of the United Nations General Assembly.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 23 -- Duke Snider was the big gun today as the Dodgers beat the Pirates twice, 10 --4 and 9 -- 7, before a Forbes Field crowd of 18,418. The Brooks clouted twenty-eight hits in the twin bill.

A continued membership increase in churches in the United States was reported yesterday by the Department of Research and Survey of the National Council of the Churches of Christ in the U. S. A. It said the gain in 1952 was 3,604,124 over figures for the previous year, or 4.1 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (AP) -- The Defense Department identified 149 additional Korean combat casualties today in a list that included forty-six dead, ninety-eight wounded and five injured. Those listed for New York and New Jersey (none from Connecticut) follow:

Dragging data from the most unlikely places, including the building inspector's office in the City of Glasgow, A. K. Cairncross has turned out a remarkable reconstruction of Britain's home and foreign investments during a period when reliable statistics were more often absent than scarce.

WEST BARRINGTON, R. I., Aug. 23 -- As a steady wind swept in from Narragansett Bay over the Rhode Island Country Club course today, most of the 149 golfers slated to participate in the United States women's amateur championship completed their practice sessions.

A sorely needed traffic reform near the George Washington Bridge is being blocked by Washington Heights realty interests that are trying to "blackjack" the Port Authority into an unsound, more ambitious plan, according to Austin J. Tobin, executive director of the agency.

NEW LONDON, Conn., Aug. 23 -- The American Dance Festival sponsored by Connecticut College closed a highly successful series of five performances at Palmer Auditorium with a matinee this afternoon. Attendance was generally excellent, and the last three performances were completely sold out.
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 23 (AP) -- Ken Raffensberger combined some great clutch pitching with a double that scored two ninth-inning runs to give the Redlegs a 5-3 victory over the Cardinals today.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 23 (UP) -- Al Rosen hit his thirty-third home run of the year today as the Indians swept a double-header with the Browns, 3 -- 1 and 9 -- 0. Rosen now leads the league in batting, home runs and runs batted in.

The year 1952 brought both "the greatest threat and the greatest promise" in the nation's fight against poliomyelitis, according to the annual report of the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis, made public yesterday.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 23 (UP) -- Aided by a pair of 47-yard field goals by Lou Groza, the Cleveland Browns opened their exhibition schedule today with a 20-7 victory over the San Francisco Forty-Niners.

BONN, Germany, Aug. 23 -- Although the way they mark their ballots on Sept. 6 may be a critical factor in the future of Europe, West Germany's voters have so far reacted to the parliamentary election campaign with remarkable calmness. It might almost be a city council race, not a contest for control of one of the most disputed areas in the world.

A new name, Fortisan, has been added to the long list of manmade materials, which, because of their special qualities, are particularly useful to the homemaker in furnishings or in garments. This one is made of cellulose by the Celenese Corporation of America and, according to William Whitehead, one of the concern's technical experts, is distinguished by great strength, dimensional stability and fade resistance.

LOUISVILLE, Ky. -- There's a line in the current musical drama, "The Tall Kentuckian," describing the tension in these parts during Kentucky's more or less neutral stand in the war between the states:
BOSTON, Aug. 23 (AP) -- The "law of the jungle" applies to news reporting of court trials, the head of the New York County Lawyers Association said today.

In line with their new tactic of attempting to split the West by wooing individual countries through a particularly blatant application of the carrot and the stick policy, the Soviets have now launched their most massive offensive to pry Germany loose from the West, and thus break up all further efforts toward European unification, as an essential step toward the establishment of their own hegemony over the Continent.
Holders of Wisconsin Power and Light Company's common stock are being offered rights to subscribe for 329,194 additional shares at $19.60 a share on the basis of one share for each seven shares held.

HONG KONG, Aug. 23 -- The British coastal freighter Inchulva was fired upon and intercepted by two armed junks early this morning off Foochow, along the southeast China coast. The interception was disclosed in a wireless message received here from the 1,772-ton Inchulva.

Cotton prices in the domestic market continued to hold to a narrow trading range last week. At the close of trading on Friday on the New York Cotton Exchange prices of futures were 5 points higher to 7 points lower, or up 25 cents a bale to down 35 cents.
New skirt and stole teams are as easy to make as they are to wear, and their smartness is demonstrated in the sketches on this page.

The American Merchant Marine Library Association anounced yesterday that with financial assistance from the shipping industry and the general public it had been able to function for the second successive year without a loss.

MILWAUKEE, Aug. 23 (UP) -- The second-place Braves dropped nine games behind the Dodgers in the National League when they split a double-header with the Cubs today, winning the first game, 10 to 2, and then losing the second, 7 to 2,

BONN, Germany, Aug. 23 -- Coming to the Rhine from the Danube highlights a dramatic contrast. Though the Danube serves at least five nations and used to link them together, at Vienna there is now only a trickle of Sovietcontrolled traffic. The Danube flows through the Soviet orbit and the Russians are making a belated effort to restore its life, but it is still a dead river in comparison with the past.

We are against making New York's subways any noisier than they are, and therefore against using loudspeakers in the busiest stations to blare out sweet messages from TV stars. Anybody who spends much time in the subway trains is likely to suffer the delusion, anyway, that he is hearing voices.

The Chicago, Rock Island and Pacific Railroad has put into operation a new method of switching traffic through heavily traveled junctions at its Gresham plant near Chicago, according to an announcement over the week-end. Known as the "Sequence Switch Interlocking System," it has been used in Great Britain where two installations have been handling up to 1,500 train movements a day since 1949.

RINALDO GANDOLFI, muralist, was interrupted at his canvas west of Conservatory Lake in Central Park last Friday by a group of small fry who poured questions at millrace speed. He answered as many as he could until patience wore thin.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 23 (Reuters) -- A Roman catholic Bishop and a Serbian Orthodox Bishop have fled their dioceses in Bosnia after threats by mobs of Communists, the Yugoslav press reported today.

Enlisted men, just like every other sub-species of the human male, reach from the sartorially impeccable to what might gently be termed the sartorially neglige. The G. I.'s at the sloppy end of the spread can be broken down into two more groupings: those who don't particularly care how they look and those who are firmly convinced that carelessness is next to manliness.
To enliven midsummer meal tables, there are some new dinnerware designs and drinking accessories included in a new group of imports from Europe available at Alfred Orlik, 745 Fifth Avenue.
ANN ARBOR, Mich., Aug. 23 (AP) -- Jimmy Raines of Augusta, Ga., posted a three-over-par 75 today to win the eighth international Junior Chamber of Commerce golf tournament.

DENVER, Aug. 23 -- President Eisenhower, accompanied by an old friend, Floyd Akers, Washington automobile dealer, went to church this morning and then spent a quiet day at home except for a drive of about two hours late in the afternoon.
A Communist party bid of $100 for 20,000 pieces of Red literature and several items of office equipment now in the hands of the Bronx Bureau of Encumbrances was topped yesterday by one cent.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 23 (Reuters) -- The Yugoslav Communist newspaper Borba apologized today for having edited Clement Attlee's criticism of the Yugoslav political system out of the report on a speech he made last week.
FAIRFIELD, Conn., Aug. 23 (AP) -- One person was killed, two were critically injured and two seriously injured today in a three-car smash-up on the Merritt Parkway.

BONN, Germany, Aug. 23. -- A Government spokesman described the Soviet concessions to the East Zone Communist Government as "a massive attempt to influence the West German electorate against Chancellor Konrad Adenauer in the Sept. 6 general election."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (AP) -- Jet bombers on a 3,000-mile nonstop flight from Florida and jet fighters from southern Virginia teamed today in a colorful salute to the Unknown Soldier and the nation's air heroes.

" Guernica," a seventeen-minute symphonic poem by Clermont Pepin, young Canadian composer, received its United States premiere yesterday afternoon. It was conducted by Wilfred Pelletier during the regular Sunday afternoon broadcast of the N. B. C. Summer Symphony.
ABERDEEN, Md., Aug. 23 -- Two world records were set in morning one-mile time trials today at the annual regatta of the Bush River Boat Club.

It may be that Vic Raschi has arrived at that more mature stage in his career where henceforth, as a sort of elder craftsman, he is to be known as a "Sunday pitcher." But he seems to be doing right well at his new calling.

Allie Reynolds, Yankee pitcher, and the American League's player representative refused yesterday to become perturbed over the fact that the National League president, Warren C. Giles, had stated that the players, by engaging a lawyer, J. Norman Lewis, to act for them in their relations with the club owners, were in danger of "surrendering a privilege that has been very valuable to them."
Eight new films, including an import from Britain, are slated to arrive in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:

The complexity of the United States formulating a positive foreign policy in the Middle East is pointed out by the outbreaks of internal revolt in Iran. The struggle being waged is merely the mirror for a picture which is essentially true throughout the Middle East.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (UP) -- The Agriculture Department will give "serious consideration" to a plan for shifting land made idle by production controls into grass, an informed source predicted today.

Robert A. Vogeler, who was imprisoned in Hungary for seventeen months on charges of spying, has filed a $500,000 damage suit against the International Telephone and Telegraph Company, his former employer, contending it was legally liable "for what I went through."

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Ang. 23 (UP) -- Mrs. Floyd G. Owens, a softhearted dog lover who wanted to return a lost collie to his home was busy at the telephone today calling everyone named Gross in the eight American cities named Evansville.

BERNARDSVILLE, N. J., Aug. 23 -- Chet Sanok and Phil Dameo of Forsgate scored a thrilling twenty-two-hole 1-up victory over Billy Y. Dear and Gordon Brown of Morris County to take the New Jersey amateur-amateur four-ball championship today.
BOSTON, Aug. 23 -- Approximately 3,000 lawyers assembled here for the American Bar Association convention were guests at special church services today.

For the third year Wall Street is telling its story and providing an intimate picture of its operations to a group of men from American colleges. This year twenty instructors and graduate students in business and economics are attending a forum sponsored by the Joint Committee on Education Representing the American Securtiies Business. It will open today and continue through Sept. 11.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- All subordinate units of the American Federation of Labor have been directed to "disassociate and suspend" the carpenters union because it quit the A. F. L. at the top level. But informal, unofficial moves already are being made to bring the carpenters back before the break develops into bitterness and warfare.

LONDON, Aug. 23 -- Tremendous economic forces that are swirling beneath the surface of the international oil trade could easily be let loose, with consequences of great importance for the whole world economy, if Iran, as a result of Premier Mohammed Mossadegh's overthrow, should come back to any significant extent as an exporter of petroleum products.

The boom in home air conditioning is having an important but little - advertised side effect: it is putting an end to a widely played nocturnal game involving the lowering of windows before or during, and the raising of them after, those thunderstorms that come booming and banging in from the west about 2 o'clock in the morning.

Tenant complaints handled by the local office of the State Temporary Housing Commission in July were almost double the number processed in June, Rent Administrator Joseph D. McGoldrick reported yesterday. Lanlord complaints also increased in the thirty-day period.

CHICAGO, Aug. 23 -- The grain futures markets last week failed to enlist sufficient buying support to prevent substantial price recessions except in September corn, which has been comparatively strong.

Fighting in Korea has ceased but commercial "battles," roll on. Bristol-Myers Company says it is leading off in what it calls the "battle of anti-enzyme toothpastes." The company has announced that anti-enzyme ingredients have been incorporated in its regular Ipana and Ipana A/C (ammoniated chlorophyll) dentrifices and are available at drug and all other stores handling its products.

SEOUL, Korea, Aug. 23 -- Political forces within the Republic of Korea are engaged in a tug of war for the favor of President Syngman Rhee and as a result of the struggle it is expected there will be some reshuffling of high officials within the Korean Government.

An American edition of "Americans Are Alone in the World," by Luigi Barzini Jr., will be published on Oct. 16 by Random House. Mr. Barzini, an Italian journalist, gives an interpretation of "America's unsought role as the reluctant leader of the free world." The book, published last year in Italy, has been revised to include the most recent European reactions to the Eisenhower Administration.

A five-year project begun by Columbia University's Department of Slavic Languages on a $25,000 grant from the Rockefeller Foundation has resulted in the production of thirty-one books and pamphlets for use as textbooks in the training of experts in the language, culture and customs of Eastern European countries.

MONTREAL, Aug. 23 (AP) -- Doug Ford, 31-year-old golfer from Harrison, N. Y., won the $25,000 open tournament today with a sensational fifteen-under-par 265 for the 72-hole four-day competition at the Summerlea Club.
Passenger liners of the Cunard Steamship Company are expected to average nearly three sailings a week from New York and to accommodate 400,000 persons in the twelve months ending with November, 1954.

In the fourth and fifth hours of yesterday's stock market session a spate of selling in rails hit the gently crumbling list. Before the resulting landslide had ended prices had registered their widest break since June 9 and were back to the lowest levels since July 29.

The introduction of a child to the dental chair should take place no later than his third birthday if his parents are to avoid the possibility of an unpleasant child-dentist meeting "over an abyss of cavities," Dr. Irving M. Sheppard of New York advises.

The city's program for repairing the Brooklyn and Manhattan Bridges should be reduced to a minimum. These two transportation arteries between lower Manhattan and downtown Brooklyn are obsolete and should be replaced with tunnels, which could be made self-supporting.

LONDON, Aug. 24 -- The first verdicts of the Press Council as judges of the morals of British newspapers have been bitterly attacked by newspapers and outside sources. The strongest criticism has come from Lord Beaverbrook's group of papers.
Anthony Anastasia, whose activities as a boss on Brooklyn's waterfront have earned him the nickname of "Tough Tony," has found the daily presence of policemen "harassing."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (AP) -- Secretary of the Interior McKay today announced the hunting days for migratory waterfowl during the 1953-54 season as selected by state game administrators. His action made the state seasons official.
BURBANK, Calif., Aug. 24 -- Observation by radar is taking a leap upward with the production of high-altitude reconnaissance planes that will carry observation to a new height, at least 25,000 feet.

WEST BARRINGTON, R. I., Aug. 24 -- A 19-year-old golfer from Waterford, Wis., Joyce Ziske, today brought to a surprising end the bid of Marlene Stewart, the Canadian star, to win the women's United States amateur championship.

The City Planning Commission will make no appropriations in the city's capital budget for parking lot on the rim of the city and adjacent to rapid transit lines until the Board of Estimate decides which of several city agencies will build and operate the lots.

OTTAWA, Aug. 24 (Canadian Press) -- The Board of Transport Commissioners decided today to hold an additional hearing Oct. 19 on a Canadian Pacific Railway proposal that it be permitted to earn a 6 1/2 per cent rate of return on its investment in railway property.

GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 24 -- Fred Lorenzen, the 1951 champion, took the first event in the five-race international championship regatta of the Luders-16 class at the Indian Harbor Yacht Club today. The home-fleet representative, Vic Coudert Jr., won in Michigan last year. Lorenzen covered the five-mile Gold Cup course 1 minute 31 seconds quicker than Ray Person of Los Angeles.

ATLANTA, Aug. 24 (AP) -- Judge Hobson R. Reynolds of Philadelphia, a Negro, declared today that "America is the only country in the world for Negroes to live in." He told the opening session of the National Negro Elks convention that he had found this out in touring five European countries.
J. G. Patrick and James A. Stack Jr. have been named to direct the credit department of Pacific Mills, textiles.
FRANKFURT, Germany, Aug 24 -- Events of the week - end proved again how closely events in Germany were related to the heart of Soviet policy, both external and internal.

TOKYO, Aug. 25 (UP) -- The Communists have notified the United Nations Command that "about 400 Allied war prisoners have declared they do not want to be repatriated," the Peiping radio reported today.

GREENSBORO, N. C., Aug. 24 (UP) -- The next accident on a highway in Guilford County, North Carolina, will mark the start of a nation-wide study to find out how the human body can be "packaged" in an automobile to prevent injury when a smash-up occurs.

RABAT, Morocco, Aug. 24 -- The police were hopeful today of finding the saboteurs who, they believe, caused the wreck of the Casablanca-Algiers express last night, with the loss of two lives. The Diesel electric train hit an unbolted rail three miles north of Port Lyautey and ran off the track.

DENVER, Aug. 24 -- Dr. Neil Herman Jacoby, a professor and administrator, was appointed by President Eisenhower as a member of the Council of Economic Advisers. Since 1948 Dr. Jacoby has been Dean of the School of Business Administration of the University of California at Los Angeles.

A 19-year-old Staten Island high school student was killed and three companions suffered severe head injuries yesterday when an automobile in which they were riding careened off a curve on Hylan Boulevard, Oakwood, and rolled over several times in a field before crashing into a tree.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 24 -- One week after talks were initiated to settle the aggravating border incidents on the Yugoslav-Albanian boundary, Yugoslavia requested today a three-day suspension of the negotiations.

NARRAGANSETT, R. I., Aug. 24 -- This dignified resort could well be called Tuna Town tonight. Close to 200 of the Atlantic coast's top game fishermen are quartered in the big hotels on Ocean Road. And down at the new state docks in Point Judith Harbor more than seventy of the finest fishing boats in commission are tugging gently at mooring lines.

A 28-year-old ex-convict was captured yesterday in a three- block chase by an off-duty patrolman a few minutes after a Washington Heights savings and loan office had been robbed of $6,360. The money was recovered.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -- The Air Force has sent separation notices to 6,500 reserve officers and expects to release 4,000 more to make room for the incoming crop of college men from the Reserve Officers Training Corps.

LEOPOLDVILLE, Belgian Congo, Aug. 23 -- The military command and the Government of the Belgian Congo consider it a vital sector in the defense of the free world. Considerable sums are being spent rather suddenly on defense installations and plans are being developed to link the Congo with the defense of the African continent and with the strategic necessities of the democratic alliance if war should come.

Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed 3 points lower to 5 points higher. The October position inclined to lag, that delivery closing at 26 points under December against the difference of 11 points on Aug. 10. A little increase in fixations readily absorbed the scale-up hedges.

FRANKFURT, Germany, Aug. 24 (Reuters) -- A sensational West German trial ended here today with jail sentences for three bank executives charged with having helped Jewish victims of Nazi oppression to take their blocked funds abroad in an illegal manner.

BONN, Germany, Aug. 24 -- German Socialists and the Government of North Rhine-Westphalia joined hands today to suppress a renascent Nazi movement led by Dr. Werner Naumann. The electioneering activities of the former state secretary in Joseph Goebbels' Propaganda Ministry have drawn sufficient crowds to cause alarm among political parties committed to defense of the German Democratic Federal Republic founded four years ago.

UNITED NATION, N. Y., Aug. 24 -- The United Nations Security Council will meet Wednesday to decide whether to take up the charge by a group of Asian and African states that France had intervened unlawfully in Morocco to overthrow the Sultan, Sidi Mohammed ben Youssef.

The International Union of Electrical Workers, C. I. O., and the Westinghouse Electric Corporation announced yesterday an agreement for wage increases of 3 to 11 cents an hour and higher pensions for 50,000 employes.
OTTAWA, Aug. 24 (Canadian Press) -- Trade Department officials greeted Mr. Douglas' report with pleased surprise today.
ANDOVER, Mass., Aug. 24 (AP) -- The American Unitarian Association and the Universalist Church of America joined today in a partial federation of the two national liberal Church groups.

Retail shoe groups have been organized in 134 cities with populations of 25,000 or more to unify and coordinate the fall 1953 "New in Shoes" program, says the National Shoe Manufacturers Association. Most of these groups have laid elaborate plans and are working with local newspapers and radio stations.
Like a flight of bombers in V-formation a swarm of 3,000 bees buzzed a Bronx apartment house for two hours yesterday, frightening seventy-five families into seeking cover behind closed windows.

LONDON, Aug. 24 -- Price movements were small and aimless in most sections of the securities market here today and net changes were insignificant. However, the undertone among leading industrials remained firm while British Government securities were in steady demand with rises of up to one-eighth of 1 per cent recorded.
Your front-page article on music in the subways is amusing, but the threat is not.

LONDON, Aug. 24 -- Britain's international money exchange problems and the need for greater productivity and efficiency in British industry are the recurrent themes in the annual report of the General Council of the Trades Union Congress published today, two weeks in advance of the annual convention of the Congress.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (UP) -- The Federal Communications Commission announced today it had established new priority lists for handling competing applications for television station permits.

DARIEN, Conn., Aug. 24 -- Christopher Risola of 79 Post Road, who offered a tract of land in the Post Road, opposite the Darien High School, to the United States Government for a local post office, has been notified with regret that the Government is unable to accept the property.
A plan to reorganize the bankrupt New York, Ontario Western Railway into two separate companies was filed yesterday with a United States district court and the Interstate Commerce Commission.

GREENPORT, L. I., Aug. 24 -- As the summer draws to its close, the underwater "farmers" here, like their soil-tilling colleagues, are getting ready for their harvests. In this old whaling town, where many still derive their living from the sea, the gleaning of the oyster crops will start at the end of this month.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 24 -- In the $4,500 added handicap that headed Saratoga's racing program today, Trainer Jim Fitzsimmons had (1) the winner, and (2) a horse that refused to run. Wheatley Stable's Hilarious went six furlongs in a brisk 1:12 1/5 to win by a head, but the other half of Mr. Fitz' entry, the Belair Stud's Hyphasis, refused to budge when the flaps on the gate were opened.

Wage increases ranging from $1.25 to $4 a week for 35,000 hotel workers in 187 hotels of the city are provided in a contract extension announced yesterday by the New York Hotel Trades Council, A. F. L.

BONN, Germany, Aug. 24 -- The Social Democratic party dissented from the West German Government's view today and issued a warning against interpreting the Soviet Union's latest concessions to East Germany as "mere gestures."

HARTFORD, Conn., Aug. 24 -- The Connecticut Development Commission reported today that Connecticut business had achieved its highest level in history in the first six months of this year and that the "present momentum would carry business well into 1954 at a high level."

Consumption of man-made textile fibers increased four-fold between 1937 and 1951, according to a study of textile inter-fiber competition compiled by E. L du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., and released yesterday by the Textile Economics Bureau, Inc.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (AP) -- The Veterans Administration is making its first check on the financial status of parents who are receiving compensation for the death of sons or daughters in World War II. They are not entitled to the compensation unless dependent on such income.

The Ingersoll-Rand Company, in its semi-annual statement covering the six months ended June 30, reported an estimated net profit yesterday of $9,873,259, equal to $4.88 a share of common stock. In the initial half of 1952 the net profit was $9,876,697, also $4.88 a common share.
RANGOON, Burma, Aug. 24 (Reuters) -- A sudden flood surge has destroyed the town of Shwegyin [cross on map] and 1,000 persons are unaccounted for, it was reported today.

OYSTER BAY, L. I., Aug 24 -- The race committee at the Seawanhaka-Corinthian Yacht Club and competitors in the Six-Meter trials to determine the American craft that will face the European and Canadian yachts in the One Ton Cup championship late next month put in a long vigil today in an attempt to start the third and concluding race in the series.
LONDON, Aug. 24 (AP) -- Mrs. Perle Mesta, former United States Minister to Luxembourg, said today she was "shocked" by what she saw of Communist life during her two-month tour of Russia.
A new collection of furniture and accessories by designers connected with the Austrian Workshop is now on view at Fabry Associates, 6 East Fifty-third Street, and available there through decorators.

Commodity prices on the New York exchanges closed generally lower yesterday on light volume. Only potatoes registered close-to-normal activity. Potatoes, cocoa, coffee, rubber, hides, zinc and copper were lower; sugar, lead and tin ended mixed, and wool, cottonseed oil and soybean oil closed higher.

HONG KONG, Aug. 24 -- A "warning shot" fired by the destroyer Cockade drove off a blockading Chinese Nationalist gunboat along the southeast China Coast this morning as British-naval intervention saved the freighter Nigelock from possible Nationalist capture for the second time in nine days.

Directors of the Electric Bond and Share Company, once one of the nation's largest public utility holding companies, have authorized a capital distribution of seventeen shares of common stock of the United Gas Corporation for each 100 shares of Electric Bond and Share stock held.

Metropolitan area gift shop owners and department store giftware buyers flocked to three trade shows held for them yesterday and placed plenty of orders. By the end of the day satisfied exhibitors agreed that the jinx that has been dogging home furnishings trade shows for the last several months had been broken.
Rudyard Kipling got screen credit on a television drama last night, but not his literary work.
Shipment of $250,000 worth of glassed-steel equipment for a plant to produce DDT in Argentina was announced yesterday in Rochester, N. Y., by the Pfaudler Company, manufacturer of the equipment.

Back-to-school fashions for little girls never have been so varied so attractive. Grown-up trends are reflected in all the dresses, with the exception of the sheath silhouette. All little girls want "twirly skirts" that flounce and move when they run, and such apparel is to be found in quantities -- pleated, gathered or gored.

TOKYO, Tuesday, Aug. 25 -- Communist China called today for a round-table conference on Korean affairs covering a wide range of topics for international discussion and "not to take the form of negotiations between the two sides of the Korean armistice only."

With regularity letters appear in your columns complaining of the rudeness of New Yorkers, each one more horrified than the last. Recently a fellow-countryman of mine, Bruce Cunningham, saw fit to add his penn'rth of complaint. Therefore, I feel that I must make some remonstrance against this vilification, even if the citizens care little what is said about them.

Dave Beck, president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, A. F. L., yesterday ordered the local union representing striking concrete truck drivers to conduct a secret ballot on an industry offer for settlement of the fifty-two-day strike that has crippled construction in the metropolitan area.
EDINBURGH, Scotland, Aug. 24 (Reuters) -- Claire Bloom won another hypercritical Shakespearean audience tonight with a moving rendition of Ophelia in Old Vic's latest production of "Hamlet."

LONDON, Tuesday, Aug. 25 -- The Douglas report was greeted by the London press today with warm approval, though The Daily Herald, the Laborite paper, doubted that it would be heeded in the United States. This country has been calling for a liberalization of United States restrictions on imports and the report falls into line with the Government's goal of "trade, not aid."

CAMP PERRY, Ohio, Aug. 24 (AP) -- John J. Crowley, a Clintonville, Conn., custom gunmaker, captured the national small-bore rifle championship today by a narrow margin over Charles Whipple of Somerset, Pa., and John Moschkau of Waterloo, Iowa.

J. Norman Lewis, the attorney who has been retained to aid the major league baseball players in their negotiations with the club owners, had what he described as a "very satisfactory" meeting with baseball's top brass yesterday.

PARIS, Aug. 24 -- Officials of the National Assembly refused today to call that body back into session, thus halting for the moment the political offensive against Premier Joseph Laniel's Government begun by the Socialist and Communist parties with the backing of a majority of French labor.
FREEDOM VILLAGE, Korea, Aug. 24 -- Sgt. Charles H. Panco started on his way back to Brooklyn today after having spent three years and one month in Communist prison camps.

Matters are going from bad to worse in Cuba and it would be a disservice to the Inter-American System to ignore that fact. President Batista is gradually accumulating all the evils that inevitably follow from the primary evil of destroying a democratic process to install a dictatorship.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 24 (AP) -- Fifth-seeded Gwenyth Johnson of the Merion Cricket Club, the Middle States girls' grass court tennis champion, triumphed over Carolyn Rittenour of West Palm Beach, Fla., 6 -- 3, 6 -- 2, today to advance to the third round of the United States girls' lawn tennis singles tourney.

Gradually our liberated prisoners from Korea are beginning to get back to us. The first shipload has landed on the West Coast. The first group has landed by plane here in this area. These men bring even closer to us the sorrows and sufferings that they have undergone and the tribulation that has been brought to them, to us, and to Korea by the acts of the aggressor.

ROME, Aug. 24 -- By 315 votes to 215, with 44 abstentions, the Chamber of Deputies gave its confidence tonight to the Government headed by Giuseppe Pella, Christian Democratic financial and economic expert. The new Government received a vote of confidence in the Senate Saturday by a majority of 140 to 86, with 10 abstentions, and has thus been approved by both houses only nine days after its composition was announced.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (AP) -- Sir Sydney Palmer, a leading spokesman for rubber producers in Southeast Asia, made a plea today for an increase in the price of United States synthetic rubber. He told reporters that his hope was to raise the price of natural rubber and with it the income of 500,000 small holders in Malaya.
Mrs. James Thurber was a patient yesterday in the Eye Institute at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center awaiting an operation to correct a detached retina.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 24 -- Dr. Yung Tai Pyun, Foreign Minister of South Korea, said tonight that his Government would find it impossible to "collaborate" with India at the proposed Far Eastern conference if the General Assembly invited India as a representative of the United Nations.
A taxi driver with a slight built but a robust courage and a detective's instincts literally drove two suspected hold-up men last night into the arms of the law.

Shipping delays caused by fog, which cost the maritime industry in the Port of New York $500,000 annually, could be reduced substantially by installation of a permanent radar station at the harbor entrance to assist vessels to their berths, according to the Port of New York Authority.

BOSTON, Aug. 24 -- Robert H. Jackson, Associate Justice of the United States Supreme Court, asserted tonight that traditional American freedoms were in greater danger of being "bartered or traded" for temporary gains than they were of a sudden overthrow.

LONDON, Aug. 24 (Reuters) -- Surrey's spin bowlers, Tony Lock and Jim Laker, who played a big part in England's cricket triumph over Australia, today put their county in a commanding position in the match with Middlesex.

The American Broadcasting Company announced yesterday that barring any labor union difficulties its local station. WABC-TV, would televise today's twi-night double-header between the Brooklyn Dodgers and the Chicago Cubs at Ebbets Field beginning at 6 o'clock.
BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Aug. 24 -- They're going to burn down the lighthouse that has stood in this harbor's mouth since 1851.

PUSAN, Aug. 24 (AP) -- Gen. A. Rusk, director of the Institute of Physical Medicine and Rehabilitation, New York University-Bellevue Medical Center, and associate editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES, and their party arrived in Pusan today to continue their seven-day survey of South Korea's rehabilitation needs.

NEWARK, Aug. 24 (UP) -- Hein Ten Hoff of Hamburg, Germany, floored Jimmy Rousse of Albany six times tonight before scoring a technical knockout victory at 2:24 of the fifth round of their scheduled ten-round bout at Meadow-brook Bowl.

Consolidated net income of the Southern Company for the twelve months ended on July 31 was $21,369,550, equal to $1.18 each on the 18,087,643 shares outstanding at the end of the period, the company announced yesterday. In the previous twelve months, earnings were $19,406,000, or $1.13 each on 17,076,669 shares.

CHICAGO, Aug. 24 -- Grain futures were more responsive to buying today than they had been in some time. Some of the local operators switched to the buying side on the theory that the recent slump in prices had discounted bearish features, mostly of a statistical kind, to a great extent.

THE truth about anything is usually complex, but the general impression is usually over-simplified and misleading. In theory we know we should distrust sweeping generalizations and popular stereotypes. In practice they are part of our thought. Thus, if some chance should cause you to think about nineteenth-century American women you would probably think of either a prim Victorian lady cross-stitching samplers, or of a pioneer woman making her own soap and candles and shooting Indians.

TRENTON, Aug. 24 -- A statewide, peacetime disaster-control system, designed to assure fast, efficient relief in any emergency, from a train wreck to a hydrogen bomb explosion, is expected to be put into operation in New Jersey within the next three months.

The well-known fact that the diet of most of mankind is poor has been confirmed once again by the studies of the American Geographical Society's medical geographers. Speaking in terms of broad averages, about one-third of humanity has an adequate diet, both in terms of total caloric intake and qualitatively in terms of protein, vitamin and mineral consumption; the diet of the remaining two-thirds of mankind is deficient in caloric intake, protective foods, or both.
LONDON, Aug. 24 (AP) -- The International Sugar Conference made public today a provisional world marketing agreement designed to assure balanced sugar supplies at "equitable and stable prices."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -- Lewis W. Douglas, after a study of world trade problems for President Eisenhower, has reported that the unity of the free world will rest on a "precarious and fragile" base until the United States lowers the barriers to commerce.

The news that Barbara Bel Geddes will not be playing the leading feminine role in the Playrights Company production of "Sabrina Fair" was accompanied yesterday by contradictory statements on the validity of contractual obligations and an atmosphere of strained feelings.
The following booklets, published recently, are available from Science Research Associates, 57 Grand Avenue, Chicago 10, for 40 cents each:

A five-day mass blood donation by personnel aboard the aircraft carrier Antietam, tied up for repairs at the New York Naval Shipyard, Brooklyn, began yesterday with the giving of 225 pints. The first donor was the commander, Capt. S. M. Pickering.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (AP) -- Secretary of the Army Robert T. Stevens today appointed a commitee of four business leaders and a general to study Army organization and recommend changes.

LONDON, Aug. 24 -- The impact of modern science, technology and socialization on the education of medical men was the theme of the First World Conference on Medical Education, opened here today under the auspices of the World Medical Association.

SAIGON, Vietnam, Aug. 24 -- For the first time since the beginning of the Cambodian crisis, King Norodom Sihanouk feels optimistic about the future of Cambodia. Speaking in Battambang, where he reviewed a parade of 20,000 soldiers, the King said Cambodia's future now presented itself in a favorable light.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (AP) -- The Defense Department today identified 83 Korean war casualties in a new list that included 22 killed, 55 wounded and 6 injured. Those listed from New York and Connecticut (none from New Jersey) follow:
The New York Knickerbockers yesterday obtained Jim Baechtold, 1953 rookie sensation of the National Basketball Association, from the Baltimore Bullets in a five-player deal.

The Soviet newspaper Izvestia is again decrying the sad state of professional clowning in Russia. Once, it seems -- and not in Czarist times, either -- there was an abundance of first-rate circus clowns all over the U. S. S. R. But now, alas, not a single top-drawer funny man is left to the Russian big tops.

The sleek, white-hulled training ship Empire State of the State University Maritime College, Fort Schuyler, the Bronx, weighed anchor yesterday morning and steamed up the Harbor on her way to Albany, the final port of call on her current eighth annual European training cruise.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Aug. 24 -- Dr. David M. Spain, Westchester medical examiner and pathologist, has notified county officials that he will leave his $14,310 county job soon to become head of an expanding laboratory program at Beth-El Hospital in Brooklyn, it was learned today.

Mortgage lending by members of the United States Savings and Loan League for home buying and building during the first six months of this year amounted to $3,738,000,000, according to Charles L. Clements, president, who said the total set a record.

SAN JOSE, Calif., Aug. 24 -- Under a glistening aluminum dome atop near-by Mount Hamilton, optical experts are beginning a final painstaking phase of the task of preparing the world's second largest telescope to peer through the heavens at stars 900,000,000 light years away.

A block of $6,887,000 of common stock of Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company was distributed yesterday by a syndicate of forty-four underwriting houses headed by Goldman, Sachs Co., Kidder, Peabody Co. and Piper, Jaffray Hopwood.

YONKERS, Aug. 24 (AP) -- Big Cannon, owned by Mrs. William C. Harris of Massapequa, L. I., scored by two and three-quarter lengths in the $4,640 feature for 2-year-old trotters tonight at Yonkers Raceway.
Over the vehement objections of the Hack Bureau of the Police Department, the four-year-old ban on driver control of taxicab radios has been lifted at Mayor Impellitteri's insistence.

RYE, N. Y., Aug. 24 -- Al Femminelli, Old Oaks aide, and Joe Gondo of Knollwood won the first prize in today's pro-amateur tournament staged by the Westchester County Golf Association at the Apawamis Club. They triumhped in the draw after three of the 103 participating teams had deadlocked with six-under-par 66's.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Aug. 24 (AP) -- Nashville's first repatriated Korean war prisoner signed up today for his third hitch in the Army with the comment, "I had six days of civilian life and that was enough."

Mayor Impellitteri asserted yesterday that Abe Stark, a running mate of Manhattan Borough President Robert F. Wagner Jr. in the Democratic primary, had offered to back him in 1950 in return for appointment as Deputy Mayor. The Mayor said the proffer was flatly rejected.

TEHERAN, Iran, Aug. 24 -- Iran's new Premier, Maj. Gen. Fazlollah Zahedi, has opened an offensive against the outlawed Tudeh (Communist) party, which was courted dangerously by his ousted predecessor, Dr. Mohammed Mossadegh, and against prominent Iranian fellow-travelers, including a Prince of the nation's former ruling dynasty.

The catastrophic wars since 1914 and the evidence of the awesome power of the atom and hydrogen bombs have been arousing a new interest in religion in the United States and especially in the colleges and universities, according to the Right Rev. Henry Knox Sherrill, Presiding Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Church.

GLEN COVE, L. I., Aug. 24 -- The invitation tennis tournament of the Nassau Country Club began today with fifteen foreign players included in the strong entry that set out in quest of one of the most prized of all tennis trophies.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Aug. 24 -- The United States and Colombian navies are collaborating in the establishment of three naval bases on the Meta River, hundreds of miles from the ocean. In addition to the strategic needs for the bases, their creation is expected to open to commerce a huge area of the Colombian plains known as the Lanos.
DENVER, Aug. 24 (AP) -- Two cash dividends of $2 each on the common stock and a 50 per cent stock dividend were declared today by directors of the Denver and Rio Grande Western Railroad.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -- The State Department placed a low evaluation today on the tangible benefits expected to accrue to the East Germans as a result of the protocol signed in Moscow yesterday by Soviet officials and Otto Grotewohl, East German Premier.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (AP) -- Herbert Brownell Jr., Attorney General, announced today the entry of a deportation order against Leo Feinstein of New York, described as long active in Communist party affairs. Feinstein, 40, years old, is a native of Switzerland and a naturalized Russian citizen.

Dorothy Norman in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Aug. 22 is especially concerned that such great Asian nations as India be included in the post-truce political conference. I feel, however, that she overlooks a more fundamental aspect of the issue now before the General Assembly.

Francis W. Coker, Professor Emeritus of Government at Yale University, was incorrectly described in a story in THE NEW YORK TIMES on Aug. 17 as having been questioned about communism in a Yale investigation.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -- The Department of Justice asked the Federal Court of Appeals here today to reinstate the four counts of perjury against Owen Lattimore that were dismissed by Federal District Judge Luther W. Youngdahl May 2.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (AP) -Elpidio Quirino, President of the Philippine Islands, said today greater economic aid to Far East countries would help them "increase their efforts to preserve free institutions."

Long-lines employes of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company staged sudden walkouts yesterday in four Eastern cities as a protest, according to union leaders, against what they called, "company stalling" in contract negotiations here. The walkouts were expected to be temporary.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -- The Committee on Un-American Activities of the House of Representatives has voted to send to the Department of Justice the complete record of sworn testimony taken in the case of the Rev. Jack Richard McMichael, the first minister called under subpoena before the investigating panel.

The White House, according to reports from Washington over the weekend, is planning to set up a network of qualified volunteers whose function it will be to keep the Administration informed of any local or regional changes in the economic weather that might conceivably foretell a major change to come on a national scale.

NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 24 -One of the major difficulties confronting India in discharge of her functions as chairman of the Neutral Nations Repatriation Commission in Korea is lack of trained interpreters knowing the Chinese and Korean languages.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 24 -The rank and file of labor in the motion picture and television industries here was thrown into confusion today by the disclosure of what appears to be a serious division of opinion between Roy M. Brewer, international representative in Hollywood of the International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employes, and Richard F. Walsh, international president of the A. F. L. union.

MAYS LANDING, N. J., Aug. 24 (AP) -- The Killian Farms' Dark Royal upset the form players in today's crowd of 18,715 at the Atlantic City track when he equaled the seven-furlong course record in the $6,000 Avalon Purse. The 3-year-old colt sped the distance in 1:23 2/5 to hold off the Kay-Gee Stables' Marked Game by a nose in a photo finish.

A revised estimated uniform price of $4.25 a hundredweight for August milk deliveries to New York Pool-approved plants was announced yesterday by Dr. C. J. Blanford, market administrator for the New York metropolitan milk marketing area.

The first New Yorkers among the returned prisoners of war who reached San Francisco by sea Sunday arrived here by air yesterday. Several veterans from near-by states and from Puerto Rico were also among the fifty-two men who landed at La Guardia Airport in half a dozen commercial airliners.
The State of Connecticut announced yesterday that it would offer for sale on Sept. 9 an issue of $73,500,000 of housing notes due March 5 and Sept. 29, 1954.

After increasing for three weeks altogether, steel-making operations were expected to fall off slightly this week. The industry scheduled operations at an estimated 94.9 per cent of theoretical capacity, indicating output of 2,138,000 tons of ingots and steel for castings, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -- A program to assist small business was explained to regional officials of the Small Business Administration at week-end conferences here.

Restored Colonial Williamsburg, in Virginia, undertakes in John D. Rockefeller Jr.'s own carefully chosen words -- including the split infinitive -- "to faithfully recall" the physical pattern of the town which was the Capital of the Old Dominion for three-quarters of a century and the scene of significant events in the history which produced these United States.

HANOVER, Germany, Aug. 24 -- The ultranationalist German Reich party fought back against suppressive efforts of two West German provincial governments today and still appeared to have a chance of returning a score of candidates to the Bundestag.

CAMP DRUM, N. Y., Aug. 24 -- The 9,000 troops from the New York City area of the Seventy-seventh Infantry Reserve Division and the Forty-second National Guard Division, who arrived at this reservation over the week-end for two weeks, lost no time today in getting down to the serious business of field training.

Changes in United States tax laws to provide that foreign-source income will not be taxed until actually remitted to this country have been urged in a statement filed by the Commerce and Industry Association of New York with the House Ways and Means Committee, the association announced yesterday.

EDMONTON, Alberta, Aug. 24 (Canadian Press) -- Tenders from American and Canadian pipeline contractors for construction of a petroleum products pipeline in the Yukon and Alaska will be called on Saturday, the Alaska District Corps of Engineers announced today.
