Harry J. Zweibel, 45-year-old lawyer, of 210 West Ninetieth Street, went to Bronx Magistrate's Court yesterday to answer a summons for speeding fifty-two miles an hour in the Bronx on June 29.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Aug. 24 (UP) -- Former President Harry S. Truman broke his self-imposed silence today and said his containment policy had "kept the Russians from overrunning the whole world." Mr. Truman warned that if America did not assume its responsibilities "we will be in for another world war."

BAY HEAD, N. J., Aug. 24 (AP) -- The Westhampton Yacht Club team got off to a quick lead in the Eastern finals of the national junior sailing championship today with victories in the first two contests of the six-race series.

EDINBURGH, Scotland, Aug. 24 -- The authentic idiom of American ballet in the form of Agnes De Mille's "Rodeo" swept the American National Ballet Theatre to a resounding first-night triumph here tonight at the International Festival of Music and Drama.
WESTBURY, L. I., Aug. 24 (AP) -- Proclamation led from the start at Roosevelt Raceway tonight and gained a length and three-quarter decision over Mynah Hanover in the Virginia Pace.

Harry Edwards, a lifelong resident of Yonkers, was sworn in yesterday as the thirty-third Surveyor of Customs of the Port of New York by Robert W. Dill, Collector of Customs, in a brief ceremony at the Custom House, 1 Bowling Green.

LONDON, Aug. 24 (Reuters) -- Australia, currently caught up in the world wheat glut, is in a favorable position to find customers among countries which want to buy wheat without spending dollars, although in the new international wheat season, which started on Aug. 1, her sales on the export market have been lower than those of hard-hit North America.
An apparently isolated case of poliomyelitis was contracted more than a week ago at the Ten Mile River Camp for 1,500 Boy Scouts near Narrowsburg, N. Y., the Health Department disclosed yesterday.
MONTREAL, Aug. 24 (AP) -- The field in the Canadian amateur golf championship toiled along for eleven hours today in the opening round with some hacking and chopping but without a major upset.

As was to be expected the whole Soviet state, party and propaganda machine has gone into high gear to exploit Premier Malenkov's "concessions" to the East German puppet regime and his threats of war in an effort to overthrow Chancellor Adenauer in the impending German election in order to kill the European Defense Community and European unification.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 24 -- Following are excerpts from a statement today by Dr. Yung Tai Pyun, South Korean Foreign Minister, to the Political and Security Committee of the United Nations General Assembly:

Once known as "Little Syria," an area around Atlantic Avenue in Brooklyn Heights is still the shopping center for delicacies of that Near Eastern country. Most of the Syrian-Americans have moved away, many to Bay Ridge, but they still return to the small stores, redolent with exotic spices, for flat, round loaves of the bread known as marad, for crisp, sweet baklava and for soft, white Syrian cheese.

Your editorial in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Aug. 18 deserves much attention. However, this problem of the Moroccan crisis leads one to be cautious about the facts behind the scene. For this reason I would like to bring to your attention the following facts:

GENEVA, Aug. 24 -- Invisible rays of an artifically made variant of carbon created in an atomic energy furnace in Britain are serving as searchlights illuminating a profound mystery of rheumatic disease. The first report on the results of such studies was presented today at the opening sessions of the Eighth International Congress on Rheumatic Diseases by Dr. J. H. Kellgren of London.

NEWARK, Aug. 24 -- Federal Judge Alfred E. Modarelli denied today an application for a preliminary injunction to restrain Algonquin Gas Transmission Company of Jersey City and Boston from putting a natural gas pipeline into operation on property in Passaic and Bergen Countie owned by Ramapo Park, Inc., and Rockledge, Inc., realty concerns.

MOUNT VERNON, N. Y., Aug. 24 -- For the last three years, Thomas E. Heckett, 23 years old, has been a volunteer fireman at the Oak Street fire balm here. Forced to play second fiddle to the paid firemen, he has been allowed to ride only on a precarious rear platform of the $21,000 pumper as it clanged and swayed through the streets with its siren wailing.
The Ampac Idaho, a 7,176-ton, Liberty-type, dry-cargo ship was seized by customs officers at an anchorage in the harbor yesterday on the ground the vessel was owned by aliens.

HILVERSUM, the Netherlands, Aug. 25 -- Robert Schuman, former Premier and Foreign Minister of France, called on Europe today to gather its dispersed energies, renounce its ideas of national sovereignty and create "a close union in time of peace and not under a threat of war."

The victory-starved Giants had to settle for half a loaf in last night's twilight-night double-header with the Cardinals at the Polo Grounds. Ruben Gomez hurled a four-hitter, blanking the Redbirds, 3 -- 0, and ended his club's losing streak at seven games.

If it comes about, the plan to have recorded voices of television personalities give instructions to New York City subway riders will be an odious retrogression in the city's affairs. I oppose the plan not only as a subway rider who will suffer but also as a person professionally interested in the future of television.

Futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed yesterday with gains of 13 to 19 points, compared with Monday's prices, and at the day's best levels and at the highest point in more than two weeks. Not since July had there been a daily price advance comparable to that of yesterday.
STOCKHOLM, Aug. 25 (AP)--TheI United States ruled the heavy fa-J rotate to win the major share of[ honors in the world weight-liftingl championships starting here to-[ morrow ]

Tests made with a plastic model have brought about a modification of the self-priming centrifugal pumps made by the Marlow Pump Company in its plant at Ridgewood, N. J., it disclosed yesterday. The testing procedure resulted in a more efficient design for increased capacity, it was explained.
Carroll J. Tresslar has been appointed general manager of the Chicago sales branch of Servel, Inc., household appliances.

BERLIN, Aug. 25 (AP) -- The Communists announced today the names and locations of the thirty-three Russian-managed mills and plants that Moscow said would be turned over to the East German Government when reparations ended Jan. 1.

CAMP PERRY, Ohio, Aug. 25 (AP) -- Master Sgt. Jewell C. Palmer today scored 287 of a possible 300 points to win the national trophy individual pistol match held in connection with the national rifle and pistol championships.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- Emil G. Stanley, executive vice president and secretary of the Traffic Service Corporation, has been named president and treasurer to succeed Edward F. Hamm Jr., who resigned to become the first managing director of the Interstate Commerce Commission.
HAVANA, Aug. 25 (AP) -- Four Cuban trade associations have asked the Cuban Government to reduce import duties on textiles.

MATTOON, Ill., Aug. 25 -- A plucky railroad engineer suffered a stroke in his cab today but clung to the throttle and piloted his train to its destination "on time." C. S. McNeil brought his train in even though he had suffered paralysis over his body except for his left arm, which he used to work the throttle.

The statement in your editorial of Aug. 21, "Policy on Power," that "on the other hand, there is not necessarily an overwhelming case for federal action when it comes to projects for the production of electric power that can be carried out locally under public regulation," takes, it seems to me, the prize as an outstanding example in modification, delimitation and almost complete sterilization of a statement of principle.

An account of the strategic place of railroads in the Civil War, entitled "Victory Rode the Rails," will be published Monday by Bobbs-Merrill. The author, George Edgar Turner, a retired lawyer and insurance company president, describes how the railroads became a new weapon and how the military learned to use and protect it.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Aug. 25 -- The thousands of Colombians straggling back to the homes from which they had been driven by guerrilla warfare and the thousands of others still living in guerrilla bands and hesitant about accepting the Government's amnesty pose serious problems for the regime of Maj. Gen. Gustavo Rojas Pinilla.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (AP) -- General of the Army Omar N. Bradley advocated today that scientists receive a greater voice in the Pentagon's strategic military planning.
Washability was rated as important as the fashion design at a showing of garments made of synthetic fabrics yesterday by the Princeton Knitting Mills at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

To relieve the acute theatre shortage, the Longacre, leased since 1944 by radio station WOR from the Shuberts, is on its way back to the legitimate fold. Walter Fried will have the distinction of restoring the 917-seat house to the drama with his presentation of "The Ladies of the Corridor," the premiere of which has been deferred to Oct. 21.

Dr. John F. Mahoney, the city's Commissioner of Health, called a meeting of the Board of Health on short notice yesterday to consider the "tremendous" demand for gamma globulin to ward off poliomyelitis. The board reaffirmed the basic policy of reserving the city's share of the scarce blood fraction from the national pool for those most dangerously exposed to the disease -- "household contacts" in homes where a case of polio had occurred.

As part of its ten-year expansion plan, New York University will build a $900,000 men's residence hall on the University Heights campus in the Bronx, it was announced yesterday. The over-all plan calls for an expenditure of $102,105,000.

TEHERAN, Aug. 25 (AP) -- Premier Zahedi announced today his Government would continue the negotiations that Dr. Mossadegh started with the Soviet Union twelve days ago. He added, however, that Iran would go slow in resuming diplomatic relations with Britain.
CHICAGO, Aug. 25 (UP) -- Gus Zernial blasted two home runs tonight, the last in the eighth inning with a man on base, to give the Athletics a 4 -- 2 victory over the White Sox.

The sixteen-story Engineering Societies Building at 25-33 West Thirty-ninth Street, which was constructed forty-five years ago, is growing too small for its needs. Its occupants are seeking larger quarters in any city that will provide them with a suitable site.

DETROIT, Aug. 25 -- Work was resumed today toward converting part of the Willow Run plant of the Kaiser Motors Corporation into a hydramatic-transmission-producing unit for the General Motors Corporation.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Aug. 25 -- A military tribunal in Sarafand sentenced thirteen persons today to one to twelve years in prison following their conviction on charges of having led or having belonged, to terrorist organization, participating in its deliberations or instructing its followers.

GENEVA, Aug. 25 -- Isolation in pure crystalline form of the adrenal gland hormone that controls utilization by the body of the minerals essential to life was announced here today at the Eighth International Congress of Rheumatic Diseases.
OTTAWA, Ont., Aug. 25 -- The appointment of Dmitri Stepanovich Chuvakhin as Soviet Ambassador to Canada was revealed here today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (AP) -- Draft-age youths who become fathers in the future will be ineligible for deferment from military service simply because they have a child. Tightened regulations went into effect today.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Aug. 25 -- Judy Webb of the Riverside Yacht Club, Syce Cup winner last month, gained a slim lead in the women's national sailing championship today as the first half of a six-race series for the Mrs. Charles Francis Adams Trophy was held on Long Island Sound.

MINEOLA, L. I., Aug. 25 -- Mrs. Eleanor Butler Roosevelt, daughter-in-law of the late President Theodore Roosevelt,-who had renounced an $811,247 trust fund early this year "for tax considerations," asked the State Supreme Court today to turn the money back to her.
What can be done about a 13-year-old girl who stays out "till all hours," appears to hate her mother and shows no respect for her at all?

Volume increased slightly in most commodities on the New York exchanges yesterday. Soybean oil had its most active day since July 22, cottonseed oil since July 29 and world sugar since Aug. 14. Prices closed irregular, with sugar, rubber and potatoes mixed; cottonseed oil, soybean oil, cocoa, hides and tin higher, and coffee, copper, lead, zinc and wool lower.
ONE of the city's quaintest subsurface institutions is the New York Reading Laboratory one floor below the street at 500 Fifth Avenue, across Forty-second Street from the New York Public Library.

LONDON, Aug. 25 -- Sir Winston Churchill presided at a Cabinet meeting in London today and, among other things, took a look at British-United States differences that have developed during the current session of the United Nations General Assembly over the role of India in the proposed Far Eastern political conference.

Low-sodium canned foods -- popularly known as low-salt foods, salt being a compound of sodium and chloride -- have become a standard commodity in many groceries. They are no longer confined to specialty and health food stores.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 25 -- Andrei Y. Vishinsky, Soviet representative in the United Nations, charged today that United States opposition to the participation of India in the proposed Far Eastern political conference resulted from a wish to "take revenge" on India because she had not sent troops to help defend South Korea.
The Waterloo, Iowa, Independent School District announced yesterday that it would receive bids Sept. 15 on an issue of $3,000,000 of bonds dated Oct. 1, 1953, and due from 1954 to 1972.

GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 25 -- Fred Lorenzen, representing the host fleet, held the lead for the international championship of the Luders-16 class after the second and third events of the five-race series were completed today off the Indian Harbor Yacht Club.

The General Motors Acceptance Corporation, which came to the public market in June for the first time in seventeen years to borrow $150,000,000, announced yesterday that the sustained increase in its automobile financing business will require it to borrow another $150,000,000 publicly within the next few weeks.

The crew of a Navy landing craft saved a 1,419-ton Danish freighter from burning and sinking off Newfoundland last Wednesday after the ship, which was carrying $2,000,000 in cryolite, had been abandoned by her captain and crew, the Military Sea Transportation Service disclosed yesterday.

Holders of approximately $350,000,000 par value German dollar bonds will be able to begin the process of having them validated next Tuesday, it was announced yesterday. According to Douglas W. Hartman and Dr. Walter Reusch, United States and German members respectively of the Validation Board for German Bonds, it is believed that about 100,000 persons in the United States own some of the ninety-two separate bond issues which the board will review.

Rear Adm. William S. Maxwell, retired, who is Deputy Commissioner of the Department of Air Pollution Control, said yesterday that he was weighing the possibility of running for Borough President of Manhattan as an independent candidate.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 25 -- Following are excerpts from speeches in the Political and Security Committee of the United Nations General Assembly today by Andrei Y. Vishinsky of the Soviet Union, V. K. Krishna Menon of India and Henry Cabot Lodge Jr. of the United States:

The closest Wallace Warren Smith, a six-footer from Wisconsin, came to swimming the English Channel was a nostalgic look at the Southampton waterfront through a porthole of the Cunard liner Queen Mary.

Negotiations between the Long Lines Department of the American Telephone and Telegraph and the Communications Workers of America, C.I.O., continued here yesterday amid unconfirmed reports of possible nation-wide telephone walkouts.

VIENI., Aug. 25--- Rumania has announced that, following (he recent example of Hungary, she will slow 'down her industrialization to allow-agriculture and the needs of the consumer to catch up. The announcement came in a speech Sunday by Premier Gheorghe Gheorghiu-Dej, head of the iumanian Communist party.

The bankbook is a symbol of our mundane existence and yet there dwell among the solid rows of cold figures the warm memories that bring for those who care to seek them what the poet called "the June roses in December."

Two new films will open at first-run theatres today. "Plunder in the Sun," a melodrama starring Glenn Ford, Diana Lynn and Patricia Medina, is at the Paramount. The Warner Brothers release was written by Jonathan Latimer, based on a novel by David Dodge.

NARRAGANSETT, R. I., Aug. 25 -- Sixty-seven fishing boats carrying 300 anglers dumped more than 13,000 pounds of bait in a twenty-five-square-mile area of Block Island Sound today. But not a member of the giant tuna family was caught.

OTTAWA, Ont. Aug. 25 -- Unless the nations of the free world can reconcile their viewpoints and combine in pursuit of a common strategy on a global basis, they are doomed to failure in the East-West struggle for power, Field Marshal Viscount Montgomery, deputy commander of North Atlantic Treaty forces, said today.

Plans are being formulated for the annual dinner dance for the benefit of the Outdoor Cleanliness Association on Oct. 14 in the Trianon Room of the Ambassador, which will be opened formally for the season the next day.

The Brooklyn Dodgers' baseball games continued to remain off television last night when striking engineers from WOR-TV, doing picket duty at Ebbets Field, refused to allow cameramen and equipment from the Du Mont station, WABD, to enter the ball park.

City Budget Director Abraham D. Beame conferred for six hours yesterday with representatives of various city employe groups regarding steps necessary to obtain Federal Social Security coverage for 42,000 municipal workers not enrolled in city pension systems.

Italy has solved her governmental crisis, at least temporarily, with a remarkable amount of common sense and political maturity. A stop-gap, "business" Government of technicians, headed by the Christian Democratic financial expert, Giuseppe Pella, has received votes of confidence from both Houses of Parliament with exemplary speed.

JERSEY CITY, Aug. 25 -- Longshoremen of the strife-torn Local 1247, International Longshoremen's Association, A. F. L., here, voted tonight to oust incumbent leaders who had been Criticized for allegedly "importing" New Yorkers for local jobs and to replace them with an entirely new slate of insurgents.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (UP) -- President Eisenhower said today that a "long list" of women in high public office demonstrated the wisdom of those who gave women the right to vote thirty-three years ago.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (AP) -- The Detroit Edison Company asked the Federal Power Commission today to approve an exchange agreement under which it would export electric power to Canada at certain periods and import it at other times.

Mayor Impellitteri, battling to win the Democratic nomination to succeed himself in the Sept. 15 primary, was the target yesterday for two separate and unrelated sets of charges by political adversaries. He countered by ridiculing both.

EDINBURGH, Scotland, Aug. 25 -- T. S. Eliot's new play, "The Confidential Clerk," was produced here tonight as one of the main dramatic offerings of this year's Edinburgh Festival, and the cheers at curtain-fall suggested that it will be as great a success, in Edinburgh at least, as was "The Cocktail Party."
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 25 -- The Bucks County Bankers Association today assailed the proposed merger of the Philadelphia National Bank with the First National Bank of near-by Conshohocken.
SAIGON, Vietnam, Aug. 25 (UP) -- French and Vietnamese commandos struck deep behind enemy lines today to destroy ammunition and supplies stockpiled by the Communists for an expected fall offensive.

LONDON, Aug. 25 -- Wall Street's setback yesterday and the news of a labor dispute in the electrical trade in this country brought lower prices in early trading on the securities markets here today. However, selling was slight and some issues tended to move back toward their opening levels.

Edward F. Cavanagh Jr., Commissioner of Marine and Aviation, urged yesterday that the city buy two new ferryboats for the South Ferry-Staten Island run. He acted as a result of an informal complaint by Coast Guard officials that the ferries had been overloaded at times.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (AP) -- Following are the names of twenty additional United States service men reported by the Communists to have died in enemy prison camps. Earlier lists contained the names of 837 of the 1,022 Americans reported by the enemy to have died in captivity. The Pentagon has emphasized that there is no independent confirmation of the Communist reports:

LINDEN, N. J., Aug. 25 -- Formation of a major new unit at the Esso Standard Oil Company's refinery here, designated as the technical department, was announced today. Taking over the functions of several other units, the technical department is responsible for all laboratory, mechanical engineering, process engineering, economic study, cost analysis, metal inspection and other technical work at the refinery.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (AP) -- Douglas McKay, Secretary of the Interior, today abolished one of the three posts of Assistant Commissioner in the Reclamation Bureau.

PARIS, Aug. 25 -- The Communist trade union leaders abandoned their effort today to carry on the strike in the National Railways that the non-Communist unions had already called off. The Communists yielded as their own followers were joining in increasing number the non-Communists in resuming work.

More than 400 salesmen from its principal New York wholesalers attended here yesterday the first of forty sales meetings to be held throughout the country by Schenley Distributors, Inc., to outline the intensified fall campaign for Schenley Reserve, which, Thomas Harrington, New York sales manager, said, would "give it undisputed leadership in the blended whiskey field."

Despite some remaining passive resistance and a Communist underground call for new revolt, the Shah of Iran appears to have re-established himself firmly on his throne again, and the Government of Premier Zahedi is now trying to lead the country back to normalcy and constitutional government.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (UP) -- The United States exported goods valued at a record $8,091,000,000 in the first six months of this year, the Department of Commerce reported today. Imports totaled $5,630,000,000, also a record rate.

An investment banking syndicate headed by Blyth Co., Inc., will place on the market today a new issue of twenty-five-year $30,000,000 of first and refunding mortgage bonds of the Southern California Edison Company at a price to yield 3.625 per cent to maturity.

ARGOSTOLION, Greece, Wednesday, Aug. 26 -- King Paul and Queen Frederika paid a second visit to the devastated islands of Cephalonia and Zante today shortly after the Ionian Islands were shaken by the most powerful tremors since the disastrous quakes of Aug. 11 and 12.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 25 (UP) -- Robin Roberts, aided by Del Ennis' bat, notched his twenty-first victory of the season as the Phillies took the opener of a doubleheader, 6 -- 1, tonight but the Braves won the second game, 6 -- 2, on the twelve-hit pitching of Lew Burdette before 31,596 fans.

Mayor Impellitteri declared yesterday that the decision to lift the four-year-old ban on driver control of taxicab radios had been made solely by Police Commissioner George P. Monaghan. The Mayor denied that the new rule was adopted at his insistence but acknowledged that he had met with a group of taxicab owner-drivers and made arrangements for them to see Mr. Monaghan.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (AP) -- Foreign military aid shipments kept United States exports during the first six months of this year from falling far behind the level of a year ago, the Department of Commerce said today.

ROME, Aug. 25 -- Italy expects to spend 483,820,000,000 lire ($774,000,000) on defense in the fiscal year beginning July 1, according to the budget that Premier Giuseppe Pella submitted to the Senate today.

WILLIAMSPORT, Pa., Aug. 25 (AP) -- Shortstop Garry McKee's home run with two out in the bottom of the eighth gave Schenectady, N. Y., a 3-2 triumph over North Newton, Mass., in the opening game of the seventh annual Little League world series today.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Aug. 25 -- The Saw Mill River Parkway will be extended another 2.68 miles north by a contract to be awarded next month by the State Department of Public Works, Westchester County officials were informed today. Bids will be opened Sept. 17 for the project, estimated to cost $2,527,000.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- Ezra Taft Benson, Secretary of Agriculture, urged today an expanded progrom of farm research and education to help meet the basic long-range needs of the American farmer for lower costs, improved quality and wider markets.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (UP) -- Leo A. Roth asked the Federal District Court today to force the Justice Department to restore him to his $10,800-a-year legal job, arguing that he had been dismissed last June in violation of Civil Service rules.
DETROIT, Aug. 25 -- The Yankees launched their final swing of the season through the West on a triumphant note today but it took a bit of doing before they were able to sound off on the right pitch.

HONG KONG, Aug. 21 -- Grassroots elections are being held in groups of administrative villages, towns, county sub-districts and small municipalities throughout China for the establishment of local "people's congresses" as the base of a pyramid scheduled to culminate in the projected All-China People's Congress.
PARIS, Aug. 25 (AP) -- Five French Communist leaders accused of plotting against the security of the nation were temporarily freed from jail on bail tonight by a Grand Jury order.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 25 -- A charge that Congressional committees were laying plans to put state-controlled hiring halls on the West Coast has been made by officials of the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union, unaffiliated, in a letter to its longshore, ship clerks and walking bosses locals.

A thunderous roar, probably caused when an Air Force flight of two F-94 Shooting Stars spurted suddenly for home base with the aid of their reserve power, frightened numerous residents in this area last night. Several hundred telephone calls flooded switchboards in police precincts, air bases and newspaper offices here and in New Jersey.

More than $2,000,000 will be spent by the Independent Grocers Alliance on a "new look" newspaper ad campaign next year, it was announced yesterday by Orville Johler, national advertising manager. He spoke in Chicago at the twenty-seventh international convention of the alliance, attended by 1,500 wholesale and retail members.

LEOPOLDVILLE, Belgian Congo, Aug. 24 -- Leo Petillon, Governor General of the Congo, in an interview here today said that the Belgian Congo Government "did not want to install democracy yet in this country, but to teach deocracy."

Jackie Robinson paced the Dodgers to a 6-5 victory over the Cubs last night after they had bowed, 3 -- 1, in the opener of a twilight-night double-header that attracted 24,900 spectators to Ebbets Field. The even break kept the Brooks nine games in front of second-place Milwaukee, which split with the Phillies.

New inducements just decreed by the Brazilian Government to stimulate expanded production of cement reflect greatly increased demand arising from a construction boom, a Brazilan trade official said yesterday in citing investment aspects of the move.

Great changes are in store in the next quarter century in the methods by which goods move through the channels of distribution, Daniel Bloomfield said yesterday in disclosing detailed plans for the Boston Conference on Distribution, of which he is director.
DENVER, Aug. 25 -- The White House announced today the outlines of a busy fall schedule for President Eisenhower, including the occasions for major political and policy speeches.

INWOOD, L. I., Aug. 25 -- Carding a 79, Joseph Marra and La Junta White of Dunwoodie captured the first gross award in the Metropolitan Golf Association mixed foursomes event conducted over the Inwood Country Club course today.

J. Norman Lewis said yesterday that major league players had submitted "a lot of proposals" to baseball's high command and "are in deadly earnest that a solution be found for each," The Associated Press reported.

BONN, Germany, Aug. 25 -- The West German Cabinet, meeting today under the chairmanship of Chancellor Konrad Adenauer, decided to request the Allied High Commission to start negotiations with the Soviet High Commissioner to restore freedom of movement to all parts of Germany.
CHICAGO, Aug. 25 (AP) -- Byron Nelson, Ben Hogan and Sam Snead today were named to the Professional Golfers Association hall of fame.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 25 -- The United States has decided to vote against putting the Moroccan case on the agenda of the United Nations Security Council when that body meets tomorrow.

LONDON, Aug. 25 -- The difficulties in training medical students, ranging from the shortage of medical schools in the United States to the shortage of bodies for dissection in Britain, were related to the 600 delegates at today's session of the First World Conference on Medical Education here.

YONKERS, Aug. 25 (AP) -- Tyler Hanover took the Mahopac pace at Yonkers Raceway tonight by a head over Lady Attorney, after the withdrawal of Adios Boy, the 2-year-old world record holder for the mile.

EDINBURGH, Scotland, Aug. 25 -- "The Rake's Progress," the Auden-Stravinsky opera that had its New York premiere last winter and which most of the capitals of Europe already have heard, had its first performance in Britain here tonight under the Glyndebourne banner.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (AP) -- The Department of Justice said today it was bringing a denaturalization proceeding against Russian-born Paul Novick, 61 years old, of New York City, described by Attorney General Herbert Brownell Jr. as having been an active Communist.

SEOUL, Korea, Aug. 25 -- A broad relief and rehabilitation program for the Republic of Korea that envisages an expenditure of $1,000,000,000 by the United States Government within the next four or five years, already is being put into high gear.
MUNSAN, Korea, Wednesday, Aug. 26 (AP) -- The United Nations Command announced this official master list of United States war prisoners freed today at Panmunjom:

BAY HEAD, N. J., Aug. 25 (AP) -- The Westhampton Yacht Club team held its lead in the second day of the Eastern finals of the junior sailing championship today, but two of yesterday's also-rans leaped into contention with strong races.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (AP) -- Senator Milton R. Young, Republican of North Dakota, urged Secretary of Agriculture Ezra Taft Benson today to support sagging wheat prices by refusing to sell any Government-held wheat below the Government-loan level of $2.21 a bushel.

Sellers appeared more eager than buyers in the stock market yesterday. Neither group, however, had the driving conviction that makes for a positive move in stock prices. In the early selling the ticker picked up speed, but losses seldom went past a point, while on the rebound volume slackened and prices rallied laboriously.

Ascanio Spolidoro's Department of Parks puppeteers began their fourteenth yearly circuit of Manhattan's parks and playgrounds this week, drawing from lower East Side caverns hundreds of young members of a sensible, discriminating generation.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 25 -- Ogden Phipps' 4-year-old colt Ancestor and Joseph H. Roebling's 4-year-old gelding. Freedom Bell, hooked up at the far turn, and stayed hooked up for the rest of the way in the $5,000 added handicap that headed the Saratoga Association's program today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (UP) -- Federal Judge Richmond B. Keech threw out today an indictment charging the Baltimore Ohio Railroad with having filed false financial statements with the Government in 1942 and 1943.

LONDON, Aug. 25 -- Lewis W. Douglas' report on the foreign economic policy of the United States, with its special reference to the problems of the sterling area, has pleased the British very much, but they do not expect it to have any decisive influence on the actual course of United States policy.

THE N. B. C. "Television Playhouse," which usually offers a single drama between 9 and 10 o'clock each Sunday, flew off on a tangent last week and put on two plays. Both were corny -- one delightfully so, the other tritely.

August white sales throughout the nation have cleared retailers' stocks and brought much greater firmness in the primary market, it was disclosed by Worth Street sources yesterday. While manufacturers did not predict a rise in sheet and pillowcase prices, they inferred that any price changes in coming weeks would be upward.

TOKYO, Wednesday, Aug. 26 -- United States and British members of the United Nations Red Cross mission returned to South Korea yesterday and told of frustration and interference by the Communists in their work among Allied war prisoners in the Yalu River camps.

While the Oliver Corporation's sales of defense products rose to $25,451,000 in the nine months to July 31 from $9,880,000 in the nine months ended July 31, 1952, the company's sales of regular products -- farm implements -- in the same period dropped to $69,700,000 from $92,140,000.

WESTBURY, L. I., Aug. 25 (AP) -- Royal Bonny won his third straight victory tonight at Roosevelt Raceway in the featured Whitinsville Pace, triumphing by two and one-quarter lengths in 2:06 1/5 over Shamrock Mary. Frisky Hal was third.
The former Navy hospital ship Comfort has been turned over to the Maine Maritime Academy as a training vessel for its student body of 230 cadets.

An article headlined "Two Governors Accuse F. B. I. of Invading States' Power" appearing in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Aug. 4, under the by-line of W. H. Lawrence, has apparently received exceedingly widespread dissemination.

Yesterday was a bright day for James Thurber, the author, despite the fact that he is almost blind and that the vision of his "seeing-eye wife," Helen, had been threatened by a partial detachment of the right retina.
BOSTON, Aug. 25 -- The House of Delegates of the American Bar Association unanimously adopted today a report calling on the legal profession to clean its ranks of Communists.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 25 -- In an increasingly large country-wide migration of persons in the age bracket of 65 years and older, California was estimated today to have had a net gain of 130,000 to lead the nation in the decade of the Nineteen Forties, while New York suffered the greatest loss -- 56,000.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- The Republicans are preparing a quick reply to the return to the domestic political scene of Adlai E. Stevension, the 1952 Democratic Presidential nominee, whose official homecoming from his world tour is set for Sept. 14-15 in Chicago.

For the first time in New York City a three-way combination attack is being proposed in a program for redevelopment of two large adjoining areas in the Greenwich Village section, a plan that excites the imagination for its dollar magnitude and the scope of benefits it would confer.

Food Fair Stores, Inc., had record sales exceeding $91,500,000 in the sixteen weeks ended last Aug. 15, an increase of 7 per cent over the showing for a year ago, George Friedland, president, reported to shareholders at their annual meeting yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- United States business men who ship goods abroad were invited officially today to play up the origin of their goods so that foreigners might know the wide variety of products Manufactured in this country.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Aug. 25 -- Disposal of 84,000 tons of blister and electrolytic copper -- Chile's stockpile which has mounted since last April when sales practically ceased in world markets -- will probably be announced tomorrow, according to informed circles. It is presumed the United States Government will acquire this stock to amplify reserves of strategic materials at a market price believed to be close to 30 cents a pound.

The Coast Guard yesterday scuttled the plan of its engineers to burn down the Bridgeport (Conn.) harbor lighthouse and announced that it would dismantle the 102-year-old structure when a semi-automatic light on a steel tower is ready to replace it in November.
KANSAS CITY, Aug. 25 -- Disabled veterans were admonished today to beware of moves to take from them the Civil Service point advantage secured by law since 1944.

HANOI, Vietnam, Aug. 25 (AP) -- Vietnam's Premier Nguyen Van Tam said today he would visit President Eisenhower in Washington next month on his way home from Paris talks seeking greater independence for this French Union state.

LONDON, Aug. 25 -- The news that Premier Zahedi intends to abandon the attempt to dump Irarian oil on the world market at half price was received in Britain with satisfaction today. The disposition is to see in this action the first step toward a resumption of normal relations with Britain and a possible settlement of the oil dispute that has gone on since the nationalization of the Anglo-Irarian Oil Company's holdings in 1951.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 25 (AP) -- Kern County's treasurer had to hitch a ride but he arrived here in time to sign more than $1,000,000 worth of bonds and checks and avoid a late-delivery penalty. The bonds and the checks were in the hands of the Bank of America here but Kern County Treasurer Frank Wilkson's signature was needed before the bank could purchase the $1,350,000 bond issue.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (AP) -- The Tariff Commission has ruled that rosaries are not being imported into this country in such volume as to require an increased tariff.

The winners of the city-wide boys' baseball and softball leagues received trophies from Mayor Impellitteri yesterday at a ceremony held on the steps of City Hall. The leagues were held under the sponsorship of the Bureau of Community Education of the Board of Education.

Stockholders of the Westinghouse Air Brake Company at a meeting held in Wilmerding, Pa., yesterday authorized an increase to $50,000,000 in the company's indebtedness. This paved the way for an offering of $35,000,000 debentures, the proceeds of which will be used mostly to pay off a $30,000,000 short-term debt owed by the Le Tourneau-Westinghouse Company, a new subsidiary, to the Mellon National Bank and Trust Company.
In a brief ceremony at City Hall, Mayor Impellitteri issued a proclamation yesterday designating Aug. 31 to Sept. 6 as "Rodgers and Hammerstein Week."

TEHERAN, Iran, Aug. 25 -- Maj. Gen. Fazlollah Zahedi, Premier of Iran, scheduled his first private meeting with United States Ambassador Loy W. Henderson for tomorrow, with the question of economic aid to save Iran from bankruptcy as the most likely subject for discussion.
Skirts and pants were shown in equal numbers, teamed with shirts and jackets, in Ken Barr's collection of campus or career separates, presented to the public yesterday on Russeks seventh floor.

Harry Brown, former boy camper at the Madison Square Boys Club, received a hearty welcome yesterday from former associates upon his return from five years of service in Japan and Korea as a staff sergeant in the Thirty-fifth Infantry.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 25 -- Huntington Hartford, independent film producer and heir to the Atlantic and Pacific grocery chain-store fortune, announced today that he would endeavor to establish a foothold for the legitimate theatre in the heart of Hollywood.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- Views of bondholders and stockholders of the Missouri Pacific Railroad Company on the reorganization of the road, expressed in briefs filed with the Interstate Commerce Commission, were made public today. The reorganization has been in the courts and before the I. C. C. for twenty years.

Kid Gavilan, world welterweight champion will test his ability against a heavier opponent when he meets Ralph (Tiger) Jones of Yonkers, fifth-ranking middleweight fighter, in the feature bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden tonight.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Aug. 25 -- Countries in and out of the European Payments Union owing money to the German Federal Republic will clear part of their debts by shipping goods to Israel on account of Bonn's undertaking to supply goods to the value of $714,000,000 reparations as compensation for Nazi war crimes.

Milgrim's custom millinery designer, Mr. Bernard, based his fall collection, previewed yesterday at this Fifty-seventh Street shop, on the close relationship between coiffures and hats. He turned out small silhouettes created to flatter the Italian hairdo, the sleek and shorter cuts.

LONDON, Aug. 25 -- Samples of "thin air," sucked into the nose of rockets flown high above the New Mexico proving grounds, may represent exactly the chemical composition of the last "solid barrier" between man and space, but the present results suggest that the evidence has been accidentally falsified.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Aug. 25 -- One result of the unpopularity of some western countries in the Moslem lands of North Africa and West Asia has been the gradual increase of German influence in those areas. As French and British prestige decline in the world of Islam that of Germany revives.
GLEN COVE, L. I., Aug. 25 -- Kurt Nielsen of Copenhagen, a finalist at Wimbledon, was eliminated from the invitation tennis tournament for the Nassau Bowl today.
A pretty Massachusetts girl, wanted for questioning in the bizarre slaying of the teen-aged sister of her former boy friend, was picked up by a traffic policeman last night near Times Square.

OCEAN GROVE, N. J., Aug. 25 -- Mr. Selby had been president of the Ocean Grove Camp Meeting Association since October, 1952. He had been a vice president of the organization since 1941 and a member since 1934.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, Aug. 25 -- When selling basic materials to Communist China ceases to be frowned on by Washington, rubber-producing Ceylon will apply for United States financial assistance on projects designed to raise the standard of living in this highly strategic but food-deficient island dominion of the British Commonwealth.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 25 (AP) -- United States District Judge Rabe F. Marsh today gave five-year prison terms, the maximum, to each of five Communists convicted of conspiring to advocate the violent overthrow of the Government.

LONDON, Aug. 25 -- While affirming in principle the Socialist faith in the nationalization of industry and agriculture, the General Council of the Trades Union Congress, Britain's national federation of labor, reported today that any new proposals for public ownership "must not only be sound in themselves; they must be capable of attracting wide public support.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 25 -- Twentieth Century-Fox is again paring the size of the studio staff to bring operating overhead more into line with its new policy of making fewer but-bigger pictures in the new CinemaScope process. Approximately fifty employes received dismissal notices in recent days.

CHICAGO, Aug. 25 -- Grain futures reacted from initially higher prices on the Board of Trade today, but showed at greater capacity for absorbing profit-taking sales than in recent weeks and from the moderate setbacks prices again developed strength. Apparently there is little hedge pressure on any grain, and for wheat this suggests that most of it is under loan or will be impounded.

Acting in the capacity of deputy for Secretary of State Dulles, Lewis W. Douglas, former Ambassador to Britain, sat in last winter on the Anglo-American discussions of currency. and trade problems held in Washington. At the end of the conversations President Eisenhower persuaded Mr. Douglas to prepare a report for him on the implications of the talks, particularly in terms of American policy on foreign commerce.
WASHINGTON, AUG. 25 (UP) -- The American Automobile Association said today that its 1953 Glidden tour would bring out "the finest and largest collection of old cars ever assembled."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- Representative Carl T. Curtis, the Nebraska Republican who heads the House of Representatives subcommittee assigned last May to investigate the whole social security system with a view to improving and broadening its programs, accused the new Department of Health, Education and Welfare today of refusing to cooperate.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 25 (AP) -- The Senators scored four runs off Bob Lemon in the first inning and then drove him out of the box with another four-run barrage in the fourth inning tonight to defeat the Indians, 8-4.

The fight against noise in New York City is an up-hill battle. Now Police Commissioner Monaghan has signed and filed an order permitting radios in taxicabs, which the cab driver as well as the passenger can play at will, whether cruising or standing. On matters of policy we had always understood that the Police Department never made a move without calling City Hall.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 25 (AP) -- Outfielder Bob Borkowski and Shortstop Roy McMillan blasted key homers to give the Redlegs 8-6 and 9-8 victories tonight over the Pirates in a twilight-night double-header.

The Emerson Radio and Phonograph Corporation will market a color television receiver selling from $230 to $240 eighteen months after approval of compatible color television by the Federal Communications Commission, Benjamin Abrams, Emerson president, said yesterday.
MONTREAL, Aug. 25 (UP) -- Britain's ten-man Walker Cup team made a clean sweep today in the second round of the Canadian amateur golf championship at the Kanawaki Club.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 25 (AP) -- The top-seeded stars in the United States girls' lawn tennis singles championship won their third-round matches with ease today at the Philadelphia Cricket Club.

As a teacher of mathematics, and of probability theory in particular, I cannot leave unanswered a statement which you made in your dissertation on gambling to the effect that prolonged experiments involving the tossing of coins defy mathematical theory.

WEST BARRINGTON, R. I., Aug. 25 -- Grace Lenczyk of Newington, Conn., who won the national title in 1948, today emerged as a third-round victor in the women's United States amateur golf championship by defeating the 19-year-old Wisconsin contender, Joyce Ziske, at the twentieth hole.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (UP) -- The Spanish Ambassador said today that Spain and the United States were "on the eve" of reaching an agreement that would let this country use Spanish air and naval bases in the European defense system.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- The Air Force announced today perfection of a technique that could be used to deliver an atomic bomb farther behind enemy lines than now was possible, and with greater safety for the attacking airplane.

Manufacturers and retailers should revise their operations to avoid ordering and shipping less than six pairs of shoes at one time, according to Maxwell Field, executive vice president of the New England Shoe and Leather Association.

ATHENS, Aug. 26 -- A foreign Ministry spokesman said today that Greece, Turkey and Yugoslavia had each submitted to the others proposals for the establishment of a permanent secretariat to deal with political, economic and cultural matters of common interest under their Balkan pact.

BOSTON, Aug. 26 -- John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, called on the American Bar Association today to meet the challenge of the times by moving cautiously in proposals to amend the United States Constitution but supporting drastic revision of the "obsolete" Character of the United Nations.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities show the following principal changes for the week ended Aug. 19, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
CLEVELAND, Aug. 26 (UP) -- Four home runs helped beat the Senators, 9 -- 5, today as Jim Hegan, Larry Doby, Harry Simpson and George Strickland connect for the triumphant Indians.
CAMP PERRY, Ohio, Aug. 26 (UP) -- The United States, Great Britain and Canada finished 1, 2, 3, respectively, in two team matches at the national rifle and pistol competitions today.

A method has been devised that will make use of great quantities of tiny diamonds that hitherto have been set aside as not usable as gems for lack of color, brilliance and perfection and of no value industrially for lack of size and weight.

City Council President Rudolph Halley and Harold Riegelman, Liberal and Republican designees for Mayor, respectively, have decided also to seek independent nominations to bolster their chances of winning, it became known yesterday.

PARIS, Aug. 26 -- The note of the three Western powers to the Soviet Union that is being drafted here and is expected to be sent before the West German election Sept. 6 will repeat the invitation to a four-power foreign ministers' conference that was issued in Washington July 15 by the Western Big Three foreign ministers.

The Port of New York Authority has decided to borrow $20,000,000 next month on a public bond issue to finance capital expenditures related to Port Newark, the Lincoln Tunnel and other Authority properties. According to Donald V. Lowe, vice chairman of the Authority, the bond issue will be advertised on Sept. 3 and bids will be received Sept. 16.

McKesson Robbins, Inc., achieved a record in sales during the fiscal year ended on June 30, which was reflected in increased earnings, according to the preliminary unaudited figures issued yesterday by William J. Murray Jr., chairman.

The average price of New York Stock Exchange listed bonds rose in July to $95.82, the highest level since the $96.57 average on March 31. The figure for June 30 was $95.30. The July 31 average is $1.04 below that for the end of 1952.

LONDON, Aug. 26 -- The first complete census of British retail and service trades was published here today. Unlike the United States Government, the British Government had never before really dug out the facts about how many stores there were, how big they were, what they sold and how many persons they employed.

CHICAGO, Aug. 26 (AP) -- Queen Hopeful today completed a grand slam of summer racing for 2-year-old fillies by winning the $107,490 Princess Pat Stakes at Washington Park after a sizzling stretch duel with Chorus Khal.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 (AP) -- The emphasis on loyalty and Government security is at the heart of the Defense Department's insistence on the right to disapprove any university employe who handles correspondence courses for service men and women.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- For the ninth consecutive year more students will flock to the nation's schools this fall than ever before.
The New York City C. I. O. Council sent a telegram yesterday to the Kings County Medical Society protesting that the society was attempting to "destroy" the Health Insurance Plan of Greater New York.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 26 (AP) -- President Juan Peron's Government named a commission today to investigate the question of whether Protestant missionaries in Argentina endangered national defense along the frontiers and in special security zones.

Half a century ago giant parts were forged for railroad engines and for ships. Much the same process is still in use to make jet engine components, landing gear parts and other equipment for a vastly changed world. Spanning all the years is Joseph H. Pargeter, a veteran of more than a half century in forging operations and management, who was named yesterday as chief of steel forge operations of Willys Motors, Inc., in Toledo.

The Greater Blouse and Skirt Contractors Association announced here yesterday that it was shutting down 400 blouse shops, employing 12,000 workers in four states, as a result of a dispute with blouse jobbers over higher rates.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 (AP) -- Military officials said today they had received Congressional approval of plans to reopen the Blue Bonnet ordinance plant at McGregor, Tex., for the manufacture of jet plane and rocket fuels.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Aug. 26 -- Judy Webb and the Riverside (Conn.) Yacht Club were within one race of the title in the national women's sailing championship as a result of victories in two events today on the Sound off the Manhasset Bay Y. C.

Dock workers of the International Longshoremen's Association, A. F. L., struck the big British liner Queen Mary just before sailing time yesterday, forcing passengers to carry their own baggage up the dock and to the ship.

The late August doldrums seem to have the Dodgers in their grip. In the wake of a lackadaisical split of a double-header the night before, the Brooks took a 13-4 lambasting from the the lowly Cubs yesterday. It was the most one-sided defeat Charley Dressen's pennant-bound forces have suffered in their Ebbets Field bastion this season.

WILLIAMSPORT, Pa., Aug. 26 (AP) -- Pitcher Sam Cooksey singled home the winning run in the eighth inning today as Front Royal, Va., beat Vancouver, B. C., 3 -- 2, in a first-round game of the Little League baseball world series.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Aug. 25 -- Premier Ali Sastroamidjojo in presenting his new Cabinet to Parliament here today announced it was the intention of his Administration to send an Ambassador to Moscow, to conclude a new bilateral treaty with Japan and to negotiate new agreements with the Netherlands.
Stauffer Chemical Company, 68-year-old producer of industrial and agricultural chemicals, announced yesterday plans for the first public financing in the company's history.

BONN, Germany, Aug. 26 -- Dr. Gerhard Fuerst, West German Commissioner for Elections, announced today that 1,790 candidates had been approved to compete in the Sept. 6 election for the 242 constituency seats in the Bundestag.

The three-family dwelling at 42-55 Seventy-seventh Street in Elmhurst, Queens, has been sold by Emilia and Carlos Lenaz to Johann Elskany. Terminal Realty, Inc., was the broker and the Lawyers Mortgage and Title Company insured title.

LONDON, Aug. 26 -- The theory that the earth may be bombarded periodically by the equivalent of hydrogen bomb shock-waves from the sun was put forward at today's session of the Oxford Conference on the Physics of the Upper Atmosphere.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- Mohammed Kuttob, 21-year-old private in the Arab Legion, is a guest of the Jordan Embassy here preparatory to returning to his army post after probably as long and as costly medical treatment afforded any one soldier of any army.

PURCHASE, N. Y., Aug. 26 -- Doctors, housewives, engineers, publishers and other sports car enthusiasts of the Northeastern states donned goggles today at the Westchester County Airport here, studied road maps, checked compasses, turned a weather eye toward the skies and then slid behind the wheels of $120,000 worth of European machinery for the start of their automobile "race."
CHICAGO, Aug. 26 (AP) -- The International Harvester Company asserted today that the rise in the living cost index would result in a pay rise of 1 cent an hour for thousands of its employes.
Fifty families were evacuated in a matter of minutes yesterday from a tenement that is in "actual and imminent danger" of falling.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 26 -- A simple new test to measure the physiological age and health of arteries, with the aid of radioactive tracers injected into the bloodstream, was announced here today by Dr. Paul C. Aebersold, chief of the isotope division of the Atomic Energy Commission at Oak Ridge, Tenn.

Brazil is continuing to use her $300,000,000 Export-Import Bank credit to reduce the backlog of long-overdue drafts, according to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York's monthly survey of Latin-American export credit conditions, issued yesterday.

The continuance of the United Service Organization's voluntary services at 248 clubs over the country and at seventeen overseas was urged yesterday by Emil Schram, president of the organization, in an appeal for 100,000 volunteers to maintain "the religious, spiritual, social, welfare and educational needs of the armed forces."

A year ago last week the Soviet press suddenly announced to the world that there would be the first Congress of the Communist Party since 1939, and made public a new party constitution and the main features of the fifth Five-Year Plan. Yet so rapid has the tempo of events been since then that one might have imagined a decade rather than a year had passed.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 (AP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board's Bureau of Air Operations today opposed a merger -- this year at least -- of two major freight airlines, Slick and Flying Tiger.
COLORADO SPRINGS, Colo., Aug. 26 (UP) -- The Air Force today saluted the scientists of another day who made possible high-altitude long-range flying and indirectly ushered in the jet age.

PARIS, Aug. 26 -- Today a Frenchman could write a letter or send a telegram and be reasonably sure either would get to its destination. Or, he could go to a railroad station and find his train as scheduled and, once on it, be more or less sure it would take him where he was going.

Rumors of a nation-wide strike by long distance telephone operators abated yesterday as talks continued between the Long Lines Department of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and the Communications Workers of America, C. I. O.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- Living costs rose to a record high in mid-July, and, as a result, about 1,000,000 automobile workers will receive an automatic wage increase of 1 cent an hour in September.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y. Aug. 26 -- The United Nations Korean Reconstruction Agency was given a go-ahead signal today on its plains to spend $130,000,000 for long-range rehabilitation in Korea.

The disquieting reports of increasing delinquency call for a serious examination of the manner in which we are handling matters of law enforcement and crime prevention, especially in the case of young offenders.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Aug. 26 -- The Standard-Vacuum Oil Company, foreign operations subsidiary of the Standard Oil Company. New Jersey, and the Socony-Vacuum Company of New York, announced today that it would build a new international headquarters on a fifty-five-acre tract in Harrison Township, near the eastern boundary of White Plains.

Less than two weeks after the unexpected withdrawal of the United Brotherhood of Carpenters from the American Federation of Labor, top level talks have begun looking toward speedy reaffiliation of the 822,500-member union.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 (AP) -- The Government decided today upon a set of terms under which it would be willing to meet Chile's request that the United States relieve a financial crisis there by buying its surplus copper.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 (UP) -- The Marine Corps today promoted five generals to two-star rank and confirmed as major generals four others serving under temporary promotions.

Futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed irregular yesterday, 5 points lower to 6 higher than on Tuesday, with the October position inclined to lag. Late trading was characterized by a slight increase in hedge selling, which was counterbalanced by fixing, particularly in the near-by position.

You cannot measure a young angler's triumph with a ruler or a weighing machine, but the devices do have their use in deciding prize winners. This was illustrated yesterday, when the Parks Department conducted the fourth annual Junior Fishing Contest under the sponsorship of Better Fishing, Inc., a nonprofit sportsmen's organization.

Margaret Sullavan, who was seen on Broadway last year as the highly emotional and complicated woman with a desperate love for a young bounder in "The Deep Blue Sea,'' is virtually certain to undertake the co-starring role with Joseph Cotton in the forthcoming Samuel Taylor play, "Sabrina Fair," due at the National Theatre Oct. 27.

THE HAGUE, Aug. 26 -- World mine production of tin in concentrates was 13,800 long tons in June compared with 15,000 in May, the International Tin Study Group reported here today. The decrease characterized producers in widely separated areas.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Thursday, Aug. 27 -- Bills perpetuating rabbinical control of marriage and divorce and providing a special form of national service for religious girls who are exempt from military service were adopted early today by Israel's Knesset (Parliament).
BONN, Germany, Aug. 26 (AP) -- West Germany announced plans today to resume trans-Atlantic passenger ship service for the first time since 1939.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 26 -- President Manuel Odria of Peru made it clear today that his nation stood for Pan-American solidarity and against forming groups that clash with hemisphere unity.
H. Laird Loftis has been appointed interline and agency officer of the North American sales division of British Overseas Airways Corporation.

A contemporary version of the multi-purpose room, popular in Colonial houses in this country, is on view in a handsome new model house, which, together with a new split-level house, will open to the public Saturday in the Bar Harbour development in Massapequa Park, L. I.

DUESSELDORF, Germany, Aug. 26 -- West Germany's trade unions, whose central office is here in Duesseldorf, on the perimeter of the Ruhr industrial district, are playing a strange and anomalous role in the West German election campaign.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 26 -- Andrei Y. Vishinsky, Soviet representative, made a veiled threat today that Communist China and North Korea would refuse to attend the proposed con ference on Korean and other Far Eastern political questions if the United Nations General Assembly did not accept the list of participants proposed by the Soviet Union.

PADUCAH, Ky., Aug. 26 -- The 15,000-man construction force at the billion-dollar Paducah atomic plant was idle today in the seventy-fifth strike at the plant since construction began thirty months ago.

The New York commodity exchanges were unusually quiet yesterday. Trading was light and only potatoes registered a larger-than-recent volume. Prices closed irregular with sugar, coffee, cocoa, wool and rubber mixed; cottonseed oil, soybean oil, zinc and tin lower, and potatoes, hides, lead and copper higher.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Aug. 26 -- Death and injuries have foiled a nine-man United States mountain-climbing expedition in its attempt to scale Mount Godwin Austen, (K-2), the world's highest unconquered peak.
CHICAGO, Aug. 26 -- The grain futures list had a reactionary trend early today, demand being less active, with buyers inclined to avoid profit-taking sales by longs.
CLEVELAND, Aug. 26 (AP) -- The United Rubber Workers, C. I. O., struck the giant Firestone Tire and Rubber Company throughout the country tonight as negotiations on new wage agreements continued.

Syngman Rhee is unquestionably right in his refusal to sit down at a peace conference with India. He was equally right in his condemnation of the truce which we effected with the Communists in China, in North Korea, and equally in Russia.

WEST BARRINGTON, R. I., Aug. 26 -- Pat O'Sullivan, the North and South champion from Orange, Conn., eliminated one of the pre-tournament favorites in the fourth round of the women's United States amateur golf championship today when she defeated Barbara Romack of Sacramento, Calif., the holder of the Canadian title.

Parents from Donald Court, a summer bungalow colony in Far Rockaway, Queens, obtained gamma globulin for their children yesterday afternoon after camping for more than twenty-seven hours in the Health Department headquarters at 125 Worth Street to press their demand.
MUNSAN, Korea, Aug. 26 -- Removal to the neutral zone of prisoners who do not wish to be repatriated will begin soon.
DENVER, Aug. 26 -- President Eisenhower will leave Denver early tomorrow for several days of real vacation with a minimum of business across the Continental Divide at Fraser.
BOSTON, Aug. 26 (AP) -- Following is the text of Secretary of State John Foster Dulles' address today before the American Bar Association:

The little hat emerged triumphant in the first collection of French imports from the recent Paris showings to be seen in this country. Viewed at Saks Fifth Avenue, the collection consisted of thirty designs from Paulette, Balenciaga, Jacques Fath, Christian Dior, Gilbert Orcel, Simone Cange and Svend.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- Senator Hubert H. Humphrey, the Minnesota Democrat who last year headed a subcommittee investigating Communist domination of some trade unions, urged the Administration today to start early training of specialists how to tell "a bona fide militant unionist from a Communist agent."

What has happened to the traditional Yankee frugality? Where are the voices to be raised in protest over the latest bit of contempt for the penny? True, the disdain shown is in the interests of economy and will be directed at saving perhaps half a million dollars per year.

Two new films open today at first run theatres. At the Radio City Music Hall is Paramount's "Roman Holiday." Starred in the comedy are Gregory Peck, Audrey Hepburn and Eddie Albert with a supporting cast headed by Hartley Power, Harcourt Williams and Margaret Rawlings.
MUNSAN, Korea, Thursday, Aug. 27 (AP) -- The United Nations Command's official list of United States prisoners freed in today's armistice exchange:

DETROIT, Aug. 26 -- The Yanks touched off thirteen blows today, polishing off Ted Gray along the way, but it still took a great deal of effort to bring the Bombers home in front, 5-to-4, as they bagged their series finale with the Tigers for a sweep of the two-game series.

For five years intensive engineering work has been going on to develop and perfect a new form of mass transportation of people over short distances in continuous operation. The result takes two forms: a moving sidewalk which is simply a flat conveyor belt moving continuously at about half a normal walking speed and, secondly, a modification of this idea for longer distances that provides small cars in which passengers can be seated.

LONDON, Aug. 26 -- British Government securities led the securities markets here today with rises of up to one-eighth of 1 per cent in revived activity among gilt-edge issues. Other markets, notably the industrials, were under the shadow of the further decline on Wall Street yesterday, and a quietly dull tone persisted until near the close, when a firmer trend developed.

The fifteen-story and penthouse apartment building occupying a plot 101 by 175 feet at 600 West 111th Street, southwest corner of Broadway, has been purchased by Phillip P. Zipes, operator, in a deal negotiated by Pearce, Mayer Greer, brokers, for cash over mortgages amounting to $940,000. There are seven stores and 103 apartments in the property, which is assessed at $1,100,000.

DENVER, Aug. 26 (AP) -- Senator William Langer, (R. of North Dakota) reopened a Senate investigation into an alleged "medical monopoly" today by charging a "conspiracy on the part of the press and the medical profession to discredit the practice of chiropractic."

EL PASO, Tex., Aug. 26 -- Judge R. E. Thomason of the United States District Court of the Western District of Texas sentenced 350 illegal Mexican aliens, commonly called "wetbacks" because many of them wade the Rio Grande, in a two-day session that ended today.

Kid Gavilan's invasion of the middleweight ranks proved a success last night at Madison Square Garden. The world welterweight champion gained a unanimous decision over Ralph (Tiger) Jones of Yonkers in the ten-round contest. Gavilan weighed 154 pounds, two more than his rival.

LONDON, Aug. 26 -- A conspicuous lack of enthusiasm was manifest here tonight as advance press reports of Secretary of State John Foster Dulles' proposal for revision of the United Nations Charter were studied in Whitehall.

EAST HAMPTON, L. I., Aug. 26 (UP) -- Maureen Connolly, warming up for a defense of her national crown at Forest Hills, teamed with Julie Sampson of San Marino, Calif., to swamp a pair of local youngsters, Lolly Goodrich and Anne Cook, 6 -- 1, 6 -- 1, as doubles competition opened in the annual Maidstone invitation tennis tournament today.

You are to be complimented for your splendid editorials concerning the completely unwarranted A. F. of L. Local 282, Teamsters "strike." Yours seems to be the only paper in the City of New York aware of the gravity of the situation occasioned by this work stop-page.

It is paradoxical that a universal symbol of sentiment -- sentiment being part and parcel of emotion, and hence subject to swift and unpredictable changes -- should be the diamond, one of the earth's most durable and stable substances.
Representative Charles A. Buckley was chosen without opposition yesterday to succeed the late Edward J. Flynn as Democratic leader in the Bronx.

The increased demand for canned meats, which American industry is meeting, has attracted the attention of European exporters. Evidence of this is found in delicacy shops where many tinned meats from abroad are offered.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission, with an eye on the coming session of Congress, announced today that it is ready to consider any suggested changes in the legislation under which it operates.

BOSTON, Aug. 26 -- The House of Delegates, the policy - making body of the American Bar Association, unanimously adopted today a resolution upholding the freedom to read as a corollary of the constitutional freedom of the press.
DETROIT, Aug. 26 (UP) -- A group of doctors and chemists today announced encouraging experiments with use of a common water softening chemical to control hardening of the arteries in animals.
An improved type of sealed beam headlight, designed to reduce night accidents on highways, has been approved by a subcommittee of the American Association of Motor Vehicle Administrators.

PARIS, Aug. 26 -- A first series of governmental and administrative reforms for Morocco were approved in principle today by French Cabinet Ministers. The Ministers remained undecided on a program of more far-reaching reforms proposed by Foreign Minister Georges Bidault.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 (AP) -- J. Edgar Hoover, director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, said today there was an alarming increase last year in attempted frauds against the Government.

A trend toward textured designs is noticeable in a new collection of patterns introduced by Wall-Tex and available after next Tuesday at Gimbels, Bloomingdale's and Abraham Strauss. This plasticized fabric for walls is only 24 inches wide, is pre-trimmed and is said not to tear in the handling as ordinary wallpaper would, so it should be particularly acceptable to amateurs who would like to install it themselves.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 26 -- Stories about Hollywood producers and directors sitting by their television sets at home and finding new talent for the movies or rediscovering seasoned performers who have dropped out of the picture business are becoming commonplace.

The major New York political parties have each selected a Negro as nominee for the office of President of the Borough of Manhattan. The three major parties have also selected slates of candidates for the three important city-wide offices so that each slate contains a member of each of the three largest religious faiths in New York.

D. A. Schulte, Inc., which this year is celebrating its seventieth anniversary, plans the first big birthday sale in its history next month, it was announced last night by N. W. Brasuell, vice president in charge of merchandising. He spoke at a dinner meeting in the Park Sheraton Hotel of representatives of the fifty-five Schulte stores in the New York area.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- Public Housing Commissioner Charles E. Slusser announced today that twenty-four local housing authorities had sold $81,870,000 in short-term loan notes at competitive bidding.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, Aug. 26 -- The Prime Ministers of India and Ceylon will meet in New Delhi within a few weeks to try to reach an agreement on the complex and crucial problem of the 950,000 Indians who form nearly one-eighth of this island dominion's population.

After pushing forward in the early hours to recover all the losses of Tuesday, the stock market yesterday afternoon found the grade a little too steep and slid back to the lowest level since June 16. That was the date on which the 1953 low in THE NEW YORK TIMES combined average was registered at 170.68.

Reflecting the 10.7 per cent increase in gross revenues, earnings of the Hilton Hotels Corporation in the first half of this year improved over the corresponding period last year, according to the report of Conrad N. Hilton, president, mailed to stockholders yesterday.
An underwriting syndicate headed by Eastman, Dillon Co. will make a public offering today of $25,000,000 of twenty-year 4 1/4 per cent debentures of the Beneficial Loan Corporation at 100.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 26 (UP) -- Dr. Lee De Forest, whose vacuum tube made radio, television, radar and talking pictures possible, celebrated his eightieth birthday today and looked forward to "ten more years of hard work."

NARRAGANSETT, R. I., Aug. 26 -- Louis E. Marron of the Brielle Marlin and Tuna Club took the eleventh United States Atlantic tuna tournament out of the doldrums today with a 667-pound fish. It was the first taken in this three-day contest, which has another day to go.

ALBANY, N. Y., Aug. 26 (AP) -- The experimental summer slowdown campaign in eleven northeastern states has cut traffic deaths since June 1 by 2.5 per cent, the chairman of the Northeastern State Safety Coordinators said today.

CEDARHURST, L. I., Aug. 26 -- The visiting International Lawn Tennis Club team gained a 27-25 victory over the International Club of the United States and the national junior Davis Cup squad in an informal match on the grass courts at the Rockaway Hunting Club today.

Three factory buildings on plot 50 by 100 feet at the southeast corner of Clay and Oakland Streets, in Brooklyn, have been sold by John Hassal, Inc., to the Pitegoff Realty Company, which insured title with the Title Guarantee and Trust Company.

TEHERAN, Iran, Aug. 26 -- Iran's new Premier, Gen. Faziollah Zahedi, and the United States Ambassador, Loy W. Henderson, met for an hour and a quarter today to discuss "urgent matters between the two nations," notably the question of aid from Washington to avert the bankruptcy threatening Iran.
There is an important issue missing in your analysis of the "wetback" situation, as well as in that of Attorney General Brownell and most organizations in this field.
SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 26 -- A group of promoters, headed by Howard E. Booker of San Francisco, offered today to set up a legalized system of off-track pari-mutuel betting in the state.

GOTEBORG, Sweden, Aug. 26 (AP) -- Four runners, two from the United States, finished the 1,500-meter race in an international track meet tonight under 3 minutes 50 seconds, with Sweden's Ingvar Eriksson winning in 3:48.2.

NEWARK, Aug. 28 -- Vacation checks for 300 striking employes of the Kidde Manufacturing Company, Inc., and the Bloomfield Tool Corporation, both of Bloomfield, were mailed today after Superior Court Judge John O. Bigelow had denied to the company an interlocutory injunction to restrain the United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers of America, Local 437, from "oppressive'" mass picketing.

TODAY, 11 A. M.: "Timid Timothy" and "Dick Whittington" are two stories to be narrated at the outdoor programs at Bensonhurst Park and Fort Greene Park. Arranged by the Brooklyn Public Library, similar story hours will be held at 3:30 P. M. at Mount Prospect Park and Owl's Head Park, all in Brooklyn.

GLEN COVE, L. I., Aug. 26 -- Robert Perry of Los Angeles came closer to fulfilling the high promise of his junior career than he has all season when he defeated Gardnar Mulloy today in the quarter-finals of the invitation tennis tournament for the Nassau Bowl.

Charles A. Lindbergh's account of his trans-Atlantic flight in 1927, "The Spirit of St. Louis," which Scribners will publish on Sept. 14, has been chosen by the Book-of-the-Month Club as its September selection. The book is divided into two parts.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Aug. 26 (UP) -- Bishop Homer A. Tomlinson of New York today took what he called the first step in a program to reunite the widely split Church of God and its $5,000,000 properties at Cleveland, Tenn.

Seeking to adhere to the Maybank amendment to the Defense Appropriation Bill, the Office of Defense Mobilization has directed the Army to drop "bid matching" in Quartermaster negotiated bids. This directive, it was asserted yesterday, has led Government bidders to believe that the entire program for favoring surplus labor areas has been dropped.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- Admiral Arthur W. Radford, new Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, said today he favored continuing the present roles and missions of the armed forces in the strategic defense of the United States.
MONTREAL, Aug. 26 (UP) -- The Seafarers' International Union, A. F. L., tonight called for a strike vote by its 8,000 Canadian members to back demands for a forty-hour week.
YONKERS, Aug. 26 (AP) -- Torch Key withstood a powerful stretch drive by Bengazi tonight to win the $5,800 Central trot by a half length at Yonkers Raceway.

MOSCOW, Thursday, Aug. 27 -- The Soviet Chess Society has invited United States chess players to come to the Soviet Union in November or whenever will be convenient for the Americans "in the interest of strengthening friendship" between United States and Soviet chess players.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 26 -- Henry Cabot Lodge Jr., United States representative to the United Nations, expressed regret today that the disagreement between the United States and Britain over India had been dramatized rather than the agreement between the two nations on "fundamental points" regarding the proposed conference on Korea and other Far Eastern problems.

I suggest that Postmaster General Summerfield check the cost of subsidizing the mail of Senator McCarthy. The Senator is scraping the bottom of the barrel for issues. He therefore puts under his indictment three papers: The Washington Post, The Wall Street Journal and The Daily Worker, and challenges their mail subsidies.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 26 -- The Legislative Committee of Parliament has prepared for ratification early next month an election law that opens the possibility for Opposition elements to name candidates for Parliament.

OTTAWA, Ont., Aug. 26 -- The recently discovered relics of three early Arctic expeditions, including that of the United States explorer Admiral Robert E. Peary in 1906, were displayed here today by two Canadian scientists who found them on a survey of the northern coastline of Ellsemere Island, 400 miles south of the North Pole.
