BANGKOK, Thailand, Aug. 26 (AP) -- The police last night and early today rounded up eleven persons, including Thailand's former Deputy Army Commander, and charged a Communist - inspired plot to overthrow the Government of Premier Pibul Songgram.

TOKYO, Thursday, Aug. 27 -- Some American prisoners sentenced for long terms of confinement just before the armistice in the Korean war and told by their Communist captors they would not be returned to freedom, may be repatriated soon, returning United States Officers said yesterday.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 26 -- The conditions of the seventy-third running of the Alabama Stakes at the Saratoga track today called for Mrs. Ben F. Whitaker's Grecian Queen, the top-ranking 3-year-old filly, to take up 126 and spot the Belair Stud's Sabette a dozen pounds. Grecian Queen gave it a rousing try, but Sabette beat her by a neck in a whipping finish.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., Aug. 26 -- Three family teams scored gross-77's, six over par, over an alternate-stroke route at Bonnie Briar today to tie for the twenty-fourth father-son championship of the Westchester County Golf Association.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 26 -- The romance had begun in Kentucky last May. This reporter fell madly in love with a race horse, Native Dancer. It was hopeless, of course, and common sense demanded that it be broken off. But absence only made the heart grow fonder and this morning the lovesick swain was drawn irresistibly to the stall where the big gray stood in solitary majesty.

WESTBURY, L. I., Aug. 26 -- Pronto Don, the world's leading money winning trotter, heads a field of ten in the $25,000 American trotting championship tomorrow night at the Roosevelt Raceway. A bid will be made with the 8-year-old gelding from the Hayes Fair Acres Stable, Du Quoin, Ill., to break the world mark of 2:37 2/5 for the mile and a quarter distance.

MOST pundits will agree that the noblest theme in all our literature is the destiny of man. Poets and philosophers (and even an occasional politician with an itch for empire building on the side) have wrestled with the riddle since the dawn of recorded history. Inasmuch as man is an ingenious creature, many solutions have been invented down the ages.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Aug. 26 -- Large bands of native Africans, armed with spears, bows and arrows and knives of the type used by the anti-white Mau Mau terrorists in Kenya, have made threatening gestures toward white settlers and missionaries in the Cholo area of Nyasaland, according to reports from there. The British protectorate has a population of 2,500,000 Negroes, about 2,000 whites and 3,000 Asians.

The New York City Transit Authority collected more revenue from the 15-cent fare last week than in any of the three previous weeks since the fare was increased from 10 to 15 cents. Figures reported by the authority yesterday also showed a 9.8 per cent average loss of passengers for the four weeks of the 15-cent fare, instead of the 11.1 per cent drop that had been expected.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 (UP) -- Lewis W. Douglas, former Ambassador to Britain, was accused today of being either inexcusably ignorant or dishonest in recommending lower United States import barriers to President Eisenhower.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 26 -- Baron D. W. van Lynden of the Netherlands delegation, expressed approval today of Secretary of State John Foster Dulles' suggestion that members of the American bar begin to deliberate about possible revisions in the United Nations Charter.

Tariff changes must be worked out "slowly, judiciously and selectively" by qualified experts who utilize "sound economic considerations as their guide," Dr. Leland I. Doan, president of the Dow Chemical Company, told stockholders attending the fifty-sixth annual meeting in Midland, Mich., yesterday.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 26 (UP) -- Del Ennis led the Phillies to a 6-5 victory over the Braves tonight as Jim Konstanty rescued Karl Drews in the ninth with the tying run on base.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 (AP) -- A Department of Agriculture official today assured Senator Milton R. Young, Republican of North Dakota, that Government-held wheat stocks are not being sold at cut rate prices.

The National Audubon Society asserted yesterday that waterfowl-hunting regulations announced Tuesday by the Secretary of the Interior, Douglas McKay, run contrary to the intent of the 1918 Migratory Bird Act and will allow more birds to be killed than is warranted by the Government's own surveys.
OTTAWA, Aug. 26 -- A plan to extend its vast oil operations to Canada is under consideration by the Anglo-Iranian Oil Company, Ltd.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- More than two score plans for raising revenue to replace taxes expiring in the coming year have been drawn up by the Treasury Department and are awaiting the perusal of President Eisenhower when he returns from his vacation.
A minor epidemic of motor trouble yesterday in the ambulances of St. John's Hospital, Long Island City, Queens, resulted in the birth of a baby in one of them.

France and the Laniel Government have gained a much-needed breathing spell. The outburst of strikes -- certainly the most impressive exhibition in many years of French working-class discontent -- has now petered out. A recall of the National Assembly, in which Premier Laniel ran the risk of being defeated, has been averted.
HANOVER, Germany, Aug. 26 -- The West German electoral struggle between parties ranging from Communist to neo-Fascist is reflected on thousands of posters throughout the area.

NEWARK, Aug. 26 -- A three-count Federal court indictment charging extortion and conspiracy was returned today against Pasquale (Patsy) Ferrone, business agent of Local 1235 of the International Longshoremen's Association, A. F. L.

CHICAGO, Aug. 26 (UP) -- Dave Philley got two triples and a home run today to pace the Athletics to a 10-8 victory over the White Sox in a game played by the Sox under protest after three and one-third innings.

President Eisenhower has opened a new chapter in the history of federal efforts to put an end to discriminatory employment practices in the execution of Government contracts. He has done this through an Executive Order revising and strengthening anti-discrimination rules that have theoretically been in effect for more than a decade, and by appointing a new and enlarged board of distinguished citizens to see that the policy is carried out.
LONDON, Aug. 26 (Reuters) -- T. S. Eliot's new play, "The Confidential Clerk," which was hailed at the Edinburgh Festival last night, received a warm welcome from the drama critics today.

Rabbi Irving Miller, president of the Zionist Organization of America, in upholding the status of Jerusalem as the capital of Israel, asserted last night that Jerusalem was "inextricably linked with Jewish history, Jewish tradition and the Jewish religion."

Importers expressed satisfaction yesterday with efforts of the Customs Bureau to facilitate the change-over to new laws applying to entry of foreign goods. The new laws are the result of the Customs Simplification Act passed by the recent session of Congress. They will become effective Sept 7.

NORTH VALLEY STREAM, L., I., Aug. 26 -- The first of 213 houses that will be moved in the reconstruction of Southern State Parkway from four to six lanes was trundled at a snail's pace today to a new location.

Providing additional interest in this week's preview of autumn fashions in furs at the Tailored Woman were fur designs proportioned to three women's height groups -- the petite, regulation and statuesque.

CHICAGO, Aug. 26 (AP) -- Hot weather trading was back in full force on the livestock market today, most prices reacting downward in consequence. Temperatures were at near-record levels for the second day in a row. The Department of Agriculture's report on the trading follows:

MONTREAL, Aug. 26 (UP) -- The favorites had trouble today as the Canadian amteur golf championship went through the third and fourth rounds at the Kanawaki Club here. Seven Americans advanced in the tourney.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission ruled today that motor carriers operating their vehicles in New York may, until Oct. 15, collect the surcharges they have been adding to freight bills to meet the cost of the New York State weight-distance tax.

Recognition in the record book eluded Dusty Rhodes yesterday at the Polo Grounds. The part-time outfielder slammed three successive homers while the Giants were overwhelming the Cardinals, 13 -- 4, and he had a chance for a fourth, only to strike out.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 26 -- France, confident that she can block the latest Asian-African attempt to get the United Nations Security Council to look into the troubles in Morocco, denounced the move today as illegal and "inane."

A decline last week of 1,243,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end these stocks amounted to 142,334,000 barrels, compared with 143,577,000 a week earlier and 116,393,00 a year ago.

Vic Seixas of Philadelphia and Maureen Connolly of San Diego, Calif., both Wimbledon champions, yesterday were top seeded in the seventy-second annual National tennis championships starting Saturday at the West Side Club, Forest Hills, Queens.

CAMP DRUM, N. Y., Aug. 26 -- Extensive small-arms firing practice on this reservation's many ranges today occupied the attention of New York City National Guardsmen and Reservists here for two weeks of field training.
The police here said yesterday they had solved the slaying of a 14-year-old Somerville, Mass., girl with the arrest of her brother's former fiancee.

Station WABD, owned by the DuMont television network, failed again yesterday to televise the baseball game between the Dodgers and the Chicago Cubs at Ebbets Field because of alleged interference by a park electrician. Chris J. Witting, DuMont's managing director, said he would go to the State Supreme Court at 10 A. M. today to seek an injunction to halt labor unions from interfering.

In an effort to discourage the possibility of Federal support of higher education, the newly formed Council for Financial Aid to Education announced yesterday that it would begin operations Sept. 15 to interest business and the general public in the plight of privately supported universities and colleges, of which there are 1,200.

Dr. Manfred Sakel, according to an article in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Aug. 21, hits the misuse of shock therapy in psychiatry. He is right if he states that what we need in psychiatry, as in any other medical branch, is differentiation of the cases and differential diagnoses.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 27 -- Following are the texts of the four resolutions regarding the proposed Far Eastern political conference that were approved today by the Political and Security Committee of the United Nations General Assembly:

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 27 -- The United States said today that the situation in Morocco did not present a threat to international peace and urged the United Nations Security Council to steer clear of the case.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 27 (UP) -- A base on balls to a pinch-hitter, Roy Sievers, sent the Browns to a 3-1 victory over the Athletics and a sweep of a double-header after the Browns had taken the first game, 5 -- 4, tonight.

PARIS, Aug. 27 -- "Total" independence of the Indo-Chinese State of Vietnam, followed by a treaty defining its relations with France and the French Union, was described as the aim of Bao Dai, the head of that state, who came to Paris today to visit President Vincent Auriol as the first step in the new negotiations with the French Government.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 -- Department store sales in the week ended Aug. 22 were unchanged from the corresponding week of last year. This was reported today by the Federal Reserve Board which listed the following percentage changes from like periods of 1952:

GENEVA, Aug. 27 -- Dr. Philip S. Hench of the Mayo Clinic, Rochester, Minn., who opened a new era in medicine by his discovery of the effectiveness of cortisone for the relief of rheumatoid arthritis and a number of other baffling conditions, outlined today situations in which less than one-fiftieth of an ounce of cortisone might make the difference between life and death.

Ralph Kiner, representative for National League players, said yesterday that he wanted to make it clear that J. Norman Lewis, the lawyer hired by Kiner and Allie Reynolds, American League player representative, would "not be a czar" or "a players' commissioner."
NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 27 -- The Lower House of Parliament approved today a bill creating the new state of Andhra, composed entirely of the Telugu-speaking people of South India.

A decision is apt to be forthcoming at any minute regarding the continuance of "Wish You Were Here" at the Imperial. The booking office had allocated time for the swimming pool musical, which overcame negative reviews and celebrated its first anniversary on June 25, to open at Chicago's Shubert Theatre around Dec. 1 and would like to know whether it should cancel the reservation.
Medical authorities here repeated yesterday earlier warnings that public confidence in the efficacy of gamma globulin as a poliomyelitis preventive might have risen too high.

WEST BARRINGTON, R. I., Aug. 27 -- Mexico's 16-year-old champion, Margaret Smith of Guadalajara, gained the semi-finals of the women's United States amateur golf championship after two rounds today at the Rhode Island Country Club course.

Many readers of these pages would be willing to concede, I think, that a newspaper with so high a standing as THE TIMES is obliged to use restrained language, that it must be calm in expressing editorial opinions, and that it must avoid even the appearance of unnecessary indignation. But has not THE TIMES overdone a very good thing in its editorial "The Case of Dr. Astin"?
WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended Aug. 22 totaled 817,431 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.

LONDON, Aug. 27 -- British Government securities advanced again on the securities markets here today but they were the only section to do so. However, other groups, notably the industrials, looked firmer than they had been in recent days.

BOSTON, Aug. 27 (AP) -- Assistant Attorney General Stanley N. Barnes said today that the Department of Justice was withdrawing its eight-year-old anti-trust suit against the Cement Institute and eighty-nine of its members.

In view of the tendency in certain quarters to minimize the dangers of communism to religion and religious minority groups, it would not be amiss to remind the American people of the fate of one such group -- the Kalmyks.

A permit to carry a pistol was denied yesterday to Anthony (Tough Tony) Anastasia, Brooklyn waterfront boss who is trying to rid himself of a round-the-clock police guard, which he calls "unreasonable."
A nightclub and a hotel in the heart of the Times Square entertainment area have been purchased by the Seventh-Day Adventist Church and will be converted into a religious center.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 27 -- Thompson was taken directly to a small boat landing on San Francisco Bay and hustled aboard the launch Warden Johnston for the two-mile, ten-minute trip to Alcatraz Island. He was heavily manacled and guarded as he arrived at the pier.
The lifting of the four-year ban on driver-controlled radios in taxicabs here was hailed yesterday as "an asset to civil defense" by Herbert R. O'Brien, director of Civil Defense here.
LONDON, Aug. 27 -- Europe has absorbed the economic implications of the Korean truce without any of the unfavorable reactions that had been generally expected.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 27 -- Following are the text of a statement by Henry Cabot Lodge Jr. of the United States, and a [translation from the Russian of] a statement by Andrei Y. Vishinsky of the Soviet Union, made today in the Political and Security Committee of the United Nations General Assembly:

Federated Department Stores, Inc., large retail group which includes Bloomingdale's and Abraham Straus of this city, yesterday reported increased sales for the thirteen and fifty-two weeks ended on Aug. 1, but earnings below the corresponding periods last year.

SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., Aug. 27 -- The appointment of the Rev. Thomas W. Cunningham as vice president in charge of instruction at Seton Hall University was announced today by Msgr. John L. McNulty, president.
A stock brokerage firm employe charged with fraud, was enjoined yesterday from further securities dealings in New York State.

TEHERAN, Iran, Aug. 27 -- The Iranian people were told today that twenty-eight months of leadership by Premier Mohammed Mossadegh, who was deposed last week, had left the nation $210,000,000 in debt. Iran lost at least as much more in oil revenues during the long dispute with Britain over the nationalization issue.

Louis S. Rothschild, newly appointed Maritime Administrator and chairman of the Federal Maritime Board, and Elden C. Upton Jr., board member, returned to Washington late yesterday after a two-day inspection of Maritime Administration facilities here.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 -- The newly independent United States Information Administration announced today that cuts in its appropriations would force a reduction of its informational activities and the dismissal of about 2,000, or more than 24 per cent, of its world-wide staff.

INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 27 (AP) -- The five-week-old strike of Indiana Bell Telephone Company employes was marked last night and today by violence in the northern part of the state and the gaiety of Halloween in Indianapolis.
Peck Peck's showing of handsome tweeds yesterday had a real international flavor. The fabrics were Scotch, the designs English land the manufacture American.

Generally, the overwhelming vote in favor of controls on next year's wheat crop has been interpreted as meaning that the farmers wanted high support prices and acreage controls. Recently, however, Allan B. Kline, president of the American Farm Bureau Federation, stated that the vote was not on any long-range proposition, but on whether price supports next year were to be at 90 per cent of parity or at 50 per cent of parity.

Two near films open today at first-run theatres. At the Roxy is "Mister Scoutmaster," a comedy starring Clifton Webb, Edmund Gwenn and George Winslow. The Twentieth Century-Fox production was written by Leonard Praskins and Barney Slater from a book by Rice E. Cochran. Henry Levin directed and Leonard Goldstein produced.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 -- Senator Alexander Wiley of Wisconsin, who heads the Senate's Foreign Relations Committee, predicted today that disillusionment and unrest, indicated by official Moscow records and other sources to have mounted materially during the last two years, marked the Soviet regime for eventual overthrow.
LONDON, Aug. 27 (Reuters) -Business under the new International Wheat Agreement improved slightly during the week ended on Aug. 21 but sales remain extremely low.

BONN, Germany, Aug. 27 -- The draft of the' proposed Allied note to the Soviet Union renewing a Western invitation to a conference on the German question was shown to Chancellor Konrad Adenauer today by Dr. James B. Conant, the United States Ambassador.
The educational exchange program authorized by the Fulbright Act was one of the alarming fatalities of economizing in the last session of the Congress.

Steels and motors plunged through their 1953 lows in yesterday's stock market and rails were the lowest since May 27, 1952. At bottom for the day, THE NEW YORK TIMES combined average was within two-thirds of a point of the 1953 low of 170.68, touched on June 16. The close was the lowest of the year.

On the coveted gold medal annually awarded by the American Bar Association "for conspicuous service to the cause of American jurisprudence" is this inscription beneath the profile of John Marshall: "To the end it may be a Government of laws and not of men." One reason these words, taken from the Massachusetts Constitution, were selected for the medal is because "in the last analysis they typify the ultimate purpose of the American Bar Association itself."
CAIRO, Aug. 27 (Reuters) -President Mohammed Naguib called on the Islamic countries today to stand firm against "imperialism" in a thinly veiled thrust at the major Western powers.

The Department of Housing and Buildings yesterday temporarily relaxed its order directing immediate evacuation of the five-story brick tenement at 26 East 106th Street to permit residents to remove personal belongings.

For the second successive week, repayments by sales finance companies accounted for a net decline in business borrowings from New York banks. According to data issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, such loans dropped $22,000,000 during the week ended on Wednesday, although in the corresponding week a year ago they rose $70,000,000.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 (AP) -Gov. Luis Munoz Marin has assured Senator John F. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, that Puerto Rico's tax-exemption program "will not be used to encourage any industry to move to Puerto Rico if that involves closing an industrial plant in any part of the United States."

INCHON, Korea, Aug. 27 (AP) -- Chinese prison camp officials apparently had no further use for United States prisoner of war "progressives" after the armistice was signed, a repatriated American prisoner said today.
The Thoroughbred Racing Associations, representing thirty-seven of the country's major tracks, warned against off-course betting yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 (UP) -- The State Department relaxed travel curbs on Russian diplomats and journalists here today to allow them to visit near-by beach resorts for the rest of the summer. Somewhat similar concessions were announced by Britain and France.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 (AP) -- The nation's federally chartered banks had assets of $103,000,000,000 on June 30, Controller of the Currency Ray M. Gidney reported today. Mr. Gidney said this represented assets of 4,881 active national banks in the United States and its possessions.

FRASER, Colo., Aug. 27 -- President Eisenhower has sent his felicitations to Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi on the occasion of his return from exile, but there is as yet no indication from the White House of financial aid to that troubled country.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 -- The State Department announced today that the second annual meeting of the Anzus Council representing the United States, Australian and New Zealand alliance would be held here Sept. 9 and 10.

Six recent developments tending to strengthen the Brazilian cruzeiro, with resultant benefit to Brazil's foreign trade and investment position, were cited yesterday by Licurgo Costa, director of the Brazilian Government Trade Bureau here.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 27 -- A broadening of the perspective of medical schools in the United States to develop appreciation of all aspects of the problems of aging persons was called for tonight by Dr. Edmund V. Cowdry of the Washington University School of Medicine, St. Louis.

TOKYO, Friday, Aug. 28 --United States prisoners of the Korean war were taken to Manchuria and there interrogated by Russian officers before being sent to the stockades of North Korea, one repatriated soldier said yesterday.

CHICAGO, Aug. 27 (AP) -- Jim Rivera's triple with the bases filled in the third inning tonight gave Virgil Trucks and the White Sox a 6-4 victor over the Red Sox before 23,270. The crowd lifted the Comiskey Park attendance above the million mark for the third straight year.
FRASER, Colo., Aug. 27 -- President Eisenhower loafed away his first day here on a mountain ranch after a welcome from mountain folk, dudes and a Sheriff's mounted posse equipped with six-shooters.
DETROIT, Aug. 27 (UP) -- Frank Shea of the Senators scattered ten hits as he went all the way to deifeat the Tigers, 12--5, before 2,892 fans in Briggs Stadium today.

Improvements in subway service to reduce overcrowding and shorten the duration of trips in rush hours on three sections of the rapid transit lines were approved yesterday by the New York City Transit Authority. Subway riders in Queens and the Bronx will benefit from the changes, which will be effective next month.

CHICAGO, Aug. 27 (UP) -- One out of four house calls by a physician is unnecessary, and most of the unneeded calls are to treat women, according to a report today in The Journal of the American Medical Association.

CHICAGO, Aug. 27 -- With the exception of corn, there was a weak tone in grain futures and soybeans here today. Some further evening up of September contracts was evident in all pits, with considerable pressure on the near delivery of oats.

SOMERVILLE, Mass., Aug. 27 (AP) -- George E. Thompson, Middlesex County District Attorney, said tonight he would not ask a first-degree murder indictment against Mildred McDonald, accused slayer of a 14-year-old girl, whose brother married another girl.

Shoppers will find fruits and vegetables plentiful and reasonably priced this week-end. Nine popular summer vegetables are selling at 10 cents a pound or less, while five others are priced under 15 cents a pound.

A new field has been opened in textile printing of cotton and other cellulose fabrics through development of colors that can withstand the high temperatures of the embossing process, it was announced yesterday by Ernest Nathan, chairman of the board of the Metro-Atlantic Corporation, dyestuff manufacturers.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 27 -- Carl Dudley, president of Dudley Pictures Corporation and sponsor of the Vistarama wide-screen process, declared today that CinemaScope, WarnerSuperScope and Vistarama are like peas in a pod.
The Detroit Steel Corporation held "lighting-up" ceremonies at Portsmouth, Ohio, yesterday marking the beginning of production for its new No. 2 blast furnace, said to be one of the world's largest.

It is becoming increasingly clear that the emergency refugee bill passed in the closing days of Congress is likely to turn out to be considerably less effective than it was cracked up to be. It is, of course far better than nothing and we still have hopes that it will do good.

BERLIN, Aug. 27 -- An estimated 120,000 residents of East Germany defied Communist counter-measures and sought food parcels in a new "second round" give-away program that began in West Berlin today. This was about 10,000 more than had come on the first day of the original food handout plan last month.

The Board of Estimate handled yesterday a bulging calendar of 567 items at a six-hour meeting marked by frequent exchanges of political banter among its members. Mayor Impellitteri, who did not attend the board's executive session last Wednesday, was the only member absent from the public meeting.

KANSAS CITY, Aug. 27 (AP) -- Luke Mumford, a former caddy from Detroit, shot a 3-over-par 75 today to take the thirty-six-hole lead at 153 in the Twenty-seventh Negro national open golf tournament. Mumford was one of nineteen starting pros caught on the Swope Park course by darkness last night. He completed his first-round 78 today.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Aug. 27 -- Mohammed Ali, Prime Minister of Pakistan, told Jawaharlal Nehru, the Indian Prime Minister, today that the troops of both countries must be withdrawn from Kashmir before Pakistan would agree to a plebiscite to decide to which nation Kashmir would accede.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 27 -- The votes of Asian, African, British Commonwealth, Scandinavian and Soviet-bloc countries rolled up a simple majority today in the Political and Security Committee of the United Nations General Assembly for the participation of India in the proposed Far Eastern political conference.
The haste with which the proposed improvement of Washington Square is being rushed through has obscured a number of serious objections to the plan, which if uncorrected will do more harm than good.

Furnishings designed for a one-room home will go on display in the fifth floor furniture department opening Monday at Bond's, Thirty - fifth Street and Fifth Avenue. Included are sofa beds, curtains, tables, occasional chairs, draperies, lamps and other accessories.

Isaac Deutscher, whose "Russia: What Next?" was published by Oxford University in June, has a new work on that country on the concern's list for early next year. It is "The Prophet Armed: Trotsky, 1879-1921," wherein Mr. Deutscher presents Trotsky as the most romantic, heroic and tragic character in the Russian revolution.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 27 (AP) -- Top-seeded Mary Ann Eilenberger of San Diego, Calif., advanced to the semi-finals of the United States girls' lawn tennis championships today.

A 30-year-old robbery suspect was captured yesterday in the Bronx by an off-duty patrolman after a two-block chase in which thirteen shots were fired and a 300-pound taxi driver stopped the gunman by sitting on him.
PARIS, Aug. 27 (AP) -- In the confusion and clash of opinion over fashionable skirt lengths caused by the "Dior Revolution" only one thing is certain: skirts will not be any longer.
A noisy throng of more than 100 persons laid siege to the Health Department offices at 125 Worth Street last night demanding that the city release its scarce supplies of gamma globulin.

ALBANY, Aug. 27 (AP) -- The State Social Welfare Department proposes that local officials be required to seek court action against financially able persons who refuse to support close relatives who are on relief.

In his letter in THE TIMES of Aug. 24 Daniel Reuter apparently does not realize that the issue of Panther Dam was fully discussed and settled by the Legislature in 1950 when they passed the law which prohibits the construction of Panther Dam.

The Bell System, operated under the direction of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, reported yesterday a new record number of telephones in use throughout the United States. The total, including connecting and non-connecting telephone systems, aggregated 49,250,000.

Women headed by Mrs. Walter B. Potts and Mrs. Henry G. Hay, as co-chairmen, and including Mrs. Augustin J. Powers Jr. are active in the plans for the country fair for the benefit of St. John's of Lattingtown Protestant Episcopal Church to be held on the afternoon of Sept. 26 near the church grounds in Locust Valley, L. I.

BONN, Germany, Aug. 27 -- A proposal that all travel barriers be removed between East and West Germany was presented to the Soviet Union today by the United States, Britain and France at the request of the West German Government.

GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 27 -- Fred Lorenzen of Stamford, leader since the series opened on Monday, regained the international sailing championship of the Luders-16 Class at the Indian Harbor Yacht Club today by completing the five-race regatta with 41 points.

LONDON, Aug. 27 (AP) -- The Moscow radio announced today the Supreme Soviet of the Russian Republic had approved removal of four Deputy Premiers of the republic and named their successors in a general reshuffle of leadership.
MONTREAL, Aug. 27 (UP) -- Two gruelling, extra-hole matches featured the Canadian amateur golf championship today as a Canadian, an American and two Scotsmen moved into the semi-finals.

GLEN COVE, L. I., Aug. 27 -- Arthur Larsen was beaten by Sven Davidson, champion of Sweden, and Tony Trabert overcame Herbert Flam in a superlative display of fast, offensive tennis today in the invitation tournament for the Nassau Bowl at the Nassau Country Club.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 (AP) -The Veterans Administration said today it would dismiss about 1,000 employes from the operating staff in its insurance division here by Oct. 16.

EAST RUTHERFORD, N. J., Aug. 27 -- While three accomplices waited at the curb in a green sedan, an armed and masked thief this morning held up an elderly bank messenger on the sidewalk in front of the East Rutherford National Bank and made off with $38,000 in a canvas bag the messenger was delivering to the bank.

A block-long bridge over the New York Central Railroad's West Side tracks between West Fortyfirst and Fortieth Streets will be opened temporarily today at noon to provide an additional entrance to the Lincoln Tunnel from the north.

This is the time of the year when tennis fans swarm to the ivy-covered West Side Club in Forest Hills, where the world's foremost exponents of the court game compete in our national grass championships. From Saturday through Labor Day the best racquet wielders from thirteen countries will seek United States crowns in both the men's and women's divisions.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Aug. 27 -- Prime Minister Robert Gordon Menzies announced at Canberra today that the Commonwealth Government would seek revision of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade at the conference beginning at Geneva Sept. 17.

Reporting on operations of the Virginia-Carolina Chemical Corporation for the fiscal year ended June 30, Joseph A. Howell, president, told stockholders yesterday that sales increased 5.7 per cent to a new record of $82,126,077 from the $77,668,678 volume of the year before.

Americans in record numbers are touring Europe by car this year and are becoming increasingly budget-conscious, delegates were told yesterday at the international travel conference of the American Automobile Association at the Lexington Hotel.

Teen-agers today are groping for spiritual values, Mrs. Marion Edwards told an afternoon discussion group on "The Play by Children" yesterday at the Children's Theatre Conference, being held under the joint sponsorship of Adelphi College, Garden City, L. I., and the American National Theatre and Academy.

Mayor Impellitteri announced yesterday the appointment of two City Magistrates, both of whom will be sworn in at City Hall today at 11:30 A. M. They are Ludwig G. Glowa and Louis S. Wallach, both of Brooklyn. Both appointments are for full ten-year terms at annual salaries of $14,000.

WETHERSFIELD, Conn., Aug. 27 (AP) -- Five players, including a local star, posted 5-under-par 66's to set the pace as the second annual 72-hole $15,000 Insurance City open golf tournament opened today.

Everybody except the Cubs was happy at Ebbets Field yesterday, including Russ Meyer, who came up with his tenth straight triumph over the Bruins before a Ladies' Day crowd of 17,468 (5,795 paid), as the Dodgers won the game by 7 -- 5.

ROME, Aug. 27 -- In a concordat, or covenant, between Spain and the Holy See signed in the Vatican this morning, Spain reaffirmed that Catholicism was "the only religion of the Spanish people" and the Vatican expressly recognized the validity of Article 6 of the Spanish Constitution which states that no one may be molested "on account of his religion."

All through the day yesterday, motorists traveling over and under the Hudson River by way of the George Washington Bridge or the Lincoln and Holland Tunnels were stopped by men who came right up to them and asked:
WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 (UP) -- The Air Force said today that it had asked five corporations to bid by mid-September on "possible" production of C-123 aircraft.

Performing in lackluster style at bat, on the base-paths and in the field while the Cardinals were pounding Dave Koslo, Al Corwin and Montia Kennedy for eleven hits, the Giants dropped a 6-3 decision to the Redbirds before a corporal's guard of 3,469 spectators at the Polo Grounds yesterday.

The majority of the companies that did management research last year plan to increase their expenditures for this purpose in 1953, it would appear from the results of a survey made public yesterday by the American Management Association.

Though freezing holds the spotlight in home food preservation, both interest and research in canning continue. Interest, especially, is high at this season, when home gardens and backyard orchards gratify week-end farmers with their yields of tomatoes, peaches, apples, snap beans, green peppers and so on.

BOULDER, Colo., Aug. 27 -- A new photon-counting photometer is being employed at Palomar Observatory to collect data on the distant galaxies to enable astronomers to improve their knowledge of vast cosmological distances.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 -- John Foster Dulles, the Secretary of State, will make a major policy speech next Wednesday at the American Legion Convention in St. Louis, Vice President Richard M. Nixon said today following a meeting of the Cabinet and a meeting of the National Security Council at the White House.
HULL, Aug. 27 (UP) -- Today, before his start across the Humber, Lord Noel-Buxton said:
The Ford Foundation has made a grant of $160,000 to the Board of Education for a program of research and development dealing with the so-called "Puerto Rican" problem in the public schools.

The Department of Marine and Aviation's plans for improvement of Pier 26, North River, a large, open structure at Beach Street, call for the erection of a $3,500,000 shed to cover the concrete-decked facility, a spokesman for the department disclosed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 (UP) -- A telephone union spokesman announced tonight-that phone workers would walk out in Maryland, West Virginia and the District of Columbia at 6 A. M. Eastern daylight time, tomorrow.

BONN, Germany, Aug. 27 -- Frau Charlotte Fleischmann, a member of the National Executive Committee of the League of Germans, which is allied with the neutralist All-German Peoples party in the present West German election campaign, announced today that she had resigned and given up her candidacy for the Bonn Parliament because both parties were Communist-controlled.

As the heat wave and drought continued yesterday, with a temperature of 95.3 degrees registered in New York and forecasts of more high readings today, special measures were being taken in some surrounding towns to restrict water consumption and to guard against forest fires.

Manhattan Borough President Robert F. Wagner Jr. charged last night that "underworld influences," which he did not identify, were supporting Mayor Impellitteri, his rival for the Democratic Mayoralty nomination in the Sept. 15 primary.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Aug. 27 (AP) -- Morals charges against Miss Christina Brown, former secretary to Police Commissioner Eugene Connor, were dropped today in Police Court.

CHICAGO, Aug. 27 -- Despite "general" living costs rising to a new high in mid-July, as reported by the Bureau of Labor Statistics, the nation's housewives are paying less money for more meat for their family food baskets, the American Meat Institute declared today. An Institute statement said:

NARRAGANSETT, R. I., Aug. 27 -- Two hundred and ninety-nine of the top game fishermen on the Atlantic coast went home empty-handed from the eleventh United States Atlantic tuna tournament today. One, Louis E. Marron of the Brielle (N. J.) Marlin and Tuna Club, who caught the only fish of the three-day contest, took all the prizes.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 27 -- The Joint Legislative Committee to Study Horse Racing told three turf associations today to take concrete steps toward building a modern track in New York City or face the prospect that the legislators would find "other means" of doing it.
MUNSAN, Korea, Friday, Aug. 28 (AP) -- The United Nations Command's official list of United States prisoners freed in today's armistice exchange:
WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 (AP) -- The Senate Post Office Committee announced today it had retained a private research agency to make a survey of United States postal and mail operations.
RABAT, French Morocco, Aug. 27 -- The Sultan of Morocco, Sidi Mohammed ben Moulay Arafa, left Rabat today for a four-day ceremonial visit to Fez, the historical capital.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Aug. 27 -- Judy Webb of the Riverside (Conn.) Yacht Club finished second today in the sixth and final race of the women's national sailing championship off the Manhasset Bay Y. C. to gain the championship with 31 3/4 points in the three-day, competition.

RYE, N. Y., Aug. 27 -- Australia's chances in the national tournament beginning Saturday at Forest Hills appeared brighter today when the young men from Down Under toppled United States team, 4 -- 1, in an international tennis exhibition at Westchester Country Club.

SAIGON, Vietnam, Aug. 27 -the aggressive tone of statements made to the press today by Premier Penn Nouth of Cambodia caused a decided drop in optimism here about the outcome of current negotiations between France and Cambodia, one of the three Indo-Chinese states, on the subject of the latter's independence.
A series of fashion shows featuring new fall fabrics will mark the opening next week of Macy's remodeled sixth-floor fabric center.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 -- The United States announced today that "public views" would be canvassed Sept. 14 on the question of giving Japan temporary membership in the thirty-three nation General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade.

PANAMA, Aug. 27 -- Many thousands of Panamanians joined today in a demonstration of support for President Jose Antonio Remon and his commission that leaves tomorrow to negotiate a new treaty with the United States in Washington.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 -Olivia de Havilland, the motion picture actress, won income tax deductions amounting to approximately $48,000 in a ruling announced today by the tax court of the United States.
A 38-year-old costume-jewelry dealer shot and killed his estranged wife and their two sons and then commited suicide yesterday in the Parkchester development in the Bronx.
SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 27 -- The champion steeplechaser of the Saratoga meeting is Mrs. Vernon G. Cardy's Sun Shower, a full brother to Sun Bath, the one that was the champion here in 1949.

LOS ANGELES, Calif. Aug. 27 -- William Randolph Hearst Jr. 45 years old, next to the oldest son of the late newspaper publisher, was appointed today co-executor! of his father's $56,000,000 estate by Superior Judge Newcomb Condee.

A new musical quiz program entitled "Name That Tune" is presented over the N. B. C. television network on Mondays from 8 to 8:30 P. M. Basically it is similar to that great old-time favorite, "Stop the Music," which folded after people got tired of answering the phone to try for fabulous prizes.
An American merchant seaman has completed an unusual North Atlantic voyage alone in a thirty-foot sailboat, his union reported here yesterday.

BOSTON, Aug. 27 (AP) -- Stanley N. Barnes, Assistant Attorney General, announced today the membership of a national committee appointed by Herbert Brownell Jr., the Attorney General, to study the anti-trust laws.

MacARTHUR FIELD, L. I., Aug. 27 (AP) -- The Air Navigation Development Board reported today its study of "low weather" had reduced sharply the number of missed approaches by aircraft trying to reach airports through fog and clouds.
Frank J. Powers has been appointed head of the industrial engineering department of C. B. SColumbia, Inc., television and radio receiver manufacturing subsidiary of the Columbia Broadcasting System.
BOSTON, Aug. 27 -- Herbert Brownell Jr., Attorney General of the United States, took steps today to proscribe the National Lawyers Guild as a subversive organization.

The letter from Hans Frolich regarding the "wetback" situation, which appeared in your columns on Aug. 20, was of great interest to us. We have been working since 1920 with the agricultural migrants across the country.

SEATTLE, Aug. 27 (AP) -- Thousands of persons temporarily disenfranchised because they move from one state to another would regain their voting rights under a proposal given the nation's Secretaries of State today.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Aug. 27 -- The age-old question of what makes some fish bite and others pass up tempting morsels on baited hooks, one that has puzzled anglers the world over, is the subject of an experiment at Rutgers University here.
By a vote of 794 to 81, striking sand, gravel and concrete truck drivers spurned yesterday an offer of a wage increase of 40 cents an hour, and thereby prolonged the walkout into its ninth week.

The National Bank of Detroit plans to issue additional common stock for cash subscription and also as a stock dividend, it was announced yesterday. If the proposals are approved at a special meeting of stockholders on Sept. 24, the cash offering will consist of 313,200 shares to be offered for subscription by shareholders on the basis of one additional share for each five held.

TAIPEI, Formosa, Aug. 27 -- The Chinese Nationalists have intensified their economic blockade on Communist China in the last month in an attempt to forestall any relaxation of the embargo on the Chinese Communists after the Korean armistice.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 27 -- Around the tracks they tell the story of the pompous horseman who arrived in Albany to do a bit of unashamed lobbying. This was during Prohibition and he thoughtfully brought a case of whisky with him for any thirsty legislators who might be willing to listen to his story.
Local school districts in New York State borrowed $2,605,000 in the public market yesterday on issues of serial bonds at interest rates ranging from 3 to 3.4 per cent.

Attorneys for the Du Mont television network went into the State Supreme Court yesterday seeking an injunction to restrain a labor union from interfering with telecasts of the Brooklyn Dodgers games at Ebbets Field by WABD, the local Du Mont station.

Dr. Grayson Kirk, president of Columbia University, returned to New York yesterday from a two-month trip to Europe, during which he attended a conference of university representatives from the British Commonwealth. Dr. and Mrs. Kirk were among 1,422 passengers who debarked from the French liner Liberte at Pier 88, West Forty-eighth Street.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 -- J. Edgar Hoover, Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, announced today that F. B. I. agents had arrested two long-missing Communist party leaders in an, 8,000-foot high hide-out in the Sierra Mountains near Sonora, Calif.

NAIROBI, KENYA, Aug. 27 (Reuters) -- Dedan Kimathi, Kenya's No. 1 Mau Mau terrorist leader, has ordered his "war leaders" to lay down their arms and stop fighting, according to a letter to the Swahili-language newspaper Habara Za Dunia.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., Aug. 27 -- Ross Carino of the Harrison Country Club, Bob Julius of Briar Hall, Peter Nisselson of Hampshire and Jim Iverson of Siwanoy reached the semi-finals of the twenty-ninth Westchester junior golf championship at Bonnie Briar today.

Directors of the Chile Copper Company deferred action yesterday on the declaration of a common dividend due at this time. The company, a subsidiary of Anaconda Copper Mining Company, paid 50 cents each in February and May of this year.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 -- The State Department said tonight that the United States was "proceeding at top speed" to make entry permits into this country available to Greek victims of the recent earthquake disaster in the Ionian Islands.

CAMP DRUM, N. Y., Aug. 27 -- A group of French reserve officers has arrived here for training with the Seventy-seven Infantry Reserve Division from New York City. They are members of the Refresher School for New York French Reservists, which meets at the Seventy-seventh's New York Armory.

YONKERS, Aug. 27 (AP) -- Wicomico Ted, owned by Walter S. Farlow of Pittsville, Md., took to the middle of the track in the stretch tonight to win he $5,000 Brewster Pace by a length and a half at Yonkers Raceway. Jimmy Arthur kept Wicomico Ted in second spot behind the pace-setting Mr. Nib until the top of the stretch where he pulled to the outside and took command.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., Aug. 27 -- Ross Carino of the Harrison Country Club, Bob Julius of Briar Hall, Peter Nisselson of Hampshire and Jim Iverson of Siwanoy reached the semi-finals of the twenty-ninth Westchester junior golf championship at Bonnie Briar today.

Directors of the Chile Copper Company deferred action yesterday on the declaration of a common dividend due at this time. The company, a subsidiary of Anaconda Copper Mining Company, paid 50 cents each in February and May of this year.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 -- The State Department said tonight that the United States was "proceeding at top speed" to make entry permits into this country available to Greek victims of the recent earthquake disaster in the Ionian Islands.

CAMP DRUM, N. Y., Aug. 27 -- A group of French reserve officers has arrived here for training with the Seventy-seven Infantry Reserve Division from New York City. They are members of the Refresher School for New York French Reservists, which meets at the Seventy-seventh's New York Armory.

Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed yesterday with losses of 8 to 13 points on the more active positions and near the lows of the day. Price-fixing served to offset hedge selling in the last minute of trading, but there was no apparent eagerness to the demand.

WESTBURY, L. I., Aug. 27 -- Florican, 6-year-old bay horse owned by the Arden Homestead Stable of Goshen, N. Y., and driven cleverly by Harold Miller, caught Katie Key within the final ten yards to win the $25,000 American Trotting Championship, an invitation event, at Roosevelt Raceway tonight.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 -- This country has reached "the essential turning point toward a balanced budget," George M. Humphrey, Secretary of the Treasury, asserted today.
CLEVELAND, Aug. 27 -- The waning weeks of the 1953 pennant campaign may have little left to offer to Cleveland fans but the folks out this way still can have an occasional big moment.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 (UP) -- The "revenoors" still are kept busy hunting moonshiners in the South, the Internal Revenue Service reported today.

CHICAGO, Aug. 27 -- In its first nation-wide appraisal of education for dental hygienists, the Council on Dental Education of the American Dental Association issued today a list of twenty-one accredited schools for dental hygienists.

ELIZABETH, N. J., Aug. 27 -- A rare American bittern, first bird of its species ever seen in the Union Country park system, was recovering today from a wing injury after having been captured by five boys under the bridge of the Warinanco Park lagoon here.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 (AP) -- Senator Irving M. Ives, Republican of New York, told complaining Republicans today that if they and the American people did not support the Eisenhower Administration program the nation might be "faced with complete disaster."
CLEVELAND, Aug. 27 (AP) -- The eight plants of Firestone Tire Rubber Company were shut down by a strike of United Rubber Workers, C. I. O., today, but negotiators went back to the bargaining table.

As is their wont, people tended to sneer at the new project. It was a little past the middle of the last century, but the denizens of the Oil Creek area of Pennsylvania were no different from their ancestors or their descendants -- they just had no use for these new-fangled, radical, dangerous innovations.
TORONTO, Aug. 27 -- This, the second largest city in Canada, and Ontario's provincial capital, was crammed with buyers, sightseers and exhibition, here for the Canada National exhibition.

The Political Committee of the General Assembly of the United Nations has now been able to come to a vote on the question of the composition of the United Nations representation at the projected political conference on Korea. Thus another step has been taken in the often tedious and always complex process of coming to grips with a Korean settlement.

SHANNON AIRPORT, Ireland, Aug. 27 (AP) -- Mrs. Marion Hart, 61-year-old American, flew the Atlantic today in a small, single-engined plane. She plans to keep going on a lone air tour of Europe and perhaps on to India or Africa.

FREEDOM VILLAGE, Korea, Aug. 27 -- A young man from the Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn challenged the accuracy of statements by Chinese Communist indoctrinators concerning the legality of the occupation of Formosa. As a result, he touched off a chain of events that led to his suffering harsh punishment at the hands of his captors.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 (AP) -- A Democratic member of the House of Representatives Labor Committee accused the Administration today of ignoring his party while drafting proposed changes in the Taft-Hartley Labor Law.

Fifteen leading shipping lines asserted yesterday that the American merchant fleet was headed for "creeping obsolescence" and that 83 per cent of the fleet must be replaced within the next thirteen years.

The establishment of a joint committee of the World Zionist Organization and the Government of Israel empowered to resolve conflicting views on the present role of Zionism was proposed yesterday by Dr. Emanuel Neumann, head of the economic department of the Jewish Agency for Palestine in Jerusalem.

FOUR of the seven gondoliers who slide their craft into the colored lights on the lagoon at Jones Beach in the nocturnal spectacle, "A Night in Venice" are native Venetians, gentlemen with broad cultural backgrounds.

Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll's appointment of Maj. Gen. Edward C. Rose of Trenton to represent his state on the New York-New Jersey Waterfront Commission is welcome news. The new appointee is a citizen-soldier with a distinguished record and a successful business and banking executive.

The city is having great difficulty in recruiting patrolmen. For the first time in its history the Municipal Civil Service Commission will hold two examinations within one year in the hope of keeping the force up to its authorized strength of 20,878 men.

The country's supermarkets this year will sell $135,000,000 worth of such non-food items as cutlery, cake pans, butter dishes, cheese cutters and vacuum bottles, Allen Levis, president of the American Rack Merchandisers Institute, predicted yesterday.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 28 -- V. K. Krishna Menon, Indian representative asked the United Nations General Assembly today not to take a vote on India's participation in the proposed Far Eastern political conference.
PITTSBURGH, Aug. 28 (AP) -- Red Schoendienst's pinch single with the bases filled in the seventh inning gave the Cardinals a 10-9 victory over the Pirates tonight.

JERUSALEM, Aug. 28 -- The Minister of Finance, Levi Eshkol, said today that Israel had begun negotiations to obtain a foreign loan through the medium of her reparations agreement with Germany. He expected the negotiations to mature after the West German elections of Sept. 6.

MITCHELL, S. D. (AP) -- Release Wednesday of a South Dakota soldier who had been a Communist prisoner in Korea led to disclosure that his wife had remarried in the belief that he was dead but that the second marriage had been annulled.
Pee Wee Reese put across the last big punch of a Brooklyn-Cincinnati slugfest to give the Dodgers a 9-8 decision over the Redlegs before 15,702 sweltering spectators at Ebbets Field last night.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., Aug. 28 -- Understanding between children the world over can be promoted through the theatre, speakers at tonight's session of the Children's Theatre Conference of the American Educational Theatre Association told conference delegates. Conducted under the joint sponsorship of Adelphi College and the American National Theatre and Academy, the conference is being held on the Adelphi College campus.
WILLIAMSPORT, Pa., Aug. 28 (AP) -- Birmingham, Ala., today won the 1953 Little League baseball world series when bubblegum-chewing Joey Sims shut out Schenectady, N. Y., 1 -- 0, on two hits.

Donations to the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program on Thursday were 947 pints, the high for the month. The blood collected so far this month, however, totaled only 8,831 pints on Thursday night, indicating that the August quota of 15,000 pints would not be met.

TORONTO, Aug. 28 -- Field Marshal Viscount Montgomery called upon Canada today to give independent new world leadership to the powers of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization while clinging to her Commonwealth ties and without being "unduly" influenced by the United States.

JERSEY CITY, Aug,. 28 -- The New Jersey State Racing Commission today held hearings on applications for race tracks in near-by Secaucus submitted by two rival groups of financiers. After five hours and fifteen minutes of hearing arguments, for and against the proposed tracks, the commissioners reserved decision.

WETHERSFIELD, Conn., Aug. 28 (AP) -- Jim Turnesa, 1952 Professional Golfers Association champion, shot a seven-under-par 64 today for a 36-hole total of 131 and the halfway-mark lead in the second annual\$15,000 Insurance City open golf tournament.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 (AP) -- The Federal Power Commission announced today approval of an application by Tennessee Gas Transmission Company, Houston, Tex., to transport natural gas from the southwestern United States to the Canadian border for resale in Toronto, Canada.
The Cunard Line bowed yesterday to a protest by longshoremen against a plan to change the pier at which to dock the Mauretania.

There must be some lesson for us, as the new school year approaches, in the incident reported from Summit, N. J., 1950 population 17,929. A high school teacher there, Arthur Kull, a 33-year- old veteran of the Second World War, has just notified the board of education that he is quitting his job, which pays $85 a week, and is taking a job driving a brewery truck for $137.50 a week.
MILWAUKEE, Aug. 28 (AP) -- Robert Lippincott of Riverton, N. J., won the North American Star Class sailing championship in Milwaukee Harbor today.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 28 -- The General Assembly of the United Nations formally saluted today the soldiers who fought under the flag of the world organization in defense of the Republic of Korea.
WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Aug. 28 (AP) -- The American people should realize that "adequate roads don't cost -- they pay," the chairman of the Project Adequate Roads movement said today.

On Aug. 20 Gen. Hugh J. Casey, chairman of the New York Transit Authority, told reporters: "Policemen and firemen riding through the transit system are a protection to the riding public. We have a limited number of transit policemen. In an emergency, such as a fire, a short circuit or some other occurrence, these men are an asset to the system."

STOCKHOLM, Aug. 28 (AP) -- Pete George, 24-year-old Akron, Ohio, athlete, set a world lightweight record tonight as he won the first gold medal for the United States in the world weightlifting championships.

According to a meticulous survey by the West German Government, the Soviet authorities and their Communist puppets in East Germany have executed a minimum of sixteen persons for participating in the anti-Communist revolt last June. Another death sentence is known to have been imposed but it is not known whether that has been carried out.

BONN, Germany, Aug. 28 -- West Germany's Social Democratic party, which is challenging the Adenauer Government in the current election campaign, demanded today that the reunification of Germany should have priority over other issues in the proposed four-power discussions on the future of this country.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- Average primary market prices declined 0.1 per cent in the week ended on Tuesday, to 110.7 per cent of the 1947-49 base, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

Down in Wall Street the volume of business transacted this summer on Fridays has been so small that the fifth day of the week is getting to be known as Terrible Friday. Actually the pace of trading in stocks yesterday was not too bad, volume in shares crossing the 1,000,000-share mark.

Victor L. Anfuso, candidate for Borough President of Brooklyn on the Democratic slate headed by Borough President Robert F. Wagner Jr. of Manhattan, and Harry R. Bell, reputed to be Mayor Impellitteri's candidate to take over the leadership of Tammany Hall, were eliminated from the primary ballot in court actions yesterday.

CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa, Aug. 28 (AP) -- The office of the Order of Railway Conductors, representing 35,000 trainmen across the country, said today that a progressive strike had been set to begin at 6 A. M. local standard time on Sept. 10.

A twenty-eight-hour siege of the Department of Health was lifted yesterday afternoon, at least for the week-end, after parents of children attending a Bensonhurst day camp learned that the Commissioner, Dr. John F. Mahoney, had urged the State Health Department to release gamma globulin for 132 of the 450 children.

LONDON, Aug. 28 -- The stock markets ended an uncertain week on a firm note today. Early hesitancy caused by the further setback on Wall Street yesterday disappeared later and prices more than eliminated early falls. However, business remained sparse except in the market for British Government securities, which rose again from the start and ended up to one-eighth of 1 per cent higher among undated, medium and long dated stocks.
A nineteenth-century merchant's desire to keep young people "away from demoralizing influences" will result in the erection of a four-story $2,500,000 library in midtown Manhattan.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- A report dealing with what were termed "devious financial transactions" of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, that was sent to the Justice Department in January by a Senate subcommittee is still under study, Herbert Brownell Jr., Attorney General, said today.

ANCHORAGE, Alaska, Aug. 28 -- The Right Rev. Henry Knox Sherrill, Presiding Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Church in the United States, left Anchorage by airliner today for Fairbanks, where he is scheduled to start on his first trip into the Arctic.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 28 -- From contract to finished product it usually takes about a year to turn out 8-inch howitzer shells. This time schedule has been blasted by the Berwick plant of the American Car and Foundry Company.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 (UP) -- Farm prices dropped four-tenths of 1 per cent in the month ended Aug. 15, resuming a downward trend that was halted in July, the Department of Agriculture reported today.

BONN, Germany, Aug. 28 (AP) -- The United States High Commissioner, Dr. James B. Conant, proposed today a joint conference with the West Germans to discuss a series of legal disputes that threaten to become a politically explosive international issue.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- State Department officials said today that they saw no chance of reaching agreement between the United States and Spain on military bases and aid before the end of next month.

I have read with great interest the letter of J. Edgar Hoover in which he dealt with the quite unbelievable criticism leveled at the Federal Bureau of Investigation at the Governors' Conference by Governor Fine of Pennsylvania and Governor Battle of Virginia, and apparently acquiesced in by Governor Dewey.

INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 28 (AP) -- A Superior Court Judge ordered picketing halted today at Indiana Bell Telephone Company exchanges in Marion County (Indianapolis) but later modified the order to allow restricted picketing.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Aug. 23 -- The leading Australian Communist, Ernest Thornton, who has spent three years in Communist China including most of the period of the Korean war, unexpectedly returned to Sydney today, travelling on a British passport as secretary general of the Communsitled World Federation of Trade Unions.

Members of the Sea Gate Association, residents of a private housing colony on the western trip of Coney Island, yesterday threatened to dump their garbage on the nearest city streets and to march on City Hall if the Sanitation Department did not continue to haul away Sea Gate garbage during a strike of the colony's private sanitation workers.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- Holders of $7,986,242,500 of ten-year 2 per cent Treasury bonds maturing on Sept. 15 were offered the chance today to exchange their securities for one-year certificates of indebtedness paying 2 5/8 per cent or three and one-half year Treasury notes paying 2 7/8 per cent.

An habitual user of narcotics who carried a straight razor and a .32 caliber pistol -- and did not hesitate to use both when angered was seized last night by the police on a West Side roof after a short chase and a furious struggle that continued until he was lodged in a cell.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 28 (AP) -- An alarm concerning the state of the national defense was sounded today for members of the American Legion as they gathered in St. Louis for their national convention that opens Monday.

The 1954 capital budget to be proposed by the City Planning Commission by Nov. 1 will allocate to the New York City Transit Authority far less than the $225,425,405 it seeks for permanent improvements on the subway and surface lines it operates under a ten-year lease from the city.
VIENNA, Aug. 28 -- The appointment of an international commission to report on the Austrian banking system will be announced shortly by the Austrian Government.

BOSTON, Aug. 28 -- An American Bar Association study of Congressional investigations and their effect on individual rights was authorized today at the closing session of the association's sixth annual meeting.

NAIROBI, Kenya, Aug. 28 -- Difficulties are being placed in the way of locust-control teams in eastern Ethiopia by what a spokesman of the desert locust-control headquarters here described today as the truculence of the Issa section of the Somalis in the southeastern Danakil country.

READING, Pa., Aug. 28 -- Officials of the Beryllium Corporation here began tests today of a shipment of ore that might prove the existence of a valuable deposit of beryllium, a strategic metal used in the manufacture of fissionable materials, in an old mine near New Milford, Conn.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 28 -- Brazil and Peru signed five economic and cultural treaties today. The pacts were signed by Vincent Rao, Brazilian Foreign Minister and Ricardo Rivera Schreiber, Peruvian Minister of the Exterior.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 28 -- Out of hundreds of thousands of visitors who have filed through the United Nations headquarters on the East River on guided tours the most fascinating group, by consensus among the uniformed escorts, has been four blind chil
DETROIT, Aug. 28 (AP) -- Mickey Vernon, the American League's top hitter, lifted his average to .329 tonight with two singles and a home run in leading the Senators to a 7-4 victory over the Tigers.

WEST BARRINGTON, R. I., Aug. 28 -- Polly Riley, from Ben Hogan's home town of Fort Worth, Texas, rallied to win at the nineteenth hole this afternoon and reached the final of the women's United States amateur golf championship along with Mary Lena Faulk of Thomasville, Ga.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 28 (AP) -- Curt Simmons pitched a four-hitter as the Phillies beat the Cubs 5 -- 0 tonight. Richie Ashburn cracked two singles to drive in a pair of runs to help Simmons get his twelfth victory of the campaign.

PERCE, Que., Aug. 28 (AP) -- Magistrate Joseph Duguay late tonight committed Wilbert Coffin, 39-year-old prospector, for trial on a charge of murder in the death of one of three Pennsylvania hunters killed in the Gaspe wilds last June.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- Prospects that the Administration's views would prevail on the National Labor Relations Board came nearer to reality today when Philip Ray Rodgers, an appointee of President Eisenhower, was sworn in as a member replacing John M. Houston, who resigned.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 28 -- If they succeed in keeping out of traffic trouble, and if they perform up to the limit of their capabilities. James Cox Brady's Artismo and the Cain Hoy Stable's Turn-To figure to make a two-horse race of the forty-ninth running of the Hopeful Stakes at the Saratoga track tomorrow.

CHICAGO, Aug. 28 -- Evening-up of September grain contracts was in evidence today on the Board of Trade, with early prices easier for wheat, oats and rye, especially for the September deliveries. Corn continued relatively strong on the forecast for continued hot and dry weather in the next five days.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- The General Motors Acceptance Corporation filed a registration statement today with the Securities and Exchange Commission for the sale of $150,000,000 worth of eight-year debentures due 1961.

Your editorial "The Need for Public Housing," which appeared in the Aug. 22 issue of THE TIMES, once more places your paper in the front rank of those whose social and economic views truly reflect the tempo of our times.

PARIS, Aug. 28 -- About 200 French Deputies and Senators opposed to the projected European army, which would include West German forces, have sent an appeal to members of the United States Congress for support, the group's organization announced today.

The present commentator is not indulging in dramatics.

WESTBURY, L. I., Aug. 28 (AP) -- Sandy Fingo won the Alabama Pace in 2:04 2-5 tonight at Roosevelt Raceway, beating Uhleen Fingo to the wire by a length, with Symbol Chance third. Sandy Fingo paid $29 for $2.

Hot weather such as we are having now calls for cold desserts, and ice cream is probably the most popular of these. It is wholly satisfactory served as is, but dressed up with an unusual sauce or other enhancement it fits into the most gala occasions.

OTTAWA, Aug. 28 (Canadian Press) -- Canada's exports in July reached $393,100,000, second highest monthly total on record, the Bureau of Statistics reported today. The July figure compared with the June record of $411,700,000 and last year's July total of $370,400,000.

A Havana taxi driver named Luis Rodriguez Acosta arrived here yesterday by air from Europe, where he had tried to give a bag of Cuban sugar to Soviet Premier Georgi M. Malenkov. Now he wants to give one to President Eisenhower and hopes for better luck than he had with the Russians, who told him the plump Premier doesn't use the stuff.

TRENTON, Aug. 28 -- A new era for the Port of New York was forecast today by Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll as he announced his appointment of Maj. Gen. Edward C. Rose, chief of staff of the New Jersey Department of Defense, as this state's representative on the New York-New Jersey Waterfront Commission.

With competition for the consumer dollar keener than it was even a few months ago, it is imperative that the fur industry advertise more extensively. This is the gist of an article in the latest Fur Trade Review, which emphasizes that fur retailers who equaled 1952's August fur sales this year were those who promoted their wares most vigorously.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Aug. 28 -- Thousands of sodden United States and British bank notes, salvaged in secret operations from the sunken hull of the Flying Enterprise, were deposited in a Brussels bank today.
The only book published today is "The Alligator Lamp," a novel by John Kellogg. Exposition Press is the publisher and the price is $3.50.
BURLINGTON, N. J., Aug. 28 -- A 54-year-old truck driver was crushed to death at 1:55 A. M. today when his tractor-trailer ran into the locomotive of a freight train crossing Route 130.

NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 28 (UP) -- A gang of youths that included two members of a former Nazi-type "storm troopers" club, tried to wreck the Southern Pacific's Sunset Limited yesterday by jamming a switch, the police reported today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- Ben Gold, president of the International Fur and Leather Workers Union of the United States and Canada was indicted by a Federal grand jury here today for swearing falsely to the National Labor Relations Board that he was not a Communist on Aug. 30, 1950.

Allowances, a weekly item eagerly anticipated by the young in many a household, hold no special favor with a group of boys and girls 7 to 19 years of age, according to the findings of a survey released yesterday. Even those too young to work at other than small, odd jobs prefer to earn a little cash on their own, findings indicate, rather than have mother or dad dole out spending money.

Futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed irregular yesterday, 6 points lower to 7 points higher than on Thursday, with the 1954 crop positions showing relative firmness. Activity late in the day broadened with the feature being the fair absorption of December, which was looked upon as month-end mill fixing.

Establishment of permanent arbitration machinery for the settlement of labor disputes in the Port of New York -- with the arbitrator having power to fine the guilty party -- was suggested yesterday by the New York Shipping Association.

MONTREAL, Aug 28 (AP) -- Don Cherry, the singing golfer from Wichita Falls, Tex., and Don Doe of Granby, Que., advanced today to the final of the Canadian amateur golf championship by defeating two Scottish members of the British Walker Cup team by identical scores.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 (UP) -- Senator Spessard Holland, Democrat of Florida, said today that there was room for both private and public power development in the Pacific Northwest and construction of each project should be determined individually.
PITTSBURGH, Aug. 28 (UP) -- The Carnegie Museum announced today that one of its archaeological teams had discovered Indian relics 3,000 to 5,000 years old in mounds near Newell, W. Va.

A new program of the United Service Organizations, Inc., under which U. S. O. activities will be extended into the field of religion, has been announced by Emil Schram, president of the U. S. O. The project, Mr. Schram said, will enable members of the armed

Peter Potter, Pacific Coast disk jockey, will be master of ceremonies for "Peter Potter's Juice Box Jury," a variety show scheduled to make its debut over the A. B. C. television network on Sept. 6 from 9:30 to 10:30 P. M. The format calls for pre-release playing of records, a discussion of the merits of the songs and presentation of guests from all fields of show business.

The Garlock Packing Company and its subsidiaries reported yesterday in the semi-annual statement covering the first six months this year, net income amounted to $768,316, after providing $1,334,465 for taxes.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 28 -- Although in the end it may prove to be nothing more than a mirage, Cleveland's fandom was still living in a land of pleasant dreams tonight as Al Lopez' third-place Indians upset the front-running Yanks for the second time in a row.

United States' exports in the first half of 1953 (excluding nearly two billion dollars worth of foreign military aid shipments) were down 14 per cent from last year, according to a Department of Commerce report published by THE TIMES of Aug. 26. Moreover, June exports were considerably below those for May.

BONN, Aug. 28 -- In a talk with this reporter a few days ago Chancellor Adenauer brought up the subject of the hydrogen bomb. He mentioned the report of a statement of Harold E. Talbott, American Secretary of the Air Force, to the effect that Russia is now capable of an atomic attack on any point in Europe or the United States.

Two sixteen-family apartment houses at 719 and 723 Eighth Avenue, corner of Eighth Street, in Brooklyn have been sold by Edward Kummer to Benjamin Rubins in a transaction negotiated by L. L. Yearsley in conjunction with Paul Jordan as co-broker.

There were four companies on the casualty list because of dividend omissions yesterday. The day's dividend news was brightened, however, by the increased quarterly rate plus an extra voted by directors of the Minneapolis and St. Louis Railway Company.
The Lurie Mortgage Corporation has moved from 22 East Fortieth Street to the building at 30 East Thirty-ninth Street, which was recently altered and named the Lurie Building.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 28 -- Agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation followed today further twistings of a trail that led yesterday to the capture of two fugitive Communist leaders and four persons accused of helping them evade arrest.
A sweltering New York weekend was forecast yesterday by the Weather Bureau, which saw no relief in sight from the heat wave that sent temperatures up to 95.5 degrees yesterday.

Robert F. Wagner Jr., Borough President of Manhattan, made public last night a letter in which he criticized a recent action by the Kings County Medical Society concerning the Health Insurance Plan of Greater New York.
MUNICH, Germany, Aug. 28 -- There is no doubt that the moral authority of Americans in West Germany has been weakened by the exit of some of the leading United States officials here.

FREEDOM VILLAGE, Korea, Aug. 28 -- The Communists made a concerted but unsuccessful attempt to indoctrinate captured officers with their ideas, an Air Force captain said today after his release from thirty-four months of captivity in North Korea.
Not long ago the head of the house was on a vacation. In advance this had promised to be a time of perhaps better than average pleasures, even though a moonlit trip to the Taj Mahal was not included.
CHELTENHAM, Pa., Aug. 28 (UP) -- No one could complain the new siren atop the Lamott Fire Company was not loud enough.

The combined men's and women's national grass court tennis championships start today at Forest Hills, with Maureen Connolly of San Diego, Calif., defending the title she has won for the past two years, and a new champion to be crowned as successor to Frank Sedgman of Australia.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Saturday, Aug. 29 (AP) -- The Bangkok police said yesterday that an alleged revolt plot had been smashed, and announced the arrest of an Indo Chinese suspected of being a Communist agent.
MOSCOW, Aug. 28 -- Today was moving day in Red Square.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 28 -- Indications that the Yugoslav Government is discontented with actions of the Greek Government appeared today, contributing to the view that the treaty of friendship and military collaboration among Greece, Turkey and Yugoslavia was endangered.
CHICAGO, Aug. 28 (UP) -- The Red Sox defeated the White Sox, 4 -- 3, tonight in a game enlivened by a third-inning dispute among free-swinging players from both sides.

Mothers and fathers of 500 campers were in Grand Central Terminal at 6 A. M. yesterday to meet their offsprings due from Maine and New Hampshire. But fond embraces and glad cries of reunion did not take place until seven and eight hours later.

From Edinburgh, Scotland, where T. S. Eliot's new verse play, "The Confidential Clerk," had its premiere this week, comes the news that Henry Sherek, London producer, will be coming here in November in an effort to obtain permission from Actors Equity Association to stage the play here with an all-British company.

Trading continued more active yesterday on the New York commodity exchanges although volume was generally below the levels of July and early August. Prices closed irregularly lower with cocoa, wool, lead, hides, rubber and potatoes off; coffee, sugar, zinc and copper mixed, and cottonseed oil, soybean oil and tin higher.

TUNA fishermen, undismayed by the one-fish-only catch in the eleventh United States Atlantic tournament which closed Thursday off Narragansett, R. I., are busy planning for next year's contest. Just as every angler has his way of doing things, so has every angler his ideas of where and at what time to do it.

Capt. Giovanni Giurini, master of the Italian liner Saturnia, will come of age tomorrow one day before his ship is scheduled to arrive here. The age is 60 and it is the mandatory retirement age of the company.
