SAIGON, Vietnam, Aug. 28 -- The negotiations between France and the Indo-Chinese state of Cambodia on the latter's independence have been halted following the Cambodian demands for greater military authority. These could not be satisfied by the French negotiators on the spot.

After receiving 400 letters from his fiancee that said only "I love you," a Queens corporal who was exchanged this week in Korea soon will read the details that the Communist censors would not let through.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 28 -- Following are excerpts from statements in the United Nations General Assembly session today by V. K. Krishna Menon of India, Henry Cabot Lodge Jr. of the United States and Sir Gladwyn Jebb of Britain:

Arlyne Bernstein and Shirley Robens have sold the two-family dwelling at 75-03 197th Street in Flushing, Queens, to Anna Sudak. James F. Sullivan was the broker and the Inter-County Title Guaranty and Mortgage Company insured title.

ALLENTOWN, Pa., Aug. 28 -- George Hyson of Rye, N. Y., with his father as "navigator" or alternate driver, became the first to cross the finish line at 3:45 P. M. today in the first "International 1,000 Rally" of European sports car enthusiasts to be held in this country.

Not only are Americans visiting foreign countries in ever-increasing numbers, but as time goes on more and more of our travelers are taking their automobiles abroad with them. Long since, the nomadic American has learned to prefer seeing the sights in his own car, so he can jog along at whatever pace he wants, stopping and starting when he pleases.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- The United States criticized Guatemala today on the ground that she had discriminated against the United Fruit Company and had offered grossly inadequate compensation for the company's land expropriated by the Central American Government.

CHICAGO, Aug. 28 -- The topmost ranks of the Democratic National Committee were upset today when the general chairman of the party's $100-a-plate dinner on Sept. 14 resigned unexpectedly. It seemed possible that this affair, featuring former President Harry S. Truman and in honor of the 1952 Presidential candidate, Adlai E. Stevenson, might be held without a general chairman.

CAIRO, Aug. 28 -- A British Embassy spokesman said tonight that Robert Hankey, British charge d'affaires, had made representations to Dr. Mahmoud Fawzi, Egyptian Foreign Minister, regarding interviews granted by President Mohammed Naguib and other members of the Army's ruling Revolutionary Council, to Joseph Murumbi, self-described successor of Jomo Kenyatta as leader of the terrorist Mau Mau organization in Kenya.
COLUMBIA, S. C., Aug. 28 (UP) -- New contracts for Government crop loans forbid the banks handling them to discriminate against any job applicants because of race.

With his arm and his bat, Warren Spahn accounted for his nineteenth victory of the season, a highly commendable 3-1 triumph over the Giants at the Polo Grounds last night. Three of the ten hits the Braves collected against Larry Jansen and Al Corwin -- Marv Grissom yielded only a walk -- were made by Spahn, who slammed a homer and two singles.
The Brooklyn Dodgers, kept off the TV-channels for ten days as a result of a labor dispute, were back on living room and restaurant screens last night.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Aug. 28 -- The Governor of Nyasaland, Sir Geoffrey Colby, broadcast an assurance today that the Government had enough security forces to deal with Negro unrest resulting from disturbances in the Cholo district.
BOULDER, Colo., Aug. 28 -- The construction of a topographical or relief map of Mars, the only solar system planet on which some forms of life may exist, was proposed here today.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., Aug. 28 -- Peter Nisselson of Hampshire C. C. captured the twenty-ninth Westchester junior golf championship with a 3-and-2 final victory over Ross Carino of Harrison at the Bonnie Briar Country Club today.
DALLAS, Aug. 28 (AP) -- A razorsharp passing attack and a vicious pass defense gave the National Football League champions, the Detroit Lions, a 38-7 victory over the New York Giants tonight.

The recent Moscow communique on new Soviet concessions to East Germany adds to the mounting evidence that Nikita S. Khrushchev, Communist party secretary, has been, next to Premier Georgi M. Malenkov, the chief gainer from the purge of Lavrenti P. Beria, former secret police chief.
MUNSAN, Korea, Saturday, Aug. 29 (AP) -- The United Nations Command's official list of United States prisoners freed in today's armistice exchange:
MONTGOMERY, Ala., Aug. 28 (AP) -- Gov. Gordon Persons signed today a bitterly disputed bill outlawing the union shop and similar labor-management agreements in Alabama.

The required number of floating weather stations on the North Atlantic and extra vessels to service them may be determined some time in the fall or early winter. It was learned yesterday that the representatives of member nations of the International Civil Aviation Organization hope to hold a full conference before the end of the year to review the problems of maintaining and financing the important weather reporting system.
HOUSTON, Tex., Aug. 28 -- Plans to hold a world's fair here in 1956 were announced today by officials of a state-chartered philantropic organization, Houston World's Fair, Inc.

OYSTER BAY, L. I., Aug. 28 -- Patience and a diligent search for wind paid off this afternoon as the first Six-Meter trial for the British-American Cup was completed on Long Island Sound. Yachtsmen on the five competing American boats had waited six hours hoping for a wind and, just when it seemed the vigil had been in vain, a breeze came out of the south.

CAMP DRUM, N. Y., Aug. 28 -- The Forty-Second Division's military police company, composed of Mount Vernon men, will receive the Eisenhower Trophy, which is awarded annually to the National Guard unit in each state that ranks highest in drill attendance, total strength and greatest efficiency in firing individual weapons.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 28 (AP) -- Dick Kryhoski banged out a double, triple and home run tonight to drive in four runs as he paced the Browns to an 8-3 victory over the Athletics for a sweep of their three-game series.

Thomas E. Lewis, for the last twelve years president of Local 32-E, Building Service Employes International Union, A. F. L., was shot dead yesterday afternoon in a fifth-floor corridor at 50 East 191st Street, the Bronx, barely twenty feet from his apartment.

GLEN COVE, L. I., Aug. 28 -- Robert Perry defeated Hamilton Richardson today to gain the final round of the invitation tennis tournament for the Nassau Bowl with Tony Trabert, and it becomes pertinent to ask whether the 20-year-old Californian is on the way to moving in with the elite.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- An air-conditioned work suit for the farmer was patented this week by Ralph J. Schaeffer of Ferdinand, Idaho. The design calls for a transparent plastic helmet with room at the top for a radio receiver and with a mouthpiece for a cigarette holder.

JONES BEACH, L. I., Aug. 28 -- Eleven husky, sun-tanned Nassau County youths slipped on their swim trunks today and splashed into the ocean at Jones Beach State Park. They had a two-fold purpose -- to escape the 90-degree heat and to pass their final examinations as surf guards.

Stocks had a week-end market yesterday -- dead, dull and without much movement. Prices closed irregularly lower, but none of the averages made a new low for 1953. The volume was 1,060,000 shares, compared with 1,290,000 on Thursday.

Despite great productive capacity in the women's apparel field, it is strongly possible that delivery bottlenecks will develop in late September and early October, according to the Independent Retailers Syndicate, a New York resident buying office.

LEOPOLDVILLE, Congo, Aug. 24 -- Motorized banks on wheels, loudspeaker appeals, advertising and propaganda of every sort have increased in two years the number of Congo African natives with savings accounts from 8,500 to 130,000.

WEST SHOKAN, N.Y., Aug. 28 -- University and college students from five countries participated this evening in a traditional Jewish observance ushering in the sabbath at Camp High Point, scene of the eighth annual national B'nai B'rith Hillel Foundation Summer Institute.

Lumber production for the week ended last Saturday was 5.9 per cent below that of the like week of last year, according to reports wired yesterday to THE NEW YORK TIMES by regional associations. Shipments were down 16.1 per cent and orders 8.2 per cent.

In a statement of principles concerning the relationship of American Jews to Israel, Dr. Nahum Goldmann, Zionist leader and chairman of the Jewish Agency for Palestine, held yesterday that the efforts of American Jews on behalf of Israel supplemented their contribution to American ideals.
WILMINGTON, Del., Aug. 28 (UP) -- E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., said today it had set aside more money to pay Federal income taxes in the first half of this year than it had paid to employes.

In the first sale of the property since 1895, the two six-story loft buildings at 20-22 and 24-26 Greene Street have been conveyed by the heirs of Samuel Inslee to the Mircon Realty Corporation. Carl E. Schutak was attorney for the buyer and DeWitt, Lockman DeWitt acted for the sellers.

YONKERS, Aug. 28 -- Red Sails set a world pacing record for a mile and a sixteenth tonight when he came on in the stretch under the urging of Robert Walker to capture the $5,000 junior free-for-all feature at Yonkers Raceway in 2:08.

The Mayor's special mediation committee in the strike of concrete, sand and gravel truck drivers began yesterday meetings to find a peace formula for ending the fifty-six-day tie-up that has halted most public and private building.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Aug: 28 -- While the press continued today to inflame public opinion on the Kashmir issue, leaders of the All Jammu-Kashmir Moslem Conference announced plans for the formation next month of a "Kashmir liberation front."
TORONTO, Aug. 28 -- Texas took a long lead over favored Alberta today in the race to provide this rich commercial area with its first flow of natural gas.

Two weeks ago the Department of Agriculture, faced with the prospect of a wheat supply 50 per cent above normal, took a vote of the nation's wheat producers on the question of whether acreage and marketing controls should be applied with respect to the 1954 crop.
NEWARK, Aug. 28 -- Rubber stamps used for write-in votes in the primary election April 21 in the Borough of South River were held valid today by Superior Court Judge C. Thomas Schettino.

GENEVA, Aug. 28 -- Success in the treatment of both acute and chronic forms of gout with the recently developed new drug phenylbutazone was reported today at the eighth International Congress of Rheumatic Diseases. The report was made by a group of rheumatologists from the Stanford University School of Medicine in San Francisco headed by Dr. William C. Kuzell.

NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 28 -- Official circles here expressed concern today at the sweeping allegations being made in the Pakistani papers that India is trying to sabotage the agreement reached between Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru of India and Mohammed Ali, the Prime Minister of Pakistan, on the settlement of the Kashmir dispute.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y. Aug. 28 -- A last-minute move to postpone the next session of the General Assembly for two weeks until Sept. 29 was stamped out quickly today by delegates from Sweden, India, and Australia, with the backing of Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- Some 7,000 to 12,000 telephone workers went on strike today in Washington, Maryland, Virginia and West Virginia, but union officials later ordered them back in the Washington area and said operating conditions should be normal by 6 A. M. tomorrow.
The Retail Clerks International Association, A. F. L., abandoned yesterday its efforts to win recognition as the collective bargaining agent for workers of two strike-bound Hearn department stores.
DETROIT, Aug. 28 (AP) -- The Aug. 12 fire that destroyed General Motors' Livonia transmission plant may cost the production of is more than 75,000 cars, Ward's Automotive Reports said today.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 28 -- Puerto Rico, which thirteen months ago became a self-governing commonwealth, formally asked a United Nations committee today to recognize its changed status by dropping the island from its list of dependent territories.
School districts in Central states had mixed success yesterday in borrowing funds in the public market by the sale of bond issues.

KIEL, Germany, Aug. 28 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer invaded today Social Democratic strongholds of North Germany, which together with the states of Schleswig-Holstein and Lower Saxony may determine the outcome of the Sept. 6 elections.
MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 28 (AP) -- Control of the Minneapolis and St. Louis Railway apparently was retained today by the majority group that has been operating the road.

Dr. Ralph L. Dodge has been appointed administrative assistant to general management of the polychemical department of E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc. Russell C. Weigel has been named division head and Dr. Lawrence T. Jilk replaces Mr. Wiegel as assistant planning manager.

WESTBURY, L. I., Aug. 29 -Donna Lee Own's Scotch Spencer from Omaha, Neb., driven by Neal Houslet, scored a smashing upset in 2:02 in the $5,500 Indiana junior free-for-all pacing feature at Roosevelt Raceway tonight.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 (UP) -- Val Peterson, Civil Defense Administrator, said tonight that evacuation of target cities in an atomic attack was not now planned because of the probable short warning time.
SARATOGA SPRINGS N. Y., Aug. 29 -- "Hey, fellers," said Charlie O'Brien, eyes shining and voice quivering, "I'm riding tomorrow. Can you imagine? Me. I'm riding."

OF all the burgeoning careers being noted these days, possibly the most meteoric of the lot is the property of Audrey Hepburn, a multi-talented performer of 24 -- born in Belgium, raised both in Britain and in Holland -- whose first American movie, "Roman Holiday," opened at the Music Hall last Thursday. In Miss Hepburn's case, her American film career postdated her American stage career, but one was just about as meteoric as the other.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 (UP) -- The Administration has about decided it cannot cut military manpower as much as originally planned, according to the Army-Navy-Air Force Journal.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 29 -- Daniel C. Rogers, chairman of the State Board of Mediation, said today that he had prepared a formula for settling the single remaining issue that was prolonging the strike of 53,000 nonsupervisory employes of Southwestern Bell Telephone Company in six states.

THANKS to Adolf Hitler's vanity and the incredible adulation of his entourage, posterity now has available a transcription of the Fuehrer's "secret conversations," 1941-44. This gatherum offers, contrary to the expectations of those who preserved it, an accurate portrait of his fanatically self-confident, egocentric, dark character.

FREEDOM VILLAGE, Korea, Aug. 29 -- M. Sgt. Frederick J. Stumpges of Sheboygan, Wis. cried like a baby when he crossed the line to freedom at Panmunjom today. He had good reason to be happy. He had been a prisoner of the Communists for two years and nine months. During World War II he had been captured at Corregidor and had been a prisoner of the Japanese for three years and five months.

A NEW model of the Brownie Movie Camera, with the new fast f/1.9 Kodak Cine Ektanon, is announced by Eastman Kodak Company for availability next month. The camera will cost $49.50, a new low price in movie cameras with this fast lens, which extends movie making to night and indoor photography.

WAYSIDE, N. J., Aug. 29 -- Three score state Democratic leaders, representing virtually all of New Jersey's twenty-one counties, gathered here in this Monmouth County village this afternoon to discuss campaign strategy with their candidate for Governor, Robert B. Meyner.

AN experiment in democracy was the last thing that Angelica Foster wanted when her father insisted that she transfer to plebeian Bennett High School instead of going to the smarter school where most of her friends went.

After trailing by two sets following thirty-four games played in broiling heat, Mervyn Rose of Australia defeated Allen Morris of Atlanta yesterday as the seventy- second national grass court championships started at the West Side Tennis Club, Forest Hills, Queens.
MOSCOW, Aug. 29 -- The Soviet Government rejected the Western proposal in identical notes delivered to the United States and other Western powers.

Topics usually discussed only in whispers will be aired this week at the second annual market week sponsored by the National Association of Shirt, Pajama and Sportswear Manufacturers at the New Yorker Hotel. Should the meetings tomorrow through Wednesday prove successful, the industry would be well on the way to making improvements that will be extremely helpful to the consumer.

GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 29 -- Greenwich, which in 1946 rejected the United Nations' bid to establish headquarters here, will evidence a more conciliatory attitude when the community celebrates United Nations Week in October.

HANOI, Vietnam, Aug. 29 (AP) -- Communist China, for the first time, is sending big field guns into Indo-China to help the Communist-led Vietminh, according to Gen. Rene Cogny, commander of French Union forces in northern Indo-China.

What little remained of the feeble summer rally was virtually wiped out in the stock market last week. For the commission houses it was very much like a fire sale; volume expanded, but only at the expense of stock prices. The third decline in as many weeks carried industrial stock prices close to the 1953 low point set in June, and pushed the rails down to the levels of May, 1952.

SYRACUSE, Aug. 29 -- Speedboat drivers from forty-two states and a couple of Canadian provinces congregated today on Onondaga Lake for the three-day race meet for the national stock outboard titles. It was the biggest closed-course regatta in history, with 294 registered.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 29. -- Retired school teachers in New York are happier in their post-classroom life than is the general run of New York City employes now in retirement, according to findings presented here this week to members of the Gerontological Society.
TORONTO, Aug. 29 (Canadian Press) -- Leopold Stokowski will conduct a program of all-Canadian classical music in New York this fall and composers from coast to coast are vying to be included.
Can a ship that saves an airplane that has fallen into the sea collect a salvage award?

A COUPLE of seasons ago Jean-Louis Curtis published a fine novel, "The Forests of the Night," studying many levels of French life during and immediately after the war. There was about it a quality of Balzac at his best -- which is very good indeed.

PROVIDE Teheran with a political stir and out pours the mob from its slums and shanty towns no matter what the pretext for a demonstration. On Monday, Aug. 17, it was following and cheering the lorries which, driven by students and other Communist supporters, were stripping the town of its statues of the royal house and dragging them on tow ropes through the dusty streets.

HANOVER, N. H., Aug. 29 -- A letter signed jointly by George Washington and his wife, Martha, has been presented to the Baker Library at Dartmouth College by Mrs. Frederick E. Atwood of West Roxbury, Mass., widow of a member of the Dartmouth Class of 1900.

A THOUGH he is famous as the youngest of America's modern old masters and the subject of a biography by Selden Rodman which is in its third edition, in the town of Roosevelt, N. J., population about 800, the artist is simply one of the respected and functioning members of the community.

SINCE Labor Day pops up again next week, it will soon be possible to visit Mr. Inge's "Picnic" in the proper frame of mind. For you will remember that Mr. Inge discovers his characters on the morning of Labor Day in Kansas at the time when they are getting ready for a neighborhood picnic.

IT'S true what they say about the United States in Asia. We are dogmatic, inexperienced -- an unfortunate combination -- flighty, contradictory and unpopular. But it's only a part of the truth and not by any means the main part; for America is engaged throughout this vast area in one of the noblest enterprises in our history, and the tragedy of it is that most Americans don't know it.

CAIRO, Aug. 29 -- Although "cold war" battles between the Soviet Union and the Western powers are being fought in Europe and fierce hot wars continue to bloody the map of the Far East, neither side dares divert its attention from the turbulent but militarily weak Middle East, which could be the strategic key to victory in a third world war.

Harold Riegelman, Republican candidate for Mayor, called yesterday for facts that would shed light on such pressing city problems as education and traffic and accused the "warring Democratic candidates, and the strangely coy Rudolph Halley" of blanketing issues and dealing mainly in personal vituperation.

CAMP DRUM, N. Y., Aug. 29 -- Lieut. Gen. Withers A. Burress, commander of the First Army, inspected today the Forty-second National Guard Division from New York as it ended its first week of field training here with a review parade.

Although the New York savings bankers' pool of common stock investment money has been increased about $1,000,000 since mid-May and is now approximately $4,500,000, the bankers are moving cautiously in using their own new Institutional Investors Fund.

ROME, Aug. 29 -- That Premier Giuseppe Pella is an exceptionally smooth political operator was proved beyond the shadow of a doubt when he reconciled the irreconcilable by talking such complete political opposites as the Republicans and Monarchists into supporting his Government.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 29 -- Strange things happen in baseball and certainly one of the strangest occurred on this steaming afternoon in Cleveland's vast lake front stadium as Bob Lemon spun a glittering three-hitter, thereby enabling the Indians to polish off the Yankees, 6 to 0, before a cheering Ladies' Day crowd of 24,811.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 29 -- Loans by member banks in the Third Federal Reserve District continued their upward sweep during the first half of 1953. Gross earnings, in keeping with this trend, also rose materially, but additions to distributable funds were limited by rising expenses and income taxes.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 29 -- The labor supply remains tight but not critical, with no immediate relief in sight for employers seeking to recruit experienced professional men and skilled and semi-skilled factory machine operators. Employment in Greater Cleveland is estimated at 655,000 with employers planning to recall or hire 2,250 manufacturing and 620 non-manufacturing workers by Sept. 15.
WEST SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Aug. 29 -- President Eisenhower will pay special tribute to the youth of New England during his visit to the annual Eastern States Exposition on Sept. 21.

Laboratory models that simulate the flow of ocean currents, the movement of weather and other natural phenomena will be demonstrated and discussed during a symposium to be held at Johns Hopkins University Sept. 1-4. The purpose is to help in solving the problems of those who must approximate in the laboratory the conditions above, below and at the surface of the earth.

The John and Mary R. Markle Foundation announced yesterday that in 1954, in cooperation with approved medical schools in the United States and Canada, it would continue its "scholar in medical science" program for the seventh year. The program is intended to aid young men and women planning careers in academic medicine.

WHEN 11-year-old Penny Page moved from New Haven to Florida, in 1886, she faced many disappointments. Her father's new store had competition from a fascinating trade boat. Their sparsely populated home site on the Indian River had no school.

BUYERS of new homes usually have a lot of spade work to do before they can proceed with lawn planting. That is, if they're trying to conserve green stuff of the folding, pocket variety. For it's rare to find more than one to two inches of topsoil on any lawn area.

THE foreign types of bread still to be enjoyed in New York are as old-fashioned as a cracker-barrel grocer. But unlike him they have resisted the standardization brought about in our food by the can, the jar and the carton.

WHEN I moved into my new home in southern Connecticut not quite four years ago I was beset with all the usual problems facing new home owners. The area immediately around the house had been roughly graded by the contractor, complete with assorted buried trash, and pounded to the consistency of rock by the bulldozer.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 29 -- In a tight finish, after a side-by-side run through the stretch, James Cox Brady's 13-to-20 Artismo beat the Brae Burn Farm's third-choice War Piper in the forty-ninth running of the Hopeful Stakes for 2-year-olds at the Saratoga track today.

BRANCHVILLE, N. J., Aug. 29 -- Sussex County officially took time out today to recall the way of life it practiced 200 years ago. As part of a month-long bicentennial celebration, it opened and staffed a log cabin, a model of the home of the rugged pioneers, and called in the New Jersey Irregulars, a club of muzzle-loading gun enthusiasts, to stage a shoot.
" The country," Secretary of the Treasury George M. Humphrey told a press conference on Thursday, "has reached the essential turning point toward a balanced budget."

A former convict who worked until last month as a "trouble shooter" for Yonkers Raceway, the harness-horse track, was questioned yesterday in the Bronx murder of Thomas E. Lewis, building service union official.
Despite the cessation of Korean hostilities, American shipowners and seamen's unions are still reluctant to discuss any reduction of war bonuses still being paid in Pacific and European waters.

THIS collection of short stories suggests what is already on record -- that Martha Gellhorn is a first-rate war correspondent. They show, for example, her journalistic gift of isolating the pertinent and pathetic detail that illuminates the virtually indescribable totality of a wartime situation.

Dr. Abba Hillel Silver, Zionist leader, declared last night that the United States Government's attitude toward Israel was "friendly and sympathetic" and that the Government was eager to see the new state "secure and prosperous."

IN 1853 a village improvement association was organized in Stockbridge, Mass., as a result of long and untiring effort by Mrs. Mary Hopkins Goodrich. She called the townspeople together, and citizens of near-by towns also came. This resulted in the formation of the Laurel Hill Association, Inc., which is celebrating its centennial this month.

Almost inevitably, some skepticism was mixed with the generally warm praise given last week to the Douglas Report, stressing the need for more liberal American trade and tariff policies as a prerequisite to fuller convertibility of the pound with other currencies.

FROM his teaching experiences at the Outward Bound Sea School in North Wales, the author has fashioned a rousing tale of adventure on and about the Irish Sea. This is the story of twelve boys enrolled at the famous British maritime school.

BLANDLY assuming that anything can happen anywhere, Mr. Fischer, Swedish author-illustrator, gives us a happy extravaganza concerning two unwitting stowaways. During a game of hide-and-seek Pete and Katie fall asleep on a steamer in port, wake to find they are bound for Africa.

EIGHT months ago the average discophile would have been hard put to explain the exact nature of the relationships between major American and European recording companies. Since then, a number of significant shifts in international affiliations have made 1953 the most fluid year in the history of the LP record industry -- and have left the record collector in an even more confused state of mind.

The Dodgers' pennant machine continued to roll in high gear at Ebbets Field yesterday as the league leaders beat the Redlegs, 10 -- 3, although a Brooklyn starting pitcher failed to finish for the seventh straight game.
The Holland-America "economy" liner Maasdam completed her first year of service last week, having carried 18,008 passengers to Europe and on Caribbean cruises.

GRAFENWOEHR, Germany, Aug. 29 -- On these maneuver grounds amid the rolling woods of Franconia, where Hitler trained his Wehrmacht, are villages ground to ugly fragments by German guns practicing to pulverize Europe, squashed cement fortifications where the Maginot Line was smashed in minuscule, and pitted dusty fields over which the Afrika Corps first paraded toward the River Nile.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 (UP) -- Officials of the Internal Revenue Service said today their recent door-to-door check of tax evaders in New England probably would be extended on a nation-wide basis in the next few months.
QUINCY, Ill., Aug. 29 (AP) -- Take a traveling salesman, add an 8 by 34 foot sample kit on wheels and you've got "furniturama."

The Brooklyn Dodgers home baseball games, kept off the TV channels for the last week or so because of a labor dispute, went on without incident yesterday over WABD, Channel 5, and will continue today, tomorrow and for the remainder of the season over that station.

OTTAWA, Canada, Aug. 25 -- Canada, often referred to as "The Queen of Snow," has played a leading part in the development of a new international snow "language" that has recently been adopted by a large part of the world.

Blazing sunshine, its effects ameliorated somewhat by generally low humidity, broke heat records yesterday for both the year and the date. The forecast was for continued high temperatures -- in the 90's -- today and possibly tomorrow.

Dave Beck, president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, A. F. L., demanded yesterday that Local 282, representing sand, gravel and concrete truck drivers, settle its eight-week-old strike by Tuesday.
MUNSAN, Sunday, Aug. 30 (AP) -- The United Nations Command's official list of United States prisoners freed in today's armistice exchange:

TOMO, sitting against a great rock high in the Peruvian Andes, watches his little herd of goats and thinks. Tomorrow he will be 12 years old -- and a man! According to the custom of his people, he must choose his life-work, that of a farmer or a goat-herder.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Aug. 29 -- A Rutgers University faculty review committee, in a report made public today, recommended that an opportunity to resign without prejudice be given to Abraham Glasser, 38-year-old law school professor, and that he be dismissed if he refused to do so.

One of the good results of the influx of so many Spanish-speaking people from Puerto Rico is that making records of Spanish music has become more profitable. In consequence, a good deal of Spanish music is being committed to disks.
The American Federation of Labor, it was learned yesterday, now is moving toward expulsion -- not suspension -- of its racket-ridden affiliate, the International Longshoremen's Association.

IRIS catalogues with gay illustrations tempt the novice and experienced grower alike to order for summer planting. Varieties may be chosen to replenish stock or to add fresh colors to the garden scene at iris time. When the final choice has been made, prompt ordering insures the arrival of roots for planting from now until October.

CHICAGO, Aug. 29 (AP) -- Phil (Wildcat) Kim, squat Chinese-American from Honolulu, stopped Virgil Akins of St. Louis at 2:11 of the tenth and final round of their nationally televised fight at Rainbo Arena tonight. Each boxer weighed 141 1/2 pounds.

SOME bright spots are showing up in the new fall season's television programming pattern as it begins to take shape. Not the least of these should be the addition of a new series of symphonic concerts -- a programming area in which TV is unbelievably deficient -- to the schedule of WABD and the Du Mont network.

IN philately every "error" variety has its story. Such tales of discovery are treasured by contemporary collectors. Eventually the details find niches in the hobby's literature for future collectors interested in researches into the past. This is an account of the recent "find" of what may become one of the most valuable of United States varieties.

TEHERAN, Aug. 29 -- A political miracle on Aug. 19 jerked Iran out from under the Iron Curtain as it was about to be lowered. To give the nation a fighting chance to stay in the free world will take something much more prosaic, an expensive economic salvage operation extending over the next few years.

PUSAN, Korea, Sunday, Aug. 30 (AP) -- Republic of Korea soldiers will "fight communism anywhere," President Syngraan Rhee declared Saturday shortly after United States Senator William F. Knowland, Republican of California, had said "the free world cannot afford any more Munichs."

CHORE FOR THE WEEK: Black spot and mildew are two diseases prevalent at the end of summer. Although black spot will defoliate rose bushes, another set of leaves will appear soon. Spray weekly with fermate or a three-purpose rose spray. Dusting with sulfur will check the spread but will not eliminate the mildew on roses, zinnias and other plants.

A NEW lawn can be established on most clay soils, although it seems incredible that grass can send roots into such hard or compact ground and develop into a good green cover. However, unless the home owner makes essential treatments, grasses may fail on such soils.

FROM the 747 letters which are part of a large collection of Carlyle manuscripts in the National Library of Scotland Lady Bliss has selected the most interesting and the least repetitious Froude, Carlyle's early biographer, had made slight use of them, as had Charles Eliot Norton and Alexander Carlyle, but for the most part the greater part of this treasure has lain untouched until the publication of this important book.

Coffee has a stronger smell than an onion or camphor. At least, it causes a greater response on brain wave recordings, according to Drs. Carl W. Sem-Jacobsen, Reginald G. Bickford, Henry W. Dodge Jr. and Magnus C. Petersen of Rochester, Minn., who reported on the subject before the Third International Congress of Electroencephalagraphy (brain-wave recording), and Clinical Neurophysiology.
CLEVELAND. Aug. 29 -- Scores of Great Lakes freighters will head for winter berths about the middle of November because of a scarcity of cargoes, it was learned today.

NANTUCKET, Mass. -- Scratch a Nantucket visitor and you find an amateur sociologist. Around the beach-picnic fires and the bars with New York decor, in the gifte shoppes and the general delivery line at the post office, the summer people ponder and argue with the

HOLLYWOOD. WE will not bring people back to the theatres or develop new audiences where quality has been sacrificed for economy. You will never read on a marquee how fast a picture was shot, how few extras are in it or that the script was written in three weeks.

Ben Gold, president of the independent International Fur and Leather Workers' Union of the United States and Canada, will surrender tomorrow to an indictment returned on Friday, his attorney informed the United States Attorney's office here yesterday in a telephone conversation.

PAWTUCKET, R. I, Aug. 29 (UP) -- Four more victories at Narragansett Park today raised Tony DeSpirito's year's total to 200. The jockey stole the spotlight from favored Repelled's victory in the $7,500 Watch Hill Purse before 19,011 fans.

It has been known for years that cancer cells need food just as normal cells do. One of the essential foods is sugar (glucose). Cancer cells ought, therefore, to starve to death if they cannot metabolize sugar -- that is, convert it into the energy required for growth.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- Raymond C. Blattenberger, the new Public Printer, told the Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations today that fifteen employes of the Government Printing Office, now under inquiry on alleged Communist inflitration there, had been transferred recently to posts where secret documents were no longer within their reach.

ALTHOUGH there have been a few tears shed occasionally over the allegedly sad state of the motion picture in our time it might be noted that the lachrymose observers generally are expending motion and effort in advance and in the wrong cause.

After years of almost unquestioned, if sometimes cynical, acceptance, the political practice of presenting voters with a "balanced ticket" -- a list of candidates designed to appeal to the racial pride of numerically large sections of the electorate and to local geographic prejudice -- is coming under serious attack in the current municipal election campaign in New York City.

ROME, Aug. 29 -- All troops on the Italian side of the Italian-Yugoslav frontier were alerted, furloughs were canceled for all members of the armed forces and some units of the Italian Navy were ordered into the Adriatic today when reports reached Rome from Belgrade indicating that Yugoslavia was perhaps planning to annex the Yugoslav-occupied Zone B of the Free Territory of Trieste.

ADDITIONS in the series the for the centenary of Jose Julian Marti (1853-95), Cuba's "Apostle of the Independence," have been received from E. Taboada in Havana. A 1-centavo green and chestnut shows Marti being tried before a Spanish court in 1870.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 (UP) -- House members talked less than Senators in the recent session and got much more work done.

ALLENTOWN, Pa., Aug. 29 (AP) -- Bill Price of Erie, Pa., driving an MG, was declared over-all winner of the first 1,000-mile International Sports Car Rally today, ending a three-day cross-country tour at Dorney Park here with accelerating and braking tests. Driving with Price was John Chaffee, also of Erie.

IN HIS famous conversations with William Drummond of Hawthornden, Ben Jonson has a story that might serve as a wry kind of text for my remarks here. "A Gentleman reading a Poem yt began with Wher is that man that never yet did hear Of fair Penelope, Uiisses Queene.

The training of experts who have a first-hand knowledge of the language, culture and customs of the Eastern European countries in Soviet Russia's orbit has been materially improved as a result of a five-year project just completed by the Department of Slavic Languages at Columbia University on behalf of the Rockefeller Foundation.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- There are growing indications that the Korean war veterans are not taking advantage of the benefits of the Korean G.I. bill of rights with nearly the alacrity that veterans of World War II showed in respect to the original G.I. bill of rights.

TULSA, Okla., Aug. 29 (AP) -- The Chicago Bears scored two touchdowns and a field goal in the fourth quarter tonight to beat the Pittsburgh Steelers, 31 -- 28, in an exhibition game of the National Football League teams before a crowd of about 12,000.

BALTIMORE -- Western Maryland's vacation spots are chronically unpublicized, but at least one, the Catoctin Recreational Demonstration Area under National Park Service supervision, has come into somewhat greater prominence of recent years as the retreat of harassed Presidents.

Byer's Peak Ranch, 8,700 feet up in the Colorado Rockies in the town of Fraser, is a 1,900-acre tract which belongs to two Denver businessmen. It has four sleeping cabins equipped with fireplaces and electric blankets, a recreation cabin with ping pong table and a kitchen-and-dining cabin.

THE Rochester International Salon of Photography, the largest in the country, invites entries for its eighteenth annual exhibition, to be shown March 5-28 in Memorial Art Gallery, Rochester. Special recognition will be offered this year in the form of fifteen bronze medals, designated Rochester Medals, for the best fifteen prints in the salon's five sections.

BONN, Germany, Aug. 29 -- Leaders of the League of Germans, a West German political party accused this week of being financed by the Communists, had a talk in Berlin yesterday with Vladimir S. Semyenov, Soviet High Commissioner in Germany.

The creeping slum is engulfing large areas of New York City faster than the combined efforts of government and private enterprise are able to substitute modern housing for substandard dwellings in the older slums. This is the problem underlying such efforts as the recent start of construction on the Baruch Houses on the Lower East Side and the proposal announced last week for rehabilitation of a large area in Greenwich Village.

In a recent issue under the heading "When Is an Invention 'Obvious'?" Waldemar Kaempffert discusses a problem that sometimes confronts our federal judges, and he makes reference to an article on the subject by Judge Clarence G. Galston of the United States District Court, Eastern District of New York.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, Aug. 29 -United States opposition to Indian participation in the political conference on Korea, along with other attitudes taken by Washington on the Korean question, are further antagonizing public opinion in India.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 (UP) -- Senator Alexander Wiley, chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, has credited the Republican - controlled Congress with an "impressive record" of foreign policy accomplishments, it was disclosed today.

TRENTON, N. J., Aug. 29 -- Michael Stroukoff, developer of the C-123 military cargo plane, was paid $1,750,000 today to release his entire interests in Chase Aircraft Company. Payment was made by the Kaiser organization.
Major league players generally are adopting a "wait and see" attitude on the question of whether it was wise to hire a lawyer to represent them before baseball's executive council.

THERE'S a bright new entry in the C. B. S. television morning line-up on Tuesdays and Thursdays at 11:15 o'clock. Called the Bil Baird show, it is a disk jockey program with puppets. It's tuneful, cheerful and imaginative, and after a fast fifteen minutes, the housewife can grab her mop and happily make up for lost time.

O'NEILL, Neb., Aug. 29 -- Air Force weather experts, aided by research teams from several universities, were attempting by new methods this week to catch and record the movements of winds that sweep the Great Plains region.

A series of six lectures on the psychiatric diagnosis and treatment of martial discord problems will be presented in the 1953-54 season by the Psychiatric Forum Group at the New York Academy of Science, 2 East Sixty-third Street, Dr. Victor W. Eisenstein, chief of the psychiatry clinic at Lenox Hill Hospital and coordinator of the group, announced yesterday.

SAULT SAINTE MARIE, Mich., Aug. 25 -- Negro airmen assigned to a radar station and an interceptor squadron guarding the vital Sault Sainte Marie canals, more popularly known as the Soo, have been shocked to discover that here, on the nation's northern border, barber shops, restaurants and taverns refuse them service.
The volatile anesthetics used in operating rooms -- ether, ethylene and cyclopropane -- are all highly combustible, and there is danger of explosion in the use of X-ray equipment.

Phil Walters, driving the No. 2 Briggs Cunningham gray roadster, sped over 215 miles of hot, black, asphalt track at the United States Naval Air Station, Floyd Bennett Field, Brooklyn, to win the Floyd Bennett Grand Prize Cup in the feature sports car road race yesterday.

MAMARONECK, N. Y., Aug. 29 -- William H. Stanley's Bumble Bee, with Arthur Knapp at the tiller, scored her third straight victory in the International Class today in the Beach Point Yacht Club's regatta on Long Island Sound.

WEST BARRINGTON, R. I., Aug. 29 -- Mary Lena Faulk returned the women's United States amateur golf title to Georgia today as she won the scheduled thirty-six-hole final at the Rhode Island Country Club from Polly Riley of Forth Worth, Tex., by 3 and 2.

A pickle can be quite a number of things, from trouble to salt brine; but about now it has only one meaning, which any nose can identify in the vicinity of any rural kitchen. It means vinegar and dill and cloves and allspice and onions and cucumbers and peppers. It means savor and tang and a delight to the nose, the eye and the appetite.

That which had been suspected by many at least a month ago became a mathematical certainty yesterday. The Giants will not win the National League pennant this season. For even while they were beating the Braves by 4-1 at the Polo Grounds, Leo Durocher's athletes were being eliminated from the race because the Dodgers were succeeding against the Reds over at the Ebbets Field.

LIFE, the poet has said, is a tale full of sound and fury, signifying nothing. With rather less eloquence the author of this first novel has sought to say the same thing. If his grim tale holds any moral at all, it is this: life is real, life is earnest and the grave is its goal.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 29 -- The State Secretariat for Foreign Affairs announced today the successful completion of talks with the Hungarian Government in the establishment of a two-nation commission to investigate all future incidents on the Yugoslav-Hungarian border.

ACROSS this flowery tapestry of the Elizabethan English highway marches Hugh Copplestone, 12-year-old orphan, "with his legs straight and his shoulders back as the Players taught him." His peregrinations begin on the night that he, with his dog Argos, steals away from his avaricious aunt's cruelty to seek Oxford and the New Learning.

BONN, Aug. 29 -- The case of Dr. Werner Naumann, former state secretary in Joseph Goebbels' Propaganda Ministry, who was barred from participating in the current general election campaign, has focussed attention on the question of the importance of authoritarian-minded elements in West Germany.

MUCH-TRAVELED landscape men have said that Denver has the best lawns in the world. Yet this city is in the center of a vast area where growing conditions are generally considered rather difficult. For over most of the area the soil is inclined to be alkaline and the rainfall is limited.

David Dubinsky's article, "Instead of the McCarthy Method" (July 26) makes out what might have been a plausible case for his union's method of dealing with Communist subversion, except for one fact. The functions which Mr. Dubinsky and the International Ladies Garment Workers would vest in a Presidential commission and in a private information center, collectively, are already, as I understand it, singly and more effectively being performed by the Subversive Activities Control Board.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 (AP) -- Senator Harry F. Byrd, Democrat of Virginia, and five of his colleagues said today that a prospective $2,000,000,000 spending cut had made it unnecessary for Congress to increase the national debt limit.

Fifteen recognized international grand masters at chess, representing seven countries, reported yesterday for the opening of the world championship challengers' tournament at a preliminary meeting at the Casino in Neuhausen, Switzerland.

OYSTER BAY, L. I., Aug. 29 -- Four six-meter yachts gained places on the United States team that will compete in the British-American cup races as the second of two trials was completed on Long Island Sound this morning. Heading the fleet of five past the final marker was Llanoria, owned and sailed by Magnus Konow, formerly one of Norway's leading yachtsmen.
The way is at last clear for an estimated 100,000 American owners of about $370,000,000 in dollar bonds of pre-war Germany to show formally that their holdings are bona-fide.

All last week the prisoner exchange went forward at Panmunjom without hitch. Each day the United Nations Command returned 2,400 Chinese and North Koreans; the Communists returned 400 U. N. and South Korean P. O. W.'s. Unlike many of the first Allied soldiers returned, those last week were in good physical shape.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 (AP) -- Senator Ralph E. Flanders, Republican of Vermont, proposed today that President Eisenhower and other Government policy makers consider cutting billions of dollars from programs for hydrogen-atomic weapons, defense and foreign aid.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Aug. 29 -- The rivalries that have developed recently between Indonesian political groups are being brought into sharper focus in the debates in Parliament on the program of the new Cabinet of Dr. Ali Sastroamidjojo.

" FATHER, Dear Father" is Ludwig Bemelmans' fourteenth book, and, according to the foremost living authority on the subject, it was turned out with the same ease that marked the birth of all its predecessors. That ease, for the records, is similar to nothing so much as the pulling of teeth.

I have read your editorial "Return From a Mission," commenting on Dr. Milton Eisenhower's trip through South America. The editorial considers the trip a success and comes to an end with this idea: "Probably the longest test of this success will come next March, when the Tenth Conference of American States convenes at Caracas.

ROBSTOWN, Tex., Aug. 29 (UP) -- Torrential rain and swollen creeks poured millions of gallons of water into Robstown today, and Lester Newell, police chief, said "99 and nine-tenths per cent of the city is under water."

TRENTON, Aug. 29 -- The promise of an all-out drive against all forms of gambling in New Jersey, made in April by the state's twenty-one county prosecutors after a conference here with Attorney General Theodore D. Parsons, appears to have been a meaningless gesture.

Harvey Breit, in "Ballade of the Sidewalk Cafe (Aug. 9) writes: "You will read only the Kafkan graces." On a neighboring page, in the article. "Rules for Writing to Camp Noosa Woosa," Emily Amber says, "Accept the fact that this is a somewhat Kafka-like correspondence."

LONG ISLAND soils are basically light and sandy. Such soils there and in other parts of the country do not maintain moisture and fertility readily. Nutrients leach out easily and the lawn suffers from any dry weather. It is wise to have a soil test made to determine the nutrient level of any soil, and particularly the sandy one.

TO say that I am horrowfied at your new book called "Sexual Behavior in the Human Femail" is really putting it mildly. For I am not only horrowfied at you and the cohorts who abetted you in interviewing those Femails but most of all I am horrowfied at the Femails you interrigated. And all I can say is that you have manadged to incounter 5,940 Human Femails who will never get anywheres.

VIOLATIONS of traffic statutes are one of the four leading manifestations of crime in this country, according to a summary of lawlessness by Chief Justice Arthur T. Vanderbilt of the Supreme Court of New Jersey, president of the Institute of Judicial Administrators.

FRASER, Colo., Aug. 29 -- President Eisenhower gave a coffee-and-doughnuts party for the White House reporters this afternoon, but 9-year-old Philip Sproul Warden became the life of the party. He received a lesson in fly casting from the President.

FORT SMITH, Ark. -- Perhaps because mention of the Ozarks often brings to mind the hillbilly caricatures of radio programs, this region of wooded hills, lakes and meandering streams is easily underrated as a vacationland by strangers.
EL PASO, Tex., Aug. 29 -- Even housewives are getting in the controversy over Mexican aliens who enter the United States illegally.

THE TIMES recently carried a letter of Harold J. Newman on the question of "stabilizing" the Middle East. I should like to present a few observations which his statements have provoked on the subject.

MR. C. L. SULZBERGER in reviewing "My Europe" by Sir Robert Bruce Lockhart starts off thus: "Sir Robert Bruce Lockhart is one of those not uncommon Britons (here he would indignantly interject 'I am a Scot') * * *"

LONDON, Aug. 29 -- The British Treasury announced tonight that some restrictions on Japanese imports into areas controlled by Britain would be relaxed to help Japan meet her growing shortage of sterling.

When the summer vacation ends next month, American schools and colleges will enroll a record number of pupils. A total of 36,949,700 students will enter classrooms and campuses, about 2,000,000 more than during the past academic year, Dr. Lee M. Thurston, recently appointed United States Commissioner of Education, reported last week.
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 29 (UP) -- The United States is prepared for atomic war if it is forced upon the nation, Lieut. Gen. Erle E. Partridge, Air Force Deputy Chief of Staff, said here today.

WESTPORT, Conn., Aug. 29 -Kate Kimball of Fairfield, Conn., and her 9-year-old chestnut mare, Golden Lady, took both of the junior Olympic events at the two-day fourteenth junior horse show of the Fairfield County Hunt Club, which ended today.

LILIAN WELLES, the Vicar's only daughter, motherless since birth, is in Paris, working as governess to a younger French girl. Roger Burnett, Lilian's fiance, has just returned home to England after a four year's absence on business in South America.

FREEDOM VILLAGE, Korea, Sunday, Aug. 30 -- A word picture of the Tiger, a North Korean major who is personally responsible for the death of ninety-six United States soldiers, was drawn today by a group of released sergeants captured in the earliest days of the Korean war.
LONDON, Aug. 29 (AP) -- Russian salesmen are bidding for a share of the Western oil market. Their current campaign indicates the Soviet bloc is ready to export about 2,000,000 tons annually.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 (UP) -- An investigator for the Senate Commerce Committee said today there was an "interstate conspiracy of allarming proportions" to restrict the sale of krebiozen, a controversial cancer draug, and the American Medical Association might be involved.

LEOPOLDVILLE, Belgian Congo, Aug. 26 -- The great air base and military base at Kamina in the Central Congo, now nearing completion, is intended to be an alternate air crossroads for Belgium and her allies and an air relay transport base route toward the Indian Ocean if, in case of war, the North African coast route is denied them, a representative of the Belgian Ministry of war said today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 (UP) -- An official of the Civil Aeronautics Board said today that some feeder-line airports, particularly in mountain areas, might have to lengthen their runways or lighten plane loads by Oct. 1.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- Mrs. Charles P. Howard, acting Civil Defense Administrator, urged today greatly increased "down-to-earth, home-by-home" civil defense protection through a "family action program."

CARMEL, Calif. -- The road turns off at a place called Wild Cat Hill. One has been to Monterey, thence down along the coastline of the Pacific to Point Lobos, unique state park and inspiring symbol of a photographer's single-minded devotion to an ideal.

THE world would have lost little, it always seems to me, if the secret had not been divulged, or if the reader had been permitted to discover his own analogies: for the chief qualities of "Ulysses" are the un-Homeric ones of urbanism and urbanity.

AT age 41 Digby P. Ross II finds the world -- in Mr. Wordsworth's phrase -- too much with him. Late and soon, getting and spending, as head of a huge American construction company, he feels that he is laying waste his powers.

I WAS surprised to find the ever-recurring dispute about the authorship of the distich, "Either be a whole or join one" even in the columns of the Book Review. Your reviewer T. V. Smith assigned it to Goethe. One correspondent called him on it and assigned it to Schiller, whereupon another wrote to say correctly that "Goethe said it too."

ALBANY, Aug. 29 -- New York State Troopers, who since 1917 have staggered in winter and perspired in summer in uniforms that were designed for cavalry operations now long extinct, are due for a sartorial change.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 29 -- Another hard struggle over the role that India is to play in United Nations affairs is in prospect when the 1953 session of the General Assembly convenes Sept. 15. Mme. Vijaya Lakshmi Pandit, the sister of India's Prime Minister, Jawaharlal Nehru, will be a candidate for President of the Assembly, and this time the United States will support India.

AMONG the Central European festivals, Munich's offers the greatest operatic variety. For the visitor curious as to what goes on in the German theatre, it provides the most instructive cross-section of productions, conductors and singers.
CARTERET, N. J., Aug. 29 (AP) -- The whole borough turned out today for a warm, colorful welcome to one of its sons who returned this week after twenty-eight months in a Red prison camp in Korea.

WE quoted last week in this column the remark of Henry W. Simon that the libretto of "Otello," which Arrigo Boito fashioned from Shakespeare's drama for Verdi, was the finest opera libretto that an Italian ever had.

Two new models have been opened in the Bar Harbour colony on Merrick Road in MassapequaPark L.I., where 650 dwellings are 'planned for the 220-acre peninsular community which was opened last fall. Six models of ranch, colonial, split-level and contemporary i homes are now offered in the development at prices starting at $20,000. I One of the new models, designed bY Matern York, architects, is {priced at $21,990.

" MA seconde calamiteuse" was the poor cobbler of Cairo's epithet for his second spouse in Rabaud's delightful opera "Marouf." The Princess Carolyne zu Sayn-Wittgenstein was Liszt's seconde calamiteuse, the first having been the Countess Marie d'Agoult, by whom he had had three children, Daniel, Blandine and the famous Cosima.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 29 -- Two months from now, according to the deadline just fixed by the General Assembly, the nineteen nations that fought in Korea, plus the Soviet Union, which was the arsenal of the Communist forces, will be hard at work negotiating a final peace settlement for that war-torn peninsula.

The Korean conflict being more than three years old, a sizable number of veterans have been mustered out of service and back to civilian life. For many this is an opportunity to continue higher education -- or begin it for the first time.

LONDON, Aug. 29 -- The British Government intends to establish a new television service to compete with the British Broadcasting Corporation, Earl de la Warr, Postmaster General, said today in a speech at Mottram.

THE majority of home lawns are in better condition than usual at this time of year. For although summer rainfall has not been above average in the Northeast, it has arrived at opportune times, and this, plus the occasional cool spells, has permitted lawns to hold their own during the hot season.

LIKE a botanist strolling through the countryside culling his specimens and classifying them neatly, side by side. Hugh Seton-Watson in "From Lenin to Malenkov" ranges all over the world, seeking out and classifying the similarities or differences which modern Communist movements display.
DENVER, Aug. 29 -- Gold, once Colorado's principal product, has slipped far down the list while oil and uranium rank one-two as the state's chief yields from soil and rock.

AS in his preceding volume on trees of eastern and central North America, Donald Culross Peattie takes a middle course in this book between brevity and encyclopedic completeness. He covers the half continent of varied trees and forests between the Pacific Ocean and the eastern edge of the Great Plains, the Arctic Ocean and the Mexican boundary.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Aug. 29 -- Prof. James A. Reyniers, founder and director of the University of Notre Dame's Lobund Institute, will leave Friday for Europe on a six-week tour of ten countries, during which he will report to scientists on germ-free research in progress at the institute.

Veterans of the premium producing business are jubilant. While they have been making a strong comeback since World War II they now envision a sharp rise in business as a result of the widely predicted upturn in the buyers' market.

Many Americans who never could afford fine china have placed it on their family tables since the end of World War II and their purchases have aided considerably in the economic recovery of Japan. Last week Alfred Funabashi, vice president of American Commercial, Inc., said this happy situation could not last if proposals to increase the tariff on imports of Japanese china dinnerware were adopted.

RANGOON, Burma, Aug. 29 -- H. Inagaki, leader of the Japanese trade mission now in Burma, is understood to have offered to sign a bilateral trade agreement with the Burmese Government and to have invited Rangoon to name its minimum terms for a peace treaty with Japan.

THERE are several good things to be said for Mary Stolz's "Truth and Consequence." The characters are believable and the situations in which they find themselves are convincing. The dialogue is excellent.

THE leveling-off process is in full swing Employment, national gross product, and consumer disposable income reached their peaks early this month. For the months ahead, they are not likely to point upward, but will either remain level or point slightly downward.

A WORLD Travel Photographic Awards amateur contest, with a grand prize of a trip around the world by air, is announced by The Saturday Review. The purpose of the awards, according to the weekly, "is to encourage public understanding of the unique pleasure and cultural values to be found in both travel and photography."

ELIZABETH, N. J., Aug. 29 -- The New Jersey Turnpike Authority is making "voluntary contributions" to the city each time the city's fire department answers a pike call here, the authority has advised the Board of Fire Commissioners.

IT will be news to a great many people, as it was to me, that the best-known woman in America in the Eighteen Eighties was Frank Leslie. In the first place, I had always thought that Frank Leslie, whose Frank Leslie's Illustrated Newspaper preceded our modern tabloids by sixty-five years or so, was a man.

PEOPLE in possession of old and valued antiques need not shy away from contemporary furnishings as the two apartments illustrated on these pages indicate. In both cases, the owners, as do most families today, had a certain amount of traditional furniture. When they moved, it became necessary to replace some pieces that were worn with age, and add others.

The nation's quicksilver producers are beginning to get that uneasy feeling again. Prices of the lustrous liquid metal have been falling for eight months. The market has been consistently slow. And no new major use has been developed lately to take up the slack of gradually declining consumption in several fields, notably agriculture and the pharmaceutical, electrical and paint industries.

UNTIL 1947 a major in the economic directorate of the Soviet Military Administration in Berlin, Gregory Klimov has given a well-written and convincing account of his experiences in the Soviet Army and of its control system in Eastern Germany.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 29 -- Federal Bureau of Investigation agents scoured the rugged mountain country northwest of Yosemite National Park today for "at least one more" suspect in their roundup of Communist conspirators.

A quarter of a century ago and more, when the Steinach operation and the transplantation of chimpanzee glands to men had a vogue, the more romantic physiologists were certain that the way to restore youth to the aged had been found. Some remarkable results were recorded, but in the end the conservatives decided that sex hormones alone would not realize a dream of rejuvenation thousands of years old.
FRASER, Colo., Aug. 29 -- President Eisenhower is here among the peaks, enjoying a vacation away from his vacation in Denver.

THE HAGUE, The Netherlands, Aug. 10 -- Those who have the Dutch typed as a staid and conservative people had better have another look, and quickly too. This country of 10,000,000 population is in an acute stage of helicopter mania, with loud cries rising from al lover the landscape demanding more and more of the strange, ungainly aircraft.

BURLINGTON, Vt., Aug. 29 -- A University of Vermont Board of Review ruled early tonight that Dr. Alex B. Novikoff, a biochemist, was guilty of "conduct which justifies his dismissal" on charges arising from his refusal to discuss his activities prior to his joining the faculty in 1948.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- Post Office officials are puzzled over whether the Department should continue to investigate alleged abuses of the government franking privilege by members of Congress now that both Houses will pay for mail service.

RUDOLF BING announced in the spring that he was restoring "Faust," "Tannhaeuser" and "The Barber of Seville" to the repertory of the Metropolitan Opera during the 1953-54 season. Later it was learned that one of the works Pierre Monteux would conduct would be a revival of Debussy's "Pelleas et Melisande."

America's school children must have opportunities to learn in school the reasons for and the methods of this country's policy of international cooperation through such agencies as the United Nations and UNESCO, the Educational Policies Commission declares in a report outlining educational policy for the nation's schools.
NORRIS, Tenn., Aug. 29 -- A large segment of this government workers' hamlet is up for sale again, and the 1,100 residents are hopeful that this time they can buy it and call the town their own.

Gamma Globulin (GG) is a minute fraction in the blood rich in antibodies -- the organisms that resist disease. For years it has been used in vaccination against measles and jaundice. Last year tests showed that GG injections in many cases conferred temporary immunity against infantile paralysis (poliomyelitis).

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 29 (UP) -- Paul Minner, aided by a late extra-base barrage by his teammates, pitched a six-hitter today to beat Robin Roberts in a hurling duel as the Cubs blanked the Phillies, 2 -- 0.

Designed to overcome the difficulties faced by the small or medium-sized business in providing benefits for workers comparable to those of larger concerns, a new type of insurance policy has recently been introduced to solve their problem.

With a view to creating incentive and to retaining the services of business executives and other personnel, many industrial corporations in recent years have offered inducements in the form of stock options to acquire ownership in the corporate employer.

WITH the Joseph Fields-Jerome Chodorov book for "The Girl in Pink Tights" now safely locked in the vault and only Leo Robin's lyrics to the late Sigmund Romberg's score still to come, producer Shepard Traube is enjoying the breezes off Fire Island these days and rosily contemplating his immediate future.

ATHENS, Aug. 29 -- Diplomatic circles in Athens expressed surprise today over what appeared to be an attack on the Greek Government by the Yugoslav semi-official news agency Yugopress and declared that it must have been made with the knowledge of the Yugoslav Government if not its endorsement.

PARIS, Aug. 29 -- Mme. Jacqueline Auriol, 36-year-old daughter-in-law of the President of France, today became the second woman flier to break the sound barrier when she dived her French Mystere II jet fighter at 687.5 miles an hour.
LONDON, Aug. 29 (AP) -- Rain held attendance to a total of 850,000 at the forty-six English League soccer matches today, but the fans were treated to a feast of goals.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 29 -- Significant obstacles loomed for the first time this week in the path of the illegal immigration over the nation's southwestern border which has been in progress, at a rate of hundreds of thousands of persons a year, for a decade.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- With Congress in adjournment and President Eisenhower in the Rockies on an extended vacation, a series of Presidential and Congressional commissions and committees has taken on the task of formulating the basic policies and programs by which this Administration will be judged initially by the voters and ultimately by history.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- Despite the truce in Korea and the reduction in the size of the Army because of budget cuts, draftees now in service and those to be called in the coming months will apparently serve the full twenty-four months to which they are obligated by law.

DURING a recent visit to Washington, Bernard M. Baruch, who has been an acute observer of, if not an active partner in, so many Presidencies, talked with various high officials of the Eisenhower Administration, Several times the same question was put to him in almost the same words: "How can we get a good press?"

JANE NICKERSON'S review of "Food to Make You Famous," by Mary Hill and Irene Radcliffe, complains that "in one recipe sour cream is cooked at a temperature almost certain to curdle it," and "that the recipes are a bit tearoomy."
The Metropolitan Golf Association thirty-six-hole sectional qualifying round for the United States amateur golf championship will be held Tuesday on the Baltusrol links in Springfield, N. J.
IAN NIALL is best remembered in this country for "No Resting Place," that unusual first novel about Irish tinkers, which was subsequently made into a good movie.

YONKERS, Aug. 29 -- The finale of the Yonkers Raceway summer meeting drew a crowd of 22,690 tonight as the featured $5,500 Blue Mountain trot went to Queen's Joy. The mare, owned by Mrs. Catherine Peters of Schuylkill Haven, Pa., scored her third straight victory by a half-length over Emerson Hanover.

Now that irresponsible and incompetent concerns have been kept from bidding for Queens sewer contracts, many new contractors have become interested in public works projects in that borough and "bids are far more competitive," James A. Lundy, Borough President of Queens, said yesterday.

ONE thing about the United Nations -- the tourists love the place. Come war talk, peace talk, big-meeting day, no-meeting day, the sight-seers are always lined up waiting to see the sights, the most popular of which, of course, are the Russians.

BONN, Germany, Aug. 29 -- West German frontier police have detained within the last forty-eight hours nearly 500 East German youths trying to enter West Germany by train at Helmstedt and confiscated from them more than 60,000 West German marks and large quantities of Communist propaganda material, reports from Hanover said today.
Armed with rules intended to eliminate, the controversial two platoons system, most major college football teams begin practice Tuesday for perhaps the most interest-arousing season in recent years.
THE contract bridge scoring table is so constituted that it is very "cheap" to sacrifice against an opposing grand slam contract, especially when the sacrificing side is not vulnerable.

THE 1,300-mile rail journey south of the border to Mexico City can now be made in a train comparable to American streamliners, with the added feature of shower baths in coaches as well as Pullmans. Last Thursday the National Railways of Mexico began operation of

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 29 (AP) -Steve Bilko batted across two runs with a fly ball and his seventeenth homer of the year, and Rip Repulski clouted his fourteenth round-tripper to pace the Cardinals to a 5-4 victory today over the last-place Pirates. The victory moved the Cards into third place by 1 percentage point over the Phillies. The loss was the Pirates' seventh straight.

MAYS LANDING, N. J., Aug. 29 -- Miss Joanne, owned by James M. Grieve, won the first running of the $24,050 Miss America Turf Stakes at the Atlantic City race course today. A crowd of 24,988 saw the New England racer rally in the closing stages to capture the feature offering for 3-year-old fillies by two - and - a - quarter lengths.
John A. Klugherz, general manager of the Plaza Hotel, dropped fourteen floors to his death at the hotel shortly after noon yesterday.

ATLANTIC CITY, Aug. 29 -- Thirty-one men and nine women were arrested today in a series of raids by Federal, state and county police capping two months of undercover work on peddlers and users of narcotics.

ALTHOUGH it is a little early to state without indulging in some fancy qualifying that Hollywood has lost its enthusiasm for 3-D, it is becoming increasingly evident that a considerable number of the more influential producers and directors, not to overlook front office executives in the studios, now are less inclined to look upon this technique as the catholicon it appeared to represent as recently as two months ago.

Scoring five runs in each of the third and seventh innings, the Dodgers routed the Redlegs, 10 -- 3, yesterday and extended their league lead to ten and a half games as the Braves lost, 4 -- 1, to the Giants, who were mathematically eliminated from the pennant race despite their victory.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- Senator Lyndon B. Johnson, the Texas Democrat now minority leader of the Senate, today called the first session of the Republican-controlled Eighty-third Congress "a shakedown cruise" that had "retreated" on many occasions.

GLEN COVE, L. I., Aug. 29 -- Displaying a brand of improved tennis, Tony Trabert, Davis Cup star from Cincinnati, today won the Nassau Bowl invitation grass-court tournament at the Nassau Country Club.

THE ex-P. O. W. publishing his World War II escape story in 1953 has several strikes against him. The fantastic brutalities committed by the Communists since 1945 in Eastern Europe and Korea make the average German P. O. W. camp (for Western officers, at least) seem mild by comparison. And if the ex-P. O. W. also happens to be a former Etonian and Oxonian, then his story might easily be a crashing bore.

BERLIN, Aug. 29 -- As a result of the June uprising in East Germany, the Soviet Union has increased its aid to that region to the equivalent of about $3,000,000,000, according to Walter Ulbricht, East German's Deputy Premier and perhaps most influential Communist.

WHEN Tiberio Peratoner, an Italian peasant living in the south Carpic Alps, digs a well on his barren hillside, he strikes not precious water but a seep of raw petroleum. Realizing the nature of his find, yet at odds with his village officials, he has nowhere to turn -- and no one to trust but Harry Lucas, an English writer living in seclusion near by.

TOKYO, Sunday, Aug. 30 -- The Communists officially informed the joint Prisoner-of-War Repatriation Commission meeting at Panmunjom yesterday that all United Nations captives of the Korean fighting who chose repatriation would be returned, including men sentenced to prison terms for real or fabricated offenses in North Korean stockades.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- A three-point program to re-employ thousands of displaced career Government workers through the release of temporary workers has been suggested to the chairman of the Civil Service Commission by Representative Edward H. Rees, Republican of Kansas, chairman of the House of Representatives Committee on Post Office and Civil Service.
CHICAGO, Aug. 29 (UP) -- Brush Burn, an 8-to-1 shot, held off a thrilling stretch run by favored Ruhe today and won the $67,500 Meadowland Handicap at Washington Park.
