Three important American engineering groups will be represented at the fourth biennial gathering of the Europe-United States Engineering Conference, to be held in Paris for five days beginning on Labor Day. The conferees will take up matters of procedure in the cooperative program among engineers of the two areas.

THE review by Kenneth Rexroth of the poems of "Holderlin" as translated by Michael Hamburger contained this sentence, "Goethe and Schiller looked on him as a comic and embarrassing oddity. Today his poetry has more to say to the contemporary mind than all their vast and sometimes banal accomplishments."

RIVERSIDE, Conn., Aug. 29 -- John C. Snedeker, 26-year-old Starboat sailor from Bellport Bay Y. C. and representative of the Great South Bay Y. R. A., won the semifinal match-race series of the men's North American sailing championship off the Riverside Yacht Club today and will represent Area 3 in the finals for the Mallory Cup, which begin Sept. 22 at Larchmont Y. C.

HAMBURG, Germany, Aug. 29 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer's invasion of Social Democratic strongholds in North Germany this week-end has demonstrated that the Germans of 1953 are prepared to accept strong and decisive leadership rather than issues as their criteria.

THE themes of Paul Colin, that sanity and health came out of the earth and that order can be born in men's lives only if it reigns in their hearts, are certainly not new. Yet the fictional presentation this paradoxical writer gives his material is way above the treatment usually meted out to such cliches.

STOCKHOLM, Aug. 29 -- Tommy Kono of Oakland, Calif., won the world middleweight weightlifting championship today with a record hoist totaling 408.5 kilograms (about 898.7 pounds) to give the United States its second individual title.

Each evening at dusk refugee mothers with their sick children still line up quietly before the Maryknoll Sisters clinic in Pusan so -- they may be among 2,000 patients to be seen the next day. The Republic of Korea Army hospitals are still crowded with 20,000 disabled men whose definitive care has been completed but who cannot be discharged as they have no place to go.
WETHERSFIELD, Conn., Aug. 29 (UP) -- A three-way tie today posed the possibility of a play-off in the annual $15,000 Insurance City open golf tournament.

On Sunday afternoon, June 25, 1950, the United Nations Security Council was called into emergency session to consider a Communist invasion across the Thirty-eighth Parallel on a remote peninsula on the eastern coast of Asia. Ever since that fateful day the future of Korea has been the one great question before the principal political bodies of the U. N.

PARIS -- Tourists, United States or otherwise, who came during the past three weeks for a tour of colorful, exciting France got a little more than they bargained for. They ran head-on into the worst labor trouble this country has experienced since the war, and the result was that a confused and uncertain time was had by all.

SANTA FE, N. M. -- September, with its traditional quota of interesting events for visitors in the Southwest, will start off auspiciously in Santa Fe. Next Saturday the local list of attractions will be augmented with the formal opening of the new Museum of International Folk Art high on a pinon-studded hill two miles from the town's three-century-old plaza.

IT seems incredible that it was only a scant fifty years ago that two unknown bicycle manufacturers from Dayton, Ohio, lifted a rickety motorized contraption from the lonely sand dunes of Kitty Hawk, kept it in the air for twelve seconds and thus fulfilled a dream that had been haunting mankind for centuries.

LIMA, Peru, Aug. 11 -- A warm debate is taking place in the columns of the newspaper La Prensa over the activities of the Summer Linguistic Institute, affiliated with the University of Oklahoma, which has been accused by the Franciscan Bishop of Ucayali of using its linguistic activities to mask a campaign to convert the Indians in the Amazon jungle to Protestantism.

SANDUSKY, Ohio, Aug. 29 (AP) -- J. James Roosevelt's Old Crow of Oyster Bay, L. I., held a commanding lead today after the third race of the national sailing championship of the Raven Class Association on Sandusky Bay.

Lulu Perez, 20-year-old boxer from Brooklyn who is considered one of the most outstanding featherweights to make his appearance since Willie Pep. is expected to face the most difficult assignment of his career at Madison Square Garden next Friday.

NO age group makes the front pages of newspapers as consistently as teen-agers. Their shortcomings and peccadillos are continually reported to the world. What the adolescent is striving toward and what he needs to help him in his quest are less often discussed in public.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 29 (AP) -- The Government is planning to release some of its ultra-modern, high-speed "Mariner" cargo vessels to American shipping companies to enable them the better to meet rising competition from foreign merchant fleets.

Frustrated by internal rivalries among anti-Soviet exile groups, the leading United States organization seeking to unite these groups for a common struggle against the Soviet dictatorship has decided to end its subsidies and other support hitherto given to these organizations.

The Patent Office, which used to be one of the few profit-making agencies of the Federal Government, has of late years been losing money. In obedience to the Administration's general order to reduce costs the Commissioner of Patents, aided and abetted by Secretary of Commerce Sinclair Weeks, would raise the fees that applicants for patents must pay.

PARIS, Aug. 29 -- Following a series of conferences among Cabinet Ministers over the problems raised in France by the recent wave of strikes, Edgar Faure, the Finance Minister, announced today that a drive would start next week to bring down prices for essential living costs and food.

With the industry already concerned over the maintenance of orderly distribution of the world's crude oil production, which is at a peak level, the absorption by present markets of an additional flow of 700,000 barrels a day of petroleum from the Iranian wells may prove difficult and may even cause serious price disturbances.

TEHERAN, Iran, Aug. 29 -- A minor flare-up of Tudeh (Communist) party violence in Teheran early this morning was followed by a new Government warning to the populace against participation, active or passive, in any form of street demonstration.

Back in the Nineteen Twenties rumors were going the rounds in the Montgomery Ward catalogue office in Kansas City that some employes were to be laid off. Paul E. Connor, whose job with the big mail order house was correspondent answering customers' complaints, fearing the worst, began paying increasing attention to the help-wanted advertisements.

THE old saying that "every day the sun rises there is a fiesta in Mexico" has at last been officially documented with the publication by the Mexican Government of a 143-page booklet listing every traditional celebration in the country, from the big national holidays to village fairs.

CONCERT HALL has just released seventh series of limited editions. As in previous years this series consists largely of off-beat items from the seventeenth century to the present, and the disks are not available to non-subscribers.

A constituent assembly on Dec. 31, 1925, elected Reza Khan Pahlevi Shah of Persia and decreed that the crown of Darius should be hereditary in his family. The present Shah, son of Reza Khan, according to the law of the land, inherits the crown of Darius, which, if the title is allowed, makes him the heir to an older throne than any now extant in Europe.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- Representative Louis B. Heller, Democrat of Brooklyn, asked the Post Office Department today to bar from the mails the forthcoming book, "Sexual Behavior in the Human Female," by Dr. Alfred C. Kinsey, pending a Congressional investigation of its text. The book is scheduled for publication Sept. 14.

Robert Malloy, 41 years old, was fined $25 in Felony Court yesterday on a disorderly conduct charge involving another man and a 19-year-old youth. He described himself as an administrator of New York Hospital.
CHICAGO, Aug. 29 -- The White Sox beat the Red Sox and southpaw Mel Parnell, 5 to 1, today, halting a ninth-inning Boston threat with a triple play.

LONDON, Aug. 29 -- A campaign to rehabilitate the memory of the man generally regarded as England's wickedest King, Richard III, has been begun by a group of Britons, The Company of Memories, headed by Dr. Eugene Horsfall-Ertz, tutor at the Colebrook School, Bognor Regis, Sussex.

It takes an average of four years and five months for a civil case to reach a jury in Brooklyn Supreme Court from the time the case is marked "at issue." In New York County Supreme Court the average time lag is three years and seven months; in Queens County Supreme Court it is three and a half years.

Interest in fall merchandise brought heavy reorders to the wholesale markets here last week, resident buying offices reported. The unusually large sportswear orders have caused delivery delays on many lines with leather items tightest.

EARLY fall is the best time of year for the making of lawns. This timing is recommended by turf experts in all parts of the country from the mild climate of the South to the more rigorous one of New England. The cool nights and warm days of autumn are ideal for stimulating growth of the better perennial grasses.
MONTREAL, Aug. 29 -- Don Cherry of Dallas rallied to win the Canadian amateur golf championship today with a 1-up victory over Don Doe, a tobacco company accountant from Granby, Que.

CHICAGO, Aug. 29 -- Retail trade here has taken a definite downturn and retailers are uncertain whether to blame it on the record August heat, the later date for Labor Day, or a growing uneasiness over reports of lay-offs of factory workers in other cities.

UNITED NATIONS, New York, Aug. 29 -- Scientific surveys to discover additional underground water sources in Israel have already contributed materially to progress in that country, Dr. Albert G. Black reported today. Dr. Black, head of the mission of the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization in Israel, leaves by plane tomorrow to resume his post after home leave in Stanton, Va.

IN maybe an impishly envious mood Sir Max Beerbohm once told Cecil Roberts, "What fun to be you!" It was hardly a compliment the recipient himself would have echoed during much of 1950, the year honored in the title of this diary, which records his peregrinations through Western Europe, Britain and Manhattan.

THERE is nothing more fascinating to the average American small boy than machinery in action. His curiosity about it is indefatigable, his admiration boundless. Two new picture books will give him a great deal of pleasure.

LONDON, Aug. 29 -- The British airman, A. V. Rigden, whose disappearance from a hotel in Ismailia July 9 caused a British-Egyptian crisis, has turned up alive and well in Britain. But the Air Ministry declined tonight to explain how he got here or say whether he had actually been kidnapped by Egyptians, as the Commander in Chief of the British forces in the Suez Canal zone had charged.

GREENWICH, Conn., Aug 29 -- A record-high town budget of more than $9,200,000, providing for the construction of a $2,000,000 junior high school, has been drafted for 1954 by the two-man budget committee of the Greenwich Board of Estimate and Taxation.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- The Soviet Union rejected today an invitation by the three Western powers to attend a meeting of deputy foreign ministers that had been scheduled to open in London Monday to take up the long-pending Austrian state treaty.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 29 -- Dr. Radenko Stankovic, one of the three pre-war Regents of Yugoslavia, has been released after eight years of imprisonment, it was learned today. He is now 73 years old, partly paralyzed and barely coherent in expression.

CATCHING upon on the catches: The forthcoming international tuna match off Wedgeport, N. S., should be a record one if the season run that has resulted so far in eighty-one catches continues. Fifteen were taken in six days from Aug. 17 to Aug. 22. Among the lucky anglers were Stuart Dreier of New Brunswick, N. J., 572-pounder in 1 hour 25 minutes; Louis C. Rambone, Vineland, N. J., 295-pounder in 40 minutes; Herman Calodin,

WHAT Edwin Arlington Robinson called "the worst loafing place in the world" is currently the workshop for one of the most brilliant groups of creative artists in its forty-six-year history. Even veterans of the MacDowell Colony in Peterborough, N. H., are unable to put a precise finger on the alchemy which makes it unique.

LONDON, Aug. 29 -- R. A. Butler, Chancellor of the Exchequer, declared today that Britain must speak her own mind and follow her own line in international affairs, but at the same time keep "in sympathy and in step" with the United States.

FLINT, Mich., Aug. 29 -- Operation Tornado, this city's voluntary effort in mutual assistance, was off to a brave start today as 5,500 men and boys raised fresh timbers on 193 houses to replace those destroyed or damaged in the tornado of June 8.
DETROIT, Aug. 29 (UP) -- Jackie Jensen got two hits in four times at bat and drove in three runs to lead the Senators to a 7-to-2 victory over the Tigers in Briggs Stadium today.

TULSA, Oklahoma, Aug. 29 (UP) -- Oil production in the United States and the rest of the free world was almost ten times that of the Soviet Union and the other Communist nations during June, the Oil and Gas Journal reported today.

LONG BRANCH, N. J., Aug. 29 -- Danny Ardolino, West Long Branch, captured the national championship for Jersey speed skiffs today by driving his Jo-Carol-Too to a decisive two-heat triumph, highlight of the fourth annual Long Branch inboard regatta at Pleasure Bay, Shrewsbury River.

EACH of the two main offerings of this year's Edinburgh Festival is an event in itself. A new comedy by T. S. Eliot and a new young Hamlet with the Old Vic Company to support him -- it is not likely that the forthcoming London season will have anything more exciting to show than these.

A 141-PAGE report on the "activities of the Federal Government in the field of art" is now lying on the President's desk. It was prepared by the federal Commission of Fine Arts and contains a survey and recommendations.

VERY few of the ladies who pass in these pages were lovable, but that was the small price they paid for their boldness. Each in her own way proved the good sense of the adage: Hell hath no fury like a woman with an idea. Not all their ideas have stood time's test, like, for example, the water cure and free-love notions of Mary Gove Nichols.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 (UP) -- The Congress of Industrial Organizations charged today that "millions of citizens" were not getting a fair voice in Congress and state Legislatures because of the present system of electing representatives.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 29 -- A study of each spouse's responsibility to self, to partner and to their children was recommended today to the meeting of the National Federation of Catholic College Students by its National Commission on Family Life.
A detailed picture of what the Korean truce and the uneasy state of the world generally is doing to the economy was drawn yesterday by a group representing the country's purchasing agents.

PLANS are nearing completion for the screen version of John Steinbeck's widely acclaimed novel, "East of Eden," it was learned last week, with a shooting script now being penned at the Newtown, Conn., home of Paul Osborn, the playwright and, of course, an established scenarist as well.

CAIRO, Aug. 29 -- Gen. Sir Brian Robertson, military member of the British team negotiating with Egypt on the future status of the Suez Canal military base, will leave Cairo for London at the end of next week, a British Embassy spokesman announced tonight.

Viscount Montgomery of Alamein has turned a phrase from time to time in his colorful career and he has never turned a better one than when he described Canada as a "hinge of pure gold" between the Old World and the New. He applauded the Commonwealth ties and at the same time urged upon Canadians the development of their own unique culture.

With Securities and Exchange Commission approval, the New York Stock Exchange will put into effect tomorrow a new method of marketing big blocks of slow-moving stocks. It is intended to win back for the Exchange some of the lucrative business taken in recent years by the over-the-counter market.
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 29 (UP) -The Los Angeles Rams loomed as a top professional gridiron threat today after trouncing the Cleveland Browns, 27 to 9, in an exhibition game at Memorial Coliseum.

GUAYAQUIL, Ecuador, Aug. 29 -- Jose Maria Velasco Ibarra is rounding out his first year as President of Ecuador in an uneasy situation in which there is a confused and obscure struggle between moderate and extremist elements for dominance in the country.

DEL MAR, Calif., Aug. 29 (UP) -- Frosty Dawn, a 19-to-1 shot, outgamed the odds-on favorite. Lady Cover Up, in the stretch today to win the third running of the $30,250 Del Mar Debutante Stakes for 2-year-old fillies.
Rabbi Louis I. Newman advised yesterday that the United Nations proceed cautiously with any plan to revise its charter.

Federal authorities charged with the distribution of gamma globulin, the polio preventive, turned down a request yesterday by the New York State Health Department for additional supplies of the scarce blood fraction and suggested that the department use its supplies "as deemed necessary."

BONN, Germany, Aug. 29 -- If and when a four-power conference is held on the subject of Germany the Western Allies according to information in diplomatic quarters here, will be prepared to discuss security safeguards for the Soviet Union in the event of Germany's reunification.

In 1807 Britain published decrees known as "Orders in Council" which prohibited free trade with France or her allies. Much injury resulted to American commerce. Every American ship became liable to capture.

Stanley Sayres, the gray-haired Seattle auto dealer who holds the world record for speed boats at 178.497 miles an hour, has started his Slo-Mo-Shun V eastward and it is due to arrive in Detroit this week-end for the long-indicated barnstorming tour of Eastern regattas.

BEDFORD HILLS, N. Y., Aug. 29 -- Automobile travel between New York and western New England will be speeded with the completion of the Saw Mill River Parkway in northern Westchester County, engineers said today. Begun thirty years ago at the Bronx-Westchester boundary, the parkway has crept northward to Mount Kisco, will reach to Bedford Hills this autumn, and reach its terminus at Katonah by the end of next year.

The heat and the calendar slowed department store volume last week. Business was poor early in the week as the sultry weather kept purchasers at home. Yesterday had been expected to add traffic and volume with many stores resuming Saturday openings, but the hot weather again was a deterrent.

Meeting for the first time in a Great Lakes port, the Propeller Club of the United States will hold its twenty-seventh annual convention in Cleveland this year. The four-day meeting, which is being held in conjunction with the club-sponsored American Merchant Marine Conference, will begin on Sept. 21.

Dr. Sidney Dressler, medical director, and Dr. Gardner Middlebrook, director of research and laboratories, of the National Jewish Hospital, Denver, Colo., have a pilot program for getting patients with tuberculosis out of bed months ahead of current practice while they are treated with isonicotinic acid hydrazide.

MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 29 -- Building activity in the Ninth Federal Reserve District continued to run ahead of last year's pace through July, the Minneapolis Reserve Bank reported. Value of building permits in eighty-two cities of the district was $28,945,340 in July, a gain of more than $3,000,000 over last year.

THE sixth of the annual festivals of modern dance sponsored by Connecticut College at New London made a new record this year, both in the number of students enrolled in the six-week summer school and for attendance at the five professional performances in the Palmer Auditorium.
NYACK, N. Y., Aug. 29 -- Nyack merchants and officials opened a campaign today aimed at obtaining easy access to the New York Thruway, both east and west, from this area.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Aug. 29 -- For the first time in its 270 years as a county, Westchester will add higher education to its tax-supported functions on Tuesday when it begins to operate the new Westchester Community College, successor to the State Institute of Applied Arts and Sciences here.

BOULDER, Colo., Aug. 29 -- This was payoff day for astronomers who have spent much energy in recent years in maintaining high-altitude observatories and in sending expedition to view total eclipses of the sun in far-away places.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 30 -- Columbia has lined up three members of the all-star cast that it is seeking for the musical version of "My Sister Eileen."
Three high officials of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, A. F. L., will try today to devise a formula for settling the eight-week-old strike of sand, gravel and concrete truck drivers.

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, Aug. 30 -- It is understood here that the budget deficit for 1954 is officially estimated at 600,000,000 to 800,000,000 guilders with expenditures topping the 6,000,000,000 level, as against the 5,600,000,000 originally estimated for 1953. The budget statement will be published on Sept. 15.

MOSCOW, Aug. 30 -- Moscow's new Red Square department store is going to have modified supermarket techniques and coin vending machines for certain items, Director A. V. Morgunov revealed in a statement to the newspaper Evening Moscow.

CAZENOVIA, N. Y., Aug. 30 -- Roy T. Black of Buffalo, a former state champion, defeated Jack W. Collins of Brooklyn, defending titleholder, in the first round of the annual tournament at the meeting of the New York State Chess Association today.

The Emerson Radio and Phonograph Corporation and its subsidiaries had a consildated net profit of $2,333,227 in the thirty-nine weeks ended Aug. 1, more than doubling the $1,005,359 earned in the corresponding period last year, according to the report to be issued to stockholders today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- The Bureau of Census reported today that the forty-eight states had collected a record $10,542,000,000 in taxes in the fiscal year 1953, which ended June 30.
WETHERSFIELD, Conn., Aug. 30 (AP) -- Bob Toski 126-pound golfer from Northampton, Mass., won the $15,000 Insurance City Open tournament today with a 15-under par 269 for seventy-two holes.
PELHAM MANOR, N. Y., Aug. 30 -- William H. Stanley's blue-hulled Bumble Bee continued to show the way in the International class in the New York Athletic Club's regatta on Long Island Sound today.

LONDON, Aug. 30 -- British official embarrassment increased and confusion became confounded today in the case of Leading Aircraftman A. V. Rigden, the 21-year-old Royal Air Force man who turned up unheralded in London last night when his family, and indeed the entire country, thought he was a prisoner of unidentified Egyptians who were alleged to have kidnapped him last month in the Suez Canal Zone.

Washington Heights civic, realty and political groups have appealed to the Mayor and the City Planning Commission to reject the Port Authority plan for traffic relief near the George Washington Bridge, contending that its limited program would add to traffic hazards.

The eleven members of the cast of "Porgy and Bess" who are known as the Allied Singers completed their four-concert series yesterday afternoon at Carl Fischer Concert Hall. The last three to appear were Howard Roberts, the tenor who sings Robins in the show, and two members of the chorus, Doris Galiber, mezzo soprano, and Charles Colman, baritone.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (UP) -- The National Grange endorsed today a new wheat support proposal in which prices would be high on grain used in this country and low on exports.
DENVER, Colo., Aug. 30 (UP) -- Mrs. Eisenhower, appearing refreshed and rested after three weeks of relaxation in her mother's home here, will make a few public appearances this week.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (AP) -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, said today he was asking the State Department to look deeper into the story of an alleged attempt by some of its employes to extort $150,000 from a friendly foreign government.

Standard forms of paper for handling realty transactions have been adopted by the New York Board of Title Underwriters, according to William H. Deatly, president, who said the forms were for distribution by member companies of the board.

OYSTER BAY, L. I., Aug. 30 -- Llanoria, Magnus Konow's white-hulled yacht, will represent the United States in the Seawanhaka International Cup six-meter match against an English yacht Sept. 13 to 17. This was determined today when the fast-moving sloop defeated the May Be VII, owned and skippered by William Horton of Wilmington, Calif., in two races on Long Island Sound.

CHICAGO, Aug. 30 -- The National Safety Council reported tonight that vacation motorists had driven a little more cautiously this summer. During May, June and July -- heavy vacation tour ing months -- highway fatalities dropped 1 per cent compared with the same three months last year.

The volume of ship charter business increased a bit last week but the rates were still at Death Valley levels, according to brokers who continued to describe the situation as bad, dull and listless and the market as "demoralized."

MOSCOW, Monday, Aug. 31 -- The Soviet Government, in a note delivered Aug. 26, advised the United States that it had no information regarding the fate of the members of the crew of the B-50 bomber that went down in the Japanese Sea July 29 after what the Russians called an exchange of fire with Soviet fighter planes.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (AP) -- The American Political Science Association today announced completion of an exhaustive study that may ultimately have an influence in bringing more uniformity to methods of selecting delegates to Presidential nominating conventions.

STOCKHOLM, Aug. 30 (AP) -- Russia outclassed the United States in their first athletic meeting since last year's Olympics by gaining the "best nation" title in the world weight-lifting championships today.
Seven new feature films, including three British-made imports and a Russian program, will open in first-run theatres this week. The schedule follows:

BERLIN, Aug. 30 -- On a rainy day in Berlin the queues at the stations where food parcels are distributed look particularly drab and damp. The crowds flocking to the Western sectors for free food -- about 3,000,000 to date -- constitute the largest sample of the population of the Eastern zone the West has yet seen, and the exhibit is very impressive.

The National Broadcasting Company announced yesterday that it would begin to experiment with on-the-air "color premieres" of its major television programs on Sept. 28, provided the Federal Communications Commission had approved the new compatible color system by that date.
MAMARONECK, N. Y., Aug. 30 -- Al Brosch of Cherry Valley tied Hampshire's competitive course record by firing a seven-under-par 30, 34 -- 64 in the club's fourth pro-member tournament today.

New York's Roman Catholics were warned from every pulpit in the archdiocese yesterday that a prayer book titled "The Secret of Happiness" did not have, as its publishers assert, the seal of approval of Cardinal Spellman.

Samuel Reshevsky, representing the United States among fifteen contenders in the world championship challengers' tournament, encountered Miguel Najdorf of Argentina, whom he had twice defeated in set matches, in the first round at Neuhausen last night, according to a report from Zurich, Switzerland.

EDINBURGH, Scotland, Aug. 30 -- The British motion picture of Nicholas Monsarrat's best-selling novel, "The Cruel Sea," was named here today as the winner of the David O. Selznick Golden Laurel for 1953.
TRUCKSVILLE, Pa., Aug. 30 (AP) -- Pierre Antoine Jean Boutaud de la Combe is a Frenchman who likes to fish.

The awarding of nineteen fellowships to scholars and artists in Latin America and the Philippine Islands was announced yesterday by the John Simon Guggenheim Memorial Foundation. The grants total $70,000 and are for studies in science, education and art.
Waistlines claim an important role in this season's silhouette trends. The severe lines of the sheath dress are interestingly diversified by the ascending or descending belt.
HANOVER, Germany, Aug. 30 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer wound up his North Country election campaign tour today in this city, which is the capital of the hotly contested state of Lower Saxony.

City Construction Coordinator Robert Moses made public yesterday a study of how so-called "areas of influence" in the neighborhoods of fifteen major public works projects had found their values increased by "millions" of dollars, far exceeding normal increases in other sections.

This is "Reopening Day" for horseplayers in the metropolitan area. The four-week race meeting at Saratoga Springs ended on Saturday, and the horses are back on Long Island -- where they'll stay for the final sixty-six days of New York's 196-day try-to-pick-the-winners campaign.

OTTAWA, Aug. 30 -- The success of the United States in blocking an invitation to India to participate in the Korean peace conference has been profoundly disturbing to Canadian public opinion. It has been disquieting, too, to the Government, which has the task of preserving this country's balance between the strong economic and strategic ties with the United States and its historic links with Britain, the Commonwealth and Western Europe.

An event that should be of educational importance to Westchester County for many generations will take place at White Plains tomorrow. The county will embark on its first venture in higher education by beginning to operate the new Westchester Community College, which will take the place of the successful but short-lived New York State Institute of Applied Arts and Sciences.

If they had any regard for the public interest and for the obligations of collective bargaining the leaders of Teamsters Local 282 will voluntarily submit the eight-weeks-old strike of Concrete Mix drivers to arbitration. They can do so before Tuesday, the deadline set by Dave Beck, president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, in his ultimatum to the local.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 30 -- Settlement of the eleven-day strike against the Southwestern Bell Telephone Company's six-state system appeared likely tonight as committees representing management and the union continued negotiations.

Revival of a "Made in U. S. A." trade mark developed after World War I was advocated here yesterday by Jim Nash, industrial designer. The design was registered first by the Detroit Board of Commerce but made available nationally for American products than competing with German.

Brooklyn parents picketed City Hall and Gracie Mansion yesterday with renewed demands for gamma globulin for children who had attended the day camp of the Jewish Community House of Bensonhurst, where two counselors were stricken last week with poliomyelitis.

The men's clothing industry operated at "normal" levels for the first half of the year, according to Harry A. Cobrin, executive secretary of the Clothing Manufacturers Association of the U. S. A. Factory production was at 87 per cent of capacity compared with 68 per cent in the 1952 period.

ZURICH, Aug. 30 -- Five agreements between West Germany and Switzerland to implement the accord reached on Aug. 26, 1952, settling Swiss claims known as "the clearing milliard" for goods and services extorted from Switzerland by the Reich during World War II, will be signed at Bern next Wednesday.
ROCQUENCOURT, France, Aug. 30 -- The long-range defense planners at Supreme Allied Headquarters here are critically re-examining the basic factors of the North Atlantic Treaty strategy for Europe.

FREEDOM VILLAGE, Korea, Aug. 30 -- Returning prisoners are confirming intelligence reports that the Chinese Communist Army now dominates all of North Korea and that the North Koreans who remain there have been stripped of just about everything the Chinese want -- food, clothes, even homes.

Phil Cavarretta is a manager who does not hestitate to put himself on the spot. The pilot of the Cubs, who still is on the active list, went up to pinch hit in the eighth inning of the second game against the Giants yesterday at the Polo Grounds at a time when the score was tied and the bases were loaded.

Prices of domestic cotton futures held to a narrow range last week. Futures on the New York Cotton Exchange ended the trading session on Friday down 5 points to up 17 points, or 25 cents lower to 85 cents higher a bale. All future deliveries gained except the nearby October option.

To be in show business for five decades and still be able to look ahead to many years of pleasant association with it is both a notable and enviable achievement. The holder of this remarkable record is Sophie Tucker, earlier known as a "red-hot mama," but now regretfully characterized as the last of the species.

Back in 1935 Congress passed the Robinson-Patman Act, intended to protect small distributors from the great market power of the chain stores. It forbade special price discriminations on goods moving in interstate commerce unless the suppliers granting them could demonstrate that lower prices were made possible by actual differences in cost.
LONDON, Aug. 30 -- Britain is preening herself to play once again the role of rich uncle to what used to be her empire, but is finding that some of the old outfit is rather worn.
MUNSAN, Korea, Monday, Aug. 31 (AP) -- The United Nations Command's official list of United States prisoners freed in today's armistice exchange:

KARACHI, Pakistan, Aug. 30 -- With the prices of basic commodities soaring beyond the reach of almost everyone in Karachi despite control measures, the Controller General of Prices and Supplies today broadcast an appeal to the people to "take your complaints to the police."

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 30 -- A major seventy-six-year-old scientific mystery -- an apparent network of canals on Mars -- may be solved next summer. This was disclosed today by Dr. Edison Pettit of Mount Wilson Observatory in a report to the Astronomical Society of the Pacific.

The Merchant Marine Act of 1936 has been attacked and misunderstood, with the result that the original intent of the legislation -- to create a merchant marine adequate for commerce and defense -- has not been fully implemented, Alexander Purdon, secretary-treasurer of the National Federation of American Shipping, said in his address to an American Legion group last week.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Aug. 29 -- Dr. Nelson Glueck, the archaeologist, reported today during a brief interruption of his archaeological survey of the Negev that he had established that the semi-desert central Negev was inhabited during the chalcolithic period (the Bronze Age), about 3500 B. C.
IN Gotham's asphalt desert, the United Nations has won its summer-long battle against grime and carbon monoxide to create a new oasis.
BALTIMORE, Aug. 30 -- Telephones in this state, disrupted by sporadic strikes and picketing last week, had a quiet day today, and the way was open for the resumption of negotiations tomorrow.

The major leagues loosed a barrage of thirty-one home runs in the fifteen games played yesterday, just six short of tying the record. In fact, if the American League had cooperated a trifle more, the statisticians would have been revising the books, The Associated Press reported.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 30 -- In the wake of reports from Rome that Italy had alerted her armed forces in fear that Yugoslavia planned to annex Yugoslav-occupied Zone B of the Free Territory of Trieste, the Belgrade radio declared today that Italy was seeking to create a "war atmosphere" over the Trieste issue.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 30 (AP) -- The Braves smashed twelve homers to establish three new National League records and tie a major league mark today in sweeping a double-header, 19 -- 4 and 11 -- 5, with the last-place Pirates.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- Senator Spessard L. Holland, Democrat of Florida, said today he had declined an invitation to a Democratic rally for Adlai E. Stevenson in Chicago next month because he thought the South would gain nothing there.

The Zionist Organization of America closed its fifty-sixth annual convention yesterday as Rabbi Irving Miller, re-elected president, denounced charges that the establishment of Israel as a nation "implies the spiritual and cultural disintegration of American Jewry." He spoke in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

A sign reading, "Thank You, Mr. Eisenhower, your 20 per cent tax closed this theatre," was prominently displayed yesterday outside the Inwood Theatre at 106-03 Metropolitan Avenue, Forest Hills, Queens. The theatre gave its last movie show last night.
TEL AVIV, Israel, Aug. 30 -- One hundred and sixteen ewes and three rams arrived here by plane from Australia over the week-end en route to a new ranch in the northern Negev.

EDINBURGH, Scotland, Aug. 30 (Reuters) -- A husband's place is in the kitchen right alongside his wife, the Eighth International Congress on Home Economics has decided after a week-long conference here.
DALLAS, Tex., Aug. 30 -- Floods routed 4,500 persons from their homes in rain-soaked Texas today as fresh showers posed new threats along the flat Gulf Coast area of the state.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Aug. 30 (AP) -- Alabama labor leaders mapped a double-barreled court and political attack on the new "right to work" law today.

Limitations of the new Argentine investment law make it doubtful whether it will offer any large-scale inducement to the North American capital market, it was concluded in an analysis of the law released over the weekend by the National Foreign Trade Council.

HURSTMONCEUX England, Aug. 20 -- For all their vaunted steadiness of character, the British are quietly switching the basis of time and space measurement on earth this year. Some time next January they will begin subtracting about a minute and a quarter from observed time at the Royal Greenwich Observatory to get back to where they started.

A great outdoor food for this time of year, when everyone eats in the fresh air or wishes he could, is the blue hardshell crab found extensively in inshore waters from Massachusetts to northern South America.

The sphere of Christian faith has all the pains and pleasures of reality, the Rev. J. Fraser McLuskey, chairman of the Youth Department of the British Council of Churches, said yesterday morning at St. Bartholomew's Protestant Episcopal Church, Park Avenue and Fifty-first Street.
In the Aug. 24 issue of THE TIMES, on Page 10, in a carry-over story from Page 1, a dispatch datelined Washington says:

Dean Sturgis Lee Riddle of the American Pro-Cathedral Church of the Holy Trinity in Paris, in a sermon yesterday morning at Trinity Protestant Episcopal Church, Broadway at the head of Wall Street, said he had been encouraged during his visit to the United States this summer by signs he had seen of a return to the Christian faith.

The primary battle among Democratic factions resulted yesterday in a series of acrimonious exchanges between Abe Stark, running for the Council President nomination on the slate headed by Robert F. Wagner Jr., Manhattan Borough President, and Assistant District Attorney Julius Helfand, candidate for Council President on Mayor Impellitteri's ticket.

CAMP DRUM, N. Y., Aug. 30 -- Preparations were completed today at this reservation for the three-day bivouac beginning tomorrow that will give about 9,000 National Guardsmen and Reservists from the New York City area a chance to show their prowess against an "enemy" in the field.

BERLIN, Aug. 30 -- The Leipzig industrial fair, described in the Communist press as the largest since World War II, opened today with emphasis on the stimulation of East-West trade. Western press representatives were invited to attend at the last minute.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 30 -- With steel furnaces producing at only a few points under their theoretical capacity, there was little disposition among steel men last week to complain about business. August will wind up with a production of about 9,500,000 net tons of ingots, or approximately 95 per cent of the industry's rated capacity. Most observers here feel that September will approximate this figure.
DID you ever hear of Ramar of the jungle? Is Ramar a man, a beast or a secret society? Can you pronounce it with confidence, without hesitation? Stand by and the mystery will be unfolded.

FRASER, Colo., Aug. 30 -- President Eisenhower went fishing this afternoon for the first time in two and a half weeks and he caught a twelve-inch rainbow trout on his first cast, James C. Hagerty, White House Press Secretary, reported.

Once again the "wetback" problem is getting public attention through Attorney General Brownell's recent visit to California to study the situation. As your paper knows, there are thousands of pages of testimony in reports in Washington and elsewhere of conditions and problems in connection with farm labor.

In view of the weeks ahead when the polio threat will have subsided and when Junior may be about to undergo a much-needed tonsillectomy, some suggestions on how to help youngsters meet this ordeal without too much fear may be of interest to parents.

LONDON, Aug. 30 -- Dr. Cyril Garbett, Archbishop of York, made a forceful plea today for the admission of Communist China into the United Nations. He declared also that isolated United States action in the Far East would be a "fatal blow to world cooperation."

TOKYO, Monday, Aug. 31 -- Reports from the Allied prisoners released from captivity by the Communists indicate that more Americans and other non - Korean prisoners of war may come back from the North Korean stockade than originally promised by the Reds.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (UP) -- Sen. John F. Kennedy said today that the problem of large wool stocks results from Department of Agriculture "inaction" in failing to dispose of surplus wool held under the farm price support program.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 30 (AP) -- Don Larsen hurled the Browns to a two-hit, 3-0 shutout against the Senators in the first half of today's double-header, but Washington pounded nine hits in the second game for a 9-3 decision. Larsen's bid for a no-hitter was spoiled by Wayne Terwilliger's single in the eighth. The box scores:

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 30 -- A special aeronautics subcommittee of the American Legion's National Security Commission today termed the recent $5,000,000,000 cut in Air Force appropriations "ill timed" and urged the Joint Chiefs of Staff to re-evaluate this nation's defensive potential with regard to air power.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 30 -- A serious situation has arisen in manufacturing centers here due to restrictions imposed by the Export and Import Control Board. The restrictions affect the automobile assembling plants in Sao Paulo of Ford and General Motors which are unable to obtain import licenses for dismounted automobiles to be assembled here.
ANTWERP, Belgium, Aug. 30 -- From an advanced position of trade liberalization among European nations, Belgium is planning to move forward to a system of international free trade in a limited field.

It is gratifying to read of the city's cordial relations with Columbia University, which have led to the grant by the city of the portion of 116th Street running through the university grounds to unify the campus.
Herbert Flam made his exit from the national tennis championships at Forest Hills yesterday and Budge Patty appeared on the way out when he lost the first two sets of his match.

WEST POINT, N. Y., Aug. 30 -- Awards to winners of the Buckner Sweepstakes, a competition to test the proficiency of United States Military Academy cadets in various phases of instruction, were made here tonight during the annual Camp Illumination ceremonies.

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, Aug. 30 (AP) -- The International Council of Christian Churches said today that the United States State Department had refused it permission to float small Bibles by balloon into Communist - controlled nations from the United States-occupied zone of Germany.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 30 -- You Chan Yang, Korean Ambassador to the United States, expressed a hope today that reports were accurate that Gen. James A. Van Fleet, retired former commander of the Eighth Army, would be named supreme military adviser to the Republic of Korea.

Bold and consistent action by the Federal Reserve System is needed for defense of the dollar, according to a report prepared for the Twentieth Century Fund by Prof. Albert G. Hart of Columbia University, which is being released today.

BAD GODESBERG, Germany, Aug. 30 -- More than 2,000 persons said to be East German Communist agitators have been arrested at East-West German border stations and in various West German cities in the past three days, the police announced tonight.

INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 30 -- A plane ready for take-off at Indiana's Stout Field National Guard Airport emphasized tenseness in the telephone strike. The craft was prepared for a flight to St. Louis where the Hoosier Governor, George N. Craig, an American Legion member, was at the national convention.

Phillip P. Zipes, operator, after an ownership of only two weeks, has resold the six-story apartment house at 1645 Montgomery Avenue, in the Bronx, to a client of Irving Waxman, lawyer. The thirty-one-family building occupies a plot 50 by 100 feet and the assessed valuation is $75,900.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Aug. 30 -- More than a hundred delegates and observers from the fourteen North Atlantic Treaty Organization countries are here for the Second International Study Conference on the Atlantic community held here by private NATO support groups.

" Hue and Cry," a new novel by Elizabeth Yates, which deals with justice tempered with mercy and of good resulting from evil, is scheduled for September publication by Coward-McCann. It is a story about a thief who is befriended by a little deaf-mute girl and sheltered by her father.

No one, probably, would contend that it would be a fair test of the comparative speeds of two railroad trains to time them over a run of the same distance if one of the trains, for reasons beyond its control, was off the rails when the race started.

Mayor Impellitteri's proclamation designating this week as "Rodgers and Hammerstein Week" focuses the spotlight on the varied accomplishments of Richard Rodgers (composer) and Oscar Hammerstein 2d (author-lyricist). With "Oklahoma!" opening under their own auspices at 8 o'clock tonight at the City Center, the talented pair will have four musicals running simultaneously on Broadway.

Softness in the British pound sterling and continued strength in the Canadian dollar marked the trend in the foreign exchange market during the past week. Business transacted was reported as only moderate in volume.

ROME, Aug. 30 -- After a long conversation this morning between Premier Giuseppe Pella and Elbridge Durbrow, Minister Counselor of the United States Embassy, the Italian Government took a calmer view of Yugoslavia's alleged annexionist designs on Zone B of the Trieste Free Territory.

NUWARA ELIYA, Ceylon, Aug. 30 -- The teaching of foreign languages in United States public schools is all wrong except in a few areas where instruction begins in the elementary grades, according to conclusions reached at a three weeks' United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization seminar on language problems, which has just ended in this cool tropical mountain resort.

BONN, Germany, Aug. 30 -- As West Germany's general election campaign entered its last week a spokesman of the Social Democratic party proposed today that a reunited Germany, instead of joining any Western bloc, should have a status similar to that of Sweden and Switzerland and that her borders should be guaranteed by the four great powers.

DETROIT, Aug. 30 (AP) -- The Tigers snapped a seven-game losing streak today by sweeping a double-header from the Athletics, 10 -- 1 and 9 -- 1, as Steve Gromek and Al Aber each hurled a seven-hitter. The second game was called after seven and a half innings because of darkness.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 30 (AP) -- Smoky Burgess hit a ninth-inning homer to give the Phillies a 4-3 victory over the Redlegs in the finale of today's twin bill. The Phils won the opener, 4 -- 2, despite a Cincinnati triple play -- the first in the National League this season.

A vice president and a traffic clerk of radio station WOR were knocked down and kicked by a group of men in front of the ofices of the station yesterday after striking engineer pickets had called them "scabs," according to the police.

The pennant-bound Dodgers yesterday assaulted both the record books and the Cardinals at Ebbets Field as they scored four more runs than they had tallied in any previous game this year, routing the Redbirds, 20 -- 4.

CHICAGO, Aug. 30 -- The Yankees came out of their current tailspin today long enough to take an extra little hitch on first place as they split a double-header with the runner-up White Sox before a sweltering crowd of 35,097. Thus with time working on their side, Casey Stengel's Bombers retained their lead of eight-and-a-half lengths in the American League flag race with only twenty-five games to play.

Harry Gildin and Sons, Inc., building, have acquired the site at the northeast corner of West 187th Street and Overlook Terrace, in Manhattan, consisting of about 45,000 square feet of land, as the site for a new six-story apartment building.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (AP) -- The Potomac Boat Club of Arlington, Va., won the President's Cup rowing regatta on the Potomac River today, scoring 71 points. The runner-up Vesper Club of Philadelphia had 66.
FLINT, Mich., Aug. 30 -- There was open-air dancing in Beecher Township at sundown today as Operation Tornado, dedicated to rehousing of the victims of the June 8 tornado, ended successfully.

THE story has grown to be an accepted fact. On June 2, 1925, Wally Pipp, the regular Yankee first baseman, reached into his locker and took out an aspirin bottle -- so the legend would have everyone believe.

THE story has grown to be an accepted fact. On June 2, 1925, Wally Pipp, the regular Yankee first baseman, reached into his locker and took out an aspirin bottle -- so the legend would have everyone believe.
BURBANK, Calif., Aug. 30 (AP) -- A $1,000,000 Air Force plane was grounded today because of a $2,999 damage suit brought through the legal ingenuity of the Flying Finn twins.

SUFFERN, N. Y., Aug. 30 -- Mrs. W. French Githens' standard poodle, Ch. Ensarr Cygne, was named best in show among 477 dogs entered in the seventh annual fixture of the Rockland County Kennel Club on the Suffern High School grounds today.

A citizens' committee proposed yesterday a housing study directed toward tightening the city housing laws, encouraging private capital to invest in more housing here, and inducing middle and high-income families to live in the city instead of the suburbs.
SYRACUSE, N. Y., Aug. 30 -- A pair of Jersey pilots kneeling in the cockpits of fragile stock outboards won two heats each on Onondaga Lake today and took national titles.

Describing as "degrading" the conditions in New York State under which migrant farm laborers are forced to live and work, the Rev. Dr. William Lloyd Imes declared yesterday morning that "sooner or later the Food and Agricultural Organization of the United Nations must come to grips with this problem of migrant workers right in the beloved United States."

The Rev. Dr. Glenn H. Asquith, executive secretary of the Baptist Missionary Convention of New York State, yesterday defined the average man's attitude toward spiritual responsibility as one of escape. He was guest preacher at the Madison Avenue Baptist Church, at Thirty-first Street.

Detectives investigating the Bronx murder of Thomas E. Lewis, building service union official, directed their major efforts yesterday to the search for a paroled convict whose automobile was seen in the neighborhood when the labor leader was killed Friday.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 30 (UP) -- The late-surging Indians swept a double-header from the Red Sox today, 6 to 5 and 8 to 4, to run their winning streak to six games and give them twelve victories in their last thirteen games.

UNITED NATIONS, New York, Aug. 30 -- The Security Council is scheduled to resume debate at 3 P. M. tomorrow on the proposal of fifteen Asian-African nations to have the situation in Morocco placed on the Council agenda.

New Yorkers perspired through the sixth straight day of temperatures in the nineties yesterday as the heat set a new record for the date, and the Weather Bureau predicted higher humidity would mean even more discomfort today and tomorrow.

A vocabulary handbook from a bygone college day opens with this challenging bid to study: "If, the minute you opened this book, a fairy godmother had appeared and offered you the choice between an adequate vocabulary and a purse full of money, the chances are you would have taken the latter."
In an effort to avoid over and undercharging on shipments, the Far East Conference has established the Atlantic Cargo Inspection Bureau, the first of its kind on this coast.

TEHERAN, Iran, Aug. 30 -- The Iranian Government produced evidence today that former Premier Mohammed Mossadegh, a few hours before his overthrow on Aug. 19, was preparing a nation-wide referendum to change the form of government, probably from monarchy to republic.
The Seamen's Church Institute of New York, a South Street hostelry catering mostly to seafaring men, has a lady with a mysterious past on its hands.

Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public, which will mature within twelve months, amount to $84,769,227,337. They consists of Treasury bonds, certificates of indebtedness, bills and notes as follows:

WEST SHOKAN, N. Y., Aug . 30 -- An appeal for a "golden age" of American Jewish culture in the United States was made here tonight by the president of B'nai B'rith in an address marking the thirtieth anniversary of the establishment of Hillel Foundation.

LONDON, Aug. 30 -- In the last few days the markets have been rather sharply reminded that Wall Street can exert quite a strong influence on this side of the Atlantic. It has certainly called the tune as regards the course of industrial share prices, which received their first noticeable check to a rise that had been proceeding steadily for several weeks.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (UP) -- The National Federation of Independent Business served notice today it is keeping an eye on the Justice Department's new committee to study the anti-trust laws.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Aug. 30 -- Mohammed Ali, the Pakistan Prime Minister, received today a "top secret" conciliatory reply from Jawaharlal Nehru, the Prime Minister of India, to the several demands he sent to New Delhi Thursday to be met by India before Pakistan will agree to an accession plebiscite in Kashmir.

Leading insurance companies have reached agreement on a complex new schedule of automobile liability rates for private car owners that will cut rates for adult pleasure car drivers up to 15 per cent, and at the other extreme increase rates for young driver-owners with uncontrolled use of cars to two and one-half times the rate for the best risks.
I read your editorial "Trial by Newspaper," which appeared in the issue of Aug. 26.

Years ago, ship news reporters used to ask arriving celebrities on their way up the Bay what they thought of the New York skyline. But ever since last April 21, when Edna Ferber, author, brightened an otherwise dull arrival of the Queen Mary by criticizing New York as the most "disgustingly filthy" city in the world, ship news men have been asking ocean travelers what they think of our streets.

James P. Warburg's letter which appeared in THE TIMES of Aug. 23 contained suggestions for an East-West compromise on the German problem which seem to be essentially right and practical. May I submit a personal, trans-Atlantic viewpoint in support of his thesis?

TEHERAN, Iran, Aug. 31 -- Anatoli I. Lavrentiev, Soviet Ambassador to Iran, is seriously ill in his summer residence in a suburb of the capital and there were apparently well-founded reports in Government and diplomatic circles today that he had attempted suicide.

National Airlines, Inc., achieved a new record in earnings in the fiscal year ended on June 30 with a net profit of $4,034,468, equal to $3.99 a share, G. T. Baker, president and board chairman, reported to stockholders yesterday. This was nearly double the $2,048,300, or $2.05 a share, earned in the previous fiscal year.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (AP) -- Herbert Brownell Jr., Attorney General, said today that domestic Communists were "a greater menace now than at any time" and "I suppose there are more in labor unions than anywhere else."

A pamphlet by Ernest T. Weir contending that the United States should negotiate for peace with the Soviet Union "in a spirit of give and take" was reprinted in Russian translation last Thursday and Friday by Pravda, the leading Soviet newspaper, though with some striking omissions.

TOKYO, Tuesday, Sept. 1 -- North Korean Premier Kim II Sung declared yesterday that his Communist regime would oppose "foreign intervention" in the problem of unification of the Korean peninsula at the coming peace conference.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (AP) -- Largely because of vacations, the nation's industrial production fell in July from 240 to 233 per cent of the 1935-39 average, the Federal Reserve Board reported today on the basis of its seasonally adjusted index.

CHICAGO, Aug. 31 -- The continuance of hot and dry conditions over most of the important grain areas of the country over the week-end caused big price upheavals in corn and soy beans in the early trade today. However there was a lot of profit taking which wiped out part of the gains despite persistent buying by commission houses on the recessions.

HONG KONG, Aug. 31 -- Radio monitors here tuning in on Red China's smaller provincial stations report that a "beast calamity" is now getting considerable official attention in Kweichow, Hupeh, Yunnan and Shensi provinces.

BERGEN, Norway, Aug. 31 (AP) -- Dr. Bjoern Trumpy, rector of the University of Bergen, appealed today to Norwegian students to rally behind Columbia University in the fight for "man's spiritual rights."

TRENTON, Aug. 31 -- Clendenin J. Ryan, independent candidate for Governor, may withdraw from the campaign, it was learned today. The financier and crusader against crime is expected to make his decision public within three weeks.

BONN, Germany, Aug. 31 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer returned here today from his tour of Socialist strongholds in North Germany confident that he would lead the Government coalition to victory in the elections on Sunday, but careful to avoid any prediction on the size of the coalition's majority.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 31 -- The eleven-day strike of 53,000 employes of the Southwestern Bell Telephone Company ended this morning when management and union negotiators reached a compromise agreement after an all-night meeting. Federal and state mediators participated in the talks.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- A special grant of economic aid from the United States to the new Government of Iran appeared imminent today as officials awaited word from Teheran on the outcome of discussions there between Premier Fazlollah Zahedi and representative of the Foreign Operations Administration.

HONG KONG, Aug. 31 -- Reports by missionaries arriving here almost daily after their expulsion from China indicate that the Chinese Communists are bent on banishing all foreign missionaries by the end of the year. Sixty-three Catholic missionaries have arrived in Hong Kong this month and church authorities here estimate the number of priests and nuns still in China at fewer than 500 compared with more than 5,000 in January, 1951.

Flotations of new securities last month dropped to the smallest total for any month in more than a year. Bond financing was the smallest since March, 1952, and the least for an August since 1951. Stock offerings fell to the lowest figure since February, 1951, and to the poorest total for an August since 1950.

Wool prices fell yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange following the announcement by the Commodity Credit Corporation that wool from the 1952 support program will be sold at a 12 per cent discount from the previous rate.

SALT LAKE CITY, Aug. 31 -- A walkout that could cripple one-third of the nation's copper output seemed likely late tonight, following unsuccessful day-long negotiations between employers and two union locals representing 2,800 smelter and refinery workers.

A fireman was critically injured yesterday while fighting a three-alarm fire in a six-story tenement at 231-233 East 118th Street. The fireman, Julius Feldman, 38 years old, of 314 East 143d Street, the Bronx, attached to Hook and Ladder Company 43, was blown out of a window by a blast of hot air in the sixth-floor apartment in which the blaze began.
FRASER, Colo., Aug. 31 -- President Eisenhower turned to a novel pursuit today. He took a shovel in hand and helped build a dam of earth and logs on St. Louis Creek here, the better to catch trout.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- The Atomic Energy Commission announced tonight that the Soviet Union had set off on Aug. 23 another fission type of explosion. The term fission would imply a conventional atomic weapon.

The protest made by our State Department to the Guatemalan Government on Friday over the expropriation of land belonging to the United Fruit Company deserves the consideration and understanding of all members of the Inter-American System. A. principle of the first importance is involved for all Latin-American countries and for all investors, which primarily means North American firms.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- The Treasury announced tonight that tenders for $1,500,000,000 of ninety-one-day Treasury Bills to be dated Sept. 3 and to mature on Dec. 3, were opened at the Federal Reserve Banks today. Of the $2,367,832,000 applied for, $1,500,139,000 was accepted, including $229,625,000 entered on a noncompetitive basis and accepted in full at the average price of 99.504, representing a discount rate of about 1.961 per cent per annum.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (UP) -- A rocket-powered plane has ascend-83,235 feet to set a new unofficial world's altitude record, the Navy announced today.

BERKELEY, Calif., Aug. 31 -- The maintenance of secrecy among police is considered by law enforcement officers to be more important than law enforcement itself, according to a paper prepared by Prof. William A. Westley of McGill University for the annual three-day meeting of the American Sociological Society in session here.

The steel industry's operating rate dipped 2.5 points last week, but is scheduled to regain 2 points this week. Production last week was 2,106,000 net tons of ingots and steel for castings, a decline of 56,000 tons from the preceding week, while output for the current week is expected to reach 2,150,000 tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Aug. 31 -- The American Council on the North Atlantic Treaty Organization urged that alliance today to take steps to bridge the differences of opinion in the United States and Europe regarding the organization. This proposal featured the day's discussions in the second international Atlantic alliance study conference.
George Altz, marine department office manager, on Pier 90, Hudson River, retired yesterday after forty-nine years of service with the Cunard Line.

The news that Congressional appropriation cuts have forced the Census Bureau to drop plans for a 1953 Census of Business and a 1954 Census Of Agriculture will come as a shock to the many who are aware of the fundamental need for the information from these two surveys.

CHICAGO, Aug. 31 (AP) -- A moderate run of 5,500 hogs cleared at steady to 25 cents higher prices today with sows showing the advance. This brought the total estimated salable supply for the month to about 129,000, fewest for any month since September, 1948.
With autumn approaching, housewives with summer houses to close may be interested in the following advice.

TEHERAN, Iran, Aug. 31 -- United States Ambassador Henderson, with technical and financial advisers, conferred for two hours today nth Premier Zahedi on terms for ited States aid to bolster Premier Zahedi's fifteen-day-old regime, which has checked this nation's slide toward communism.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (AP) -- Representatives of the wool growing industry declared today that Department of Agriculture recommendations for higher wool tariffs fall far short of what the industry wants.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Aug. 31 -- Damage claims against communities in this state are multiplying so rapidly -- because of recent legal interpretations by the courts -- that some cities, villages and towns can no longer obtain liability and property damage insurance at any price, Edwin G. Michaelian, Mayor of White Plains and president of the State Conference of Mayors, said this afternoon.

Mayor Impellitteri "guaranteed" last night that he would bring the city's police force up to its authorized strength of 20,878 from its present complement of 19,828. He said it was his hope also that the members of the force could work a reduced forty-hour week as soon as finances permitted.
EAST LANSING, Mich., Aug. 31 -- Three hundred family-life specialists began a three-day meeting here today to look into the problem of helping families meet currently increasing stresses.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- Ezra Taft Benson, Secretary of Agriculture, is expected to name a liaison officer to work with Congressional committees as a step in reorganization of the Department of Agriculture and in shaping farm policy.

Among those stalled on sizzling Grand Central Parkway in yesterday's heat was Park Commissioner Robert Moses, whose many functions include direction of the network of parkways in the metropolitan area. The mishap made Mr. Moses late for an appointment at Gracie Mansion with Mayor Impellitteri.

Eddie Stanky found nothing funny at Ebbets Field last night as his Cardinals went down to a second straight defeat at the hands of the Dodgers, suffering their tenth loss at Brooklyn this year without a victory.

As a frequent Gotham visitor and a constant reader of THE TIMES, permit me to express my congratulations to your great paper, and to Peter Kihss and his assistants, for the series of articles surveying the physical plant of New York City.
Joseph L. Armstrong has been appointed director of Crosley and Bendix Home Appliances laundry equipment sales of the Avco Manufacturing Corporation.

In Washington, D. C., last week I encountered an astounding example of the harm done to the public interest by the latest Administration "economy" measure. The Library of Congress now closes its Periodical Room at 5:30 P. M. Even more astounding is the limitation on the use of the main reading room, which remains open until 10 P. M., but no books can be taken from the stacks after 5:30.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 31 (AP) -- A Beach Haven, N. J., owner of 500 shares of Autocar Company common stock asked the United States District Court today to set aside the sale of the company to the White Motor Company of Cleveland.

Boy Scout officials and a militant group of Brooklyn parents failed yesterday to get city and state health officials to reverse their decision to make no further special grants of gamma globulin here unless the Federal Government increased its allocation to New York of this temporary preventive of poliomyelitis.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- The Bureau of Customs reported today that its agents had been kept busy in the 1953 fiscal year that ended June 30 with smuggling cases involving arms, airplane engine parts, cattle, parrot-like birds, gold, diamonds and narcotics.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 31 (AP) -- After a shaky first inning, Southpaw Harry Perkowski settled down to pitch a seven-hitter as the Redlegs beat the Phillies, 7 -- 5, in the second game of a twilight-night twin-bill tonight. The Redlegs scored nine runs in the sixth inning to take the opener, 12 -- 6.

Nothing could introduce a new theatrical season more attractively than a revival of "Oklahoma!" Thanks to the enterprise of the City Center, that is exactly what we have -- an amiable revival that opened there last evening. Just by the merest coincidence, it comes as the major event of Rodgers and Hammerstein Week, which has been officially promulgated by the Mayor and will be suitably observed by every honest citizen until next Sunday midnight.

A new biography of Anton Chekhov by David Magarshack, author of a life of Stanislavsky and of a critical study of Chekhov's plays, will be published on Sept. 14 by Grove Press. "Chekhov: A Life" is based on new material contained in the complete edition of Chekhov's letters, published recently in Moscow, as well as the reminiscences of Chekhov's closest friends and relations.

CEDARHURST, L. I., Aug. 31 -- L. S. Potter and Gil Cavanagh of the Home Club shot a 33, 31 -- 64, six strokes under par, to take the first prize in Group I for handicap players 0 to 6, in the weekly amateur-pro tournament of the Long Island P. G. A. at the Rockaway Hunting Club today.

The introduction of man-made fibers to the men's wear industry has created sales by stimulating the imagination of the consumer but the value of the synthetics is being harmed by exaggerated claims, Isidore S. Immerman, counsel and executive director of the Associated Men's Wear Retailers of New York, said yesterday.

I am not in the habit of replying to letters about the work or program of this department that are not directed to it. However, the topic discussed by John A. Ward in your column on Aug. 25 is so important to the economy and welfare of our city that I deem it necessary to state my views.

Elegance marks most of the new furnishings introduced for fall on Lord Taylor's remodeled eighth and ninth floors, opened to view yesterday. Sparkling Steuben crystal, rich Scalamandre silks, flashing brass used for accessories and furniture contribute to this luxurious look.

CAMP DRUM, N. Y., Aug. 31 -- The Forty-Second National Guard Division and the Seventy-Seventh Reserve Infantry Division concentrated on small unit training problems as they opened today a three-day bivouac exercise on this 107,000-acre post.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 31 -- Private enterprise, as represented by organizations in the field of medicine, was challenged today by Mrs. Oveta Culp Hobby, Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, to find the way to "save any average American family from destruction by the catastrophy of illness."
Mayor Impellitteri's Bronx campaign manager in his present primary fight was questioned yesterday on his relations with Thomas E. Lewis, the union official who was slain last Friday.

Although committed to presenting a season of winter stock at Syracuse, N. Y., beginning late this month, the Messrs. James Russo and Michael Ellis, recalled as the gentlemen responsible for Bette Davis' return to the local stage last season, are not overlooking the bright lights of Broadway.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Aug. 31 -- Arthur K. Gilkey, who was killed while trying to conquer Mount Godwin Austen (K-2) as a member of a nine-man American team, was believed to have been buried alive under an avalanche on a ridge at a height of 25,000 feet on Aug. 10, Dr. Charles S. Houston said today.

Mrs. Isabel Dodge Sloane, owner of Brookmeade Stable, wasn't among the 17,738 customers at the Aqueduct track yesterday. Despite the heat she would have enjoyed the proceedings. For her 3-year-old gelding First Aid, who is an in-and-outer, had an "in" afternoon and ran off with first money of $19,050 in the $28,075 Aqueduct Handicap.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 31 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon asserted today that the greatest obligation facing this country was to make certain that the principles for which 25,000 Americans gave their lives in Korea were not "compromised away" in the peace negotiations.

MOSCOW, Tuesday, Sept. 1 -- Pravda, the Communist party newspaper, announced today that the Government had ordered the establishment of a strict eight-hour working day in all Soviet ministries, departments and other establishments in Moscow, with one hour off for lunch.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (AP) -- Ben Gold, Russian-born president of the International Fur and Leather Workers Union, was rescued from jail by a professional bondsman today after surrendering to answer a three-count perjury indictment.

The Federal Paper Board Company has arranged with some of the principal stockholders of the National Folding Box Company, New Haven, Conn., to buy a majority of National's capital stock, it was announced yesterday by John R. Kennedy, president of Federal and Walton D. Lynch, chairman of National.
BONN, Germany, Aug. 31 -- A heated debate on foreign policy, predominant issue in West Germany's election campaign, continued today between the Federal Republic's two largest parties.

The Detroit Harvester Company has acquired all of the outstanding stock of the Moto-Mower Company, Detroit pioneer in the rapidly growing power lawn mower industry, J. Thomas Smith, president of Detroit Harvester, announced yesterday.

DETROIT, Aug. 31 (AP) -- Louis Norman (Bobo) Newsom won his 200th American League game tonight, hurling the Athletics to a 10-4 victory over the Tigers in the second game of a twilight-night double-header. Detroit won the opener, 9 -- 7.

The General Dynamics Corporation and its Canadian subsidiary, Canadair, Ltd., attained the highest sales and earnings for an initial half year period in the first six months of this year, according to the report yesterday of John Jay Hopkins, board chairman and president.

MAYS LANDING, N. J., Aug. 31 (AP) -- Joseph Gavegnano's Joey Boy was extended to a turf course record of 1:42 4/5, clipping one and one-fifth seconds off the old mark, before gaining a head triumph in the featured $5,000 Beach Haven Purse at the Atlantic City Race Course today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (AP) -- Senator Arthur V. Watkins, Republican of Utah, declared today that he believed the Republicans were in a "strong position" on the immigration issue and urged delay in any recommendations for changes in the law.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- Contracts for the sale of three of the thirty-five "mariner" class dry-cargo ships to be built by the Government were signed today in the offices of the Maritime Administration of the Department of Commerce.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- The State Department denied today that it had refused to authorize the floating of Bibles by balloon into Communist-controlled countries of Europe, and officials expressed doubt that approval or clearance by this Government was needed.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Aug. 31 -- The Harvard Corporation said today that it was lifting its recent suspension of Dr. Helen Deane Markham, associate professor of anatomy, in the absence of "adequate" proof that she now was under Communist domination.

PARIS, Aug. 31 -- Although on paper the defense forces of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization are stronger in the Mediterranean area than anywhere else in Europe, the current Italian-Yugoslav dispute over Trieste emphasizes how weak the political structure of the anti-Soviet bloc remains in that quarter.

A good 200 years before the New World was founded, the Swiss were making cheese. It was, therefore, a surprise to learn yesterday that twenty Swiss dairy specialists had arrived here over the weekend to see what was new in the field.
BONN, Germany, Aug. 31 -- For the first time in West Germany's election campaign thousands of supporters of the Neo-Nazi German Reich party clashed with the police tonight in Nuremberg and Fuerth.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Aug. 31 -- Four days of debate in Parliament on the program of the new Cabinet have produced sufficient affirmations of support to insure its survival for the time being.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 31 (AP) -- Edward K. Inman, editor of The National Tribune, a veterans' affairs weekly, assailed Congress and the Veterans Administration today for "economy at the expense of the veterans."

Bonds called for payment in August before maturity totaled $15,984,000, the smallest amount in three months and the lowest for an August since 1949. The redemptions compared with $40,790,000 in July and $40,908,000 in August, 1952.

Distance Measuring Equipment, a new aid to aircraft navigation that gives the pilot the exact distance to an airport, was demonstrated yesterday by Pan American World Airways in a three-hour flight over Long Island and Connecticut.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway, new Chief of Staff of the Army, warned the large cities of the United States today that they could not expect, in case of war, an airtight defense against bombardment by atomic or hydrogen bombs.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 31 (AP) -- Ted Williams walloped a three-run homer in the seventh inning tonight to give the Red Sox a 6 -- 4 victory over the Indians and snap the Tribe's winning streak at six games.

The novelty of an American giving an Australian a lesson in the virtue of solid driving with good length on the tennis court was provided for the clientele at Forest Hills yesterday and there came about the first genuine shock in the national championships.

Frederick Brown, operator, has purchased an automobile salesroom and service garage at 74-80 West Post Road in White Plains, N. Y., from Estelle Herschkopf. The property is rented to a Lincoin-Mercury agency which is planning to move to larger quarters at the end of this year.

SOUTHPORT, Conn., Aug. 31 -- George Carter of the Pequot Yacht Club took the lead in Pequot's new invitation Blue Jay regatta today by winning the first two brushes in the three-race series which ends tomorrow.
SAIGON, Vietnam, Aug. 31 -- The French were reported today to have stiffened their attitude toward Cambodia on the latter's demands for complete military independence.

The forty-fourth annual meeting of the Association of National Advertisers will be held Sept. 21 through 23 at the Drake Hotel, Chicago. Representatives of a cross-section of the country's leading advertisers are expected to attend.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 31 -- A new charge, that of "receiving, assisting and comforting" Robert G. Thompson, one of the top leaders of the Communist party in this country, was placed today against Sidney Steinberg, 38 years old, an accused "second string" Communist. He is being held here in $100,000 bail as a fugitive from an indictment in New York.

Liberated prisoners returning from North Korea are telling about bad relations between the Chinese soldiers and the North Korean civilians. In a dispatch to this newspaper our correspondent at Freedom Village has reported that there are chalked signs in evidence saying "Chinese go home.
