THIS should be an active and productive season for New York upland game and waterfowl hunters, for a general abundance of upland game has resulted in longer seasons and more generous bag limits on some birds, and wildfowlers will have a continuous sixty-day season with the state now divided into two zones.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Aug. 31 -- The Northern Rhodesian Government has evidence that suggests a "definite" attempt to introduce a relatively large number of East Indian immigrants into Northern Rhodesia before the interim federal government takes over the administration of Southern and Northern Rhodesia and Nyasaland Sunday, Sir Roy Welensky said today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- An Interstate Commerce Commission examiner today proposed a final settlement of the claims of holders of debentures and stock of the Boston and Providence Railroad Corporation, involving purchase of the B. P. properties by the New Haven for a total of $9,026,095 in cash and securities.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., Aug. 31 -- The third and final day of a regatta for national championships in the stock outboard classes wound up late this afternoon with a new list of titleholders. Some of the classes were formerly called utilities. Others are in the newer racing divisions which use stock motors clamped to three-point hydroplane hulls for greater speeds.

The Simpson Logging Company yesterday reduced mill prices of its fir wood 5 per cent. The company is a large lumber producer and a factor in plywood. Its action may touch off a general break in mill prices of fir plywood, according to some distributors.
HOUSTON, Tex., Aug. 31 -- The Texas Gulf Coast from the Rio Grande Valley to Houston -- a distance of more than 300 miles-- was described today as "almost a solid lake of water."

Budget Director Abraham D. Beame told Mayor Impellitteri yesterday that the city must cut back its plans for new public works construction at least $17,300,000 for 1954 to meet limitations on the funds that would be available for next year's capital budget.
New York's current heat wave went into its second week this morning, with no relief in sight from temperatures that climbed yesterday to 97 degrees.

Communist party members were "advised" yesterday in two articles appearing in The Daily Worker, official organ of the party, to devote their energies to making the Democratic party and Democratic candidates more "progressive."

The indictment of Ben Gold, long-time Communist party leader of the Fur Workers Union, on a charge of falsely swearing that he was not a Communist opens the door to judicial airing of the Taft-Hartley Act's Non-Communist Oath section.

Breaking out with a fourteen-hit attack, the Giants walloped the Cubs, 13 to 4, at the Polo Grounds yesterday. The victory, marked by a seven-run fourth inning, enabled the Polo Grounders to clinch the season's series with the Cubs, 12-7, and it also gave Leo Durocher's team a 2-1 edge in the current four-game set.

The New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program received 864 pints of blood last Friday. The donations included 372 pints that were contributed at Fort Monmouth, N. J., on the second of a two-day drive that netted 640 pints, and 240 pints that were collected at the Pepsi-Cola Metropolitan Bottling Company, 48-02 Fifth Street, Long Island City, Queens.

Determined selling yesterday sent stocks on the New York Stock Exchange into the widest decline since June 9, shoved THE NEW YORK TIMES industrial, rail and combined averages through their 1953 lows and left the list at the lowest level since May 1, 1952.

OYSTER BAY, L. I., Aug. 31 -- The preliminary phase of America's Six-Meter yachting program, setting the stage for the forthcoming international competition, ended today, with Magnus Konow's Llanoria winning the final race in the One-Ton Cup trial series. As the result of her victory, Llanoria gained the right to defend the cup it won for the United States off Sandhamn, Sweden, last summer.
ROME, Aug. 31 -- The Italian Government, through the semi-official news agency, Ansa, denied reports from Belgrade of a "new Italian provocation" at the Italo-Yugoslav frontier.

Rudolph Halley, President of the City Council and Liberal candidate for Mayor, charged last night in a television appearance that New York was suffering the effects of a crime wave because of the atmosphere of corruption that he said permeated former Mayor William O'Dwyer's administration, and "the moral laxity of New York's political leadership."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 31 -- In line with the new Hollywood thinking of making fewer pictures in the hope of turning out bigger and better ones, Metro-Goldwyn- Mayer disclosed today that it would make only eighteen pictures between now and next July.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- The United States Government took close note today of charges and counter-charges hurled by Italy and Yugoslavia over Trieste, but did not lose its official calm over developments.
The price for world series tickets may be increased by as much as $2 for the fall baseball classic starting Sept. 30.

Two Army civilian employes whose jobs give them information by which they could tip off troop movements to Korea and other foreign areas, as well as in camps here, have admitted ties with Communist activities while denying membership in the Communist party, Senator Joseph R. McCarthy announced here yesterday.

Aides of Dave Beck, president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, A. F. L., reported "some progress" last night in efforts to end the eight-week strike of sand, gravel and concrete drivers here, but emphasized that it was too early to tell whether a settlement could be effected today.

ITHACA, N. Y., Aug. 31 (AP) -- Judge Francis L. Valente, who barred reporters from the Minot (Mickey) Jelke vice trial, called on the press tonight to observe its own canons of decency and responsibility.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- Robert T. Stevens, Secretary of the Army, announced today that it might not be possible to offer reserve commissions to all graduates of Reserve Officers Training Corps courses in June, 1955, because of budget limitations, and that individuals who were not commissioned would be subject to the draft.

Mason H. Bigelow, president of the National Society for the Prevention of Blindness, predicted yesterday that 750,000 Americans now alive would be overtaken by blindness unless "sight-saving knowledge already at hand is more generally applied and the field of research into the causes of blinding eye diseases is substantially expanded."

Anthony (Tough Tony) Anastasia, union boss of the Brooklyn waterfront, is back in the good graces of the racket-ridden International Longshoremen's Association, A. F. L. After five weeks of fruitless efforts to suspend Anastasia from his job as a business agent, the union's executive council has decided to call the whole thing off.

Martin Broad has purchased the three-story building containing sixteen apartments at 4310 Beach Forty-third Street, Brooklyn, from the Dubar Holding Corporation, of which Harvey S. Duke is president. Title was insured by the Lawyers Mortgage and Title Company.
BAYONNE, N. J., Aug. 31 -- This city spread its welcome mat today for two homecoming heroes recently released from Communist prisoner-of-war camps in Korea.

A considerable difference of opinion about the pricing of a new issue of $8,000,000 of mortgage bonds of the Wisconsin Power and Light Company was registered yesterday by investment banking syndicates competing for purchase of the issue.

LARCHMONT, N. Y, Aug. 31 -- The opening race in the Two-Ten Class national championship regatta, was sailed in a tricky breeze off the Larchmont Y. C. today and was won by Gregg Bemis Sr. at the helm of his Alar.

BERLIN, Aug. 31 (AP) -- An American soldier who had spent the past nine months east of the Iron Curtain has surrendered to United States military authorities in Berlin. He has been sent to West Germany pending a court martial, the Army said today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (AP) -- Harold E. Stassen, Foreign Operations Administrator, dismissed about 250 of his Federal employes today, partly on the basis of a special "aptitude test," which he took himself. About 100 more letters of dismissal will go out this week.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 31 (AP) -- Johnny Schmitz and Sonny Dixon of the Senators gave up three home runs, but their team-mates capitalized on eight hits as Washington downed the Browns, 4 -- 3, tonight. Two of the Senators' blows were four-baggers.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange continued to move within a narrow range yesterday and closing prices were unchanged to 6 points lower than on last Friday.

You are quite right. Not nearly enough honors have been bestowed upon that excellent delicacy known in quartermasterly jargon as "canis calidus Americanus." But one must question the belief of those historians cited by Topics of THE TIMES on Aug. 20 that "the hot dog was born on a cold day in the Eighteen Nineties" at the Polo Grounds in New York City.

Two new films open today at first-run theatres. At the Plaza is "Below the Sahara," a Technicolor film record of an African trip recently taken by Armand and Michaela Denis. Jay Bonafield supervised the production, which R. K. O. Radio Pictures is releasing.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 31 -- Sixteen of the seventeen nations named by the General Assembly to represent the United Nations at the proposed political conference on Korean and other Far Eastern affairs will meet in Washington tomorrow to discuss the place where it is to be held and the date.

WESTBURY, L. I., Aug. 31 (AP) -- Lady Attorney, owned by Eddie Cobb and Pat O'Shea, and driven by Cobb, scored her sixteenth victory in twenty-three starts tonight, taking the Maryland Pace at Roosevelt Raceway by a length and a half. The 4-year-old mare, the favorite, paced the mile and one-sixteenth in 2:13 1-5, paying $3.50 for $2.

D. A. Schulte, Inc., will effect big operating economies in its twenty-six Western stores through the facilities of Stineway Drug Company of Chicago, which it recently purchased, N. C. Earl, president of Schulte, predicted yesterday following his election as chairman of the Stineway board.

BERGEN, Aug. 31 (Reuters) -- Dr. Trumpy told the new students Columbia had taken the initiative for uniting all the universities of the world in the fight for academic ideals and rights, for freedom of thought and word.

There are several interesting trends in new fall suits for women. Of first importance, is the return of the fitted suit. After having been relegated to the background by the box jacket styles of last spring, it has soared once more to first place in prominence because of the emphasis this fall on slim, shapely waistlines.

CAZENOVIA, N. Y., Aug. 31 -- James T. Sherwin of New York City, Roy T. Black of Buffalo, Vernon Gable of Tonawanda and Hans Berliner of Washington repeated their successes of the opening round and led the field with scores of 2.0 today in the annual tournament for the championship of the New York State Chess Association.

TYRUS RAYMOND COBB, who certainly should be able to recognize a base hit when he sees one, offered a justifiable complaint a few months ago. The famed Georgia Peach said that baseball was being overwhelmed by too many hits, too many runs and too many lopsided scores. It was natural, of course, that he should yearn for the inside, scientific 1-0 baseball of his youth.

J. Norman Lewis, the attorney recently retained to represent the major league players in their dealings with the club owners, said yesterday that "definite progress" had been made toward the acceptance of the players' proposals, The Associated Press reported.
MOSCOW, Aug. 31 (UP) -- The Government announced today that Moscow University's thirty-two-story "temple of learning" had been completed and would open tomorrow.

Gross operating revenues of the Dayton Power and Light Company reached a record $55,213,000 in the twelve months to June 30, an increase of 8.4 per cent over the preceding year. But operating costs also rose and as a result net income was held to $6,941,200 or $2.69 a share, according to the statement issued for publication today by Kenneth C. Long, president.

Theodore M. Wolkof on the teamster strike in the concrete, sand and gravel industry charges that "to date all that has been done by the Mayor of our fair city has been to appoint a so-called Citizens Mediatory Committee. While I do not criticize the members of this committee in their tireless efforts to settle this 'strike,' the fact is that they do not have the power to cope with the situation."

The promotion of James J. Doyle to the post of controller of the Port of New York Authority was announced yesterday. Mr. Doyle, who joined the agency last year as deputy controller, succeeds Karl G. Clement, who resigned recently.

Trading volume on the New York Stock Exchange in August was slightly larger than in July and the largest for the month since 1951. Sales exceeded the million-share mark in thirteen sessions, the largest of which was 2,192,220, yesterday. The smallest daily turnover was 846,275 shares, on Aug. 21.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- The Department of Defense announced today that Roger M. Kyes, its Deputy Secretary, would leave next Thursday on a thirty-day inspection trip to United States military installations and military units in Europe.

For the past year, in the Riverdale community of the West Bronx, an act of interfaith has added an unforgettable chapter to the principles of "living religion." It is just a year since the ground was literally cut from under Riverdale Temple to make way for the mushrooming apartment houses, and left the congregation without a house of worship.

The three-story building containing a store and two apartments at 104-18 Corona Avenue in Corona, Queens, has been sold by Vincent Santangelo to Joseph Valwie. Anthony Presto and Charles Vante were the brokers and the Lawyers Mortgage and Title Company insured title.

Sayan Bargan Ati's letter in your issue of Aug. 28 is highly interesting to us. It points up so clearly the terrible price the Kalmyks have paid for their love of freedom. But it fails to mention that some 600 of the Kalmyks have been given permanent sanctuary in the United States, where they are rapidly demonstrating the very strong "American" attributes which Bargan Ati mentions.
Deere Co., agricultural equipment makers, suffered a sharp setback in earnings as a result of lower sales volume, according to the report issued yesterday for the nine months ended July 31.

BERLIN, Aug. 31 -- The West Berlin Government sought today to take the sting out of the Communists' propaganda against the West's food giveaway program in this city. It announced a special aid program for the unemployed in the Western sectors this winter.

SALT LAKE CITY, Aug. 31 -- The refusal of Gov. J. Bracken Lee to proclaim Oct. 24 as United Nations Day in Utah brought the retort from citizens' groups today that the Governor "has no right to reject the United Nations in the name of the state as a whole."

The ending of vacation time is almost here. It has gone quickly, too quickly; almost as fast as either light or the vacation time of last year. The car now is a little dusty from travel along country roads, and the paint of the boat bears scars from the rocks guarding pools where the pickerel lay.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 31 -- Yugoslavia is about to repudiate the clauses of the Italian peace treaty of 1947 that provide for the establishment of the Free Territory of Trieste under United Nations sponsorship.
Production of a diamond grinding tool for fine-finish work that combines several "firsts" was announced yesterday by Maurice S. Dessau Company, Inc., industrial diamond concern founded in 1841.

The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, through its administrator, Roy Wilkins, at 20 West Fortieth Street, yesterday called on Gov. G. Mennen Williams of Michigan to help end discrimination against Negro airmen in Sault Sainte Marie.

PARIS, Aug. 31 -- The agreement of butchers in the Paris region to lower prices of certain cuts of beef by 10 per cent beginning Sept. 8 was seen today as the first tangible result of present efforts by Premier Joseph Laniel to lower the cost of living. This was one of labor's complaints in the recent strike wave.

Over the week-end the Department of Sanitation sent four trucks into Sea Gate, a private colony on the western tip of Coney Island, thus averting a threatened protest march on City Hall set for yesterday by the strike-bound homeowners.

LONDON, Aug. 31 -- The stock market here finished a quiet session today with a sprinkling of modest gains among leading industrials and improvements up to 1/8 per cent in British Government securities.

Another victory by Dr. Max Euwe of Amsterdam enabled the former international champion to take the lead in the world championship challengers tournament among fifteen contenders at Neuhausen, last night, according to a report from Zurich, Switzerland.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 31 -- India today disputed the United States' contention that Puerto Rico was a former territory that had achieved self-government, and expressed the opinion that the matter should be referred to the United Nations General Assembly for decision.

William O'Dwyer, former Mayor of New York City and Ambassador to Mexico, was described by his former wife here yesterday as a "perfectly honest man who almost killed himself trying to be a good Mayor."

Mayor Impellitteri cut the ribbons yesterday that opened an exhibit of paintings and sculpture by twenty Philippine artists. It is the first showing held in the galleries of the new Carnegie Endowment International Center at United Nations Plaza and Forty-sixth Street.

A group of eleven women leaders f Italian trade unions, now visitng this country under State Deartment auspices, was received by [ayor Impellitteri yesterday.' He :reeted the women*on behalf of the ity and urged them to take home a convincing story of how democsay works."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (UP) -- The Foreign Service Journal said today that the career service might lose its nonpartisan makeup and some of its best men if State Department employes were dismissed merely because they had worked under a Democratic administration.

Federal and city narcotics squad authorities collaborated yesterday in arresting a man -- in this country only four months -- who was in possession of ten pounds of hashish. He was seized as he was about to leave the Port Authority Bus Terminal, Eighth Avenue and Forty-first Street.

Yesterday's heat did not stop Fordham University from starting football practice on schedule, Ed Danowski began his eighth season as head coach by sending a squad of forty-seven, including twenty-two lettermen, through light morning and afternoon workouts at Fordham Field.

SPRINGFIELD, N. J., Sept. 1 -- A thirty-three-year-old home club player, Homer O. Lichtenwalter Jr., led the Metropolitan district's sixteen qualifiers in the sectional trials for the United States Golf Association's amateur championship at the Baltusrol Golf Club today.

Rank-and-file leaders of the two-month strike of sand, gravel and concrete drivers gave assurances last night that the strikers would return to work today in response to an arbitrate-or-else ultimatum from Dave Beck, president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, A. F. L.

Commercial and industrial failures turned upward in the week ended on last Thursday. Figures compiled by Dun Bradstreet show 182 failures against 122 a week before and 132 a year earlier. In the 1951 week there were 164 and in the pre-war 1939 week there were 229.

The United Seamen's Service is considering a program of expansion of its work abroad as a result of surveys of shore recreational facilities for American merchant seamen in Europe, the Middle East and the Far East.

BERLIN, Sept. 1 -- Berlin remains the most fantastic of all cities. It is still a sprawling skeleton of its former self, but the inhabitants no longer seem to notice the ruins. Physically the broken skyscape changes every year as new buildings go up -- more slowly than in other German towns -and the remains of old ones are cleared away.

The State of Texas borrowed $15,000,000 yesterday on veterans' land bonds at an interest cost of 2.6626 per cent. The bonds, which will come due serially from 1960 to 1989, were sold at public bidding to a syndicate headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., at a bid of 100 for bonds bearing interest coupons of 3 per cent, 2 1/2 per cent, 2.7 per cent and 2 3/4 per cent.

CHICAGO, Sept. 1 -- Wheat futures which were under pressure of long liquidation yesterday turned strong today, while corn and soybean futures met rather free selling. Spreads between wheat and corn and soybeans which have been popular recently were closed out in many cases, the wheat end being bought today.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 1 -- The voluminous transcript of the United Nations General Assembly debate on the proposed Far Eastern political conference has been sent to Moscow by air mail for relay to Communist China and North Korea. The transscript was mailed yesterday and is expected to reach the Moscow Information Office of the United Nations within five to twelve days.

LONDON Sept. 1 -- Britain will ask the United States and other Governments adhering to the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade to approve some specific tariff increases when the member Governments meet in Geneva on Sept. 17, but will not ask for any general revision of the agreement, official sources said here today.

The Duke Power Company borrowed $35,000,000 of long-term capital in the public market yesterday by the sale of an issue of first and refunding mortgage bonds at an interest cost of about 3.65 per cent.

FRASER, Colo., Sept. 1 -- President Eisenhower, responding to a plea from bankrupt Iran for technical, financial and economic aid, released tonight a declaration that the United States stood "ready to assist."

TOKYO, Wednesday, Sept. 2 -- The exchange of Korean war prisoners continued today at Panmunjom with the completion of the transfer expected within a week. The Communist delivery of Allied prisoners dropped to 300 today, 100 fewer than the daily total turned over to the United Nations authorities since Operation Big Switch began early in August. Among those returned today were 100 Americans and 200 South Koreans.

The proposed redevelopment plan for the area south of Washington Square illustrates the value of a slower and more painstaking approach to site selection and planning. The combination of housing renting at $9, $17 and $48 per room is precisely what the city needs.

Stock technicians appeared to have gotten their signals mixed yesterday. After the persistent and steady liquidation of share values on Monday, which had pushed prices down to their lowest levels since May 1, 1952, there had been a growing belief in Wall Street that the brokerage houses at the opening yesterday could expect a fresh deluge of selling orders before a technical rebound would set in.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (AP) -- The Army said tonight it was investigating the case of a supervising engineer who has remained in his job since his indictment in July, 1952, on charges of perjury and fraud against the Government.

The city will be without a major mid-Manhattan convention and exhibition hall for more than three years because Grand Central Palace will hold its last show next month and construction of the New York Coliseum has been blocked by litigation.

One of the rewards of having Robert Moses as a city official is the steady succession of lucid and stimulating brochures that come from his pen, instructing the public on what he is doing and thinking, outlining the future, and taking on all comers in hand-to-hand combat when necessary. The latest of these brochures, issued under the imprint of the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority, is titled "The Influence of Public Improvements on Property Values."

PARIS, Sept. 1 -- Marshal Alphonse Pierre Juin, Commander in Chief of all North Atlantic Treaty forces in the strategic central sector of Western Europe, publicly urged the United States Government today to release sufficient information on atomic weapons to allow non-American Allied commanders to do their job effectively.

CAMP DRUM, N. Y., Sept. 1 -- The use of secret writing by radio-active materials and its detection through a Geiger counter was advanced as a possibility in espionage here today by Capt. James W. Osterburg of the 497th Military Police Crime Laboratory Detachment in a lecture to reservist criminal investigators.

WILLSBORO, N. Y., Sept. 1 Miss Sylvia Doris Hayes, daught of Dr. and Mrs. Albert L. Hayes Willsboro, was married to Sidn Robert Lawrence Couling, son Mrs. Sidney N. Couling of Va couver, B. C., and the late Mrs. Couling, this morning in St. Phillip of Jesus Roman Catholic Church.

The Lockheed Aircraft Corporation in the first six months this year achieved the highest sales in its history and a post-war record in earnings, according to the semi-annual report yesterday of Robert E. Gross, president.

BAY SHORE, L. I., Sept. 1 -- Two men who set out on a fishing trip early Sunday from East Rockaway in an eighteen-foot flat-bottomed boat propelled by an old outboard engine were found today adrift in the Atlantic Ocean, twenty-five miles south-southwest of Fire Island Inlet.

BARCELONNETTE, France, Wednesday, Sept. 2 (UP) -- An Air France Constellation with forty-two persons aboard crashed in flames on a peak in the French Alps, about 100 miles northeast of Marseilles, shortly before midnight. All were feared to have died.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (AP) -- Cigarette users sent up record clouds of smoke in the twelve months ended June 30.

RABAT, Morocco, Sept. 1 -- The Sultan of Morocco, Sidi Mohammed ben Moulay Arafa, sealed an imperial decree today delegating his administrative powers to an Inner Council to be presided over by the Grand Vizier (Premier).
The cotton futures market closed steady yesterday, with active months 2 to 7 points net higher than on Monday, due to last-minute covering by local traders and a little price fixing.

Commissioner Edward F. Cavanagh reported yesterday that his Marine and Aviation Department had spent, or made commitments to spend, $33,000,000 on improving the city-owned waterfront in the three years ended last Dec. 31.

Ownership of Chase Aircraft Company passed into new hands today when Willys Motors, Inc., purchased from Michael Stroukoff his 51 per cent interest in the company for $1,690,000. Kaiser Motors Corporation, which purchased Willys Motors, Inc., last April 28, owns the remaining 49 per cent of the Chase stock.

Plans are being formulated for the dinner-dance and fashion show to be held for the benefit of various organizations on Oct. 6 in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf- Astoria under the auspices of the National Federation of Textiles, Inc.
MUNSAN, Korea, Wednesday, Sept. 2 (AP) -- Official list of United States war prisoners freed by the Communists today at Panmunjom:

Charles I. Stewart, Americ Labor party candidate for Pre. dent of the City Council, asserh last night in a television spee{ that thousands of parcels'of indu trial real estate in New York we underassessed for tax purpose This situation, he declared, is r sponsible for the increase in t] trar/sit fare to 15 cents.
MINEOLA, L. I., Sept. 1 -- It's harvest time at the Nassau County Prison Farm and canning time at the Nassau County jail.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Sept. 1 -- Mohammed Ali, Prime Minister of Pakistan, told the nation in his second monthly 'fireside chat" tonight that the Government "would not rest" until its pledge to the people of Kashmir had been redeemed.

Your editorial "Teach -- or Drive a Truck" merits the appreciation not only of teachers but of the public at large. Taken together with the recent news account that the country faces a shortage of 72,000 qualified teachers with the reopening of schools in a few weeks, the editorial underscores what is a major concern for the country.

A Federal mediator will attempt this afternoon to end the two-week-old strike of broadcast engineers against Stations WOR and WOR-TV. Commissioner J. R. Mandelbaum of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service announced that he had arranged to meet at 2:30 P. M. with officials of the two stations and the Radio and Television Broadcast Engineers Union, Local 1212, A. F. L.

Such popular materials as brass, wrought iron, glass and walnut have been used in a collection of furniture and decorative accessories made by the Elton Company and available at the Tropic Shop, 381 Fifth Avenue.

PORT JERVIS, N. Y., Sept. 1 -- The National Jewish Youth Conference today voted to reorganize itself into a nation-wide body of more than 300 local and regional Jewish youth and young adult councils. The action tok place at the next to final session of the conferences sixth annual assembly, now being held at Cejwin Camp near here.

The first penal provisions of the New York-New Jersey waterfront control laws became effective in a technical sense yesterday, but the checkerboard pattern of operative dates embodied in the statutes enabled locals of the crime-infested International Longshoremen's Association, A. F. L., to ignore the sanctions without fear of immediate prosecution.

CHICAGO, Sept. 1 -- The United Rubber Workers of America, C. I. O., today concluded contract negotiations here with the B. F. Goodrich Company granting wage increases and other benefits. This moved the union a step toward pressing for general adoption in the industry of the pattern set with the Goodrich company and with the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company.

The Right Rev. Horace B. Donegan, Protestant Episcopal Bishop of New York, stepped ashore here from a European vacation trip yesterday with sharp criticism of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin.

BONN, Germany, Sept. 1 -- The West German Cabinet decided today to ask the constitutional court in Karlsruhe to outlaw the extreme nationalist German Reich party, which has thirty-nine former Nazis among its candidates for Parliament in Sunday's elections.
FRASER, Colo., Sept. 1 (AP) -- Following is the text of the exchange of correspondence between President Eisenhower and Premier Zahedi:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- A House of Representatives investigating subcommittee recommended today that testimony in its inquiry into strikes and alleged racketeering that had paralyzed the building trade industry in the Kansas City area for two months be sent to the Department of Justice for grand jury study.

CHICAGO, Sept. 1 -- Stephen A. Mitchell, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, was like a nervous hostess today whose dinner invitations were lost or delayed in the mails. He did not know how many places to set at the table.

NYACK, N. Y., Sept. 1 -- Assurance that this community would have full access to the New York-Buffalo Thruway was offered today by representatives of the Thruway Authority at an indignation meeting called by the Chamber of Commerce.

LONDON, Sept. 1 -- The British Post Office Department displayed today devices used to detect television sets whose owners have not paid the license fee that supports the state-owned British Broadcasting Corporation.

Siegfried Frisch Hartman, for many years a leading lawyer here, fell or jumped to his death at 6:45 o'clock last night, the police reported, from a window of his office on the thirty-sixth floor at 39 Broadway. He was 65 years old, lived at 1 East Sixty-sixth Street and had a summer home at Harbourton, N. J.

WESTBURY, L. I., Sept. 1 (AP) -- Yuk-a-Puk, owned by A. M. Nardin and Mr. and Mrs. Morey Amsterdam of New York, held off the late charge of Dominion Prince tonight to win the Greenvale Pace by a neck at Roosevelt Raceway.

In 1910 Elizabeth Shepley Sergeant, just out of Bryn Mawr, sold her first article to Willa Sibert Cather, then managing editor of McClure's magazine. That began a friendship of long duration. Next Wednesday Lippincott will publish Miss Sergeant's "Willa Cather: A Memoir," wherein the author traces Miss Cather's development as a novelist and as an individual in relation to the changing times.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., Sept. 1 -Howard McMichael, seeking to bring the Two-Ten class national sailing championship to the Western Long Island Sound fleet for the first time, led his nine rivals to the finish in the second and third tests of the five-race series today.
TONY SCHWARTZ collects the sounds along the sidewalks of New York.

YOU Are There," the C. B. S. television program that deals with historical events, returned in the midst of the summer heat wave last Sunday for the new season. Despite the hot weather, it bore up rather well.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 1 -- The United States decision to vote against placing the Moroccan question on the agenda of the United Nations Security Council was criticized today by both the Pakistani and Lebanese members of the council.

Picking up an unearned run in the eighth after tying the score in the seventh, the Giants defeated the Cubs, 10 -- 9, at the Polo Grounds yesterday. Sal Maglie failed to survive three innings in this thirty-hit struggle.

It was fine weather yesterday -- for the tropical fish in Mrs. Minnie Goldberg's pet shop at 51 East Ninety-eighth Street, Brooklyn. But the rest of the merchandise, furred and feathered, was getting fed up with eight days of gasping heat.

Harold Riegelman, Republican designee for Mayor, took his three major adversaries to task in a television appearance last night. Neither Mayor Impellitteri nor Borough President Robert F. Wagner Jr., the principal rivals for the Democratic nomination, offers any hope of good government, he said. Rudolph Halley, the Liberal candidate, he went on, would be the captive of a "labor czar."

Vice President Nixon went far beyond the grudging words of the Republican platform of last year when he spoke of Korea in his address at the American Legion Convention in St. Louis on Monday. "Let's recognize right now," he said, "that the decision to go into Korea was right.

TRENTON, Sept. 1 -- Elmer K. Wene, Vineland poultry farmer and unsuccessful candidate for the Democratic nomination for Governor, admitted today that his supporters were circulating petitions throughout New Jersey in hope of getting him back into the race for Governor.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 1 -- The dismissal during a Congressional loyalty inquiry of eleven of twenty-one United States citizens who were employes of the United Nations was declared "illegal" today by the Administrative Tribunal of the world organization.

Sears, Roebuck Co., the nation's largest merchandising organization selling through the mail and through a nation-wide chain of retail stores, set a sales record in the twenty-four weeks ended on July 16 and also increased its earnings over the corresponding period of 1952.

An "alarming" number of resignations as a result of low pay and long hours has caused the highest turnover in history in police departments in this state outside New York City, delegates to the twenty-eighth annual convention of the Police Conference of the State of New York at the Commodore Hotel were told yesterday.

IT was either the first or second time that he appeared in the national tennis championships at Forest Hills. Vic Seixas, an unknown of 17, found himself matched against Frankie Kovacs, the uninhibited character. Kovacs could play like crazy and also behave in the same manner. Vic was nervous, anyway, and the prospect of meeting Kovacs left him with feelings akin to complete awe.

State Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein announced yesterday that he was investigating all forty-two of the proprietary hospitals here for possible violations of the law, as a result of scores of complaints from every borough in the city and some outlying counties.
Princess Christine, an alert Dalmatian, celebrated her first birthday yesterday by being presented to the Uniformed Firemen's Association and the members of Engine Company 44 as a mascot.

NEW CANAAN, Conn., Sept. 1 -- Mrs. John H. Bartol of Greenwich, a former Westchester-Fairfield champion, won low gross honors in the Westchester division of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association one-day tournaments.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Sept. 1 -- The second international study conference on the North Atlantic Treaty Organization heard today a Norwegian proposal to establish an "Atlantic Parliament" in Paris, and a United States suggestion of an advisory council of labor and trade union representatives to be at the organization's disposal for consultation on labor questions.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (UP) -- Farming representatives urged the Tariff Commission today to increase import duties on wool to protect United States growers, but wool manufacturers and importers immediately protested.

FREEDOM VILLAGE, Korea, Sept. 1 -- A United States lieutenant colonel who is a West Point graduate told today how the Communists, using starvation as a lever, forced him to make radio broadcasts and write magazine articles following the Communist party line. He was compelled to say, among other things, "Capitalists in America started the Korean war."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- The Department of Justice was asked by the Congress of Industrial Organization to continue the work of the Federal Bureau of Investigation in tracing down violations of the Federal Civil Rights statutes despite complaints by two state governors that this was an invasion of state police powers.

New York's floating grain elevators have completed the loading of 17,000,000 bushels of grain aboard seventy-five Liberty ships from the Maritime Administration's Hudson River reserve fleet, it became known yesterday.

CHAPEL HILL, N. C., Sept. 1 -- Frank P. Smith, University of Michigan was elected president of the American Accounting Association at tonight's session of the annual convention of the association at the University of North Carolina.
An important fabricator of copper and copper-alloy products has trimmed its prices, effective today, in a move expected to touch off an industry-wide revision of the price structure.
I read with the greatest dismay the plan to add bedlam to "Bagdad-on. the-Subway."
WENDOVER,, Utah, Sept. 1 (AP) -- A California driver sent his modified "jalopy" speeding over the Bonneville Salt Flats at 136.158 miles an hour today to set a record in its class.

PARIS, Sept. 1 -- Edgar Faure, the Minister of Finance, announced today a campaign against income tax evasion, which, he said, had already uncovered frauds amounting to 30,000,000,000 francs, or $85,000,000, including undeclared funds held abroad by Frenchmen.
Sales in August for eleven major New York City department stores registered an aggregate loss of 5 per cent compared with a year ago, according to a survey made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (AP) -- Wool traders and representatives of textile manufacturers before the Tariff Commission today opposed proposed increases in duties on imported wools.

President Eisenhower has named two new members to the National Labor Relations Board and will soon name a third to the five-member body. This major personnel change may have widespread repercussions on labor-management relations and should therefore be of great public interest.

MONTREAL, Sept. 1 -- New studies suggesting that the blood vessels have tiny holes that normally leak dissolved materials into body tissues surrounding the blood vessel endings were reported here today at the opening of the scientific session of the Nineteenth International Physiological Congress.

LONDON, Sept. 1 -- The stock markets here were depressed at the start of business today by the set-back on Wall Street yesterday. However, little selling developed and prices rallied to close with minor irregular movements.

Two new films open today at first-run theatres. At the Trans-Lux Sixtieth Street is "Sailor of the King," the film version of the C. S. Forester novel "Brown on Resolution." The Twentieth Century-Fox production stars Jeffrey Hunter, Michael Renie and Wendy Hiller. Valentine Davies wrote the screen play and Roy Boulting directed it.

MEXICO CITY, Sept. 1 (UP) -- President Adolfo Ruiz Cortines said today that Mexico planned to open new lands to cultivation in an effort to stem the tide of migrant workers entering the United States illegally.

Reference is made to Benjamin Welles' dispatch from Roquencourt, published in THE NEW YORK TIMES on Aug. 14, on the planned visit to Norway and Denmark by Gen. Alfred M. Gruenther, Supreme Allied Commander.

A second "Kraft Television Theatre" program will be initiated on Oct. 15 over the A. B. C. network, where it will be presented each Thursday from 9:30 to 10:30 P. M. The current drama program by that title, which will continue, is televised over the N. B. C. network on Wednesdays from 9 to 10 P. M.

In conformity with the resolution of the General Assembly of the United Nations requesting the United States, after consultation with the other participating countries on our side, to arrange with the Communist side the time and place for the political conference on Korea, representatives of the seventeen nations concerned have met in Washington and have reached a quick "identity of approach" in regard to both points.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (AP) -- More Americans were working last month than ever before and fewer were unemployed than at any time since the end of World War II, the Department of Commerce reported today.

EAST LANSING, Mich., Sept. 1 -- The idea that "adjustment" is an ideal state for individuals and families to achieve, the one that will best ease their problems and increase their happiness, is outmoded and should be supplanted by an aim based on more positive values, Dr. Nelson Foote, director of the Family Study Center, at the University of Chicago, declared today.

The present ugly conflict over Trieste will at least serve to call attention to one of the most sensitive and dangerous spots in Europe. This is small consolation at a time when the world is so full of conflicts and trouble spots, but it never pays to ignore a keg of dynamite in these inflammable times.
DES MOINES, Iowa, Septt. 1 (UP) -- Iowa's once-booming corn crop has been scorched severely by a long spell of hot, dry weather and will fall far short of 1952's record crop, two reports said today.

Subscription books will be opened today for the Treasury's offering of one-year 2 5/8 per cent certificates of indebtedness and three-and-one-half-year 2 7/8 per cent notes in exchange for $7,986,242,000 of 2 per cent bonds which mature on Sept. 15. The books will be closed after the close of business Friday. No cash subscriptions will be taken.

TEHERAN, Iran, Sept. 1 -- Premier Fazlollah Zahedi made a ceremonial visit to the Majlis (lower house of the Iranian Parliament) today where he was received by about fifteen of the twenty-two Deputies who resisted Dr. Mossadegh and refused to recognize his dissolution of the Legislature in July.

Borough President Robert F. Wagner Jr. of Manhattan renewed and amplified yesterday his charge that underworld support was being given to his principal rival for the Democratic mayoral nomination, Mayor Impellitteri, in the Sept. 15 primary.

Organization is not only the key to efficient housework but also a time-saving device, whether it be in scouring a bathroom or removing 40,000 dead pigeons from a theatre floor, according to two representatives of the Handi-Man Company, Inc.

A seventeen-hit Dodger assault on five Cardinal pitchers more than nullified the five home runs yielded by Preacher Roe yesterday as the Brooks, who now lead the second-place Braves by eleven games, romped to a 12-5 triumph over the Redbirds before a Ladies' Day assembly of 15,477 spectators.

LIMA, Peru, Sept. 1 -- President Manuel A. Odria returned this afternoon from a one-week goodwill visit to Brazil. That is an important milestone in South American relations. It marked the establishment of what might be called a Lima-Rio de Janeiro axis in opposition to the spread of the influence of President Juan D. Peron of Argentina.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- The secrecy covering the present exercises of the Strategic Air Command in the Far East fails to conceal the principal fact that will be gleaned by all professional military observers, friendly and unfriendly alike.

ROME, Sept. 1 -- In reply to the note from Belgrade protesting against the military precautions taken by Italy at the Yugoslav frontier, the Italian Government deplored the unsatisfactory state of its relations with Yugoslavia, but asserted its right to take whatever precautions it believed necessary on its own territory.
ALTHOUGH the big fish reports are scarce, the coastal fishing is extremely productive for those willing to accept bluefish, fluke, blackfish and occasional school stripers.

Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, chairman of the Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations, "ordered" the Army yesterday to produce personnel files and names of individuals responsible for clearance of three civilian employes whose alleged links with Communist activities he is now studying.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 1 -- An estimate that 3,000 voluntary, non-profit hospitals in this country had sustained a net loss of $140,000,000 last year was made at the annual convention of the American Hospital Association here today. Hospital administrators were told that the day had passed when they could be confident that losses would be made up from philanthropy.
CAMP PERRY, Ohio, Sept. 1 (UP) M/Sgt. Maxim R. Beebe of the Marine Corps, San Diego, Calif., gained the lead today in the service rifle division of the national high-power rifle championships.

BIARRITZ, France, Sept. 1 (UP) -- A cannonade of champaigne corks launched what may be Europe's biggest post-war party here tonight as 2,000 of the international elite assembled to gambol until dawn in an ornate eighteenth-century setting.

LONDON, Sept. 1 -- Squadron leader Neville Duke flew his red Hawker Hunter swept-wing jet plane yesterday at an average speed of 722 miles an hour -- six miles an hour faster than the world's record, the Royal Aero Club announced tonight.

It was a little cooler yesterday, but not enough to make anyone notice it particularly. The day's highest temperature, registered at 1:40 P. M., was 93.1 degrees, and that was sufficient to make it the hottest Sept. 1 on record here. At least six persons in the area died from the heat.

Last summer, like this, had its hot days, but not so persistent and tormenting a succession of them. Some of the meteorologists then attributed the heat to a 200-mile-wide wind that blew in June out of Siberia, swept over the Pacific and then raced across the United States in an irregular course.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Sept. 1 -- More than 85,000 persons marched through the searing heat and heavy humidity of downtown St. Louis today, as the American Legion staged its annual national convention parade.

Directors of Foremost Dairies, Inc., placed the common stock on an annual basis of $1.40 a share yesterday with the declaration of quarterly dividend of 35 cents, voted for payment on Oct. 1. Common stockholders had been receiving 25 cents quarterly.

Six adjourned games, four from the first round and two from the second, were decided yesterday in the world chess championship challengers' tournament at Neuhausen in Switzerland, according to a report from Zurich.
DETROIT, Sept. 1 (AP) -- Ray Herbert, a big disappointment all season, achieved a sparkling relief job today as the Tigers defeated the Athletics 7 -- 5.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept. 1 (UP) -- Dr. Oswaldo Aranha, Minister of Finance, asked Congress today to enact a drastic eight-point retrenchment program designed to lift Brazil out of her current economic troubles.

The Metropolitan area will have 102 athletes among those representing the United States in the fourth World Maccabiah Games at Tel Aviv, Israel, Sept. 20-29. The tentative list of candidates, including alternate choices, was released yesterday.

If Winifred Lenihan, Katharine Cornell and Uta Hagen can do it, Jean Arthur feels she can, too. Although Miss Arthur has been extremely reticent in discussing the subject, it was learned on excellent authority yesterday that she had agreed to depict the title role in "Saint Joan,". Shaw's episodic chronicle play.

CHICAGO, Sept. 1 -- Chicago's goose was seen as good as cooked tonight when, in the steaming arena of Comiskey Park, Casey Stengel's Yankees brought down the White Sox, 3 to 2, before a gathering of 45,003 sweltering fans.

Growth, in summer, by no means is confined to flowers, vegetables and weeds. The head of the house may have this impressed upon him one day when, as he is planning to get in some late-season fishing, a certain member of the family whose eye for matters domestic is unusually keen observes that the young man of the house now seems big enough to be taken on angling expeditions.

A new fish restaurant is a timely subject to bring up at the start of the cold weather oyster season, which opened yesterday, despite the anything but cold weather. The Sea Gull is the restaurant's name. It's a small place at 810 Third Avenue (Fiftieth Street), which pleases diners in the seemingly minor details that, all together, help in totaling a successful meal.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 1 -- Yugoslavia threatened today to bring the problem of Italian-Yugoslav relations before an "international forum" unless Italy ceased her alleged "armed demonstrations" at the Yugoslav frontier near the Free Territory of Trieste.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- The United States and sixteen other countries whose troops fought in Korea on the United Nations side were reported today to have agreed on three alternate sites for a Korean political conference with the communist representatives.

NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 1 -- The Indian Government emphatically repudiated today reports said to be circulating in Central Africa that a large number of Indians were attempting to enter Northern Rhodesia with a view to swelling the Indian population in that territory before the Central African Federation -- Northern and Southern Rhodesia and Nyasaland -- comes into being Sunday.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 1 -- Plans for floating of a bond issue at least $2,000,000 to build a motion picture museum or hall "fame" here were disclosed today by Jean Hersholt, president of the Motion Picture Relief Fund, which would operate the museum a fund-raising enterprise.
CLEVELAND, Sept. 1 (UP) -- With Al Rosen belting his thirty-sixth homer and driving in three runs, the Indians routed the Red Sox today, 13 to 3.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept 1 -- By a vote of 12 to 0 with three abstentions -- Indonesia, Iraq, and Pakistan -- the Committee on Information from Non-Self-Governing Territories this afternoon adopted a resolution regarding the changed governmental status of Puerto Rico.

In his Aug. 26 speech before the American Bar Association Secretary John Foster Dulles has added to be wilderment and irrelevancy by indicting the "unanimity principle" which governs action by the Security Council of the United Nations on other than procedural matters.

Estimates by the B. F. Goodrich Company indicate that the United States will consume more new rubber this year than ever before and sales of all types of pneumatic tires will be the second highest in history.

The fur touch is almost a magic word in fall fashion, so important is its influence. Endorsed on both sides of the Atlantic, luxurious-looking little fur trims add new style significance to whatever they ornament. This trend, which has been dramatized by coat, suit and dress designers as well as by furriers, has spread through the accessory field, leaving its mark on almost every type of fashion.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- The Public Health Service advised a group of New York health officials today that country-wide supplies of gamma globulin were so limited that any extension of its wholesale use to camps and schools where poliomyelitis occurred "does not seem justified."

SAIGON, Vietnam, Sept. 1 -- Official negotiations between France and Cambodia were resumed today in Pnompenh in an effort to settle the question of Cambodian independence in the military sphere. The negotiations have reached an agreement on Cambodia's control of the local police and judicial systems.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (AP) -- Congress may insist on a cut in corporation income taxes next year, Representative Richard M. Simpson, Republican of Pennsylvania, said today, but may compromise on 4 per cent instead of 10.

The Atomic Energy Commission announced yesterday a modification of its existing contract with the Union Carbide and Carbon Corporation to include operation of additional facilities now under construction both at Oak Ridge, Tenn., and at Paducah, Ky.

Hundreds of defaulted dollar bonds of pre-war Germany were presented for validation here yesterday as the two special depositaries named for the purpose -- J. P. Morgan Co., Inc., and National City Bank -- began the big job of sifting the holdings of American investors.

CAIRO, Sept. 1 -- The progress made at an unscheduled meeting today between British and Egyptian negotiators on the future status of the British Suez Canal military base led a high Egyptian official to declare that "it is unlikely that we shall fail to reach an agreement."

TOKYO, Sept. 1 -- The Communist radios at Peiping and Pyongyang announced today that Kim Il Sung, North Korean Premier, and five other top leaders of the North Korean Communist regime had departed for Moscow this morning "on the invitation of the Government of the U. S. S. R."

Stopping Robert Perry a stroke short of 2 sets-all after the 20-year-old Los Angeles youth had taken nine games in a row to lead by 4 -- 0 in the final set, Straight Clark of Pasadena, Calif., won the match, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 3, 1 -- 6, 7 -- 5, yesterday in the national tennis championship at Forest Hills.

NAPLES, Sept. 1 (AP) -- Lieut. Comdr. Agostino Straulino of the Italian Navy today piloted his Merope II to a second straight victory in defense of his world Star Class sailing championship. The five American yachts finished far back.

Volume continued light yesterday on the New York commodity exchanges except on hides, cottonseed oil and soybean oil, which registered the most activity in more than a week. Prices closed irregular with cottonseed oil, soybean oil, cocoa, coffee, copper and lead higher; wool, sugar, zinc, tin and rubber lower, and hides and potatoes mixed.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (AP) -- A Senate subcommittee announced today it would open public hearings about Nov. 1 in an investigation of Communist penetration of trade unions.

LANSING, Mich., Sept. 1 -- Gov. G. Mennen Williams of Michigan said today that he had received a telegram from Roy Wilkins, administrator of the National Association for the Advancement of the Colored People, complaining of alleged race discriminatory practices by Sault Ste. Marie business places.
ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 1 (UP) -- Two jockeys suffered slight injuries and a horse was fatally injured in a spill during the fourth race today at Atlantic City.

Level Lea kept trying when all seemed lost in the feature race at Aqueduct yesterday and the perseverance exhibited by John S. Phipps' colt paid off in victory. Established the odds-on favorite by the crowd of 14,959 in the mile and a sixteenth test, Level Lea responded to Jockey Bennie Green's urging to win by a length.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- The Office of Defense Mobilization is reviewing expansion goals it set for some 233 industries following the outbreak of war in Korea, Arthur Flemming, head of the Defense agency, said today.

Thomas E. Lewis, slain union leader, knew that his life was in danger and had reason to believe that his death was plotted by persons who sought to take over his labor post, Assistant District Attorney George Tilzer of the Bronx said yesterday.

The Association of American Geographers, stimulated by Professor Coulter of the University of Cincinnati, has called upon the Department of Health, Education and Welfare to stress to educators the need for greater emphasis upon the study of geography in its widest aspects.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., Sept. 1 -- Gov. Earl Warren said today that he would announce "in the not too distant future" whether he would be a candidate for re-election next year. He is serving his third term.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- The National Mediation Board met twice today with representatives of the Order of Railroads Conductors and with representatives of the carriers in an attempt to forestall a walkout threatened by the conductors' union for Sept. 10.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Sept. 1 -- The seventh general assembly of the World Medical Association, which opened its sessions here today, voted to admit the medical associations of Brazil, Indonesia and Liechtenstein as members, bringing the total of countries represented by their national medical organizations to forty-six, with a membership of nearly 750,000 physicians.

CHICAGO, Sept. 1 -- An agreement providing for the merger of Walter E. Heller Co., commercial financier, and National Discount Corporation, automobile financing organization, was announced today by Walter E. Heller, president of the Heller company.

JERSEY CITY, Sept. 1 -- The resignation of Capt. J. Leo O'Connor, commander of the Montgomery Street police station, was accepted by the City Commission today, less than two weeks after Henry (the Dutchman) Grunewald, the so-called Washington mystery man, was found overcome by gas in an apartment two blocks from the station.

TEHERAN, Iran, Sept. 1 -- The Soviet Embassy's denial today failed to silence reports that Ambassador Anatoli I. Lavrentiev had attempted suicide in his summer residence at Gholhak, ten miles north of Teheran.

A campaign to garner for the building materials industry some of the large sums spent by consumers around Christmas has been started by the Douglas Fir Plywood Association of Tacoma, Wash. The plan is geared to develop new over-the-counter plywood business for lumber dealers -- the kind that has formerly passed them by during the holiday season.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 1 -- Following are excerpts from a decision handed down today by the United Nations Administrative Tribunal ordering the reinstatement of Miss Ruth E. Crawford, one of twenty-one United States citizens who had been dismissed from the staff as a result of loyalty investigations:

BONN, Germany, Sept. 1 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer promised today to carry through his policy of integrating West Germany into West Europe if his coalition returned to power after Sunday's general election.

BONN, Germany, Sept. 1 -- The Soviet High Commissioner, Vladimir Semyenov, countered tonight a proposal of the three Western High Commissioners to negotiate the restoration of freedom of travel for all Germans to all parts of Germany with the suggestion that the rival Governments of the East Zone and the Federal Republic discuss this problem and other "urgent questions" on the reunification of Germany.
CLEVELAND, Sept. 2 (UP) -- Wally Westlake walloped a pair of home runs tonight to pace the Indians to a 6-3 victory over the Athletics.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 (AP) -- The Tariff Commission was told today that wool growers were "stunned" by the Department of Agriculture's proposal for only a 7 cents a pound boost in import fees on clean wool.

Addressing the annual Police Conference of the State of New York, Mayor Impellitteri "guaranteed" he would bring this city's police force up to authorized strength of 20,878 men. This we will have to wait to see.

ALBANY, Sept. 2 -- The State Motor Vehicle Bureau ruled today that drivers charged with operating a car while intoxicated should not be permitted to choose which of the four types of chemical tests for drunkenness they prefer.

The New York Board of Rabbis, meeting yesterday morning, at Temple Ansche Chesed, West End Avenue and 100th Street, adopted a resolution protesting the proposed demolition of the Sineer Synagogue (Orthodox), Madison and Montgomery Streets, to make possible the widening of a street.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 2 -- Yugoslavia sent a second note of protest to Italy today as the flare-up in the relations between the two countries over the Free Territory of Trieste continued heatedly despite efforts of the Western powers to moderate it.

The American Smelting and Refining Company trimmed the price of zinc yesterday to the lowest level in more than three years, and went back to a modified version of the East St. Louis, Ill., pricing basis which it had abandoned in mid-July.
Active cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange rose 6 to 13 points net yesterday.
The Army suspended without pay yesterday a Signal Corps civilian guard whose job was to protect highly secret Army films at Astoria, Queens.

FREEDOM VILLAGE, Korea, Thursday, Sept. 3 (AP) -- The first captured United States Army doctors freed by the Reds told yesterday of needless death and suffering because Communist doctors were more concerned with teaching communism than practicing medicine.

BARCELONNETTE, France, Sept. 2 (AP) -- Sure-footed mountain mules picked their way down snowcapped Mt. Cemet in the French alps today with the bodies of forty-two air crash victims including Jacques Thibaud, French concert violinist. He was enroute to entertain French troops in Indo-China.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., Sept. 2 -- Howard McMichael, of the Orienta Yacht Club, Mamaroneck, added the Two-Ten Class national sailing championship to his recently acquired Long Island Sound crown as the sixth annual title regatta ended off Larchmont Yacht Club today. He represented the host Western Long Island Sound fleet.
LONDON, Sept. 2 -- British government securities provided the chief interest in the stock markets here today, with gains up to five-sixteenths per cent among undated and long-term stocks.

Although the Bureau of Standards and Appeals has not yet passed on Frank Lloyd Wright's plans for a permanent spiraling concrete structure for the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum, New York soon will have a building designed by the famous 84-year-old architect.

PARIS, Sept. 2 -- French officials expressed themselves as highly pleased by that part of Secretary of State John Foster Dulles' speech at St. Louis today that if Peiping were willing, peace for Indo-China might grow out of the political conference on Korea.

PARIS, Sept. 2 -- The Cabinet approved today an emergency economic program in rour stages, which will be fully operating within four weeks, according to Edgar Faure, Finance Minister. It did so under the threat of renewed strikes if a better relationship between prices and wages could not be achieved rapidly.

R. D. Rogers has been appointed a vice president of the Tide Water Associated Oil Company and vice chairman of the operating committee, eastern division, it was announced yesterday by D. T. Staples, president.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 2 -- An acute shortage of nurses and lack of trained supervisory personnel were declared at the annual convention of the American Hospital Association today to be countrywide problems.

ABOARD THE GEN. MAURICE ROSE, Staten Island, N. Y., Sept. 2 -- Four sailors who have never been to sea were welcomed aboard this ship today by one rear admiral, one captain, no less than three commanders and any number of other high-ranking officers who stood when the sailors stood, ordered sandwiches and ice cream for them and referred deferentially to each of them as "Miss."
Traders were highly selective yesterday, but when the stock market closed stocks had pushed forward to new moderate gains. THE NEW YORK TIMES combined average closed at 170.89, up 1.33 points.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- Senator William E. Jenner, Republican of Indiana, announced tonight that the Senate Internal Security Subcommittee, which he heads, was reopening "all aspects" of the investigation into the cases of a dozen United States citizens whose discharge from employment at the United Nations on loyalty counts had been declared "illegal" by the administrative tribunal of the world organization.
ST. LOUIS. Sept. 2 (AP) -- Following is the text of Secretary of State John Foster Dulles' speech before the American Legion Convention today:

KARACHI, Pakistan, Sept. 2 -- Horace A. Hildreth the United States Ambassador, introduced Biscuits, informality and a homespun diplomacy that mitigated the acerbity of a testy local editor during an hour-long tea for the Pakistan press this afternoon.

The democratic West has had little to be thankful for in recent months. It is natural therefore to feel especially happy over developments in Iran, where Dr. Mossadegh is out and a new and hopeful regime is in.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 2 -- Egypt, whose culture dates back to the earliest civilization, has been found to have an industrial potential that needs only to be harnessed to give the nation a leading economic position in the general economic awakening of Asia and Africa.

MOSCOW, Sept. 1 -- The appointment of Mikhail A. Menshikov, former Foreign Trade Minister, as the Soviet Ambassador to India emphasized today the increasingly close attention being given by Russia to the deepening and broadening basis of Soviet relations with India.

The National Retail Dry Goods Association is "vehemently opposed" to all sales and excise taxes it insisted yesterday, declaring that its position has been interpreted erroneously as favoring passage of a broad-based national retail sales tax.

The Allegheny Ludlum Steel Corporation announced yesterday an expanded program for the production of zirconium strip and other shapes for atomic energy applications. The company's work in this field has been carried on in cooperation with the Atomic Energy Commission's Bettis Plant at Pittsburgh, operated by the Westinghouse Electric Corporation.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, Sept. 2 -- In the coming year Ceylon's Government will attempt to pull itself out of the financial predicament caused largely, as the last report of the Government bank says, by the fact that the strategic island dominion "lived far beyond its means" in 1952.

NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 2 -- Negotiations here between India and the Soviet Union during the last two weeks for conclusion of a barter deal for the exchange of Russian wheat for a variety of Indian goods have broken down, authoritative sources said today.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Sept. 2 -- Sir Earle C. G. Page, Australia's Minister of Health, outlined today before the annual assembly of the World Medical Association the national health insurance plan recently started in his country.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 2 -- Dr. Francisco Urrutia, the Colombian representative, announced today that he would vote against placing the Moroccan question on the agenda of the Security Council. His statement made it certain that the Council would decide against discussion of the complaint by fifteen Arab and Asian countries against France.

The Yonkers Trotting Association defended yesterday its hiring of a former convict as a $2,000-a-month labor expert on the ground that he "performed valuable services in combating the excessive demands" of a union representing workers at the track.

An increase last week of 953,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end total supplies were 143,287,000 barrels, compared with 142,334,000 a week earlier and 117,240,000 a year ago.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- The Truman order to which Senator McCarthy referred was adjudged today by Defense Department lawyers to consist of two executive orders, plus a series of remarks at a Presidential news con ference. The executive orders areI ference.. still in effect.

SAIGON, Vietnam, Sept. 2 (AP) -- With a Communist autumn offensive believed imminent, Premier Nguyen Van Tam of Vietnam declared today he was prepared to promise France to keep this country fighting against the Communist-led Vietminh insurgents.
The announcement of the proposed housing projects south of Washington Square, and your editorial "Rebuilding the 'Village'," under date of Aug. 26, are amazing in what they omit.

BONN, Germany, Sept. 2 -- Street brawls broke out in zonal border cities tonight between anti-Communist crowds and 1,500 Communists who had crossed into West Germany to disrupt Sunday's general elections.

National and local advertising placed last year in all media reached $7,149,700,000, a gain of 11.3 per cent over 1951, according to the final estimate by Printers' Ink magazine. This is a new high record.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 (AP) -- Army enlistments in the month since the Korean truce was signed have risen 75 per cent above the average of the twelve months before the truce. An Army official said he could not comment on the reasons for the increase and it was too early to tell whether it would continue.
Ruben Gomez, the Giants' top hurler, notched his third triumph in a row and thirteenth of the campaign as he checked the Redlegs, 4 -- 3, at the Polo Grounds yesterday.

The remaining stock interest of the Harriman family in the investment banking business of Harriman Ripley Co., Inc., has been purchased by the Harriman Ripley management, according to an announcement made yesterday by E. Roland Harriman, W. Averell Harriman and Joseph P. Ripley.

Designs from the past, ranging from old English sign boards to an ancient Far East temple, inspired many of the new wallpapers that are now available through decorators at Katzenbach Warren, 575 Madison Avenue. The papers were shown to the press yesterday.

Milwaukee's battling Braves last night served notice on the Dodgers that they have not tossed in the towel. In such oppressive weather that they hardly could be blamed for resignedly accepting their indicated fate, Charley Grimm's spirited forces charged from five runs behind to nose out the league-leading Brooks, 9 -- 8, before 30,877 steaming spectators at Ebbets Field.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 (AP) -- The Air Force said today the Sabrejet fighter to be assembled in Italy would lack some of the secret electronic devices of the American-assembled version and will be known as the F86K.

NEW DELHI, India, Sept 2 -- Although India in the past has been one of the most heavily infected malaria areas of the world the efforts of the Indian Ministry of Health and a number of cooperating United Nations and United States agencies are methodically bringing malaria under control.

The likelihood of a national telephone strike was eliminated yesterday when the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and the Communications Workers of America, C. I. O., agreed on a new contract covering 22,000 long- distance employes.

The women's United States field hockey team sailed yesterday on the Cunard White Star Line's Queen Elizabeth to attend the fifth triennial conference and tournament of the International Federation of Women's Hockey Associations at Fo1kestone, England.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 2 -- The American Legion national convention called today for a Congressional investigation of the American Civil Liberties Union, and, "if warranted," prosecution.

PARIS, Sept. 2 -- The North Atlantic Treaty Organization has still to take official cognizance of the Trieste crisis. Although the alliance's permanent council has held two meetings since the dispute between Italy and Yugoslavia flared into the headlines, everybody seemed to think it would be best to let this awkward political skeleton remain in the cupboard.

Gen. Jonathan M. Wainwright, wearer of the Medal of Honor, will not be forgotten as long as Americans pay tribute to the man who, when he is selected to head the desperate rearguard that fights for no reason but honor, does his grim duty and has little to say about it later.

LAKESIDE, Conn., Sept. 2 -- Columbia's forty-two man football squad arrived at Camp Columbia late today to begin its pre-season practice under Coach Lou Little. The team will work out twice daily starting tomorrow, returning to New York Sept. 18.

Directors of the United States Plywood Corporation, world's largest plywood organization, yesterday elected as its president S. W. "Tony" Antoville, who began work with the company as a vacation-time office boy thirty-two years ago. He succeeds Lawrence Ottinger, founder and only other president of the company in the thirty-four years since he organized it in 1919.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 2 (AP) -- The Legion delegates termed Tass, the Soviet news agency, "an espionage center and lookout station in this country" and said its representatives should be treated as foreign agents.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Sept. 2 -- The Social Democratic (Labor) members of the Rigsdag (Parliament) Financial Committee rejected today a Government demand for $11,600,000 for military constructions. The refusal was based on the ground that "there was no hurry" and that the appropriation therefore could await consideration until after the general elections at the end of this month "when the political situation is clearer."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- The elevation by Pope Pius XII of the Diocese of Hartford to an Archdiocese and designation of Bishop Henry J. O'Brien as Archbishop were announced today by the Most Rev. Amleto Cicognani, Apostolic Delegate to the United States.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- Dr. Yung Tai Pyun, Foreign. Minister of South Korea, vigorously opposed today the expenditure of United States Korean aid funds for the purchase of goods made in Japan. He proposed that his Government be enabled to veto such a use of United States assistance.
The formation of the Tennis Players League, with Sidney B. Wood Jr. of New York as president, was announced yesterday at the West Side Tennis Club, Forest Hills, Queens.

Seven college newspaper editors, 20 to 25 years old, were informed yesterday by the Soviet Embassy in Washington that they could obtain Moscow visas to visit "anywhere" they wished in Russia simply by presenting their passports for stamping and paying the $2.50 consular fee.
LONDON, Sept. 2 (AP) -- The Soviet Government newspaper Izvestia said today it had observed a "certain easing" in international tension.

The city-owned transit lines suffered the greatest loss of passengers -- 12 per cent -- since the fare was increased from 10 to 15 cents in the seven-day period from Aug. 22 to 28, the New York City Transit Authority reported yesterday in the first weekly record of passenger volume to include a Saturday and a Sunday.

One of those persons who indulge a reprehensible inclination to look backward when others are looking hopefully forward has recalled to the memory of the many grown careless about the origin of familiar names in our town the fact that in the region south of Washington Square, to which it is proposed to give a cleaner and greener dress, are six streets named in honor of major generals in Washington's Continental Army.
CHICAGO, Sept. 2 (AP) -- The White Sox, battling to hold second place in the American League race, rocked four Washington pitchers with a 16-hit barrage today to defeat the Senators, 7 to 3.

DANVILLE, Va., Sept. 2 -- The Virginia drought, which has lasted over a month, now threatens to affect the economy of the tobacco planters whose staple crop is far below normal. Gov. John S. Battle has called the State Drought Committee to meet Friday in Richmond to discuss what steps shall be taken.

MAYS LANDING, N. J., Sept. 2 (AP) -- Joseph Gavegnano's Errard King picked up 126 pounds in the second running of the $15,000 added Longport Handicap at the Atlantic City track today and galloped home an easy winner of the six-furlong dash. Taking the lead at the start, Errard King turned back seven other juveniles for a five-length score before 14,951.

Income from dividends totaling $9,793,845 was responsible for the extraordinary rise in net income of the Hancock Oil Company to $11,950,067 in the fiscal year ended last June 30 from $3,731,990 reported in the previous fiscal year.

An extensive survey to determine whether export traders favor establishment of Government insurance on foreign credit and currency exchange transfer risks was announced yesterday at a meeting of the Foreign Credit Interchange Bureau.

As youngsters throughout the country start back to school this month, the National School Lunch Program, operated jointly by Federal, state and local governments, will be entering its seventh year of operation.

New York State's chartered banks and trust companies made their best net operating earnings of the post-war period during the first half of 1953, but net profits were off slightly, according to the official figures issued yesterday.

Commodity prices were generally higher yesterday on the New York exchanges. Volume was light with only wool, cottonseed oil and soybean oil approaching normal levels. Cottonseed oil, soybean oil, wool, coffee, potatoes, hides and rubber closed higher. Cocoa, zinc, lead and tin were lower and sugar and copper ended mixed.
FORT BRAGG, N. C., Sept. 2 -- A boat loaded with Army Engineers capsized on a lake during a training problem on this military reservation today and twenty soldiers drowned. Two were hospitalized.

DETROIT, Sept. 2 -- Gov. G. Mennen Williams, urged by the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People to help to end discrimination against Negro airmen stationed in Sault Sainte Marie, Mich., acknowledged today that the local community had been remiss in dealing with the problem.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 2 -- One by one the old hands of the Yankees, inhaling the fragrant and familiar scent of another World Series melon, are suddenly beginning to show signs of life.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- The Order of Railroad Conductors declined today, after a second day of discussion, to accept a National Mediation Board proposal that would postpone its strike set for Sept. 10.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Aug. 26, the Federal Reserve Board reported today:

CHICAGO, Sept. 2 (AP) -- Sunny Dale, owned by David Paper, St. Paul industrialist, today scored a length-and-a-quarter victory over Mrs. Henry J. Damm's Arab Actress to win the $28,475 Beverly Handicap for fillies and mares at Washington Park.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 (UP) -- The Administration today agreed to help find other Federal jobs for dismissed Government workers as a union employe charged that giving intelligence tests demoralized the Foreign Operations Administration.
In your editorial of Aug. 31, "New York's Primary," you say:

Marketing and selling techniques in the textile field have failed to keep pace with developments in production, Hugh M. Comer, chairman of the board of Avondale Mills, Sylacauga, Ala., said yesterday at the meeting of the National Association of Shirt, Pajama and Sportswear Manufacturers at the New Yorker Hotel.

ANGLERS from thirteen countries will gather at Wedgeport, Nova Scotia, next Wednesday for the opening of the three-day international tuna tournament, the classic of angling derbies, in which ten teams will compete for the Sharp Trophy.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 (UP) -- Following is the text of the United States note to the Soviet Union, parallel versions of which were sent by Britain and France, on a proposed four-power conference on German and Austrian problems:
