It was a great day for hot favorites at Aqueduct yesterday until the feature race, the $12,075 Astarita, came along. Four of the five earlier events had been won by the public choices, and the crowd of 15,450 expected this average to be extended by the Brookmeade Stable's Riant.

In heat that exceeded 100 degrees in the stadium enclosure, the national tennis championships were brought down to the round of sixteen at Forest Hills yesterday, with the favored player gaining in every instance excerpt one, but only after a taxing ordeal for some of them.

The first collection of French and Italian imports to be officially presented to the fashion press was seen yesterday morning at Russeks. They illustrated vividly the fashion news reported from abroad during recent weeks.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 (AP) -- The Department of Commerce reported today that the personal income of Americans was at a record rate of $288,000,000,000 a year in July -- more than $1,500,000,000 higher than in June.

TEHERAN, Iran, Sept. 2 -- Iran's fluttering economic pulse strengthened on the promise of United States financial aid implicit in a letter from President Eisenhower to Premier Fazlollah Zahedi made public here today.

One is naturally pleased that the eight-week strike of concrete-mix drivers is over. The men have bowed to the demand by President Dave Beck of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters that they submit the dispute to arbitration.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 2 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold of the United Nations announced tonight that he would not reinstate the four United States employes who had been dismissed on loyalty counts but who had been ordered back on their jobs yesterday by the Administrative Tribunal of the world organization.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- Chauncey O. Rowe, acting president of the Institute of Inter-American Affairs (the Point Four agency for Latin America) and twenty-five other institute employes have received dismissal notices from Harold E. Stassen, Foreign Operations Administrator.

Business activity is being well sustained by high levels of employment, incomes, retail trade and construction, and these lend strength to the nondurable goods manufacturing industries, the National City Bank of New York comments in its monthly letter, issued today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 2 -- Warner Brothers has sewed up the screen rights to the life story of Capt. Joseph McConnell, jet fighter ace, who added to his World War II exploits by shooting down sixteen MIG's in Korea.

WESTBURY, L. I., Sept. 2 (AP) -- Knight's Princess, owned by the Arthur Mardin Corporation of New York, came out of the pack in the stretch to score a one-length victory tonight in the New York Race at Roosevelt Raceway.

Patrolman Samuel Gallagher of the Rockaway Beach station in Queens returned to duty yesterday from his vacation and stepped into a role that by this time has grown somewhat monotonous -- delivering a baby.

Twenty-two new schools and additions, providing facilities for 22,266 pupils, will be ready for occupancy on Sept. 14, when the 1953-54 school year begins, the Board of Education announced yesterday. The projects represent a construction outlay of $38,683,017, exclusive of the cost of land, furniture and equipment.
E. 1V[. Braden has been appointed general sales manager of the Chrysler division of the Chrysler Corporation.
Striking sand, gravel and concrete drivers started back to work yesterday in compliance with an arbitration ultimatum from Dave Beck, president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters A. F. L.

LIVERPOOL, England, Sept. 2 -- Although the 115th meeting of the British Association for the Advancement of Science began here tonight with the usual academic, ceremonial and nationally broadcast opening speeches, there are signs that this most venerable of British institutions is declining in its old age and may suffer eventual extinction unless it is reorganized completely.

LONDON, Sept. 2 -- Britain, as banker for all countries that use the pound sterling or currencies rigidly tied to sterling, took in $13,000,000 more than she spent last month, the Treasury announced today.

The third volume of Maxwell Geismar's five-volume study, "The Novel id America," will be published on Sept. 17 by Houghton Mifflin. In "Rebels and Ancestors: The American Novel, 1890-1915," Mr. Geismar discusses the changing trends and attitudes as illustrated in the works of FrankI Norris, Stephen Crane, Jack London, Theodore Dreiser and Ellen' Glasgow.

Citing the failure of Prohibition as an example .of unrealistic and ineffective law enforcement, delegates from police departments throughout the state approved yesterday a proposal to legalize off- track betting on horse races.
NUEMBURG, Germany, Sept. 2 (AP) -- William D. Canfield, a United States prosecutor, said today he has asked for the extradition of a Texas businessman to face charges here in a $250,000 bribery case.

The Roxy on Sunday, will discontinue its regular ice revue because of preparations for the forthcoming world premiere of "The Robe," in CinemaScope. The theatre has scheduled a double bill of the current "Mister Scoutmaster" and "Vicki," a new melodrama, from Monday through Sunday, Sept. 13, the management announced yesterday.

Ronald Alexander, whose comedy "Time Out for Ginger" enjoyed a successful run in the Times Square sector last winter, has written another light script called "A Lady's Gentleman." Owned by Peter Lawrence, the new comedy will be tested next week at the Woodstock (N. Y.) Playhouse.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Sept. 2 -- About 178 dock workers at the Queensland port of Bowen, 900 miles north of Brisbane, refused to load sugar today in protest against the arrival of 102 soldiers by plane from Brisbane to load meat for the United Kingdom.

FOREST PARK, Pa., Sept. 2 -- David Dubinsky, president of the International Ladles Garment Workers Union, A. F. L., announced today the first step in a program to unionize garment workers in Puerto Rico.

Paul Keres, former Soviet champion, was the sole winner in the third round of the world championship challengers' tournament contested last night in Neuhausen, Switzerland, according to a report from Zurich. His opponent was Lazslo Szabo of Hungary, whose Queen's Gambit was accepted.

LONDON, Sept. 2 -- A chorus of denunciation of United States policies and demands for "more socialism" are what the leaders of the British Labor party will hear when the party assembles for its annual congress at Margate at the end of September.
Several tributes to General Wainwright were received from former comrades.
Three of five major oil companies accused in a civil anti-trust suit of a conspiracy to engage in an international cartel denied the Government's charges yesterday in papers filed in Federal Court.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 2 (UP) -- A six-run rally in the seventh inning, powered by a three-run homer by Ray Jablonski and a bases-empty blast by Steve Bilko, carried the Cardinals to a 10-7 victory over the Phillies tonight.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- The United States, Britain and France proposed to the Soviet Union today that the Big Four foreign ministers meet in Lugano, Switzerland, Oct. 15 to discuss the future of Germany and Austria.

I agree with most of your recent editorial, "Moscow's H-Bomb." The task, as you say, is to face the consequences of this harsh reality and to do some additional thinking about the problem of American defense. I know of no more authoritative nor pithy statement on this subject than that made by Albert Einstein not long after the destruction of Hiroshima and Nagasaki.

WASHINGTON, Sept.2 (AP) -- N. Henry Gellert, president of the Seattle Gas Company, declared today Canadian laws make it impossible for a proposed pipeline company to make a firm contract to import natural gas to the United States at a fixed price.
The American Locomotive Company announced the retirement of Thomas B. Walker of its administrative staff after forty-three years with the company.
NAPLES, Sept. 2 (AP) -- A retired American financier made America's strongest bid today in a day of surprises at the world Star Class yacht racing championship.

Investment banking syndicates will place on the market today two new issues of AAA-rated public utility bonds totaling $65,000,000, obligations of the Duke Power Company and Southern Bell Telephone and Telegraph Company. The offerings are as follows:

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 2 -- John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, warned the Chinese Communists today that if they desired to resume the war in Korea they could no longer count on their "privileged sanctuary" north of the Yalu River. Mr. Dulles was speaking to an enthusiastic audience of delegates to the national convention of the American Legion.

Mayor Impellitteri characterized yesterday as "completely unfounded and unmitigated lies" the charges of Borough President Robert F. Wagner Jr. that the Mayor was receiving underworld support in the Democratic primary contest.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- Theodore C. Streibert, Director of the new United States Information Service, today appointed four assistant directors to be the "eyes and ears" of Washington headquarters in various areas of the world.

MONTREAL, Sept. 2 -- Fifteen Soviet scientific reports, presented at the Nineteenth International Physiological Congress meeting here, hew closely to the general line that the animal mind and animal thoughts are physical objects that can be dealt with in a materialistic, or objective, fashion.
CHICAGO, Sept. 2 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture, follows:
Republicans here have purchased 200 "spots" on television that will be used through Primary Day by Harold Riegelman, their candidate for Mayor, even though he is unopposed for the nomination.

DENVER Sept. 2 -- President Eisenhower tonight appointed fifteen of the eighteen members of the National Agricultural Advisory Commission, a new body that will study farm policy, one of the toughest domestic political problems now facing the Administration.

OYSTER BAY, L. I., Sept. 2 -- A mahogany-hulled yacht from California, Maybe VII, slipped over the course as though urged by spurs to lead the United States to victory in the first team match for the British-American Cup today. The race began more than a month of international sailing competition in six-meter craft under the burgee of the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club.

CHICAGO, Sept. 2 -- Wheat futures moved up sharply following an early decline today, touching new highs for the move before reacting. Again there appeared to be buying of wheat against sales of corn, spreaders acting on the theory that the bread grain is behind the general market.

Barring sudden adverse developments, recent and prospective trends in Canada indicate that her economic expansion is likely to continue against a background of internal stability, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York says in its monthly Review, issued today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 (AP) -- The Air Force announced today that it had converted a B-47 jet bomber into a tanker plane capable of refueling other B-47s in flight.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 (UP) -- The American Civil Liberties Union today urged Herbert Brownell Jr., Attorney General to refrain from declaring organizations Communist-controlled until they had received hearings from the Justice Department.

LONDON, Sept. 2 (AP) -- The Moscow radio broadcast today a Pravda editorial declaring that the seating of Communist China in the United Nations was an "absolute precondition" for ending world tension.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- The Government Printing Office, now under inquiry by the Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations for alleged Communist infiltration, will return to a wartime security status pending completion of its own check-up on the safety of its secret documents from delivery to Reds.
MUNSAN, Thursday, Sept. 3 (AP) -- Official list of United States war prisoners freed by the Communists today at Panmunjom:

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Sept. 2 -- Gen. Jonathan M. Wainwright, World War II hero of Corregidor, died here today in Brooke Army Hospital at the age of 70, eight years to the day after he had witnessed the Japanese surrender in Tokyo Bay.

EAST LANSING, Mich., Sept. 2 -- Specialists in family life -- those who study it, teach courses in it or counsel couples on its problems -- took a long look today at their own professional "family." Discussion of what they practice in relation to what they preach, occupied members of the National Council on Family Relations at their annual meeting here at Michigan State College.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 2 (AP) -- Preston Ward drove in six runs with a grand-slam homer and a double and Bobby Friend notched his first victory since July 16 as the Pirates walloped the Cubs, 8 -- 1, tonight and snapped a nine-game losing streak.

Eighteen Brooklyn service men who have been released as prisoners of war by the Communists and one man who died in captivity were honored yesterday at a civic ceremony in Brooklyn Borough Hall. Citations were given to the nine former prisoners who attended and bouquets and citations to the wives, mothers or sisters of those who have not yet returned.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- Expenditures totaling $138,963,949.52 were detailed today in the annual report of the Welfare and Retirement Fund of the United Mine Workers of America headed by John L. Lewis.

KATE O'BRIEN is an all-Irish, intensely feminine novelist with a following all her own. Most of her books have received their quota of hosannas when they appeared in American editions; they have appeared frequently, for Miss O'Brien, like many of her compatriots, seems to produce books almost as easily as conversation.

STAMFORD, Conn., Sept. 2 -- Bill Thomson of the Stamford Yacht Club took the lead for the Jesse A. B. Smith Trophy, emblematic of the Long Island Sound Y. R. A. associate-member championship, by winning both of today's races run by Malcolm Robinson and the Stamford Y. C. committee,.

CHICAGO, Sept. 2 -- A sharp attack on cuts in national defense appropriations as representative "of a type of thinking that is completely blind to the realities of Soviet ambitions and Soviet technological capacity" was made here tonight by Jesse Moss of New York, National Commander of the Jewish War Veterans of the United States.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- Senator Homer Ferguson of Michigan, chairman of the Senate Republican Policy Committee, ran into a quick Democratic challenge today when he charged that Democratic leaders were spreading "false and misleading information in saying their votes 'saved' President Eisenhower's program."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 (AP) -- The Power Commission announced approval today of natural gas rates filed by Algonquin Gas Transmission Company, Boston, which are about 10 per cent higher than the company proposed during hearings on its application for authority to serve part of New England.

In a significant and hard-hitting speech before the American Legion convention Secretary Dulles again took account of the fact that destiny has placed upon the United States the responsibility of leading the free world in the battle for peace and outlined the principles and practices that will guide the Eisenhower Administration in carrying out that historic mandate.
DETROIT, Sept. 2 (AP) -- The Red Sox clicked off four double plays -- three of them on hard line drives -- to halt the Tigers, 5 -- 2, today.

The first bolt from the crime-encrusted International Longshoremen's Association came yesterday with the granting of a charter in another American Federation of Labor union to an I. L. A. local representing 2,500 workers in New York lumber yards.

ALEXANDRIA, Va., Sept. 2 (AP) -- Federal Judge Albert V. Bryan refused today to order that the Army discharge a 37-year-old dentist, an admitted former Communist, who was drafted and denied a commission.
Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway, the new Army Chief of Staff, joined this week a large company of his peers who have viewed with alarm the morale of the armed services.

PORT JERVIS, N. Y., Sept. 2 -- Ray Kosakoff of 244 Riverside Drive, New York, was unanimously elected chairman of the National Jewish Youth Conference today at the closing session of the organization's annual assembly at Cejwin Camp near here.

CAMP DRUM, N. Y., Sept. 2 -- Special precautions against the setting of accidental forest fires by artillery shells were taken here tonight by four field artillery battalions of the Forty-second National Guard Division, which joined in a two-hour night firing exercise.

LONDON, Sept. 2 -- The Foreign Office released the text of the Western notes to Moscow tonight without comment, but it is known that the language in which it emerged conforms to the views of Prime Minister Sir Winston Churchill in one major respect.

PARIS, Sept. 2 -- Pierre Voizard, French Minister to Monaco, who has had a long career in French administration, both at home and abroad, was named by the Cabinet today after some heated discussion to replace Jean de Hauteclocque as Resident General in the French Protectorate of Tunisia.

BONN, Germany, Thursday, Sept. 3 -- West Germany's two largest political parties, although rivals in the elections next Sunday, found themselves warmly in agreement on one thing tonight. They both liked the terms of the Western Allies' notes delivered to Moscow today.

SAN FRANCISCO Sept. 2 -- The Sailors Union of the Pacific, A. F. L., has just negotiated with West Coast shipowners what Harry Lundeberg, the union's secretary-treasurer, described today as "the first genuine pension plan in the seagoing industry.
Anthony (Tough Tony) Anastasia, union boss of the Brooklyn waterfront, was unsuccessful yesterday in his legal move to get rid of a police bodyguard assigned to him since Aug. 6.

In your editorial of Aug. 24 concerning the recent Soviet proposals for German unification you state that "the one thing the Soviets fail to promise is the genuinely free elections on which the Western Powers and the Germans * * * insist."

President Eisenhower has signed a bill which should further enhance the influence and effectiveness of the National Safety Council. It grants a federal charter to that body and brings to a successful conclusion an effort which was begun by the board of directors in 1944. The council thus becomes one of the very few public service organizations which have received this type of recognition for their work.

In accordance with its new system previously announced, the United States Treasury's daily statement was not issued yesterday. Under the new procedure, the statement for the last day of each month is deferred in order to show month-end figures on the public debt.

The backlog of local government financing that has been building up for the month of September prompted the Port of New York Authority yesterday to postpone indefinitely its sale of $20,000,000 of bonds scheduled for Sept. 16.

SEATTLE, Wash., Sept. 2 -- Twelve months' work on the production of this country's first jet transport plane was completed today and its manufacturer, the Boeing Airplane Company of Seattle, announced that it would be in the air as planned next August.

FREEDOM VILLAGE, Korea, Sept. 2 -- When the nation's highest military award was bestowed today on a young lieutenant from Arkansas just after his release from twenty-one months' captivity, it almost brought tears to his eyes.

From Washington, D. C., comes the news that Lieut. Col. Marion E. Carl of the Marine Corps has reached an altitude of 83,235 feet, almost sixteen miles, thereby beating Bill Bridgeman's record of 79,494 feet, made in 1951. Lieutenant Colonel Carl went up largely for the purpose of testing a new Navy high-altitude suit.

MOSCOW, Thursday, Sept. 3 -- Premier Georgi M. Malenkov and Foreign Minister Vyacheslav M. Molotov, in a message to China today, expressed confidence that the "great union and brotherly friendship" between Russia and China would serve as a basis for securing peace and security in the Far East.
A decline of 233 ships measuring 1,421,233 gross tons in building of vessels during the year ended July 1 was reported yesterday by the Shipbuilders Council of America.

TOKYO, Thursday, Sept. 3 -- Communist deliveries of Allied war prisoners continued at a reduced rate today as United Nations authorities indicated that the exchange of captured personnel willing to be sent home would be completed Sunday.
SINGAPORE, Sept. 2 -- Malaya's first "Mister Speaker," Dato Setia Wangsa Mahmud Bin Mat, was installed today at a special ceremony in Kuala Lumpur, capital of the Federation.

The suspicion that Vyacheslav A. Malyshev, is in charge of Soviet nuclear-weapons development has been strengthened by a study of the Soviet press during the last month in which the United States Atomic Energy Commission confirmed three nuclear explosions in Russia, one of a hydrogen bomb-type device.

Predicting that this probably will be one of the lowest years for poliomyelitis in the city, Dr. Samuel Frant, acting Commissioner of Health, recalled yesterday that even in epidemic years here there had been no increase after the schools opened.

The editorial in THE NEW YORK TIMES, "Taxing the Inventor," which discussed the proposed further increase in the fees that applicants for patents must pay, is an apt reminder that the Eisenhower Administration is in effect following a pattern similar to that of the past twenty years.

MCCHORD AIR FORCE BASE, Wash., Sept. 2 (AP) -- A chartered airliner that vanished on a flight from California last night carried nineteen soldier passengers and two crew members to their deaths just below the crest of a timbered Western Washington ridge.

MIAMI, Fla., Sept. 2 (AP) -- The Far Western champions from Yakima, Wash., shoved six runs across in the fifth inning tonight to defeat the Midwestern titleholders from Winnetka, Ill., 6 -- 1, in the second round of the American Legion junior baseball world series.

ELIZABETH, N. J., Sept. 2 -- An enraged 1,000-pound steer led Elizabeth and Newark policemen and scores of pedestrians on an hour-long chase through residential areas here today before it was killed in a back yard at 521 Jefferson Avenue.
Eddie Mathews, the young muscle man who has a chance to break Babe Ruth's record of sixty home runs in a season, made an emphatic move in that direction at Ebbets Field yesterday before 12,215 fans.

Count me as one patent lawyer who disagrees with the opinion expressed in Sunday's editorial that raising the Government fees required to be paid by an inventor seeking to patent his invention will discourage individual inventors (as distinguished from corporations) from filing patent applications.
CHICAGO, Sept. 3 (UP) -- The Senators sent the White Sox into a second-place tie with Cleveland tonight as Bob Porterfield and Johnny Schmitz combined to give up only four hits for a 5-to-1 victory.

NEWARK, Sept. 3 -- A city government consisting of a Mayor and nine Councilmen was recommended today by the Newark Charter Commission to replace the city commission type by which Newark has been ruled since 1917.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 3 -- The sorest aspect of this week's violent storm over Trieste, according to qualified observers here, is that nothing is likely to come of it. Sometimes storms of this nature serve to clear the air but experienced diplomats here do not expect a change in the atmosphere between Yugoslavia and Italy.

Three adjourned games were played off last night and brought about a five-way tie for first place in the world chess championship challengers' tournament in Neuhausen, according to a report from Zurich, Switzerland. Dr. Max Euwe of Amsterdam, former world champion, met his first defeat in his third-round match with Vassily Smyslov of Moscow, after fifty-eight moves.
GREENWOOD LAKE, N. Y., Sept. 3 -- Roland La Starza lay outstretched in the shallow water at the edge of Greenwood Lake today, the picture of relaxation and contentment.

WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 4 -- Mrs. Donald O'Brien of Winged Foot, former Tri-County champion, won low gross honors with a three-over-par 41, 37 -- 78 in a one-day tournament of the Westchester and Fairfield Women's Golf Association at the Knollwood Country Club today.

ALBANY, Sept. 3 -- A real haunted house containing displays that deal with fear will be open to the public Saturday at the State Fair in Syracuse, Dr. Newton Bigelow, Commissioner of the State of Department of Mental Hygiene, announced today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- Purchase goals on half of the seventy-six critical materials which the Government is stockpiling have been three-quarters completed, the Office of Defense Mobilization disclosed today. At the same time the agency made public details of a directive covering stockpiling policies which will be followed hereafter.

MONTREAL, Sept. 3 -- A new study comparing the chemical constitution of the blood of middle aged men in the United States with blood of men in other nations, reported here today at the International Physiological Congress, suggests strongly that American men pay for their rich diets with the afflictions of the heart and arteries that are now the leading cause of death in the nation.

DENVER, Sept. 3 -- President Eisenhower today established a new Operations Coordinating Board within the National Security Council to insure that national security policies are effectively implemented.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- The Northern Natural Gas Company of Omaha asked the Securities and Exchange Commission today for authority to market $25,000,000 worth of $100 par cumulative preferred stock. The securities, 250,000 shares, will be offered for public sale through an underwriting group headed by Blyth Co., Inc.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 (AP) -- Milton Marusic, a little known professional from Herkimer, N. Y., gave the big names and the baking fairways a licking today as he shot a 5-under-par 67 to take the opening round lead in the national celebrities open golf tournament.

WITH the temperature in the middle 90's and the Weather Bureau taking a fatalistic attitude about the indefinite duration of the heat wave, there was something magnetically attractive in a book called "North."* There it was beckoning to me on the shelf, handsomely arrayed in a cool blue and white jacket with a picture of a lonely human figure standing on an immense waste of ice.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 (AP) -- A United States negotiating team was ready today to start bargaining with Chile over her request for this country to buy 84,000 tons of copper at world market prices for the American stockpile. Chile made the official request about a month ago after she was unable to sell copper at prices above the world level.

The Carrier Corporation, manufacturer of air-conditioning equipment, announced yesterday plans for a $10,000,000 expansion program to be financed mostly by an offering of 170,000 shares of new $50 par value convertible preferred stock for subscription first by the company's common stockholders.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 3 -- Motion-picture producers and theatre owners were urged today by Herbert J. Yates, president of Republic Pictures, to hasten the long contemplated marriage with television.

BONN, Germany, Sept. 3 -- Reserve units of the West German frontier police have been sent to the East German border to stand guard against a possible second wave of East German Communist youths sent to the West to interfere with the Federal elections on Sunday, the Bonn Ministry of the Interior reported tonight.

SHIRAZ, Iran, Sept. 3 (AP) -- A special envoy from Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi -- backed by a show of force -- apparently has averted a revolt by the powerful Ghashghaies tribe and staved off an invasion threat to this historic Iranian city.

Concrete and building supply drivers were back at work in virtually full strength yesterday after a two-month strike, but construction experts estimated that the delay caused by the tie-up might run to three or four months in the completion of major building projects.

Twenty-three persons, including five firemen, were injured last night when accumulated gas exploded in four manholes near the intersection of Myrtle and Putnam Avenues in the Ridgewood section of Queens.

Another of Australia's top entries, Mervyn Rose, and Arthur Larsen, 1950 titleholder, passed from the scene in the national tennis championships at Forest Hills yesterday. For a while it appeared that Kurt Nielsen of Denmark, Wimbledon finalist, would make his exit too, until he rallied to defeat Fred Kovaleski of Washington, D. C., 6 -- 3, 5 -- 7, 4 -- 6, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 4.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 3 (AP) -- The Revlon Products Corporation, New York City cosmetics concern, must pay $150,000 to a Philadelphia couple under a judgment entered here today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 (AP) -- John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, said today a preliminary investigation had indicated that no one now connected with the State Department had any part in a 1947 incident that Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, called a "shakedown" of a friendly foreign Government for $150,000.
OTTAWA, Sept. 3 -- Canada's foreign trade in the first six months of 1953 showed a deficit of $2,000,000 daily, according to figures made public today by the Bureau of Statistics.
CLEVELAND, Sept. 3 (UP) -- The late-driving Indians scored their fifteenth victory in the last seventeen games today when they defeated the Athletics, 9 -- 4.

GENEVA, Sept. 3 (UP) -- The Soviet Union has failed to repatriate or account for nearly 2,300,000 German, Italian and Japanese nationals captured in World War II, reports to the United Nations disclosed today.
The New York City Transit Authority was unable to hold a scheduled weekly meeting yesterday because it could not muster the necessary quorum of three of its five members.
For the first time in the current heat wave the city yesterday ran up an alarm signal on the use of water.

STAMFORD, Conn., Sept. 3 -- Bill Thomson of the host club became the fifth Long Island Sound Yacht Racing Association associate-member champion by winning the third and final race of the Jesse A. B. Smith Trophy series at the Stamford Yacht Club today for a sweep of the two-day program.

DETROIT, Sept. 3 (AP) -- A grand jury inquiry of the juke box industry in the metropolitan Detroit area resulted today in indictment of seven men charged with extortion, threats and obtaining large sums of money under false pretenses.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 3 -- Gov. Earl Warren ended an intensive debate about one phase of his political future by announcing today that he would not be a candidate for election to a fourth term next year.

Today there is a prevalence of puffers. A puffers purpose in life, as the word was used many years ago, was to mislead the public; usually for the puffer's gain. We were particularly incensed recently, as a matter of fact, because we had just read a book whose blurb (written by a puffer) belied its contents.
DAYTON, Ohio, Sept. 3 (AP) -- Ten leading Air Force jet pilots were named today to participate in Saturday's Bendix Trophy Race from California to Ohio.

James Lynch, official of Local 32-E, Building Service Employes Union, A. F. L., and brother Lawrence (LaLa) Lynch, an ex-convict who has been questioned in the slaying of Thomas E. Lewis, union local president, has been suspended from his post, it was announced yesterday by the union's trustees.
Former President Harry S. Truman has been engaged for a commercial appearance on a children's television program to discuss the opportunities that lie ahead for young people and their country.

It is a pleasure so welcome back to this country Mr. Syed Amjad Ali in his new capacity as Ambassador from Pakistan to the United States. Mr. Amjad Ali is no stranger to us, since he has served his country with distinction as Minister for Economic Affairs in the Pakistan Embassy in Washington.

More than 250,000 sick and wounded of the armed forces have been cared for in the world-wide aeromedical evacuation operations of the Military Air Transport Service since it was established in June, 1948.
In the early summer you were good enough to print an appeal to animal owners not to abandon their pets when they went away on vacation.
The Radio-Electronics-Television Manufacturers Association may soon start an all-out drive to recruit as new members 100 or more companies with an aggregate of $1,500,000,000 in Government contracts.
CLEVELAND, Sept. 3 -- Resolutions aimed at Communists were adopted at the closing session of the fifty-fifth national encampment of the United Spanish War Veterans today.

PURCHASE, N. Y., Sept. 3 -- The Aurora Polo Club of Buffalo, N. Y., paced by two brothers, Seymour and Northrup Knox, defeated the Oak Brook Club of Chicago, 9 to 8, at Blind Brook Field today to reach the final of the national twenty-goal championship tournament.
WASHINGTON Sept. 3 -- John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, provided today what may be the first public indication that the United States has its policy toward Trieste under review.
What do visiting firemen do in New York, away from their families, over the Labor Day week-end?

Merchant seamen, for whom the Federal Government has made medical and hospital care available since 1798, are now in danger of losing this protection. Budget Director Joseph M. Dodge has directed Secretary Oveta Culp Hobby of the Department of Health, Education and Welfare to submit her budget looking toward legislative or administrative "termination of the free program of medical care and hospital care for merchant seamen."

In your editorial of Aug. 29, "Teach -- Or Drive a Truck?" you once again show clear evidence of your understanding of the major problem confronting the public schools today. The wage comparisons that you make tell a tale of criminal neglect by our public officials.
BLAIRSTOWN, N. J., Sept. 3 -- Princeton opened practice for its eighty-fifth season of football today with a curtailed workout at the Tigers' camp.

More than 700 newspapers throughout the country will be used by Melrose Distillers, Inc., in a campaign from now to Christmas, according to K. H. Seidel, director of advertising and merchandising. National magazines, outdoor posters and beverage trade publications will also be used.

ROME, Sept. 3 -- The Yugoslav Legation in Rome delivered today its third protest note to Italy since Saturday of last week. This time Yugoslavia protested against an alleged violation of the Yugoslav frontier on Aug. 31 near Canale, on the Isonzo River, by fifteen Italian soldiers who were said to have penetrated about 100 yards into Yugoslav territory.
DETROIT, Sept. 3 (AP) -- The Tigers edged the Red Sox by 5 -- 4 today, but needed a ninth-inning break to do it.

Reversing their repayment position of recent weeks, sales finance companies were heavy borrowers last week, exerting the major influence in a $64,000,000 expansion in the volume of New York bank loans to business.
Owen Kelly, former president of the sandhogs' union, and his wife were found dead early yesterday in their Brooklyn apartment and police ascribed their death to overdoses of barbiturates.

Motors, steels and public utilities did fairly well in flaccid stock market yesterday but rails, chemicals and aircrafts lost ground and the close showed a slight, general recession. Volume slipped to 900,000 shares, the lowest since Aug. 21.

The present bosses of the racket-ridden International Longshoremen's Association seem to be challenging the American Federation of Labor to take the most drastic action possible against their organization.

CHICAGO, Sept. 3 -- Lower temperatures with scattered showers in parts of the corn belt and in the Southwest had a bearish effect on grains today. Corn and soybean futures broke sharply, and there was little support in wheat except on substantial setbacks.

It would be ungracious, in the midst of the satisfaction over the end of hostilities in Korea, for the United States to withhold a tribute to the one Latin-American country that stood by our side -- Colombia. The Colombian Battalion fought superbly (it was cited for bravery on more than one occasion) and it suffered heavy casualties.

Organic solvents, which make up about half of conventional enamels, lacquers and varnishes, are costly, toxic and flammable. These objections are said to have been met and defeated by Reichhold Chemicals, Inc., international chemical-manufacturing concern, which announced yesterday a process that uses water as a solvent for synthetic resin surfaces.

MARION, Mass., Sept. 3 -- A highly favored United States team of amateur golfers appeared ready today for tomorrow's renewal of the international Walker Cup matches with a squad from the British Isles at the Kittansett Club.

A victory by Herbert C. Boorse's 4-year-old colt G. R. Petersen surprised the 13,912 fans at the Aqueduct Race Track yesterday. The success registered by the son of Heather Broom was decisive enough, the colt enjoying the margin of a length over Ogden Phipps' Ancestor.

The news that the Soviet newspaper Pravda has seen fit to reprint almost all of a recent pamphlet by Ernest T. Weir will bring a chuckle to many who recall the denunciations that were heaped on that gentleman some years ago for his opposition to the C. I. O. unionization of his steel employes.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 (UP) -- The Department of Agriculture today withdrew its endorsement of an eleven-year-old system of classification for house and barn paints because of misinterpretation in some paint advertising.

The spring men's clothing season is narrowing with sportswear items filling in the void, Quin Goldman, vice president in charge of the franchise division of Witty Brothers, Inc., said yesterday, Mr. Goldman, who recently returned from a trip surveying business conditions in forty-one states, said the worsted suit sales season is now less than six weeks in duration.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, placed squarely on the Soviet Union today the blame for the "continued partition" of Germany. That division is "a scandal" and "a crime" and "a menace to the peace," he said in a prepared statement read at a news conference.

CHICAGO, Sept. 3 (UP) -- The American Meat Institute reported tonight that the nation's packers had net earnings of only 3/5ths of a cent on each dollar of sales last year. Sales for the industry in 1952 were $11,250,000,000. The 3/5ths of a cent return was on sales of meat and other products made by packers.

Maj. Gen. William F. Dean, former commander of the United States Twenty-fourth Division, who had been released by the Communists at Panmunjom today, was the first soldier to win the Medal of Honor during the Korean war.

DENVILLE, N. J., Sept. 3 -- Thirteen boys and young men ranging in age from 14 to 22 years were arraigned here this afternoon charged with the killing of Ross Midgette, 32, of Denville, last Sunday morning.

Robert F. Wagner Jr., candidate for the Democratic Mayoralty nomination, toured Queens yesterday for six hours to study at first hand the borough's problems of transportation, school facilities and sewers.

ANKARA, Turkey, Sept. 2 -- The Government announced tonight that henceforth all imports would be subject to a strict official licensing system, thus formally abandoning in part the free import program adopted in 1950 under the auspices of the European Payments Union.

LAKESIDE, Conn., Sept. 3 -- Columbia's undermanned football squad began pre-season practice at Camp Columbia today with light morning and afternoon workouts as Lou Little officially began his twenty-fourth season as the Lions' coach.

Exhausted and wilted citizens in many cities yesterday cursed the heat wave heartily. But appliance store executives loaded with heavy stocks of room air conditioners during the cool first three weeks in August blessed every searing moment.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 3 -- United States spokesman said today that Mr. Hammarskjold had been "right and within his prerogatives" in deciding yesterday against reinstating the four American employes involved in Congressional loyalty checks.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 3 -- This nation now has the most powerful and effective air force in the world and it will continue to increase in size and strength despite recent cuts in Air Force funds, Charles E. Wilson, Secretary of Defense, declared today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, registered today his firm approval of shorter skirts but expressed some reservations about shorts as street-wear for men.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- James H. Douglas, Under Secretary of the Air Force, announced today that the Air Force had decided it could do without 965 airplanes on its purchase program and that an undisclosed number of the un-bought planes would be replaced by a new supersonic fighter, the North American F-100.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- Robert W. Toth, former sergeant in the Air Force charged with murder in the death of a South Korean civilian, was freed in Federal District Court today in bail of $1,000. He was released pending appeal on a ruling that, as a civilian, he had been illegally removed to Korea last May to face court-martial proceedings.

SAIGON, Vitnam, Sept. 3 -- Negotiations between France and each of the three Associated States of Indo-China are proceeding simulatneously but separately with France seeking an agreement by which the four countries would be bound together in a common defense effort against the Communist-led Vietminh rebels and with each of the Indo-Chinese states seeking its own independence.

LONDON, Sept. 3 -- The small rise in gold and dollar reserves figures for August heartened the stock markets today but brought little extra business. British Government stocks continued to improve and industrial shares responded to selective buying, with stores making the best showing, followed by brewery, radio and tobacco groups.

Walter G. Bain, until recently Major General, United States Air Force, has been appointed executive assistant to Mundy I. Peale, president of Republic Aviation Corporation. Mr. Bain is a graduate of the University of Colorado and Massachusetts Institute of Technology.
Near-by farms that supply New York with most of its fresh fruits, vegetables, poultry and dairy products are suffering serious effects from the heat wave.
AT the Second District Federal Reserve Bank, an incongruous Florentine palazzo in the heart of New York's financial district, they have money to burn.

FREEDOM VILLAGE, Korea, Friday, Sept. 4 (AP) -- General Dean, after being freed today, told of difficult marches and long stretches of interrogation by his Red captors. Otherwise, he said, he was treated reasonably well.

Claude Jean Chiasson, one of the very few musical artists to perform in public on instruments of their own construction, was one of the performers heard last night at Norman Seaman's "Interval Concert" in Carnegie Recital Hall.

TEHERAN, Iran, Sept. 3 -- The United States agreed today to continue technical assistance to Iran at the present level of $23,400,000 annually -- the largest expenditure in any country -- as one of a series of measures planned to aid the nation's recovery under the new regime of Premier Gen. Fazlollah Zahedi.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 (UP) -- The Air Force made public today the types of jet engines it planned to install in three of its newest fighter planes after accidentally letting the information leak out in a routine regulation.

FREEDOM VILLAGE, Korea, Sept. 3 -- A United States Air Force captain said today that a senior Russian officer, while under the influence of vodka, had told him that Soviet pilots were flying MIG fighter planes in air battles over Korea.

From the way things were shaping up yesterday, it looked as if the redoubtable "Wish You Were Here" was preparing to close up shop at the Imperial on Nov. 28. Not bad for a show that opened last year on June 25 (a scorching day with the maximum temperature at 96.5) to one favorable review.

The longest heat wave in New York's recorded weather history is expected to continue today, with temperature readings probably higher than yesterday's 91.6 maximum, but the high-mercury marathon is due to wind up late tomorrow.
Cotton futures prices fell 6 to 12 points yesterday with trading quiet on the New York Cotton Exchange.

THE present moon phase does not provide the high tides that make rail-pushing easy, but the first report on this shooting on the Housatonic River in Connecticut revealed plenty of birds on the wild rice flats.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 (UP) -- The Agriculture Department is hopeful of dropping the anti-discrimination clause in the farm-loan contracts that stirred bitter protests from Southern bankers.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- The Mid-Century Conference on Resources for the Future, to be held in Washington on Dec. 2, 3 and 4, will not endorse any specific program or seek to formulate a program of its own, Dr. R. G. Gustavson said today.

LONDON, Sept. 3 -- The British Government intends to use the meeting of the Governors of the International Monetary Fund and the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development in Washington next week as an occasion for preaching the gospel of freer trade and an end of currency restrictions.
LONDON, Sept. 3 --Prime Minister Sir Winston Churchill intends to remain at the head of the British Government and to keep Anthony Eden as his Foreign Secretary.

Harkening to the needs of college and career girls as well as thrifty young matrons, the Rosette Penington Shop, 20 East Fifty-sixth Street, has just opened a new first-floor department specializing in fashions priced from $25 to $50. Shown to the press yesterday, this new Chez Rosette Salon proved as attractive as its clothes were chic.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, said today that the United States expected peace to continue in Korea and did not look for a resumption of the fighting.
LONDON, Sept. 3 (Reuters) -- Business under the new International Wheat Agreement goes from bad to worse.

The New York District Council of the International Longshoremen's Association, A. F. L., has voted to reinstate John J. (Gene) Sampson as business agent of Local 791, but parliamentarians of the troubled dock union say the vote is meaningless.
Sales and earnings of the Spencer Chemical Company reached new highs in the fiscal year ended on last June 30, the annual report of Kenneth A. Spencer, president, revealed yesterday.

Women who see Bergdorf Goodman's collection of French millinery imports will be hard put to resist their flattery and charm. As shown yesterday, they were tiny, light as a puff of air and enhanced with a wealth of enchanting detail.

Representative Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr., making his first speaking appearance of the primary campaign on behalf of Borough President Robert F. Wagner Jr. of Manhattan, attempted last night in talks delivered at two open air rallies in Brooklyn to read Mayor Impellitteri out of the Democratic party.

PAUL WINCHELL, the ventriloquist, and Jerry Mahoney, his dummy, resumed over the N. B. C. television network last Sunday from 7 to 7:30 P. M. Had the show used a subtitle, it might have been called "The Problems of a TV Ventriloquist."
ALBANY, Sept. 3 (AP) -- The State Election Bureau today certified nine proposed Constitutional Amendments to be submitted to the voters in the Nov. 3 election.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- During the week ended Sept. 2 member bank reserves decreased $115,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 3 --After a ten-day discussion, the United Nations Security Council decided today not to place the Moroccan question on its agenda. The vote was a tie, five in favor and five against, whereas seven votes were required for a majority.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended last Saturday totaled 818,461 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.

DU QUOIN, Ill., Sept. 3 (AP) -- Newport Dream, owned by the Newport Stock Farms of South Plainfield, N. J., broke two world records for 2-year-old trotters today at the Du Quoin State Fair's Grand Circuit races.

Cincinnati teed off on Larry Jansen, Marv Grissom, Hoyt Wilhelm and Montia Kennedy for fifteen hits yesterday in drubbing the Giants, 9 -- 2, at the Polo Grounds before 1,078 fans, the smallest turnout of the local season.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Sept. 3 -- Minister of Labor Harold Holt today authorized troops at Bowen, a port in Queensland, to extend their loading of ships from meat to sugar. The troops were idle because they had completed loading all available meat for Britain on the liner Port Wellington and because workers at the Merinda meat works five miles away refused to load any more meat on trucks which railwaymen also refused to move.
DES MOINES, Sept. 3 (AP) -- The New York Giants punched over two touchdowns in the second half tonight to defeat the Chicago Bears, 14 -- 7, in an exhibition game.

The Carbide and Carbon Chemicals Company announced yesterday that it had shipped the first tank car of high-boiling phenols, a chemical mixture produced directly from coal, from its coal-hydrogenation plant at Institute, W. Va.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 3 (UP) -- A run-down error by Del Rice enabled Gran Hamner to score from third base with the winning run tonight as the Phillies defeated the Cardinals, 2 -- 1, to retain their grip on third place.
Russell L. Baker has been appointed manager of the builder sales department for the Republic Steel Kitchens organization of the Berger Manufacturing division of Republic Steel Corporation.

LIVERPOOL, England, Sept. 3 -- Chemists at the meetings of the British Association for the Advancement of Science here today recounted how a complex group of yellow pigments called carotenoids have an important, if little understood, sexual significance in the life of many plants and animals from seaweed to man.
SAVANNAH, Ga., Sept. 3 (UP) -- Mr. Toomer, a Negro, said today he considered his appointment a tribute by the Republicans to his race.

OYSTER BAY, L. I., Sept. 3 -- The United States flag was hoisted on the flagstaff of the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club today to denote a second successive victory for the defenders in the six-meter team competition for the British-American Cup.

" The Boat," an account of a 1,000-mile, twenty-eight-day journey in a lifeboat, will be published on Sept. 15 by Houghton Mifflin. The author is Walter Gibson, who in 1942 was among the troops and civilians being evacuated from the Malayan settlements.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- A White House source said tonight that the first vacancy that occurred on the Supreme Court would go to Governor Warren if he wanted it.

Full of excitement and "memories to last a lifetime" and with some serious views about world conditions, 985 students and teachers returned yesterday aboard the chartered Swedish motor ship, the Anna Salen, after having spent the summer in Europe.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Sept. 3 -- The Government will not arm volunteer battalions to fight the Darul Islam and other rebel groups in Indonesia, Prime Minister Ali Sastroamidjojo asserted in a defense of his new Government's program in Parliament here yesterday.
MUNSAN, Friday, Sept. 4 (AP) -- Official list of United States war prisoners freed today at Panmunjom:

INDIANAPOLS, Sept. 3 -- Thruston B. Morton, Assistant Secretary of State, told the ninth annual convention of Amvets (American veterans of World War II and the Korean campaign) here today that the United Sates would forefeit its national security by following the counsel of those who would abridge the rights of individual citizens and surrender to fear.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Sept. 3 -- Dr. Shao Yu-lin personal envoy from Chiang Kai-shek to the irregular troops of the Chinese Nationalist Army in Burma, leaves this city tomorrow for Taipei after successfully completing his mission to persuade some of the troops to agree to leave Burma for Formosa.

TOKYO, Friday, Sept. 4 -- Maj. Gen. William F. Dean, former commander of the United States Twenty-fourth Infantry Division and highest ranking prisoner of the Korean war, was released from his three-year captivity by the Communists today.
SINGAPORE, Friday, Sept. 4 -- High Commissioner Gen. Sir Gerald W. R. Templer yesterday declared 221 square miles of the coastal Malacca Settlement "white" -- free from Communist terrorism.

CAMP PERRY, Ohio, Sept. 3 (AP) -- Two United States Marine sergeants won a pair of coveted titles today by defeating 700 of the nation's finest riflemen in the national high-power rifle championships.
Traffic experts warned yesterday that the three-day Labor Day holiday week-end might bring the heaviest highway congestion of this or any other season.

Volume continued light yesterday on the New York commodity exchanges. Only cottonseed oil, soybean oil and zinc approached normal activity. Prices closed irregular with soybean oil, sugar and coffee mixed; cottonseed oil, cocoa, wool and rubber higher, and zinc, hides, copper, lead, tin and potatoes lower.
Dallas County, Tex., received bids yesterday on three issues of debt securities totaling $10,600,000.
WASHINGTON, Sept 3 (AP) -- The Public Health Service reported today that the 2,238 new cases of infantile paralysis listed last week rpresented a drop of thirteen under the preceding week.

Charles T. Douds, regional director of the National Labor Relations Board, yesterday dismissed a second set of unfair labor practice charges brought against the Hearn department stores by the Distributive, Processing and Office Workers, C. I. O.

LONDON, Sept. 3 -- The unequal struggle between stone and the London climate has reduced Westminster Abbey, where Britain's Kings and Queens are crowned and her heroes enshrined, to a state of dilapidation that, unless large-scale restoration is promptly undertaken, may make many parts of the building unusable.

A New York County grand jury returned informations yesterday charging four men with simple assault in an attack last Sunday on two employes of radio station WOR in front of the station, 1440 Broadway.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 (AP) -- Justice Department experts were reported today to have taken the position that the department was without legal authority to initiate any mass disbarment proceedings against Communist lawyers.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- T. Coleman Andrews, Commissioner of Internal Revenue, denied today there was either an invasion of privacy or harassment of the citizenry in the bureau's current drive to track down delinquent taxpayers.

The Appellate Division yesterday by a 3-to-2 vote upheld the right of Dr. Louis F. Von Pritzel Witz Vanderhorst to contest his wife's suit for annulment seven months after he had defaulted and a referee recommended the granting of a decree.

MASSAPEQUA, L. I., Sept. 3 -- Richard E. Enright, 82 years old, former Police Commissioner of New York, was seriously injured at 8:15 tonight when he fell down a flight of stairs at the home of a friend here.
ALBANY, Sept. 3 (UP) -- Seven new forest fires were reported burning in the critically dry state forest preserves today, two of them out of control.

Although the weather belies it, the "fall-winter boxing season" opens at Madison Square Garden tonight when Lulu Perez of Brooklyn engages Dave Gallardo of Los Angeles, California state champion, in a ten-round featherweight bout.

Your correspondent David Anderson had an interesting article in your paper recently concerning Joseph A. Dietrich, Superintendent of Parks and Trees in Greenwich. Conn., and the matter of selective street tree planting.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- The refusal last night by Dag Hammarskjold, Secretary General of the United Nations, to reinstate four American employes of the United Nations has not changed plans of the Senate Internal Security subcommittee to reinvestigate "all aspects" of the case.

Safeway Stores, Inc. which operates 1,926 retail stores across the United States and 139 in Canada, transacted net sales of $787,578,737 in the twenty-four weeks ended on June 13, an increase of $55,894,552, or 7.64 per cent, over the $731,684,185 volume in the 1952 period.

GUATEMALA, Sept. 3 -- Guilermo Toriello, Guatemala's Ambassador to Washington, told newsmen today that this country considered the recent protest by the State Department against the compensation given to the United Fruit Company for its expropriated land to be "offensive" to its national "dignity." He added that the protest "should be rejected."

Broiler cookery -- quick, convenient and versatile -- seems particularly appropriate for the coming holiday week-end. If the heat wave continues, it probably will be about the only type of cooking most women will care to do.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 3 -- Dr. Basil C. MacLean, director of Strong Memorial-Rochester Municipal Hospitals, Rochester, N. Y., and a strong advocate of area-wide concerted action by hospitals, received tonight the Award of Merit of the American Hospital Association as it ended its four-day convention here.
The American Export liner Independence became yesterday the headquarters of the nation's second seagoing Naval Reserve merchant marine company.

There is little reason to hope that a settlement of the German and Austrian treaty problems is any nearer today after the latest exchange of notes between the Soviet Union and the United States, Britain and France. Why, then, do these long-drawn-out exchanges go on ? An answer is worth seeking, because we are dealing here with one of the fundamentals of contemporary European history.

CAMP DRUM, N. Y., Sept. 3 -- Field training, much of it in 90-degree heat, neared the end today for members of the Forty-second National Guard and Seventy-seventh Infantry Reserve Divisions, both from the New York City area. The units arrived almost two weeks ago.

James M. Power, president of the Board of Elections, urged the Court of Appeals yesterday to act promptly on primary election cases so that the paper ballots to be used in the primaries can be printed in time.

The much-buffeted International Longshoremen's Association, A. F. L., got outlaw strikers back to work at four Jersey City piers yesterday after shipping employers had warned they would boycott further contract negotiations with the union until they got written assurances that there would be no more illegal strikes.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- A strike of 35,000 members of the Order of Railroad Conductors scheduled for Sept. 10 has been canceled by agreement of the railroads to consider union demands after Oct. 1, the Government announced today.

WESTBURY, L. I., Sept. 3 (AP) -- Casanova, owned by the Craig Cimaron Ranch of Lemoore, Calif., tonight established a Roosevelt Raceway pacing record for one and one-sixteenth miles. Dana Cameron brought Casanova home by half a length over the favored Mamscot, in 2:12 1-5.
DENVER, Sept. 3 -- President Eisenhower tonight authorized the shipment of 10,000 tons of agricultural commodities for famine and other relief to Jordan.

As a psychiatrist, chief of the Electroshock Department of Lebanon Hospital, and author of a number of scientific articles on various forms of shock treatment, I feel it necessary to write to you regarding the article by William L. Laurence, which appeared in THE NEW YORK TIMES on Aug. 21.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 3 -- Taking what could be their last view of this fair metropolis until such times as they may, in the distant future, engage the Cardinals in a world series, the Yankees today gave Marty Marion's Browns a farewell drubbing, 8 to 5, before a sparse crowd of 2,350.

LIVERPOOL, England, Sept. 3 (Reuters) -- Huge supplies of grain are choking the port of Liverpool and delaying the return of free enterprise trading, an official of the Liverpool Corn Trade Association said today.

Twenty-two harbor workhorses representing a cross-section of the port's towing companies will drop their prosaic tasks for a day Sept. 12 for a series of tugboat races on the Hudson River in conjunction with the International Lifeboat Race.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- Following is the text of a statement on the partition of Germany issued by John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, at his news conference today:

Venezuela must not depend on oil alone but rather should look forward to diversification of its industrial development, mining and agriculture, Delfin Enrique Paez, Consul General of Venezuela in New York, declared yesterday.

A Halsey, Stuart Co. syndicate closed subscription books yesterday on the new issue of $30,000,000 of debentures of the Southern Bell Telephone and Telegraph Company, thus bringing to a happy ending a war of nerves between the issuing company and the bond market and between banking syndicates and investors.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 (AP) -- Livestock producers are "apprehensive," the Department of Agriculture reported today, but it added that price prospects "do not warrant undue pessimism."

The tumult and the shouting at Baruch Houses have died as the Mayor, the Governor and the President made their speeches and departed, leaving our city with a project one-third completed while about 1500 families continue to live in six-story slum walk-up buildings that fill the nine blocks still remaining of Baruch Site.

PARIS, Sept. 3 -- The first open break in Premier Joseph Laniel's two-month-old Cabinet occurred today when Francois Mitterand, Minister in Charge of Relations with the Council of Europe, resigned because of a disagreement with the Government's North African policy.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- Department store sales in the week ended Aug. 29 were 9 per cent below those of the corresponding week of 1952. This was reported today by the Federal Reserve Board which listed the following percentage changes from like periods of last year:

CAZENOVIA, N. Y., Sept. 3 -- By defeating Dr. Ariel Mengarini of New York in a Queen's Gambit declined lasting thirty moves, Hans Berliner of Washington today held his lead with a score of 5 -- 0 in the annual tournament for the championship of the New York State Chess Association.

Two widely differing shoe collections were presented yesterday. Resort and evening shoes predominated in a Schiaparelli-designed collection shown at the Plaza Hotel, while at Andrew Geller's salon at 18 West Fifty-seventh Street street shoes designed for the business woman were on view.

BERLIN, Sept. 3 -- Encouraged by overtures from the East and driven by a dearth of markets elsewhere, more West European concerns appear to be doing business at the Leipzig Fair now than in any year since the end of World War II.

CHICAGO, Sept. 3 -- The need for more Jewish community relations organizations to cope with specific programs to cope with changing Communist strategy and "to expose and defeat any attempt to confuse and divide public opinion," was stressed in a report adopted today by the Jewish War Veterans of the United States.

Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, chairman of the Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations, ran into a flat refusal by the First Army here and the Army's chief of legislative liaison in Washington yesterday to disclose the names of individuals responsible for loyalty or security clearances.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 (UP) -- The Army has dropped plans for an immediate manpower cut and will continue to draft about 23,000 men monthly until a "firm agreement'' is reached in Korea, informed sources said today. The Defense Department had intended to reduce draft calls to about 19,000 a month, starting in November.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- The upward trend in municipal taxes and expenditures continued last year, according to a survey released today by the Department of Commerce's Bureau of the Census. The report, covering 481 cities of more than 25,000 inhabitants, showed that the municipalities had collected taxes averaging $55.82 a person, a gain of 8.5 per cent compared with 1951.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 3 -- Replying to yesterday's demand by the American Legion for a Federal investigation of the activities of the American Civil Liberties Union, the latter organization suggested to the Legion today that it "learn how to oppose illegal acts while defending civil liberties and how to oppose what a man says while defending his constitutional right to say it."

KARACHI, Pakistan, Sept. 4 -- The Pakistan Government will begin operation of an international commercial air service in April. A bill to nationalize the industry and absorb the only domestic airline is expected to pass unanimously when introduced in the Constituent Assembly which convenes Sept. 23.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 -- The Department of Defense announced today that no further draft calls for physicians would be issued for an indefinite period and that no further volunteers for medical service would be accepted until new vacancies were available.

MONTREAL, Sept. 4 -- Contrary to the usually accepted idea, it was suggested here today at the International Physiological Congress, the human body may not be equipped to maintain accurately a constant internal temperature.

DENVER, Sept. 4 -- President Eisenhower shuffled his staff today on the basis of his experience of seven months in the White House, appointing I. Jack Martin, administrative assistant to the late Senator Robert A. Taft, Republican of Ohio, as an administrative assistant for Congressional liaison. He also created the new office of Deputy Assistant to the President for Maj. Gen. Wilton B. Persons, U. S. A., retired.

SAIGON, Vietnam, Sept. 4 -- Nationalist elements in the Indo-Chinese State of Vietnam emerged suddenly today as a single powerful voice with the announcement that a national congress would shortly be held to consider the question of independence now being negotiated in Paris.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 4 -- Overemphasis on the dangers of the atomic and hydrogen bombs is endangering the emotional security of children and may lead to the development of neurotic fears, a leading psychologist said here today.

NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 4 (AP) -- A Foreign Office spokesman said today the Indian Government had been informed that Admiral Chester W. Nimitz had resigned as plebiseite administrator for disputed Kashmir -- a "name only" post for the last two years.

Just before each week-end Elizabeth Haight Harris leaves the New York Public Library at Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street, rides out to Teterboro Airport in New Jersey with her husband, Stanley Harris, a commercial artist, and they fly up the Hudson, over the Catskills, to her native Morrisville, southeast of Syracuse.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 4 (AP) -- The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company and the United Rubber Workers, C. I. O., agreed today on a general hourly wage increase of 2 1/2 to 5 1/2 cents, retroactive to Aug. 31, for 30,000 workers in the company's ten plants.
Cleveland, Ohio, announced yesterday that it would reoffer $6,000,000 of its water revenue bonds on Sept. 30. The sale originally posted for Aug. 13, was postponed at that time.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 -- Loans of $12,500,000 to the Government of Chile and $14,000,000 to Japan in pounds sterling were announced today by the International Monetary Fund. Both transactions were arranged through purchase by the fund of the currencies of the applicant countries.

CAZENOVIA, N. Y., Sept. 4 -- Hans Berliner of Washington remained unbeaten in the annual tournament for the championship of the New York State Chess Association today by defeating Philip Le Cornu of Detroit in a Sicilian defense lasting twenty-seven moves.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 4 -- While troops from all parts of the country were converging on northern Yugoslavia for impending maneuvers, the Yugoslav Government today threatened to bring some of them to positions opposite Italian forces on the frontier at Gorizia, charging that Italy had created an "abnormal situation."

Mrs. Marian W. O'Connor's 4-year-old filly La Corredora bobbed up with an extremely frisky bit of running in the $10,000 added handicap that topped Aqueduct's program yesterday, and those who had backed her were also rather frisky as they headed to the cashiers' windows.
KANSAS CITY, Sept. 4 (AP) -- The show, "Annie Get your Gun," went on last night -- without Annie.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., Sept. 4 (UP) -- The country's newest race track, Las Vegas Park, got off to a ragged start today but staged its inaugural program of nine races despite minor difficulties, including the failure of its electrical totalizator board during the first race.

PARIS, Sept. 4 -- Price cuts in a large number of food and manufactured products were announced today as producers and distributors responded favorably to the Government's appeal to bring down the cost of living.
VENICE, Italy, Sept. 4 (AP) -- Lilli Palmer, star of the American film "The Four Poster," won the best actress award here tonight at the fourteenth International Film Festival.

CAMP DRUM, Sept. 4 -- The last parade of the summer training season was held here this afternoon, when nearly 2,000 members of the Seventy-seventh Infantry Reserve Division of New York, under the command of Maj. Gen. Julius Ochs Adler, marched beneath a broiling sun with the mercury in the midnineties.

MOSCOW, Sept. 4 -- The Soviet Foreign Office, in a circular note to the heads of all diplomatic missions in Moscow, had advised them that henceforth the Foreign Office, like all other Government institutions in the capital, will be on a strict 9 A. M. to 6 P. M. regime, with one hour off for lunch.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 (AP) -- Senator Alexander Wiley, Republican of Wisconsin, and chairman or the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, demanded a showdown today on the employment of Americans in the United Nations when their loyalty to the United States Government had come under fire.

As Isidor Tabor, 66 years old, drove up to his place of business at 409 East 106th Street yesterday at 9:30 A. M., he was met by two men with their hands in their pockets, seemingly holding pistols. They warned him, under threat of death, not to make any outcry.

The general strike in France proved not only a bane to the citizens of that country but also to such tourists-on-business as Joshua Logan. The disruptive circumstances there prevented Mr. Logan last month from getting within talking distance of Marcel Pagnol for a conference of "Fanny," the musical version of the latter's three plays, "Marius," "Fanny" and "Caesar," due on Broadway this season.
The International Longshoremen's Association, A. F. L., promised in writing yesterday that there would be no more illegal wildcat strikes in the Port of New York.

DENVER, Colo., Sept. 4 -- President Eisenhower has summoned John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, for a conference here Sunday. Richard M. Nixon, the Vice President, and other important officials are to follow later next week.

TEHERAN, Iran, Sept. 4 -- Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi has told intimates that a new reign by a new ruler began Aug. 22 with his return from a six-day exile, aged and sobered by the near loss of his throne.
TAMPA, Fla., Sept. 4 (AP) -- A B-47 Stratojet bomber crew clipped forty minutes off the record time of a nonstop crossing from England to MacDill Air Force Base here today.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Sept. 4 (AP) -- Walter P. Reuther, president of the C. I. O., said today that America was following a "narrow, negative policy" which provided "billions for war, pennies for peace." He told the United States Assembly of Youth:
WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 (UP) -- The Defense Department reported today that 79 per cent of the strategic materials scheduled for stockpiling in case of war had been obtained or was on order on June 30.

Justice Anthony J. DiGiovanna of the Supreme Court signed an order yesterday restraining the Trojan Realty Corporation, owner of a large apartment house at 455 Schenectady Avenue, Brooklyn, from removing ten air-conditioning units installed by tenants. Justice DiGiovanna directed that a hearing be held by the Appellate Term of the Brooklyn Supreme Court on Sept. 15 before further action is taken.
LIVERPOOL, England, Sept. 4 (AP) -- Roger Bannister, Britain's star miler, said today the first man to run the four-minute mile might turn the-trick by toting a lightweight oxygen supply system.
OYSTER BAY, L. I., Sept. 4 -- The third match for the British-American Cup ended today as had the other two -- with victory for the United States six-meter team.

Among the most looked-at objects in New York for the last ten days have surely been thermometers and barometers. Some new designs of these items should make intriguing and attractive additions to the home.

Company-wide plans permitting employes to buy stock have risen sharply since 1950, the New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday. In that year only six companies listed were with such plans. At the end of 1952 there were forty and interest in the idea has become so great that the Exchange has been obliged to reissue its booklet, "Stock Ownership Plans for Employes."

A special envoy of President Chiang Kai-shek, Dr. Shao Yu-lin, has just completed an arduous and semi-secret mission to the border area of northern Burma. His purpose was to persuade Chinese irregular forces, or Nationalist guerrillas, to accept transfer to Formosa and thus ease the strain between Nationalist China and Burma.
ALBUQUERQUE, Sept. 4 (AP) -- A team of Los Alamos scientists has reported it believes it has observed the free neutrino -- a never before detected particle of the nucleus.
NAPLES, Sept. 4 (AP) -- Agostino Straulino's Merope II easily won the next to last race in the international Star class yacht championship today.

LONDON, Sept. 4 -- There are five countries or groups of countries to which British Government economists are now looking for most of the expansion of exports this country will need to achieve in the next few years.

OTTAWA, Sept. 4 -- Because of the triangular pattern of her trade with the United Kingdom and the United States. Canada's delegation to next week's meeting of the International Monetary Fund in Washington is expected to give strong support to any British move toward the liberalization of existing currency and import restrictions.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 (UP) -Lew Worsham, Oakmont, Pa., pro, with long drives and sure putting, took the lead today with a 3-under-par 69 in the second day of the $15,000 National Celebrities Open at Woodmont in suburban Rockville, Md.

The cotton futures market closed steady yesterday, 1 point higher to 4 points lower than on Thursday, with light trading on the New York Cotton Exchange. The market opened 2 to 5 points net lower on active months, but held within a comparatively narrow range awaiting the Government's second cotton estimate Tuesday.

BONN, Germany, Sept. 4 -- Solingen today banned the Communist sports festival scheduled for election day, next Sunday, on the ground that it was a ruse to assure the election Of Max Reimann, national leader of the West German Communist party, who is a party candidate in the Solingen constituency.

Greatly increased sales enabled the Ryan Aeronautical Company to report yesterday a net income of $1,342,946 for the nine months ended on July 31, last, more than doubling the $609,669 earned in the corresponding period of the previous year.

Two of the city's newest public schools, now being constructed in Manhattan and the Bronx, will be named in memory of Dr. Eugene Percy Roberts, first Negro member of the Board of Education and Paul Laurence Dunbar, Negro poet.

Mayor Impellitteri and Kenneth F. Sutherland, Democratic leader of Brooklyn, made angry replies yesterday to the charges Representative Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. had leveled against them the night before. The son of the late President had made campaign appearances on behalf of Borough President Robert F. Wagner Jr., Mr. Impellitteri's rival for the Democratic mayoral nomination.

HAVANA, Sept. 4 -- President Fulgencia Batista today warned the Cubans against communism, which he linked with the activities of his political enemies, and expressed the hope that plans for holding elections next June would not be disrupted by any further revolutionary attempts.

A significant interview with Chancellor Konrad Adenauer was reported in THE TIMES of Aug. 26. Dr. Adenauer is quoted as having said that a European defense army "prevents the member states from going off on any military adventure on their own."

BONN, Germany, Sept. 4 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer suggested today that a comprehensive security system might be established by means of agreements between the various re gional groupings in the world.

The woebegone Giants last night put the Dodgers a step closer to a second straight National League pennant by booting five runs across the plate with four glaring errors. With the help of these misplays, the Brooks scored an 8-6 victory in a 3-hour 20-minute game marked by a series of "bean ball" incidents and umpire-baiting.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 -- Average primary market prices declined 0.4 per cent in the week ended Sept. 1 to 110.3 of the 1947-49 average, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. Lower average prices for farm products and processed foods were largely responsible for the decline.

KANSAS CITY, Sept. 4 (AP) -- Orville L. Ring, head of Local 541, Teamsters' Union, A. F. L., was indicted today by a Jackson County grand jury on two charges of embezzlement and two counts of second degree robbery.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 (AP) -The Federal Power Commission today set a hearing to start here Oct. 19 on complaints by the Maryland Public Service Commission and Consolidated Gas Electric Light and Power Company, Baltimore, concerning Pennsylvania Water and Power Company, also of Baltimore.

ROME, Sept. 4 -- A wave of protests and indignation that may have adverse effects on Italian-American relations and even on Italian collaboration with the other North Atlantic Treaty Organization powers swept over Italy today when the people read the statement about Trieste made yesterday by Secretary of State John Foster Dulles at a press conference.
WENDOVER, Utah, Sept. 4 (AP) -- A national hot-rod speed record, set by the same car that broke the mark last year, was registered today in the Bonneville speed trials over Utah's salt flats.

CAIRO, Sept. 4 -- The British and Egyptian negotiators in the dispute over title to the British Suez Canal military base, held their seventh and last scheduled informal meeting last night before Gen. Sir Brian Robertson's expected departure for London tonight.

Copley Fabrics, Inc., rayon converters, have purchased the eleven-story loft building on plot 100 by 108 feet at 97 East Houston Street where they plan to occupy large space for warehouse purposes. Assessed at $445,000, the property was bought from the I. A.

CAIRO, Sept. 4 -- The Arab Supreme Defense Council met here for the first time tonight and broached plans to create a unified high command for Arab League armies, which, however, will retain their separate identities.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 -- An investigation into the beating on Aug. 31, of an official of the Congress of Industrial Organizations at Ashland, Miss., was requested of the Attorney General, Herbert Brownell Jr., today by Arthur J. Goldberg, the C. I. O.'s general counsel.

TOPEKA, Kan., Sept. 4 -- The Topeka Board of Education took the first step today to end all segregation in public schools here by adopting a policy against separate schools for Negro elementary pupils.
