The drowning of twenty soldiers at Fort Bragg in one of the worst training accidents since the Second World War was a tragedy all the more heart-breaking because it was plainly preventable.

While total value of Philippine foreign trade for the first five months of 1953 was less than in the 1952 period, a closer balance of exports with imports was achieved, according to the monthly review of the Philippine Association.

The Cuban people owe THE NEW YORK TIMES a tribute of gratitude for the recent magnificent editorial on "Batista's Dilemma." The editorial accurately describes Cuba's tragic condition under the dictatorship that overthrew our democratic institutions. It underlines the dictator's own impotence to break the "vicious circle that tyranny sets in motion," which is relentlessly and unavoidably pushing Cuba into the throes of violence, rebellion and economic collapse.
Nine members of Congress sailed aboard the United States liner United States yesterday to study foreign aid, immigration and American military building problems in Europe and Asia.

The Canadian aircraft carrier Magnificent, escorted by the cruiser Quebec, arrived yesterday with 1,700 officers and enlisted men, many of whom immediately expressed their good neighborliness by donating blood to the American Red Cross.

LONDON,. Sept. 4 -- The stock markets here were quieter today in anticipation of the week-end. Prices moved only slightly up or down although a number of industrials were bright features and further speculative interest in the overseas groups accounted for sharp movements among the United Railway of Havana stocks.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 (AP) -Conflict over whether a pipeline company or a distributor should serve an aluminum plant near Wenatchee, Wash., was disclosed today at a Federal Power Commission hearing on applications to pipe natural gas to the Pacific Northwest.

LONDON, Sept. 4 -- The British Foreign Office has explained to the Soviet Union that in a constitutional monarchy even sovereign governments must go to court if they wish to gain the legal custody of their citizens -- and especially of minor children.

There is general relief and rejoicing over the return to freedom, after more than three years in Communist prisons, of Maj. Gen. William F. Dean. His heroism, as commander of the Twenty-fourth Division in the darkest days of the early Korean campaign, has long been recognized and has been suitably noted with our highest military decoration.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Sept. 4 -- The dispute over the use of troops to load ships at Bowen, in Queensland, was settled at a conference here today between Minister of Labor Harold Holt and representatives of the Australian Council of Trade Unions, the Waterside Workers Federation and the Railway and Clerks Unions.

Wilted and weary New Yorkers, who have been suffering through the longest heat wave in the city's recorded weather history, received a bit of relief yesterday when afternoon breezes from the Atlantic prevented temperatures from reaching 90 degrees for the first time in eleven days.

PARIS, Sept. 4 -- It is understood the French Government will ask Washington for an additional $150,000,000 of aid for the war in Indo-China in the current fiscal year that will end next July, on top of the $400,000,000 for this fiscal year that has already been appropriated.

THE HAGUE, The Netherlands, Sept. 4 -- The annual Assembly of the World Medical Association, representing more than 700,000 doctors in forty-six countries, voted unanimously here today to ask the International Red Cross to include medical workers in the civilian defense organizations of combatant nations among the list of personnel protected under the Red Cross banner.
TOKYO, Saturday, Sept. 5 -- The United Nations and Communists announced today that they would complete the exchange of prisoners of the Korean war tomorrow.

Directors of the Pacific Lighting Corporation yesterday voted a two-for-one split of the common stock, subject to approval of stockholders, and declared a quarterly dividend of 50 cents on the new comman, payable on Nov. 16.

LIVERPOOL, England, Aug. 4 -- Outstanding advances in husbandry including the production of milk from steers and sterile or virgin heifers were reported at today's session of the British Association for the Advancement of Science here by Dr. John Hammond of Cambridge, Britain's leading animal physiologist.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 4 -- The Federal Government is reinforcing its corps of guards along the nation's 1,600-mile Southwestern Border, over which Mexicans have been filtering illegally at a rate of about 1,000,000 a year.

Today's new film is a combined Russian importation at the Stanley. "Life in the Arctic," a Moscow Popular Science Film Studio documentary in Magicolor, will be the first half of the program. A. Zguridi wrote and directed the offering. "The Snow Maiden," a Soyuzmult-film Studios presentation, based on the story by A. N. Ostrovsky, using the music of Rimsky-Korsakov, will be the latter portion of the program.
Jean Marcel Berret, East Side restaurateur, returned the other day to the heat and sun of New York after a month in the damp coolness that France has been experiencing this summer.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Sept. 4 -- The Crane Company will build its $25,000,000 titanium plant in this Southern industrial city, according to an announcement last night by W. M. Hamilton, manager of the company's Chattanooga division.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 4 -- The United States is sounding out other delegations on a proposal under which the United Nations General Assembly, which will open its 1953 session Sept. 15, would bar consideration of the question of seating representatives of Communist China at any time during the session.

MINEOLA, L. I., Sept. 4 -- Frank Bailey, treasurer of Union College, Schenectady, N. Y., and former president of the Title Guaranty and Trust Company of New York, left $1,500,000 to the college, it was disclosed today at the filing of his will for probate in Surrogate's Court here.

A one-story building containing 12,000 square feet of space at 107-01 Northern Boulevard in Carona, Queens, has been leased from Leonard Sirling by T. C. Chris, manufacturer and finisher of costume furniture. Colony Realty and Charles M. Richardson were co-brokers in the transaction.

By the thin margin of a stroke, Kenneth Rosewall of Australia escaped defeat in the national tennis championships at Forest Hills yesterday and reached the semi-final round with Tony Trabert of Cincinnati.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Sept. 4 -- Policemen carrying gas masks and rifles, or heavy batons and shields of wickerwork or light metal, are actively patroling trouble areas of Nyasaland, where armed bands of Africans have been defying the authority of the British Government for two weeks.
Keyed to contemporary interiors, new additions to two collections of handwoven wool rugs are now available at Lorton Studios, 21 East Sixty-second Street, and at Simon Manges, 575 Fifth Avenue.

Invited by Harvard University to attend its international summer seminar, I have had occasion during the past weeks to meet Americans of the most diverse political opinions, of the most varied cultural backgrounds, of different sorts and grades of social responsibility.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 -- The Department of Agriculture today withdrew its requirement that lending agencies that make farm price support loans must sign a non-discrimination employment pledge.

MARIO, Mass., Sept. 4 -- The United State team appeared on the way toward retaining the Walker Cup after the first day's play in the international golf series with the British at the Kittansett Club today.

A two-month police watch on a gang of loft burglars came to a spectacular end early yesterday with the capture of the five-member gang in Greenwich Village amid a hail of bullets. One suspect broke both ankles when he plunged 20 feet through an open third-floor window in an attempt to escape.
DENVER, Sept. 4 -- President Eisenhower detoured to an osteopath's office on his way to work this morning, but his sore elbow did not prevent him from playing golf.

The city's drive against water wastage by the illegal opening of street hydrants was in full swing yesterday as water consumption for the third straight day topped 1,400,000,000 gallons. Police and Water Department patrols worked around the clock and had closed 766 illegally opened taps in the twenty-four hours ending yesterday morning.

Opening night festivities incidental to the Coney Island Mardi Gras celebration will be televised over the A.B.C. network on Tuesday from 8:30 to 9:30 o'clock. Included will be the parade, with floats and bands, and views of the Queen of the Mardi Gras.
CORPUS CHRISTI, Tex., Sept. 4 -- Scattered towns in south Texas were fighting floods again today after heavy rains were ushered into the area by a summertime cold spell.

The five-story apartment house accommodating forty-six families at 1645 Grand Avenue, the Bronx, has been sold by Mary Cohen to the Welwax Realty Corporation. The property, on plot 116 by 100 feet, is assessed at $150,000. It was sold for cash above mortgages of $137,000 in a transaction negotiated by Allan S. Feldman Co. as brokers.

Lulu Perez, Ked Hook featherweight, scored a technical, knockout over Dave Gallardo of Los Angeles in the main bout, scheduled for ten rounds, at Madison Square Garden last night. Gallardo finished the eighth round but was bleeding so badly from a cut over his left eye that he was prohibited from starting the ninth round by Dr. Vincent A. Nardiello.

Stock market volume shrank yesterday to the smallest figure -770,000 shares -- since Oct. 3, 1949, but prices performed well, holding firm through most of the day and pushing forward in the final thirty minutes of trading.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, Sept. 4 -- The Maldives, a cluster of little islands 400 miles southwest of Ceylon, which became the world's youngest republic last January, received its first political shock yesterday. A successful coup was staged by Ibrahim Mohamed Didi, Maldivian Vice President and another political agitator, Ibrahim Ali Dadi, who seized power and ousted Amin Didi, the first President of the republic, who was placed under arrest.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 -- Supremely confident that in short order they would nail that fifth straight American League pennant to their flagstaff and in due time handle the Dodgers, as well, Casey Stengel and his Yankees returned to the Atlantic seaboard today pre pared to mop things up as quickly as possible.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 -- New regulations relaxing the Army's control over alcoholic beverages on its land installations are being distributed among Army commanders. Similar instructions, which aim to standardize practices regarding use of alcoholic beverages on the land installations of the services, are shortly to be issued by the Air Force. The prescribed practices follow those now in effect in the Navy and the Marine Corps.
The following is a round-up of new products that may be of interest to homemakers:
Special masses and other religious ceremonies for Roman Catholics will be conducted on Labor Day.
MUNSAN, Korea, Saturday, Sept. 5 (AP) -- The official list of United States prisoners of war freed today at Panmunjom:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 -- An arrangement that should give a commuter leisure for his second cup of breakfast coffee was among the 674 inventions patented this week. By setting a time clock in his car the night before he can have the engine warmed up and ready for the dash to the station.

STAMFORD, Conn., Sept. 4 -- Led by William Ziegler Jr.'s Bounding Home, 53-foot Class A staysail schooner flying the burgee of the host club, the Stamford Yacht Club's nineteenth annual overnight race to Vineyard Sound Lightship got off to an excellent start tonight.
INCHON, Korea, Sept. 4 (UP) -- The Communists forced captured United States airmen to draw detailed sketches of American cities, airfields and radar layouts, it was reported today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 (AP) -- The United States Court of Appeals ruled today that the Government could not keep a Chinese from returning to China without first giving him "a full and fair hearing."

CHICAGO, Sept. 4 -- Coincident with the Defense Department's announcement that no more physicians would be drafted for the time being, the American Medical Association, speaking editorially in its official journal, today accused Selective Service officials of conscripting more physicians than were needed.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Sept. 4 -- Despite a pronounced divergence of views both on the subject matter and texts, the final session of the Second Study Conference on the North Atlantic Treaty Organization today adopted or "noted" the reports and resolutions of its four commissions.
Labor Day holiday travelers crowded the highways, railroads and airlines yesterday, with resulting delays on the metropolitan area's traffic arteries.
SYRACUSE, Sept. 4 (AP) -- Chief John A. Kinney has penalized more than fifty policemen for failing to attend the funeral of a fellow member of the force.
A new setting for the exhibition of world-wide art has been appropriately provided for on United Nations Plaza, at the Carnegie Endowment International Center.

What is described as a self-contained sales stimulation program for an individual company has been developed by Joseph A. Alexander Staff, management consultant organization, it was announced yesterday.
ALBANY, Sept. 4 -- William L. Pfeiffer is to resign as Republican state chairman in the near future to devote all of his time to business interests.

INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 4 -- Opposition to the Bricker Amendment, which would limit the President's treaty-making power, was recorded today by the ninth annual convention of Amvets (American veterans of World War II and the Korean campaign).

A new novel by John Hersey, his first since "The Wall" in 1950, has been scheduled for publication on Nov. 9 by Knopf. Entitled "The Marmot Drive," the story deals with certain events on two summer days in an out-of-the-way Connecticut village.

CLEVELAND, Saturday, Sept. 5 (UP) -- The Indians and White Sox fought to a 6-6 deadlock early today and remained tied in their battle for second place as rain fell from the third inning on and finally resulted in the calling of the game with Cleveland at bat in the eleventh inning.

CHICAGO, Sept. 4 (AP) -- Jockey Eddie Arcaro and Hasty House Farm, owned by Mr. and Mrs. Allen Reuben of Toledo, will shoot for Chicago horse-racing records tomorrow in the $156,085 Washington Park Futurity.

MAMARONECK, N. Y., Sept. 4 -- Competition for the Manhasset Bay Challenge Cup, held on Western Long Island Sound for the first time in twenty years, began at Orienta Yacht Club today, and John J. (Don) McNamara, representing Corinthian Yacht Club of Marblehead Neck, Mass., won the first of the three-race series.

Regardless of the downtrend in steel scrap prices and machine tool orders, retail volume of soft goods, including shoes, will continue to hold the same favorable comparison with last year experienced so far in 1953. This is the opinion of Council News, issued by the Tanners Council of America, which expresses alarm over the hesitancy that has appeared in the shoe production business, particularly in women's lines.

Col. Robert A. Howard Jr., who arounsed the ire of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, by declining to answer certain questions at a Senate hearing Thursday, said yesterday he did so because he was not authorized to disclose confidential information.
Lewis M. Douglas' report to the President concerning freer trade policies is gratifying to read.

REPORTS from New Brunswick indicate excellent hunting prospects for this fall, on both big and upland game, and, with the season opening on Oct. 1, those planning a hunt in this Province would do well to decide on their camp and make reservations without delay, for the bookings are heavy.

New York's population is divided into many political, racial and religious segments, but there is no cleavage so pronounced in any of these as there is between those two rival groups, the day workers and the night workers.

CHICAGO, Sept. 4 -- A stronger tone developed in the grain market today following early declines. Commission absorption of wheat and especially corn was marked at times. Oats and rye were helped by the improvement in the major grains, and soybeans moved up on a rather bullish private estimate. A supplemental North Western railroad report issued late yesterday predicted a corn crop of only 3,000,000,000 bushels, and this encouraged some buying.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Sept. 4 -- Indonesia's shaky economic position will present the new Cabinet of Dr. Ali Sastroamidjojo with one of its most serious problems. Observers here are watching to see how a Government susceptible to internal rifts and pressures from Leftists and Radical Nationalists will handle the situation.

The announcement that the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum will shortly open a major retrospective exhibition of work by Frank Lloyd Wright in a pavilion he himself has especially designed focuses attention again on the controversy between Mr. Wright and the New York Bureau of Standards and Appeals.

In a recent news broadcast on the North American Service of Radio Moscow the news commentator spoke of the high production levels of three women coal miners in the Ukraine, and the visit of a Japanese scientist who said American "propaganda" had led him to believe that Russia was becoming a "vast armed camp."

CHICAGO, Sept. 4 -- An intensification of efforts to safeguard the civil right of the country's citizens as guaranteed by the Constitution and protected by Federal laws was pledged here today by Arthur B. Caldwell, chief of the Civil Rights Section of the Justice Department.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 4 (AP) -- The Browns pounded across ten runs in the fifth inning, four of them on Vic Wertz' eighteenth homer of the year, for a 14-6 victory over the Tigers tonight.

BONN, Germany, Sept. 4 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer ended his general election campaign tonight in Essen, capital of the Ruhr, where 30,000 persons gave him the greatest ovation of his career for his defense of West European unity and a free market economy as opposed to the Social Democratic platform of Germany first and a new economic deal.

Michael J. Quill, president of the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., yesterday called the Transit Authority's plan to add an eleventh car to trains on the Flushing I.R.T. line a violation of the agreement between the union and the authority.
MILWAUKEE, Sept. 4 (UP) -- Stan Musial slammed his twenty-third home run of the year with two on base tonight to give the Cardinals a 4-to-2 victory over the Braves.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 (AP) -The Federal Power Commission today refused to reconsider its order granting the New York State Power Authority license to construct the United States portion of a huge international hydroelectric project on the St. Lawrence river.

FLEMINGTON, N. J., Sept. 4 -- Twenty-three expressive words in an advertisement seeking a small furnished apartment placed in the classified section of a local weekly newspaper today gained a house on a Hunterdon County estate for an imaginative young interne and his bride-to-be.

The State Harness Racing Commission moved officially yesterday to open an inquiry into the affairs of the Yonkers Raceway, employer of several persons -- two of them former convicts -- who have become key figures in the police investigation of the murder of Thomas E. Lewis.

MOSCOW, Saturday, Sept. 5 -- The Soviet Government attacked Chancellor Konrad Adenauer's declaration regarding possible negotiations on the German question as "primarily a pre-election maneuver," according to a special statement by Tass, Soviet news agency, published by all Soviet newspapers today.
PANMUNJOM, Korea, Sept. 4 (UP) -- Following is an Army stenographic transcript of Maj. Gen. William F. Dean's press interview at Freedom Village today:

WESTBURY, L. I., Sept. 4 -Pronto Don, the world's leading money-winning trotter, created a new world record for a mile and a sixteenth by taking the feature Tennessee $7,500 free-for-all trot at the Roosevelt Raceway tonight.

President Eisenhower's order abolishing the Psychological Strategy Board and instituting a new Operations Coordinating Board amounts, in effect, to the installation of new organizational leadership and presumably a new philosophy for United States efforts in the cold war.

CHICAGO, Sept 4 -- Judge Rudolph Desort of the Cook County Superior Court today denied the claim of Mrs. Syma Busiel Harris, 62 years old, that she and her late brother, Alfred Busiel, cosmetics manufacturer, made an agreement under which the survivor would inherit his company, Lady Esther, Ltd.

A 30-year-old Long Island woman, fleeing by station wagon and then by foot, led a traffic patrolman, a taxi driver and another motorist last night in an hour-long chase that began at 125th Street and ended near Columbus Circle.

Promotions for returned prisoners of war, elimination of temporary advancements of petty officers and improvement of housing facilities were cited yesterday by Vice Admiral James L. Holloway Jr., Navy Chief of Personnel, as important factors in maintaining the morale of Navy men.

Max J. Filler and Robert Corinthal, executives of the Terminal Radio Corporation, have purchased houses in the Stratton Heights development of Ben Okun Associates at Baraud Road and Puritan Drive in the Wilmot section of New Rochelle, N. Y.

YONGDUNGPO, Korea, Sept. 4 -- With tears in his eyes, President Syngman Rhee presented South Korea's highest military decoration to Maj. Gen. William F. Dean today for his "outstanding contribution to the survival of the Korean nation" and for "conspicuous gallantry and intrepidity."

Commodity prices were generally lower yesterday on the New York exchanges. Volume continued light under evening-up prior to the extended week-end. Metals however were active with zinc registering the best volume since May 27 and copper since July 24. The close showed zinc, copper, coffee, sugar, cocoa, wool and lead lower; cottonseed oil, soybean oil, rubber and tin higher, and hides and potatoes mixed.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 -- Washington was feeling the adverse reaction today -- both from diplomatic officials here and foreign capitals -- to a series of statements by John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State.

A special tax to pay Brazilian longshore personnel for occasions when they were ordered to stand by for work more than three years ago will be levied on all ship-borne cargoes entering or leaving that country for nine months after Sept. 15.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 (AP) -- The Justice Department announced today its thirtieth seizure in the program to recover former surplus Government vessels alleged to have passed illegally to alien control.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Sept. 4 -- Gen. James A. Van Fleet and five other members of a special mission of the American - Korean Foundation that has surveyed reconstruction needs in Korea arrived here today on their way back from the Far East to confer with Turkish authorities.
CHAMPAIGN, Ill., Sept. 4 (UP) -- A professor of architecture said today that his plan to put "domes" over cities would have kept temperatures at a constant 75 degrees during the heat wave.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Sept. 4 -- The expected reduction in the United States grant from $67,500,000 to $55,000,000 to divert grant-in-aid funds to Iran will not result in the curtailment of food or raw materials imports, Peretz Bernstein, Minister of Commerce, said today.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Sept. 4 -- A major political controversy on Danish defense appropriations has broken out here following a decision of the Labor members of the Parliamentary Finance Committee to defer consideration of $11,600,000 in defense grants until after the general elections later this month "when the political atmosphere has cleared."

WOODSTOCK, Ill., Sept. 4 -- Although six Roman Catholic nuns who formerly taught at the elementary school in near-by Johnsburg, have been dismissed as defendants, a Lutheran mother's suit will be continued against four public school officials.
Mid-Manhattan Court reverberated to an assortment of noises yesterday afternoon as an irate apartment dweller presented a tape recording of noises he charged were made by his upstairs neighbors.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Sept. 4 -- Gen. James A. Van Fleet and five other members of a special mission of the American - Korean Foundation that has surveyed reconstruction needs in Korea arrived here today on their way back from the Far East to confer with Turkish authorities.
CHAMPAIGN, Ill., Sept. 4 (UP) -- A professor of architecture said today that his plan to put "domes" over cities would have kept temperatures at a constant 75 degrees during the heat wave.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Sept. 4 -- The expected reduction in the United States grant from $67,500,000 to $55,000,000 to divert grant-in-aid funds to Iran will not result in the curtailment of food or raw materials imports, Peretz Bernstein, Minister of Commerce, said today.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Sept. 4 -- A major political controversy on Danish defense appropriations has broken out here following a decision of the Labor members of the Parliamentary Finance Committee to defer consideration of $11,600,000 in defense grants until after the general elections later this month "when the political atmosphere has cleared."

WOODSTOCK, Ill., Sept. 4 -- Although six Roman Catholic nuns who formerly taught at the elementary school in near-by Johnsburg, have been dismissed as defendants, a Lutheran mother's suit will be continued against four public school officials.

Permit me to cut in belatedly on the argument over whether it is the critic or the audience that makes or breaks a play. Certainly a play cannot succeed without a favorable audience response, but how many people, intending to go to the theatre, do so blindly?

SIX members of the Conference of Tour Operators, banding together to drum up business for the relatively slack off-season, have announced a list of seven conducted tours to Europe and the Mediterranean. The C. T. O. members are "wholesalers" who set up itineraries and purchase space in blocs, retailing their tours through travel agents at the customer level.
Trade melted away in the department stores under the soggy heat. Estimates of the week's decline in trade varied widely, with the average put at about 20 per cent.
To this tiny peninsula of the free world, jutting into the vast sea of Chinese communism, have come more than a million refugees since 1949.
MOSCOW, Sunday, Sept. 6 -- The Government newspaper Izvestia charged today that John Foster Dulles, United States Secretary of State, was trying to wreck the United Nations.
TOKYO, Sunday, Sept. 6 -- The United Nations and Communist armies completed today Operation Big Switch, the exchange of prisoners of the Korean war desiring to return home.

HACKENSACK, N. J., Sept. 5 -of the forty-seven competitors in the open championship tournament sponsored by the New Jersey State Chess Federation at the Northern Valley Chess Club, eight are tied with scores of 2 -- 0.

IN 1935 the American Rose Society put into words a cherished dream: "To realize the vision of a vast garden devoted to the display, study and culture of roses in all their forms. * * *" This Saturday at 3 P.M. in Columbus, Ohio, the dream will assume reality when an ultra-modern building and seven-acre rose garden are dedicated by the citizens of Columbus and members of the society.

Captive peoples may seek either revolt or reform. Our moral commitment to aid them by peaceful means exclusively makes successful revolt improbable. If Eric Hoffer in "Why Captive Peoples Revolt" (Aug. 23) is correct in holding that there is one thing a Communist regime cannot do without risk "and that is to relent and reform," then it is in our interest to minimize that risk.

THE three major airports in the New York metropolitan area will be equipped in October with two low-approach "weather observers" which are being tested purposely under the worst possible flying conditions at MacArthur Field, Sayville, L. I., by the Sperry Gyroscope Company's instrument pilots.

THE French are odd people: they demand reforms without putting up the means of effecting them; they go on strike and then groan about the consequences; they call for economies on the condition that they are not the victims, and they vote taxes only on the condition that they need not pay them.

Six months ago this week-end the world learned that Joseph Stalin had died and a new Government had been formed. In the perspective of our present knowledge, it seems likely that this most tumultuous period since has fallen into three segments. There was an initial period of confusion at the top in which Premier Malenkov sought to seize all of Stalin's old power.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 5 -- The contract negotiated this week between the Sailors Union of the Pacific, A. F. L., and the Pacific Maritime Association, representing the shipowners, was assertedly just as pleasing to J. Paul St. Sure, president of the association, as it was to Harry Lundeberg, the union's secretary-treasurer.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 (AP) -- Rain washed out the third round of the National Celebrities open golf tournament today, canceling a sizzling 64 by Doug Ford of Harrison, N. Y., and an indeterminate round by Vice President Nixon.
William Talbert of New York is the winner of the William Johnston Trophy for 1953. The presentation was made yesterday in the Stadium of the West Side Tennis Club, Forest Hills, Queens.

Max Hirsch, trainer of three Kentucky Derby winners, has another stakes' winner in his barn. Yesterday at Aqueduct the Hirschtrained Level Lea, flying the royal blue and yellow silks of John S. Phipps, did a front-running job in the $28,100 Discovery Handicap and scored with two and a half lengths to spare in the mile-and-afurlong event.

GLEN COVE, L. I., Sept. 5 -- A jobless 19-year-old machinist entered a women's apparel shop here yesterday, stuck a pistol in a saleswoman's back, told her to "start screaming for your life," and then apparently lost his nerve and fled without taking any money.

WITH the announced intention of "coming to grips with the major problems which harass and bedevil the owners and operators of the nation's 43,000,000 passenger cars," the fifty-first annual meeting of the American Automobile Association will be held Wednesday, Thursday and Friday in Los Angeles.
The citation on the first Congressional Medal of Honor awarded in the Korean war read:

T. S. Eliot's new play "The Confidential Clerk," has opened at the Edinburgh Festival to admiring laughter, cheers and shouts of "Author!" But it has the critics arguing about its real, inner meaning. On the surface at light comedy about babies changed at birth and growing up to seek the identities of their fathers.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Sept. 5 -Without fanfare, and almost unheeded by the outside world, Turkey inaugurated this week what may prove to be a new era in the economic history of the 30-year-old republic. Two decisions of fundamental importance were taken after months and even years of improvisation and debate.

WEEK-END drivers who want to escape heavily traveled highways might well set their sights on western Massachusetts' Pioneer Valley. This area consists of a belt twenty to thirty miles wide on either side of the Connecticut River an extends north from Springfield up through Hamden, Hampshire and Franklin Counties to the Vermont-New Hampshire line.
SEOUL, Sept. 5 -- For more than a month now the guns have been silent in Korea, yet life in this country except for the front-line soldier remains relatively unchanged.

HAPPILY for the American theatre, your drama critic is a Shakespeare enthusiast; confusingly for his readers, he sometimes appears to lose track of his own enthusiasms. On Aug. 23 he laid down a law: "to see Shakespeare plain," he told us, "you have to see him on a platform stage."

DUBLIN, Belgium and Italy in 1906, are the scene of Kate O'Brien's new novel, and if we could only be assured of moving in the circle inhabited by her characters, I think we should all hasten back there. It is the upper bourgeoisie with whom this Irish-Catholic novelist is concerned, but an upper bourgeoisie allied with landed gentry, unprovincial and European-minded.

MIAMI, Fla., Sept. 5 (AP) -- Tom Gibson starred in both pitching and hitting roles tonight as he led Yakima, Wash., to a 4-1 victory over Winnetka, Ill., in the final of the America Legion junior baseball world series.

TORONTO, Sept. 5 -- Wes Santee, the crack miler from Lawrence, Kan., won the handicap eight-furlong race today in one of the open events held in conjunction with the interprovincial track and field championships at the Canadian National Exhibition.

AUTHOR of last year's "Who Walk in Darkness," Chandler Brossard has now written a second novel, "The Bold Saboteurs." It is a bizarre story best read on a bed of nails, while smoking hashish rather than in a hammock.

THE war years -- the wasted years, you say. I wonder. By the grace of God a lot of people matured during that time. It separated the men from the boys. Those who experienced it from the fringe of effort, can they possibly imagine how it was to be caught up in the vortex and to have one's sense of values and feeling for life change out of recognition?

MARION, Mass., Sept. 5 -- The Walker Cup remained in the possession of the United States as the amateur golfing team representing this country won the two-day international series with the British, 9 to 3.
The Association of the Bar of the City of New York made public yesterday the list of committees appointed by Bethuel M. Webster, president, for 1953-54.

WE enjoyed Dortia Lamont's article, "By Car Around the Horn," in the Aug. 23 issue. It was interesting to my wife and me because we saw the Lamonts in front of the American Embassy in San Jose, Costa Rica.

TEHERAN, Iran, Sept. 5 -- The Iranian Premier, Gen. Fazlollah Zahedi, thanked President Eisenhower today for the speed with which the United States had granted $45,000,000 in emergency aid to help this nation surmount its current financial crisis.

NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 5 -- The debate in the Indian Parliament yesterday on this country's immense and growing unemployment problem incidentally brought out factors that have contributed to the discouragement of United States private investment here despite the Government's assertion that foreign capital, particularly from the United States, is welcome.

A modern Rip Van Winkle who plans on seeing his first college football game in twenty years this fall shouldn't be taken in by all the talk about a "brand new" game. He'll discover it's basically the same sport he watched in the early Thirties with a few new twists.

HEROICS went out of polar explorations in 1937 when Ivan Papanin, leader of a Soviet scientific party camped at the North Pole, listed caviar and chicken among the expedition's rations. Obviously, air mattresses could not be far behind.

DAYTON, Ohio, Sept. 5 -- Maj. William T. Whisner Jr., an Air Force ace in two wars, won the 1,900-mile Bendix Trophy Race in record time today at an average of 603 miles an hour, beating his closest rival by seconds.
Prof. D. W. Brogan's article, "The 'Great Revolution' Lives On in France" (Aug. 23) was very revealing.

STE. ANNE DE BELLEVUE, Quebec, Sept. 5 -- Studies of the chemical configuration of drugs that block and drugs that stimulate nerve transmission are providing new information about the nature of the nervous impulse, a subject that puzzled scientists for many years. This was reported here today at a day-long symposium of the international meeting of pharmacologists.

PEEKSKILL, N. Y., Sept. 5 -- Two country fairs will be held in Northern Westchester this month. The Westchester County Fair will open at Indian Point Park in Cortlandt tomorrow and continue through Saturday. The Yorktown Grange Fair will open at the school grounds in Yorktown Heights on Sept. 17 for a three-day run.

HAVING already considered Doris Humphrey's new "Ruins and Visions," which grows in depth and dimensions as it lingers persuasively in one's memory, it is now time to focus briefly on the other works which had their first presentations at the recent American Dance Festival in New London.
MILWAUKEE, Sept. 5 -- The Cardinals came from behind today to beat the Braves, 7 to 5, and spoil Warren Spahn's bid for his twentieth victory of the season.
Radio's appeal is, primarily, to the auditory sense. That being the case, one wonders why good talk as exemplified by the spoken essay is such a rarity over the air.

THREE of television's older drama series ended their summer vacations last week and returned for a new season. Among the premieres, which included the Robert Montgomery show, "Circle Theatre" and "Fireside Theatre," all on the N. B. C. network, a viewer could find a mingling of satisfaction and disappointment.

INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 5 -- Attorney General Herbert Brownell Jr. disclosed today that the Justice Department, with a view to prosecution, was studying the problem of witnesses appearing before Federal grand juries and Congressional investigating committees who refuse to answer questions about Communist affiliation.

FEW story-tellers can boast faithful an audience as that which listens to TV's "Miss Frances" of Ding Dong School. A Chicago educator with a currently estimated small fry audience of 3,000,000, Miss Frances Dr. Frances Horwich) plays at the nursery school level, uses inexpensive, familiar toys and equipment, and tells stories skillfully pitched to evoke participation by the listener.

TWENTY miles south of this old frontier post, on the buttes that rise above the Belly River, the Bloods of the Blackfoot Confederacy have assembled for their annual sun-dance. Their tepees and tents form a great circle in the center of which stands the framework for the sun lodge.

THE Sadler's Wells Ballet Company, of the Royal Opera House Covent Garden, is starting its third tour of the United States next Sunday at the Metropolitan Opera House, bringing with it Margot Fonteyn, who is its star attraction and probably, all things considered, the greatest living dancer in the world today We are proud of her in England and miss her while she is away
MUNSAN, Korea, Sunday, Sept. 6 (AP) -- Following is the official list of American prisoners of war returned today at Panmunjom:

STAMFORD, Conn., Sept. 5 -- Walter H. Wheeler Jr.'s 71-foot yawl, Cotton Blossom IV, and DeCoursey Fales' schooner, Nina, dueled to the finish of the Stamford Yacht Club's nineteenth Vineyard race tonight as Cotton Blossom established an elapsed-time record for the 234-mile run, bettering the previous mark by 1 minute 3 seconds.

If, as is often mistakenly presumed, Democratic district leaders could "deliver" the party vote within their domains to any candidate of their choice, Mayor Impellitteri would be a sure winner in his Sept. 15 primary contest with Borough President Robert F. Wagner Jr. of Manhattan for the Democratic nomination for Mayor of New York.
RADIO and television networks and independents are to be congratulated on the fine work they are doing in presenting candidates and their ideas in New York City's coming political hassel.

DEL MAR, Calif., Sept. 5 (UP) -The Del Mar Board of Stewards today ruled that Frosty Dawn was ineligible for the Del Mar Debutante Stakes which it won last week and awarded its first place money of $20,425 to Lady Cover Up, the second place finisher.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Sept. 5(UP) --Sergeants and generals joined today in tribute to Gen. Jonathan IV[. Winwright, hero of Corregidor, at a simple funeral service at Fort Sam Houston, where he began his military career fifty-one years ago.

FREEDOM VILLAGE, Korea, Sept. 5 -- American prisoners of war returned by the Communists today included airmen who, in the face of torture and what seemed certain death, refused to sign "confessions" that they had taken part in biological warfare.

THE display of fall asters might well be called a dress rehearsal for autumn, since their show begins well before the real performance is scheduled. Hardy perennial asters, also known as michaelmas daisies, are fine for massed color in the garden from late August until frost.

In a tense atmosphere created by an invasion of Communist "goon squads" from the East and the mobilization of all West German forces of law and order to combat them, the 33,000,000 voters of the Federal Republic go to the polls today in one of the most crucial elections Europe has witnessed since the end of the war.
Until this year the chief claim to fame of the National Homefurnishings Show was that it was the only one of its kind -- not a trade affair but a home furnishings show for the consumer.

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, Sept. 5 -- The council of the International Society for the Welfare of Cripples, meeting here, has authorized the establishment of a world committee for the education of crippled children and adults.
DEL MAR, Calif., Sept. 5 (AP) -Unbeaten in three previous starts, Double Speed lived up to his name today to win the $47,600 Del Mar Futurity by three lengths.
The body of a 12-year-old girl who had been strangled was found yesterday morning in the high weeds of a marshy section of Howard Beach, Queens, by two junk men.
Thirty-seven visiting firemen from Cambridge, Md., on a weekend package tour of New York, were properly overwhelmed yesterday by the first half of the wonders on the schedule.

Problems of foreign investment, liberal trade and currency convertibility are ripe for decision, providing interested nations treat them with the emphasis they have given political and military cooperation. This was the prime point made last week by Warren Lee Pierson, chairman of the United States Council of the International Chamber of Commerce.

Speed boat daredevils who have been practicing all summer revving up to the last notch on their throttles now approach the zenith of the season. When September rolls around all the preliminaries have ended and the air is cleared to make top performances, whether of super-powered extensive toys called inboards or the more modest outboard hydroplanes and outboard stock creations.

WORKSHOPS in photography by Berenice Abbott, Lisette Model and Alexey Brodovitch are scheduled for the fall term starting Sept. 23 at the New School for Social Research, 66 West Twelfth Street. Miss Abbott will teach a workshop in fundamentals, meeting 6 to 8 P. M. Mondays for fifteen weeks; an advanced class in specialized photographic problems 6 to 8 P. M.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Sept 5 (AP) -- A 3-over-par 76 put Mrs. Marjorie Lindsay McMillen of Decatur, Ill., ahead of a rain-swept field in the first round of the Mason-Dixon women's amateur invitation golf tournament today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 -- The Yankees' final drive to their fifth straight pennant struck a slight snag tonight when rain washed out the opener of their two-game series with the Senators. The postponement will be played off as part of a double-header tomorrow afternoon, when the Bombers make their farewell appearance of the season in the capital.

AFTER experiencing the frustrations of a Free India in its hopes to lead an Asiatic fight against "misrule, oppression and poverty," Raja Hutheesing, prominent Bombay journalist and brother-in-law of Nehru, made two trips to China to see if the Sino-Communists had found the magic answer for Asia.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Sept. 5 (AP) -- French military negotiators agreed today to return to the command of the Royal Cambodian Army five battalions of Cambodian soldiers who had been under French Union command in the war against the Communist-led Vietminh rebels.

The present farm program, with its key provision of 90 per cent price supports for basic commodities, is scheduled to expire at the end of next year. Since the Administration is regarded as favoring a more flexible system of supports, the farm problem is certain to be among those most spiritedly debated in the election campaign of 1954.

CLIFTON, N. J., Sept. 5 (AP) -A ten-minute baby tornado ripped up trees, knocked down garages and injured two persons slightly today as it skittishly played hopskip and jump through Clifton, Paterson and Upper Montclair.

CAZENOVIA, N. Y., Sept. 5 -With two rounds to go in the annual tournament for the championship of the New York State Chess Association, Hans Berliner of Washington, with seven straight victories, needed only half a point to clinch the title after defeating Jack W. Collins of Brooklyn, last year's winner, in thirty-six moves today.
CLEVELAND, Sept. 5 -- The need for sleep can cause drivers to see animals or other objects on the road "that aren't there," resulting sometimes in accidents, according to a Harvard psychologist.

NEWARK, Sept. 5 -- The effects of the drought in New Jersey were reflected today at the opening of the two-day dahlia show, arranged by the Dahlia Society of New Jersey and the Essex County Park Commission.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 5 -Delegates from thirty-six states began arriving today for the fortythird annual conference of the National Urban League, a voluntary service agency that seeks to promote equal economic opportunities.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 5 -- Plans for aiding the maternal and child welfare services of fourteen Asian countries will be put before the executive board of the United Nations International Children's Emergency Fund at its semi-annual meeting beginning Tuesday.

THE history of the mythical Scotch village, "Brigadoon," after materializing in a Broadway stage mist for over two years, soon will repeat itself on the Metro sound stage, according to director Vincente Minnelli, who, accompanied by his producer, Arthur Freed, spent a busy week testing local talent and conferring with their lyricistscenarist, Allen Jay Lerner.

A WRITER R who is deeply concerned with the thornier problems of teen-agers, Henry Gregor Felsen follows up his "Hot Rod" published three years ago with another story of the young buckos of the road. Like the earlier story this is almost as much tract as fiction.
SYRACUSE, N. Y., Sept. 5 (AP) -- An estimated 35,000 persons braved heavy rain that washed out parts of the first day program at the New York State Fair today.

DU QUOIN, Ill., Sept. 5 (AP) -Mike Nazaruk, North Bellmore, L. I., nursing a badly worn tire and almost out of fuel, won the A. A. A. 100-mile national championship midget auto race at the Du Quoin state fair today, setting a new track record.

WHEN a writer, and especially a British writer, is sent on a mission which he thinks he ought to undertake, but does not really wish to, there is always one consolation: he can come back and write about it. Eric Linklater, who was in Sweden on a vacation in 1951 when his government asked him to go to Korea and other places, found profit in the interruption.

THE unspoiled, naive, barefooted American farm boy with freckles, a snub nose and native shrewdness is a vanishing breed. But you still can find him in remote sections. Meeting him -- if it happened that you spent your youth in a small town -- is like meeting yourself coming around a corner.

Two group exhibitions, each containing some excellent things anticipate the opening of the new season. The paintings at Kraushaar's go back a number of decades to include a decisively designed cubist still-life by Preston Dickinson and an appealing portrait by Maurice Prendergast.

GREEN BAY, Wis., Sept. 5 (UP) -- Coach Curly Lambeau's Washington Redskins beat the Green Bay Packers tonight, 13 to 6, to give Lambeau his first victory over the Packers since he left them in 1950 after thirty years as Packer coach.

THE blossoms of the annual vine, moonflower, which begin to appear in early August, are a late-summer's conversation piece. For the fragrant, chalk white flowers open only in the twilight hours, long after the morning glory has called it a day.

The rapid-fire succession of events of the last few days highlights in a dramatic way the necessity of deep study, reorientation and the possible evolvement of an entirely new approach to foreign policy by our country.

THE pink and black and white jacket of Peter Towry's novel describes his story more vividly than words. The pen and ink sketch of boudoir chair, frothy negligee and lone silk stocking imply all the naughtiness and insouciance with which the novel is filled.

September 6 marks the birthday of a gallant Frenchman, Jean Paul Yves Roch Gilbert Motier, the Marquis de Lafayette, who was born in the Castle of Chavagnal in the Department of Haute-Loire on that day in the year 1757.

HERE is an unusual novel, violent and beautiful. The Rocky Mountain West during the transition period from the time of the mountain man to that of the settler is depicted with profound comprehension. One must go back to A. B. Guthrie, who caught the popular attention with his "The Big Sky" and "The Way West," for comparable skills.

What is described as the smallest fifty-horsepower steam boiler ever manufactured, designed primarily for metropolitan areas where floor space is limited, is being produced by the Cyclotherm division of United States Radiator Corporation, Oswego, N. Y.

DENVER, Sept. 5 -- President Eisenhower has drafted a personal message to Indian tribes across the United States assuring them that their "thoughts, needs and aspirations" would be considered in formulating policies and programs affecting them.

OKROGLICA, Yugoslavia, Sept. 5 -- In an atmosphere suggestive of impending action, tens of thousands of spirited partisan veterans, their families and politically led workers and peasants poured into the huge encampment here near the Italian border tonight.

THE series of Sibelius symphonies that Mercury started several months ago continues with Nos. 5 and 6. By now all the seven symphonies are available, played by the Stockholm Radio Symphony under the direction of Sixten Ehrling.

THE many variations in traffic regulations from state to state have become a year-round problem for the driving public, which has discarded the notion that Labor Day marks the end of the vacation season. With the trend toward off-season holidays and with winter motor trips to warmer climates, the interstate driver has become something more than a summertime phenomenon.
Synagogues throughout the world will herald at sundown on Wednesday the advent of Rosh ha-Shanah, the Jewish New Year 5714.

Facsimile, one of the newest entrants into the field of electronic communication, is being employed by one of the nation's major utilities to work out its daily electric generating schedule with greater accuracy than ever before and with a saving up to five skilled man-hours a day.

DETROIT, Sept. 5 (AP) -- There may be a slowing down of auto output and sales before the year-end but most industry leaders insist 1953 will be the second biggest year in automobile history. Nearly 4 1/2 million passenger cars already have been built this year.

The heat was on in Wall Street in more ways than one last week. As the thermometer rose, prices dropped. And, as usual, when there is pressure on the market, efforts were made to determine the cause of the selling. One reason given was Defense Mobilizer Arthur E. Flemming's report that the majority of 233 defense production goals have been met.

THIS magisterial volume completes the most important and scholarly work in diplomatic history that has appeared in the last quarter-century -since the epoch-marking contributions of Sidney B. Fay and Bernadotte Schmitt on the origins of World War I.

LONDON, Sept. 5 -- The British Government warmly endorsed today the action of President Eisenhower in extending emergency aid to Iran. A Foreign Office statement, saying "Her Majesty's Government are very glad to know" of the decision, added that Britain had been consulted during the planning of the move and had approved it.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Sept. 5 (AP) -- Football coaches in the East will be honor bound to abide by the new rule that limits substitutions and does away with the platoon system.
The recent Soviet detonation of a thermonuclear, or hydrogen, device and the continuing series of atomic tests in Russia open a new chapter in the accelerating race for atomic armaments.

LABOR DAY customarily marks a turning point for business men. It is preceded by an upturn in store volume; people stock up on food and drink for the long week-end and go a little gay in the last summer fling at the apparel and accessories shelves.

PARIS, Sept. 5 -- The Western defense coalition was rather painfully reminded during the past week that the political irritation accumulating around the Adriatic seaport of Trieste could very well develop into a dangerous cancer.

Last week was the fourth of President Eisenhower's vacation. The first three days he spent at Byer's Peak Ranch near Fraser, 8,750 feet up in the Rockies. Then he returned to Denver. Though he found time for rest and sport, the affairs of state began to press more heavily upon him.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 (UP) -- Justice Department officials said today they believed their new "get tough" policy toward income tax dodgers would result in stiffer jail sentences and also discourage would-be evaders.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 5 -- Leaving aside Andrei Y. Vishinsky, who is keeping his own counsel at the Soviet summer headquarters on Long Island, a delegate has yet to be found who believes that it will be possible to get an agreement on Korea -- or anything else -- at the proposed Far Eastern political conference.

LONDON, Sept. 5 -- Gen Sir Brian Robertson, Britain's princpal negotiator with the Egyptians over the future of the Suez military base, arrived here today by plane from Cairo. Officials here promptly did all they could to discourage speculation that his visit here was related to the Suez talks that have been going on informally for almost a month or that it marked any particular climax in the negotiations.
MAYS LANDING, N. J., Sept. 5 -- Saddle Tramp caused a lot of racing fans to stare in complete disbelief at the finish of the $23,850 Atlantic City Turf Handicap today.

BONN, Germany, Sept. 5 -- The West German political parties expect a record vote in tomorrow's general election, which has assumed the character of a national referendum for or against Chancellor Konrad Adenauer and his policy of integrating Germany into a Western European political economic and defense community.
LAS VEGAS, Nev., Sept. 5 (UP) -- A breakdown in betting facilities snarled the second day of racing at the new $6,000,000 Las Vegas race track.

Today throughout West Germany 25,000,000 voters will go to the polls in the second free vote in Germany since the Bonn Republic was set up under Western auspices in 1949, and the first held under German supervision since the Nazis broke the Weimar Republic two decades ago.

A MAN falls out of the wreck of a space ship in some unspecified time and place, and wonders whether his wife has survived. Then we move to Oak Ridge, where the Government is trying to find out something about the past of one Gilbert Nash.

In Beecher Township, a suburb of Flint, Mich., hundreds of families have struggled all through the summer to find the means of rebuilding their homes which were shattered by the tornado of June 8. Last week-end the problem was solved for most of them when a voluntary mobilization of manpower provided free labor for all who were ready to rebuild or repair their houses.

SUMMER vacations may be over for most people, but those who want to travel in imagination can obtain a good deal of help from phonograph records. Releases of folk material of the last few months allow the vicarious traveler to go from Armenia to Yugoslavia, taking the countries alphabetically, and from Bartok's arrangements of Hungarian folk songs to Australian tribesmen beating on sticks, taking the material in descending range of musical sophistication.

MAMARONECK, N. Y., Sept. 5 -- John J. (Don) McNamara kept the Corinthian Yacht Club of Marblehead Neck, Mass., the leading contender as eleven challengers continued their sailboat series for the Manhasset Bay Challenge Cup at the Orienta Yacht Club today by finishing the second of three scheduled races in second place.

Nickel stands out like a sore thumb in this post-Korean period when controls on strategic materials are being relaxed. It is the last major metal still under complete Government allocation and end-use restrictions. And a quiet but determined tug of war has been going on several weeks over the question of its decontrol.

UNDOUBTEDLY the best of the many biographies written by Andre Maurois, "Lelia" combines the narrative flow of his earlier books with the solidity of his recent volume on Proust. Such was the succession of events in the life of George Sand that even a bare and bumbling account of them could scarcely avoid achieving a certain interest.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 (AP) -- Bill Bossio of Pittsburgh outslugged Gene Smith of Washington tonight in a free-swinging televised 10-rounder. Bossio was a unanimous winner on the cards of the referee and both judges.

FOR an American an automobile is a natural habitation which he gets into or out of with no more ceremony than sitting down to a meal. An American learns to drive as naturally as he breathes. He likes speed, long white stretches of road, the wind in his face, preferring convertibles to closed cars, though he can rarely afford them.

THREE orchestras which have not visited New York in a number of years will be heard here during the forthcoming season. In order of appearance at Carnegie Hall, they will be the Detroit Symphony on Jan. 15, the Minneapolis Symphony on Feb. 23 and the Rochester Philharmonic on March 26.

The Port of New York Authority petitioned the Federal Maritime Board last week to reconsider a decision to allow five Swedish steamship lines to keep charging more for bringing wood pulp to Port Newark and New York than to other North Atlantic ports.
Strength in sterling, according to foreign exchange brokers, has been due principally to developments in "switch pounds," or security sterling.

PARIS, Sept. 5 -- To the United States the two most important overseas possessions of France are the quasi-independent states of Indo-China and the dependent Sultanate of Morocco. In both those areas French policy is undergoing a change, partly because of diplomatic prodding from Washington.

East of the Rockies millions were talking about the unprecedented duration of hot weather. Day after day the thermometer registered more than 90 degrees F. It was freak weather. We were immersed in a tremendous vortex of Warm air that moved clockwise from the Southwest, curved over the Great Lakes and swept on to the East.

ROME, Sept. 5 -- The atmosphere between Italy and the United States improved appreciably today after the long conversation that Ambassador Clare Boothe Luce had at her own request with Giuseppe Pella, Premier and Foreign Minister.
BONN, Germany, Sept. 5 -- A quiet campaign came to a quiet end tonight on the eve of Western Germany's second post-war general election.

TEHERAN, Sept. 5 -- What actually happened to Anatoli Lavrentiev, Soviet Ambassador to Iran, behind the walls of his summer residence ten miles from Teheran last Monday -- gunshot, poison or germ, an act of desperation or a diplomatic illness -- may never be known.

OYSTER BAY, L. I., Sept. 5 -- Wind up to thirty knots in puffs brought various troubles to several among sixty starters in the eighty-first fall regatta of the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club, part of the Long Island Y. R. A. series, today and victories the hard way to Anderson Hewitt's Atlantic Vixen, Billy Luders' International Surf and Warner Willcox's Class S Twister.

FAR HILLS, N. J., Sept. 5 -- An official of the local kennel club must have an "in" with the weather man. At least, that's what most exhibitors and spectators thought this afternoon as they saw the Giralda Farms' black and tan bloodhound, Champion Giralda's King Kole, capture top honors at the nineteenth annual Somerset Hills K. C. show on the fair grounds.

FREEDOM VILLAGE, Sunday, Sept. 6 (AP) -- Two Air Force colonels with brilliant records said today they had broken under relentless Communist mental torture and made false statements that they dropped germ bombs on North Korea.

Pension plans usually provide for an option to the employe to take a reduced annuity for himself in order to provide a survivorship annuity for his wife. In such cases the question has arisen as to whether the value of such surviving annuitant's interest is taxable as a part of the gross estate of the employe.

DENVER, Sept. 5 -- President Eisenhower granted $45,000,000 to Iran today in response to that country's urgent request for assistance. The amount is in addition to United States technical and military programs in operation there.

WINDOW boxes always look their best in August. As the days grow shorter and the nights cooler, flowering plants are covered with bloom and buds, and the leafy ones take on vivid tones. Most of these plants will be damaged somewhat by the first light frost, which can be expected possibly within the next four to six weeks.

SEPTEMBER is the peak month in local markets for fresh prunes, pears from near-by orchards, pomegranates, quinces. It is a time of abundance for honeydew melons, fresh figs, Florida avocados and plums. And this month starts off the big season for grapes, Western pears, apples, cranberries.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 -- A watershed protection program for which the Department of Agriculture has scheduled $28,000,000 may provide the answer to whether local communities are ready and willing to bear their share of responsibility in the conservation of natural resources.

During recent years increased emphasis has been given to citizenship training in the nation's public elementary and high schools. Various projects and studies, costing substantial sums of money, and mostly subsidized by foundations, have been undertaken to determine the best ways of developing sound citizenship programs for the 30,000,000 boys and girls attending the public schools.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 -- Department of Justice lawyers, after a seven-month study of a Senate report critical of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, were reported today to have found no basis for indicting the Wisconsin Republican for fraud or any election law violation.

WILDFOWLERS are hard to please, and in recent years the annual announcement of the waterfowl regulations was enough to stimulate a flurry of comment, most of it harshly critical, but the publication of the 1953 regulations apparently left most duck shooters with little basis for complaint.

A PHOTOGRAPH of the design of 3-cents blue and 5c crimson stamps which the United Nations will release on Dec. 10, the world organization's "Human Rights Day," was made available last week by Reidar Tvedt, head of the U.N. Postal Administration.

Few buyers were in the wholesale markets here last week. Resident buying offices report most ordering was by telephone, telegraph and mail. The excessive heat reduced the demand for coats and outerwear in women's and children's departments.

THIS year, more than ever before, the international spotlight foscused on the documentary and short film exhibition of the annual Vencie Festival, a comparatively new competitive category, exhibited prior to the world-wide feature entries.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 -- The Italian Embassy sought and received today assurances that United States policy pledging the return of Trieste to Italy had not changed.

WHEN "Your Show of Shows" emerges from summer mothballs over N. B. C.-TV on Saturday night at 9 o'clock, devotees of the hour-and-a-half-long variety program will see not just a neatly cleaned and pressed version of what they've been watching for the past four seasons, but a completely restyled, relocated and rebudgeted revue.

For all we know, a life and death struggle may be waged somewhere within our bodies between a virus and its antibodies. If the virus loses, illness ensues; if the antibodies win there is no sign of illness.

THE old razz-ma-taz of show business was very much in evidence last week at the Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer studio, where some 120 of the company's sales executives gathered for the first time in years, literally from the four corners of the earth.

Plans are being formulated at frequent meetings for the Nov. 16 performance of "Sabrina Fair," with Margaret Sullavan and Joseph Cotten, at the National Theatre, which has been taken over to raise funds for the West Side Day Nursery.

THE summer season at the renowned Woodstock art colony (in the heart of New York State but more baked than green this year) reaches its climax this week-end. The various galleries groan with pictures; sculpture; weavings; wicker baskets -- every conceivable artifact right down to home-made preserves.

Vassily Smyslov of Moscow broke a five-way tie in the world chess championship challengers' tournament at Neuhausen, Switzerland, and took the lead with a score of 3 -- 1 when he defeated Gideon Stahlberg of Sweden in thirtythree moves last night, according to a report from Zurich.

WESTON, Conn., Sept. 5 -Members of the Westport and Weston River Association, property owners along the Saugatuck River, had assurances today from officials of the Bridgeport Hydraulic Company that an adequate flow of water from the Saugatuck Reservoir in North Weston would continue after a contract between the company and the town of Weston ends on Oct. 1.
KARACHI, Pakistan, Sept. 5 -- Negotiations between India and Pakistan over the Kashmir dispute moved close to an open break tonight.

THERE is restlessness and division these days in the Far West -- those eleven states which sprawl between the lofty Continental Divide and rolling Pacific surf -- concerning two issues close to the political nerves of the wide open spaces: public lands and public power.
SAIGON, Vietnam, Sept. 5 -- The nationalists in the Indo-Chinese state of Vietnam announced today that they would meet tomorrow as a single bloc in a congress in Saigon. They accom- ...

EXCELLENT re-creations of aspects of the American past have been staples in the juvenile field for some time. This fall, the grown-ups will also be getting their share of enlightenment. On Oct. 8, Doubleday will launch an impressive publishing venture with Stewart H. Holbrook's "The Age of the Moguls," a story of the heyday of the tycoons, the first of a projected fifteen-volume series bearing the over-all title, "The Mainstream of America."

Rabbi Theodore L. Adams, president of the Rabbinical Council of America, in his first sermon as spiritual head of Congregation Ohab Zedek (Orthodox), 118 West Ninety-fifth Street, called yesterday morning on representatives of world democracies to unite "under God" for the betterment of mankind.

THE main events up to now of the 1953 Edinburgh Festival have been the first British stage performance of Stravinsky's opera, "The Rake's Progress," and a series of concerts designed to illustrate the history and development of the violin.

SANTA MONICA, Calif., Sept. 5 -- The Douglas Aircraft Company, which has produced the twin-engined transports known as DC-3's, CX-47's and R4D's that have been flown in almost every country in the world for fifteen years, delivered today the 400th plane in its series of four-engined DC-6's.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 5 (AP) -- The Browns' Dick Kokos broke up a brilliant pitching duel between Ralph Branca and Bob Turley tonight with a twelfth-inning home run into the right-field pavilion, enabling the Browns to gain a 1-0 triumph over the Tigers.
BALTIMORE, Sept. 5 (AP)-- Jim Tatum, head football coach at the University of Maryland, expects to be discharged from University Hospital within twenty-four hours," an aide said tonight.

THE author of this sparkling memoir of an eventful life was born into the turbulent, history-making group that made its habitat at Oyster Bay, and his childhood there was spent when the Oyster Bay Roosevelts were, as Frank Sullivan once observed, "in season."

WHEN "Oklahoma!" opened in Boston in March, 1943, under the title "Away We Go," there was at least one member of the cast who thought it was an exceptional production. Owen Martin, who doubled in the roles of Cord Elam and Ike Skidmore in the pre-Broadway tryouts, says: "Even then I thought we had something." He hardly anticipated, however, that he would still be playing in the musical bonanza ten-and-a-half years later.

CHORE FOR THE WEEK: Postpone planting of new perennials and the division and transplanting of established ones until there has been a good rain. For the rest of the summer and throughout the fall soak thoroughly, once during each week no rain falls, any perennials that were moved this summer and particularly shrubs set out this year.

A bomber like the Boeing B-17 cost the taxpayer about $660,000 during World War II. Today's bombers cost about $2,000,000 each. Yet, according to Admiral DeWitt C. Ramsey, U. S. N., Ret., president of the Aircraft Industries Association, one manufacturer saved the cost of eleven modern bombers, $22,000,000, from employes' suggestions alone.

PARIS, Sept. 5 -- The French Government attaches great importance to the prospective additional United States aid of $150,000,000 or more for the war in Indo-China in the coming year because of its economic effects in France.
BELLPORT, L. I., Sept. 5 -- Ralph Cameron, Larchmont skipper, won today's Star Class race sailed as part of the annual Labor Day week-end regatta of the Bellport Bay Yacht Club.
The stage was set yesterday at Forest Hills for a preview of the Davis Cup challenge round pairings envisioned for Australia in December.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 -- The Federal Government is firing employes these days and hiring very few. A Civil Service Commission report this week showed that 18,000 Federal workers were fired in the month of July, with 3,800 of the dismissals here in the capital.

ONE never knows what to expect from Arthur C. Clarke. Here is a saga of a world so vastly remote from the present that we may not comprehend the rudiments of its science. We cannot even guess at the powers that govern its wondrous machines, yet the masters of such tools are people, differing emotionally and spiritually from us, their forefathers only in their loss of drive.

Ripping into five pitchers for seventeen hits, the pennant-bound Dodgers handed the forlorn Giants a 16-7 lambasting before 23,636 jeering onlookers at the Polo Grounds yesterday. It was the Brooks' ninth straight victory over their interborough rivals and raised their league lead over the runner-up Braves to eleven games.

IF Humphrey Bogart had listened to his Hollywood friends when the technical "revolution" erupted last winter, he would have packed his bags and left Italy and "Beat the Devil" would not have been made. If, on a previous occasion, he had been influenced by the knowledge that practically every major studio had turned down C. S. Forester's improbable story of "The African Queen" he would not have won in 1951 the Academy's best-actor "Oscar."

Leaders of America's high schools have invited business and industry to cooperate with them to promote better understanding of this nation's free-enterprise economy among secondary school students, it was announced last week by Kenneth B. Willson, president of the National Better Business Bureau.

ATHENS, Sept. 5 -- An earthquake of sufficient violence to impair the Athens Observatory seismograph shook this city today, causing doors to open and close and objects to fall from shelves and tables.

LOS ANGELES -- Although September in the Southwest has its back-to-school and back-to-work connotations as elsewhere, climatically, recreationally and touristically it marks the beginning of the region's "second summer," with three months of weather just a little blander than the preceding season.

IF it is a legitimate objective of the historical novel to plunge the reader into a distant time and make him share its feelings and emotions, then "The Dark Island" by Henry Treece certainly deserves a high place in the crowded ranks of present-day historical fiction.

LAST week we reviewed the background of the Commission of Fine Art's report on government activities in art, the Commission's recommendations for a "status quo" position for itself and its recommendations concerning American art at home.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 (AP) -- Democratic leaders may try to stave off a showdown with southern dissenters by agreeing at a Chicago rally Sept. 14 and 15 to a re-examination of their party's national convention "loyalty oath."

Early Adriatic Questions The long arm of the Mediterranean known as the Adriatic Sea got a bad name early in history for its storm and its pirates. Phocaean Greeks first explored it and as early as 600 B. C. are believed to have reached its northern extremity at the peninsula which they called Istria, because they fancied that it was somehow related to the Danube, the Greek Ister.

NINETY years ago Lincoln read his Emancipation Proclamation. Rossini was living in Paris. Debussy was a year old. Berlioz was hard at work on his "Trojans." Offenbach was all the rage and Wagner was not all the rage among the conservative listeners of Europe.

THIS summer is one of change and challenge in Europe. Nowhere are the changes or challenges greater than in Germany, where nearly seventy million people are emerging from defeat and division to play again a decisive role in Continental affairs.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 (AP) -- No wonder single girls suspect there is a shortage of available young bachelors. It's true. The Census Bureau went into the problem today, analyzing last year's supply of "eligible" civilian males as against the number of young women of marrying age.
NAPLES, Sept. 5 -- Lieut. Comdr. Agostino Straulino of the Italian Navy won his second straight Star Class world racing championship today.
Here is the case history of a blob of Canadian cold air that, turning delinquent after crossing the border, achieved notoriety as the greatest heat wave that has ever broiled New York.

With the return of the one-platoon system, the Ivy Colleges, which refrained from spring practice, are accelerating their pre- season football training in an endeavor to field the strongest elevens possible by the time the 1953 campaign gets rolling in three weeks.

The eighth annual meeting of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development and the International Monetary Fund will be held in Washington, D. C., this week -- the first such assembly under a Republican Administration.

DOUGLAS, Isle of Man, Sept. 5 -- Most of the more than 900 delegates of Britain's 8,000,000 union members arrived here today for the annual Trades Union congress that determines officially the attitude of organized labor in this country toward political, economic and international questions.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 (AP) -Some liquor industry spokesmen joined voices today with temperance advocates in condemning new Army and Air Force regulations allowing alcoholic beverages to be sold to commissioned and non-commissioned officers on military posts.
TRENTON, Sept. 5 -- Bids totaling more than $5,000,000 for construction work on the new Garden State Parkway were received here yesterday by the New Jersey Authority.
