MISSOULA, Mont. -- Once more the cultural life and the outdoor life have been happily blended for a summer, to the distinct advantage of both. People have been learning to be writers, poets, playwrights, actors, ballerinas and even squaredancers here in the Northwest while at the same time enjoying a vigorous vacation in the open.

TODAY'S amateur is in a peculiar sort of dilemma: should he shoot pictures in black-and-white, in color or in stereo? The amateur moviemaker, who has more or less settled on color and for whom the influence of stereo is not yet comparable to its influence in the still field, has no such problems.

ONE factor contributing to the continued robust health of Dixieland jazz is the vast body of highly competent musicians -- as opposed to those who may be considered virtuosos -who have been attracted to this vein.

The Board of Elections urged Governor Dewey yesterday to reject a request for a special session of the Legislature to extend the voting period on Primary Day, Sept. 15, as "an unnecessary financial burden on the city."

LONDON, Sept. 5 (Reuters) -West Bromwich Albion continued its pace at the head of the first division in England soccer, defeating the Tottenham Hotspurs by 3 -- 0 today. The victory gave Albion a thrree - point margin over four teams on the eight - point mark -- Tottenham, Wolverhampton, Blackpool and Burnley.

Crashing seventeen hits, the Dodgers defeated the Giants, 16--7, yesterday for their ninth straight victory over the Polo Grounders. Roy Campanella walloped two home runs and Carl Furillo had four safeties in as many times at bat for the National League leaders.

After 25,000 miles before the mast, such shore installations as lawns, trees, fire hydrants, lampposts and long stretches of curb have lost their fascination for Skippy, 3-year-old cocker spaniel and unofficial mascot of the New York State University Maritime College training ship, Empire State.

Elizabeth Monroe in "Key Force in the Middle East -- The Mob" (Aug. 30) aptly pointed out the derivation of the word "mob" from the Latin for "a people on the move." Apart from riots there is another example of this definition -- panic in Eastern lands.

The end is not yet in sight for the rugged experience besetting the Public Housing Administration's effort to finance its multibillion-dollar program of subsidized low-rent housing through the public market.

As reported in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Sept. 1, Mrs. Oveta Culp Hobby, Cabinet Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, pointed to the financial burden of catastrophic illness as "one of the most pressing burdens on the average American family."
A new device to forestall unnecessary stresses and strains on ships caused by improper loading has been developed in Great Britain and placed on the American market by Bludworth Marine.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 -- Secretary of Labor Martin P. Durkin directed today a message of "fellowship" to workers in the free world and one of "hope and sympathy" to workers behind the Iron Curtain.

What is described by pipeline engineers and construction experts as the biggest and one of the most difficult feats in oil pipeline history is under way at St. Ignace, Mich., where the Straits of Mackinac separate Lake Huron from Lake Michigan.

GLEN COVE, L. I., Sept. 5 -Cyril Claude Andersen, a 36-yearold retired Army major, who was permanently crippled in combat in World War II, was a happy man today because he will not have to provide proof to the Government of his citizenship or face a threat of deportation.

MISS ANNA RUSSELL is a splendid blonde monolith from Canada with a face as flexible as a collapsible camp chair, a frame as awesome as half of the Two Grenadiers and a style not unlike, but considerably more informed than, that of the late Florence Foster Jenkins.

In his informative article, "Public Relations Along the Potomac" (Aug. 30), Marquis W. Childs says nothing about the relative inadequacy of the relationship of the Administration's head man with the press.

Recognizing the need for large American-flag heavy-lift ships, capable of handling railroad locomotives and other bulky items, the Navy's Military Sea Transportation Service has decided to go ahead with the conversion of two of its C-4 type cargo vessels.

THREE years ago Negley Farson, an American-born writer who knows his Africa, wrote a perceptive and vaticinatory report under the title "Last Chance in Africa," in which he sounded a clear warning that the sands of time were fast running out for the white man in Kenya.

OLD -- and top -- hands Pohl and Kornbluth have joined talents to predict a future grim enough to please the sourest of contemporary pessimists. Thinking with slide rule precision, these writers have projected a civilization built on the code of the huckster, where the account executive is king and his captive audience just that -- a mass of helpless, hapless serfs, living by the law of the singing commercial.

WHEN Harold Stassen hit upon intelligence tests a one way to help him decide which of the 1,500 members of his Foreign Operations staff to eliminate in the Government economy drive, he was neither inventing a new criterion for the desirability of employes nor segregating a small parcel of victims for a specialized form of punishment.

THE N. B. C. radio network plans to unveil a revamped and revitalized program structure during the week starting Sunday, Oct. 4, when it introduces no less than twentyeight new shows -- thirteen of them on Oct. 4 alone.

For years the astronomers of Greenwich Observatory have been finding it increasingly difficult to tell the time of day correctly, and all because London is smokier, foggier and dirtier than ever and because the lights o' London, about which Victorians wrote as we write about those of Main Street, produce a glare that suffuses the night sky.

OF THE country's great conservation organizations, the National Audubon Society has traditionally been one of the most conservative, cautious, and least given to excited cries of alarm. That is why the society's unusual action in denouncing the Department of the Interior's 1953 waterfowl-hunting regulations deserves special attention.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 5 (AP) -Risque Rouge defeated Combat Boots by a nose in a photo finish at Randall Park today to win the $30,000 added Buckeye Handicap. My Nell was third and Olympic View fourth over the muddy track.

The two-week heat wave, which melted one weather record after another in the city, finally was ended yesterday by afternoon showers and southeasterly winds from the ocean traveling at an average velocity of twenty-five miles an hour.

CHICAGO, Sept. 5 -- Under Secretary of State Walter Bedell Smith defended here tonight the conduct of American foreign policy and credited Secretary of State John Foster Dulles with "victories that cannot be advertised until long after the event."

A portable towboat, designed to work its way downstream by water and quickly return upstream for another job by rail, has begun the task of pushing newly-built Army craft from Leavenworth, Kan., to New Orlean.

A new method developed during recent years by the Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution has made it possible to measure continuously fluctuations in the Florida Current, an important branch of the Gulf Stream. The method based on a century old law of electromagnetic induction also has been used to measure ocean currents directly from a moving ship and the flow of tides in the open Atlantic Ocean.

NEWARK, Sept. 5 -- Three separate accidents involving sixteen automobiles and a bus and occurring within a space of 1,000 feet and fifteen to twenty seconds in time on the New Jersey Turnpike near here at 1:15 P. M. today injured more than a score of persons, four of them seriously.

ON Shikoku, smallest and most isolated of the Japanese home islands, lies the ancient province of Tosa. The Tosa men, lumberjacks and sailors from time immemorial, are brusque and aggressive by the polite Japanese standards, individualists, with an individualism that would prove excessive in the more crowded paddy lands.

" The Robe," the subject of Lloyd C. Douglas' best-selling novel of faith in early Christian days, will get a chance next week to perform one more miracle -- reversing the tide of entertainment dollars which has flowed toward television, leaving the movie makers and exhibitors alike foundering in a sea of red ink.

BACH: Six English Suites; Alexander Borovsky, pianist (Vox, three disks). Musical and sensitive performances, but not the most flexible of playing. Hard to recommend when more authoritative versions are available on the harpsichord.

BONN, Germany, Sept. 5 -- There will take place tomorrow in West Germany a general election that could fairly be described as one of the most important in Europe since the end of World War II and certainly the most important in Germany since 1933, when Hitler came to power.
TORONTO, Sept. 5 (Canadian Press) -- Samuel Zamudio, a 43year-old skier from Cuernavaca Morelos, Mexico, won the world water skiing championship for veterans today.

In an effort to shed light on the unsolved slaying nine days ago in the Bronx of Thomas E. Lewis, president of a building service union local, investigating officials will examine the local's books and financial records Tuesday, the day the union has promised to deliver them.
BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 5 (AP) -Argentina and Brazil announced last night they had settled a dispute over a coffee deal that caused strained relations between the two countries three months ago.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 (UP) -The Federal Trade Commission announced today that two publishing companies had agreed to specify both in advertising and on book covers when their pocket-sized reprints had been abridged or retitled.

HARBINGERS of the music season of 1953-54 are upon us. One of these is the announcement of the opening of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Society's 112th season, Oct. 8, in Carnegie Hall, under Dimitri Mitropoulos, with Hector Berlioz's "Harold in Italy" symphony as the main offering of the occasion.

WESTBURY, L. I., Sept. 5 -Steward Lad, with Jimmy Jordan in the sulky, captured the nominal feature of the nine-race card at Roosevelt Raceway tonight, pacing the Kentucky Mile in 2:04 2/5. The mile and a sixteenth race that followed was a more interesting event, as Willie S. won the Class A trot in 2:11 3/5.

A BRAZILIAN series for the sesquicentennial of the birth of the Duque de Caxias has reached New York Stamp Company. He was Luis Alves de Lima e Silva (1803-80), who commanded armies in wars against Argentina and Paraguay and was four times Prime Minister.
YONKERS, Sept. 5 -- A released prisoner of war from this area faces the heartbreaking news that both his wife and son died in the nearly three years he was in captivity.

In 1937, when gangsters ruled the A. F. L.'s Building Service Employes International Union, a 19-year-old elevator operator named Thomas E. Lewis took out a membership card in Local 32-E in the Bronx and set out to make himself a career as a labor leader. His union bosses were practiced labor racketeers.

DENVER, Colo., Sept. 5 -- The White House denied today as "completely untrue" a published report that said President Eisenhower was "gravely concerned" about a press conference statement by John Foster Dulles, the Secretary of State, on Thursday.

IN the Beaujolais district of France there is the small village of Saint Michel. About the village stretch the vineyards and, on up into the hills, the familiar white-washed houses. At Espagne, the larger of the surrounding farms, live the two outstanding families of the neighborhood: the Vermorrels, impractical, sensitive, warmhearted, and the Morins, practical, calculating, anxious to continue their position of respectable reliability.

Marymount College in New York City will institute new courses in journalism this semester to aid students to overcome the problem of employment saturation in the newspaper field. The new program will emphasize interdepartmental application of the course material and will guide students toward these career objectives: other phases of publishing, particularly trade journals and technical publications; business and technical vocations, and the non-vocational field of community life.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 5 (AP) -- Nancy Nieman, 22, of Detroit won the one and three-mile races in the girls' division of the national amateur bicycle championships that started today.

TRENTON, Sept. 5 -- The State House here, which has been relatively deserted for the last two months, the Legislature being in recess and many state officials on vacation, will be the scene next week of renewed activity.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 (UP) -- The Petroleum Administration for Defense has cautioned the oil industry that the pending revocation of a gasoline quality-control order does not mean the nation has an abundant supply of aviation gasoline.

CHICAGO, Sept. 5 -- Hasty Road, a sprinting son of Roman, made a clean sweep for Hasty House Farms of Chicago's juvenile stake races today with a going-away three-and-a-half-length victory in the $156,085 Washington Park futurity.

D. W. Brogan's stimulating article recalls to my mind the following observation of another keen student of French affairs: "I believe that when the humanist Socialists and the Christian partisans of truly social policies will not only have found a parliamentary modus vivendi but reached complete agreement as well, there will be few or no political problems left in France."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 -- Senator Styles Bridges disclosed today that an investigation into the results of government expenditures of some $4,000,000,000 for critical and strategic materials -- and with about $1,000,000,000 more available for further buying -- was probable.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 5 -- The White Sox and the Indians split a double-header tonight to remain tied for second place in the American League, ten and a half games behind the Yankees. Saul Rogovin hurled a four-hit shutout to beat the Tribe, 2 -- 0, in the opener and Bob Feller turned in a six-hitter for a 4-1 victory in the second game.

OF all the branches of the tree of life, that containing the insects is the most densely populated and is, to many students, the most interesting. Figures attempting to give an idea of the number of species are vast and vague -- and yet, for all their abundance, many of the commonest insects remain mysterious.

The cardinal flower, which blooms now in moist woodland pasture corners just across the stone wall from the early goldenrod, offers one of the most satisfying reds in the whole wildflower spectrum. The only one that can rival it in our area is the Oswego tea, the deep red variety of wild bergamot, now almost through blooming.

AS the year comes to its great dead-center of the rolling wheel, as the semi-tropic sumac dips its chevrons in the first blood of time, as even the hummingbird pauses his millimetric whirr (I saw one actually sit to drink on the rim of the birdbath) and the catbird goes hunting underleaf the arbor to speir if any grapes are yet softened for the beak, the garden-loafer sits in his deeply rounded canvas chair.

THE next world championship bridge match will be played in England; that was decided in Helsinki, Finland, last week when the English team won the championship of the European Bridge League in an eight-day tournament in which eleven European countries were represented.
CHICAGO, Sept. 5 (UP) -- Paul Minner went the distance, giving up eight hits to the Redlegs today, as his Cub team-mates got nine hits for a 5-to-4 victory before 10,801.

BURLINGTON, Vt., Sept. 5 -The trustees of the University of Vermont voted this afternoon to dismiss Dr. Alex B. Novikoff, a biochemist, on charges arising from his refusal to discuss his activities prior to joining the faculty in 1948.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Aug. 27 -- Prices in Australia today seem to be a bad dream to those who recall what they were before the war. The Australian pound is worth about a third of its prewar value and while national income is four to five times that of 19381939 the volume of goods on which it can be spent has probably not increased by much more than 50 per cent.
Final plans for the Conference on Moral Standards, marking the fiftieth anniversary of the incorporation of the Jewish Theological Seminary of America, 3080 Broadway, were announced yesterday.

DETROIT, Sept. 5 -- A whiteheat boat-racing town, if there ever was one, Detroit, which has had spectator throngs as large as 400,000 watching Gold Cup and Harmsworth classics, is on edge again this week-end.

TOKYO, Sunday, Sept. 6 -- Maj. Gen. William F. Dean, held in solitary confinement by the Communists for three years, announced today he would remain in Tokyo fifteen days under the care of an army specialist. He said he had a trace of amoebic dysentery.
Industrial television turned detective and solved a case by giving police an eyewitness view of thieves at work.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 5 -- The l4,000-ton aircraft carrier U. S. S. Belleau Wood was turned over to the French Navy today in a ceremony at the San Francisco Naval Shipyard.
CHICAGO, Sept. 5 (AP) -- The dream of Chicago as a great seaport has inspired its business men to campaign for a Congressional appropriation to improve "the sixteen sad miles of the Calumet-Sag."

A Brooklyn girl was disenchanted yesterday when the man in uniform she had met at a service men's canteen was held on charges of stealing her brother's watch, ring and $25 in cash and of illegally wearing a naval uniform.

Between 7,000 and 10,000 persons swarmed aboard the Royal Canadian Navy's aircraft carrier Magnificent and cruiser Quebec yesterday on the first of two visitors' days aboard the vessels docked at Pier 26, North River, at Beach Street.

A number of trade associations in the maritime industry are renewing efforts dropped several years ago to merge competitive groups into a single powerful organization, it became known over the week-end.
An Air Force lieutenant colonel came back again yesterday to his policeman's job in Brooklyn.

Samuel Reshevsky of New York, after winning his adjourned fourth-round game with Laszlo Szabo of Hungary, defeated Dr. Max Euwe of Amsterdam in the fifth round of the world chess championship challengers' tourney in Switzerland last night and tied for first place with Vassily Smyslov of Moscow, both with scores of 3 1/2-1 1/2, according to a report from Zurich.

SALT LAKE CITY, Sept. 6 -- An $8,000,000 Veterans Administration hospital, in which such varied items as a battered 1939 sedan, an Olympic-size indoor swimming pool, scale model electric trains and an old-fashioned, hand-cranked ice cream freezer are used for therapy, has "more than proved its usefulness" in its first year of operation, psychiatrists reported here today.
OYSTER BAY, L. I., Sept. 6 -Good News, Nereus and Sleipnir, as different as sailing craft can be, were winners today in races conducted by the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 (UP) -- Driving rain washed out the National Celebrities golf tournament today for the second successive day, leaving Gen. Omar N. Bradley and a score of other notables with nothing but a soaking for their efforts.
Business transacted in the foreign exchange market during the past week was only moderate as the British pound sterling turned easier and the Canadian dollar continued steady.

SLOATSBURG, N. Y., Sept. 6 -- Ground was broken today for the first home for the aged that will be built in this country by the Seventh - Day Adventist Church. It will be at Eagle Lake Park, a 460-acre woodland tract three miles west of here, purchased by the church in 1951.

FREEDOM VILLAGE, Korea, Sept. 6 -- Two colonels of the United States Air Force who returned today from Korean war prisons said they had tried to kill themselves rather than sign confessions that they had taken part in biological warfare.
PORTLAND, Ore., Sept. 6 -- A drive to change the name of this city to Multnomah has been started by a committee of "Multnomans" headed by Stewart H. Holbrook, author.

LONDON, Sept. 6 -- Although London stock markets remain fully aware that Wall Street has a way of registering in advance the future course of business in the United States, they continue to show strong resistance to the New York market's weakness and its noticeably feebler power of recovery.
CAIRO, Sept. 5 (AP) -- Egypt will seek a long-term loan from the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development to help finance her huge High Aswan Dam project.

A ring of four small-time burglar suspects, who were said to have entered 100 homes in Queens since May, was rounded up by detectives yesterday. The police said that total loot, taken mainly from the wallets of their victims, was $600.
A mansion of ninety-six rooms on a mountain forty miles from New York has been assuming increasing importance in the affairs of the nation.
BONN, Germany, Monday, Sept. 7 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer's sweeping victory in yesterday's general election established a trend toward a two-party system in Western Germany.
WIDEN, W. Va., Sept. 6 -- In the hills here sixty miles from Charleston, two titans of labor and capital are waging a stubborn battle.

TOKYO, Aug. 30 -- Many Japanese officials and Americans here have become increasingly concerned over the growth of anti-United States sentiment among the Japanese people. These observers fear that if this attitude continues to develop, it could endanger, if not destroy, the bases of friendship patiently established between the two countries in the years since World War II.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 6 -- Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer is exploring the possibility of producing a motion picture dealing with the experiences of American soldiers taken prisoner by the Communists during the Korean fighting. The studio started its spade work by assigning Allen Rivkin to cover the recent arrival in San Francisco of troops liberated under the armistice agreement.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 6 -- For the seventh successive week, hot weather and vacations have kept the steel industry from achieving its production schedules. Inability to hold to the scheduled rates has cost several hundred thousand tons of steel during this period.

LONDON, Sept. 6 -- In a sharp attack on Secretary of State Dulles, Woodrow Wyatt, a Labor party Member of Commons, declared tonight that never before had a man "spent so long in preparing himself to be Foreign Secretary and made such a fool of himself and his country when he finally got the job."

CHICAGO, Sept. 6 -- The record heat wave last week resulted for a time in active buying of both corn and soybean futures, but with the change to more moderate temperatures many longs unloaded these products. In the process of liquidation much of the early week gains were erased, and with the change to more normal weather there appeared little urge to press the buying.
Thirty-two members of the congregation of the Church of the Open Door, 209 Concord Street, Brooklyn, brought implements used in earning a living and had them blessed at the morning service yesterday.

BELLPORT, L. I., Sept. 6 -- E. W. (Skip) Etchells' Sharon from Larchmont gained the Star Class series lead today in the annual three-day regatta of the Bellport Bay Yacht Club, when she showed the way to a fleet of forty boats.

It's getting so that fans who turn out to see the Giants and the Dodgers are not certain whether it's for a ball game or a fight. At the Polo Grounds yesterday, the spectators were treated to both. The Dodgers won the game, 6 -- 3, but the jury is still deliberating over who won the fight between Leo Durocher and Carl Furillo, who wound up with a broken bone in his left hand.

For the first six months of this year advertising in four major media was a record $529,400,000, up $49,200,000 from the same period last year. The figures are contained in the semi-annual National Advertising Investments, issued by Publishers Information Bureau, Inc.

ZURICH, Sept. 6 -- All last week sperrmarks were in heavy demand because all reports from Germany predicted that Chancellor Konrad Adenauer, returned to power in the election, would make reestablishment of Germany's credit standing his first major aim to accomplish which no efforts would be spared to resume the transfer of the earnings of all foreign-owned German investments as soon as feasible.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 6 -- Eleven Korean students are due to arrive in this country this month to begin training under scholarships and fellowships awarded by the United Nations Korean Reconstruction Agency in connection with its program of agricultural rehabilitation in that country.

ITHACA, N. Y., Sept. 6 (AP) -- John P. Burton, chairman of the State Power Authority, said last night he believed that the action of the Federal Power Commission in denying petitions for a rehearing of its July 15 order indicated that it had issued the license for the St. Lawrence power project.

ROME, Sept. 6 -- The Italian Foreign Ministry made no official comment on the speech on the Trieste situation that Marshal Tito, the Yugoslav President, delivered at Okroglica today. Unofficially, however, more than one Foreign Ministry official lost no time making it clear that Italy rejected Marshal Tito's proposal to internationalize the city and port of Trieste and to cede the hinterland to Yugoslavia.

HACKENSACK, N. J., Sept. 6 -- Franklin S. Howard of East Orange, a former state champion; Adolph Stern of Asbury Park and O. Popovych of Newark tied for first place with scores of 3 1/2 -- 1/2 after four rounds of the New Jersey open tournament sponsored by the New Jersey Chess Federation at the Northern Valley Chess Club tonight.

OLD WESTBURY, L. I., Sept. 6 -- Two quick goals by Al Parsells and Mike Healy, three minutes before the end, enabled Long Island to clinch a 10-7 decision over Bostwick Field in the weekly high-goal game on Bostwick Field today.

A Protestant Episcopal clergyman proposed yesterday that religion and labor form a working alliance that, if carried forward to its logical conclusion, would constitute "an irresistible force for the building of a better America and a better world."
THOMPSON, Conn., Sept. 6 (AP) -- Phil Walters of Palm Beach, Fla., drove his Cunningham to victory today in the feature race of a national sports car program at the Thompson Raceway.
WASHINGTON, Sept 6 -- Farmers got 6 percent less for what they sold in the first eight months of this year than in the same period of 1952, the Agriculture Department reported today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 -- More married women than ever are working and there is a tendency for married women to return to work, or take jobs for the first time, after reaching middle age.
SEATTLE, Wash., Sept. 6 (UP) -- Witnesses said that the airliner's co-pilot, Dale Moore, had risked his own life to see that the passengers were safely evacuated from the flaming wreckage.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 6 (AP) -- The Red Sox teed off against Harry Byrd for five hits and four runs today to beat the Athletics, 4 -- 0, in the second game of a twin bill, with the winning pitcher, Maurie McDermott, contributing a single and scoring one of the runs.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 (UP) -- The Democratic National Chairman, Stephen A. Mitchell, said today that the party had made "a good deal of progress" toward healing its North-and-South split.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Sept. 6 -- The United States team that came within 2,250 feet of scaling the world's highest unconquered mountain -- Godwin Austen (K-2) 28,250 feet high in the icebound Karakoram of northern Kashmir -- will make another assault in May.
The charter market last week was as bad as the weather, shipping men agreed. However, they said, the market showed signs of becoming slightly more comfortable after the summer slump.

HANOVER, Germany, Sept. 6 -- Turbulent Lower Saxony, whose extreme Right and Left had violent exchanges in previous elections, went to the polls today without serious trouble, although predawn clashes broke out in the ancient town of Celle.

HARRISON, N. Y., Sept. 6 -- Superior team-work enabled the Aurora Polo Club of Buffalo, N. Y., to defeat the Pittsfield (Mass.) P. C., 9 to 4, in the final of the national twenty-goal championship at the Blind Brook Club today.

Public jobs in nearly half the states and cities are still filled through the political spoils system of appointing workers from the party in power, the National Civil Service League reported yesterday.
DETROIT, Sept. 6 -- Tomorrow's Silver Cup race here for speed boats of limited size and power will have a brand new push-button feature.

WORCESTER, Mass., Sept. 6 -- Priests, temporarily discarding Roman collars and cassocks for workmen's clothing, are making it possible for Assumption College to rise from the wreckage of a June 9 tornado in time for the academic year.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Sept. 6 -- Mohammed Ali, Prime Minister of Pakistan, maintained complete silence for the second day on the contents of a reply received yesterday from Jawaharlal Nehru, Indian Prime Minister, to his request for early implementation of a plebiscite in the state of Kashmir.

THE producers of the television program "Pentagon U. S. A." have been ordered by the Department of the Army to delete all assertions that its stories come from the "confidential" files of the Army's Military Investigation Division.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 6 -- The Los Angeles Times said today that Vice President Richard M. Nixon was expected to discuss with the Department of Justice soon the possible tempering of the stepped-up campaign against illegal immigration from Mexico, in the interests of assuring Southern California farmers of a supply of labor.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 (AP) -- The long pending reorganization of the Veterans Administration becomes effective tomorrow.

DENVER, Sept. 6 (AP) -- President Eisenhower, in a proclamation for Labor Day, today hailed the freedom of American workers, and said they "give the lie to the sly evil of the promises of totalitarianism."

AMSTERDAM, Sept. 6 -- The Netherlands will start liberalization of dollar imports and probably will abolish the 10 per cent dollar export yield retention plan. According to the official statement issued last Tuesday the dollar position is so improved that substantial alleviations in restrictions on dollar imports have become possible -- primarily in raw materials and semifinished products of which some categories to be defined later will be completely freed from controls.

The city's general financial condition is sound, its credit good and its bonds are worthy of "favorable consideration by discerning investors,'' in the opinion of John S. Linen, vice president of the Chase National Bank and member of the Mayor's Committee on Management Survey.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 -- The United States is quietly exercising the influence of its good offices in a little-known dispute between Britain and Saudi Arabia that has aroused some concern in high official quarters here.

DAYTON, Ohio, Sept. 6 (AP) -- A 110-mile jet race, a rendezvous between atomic bombers flying non-stop from Japan and England, and an unscheduled helicopter collision provided excitement at the second day of the National Aircraft Show today.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 6 -- The National Urban League opened its forty-third annual conference here today with the registration of about 1,000 delegates from thirty-six states.

RICHMOND, Va., Sept. 6 -- Virginia's poll tax appeared today to be the key early issue in a campaign that pits the Democratic choice in a traditionally Democratic state against the strongest Republican opposition in many years.

LOVELAND, Colo., Sept. 6 -- The Colorado Big Thompson project, a gigantic siphon operation designed to scoop up water from the Western slope of the Rocky Mountains and pass it over the Continental Divide to the farm lands of Eastern Colorado is now 95 per cent completed.

The United States, we are frequently told, should be prepared to accept its responsibilities as the world's leading creditor nation by reducing its trade barriers and by lending abroad on a generous scale. CAMP PERRY, Ohio, Sept. 6 (AP) -- Marine Corps teams from Parris Island, S. C., won both of today's events at the National Rifle Matches.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept. 6 -- Figures issued by the Brazilian Coffee Institute, a Government department, show that in the past two years 1,000,000 bags of coffee were re-exported to United States ports by nine European nations.

CHICAGO, Sept. 6 -- Mei-lan, the Giant Panda, of Brookfield Zoo, died in its cage last night, the last of the species known to be in a zoo. The 15-year-old panda had been ill for the last eight days, Ralph Graham, assistant zoo director, said.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 (UP) -- Congressional farm experts said today that wheat farmers might make more money -- at less cost to consumers -- under a new price support plan now being studied by the Administration.

COLOGNE, Germany, Sept. 6 -- After church this morning the placid burghers of Cologne and their wives, wearing their Sunday best, strolled through the warm sunshine on their way to the polls. As likely as not they took the children with them.

ROME, Sept. 6 (Reuters) -- Twenty Capuchin abbesses, normally secluded from the outside world and rarely allowed to speak to each other, will meet tomorrow to discuss ways of preventing some of them from starving.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 -- The pennant drive of the Yankees to their fifth straight flag still was stalled today as rain for the second successive day held them idle.
TEL AVIV, Israel, Sept. 6 -- The port police in Haifa reported today they had foiled a plot to sabotage the harbor when they caught a newspaper reporter with a time bomb in the port area.
INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 6 -- In the organization's closest election, the American Veterans of World War II today chose Henry J. Mahady of Latrobe, Pa., as national commander.

MONTREAL, Sept. 6 (Canadian Press) -- Three Americans on a fishing trip spent a night of horror in the woods after one of them had been attacked, beaten and robbed at St. Michael des Saints, seventy miles north of here, the Provincial police said.

DETROIT, Sept. 6 (UP) -- Walter F. Reuther, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, said tonight that if he were Martin P. Durkin, Secretary of Labor, he would be unhappy with the Eisenhower Administration.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 -- The story of how an official of President Eisenhower's Inaugural Committee quoted classified Navy information in an attempt to set himself up as a business representative is under final study by an investigating committee of the House of Representatives.

PROSPECT PARK, N. J., Sept. 6 -- Two youths, 14 and 15 years old, apprehended late yesterday by police, were in the custody of their parents today awaiting arraignment in Passaic County Juvenile Court on charges that they had caused damage estimated at $5,000 in the only public grade school here.

American students returning from a summer of work, study and travel in Europe expressed satisfaction with the friendly welcome they received abroad and voiced a desire to go back next summer as they debarked yesterday morning from the Netherlands Government vessel, Sibajak, at Pier 1, Fourth Street, Hoboken, N. J.

TOKYO, Monday, Sept. 7 -- United Nations Command authorities prepared today to demand that Communist officials on the joint Military Armistice Commission explain the fate of Allied soldiers held by the enemy and not returned in the prisoner exchange completed yesterday.

A four-story remodeled apartment building at 30 Schermerhorn Street in the Brooklyn Heights section of Brooklyn has been sold by the Celved Realty Corporation to an investing client of Irving Honigsberg, attorney, who insured title with the Inter-Country Title Guaranty and Mortgage Company.

The Port Authority's plan for an off-street bus loading and unloading station near the George Washington Bridge would not end the hazard to pedestrians but merely shift it to another location, Robert F. Wagner Jr., Borough President of Manhattan, said yesterday.

A new personality, as far as Broadway is concerned, will be introduced at 8 o'clock this evening at the Vanderbilt. She is Anna Russell, a singing comedienne, who established herself in the concert department with a one-woman program.

When New York's public schools open, a week from today, twenty-two new buildings and additions accommodating 22,266 students will be ready for first occupancy. These nineteen new schools and three additions represent a cost of $38,683,017 exclusive of land, furniture and equipment.

NEWARK, Sept. 6 -- Two of seven persons hospitalized yesterday as the result of a "chain reaction" smash-up, involving sixteen automobiles and a bus, near the Elizabeth interchange on the New Jersey Turnpike, were released today.

Distress conveyances of Manhattan real estate during the first six months of this year were the lowest in recent years although the June total was the highest since 1950, according to figures compiled by the Real Estate Board of New York.

TEHERAN, Iran, Sept. 6 -- Iran's Government and press today welcomed the promise of $45,000,000 in emergency aid from the United States with declarations that the funds would be wisely spent to overcome the immediate financial crisis and begin the long-delayed economic development of the country.
HARTFORD, Sept. 6 -- Connecticut's four major cities and several lesser communities will hold municipal elections in November that may provide a clue to voters' sentiments in the 1954 state election.

FAIRFIELD, Calif., Sept. 6 (UP) -- "Slick," a repatriated soldier accused of betraying fellow captives to the Communists, returned to the United States today and denied their charges.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 6 (AP) -- The Indians took undisputed possession of second place and dropped the White Sox to third today with a 4-2 victory, paced by Larry Doby's two-run homer in the sixth inning. Cleveland trails the league-leading Yankees by ten games.

Prices of cotton futures moved narrowly last week, as they had the week before. Active contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange closed on Friday up 5 points to down 6 from the previous week's closing, or 25 cents a bale higher to 30 cents lower.
LONDON, Sept. 6 -- The British Productivity Council asserted today that at least 30,000,000 tons of coal could be saved annually in Britain if it were used more efficiently.

The Rev. Dr. David A. MacLennan of the Divinity School of Yale University criticized yesterday what he called a growing tendency toward conformity to prevailing standards in America that often were alien to Christian ethics. In a sermon as guest preacher at Riverside Church, Dr. MacLennan, Professor of Preaching and Pastoral Care at the school, declared that "adjustment" to one's environment should never lead one to make "soft and easy compromises with what is right."

YONKERS, Sept. 6 -- Like any purchaser who feels he has won a terrific bargain, Raymond Lauzon, 30 years old, of 126 Stanley Avenue, was delighted with himself last night when he bought a neat-looking, sixteen-foot motorboat for only $40.

SEOUL, Korea, Monday, Sept. 7 (AP) -- Two South Koreans are in jail, accused of betraying Maj. Gen. William F. Dean, former commander of the United States Twenty-fourth Infantry Division, into Communist captivity. They received $5 in Korean money from the Reds for the betrayal, national police headquarters said.
CHICAGO, Sept. 6 -- Two young scientists, one Canadian and the other Swiss, reported tonight that they had solved one of chemistry's classic problems -- synthetic production of common sugar.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Sept. 6 -- Turkey is showing an encouraging awareness of the need for effective rehabilitation of disabled and handicapped persons, Dr. Howard A. Rusk, associate editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES and a rehabilitation and physical medicine authority, said here today after visiting several turkish institutions and conferring with medical leaders.

NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 6 -- Lieut. Gen. K. S. Thimayya of the Indian Army, chairman of the Neutral Nations Repatriation Commission in Korea, and other members of the Indian staff left this morning for Tokyo by air. They expect to complete in about five months their task of overseeing the disposition of prisoners of the Korean war who refuse to be returned to their homeland.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Sept. 6 (AP) -- "I killed her because I loved her," Herman H. Nagle declared in an interview in his city jail cell tonight following the slaying of his 28-year-old invalid daughter in what the police said appeared to have been a "mercy killing."

MILWAUKEE, Sept. 6 (AP) -- The Braves and Cardinals played a 3 -- 3 tie in the second game of a double-header called by darkness at the end of the eighth inning today after the Braves had won the opener, 3 -- 1, as Eddie Mathews belted his forty-fifth home run.

CHICAGO, Sept. 6 -- Wheat trading on the Board of Trade last week continued active, with purchases more than three times the volume of a year ago, 111,709,000 bushels compared with 34,648,000 bushels. With the exception of oats, trade in all grains and in soybeans was much larger than a year ago.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 6 -- Two-thirds of the people of the United States do not understand the principles that underlie the nation's foreign policies, one of the country's foremost psychologists said here today. He warned that this represented a serious threat to the stability of the Government in the event of an enemy attack.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Sept. 6 -- Bill Luders' Surf, which finished first yesterday when the wind puffed as high as thirty knots showed it could win in soft breezes, too, as it led a fleet of fourteen Internationals to the finish today in the thirty-first regatta of the Long Island Sound Yacht Racing Association.

NEW HYDE PARK, L. I., Sept. 6 -- The dream of glory of a 15-year-old Long Island boy vanished yesterday in the choppy waters of Long Island Sound. Inspired, perhaps, by the recent exploits of Florence Chadwick in swimming the English Channel, Carl Christensen plunged into the Sound near Bayville at 9:40 yesterday morning and bravely headed for the Connecticut shore, seven miles away.

OKROGLICA, Yugoslavia, Sept. 6 -- Marshal Tito, President of Yugoslavia, proposed today internationalizing the city of Trieste and awarding to Yugoslavia all the Free Territory of Trieste around the port city.

STAMFORD, Conn., Sept. 6 -The Stamford Yacht Club's Vineyard Trophy went to DeCoursey Fales again today after his 59-foot staysail schooner, Nina, was adjudged the corrected-time winner of the nineteenth Vineyard Race which had the skippers buzzing as they came back to the clubhouse from the 234-mile thrash.

DENVER, Sept. 6 -- Secretary of State John Foster Dulles arrived here tonight from Washington for a conference with President Eisenhower concerning "a docket of ten items."

TOKYO, Tuesday, Sept. 8 -- The United Nations Command begins today the transfer to the Korean demilitarized zone North Korean and Chinese war prisoners who have refused to return to their homelands. The Allies hold an estimated 22,600 prisoners who have said they would resist their transfer to Communist authorities.

POINT LOOKOUT, L. I., Sept. 7 -- Eleven life guards from the Hempstead Town Park Beach plowed a surf boat through twenty-foot waves here this morning to rescue three men, two women and a 12-year-old boy who had been dumped into the ocean a mile and a half offshore when a forty-two-foot fishing boat capsized and sank.

SAIGON, Vietnam, Sept. 7 -- After a strong political counter-offensive by Bao Dai, the Chief of State of Vietnam, who now is in France, several important elements that participated in the Nationalist Congress in Saigon yesterday have sent telegrams of loyalty to him.

OYSTER BAY, L. I., Sept. 7 -- The British-American Cup, a Six-Meter sailing prize in competition since 1921 and held by the United States almost a quarter-century, will remain at the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club for a while longer.
Nine ships, up to a full day behind schedule because of the heavy seas kicked up by Hurricane Carol, will dock here today and tomorrow with 5,961 passengers.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 (UP) -- An Administration reorganization plan to simplify the activities of the Veterans Administration went into effect today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 7 -- Negotiators for the International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employes and the Association of Motion Picture Producers will meet tomorrow to begin discussing terms for a new basic work agreement covering some 14,000 craft workers in the studios.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., Tuesday, Sept. 8 (AP) -- The 475 drivers and mechanics of the Syracuse Transit Corporation yesterday ended their twenty - two - day - old strike for higher wages and the first buses rolled early today.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Sept. 7 --Considerable tonnages of uranium oxide will be produced in South Africa when output goals have been achieved, J. H. Viljoen, Minister of Mines, said today. He spoke at a luncheon honoring members of the Joint United States Congressional Committee on Atomic Energy who are inspecting uranium plants in South Africa.
HALIFAX, Sept. 7 (Canadian Press) -- The hurricane rammed across the Maritime Provinces late today, hitting Nova Scotia a damaging blow and then whistling on toward Newfoundland.

BOSTON, Sept. 7 -- Coast Guardsmen, battling twenty-foot waves, rescued by breeches buoy and amphibious duck today seventeen seamen of the Panamanian freighter Evgenia, which had been hurled aground seventy-five yards off a Cape Cod beach in the tail of the hurricane Carol.
Your editorial of Sept. 4 regarding my statement on the foreign situation wrongly interprets the statement in one important respect.

Five rounds were completed yesterday in the world chess championship challengers' tournament in Neuhausen, Switzerland, when six adjourned games were played, leaving Samuel Reshevsky of New York tied for the lead with Vassily Smyslov of Moscow.

PARIS, Sept. 7 -- European financial experts attending the International Monetary Fund conference that opens Wednesday in Washington will ask for greater liaison between the Fund and the European Payments Union.

STRATFORD, Conn., Sept. 7 -- Those who think of a "railbird" as a person in a flashy jacket clocking race horses from the top rail of the track fence at daybreak would have found a new definition by pushing through the rice flats on the Housatonic River this morning, where the railbirds were really plentiful.

The child entering nursery school for the first time needs help from his parents and particularly his mother in making "one of the most important transitions of his life," Dr. Peter B. Neubauer declared in a recent interview. Dr. Neubauer is director of the Council Child Development Center, an agency that studies and treats problems of the pre-school child.
INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 7 (AP) -- Kimberly Kid and Keystone gained straight heat victories today in the Horseman Futurities on the opening Grand Circuit program at the Indiana State Fair.

When the Civil Aeronautics Administration closed the books this month on another fiscal year of recording aircraft titles and mortgages, it disclosed that it's cheaper to buy a license for an airplane than for an automobile.

ROME, Sept. 7 -- Yesterday's address by Marshal Tito, President of Yugoslavia, is thought in Rome to have closed, at least for the present, the violent phase of the Italian-Yugoslav controversy over Trieste and the Free Territory and to have shifted the entire problem back onto the diplomatic plane.

The American National Retail Jewelers Association is attacking in detail a House Armed Services subcommittee report on post exchanges. The report, issued Aug. 12, provoked a vigorous general attack at the association's annual convention then being held at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

The eight-story industrial building on plot 25 by 100 feet at 42 West Fifteenth Street has been purchased by a client of Joshuah Sidney Schultz, attorney, which plans to occupy a portion of the structure for manufacturing purposes.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 7 (AP) -- Mickey Vernon, the American League batting leader, hit a pair of doubles and a triple as the Senators trounced the Athletics, 6 -- 3, in the second game of today's twin bill. The Senators made eighteen hits as they won the opener, 13 -- 2.

MAYS LANDING, N. J., Sept. 7 (AP) -- The Kay-Gee Stable's Go a Bit drove home an upset winner in the $23,650 Philadelphia Turf Handicap before a record crowd of 33,404 at the Atlantic City Race Course today. The chestnut colt beat eight other 3-year-olds in the one-mile grass race for the first stakes victory of his career.

Two brothers were booked by the police last night after an automobile accident on Grand Central Parkway in which an elderly couple was injured, traffic halted for twenty minutes and an angry crowd of motorists threatened to lynch one of the brothers.

Traffic flowed freely in and out of the city yesterday as the summer holiday season unofficially ended. Homeward-bound vacationists and Labor Day week-end crowds encountered no serious obstacles to smooth passage as they motored cityward, and the estimated 400,000 persons who visited New York between Friday and last night had equally uneventful return journeys.

Following is the text of former President Truman's nation-wide broadcast address yesterday in Detroit before a Labor Day rally of Michigan unions of the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations as recorded by THE NEW YORK TIMES:

A banker with long experience in marketing of New York City's bonds, who also took active part in the work of the Mayor's Committee on Management Survey of the city government, expresses the conviction that New York's general financial condition is sound, its credit good and its bonds worthy of "favorable consideration by discerning investors."

IT was announced the other day that Dr. John Bain Sutherland would be formally installed this season in football's Hall of Fame. That's as it should be. There were gasps of dismay among the gridiron cognoscenti a couple of years ago when the original list was compiled. There was one glaring omission. Jock Sutherland, the phenomenally successful Pitt coach for a decade and a half, had unaccountably been overlooked.

" Report on the Atom," by Gordon Dean, recently retired chairman of the United States Atomic Energy Commission, will be issued Sept. 21 by Knopf. Mr. Dean describes the nation's vast program of atomic development for both military and peaceful purposes. The book also contains a chapter on Russia's atomic program.
ANTWERP, Sept. 7 -- An oil refinery which its operator, Esso Standard Refinery Societe Anonyme, says is the most efficient in the world, will be officially opened here tomorrow.

Twenty-six films starring Hollywood players will be produced for showing on television before they are made available for theatre distribution, according to a joint announcement yesterday by the Vitapix Corporation and Princess Pictures, Inc.

A festive atmosphere surrounded Mayor Impellitteri yesterday as he campaigned in what is known as Harlem's Little Italy. Borne aloft on a seventy-foot-high religious statue supported by a hundred Italian-Americans, the Mayor took part in singing an Italian air, was serenaded with "He's a Jolly Good Fellow," and finally, after ten minutes, was carried off on the shoulders of three stout men.

DOUGLAS, Isle of Man, Sept. 7 -- British labor must expand its own productivity if the standard of living in this country is to be maintained and improved, Tom O'Brien, Member of Parliament and president of the Trades Union Congress, told delegates to the eighty-fifth annual convention of the congress, which opened here today.

SOMERSET, Pa., Sept. 7 (AP) -- Two aircraft executives were found dead near the wreckage of their single-engined airplane late yesterday on an abandoned farm eight miles west of this southwestern Pennsylvania town.

In an election which smashed all precedents and swept away much of the debris of a dismal past the people of Western Germany have rolled up a landslide victory for Chancellor Adenauer, and have therewith also cast their votes in favor of the West, of European unification and of a common defense of Western civilization against the new barbarism threatening from the East.

CHICAGO, Sept. 7 -- St. Peter's Franciscan Church and Friary, a $4,000,000 structure designed to fulfill the spiritual needs of Roman Catholics in the heart of Chicago's Loop business district, was dedicated today amid brilliant ceremonies in the presence of more than 2,000 persons.

MADISON, Wis., Sept. 7 -- Living plants, using the energy of sunlight, can transform atmospheric gases in ten seconds into solid cellulose, the principal structural material of plants and one of the most complex substances known to chemists, it was reported here today at the opening of the meeting of the American Institute of Biological Sciences.

PARIS, Sept. 7 -- While the victory of Chancellor Konrad Adenauer in the West German election yesterday was generally considered here to be a success for the Western policy on Germany, it was a success that caused considerable disquietude in this country, which is sharply divided over that policy, as over much else.

To handle the growing volume of traffic more speedily and with greater safety, the nation is in the midst of its greatest highway building and modernization program. Highway expenditures in the United States this year are expected to reach a new peak of nearly $5,500,000,000 -- about 10 per cent more than last year.

DEMAREST, N. J., Sept. 7 -- Dr. Beridge Leigh-Mallory Robertson, wife of David Allan Robertson Jr., Associate Professor of English at Barnard College, died today in her home, after a long illness. Her age was 35. She was a practicing pediatrician.

DENVER, Sept. 7 -- Robert T. Stevens, Secretary of the Army promised wholehearted cooperation today with Senator Joseph R. McCarthy in his investigation of Communists in the Army, but indicated Presidential Executive Orders might require him to withhold confidential loyalty files.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 7 -- Mayor Raymond R. Tucker will go tomorrow to Jefferson City to attempt to persuade Gov. Phil M. Donnelly to call a special session of the Legislature so St. Louis may keep alive its city earnings tax.

A seeming lack of interest in the outcome of next Tuesday's primary appeared yesterday to be giving serious concern to the three principal rivals for the Democratic nomination for Mayor, their running mates and supporters. Apathy was indicated by small attendance at rallies, the difficulty of getting campaign contributions and a lag in the recruitment of volunteer workers.
After horses paying $24.80, $59, $51.70 and $35.50 had won the first four races at Aqueduct yesterday, the Winfrey family provided first aid for the players of favorites.

Trade and production have been remarkably steady since January, when due allowance is made for seasonal factors, says the September letter of the Northern Trust Company of Chicago. Retail sales, it points out, were 6 per cent above a year ago, "a gain which corresponds closely to the rise in total personal incomes after taxes."

LARCHMONT, N. Y., Sept. 7 -- Cornelius Shields' Aileen showed the way to seventeen International Class sloops today in the Larchmont Yacht Club's Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound regatta. A fleet of 113 craft in nine classes raced.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Aug. 24 -- About 3,000 city workers have moved to farms in the last year in response to appeals by the Government, whose program to settle 35,000 families on the land over the next five years has been threatened by the virtual cessation of immigration.

WESTBURY, L. I., Sept. 7 (AP) -- Midway Queen won the featured Labor Day Pace in 2:06 4/5, rallying in the stretch to sweep by Todd Scott for a length victory tonight at Roosevelt Raceway. Frisky Hal was third.

Everyone in the Army "now is a number in an I. B. M. machine," the Combat Forces Journal states in a recent bitter editorial on the state of the Army, one of the frankest and most important criticisms in several years.

PARIS, Sept. 6 -- Despite the continual warnings of military leaders that the war-making capabilities of the Soviet Union are constantly increasing, the rearmament pace of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization is lagging dangerously.

An industrial plot fronting on East 134th and East 135th Streets, 100 feet east of Willow Avenue, in the Bronx, has been sold by Florasynth Laboratories, Inc., to Marine Welding, Inc., of which Nicholas Falco is president. The new owner plans to improve the parcel for its own use.

PURCHASE, N. Y., Sept. 7 -- Danahy's Blue Belle, owned by Charles Danahy of Syosset, L. I., today won the competition in the fifteen-inch class for bitches, the closing event of the four-day licensed field trials of the Southern New York Beagle Club.
BERLIN, Sept. 7 -- East Germany is trying to crush an anti-Communist underground among its workers by weeding out of its major factories those suspected of participation in such activities.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Sept. 7 -- Jawaharlal Nehru, the Prime Minister of India, has warned Pakistan that demands for "armed liberation" of Kashmir may precipitate retaliatory action against the 35,000,000 Moslem minority in Hindu India. The warning was contained in a letter received Saturday by Mohammed Ali, Prime Minister of Pakistan.

CHICAGO, Sept. 7 (AP) -- International Harvester Company sales declined in the quarter ending on July 31 from those in the same period a year earlier, John L. McCaffrey, president, reported to stockholders today.

TOKYO, Aug. 31 -- The rise of anti-American sentiment in Japan, or at least its coming clearly into the open, during the last year has been a surprise to many Americans. Remembering six and a half years of Japanese cooperation and compliance under the Allied occupation, they cannot understand this seeming reversal of sentiment.

HYDEN, Ky., Sept. 7 -- In the capital of the nonunion coal producing country here, John L. Lewis' United Mine Workers Union has been waging a campaign for more than two years to bring the operators under contract.

BERLIN, Sept. 4 -- A visit to the Leipzig Fair, whence this correspondent has returned, is worth the time and trouble it costs to get a Soviet visa for the rare glimpse it affords of existence deep in the heart of East Germany.

The two three-story apartment houses operated as a single unit with accommodations for twenty families at 45-16 and 45-18 Thirty-ninth Place in Sunnyside, Queens, has been sold by Thirty-ninth Place, Inc., to a syndicate headed by David B. Israel.

Half a little show would probbly be the right size for Anna Russell. She is an energetic lady with a powerful voice and a rowdy sense of humor. In the first part of her "Little Show," which opened with loud reports at the Vanderbilt last evening, she burlesques songs of all nations at the top of her voice with double-takes and other grimaces.

LIVERPOOL, England, Sept. 7 -- Impairment in the food value of breakfast cereals, toast and pressure-cooked proteins was discussed by leading nutritionists at today's meeting of the British Association for the Advancement of Science here.

A double defeat by the eighth-place Pirates, who had not captured a double-header all season, was about the last straw for the Giants yesterday at the Polo Grounds. Leo Durocher's club, no longer pretending that anything is at stake, dropped its fifth and sixth games in a row, blowing the opener, 9 -- 7, with an horrendous, butter-fingered exhibition of baseball.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 (AP) -Ted Kroll of New Hartford, N. Y., Overcame a vigorous challenge from Lew Worsham to capture first prize in the National Celebrities golf tournament today with a 7-under-par 281.

QUEBEC, Sept. 6 -- Deposits of the rare and valuable metal, geranium, have been discovered in Cape Breton Island, it is reported here, together with geranium, copper, nickel and at least three other metals.

MASSAPEQUA PARK, L. I., Sept. 7 -- Nassau County officials advised today that the State Health Department had rejected a request by this village for mass inoculation with gamma globulin of the residents of a four-block area here that has been hit by polio.

Even in the long catalogue of atrocious Communist treatment of prisoners in Korea the items concerning the extortion from our airmen of "confessions" regarding germ warfare stand out as singularly ugly. This behavior is not accidental or casual. It is carefully designed and diabolical cruelty, practiced for a specific purpose -- namely, to give specious currency to a monstrous lie.

MONTICELLO, N. Y., Sept. 7 -- Isidore Present, president of the Brooklyn Kosher Butcher Association, Inc., was found slain on the front lawn of his rented bungalow in this summer resort at 7 A. M. today.
BONN, Germany, Sept. 7 -- Dr. Konrad Adenauer, West German Chancellor, stepped into the leadership of the European unity movement today, but for the moment, his following was in doubt.

Insurgent vice presidents of the International Longshoremen's Association, who represent locals outside the racket-encrusted Port of New York, disclosed yesterday that they would ask the American Federation of Labor for a new pier union charter without waiting for the A. F. L. to expel the present union.

MANILA, Sept. 7 -- President Elpidio Quirino returned today from the United States and plunged back into the Philippine election campaign with an expression of confidence that he would win re-election next November.
LONDON, Sept. 7 -- German issues, especially Government bonds, were in brisk demand on the stock market here today and gained as much as four points on Chancellor Adenauer's election victory.
An ex-sailor, less than three months out of the Navy, won the amateur tennis championship of the United States yesterday in as stunning a final-round reversal as Forest Hills has seen in many years.

On record sales of $42,497,447, the Atlas Plywood Corporation in its fiscal year ended on June 30 last, increased earnings by 295 per cent over the previous year, according to the annual report of Elmore I. MacPhie, president, released today.

Dr. Howard Rusk's letter from Korea and your editorial arising from it are not only timely and of extreme urgency; they call the attention of your readers to something that has been of passionate concern to a limited circle for many years: the tragic prevalence of leprosy (or as it is now coming to be known, Hansen's disease) in Korea.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 -- The German election triumph of Chancellor Adenauer was hailed by this Government today.

MOSCOW, Tuesday, Sept. 8 -The Soviet press charged today that Chancellor Konrad Adenauer's election victory had been won in an atmosphere of terror and that it raised "a serious threat" that the Bonn peace contract and the European Defense Community Treaty would be ratified "and make impossible the peaceful reunion of Germany."
CHICAGO, Sept. 7 -- American scientists and the chemical industry were challenged tonight to embark on a program for developing new sources of fuel and food for future generations.

LISBON, Portugal, Sept. 7 -- More than 1,000 delegates from thirty-six countries are attending the fifth international Congress of Neurology that opened here today. An international multiple sclerosis conference and meetings of the International League against Epilepsy are integrated within the Congress.

Among the pleasant activities related to the opening of college is the arrangement of the dormitory room in which the student will spend the major portion of the school year. A variety of furnishings are available to soften the somewhat austere look of such quarters and to contribute to their comfort.

JAKARTA, Sept. 7 -- The five-week-old Government of Dr. Ali Sastroamidjojo has run into a serious crisis that may lead to a Cabinet shift. The United Islam party, a Marxist-oriented Moslem organization, announced today it had suspended three of its most important members, including two who hold portfolios in the Cabinet.

Almost every year about now a man with a little time on his hands -- enough to let him go out to the back porch and just sit there, thinking about nothing in particular -- may find himself wondering just when autumn begins, anyway.
A course in waterfront safety under the sponsorship of the New York Shipping Association and New York University's Center for Safety Education will begin on Sept. 22.

DETROIT, Sept. 7 -- Former President Truman, a silent observer since the Eisenhower Administration took office last Jan. 20, opened fire today on the Republican successors to his regime, charging them with betrayal of the people's interests and disregard of the nation's defense needs.

Wine-of-the-year -- a good catch phrase -- denotes a trend that should be of interest to wine-buying consumers, in the opinion of Frank Schoonmaker, a New York wine importer who uses the expression often.

UNITED NATIONS, New York, Sept. 7 -- Maurice Pate, executive director of the United Nations International Children's Emergency Fund, is due back today from Korea, where he spent a week in Pusan and Seoul consulting with military and Government officials on the needs of Korean children.

A record thirty-six million children will soon enter school, where they face alarming overcrowding, part-time sessions and a grievous teacher shortage. A faster construction of schools can partially solve the problem of overcrowding. Finding more and better teachers will be a far more difficult task, however.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Sept. 7 -- The announcement by Premier Ali Sastroamidjojo that the new Indonesian Government would take steps to terminate the Netherlands-Indonesian Union has caused little concern in Dutch circles here.

Two eight-man teams of American seamen will race down the Hudson River over a one-and-a-half-mile course in standard Coast Guard lifeboats today to determine which crew will represent this country Saturday in the fifteenth annual International Lifeboat Race.

A new merchandise mart is planned for Route 4 in Paramus, N. J. The site was sold by the Powell Realty Corporation to Morris Cooper of Fair Lawn who contracted to erect a building which in turn has been leased to Famous Brands Merchandise Mart, Inc., of New York.

The American Bulgarian League ended a three-day convention yesterday by voting to authorize a committee to assist Bulgarians escaping from communism who qualify under the new Refugee Relief Act. Under this program, the league will renew activities by which in 1951 and 1952 it brought to the United States fifty-eight Bulgarian displaced persons from Europe.

John Velasquez, 23 years old, of 126 West Eighty-fourth Street, died at 6:15 P. M. yesterday, three hours after he plunged to the tracks in front of a northbound local of the Broadway-Seventh Avenue I. R. T. line's Eighty-sixth Street station, the police of the West 100th Street station reported.

BOSTON, Sept. 7 -- The Yankees had to do some valiant fighting today to grind out just a little headway in their pennant drive as they spilt a double-header with the Red Box that went through rain, shine and finally wound up under lights.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 7 (UP) -- The big bats of Red Schoendienst and Stan Musial today enabled the Cardinals to beat the Redlegs, 4 -- 3 and 1 -- 0, before a crowd of 15,530 at Busch Stadium.

TEHERAN, Iran, Sept. 7 (UP) -Premier Fazlollah Zahedi stepped up his campaign against the Communist Tudeh party today with the arrest of fifty-five of its members and supporters of former Premier Mohammed Mossadegh.

NEW CANAAN, Conn., Sept. 7 -- Miss Mary J. Kelley will step to the front door of "the little red schoolhouse" in Carter Street here Wednesday morning and, for her forty-third consecutive year, will sound the old-fashioned hand bell to summon twenty-four students to their seats in the one-room building.
Refused a drink in a Broadway bar yesterday because he appeared intoxicated, a young man was just taking $10 at pistol point when policemen arrived.

A solemn, flinty authoritarian holdover from an earlier period in German history, Chancellor Konrad Adenauer, whose Christian Democratic party decisively won the German general election Sunday, has been described by Sir Winston Churchill as the most astute German statesman since Bismarck.

The Venezuela Line will expand its services from that country to the United States and Canada next Tuesday, when six ships, formerly part of the Flota Mercante Grancolombiana, will be officially taken over by the Government-owned line.
When the Dodgers entrain this evening for Cincinnati on the first leg of their final Western tour they'll almost be in a spot to ask: "Is this trip necessary?"
AKRON, Ohio, Sept. 7 (AP) -- The Cleveland Browns rallied tonight to defeat the Baltimore Colts, 23 -- 21, in a National Football League exhibition.

Leaders of the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations criticized the Republican Administration yesterday and warned against policies that might endanger peace and prosperity.

ALBANY, Sept. 7 -- Since New York State went into the truck weighing business in a big way just a year ago to enforce its new ton-mile tax, 42,776 vehicles have been caught traveling the highways with a heavier cargo than that for which the owners were paying taxes.

It is good news that Admiral John H. Towers, U. S. N. (Ret.), has accepted the invitation of the directors of the Flight Safety Foundation to become its president. This organization, which has grown in stature under the leadership and dedicated service of Jerome Lederer, is playing a unique and all-important role in bringing about greater safety in the air for all categories of flight.

An important statement from Sinclair Weeks, Secretary of Commerce, on general marketing conditions and the part his department and its multiple agencies can play in solving marketing problems is expected when he speaks at the opening dinner of a three-day session of the National Industrial Conference Board at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel on Sept. 23.

PEEKSKILL, N. Y., Sept. 7 -- The Buchanan Engine Company from Westchester County's smallest village two miles south of here won two of the five trophies awarded tonight at the close of the celebration of the twenty-fifth aniversary of the Peekskill Fire Patrol.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 -- Crown Prince Akihito of Japan and his party will arrive in this country by plane tomorrow on a visit that is rare for Japanese royalty.

BONN, Germany, Sept. 7 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer will meet Thursday with the Executive Board and Bundestag floor leaders of his Christian Democratic Union to decide whether to form a one-party government or invite one or more other parties to reform present coalition.

CHICAGO, Sept. 7 (UP) -- Sickle's Image, a 5-year-old brown mare owned by Clarence Hartwick, swept home with a stretch run today to win the $108,500 top prize in the $165,200 Washington Park Handicap by a half length from Hasty House Farm's Ruhe before 38,600 Labor Day fans.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 7 -- New possibilities of determining how human vision develops are available as a result of evidence presented here today at a national convention of psychologists that chickens and humans see objects in the same three-dimensional manner.

STONEVILLE, Miss., Sept. 7 -- Representatives of the hardwood industry in five Southern states have joined in the raising of a private fund to reinforce Government hardwood forestry research in the mid-South area.

DETROIT, Sept. 7 -- The wonder speed boat of the century, Slo-Mo-Shun V, pride of Seattle and the Pacific Northwest, was fourth today instead of first in the seventh annual Silver Cup regatta. Just what beat Stanley Sayres' creation will continue to be debatable among the Detroit River spectators who numbered 250,000, according to Commodore R. Dean Ament of the Detroit Yacht Club.
DETROIT, Sept. 7 (AP) -- Motor vehicle output will slump sharply this week, primarily because of the Labor Day holiday that halted virtually all assembly lines today.

Color television probably will have a greater effect on the sale of apparel than has any other factor during the last decade, according to James B. Lee, president of the Frank H. Lee Company, manufacturer of men's hats. A majority of the more than 3,000 dealers handling the company's hats intend to use color television, once it is introduced, to advertise merchandise, he said.

CHICAGO, Sept. 7 (UP) -- Howie Pollet scattered nine hits to beat the Braves, 6 to 4, in the second game of a double-header today after a fine relief performance by Turk Lown helped the Cubs win the first game, 4 -- 3.

DETROIT, Sept. 7 (AP) -- Walt Dropo and Ray Boone led the attack today as the Tigers rallied twice to sweep a double-header with the fading White Sox, 6 -- 2 and 4 -- 2. The twin victories moved the Tigers into sixth place -- their highest standing since the 1951 season.
TURIN, Italy, Sept. 7 (AP) -- Film stars Lana Turner and Lex Barker were married here today at a civil ceremony in the city hall. Emilio Bachi, a municipal assessor, performed the ceremony.

CHICAGO, Sept. 7 -- Two Japanese business men visiting Chicago said today that if Japan was to achieve economic stability and take her place among free countries she must be allowed to increase her foreign trade. Japan's foreign trade is 40 per cent of the level prior to World War II, they said.

LONDON, Sept. 7 -- Britain claimed the world's air speed record for level flight tonight after a Hawker Hunter fighter piloted by Squadron Leader Neville Duke had flashed four times over a three-kilometer (1.7 miles) course off England's south coast for an average speed of 727.6 miles an hour.

HAVANA, Sept. 7 -- The recent head injury of Manuel Cardinal Artega Betancourt, which kept him in a hospital several days and aroused widespread speculation both in Cuba and in the United States, was caused by a blow from a revolver in the hands of one of three men who attempted to rob him, the Rev. Raul del Valle, private secretary of the Cardinal said tonight.

Overtures are being made to members of the Army Inactive Reserve Corps to request transfer to an active Organized Reserve unit so that the following benefits might be realized: reserve commitment of three instead of five years, regular promotion, continued pay, assurance that act of Congress and not merely Presidential decree will be the legal basis of recall to active duty.

PROBABLY more travel books have been written about Italy than about any other country. For 150 years writers from Northern countries have lived in Florence and Venice and Rome, studying Italian art and Italian history and Italian wines -- and writing books about them. Germans, Norwegians, English and Americans, they feel an expansion of the soul in a country of warm sunshine, bright colors and cheap food and lodging.

ROME, Sept. 7 -- Dr. Selman A. Waksman, Nobel Prize-winning discoverer of streptomycin, reported today at the opening sessions of the sixth International Congress of Microbiology that a chemical he isolated more than twelve years ago from a soil micro-organism and discarded as much too toxic for human use was now offering promise as a chemical weapon against certain types of cancer.

BONN, Germany, Sept. 7 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer emerged today from West Germany's second post-war general election with a secure majority for another four-year term and a clear mandate to carry on with his policy of integrating Germany with the West.

TORONTO, Sept. 7 (Canadian Press) -- The Rev. Bob Richards of Long Beach, Calif., Olympic pole-vault champion, today set a Canadian open record, clearing the bar at 15 feet, 1/4 inch at the sixty-fifth annual Canadian National Exhibition track and field day before a crowd of 23,000.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- Chief Justice Fred M. Vinson died unexpectedly of a heart attack at his apartment at 2:15 A. M. today.

CHICAGO, Sept. 7 (AP) -- A woman described as an acquaintance of Rogers Hornsby, former baseball star who now manages the Cincinnati Redlegs, was found dead today beneath the windows of her third-floor North Side apartment, from which she apparently had plunged, according to the police.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 (AP) -- Senator Harry F. Byrd, Democrat of Virginia, reported today that the Government's civilian payroll had increased by about $322,000,000 during the 1953 fiscal year which ended on June 30, although the number employed declined 127,124.

The money available for payment of unemployment insurance benefits in New York State reached a record of $1,292,520,772 in the week ended Aug. 21, Milton O. Loysen, executive director of the State Labor Department's Division of Employment, reported yesterday.

With fair and cooler weather bringing the holiday crowds to Broadway, first-run movie theatres did a land-office business yesterday. The Paramount, running a stage show starring Dean Martin and Jerry Lewis, with its picture, "Plunder of the Sun," had capacity attendance and street lines throughout the week-end.
BERLIN, Sept. 7 -- The ultra-nationalistic German Reich party, which loomed yesterday as a seeming mountain in the West German political scene, emerged today as a molehill.

Reeves Brothers, Inc., had a net profit of $1,488,623, equal to $1.31 a common share in the fiscal year ended June 30 last, John M. Reeves, president, of the textile manufacturing company diclosed. The profit, realized on sales of $69,279,961, compared with $2,355,153, or $2.07 a share for the previous year, on sales of $71,356,718.
CLEVELAND, Sept. 7 (UP) -- The Indians completed one of the most successful home stands in their history today by defeating the Browns in a double-header, 3 -- 0 and 10 -- 7.
CINCINNATI, Sept. 7 (AP) -- Warren Giles, president of the National League, indicated today he would do nothing about the Leo Durocher-Carl Furillo tussle yesterday in New York.

William J. Jorden's two articles in this newspaper on anti-American feeling in Japan deserve thought -- and perhaps a sigh at the vagaries of human nature and the thankless tasks that great power and responsibility impose. There is no need, however, for pessimism or cynicism, or even for much criticism.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 (UP) -- The State Department's sweeping personnel cutback has set off a chain reaction that is forcing a wholesale shift of jobs within the department.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 (UP) -- The fortunes of the country's wage earner were today at the highest level in history, but there were darkening shadows across his future.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 (AP) -- Senator Everett M. Dirksen, Republican of Illinois, hit back today at Mr. Truman's assertion that the Eisenhower Administration was seeking to balance the budget at the expense of national security. Mr. Dirksen said:

BOSTON, Sept. 7 -- Following the receipt of a letter threatening his life if he set foot in Boston, Mickey Mantle, Yankee outfielder, had two detectives guarding him today from the time he arrived this morning until he left tonight with the Bombers.

It has been a long, difficult and rough road to Broadway for "Carnival in Flanders," but tonight, finally, the musical attraction will reach its destination, the Century Theatre. Perhaps to make up for the lost time (the musical has been in the making for more than a year), the opening night curtain will go up at the unusually early hour of 7:30 o'clock.
