DENVER, Colo., Sept. 7 -- John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, quoted President Eisenhower as saying today that the results of the election in West Germany were far better than this country had "dared to expect" as a good augury for German and European unity.

The two local trains on the West Side I. R. T. subway have always been distinct from each other by their top markers; one reading Broadway-Seventh Avenue, the other Seventh Avenue; the former ending at 137th Street and Broadway, the latter at 145th and Lenox Avenue.

DAYTON, Ohio, Sept. 7 (AP) -- Four world speed and altitude records for jet airplanes and helicopters -- set several days ago as a form of insurance against unfavorable weather -- were disclosed at the National Air Show today.

CAZENOVIA, N. Y., Sept. 7 -- James T. Sherwin, titleholder in 1951, won second place from Jack W. Collins, last year's winner, in the ninth and final round of the annual tournament for the championship of the New York State Chess Association today.

BELLPORT, L. I., Sept. 7 -- A twenty-two-mile-an-hour southwest wind played havoc with the fleet today in the finale of the annual three-day regatta of the Bellport Bay Yacht Club. Approximately a third of the 147 craft that took the starting gun failed to finish.

BURBANK, Calif., Sept. 7 -- The Lockheed Aircraft Corporation's assembly line, which already has produced more than 450 commercial and military versions of the well-known four-engined Constellation with piston motors, now is devoted exclusively to the manufacture of transports with turbo-compound drive.
Jews the world over will welcome at sunset today the arrival of still another New Year, the 5,714th of their long and eventful history.

The growing parent movement to improve the welfare of mentally retarded youngsters is to be aided by the education committee of the National Association for Retarded Children. Program plans and activities are outlined in a report by the committee in "Children Limited," the association's bulletin.
BALTIMORE, Sept. 8 (AP) -- Doctors today managed to free a kidney stone that for three days had sidelined Jim Tatum, the University of Maryland's head football coach.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 8 -- "New York Confidential," the Jack Lait-Lee Mortimer book about gangsterism and political skullduggery, has been acquired for filming by Edward Small.
New simplified customs procedures affecting entry and appraisement of imports were put into effect here yesterday with a minimum of difficulty over legal technicalities.

WRITERS, being human, are often discontented with the kind of writing they do best. Like the proverbial comedian who yearns to play Hamlet, certain novelists long to excel in varieties of writing for which they have no noticeable gift. Henry James and Joseph Conrad, who were great novelists, wasted much precious time and mental anguish in foredoomed efforts to be playwrights.

CHICAGO, Sept. 8 -- Choppy fluctuations featured the trading in grain futures on the Board of Trade today, but on the whole there was a strong tone, with wheat responsive to a show of strength at Minneapolis in the face of large receipts.

One more step has now been taken in the long, slow and painful process of getting the St. Lawrence Seaway and the hydroelectric power development at the International Rapids section of the river. The Federal Power Commission has reaffirmed its decision to give the New York State Power Authority a license to construct the United States portion of the hydro-electric development.

A merger, blending the talents of such top flight craftsmen as James A. Michener, author of the Pulitzer Prize book, "Tales of the South Pacific;" Joseph L. Mankiewicz, scenarist-picture director, who won three Oscars, and Joshua Logan, Broadway director-dramatist-producer, is being discussed.
PROVINCETOWN, Mass., Sept. 8 (AP) -- Coast Guard officials said tonight that a New York concern would attempt to salvage the 3,500-ton freighter Evgenia, which was grounded off shore yesterday.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Sept. 8 -- Most striking A. F. L. carpenters today failed to return to work at the $464,000,000 K-33 plant construction job in Oak Ridge, though told by their international union officers to return.

Three robbers escapes with $70,000 worth of mink furs yesterday afternoon from the Philip Buchberg Fur Corporation at 224 West Thirtieth Street and later sent a messenger to the office to insure the release of their tied-up victims.

NORTH BERGEN, N. J., Sept. 8 -- Ideal Studios, built in 1898 and one of the earliest motion picture studios in the country, was destroyed by flames that broke out at 2:40 P. M. today. Perched on the edge of the Palisades, the three-story stucco building made a spectacular fire visible in Manhattan.

Carl-Otto Claesson, first officer of the Swedish American liner Gripsholm, was transferred from the ship to the Coast Guard cutter Manitou at Quarantine yesterday afternoon after a five-day siege of stomach ulcer trouble.

World series ticket prices were raised to $10 for box seats, $7 for reserved seats and $2 for bleacher seats at a conference yesterday in the office of the baseball commissioner, Ford C. Frick. Representatives of the Yankees, Dodgers, Indians and Braves attended.
LE HAVRE, France, Sept. 8 (UP) -- The French liner Liberte, with 1,075 passengers aboard, spent six hours stuck in the mud off Le Havre today before finally getting under way on a voyage to New York.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Sept. 8 -- Five one-time members of the terrorist Irgun Zvai Leumi detained in connection with Sunday's bomb plot in Haifa harbor were remanded for fifteen days today by a Haifa magistrate. At the same time, military court proceedings were opened in the Sarafand army camp against two young men said to be important figures in an outlawed but unnamed terrorist organization.

MILWAUKEE, Sept. 8 (AP) -- Bill Bruton struck out but got two bases when Catcher Stan Lopata missed the ball in the ninth inning tonight. Bruton scored moments later on a fielder's choice to enable the Braves to gain a 3-2 victory over the Phillies in the play-off of a July 31 tie game.
B. Lowell Jacobson has been appointed personnel director of the National Broadcasting Company.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 8 -- A country-wide campaign to rid the roads of persons driving without licenses was urged today by Burton Marsh, director of the Traffic Engineering and Safety Department of the American Automobile Association.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Sept. 8 -- Foreign press correspondents, both full time and part time, were accused of "one-sided" reporting in the South African Parliament today by Dr. J. H. O. du Plessis, Nationalist party member who was head of the Malan Government's information services before being elected to Parliament in this year's national elections.

The Celotex Corporation had a net income in the nine months ended last July 31 of $2,015,919 compared with $478,024 in the corresponding period of the previous year, when operations were curtailed by a strike at the main plant in Marrero, La.

IT'S quite possible that the most fortunate swing Carl Furillo made all season was the one he took at Leo Durocher the other day. Whether the hot-headed Dodger outfielder ever connected with his former boss is immaterial. The important thing is that the seething Furillo emerged from the melee with a finger broken and probably won't play again until the world series.

THE Television Playhouse, starting its sixth season over N. B. C., presented "Othello" on Sunday night, but the production was patched-up Bard that never quite provided a deep-dimension picture of either Iago or the Moor. It was the familiar story in TV drama of commendable ambition running away with artistic discretion.

It is always difficult to get down to business on the day before and the day after a holiday. In Wall Street a lot of brokers evidently never made it at all yesterday. The ticker tape moved slower than it has in any session in four years -- since the Tuesday after Labor Day of 1949, to be exact.

BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N. Y., Sept. 8 -- Clarence Doser, former champion of the Metropolitan Professional Golfers Association, and Bobby Smith of Scarsdale won the Westchester P. G. A. pro-amateur best-ball tournament over the Briar Hall Country Club course today.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 8 (AP) --Maj. John Eisenhower, son of the President, told a news conference today he hoped for an assignment on the East Coast.

PARIS, Sept. 8 -- Nguyen Van Tam, Premier of the Indo-Chinese State of Vietnam, announced here today that he had been instructed by Bao Dai, his Chief of state, to return to Saigon to form a national congress of 200 persons to prepare for the forthcoming negotiations with France on Vietnamese independence.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 (AP) -- The State Department said tonight that it had received a new note from the Czechoslovak Government saying it could not grant amnesty to John Hvasta because his whereabouts still were unknown. The note, a spokesman said, commented that Mr. Hvasta was being considered for a pardon when he "escaped" from prison last year.

Manhattan Borough President Robert F. Wagner Jr., candidate for Mayor in the Democratic primary, called on the Board of Education yesterday to rescind its order raising by four months the age requirement for a kindergarten beginner.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- The thirteenth Chief Justice of the United States, Fred M. Vinson of Louisa, Ky., died of a heart attack early this morning.

DOUGLAS, Isle of Man, Sept. 8 -- The Communist threat to free labor was the theme today of a speech by J. Scott Milne of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, a fraternal delegate from the American Federation of Labor to the British Trades Union Congress, which is holding its annual conference here.

Mayor Impellitteri appointed a committee of four yesterday to study a plea by a union of Sanitation Department workers that their contributions to the city pension fund be cut from 50 to 25 per cent of the cost of the benefits and that the city's share be increased from 50 to 75 per cent.

Inevitably, many of the Labor Day speeches delivered by union leaders emphasized negative aspects of workers' problems today. The growth of living costs, the need for more housing -- these and related matters received much attention in the traditional orations. A man from Mars just arrived and listening to this flood of words might get the impression that the worker's lot in this country is dreadful indeed.
LONDON, Sept. 8 (AP) -- Britain has pledged $22,400,000 this year toward a United Nations program of reconstruction in Korea, it was announced today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- Robert T. Stevens, Secretary of the Army, agreed today to review his department's refusal to give a Senate subcommittee the names of security officials who had approved the employment of three civilians accused of Communist activities.

Where -- the family breadwinner exclaims periodically, and especially around the first of the month -- does the money go ? Business wants -- and needs -- to know the answer to that, too, which is one reason why the Bureau of Business Economics of the United States Department of Commerce collects and publishes from time to time reports on personal consumption expenditures.

Some day something will have to be done about rescuing Dolores from mediocrity. At the moment she is gallantly beating her way through "Carnival in Flanders," which opened at the New Century last evening. She is an intelligent, thoroughly accomplished professional with an agreeable voice that has a lot of resonance and she takes an old-fashioned interest in singing lyrics clearly.

PARIS, Sept. 8 -- The great majority of butchers in the Paris religion made good today their agreement with the Government to lower prices on ordinary cuts of beef and so got the campaign to raise the workers' purchasing power off to a promising start.

PARIS, Sept. 8 -- After four months of negotiation the West German Government has accepted a request by the High Authority of the six-nation European Coal and Steel Community to end a discriminatory freight rate system. The system permitted Ruhr Valley producers to deliver steel cheaper to customers in South Germany than could producers in other member countries.
J. P. Stevens Co., Inc., increased its net profit in the quarter ended last Aug. 1 to. $2,496,467 from $409,516 earned in the similar period last year, despite larger taxes and lower sales volume.

INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 8 (AP) -- Newport Dream won a straight-heat victory in the Horseman Stake for trotters at the Indiana State Fair today and became the top 2-year-old money winner in harness racing history.

Fred M. Vinson enjoyed a note-worthy career in each of the three branches of the Federal Government -- legislative, executive and judicial. In twelve years in the House of Representatives he won wide renown as a tax and fiscal expert.

LIVERPOOL, England, Sept. 8 -- The complete collapse of Britain's southwestern herring fishery was attributed to trans-global movements of sea water along the submarine canyons of the Atlantic at today's meeting of the British Association for the Advancement of Science here.
NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 8 (AP) -- A New York attorney denied today that Louisiana offered equal college facilities to whites and Negroes.

Jay Ehret Mahoney of New York was elected president of the Metropolitan Association of the A. A. U. at the annual meeting held last night at the city clubhouse of the New York A. C. Mahoney succeeds Frank Diamant, who held the post for the past two years.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 (AP) -- Every member of Congress receives questions about the Government from the people back home. Out of this has grown a sixty-eight-page booklet, just published by the Government, answering 291 questions.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- An investigating committee of the House of Representatives decided today to release all its testimony on the way an official of the Eisenhower inaugural committee reportedly had used classified Navy information in an effort to build himself up as a business agent.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 8 -- The possibility that Gov. Earl Warren night be appointed Chief Justice of the United States to succeed Fred M. Vinson was widely accepted today on the West Coast.

The New York State police, in an effort to cut down highway fatalities, arrested 4,101 motorists for traffic violations over the Labor Day week-end, Superintendent Albin Johnson said yesterday at his headquarters in Albany. The rate of arrests exceeded 1,000 a day for the four-day period between 8 A. M. Friday and 8 o'clock yesterday morning.

Communist Rumania apparently hopes to increase her heavy industrial output 20 per cent or more in the next two years despite the new policy of concessions to consumers' needs announced late last month.

James M. Gaines, vice president of WOR-TV, said yesterday that the station was considering closing down for several weeks until its new transmitting antenna had been installed atop the Empire State Building. A decision is expected by tomorrow or Friday, he said.

Robert F. Wagner Jr. declared in a television speech last night that he had received and rejected offers of the Liberal party's nomination for President of the City Council. He declined, he said, because he felt he must make a fight for the Democratic Mayoralty nomination to avert "the nomination of Vincent Impellitteri by default."

The Alabama Gas Corporation announced yesterday that it had received authorization of the Alabama Public Service Commission to increase rates to all classes of customers by 7 1/2 per cent, effective with bills dated Sept. 17. The increase is expected to add $1,550,000 to the company's annual revenues.

JERSEY CITY, Sept. 8 -- Disorderly person charges against 63-year-old Henry (The Dutchman) Grunewald, mystery man of Washington tax case inquiries, and Mrs. Ann Anderson, 46-year-old Catonsville, Md., grandmother, were dismissed today by Magistrate Morris E. Barison in Municipal Court here.

SYRACUSE, Sept. 8 -- The "women's world" at the New York State Fair revolves inside the pillared entrance of the Harriet May Mills Memorial Building, which has been visited by an estimated 80,000 persons since the fair opened Saturday.

Advertisers are changing agencies at a faster rate than heretofore, according to the results of a study released yesterday by the Sales Executives Club of New York. For example, the survey showed, 34.3 per cent of the 101 companies studied switched agencies in the last three years while only 32.6 per cent changed in the proceeding seven years.
FARNBOROUGH, England, Sept. 8 (UP) -- A helicopter crashed at the big British air show here today.
Six new courses are included in the Special Education Program of the Mannes College of Music for the 1953-54 season starting Oct. 1, it has been announced by Dr. Felix Salzer, executive director.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 (AP) -- The Civil Service Commission today announced a new series of steps in its campaign to find new jobs for career Government workers who have been laid off for reasons of economy.
Last week's hot weather brought about a 23 per cent decline of sales in New York and Brooklyn department stores, according to the preliminary report released yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 (AP) -- A top television expert predicted today that color video would be available "for the millions" in three or four years, but hardly sooner.

LONDON, Sept. 8 -- Trade officials of the nine Commonwealth countries will meet in London tomorrow to iron out some of the differences that separate their Governments on the future development of their international trade policies.

CHICAGO, Sept. 8 (AP) -- Traders in live hogs found themselves coping with the largest supply for any day since March 10 today. It represented the accumulation over the long holiday week-end but required price cuts of 25 and 50 cents a hundred pounds before good clearance was obtained.
Permit me a few words on your editorial "The Mayor's Guarantee" and only as to that portion of the editorial which refers to the 10-cent fare as a "deficit-breeding low fare."

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 8 -- In the General Assembly chamber here tonight, the rostrum customarily reserved for speech-making served as a stage for a group of famous entertainers. The occasion was the closing feature of the United Nations first "staff day," at which the organization played host to its personnel.

WASHINGTON Sept. 8 -- Harold E. Stassen, Director of Foreign Operations, predicted today that Western Europe would need little or no economic aid after next June 30 if recovery continued at the present rate.

Volume was extremely light yesterday on the New York commodity exchanges with many items registering the smallest activity in some time. Rubber was the only exception, having the largest volume of the year. Prices closed higher with cocoa, zinc, copper, lead, tin, and hides up.

WESTBURY, L. I., Sept. 8 -- Adam Frisco, a 4-year-old brown horse owned by Albert F. H. Gutzmann of Waverly, Mass., and driven by Jimmy Jordan, came up on the outside to win the Pennsylvanian, a mile-and-a-sixteenth pace at Roosevelt Raceway tonight.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- Arthur E. Summerfield, the Postmaster General, announced today an experimental plan to send by airplane the bulk, and possibly all, of the "preferential mail" between New York and Chicago, and between Washington and Chicago.

CHICAGO, Sept. 8 -- Chemical specifics have mitigated the ravages of influenza, poliomyelitis and other virus diseases in animals and have effected cures in a few instances, the American Chemical Society was told today.

Maj. Gen. Edward C. Rose, swinging into his duties as New Jersey member of the bi-state commission appointed to clean up the crime-befouled Port of New York, estimated yesterday -- with a grin -- that it would take 999 years to drive rackets from the water-front.

CHICAGO, Sept. 8 -- The board of directors of Texas Illinois Natural Gas Pipeline Company at the regular quarterly meeting today declared a dividend of 25 cents a share on the common stock, payable on Sept. 23 to stockholders of record on Sept. 15.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 8 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold warned today that the coming months might bring even more acute personnel problems to the United Nations staff, which was shaken by the recent dismissals of United States employes on loyalty counts.
Vice President Richard M. Nixon, former President Truman and Governor Dewey voiced tributes to Mr. Vinson.

Paul Keres, Estonian grandmaster at chess, who has twice held the Soviet championship, last night took the lead in the world championship challengers' tournament at Neuhausen, Switzerland, according to a report from Zurich.

Rafael Buscaglia has resigned as president of the Government Development Bank for Puerto Rico and as chairman of the bank's board because of a stalemate in matters of policy governing appointments to the bank's directorate.
New York University seems to be engaged in a land grab. It shows every evidence of making an intensive effort to take over Washington Square, an ancient public park, as its private campus.
The most discussed development in fresh meat merchandising in the last five years has been the marked trend toward self-service sale of pre-packaged items.
ANYONE who doesn't think that work can be wonderful is hereby referred to two medium-sized, middle-aged men and a trim young woman.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 8 -- India has withdrawn her candidacy for a seat in the United Nations Security Council to succeed Pakistan. This decision, which apparently was taken to further the candidacy of Mme. Vijaya Lakshmi Pandit, sister of India's Prime Minister, for president of the General Assembly, probably means that New Zealand, the only other avowed candidate, will be elected to the British Commonwealth seat in the Council without opposition.
ST. LOUIS, Sept 8 -- Gov. Phil M. Donnelly took "under advisement" the formal request today of Mayor Raymond R. Tucker for a special legislative session to extend the St. Louis earnings tax.

Two armed men, thwarted less than an hour earlier in the attempted robbery of a home in South Orange, N. J., engaged in a twenty-eight-shot pistol battle with Port Authority policemen in the Lincoln Tunnel shortly after noon yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- The United Brotherhood of Carpenters and Joiners of America returned to the American Federation of Labor today, less than a month after severing relations. The carpenters union, with more than 800,000 members, is the Federation's second largest affiliate, exceeded in size only by the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, Chauffeurs, Warehousemen and Helpers of America.

LAUSANNE, Switzerland, Sept. 8 (AP) -- Avery Brundage, president of the International Olympic Committee, said today that a proposal to combine the equestrian events of the 1956 Olympic Games with the Winter Games might be the solution to an "impasse" in which the committee had found itself.

MADISON, Wis., Sept. 8 -- The finding that plants can absorb dew water through their leaves and store it underground for use as needed was reported today at the meeting of the American Institute of Biological Sciences at the University of Wisconsin.
NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 8 -- The Indian Government issued a statement today correcting an impression current in this country that Israel was denying citizenship to Indian Jews because of their color.

NEWARK, Sept. 8 -- Clendenin J. Ryan, independent candidate for Governor, said today that his financial responsibility in the Harold J. Adonis case had ended with the latter's return from the Netherlands "as a free citizen and not under extradition" and his release on bail.
There was Swiss chard for dinner last night, and plenty for the neighbors, too, around Thomas Jefferson Playground, 114th Street and Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive.

For the first time in more than a year the steel industry's operating rate is scheduled to go below the 90 per cent level this week. The Labor Day holiday and a strike at one of the major mills are principally responsible for the 88.7 per cent rate expected to be established.
A 14-year-old newsboy from Eugene, Ore., Teddy Lee Berg, saved up $850 last spring and sailed on his own to Sweden, where he bicycled around the country until he came upon King Gustav Adolf VI.
PARIS, Sept. 8 (UP) -- Attorneys for Rita Hayworth and Aly Khan announced today they had reached agreement on a $1,000,000 divorce settlement.

The pre-primary campaign drags into its final week with the voting public in New York City showing what one political observer calls, with understatement, "a seeming lack of interest in the outcome" of next Tuesday's election. The major question appears to be whether the electorate will not be bored to death before it can visit the polls.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was quiet yesterday; prices fell 4 to 8 points.

The sanguinary feud between some Southern soft coal operators and the United Mine Workers of America, described in reports to this paper by Joseph A. Loftus, is reminiscent of similar clashes in the even more bloody Twenties and Thirties. Then, as now, the union claimed to represent the miners for collective bargaining purposes, but the operators demurred.
In her fall and winter collection of custom order designs, shown yesterday at 42 East Forty-ninth Street, Hattie Carnegie again proved herself a master at creating beautiful clothes.

The fall fashion season in New York got fully under way yesterday when leading couturiers gave their interpretation of the new modes. Bergdorf Goodman, whose fifty-second presentation took place under the direction of Miss Ethel Frankau, showed clothes on the conservative side.
BONN, Germany, Sept. 8 (AP) -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer predicted today that the European Defence Community would come into existence before the end of this year.
This is in reference to Hanson Baldwin's stimulating column of Sept. 3 on morale in the armed services.
CHICAGO, Sept. 8 (UP) -- Rogers Hornsby testified today that his secretary was depressed by a fear of going blind, and a coroner's jury ruled her death plunge early yesterday was suicide.

Charles Pascal Franchot, lawyer and industrialist, was found dead of a rifle shot yesterday in his apartment in the Bedford Hotel, 118 East Fortieth Street. The police said Mr. Franchot, senior member of the law firm of Franchot, Corwin Dessner, apparently had committed suicide. No notes were found.

A group of parents who, on Aug. 26, obtained gamma globulin for their children at Donald Court, summer colony at Far Rockaway, Queens, after camping for twenty-seven hours in the Health Department headquarters at 125 Worth Street, gave blood yesterday to replace some of the gamma globulin they had taken.
LONDON, Sept. 8 -- The stock markets maintained a firm undertone today, although business shrank and buying was selective.

ROCQUENCOURT, France, Sept. 8 -- One gradual accomplishment of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and its Supreme Headquarters, Allied Powers Europe, has been the trend toward standardizing the organizational patterns of the various armed forces unified in the coalition.

PARIS, Sept. 8 -- The striking success of Chancellor Konrad Adenauer in the West German elections is regarded by qualified observers here as presenting to the French an acute dilemma in foreign policy, which has been almost forgotten while the Cabinet has been absorbed in trying to save the French economy.

Two British officials -- one from the Home Office and the other from Scotland Yard -- began here yesterday an international study of the prostitution problem, which in recent years has become "an increasing nuisance" in London.

TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Sept. 8 (UP) -- A suit threatening Florida's million-dollar scholarship fund, which is derived from race track betting and which has helped the University of Florida to develop one of the nation's top football teams, was argued before the State Supreme Court today.

Installtion of mechanical massage equipment by industrial concerns and department stores has brought astounding results in reducing employe fatigue and chronic absenteeism, and in helping employe well-being, Owen K. Murphy, president of the Niagara Manufacturing and Distributing Company of Adamsville, Pa., declared recently.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 8 -- The widespread notion that Americans are a people "readily springing to arms" in war is a myth that tends to prevent a proper adjustment to military service, the American Psychological Association was told today at its sixty-first annual convention.
ALBANY, Sept. 8 (AP) -- If Governor Dewey is appointed to the Supreme Court vacancy, as some observers believe, Arthur H. Wicks will be in line to fill out the Governor's term.

The 8,000,000th Plymouth automobile came off the assembly line yesterday at the company's main plant in Detroit, twenty-five years and three months since the first one was manufactured in 1928, it was announced here by William J. Bird, general sales manager, Plymouth division, Chrysler Corporation.

TEHERAN, Iran, Sept. 8 -- Anatoli I. Laverentiev, Soviet Ambassador to Iran, received today an official of the Iranian Foreign Ministry and complained officially of press reports that he had attempted to commit suicide.
Preparations for the International Lifeboat Race scheduled for Saturday on the Hudson River have bogged down in a sea of complications.

DENVER, Sept. 8 -- President Eisenhower proclaimed today thirty days of mourning for Chief Justice Fred M. Vinson, decreeing that the national flag should be flown at half staff during that period on all Government buildings at home and abroad.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture today forecast this year's cotton crop at 15,159,000 bales, a level that would create a surplus and require a grower referendum on production controls for the 1954 crop.

TOKYO, Wednesday, Sept. 9 -- The United Nations demanded today that the Communists account for 3,404 Allied personnel, including 944 Americans, believed to have been captured by the foe during the Korean war but not yet returned.

CHICAGO, Sept. 8 -- Plans for the construction of a new fluid catalytic hydroforming unit were announced today by Standard Oil Company of Indiana. The complex device, 200 feet high and designed to convert low octane naphtha into high octane material, will be installed at the Whiting (Ind.) refinery.
WASHINGTON, Sept 8 (AP) -- The Justice Department said today the State of Arkansas had no legal right to challenge the constitutionality of the offshore oil act passed by Congress this year.

Coat and suit silhouettes that illustrated the recently reported European trends were presented yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel by Harry Prechtel in cooperation with Loyd Taylor. Included in the fashions available at the store was a collection of designs by Schiaparelli for Frechtel as well as adaptations from Dior, Balenciaga, Fath and de Givenchy.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 (UP) -- Haiti was admitted to membership in the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development and the International Monetary Fund today on the eve of the eighth annual meeting of the two financial organizations.
LAS VEGAS, Nev., Sept. 8 (UP) -- The $6,000,000 Las Vegas race track announced tonight it was suepending operations until Sept. 26 to permit installation of new wagering equipment.

A three - day, fourteen - county civil defense exercise, described yesterday by the Office of Civil Defense here as the "greatest" yet scheduled for this country, will begin on Sept. 23 and include a full-scale public participation test in New York on Sept. 25.

The Swedish Lloyd passenger liner Patricia, the newest and largest ship in the company's Sweden-to-Great Britain service, will make a series of seven special winter cruises from here, according to the A. T. Henderson Company, general agent for the voyages. It will be the liner's first visit to this port.

Timely Reward made a determined closing rush in the Classified Handicap that served as the feature race at Aqueduct yesterday, and the rush was good enough to earn the victory. Al Widman guided the 5-year-old horse owned by Mrs. Sydelle Kissel to victory in the mile and a sixteenth event -- the Royal Minstrel -- before a crowd of 17,544.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Sept. 8 (AP) -- United States Judge H. Church Ford overruled today a motion to dismiss a Federal indictment charging thirty-six members of the United Mine Workers Union with conspiracy. The true bill, returned last May 1, accused the uniform men of conspiring to deny certain citizens the right to refrain from joining a union.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, is planning to go regularly on television beginning in January. He will appear on a weekly fifteen-minute privately sponsored "commentary" in which he will feature attacks on the Democrats.

Slightly shaken by Hurricane Carol, 5,880 passengers debarked from seventeen ships here yesterday. Although the heavy seas delayed many of the vessels, no damage was reported, nor were any passengers injured.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- The foreign secretaries of Australia and New Zealand called today on John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, for preliminary talks on the two-day ANZUS (Australia, New Zealand and United States) Council meeting opening tomorrow.

ROME, Sept. 8 -- Progress in determining the chemical structure of the new antibiotic named magnamycin was reported here today at the Sixth International Congress of Microbiology by Alexander C. Finlay and Dr. Peter P. Regna of the Charles Pfizer Research Laboratories in New York.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Sept. 8 (UP) -- The Federal Government Council moved today to prevent thousands of Uruguayan boxing fans from crossing the river Plate into Argentina to see their countryman, Dagomar Martinez, fight Archie Moore of St. Louis, world light heavyweight champion, in Buenos Aires Saturday.
PRINCETON, N. J., Sept. 8 -- Forty scholars from fourteen Moslem nations met here today with thirty-one American scholars for the opening session of a twelve-day conference on Islamic culture.

ROME, Sept. 8 -- The Roman Catholic Church places no limitations upon and raises no barriers against scientific research and quest after truth in general, Pope Pius said in a speech he delivered at his summer residence of Castel Gandolfo yesterday to a large group of geneticists from many countries. The text was made public today.

TEHERAN, Iran, Sept. 8 -- Dr. Mohammed Mossadegh, former Premier of Iran, who was ousted and jailed in the mid-August popular uprising, underwent the third day of questioning today on his alleged crimes against the state. The hearing is being conducted by a military magistrate empowered to recommend the death penalty.

Rudolf Bing, general manager of the Metropolitan Opera Company, who returned yesterday aboard the Ile de France from a three-month business-pleasure trip to Europe, said that his observations of the European opera scene had convinced him that "what we are badly in need of is a Marshall Plan for the Metropolitan."
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 8 -- Juvenile delinquency has been growing at an alarming rate in this country, Mrs. Oveta Culp Hobby, Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, said here tonight.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- Crown Prince Akihito of Japan was received in state ceremonies today upon his arrival here for the beginning of a month's tour of the United States. The slender, grave-featured young man, heir apparent to the world's oldest throne, was greeted at the Military Air Transport Service terminal by Secretary of State John Foster Dulles as a military honor guard stood at attention.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 8 (AP) -- Harold Johnson of Philadelphia won a ten-round split decision over Ezzard Charles, the former heavyweight champion, in a bruising, action-packed fight at Connie Mack Stadium tonight. Johnson a 2-1 short-ender, weighed 177 pounds and Charles scaled 185 1/2.

Shortly before midnight yesterday the Appellate Division confirmed the right of Chauncey M. Hooper, a running mate of Mayor Impellitteri in the Democratic primary, to a place on next Tuesday's ballot. The court's unanimous action reversed the decision earlier yesterday by Supreme Court Justice S. Samuel Di Falco to disqualify the Negro candidate for Borough President of Manhattan, on the ground that he now lives outside the city.

LONDON, Sept. 8 -- The British Broadcasting Corporation warned today that its financial reserves would be exhausted by the end of March, 1955, if its income from the licensing of radio and television receivers was not increased.

ALBANY, Sept. 8 -- The State Health Department announced today plans to expand its six-year-old program of tuberculosis detection to include a search for cases of lung cancer that could be spotted early enough to benefit the patient.

Chief Justices of the United States are rarer in our history than Presidents. Fred M. Vinson was the thirteenth. His passing, as was the case with each of his predecessors, is a constitutional landmark -- a point of departure from which the Court is certain, more or less perceptibly, to alter its course.

Rudolph Halley, President of the City Council and Liberal party candidate for Mayor, was prepared to vote in favor of leasing the city's transit system to the new Transit Authority if his votes in the Board of Estimate were needed to make the transfer effective, Mayor Impellitteri declared last night in a television address.

SAIGON, Vietnam, Sept. 8 -- Vietnamese nationalists here took a defiant attutude today to Premier Nguyen Van Tam and said they would not cooperate with him when he arrived in Saigon from Paris to organize a new national congress.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 8 (AP) -- The Athletics today called up the first Negro player to perform for a Philadelphia major league club, and announced that the big pitcher, Bob Trice from their Ottawa farm in the International League, would get a starting chance Sunday against the Browns.
TIMONIUM, Md., Sept. 8 (AP) -- A l0-year-old gelding who in his prime won stakes from New York to California, then ended up in a riding academy, is staging an amazing comeback at Timonium race track.
BOSTON, Sept. 8 (AP) -- A dramatic story of rescue at sea was told today when Malcolm S. Forbes, New Jersey Senator, was landed at Constitution Base by the Coast Guard cutter Evergreen.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- In its seven years under Chief Justice Fred M. Vinson the Supreme Court handed down decisions in 758 cases. However, this period will be recorded in the annals of jurisprudence not so much in terms of quantity of work as for a number of major issues resolved.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 18 -- The Yugoslav Parliament went through the procedure today of debating an electoral law for the national elections next November. One of its outstanding features is the provision for a council of Producers as one of the two parliamentary bodies.

THE weather man whistled up a wind that tossed the waves to close the Labor Day holiday, but the "ill wind" theory paid off for surfcasters, especially along the New Jersey coast, for the big striped bass moved in near the beach and took assorted lures with abandon.

" Under Strange Skies," a collection of reflections by Harry Simonhoff about Jewish groups in foreign lands, will be published by Philosophical Library next Tuesday. The data were collected by the author in travels through thirty-six lands, and the volume describes the past and present of the peoples and their acceptance or rejection by their environments.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- The choice of the fourteenth Chief Justice of the United States will depend in large measure on the test President Eisenhower applies to the various possible appointees.

Four alleged members of a five- man burglary gang found themselves in further difficulty with the law yesterday when Chief Magistrate John M. Murtagh cracked down on them as multiple traffic violators.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 9 (AP) -- Vice President Moshe Pijade said in an official report tonight that Communist Yugoslavia arrested 171,731 persons, many "without reason," on criminal and political charges in the five-year period of 1948-52.

The Government moved yesterday to punish Robert G. Thompson, one of the eleven convicted Communist leaders, for contempt for failure to surrender in 1951 to begin his three-year sentence for conspiracy.

A timely variation on the old French larding needle is the Flavor Maker. We say timely, because this new cooking tool is excellent for introducing fat and seasonings into the pot roasts that will be cut in the fall from seasonally abundant, lean, lower-quality beef.

This is, of course, the time for making good resolutions. It is not the only time, to be sure, for there also is New Year's, but the ending of vacation is one of the most satisfactory occasions on which to start life anew.
CHICAGO, Sept. 9 (AP) -- The American League soon will study a list of seven cities that Bill Veeck says have proposed to take over the St. Louis Browns' franchise.

The two gunmen who fought a pistol battle with Port Authority police in Lincoln Tunnel on Tuesday were identified yesterday as New York desperados with long criminal records. They now face possible life imprisonment as fourth offenders, but one of them is near death from his wounds.

Howard Greer, in presenting his fall designs yesterday at Jay Thorpe, based his entire collection on one theme -- the allure of the feminine figure. He cut his silhouettes stalk-slim, following every curve, and centered the attention on the bosom and handsome decolletages.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- Increased confidence in the business future was reflected in heavy outlays planned for plant and equipment by American industry this year, according to a report today by the Commerce Department and the Securities and Exchange Commission.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- The Eisenhower Administration affirmed today full United States support of the objectives of the International Monetary Fund and the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development in the first joint session this morning of the eighth annual meeting of the two institutions.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept. 9 -Joao Cleofas, the Brazilian Minister of Agriculture, placed in President Getulio Vargas' hands last night an agrarian reform bill to be sent to Congress. It calls for expropriation of fertile lands suitable for agriculture and which the owners have neglected to cultivate.

Today's new film is "Return To Paradise," starring Gary Cooper, at Loew's State. Barry Jones, Roberta Haynes, Moira MacDonald and John Hudson head the supporting cast of the Aspen Pictures Production. Charles Kaufman wrote the screen play, basing it upon a romantic story from the James A. Michener book.
CAIRO, Sept. 9 (AP) -- Young ex-Queen Narriman filed suit for divorce today from exiled former Kink Farouk.

ROME, Sept. 9 -- The Pope is in good health, and the fact that he gives pilgrims and other visitors his left hand to kiss instead of his right is not due to any infirmity but to a minor incident of which he was the victim several days ago in his summer residence of Castel Gandolfo, the Vatican said today.

BLOOMFIELD, N. J., Sept. 9 -- The amateurs almost stole the show from the pros in today's qualifying round of the annual New Jersey pro-amateur golf championship over the Forest Hill Field Club course.
The City of St. Louis borrowed $18,912,000 In the public market yesterday on serial bonds having an average life of less than five and one-half years at an interest cost of 2.016 per cent.
It was with great interest that I read in the Sept. 1 issue of THE TIMES a report on the speech made by Mrs. Oveta Culp Hobby before the American Hospital Association.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 (AP) -Gen. Lemuel C. Shepherd Jr., Marine Corps Commandant, disclosed today that production had started on the world's largest and fastest helicopter, capable of carrying twenty-six fully equipped Marines.

A four-story private dwelling on lot 17 by 100 feet at 172 West Ninety-fourth Street has been sold by Mrs. Julia Fischer to the M. C. Berg Realty Company, Abraham Schutz, president, in a deal negotiated by Abbott Adams, brokers.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 (AP) -- Mickey Vernon's double high off the right-field fence with one out in the twelfth inning scored Eddie Yost from first base to give the Senators a 2 -- 1 victory over the Browns in the second contest of a doubleheader tonight.

The Board of Higher Education announced yesterday the addition of three fact-finders to its special committee appointed in June to investigate subversiveness. All are specialists in investigative fields.

DOUGLAS, Isle of Man, Sept. 9 -- Britain's Trades Union Congress, representing 8,000,000 workers who comprise a vast majority of the socialist Labor party, decided today at its annual conference to support a go slow policy on further nationalization of British industry.

The New Curiosity Shop, devoted to gifts and decorative household objects new and old, opened yesterday at 9 West Eighth Street with new items garnered from many lands and old ones from many Northeastern states.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 9 -- The United Nations was told today by its own commission in Korea that the burden of protecting the Republic of Korea during the armistice period would have to be carried internationally.

NEWARK, Sept. 9 -- Three hundred production employes of the Kidde Manufacturing Company, Inc., and its affiliate, the Bloomfield Tool Corporation, both of Bloomfield, returned to work today after they had affirmed terms of a settlement of a strike in both plants that started July 27.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 (AP) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today was asked to permit an inspection of the ballots which it recently collected on the proposed reorganization of Wisconsin Central Railway.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- The body of Fred M. Vinson, thirteenth Chief Justice of the United States, lay in state today in the unpretentious surroundings of a Washington funeral establish ment and many hundreds filed past the open bier to pay silent last respects.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- The United States, Australia and New Zealand pledged themselves anew today to vigilance against the Communist peril and to the maintenance of peace in the Pacific.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 9 -- Pakistan, which opposed a United Nations invitation to India to participate in the political conference on Korea, has decided to support India's campaign to win the presidency of the United Nations General Assembly for Mme. Vijaya Laksmi Pandit.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- The American Red Cross announced today plans for a new program to help bolster the morale of service men who must remain in Korea during the post-armistice period.
New American tariff and trade policy must be made consistent with two major objectives of national security, members of a chemical industry group were told yesterday.

CHICAGO, Sept. 9 (AP) -- Ralph Kiner's three-run homer in the ninth inning, his thirty-first circuit drive of the season, carried the Cubs to an 8-7 victory over the Pirates before the smallest Wrigley Field crowd of the season, 2,319 paid.

A New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program citation was presented yesterday to the aircraft carrier Antietam at the New York Naval Shipyard, Brooklyn, because its officers and crew contributed 1,063 pints of blood to the program last week. Dr. William M. Markel, the program's administrator, handed the citation to Capt. S. M. Pickering, commander of the ship, aboard the vessel.

WASHINGTON, July 1 (AP) -- A Pan American World Airways executive said today that carrier should be permitted to fly to the Orient by the most direct route and not be required to fly more than 2,000 miles out of the way to "featherbed Northwest Airlines at a price of millions of dollars to the taxpayers."
The Department of Justice's round-up of aliens with criminal records reached out yesterday to corral a man whose name evoked echoes of the pre-World War I gangs of New York -- Martin Aloysius Madden.

Most of the candidates for party nominations for Mayor have agreed to participate Sunday night in a discussion of city issues over WABD-TV, Channel 5, the Du Mont Television Network announced last night. The program will run from 8 to 9 o'clock, with each candidate receiving time for a presentation of his views and, later, an opportunity for rebuttal.

TEHERAN, Iran, Sept. 9 -- The first installment, $5,300,000, of the emergency financial aid from the United States, was received today as the Iranian Finance Minister revealed that most of $45,000,000 grant must be used to meet the budget deficit, with little left for economic development work.

ATHENS, Sept. 9 -- At the request of the American Red Cross, the Greek Government published data today on the earthquake damage sustained by the Ionian islands of Cephalonia and Zante, making it clear that a detailed assessment was still impossible because of disrupted communications.

CHARLESTON, S. C., Sept. 9 (UP) -- Federal-judge delayed a decision today on the issue of education for children of a "third race" in South Carolina, where whites and Negroes already were in conflict over segregated schools.
New Yorkers spend $332,000,000 a year for furniture, or 24 per cent more than Chicago and Los Angeles combined, according to a brochure published yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES.

SYRACUSE, Sept. 9 -- Mrs. Ivy Baker Priest, Treasurer of the United States, declared tonight that world conditions had imposed upon women a challenge to be a powerful force "helping to preserve lives and our way of life."

A split that may carry 50,000 members out of the United Packinghouse Workers, C.I.O., has prompted Walter P. Reuther, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, to call a conference of union leaders and insurgents in his Detroit offices today.

Five injuries and the squad's first scrimmage marked pre-season football practice at Fordham yesterday. Quarterbacks Roger Franz and Vin Drake suffered leg injuries in a morning pass defense drill and the afternoon scrimmage re-suited in injuries to Quarterback George Murphy, End John Benczkowski and Fullback Charlie Dietlin.

Children who will make their first appearance as pupils in the public schools of the city Monday got a preview of things to come yesterday when they were registered for the big day. Ac companied in most cases by their mothers, they seemed impressed with the complicated procedure.

Dick Chapman of Pinehurst, N. C., United States Walker Cup star, three members of the British Walker Cup squad and seven other qualifiers withdrew yesterday from the fifty-third national amateur golf championship which will start Monday at the Oklahoma City Golf and Country Club.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 9 -Mark Robson has been signed to direct the film version of James A. Michener's novel, "The Bridges at Toko-Ri." Paramount is moving fast to get the story of carrierbased jet fighters over Korea into production by Nov. 15, with William Holden as the star.

SEOUL, Korea, Thursday, Sept. 10 (AP) -- The Polish delegate to the Neutral Nations Supervisory Commission charged at Panmunjom today that Hajdukiewicz had been "kidnapped" by the United States Army and said a strong protest would be lodged.

Moved by the protests of business, real estate, tenant and civic groups who asked for more time to study the project, the City Planning Commission decided yesterday to continue to Oct. 14 a public hearing on the Washington Square Southeast slum-clearance, low-cost housing redevelopment plan of the Mayor's Committee on Slum Clearance.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 9 -- Society's attitudes toward growing old probably cause more mental illness than the process of aging itself, the delegates at the sixty-first annual convention of the American Psychological Association were told here today.

Gustavus A. Pfeiffer, retired drug man, who died Aug. 22 at the age of 81, left four-fifths of his residuary estate to the Gustavus and Louise Pfeiffer Research Foundation, which he and his wife established in 1942 for improving the public health through the advancement of medicine and pharmacy. Mr. Pfeiffer's will was filed for probate yesterday in Surrogate's Court.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 (AP) -- The Association of American Railroads today estimated the net income of Class I carriers for July at $71,000,000, compared with $39,000,000 in the same month of 1952. The report noted that earnings were adversely affected in July of last year by a steel strike.
An electronic calculator, used for the first time to analyze retail selling trends, indicates that the seasonal buying patterns in 1954 will parallel those of 1952 with only slight variations.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 (UP) -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon today awarded posthumously the Medal of Honor to the next of kin of five Marine heroes in a full-dress ceremony at the Marine Corps barracks here.

Walter Winchell, commentator, testified yesterday that before writing a series of articles last year questioning the anti-communism of James A. Wechsler, editor of The New York Post, he conducted an investigation into the facts but did not find out about, or could not recall, a number of articles by and about Mr. Wechsler, which the latter's counsel introduced as evidence of genuine anti-communism.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Sept. 2, the Federal Reserve Board announced today.

Smelter shipments of slab zinc dropped last month for the fourth consecutive month -- and the August level was the lowest since July last year, when the steel strike sharply reduced consumption of zinc for galvanizing purposes.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Sept. 9 (UP) -- Discovery of a 200-pound stone bearing the date 1688, a time when the French and English were struggling for possession of the Hudson Bay area, was announced today by the Minnesota Historical Society.

The group of six nine-story apartment buildings known as Flagg Court, in the Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn, figured in a deal yesterday by Murray Adler, broker, representing the investing syndicate which has acquired the property.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- A "restricted" Army document that he described as "the best Communist propaganda I've seen in some time" was made public today by Senator Joseph R. McCarthy with a demand that those responsible for it be disclosed.

TORONTO, Sept. 9 -- Alcohol is likely to have a greater effect on stout persons than on thin persons, and fat persons are therefore more dangerous when driving after drinking than thin persons, the delegates to the Second International Conference on Alcohol and Road Traffic were told here today.

The Yankees, back from their tour of six cities, battered their way forward for another full stride to their coveted fifth straight pennant at the Stadium last night as they crushed the White Sox, 9 to 3, in the opener of a two-game series before a roaring homecoming crowd of 34,691.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 9 -- Automotive manufacturers must build less competitive speed and more safety into cars to avert ghastly increases in highway accidents, delegates were told today at the opening session of the fifty-first meeting of the American Automobile Association here.

PARIS, Sept. 9 -- The Government stepped up its offensive against widespread tax fraud by announcing today that inspectors from the Ministry of Finance were now checking on persons who display great wealth in their daily living but poverty on their income tax returns.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., Sept. 9 -- Governor Dewey declared tonight that the leaders of New York City's Democratic Administration were a "collection of political incompetents" whose only solution for the city's financial ills had consisted of "demagoguery."
BOSTON, Sept. 9 (AP) -- Al Rosen's fortieth homer of the season -- a two-run affair in the eighth inning -- tonight gave the hard driving Indians a 2-1 victory over the Red Sox.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 9 -- Lefty Dave Koslo went all the way for the first time this season, hurling the Giants to an 8-3 triumph over the Cardinals before 7,487 fans at Busch Stadium tonight.
Miles F. McDonald, Kings County District Attorney, praised Mayor Impellitteri in a television address last night as a "strong ally" in the fight against corruption in the City of New York.

MADISON, Wis., Sept. 9 -- A new study of more than 2,000 growths of corn in Mexico has uncovered a number of native types that promise to provide for United States farmers hybrid corn more productive and more resistant to drought, disease and insects, the meeting of the American Institute of Biological Sciences heard here today.
TORONTO, Sept. 9 -- The Ontario Securities Commission canceled today the brokerage license of the firm of Picard Fleming, members of the Toronto Stock Exchange.

Trading in burlap futures was initiated yesterday on the New York Commodity Exchange, Inc. During the session, thirty-three contracts of 50,000 yards changed hands. Speculators sold short and local dealers were the best buyers. Bids ranged from 10.95 cents a yard on 40 inch 10 ounce burlap for delivery in August, 1954, to 11.7 cents for delivery this November.

Plagued by a series of labor conflicts, the on-again-off-again construction of the ramp to siphon eastbound vehicles directly from the George Washington Bridge to the southbound lanes of the Henry Hudson Parkway will resume again today.

The Most Rev. Fulton J. Sheen, Auxiliary Bishop of New York and national director of the Society for the Propagation of the Faith, will speak at a series of Roman Catholic religious rallies to be held in and around New York beginning Sunday, Sept. 20.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Sept. 9 -- Manhasset Bay Yacht Club had blight, sparkling weather but only a whisper of wind today for the opening regatta of its twenty-first annual fall race series. As a result of these conditions, darkness had long since fallen when the straggling finishers of a starting fleet that numbered 199 craft ghosted back to port.

New issues of corporate securities totaling more than $39,000,000 will be offered to investors today. Among the offerings are debentures of a finance company, and convertible debentures and common stock of public utility companies. The new issues are as follows:

BERLIN, Sept. 9 -- Despite the surprising extent of the victory of Dr. Konrad Adenauer in the West German elections Sunday, with a consequent strengthening of his policy of European integration, there is no sign that the Communists are going to change their "new course" policy in East Germany.

BELLEVILLE, Ill., Sept. 9 (AP) -The Belleville draft board reoorted today that Wilmer (Vinegar Bend) Mizell, southpaw hurler fo:' the Cardinals, had keen L rantsd a draft deferment. 1Kizell said he had requested the po3tponernent until the baseball season end3. !el Isaid he pected to be inducted: next month.
Samuel Reshevsky of New York last night gained the lead in the world chess championship challenger's tournament in Neubausen, Switzerland, according to a report from Zurich.

We are indebted to A. A. Berle Jr., stats chairman of the Liberal party, for a revealing insight into the devious thinking that precedes a vote by Council President Rudolph Halley in the Board of Estimate on a matter vital to the welfare of the people of New York and the fiscal soundness of the city government.

BERLIN, Sept. 9 (AP) -- The Berlin Neue Zeitung, newspaper of the United States High Commissioner's office, reported today that an East German housewife had killed a Communist policeman with the two-pound can of lard from the Western food parcel he was trying to take away from her.
CHICAGO, Sept. 9 (UP) -- Former President Harry S. Truman and Adlai E. Stevenson will meet here Sunday for the first time since Mr. Stevenson's world tour, it was announced today.

Indian File sped through on the inside to win the $12,925 Babylon Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday. The victory came as more than a mild surprise to the 17,519 spectators, for all pre-race calculations indicated that the six-furlong stakes would be a duel between the Wheatley Stable's Quick Lunch and the Greentree Stable's Gotta Go.

Washington, Sept. 9 -- How an official of the Eisenhower Inaugural Committee tried to parlay bluff, misrepresentation and braggadocio into an ambitious "four percenter" enterprise in the new Administration was disclosed today in the official record of the House of Representatives.

Staff members of Cumberland Hospital in Brooklyn beamed on their new out-patient department yesterday as Mayor Impellitteri dedicated the $1,082,000 project at a ceremony on the grounds at Auburn Place and North Portland Avenue.

NEWARK, Sept. 9 -- A bench warrant for the arrest of Thomas H. Bloom, 57-year-old ex-convict of Paterson and a major witness in the New Jersey Law Enforcement Council's hearings into collections by police associations, was issued this morning by Chief Magistrate Harry A. Pine when Bloom failed to appear for trial.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- The Treasury Department disclosed today that 96 1/2 per cent of the $7,986,000,000 in obligations maturing on Sept. 15 have been exchanged for new one-year 2 5/8 per cent and three and one-half year 2 7/8 per cent Treasury obligations.

CHICAGO, Sept. 9 -- If junior refuses to eat his dish of oatmeal, that is no reason for dad to get into an uproad. Chemists have found other uses for oatmeal besides eating it, and a team of researchers reported today that new compounds derived from oatmeal had relieved ulcer pains in animals.
The sixty-fifth National Horse Show, listed for Nov. 3 to 10 at Madison Square Garden, will present a total of 125 events, including twenty-one championships worth $31,352 in prizes.
I wish to voice my protest against the mounting opposition to veterans' free use of Veterans Hospital facilities.

TOKYO, Thursday, Sept. 10 -The Japanese Government delivered yesterday a stern note to the South Korean diplomatic mission here protesting the Republic of Korea's decision to oust Japanese boats from the rich fishing grounds coast.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Sept. 9 -- A Foreign Ministry spokesman in Jerusalem today charged the Government of Jordan with spreading false rumors about the massing of Israel troops in the Jerusalem area to propagandize for aid from other Arab countries in strengthening Jordan's national guard, a civilian volunteer defense organization.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Sept. 9 -- The Hebrew calendar year 5714, calculated from the date of creation, and the Mohammedan year 1373, reckoned from the day following Mohammed's flight from Mecca to Medina, began by coincidence simultaneously at sunset this evening.
Emily Wilkens has a fashion idiom all her own. This was evidenced in a collection she has designed for Bonwit Teller, presented yesterday on the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 9 -- In an attempt "to carry out the dietary doctrines of General Peron," the Ministry of Public Health announced tonight that this traditional land of beefeaters would celebrate a "fish week" beginning tomorrow.

BONN, Germany, Sept. 9 -- Chancellor' Konrad Adenauer issued a peremptory statement this morning through the Federal Press Office calling to order his lieutenants and political allies who since the elections had been awarding to each other Cabinet posts, including the Chancellor's own Ministry of Foreign Affairs.

INWOOD, L. I., Sept. 9 The Women's Long Island golf team of ten members retained the Myra D. Patterson Trophy by scoring 40 1/2 points against rivals from Westchester and New Jersey today over the Inwood course.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- The Defense Department announced today that the names of the 944 United States personnel missing in Korea for whom the Communists have not accounted would be made public after the next of kin had been notified.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was quiet yesterday, and closing prices were 3 points lower to 8 points higher than on Tuesday.

MIAMI, Fla., Sept. 9 (UP) -- The Federal Bureau of Investigation said today that an accommodating woman bank clerk falsified figures to cover up $111,232 in checks drawn by five men who asked her to hold them and then failed to make them good.

Stocks did virtually nothing yesterday. The market averages lost a few pennies and volume was only 860,000 shares. Five of the fifteen most active stocks -- and none was exceptionally active -rose and five fell. There were two new highs for the year -- New York Shipbuilding and Real Silk Hosiery, the latter because of a company offer to buy its own stock at $25 -- and fifty-one new lows.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- A bipartisan commission of eight Senators was chosen today to make a study of proposals to revise the United States Charter -- a subject that will come before the General Assembly in 1955.
HONG KONG, Sept. 9 -- A Chinese Communist warship shelled a British Navy launch today, killing seven servicemen and wounding five others.

KARACHI, Sept. 9 -- Beginning tomorrow, Pakistan will impose a duty of $20 on each bale of cotton exported. Despite the report yesterday of the United States' cotton surplus, Pakistan traders feel the market here will withstand the imposition due to increasing demands and the fact that the indigenous commodity sells 20 per cent below the United States parity price.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 9 -- It was supposed to be Johnny Podres' "Night" at Crosley Field this evening but it turned out to be Bob Milliken's as the Dodgers routed the Redlegs, 6 -- 0, and moved a little closer to another pennant.

In the collection of designer clothes presented yesterday by Russeks at the Plaza Hotel, brown was emphasized as an important color on the fall fashion chart. From pale beige to deep, rich Vicuna were suits, dresses and coats.
ALBANY, Sept. 9 (AP) -- The Court of Appeals held today that Chauncey M. Hooper was qualified to run for Manhattan Borough President in Tuesday's Democratic primary.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Sept. 9 -- Senator Bourke B. Hickenlooper, leader of the Joint United States Congressional Committee on Atomic Energy, defended the United States press today against attacks by a Nationalist Parliament member, Dr. Otto Duplessis.

DENVER, Sept. 9 -- President Eisenhower took off from Lowry Air Force Base at 8:56 P. M., Mountain Standard Time (11:56 P. M. Eastern Daylight Time) for Washington to attend the funeral of Chief Justice Fred M. Vinson tomorrow afternoon.

In one of the most cheerful reports of recent weeks Foreign Operations Director Stassen finds that Western Europe is making such real economic progress that if recovery continues at the present rate it may soon be able to dispense with further American economic aid.

OAKLAND, Calif., Sept. 9 (UP) -- Johnny Gonsalves, 136 pounds, of Oakland, counter-punching with the accuracy of a precision machine, gave Henry Davis, 137, of Los Angeles a boxing lesson in winning a unanimous ten-round decision tonight.

After an ownership of about four months, the Estate Securities Company, operators, resold the four-story apartment house at 1299 Franklin Avenue, corner of 168th Street, the Bronx, to a client of Abraham Bordan, broker in the transaction. The building occupies a lot 30 by 100 feet and contains five stores and ten six-room apartments and was bought subject to a first mortgage of $18,500 held by the Bowery Savings Bank.
The Jewish New Year 5714 was ushered in yesterday at sunset when Rosh ha-Shanah services were conducted for congregations in this nation and many other countries.

The ingenuity and variety of the means used by subjects of the Kremlin to escape from its rule afford a good measure of the fervor with which those people desire freedom. The young Polish interpreter in Korea who has now taken leave of the Polish truce supervision team there offers an instructive case in point.
Your lead editorial of Sept. 8, "The Adenauer Triumph," is an admirably plausible appraisal of the momentous importance of the doughty Chancellor's great victory.

TEHERAN, Iran, Sept. 9 -- Dr. Mohammed Mossadegh, former Premier of Iran who is facing charges of rebellion against the throne punishable by death, began a hunger strike today and demanded the right to consult a lawyer on the preparation of his will.

A property containing three buildings and an area of 38,000 square feet on the northwest side of Ninth Avenue, between Sixty-fourth and Sixty-fifth Streets, in Brooklyn, has been sold by the Kings County Lighting Company to Mist Properties, Inc., of 50 Court Street.

Representatives of nine national organizations, including the Quakers and the Congress of Industrial Organizations, issued a statement here yesterday protesting any change in the administrative direction of the race relations service of the Housing and Home Finance Agency in Washington.

Station WOR-TV announced yesterday that it would cease operations temporarily after Sunday night "in order to coordinate plans" for moving its transmitter and studio facilities to the Empire State Building. It did not say when programs would resume over Channel 9.

The New York City Transit Authority decided yesterday to fill 1,500 jobs in the transit system with permanent employes. Eight hundred are held by temporary workers, some of whom will lose their jobs if they cannot meet Civil Service requirements, and 700 have been kept vacant for economy reasons.

INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 9 (AP) -Meadow Pace, owned by Sol Camp of Shafter, Calif., defeated Excellent Chief by four lengths in a race-off today to win the Fox State for 2-year-old pacers at the Indiana State Fair.

Socialism in Britain is going through such a confused, conflicting, floundering experience that it is difficult to pin down trends or pass judgments. The annual conference of the Labor party is due at the end of this month, with the great British Leftist movement still in search of a policy and divided on its leadership.

If the return of the United Brotherhood of Carpenters to the American Federation of Labor is followed by the creation of additional machinery to eliminate raids among A. F. L. unions it will be all to the good. The public will benefit, and so will employers and employes.

VENICE, Italy, Sept. 9 (Reuters) -- A jeep filed with batonswinging riot police roared onto the stage for the finale of a novel one-act "chamber opera" presented at the Venice Festival of Contemporary Music last night.

ROME, Sept. 9 -- Giuseppe Pella, Italian Premier and Foreign Minister, discussed the Trieste problem this morning with United States Ambassador Clare Boothe Luce, Jacques Fouques Duparc, French Ambassador, and Archibald Ross, British Charge d' Affaires.
WASHINGTON, July 1 -- President Eisenhower designated today Louis S. Rothschild of Kansas City, Mo., to be chairman of the Federal Maritime Board.

Preliminary reports on file yesterday with the Board of Elections indicated that contributions to groups allied with Mayor Impellitteri in his campaign for the Democratic mayoral nomination were larger than gifts o committees supporting Borough President Robert F. Wagner Jr. of Manhattan, his principal rival.

Colombo, Ceylon, Sept. 9 -- A Japanese trade mission has arrived here in search, among other things, of Ceylonese graphite, ilmenite and monazite. The mission, led by Yoshiteru Kogane, a member of the Japanese Diet, said the three minerals would find a ready market as they were badly needed.

The Sept. 15 Democratic primary contest cannot be passed off as an intraparty fracas between two bossridden factions. The Wagner-Impellitteri fight, in my opinion, should be of extreme importance to all registered Democrats in this city.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 1 -Members of the International Association of Machinists, A. F. L., struck a group of Pacific Coast shipyards today in a wage disagreement. At a number of yards some of which have navy contracts, other A. F. L. craftsmen refused to cross picket lines and tied up all work in the plants.

PARIS, Sept. 9 -- French officials expect that the National Security Council in Washington will discuss tomorrow or soon thereafter a French request for further United States aid for the war in IndoChina in addition to -- and possibly comparable to -- the $400,000,000 already voted by the United States Congress for such aid in the year 1954.

WORD has just arrived from our correspondent on the banks of the Pungo River (North Carolina) concerning the hopes and fears for the coming duck, goose, quail, deer, squirrel, opossum, raccoon and bear seasons in those parts, and we gather that the prospects are much brighter than usual, for the hunters as well as our correspondent.

To build up its summer business the Kings County Lighting Company has started a gas refrigerator rental plant, Ephraim F. Jeffe, president, told members of the New York Society of Security Analysts yesterday. He said on a ten-year contract a landlord can rent a six-foot-cubic refrigerator at $1.75 a month, or an eightcubic-foot one at $2.50, with the company providing full service on the appliance.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 9 (AP) -- More than 400 former United States war prisoners arrived today aboard the navy transport Gen. John Pope and got a wild welcome by a crowd giving scant attention to another ship alongside.

AN event of far-reaching significance in sports occurred a few days ago and the chances are that comparatively few readers of the sports pages noticed it. For the first time Russia defeated the United States for the world weight-lifting championship. Don't snicker, please. Weight-lifting has ceased to be a laughing matter. Once upon a time the muscle men were the butt of jokesters. Not any more.

BONNEVILLE, Utah, Sept. 9 (UP) -- Six international speed reords were set today at the fifth annual Booneville national speed trials by Mal Hooper, a telephone lineman from Los Angeles who drove a hand-built hot-rod Shadoff Special Streamliner.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 (UP) -- Two Republican Representatives reported today that William D. Mitchell, Small Plants Administrator, had outdone Congress with an economy drive of his own.
A showdown neared last night on whether Rita Hayworth would approve a divorce settlement from Prince Aly Khan.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture has issued a complaint charging that thirteen Midwestern and Southwestern concerns and individuals manipulated prices of eggs on the Chicago Exchange last December.

The Boys Club of New York will be the beneficiary of a dinner dance and entertainment, known as "Un Brin de Bonheur," to be held on the night of Oct. 22 in the main ballroom of the Plaza. Mrs. John R. Stevenson heads the executive committee for the forthcoming event, and serving with her as co-chairmen are Mrs. Walter C. Teagle Jr. and Mrs. Edward Patterson.

The consolidation of the departments of diagnostic radiology and radiation therapy of the New York UniversityBellevue Medical Center into a department of radiology was announced yesterday by Dr. Marcus D. Kogel, City Commissioner of Hospitals, and Dr. Currier McEwen, dean of the College of Medicine of the center.

An American edition of "the first book about a British submarine commander" has been scheduled for Oct. 20 publication by McGraw- Hill entitled "Undersea Patrol." The author is Comdr. Edward Young, who was the first Naval Reservist to command an operational submarine.

The lop-sidedness of the present tax structure, with 80 per cent of federal revenues derived from corporate and personal taxes, makes an already strained budget situation especially vulnerable to a business decline of even moderate proportions.

BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 9 -- After having maintained silence for more than a year, the resurgent Alianza Libertaclora Nacionalista reopened today its anti-Semitic campaign in its fortnightly by attacking the newspaper La Prensa on the ground that it published too many articles by Jewish writers in its Sunday supplement.

DEER PARK, L. I., Sept. 9 -- A woods fire burned through thirty acres of pine and scrub oak this afternoon and approached within 1,000 feet of the Edgewood State Hospital here, a fourteen-story brick mental institution adjoining the Pilgrim State Hospital in Brentwood.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 9 -- The United States has proposed the appointment of Lieut. Gen. Raymond A. Wheeler for the key post as head of the United Nations Relief and Works Agency for Palestine Refugees. General Wheeler was Chief of Engineers of the United States Army until his retirement in 1949.
The new Spanish passenger ship Covadonga, fresh from a baptism of storm on her maiden voyage, arrived yesterday morning and received the port's traditional welcome.

That there could have been even a single swimming injury, not to mention twenty drownings, in the recent Fort Bragg disaster is a disgraceful reflection not on the Army but on the citizenry and the physical education programs they provide in the schools. At army age every youngster should be expert in survival swimming and in sports such as volley ball, softball, table tennis, handball, badminton, bowling, and tennis.

CHICAGO, Sept. 9 -- Substantial gains again were registered early in wheat and corn futures today, the wheat market still reflecting a tight cash situation at Minneapolis, while corn was in good demand from local bulls and commission houses, with shorts covering on the possibility of a bullish September corn crop estimate.

Sales, production and earnings of the Crown Zellerbach Corporation for the quarter ended July 31 were greater than for any threemonth period of the preceding year, the report disclosed yesterday. Without giving effect to the acquisition of Canadian Western Lumber Company, Ltd., and St. Helens Pulp and Paper Company, sales and earnings were about 12 per cent above the similar period last year.

The Netherlands Chamber of Commerce in the United States yesterday announced plans for a food exhibit which, it is hoped, will help to make up for the loss of exports here due to severe import restrictions on dairy products. Last year dairy imports ran to $4,400,000 out of a total of $31,700,000 in the food and beverage group.

Scheduled for presentation early this season is a new play by Julian Funt called "Child of Grace," described as a contemporary work "about a young woman, the men in her life and the double standard." In the light of current reports on the sexual behavior of the distaff side, Alexander H. Cohen and Ralph Alswang, producers of the attraction, believe that "Child of Grace" contains a "timely" theme.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 (UP) -Crown Prince Akihito of Japan paid the solemn respects of his country today at two of the United States national shrines.
MONTICELLO, N. Y., Sept. 9 (AP) -- Two Bronx youths were held in bail today after they were questioned in the Labor Day slaying of Israel Present.

Sophie's fall and winter collection of custom-made fashions, shown yesterday at Saks Fifth Avenue, was breath-taking. The fabrics had an Arabian Nights magnificence. The workmanship was exquisite in the extreme. Co-author of these styles with Sophie (Mrs. Adam Gimbel) was Stephen Erklin.

SEOUL, Korea, Sept. 9 -- A Polish member of a neutral nations inspection team in South Korea dramatically asked for and received political asylum from communism today just as a plane was about to take him back into North Korea.
