BELGRADE, Yugoslavia,Sept. 9 -- Premier Vulko Chervenkov of Bulgaria said last night that his country was ready to re-establish diplomatic relations with the United States, according to a broadcast from Sofia. He made the same suggestion with regard to Greece.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Sept. 9 -- The Australian Government has broken off negotiations with Japan that had been proceeding since April for an agreement on conditions under which the Japanese would be permitted to fish for pearlshell in the waters off the north coast of Australia.

The royal carpet was out yesterday at the Bronx Zoo, and uninformed attendants to Peter II, the princeling hippopotamus who is successor to the late Peter the Great, were waiting expectantly for the arrival of Peter II's future mate.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- Speaker Joseph W. Martin Jr. of the House of Representatives predicted today the Administration would accomplish the difficult task next year of simultaneously cutting taxes and balancing the budget.

ROME, Sept. 9 -- A new technique that makes it possible for the first time to observe accurately the interrelations between animal cells and animal viruses was announced here today at the Sixth International Congress of Microbiology.

The heavy outbound passenger ship traffic this week, brought about by the approaching peak of the eastbound trans-Atlantic passenger season and the outflow of summer vacationists to the West Indies, will reach a climax tomorrow when thirteen liners carrying more than 7,300 travelers sail within twelve hours. Six thousand passengers already have left this week.

HEWLETT, L. I., Sept. 9 -- The Rev. Francis R. Ryan of Roslyn, L. I., a member of the Wheatley Hills Golf Club, began the defense of his Long Island Seniors Golf Association title today with a 2-over-par-74 at the Seawane Harbor Club.
MILWAUKEE, Sept. 9 (UP) -- Bob Miller, Phillies' right-hander, tossed a three-hitter tonight to beat the Braves, 2 -- 0.

The impending end of the monsoon rains and the opening of a new campaign season in IndoChina emphasize the importance of the speech of Secretary of State Dulles to the American Legion convention last week.

City Controller Lazarus Joseph, who has usually sided with Mayor Impellitteri in the Board of Estimate, announced yesterday his support of Borough President Robert F. Wagner Jr. of Manhattan for the Democratic nomination for Mayor in Tuesday's primary election.
MELBOURNE, Australia, Sept. 9 -- A budget introduced in the House of Representatives today by Treasurer Sir Arthur Fadden cuts an estimated 118,400,000 Australian ($266,400,000) in taxes annually.

CLEVELAND Sept. 9 (AP) -- Three members of the news staff of The Cleveland Press, a ScrippsHoward newspaper, were convicted of contempt of court late today by Common Pleas Judge Joseph H. Silbert. The case involved the taking of a photograph in Judge Silbert's courtroom after the judge had told one of the defendants no pictures would be allowed.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- Felix Belair Jr. today was appointed special assistant to James Reston, Washington correspondent of THE NEW YORK TIMES.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 9 (AP) -- Warren Giles, president of the National League, tried all day today to reach Carl Furillo, Dodger out- fielder, who has said he will "get" Manager Leo Durocher of the Giants the next time he sees him.

Gross income of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation and its subsidiaries (consolidated) reached $203,724,412 in the first half of 1953, an increase of $27,364,752 over the same period of last year, when it was $176,359,660, Sosthenes Behn, chairman, and William H. Harrison, president, announced yesterday.

Directors of the Hygrade Foods Corporation intend to authorize, before Nov. 1, a 100 per cent stock dividend on the common stock. There now are 249,441 shares of common stock outstanding. In announcing the projected stock dividend the company said the board was disclosing its intention without any commitment to do so and that the dividend would be subject to a merger and consolidation with Kingan Co., Inc., becoming effective.
TODAY, 11 A. M.: Two films, "Animals Growing Up" and "Early Settlers of New England," will be shown at the Brooklyn Children's Museum, 185 Brooklyn Avenue. They will be followed by a story hour.

Your editorial of Aug. 29 "Teach -or Drive a Truck?" regarding teachers' salaries and its implication that New York City teachers are underpaid, prompts me to cite a few pertinent facts. I shall confine myself to the situation in New York City.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 9 -- Increased employment for minority groups has created a "tremendous market" for housing for non- whites, Guy T. O. Hollyday, ComMissioner of the Federal Housing Administration, declared here today.
CHICAGO, Sept. 9 (AP) -- The will of Mrs. Bernadette Ann Harris, who left her entire estate to Rogers Hornsby, manager of the Cincinnati Redlegs, was filed today in Cook County Probate Court.

Daniel R. Ackerman, chairman of the Great American Insurance Company, announced yesterday that a special meeting of stockholders will be held on Oct. 20 to approve a proposed reorganization of the company's holdings in its affiliated insurance companies.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 9 (AP) -- Rookie Marion Fricano pitched a four-hitter and Pete Suder batted in three runs with a triple and homer as the Athletics romped over the Tigers, 7 -- 1, in the second game of a double-header tonight.

WESTBURY, L. I., Sept. 9 (AP) -- Stanley Dancer drove John A. Zeyak's Tokyo Express to victory tonight in the feature pace of a mile and a, sixteenth at Roosevelt Raceway. Tokyo Express, returning $9.40, $5.10 and $3.60 for $2, defeated Bluett Hanover by a length as Noble Dean finished third.

TOKYO, Thursday, Sept. 10 -- The United Nations will begin today to transfer into the custody of Indian guards the first group of former Communist soldiers captured in the Korean war who refuse to be repatriated.

NEW CANAAN, Conn., Sept. 9 -- At 8 o'clock this morning, while parents in many communities were trying to rouse their unhappy youngsters in time for the start of school, a good-sized crowd had formed outside the "little red schoolhouse" on Carter Street, excited over going back to school.
The work of Italian and German handcraftsmen is represented in a new group of lamps that will go on view Monday at Macy's.

The Allied Stores Corporation and its consolidated subsidiaries, which operate more than seventy stores including 97 per cent-owned Stern Brothers, and Gertz in Flushing and Jamaica, Queens, showed substantial improvement in sales and earnings for the three, six and twelve months ended on Aug. 1, over the corresponding periods a year earlier.

GROSSINGER, N. Y., Sept. 9 (UP) -- Al Weill, manager of Rocky Marciano, said today that he would not "agree to any change in the style of boxing gloves" for Marciano's world heavyweight title defense against Roland La Starza on Sept. 24 at the Polo Grounds in New York.
LONDON, Sept. 9 -- A modest expansion of demand for good industrial shares and South African gold mine issues today gave the stock market a more cheerful tone.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 10 -- As the Giants lost to the Cardinals, 7 -- 6, today, it became known that Manager Leo Durocher had formed a four-member "Manager-of-the-Day Club." Bill Rigney, who was first to receive the opportunity to direct the team, broke even in his two games here, since the Giants had won last night.

CHICAGO, Sept. 10 -- Former President Truman has been granted first position in the television and radio broadcast portions of the $100-a-plate dinner to be held here by the National Democratic Committee Monday.
LAKESIDE, Conn., Sept 10 -- Put Lou Little down as one football coach who isn't moaning low or high over the doing away with the two-platoon football system.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- President Eisenhower rushed through a series of conferences on a brief visit to the capital today and then returned by plane to Denver to resume his vacation.

Harold Riegelman, the Republican Mayoralty aspirant, has warmed up to the spirit of the campaign. In high gear he rides the muddy road of New York politics, spattering mud as he sails along on his first outing. His obvious reference to David Dubinsky as a "labor czar" and his epithet hurling at Rudolph Halley at the first salvo follow the pattern of uninspired and barren leadership for which New York City politics is famous.
The Southern Pacific Company borrowed $5,250,000 in the public market yesterday on equipment trust certiifcates maturing annually from 1954 to 1968 at a dividend cost of about 3.42 per cent.

WAYNESBORO, Pa., Sept. 10 (AP) -- The Defense Department was asked today if a "Berchtesgaden for high defense officials" similar to Hitler's former hideout in Germany is being built under the Blue Ridge Mountains near the Pennsylvania-Maryland line.

Severe price jumps in fresh water fish this week reflect Jewish observance of the High Holy Days when whitefish, carp and yellow pike are demanded for traditional dishes. Since the end of August whitefish has increased 80 per cent in price to $1.25 a pound, 56 cents more than two weeks ago,

The Commonwealth Edison Company on Oct. 1 will observe the fiftieth anniversary of the use of the first large steam turbine in America. That unit, which has been enshrined by its builder, the General Electric Company, as a "monument to courage," at its Schenectady, N. Y., plant, was rated at 5,000 kilowatts (approximately 6,700 horsepower) and was a daring innovation for its day.

Willie Lester kept William Ziegler Jr.'s Expletive in front all the way to win the six-furlong event that occupied the feature spot on the racing card at Aqueduct yesterday. A gathering of 26,186 saw the jockey guide the son of By Jimminy close to the rail to register by two and a half lengths over Full Brother of the High Tide Stable.

The Dodgers disclosed yesterday that they would accept mail orders immediately for reserved seats at Ebbets Field for the three world series games scheduled there on Friday, Saturday and Sunday, Oct. 2, 3 and 4.

Following are the texts of letters exchanged by Martin P. Durkin and President Eisenhower as transmitted by The Associated Press. The Durkin letter was released by the President's office in Denver, and the President's reply by the White House in Washington:

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Sept. 10 -- There was by no stretch of imagination a gale for the second day of Manhasset Bay Yacht Club's fall race series, but today at least the light southerly in which 190 craft started filled in sufficiently to enable even the fleet stragglers to finish their shortened courses in daylight.

CHICAGO, Sept. 10 (AP) -- Live hogs took to new high price ground today as receipts again were fewer than anticipated by the trade. Advances of 25 to 50 cents were registered in all departments. Cattle ranged all the way from 50 cents higher to as much lower while sheep were steady to $1 higher.

The Rockefeller Foundation, in its annual report made public yesterday, announced grants during 1952 of $16,640,355. In addition, appropriations for general administrative expenses and field offices came to $2,106,877.

LONDON, Sept. 10 -- A solution of the British-Egyptian dispute over the Suez Canal military base is much nearer than it has ever been, Sir Mohammed Zafrullah Khan, Pakistan's Foreign Minister, declared here today. He arrived by air from Cairo where he had a talk yesterday with Maj. Gen. Mohammed Naguib, President of Egypt.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (AP) -- The October issue of The Democratic Digest said today a Federal sales tax, opposed by past Democratic Administrations and now being studied by the Republicans, was "bound to be a major campaign issue in the 1954 elections."

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Sept. 10 -- Mrs. James C. Maples of Apawamis and Mrs. James F. Clark of Round Hill scored 41, 38 -- 79 over an alternate-stroke route at Westchester Hills today to head forty rival pairs in the Women's Westchester-Fairfield Golf Association annual two-ball foursomes event.

In the interest of removing falsely founded barriers to that mutual understanding between peoples so basic to continuing friendship and cooperation. I feel it necessary to clarify certain issues raised in your Sept. 7 editorial "Tito and Trieste."

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 10 -- Yugoslavia hinted again today that she might take retaliatory measures on Italy's movement of troops along the Yugoslav border north of Trieste. Dr. Ales Bebler, State Under Secretary for Foreign Affairs, was not explicit, but he told the closing session of Parliament today that "the exceptional measures of military character undertaken by the Italian Government still remain in force."

Steel production in this country last month set a new high for any August. And the output in the last twelve months was far greater than that of any previous twelve-month period, more than 114,600,00 tons, or about two and three-quarter times Russia's expected production this year.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (AP) -- The Defense Department released tonight the names of 126 Americans who were not returned in the exchange of prisoners of the Korean war and for whom it has asked a strict accounting from the Communists.

It is hard to imagine a better choice of a man for a job than the nomination of Lieut. Gen. Raymond A. Wheeler for the post of chief of the United Nations Relief and Works Agency for Palestine Refugees. The task of improving the lot of some 800,000 persons who are adrift as the result of the conflict in Palestine is monumental.

The City Center of Music and Drama has added another phase of the arts to its program -- a gallery for the exhibition of contemporary paintings and prints, which will open to the public on the evening of Sept. 29. Newbold Morris, chairman of the City Center board, announced the completion of the gallery yesterday.

PARIS, Sept. 10 (UP) -- The archives at Supreme Headquarters, Allied Dowers in Europe, disclosed today an exchange of communications between a general and a colonel over teaching a parrot to utter Scottish accents.

The Communist party asserted yesterday that the real danger to the United States did not come from it but from the Eisenhower Administration and particularly from Attorney General Herbert Brownell Jr., J. Edgar Hoover, director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, and Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, who is investigating Communist infiltration of the Government.

CHICAGO, Sept. 10 -- The Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers will ask railroads for a percentage pay increase that will figure out to not less than 37 1/2 cents an hour, Guy L. Brown, Grand Chief Engineer of the union, said today. The general chairmen of the brotherhood, representing 75,000 to 80,000 locomotive engineers, are meeting here to formulate wage proposals.

LONDON, Sept. 10 -- The feature of a quiet stock market today was the increased demand for British Government securities, which advanced as much as 1/4 per cent. Dominion and colonial stocks also developed a firmer trend.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Sept. 10 -- Authorities at Camp Kilmer said today it probably would be a week before they could verify the story of a 21-year-old soldier who had fled from the Korean front, stolen aboard an Army transport and upon reaching the West Coast, hitchhiked to his home in Plainfield.

An account of the experiences of ten men during and after the Battle of Sunda Strait in World War II will be issued Monday by Bobbs-Merrill under the title "The Survivors." The author, Ronald McKie, for twenty years an Australian newspaper man, became interested in the subject after reading the diary of Commander Owen of the Royal Australian Navy written during the four years he was a prisoner of war in Japan.

This is the season when the people of New York State sometimes begin to get an inkling of Governor Dewey's preliminary thoughts on state problems that later take form in his annual messages to the Legislature. So it is welcome news that in a speech in Syracuse on the eve of Governor's Day at the State Fair he emphasized highway needs and hinted at substantial new developments.

Station WOR-TV, which plans to close down temporarily after Sunday night, expects to resume operations about a month after it reaches a settlement with its striking engineers, according to Thomas F. O'Neil, president of General Teleradio, Inc., owner of the station. He said he did not know when the strike might end.

SEOUL, Korea, Sept. 10 (AP) -- A young Polish interpreter who bolted from Communist control and received United States sanctuary said today his people would rise in revolt against the Reds some day, "but now is not the time."

As in recent weeks, sales finance companies continue a major influence in the volume of New York bank loans to business, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. Repayments by the companies during the week ended on Wednesday cut the commercial borrowings $14,000,000. A week earlier sales finance credits were prominent in an expansion of business loans amounting to $64,000,000.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- Men who make careers for themselves by exploiting public concern over the Communist threat were assailed by a leading political scientist tonight as "political quacks" and practitioners of "malarkeyism."

GARDEN CITY, L. I., Sept. 10 -- The Arma Corporation has notified 3,500 of its 5,000 striking employes that it will end as of midnight Monday a gentlemen's agreement made to halt violence that broke out during the first week of the labor dispute.

PEMBERTON, N. J., Sept. 10 -- Migrant farm workers are swarming over the hundreds of acres of cranberry bogs in this area of Burlington County to assure the public that its traditional Thanksgiving turkey will not lack one of its all-important adjuncts. The 1953 harvest, delayed by the heat wave, got under way this week.

Maj. Gen. Wincenty Kowalski, former commander of the Polish First Division, last night presented the Cross of the Order of Virtuti Militari to Lieut. Gen. C. R. Huebner, director of the State Civil Defense Commission and commander of the United States Army's First Infantry Division during World War II campaigns in Sicily and Normandy.

BONN, Germany, Sept. 10 -- The Executive Committee of the Christian Democratic Union empowered Chancellor Konrad Adenauer today to negotiate formation of a new coalition government with the Free Democratic party and the German party, which had participated in the first coalition.

The monthly report of Robert W. Dill, Collector of Customs for the Port of New York, issued yesterday, showed that collections on shipping in August had totaled $24,975,279, a gain of about 20 per cent over the same 1952 month.

Electric power production for the week ended on last Saturday climbed to a new record high of 8,694,301,000 kilowatt hours, more than 154,000,000 above last week's peak figure of 8,539,557,000, according to report received yesterday from the Edison Electric Institute. The figure for the week ended on Sept. 6, 1952 was 7,324,127,000. Comparative percentages with the like two weeks of 1952 are:

Major reorganizational changes in the United States Maritime Administration, said to be the first in a series, were announced in Washington and in New York yesterday by Louis S. Rothschild, administrator of the agency and chairman of the Federal Maritime Board. The two agencies lie within the Department of Commerce.

PARIS, Sept. 10 -- The decision of the National Security Council in Washington in favor of granting France in the coming year additional aid for the war in Indo-China amounting to $385,000,000, which Premier Joseph Laniel welcomed today, is expected by officials to go a long way toward breaking the political and military deadlocks in Europe as well as in Asia.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, Sept. 10 -- A small Maldivian vessel anchored in Colombo harbor last night bringing the first on-the-spot news from the Maldive Islands where a dramatic coup took place Sept. 2. Then Ibrahim Mohamed Didi, Deputy President of the islands, assisted by Ibrahim Ali Didi, another politician, wrested power from Amin Didi, President of Asia's youngest republic.

A basic coffee cake dough, made with a nutritious combination of rolled oats and flour, should appeal to home bakers during the first cool days. The brisker weather that has revived appetites generally also perks up the cook. She again feels like rolling up her sleeves, lighting the oven and producing something more complicated than the salad and cold cuts she offered all too often during the recent Great Sizzle of unhappy memory.

Nineteen top-priority advertising campaigns in the interest of the public were conducted by American business in 1952-53 through the Advertising Council. In addition, the Council supported in varying degrees forty-seven other public interest programs.

Paul Richards and his White Sox, after having engaged the Yankees in twenty-one more or less tempestuous battles, passed out of the lives of the Bombers for the 1953 campaign at the Stadium yesterday in surprisingly docile fashion.

GROSSINGER, N. Y., Sept. 10 -- "Would you mind passing the salt, please?" asked Rocky Marciano at breakfast this morning. There was nothing extraordinary about the request. Yet a visiting fireman couldn't help but be struck by the fact that it was so typical of the heavyweight champion of the world. The average fighter would simply have reached for the shaker.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- A Three-man division of the Interstate Commerce Commission approved today an increase from twelve miles to fifteen miles an hour in the speed of Long Island Rail Road trains over specified portions of the company's lines. A tolerance of three miles an hour above the restricted speed is continued.

A vacant plot at the northeast corner of Central Avenue and Rutland Road in Yonkers, N. Y., has been sold by Winthrop Brookhouse to clients of Travis S. Levy, attorney. George Piantadosi was the broker and the Title Guarantee and Trust Company insured title. The property has a frontage of more than 400 feet on Central Avenue and 100 feet on Rutland Road.

Rosh ha-Shanah, the Jewish New Year, was acclaimed yesterday by rabbis over the city as a time for penitence, faith and courage. The holy period, observed for one day by Reform Jews and for two days by those of the Conservative and Orthodox traditions, began at sundown on Wednesday.

George F. Smith, president of Johnson Johnson, yesterday challenged John Schwegmann Jr., opponent of fair trade pricing, to divulge the names of New Orleans stores which Mr. Schwegmann says are selling Johnson Johnson surgical dressings and baby products at prices below fair traded minimums. Mr. Smith pledged a thorough investigation and court action if Mr. Schwegmann's contentions are justified.

Terrebonne Parish, La., announced yesterday that it will receive bids on Oct. 9 on an issue of $2,400,000 of bonds of Waterworks District No. 1. Dated Nov. 1, 1953, the bonds will come due on Nov. 1, 1955 to 1983.
The mature woman who wears half or women's sizes received a bow from Abraham Straus yesterday when the store officially opened a new floor catering to these sized models.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 10 (AP) -- A gas explosion under a three-quarter-mile section of West 117th Street late today killed a woman motorist and injured at least fifty persons in rush-hour crowds, some seriously.

Collections of imported designs proved exciting fare yesterday at two of the city's specialty shops. At Bergdorf Goodman, French and Italian imports were shown, while at Hattie Carnegie, French fashions held complete sway.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- The United States is considering the resumption of diplomatic relations with Bulgaria after a lapse of more than three and a half years, informed quarters said today.
Motifs that hint of autumn appear in some of the designs of a new collection of decorative fabrics available through decorators at Jofa, 45 East Fifty-third Street.

A new offensive against "gray zone" advertising, bad taste, fear appeals and other abuses which bring advertising into bad repute is planned by the Advertising Federation of America. Besides an itemized program of promotion for the campaign this year, the federation is offering a cash prize of $250 for the design of a new emblem for Integrity in Advertising. The contest for the emblem will end on May 15, 1954.
After ten years the Board of Education finally cleared the way yesterday for approval of a $5,400,000 building in midtown for the New York School of Printing.

HEWLETT, L. I., Sept. 10 -- Edward F. MacGrath, 52-year-old member of the Rockville Country Club, captured the Long Island Senior Golf Association championship today at the Seawane Harbor Club with a 36-hole aggregate of 151.
TORONTO, Sept. 10 (AP) -- Canada's five-man team defeated the United States squad twice in succession today to win the best-of-three series for the initial international Y-Flyer sailing championship.
The New York Rangers have drawn seventeen Sundays and one Saturday among their thirty-five home engagements for the 1953-1954 National Hockey League campaign at Madison Square Garden.

Contracts for the first new pier to be built in the port of Hoboken, N. J., in twenty-five years have been let by the Port of New York Authority as the first major improvement in the bi-state agency's Hoboken waterfront reconstruction program.

" Zanetto," a little-known opera in one act by Pietro Mascagni, was performed by the Amato Opera Theatre last night on a double bill with "Pagliacci" to open the company's fall season at 159 Bleecker Street.
Public utility companies serving the New York metropolitan area announced plans yesterday for the early sale of more than $60,000,000 of new securities.
The transfer of Rear Admiral John M. Will, U. S. N., commander of the Military Sea Transportation Service's Atlantic Area to another command, effective next month, was announced here yesterday.

The increasingly close relationship between contemporary and traditional furniture is dramatically apparent in the collection of new model rooms opening at Altman's today. Although only five of the seventeen model rooms are labeled "modern," the background and furnishing of all bear the mark of fall, 1953.

TORONTO, Sept. 10 -- Drifting icebergs and melted snow provide the main source of fresh water for two of the five jointly operated Canadian-United States weather stations in the Arctic, delegates to the Toronto Meteorological Conference were told today.

Construction costs dipped slightly this month, after reaching an all-time high in August, according to The Engineering News-Record, which attributes the decline to lumber prices. Lumber costs were reported lower in ten of the twenty cities covered by the cost survey.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (AP) -- Representative Augustine B. Kelley, Democrat of Pennsylvania, announced today he has asked again for a report on the deaths of two Marine Corps officer candidates at Quantico, Va., last July.

DETROIT, Sept. 10 -- Leaders of disputing factions in the United Packinghouse Workers, C. I. O., met today with Walter P. Reuther, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, and a three-man C. I. O. committee assigned to help in patching the union's internal difficulties.

Huntington Hall, Inc., sold the seven-story building at 216 East Second Street to Michael Myerberg, producer of motion pictures and television films, through O'Gara Co., brokers. The building contains 50,000 square feet of space and will be occupied by the new owner.

WESTBURY, L. I., Sept. 10 (AP) -- Josedale Dandy won the Wyoming Pace in 2:06 at Roosevelt Raceway tonight as Stanley Dancer guided the aged gelding across the line a length ahead of the favored Vonian Chief for his fourth victory in twenty-two starts this year.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- Any hopes that the nickel industry might have entertained as to an immediate end to Government allocation and controls were dashed by the Office of Defense Mobilization today.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Sept. 10 -- The House of Representatives passed through all remaining stages today the bill amending the Pearl Fisheries Act to provide for stricter control of pearling in the waters off the northern coast of Australia. It was introduced Wednesday.

CHICAGO, Sept. 10 -- Chemical discoveries for growing bigger food animals, curing vegetable and fruit blights, preserving fish for longer periods against spoilage and producing cheaper fertilizers were reported here today.
Italian craftsmen have copied such French originals as pink leather gloves with beaded embroidery and they're shown in Macy's fifth annual accessory bazaar, opening Monday and previewed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (AP) -- The United Air Lines, supported by Pacific Northwest interests, today urged the Civil Aeronautics Board to permit it to fly non-stop from Chicago to Seattle, Wash., and Portland, Ore. United now serves these cities, but is required by the Board to make intermediate stops at Denver, Boise, Idaho, or Salt Lake City.

Although an informal agreement exists for the purchase of a state-owned eleven-acre tract in Westport, Conn., where a Shakespearean center would be established, the chances are that the contemplated project will be situated in Stratford, Conn.
Staten Island firemen chalked up a new achievement yesterday in the borough's forty-seven-year-old history of organized fire-fighting: one of their number delivered a baby in a firehouse.

BLOOMFIELD, N. J., Sept. 10--Lou Barbaro and Bobby Jacobson of Hollywood, the defending title-holders, were defeated by 1 up today by Jerry Volpe and Chester Sanok of Forsgate in the second round of the eighteenth New Jersey State pro-amateur best-ball golf tournament.

Vassily Smyslov of Moscow played his adjourned games from the sixth and seventh rounds last night and attained a score of 5 -- 2 in the world chess championship challengers' tournament in Neuhausen, Switzerland. He tied Samuel Reshevsky of New York for first place in the standing, according to a report from Zurich.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 10 (AP) -- Ralph Lomeli, a Fresno, Calif., golf driving range owner using an improvised bent putter, zoomed out of a pack of unknowns with a score of 66, one off the course record, to lead the first round of the eastern open today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- During the week ended Sept. 9, member bank reserves decreased $221,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
OKLAHOMA CITY, Sept. 10 (AP)--An atomic-powered airplane could fly around the world or stay aloft for many days without refueling, a General Electric Company executive said today.

BONNEVILLE SALT FLATS, Utah, Sept. 10 (UP) -- A Monrovia, Calif., driver, attempting to break an international speed record, was critically injured today when his car careened out of control and turned over while approaching 250 miles an hour.

The Washington Square area is once again a haven for sidewalk entrepreneurs with studio wares to sell. From Brooklyn, the Bronx, Long Island, and even from Greenwich Village, artists gathered yesterday for the second event this year to be sponsored by the Washington Square Outdoor Art Exhibit.

The car-parking quarrel that brought the United Nations and New York City into open clash a month ago flared afresh yesterday in a testy cross-barrage between Robert Moses, City Construction Coordinator, and Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold.

Mayor Impellitteri's candidacy for the Democratic nomination for Mayor had something of a setback yesterday when it was learned that two Tammany Assembly District leaders had failed to appeal from the Appellate Division decision voiding their enrollment as members of the Democratic party on the ground that they did not live at the addresses from which they had registered and enrolled.

WINNIPEG, Sept. 10 (Canadian Press) -- Canada could price itself out of world wheat markets by continuing to base prices for hard wheat on stay-at-home United States crops, according to the president of the Winnipeg Grain Exchange.

New books, new books and more new books -- even during the summer they made heaps on book reviewers' desks. As fall and winter come those heaps will get even bigger. Some new books are born in obscurity and will not rise above it; others will enjoy moderate successes, still others (a few) will sell for a time almost as fast as copies can be printed and distributed.

When the President set up the Operations Coordinating Board within the National Security Council he not only swept away another doctrinal method of the two recent Democratic Administrations in dealing with the problems of the Republic. He substituted once more a practical concept for a type of the professorial thinking that dominated Washington from the advent of the New Deal with its influx of brilliant collegians.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- Found: 6,000,000 acres of range land.

WEDGEPORT, N. S., Sept. 10 (Canadian Press) -- Argentina took the lead in the tenth international tuna tournament that began today by landing a 158-pounder, the day's only catch that the team captain, Pablo Bardin, reeled up in sixteen minutes. There were no other strikes.

MADISON, Wis., Sept. 10 -- A test-tube experiment utilizing photosynthesis has bettered by at least twenty times the efficiency of plants to capture and store the energy of sunlight, according to a paper read here today at the meeting of the American Institute of Biological Sciences.

Today's new film is "The Man From the Alamo," starring Glenn Ford and Julia Adams, at the Palace. Heading the supporting cast are Chill Wills, Victory Jory, Hugh O'Brian and Jeanne Cooper. The Universal - International western was written by Steve Fisher and D. D. Beauchamp from a story by Niven Busch and Oliver Crawford.

Luigi Antonini, first vice president of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, A. F. L., and general secretary of the Italian Dressmakers Union, Local 89, will celebrate his seventieth birthday today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (AP) -- In an attack on recent oil and gasoline price rises, Federal Trade Commissioner Stephen J. Spingarn called on the Government today to bring about "a competitive market or some form of supervision" over the oil industry.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 10 -- The Dodgers' hope of clinching a tie for first place in the National League today was crushed in the eleventh inning when Clem Labine walked Andy Seminick with the bases filled to give the Redlegs a 6-5 victory.

TRENTON, Sept. 10 -- "Unethical" and "illegal" activities were charged to the New Jersey Civil Service Commission and some of its officials today by the Democratic minority in the State Assembly. The accusations, which were made as the Legislature convened here for its annual veto session, were denied within an hour by a top official of the commission.

Efforts by Harry Bridges, leftwing leader of West Coast longshoremen, to get a foothold in the strife-torn International Longshoremen's Association were reported yesterday by American Federation of Labor maritime leaders.

Sales of men's fall clothing will not be affected by the expected decline in national production and construction, according to a market letter by Jerome I. Udell, chairman of the board of Max Udell Sons Co., Inc., distributed to 8,000 retailers.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., Sept. 10 -- A fledgling congregation of a hundred families attended the first Jewish service ever held in this village last night at the Cathedral House of the Protestant Episcopal Cathedral of the Incarnation.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- Australia, New Zealand and the United States concluded a two-day conference here this evening with a restatement of their unity in the Pacific and a unanimous decision to retain their security pact in its present tripartite form.

SEOUL, Korea, Sept. 10 -- President Syngman Rhee dismissed two of his Cabinet ministers today and ordered the dissolution of all South Korean youth groups. The move appeared designed to snip off any domestic opposition before it had a fair chance to come to bud.

MOSCOW, Sept. 10 -- A North Korean Government delegation arrived in Moscow tonight aboard a special train for conversations with the chiefs of the Soviet Government. According to Premier Kim II Sung, these conversations should assist "the peaceful uniting" of Korea as well as provide a stronger base for relations between the Soviet Union and Korea, both political and economic.

BONN, Germany, Sept. 10 -- It became known today that Philip Heller, United States Labor Information officer and the one and only continuous contact between the United States High Commissioner's office and the German Trade Union Federation and Social Democratic leaders was peremptorily dismissed recently by the Foreign Operations Administration.

BONN, Germany, Sept. 10 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer's victory in last Sunday's Bundestag election was followed up today with an ultimatum to the Executive Committee of the German Trade Union Federation to submit to a reorganization of control that would place the unions under the domination of the state.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- The National Security Council has recommended almost doubling the United States contribution to the French campaign against the Communist-led rebels in Indo-China.

Record sales and eranings were achieved by the International Minerals and Chemical Corporation in the fiscal year ended June 30, according to the forty-fourth annual report, which was mailed to stockholders yesterday.

HONG KONG, Sept. 10 (UP) -- Vice Admiral Sir Charles Lambe, British Naval Commander in the Far East, flew here today to investigate yesterday's unprovoked Communist attack on an outgunned British patrol boat, which might have sunk but for the heroism of a 20-year-old sailor.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended Sept. 5 totaled 799,079 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 19,382 cars, or 2.4 per cent less than for the preceding week; 52,197 cars, or 7 per cent more than for the corresponding week last year, and 66,310 cars, or 9 per cent more than during the corresponding week two years ago.

LONDON, Sept. 10 -- A new phase in the long-drawn-out war against the common cold was announced here today in The Lancet, British medical magazine, by Dr. Christopher H. Andrewes, Britain's leading cold specialist, who has been able to preserve and grow the virus of the common cold in cultures of human lung tissue.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (AP) -- Business inventories were estimated at $77,000,000,000 on July 31, virtually unchanged from the June level, despite the fact that stocks normally decline in July, the Department of Commerce said today.

HAVANA, Sept. 10 -- A new investigation has been initiated by the Cuban police in an effort to apprehend three individuals who attacked Manuel Cardinal Arteaga last Aug. 12 in his palace, according to an official statement issued by the publicity department of the Presidential Palace today.

OXFORD, Miss., Sept. 10 -- The free flow of international private investment and freer convertibility of currencies in foreign countries constitute the main mechanisms for maintaining and expanding this country's export trade, the first annual Mid-South World Trade Institute was told today.

TOKYO, Friday, Sept. 11--Indian troops who began taking custody yesterday of North Korean war prisoners who refused to return to their homelands had to quell a disturbance by the captives when the latter spotted a group of Communist observers watching the transfer.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Sept. 10 -- Indonesia's Provisional Parliament by a surprisingly overwhelming vote of 122 to 34 has given the newly-formed left-wing Cabinet of Dr. Ali Sastroamidjojo an "opportunity to carry out its program."

A mere change of Administration does not automatically remove from Washington's social and business circles those gentlemen who make a pleasant living through their real or avowed contacts with Government officials entrusted with recommending or awarding contracts.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- A second Senate investigating panel disclosed plans today to make further inquiry into the loyalty status of certain American staff members of the United Nations. One Senate investigation thus far -- by the Jenner Internal Security subcommittee -- has been followed by the dismissal of more than a score of the employes and appeals that have resulted in controversy.
This year's drought has drained all live color from foliage on the high slopes of Palisades Interstate Park, where trees yesterday were a dead brown. Looking at the seared reaches 500...

THE born wit, who should be one of the treasured members of society, has fallen upon sad days in TV. He has been publicly seduced and reduced to the role of a spear carrier, a helpless soul who is expected to provide silly little sallies for the exhibitionists who wander in on television's panel shows. He is the water boy on the team of Goodson and Todman.

Your editorial of Sept. 7 paints a grim but realistic picture of the inadequacies of our school buildings. It should help to rouse Americans from their present complacency regarding public education. We are usually a practical people, willing, when we want the best in essentials or luxuries, to pay generously for them.

A decline last week of 437,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end on last Saturday, Sept. 5, supplies were 142,850,000 barrels, compared with 143,287,000 a week earlier and 116,830,000 a year ago.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (U. P.) -- Following is the text of the communique issued by the Foreign Ministers of the United States, Australia and New Zealand at the conclusion of their two-day conference here:

The meeting of the ANZUS Treaty Council, just ended, has brought a fresh sense of solidarity with our allies in Australia and New Zealand. In the Council's communique the visiting Foreign Secretaries reveal a close agreement on issues in respect to Asia. It is refreshing to have the strong assurance that these countries will not, under present conditions, consider the recognition of the Chinese Communist regime or its admission to the United Nations.

The cause of European unification advanced another long step when the High Authority of the European Coal and Steel Community demonstrated that it is in fact as well as in theory a new and supranational power center, able to impose its decisions on member Governments.

Oliver Smith and Peggy Fears are virtually set to go ahead with plans for the Broadway revival this season of "Cabin in the Sky," the musical fantasy by Lynn Root, John Latouche and Vernon Duke. In a matter of days, Pearl Bailey is expected to sign contracts to undertake the role of Petunia Jackson, the heroic church worker who fights for the soul of her bad-boy husband, Little Joe.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- The country's highest personages paid a last honor today in behalf of the United States to the Chief Justice, Fred M. Vinson, who died early Tuesday at the age of 63.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 10 -- Republic Pictures opened its doors wide today to independent productions in a sweeping change of operating policy that might well have a profound effect on the whole system of Hollywood film production

LIMASSOL, Cyprus, Sept. 10 -- The worst earthquake in the history of Cyprus spread death and destruction through this East Mediterranean island today and the British fleet broke off maneuvers to rush aid.

ONE of the phenomena of mid-twentieth-century, fiction that troubles the sleep of numerous publishers is the persistence with which many of the ablest novelists leave the virtue of narrative drive to their literary inferiors. To tell a story, keeping readers emotionally concerned about what happens next, is still the intention of many writers. But all too often they are mediocre craftsmen afflicted with adolescence of mind and flamboyance of style.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- Martin P. Durkin resigned as Secretary of Labor today, protesting that the White House had backed down on an agreement to send to Congress nineteen proposed amendments to the Taft-Hartley Law.

To transform the tender and delightful story of "Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs" into a sequence in an ice show might seem a challenging assignment that is not particularly astute. By this time millions of oldsters and youngsters have seen Walt Disney's brilliant screen version of the Snow White fable and just about all of the viewers have pleasant recollections of its artistry.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (AP) -- The Army today suspended Louis Fragala, an $8,500-a-year engineering supervisor at Fort Eustis, Va., who was indicted more than fourteen months ago for perjury and conspiracy to defraud the Government.

SAIGON, Vietnam, Sept. 10 -- Nguyen Van Tam, Premier of Vietnam, arrived here this evening from Paris and said he would put into effect soon instructions he had received from Bao Dai, Chief of State, to form a representative national congress to prepare for forthcoming independence negotiations with France.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- A British Treasury spokesman called on the International Monetary Fund today to help underwrite that nation's drive toward Sterling convertibility and warned that further delay might drive Britain to erect her economic fences around the Commonwealth trading area.

Robert F. Wagner Jr., Borough President of Manhattan, told Harlem audiences last night that Mayor Impellitteri, his rival for the Democratic mayoral nomination in Tuesday's primary, had blocked approval of a civil rights measure in the City Council.

DOUGLAS, Isle of Man -- Sept. 10 -- British union labor conservatism showed its strength today at the annual conference of the Trades Union Congress here as delegates voted down a series of left - wing resolutions covering East-West trade, wage restraint and union cooperation with the Conservative Government.

Cities as Investors The cash holdings and trust fund investments of the nation's major cities equal about 57 per cent of the outstanding debt of the same cities, according to the most recent survey of the Department of Commerce Bureau of the Census. As of the end of last year, 481 of the nation's major cities with population of 25,000 or more had outstanding debt totaling $10,592,000.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 10 -- The New York State law providing mandatory tests for motor vehicle drivers charged with intoxication was called an infringement of individual constitutional rights today at the fifty-first annual convention of the American Automobile Association.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (UP) -- Senator Alexander Wiley, Republican of Wisconsin, chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, called today for a revision of the United Nations Charter to block the "irresponsible use of the veto" by the Soviet Union.
I should like to add some thoughts to the articles of William J. Jorden and your editorial of Sept. 8 regarding "anti-Americanism" and "anti-Yankeeism" in Japan.

TEHERAN, Iran, Sept. 10 -- The hunger strike proclaimed by Dr. Mohammed Mossadegh, jailed former Premier of Iran, after breakfast yesterday ended before lunch time the same day, according to a Government source.

Publication of the annual report of the Rockefeller Foundation is always an event of scientific significance. The report for the year 1952 is of particular interest because it emphasizes again the debt that the world owes to the Foundation's far-flung activities and to its remarkable adaptability to changing social needs.
CHICAGO, Sept. 10 -- Stephen A. Mitchell, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, issued today the following statement on Mr. Durkin's resignation:
Prices on the New York Commodity exchanges closed generally mixed or lower yesterday, although a few commodities registered small gains. Coffee, sugar, cocoa, potatoes and burlap were most active.

Directors of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad Company yesterday declared a dividend of $2 a share on its preferred stock for payment on Oct. 2. Of the dividend, $1 is from the 1951 available net and the other $1 from the 1952 net.

CHICAGO, Sept. 10 -- Grain futures continued the decline which started yesterday, demand being conspicuously slow in contrast to the active buying which featured the trade early in the week. Wheat led the decline. There also was pressure on corn and other grains, while soybeans held rather firm, relatively.

BIARRITZ, France, Sept. 10 (AP) -- An attorney for former King Peter of Yugoslavia said today the exiled monarch and his wife, ex-Queen Alexandra, planned to get a divorce. This confirmed long-standing, rumors of a rift in the couple's marriage of more than nine years.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (UP) -The nation apparently reached the peak of the 1953 poliomyelitis outbreak in the week ending Aug. 22, the United States Public Health Services reported today.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was steady yesterday, with active months closing unchanged to 20 points up.
A Brooklyn luncheonette owner was held captive in his home for five and a half hours yesterday morning by a knife-wielding narcotics addict and robbed of $180 and a ring valued at $450.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (AP) -- Among members of Congress in town today, there was general surprise that Mr. Durkin had resigned. Comments from some Democrats indicated they saw the development as an embarrassment to the Administration and a political advantage to their party.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., Sept. 10 -- For a man who says he has not made up his mind about running for a fourth term, Governor Dewey looked like a candidate in the heat of a feverish campaign today as he made his annual Governor's Day visit to the State Fair here.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- Department store sales in the week ended Sept. 5 were unchanged from the corresponding week of last year. This was reported today by the Federal Reserve Board which listed the folowing changes from like periods of 1952:
WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (AP) -- Revenue Commissioner T. Coleman Andrews today ordered a halt to any new house-to-house canvasses by revenue agents in a search for tax dodgers.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (AP) -- Harold E. Stassen, Foreign Operations Administrator, outlined today a plan to cut the Government's multi-million-dollar Point Four aid program by increasing the use of private United States agencies in under-developed countries.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (AP) -- Hot dry weather in August trimmed the nation's corn crop about 3.5 per cent and in doing so eliminated the possibility of rigid marketing quotas on next year's crop.
National League sluggers yesterday set down the 1953 season as the most prolific home run hitting campaign in the seventy-seven-year history of major league baseball.

Bulgaria is the least of our worries these days, but it is interesting that Sofia is seeking to resume diplomatic ties with the United States. Relations were "suspended" -- not broken -- on Feb. 21, 1950, after Bulgaria had declared our Minister, Donald R. Heath, persona non grata.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development plans to market $75,000,000 of three-year bonds on Sept. 29, Eugene R. Black, president of the bank, disclosed today.

BOSTON, Sept. 10 (UP) -- Ted Williams hit two homers while driving in four runs during the six innings he played today as the Red Sox beat Cleveland, 14 -- 4, and dropped the Indians ten games back of the league-leading Yankees.

TAIPEI, Formosa, Sept. 10 -- Senator William F. Knowland, California Republican who is majority leader in the upper house of Congress, called for an early conclusion today of a Pacific alliance to include South Korea, Japan, Nationalist China, the Philippines and a "number of nations in Southeast Asia."

Rails slumped to their lowest levels since May 1, 1952, in a stock market that drifted steadily downward most of yesterday and plunged in the final hour on increased volume. Losses were general and ranged from fractions to 2 points, with rails, motors and oils giving the most ground. Closing prices were close to the lows for the day.

WITH reasonable cooperation from the weather man the week-end fishing should be pleasant and productive, for the bluefish are still plentiful, white marlin are a possibility, and albacore are present in good numbers.

STAMFORD, Conn., Sept. 10 -- Two slender youths entered the East Side branch of the Fidelity Title and Trust Company here a short time after it opened for business this morning, held up the three employes at revolver-point and walked out three minutes later with $32,000.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 10 -- The National Urban League addressed to President Eisenhower and Congress today a demand for a Federal fair employment practices law.

FRANK SULLIVAN has the courage to talk nonsense to the American people. He stands among the first of living humorists, among the last of the great Benchleyan line. If his Dr. Arbuthnot, the cliche expert, will permit me to say so, his new book of fine, irresponsible sketches, "The Night the Old Nostalgia Burned Down," * is a taut, superior, raffish, hflariously Diverting, well organized and far from undistinguished work of art.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- Average primary market prices registered no change in the week ended Sept. 8 but remained at 110.3, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. Higher average prices for farm products were counterbalanced by lower average prices for processed foods.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- An international insurance organization to protect foreign capital investors from such abnormal risks as expropriation or nationalization was proposed today to governors of the International Monetary Fund and International Bank for Reconstruction and Development.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy was accused, in effect, today by a Department of the Army spokesman of having violated the anti-espionage law by making public Wednesday a "restricted" military intelligence document that the Wisconsin Republican denounced as being "95 per cent Communist propaganda."

MILWAUKEE, Sept. 11 -- Along with 34,360 Milwaukee fans, President Walter O'Malley sat in County Stadium for three hours and twenty-five minutes tonight waiting for the moment when he and his Dodgers would begin celebrating the clinching of their second straight National League pennant.

Borough President Robert F. Wagner Jr. of Manhattan promised yesterday to drive racketeers from New York's waterfront, rehabilitate city piers, review dock rents and promote greater use of harbor facilities if he is nominated for Mayor in Tuesday's Democratic primary and subsequently elected.

WESTBURY, L. I., Sept. 11-Paige H. West's Paige Direct, with Alan Myer in the sulky, captured the $4,500 Illinois by a half length in Roosevelt Raceway tonight. Paying $11 for $2, Paige Direct was clocked in 2:04 1/5 for the mile pace. Neal Houslet finished second with Scotch Spencer, while Jimmy Jordan was third with Steward Lad.

Short-term interest rates have already passed their peak, bankers were told yesterday. Dr. Marcus Nadler, professor of finance at New York University's graduate school of business administration, added that the "pending economic readjustment" and the expiration of the excess profits tax will lead to a moderate decrease in the demand for bank credit.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 - John Edwin Hull was born at Greenfield, Ohio, May 26, 1895. He received his regular commission as a second lieutenant of infantry Oct. 25, 1917. His first assignment was with the Fifty-eighth Infantry at Camp Green, N. C.

LONDON, Sept. 11 -- Gains by British Government stocks and foreign bonds were the main feature of business in the stock markets today. Business in other markets moved cautiously on yesterday's decline in Wall Street and prices fluctuated narrowly.

Markets for basic investment yields were firm and quiet yesterday. But there was intense activity in the syndicate departments of the big underwriting houses as final preparations were made for a series of major marketings slated for next week -- a schedule ranking in volume with any in financial history.
Five of the painters now showing work in metropolitan galleries practice a variety of contemporary styles.
Chief Warrant Officer Thomas O. Beauchamp grinned as proudly as any father yesterday while three of his "boys" began a three-day round as V. I. P. guests of the Society of the First Division.

As President of the Borough of Manhattan, Bob Wagner has gone further than any of his predecessors toward restoring a means for self-expression to the local neighborhoods of his borough. The importance of the small community as a vital part of the democratic process has been neglected in New York as the gap has widened between the individual citizen and the harassed municipal administration.

" Carnival in Flanders," which had some fairly calamitous encounters on its long and determined journey to Broadway only to be buffeted by the local drama appraisers when it opened early this week at the Century Theatre, will retire after tonight's performance, the sixth.

Harold Riegelman, Republican candidate for Mayor, said early today that the Democrats have "murdered" each other in a "suicide campaign" battle for primary designations and asserted they would lose the November election because "this year they will not have the support of splinter parties."
BERLIN, Sept. 11 (AP) -- Dr. Ernst Reuter, Mayor of West Berlin, said today Soviet policy was wavering and he believed the powder-keg problem of a divided Germany would be settled without war.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- The United States sharply prodded the Soviet Union today for the return of 670 vessels supplied by Washington to Moscow under the Lend-Lease program of Warld War II.

The usual week-end doldrums, coupled with the Jewish holiday, kept volume down yesterday on the New York commodity exchanges. Prices closed irregular. Cottonseed oil, soybean oil, burlap, hides, rubber and tin were higher; coffee, sugar, zinc, lead and wool lower, and cocoa, potatoes and copper mixed.

DENVER, Sept. 11 -- Gen. John Edwin Hull, Vice Chief of Staff of the Army, was designated by President Eisenhower today to be United Nations Commander in Korea and Commander in Chief of this country's Far Eastern Command.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 11 -- Walter Pidgeon and Louis Calhern, currently busy in Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer's "Executive Suite," have been chosen by the studio for lead roles in "Panther Squadron 8."

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 11 -- Yugoslavia appeared today to be permitting the latest crisis with Italy over Trieste to take its place with several other fruitless flare-ups that have characterized relations between the two countries since the end of World War II.

A two-man team of scientists will embark next week from San Francisco for the wildernesses of Thailand to gather data on tribal groups, Dr. Harry L. Shapiro, chairman of the American Museum of Natural History's department of anthropology, said yesterday.

NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 11 -- Peasant dissatisfaction with the ancient inequalities on the land has taken a unique and peculiarly Indian form in Bombay State where crowds of up to 3000 peasant volunteers, led by officials of the Praja Socialist party, have been attempting symbolic cultivation of vast tracts of privately-owned grasslands in defiance of the owners and the police.

INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 11 (AP) -- Evalina Hanover, owned by the Poplar Mill Farm of Lexington, Ky., and driven by young Al Winger, set a season record of 1:59 2-5 for aged pacing mares in the final session of the Indiana State Fair Grand Circuit meeting today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (AP) -- Oswald Ryan, chairman of the Civil Aeronautics Board has informed Representative Thomas J. Lane, Democrat of Massachusetts, that the agency neither "prescribed nor approved" regulations by air carriers concerning their right to refuse transportation.
Cuthbert C. Snowden has been elected vice president in charge of the industrial division of Frigidinner, Inc., Philadelphia.
A further step toward the liberalization of the controversial amateur tennis code in this country was taken by the United States Lawn Tennis Association yesterday.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Sept. 11 (UP) -- Joseph E. Moody, President of the Southern Coal Producers Association, called on the operators, miners and Federal Government tonight to work together to save the coal industry.

BONN, Germany, Sept. 11 -- The office of the United States High Commissioner, acting on instructions from Washington, has agreed to the re-establishment of handicraft guild monopolies in the United States zone in answer to a pre-election appeal from Chancellor Konrad Adenauer to John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 11 -- The House of Representatives Committee on Un-American Activities disclosed here tonight that Lucille Ball, television and movie actress, had acknowledged having registered to vote as a Communist in 1936, but added that no evidence had been uncovered that she ever had belonged to the Communist party.
RABAT, Morocco, Sept. 11 -- An Arab in a speeding car knocked the pro-French Sultan of Morocco off his horse during a religious procession today in an assassination attempt.

The Los Angeles County, Calif., Sanitation District No. 21 has awarded an issue of $2,300,000 of bonds due from 1954 to 1982 to a syndicate headed by the Security First National Bank of Los Angeles at a bid of 102.18 for interest of 3 1/2 per cent, an interest cost of 3.3719 per cent.

The Sept. 2 dispatch in THE NEW YORK TIMES regarding the "loyalty ousters of United States aides in U. N." quotes the statement by Senator McCarthy to the effect that "if we can be forced to have Communists represent us in the United Nations, then we should very seriously consider the wisdom of remaining in that body."

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 11 -- The uncontrolled use of radar and other electrical speed detection devices for wholesale arrests on the highways without improving traffic conditions was opposed today at the closing session of the fifty-first annual meeting of the American Automobile Association.

Gen. Lee Bum Suk, former Premier of the Republic of Korea, denied here yesterday that the dismissal of two Cabinet Minister and dissolution of all youth groups at Seoul had anything to do with him or with a struggle for power between him and Premier Paik Too Chin.

Universal Cyclops Steel Corporation announced yesterday an extra dividend of 50 cents a share and a quarterly disbursement of 35 cents a share on the common stock, both payable on Sept. 30. The company produces tool steels, stainless steel and high-grade special steels.

" Always being told what to do" was one of the major dislikes 5-to-12-year-old boys and girls registered in regard to parental upbringing and discipline when questioned in a recent survey by the Youth Research Institute. The institute specializes in studying the tastes, attitudes and opinions of young people.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Sept. 11 -- In a proclamation issued today Governor General Sir William Slim claimed for Australia the sovereign rights over the seabed and subsoil of the continental shelf adjacent to the Commonwealth and its territories to a depth of 100 fathoms (600 feet).

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Sept. 11 -- One hundred and ninety- one boats came out today for the third session of the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club's fall race series. And they had a breeze for a change. The same courses as on the second day were set, short ones for the so-called small fry in the bay and a nine-mile journey for the larger creations.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Sept. 11 -- The trustees of Rutgers University today accepted the resignation of Abraham Glasser, Professor of Law, who had been under fire for his refusal to answer a question on Communist party membership put to him by the House Committee on Un-American Activities last March 17.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 11 -- Members of the Pacific Coast Union of Marine Firemen, Oilers, Watertenders and Wipers expect to be back in the American Federation of Labor before the end of September. This would renew an association that was severed in 1936 when the firemen reorganized as an independent union.

The victory of Mrs. Michael G. Walsh's Reno Sam in the $10,975 Harbor Hill Steeplechase shared interest with the return to action of C. V. Whitney's Fisherman at Aqueduct yesterday. Fisherman, competing in an allowance race of five and a half furlongs, won with such authority, though, that the crowd of 23,819 accorded him more attention than they gave to the 11-year-old jumper.

Now that the actors have finished with the summer, "The World of Sholom Aleichem" has come back to the Barbizon-Plaza, where it opened last evening. Even if the new theatre season were already full of good items, this would be a time for rejoicing.

DENVER, Sept. 11 -- When President Eisenhower takes to the golf links the gallery is as likely to hear "honk! honk!" as "fore!" Today, as he played his first game of golf with Vice President Nixon, President Eisenhower covered some of the long hauls along the fairways in a three-wheeled motor scooter called an "autoette."

MONTREAL, Sept. 11 (AP) -- Tony Trabert and Vic Seixas, although both were hobbling at the finish, scored quick victories over Canada's top players today to send the United States off to a 2-0 lead in the American zone final of the Davis Cup competition.

MELBOURNE, Sept. 11 -- A further 10 per cent relaxation of import restrictions imposed in March, 1952, will be effected on Oct. 1. The dollar countries will be excluded and Japan will receive separate treatment. Relaxations are expected to allow 45 million Australian pounds worth more goods into Australia annually.
BERLIN, Sept. 11 -- A child's prank in locking a schoolgirl into a bathroom eleven days ago touched off an international incident that by tonight appeared to have run its stormy course.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- President Eisenhower soon will be called on to break a tie in the Federal Tariff Commission on whether or not special tariff relief should be given the domestic hand-blown glass industry.

CHICAGO, Sept. 11 -- Five brewers of national brand beers have scheduled wholesale price increases effective Oct. 1, which would raise the price of a twelve-ounce bottle or can of beer 1 cent on the retail market, and half-cent on a ten-ounce glass of beer, the National Beer Wholesalers Association said today.

Admiral Robert B. Carney, Chief of Naval Operations, warned yesterday that the American people would surely get "bargain merchandise" in their military services if they were willing to pay no more than bargain prices.

The report made earlier this week at a meeting of the British Association for the Advancement of Science that certain processing methods damaged the protein value of breakfast cereals must have caught the attention of many women who plan home meals.

LUXEMBOURG, Sept. 11 -- Many strange events have occurred in the long history of Luxembourg, but nothing so unprecedented as what is happening now. Marched over by every conqueror for a thousand years, this tiny realm is like a mirror reflecting the martial story of Europe.

The British pound sterling continued soft in the foreign exchange market here yesterday. Under constant pressure the last ten days, with liberal offerings appearing in the market and only light demand, the pound dipped to $2.79 15/16, the lowest level reached since November, last year.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (AP) -- More than $9,000,000 worth of municipal bonds were offered for sale today by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation in its first move to liquidate its billion-dollar holdings of assorted securities.

OXFORD, Miss., Sept. 11 -- This country's assumption of leadership in the development of a trade control program to deny transmittal of strategic materials to Iron Curtain countries points up the need for more generous trade policies affecting free world markets.

GENEVA, Sept. 11 -- It is "incomprehensible to the Government and the people of the United States" that the Soviet Union could have treated with "such complete contempt for civilized international practice" the efforts of the United Nations to locate and repatriate missing prisoners of World War II, James C. Dunn, United States Ambassador to Spain, said here today.

The sweeping election victory of Chancellor Adenauer in Germany has raised two questions in many minds, especially in Europe. The first is, Did the Germans vote for a policy, or did they vote for a strong man as a new leader? The second is, What is Chancellor Adenauer going to do with his victory?

Passengers aboard the Swedish American Line's new luxury liner Kungsholm will be able to place radiotelephone calls direct from stateroom to anywhere in the world through the facilities of the extra powerful radio station being built into the vessel, company officials said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- Martin P. Durkin went back to his union president's job today after his resignation as Secretary of Labor and his charge that the White House had let him down on an agreement to recommend nineteen changes in the Taft-Hartley Law.

SALT LAKE CITY, Sept. 11 -- Dr. Edward J. McCormick, president of the American Medical Association, sharply attacked today Federal policies affording hospitalization and treatment for veterans who have non-service connected disabilities. Dr. McCormick challenged the Government's moral right to "conduct a vast, ever-expanding medical care program which has to be paid for by all tax-payers, but which operated for the benefit of just one particular group."

ROME, Sept. 11 -- Food production in the world as a whole regained its pre-World War II level for the first time in the agricultural year 1952-53, the United Nations Food and Agriculture. Organization announced today. This is the central fact of the agency's annual report, which will be released on Sunday.

With summer almost over and the family spending more time indoors, homemakers may find their hardwood floors and hard surface floor coverings receiving additional traffic. Some recently published information may aid in determining the most efficient means of maintenance and refinishing.

The Chamber of Commerce of the United States, Washington, D. C., is asking all those in the advertising and communications fields to participate in an effort to "sell" advertising to the American public. "If those in the ad business don't tell advertising's story, who will?" asks the Chamber.

ARMONK, N. Y., Sept. 11 -- Barbara Bruning, the 21-year-old whippoorwill star out of competition most of the season recovering from glandular fever, today made her second tournament appearance of the year and was victorious for the second time.

DONCASTER, England, Sept. 11 (AP) -- Britain's most illustrious race-goers -- Queen Elizabeth and Prime Minister Sir Winston Churchill, will be at Doncaster tomorrow to see the historic St. Leger race. They will be together in the royal box, but some of that royal decorum is likely to disappear soon after 10:15 A. M. (New York time).

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Sept. 11 -- Eating on the run, a mealtime practice in many American homes, may account to some extent for lack of appetite in children, according to Dr. Paul Williamson of the American Academy of General Practice here.

TRENTON, Sept. 11 (AP) -- The New Jersey Department of Banking and Insurance announced today changes amounting to an average 1.25 per cent reduction in automobile fire, theft and collision insurance rates effective in the state next Monday.

Manufacturers and retailers of men's clothing who plan on summer business to the exclusion of spring activity should realign their thinking, Phil A. Cohen, vice president of Top-O-Mart Clothes, Inc., said yesterday. While the spring season admittedly is shrinking slightly, he continued, there are many buyers waiting for these suits.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- Joseph Zack Kornfeder, who said he once was a worker at the Communist party's international headquarters in Moscow but quit the party in 1934, has told the House Un-American Activities Committee that there are 600 Protestant clergymen who are secret members of the Communist party and 2,000 more "pretty close to the machine."

Police Commissioner George P. Monaghan told 400 officers of the department yesterday to "make damn sure" that the ballot boxes were empty before the voting started at the primary election next Tuesday "so that there will be no charge that the police permitted the stuffing of the ballot boxes."

CHICAGO, Sept. 11 -- Needles that a doctor may implant and leave with safety in his patient's body have been developed at the Naval Hospital in St. Albans, Queens, N. Y., the American Chemical Society heard today at a closing session of its national meeting.

The price of zinc dropped a half-cent a pound yesterday to 10 cents, East St. Louis, Ill., the lowest level in three and one- half years. The cut was begun in the custom smelter field and soon was matched by other sellers.

OTTAWA, Sept. 11 (AP) -- The Cleveland Browns of the National Football League today filed notice they will seek special permission to have their injunction case against John Kissell, a tackle, heard soon.

DOUGLAS, Isle of Man, Sept. 11 -- Delegates representing Britain's 8,000,000 trade union workers wound up their eighty-fifth annual Trades Union Congress here today after having voted down virtually every resolution or proposal put forward by Communist-controlled unions or by the adherents of Aneurin Bevan, leader of the Left Wing of the Labor party.

Winners of the first scholarships offered by the American Theatre Wing Professional Training Program were announced yesterday. Constance Simons of Willimansette, Mass., was selected for the Mary MacArthur Scholarship, donated by Helen Hayes in memory of her daughter.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- Dag Hammarskjold, Secretary General of the United Nations, laid down a policy today of close cooperation with American political scientists in the administration of United Nations affairs.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were moderately active yesterday and closing prices were 3 points higher to 8 points lower than on Thursday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- Robert T. Stevens, Secretary of the Army, announced today his decision to award to the Fisher body division of General Motors a contract of approximately $200,000,000 for the building of M-48 medium tanks.

PARIS, Sept. 11 -- France could recapture the leadership of Western Europe if she promptly seized the perhaps unique opportunity offered by the success of Chancellor Konrad Adenauer in the West German elections and the success of French pleas to the United States to underwrite a greater share of the cost of the war in Indo-China, in the opinion of some of the most qualified French observers here.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- With an exchange of diplomatic pleasantries and a prospect of hard bargaining ahead, the United States and Panama opened negotiations today on issues that have arisen over operation of the Canal Zone.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 11 -- The United Nations was asked today to cut the United States' share in the organization's budget and increase the share of the Soviet Union. The United States' budget expert voted for the recommendation while Moscow's specialist thought it was a poor idea.

I have read your editorial of Aug. 25 "Batista's Dilemma." Since there appear in the editorial -- no doubt as a result of your having been misinformed -- certain untrue affirmations, I am compelled to make the following explanations:

Parents with children entering the first grade Monday may be interested in a special television presentation of a new film over WPIX at 6 P. M. tomorrow. Called "Skippy and the Three R's," the film was produced by the National Education Association and affiliated state education associations. The half-hour (16 mm.) picture illustrates what the first school year means to Skippy.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- The Democrats made it clear today that the development of a general attack on the farm policies of the Eisenhower Administration would be an important part of the party's national conference opening Monday in Chicago.
Rosh ha-Shanah services marking the second day of the Jewish New Year were held yesterday in Conservative and Orthodox synagogues.
The General Electric Company announced yesterday it would lay off 700 employes in the home freezer and refrigeration department for two weeks, beginning Monday.
In a statement issued at his home in Cliffside, N. J., Dr. Harry F. Ward declared last night that "I am not and never have been a member of any political party."
For the first time in its history, the Citizens Union made recommendations yesterday in five of the Tammany Assembly District leadership contests.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (UP) -- The Internal Revenue service today declined to discuss a published report that it had granted former President Truman a favorable tax ruling that would save him $165,000 on the sale of his memoirs.

Today should be a grand day on the Hudson, as well as a colorful climax to International Maritime Week. The river will be alive with fireboats, naval vessels, excursion boats, Coast Guard cutters, observation vessels, yachts, hooting tugs, darting helicopters and a clutter of small craft as it becomes the scene of this year's Port of New York Tugboat Races and the World's Championship Lifeboat Race.

Our National Security Council has recommended a substantial increase in the amount of our assistance to the campaign against the Communist onslaught in Indo-China. The Indo-China front is a vital defense point for the free world and it is, therefore, natural and logical that we should do even more, if we can, to strengthen it.
Twenty-eight Japanese municipal officials on a tour of the city yesterday got a hasty glimpse of the Statue of Liberty and a longer look at the New York Stock Exchange and the United Nations center.
NEWPORT, R. I., Sept. 11 (AP) -- The United States Lawn Tennis Association today gave conditional approval to the Newport Casino to establish a tennis Hall of Fame and Museum.

STONY BROOK, L. I., Sept. 11 -- Jazz Session, a 3-year-old bay gelding owned by Mr. and Mrs. W. Haggin Perry of Cobham, Va., and ridden by Stuart Lanham, won the green hunter championship with 14 points as the twentieth annual North Shore horse show opened today.

CHICAGO, Sept. 11 -- Grain prices suffered further declines today, with scattered local and commission selling. The Government crop figures were not construed as particularly bullish, especially as the reduction in the corn forecast was not as great as had been expected.

ANKARA, Turkey, Sept. 10 -- The problem of the large Turkish minority in Bulgaria -- one of southeastern Europe's most perplexing population dilemmas -- is being studied afresh by the Turkish Government following the pronouncement by Vulko Chervenkov, Bulgarian Premier, that his Government would seek the solution of all outstanding issues with Turkey and Bulgaria's other neighbors.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 11 (AP) -Virgil Trucks helped seal his nine-teenth pitching vistory tonight with his first home run of the season and a single as the White Sox jumped off to an early lead and then coasted home over the Athletics, 9 -- 4.
