James Brooks, an affable and modest truck driver who has driven through the Lincoln Tunnel without incident more times than he can remember, is not likely to forget the ride he took last Tuesday when, with two Port Authority patrolmen perched on the running boards of his truck, he sped into the tunnel and into a blazing pistol battle that ended with the capture of two armed hold-up men.

OTTAWA, Sept. 11 (AP) -- Although Canada's prairie farmers have produced a near-record grain crop this year, many may have to fall back on the earnings of last year's record harvest to tide them over the critical months ahead.

For the past three years Arden House, near Harriman, N. Y., has been identified with an idea that has already become far more impressive than even the magnificent estate which is its home. That idea is known as the American Assembly. The Assembly was conceived in 1950 by General Eisenhower, then president of Columbia University, and it was organized under Columbia's Graduate School of Business.
BALTIMORE, Sept. 11 (UP) -- Pete Cooper, a little-known pro who has allowed himself two years to break into the big money of tournament golf, took the lead today in the $15,000 Eastern open.

BLACKSBURG, Va., Sept. 11 (UP) -- The first Negro undergraduate to be accepted at an all-white state supported institution in Virginia will attend Virginia Polytechnic Institute here when classes begin Sept. 19, Walter Newman, President of the institute, announced today.

Again this year the United States has been blessed by bountiful crops. The Department of Agriculture's September report makes this clear. August's heat and dryness did some damage, but, even so, we are harvesting the third greatest volume of crops in our history.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Sept. 11 -- The Minister of State Welfare, Sudibyo, who was expelled from the Marxist-oriented United Islam party earlier this week for joining the new Indonesian Cabinet of Dr. Ali Sastroamidjojo without party permission, tendered his resignation today from the Cabinet, effective immediately.

LONDON, Sept. 11 -- Efforts to bring Britain into closer association with European Coal and Steel Community have been renewed by the community's High Authority. D. J. Ezra, member of the British delegation to the authority disclosed in a talk at Oxford today that Jean Monnet, President of the High Authority, was to make specific proposals to the British Government within the next few weeks and that the Government had promised to study them sympathetically.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Sept. 11 -- Dr. Daniel F. Malan, South African Prime Minister, will make another attempt Wednesday to strike 47,000 persons of mixed blood, called colored, off the electoral register of voters in Cape Province.
BOSTON, Sept. 11 (AP) -- Right-hander Duane Pillette handcuffed Ted Williams while pitching the last-place Browns to a 2-0 shutout over the Red Sox today with a brilliant three-hit performance.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (AP) -- The Department of Defense released today the names of 482 additional U. S. soldiers and marines still missing after reported capture by the Communists in Korea. The men are among the 944 Americans still unaccounted for after completion of the prisoner exchange in Korea.

CHICAGO, Sept. 11 -- Indiana Steel Products Company, Valparaiso, Ind., reported net income in the first six months of the year rose to $209,601, equal to $1.47 a share, from $145,164, or $1.02 a share in the first half of 1952. Sales and production reached a new high for a six-month period, said Robert F. Smith, president.

ROME, Sept. 11 -- Further evidence in support of the theory that cancer is caused by a living organism such as a sub-microscopic virus or even a larger type of germ was presented here today at the sixth International Congress of Microbiology.

BLOOMFIELD, N. J., Sept. 11 -- Jerry Volpe and Chester Sanok of Forsgate won the eighteenth New Jersey Golf Association's pro-amateur best-ball championship over the Forest Hill Field Club course today.

Waves of selling swept into the stock market yesterday and battered prices down to new lows for the year in every department. Before the storm had run its course 381 issues had made individual lows and volume -- heaviest when prices were weakest -- had mounted to 1,930,000 shares, biggest since Aug. 31.

BRONXVILLE, N. Y., Sept. 11 -- Joseph H. Reid, executive director of the Child Welfare League of America, described here today the growing influence of "residential treatment centers" on the rehabilitation of emotionally disturbed children over the country. He recently completed a nation-wide study of such institutions.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- Earle O. Whittier, a chemist for the Department of Agriculture, has dedicated to free public use Patent No. 2,651,574, which covers a cold method of making candy, confections and icings. Professional and amateur cooks can get the details by sending 25 cents and the patent number to the Commissioner of Patents.

Southpaw Ted Gray, who has suffered more than a fair share of indignities at the hands of the Yankees this season, pitched and batted the resurgent Tigers to a 3-2 victory over the Bombers in a ten-inning contest at the Stadium yesterday.

The instantaneous response of a patrolman resulted yesterday in the arrest of two husky young hitch-hikers who had forced their smaller host to accompany them -- in his own automobile -- from Philadelphia to the Manhattan end of the Holland Tunnel.

PARAMUS, N. J., Sept. 11 -- A three-way tie resulted for top honors in a weekly one-day tournament of the Women's New Jersey Golf Association at the Ridgewood Country Club today, Jane Goss of Somerset Hills, Mrs. Gordon Park of Glen Ridge and Essene De Cozen of Montclair all scoring 81's.

CHICAGO, Sept. 11 -- "Everything happens to me," said Alvin Dark today as he began his forty-eight-hour sentence to manage the Giants against the Cubs at Wrigley Field. "Not only do I have to make my debut as a mastermind against the hottest club in the league, but right at the outset I meet with insubordination."

TORONTO, Sept. 11 -- Personality factors play a greater role in the road accident rate than alcohol, according to the results of a recent survey of motor vehicle accidents conducted by the University of Toronto.

WEDGEPORT, N. S., Sept. 11 (Canadian Press) -- Wary tuna stayed clear of the hooks today in the second day of the tenth international tuna tournament that saw many of the world's best anglers try waters twenty miles at sea in a desperate attempt to break the jinx.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (AP) -- Senator Wayne Morse, Independent of Oregon, told the Navy today he was disturbed by a report that "East Coast Republicans" were bringing strong pressure to have the third supercarrier of the Forrestal class built at an Atlantic Coast shipyard.
DETROIT, Sept. 11 -- The effect of Mr. Stevens' decision was to leave General Motors as the country's sole producer of tanks by next spring.

TOKYO, Saturday, Sept. 12 -- Wilfred Burchett, a Communist reporter and propagandist, indicated yesterday that some Allied airmen missing in the Korean war might be held captive by the Chinese Communists in Manchuria.

The main issue in next Tuesday's Democratic primary is which candidate for the nomination for Mayor will make the city a better place in which to live, Mayor Impellitteri said last night. He listed six specific achievements of his administration as reasons why the voters should support him.

Too few old friends are around to receive birthday greetings at the age of 90. Lawson Purdy, a man who has served this community with enthusiasm, foresight and devotion to the public interest for many years, is eligible for such congratulations and good wishes tomorrow.

" The Springs of Silence," an autobiography by Sister Mary Gilbert, who teaches journalism at Holy Name College in Spokane, Wash., will be published Monday by Prentice-Hall. In telling of her call and entrance into religious service, the readjustment to her new life and her relations with the outside world, Sister Mary details the "true nature" of convent life.
James J. Sherry Jr. has been appointed assistant director of purchases of the Buick Motor division of the General Motors Corporation, effective next Wednesday.

THE comments received from hunters following the disclosure of the United States Fish and Wildlife Service of a fifteen-day jacksnipe season in thirty-six states indicate clearly that the average sportsman is taking a greater interest in conservation matters.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- H. Freeman Matthews, Deputy Under Secretary of State, has been tentatively chosen to be new United States Ambassador to the Netherlands.
Inter-American Press Association said yesterday that Nicaragua would be placed on the growing list of countries in which freedom of the press had been curtailed.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (UP) -- Attorney General Herbert Brownell Jr. today threatened "immediate" prosecution of any Government employe who might have helped a prominent Washington Republican try to get a 4 per cent fee on Navy contracts.
YONKERS, Sept. 11 -- Governor Dewey was asked today to investigate a proposed detour of the new state Thruway that critics charge will benefit the Yonkers Raceway.

TRENTON, Sept. 11 -- Dr. John P. Milligan, Superintendent of Schools in Atlantic City and well- known for his civil rights work, today was named assistant New Jersey commissioner of education in charge of the division against discrimination.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 11 (UP) -- Vinegar Bend Mizell needed stout relief pitching from Al Brazle in the ninth inning tonight to post his thirteenth victory of the season as the Cardinals defeated the Pirates, 5 -- 3.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 11 -- The United States and Britain will stand together in opposing a decision on the admission of Communist China's representatives to the United Nations General Assembly before the Christmas recess. Andrei Y. Vishinsky, the Soviet delegate, has already announced that he will raise the question in the Assembly, which is to convene Tuesday.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 11 -- Scientists from Canada, Britain, Israel, South Africa and the United States will meet in Rome Sept. 14 to 19 under auspices of the World Health Organization, as an expert committee on poliomyelitis.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- On May 2, 1803, President Thomas Jefferson received a letter from Robert R. Livingston, Minister to France. Part of the letter was in cipher, including one line that read:
LONDON, Sept. 11 (AP) -- World natural rubber production exceeded consumption by 35,000 tons in July, the International Rubber Study group announced today.

The circumstances surrounding the resignation of Secretary of Labor Durkin point to the possibility that revision of the Taft-Hartley Act may again become enmeshed in partisan politics. We trust that this will not be permitted to happen.
CINCINNATI, Sept. 11 (AP) -- Ted Kluszewski hit his thirty-ninth homer of the year to lead a six-run Redleg seventh-inning rally that defeated the Phillies tonight, 6 -- 5.
Rudolf Bing, general manager of the Metropolitan Opera, gave a preview yesterday of the Metropolitan's rebuilt orchestra circle, which offers good news of all operagoers except the standees.
WEST POINT, N. Y., Sept. 11 -- Here in the heart of the platoon country the new restrictive substitution rule is raising hob with the development of the Army football team.
PARIS, Sept. 11 -- Reports from the Ministry of Finance indicated today that a wide variety of fraud was being uncovered in the Government's week-old drive against tax evasion in France.
The following is a round-up of information that may be helpful to the homemaker:

James Harmon, who will be 69 years old later this month, is retiring after fifty-five years of service as a caddie at the Scarsdale Golf Club, Hartsdale, N. Y. Members of the club have contributed to a purse to reward him "for unfailing courtesy and faithful attention to those duties which go to make a pleasant round of golf."

TRENTON, Sept. 11 -- Harold John Adonis, former executive clerk in the office of Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll, returned to the State House here today for the first time since he was indicted for bribery, conspiracy and income tax evasion for acts he allegedly committed while in that office.

Both sides remained unyielding yesterday in the negotiations for a new longshoremen's contract covering the Port of New York, but hope for an eventual pact rose somewhat as a three-hour bargaining session ended on a note less acrimonious than usual.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 11 (AP) -- Samuel A. Peck's Potpourri, a candidate for the $25,000 added Foreign-Bred Stakes next Wednesday, turned back three other candidates for the "triple turf classic" in the $5,000 South Atlantic Purse today.

Three hundred and forty-four years ago today the explorer Henry Hudson entered the river that bears his name. A great number of changes have taken place in the verdant, tranquil setting that was to become Nieuw Amsterdam and later New York and it is doubtful that Hudson or his crew members of the Half Moon would recognize the view today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (UP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board took the first step today toward starting a one-year experiment in transporting regular first class mail by airlines when their planes have space available.
CAMP DRUM, N. Y., Sept. 11 -- Military authorities at this reservation today said they would welcome a Congressional investigation of the sale of surplus equipment now under way here.

Carmine Fiore, 24-year-old Brooklyn welterweight, closed strongly in the late rounds to upset Danny (Bang Bang) Womber, Chicago, in the ten-round fight at St. Nicholas Arena last night. Referee Harry Kessler and Judges Frank Forbes and Arthur Schwartz made it a unanimous decision, each scoring 5 for Fiore, 4 for Womber and 1 even.

The annual conference of members of Christian Action, which has been described in its news letter as "an interdenominational fellowship of Christians concerned with the social dimensions of their faith," will be held Monday through Wednesday at the Young Men's Christian Association's Camp Hilltop, Downingtown, Pa., west of Philadelphia.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (AP) -Washington spoiled Bob Lemon's bid to become the first American League pitcher to win twenty games tonight when the Senators splurged for three runs in the eighth inning and defeated Cleveland, 6 -- 4.
LONDON, Sept. 11 (Reuters) -- Britain's recent purchase of Russian silver amounted to 15,000,000 ounces, worth about $12,600,000, it was learned today.

SAIGON, Vietnam, Sept. 11 -- Premier Penn Nouth of Cambodia said today his country did not oppose military operations of the Communist-led Vietminh in other parts of Indo-China so long as they left Cambodia alone.

It was good to read Gilbert Bailey's article about the trotters, good to revive memories of county fairs in hot August or September, so American, so rooted in our past. Best of all was the point that these animals are "sturdy," that they are a native breed, that they were originally "farm" horses, which could also fetch the family to church on Sundays over the country roads.

The second section of City Island Yacht Club's annual overnight race moved out of Eastchester Bay yesterday morning on the start of a 70-mile journey to Stratford Shoal, off Bridgeport, and return. Racing in two divisions, with thirty-five feet over-all the dividing line, the craft had a good south-southwest breeze of close to 10 knots, and moved on a mildly choppy sea flecked with whitecaps.

FAIR HILL, Md., Sept. 12 -- Officials of the Cecil County Breeders Fair led by William DuPont, the race committee chairman made the fourteenth Foxcatcher National Cup Steeplechase program a successful one today, with every modern touch found at the nation's major tracks available.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept. 12 -- Though Brazil lacks any surplus products for export and the domestic market is suffering from a shortage of prime necessities, Joao Alberto Lins de Barros, who is in charge of the economic department of the Foreign Office, declared today that he would visit nations behind the Iron Curtain to set up the basis for trade agreements.

Six per cent of the student enrollment at Barnard College consisted of undergraduates from foreign countries during the 1952-53 academic year. Sixty-seven students representing twenty-five different countries were among the 1,040 undergraduates registered at Barnard during the past year.

It was a pleasure to read in Robert Gerdy's "The A. B. C. of the I. Q." (Sept. 6) that from available standards experts have guessed that Blaise Pascal would have had an I. Q. of more than 180. This seems enormously high, but why should it not be, with a "universal genius" like Pascal, mathematician, physical scientist, theologian, aphorist, all combined?

BERLIN, Sept. 12 -- Premier Otto Grotewohl of East Germany, in a speech published here today, said the Soviet zone must become "bulwark" of strength to block what he described as the avowed plans of Chancellor Konrad Adenauer to "liberate" East Germany and Poland.

In a series of street-corner speeches last night in Brooklyn, Manhattan and The Bronx, Mayor Impellitteri charged Robert F. Wagner Jr., his opponent for the Democratic nomination for Mayor, with conducting a deliberate campaign of falsehoods.

It is written of the German Emperor Otto I that "while he neither feared nor shirked battle, he was always ready to secure his ends by peace." Otto reigned one thousand years ago over a German Reich very similar on the map to the West German Republic which last Sunday gave an overwhelming vote of confidence to Chancellor Adenauer.

A PICTURE should be a stimulating experience both for the photographer and for those who see his work afterward. What the photographer selects for treatment is not always so important as how he feels about it and what, as a result of his response, he does with it.
" IF they hung him for a guide they would be killing an innocent man."

CONSUMER credit -- charge accounts, installment buying and the like -- is running at an all-time high of around $27 billion, it was recently reported. With so much credit about, it is interesting to investigate how firms decide to whom to extend it, how much to extend and what they do when their judgment proves faulty.
The North Pole is on the move, definitely heading west toward Alaska, a scientist with the Carnegie Institution of Washington has discovered. He ascribes it to the earth's erratic wobblings.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 12 (UP) -- Saul Rogovin, with relief aid from Sandy Consuegra, today won his second straight game since returning to the active list as the White Sox defeated the Athletics, 6 -- 5, before the smallest crowd of the season at Connie Mack Stadium.

CASABLANCA, French Morocco, Sept. 12 (AP) -- New violence flared today in troubled French North Africa. Persons identified as Nationalists shot and seriously wounded Gen. Salah Toumi, a police inspector, in Tunisia. It was the latest of a series of assassinations and attempted assassination of pro-French Tunisian officials.

ANCHORAGE, Alaska, Sept. 12 (AP) -- Civilian light aircraft from the King Salmon area joined the air search today for a young volcanologist lost nearly two weeks in the Valley of Ten Thousand Smokes on the Alaska Peninsula.

Dean Acheson, former Secretary of State, will receive the Woodrow Wilson Award for Distinguished Service on Oct. 1 from the Woodrow Wilson Foundation, 45 West Sixty-fifth Street. It is expected that the dinner, to be held at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, will offer the occasion for Mr. Acheson's first major speech since he left office.

CHICAGO, Sept. 12 -- Led by former President Truman, 2,000 Democratic leaders from all parts of the country began trooping into Chicago today for the party's two-day conference opening Monday morning. The rally will be the Democrats' biggest gathering since the 1952 national convention and campaign and will serve to welcome former Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois back from his recent world tour and to develop plans for the 1954 congressional election.

LONG in serious financial difficulties, the 105-year-old Rutland Railway finally faltered to a stop last June 26 when employes struck for higher wages and since that date not a passenger wheel has turned. Freight service was resumed in mid-July when the strike was settled but resumption of passenger trains still remains problematical.

AMONG the new kitchen equipment for delivery to city stores this fall is an interesting set of four cooking utensils to be introduced by Wear-Ever. Three saucepans in various sizes and a frying pan, designed by Lurelle Guild, combine durability, practicality and good looks.

DURING the last two years the forthcoming production of my comedy, "The Happy Ant-Hill," has been announced four times in THE NEW YORK TIMES, and a few months later, with disheartening regularity, the puzzled readers have been informed that it just wasn't so.

" Lifelong Education," a new project, under point sponsorship of the New York Public Library and the City College Extension Division, is offering in advance of courses a series of nine free lectures in libraries over the city.

Many boxes and seats have been purchased for the performance of the Sadler's Wells Ballet on Tuesday night at the Metropolitan Opera House, which has been taken over to raise funds for The Lighthouse, the New York Association for the Blind. Mrs. Donald S. Stralem heads the benefit committee and among her aides is Mrs. Robert Sarnoff.

THE surest sign that summer is about over, and with it holiday and vacation, is the arrival back home of the crazy, charming children, armed with new tricks or new variations of old tricks, from their mountain camps.

Plans are being formulated for the performance of F. Hugh Herbert's new comedy, "A Girl Can Tell," with Janet Blair and Marshall Thompson in the leading roles, on the night of Dec. 10 at the Royale Theatre, which has been taken over to raise funds for the Society of St. Johnland.

THE heat-resistant achilleas have many qualifications to take front rank among the sun-loving perennials. They flower in midsummer when the weather is hot and dry. To them soil presents no problems, as they grow well in clay or sandy kinds so long as it is well drained. Insects and diseases rarely bother this perennial.

NEW DELHI, Sept. 12 -- India and Pakistan appear to be nearer agreement on the seven-year-old impasse over possession of the strategic state of Jammu and Kashmir than ever before. But it has been characteristic of this long-standing quarrel that each stage in the negotiations is followed by a renewed outbreak of bitterness on both sides.

TO Americans, Mexico is a next-door vacation land: to the English it is a remote exotic ranking in glamour with Tibet. Here a sensitive artist from Devon discovers Indian Mexico. No tourist, he came as a sculptor bent on spying out the ancient secret of Oaxaca's black pottery. He lived on intimate terms with the Indians, became part of a family and tried to become an Indian.

LAST Monday Fred Allen walked across a Manhattan intersection and was hailed by a passing motorist in a small, underslung car. "Nice going, Fred!" yelled the serious-looking driver, raising his hand in salute as he sped across the avenue.

KAFKA'S transformation of Gregor Samsa reproduced for readers the nightmarish feelings of a man who believed himself to be an insect cornered in the world of humans. With a reverse twist, Francis R. Bellamy pictures the prospects of a man who shrinks to fingernail-size and sets out into the insect wilds of a garden patch.

QUITO Ecuador, Sept. 12 (AP) -- The Ministry of Interior said tonight thta one person had been killed, sixteen policemen wounded or beaten and an undetermined number of civilians wounded in political rioting at Guayaquil today.

With just a little of the earth-containing microscopic algae called diatoms, Paul S. Conger can catch food-law violators. When eggs are broken a little of the white clings to the shell. A food inspector suspected that a frozen-egg processor was trying to recover this waste material from garbage.

MICHIKO SUNAHARA, Japanese soprano who will sing Cio-Cio-San in the Fujiwara Opera Company's production of "Madama Butterfly" at the City Center in October, is an authentically costumed Butterfly off the stage as well as on.
Of all the mass-produced articles that have influenced this country's way of life there probably is none more typically American -- or more taken for granted -- than the tin can.

Joseph R. McCarthy and his followers, hangers-on and coattail riders have long assumed that if a Senatorial inquisitor is vociferously opposed to communism he is released from the obligations of fair play, integrity and truthfulness that bind lesser men. The Senator from Wisconsin has now taken another step.

Cotton supplies this season are forecast at 20,500,000 bales consisting of 15,000,000 from the present crop and a carryover of 5,500,000. Therefore, acreage allotments and marketing quotas on the 1954 crop probably will be sought by the Department of Agriculture.

As Fred M. Vinson was laid to rest at Louisa, Ky., among his old friends and neighbors on Friday the thought of his vacant, funerally draped chair behind the supreme bench in Washington must have been in many persons' minds. And with this thought must have come the question, who is to be the next occupant of that chair?

Considering special factors limiting consumer activity last week, department stores did well to fall just 15 per cent short of the volume for the similar week last year. Subtracted from the week this year were the Labor Day holiday, which occurred a full week earlier last year, and the variable Jewish High Holy Days, which occurred on Thursday and Friday.

IN 1519 Juan Christophe de Martinez, a young Spaniard, and Catalina, an Indian girl whom he had befriended, sailed from Cuba as members of Cortez' expedition to Mexico. Juan, a devout Christian, was convinced that Cortez' main purpose was to plant Christianity in the New World.

With a king-size homer into the left-field upper deck by Mickey Mantle featuring the barrage, the Yankees yesterday exploded for eight runs in the seventh inning to rout the Tigers, 13 -- 4, before a Ladies' Day gathering of 11,543 at the Stadium.

MILWAUKEE, Sept. 12 (AP) -- Ted Marchibroda, rookie quarter-back, passed for one touchdown and set up another tonight as the Pittsburgh Steelers tripped the Green Bay Packers, 26 -- 23, in a football exhibition before 16,859 fans at Marquette Stadium.
SEOUL, Korea, Sunday, Sept. 13 (AP) -- President Syngman Rhee urged South Korean Army troops yesterday to prepare for a drive north if the forthcoming Korean political conference should fail.

There is a temptation to say that fall comes early because off the drought and the late hot spell. Certainly the two combined to sere many trees and lawns and bring yellows and tans to many a hillside. Birch leaves lie in the woods in a carpet fit for October, and elm leaves swirl along suburban gutters and country roads.

PETER COTES is a British theatrical producer with such strong feelings against the star system that he has written a book called "No Star Nonsense." He is married to an actress, Joan Miller, who earnestly subscribes to his views but unfortunately makes so deep an impression on the London critics that they persist in hailing her as a star.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- A fundamental concept of the original Marshall Plan is being implemented for the first time, at least to some degree, in the current reorganization of United States foreign-aid machinery. The concept, forcefully but unsuccessfully expounded by the plan's author, General of the Army George C. Marshall, is that the Secretary of State, as the country's chief foreign-policy spokesman next to the President, should be in charge of the program.

How is a ball bearing made? That simple question asked of a dozen men familiar with manufacture and of an equal number of engineers, about a device familiar since ancient times and as widely used as the wheel produced answers both various and vague.

MUNSAN, Korea, Sept. 12 -- Trains crowded with Chinese and North Korean prisoners of war are moving past here on their way to the huge new prisoner of war compounds set up in the rust-brown hills of the demilitarized zone in Korea.

MOSCOW, Sunday, Sept. 13 -- The Communist party's Central Committee at a plenary session has elected as its first secretary Nikita S. Khrushchev, former Moscow and Ukrainian party leader, and has approved a sweeping agricultural plan he designed to remedy grave defects in Soviet livestock production.

Great Britain and the United States, which have had one test of strength already in the team matches for the British-American Cup that ended in America's favor last Monday, will begin another six-meter yachting series today.

LAVALLETTE, N. J. -- The recent heat wave and a late Labor Day have extended the summer season on the twenty-five-mile upper Barnegat Peninsula and home owners and real estate agents last week were reporting an unprecedented high in the number of small home and cottage rentals for the rest of September.

Thirty future secondary school teachers, selected from a large number of candidates from all over the United States, will begin this month a new kind of preparation at Vanderbilt University and George Peabody College for Teachers. The Vanderbilt-Peabody program contains significant modifications of the usual approach to high school teacher training.

The State Commission Against Discrimination reported last week that the exhaustion of seniority lists of furloughed workers had opened up the first opportunities for hiring of Negroes in such railroad jobs as engineers, firemen, conductors and trainmen.

HERE it is again, Broadway in motion but not a motion picture. Every second man striding through the Forties is an actor, every third a press agent, every fourth a theatrical producer -- all in pursuit of every hundredth, an angel.
The man who was Eastern Air Lines' first paying passenger twenty-three years ago is "standing in line" to buy the lines' 25,000,000th ticket.

FEW more explosive issues exist in the whole domain of Soviet affairs than the question of Ukrainian independence. Over the past third of a century this problem has caused convulsion after convulsion in the Soviet Union and most recently played a key role in the purge of Lavrentia Beria. In this country the matter has become a political football, with Congressmen and Senators playing a key role.

Eight brawny oarsmen representing the merchant marine of Norway won the fifteenth annual international lifeboat race on the Hudson River yesterday, sealing their possession of the John W. Powell Trophy. Norway had won a leg on the trophy last year.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development and the International Monetary Fund voted today to return to Washington for their ninth annual meeting in September, 1954.

Recent action by the Administration to speed reporting of changes in industrial working hours has emphasized the importance of this business index. It is probably the most sensitive now in use and has a tendency to move somewhat in advance of swings in industrial activity.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- Psychological strategy -- a "cold war" derivative of a hot war activity now viewed with distaste by official Washington -- has at last been taken from the propaganda specialists and made an explicit responsibility of every official involved in formulating policy affecting the nation's security.

MELBOURNE, Sept. 12 -- The five-man full bench of the Commonwealth Arbitration Court, sitting in Sydney, delivered a unanimous judgment today abolishing a quarterly adjustment of the basic wage to the cost-of-living index, but refused an employers' application for increasing the work week to forty-four hours from the present forty and a reduction in the basic wage.

BAY SHORE, L. I., Sept. 12 -- Primary elections in Suffolk County next Tuesday will be enlivened by a struggle for leadership of the Republican party in the towns of Babylon, Huntington and Smithtown, where firty-three election districts have contests for county committeemen.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Sept 12 -- The Manhasset Bay Yacht Club conducted two regattas in one today. In addition to the fourth session of its fall race series, it had the thirty-third Yacht Racing Association contest of the year to handle. So the fleet was split.

WESTBURY, L. I., Sept. 12 -- Philip Scott, a 5-year-old bay horse owned by George R. W. Reed and P. G. and Jere Reed of East Providence, R. I., and driven by Frank Safford, upset Hi-Lo's Forbes by a neck to win the $10,000 Oregon free-for-all pace at Roosevelt Raceway tonight.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- Representative Daniel A. Reed served public notice on the Eisenhower Administration today that any proposal for a general sales tax would meet stiff opposition from key tax men in the House of Representatives, including himself.

My violent differences with A. M. Rosenthal in his article about visitors to the U. N., "One World Wonder" (Aug. 30) exploded in reading his first sentence. "The tourists love the place." Myself and daughter not only found nothing there to love but we went away with the feeling of pretty complete disappointment -- an almost wasted summer afternoon's visit in New York.

LABOR DAY brought most of the summer vacationists back to town, but post Labor Day holidayers are busy making plans for the early fall. Resort hotels as a rule lower their rates after Sept. 1 or 15, and many of them are remaining open later than usual.

ATHENS, Sept. 4 -- The American section of the joint Hellenic-American expedition excavating at Epano Englianos, near Pylos in the southwestern Peloponnesus, has closed its ten-week 1953 campaign, rewarded by a number of discoveries that throw light on the way in which the Homeric heroes lived.

STRASBOURG, France, Sept. 12 (UP) -- The Council of Europe received a secret report today recommending the internationalizing of the coal-rich Saar Basin, which has been disputed by France and Germany for years.

THE trouble with discovering a brilliant new trick in the mystery novel is your lurking fear that some other writer may, quite independently, beat you into print with it. When, for instance, Agatha Christie's technical dazzler, "The A. B. C. Murders," appeared, John Dickson Carr and Ellery Queen and I were each separately working on books with the same plot-device; and of course all three works-in-progress had to be scrapped.

WHY did the United States decide to recognize the Soviet Union after sixteen years of non-recognition? This scholarly, well-documented and well-written book is a dispassionate account of the motives leading to recognition, the high hopes entertained in Washington and Moscow as to its profitable consequences and the swift disillusionment which followed.

MINEOLA, L. I., Sept. 12 -- Fewer than 15 per cent of Nassau County's 400,000 qualified voters are expected to participate in Tuesday's primary elections since the only scheduled public office contest is for a post on the Long Beach City Council.

THIS year's festival found Salzburg back on the musical gold standard. Following the uneven accomplishments of last summer, when the illness of Furtwaengler and a number of casting problems resulted in productions well below the festival standard, it was a pleasure this year to find performances uniformly worth traveling to Salzburg to see and to hear.
WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Sept. 12 -- Special details of police will guard the polls and a record 190,000 ballots will be distributed for Tuesday's primary elections in Westchester.

ERNEST HEMINGWAY has been publishing for almost thirty years, and it was inevitable that sooner or later the Viking "Portable Hemingway" would be succeeded by a more comprehensive selection from Scribner's.

A HIGHLY inventive storyteller, Patricia Gordon has written an eerie, intricate, literary fantasy. It is not one for the average reader of baseball stories -- or even of science fiction -- but those who have a taste for myths and fairy tales, for legend and poetry will gladly follow young Hugh on his exploration of a mysterious sunken forest on an island as elusive as Merlin's Isle of Gramarye.

IT is good to have "You Are There" back with us again. This well-staged, acted and produced program is a shining example of what the television producers could do if they scraped some of the rust from their brain and the cobwebs from their imagination.

GROSSINGER, N. Y., Sept. 12 -- About the only people who have not been completely captivated by Rocky Marciano and fallen under the spell of his charm, friendliness, thoughtfulness and gentle nature are a few business rivals who have found him rude and ruthless in the ring. Yet even they must feel that he steps totally out of character when he plies his trade.

CHILDREN are always interested in stories of unusual pets. This one tells what happened when Terry invested a dollar in a chipmunk called, alternately, Albert and Alberta. Immediately Terry and her family were plunged into a whirlwind of activity which grew into a tornado when a cat, a monkey and a dog joined the family circle and all proceeded to get into mischief separately and in concert.

ACCORDING to an ancient legend, the Pentateuch or Written Law was by no means all that Moses received on Mount Sinai's smoke-enveloped summit. The mountain shook with thunder, and the people standing below could hear the voice of a horn grow louder and louder.

THE Metropolitan Motion Picture Club's first meeting of the season will be held at 8 P. M. Thursday at the Hotel Statler. The program will deal with the use of sound tracks in amateur film-making and will be illustrated with amateur films which have employed various methods of sound accompaniment.

LOUIS DE ROCHEMONT'S "Martin Luther," which came to the Guild last week, is that rare thing in motion picture commerce. It is a scholarly religious film. Most of the screen enterprises that have fetched their subjects or themes from Biblical or related sources have been elegant and expensive costume affairs, devoted more to spectacle and sentiment than to deep and considerate thoughts and deeds.

QUIETLY, almost casually, without benefit of clique or claque, Jacques Villon has taken his place as one of the genuinely distinguished French artists of our time. But for some reason his admirable graphic work has been overshadowed by his painting, so it is a particularly happy idea for the Museum of Modern Art to have organized an exhibition devoted to sixty years of his printmaking.
SPLIT, Yugoslavia, Sept. 12 -- Yugoslav publicists charged today Italian air violations of the Yugoslav border near Gorizia.

Three Bronx youths were charged yesterday with the slaying of Israel Present, 49-year-old head of the Brooklyn Kosher Butcher Association, whose body was found on the front lawn of his rented Monticello, N. Y., bungalow Labor Day morning. The slaying, it developed, was the consequence of a well-planned but poorly executed robbery.

Players and spectators at the Yankee Stadium today will celebrate the return of Gerry Coleman after his tour of duty as a combat pilot in Korea. It is an occasion for the warmest rejoicing. Its real significance, however, lies in something more than the fact that Gerry Coleman happens to be a member of the Yankees or that he happens to be an exceptionally fine ball player.

The 630 members of the Columbia College Class of 1957 will converge on Morningside Heights this afternoon to begin a week of meetings and tours designed to familiarize the incoming freshmen with Columbia before they begin their college careers on Sept. 24.

GENEVA, Sept. 12 -- The Russians according to information received here by the International Union of Alpine Associations, made a fruitless attempt on Mount Everest last December that ended in the loss of six lives.

BERKELEY, Calif., Sept. 12 (UP) -- Atomic scientists presented assurance today that there was scant danger that nuclear reactors being operated in various parts of the country would convert themselves into atomic bombs.
More than sixty years ago Congress took a position against business monopoly by declaring trade actions which substantially lessened competition to be unlawful.

WITH engines well tuned and fuel tanks brimming, 341 venerable vehicles are assembled in Cleveland awaiting the beginning of the 1953 revival of the Glidden Tours tomorrow. The cavalcade will parade through that city with the drivers taking part in a celebration and dinner at night, then depart on Tuesday for Dearborn, Mich.

MILWAUKEE, Sept. 12 (AP) -- "This is a great ball club," a jubilant Charles (Chuck) Dressen yelled over the noise in the Dodger clubhouse today after his team clinched the National League pennant on the earliest date in modern history.

LOOKING back over the last thirty years of news (and its newsmagazines), the good, graying Time editors and researchers have produced an unusual, unmannered, ultrasophisticated "quiz book and memory jogger." It is both of these and more: a lot of good reading and good fun.
Back home in Marion, Ind., I used to like the Fourth of July. But in Prague, in 1951, I hated it. That was the day we got the bad news.

" WHY do you put up with me?" An 8-year-old boy recently asked this question of his foster parents in Connecticut. He had reason to be perplexed. On separate occasions he had set fire to their living room, torn up the draperies, smashed furniture, broken windows and been expelled from school.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 28 -- Returning this week from a year-long 87,000-mile fund-raising trip to the United States President Stephen B. L. Penrose of the American University of Beirut brought good news for the university's medical school: a five-year improvement program, partly financed by Rockefeller Foundation funds.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- Individuals owned 1,017,300,000 acres or 87.7 per cent of land in farms, in the United States, the Department of Agriculture's Bureau of Agricultural Economics reported today in an article by Buis T. Inman of the bureau and H. E. Robison of the Bureau of the Census.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (AP) -- The Air Force said today for the first time that Capt. James A. Van Fleet Jr., son of the former Eighth Army commander in Korea, might be a Communist captive.

Just before Christmas last year, Edwin A. Lahey, veteran Washington labor reporter for The Chicago Daily News, called on his old friend and neighbor, Martin P. Durkin, president of the A. F. L. Plumbers' Union, who had been named Secretary of Labor in the Eisenhower Cabinet three weeks before.
GARDEN CITY, L. I., Sept. 12 -- A truce between the Arma Corporation and its 5,000 striking employes has been extended until midnight Friday, the company announced today.

GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 12 -- Both the Republican and Democratic parties in Greenwich will wage bitter primary battles on Oct. 13, headlined by contests between the party organization candidates for the November election and independent slates led by the incumbent Republican and Democratic Selectmen who were denied renomination this week by their respective town committees.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 12 -- An expressed desire to help "the starving people of India" clinched the title of Miss America of 1954 tonight for Miss Evelyn Margaret Ay, a tall, green-eyed ash blonde from Ephrata, Pa. She is 5 feet 8 inches tall and weighs 132 pounds.

AMERICANS like to be proud of what they produce, but a group of recordings of material from the Archive of American Folk Song in the Library of Congress underlines the impression that many have already gathered -- namely, that the folk music that has originated in this country is sometimes more notable for its historic and human interest than for its musical interest.

A great upsurge is taking place in the teaching of languages. Business concerns sending workers abroad want them on speaking terms with the people they deal with. As a consequence nearly a fourth of the students in the two New York operations of the Berlitz School of Languages, now in its seventy-fifth year, are sponsored by employers.
The nation's securities underwriting machinery is about to be exposed to one of the greatest strains in financial history.

MADISON, Wis., Sept. 12 -- Voters of Wisconsin's Ninth Congressional District will make their primary selections Tuesday for the election to choose a successor to Representative Merlin Hull, Republican, who died in the spring after eighteen years in the House of Representatives. The special election has been set by Gov. Walter J. Kohler Jr. for Oct. 13.

Private colleges, especially the small liberal arts colleges, are feeling the financial pinch now as never before. Tuition rates have just about reached a limit; higher fees, many feel, would freeze out potentially good students. The question arises then as to where these colleges can turn for financial help.

THESE Lines from the Table Monitor of the Shakers express the underlying principles of eating in that religious sect in the early Eighteen Hundreds. Mrs. Caroline Piercy, who has made a study of Shaker life, has published the recipes and given an account of the group's eating habits.

A more than passive interest is being shown in the sales tax as a Federal revenue measure. In spite of strong traditional opposition to this form of taxation at the national level, its adoption as a substitute for existing selective excises appears to be gaining favor in some quarters.

LONDON, Sept. (AP) -- Nikita S. Khrushchev, 59, as first secretary of the Central Committee of the Soviet Communist party, will control vast party machinery. In the party hierarchy he ranks right after Premier Georgi M. Malenkov, chief of the party's Presidium.

FOR some years now Wright Morris has been a rather determinedly minor novelist. He has always written well, with skill, intelligence and considerable wit; but his range has been small and he has confined himself largely to subjects which could be expected to yield him only the minimum dramatic return.

PAWTUCKET, R. I., Sept. 12 (AP) -- G. S. Colella's 2-year-old Switch On hit the wire a neck in front of A. E. Smith's By Jeepers, a 4-to-5 favorite, in the $10,000-added Connors Memorial Stakes today at Narragansett Park.

A tribute for "fine cooperation" in materially reducing drawbridge openings along the inland waterways of New Jersey was paid to boat owners last week by Ransford J. Abbott, the state's Highway Commissioner.

SOUTHPORT, Conn., Sept. 12 -- Norman H. Morse won the Pequot Yacht Club's annual overnight race to Cornfield Lightship and return with his little gaff-rigged sloop, Diana, Which was last of the fleet to finish this afternoon but received top placing after handicaps were computed.
ST LOUIS, Sept. 12 (UP) -- Eddie Pellagrini's single in the twelfth inning scored Preston Ward with the winning run today as the Pirates defeated the Cardinals, 18 -- 7.

PATRICK HENRY'S oration in the Virginia burgesses denouncing the Stamp Act has become a part of American folklore. How far he went in attacking George III and urging resistance is clear in legend but cloudy in history.

BERLIN: Remember; PUCCINI: Mi Chiamano Mimi; YOUMANS: Time On My Hands, and others; Kathryn Grayson, soprano; orchestra and chorus led by Ray Heindorf (Victor, ten-inch). From the sound track of the film, "So This Is Love."

UNFORTUNATELY, this book went to press before an account of the author's latest exploit could be included. Marion Rice Hart is the dauntless 61-year-old New York lady who late last month hopped the Atlantic (Newfoundland to Ireland) in a small single-engine plane. "I Fly as I Please" is, however, not devoid of other adventure and incident.

THE Fourteenth Venice Film Festival wound up a busy and successful two-week run here last week, unfortunately hitting a sour note in the final bars. Almost inevitably, the trouble occurred when the prize list was announced, only this time it sprouted with unusual vigor.

BONN, Germany, Sept. 12 -- West Germany's heavy industries, which financed the successful general election campaign for Chancellor Konrad Adenauer's Christian Democratic Union and its coalition allies, made known today the economic policies they expected the next Adenauer Government to adopt and implement.

LONDON, Sept. 12 -- If Gen. Fazlollah Zahedi, Premier of Iran, really wants to sell some oil, as he strongly hinted this week, he is going to find himself up against difficulties somewhat more complex than those involved in escaping from rebellious Kurdish tribesmen or eluding the police dragnet of his predecessor, Mohammed Mossadegh -- in both of which he has proved exceedingly adept during his active life.

MY reading on this trip has been, up to the present, as scanty as I expected, and as I meant it to be. Aside from the customary samplings of the local press, it has been confined largely to scraping a first-hand acquaintance with current science fiction.

CHICAGO, Sept. 12 (AP) -- Smoke Screen, a 4-year-old chestnut gelding, billowed up from nowhere at the head of the stretch to score a head triumph in the $55,600 Bidwill Memorial Handicap at Hawthorne Park today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- The vast role that the Supreme Court plays in the Government of the United States and the life of its people makes President Eisenhower's choice of a successor to Chief Justice Fred M. Vinson a matter of the highest speculative interest.
CALI, Colombia, Aug. 26 -- The mushroom growth of this little industrial city is a striking example of the benefits private capital can bring to South American countries.

Because of Labor Day and the Jewish holidays few out-of-town buyers were in New York last week but reordering of children's items and women's sportswear was quite heavy, according to McGreevey, Werring Howell Company, resident buying office.
Manhattan College opens its 101st academic year tomorrow with the start of freshman week, when 781 freshmen are expected to register in the college's three schools.

MAYS LANDING, N. J., Sept. 12 -- Joseph Gavegnano's Errard King registered the easiest victory in his seven-race career when he won the eighth running of the $24,400 World's Playground Stakes for 2-year-olds at the Atlantic City race course today.

Most chemists will agree that the outstanding event of last week's meeting of the American Chemical Society at Chicago was the announcement that Dr. Raymond U. Lemieux, age 33, and Dr. George Huber, age 25, both on the staff of the National Research Council of Canada, have succeeded in synthesizing sucrose, a common sugar.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 12 -- Although overshadowed by the proposed Far Eastern political conference, the 1953 session of the General Assembly will confront the Eisenhower Administration with a major test of its capacity to regain the leadership of the non-Communist members of the United Nations.
WEDGEPORT, N. S., Sept. 12 -- A 723-pound bluefin caught in the final hours of the competition today gave Mexico victory in the tenth international tuna tournament.

CHICAGO, Sept. 12 -- If this were April rather than September, the eyes and ears of the baseball world would be on the Cubs, who today at Wrigley Field downed the Giants, 7 -- 1, and now boast an eight-game winning streak, the longest by a Chicago team since 1945.

ATLANTA, Sept. 12 -- Factories in the Southeastern states employed 1,960,000 in July, the highest number of workers on record for that month, the Atlanta Regional Bureau of Labor Statistics reported this week. Employment was 106,100 above that of the corresponding month last year.

THE election was held ten months ago, but the campaign is still being fought. Former President Truman, delivering a Labor Day address in Detroit, took the Republicans to task for policies which he held will set the economy back to the time when distribution of wealth was concentrated in the hands of the top 5 per cent income bracket.

A model bank, representing $50,000,000 in deposits, operating five days a week and staffed with seventy-five persons, serves no actual customers. That is the latest test training project of one of the country's largest banking institutions, the National City Bank of New York.

Capt. Ray V. Tillett was appointed commodore of the Isthmian Steamship Company's twenty-seven-ship freighter fleet in a ceremony last week aboard the Steel Maker in Erie Basin Terminal, Brooklyn. Captain Tillett succeeded the late Commodore Nils S. Oakland.

In behalf of the New York City Mission Society, the performance of "Kind Sir," a comedy with Mary Martin, Charles Boyer and Dorothy Stickney in the leading roles, on the night of Nov. 3 at the Alvin Theatre has been taken over by persons active in work of the organization.

SINCE its publication nine years ago, Mrs. Ets' "In the Forest" has established itself firmly in the affections of the picture book audience. "Another Day" is a companion story -- a new tale about the same little boy in the same fantastic forest.

The Greer Children's Community in Dutchess County, N. Y., will be the beneficiary of the performance of "Colombe," with Julie Harris in the leading role, on the night of Dec. 22 at a theatre yet to be announced. Mrs. Duncan S. Ellsworth is chairman of the benefit committee, and Edward Pulling heads the board of directors of the beneficiary.

BONN, Germany, Sept. 12 -- In a statement last Thursday to his Executive Committee, Chancellor Konrad Adenauer warned the more impatient and impetuous members of the Christian Democratic Union that the sweeping victory in the Sept. 6 Bundestag election had placed a special responsibility on the party.

ELIZABETH, N. J., Sept. 12 -- The Union County Park Commission defended today its expenditure of $520,077 for golf since Jan. 1, 1947, by explaining that the commission had received more than that amount for land that the New Jersey Highway Department took for the Garden State Parkway in Kenilworth and Clark.
DOUGLAS, Isle of Man, Sept. 12 -- The pagan magician Mannanan Mac Lir once ruled the Isle of Man and had the power to shroud it in mist to confound his enemies.
TROY, N. Y., Sept. 14 (AP) -- Richard H. Balch, Democratic state chairman, said today that Governor Dewey had failed completely "to speak out against the giveaway of our national security."

A ceremony in Cooper Square on Thursday afternoon will mark the original cornerstone laying one hundred years earlier of the Cooper Union's historic Foundation Building at Astor Place and Fourth Avenue. The structure is regarded as the forerunner of the modern skyscraper.

Robert F. Wagner Jr., candidate for the Democratic nomination for Mayor, telegraphed yesterday his "heartiest congratulations" to Martin P. Durkin, who resigned on Thursday as Secretary of Labor because of the failure of the Eisenhower Administration to obtain amendments to the Taft-Hartley Law.

PARIS, Sept. 12 -- Officials here said today that they were hoping that Premier Penn Nouth would deny he meant to proclaim Cambodian neutrality in the face of a threat from the Communist-led Vietminh against all three Indo-Chinese states.
Fred C. Martin has been appointed controller of the Dodge division of Chrysler Corporation.

In regard to the editorial "Learning About Our World" in your edition of Sept. 3, I am frank to state that it was in part the results of the surveys of THE NEW YORK TIMES which prompted the resolution I introduced at the meeting of the Association of American Geographers to which your editorial referred.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- In the last six months, Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois has apparently charmed everybody from the Emperor of Japan to the Queen of England, but his big test will come on Monday and Tuesday when he tries out his travelogue at the Democratic party jamboree in Chicago.

Col. Richard Cary, Maj. Hodijah Baylies, Maj. Caleb Gibbs (all of Massachusetts); Lieut. Cols. John Fitzgerald, William Grayson, George Johnston, Richard Kidder Meade, Benjamin Walker; Capts. Peregrin Fitzhugh, Presly Thornton, George Lewis (all of Virginia), and Adjt. Gen. (Acting) Morgan Connor of Pennsylvania.

EVEN when he was little and green, Proud Pumpkin was tougher than his vine-mates and determined to live forever. At harvest time he was still confident that he was not meant for pie. Nor was he. As a grinning jack o' lantern, Proud Pumpkin glowed gloriously -- and briefly -- at a Hallowe'en party; then he was tossed into the woodshed, where hungry mice and a prowling cat gave him a sorry time.

QUEEN JEZEBEL By Jean Plaid. 304 pp. New York: Appleton-Century-Crofts. $3. JEAN PLAIDY'S portrait of Catherine de Medici as Queen Mother of mid-sixteenth century France reminds one of a female version of Bela Lugosi in his more gory moments. The novel is filled with all the poisonings and stabbings for which Her Majesty was renowned.

Robert F. Wagner Jr., Borough President of Manhattan and candidate for the Democratic nomination for Mayor in Tuesday's primary, declared last night that he would rather lose a hundred elections than win one by an appeal for votes on a racial basis.

According to the geophysicists the Earth is between two and four billion years old. It takes about 5,000 million years for one-half the uranium originally in the Earth to turn into lead. The physicist has only to know how much lead is now in the Earth to arrive at this figure of between two and four billion years.

Professional football will make its 1953 bow in New York Thursday night as the Giants, geared to a new swing-T formation devised by Coach Steve Owen, tangle with the San Francisco 49ers in a charity game for the benefit of the Hearst Free Milk Fund for Babies.

Chickens develop social classes and live within their "social rules" by the time they are nine weeks old, A. M. Guhl, Associate Professor of Zoology and Associate Zoologist at the Kansas State College Experiment Station, has discovered.

MILWAUKEE, Sept. 12 -- Having led for the 1953 National League pennant since June 28, the Dodgers finally took permanent possession at County Stadium today by beating the Braves, 5 -- 2. The 34,884 fans, who strained the seating capacity, rooted almost to the end for their local heroes.

AN estimate of the flow of tourism in a resort area such as South Florida is a difficult statistical task. In the first place, the tourist as a group is not sharply segregated from the rest of the population by either place of location, manner of movement or types of consumptive behavior.

CHORE FOR THE WEEK: Dry, sunny days are ideal for spraying dandelion, buckthorn and other broadleaved weeds in lawns with a weed-killer. A few days later, apply a balanced commercial fertilizer and water deeply if it has not rained. Then, after loosening the soil with a rake, sow seed where the turf is thin. Frost kills crabgrass, but the brown plants should be raked out before sowing lawn seed.

IN 1937 the American and the English public were introduced to a new and attractive naval hero, whose fortunes they have been following ever since. He was Captain Horatio Hornblower of His Majesty's frigate Lydia, bound upon a cloak and dagger adventure to the Gulf of Fonseca on the west coast of Honduras, and he was Nelsonian in more than his first name.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (UP) -- Herbert Philbrick, former Federal Bureau of Investigation undercover agent, said m testimony published today that seven or eight clergymen were "dedicated, hardened, steeled Communists" in a secret cell in Boston.

The Dodgers beat the Braves, 5 -- 2, at Milwaukee yesterday and clinched their tenth National League pennant since 1890 and their second straight under Charles (Chuck Dressen. Cari Erskine, notching his nineteenth triumph, went the route as the Brooks eliminated the runner-up Braves from the race.
IS BACH's St. Matthew Passion to be preferred in a poor recording of a great performance, or in a less spirited but acoustically superior version?

PARIS, Sept. 12 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer's sensational election victory in West Germany had immediate repercussions. It gained for the elderly Chancellor recognition as the leading statesman now practicing his art on the free portion of the Continent. Dr. Alcide de Gasperi is out of office in Italy. A recognized leader of force as well as intellectuality has yet to be produced in France.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (AP) -- Conelrad, the radio operation designed to thwart any effort to use broadcasting signals to lead bombers or guided missiles to American cities, will have its first national test on Wednesday.

Music in the modern manner, le jazz hot which got started with the Dixie-swing-bop circuit and took off from there. This is it, man! Dig that controlled dissonance and contrapuntal technique, that reaching out for new sounds. This Edwin Gilbert, he's got it all down in a new novel called "The Hot and the Cool."

Traders were furnished with two surprises last week in the limited trading in the stock market caused by the Labor Day and religious holidays. First, the post-Labor Day session failed to show any follow-through of the previous week's selling.

This country's participation in the International Cargo Handling Coordination Association -- a group seeking a reduction in ship turnaround time in port -- appeared assured last week as the first steps were taken toward the formation of a United States National Committee of the organization.
DETROIT, Sept. 12 (AP) -- How many new passenger automobiles the retail market can absorb in each of the next five to ten years is getting intensive study.

WHILE his entry in the field of independent production is comparatively new, Stirling Silliphant obviously doesn't intend to await public and critical endorsement of his initial venture, "The Joe Louis Story," now in United Artists' distributional hands.

The eighth session of the United Nations General Assembly opens Tuesday. It promises to be tempestuous -- not only because of the chronic East-West struggle, but also because on some of the issues to arise the Western big powers are likely to be at odds among themselves.

SOMEBODY with an eye for sales has given this book a misleading title. It is not really about quackery in the public schools. It is, rather, about theories and practices in the public schools derived in part from the philosophy of John Dewey and expounded by Prof. William Heard Kilpatrick, with which and with whom Albert Lynd and many others do not agree.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 12 -- Loans by banks of the Third Federal Reserve District continued their upward sweep in the first half of this year, while net profits rose to $25,900,000 from $22,400,000 for the corresponding period of 1952.

HOLLYWOOD, Sept. 12 (AP) -- Testimony of Lucille Ball, television and film actress, that she never had been a Communist but once had registered to vote the Communist ticket to "appease an old man," her Socialist grandfather, was made public today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (AP) -- The Defense Department released today a list of 307 American Air Force personnel still unaccounted for after having been reported captured by the Communists in Korea. Today's list brought to 915 the number of identified Americans not accounted for. The list, with next of kin, follows:
MARQUETTE, Mich., Sept. 12 (AP) -- Tugs and freighters fought a Lake Superior storm today in an effort to rescue nine men stranded on a dredge about eighty miles northeast of Marquette.

THE stories of Charles Jackson are not the sort that powerful national weeklies order and ballyhoo in advance. They do not make us more pleased with ourselves, or our ways. One does not close this book with a sense of self-satisfaction, of sentimentalities coddled and preconceptions indulged.

THE loud cries of Hollywood labor leaders against so-called "runaway" production apparently are not going to stem the tide of filming abroad both by major studios and independent producers. Story requirements and economics will continue to be the determining factors.
LONDON, Sept. 12 (Reuters) -- Arsenal's English league soccer champions were routed, 7 to 1, today by Sunderland, leaving the Gunners without a victory in eight games.

AT the very beginning of this excellent book Horace Mann, about to enter the Massachusetts Legislature, is seen buttoning his greatcoat on a snowy day, dashing to the State House, and at precisely ten o'clock mounting the stairs two at a time.

MOSCOW, Sept. 12 -- Russia charged today that Avery Brundage, president of the International Olympic Committee, and "other reactionary American spokesmen" were trying to stack the 1956 games against the Soviet Union and in favor of a United States victory.

A 16-year-old boy accused of threatening to cut the throat of a young woman in Prospect Park unless she gave him her money was held in Brooklyn Felony Court yesterday in $10,000 bail on a charge of attempted assault and robbery.

Four candidates for the nomination for Mayor -- Robert F. Wagner Jr., and Robert B. Blaikie, Democrats; Harold Riegelman, Republican, and Rudolph Halley of the Liberal party -- spoke last night at the Joan of Arc Junior High School, 154 West Ninety-third Street.

DENVER, Sept 12. -- President Eisenhower today established a new Advisory Committee on Government Housing Policies and Programs, naming its twenty-one members and designating Albert M. Cole, administrator of the Housing and Home Finance Agency, as chairman.

TELEVISION station WATV (Channel 13) with studios in Newark, N. J., has set the week of Oct. 11-17 as its target date for beginning of transmission from its newly installed antenna atop the Empire State Building.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, denied again today that he had used his position to question an editor about anti-McCarthy editorials and asked seven newspaper executives to correct a committee report that he said did not do him justice.

MILWAUKEE, Sept. 12 (UP) -- Charles S. (Chuck) Dressen, who today became the first manager to lead the Dodgers to two consecutive pennants, had an undistinguished record as a big league pilot when he assumed leadership of the team in 1951.

ABOVE all others, Theodore Roethke is a poet to encourage and comfort us in our valley of literary conformism. He leads us back to the surprising upland. He makes us realize how rapidly our literature is flowing toward a dead center of accredited modernity.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Sept. 12 -- Senator Estes Kefauver, Democrat of Tennessee, today pictured public power as entering what he called "the era of the raw deal." Hhe spoke before T. V. A. power distributors from Georgia, Tennessee and Virginia at a meeting in Gatlinburg, Tenn.

IN "Moon Magic," the first of this sequence of tales, Pancho, the nascent artist, is being cared for by Maria, an Indian girl who cures the sick by invoking the spirit of a god wrapped up in a mysterious bundle. Pancho destroys the image and, though Maria's life is symbolically destroyed with it, she fails to strike the child because she loves him.

Announcement of Nikita S. Khrushchev's selection as first secretary of the Communist party's Central Committee makes him the first formal successor to Joseph Stalin as chief of the Soviet Union's Communist party apparatus. Available evidence suggests that in recent months Mr. Khrushchev has actually exercised this role, though without the formal title until now.

Harry Cassidy, candidate for the Democratic nomination for Borough President of Richmond, called upon the District Attorneys of New York and Richmond Counties yesterday to investigate the "very peculiar" circumstances surrounding the city's contract for concessions at the Staten Island Ferry Terminal.

A COMMENT in this column last month, on the hazards of reporting a bridge tournament at long distance, turned out to be more prophetic than was intended. Last week a cable from Helsinki, where the Finns had been hosts to this year's European bridge championships, announced that England had won.

Operation Mariner begins Wednesday. For nineteen days Blue forces defending the free world will range the North Atlantic area in combined sea, air and land operations. They will be testing their defenses against simulated, attack by Orange, or Communist, aggressors armed with atomic weapons.

For while suburbanites enjoy a resurgence of bloom at this time of year, the cliff dweller's plants have already succumbed to the ravages of soot -- not to mention aphids, heat and drought.

Drs. NEW YORK CITY'S Department of Sanitation had to start its annual clean-up of fallen leaves from street trees two months earlier than usual this year, according to Commissioner Andrew W. Mulrain. This is only one indication that 1953's display of autumn color will be less brilliant than in former years.

ELIZABETH, N. J., Sept. 12 -- Ten persons were injured, two seriously, in two chain accidents in which eleven automobiles and a trailer truck piled up on a fog-shrouded area of the New Jersey Turnpike paralleling the Elizabeth meadows early today.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., Sept. 12 (AP) -- A spectator was fatally injured and five racing car drivers and fifteen other persons were injured today in accidents during the 100-mile race at the New York State Fair.

Home-Made, owned by Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt, and Level Lea, running in the silks of John S. Phipps, shared the competitive honors at the Aqueduct Race Track yesterday. The former, 8-1, scored a mildly surprising victory in the $24,325 Vagrancy Handicap, and Level Lea pleased many customers in the crowd of 30,766 by taking the Edgemere Handicap, with a total value of $29,025.

One of the primary reasons for low morale in the armed services today is that enlisted men are treated as second-class citizens. In totalitarian countries, and until recently in the United States, discipline and morale in the services have been maintained most effectively by a feudal structure comprising a "nobility" of commissioned officers, selected "freemen" representing the nobility, viz., the noncommissioned officers, and the "peasants" making up the lowest four grades of the enlisted ranks.

My interest, like that or nearly all of the customers who will be arriving in especial numbers during the next few months, has been in the farms that cannot or should not be farmed.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- Dr. Ralph J. Bunche said today that if there had been no United Nations in the turbulent times since World War II "we almost certainly would have been in an atomic World War III long ago."

IN a field beside the road from Trevoux to Saint Didier, twenty-five kilometers north of Lyon, on June 16, 1944, Marc Leopold Benjamin Bloch, distinguished medievalist, professor at the Sorbonne, later "the oldest captain in the whole French Army," and subsequently a captive and tortured leader of the Resistance, was executed by a Gestapo firing squad.

ROME, Sept. 12 -- The property of certain bacteria to produce virus-like particles, named bacteriophage, which cause violent disruption of the parent bacterium and which shed light on the process of immunity, promises to lead to a better understanding of virus disease in general and may even provide important clues to the nature and cause of malignancy.

SAIGON, Vietnam, Sept. 12 -- French and United States officials began attempts today to get Cambodian Premier Penn Nouth to retract statements he made on the radio yesterday in which he told the Communist-led Vietminh that he did not oppose them so long as they left his country in peace.

BOSTON, Sept. 12 (UP) -- Billy Goodman, whose second-inning error helped the Browns gain a three-run lead, broke up a twelve-inning game today with a run-scoring single that gave the Red Sox a 7-6 victory before 11,364 fans at Fenway Park.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 12 -- Doug Ford of Harrison, N. Y., and Dick Mayer of St. Petersburg, Fla., were the last to finish today in the third round of the Eastern open golf tournament and tied for the lead with scores of 209.

HERSHEY, Pa., Sept. 12 (UP) -- Pennsylvania Republicans revealed today they had borrowed Ringling Brothers' last year's circus "big top" and reserved a 20,000-seat football stadium and a 6,000 seat sports arena to give President Eisenhower the "biggest old-fashioned birthday party in history" here Oct. 13.

MONTREAL, Sept. 12 -- Tony Trabert and Vic Seixas struck the clinching blow for the United States in the American Zone Davis Cup tennis final today by subduing Canada's Lorne Main and Paul Willey, 2 -- 6, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 2, in a doubles match played in blustery winds and steady rain.

SAVANNAH, Ga., Sept. 12 -- The old City Market, with its bell that tolled out the news of the firing on Fort Sumter and its fish-shaped weather vane that has challenged the sky over Ellis Square for generations, is on the verge of limbo.

DONCASTER, England, Sept. 12 -- Premonition, a stretch-running 3-year-old colt, charged to an upset victory today in the historic St. Leger Stakes, to the disappointment of Queen Elizabeth II and most of her loyal subjects, who rooted for the royal family's Aureole.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- Bob Porterfield, an ex-Yankee, nudged the New Yorkers closer to their fifth straight pennant today by defeating the Indians, 4 -- 3, for the Senators. Porterfield became the first American League pitcher to win twenty games.

TEHERAN, Iran, Sept. 12 -- Dr. Mohammed Mossadegh, former Premier of Iran, is to be tried jointly with some of his ministers and principal collaborators for alleged rebellion against Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi, according to the man who will present the prosecution case.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 12 -- Arthur Bisguier of New York, Hans Berliner of Washington, Herbert Avram of Arlington, Va., and Saul Wachs of Philadelphia won two matches each to share the lead as the national challenger's chess tournament began today.

CHICAGO, Sept. 12 (UP) -- Rocky Castellani, one of the top ten middleweights, punched out a unanimous ten-round decision over Johnny Lombardo tonight in the weekly television network feature from Rainbo Arena.

THE airlines began air-coach service to give their planes high, economical utilization and to open a new passenger market. The low fare was established to attract to air travel persons who had previously considered commercial flying too costly.
CLEVELAND, Sept. 12 -- The winter storage fleet in Buffalo Harbor will be the largest in the history of the Lake Erie port. grain brokers here predicted today.

SANTA FE, N. M., Sept. 12 -- New Mexico voters will approve or reject Tuesday eleven amendments to its State Constitution passed by the 1953 Legislature. Among the proposed amendments is the one that would authorize the sale of intoxicating liquor to Indians. If approved, the state laws would then conform to Federal legislation recently signed by President Eisenhower.

Out of this unfortunate circumstance came the idea for Band-Aid Adhesive Bandages, now found all over the world and responsible for building a major industry with an annual sales volume of more than $30,000,000.

WHEN you leave the day-lit street and walk up the stairs into the darkened Grace Borgenicht Gallery, you are greeted by a sight of such enchantment that your first response is one of pure esthetic delight.

WATKINS GLEN, N. Y. -- This popular resort at the foot of Seneca Lake is expecting a big influx of visitors for the annual Grand Prix automobile speed races which will be held next Saturday on new 4.6-mile road circuit just west of the village, starting at 10:30 A. M.

This Tuesday is Primary Day in New York. From 3 P. M. until 10 P. M. New Yorkers enrolled in political parties will cast their votes for party nominees for Mayor, Controller, President of the City Council and several dozen lesser officials. Of the major parties, the Republicans will mark cherry red ballots for an unopposed ticket headed by Harold Riegelman, their leaders' choice for Mayor.

ROME, Sept. 12 -- Pope Pius XII said today that priests who lived and worked among workingmen must be particularly careful not to become dupes of Marxism and other social theories that the Catholic Church condemns. This note of caution was sounded in a letter that Pro-Secretary of State Msgr. Giovanni Battista Montini sent in the Pope's name to a group of Italian diocesan ecclesiastical assistants attached to anti-Communist labor organizations.

THE result of twenty-five years of research by the author, aided by three fellowships given him for the purpose, this book is a substantial contribution to American history. For in its pages Edward D. Andrews has assembled out of existing writing by and about the "people called Shakers" a faithful, sympathetic and comprehensive account of that curious sect.

CHANCELLOR KONRAD ADENAUER is a unique phenomenon in the post-war political scene of Western Europe. He has been described as a German Talleyrand, a Teutonic Machiavelli, and as a man who conducts the mid-twentieth-century affairs of West Germany in the manner of an eighteenth-century grand seigneur.

WHEN the Sadler's Wells Ballet arrives in town, apparently everything else comes to a temporary halt. Between now and the middle of next month there is not so much as a whisper of any other dancing in the immediate vicinity.

The death last week of Chief Justice Fred M. Vinson caused many fair traders to wonder about the chances of their principle -- legal retail price fixing -- when it is tested at the next session of the Supreme Court. In one important suit Mr. Vinson went on record against fair trade.

ARTURO TOSCANINI will will open the seventeenth season of the N. B. C. Symphony Orchestra with a concert at Carnegie Hall on Saturday, Nov. 7. For the sixth consecutive season Mr. Toscanini will share the podium with the young Italian conductor, Guido Cantelli. Fourteen concerts will be conducted by Mr. Toscanini, the remaining eight by Mr. Cantelli.

Part-time college education has proved its value and has become increasingly popular for adults, Dr. Louis M. Hacked, dean of Columbia University's School of General Studies, declared last week. Nearly 7,000 men and women between the ages of 25 and 60 enroll in the school's classes each year.
DEMOREST, Ga., Sept. 12 (UP) -- Piedmont College made ready for a new term today after scoring what its president, Dr. James E. Walter, called a triumph of principles over pressure.

RED BANK, N. J., Sept. 12 -- The script for any regatta normally calls for a Gold Cup speed boat or one of the unlimited class to beat anything in sight. But Burnett G. Bartley Jr. of Columbus, Ohio, departed from the script today on the opening program of the National Sweepstakes on the Navesink River.
