EDINBURGH, Scotland -- Interest in a local legend that a hoard of medieval treasure is buried at the site of the old Castle of Dumfries has been revived by excavations to establish the plan and character of the building at Castle-dyke, where the castle was built about 800 years ago.

A new Mr. and Mrs. Television show went into the homes of New Yorkers yesterday at 1:30 P. M. on a crucial two-day commercial basis. It starred Mr. and Mrs. Vincent R. Impellitteri, who had an important product to sell: the re-election of Mr. Impellitteri as Mayor of the City of New York.

The Danish hospital ship Jutlandia steamed homeward three weeks ago after nearly three years of service in Korea. Just as she stood as a ship of mercy off the coast of Inchon while receiving the wounded of the United Nations and the United States, particularly our own marines, she was a ship of mercy on the trip homeward.

NEW CITY, N. Y., Sept. 12 -- Republican and Democratic candidates for District Attorney, neither of whom is opposed, will be nominated in Tuesday's primary elections in Rockland County. The District Attorney's office is the only county office to be filled in November.

MADISON, Wis., Sept. 12 -- Scientists meeting here this week at the University of Wisconsin with the American Institute of Biological Sciences have agreed that here is a nationwide shortage of animals needed for laboratory tests.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Sept. 12 (UP) -- The Philadelphia football machine swung into high gear in the third quarter for a 28-to-17 Eagle victory over the Los Angeles Rams in a exhibition game before 20,000 fans tonight.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (UP) -- The Army's program of wiping out racial segregation is ahead of schedule and today at least 90 per cent of the Negroes in the Army are serving in non-segregated units.

EDDIE WILSON, his many young friends will be glad to hear, is home from his visit to his uncle's Texas ranch. Gardenia, Eddie's goat, did not return, but Eddie brought along enough other "valuable property" to complicate life for whoever might be near him. Things began to happen the minute Eddie and his new parrot, Louella, came off the train.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 12 (AP) -- Ted Kluszewski's fortieth home run of the season drove in the tying and winning runs today as the Redlegs took a 3-2 decision from the Phils. The victory gave Cincinnati a sweep of the two-game series.

STEVE ALLEN, who batted around the C. B. S. studios for several seasons, has made the switch to N. B. C. and the change now appears to be agreeing with him. His late evening show over Channel 4 -- at 11:20 P. M., Monday through Friday -- is usually intelligent offbeat fun.

Synthetic rubber and synthetic textile fibers have made big names for themselves in war and peace in recent years. But there is another synthetic, cryolite, whose strategic importance to the nation has gone largely unheralded by the layman.

A SPECULATIVE observer of Europe's film festivals might well conclude that this year's Edinburgh Seventh International firmly established itself as the show case for documentary, experimental and realist films.

It is for precisely the reasons so ably set forth by Marquis W. Childs in "Public Relations Along the Potomac" (Aug. 30) that Dean William J. Ronan established the course, "Government Public Relations," which we teach at New York University's Graduate School of Public Administration.
John Cashmore, president of the Borough of Brooklyn, last night proclaimed Tuesday, Sept. 22, as "Brooklyn Dodger" day in honor of the National League pennant winners.

When Attorney General Brownell visited the Mexican border recently and saw for himself the nature of the problem of the illegal influx of Mexican workers into this country, he termed the situation "shocking" and pledged the Administration to stop the inflow. His subordinates apparently have since been taking action on the matter, raiding farms on which these "wetbacks" are employed and deporting them to Mexico.

BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 12 -- Despite President Juan Peron's assertions that the latest livestock census showed that "all previous results have been surpassed in numbers," the Government is facing a major problem in meat supplies, spokesmen for leading packing houses declared today. The problem has become so critical, they said, that unless drastic measures are taken Argentina will fail to live up to her important trade treaty with Britain.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Sept. 12 -- Lawson Purdy, one of the grand torch-bearers in the historic New York City crusades for tax reforms, zoning regulations and improvement of tenement buildings, will be a vigorous 90 years old tomorrow.

TOKYO, Sunday, Sept. 13 -- The Neutral Nations Repatriation Commission was to turn over to the Communists at Panmunjom today nine North Korean prisoners of war who originally decided they did not wish to be repatriated but then changed their minds.

TO get an idea of this book, imagine two people in an argument, say over Korea. One says Syngman Rhee is a patriot, the other a menace. The disputants get hot under the collar. They begin to shout and point their fingers. One cries: "You, my friend, what do you really know, anyhow!" The other, to everyone's amazement, sits down to show what he "really knows."

TWO men from India's Punjab knocked on the door at 35 Rue de Sevres in Paris one bleak December Day in 1950 and were greeted by the solemn face of M. Le Corbusier, over the last thirty years one of the guiding geniuses of the modern revolution in architecture.

SINCE the death of his wife, the French schoolmaster of the eastern Pyrenees village had tried to mend the shattered order of his existence. His bees were his main comfort; their industrious and devoted social life were enough to persuade him that the world was, after all, a harmonious creation. No wonder the schoolmaster was enraged the day he discovered that some human tyrant had violated one of his hives.

ON the surface this is a simple and compelling story. Frank Knight, a newspaper man, discovers that John and Eleanor Bickel, American missionaries, are not on the last refugee train out of Red China. The Bickels are not only his friends but also a potentially hot story, so Frank sets forth in pursuit.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 12 (UP) -- The New York Giants defeated the Baltimore Colts, 10 to 6, in an exhibition football game at Oakland Stadium tonight.
IF you can play a musical instrument there is a new factor on the scene guaranteed to make your life a lot happier, and your neighbors' a lot more miserable.

Twelve of the fifteen players engaged in the world chess championship challengers' tournament resumed play in the eighth round last night at Schaffhausen, Switzerland, according to a report from Zurich.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (AP) -- The Internal Revenue Service reported today that its "racket squads" and other agents turned up tax cases that yielded $178,000,000 in additional assessments and penalties in the twelve months ending June 30.

FOR most readers the word "experimental" is a fatal epithet when applied to a novel. It suggests more theory than story, character or situation; it suggests difficulty. And as most of the great novels of the world, as well as the worst, are not difficult, the reader wonders whether difficulty has any special virtue.

For sixteen months there has been growing uncertainty over the outlook for the free nations' grand design for a secure Western Europe. The uncertainty has grown because the center piece in that grand design -- the project for a six-nation European Defense Community including West Germans -- has remained a paper project, an item of imaginative, but unfinished business.

SEAN O'FAOLAIN is Ireland's foremost living man of letters. Now in his fifties, he has had his good say in a wide variety of forms. What Yeats did to discipline Irish literature, he would do to discipline Irish society, so that free Ireland might become a country in which a whole man could live a good life and the artist could stay home and write about him.

THE influence of other countries on the contemporary American home has snowballed during the last three years. During the war, quite understandably, little merchandise and few ideas were imported. True, the popular traditional classics of the Twenties (furniture of eighteenth century England and France) and modern classics of the Thirties (Swedish modern and some of Alvar Aalto's Finnish designs) remained prized by those who had acquired them.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- The prospect of a comprehensive revision of the Taft-Hartley law is just about what it was before Martin P. Durkin resigned as Secretary of Labor this week -- dim, so far as the immediate future is concerned.

Harold Riegelman, unopposed candidate for the Republican nomination for Mayor, announced yesterday that he and his running-mates, Representative Paul A. Fino, candidate for Controller, and Representative Henry J. Latham, candidate for President of the City Council, had decided not to seek an independent line on the voting machines at the Nov. 3 general election but would run on the Republican line alone.

DAHLIAS head the casts of flower shows for this month. While their major performances may be seen at the big exhibits staged by the dahlia societies, they will also have featured roles at most of the other shows in this area.

THE Commission of Fine Arts which President Truman requested in 1951 to survey "activities carried on by the Federal Government in the field of art," has recommended, in a report submitted to President Eisenhower, that "the subject-matter of postage stamps should include not only representations of persons and events of historical importance but also architectural monuments and other evidences of American culture which can, in this way, be made known to people throughout the world."

Many pages of this work would be devoted to such expressions as "democracy" or "freedom," elucidating the fact that these expressions are used with passionate sincerity by different people to mean quite different things.

THE United Nations Trusteeship Council recently passed a resolution urging the Australian Government to eliminate Pidgin English from the Pacific territories under its control, especially Papua and New Guinea.

Peace through united action was advocated yesterday morning in a "Sabbath Day of Repentance" sermon by Rabbi Samuel M. Segal at Mount Neboh Temple, 130 West Seventy-ninth Street. In company with Jews everywhere, the congregation is observing ten days of penitence opening the Jewish New Year, which began last Wednesday night.

There was one category of drivers omitted by Robert Payne in his informative round-up article ("World Drivers: An Auto-Analysis," Sept. 6), namely, women drivers. Isn't it a truism that women drivers, be they French, English, Italian, American are in a class by themselves?

STONY BROOK, L. I., Sept. 12 -- Mr. and Mrs. A. H. Merkel's gray gelding Grey Dawn, from Brookville, L. I., ridden by Gabor Foltenyi, scored 16 points to win the open jumper championship of the twentieth annual North Shore horse show today.
THE Agnes de Mille Dance Theatre, now in rehearsal, will open in Baltimore on Oct. 12, with a long tour to follow and a possible New York engagement in the spring.
A man was shot dead in a Brooklyn bar and grill last night and three other persons were injured after the proprietor tried to break up a heated baseball argument between Dodger and Yankee fans.

ALLENTOWN, Pa., Sept. 12 -- The Giralda Farms' English cocker spaniel, Ch. Springbank Ace of Giralda, handled by Ed Sayres Jr., gained best in show in the Mel Horn Sr. Memorial fixture of the Lehigh Valley Kennel Club today. Richard A. Kerns Jr. judged. The main award was the sixth for the imported spaniel.

In cities and suburbs across the country zinnias are one of the most dependable annual flowers every summer. Perhaps that is because this is an American plant, originally native to Mexico. The zinnia, however, has been transformed during the last thirty years and now appears in innumerable forms.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- Livingston T. Merchant, Assistant Secretary of State for European Affairs, will meet for three days in Vienna later this month with United States diplomatic chiefs in five Eastern European countries and Austria, the State Department announced today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- Special elections to fill three vacant and heretofore Republican seats in the House of Representatives are approaching in three states. Democratic campaign officials concede privately that the outlook is not hospitable to them.

IN the Book Review (Aug. 2) Hoffman Birney, writing of the Wild West in fiction, says: "German boys learned of it from Carl May's tales of Winnetou, the noble Indian, and old Shatterhand, trapper and guide; tales which have never been translated, and which were written, with remarkable accuracy, by a man who never crossed the Atlantic."

After having enjoyed Eric Hoffer's interesting and deeply perceptive article, "Why Captive Peoples Revolt," I was disappointed to read the conclusions drawn by a correspondent, Robert S. Field, in the Sept. 6 issue.

THE career of Thomas Mitchell -- forty - odd years long, crowded with sympathetic portrayals of earthbound men -- underwent a metamorphosis of sorts when he opened last February in "Hazel Flagg," his first musical, which returned recently to the Mark Hellinger Theatre after a summer recess.

Native Dancer is out of the Sysonby Mile. The 3-year-old son of Polynesian, owned by Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt and trained by Bill Winfrey, was withdrawn yesteerday from the $50,000 added race scheduled to be run at Belmont Park on Sept. 26. Vanderbilt explained that the action was taken because the colt was behind in his training, because of the bruised foot condition that required treatment a week ago Wednesday.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 13 -- The long-awaited test of popularity between the motion-picture theatre and pay-as-you-see home television offering the same films concurrently in the same community is scheduled to begin the first week in November in Palm Springs.

The Society of the Silurians, an organization of veteran New York newspaper men, announced yesterday the establishment of a watchdog committee to protect the interests of the press and those working in allied fields of public information.

A plan to restore the number of Mormon missionaries in foreign countries to 5,000 was outlined yesterday afternoon by George H. Mortimer, president of the New York Stake of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter Day Saints.

In conjunction with the National Home Furnishings Show this week F. Schumacher Co. has harvested an autumn collection of decorative fabrics from Europe. These are available through the decorating department of Bloomingdale's.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 -- The National Planning Association has found "steady progress" toward integration of white and Negro employes in three plants practicing nondiscrimination policies in Southern and "border" states.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (AP) -- Matt Batts' bases-loaded double with one out in the ninth inning scored three runs to give Detroit a 6-4 victory over Washington today in the second game of a double-header. The Tigers also won the opener, 10 -- 4.

The technique of the "propaganda trial" in Communist-dominated countries used to puzzle Western observers. Now we are learning something about it -- in a general way in some stories told by returning American prisoners in Korea and in specific terms in the articles by William N. Oatis, former Associated Press correspondent in Prague, now appearing in this and other newspapers.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (UP) -- Representative Charles A. Wolverton, Republican of New Jersey, Chairman of the House Commerce Committee, announced today that public hearings would begin Oct. 1 on "the causes and control" of a dozen major diseases including cancer and polio.

The Arlington Construction Company, which recently announced plans to build a store center in White Plains, N. Y., has purchased an additional plot of 8,000 square feet at 587 North Broadway, adjoining the site. The seller was Mrs. Olive Smith, who was represented by Edward M. West, Inc. Edward M. Verdes Son were the brokers.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 13 -- Communist China proposed today that the Korean peace conference be converted into a round-table discussion and that it be enlarged to include not only the belligerents but also "the Soviet Union and other Asian countries concerned."

AMSTERDAM, Sept. 13 -- Recent continuous Dutch exchange and trade liberalization (which certainly has not ended) is caused by the unabated improvement of the gold and foreign situation. This is reflected in last week's return of the Netherlands Bank's foreign exchange holdings to the end of June.

SPLIT, Yugoslavia, Sept. 13 -- President Tito expressed fears today that the Western powers were plotting against Yugoslavia on the Trieste issue. He singled out circles in Britain, which he accused of trying to slander his regime.
DENVER, Sept. 13 -- This was a day of prayer and good-bys for the Eisenhower family as the President began the sixth and final week of his vacation.

The National Broadcasting Company had to cancel its "Between the Lines" television program yesterday because Mayor Impellitteri refused to go on the air with Carmine G. DeSapio, leader of Tammany, with whom he has been at odds politically since he ran for Mayor as an independent candidate in 1950.

BOSTON, Sept. 13 (AP) -- Harry Dorish walked Milt Bolling with the bases filled in the eighth inning today to give the Red Sox a 7-6 victory over the White Sox. Bob Boyd had sent Chicago ahead in the top of the frame with a pinch three-run double, but Virgil Trucks, pitching in relief, allowed two Bostonians to reach base before Dorish was called in.
MEDAN, Indonesia, Sept. 13 -- The growing intensity of political and economic strains in Indonesia is particularly evident in this rich populous region of Sumatra.

TEHERAN, Iran, Sept. 13 -- Dr. Mohammed Mossadegh, former Premier of Iran facing trial on charges of rebellion, has admitted to investigators that he "made mistakes" during his twenty-eight months in office, but insists he had only the country's interests at heart, according to a Government spokesman.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission today reported "a virtual cessation" of fraudulent Canadian stock promotions in this country in the last year.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 13 -- The first full Republican-appointed delegation to the United Nations General Assembly will hold its initial get-together tomorrow morning.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (UP) -- Leonard W. Hall, Republican National Chairman, accused The Democratic Digest today of "promoting distrust" of this country overseas but Democratic leaders scoffed at the idea.
Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, chairman of the National Issues Committee, announced yesterday the text of "An American Platform" setting forth the beliefs and objectives of the organization.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 13 -- James T. Sherwin of the Marshall C. C. and Arthur B. Bisguier of the Manhattan C. C., New York, finished first and second, respectively, in the speed tournament finals of the Philadelphia Chess Association at the Hotel Adelphia today.

Unemployment insurance taxes in 1954 will be reduced across the board in New York State as a result of the record high balance in the Unemployment Trust Fund, it was announced yesterday by State Industrial Commissioner Edward Corsi.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Sept. 13 -- Fresh to strong winds up to 30 knots and a choppy sea greeted skippers today as the final session of the five-day Manhasset Bay Yacht Club race week program was completed on Long Island Sound.

An increase in charter activity last week, despite the loss of a business day for the celebration of Labor Day, has resulted in some optimism among ship brokers and agents as to the end of the summer doldrums in shipping. However, since rates remained at depressed levels or even dropped slightly, optimism was restrained.
A million and a quarter children, from uncertain kindergarten candidates to self-assured teen-agers, will pour on to the sidewalks of New York this morning on their way to school.
TORONTO, Sept. 13 -- Alberta has granted to Trans-Canada Pipe Lines, Ltd., the first license to export natural gas to the rich eastern Canadian market, it was learned yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 13 (AP) -- Crown Prince Akihito of Japan arrived here today for a three-day tour of Philadelphia's historic shrines and a reunion with the woman who taught him his first lessons about American democracy.

Carillon bells yesterday morning rang out "Faith of Our Fathers" from the limestone tower of the new St. Martin of Tours Roman Catholic Church at East 182d Street and Crotona Avenue, the Bronx, while Latin words of blessing and dedication were intoned by Cardinal Spellman.
MONZA, Italy, Sept. 13 (Reuters) -- Juan Manuel Fangio of Argentina gunned his Italian Maserati car at an average speed of 110 miles an hour today to win the Italian Grand Prix motor race.
An agreement involving development of a unified store construction program has been signed by Safeway Stores, Inc., as part of the expansion plan of the chain.

OYSTER BAY, L. I., Sept. 13 -- Three minutes of match racing and 2 hours 34 minutes 20 seconds of a sail-over gave America the first race for the Seawanhaka Cup in international sailing competition today.

THE Music Library at 121 East Fifty-eighth Street has just reopened after a three-month refurbishing. Miss Gladys Chamberlain and her staff of eight, all musically trained librarians, are back at the old stand, patiently answering questions from musicians, students, researchers and people bedeviled by nameless tunes in their heads.

The Juilliard School of Music will register returning students today and tomorrow. Registration for new students will take place Wednesday afternoon from 3 to 6 o'clock. Registration for the extension division will be held Monday, Sept. 28.

CHICAGO, Sept. 13 -- A relaxed group of National League champions today helped the Cubs to run their winning streak to nine games at Wrigley Field, but the Dodgers were a bit stubborn about it, at that.

The Rev. Dr. Daniel A. Poling, editor of The Christian Herald, issued an alert yesterday to the pulpits of the Protestant faith against the "insidious menace" of communism. Mackay, president of Princeton Theological Seminary, who recently declared that "anti-communism is as dangerous as communism and may be even more so."

The release by Robert Moses relative to the delay of the proposed Coliseum set forth in THE TIMES of Sept. 2 is another of the innumerable attempts to avoid blame for the delay in construction. Were Mr. Moses not so obstinate in his insistence on using the Columbus Circle site construction could have been near completion.

Of the two aspects of yesterday's news from Moscow: the naming of Nikita S. Khrushchev as First Secretary of the Communist party and the announcement of a new farm policy, the latter is the more fundamentally important. That Khrushchev was the second or third most important figure in the present Kremlin hierarchy had been apparent for several weeks, as this newspaper reported last month.
LONDON, Sept. 13 (Reuters) -- Poland announced tonight that a Roman Catholic Bishop had been arrested and would stand trial on charges of spying and conducting propaganda against the state.

There is no apparent overproduction of copper or mill products in this country, Morris F. LaCroix, president of the Copper Range Company, told stockholders in a letter accompanying the dividend check mailed today. He said, however, that while the company during the last seven months had carried on its business profitably, it had had to meet effective and direct competition of foreign production and the products of foreign rolling mills.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 13 (AP) -- Dick Meyer, 29-year-old star from Connecticut, whipped Mount Pleasant's par and tricky winds today with his favorite club, the putter, to win the Eastern open golf tournament with a score of 279.

The 1954 capital outlay budget to be proposed early next month by the City Planning Commission as a basis for public hearings will provide that the cost of completing pending transit projects and starting new ones be met next year with funds exempt from the city's debt limit.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (UP) -- Department of Agriculture researchers have developed a new, rapid test for measuring phosphorus in soil, using ordinary baking soda, it was announced today.

ZURICH, Sept. 13 -- Hopes for early release of all Swiss property blocked in the United States since World War II and out of court settlement of the Interhandel case were revived last week when Dallas S. Townsend, Assistant Attorney General in charge of the United States Office of Alien Property, arrived unexpectedly in Switzerland.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 13 (AP) -- Right-hander Harry Byrd, last year's rookie of the year in the American League, ended his nine-game losing streak today and won his first decision since July 18, beating the Browns, 2 -- 0, for the Athletics in the second game of a double-header at Connie Mack Stadium.

The Rev. Dr. Frank C. Dodger fans -- and they are legion -- can relax and breathe a collective sigh of relief. The outcome in the National League is no longer in doubt. No need to scan the standings every day or to calculate any number of won-lost combinations that will mathematically eliminate pursuers.

Beria, purged Minister of Internal Affairs, for the postwar failure of Soviet agriculture may be an effort to divert attention from the face that the farm policies followed during this period were approved by all Soviet leaders and that Mr. Khrushchev himself as one of their chief formulators.

CHICAGO, Sept. 13 -- Grain futures were unable to stand up under the heavy profit-taking on the bulges early last week, and again reflected the absence of any general outside buying interest of importance. Of top importance at this time of the year is the extra jacket that contributes warmth and smartness to a costume. It can be one of many types. Today we have selected two leading styles of the season with a dress that would look well if worn with either.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (UP) -- Deposits of all insured banks increased 3 per cent during the year ended last June 30, Chairman H. E. Cook of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation reported today.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 13 (AP) -- The last-place Pirates split a double-header with the Redlegs today, the Bucs taking the first game, 5 -- 4, behind the pitching of Paul La-Palme and Cincinnati winning, 8 -- 6, in the second contest.
Under favorable skies a colorful ceremony on the Mall in Central Park yesterday marked the city's observance of "I Am an American-Citizenship Day."

There could scarcely be a better way to open the ballet season officially than to bring over the Sadler's Wells Ballet from London and set them up at the Metropolitan Opera House, and since that is what happened last night, there is no cause whatever for complaint this morning.

Last week's rumor that James A. Michener's forthcoming book, "Sayonara: A Japanese Romance," would reach the stage was surprisingly correct. MILWAUKEE, Sept. 13 -- The Braves will not win the pennant -- they, too, "is dead" -- but the transplanted Boston club has a good chance to surpass a record now owned by the Dodgers.

BENHAM, Ky., Sept. 13 -- The warmth of a hero's welcome cooled suddenly for Staff Sgt. Jack Flanary when a "rumor" that he had been a Communist sympathizer while a war prisoner in Korea filtered through a crowd that had come to cheer him.

The art exhibitions scheduled to open this week are highly varied. Museum events include a show of water-colors by Indians of the Southwest at the Museum of Natural History, and a selection of paintings, sculpture and drawings from its permanent collection at the Whitney Museum, opening tomorrow.
William H. Howell, 35-year-old ex-convict hunted for more than two weeks in the murder of Thomas Lewis, Bronx labor leader, gave himself up to the police early today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (AP) -- The Small Defense Plants Administration said in a final report issued today that it had provided $723,000,000 in assistance to small companies during its twenty-one months of life.

A soft trend that developed in the British pound sterling and continued strength in the Canadian dollar highlighted the foreign exchange market during the past week. Volume of business transacted was reported to be fairly heavy at times.

CHARLES A. LINDBERGH, for twenty-six years the world's most celebrated aviator, is also going to be famous from now on as an author. He has written other books, successful ones, too. But his "The Spirit of St. Louis,"* which is published today, is a truly remarkable book. There has never been anything like it before in the history of autobiography or in the history of flight.

THE Columbia Broadcasting System would seem to have a new hit on its hands in the television version of "My Favorite Husband," which made its debut at 9:30 Saturday evening. Joan Caulfield is sublimely videogenic in the principal role; the basic plot situation is not too large a distortion of real life, and the dialogue is usually credible and often amusing.

TOKYO, Sept. 13 (AP) -- Following is the text of a statement by Chou En-lai, on terms for the Korean peace conference, addressed to Dag Hammarskjold, Secretary General of the United Nations, as broadcast from Peiping and monitored here.

RED BANK, N. J., Sept. 13 -- Guy Lombardo's appropriately named Tempo VI came back today and with a substitute pilot at the steering wheel succeeded in winning both of the feature heats on the Navesink River. But this wasn't enough to carry off the National Sweepstakes title which went to Burnett G. Bartley Jr. of Columbus, Ohio, on points, 700 to 625.

MONTREAL, Sept. 13 (AP) -- The United States completed a 5-0 rout of Canada in the American Zone Davis Cup tennis final today on single victories by Straight Clark of Pasadena, Calif., and Bernard Bartzen of San Angelo, Tex.

Well-known men and women are aiding in furthering the success of a preview of the annual National Home Furnishings Show on Wednesday night at the Grand Central Palace, which has been taken over to raise funds for the Sister Elizabeth Kenny Foundation.

ROME, Sept. 13 (AP) -- Russian complaints that the United States is trying to "stack" the Olympic Games to Russia's disadvantage are "simply out of date," Avery Brundage said today.

WESTBURY, L. I., Sept. 13 -- Racing to a five-goal lead in the first period, the Meadow Brook quartet rode into the final round of the thirty-seventh national open polo championship tournament today by halting Milwaukee, 10 to 4, on International Field at the Meadow Brook Club before a crowd of 3,500.

LONDON, Sept. 13 -- British progress in the development of jet fighters and bombers, guided missiles for both offense and defense and certain mechanisms associated with the atomic bomb is the basis for a movement on the part of this country to seek the restoration of the free flow of scientific information between Britain and the United States.

Cayce Morrison, who will leave his present post as Assistant Commissioner and Coordinator of Research in the State Education Department Oct. 1.

Stevenson, the 1952 Presidential candidate, planned today a harmonious two-day party rally tomorrow and Tuesday that would avoid divisive North-South issues while stepping up the tempo of attacks upon the Eisenhower Administration.

A comprehensive collection of fall fashions that included outstanding trends in coats, suits and dresses was previewed for the press last week by Martin's. The fashion show will be presented for the public tomorrow at 2:30 P. M. on the store's fifth floor.

Certain characteristics become associated with the work of various designers through repeated use. It is the unfailing application of fine detail which distinguishes Sally Milgrim's handsome custom order designs. Previewed Friday at Milgrim, 6 West Fifty-seventh Street, her fall and winter collection was rich with minute tuckings, luxurious imported fabrics, the play of contrasting fabrics.

The scene of the world chess championship challengers' tournament moved today from Neuhausen to Zurich, where the remaining rounds, starting with the tenth, will be contested, according to Swiss news reports received yesterday.

The New York and New Jersey waterfront commissioners, appointed recently and charged with giving the crime-ridden Port of New York a thorough housecleaning, are scheduled to meet here today with Governor Dewey for an important discussion of their plans to drive rackets from the waterfront.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 13 (AP) -- Harvey Haddix, Cards' southpaw, coasted to his eighteenth triumph of the season today, holding the Phillies to five hits while St. Louis pounded out a 17-3 victory.

Robert D. Murphy, Assistant Secretary of State for United Nations Affairs, said today that the tendency of the United Nations General Assembly to discuss matters of only domestic concern to various countries had gone too far.

End of Summer Summer may attempt to extend the glory of its short reign with a few more warm and sunny days, but there can be no denying that the King is dead. The proof of summer's demise will be provided this morning, when some 915,000 of its loyal subjects in the city lay down their arms -- slingshots and canoe paddles -- and capitulate.

The hats that Tatiana of Saks Fifth Avenue has created for fall and winter are artful in their conception and execution. Small and graceful, they rest lightly but firmly on the head. In color they are delicious, favoring dull and muted tones that include gold, blue, cocoa, vanilla, with an occasional use of ruby red and sapphire blue.

TRENTON, Sept. 13 -- Edward J. Patten, campaign manager for Robert B. Meyner, Democratic candidate for Governor of New Jersey, charged tonight that all of Elmer H. Wene's primary election petitions had been "illegally removed" from the office of the Secretary of State in the State House here.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 -- The Special Antitrust Subcommittee of the Judiciary Committee of the House of Representatives today suggested a broad program of action and study for Government and private industry to prevent recurring shortages of newsprint supplies. It recommended increased domestic production and the use of new resources.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Sept. 13 -- Veterans of Jewish formations involved in the Palestine War of 1948 have formed a citizens' committee here to fight the Government order banishing eight Arabs of the Abu Ghosh clan from their village northwest of Jerusalem to other parts of Israel.

Harold M. Lane's 63-foot yawl, Doris, from the Beach Point Y. C. fleet in Mamaroneck, switched trophies over the week-end during the 140-mile Cornfield Lightship haul which featured the City Island Yacht Club's twentieth annual overnight race program.

The prices of cotton futures continued to fluctuate last week within a relatively narrow trading range. The larger than expected cotton crop estimate of the Government, released Tuesday, failed to generate any sharp rise in trading activity, and prices weakened only slightly.
SAULTE STE. MARIE, Mich., Sept. 13 (AP) -- The Coast Guard cutter Mackinaw rescued today the nine men on a dredge that had drifted helplessly in the storm on Lake Superior from early yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 -- With a nursing shortage persisting, the Women's Bureau of the Department of Labor will issue today an informative eighty-page booklet entitled "The Outlook for Women in Professional Nursing Occupations." It is on sale for 30 cents at the Government Printing Office in Washington.

ROME, Sept. 13 -- Recalling the precedent of Danzig, which furnished a spark that caused World War II to explode, Premier Giuseppe Pella appealed to the Western Powers today not to allow Trieste to grow into a like threat to peace, and proposed a plebiscite to determine whether the city of Trieste and the Free Territory should be assigned to Italy or Yugoslavia.

OTTAWA, Sept. 13 -- A bitter quarrel was developing today between the citizens of Ottawa, led by their woman Mayor, and the Federal Government of Premier Louis St. Laurent concerning the future of Ottawa as the capital of Canada.

Plans for an International Surgeons Hall of Fame in Chicago were announced yesterday as the eighteenth annual congress of the International College of Surgeons opened at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel here.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Sept. 13 -- The Southwest will be playing host to the United States Golf Association amateur championship for the first time when the fifty-first tournament of the organization begins tomorrow morning at the Oklahoma City Golf and Country Club.

When the American colleges and universities start their 1953-54 academic year this month, 200,000 ex-servicemen will be enrolled under provisions of the G. I. Bill for veterans of the fighting in Korea. For the first time since the influx of World War II veterans began to ease off several years ago, a substantial number of new veterans are coming to college campuses.

GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 13 -- John H. Hosch 3d, 18-year-old son of a vice president of the J. Walter Thompson advertising agency, was killed in an automobile accident early this morning a few minutes after leaving a debutante party at the Field Club here.

Rudolph Halley, President of the City Council and unopposed for the Liberal nomination for Mayor in tomorrow's primary, disclaimed last night knowledge of a conversation with Adolf A. Berle Jr., state chairman of the Liberal party, in which it allegedly was agreed that Mr. Halley would vote for leasing the city's transit system to the Transit Authority only if his votes were needed to make the transfer effective.

SAIGON, Vietnam, Sept. 13 -- The Foreign Minister of Cambodia, Sirik Matak, tried today to reassure the United States and France concerning a radio speech Friday in which Premier Penn Nouth told the Communist-led Vietminh rebels that Cambodia did not oppose them as long as they kept away from her territory.

New York University this year has moved into a new field -- economic education for the leaders of the business world. Registrations have been made for an evening seminar on "New Perspectives in Economics for Top Management."

PARIS, Sept. 13 -- Crossing from Germany into France by way of Luxembourg is a suggestive journey just now from several points of view. It points up the sharp contrast in the mood of the two countries. It highlights the difference between the frontier character of the improvised German cities, which somehow produce the effect of a new country, and the old gray towns of France, on the surface so settled and unchanging.

MADISON, Wis., Sept. 13 -- Snow would be much handier to have around in the springtime if it were some color other than white, it was suggested here today at the conference on the utilization of solar energy. The three-day session is being jointly sponsored by the University of Wisconsin and the National Science Foundation.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (UP) -- Two of the nation's three leading farm organizations endorsed today the Administration's Federal power policy. The third called it "total surrender" to private interests.

Fifteen young men gave a bachelor party Saturday night in a Greenwich Village night club for a Queens bridegroom-to-be, and fifteen other young men gave a bachelor party for a Brooklyn bridegroom-to-be in the same place at the same time.

NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 13 -- Communist China seemed today to have won another propaganda victory over the United States in India by demanding New Delhi's participation in the Korean peace conference. This comes after United States opposition had caused this country to withdraw its candidature despite a majority vote in its favor by the Political and Security Committee of the United Nations General Assembly.

The vast majority of American seamen and port workers has been screened and cleared for work aboard ships and along the nation's waterfront, the maritime committee of the Congress of Industrial Organizations reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 -- Senator Lyndon B. Johnson of Texas, Democratic leader of the Senate, said today that prospects were excellent for an agreement at the next session of Congress on means to safeguard further the constitutional rights of the American people against impairment under treaties.

FLORAL PARK, L. I., Sept. 13 -- Two jet fighter planes, representing aviation -- Long Island's major industry -- zipped across Belmont Park here at 6:30 P. M. today to start the Long Island Industry Fund's third annual Hospital Star Nite performance.

Any attempt to evacuate cities in advance of possible enemy air attacks is impracticable and would be opposed by the New York State Civil Defense Commission, Lieut. Gen. C. R. Huebner, State Director of Civil Defense, announced yesterday.
ISTANBUL, Turkey, Sept. 12 -- Bulgaria appears to be the last of the Soviet satellites to have begun a retreat from the extreme Stalinist methods.

Practically none of today's popular motifs and materials have been omitted from a new collection of furniture being introduced today at John Wanamaker. Called "Mid-Century Modern," the group is by J. Stuart Clingman, a designer who heretofore had been associated almost completely with traditional furniture.

LONDON, Sept. 13 -- The divergence between the views of the London market and those of Wall Street on the business outlook in the United States continues to keep our stock market moving quietly on the upgrade in face of a continuing downward trend in Wall Street.

Vendors of cold soft drinks and ice cream had few takers yesterday at the annual outdoor art show on Staten Island, but the purveyors of the wares that hung like brave pennants on a long iron fence bordering a former pasture of Sailors Snug Harbor seemed to be in business.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, Sept. 13 -- The Ceylonese Government will decide shortly on a recommendation by the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development that the total area under rubber cultivation in Ceylon should not be increased, and might even be decreased.

MOUNT KISCO, N. Y., Sept. 13 -- Hutchinson Stable's consistent-winning jumper, Peg's Pride, and Barbara Friedemann's 4-year-old foxchaser, the gray mare Pebble Hill, dominated their respective divisions at Lawrence Farms' twenty-third annual horse show today.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 13 -- The 20-year-old ash blonde who took time out from her summer vacation as a student at the University of Pennsylvania to win the title of Miss America of 1954 left this afternoon for New York to start her reign with a clothes shopping tour and television appearances.

Borough President Robert F. Wagner Jr. of Manhattan, candidate for the Democratic nomination for Mayor, appealed for a heavy vote in the primary election tomorrow. He said he was confident of the outcome if a high percentage of the 2,135,000 enrolled Democrats exercised their right to vote for their party nominees.

Alfred Marshall, re-examining classical economic theory, decided that full employment under the old rules was unlikely because business men got skittish whenever conditions looked too good and brought on recessions by anticipating them with payroll and inventory cuts.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (AP) -- Speaker Joseph W. Martin Jr., Republican of Massachusetts, named today six members to a special commission created by Congress to study Congressional and judicial salaries.

TOKYO, Monday, Sept. 14 -- Communist authorities in Korea have signified their intention to transfer to the custody of the Neutral Nations Repatriation Commission next Sunday all United Nations prisoners in their control who refuse to return home.

A cookbook of more than usual interest, because its author would seem on the surface to be far removed from the kitchen range, appears today. He is Brig. Gen. Frank Dorn, deputy chief of information in the Department of the Army at Washington.

MUNSAN, Korea, Monday, Sept. 14 -- Some Allied prisoners who "chose communism" in Red prison camps now have changed their minds and want to return to their democratic homelands, a Communist newspaper man said at Panmunjom today.

The Democratic feud between the Impellitteri and Wagner factions comes to a test tomorrow, with polls open for the primary election from 3 P. M. to 10 P. M. It has been, for the most part, a dreary campaign, confirming, in our opinion, the mediocrity of both major candidates and their inadequacy for the office they seek.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (UP) -- The Government today charged a London export-importer and a Swiss shipping agent with unlawful shipment of a strategic material from the United States to Russia in 1950.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 13 -- Following are the items proposed for inclusion on the regular and supplementary agenda of the eighth regular session of the United Nations General Assembly, which will convene here Tuesday. Explanatory material within parentheses was compiled by the United Nations Department of Public Information:

ROME, Sept. 14 -- Procedures for inquiring into the mysteries of poliomyelitis and rabies, and perhaps methods for dealing with these diseases, are expected to be advanced by two committees of experts that are meeting in Rome. Both were appointed by and are operating under the auspices of the World Health Organization, a specialized agency of the United Nations.
AUCKLAND, N. Z., Sept. 14 (AP) -- An earthquake accompanied by a tidal wave struck the Fiji Islands in the southwest Pacific today, killing at least two persons and smashing buildings.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 14 -- Without fanfare and without warning, Jordan Oliver suddenly found himself Yale's head football coach only a few weeks before the squad reported for practice last year, and the Eli's had their most successful season since 1946.

The special grand jury impaneled two years ago to inquire into organized gambling and official corruption on State Island will reconvene at 10 A. M. today after a two-month summer recess. It will sit in the Richmond County Courthouse at St. George.

The Horn Hardart Company, operator of the Automat restaurants and retail food stores, has sold the four four-story buildings at 800 to 806 Eighth Avenue to a client of Walter Scott Co. through Tankoos Co., brokers. Milbank, Tweed, Hope Hadley were attorneys for the seller and Reuben Lesser acted for the buyer.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Sept. 14 -- The United party -- main Opposition group --decided unanimously today to vote against the move of Dr. Daniel F. Malan, the Prime Minister, to strike mixed blood voters off the white register and segregate them on a register of their own.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 14 -Arthur B. Bisguier of New YorkI and Hans Berliner of Washington, I with three straight, tied for the] lead today in the national chessI challengers tournament at the Hotel .delphia.

David A. Stretch, partner of the New York law firm of Simpson, Thacher Bartlett, has been chosen jointly by the United States Government and by the government of the West German Federal Republic to be arbitrator of the Validation Board of German Dollar Bonds.

Robert F. Wagner Jr., Borough President of Manhattan, brought his primary campaign for the Democratic nomination for Mayor to a close last night with promises to improve schools, living conditions and police protection in the city if he is installed in City Hall.
CHICAGO, Sept. 14 (AP) -- Former President Truman said today the head man of the Democratic party is Adlai E. Stevenson.
GENEVA, Sept. 14 (UP) -- The United Nations World Health Organization reported today that the world's death rate had declined steadily since 1951, while the birth rate had remained almost stationary.

A faulty steering mechanism caused an Army bus carrying thirty-seven wives and children of service men to ram into a pillar of the West Side Highway yesterday at Fifty-seventh Street and Twelfth Avenue, injuring eight persons slightly.

Yesterday this newspaper published the results of a spot check it had made through its correspondents across the country on the impact of the Korean truce on business production and employment. After assembling and analyzing the results of this survey A. H. Raskin of our staff reached two major conclusions.

New York's extensive fleet of 2,141 city-owned and city-operated buses is almost literally falling apart at the rivets, it was indicated today in a hitherto unpublished report of a study made by a leading independent engineer.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., Sept. 14 -- Delegates to the Rochester Photo Conference, a gathering of 175 news photographers, editors and production men, heard criticism today of the conviction of three Cleveland newspaper men who had been instrumental in the publication of a courtroom photograph.
Dr. David E. Alexander, well into his second half century of medical practice, is observing his seventy-seventh birthday today, but he has no intention of ever retiring voluntarily.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 (AP) -- The Citizens Committee for Eisenhower and Nixon reported to Congress today that it was making refunds amounting to $223,592 to several thousand individual contributors.

The New York commodity exchanges continued dull yesterday but soybean oil had its most active day since July 13, cottonseed oil since Aug. 25 and burlap since trading opened last Wednesday. Prices closed generally lower, with cottonseed oil, soybean oil, burlap, lead, zinc, tin and hides off; sugar, coffee, wool and copper mixed, and cocoa, potatoes and rubber higher.

Bids for the purchase of the liner Puerto Rico, owned by the A. H. Bull Steamship Company, will be opened this afternoon. A company spokesman said the vessel, at her Brooklyn pier since last March, had been offered for sale Aug. 5.
LISBON, Portugal, Sept. 14 -- The fifteenth congress of the International Society of Surgery was opened here today by Gen. Francisco Higinio Craveiro Lopes, President of the Portuguese Republic.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Sept. 14 -- The State Thruway Authority filed notices here today that it would open bids on Oct. 1 for construction of 7.61 miles of the New York-Buffalo Thruway and 6.53 miles of access roads in southern Westchester, but the County Board of Supervisors expressed displeasure with plans for "inadequate" center islands on some parts of the project.

According to the Sept. 10 issue of THE NEW YORK TIMES Australia has drawn an approximately 200-mile ring around her shores. Korea has decided to exercise sovereignty up to sixty miles. The issue is pearl fisheries and other fisheries, and Japan is the victim. This action is the natural result of our Congressional action in the tidelands oil case to extend a few states' sovereignty beyond the three-mile limit.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- The Post Office Department increased today postage rates and fees for surface mails to all countries of the world, except Canada and Mexico, in an effort to raise revenues by about $8,000,000 annually. Air mail rates will remain unchanged.

MINEOLA, L. I., Sept. 14 -- The Nassau County Board of Supervisors authorized County Executive A. Holly Patterson today to engage the engineering firm of Andrews, Clark Buckley to provide contract plans for three improvement projects on Sunrise Highway.

LONDON, Sept. 14 -- British Government securities and German and Japanese bonds were in most consistent demand on the stock market here today. Elsewhere, caution induced by recent setbacks on Wall Street made for slight weakness and many domestic industrial groups suffered small losses.

The Rev. George B. Ford, pastor of Corpus Christi Roman Catholic Church, said last night at a conference on moral standards that there was no one candidate running for Mayor here for whom "one can feel in his heart of hearts that he wants to vote."
MOSCOW, Tuesday, Sept. 15 -- A reorganization of Soviet ministries in the drive to increase agricultural production and improve the supply of consumer goods was announced today.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 14 (AP) -- Crown Prince Akihito of Japan had a brief review of American history today touring places where much of it was made. An expert historian said afterward: "The Prince has a firm knowledge of our history."
Alexander Schneider conducted a chamber orchestra last evening in the second of two summer concerts designed to prove his contention that outdoor chamber music is feasible in Washington Square.

CHICAGO, Sept. 14 -- Absence of aggressive buying support encouraged local selling of grain and soybean futures today. Pessimistic reports from Canada on the wheat storage situation were a bearish influence. Selling of corn and soybeans was induced by prospects for unusually early marketings of these crops, although so far no heavy country offerings have been reported.

The Trieste dispute is showing signs of developing into a typical vicious spiral in which first one side, then the other, feels it necessary to take up ever stronger positions. The atmosphere becomes more emotional daily, with Premier Pella talking about reconsidering Italy's position in NATO and Marshal Tito threatening to be "more masterful" than the Western Powers.

Rooms in which an assortment of furniture receive a uniform look by the use of a controlling theme are the outstanding news in W. J. Sloane's luxuriously refurbished "House in Town," opened to the public today. Since this presentation of a traditionally furnished seven-room apartment is completely done over each fall, it often provides a synopsis of the season's trends in period decor.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept. 14 (Reuters) -- A British Comet jet-liner pioneered today a new London-South American passenger service with a trail-blazing flight over the 6,000-mile course in just half the flying time it takes piston-engined planes.

Rabbi Irving Miller, president of the Zionist Organization of America, accused the House Committee on Un-American Activities yesterday of "almost unbelievable irresponsibility" in releasing a former Communist's testimony that the late Rabbis Stephen S. Wise and Judah L. Magnes had followed the Communist party line.
The Yankees announced yesterday that they would accept ticket orders for the world series starting today. Orders postmarked before 12:01 A. M. will be returned.

On record sales of $59,932,793, the Vick Chemical Company, in the fiscal year ended on June 30 last, increased net earnings to $4,524,622 from $3,435,039 in the preceding fiscal year, the annual report disclosed yesterday.

HACKENSACK, N. J., Sept. 14 -- Bergen County's treasury was $127,000 richer today when County Treasurer A. Theodore Holmes deposited that amount to its account. The money was seized on Oct. 23, 1950, in a raid on the home of Leo Link, gambler, who is now serving a prison sentence for Federal income tax evasion.

SINGAPORE, Sept. 14 -- Yong Hoi, a Communist terrorist in Perak State, who killed more than 100 persons, has been shot dead by his own section leader. The section leader, carrying Yong Hoi's personal belongings, walked into the Kampar police station in Perak recently and surrendered.

TOKYO, Tuesday, Sept. 15 -- Chinese prisoners who rejected repatriation to their Communist-ruled homeland staged numerous demonstrations yesterday as they were transferred to the custody of the Neutral Nations Repatriation Commission in Korea.

Governor Dewey visited the Federal Building here yesterday to talk and reminisce with the staff of the first Republican United States Attorney in the Southern District of New York since the Governor held the post twenty years ago.
Accoutrments for the dining table are included in a new collection of decorative accessories for the home assembled by the Penthous Gallery in its redecorated quarters at 15 West Fifty-fifth Street.

Dr. Max Euwe of the Netherlands, world champion in 1935, moved to third place, half a point ahead of Paul Keres of Russia, in the world chess challengers championship tournament in Zurich yesterday, according to a Swiss news report.

MONTREAL, Sept. 14 (Canadian Press) -- The Seafarers International Union, A. F. L., today announced that its 500 members aboard twenty-six ships of Colonial Steamships, Ltd., have voted to go on strike at noon Monday, Sept. 21.
One day in November of 1950 a postcard summoned me to the Prague office that issued residence permits to foreigners in Czechoslovakia.
The Yankees' fifth straight American League pennant had been in the cards for too long a time for the Bombers to get wildly excited when the numbers ran out on the Indians yesterday.

Underwriting syndicates will offer to investors today new issues of corporate securities totaling more than $180,000,000 and consisting mostly of debentures and preferred stock of the General Motors Acceptance Corporation and the Tennessee Gas Transmission Company.

In celebration of Arnold Constable's 128th anniversary, one of Italy's leading designers, Signora Micol Fontana, flew here from Rome with forty of her original designs and three models for a gala presentation yesterday at the store. Rich in fabric, the late afternoon and evening designs featured Renaissance-inspired deep wines and reds as well as a wealth of black and white.

Election of O. F. Holmgren as executive vice president and A. P. Cortelyou as vice president of the United States Vanadium Company, a division of the Union Carbide and Carbon Corporation, was announced yesterday by W. E. Remmers, president. H. L. McKinley was made general manager of the division.

BONN, Germany, Sept. 14 -- Leaders of the powerful West German Steel and Metal Workers Union agreed unanimously after a two-day conference last week-end to fight the attempts of Chancellor Konrad Adenauer's Christian Democratic Union to capture control of the national German Trade Union Federation.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- The United States, Britain and France are continuing their consultations on the Trieste developments, and the appeal of Giuseppe Pelia, Italian Premier, for a plebiscite will "certainly" be considered, a State Department spokesman said today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 14 -- Universal-International is going into the home stretch of its thirty-two-picture program for 1953 and is making plans to put the final twelve features before the cameras during the next three months.

DES MOINES, Sept. 14 (AP) -- Trustess of the University Christian Church announced today they have lifted a rule adopted in 1950 in order to make the church auditorium available for an Oct. 5 human rights speech here by Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt.

Dr. Charles S. Cameron, medical and scientific director of the American Cancer Society, Inc., expressed confidence yesterday that cancer would be conquered by "persistent research attrition," but he warned that it would not happen suddenly or soon.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- A Congressional investigation is under way to determine whether one reorganization after another in the Internal Revenue Service has injured employe morale to the point where tax collections may drop.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- The President's Committee on Government Contracts went to work today with assurance of the personal interest of President Eisenhower in erasing job discrimination.

CHESTER, Pa., Sept. 14 (AP) -- Two of this city's four fire companies were suspended today in what Fire Chief James A. Devlin described as a "disciplinary action" because firemen of the companies took city-owned equipment to a parade in Wilmington, Del.

Senator Joseph R. McCarthy was described yesterday as "the touchstone by which we can test Americans.'' The Republican of Wisconsin was so designated by Rabbi Benjamin Schultz, executive director of the American Jewish League Against Communism.
The opulence of the Italian Renaissance was a discernible influence in Eleanora Garnett's custom collection, shown to the press yesterday in her salon at 47 East Fifty-first Street.

President Eisenhower, in a message to Dag Hammarskjold, Secretary General of the United Nations, reiterated last night the intention of the United States to strive to make the world organization "ever more successful" in the tasks it faced.

The Chicago Transit Authority has designated Sept. 25 for the sale of $7,000,000 of revenue bonds to finance purchase of an eight-and-one-half mile stretch of right of way from the Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul and Pacific Railroad

Fire Commissioner Jacob Grumet swore in 112 probationary firemen yesterday in a ceremony at Engine Company 31, Lafayette and White Streets. Their eligibility on the four-year-old Civil Service list would have expired last midnight.

Highest priority in the city's prospective cramped capital budget for 1954 should go toward construction of new public schools and rehabilitation of old ones, Mayor Impellitteri told the City Planning Commission yesterday.

" PI: A Hodge Podge of the Letters, Papers and Addresses Written During the Last Sixty Years," by Bruce Rogers, has been scheduled for Nov. 16 publication by World. Mr. Rogers, who at 83 is considered the "grand old man of the American graphic arts" and "the foremost American book designer," gives his views on fine bookmaking, typography and a "host" of related subjects.

Your special dispatch of Sept. 8 from Albany "that the chest X-rays now taken free by the state in hospitals and community clinics will be studied twice from now on -- once for tuberculosis cavities in the lungs and once for any indication of malignancy there" -- is news of vital importance.

DENVER, Sept. 14 -- President Eisenhower added another engagement today to his busy fall travel and speech-making schedule by accepting an invitation to dedicate the new headquarters of the American Hereford Association in Kansas City Oct. 16.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 14 -- For the first time since 1949 the United Nations General Assembly will open its annual session here tomorrow without having to concern itself with actual fighting in Korea. However, the important role that Asian problems will play at the 1953 session is symbolized by the fact that the Assembly's President is certain to be an Asian.
WASHINGTON, Sept 14 (AP) -- The Treasury announced today that exchange subscriptions to its new three-and-a-half-year notes paying 2 7/8 per cent interest went just over $3,000,000,000.

THE waterfowl picture is not as bright as it seemed two months ago. This is primarily because of the limited breeding success of two species, mallards and pintails, although most of the other species are plentiful, diving ducks especially, according to a recent survey by Ducks Unlimited.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 14 (AP) -- A Common Pleas Court hearing on the question of continuing an injunction against the Pennsylvania Coal and Coke Corporation of New York to prevent a $350,000 loan from the Industrial Brownhoist Corporation was continued again today until Monday.

MAYS LANDING, N. J., Sept. 14 (AP) -- E. A. Dodson's Bye and Bye returned to winning form at the Atlantic City track today, capturing the Lloyd Wood Purse before a crowd of 12,876. The By Jimminy filly was two and one-half lengths clear of Suky Susie after seven furlongs.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 (UP) -- J. B. Matthews, who resigned as executive director of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy's inquiry committee, said tonight that he expected to show that his estimate of 7,000 Protestant clergymen who were serving communism was "conservative."

SAIGON, Vietnam, Sept. 14 -- Senator William F. Knowland, the Republican majority leader from California, went to Pnompenh, the capital of Cambodia, today amid continued controversy over that Indo-Chinese State's policy in the war against the Communist-led Vietminh.

BOLTON LANDING, N. Y., Sept. 14 (UP) -- A New York insurance executive warned today that Government security programs could lead to much economic power in the hands of Government and lower the standard of living.

COLD SPRING HARBOR, L. I., Sept. 14 -- Henry Castillo, a former Southern Intercollegiate champion who came to Fresh Meadow last year after teaching golf at Alexandria, La., teamed with two of his club's members today to win top honors in both groups at the weekly Long Island Professional Golfers' Association's one-day pro-amateur tournament.
MIAMI, Sept. 14 -- Complete wearability is the keynote of the clothes on exhibit at the Roney Plaza Hotel, Miami Beach, for the Miami Fashion Council s cruise and resort wear market week.

It was the special experience of the late Senator Taft in the legislative history of the trades unions that impelled him to term "incredible" the selection of Martin P. Durkin by President-elect Eisenhower as his Secretary of Labor. And these circumstances helped to sanction the blunt, prophetic word:...

Rudolph Halley, President of the City Council, who is unopposed in the Liberal party nomination for Mayor, announced last night during a television appearance that he intended to vote in today's Democratic primary. As an enrolled Democrat he has that right.

Mayor Impellitteri, in his final bid for votes in today's primary, charged last night that his principal rival for the Democratic nomination for Mayor, Borough President Robert F. Wagner Jr. of Manhattan, had "plotted" with Governor Dewey to impose a payroll tax on the city residents.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 14 -- Five high-ranking Roman Catholic clergymen have been injured seriously and a seminary has been damaged in new outbreaks against the Church, Catholic sources reported today.
This is primary election day, and the polls in New York City will be open from 3 P. M. to 10 P. M. In the New York suburban areas the polls are open from noon to 9 P. M.

The Korean truce has brought no public clamor for termination of the draft or a headlong cut in defense spending. This was indicated yesterday by a survey of Congressional mail and of local sentiment, as gauged by correspondents of THE NEW YORK TIMES in a dozen large cities across the country.

A large and well-rounded collection presented yesterday at Henri Bendel, the Fifty-Seventh Street specialty store, included styles from many name designers at home and abroad. The pivotal group was composed of Bendel originals designed by Berthe Stern Simmons.

The aircraft carrier, the capital ship of the modern navy, will steam into the world spotlight again this week, with the start tomorrow of Exercise Mariner, a North Atlantic Treaty Organization naval training maneuver.

GENEVA, Sept. 14 -- The West German Government, fresh from its triumph in the elections eight days ago, intends to assume without delay a position of leadership in the formulation and development of a common international trade policy for the West.

ALBANY, Sept. 14 -- William L. Pfeiffer announced today that he was resigning as Republican State Chairman, effective Sept. 23. He said that his decision was based on the "increasing pressure of personal business."

About 300,000 recently discharged veterans are now or soon will be going to college at Government expense, a survey by this newspaper reveals. By and large, the Korean veterans on American campuses today are younger than the Second World War veterans who received similar benefits after 1945.

Your recent editorial and series of articles by Hanson W. Baldwin on the low morale of the armed forces have failed to point out an important factor that holds the key to all analyses of the problem. This is the existence of the first large peacetime citizen army in the history of our nation.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- A clearer Congressional mandate to the Export-Import Bank in administering its $3,500,000,000 of foreign trade credits is one of the purposes behind the Senate Banking Committee's investigation of the nineteen-year-old agency that gets under way tomorrow.
The world's only flock of whooping cranes will soon be winging its way from the Canadian Northwest to wintering grounds on the Gulf coast of Texas.

LONDON, Sept. 14 -- The objections of the Chinese Communist and North Korean Governments to the United Nations proposals for a Korean peace conference thus far have produced no agitation by the British for an alteration of the Western world's position.

At 7 o'clock every weekday morning, handsome, white-haired Mrs. Sol Broome leaves her Sutton Place apartment for the small Nassau County kitchen where she prepares and freezes the delicious gefullte fish sold under the Aunt Tilly label.

BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 14 -- Determined to end a $500,000 daily drain in foreign exchange for fuel imports, the Argentine Government is attempting to interest British and American oil companies in making large-scale investments for exploitation of the nation's resources.

Voting in New York's first major contest in sixteen years for Democratic nominations for Mayor and other major municipal offices will get under way at 3 P. M. today after a primary campaign marked by unusual bitterness.

Twenty-three public school teachers who have admitted past membership in the Communist party have been allowed to retain their jobs because they have proved that they left the party in good faith and severed all connections, it was announced yesterday.

The apartment property for sixty-nine families with garage accommodations for thirty-seven automobiles at 230 Atlantic Avenue in Lynbrook, L. I., has been sold by Rocklyn Gardens, Inc., to Bertha Slepoy and Rubin Chait. The parcel occupies a plot about 200 by 365 feet and is assessed at $231,000.
Former President Harry S. Truman will be allowed to spread income tax payments on the sale of his memoirs over a six-year period, his attorney disclosed here today.

At exactly 4:45 P. M. by the clock atop the Stadium scoreboard Charles Dillon (Casey) Stengel yesterday became the first manager and his Yankees the first ball club to win five major league pennants in a row.

MONMOUTH BEACH, N. J., Sept. 14 -- Harold Seide, former vice president of The Jersey Observer, a one-time afternoon daily newspaper in Hudson County, was found dead yesterday in his summer home at 46 West Street here. He was 47 years old.

CHICAGO, Sept. 14 (AP) -- A strong to 50 cents higher market developed for hogs today and lambs advanced $1 to $1.50 a hundred pounds. Cattle were steady to 50 cents lower, however on the largest run in five months. Today's report of the livestock market here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

Another effort to save the frigate Constellation -- one of the Navy's greatest eighteenth and nineteenth century sea fighters and the oldest naval vessel afloat -- is being spearheaded by the Council of American Master Mariners.

" End as a Man," Calder Willingham's dramatization of his first and best-selling novel of the same name, will have its premiere at the Theatre De Lys, 121 Christopher Street, tonight at 8 o'clock. Claire Heller, making debut in the producing ranks, is the sponsor of the presentation.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- The State Department said today it would be a mistake for anyone to interpret a week-end Peiping broadcast as a bid by the Chinese Communists to work toward a truce in Indo-China like that in Korea.
Two of the biggest newspaper publishers in the world -- 476 pounds in identical formats -- paused in New York last week and reported enthusiastically about the new deal on the old Nile.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- General Accounting Office attorneys suggested today that New York State officials seek a formal ruling from the Controller General of the United States whether the Federal Government should pay the employer's share for Social Security for civilian workers of the National Guard in the state.

Action to eliminate charity chiselers in this state began yesterday with the mailing of questionaires to 1,100 charitable organizations by the New York State Joint Legislative Committee on Charitable and Philanthropic Agencies and Organizations.

STRASBOURG, France, Sept. 14 (UP) -- Paul-Henri Spaak, Belgian Socialist leader and former Premier, urged the nations of Western Europe today to unite speedily and seek peace with the Soviet Union on a "family" basis.

When the question of sentiments concerning the Yankees comes up for discussion in remote and near places where baseball fans gather, one seldom finds a middle ground. A lukewarm attitude is inconceivable in relation to the Yankees. One is either unswervingly devoted or bitterly hostile to them.

OYSTER BAY, L. I., Sept. 14 -Sagamore Hill, the home of Theodore Roosevelt that became a national shrine on June 14, this afternoon drew 700 philatelists. The collectors made a pilgrimage here to buy the 3-cent Sagamore Hill memorial stamp, which was issued today, and to arrange for cancellations on "first day" covers.

TEHERAN, Iran, Sept. 14 -- Iran's Finance Minister, Dr. Ali Amini, proclaimed today a "holy war" on corruption, waste and inefficiency in government and on widespread tax evasion as an essential element in an effort to balance the budget and avert threatened bankruptcy.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 14 (UP) -- Top-seeded tennis stars came through as expected today in the first round of the men's singles of the Pacific Southwest tennis tournament.

PARIS, Sept. 14 -- Some of the administrative red tape that Frenchmen are always stumbling over in their daily lives will disappear with the promulgation of reform decrees that are to be discussed, and possibly approved, by the Cabinet tomorrow.

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y. Sept. 14 -- Herman Barron, Fenway professional, and Arnold Lipman of the Harrison Country Club, fashioned a 32, 32 -- 64 to gain a one-stroke triumph in the Westchester County Golf Association's pro-amateur best-ball tournament at the Wykagyl Country Club today.

Genuine religious education of children can take place only when church and home work together, according to the Rev. George G. Parker, minister of the Congregational Church of Manhasset, L. I. Mr. Parker expresses his opinion in the latest issue of Child Study, quarterly journal of the Child Study Association of America.

Uncertain investors unloaded enough stock yesterday to send prices tumbling for the fourth straight session and to force THE NEW YORK TIMES industrial, rail and combined averages through the lows for the year. At their worst of the day they were lower than at any time since July 3, 1951.

ROME, Sept. 14 -- The formal proposal that the Trieste question should be settled by a plebiscite that would enable the inhabitants of that Free Territory to decide for themselves whether they wished to belong to Italy or Yugoslavia was made in a note the Italian Government addressed to Yugoslavia and to the United States, Britain and France as. the powers that signed the three-power declaration of 1948.

William H. Howell, ex-convict who surrendered to the police early yesterday after having been hunted as an alleged accomplice in the murder of Thomas E. Lewis, Bronx union leader, was charged yesterday noon with homicide and violating parole.
The mother of eleven children was killed in Waldwick, N. J., last night when she was struck by a passenger train. Two other persons died in New Jersey as a result of automobile accidents.
OKLAHOMA CITY, Sept. 14 -- The fifty-third United States Golf Association amateur championship began at the Oklahoma City Golf and Country Club today with one major upset in seventy-two matches.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 14 (UP) -- Del Ennis' ninth-inning single enabled the Phillies to gain a 6-5 victory over the Cardinals tonight.
Members of the New York Army Reserve began a new term of military study last night as the Army Reserve School reopened at 30 West Forty-fourth Street for its fourth year.

Martin P. Durkin, who resigned last week as Secretary of Labor, will have the opportunity to tell his own story next week in St. Louis before 1,000 delegates at the seventy-second annual convention of the American Federation of Labor.

In an article in THE TIMES of Sept. 6 commenting on the recent tension around Trieste and its diplomatic repercussions, Cyrus Sulzberger advanced the following formula for a definite solution of the Trieste issue: "The obvious basis for any solution will be partition of the Free Territory much along the lines of the present occupation zones, with the city itself going to Italy and some minor frontier adjustments along ethnical lines."

The polls for today's primaries will be open from 3 to 10 P. M. and all persons who registered to vote in the 1952 Presidential election and enrolled in a recognized political party are eligible to vote.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- A group of Senate Republican committee chairmen is moving to obtain control of the general Republican policy-making instrumentality and thus, in effect, take over the essential power of the existing party hierarchy.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Sept. 14 -- Pressing difficulties crowded in on the new Government of Dr. Ali Sastroamidjojo here today as his Cabinet pulled back from an initial move in the economic field designed to implement its assertion that it favors a more nationalistic policy than its predecessors did.

The domestic steel industry's operating rate, which slipped below the 90 per cent level last week for the first time in more than a year, is scheduled to rise to 90.3 per cent this week, 1.1 points above last week's actual rate. Production during the current week is expected to be 2,036,000 tons, compared with 2,011,000 tons last week, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

The Industrial Home for the Blind has purchased the six-story industrial building at 57 Willoughby Street, corner of Lawrence Street, in Brooklyn from Davis Geck, Inc. The Charles F. Noyes Company and the Bulkley Horton Company were co-brokers in the transaction.

CUMBERLAND, Ky., Sept. 14 -- A post commander of the Veterans of Foreign Wars organizations of three Harlan County towns declared here tonight that the concensus of opinion among members of his group was that "there is no evidence" that Staff Sgt. Jack Flanary of Benham was a "progressive."

TOKYO, Sept. 14 -- The International Labor Organization's third Asian regional conference opened in Tokyo today. Delegates heard the Japanese delegate propose the early admission of Communist China into that international body, which is a specialized agency associated with the United Nations.

BOSTON, Sept. 14 (UP) -- The White Sox, fighting to finish in third place in the American League, staged an eight-run assault in the sixth inning today to beat the Red Sox, 10 -- 6, before 5,239 fans at Fenway Park.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 14 -- Stringent requirements for special state licenses for tractor-trailer drivers may bring about a statewide truck drivers' strike in New Jersey next April 1 when the law goes into effect.

CAIRO, Sept. 14 -- Maj. Gen. Mohammed Naguib, President and Premier, declared in a radio broadcast tonight that his Government would "deal as severely as we know how with cockroaches who spread rumors."
Following are texts of speeches delivered in Chicago last night by Adlai E. Stevenson, as carried by The Associated Press, and by former President Truman, as transcribed by THE NEW YORK TIMES:
Plans are nearing completion for the dinner dance in behalf of the Recreation Service for Children of Bellevue, Inc., to be held Oct. 8 in the Terrace Room of the Plaza.

The National Association of Manufacturers made public yesterday a report by Dr. Harley L.
