Lutz, its tax consultant and Professor Emeritus of Public Finance at Princeton University, answering critics of the association's proposals for a straight excise tax on end-products of manufacture, except food, and for a special rollback of alcohol and tobacco excise taxes to pre-war levels.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 (AP) Wayne Terwilliger led Washington's ten-hit attack with three singles and a double tonight as the Senators defeated the Tigers, 6 -- 1, before a gathering of 1,257, the smallest crowd of the year at Griffith Stadium.

JERSEY CITY, Sept. 14 -- The first public hearings in the court-ordered inquiry into Jersey City's financial affairs was held here today. Samuel A. Larner, Newark lawyer who was appointed by Superior Court Judge Haydn Proctor to conduct the investigation, questioned City Controller Joseph F. S. Fitzpatrick, City Clerk James A. Tumulty and City Purchasing Agent Cornelius Hayes.
The futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange closed easy yesterday, off 11 to 15 points.

As the General Assembly of the United Nations convenes today for its eighth regular session it becomes clearer than ever before that the Assembly has displaced the Security Council as the main agency of the United Nations. It is the Assembly that is now called upon to carry out virtually all the functions for which the United Nations was created.

PATIENCE is a virtue, especially in Brooklyn. From time immemorial the watchword along the banks of the fragrant Gowanus has been: "Wait until next year." That cry usually was laced with undertones of despair as the floundering Brooks staggered along in their maladroit fashion in the lower reaches of the second division. The Flatbush Faithful, a long-suffering breed, endured it all without complaint.

President Eisenhower extended his greetings yesterday to the members of the Propeller Club of the United States, who will meet in Cleveland next Monday for their twenty-seventh annual convention and for the American Merchant Marine Conference.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 (UP) -- Federal Judge Alexander Holtzoff today ordered Henry W. Grunewald to appear for a hearing on Wednesday to determine whether the former Washington mystery man was a probation violator subject to a ninety-day jail term.

DETROIT, Sept. 14 -- The Rev. Charles C. Webber, former president of the Virginia C. I. O. Council, entered a vigorous denial today of a charge by Mr. Gitlow that he had been involved in a Communist conspiracy to subvert the Methodist church.

CHICAGO, Sept. 14 -- Adlai E. Stevenson charged the Eisenhower Administration with "government by postponement" tonight and said the Republicans were making empty threats to the Communists while reducing our defense preparedness.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Sept. 14 -- The Japanese pearling fleet has left the area over which the Australian Government proclaimed sovereign rights Friday. Today the fleet was reported passing Melville Island off the coast of Arnhem Land, just north of Darwin, on the way to a pearl shell area some distance to the east where Australian luggers are not operating.

An American employe of Communist Poland's delegation to the United Nations refused to say whether he had ever known of any espionage by other persons, Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, reported yesterday after hearing the man in a closed session of his Senate Permanent Subcommitte on Investigations here.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 (UP) -Advertising executive H. Arno Johnson said today the Government could balance the budget and trim taxes if the nation's salesmen increased sales of consumer goods by 10 per cent.

IDENTIFY the author of the following famous, but somehow irritating, words of edification: "Lost, yesterday, somewhere between sunrise and sunset, two golden hours, each set with sixty diamond minutes. No reward is offered, for they are gone forever." If you know he was Horace Mann, founder of the American public school system, you are better informed than 99 per cent of your fellow-countrymen.

It is probably a good thing that at least some of the approximately 34,200,000 young persons now attending elementary and secondary schools are looking forward to their pursuit of education, for if all of them regarded the reopening of school with apprehension, distrust or even with something akin to loathing the task of the nation's teachers would be more difficult than it is.

Forty-four years of richly varied baseball experience lie behind Charles Dillon, (Casey) Stengel's current rank at the pinnacle of his profession as the first manager to capture five straight major league pennants.
A giant back-to-school movement emptied the city's streets yesterday morning as 1,250,000 youngsters answered the call of the bells to get the new term off to an auspicious start.

ALBANY, Sept. 14 (AP) -- Candidates for party Mayoralty nominations will test their strength tomorrow in primary contests in twelve upstate cities. In two of them both Republicans and Democrats face primary battles. In seven there are only G. O. P. contests. In the remaining three only the Democrats will pick their candidate.

CHICAGO, Sept. 14 -- With all the regulars save Duke Snider, Junior Gilliam and Billy Cox taking a day off, the champion Dodgers were beaten again by the Cubs today at Wrigley Field, 3 -- 1, before a small Ladies' Day gathering of 8,783, thereby extending the winning streak of the Bruins to ten games.

Myron C. Fagan, who has not been operating in this neighborhood since 1931, has returned with "A Red Rainbow," which opened at the Royale last evening. He has not improved his craftsmanship much. His current exhibit is a melodrama about "Mr. Moscow" in America who is helping to mastermind the world revolution and has to be murdered in the last act by a patriotic American.

MADISON, Wis., Sept. 14 -- Within 245 years, it was predicted here today, man must be prepared to capture 1 per cent of all incoming rays from the sun and utilize them for heat and for power to drive the world's machinery.

Open Show of the Lester Manor Stable won the race that occupied the feature spot on the program at Aqueduct yesterday. The result was well received by the crowd of 19,616 for the triumph was the only one recorded by a favorite all day.

Tests demonstrating that most heart patients can hold jobs are reported in the September issue of Circulation, monthly journal of the American Heart Association. The tests, conducted with patients at the New York University-Bellevue Medical Center, are reported by Dr. Howard A. Rusk, director of the Department of Physical Medicine and Rehabilitation at the New York University College of Medicine, and Dr. Joseph G. Benton, assistant professor in that department.
Governor Dewey declared yesterday he was "impressed and delighted" with the way the New York-New Jersey waterfront commission was tackling its "monumental" job of driving crime from the docks.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 (UP) -- Don't be alarmed if you can't tune in the radio or television programs early Wednesday morning. It will be just a test of the "conelrad" civil defense radio set.

WENDOVER, Utah, Sept. 14 (UP) -- A former British racing king and an English auto designer established a new record of 123.75 miles an hour for light Class D autos in a six-hour run over the Bonneville Salt Flats today.

The country will almost double its use of electric power to light homes, businesses and streets ten years from now, Walter H. Sammis, president of the Edison Electric Institute, predicted yesterday. He spoke at the national technical conference of the Illuminating Engineering Society in the Commodore Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- The Eisenhower Administration was both praised and strongly criticized before a meeting of city law enforcement officials today for its attitude toward Federal aid to municipalities.

LONDON, Sept. 14 (Reuters) -A 58-year-old Roman Catholic Bishop came out of two years in a Polish Communist prison today into a Warsaw courtroom and slowly recited a detailed confession of spying for the United States.

If there is any business slowdown this year it will not be due to economics caused by the Korean truce but because of the pessimism of some top-brass business men, according to Dr. Vergil D. Reed, a vice president of the J. Walter Thompson Company.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 (UP) -The Justice Department soon may ask for grand jury indictments against "several" former Goveuarent employes believed to have violated the "conflict of interest" law.

Macy's deserves bravos on the store's latest collection of French and Italian imports and line-forline copies, shown yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. Twice a year this store brings back what it considers to be the cream of the foreign collections and has them copied to sell for a fraction of what the originals would cost.

NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 15 -Presaging an early end to princely fortunes and other long-standing amassments of great wealth in India, Parliament today passed the Estate Duty Bill, an inheritance tax plan that has been seven years in the making.

The report from the Newark Public Library, published yesterday, that television had been responsible, in part, for the decline in book borrowing, finds no echo in a report issued yesterday by the Brooklyn Public Library.

ALBANY, Wednesday, Sept. 16 (AP) -- Former Representative Edwin Arthur Hall early today won the Republican Mayoral nomination in Binghamton. His victory was registered in one of the fourteen Mayoral primaries in the state.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 15 -- Representatives of the General Staffs of the armies of Turkey, Greece and Yugoslavia will meet here soon, probably after the Yugoslav Army maneuvers beginning next week.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Sept. 15 -- Queen Juliana opened a new parliamentary session here today with the speech from the throne outlining the Government's program for the coming parliamentary year.

CHICAGO, Sept. 15 (AP) -- Trading in hogs turned sensitive to supplies today with only a small overrun looming large in making a steady to 35 cents lower market. In cattle, where receipts of 7,500 were down 1,500 from the anticipated numbers, price movements were broadly mixed, ranging from 50 cents lower to $1 higher.

The National Hockey League will open its 1953-54 season on Oct. 8, the earliest date in the history of the circuit, the schedule of the six-team loop disclosed yesterday. Each team will play seventy games.

Hector Chevigny has offered his resignation as national president of the Radio Writers Guild as the result of a policy disagreement with the guild's Eastern council. The resignation has not yet been acted upon by guild officials.

SAIGON, Vietnam, Sept. 15 -Senator William F. Knowland, Republican majority leader, called on all Asian peoples today to fight communism and declared there could be no aid from the United States for those who did not cooperate in the fight.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- President Eisenhower is giving active consideration to a series of Administration television and radio broadcasts designed to increase public awareness of the growing threat of Soviet atomic and air power.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 15 -- The illegal immigration of Mexican "wetback" workers into the United States over the nation's southwestern border has reached a record rate of more than 100,000 persons a month.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (UP) -- The Reconstruction Finance Corporation opened the nation's biggest "going out of business" sale today. The R.F.C. has lost its lease on life and everything must go -- stocks, bonds, notes, mortgages, houses, factories and various other assets.

During the first two weeks of this month, the regional Red Cross blood program received less than a quarter of its September quota of 15,000 pints. The amount collected up to Monday night was 3,334 pints. Officials are hopeful, a spokesman said yesterday, that cool weather and the end of the vacation season will increase donations.

CHICAGO, Sept. 15 -- Rallies in grain and soybean futures proved short-lived today. There was both local pressure and further long liquidation, which forced prices to new lows for the movement. Absence of export buying in wheat was discouraging, while in corn and soybeans operators were apprehensive in regard to the effect of an early crop movement.

The Dodgers disclosed yesterday that their mail order tickets for the three world series games at Ebbets Field Oct. 2, 3 and 4 were sold out. Meanwhile, the Yankees are still accepting orders for the first, second, sixth and seventh games.

Long and careful training given the city's school children would minimize the casualty toll in case of an atomic bomb attack, Herbert R. O'Brien, director of the city's Office of Civil Defense, said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- The Department of Defense today made public the names of thirty-six Army personnel who, according to Communist reports, escaped from Korea prison camps. It was emphasized that in no case have the Communist reports been verified and that none of the men listed had returned to United Nations lines.
For sixteen months sales of leading chain store and mail order companies, as compiled by THE NEW YORK TIMES, have been showing increases in a steady parade of plus signs over the year before.

CHICAGO, Sept. 15 -- The national Democratic organization today indicated that it intended to make considerable political hay in forthcoming campaigns over what it called the "failure" of President Eisenhower and his Administration to fulfill "golden promises" to the American farmer.

BOONVILLE, N. C., Sept. 15 (UP) -- Two soldiers who survived almost three years of Communist imprisonment died together last night when the automobile one of them bought with his accumulated Army pay crashed into a power pole.

HEWLETT, L. I., Sept. 13 -- Peggy Mackie, former metropolitan champion, shot 38, 35 -- 73 to win low gross honors in the Long Island division of the women's Metropolitan Golf Association's one-day tournament for Class A players at the Seawane Harbor Club today.

RANGOON, Burma, Sept. 15 -A Burmese Government spokesman announced today that if the reported stalemate continued in the Bangkok talks among the United States, Burma, Thailand and Nationalist China on withdrawal of Chinese Nationalist troops "Burma will have no alternative but to move in the United Nations to take the strongest possible measures against the aggressors in Burma."
WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (UP) -The Navy announced today a new plane production "stretch-out" under which ninety-one fewer jet fighters would be delivered in the fiscal year ending next June 30.

Scarcely a day goes by that someone does not seek the return, through the Lost and Found column, of a lost dog. Not long ago that portion of L. and F. in this newspaper given over to advertisements for missing pets extended to an unusual length.

MAMARONECK, N. Y., Sept. 15 -- Mrs. T. Arthur Menzel of Innis Arden gained the low gross prize in the Westchester division of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's Class A one-day tournament with a three-over par 38, 39 -- 77 over the Hampshire course today.

OTTAWA, Sept. 15 -- In a move ot avert a threatened seamen's strike that could tie up all but 1 per cent of Canadian shipping on the Great Lakes, Labor Minister M. F. Gregg appointed a Federal mediator today to seek an agreement.

A youth who had been under psychiatric care plunged to his death at 8:55 A. M. yesterday from the seventieth floor of the Empire State Building, landing on the thirtieth floor setback on the Fifth Avenue side. He was identified as Alfred J. Tua, 22 years old, of 553 Sixty-fifth Street. West New York N. J.

ON the night of Feb. 28, 1942, the Australian light cruiser Perth and the American heavy cruiser Houston were sunk in the Sunda Strait between Java and Sumatra in a battle with more than twenty Japanese ships. The following night, March 1, in the Indian Ocean the Dutch steamer Rooseboom was sunk by a torpedo. Each tragic disaster caused the deaths of many hundreds of persons.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Wednesday, Sept. 16 -- A switch in Republican leadership in New Rochelle was indicated by late returns early this morning as insurgent forces under former City Judge Thomas N. Fasso, in the most important of several Westchester County political contests, made many inroads into the regular party ranks by electing Fasso men to the Republican committee.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- Former Senator Frederick A. Seaton of Nebraska was sworn in today as Assistant Secretary of Defense for legislative and public affairs. This completes the Pentagon's top civilian team under President Eisenhower's latest Government reorganization plan.

NEWARK, Sept. 15 -- Former Governor Charles Edison, Mayor Leo P. Carlin and scores of public and professional figures attended the dedication this afternoon of the Henry C. Barkhorn Hearing and Speech Center at the Eye and Earl Infirmary. Dr. Barkhorn, who died several years ago, was president of the medical staff of the infirmary and was a pioneer worker for the establishment of the center.

LONG BEACH, L. I., Wednesday, Sept. 16 -- The Democratic-Republican coalition in this Long Island community defeated Thomas F. Nugent, a City Councilman wh had challenoged the bipartisan slate for the November election, in yesterday's primary. This was the only contest for nominations for public office in Nassau County.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (AP) -The Power Commission today gave New York State sixty more days in which to accept a license for construction of the United States half of the $600,000,000 St. Lawrence River power project.

ALBANY, Sept. 15 -- The State Thruway Authority today sold an issue of $125,000,000 of bonds backed by the guarantee of the State's credit. The sale was negotiated by State Controller J. Raymond McGovern at a net interest rate of 2.6981 per cent.
WESTBURY, L. I., Sept. 15 (AP) -- Florita, owned by Dayton Benham of Alabama, withstood a strong stretch drive by Hal Adam to win the Iowa Pace tonight at Roosevelt Raceway.

MOSCOW, Sept. 15 -- A highly revealing and basic critique of Soviet agriculture is the essence of the 25,000-word report by the Communist party's new first secretary, Nikita S. Khrushchev, published today by Pravda, the party newspaper.

CAIRO, Sept. 15 -- Maj. Saleh Salem, a member of the army's ruling Revolution Council and Minister of National Guidance, asserted tonight the Government had documentary evidence of an alliance between Egyptian traitors and "foreign imperialists."
George Antheil's "Volpone" will be presented by Punch Opera at the Cherry Lane Theatre tonight at 8:30.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (UP) -Senator Leverett Saltonstall, Republican of Massachusetts, today described as "unnecessary and undesirable" proposed import fees on foreign wool. He urged the Tariff Commission to reject proposals to impose import fees of at least 7 cents a pound on wool, and disputed claims the fees would create better prices for domestic wool.

LIMA, Peru, Sept. 15 -- Rising domestic prices and the declining value of the Peruvian currency in foreign exchange have brought demands from the Lima Chamber of Commerce and at least one member of Congress that the Government institute economy measures and reduce the currency issue:
The average American citizen received a pat on the back yesterday for his moral standards. But the hand that patted his back had a finger lifted that warned him of the pitfalls about him.

The trials of ten teachers and a clerk, who were suspended after refusing to answer questions concerning membership in the Communist party, will be held Sept. 28 at the Board of Education headquarters, 110 Livingston Street, Brooklyn, it was announced yesterday by Arthur Levitt, trial examiner and Brooklyn member of the board.

CAMP DRUM, N. Y., Sept. 15 -A public hearing will be held at this reservation next Tuesday by the House of Representatives' Military Operations subcommittee on the sale of surplus military equipment here, Representative R. Walter Riehlman, Republican of upstate New York and head of the subcommittee, announced today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 15 -- Vittorio Gassman will co-star as the Emperor Justinian opposite Ava Gardner's Empress Theodora in Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer's projected CinemaScope portrayal of Byzantine Empire romance and pageantry in "Empress of the Dusk."

LONDON, Sept. 15 -- The Peiping radio said tonight that Communist China's leader Mao Tse-tung had announced his country and Moscow had negotiated "an unprecedented" new program of economic aid to the Chinese.

Experimental results suggesting that regrowth of the spinal cord after it had been severed was not impossible in animals were reported here yesterday at the eighteenth annual congress of the United States and Canadian sections of the International College of Surgeons.
TORONTO, Sept. 15 -- The Ontario Government expects an early decision favoring an all-Canadian pipeline to bring Alberta natural gas to eastern Canada's big industrial market, it was learned today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (AP) -United States foreign trade policy makers today heard business men argue for opening the door to a general rise in tariffs next year.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- A story of how a labor leader who had been forced out of the vicepresidency of an international union for alleged Communist activities moved into a key post with the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service was related before the Committee on Un-American Activities of the House of Representatives today.

JERSEY CITY, Sept. 15 -- A Bergen County nurseryman, testifying today in the Superior Court inquiry into Jersey City's municipal expenditures, told of a $26,000 deal to supply the city's Department of Parks with trees, hedges and peatmoss, for which he paid a 10 per cent kickback.

OTTAWA, Sept. 15 -- Whatever other Atlantic pact countries, including the United States, do, Canada is unlikely to reduce her defense expenditure much below last year's level, which was about $2,200,000,000.

Out-of-town buyers are crowding showrooms of New York apparel manufacturers to obtain their final requirements for the fall season. Arrivals of buyers so far this week are running almost 10 per cent ahead of the corresponding week a year ago, and demand for goods generally has been described as brisk with some overtone of caution noted.
Monday, April 23, 1951, was a bad day for me.

PARIS, Sept. 15 -- For the moment at least all political discussion in France turns on Franco-German relations. In the uneasy interval since the German elections even the arguments about Russia and the United States are secondary to the controversy on how to deal with the new Germany.
OTTAWA, Sept. 15. (UP) -- Canadian department stores recorded a decline in sales last month for the first time in fifteen months.

We trust that the United Nations General Assembly will lose no time in placing on its agenda the report of a special U. N.-International Labor Office committee on forced labor. The committee, headed by Sir Ramaswami Mudaliar of India, raised questions that must be aired promptly in the U. N. and its related agencies.

The largest hangar at the world's largest airport was dedicated yesterday at the New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, by the Port of New York Authority and the lessee, National Airlines. Howard S. Cullman, chairman of the authority, and G. T. Baker, president of the airline, officiated at the ceremonies, attended by 150 persons.

As the collections of imports from Europe unfold in New York's stores, it becomes increasingly evident that the waist is the most important part of this season's fashion silhouette. This judgment received additional confirmation yesterday at Gimbels, where the fashion press received a preview of foreign fashions.

GROTON, Conn., Sept. 15 -- The keel of a submarine that will be able to cruise around the world without refueling was laid here today at the shipyard of the Electric Boat Division of the General Dynamics Corporation.

The rare sight of a "99-to-1" shot winning a horse race occurred at Aqueduct yesterday. A 3-year- old gelding named Texola, owned by the Sunny Acres and ridden by Bob De Stefano, did that very thing, and did it decisively, scoring by a length and a half over his nearest opponent.

A collection of essays that Allan Nevins gave as the Page-Barbour lectures at the University of Virginia will be published next Tuesday by Macmillan under the title "The Statesmanship of the Civil War." The author evaluates American leadership during the Civil War, comparing its effectiveness with the statesmanship of Revolutionary days and the present.

The net estate of Mrs. Addie Wolff Kahn, widow of Otto H. Kahn, banker and art patron, was valued at $935,477 in an estate tax appraisal yesterday at the State Office Building. Mrs. Kahn, whose home was at 25 Sutton Place, died in London on May 15, 1949.

HANOI, Vietnam, Sept 15 (AP)-French Union troops, preparing to meet a new Vietminh offensive, have captured two command posts seized by the Communist-led rebels in their abortive drive on the royal Laotian capital of Luang Prabang last April, the French said today.
CHICAGO, Sept. 15 (AP) -- Two streaks ended today as Robin Roberts pitched the Phillies to a 4-2 victory against Chicago to snap the seventh-place Cubs' ten-game winning string.

The collection of custom-made clothes that Elizabeth Arden showed in her salon yesterday afternoon had freshness and sparkle and were wearable. The silhouettes had been carefully studied and the fabrics selected with good taste. The designer of this collection was Count Sarmi.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission approved today the sale of $35,000,000 in first mortgage bonds of the Arkansas Louisiana Gas Company to fifteen institutional investors. The securities will bear interest at 4 1/2 per cent and fall due in 1973.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (AP) -- Senator A. Willis Robertson, Democrat of Virginia, offered today this description of a Congressional overseas junket:

BUFFALO, N. Y., Sept. 15 (AP) -A union official declared today that a State Retail Minimum Wage Board's recommendations for the retail trade industry amounted to "peon wages" that would put retail workers in a category of "second class citizens."
MIAMI BEACH, Sept. 15 (AP) -Nino Valdes, Cuban heavyweight champion, scored a unanimous decision over Charlie (Doc) Williams, Mahwah, N. J., in a grueling tenround fight tonight.

Dr. Arthur B. Robins, director of the bureau of tuberculosis of the city's Department of Health, said yesterday that chest X-rays for all patients admitted to hospitals here would be "the most important single step" in the use of mass X-rays.

The Museum of Modern Art, which concerns itself with art in many of its manifestations, has set its seal of approval on ten automobiles. They will be on public exhibition today in the sculpture garden back of the museum building at 11 West Fifty-third Street.
CHELSEA, Mass., Sept. 15 (AP) -- The police flagged down traffic to a country-style twenty miles an hour in this suburb north of Boston today.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Sept. 15 -- Jack Westland, 48-year-old player from Everett, Wash., set something of a record in golf annals today as he stepped to the first tee in the fifty-third United States Golf Association's Amateur championship at the Oklahoma Golf and Country Club.

TRENTON, Sept. 15 -- The Appellate Division of the New Jersey Superior Court ruled today that Walter G. Winne, superseded prosecutor of Bergen County who is under indictment for nonfeasance in office must be furnished by the State with a bill of particulars and has the right to inspect documents removed from his office by the state.

LONDON, Sept. 14 -- Anthony Rigden, the British airman who created an international incident by disappearing in the Suez Canal zone and reappearing nearly seven weeks later in Paris, was released from custody today by the Royal Air Force after a two-week investigation.

The proposal of the National Association of Manufacturers for a general excise tax at the manufacturer's level was labeled yesterday as a "pyramiding and highly inflationary evil" by the National Retail Dry Goods Association.

GENEVA, Sept. 15 -- The executive committee of the Federation of International Civil Servants Associations has recommended that no international civil servant should give information "prejudicial to any international civil servant" to the police of any national government.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- Daniel A. Taylor, 58-years old, a Chicago tax lawyer, is to be named chief counsel of the Bureau of Internal Revenue.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- George M. Humphrey, Secretary of the Treasury, warned today that the United States Government henceforth was going to take a hard look at any proposal to spend public funds for competitive enterprises abroad.
Rossini's "La Cenerentola" will open the fall season of the New York City Opera Company at the City Center on Thursday, Oct. 8, Joseph Rosenstock, director of the company, announced yesterday.

" The Robe," Twentieth CenturyFox initial production in the CinemaScope wide-screen process, will have its premiere tonight at the Roxy Theatre before an invited audience. Regular performa nces will commence tomorrow morning at 9 o'clock with a slight advance in prices.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- Advocates of the Coudert bill to outlaw deficit spending by the Federal Government except in time of war or grave national emergency are planning to press for a Congressional showdown in the next session.

It is a wise Soviet citizen who can keep steadily on the party line these days as that line careens unpredictably from one direction to another. It was only yesterday that every good Communist "knew" that one of the great changes made by the Malenkov regime had been the consolidation of numerous industries into a few, with the saving of large sums in administrative overhead.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 5 -- The Philadelphia Orchestra Association and Local 77, American Federation of Musicians, A. F. L., signed a contract today for the 1953-54 season embodying many gains for the 104 regular musicians on the orchestra payroll.
Far-away places and things inspired the designs for two new contemporary collections of wallpapers that are available at Wall Trends, 509 Madison Avenue.

Commercial banks in England, are "very happy" to leave mortgage lending to savings and loan associations. Sir Harold Bellman, chairman of the board of the Abbey National Building Society of London, largest savings and loan association in the world, said here yesterday.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 15 -Eric Mendelsohn, a German-born architect who left his native country when Hitler rose to pover in 1933 and who had built notable structures on the Continent, in England, Israel and the United States, died today at Mount Zion Hospital here after a short illness. His age was 66.

In a variety of forms the really basic issue at the current session of the General Assembly is whether Red China is to be admitted to the United Nations. Mr. Vishinsky lost no time in raising the question yesterday, but an American resolution to postpone a decision for the rest of this year on seating the Chinese Communists won out.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee dispatched one of its members today on a mission that may lead to fundamental Congressional decisions on the scale of future United States aid to the French in Indo-China.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 15 -- A performance of Boito's "Mefistofele," with Fausto Cleva conducting, opened the thirty-first annual season of the San Francisco Opera Association tonight in the War Memorial Opera House.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- The United States will send six atomic cannon to Germany soon to bolster the North Atlantic Treaty Organization's defense of Western Europe.
PARIS, Sept. 15 -- The French Cabinet approved today a series of measures modernizing Morocco's administrative set-up that had been presented to it by Georges Bidault, Foreign Minister.

JERSEY CITY, Sept. 15 -- At the close of a stormy three-hour public hearing in the packed Assembly chamber of City Hall here the City Commission, by a 4-to-1 vote, adopted today an ordinance enabling the Municipal Sewerage Authority to proceed with construction of a $31,000,000 sewage-disposal system.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 15 -- Mme. Vijaya Lakshmi Pandit of India, newly elected president of the United Nations General Assembly, made it clear today that she did not wish to be regarded as "Exhibit A from India." Neither does she care to have undue stress made of her election as the first woman to head the annual meeting of the sixty member states.

Rabbi Benjamin Schultz, executive director of the American Jewish League Against Communism, said yesterday that there existed "a powerful minority of the clergy which has too much influence -- on the pro-Communist side." He spoke at a luncheon of the Naval Academy Association of New York, in the Lawyers Club, 115 Broadway.

Following a two-hour luncheon conference yesterday with Ambassador Henry Cabot Lodge Jr., head of the United States delegation to the United Nations, Senator Joseph R. McCarthy referred to Mr. Lodge his first case of an American he described as active in Communist party work while holding a $12,000-a-year United Nations post.

CHICAGO, Sept. 15 -- John L. McCaffrey, president of the International Harvester Company, asserted today that farm equipment manufacturers, if they were to have a satisfactory level of sales next year and thereafter, must design and market machines so much better than those the farmer now has that he would realize he could not afford to be without the new products.

Five Queens residents, all opposed to the re-election of Mayor Impellitteri, got Supreme Court Justice Charles S. Colden's approval yesterday to a certificate of incorporation for the Experience party, the independent party that sponsored the Mayor's candidacy for his present office three years ago.

The Union Carbide and Carbon Chemicals Company will use national magazines and local newspapers to promote new apparel uses of Dynel, a textile fiber. Based on a wide range of fashion applications, the campaign was conceived to promote the fall apparel group among consumers while telling the Dynel story to retailers, manufacturers and mills. Anderson Cairns, Inc., is the agency.

TOKYO, Wednesday, Sept. 16 -Maj. Gen. Blackshear M. Bryan, chief United Nations truce delegate, submitted the roster to the Communists Sept. 9, with a demand that they return the men or disclose what had happened to them.

The few "bulls" left in Wall Street did more buying of stocks yesterday than they have in any one day in more than two and a half years. Trading on the New York Stock Exchange reached 2,850,000 shares, the biggest single session with prices rising since Feb. 2, 1951.

New findings in the Staten Island investigation of gambling, crime and official dereliction were handed up yesterday in sealed papers to Supreme Court Justice Felix C. Benvenga by a special grand jury.

ST. LOUIS Sept. 15 -- Martin P. Durkin said today that he had resigned last week as Secretary of Labor because the Eisenhower Administration had broken its pledge, affirmed by the personal assurance of President Eisenhower, to present to Congress nineteen amendments to the Taft-Hartley labor law.

BRIDGETON, N. J., Sept. 15 -- Hundreds of farm folks and even city dwellers -- some from as far away as Delaware, New York and Pennsylvania -- swarmed across a forty-two-acre tract of prairie-like pasture just west of here today to witness the opening of the annual Cumberland County Fair.

For its second performance at the Metropolitan Opera House, the Sadler's Wells Ballet last night repeated its new production of "Le Lac des Cygnes," but with Violetta Elvin and John Field this time in the leading roles instead of Margot Fonteyn and Michael Somes.
Dr. John Cocutz, chief of the Rumanian Service of the Voice of America, submitted his resignation yesterday to John Armitage, chief of the East European Branch of that agency.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Sept. 14 -Fourteen Arab families who are "absentees" under Israeli law were evicted from a farm in western Galilee today by military and civilian police and were resettled two miles away on land abandoned by other Arabs during the Palestine war.

ANKARA, Turkey, Sept. 15 -Turkey and the Soviet Union have reached full agreement for joint use of the waters of the Oktemberyan (Serderabad) Dam and other matters on the irrigation of the fertile Igdir Plain in northeastern Turkey and Soviet Armenia.

Championship trophies of a marathon racer, sporting scenes executed in gros point, and some rare old photographs hang side by side with vivid watercolors in a hobby show that opened yesterday in the lobby of the Brooklyn Post Office, 271 Washington Street. The collection illustrates the after-hours interests of some of the post office's 7,000 employes.
LONDON, Sept. 15 -- The stock markets weakened today under slightly increased selling pressure. Losses became more pronounced among industrial, oil and mining shares.

Prices closed irregularly lower on higher volume yesterday on the New York commodity exchanges. Cottonseed oil registered the best activity of the year and the domestic sugar options the largest sales since Aug. 19. Cottonseed oil, soybean oil, cocoa, sugar, zinc, copper and tin closed lower; coffee, burlap and wool, mixed, and potatoes, lead, hides and rubber, higher.
CANTON, Okla., Sept. 15 (AP) Drum-beating Cheyenne and Arapahoe Indians, charging the Great White Father has violated an old treaty, put a curse on Oklahoma City's lakes yesterday.

WHAT to do with Ezio Pinza? Ever since the Metropolitan Opera star scored in "South Pacific," where he had a tailor-made part, assorted showmen have puzzled over his next assignment. A motion picture didn't work out too well, and in television he has drifted through sundry formats, none of which proved especially durable.

Long Island horse show followers will see the new United States jumping team in action for the first time at the Piping Rock Club's event at Locust Valley, Thursday, Friday and Saturday. The American squad is tuning up for the international competition at the National Horse Show, Madison Square Garden, Nov. 3 to 10.

DENVER, Sept. 15 -- The White House made a formal report today that President Eisenhower's sore right elbow is "progressing satisfactorily." The President has explained that he bumped the arm into a piece of furniture in the White House before he came here on Aug. 8 for his vacation.

BONN, Germany, Sept. 15 -- Dr. Konrad Adenauer, West German Chancellor, predicted today that as a result of his victory in the recent West German election West Europe would be united, the proposed European army would become a reality and the Soviet Union would lose the "cold war."

Performing before the critical eyes of Chuck Dressen and with their fifth straight pennant safely tucked away, the Yankees perhaps were determined to play under wraps. Then again against the sort of pitching Bob Lemon flashed at the Stadium yesterday the result might have been the same in any event.

Urging tax relief for the salaried man, Robert R. Young, chairman of the board of the Chesapeake and Ohio Railroad, declared yesterday that no class has been harder hit by high bracket income taxes than those in sales positions.

CHICAGO, Sept. 15 -- Adlai E. Stevenson tonight urged the United States to take the initiative in new peace talks with the Soviet Union looking toward world-wide disarmament and a European system of durable assurances of nonaggression for the Russians as well as for the free world.

Recently a photograph was published of the lighthouse at Bridgeport, Conn., which the Coast Guard calls defunct. They plan to get rid of it by means of a handsome conflagration sometime this fall. This is a tragedy of the first water for everyone who loves our Atlantic seaboard.

It would appear that the agreements between the United States and General Franco are about to be signed. It is not my purpose to raise any obstacles; nor, were it my purpose, should I be in a position to do so. I write merely, as a "natural ally" of the United States in the present world struggle, to point out what the step about to be taken really means.

VIENNA, Sept. 15 (AP) -- Czechoslovakia's Government reorganized itself today along the latest Soviet lines. Tightening of controls over the police and agriculture was among the effects of a wholesale shift of Ministers. The Prague radio announced the shake-up.

American Kennel Club delegates, meeting at the Hotel Commodore yesterday, approved a change in the rule governing the closing date for show entries, accepted the membership application of the Durham (N. C.) Kennel Club and elected four new delegates.

The W. T. Grant Company, which is scheduled to open its 500th variety store on Sept. 24, had net earnings in the six months ended on July 31, last, of $2,415,928, compared with $2,202,260 in the similar period of 1952, Edward Staley, president, reported in the semi-annual statement mailed to stockholders yesterday.

Four young marines, accused in North Carolina of kidnapping a fellow marine on a Government reservation, were held here in $5,000 bail each yesterday after being arraigned before United States Commissioner Isaac Platt in removal proceedings.
BOSTON, Sept. 15 (UP) -- Bob Keegan fired a superb three-hit shutout today as the White Sox beat the Reds Sox, 6 -- 0, before 4,556 at Fenway Park in Chicago's final appearance of the season here.
Prices of cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange were unchanged to 7 points off yesterday.
A nineteen-story office building on the east side of Third Avenue, between Forty-four all and Fortyfifth Streets, was among plans filed yesterday with the Department of Housing and Buildings.

MILWAUKEE, Sept. 15 (AP) -yesterday the completion of a $1,000,000 color press expansion program enabling the paper to print full color art or advertising through the full run of its daily and Sunday editions. Previously, full color could be carried out only in relatively small main news sections of the paper.

STRASBOURG, France, Sept. 15 (AP) -- Officials of the European Consultative Assembly gave the French-German dispute over the Saar a place on the assembly calendar today despite previous West German objections.

Ever since the middle of the last century Eastern European emigrants have embraced in their adopted country the cause of their oppressed peoples at home. Many of them came to America as political exiles, but even those who were driven to emigration by economic motives sooner or later took up cudgels on behalf of their old countries.

The New York Public Library is featuring an Education Fair in its main lobby at Fifth Avenue and Fortysecond Street this month. Libraries have as their main business the supplying of books and information. As a supplement to this regular service the Public Library also conducts a variety of free courses in many fields to meet the special needs of its patrons.
PROVIDENCE R. I., Sept. 15 -For a young coach, the most youthful in the Ivy League, Alva Kelley has had more than his share of bad luck.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept., 15 (AP) -- The Eastern Railroads President's Conference today filed an answer in the $250,000,000 damage suit brought against it and thirty railroads by the Pennsylvania Motor Truck Association asserting its activities were in the public interest.

With the deadline for a crippling dock strike only two weeks off, the International Longshoremen's Association, A. F. L., warned yesterday that a tie-up would not be confined to the Port of New York, but would shut down every pier from Portland, Me., to Newport News, Va.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 15 -- Just before tonight's game with the Cardinals at Busch Stadium, Duke Snider, explaining why he wasn't in the starting line-up, said he was "a little weak."

OYSTER BAY, L. I., Sept. 15 -- The United States defender, Magnus Konow's Llanoria, defeated the English yacht, Lieut. Col. J. E. Harrison's Marylette, by a quarter of a mile today in the series for the Seanwanhaka Cup and Great Britain is facing disappointment again in her Six Meter sailing efforts.

A protective notice to close "Hazel Flagg" at the end of this week was posted Monday night at the Hellinger. According to Jule Styne, co-producer and composer of the musical written by Ben Hecht (book) and Bob Hilliard (lyrics), the notice may be rescinded tomorrow when Anthony B. Farrell, Mr. Styne's partner in the offering and owner of the Hellinger, returns from an Alaskan hunting trip.

The recent hot weather so damaged tomatoes that it looks now as if the 1953-54 pack of canned tomatoes will be much reduced. This bulletin comes from the American Institute of Food Distribution, a reportorial agency for the trade.

VIENNA, Sept. 15 (UP) -- Premier Vulko Chervenkov of Bulgaria said today that his Communist regime was up against "desperate resistance, attempts at sabotage, explosions and arson," all directed from "the outside."

Study of the American system of commercial credit by foreign business men would materially aid them in expanding their domestic and foreign trade, David Zelinka of Zelinka-Matlik, coat and suit manufacturers, declared last night.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -Spokesmen for two Evangelical Protestant denominations filed petitions with the State Department today protesting against "unjust" and "exorbitant" taxes levied by the Italian Government on their churches in Italy.
SEOUL, Korea, Wednesday, Sept. 16 -- Gen. Maxwell D. Taylor, commander of the Eight Army, asked and authorized all men under his command today to do all they could to help the Korean people.

Robert B. Blaikie appeared on the basis of incomplete figures early this morning to have lost his Democratic leadership of the Seventh Assembly District on Manhattan's West Side as a result of his quest for the Democratic nomination for Mayor.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 15 (UP) -Vic Seixas and Tony Trabert, top United States tennis stars, and three of Australia's four players advanced to the third round of the Pacific Southwest tennis tournament in men's singles.

United States companies will spend an estimated $77,000,000 in export advertising this year, according to the results of a study made public yesterday by the Export Advertising Association, Inc. This does not include advertising for foreign branches and subsidiaries, which will amount to an additional $85,000,000 to $170,000,000.

Three apartment buildings in the Bronx have been sold by Geisinger Rau, operators. Two five-story structures with eighty apartments and one store at 927-31 Faile Street, which have a combined assessed valuation of $230,000, were sold to Joseph Teichman, and the five-story building with thirty-seven apartments and eight stores at 145 West 169th Street was bought by a client of Martin Teichman, lawyer.

Out of his own novel Calder Willingham has written an uneven though remarkably interesting play, "End As a Man," which was acted at Theatre de Lys in the Village last evening. It is the harsh and horrifying story of life in a Southern military academy.
DENVER, Sept. 15 -- The White House today characterized attacks on the Administration by former President Truman and Adlai E. Stevenson as sound and fury, signifying nothing.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 15 -Arthur B. Bisguier of New York, the former national open champion, today gained his fourth consecutive victory in the national chalengers' chess tournament at the Hotel Adelphia when he defeated Hans Berliner of Washington.

We have had many letters published recently about the pay and general plight of teachers. Most of them sound as if the writers had little real knowledge of what they were writing about or else were biased to begin with.

NEWARK N. J., Sept. 15 (AP) -P. Ballantine Sons announced today it will raise the price of bottled beer and tap beer to dealers starting Oct. 1 and the G. Krueger Brewing Company said it will follow suit.
MILWAUKEE, Sept. 15 (AP) -The Pirates routed Lew Burdette with a three-run drive in the eighth inning tonight to beat the Braves, 7 -- 5, before 32,145 fans at County Stadium.

India, and the new Asian woman, won the highest honor the United Nations can bestow when the General Assembly yesterday elected Mme. Vijaya Lakshmi Pandit as its first woman President, to rule over a session which promises to be both stormy and crucial for the future of the United Nations.

Al Weill, manager of the world heavyweight champion, Rocky Marciano, said yesterday he would go before the New York State Athletic Commission on Friday to demand that one-half of Roland La Starza's purse be held as forfeit pending a return bout in the event the challenger should take the championship on Sept. 24 at the Polo Grounds.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (AP) -A group of nonscheduled airlines{ offered today to handle S-cent let-{ ter mail by air for as little as 15{ cents a ton-mile.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 15 -- The United Nations General Assembly opened its 1953 or eighth session this afternoon and quickly voted to postpone a decision on the admission of Chinese Communist representatives for the rest of this year.

MINNEAPOLIS, Sept. 15 -- A report by a special committee appointed by President Eisenhower to assess criticism of the United Nations Education, Scientific and Cultural Organization, made public today, gave the organization a clean bill of health.

Stephen Stanley Ragan, aged 58, who chooses to be known as Michael Patrick O'Brien, is to resume his wanderings, a fitting symbol of this world of ours, which sometimes seems to be drifting interminably nowhere.

CHICAGO, Sept. 16 (UP) -- Bill Veeck, an owner of the St. Louis Browns, will make a full-scale presentation to a committee of American League owners tomorrow of his plans to move his team, preferably to Baltimore, but no decision authorizing the switch is expected immediately.
Robert F. Wagner Jr., candidate of the liberal faction of the Democratic party, won the nomination for Mayor over Mayor Impellitteri in yesterday's primary election.
Nine new major issues of corporate securities aggregating more than $125,000,000 were cleared for public offering yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- A record dividend of $22,500,000, largest in its history, was paid by the Export-Import Bank of Washington to the Treasury last year. The bank, one of the profitable financial activities of the United States Government, showed a net profit for the fiscal year ended on June 30 of $51,800,000, a record high.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- A report on the country's civilian defenses that pictured many cities as on the point of abandoning the program was presented today to a meeting of city attorneys. The attorneys considered urging Congress to give states and municipalities more help in view of Russia's explosion of a hydrogen device.
MILWAUKEE, Sept. 15 (UP) -The National Boxing Association today adopted a uniform scoring system for boxing matches but there was a big question connected with the action.

LONDON, Sept. 15 -- A deal for American management of four British hotels and one continental hotel owned by Gordon Hotels, Ltd., was announced today. Leonard P. Jackson, chairman of Gordon Hotels, said that arrangements had been virtually concluded with the Intercontinental Hotel Corporation of the United States, wholly owned subsidiary of Pan American Airways, for management and financial support.

WOODCHUCK shooting, like other forms of hunting carried on adjacent to large centers of population, calls for a certain amount of advance planning and preparation, activities that apparently were ignored by several who have written to complain of the scarcity of chucks.
EDMOTON, Sept. 15 (Canadian Press) -- The annual report of the Canadian Chamber of Commerce finds that Canada is prosperous, but also finds reasons for concern.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 15 -- Two hits by Monty Irvin, who lifted his average to .340, failed to save Ruben Gomez and the Giants tonight and the Polo Grounders dropped a 4-3 decision to Fred Baczewski and the Redlegs. As a result, a fifth-place finish by Manager Leo Durocher's club is now in jeopardy, since the Giants lead the Redlegs by only two lengths.

Harold Riegelman, Republican candidate for Mayor, declared last night that the November election would be a contest between himself and Robert F. Wagner Jr., the Democratic nominee for Mayor. Council President Rudolph Halley, Liberal party nominee, "hasn't got a chance," Mr. Riegelman said, adding that Mr. Wagner and Mr. Halley would destroy each other."
Interesting lamps, along with other new accessories for the home and small pieces of furniture are on view in the new Adyvone Interiors shop at 651 Madison Avenue.

Samuel Reshevsky, United States, and Vassily Smyslov, Russia, the top two players in the world chess championship challengers' tournament in Zurich, met last night in the tenth round, according to a Swiss news report. The match was drawn in nineteen moves when Smyslov made the offer and Reshevsky accepted.

More than 100 attorneys and jurists took part yesterday in ceremonies at the United States Court House, Foley Square, commemorating the signing of the Constitution on Sept. 17, 1787. Federal Judge Sylvester Ryan presided.

After four years with the Association of American Ship Owners as vice president and Washington representative, former Senator Joseph H. Ball has joined the States Marine Lines. An announcement yesterday by C. S. Walsh, head of the steamship company, said Mr. Ball had been appointed assistant to the president, with headquarters here.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Sept. 15 -- The Japanese Embassy at Canberra has released the text of a note from Tokyo to the Australian Government in which Japan declared her readiness to resume negotiations at any time concerning pearling in waters adjacent to Australia on a fair and reasonable basis.

The National City Bank of New York has leased the banking quarters soon to be vacated by the Irving Trust Company in the New York Central Building at 66 East Forty-sixth Street. The office, comprising about 8,900 square feet of space, will be remodeled and occupied by National City early next year. Cross Brown Company, brokers, negotiated the lease.

LONDON, Sept. 15 -- A British Government ban on data on Britain's Delta-winged aircraft, the strange shaped planes that stole the show at the Farnborough Air Show last week, was made public today through a protest by the president of the Royal Aeronautical Society.

The consultants' report to the New York City Transit Authority on a new survey of maintenance of our publicly owned bus fleet contains some of the bluntest language ever delivered to an employer. The authority retained A. Ebinger, chief engineer in charge of improvements for the St. Louis Public Service Company.
Following is the text of the nationwide address by Adlai E. Stevenson last night in Chicago as recorded by THE NEW YORK TIMES:

PARIS, Sept. 15 -- A sharp clash of views between Foreign Ministry officials and members of the Government led today to the calling of a special Cabinet meeting for tomorrow to define France's European policy, notably regarding the long-pending treaty for a European army.

Mrs. Helen McCooey of 35 Prospect Park West, Brooklyn, widow of Justice John H. McCooey Jr., a prominent Brooklyn Democrat as his father was before him, had narrow escape yesterday. When she went to Public School 77, at First Street between Sixth and Seventh Avenues in Brooklyn, to vote in the Democratic primary in the Twelfth Assembly District, she was informed that she was enrolled as a Republican.
SHANNON, Ireland, Sept. 16 (Reuters) -- Athletes from %hel Lrnlted States and .Canada arrlved lin two chartered planes tonight onI their way to the Israeli OlympicI Games. I

Probably the most complete redecorating job ever undertaken in the recorded history of the City of New York has just been finished on four floors of Grand Central Palace. The occasion was the fifth annual National Home Furnishings Show, which is scheduled to open at 11 A. M. today.

Football will make its 1953 debut in New York tonight when the refurbished New York Giants face the San Francisco Forty-Niners at the Polo Grounds. The Hearst Milk Fund will benefit from the exhibition clash between these strong professional squads.

A log jam which developed Tuesday in the marketing of more than $400,000,000 of new corporate and local government securities broke up yesterday afternoon, assuring a speedy distribution of most of the offerings, and vindicating the judgment of investment bankers ready to back their price ideas in the face of a shaky and congested market.

Consolidated earnings of the American and Foreign Power Corporation in the twelve months to June 30 were $1,935,600 ahead of the preceding months, according to a financial statement issued by the company yesterday. But the parent company's net income was $1,597,925 lower.

Although Robert F. Wagner Jr. won a smashing victory in Tuesday's primary election, defeating Mayor Impellitteri for the Democratic nomination for Mayor by a plurality of 169,179, his leading supporters regard this as winning only the first round in the fight for his election.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N. Y., Sept. 16 -- When Eddie Roush played in the major leagues, he had an ardent distaste for spring training. It seems unbelievable now because Eddie always is waiting in uniform at St. Petersburg each spring so that he can work out with either the Cardinals or Yankees. He's now almost 60 years old and the training season is the happiest time of each year for him.

JERSEY CITY, Sept. 16 -- This city paid for privet hedges ten times their cost to the grower, in a deal designed to eliminate competitive bidding, a Supreme Court hearing on Jersey City's financial transactions was told today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 (AP) -- The Fairchild Engine and Airplane Corporation, Hagerstown, Md., said today it would set up a subsidiary, Fairchild Aviation N. V., in Amsterdam, Holland. The subsidiary will seek Air Force contracts for service and maintenance of Fairchild C119 Flying Boxcars and for production of parts for C119's.

More than 12,000 persons were on hand last night at the Roxy Theatre, inside and outside, for the world premiere of CinemaScope, a new film process that its Hollywood sponsors hope will successfully meet the challenge of television.

Mount Holyoke College will receive more than $1,000,000 from the estate of Newcomb Cleveland, retired advertising executive who died at his Scarsdale home on July 29, 1951 according to an estate tax appraisal filed yesterday at the State Office Building.

David Dubinsky's International Ladies Garment Workers Union, A. F. L., said yesterday it did not see what purpose would be served by appointing a successor to Martin P. Durkin, who resigned last week as Secretary of Labor.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 (UP) -- The Navy announced today a new $569,636,538 shipbuilding program for 1954 to provide an attack aircraft carrier, three destroyers, an attack submarine and 162 other vessels.

The sole union representative threatened to quit the arbitration panel that has been trying for eight months to settle the issues involved in last January's four-week strike on private bus lines that normally carry nearly 3,000,000 riders a day.

Today marks the one hundred and sixty-sixth anniversary of the signing of our Constitution, which took place at Independence Hall in Philadelphia on Sept. 17, 1787. For nearly two centuries this great document has remained the supreme law of the land and has responded to the needs of a new industrial economy, though it was drafted in an agricultural community.
The Los Angeles, Calif., Department of Water and Power announced yesterday that it will offer for sale on Oct. 14 a new issue of $20,000,000 of electric light plant revenue bonds.

In subdued trading, the stock market yesterday all but duplicated Tuesday's gains. Steels, oils, electronics and tobaccos took the leadership in an advance that never went far but included virtually every section of the list. Rails rose, too, but on a smaller relative scale.

When the autumn season is ushered in, Bloomingdale's Green Room customarily offers a thoroughgoing presentation of the outstanding fashion trends. Yesterday's show carried not only New York styles but included several French originals.

THULE AIR FORCE BASE, Greenland, Sept. 13 -- Two large experimental helicopters landed here tonight after a pioneering 4,000-mile flight from Florida to this strategic air base in the Far North. The crews of the twin-rotor craft immediately prepared to fly their machines to the North Pole in an attempt to be the first ever to set down helicopters on the "top of the world."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- Authorities familiar with official United States reports from Cairo, where on Tuesday the Naguib Government had reported a foreign-led plot against it, said today the situation in Egypt was less alarming than suggested by early accounts of revolutionary activities there.

The American Airlines office in New York released the names of the twenty-five passengers and three crew members killed yesterday in the crash of a two-motor Convair near Albany, N. Y. Passenger identifications were tentative and were compiled front reports of the coroner's offce in Albany and airline offices where tickets were purchased.

Fifty-one years at sea in all parts of the world, and would you believe it, the last few miles of my final voyage, just coming up the Bay, I have to hit fog and haze to make this the toughest stretch of them all," Capt. William W. Kuhne, retiring master of the American Export liner Exeter, said yesterday.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 16 -- Don Hartman will continue to call the shots for Paramount as head of production for another five years under the terms of a contract signed today. The new deal becomes effective in March on the expiration of a 1951 agreement, by which he became the studio's executive producer.

Most housewives know the versatility of aluminum foil as a wrapping material. But perhaps they have not thought of using strips of the foil to facilitate the removal of molded desserts or jellied salads. The bottom of the mold may be lined at intervals with the strips which, once the food has set, make it possible to slip it from the container without sticking.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Sept. 16 -- Arnold Palmer, a 24-year-old Coast Guardsman on leave, reached the fifth round of the United States Golf Association's Amateur Championship at the Oklahoma City Golf and Country Club today with two significant victories.

DENVER, Sept. 16 -- The White House joined Ezra Taft Benson, Secretary of Agriculture, today in denying rumors that he was being forced to resign in the continuing controversy over farm policy and falling farm prices.

Knickerbocker Hospital is marking its ninetieth year of service to the community. It is a non-profit hospital supported in part by contributions from the public, and serves all citizens without regard to race, creed or color. Last year Knickerbocker recorded its usual financial loss and will undoubtedly lose money again this year, since we are experiencing the heaviest demand for all our services in our entire history.

Fog forced closing of a twenty-seven-mile stretch of the New Jersey Turnpike for more than five hours yesterday until 8:30 A. M., as northern New Jersey struggled with its worst traffic congestion from fog in years.

CHICAGO, Sept. 16 (AP) -- A hog market still sensitive to supplies, managed to stem yesterday's downturn today on only a small reduction in numbers. Most sales were steady and the movement was moderately active Cattle were unevenly 25 cents lower to 50 cents higher while vealer calves were strong to $1 higher and sheep mainly steady to weak.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Sept. 16 -- Burma has presented a two-pronged take-it-or-leave-it proposal to the Chinese Nationalist representative on the committee that includes the United States and Thailand that is meeting here to negotiate the withdrawal of Chinese Nationalist troops from Northern Burma, U Pe Khin, Burma's Ambassador to Thailand, revealed today.

BONN, Germany, Sept. 16 -- Dr. Konrad Adenauer, West German Chancellor, has invited Georges Bidault, French Foreign Minister, to enter into discussions on "all aspects of French-German relations," a Bonn Government spokesman disclosed today. Undoubtedly the future of the Saar territory, in dispute between France and West Germany, would be the primary topic of the proposed talks.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 16 -- A. W. Scott, president of the National Petroleum Association, today described the 1,000,000-barrel-a-day "defense cushion" created by the nation's oil industry at the Government's request as an "industrial Frankenstein" threatening to precipitate conditions destructive to every segment of the industry.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 (AP) -- The Bureau of the Census reported today cotton consumption in August averaged 36,292 bales for each working day. This compared with an average 37,283 bales for the corresponding period a year ago, and with 29,562 in July. The daily average consumption of linters was 4,437 bales compared with 3,584 a year ago and 3,701 for July.

The public costs of caring for the state's 50,000 needy men, women and children who are public charges in voluntary institutions will be shared for the first time by the state government beginning next Jan. 1, Robert T. Lansdale, State Social Welfare Commissioner, said here last night. At present the localities alone bear the full public costs of caring for these welfare recipients, of whom there are about 24,000 in this city.

The American Federation of Labor will need all the help it can get in laying the foundations for a union of longshoremen free from racketeering. Therefore, the assistance which has been offered voluntarily by Dave Beck, president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, and Paul Hall, New York head of the Seafarers International Union, should go a long way toward strengthening all elements that would end the waterfront evils exposed by the State Crime Commission.

TOKYO, Thursday, Sept. 17 -- The United Nations commander, Gen. Mark W. Clark, pledged today that any American prisoners in Korea who have refused to return to the Allied side would get all the rights and protection guarranteed by United States law if they changed their minds.

GENEVA, Sept. 16 -- The State Department has decided to submit to the Joint Commission for Study of United States International Economic Policies, headed by Clarence E. Randall, a comprehensive proposal for linking reductions in United States tariffs with a general lowering of tariffs by the other principal trading nations of the free world.

SAIGON, Vietnam, Sept. 16 -- Premier Penn Nouth of Cambodia protested today against United States and French threats to cut off aid to his country because of his neutral attitude toward the Communist-led Vietminh rebels.

CEDARHURST, L. I., Sept. 16 -- Mrs. Willie Cruikshank of the Cherry Valley club carded 66-8 -- 58 to win the low net prize in the Women's Long Island Golf Association one-day tournament at the Rockaway Hunting Club today.

Designed for the woman who appreciates elegant simplicity and beautiful fabrics, Bernard Newman's collection of ready-to-wear originals, created exclusively for Bergdorf-Goodman, was presented yesterday at this store.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 (UP) -- The Indian Claims Commission opened a hearing today to determine who started the Black Hawk War of 1831 and 1832.
CHICAGO, Sept. 16 (AP) -- The Cubs defeated the Phillies, 7 -- 4, today with two-run scoring spurts in the sixth, seventh and eighth innings.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 15 -- Israel won her first major post in the United Nations General Assembly today as the delegates selected the countries to sit on the fifteen-member General or Steering Committee.

" A Pin to See the Peep Show," a drama by F. Tennyson Jesse and H. M. Harwood, based on the former's novel of the same name dealing with a murder case that stirred Britain thirty years ago, will make its Broadway debut this evening at 8 o'clock at the Playhouse under the producing auspices of Nancy Davids.

The price of lead was reduced yesterday by a leading custom smelter half a cent to 13 1/2 cents, New York basis, as the result of a decline in prices here and in London. Scrap steel, which has been weak recently, also was cut yesterday in Pittsburgh.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- The Democrats at Chicago did themselves and the Eisenhower Administration no apparent harm, and probably no good, either, in what was said and otherwise produced at the home-coming conclave for Adlai E. Stevenson. But they made one splendid contribution to the pinch of humor that so slightly leavens the heavy mass of politics.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 16 (AP) -- Ken Rosewall of the Australian Davis Cup team defeated Herbie Flam of Los Angeles, 2 -- 6, 7 -- 5, 8 -- 6, in the best match of the day in the Pacific Southwest tennis tournament, today. The 18-year- old Australian, top seeded foreign player, moved into the quarter- finals of the men's singles along with the United States champion, Tony Trabert; the Wimbledon champion, Vic Seixas, and others.
OYSTER BAY, L. I., Sept. 16 -- Magnus Konow and Llanoria completed a three-race sweep today to keep the Seawanhaka Cup, a major six-meter yachting trophy, in the United States a while longer.
CHICAGO, Sept. 16 (UP) -- The transfer of the St. Louis Browns to another city was approved today by a fact-finding committee appointed by the American League.

PANMUNJOM, Thursday, Sept. 17 (AP) -- A United Nations Command authority said today that being a "progressive" -- a prisoner who sided with the Reds while in their custody in North Korea -- was not considered a crime in the United States.

Borough President Wagner has won the Democratic nomination for Mayor of New York. Only 25 per cent of the 2,132,181 enrolled Democrats voted in the primary election, and Mr. Wagner's "landslide" consists of an endorsement by 16 per cent of the Democrats eligible to express an opinion.

CHICAGO, Sept. 16 -- The price trend in the grain markets was reversed today, and substantial gains were registered in wheat and corn, with soybeans also scoring a big rally from early low spots. No special change was reported in the news developments, but the markets appeared to have become badly oversold and commission absorption on the recent declines has created a stronger technical position.

LONDON, Sept. 16 -- The agreement that the United States, Britain, France and other creditor nations signed here last February with the West German Government under which Bonn assumed responsibility for Germany's pre-war external debts, became effective today.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Sept. 16 -- Prime Minister Daniel F. Malan failed by sixteen votes today to obtain parliamentary sanction to remove the colored (mixed race) voters from the white electoral register in Cape Province. He mustered 122 votes against the combined opposition's 78, leaving his Nationalist party sixteen short of the two-thirds majority needed to amend the Constitution.

ANKARA, Sept. 16 -- Turkey, the latest country to join the exclusive big time wheat exporting countries, has taken its most important step to date to retain its position as the world's fourth largest exporter, against bitter competition.

Montgomery Ward Co., Inc., the nation's second largest merchandising organization, retailing through the mail and a chain of 600 department stores, showed reduced sales and earnings in the six months ended last July 31.

NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 16 (UP) -- A Federal court judge today rejected requests for a new trial to prevent a 17-year-old Negro from enrolling at Louisiana State University, but later granted an appeal by the university's attorneys to the Fifth United States Circuit Court of Appeals.

LONDON, Sept. 16 -- The stock markets were cautious today, awaiting the development of the technical rally on Wall street yesterday. After an initial rise, prices tended to fall, although the net effect was that gains outnumbered losses. This was the case with British Government securities and industrial shares, in which some store issues rose sharply. Dollar stocks were higher, in line with Wall Street.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 16 (AP) -- Larry Doby led a twelve-hit Cleveland attack with a single and his twenty-sixth homer, good for three runs batted in, tonight as the Indians beat the Athletics, 7 -- 2, behind the eight-hit pitching of Bob Feller.

Let's pretend this morning that the Sadler's Wells Ballet just opened its season at the Metropolitan Opera House last night with its presentation of "The Sleeping Beauty," and that the preceding pair of "Swan Lakes" were only a couple of sneak previews.

ANKARA, Turkey, Sept. 16 -- The Turkish Government formally demanded today the dissolution of the small traditionalist Nation party and indicted thirteen of its leading members for violating the law of associations. Ankara also opened proceedings to deprive the party's two Deputies in the Grand National Assembly of their parliamentary immunity preparatory to preferring charges against them.

ALBUQUERQUE, N. M., Sept. 16 -- Voters in New Mexico repealed the state constitutional prohibition of liquor sale to Indians in yesterday's special election on a total of eleven constitutional propositions.

MOSCOW, Sept. 16 -- Two basic changes in Soviet agricultural statistical procedures have recently been announced by Premier Georgi M. Malenkov and Nikita S. Khrushchev, First Secretary of the Communist party.

TORONTO, Sept. 16 -- Top defense scientists from the United States conferred here today with Canadian officials on super-secret Project Y, Canada's blueprint for a disk-shaped fighter plane that can reach a speed of 1,500 miles an hour after a vertical take-off.

During hours of darkness in the last two weeks the surf off the Rockaways in Queens has been aglow with greenish or bluish light, observers have reported. The odd illumination was seen last night by Coast Guardsmen at the Rockaway Lifeboat Station at Fort Tilden and by other persons in the area.

MONTREAL, Sept. 16 -- A layoff of 3,600 textile workers in plants throughout Canada is scheduled for next week, delegates attending the Canadian Congress of Labor convention were informed tonight. About 800 delegates representing 370,000 members affiliated with the Congress are attending the week-long convention here.
I would like to congratulate you for your editorial of Sept. 8 "Moscow's Higher Learning."

CHICAGO, Sept. 16 -- More united than when they arrived, Democratic leaders left two days of party strategy conferences without certain knowledge whether Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois would try for the Presidential nomination again in 1956.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- Henry W. Grunewald, Washington "mystery man" and influence seeker, was ordered to serve a three-month term in jail today after Judge Alexander Holtzoff ruled in Federal District Court that he had "seriously" violated conditions of his parole.

GREAT NECK, L. I., Sept. 16 -- Roslyn (Cookie) Swift of the home club started the defense of her women's Cross County title with a 3-oven-par 36, 38 -- 76 in the first round of the three-day tournament today at the Glen Oaks course.

EDMONTON, Alberta, Sept. 16 (Canadian Press) -- Kenneth W. Taylor, Canada's Deputy Minister of Finance, said today that "there is no present clear reason for calling a downturn in economic conditions."

Harold Riegelman's appraisal of Rudolph Halley, Liberal party candidate, as a captive candidate has evidently pained your correspondent Eugene Victor. And this fact would seem to prove the very point Mr. Riegelman made: the disservice to organized labor resulting from a labor leader's ownership of a political party.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- John A. Hannah, Assistant Secretary of Defense, said today that liquor retailers were instigating opposition to a recently revised liquor policy of the Army and the Air Force.
Harold Riegelman, Republican candidate for Mayor, said yesterday that he "loved the results" of the Democratic primary election and that he had "sent for the plans to Gracie Mansion this morning."

Dr. Byron Curtis Brunstetter, one of the twenty-five passengers who perished yesterday in the crash of an American Airlines plane near Albany, was executive secretary of the research and grants section of the United States Public Health Service in Washington.
A slim man with pouched eyes -- a man who always reminded me of a lizard -- leaned across a desk and said, "This is the best prison in Europe."

DETROIT, Sept. 16 -- Senator Homer Ferguson, Republican of Michigan, said today the Army had agreed to award to the Chrysler Corporation a $50,000,000 contract for production of the T-51, a new vehicle designed to recover disabled tanks from battle areas.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- Announcement has been made of the engagement of Mrs. Rosemary Turner McMahon, widow of Senator Brien McMahon of Connecticut, to Baron Robert Silvercruys, Belgian Ambassador to the United States, by Mrs. Arthur Gordon Turner Sr. of Washington, mother of Mrs. McMahon.
Prices in the cotton futures market closed barely steady yesterday, 4 to 9 points lower than Tuesday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- Senator H. Alexander Smith, Republican of New Jersey, chairman of the Senate Labor and Public Welfare Committee, indicated today that the late Senator Robert A. Taft, Republican of Ohio, would have rejected proposed Taft-Hartley amendments in a White House draft, contrary to intimations of Martin P. Durkin, former Secretary of Labor, and George Meany, president of the American Federation of Labor.

PARIS, Sept. 16 -- In spite of encouragement from both London and Bonn to tackle again the long-deferred problem of ratifying the European Defense Community Treaty, the French Cabinet failed today to overcome the conflict among its members that prevents a clear definition of France's European policy and her adhesion to the pending treaty.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 16 -- Hurrying along like a fellow fearful of being shut out at the daily double window, the Giants and Redlegs completed a nine-inning game in 1 hour 39 minutes today at Crosley Field. The year's fastest contest in the National League was won by the Giants, 4-3, as Dave Koslo checked a last-inning attack by the home side.

A cooperative effort by Federal, state and city mediators was initiated yesterday to head off a coast-wide dock strike Oct. 1. Plans for the joint peace-making effort were announced as a new stalemate developed in direct negotiations between the International Longshoremen's Association, A. F. L., and the New York Shipping Association.

Samuel Reshevsky, representing the United States in the world chess championship challengers' tournament in Zurich, recovered the lead last night when he scored his adjourned game with Alexander Kotov of Russia in the eighth round without resuming play, according to a Swiss news report.

Dedication ceremonies were held yesterday afternoon in front of the new Forest Hills General Hospital, 102-01 Sixty-sixth Road, Queens, the first one in that borough to have a manifold oxygen system in which the gas can be pumped into rooms from a central place. The 150-bed structure was built at a cost of $1,750,000.
