The award of public service scholarships to two Barnard College students, Geraldine Kirshenbaum of Brooklyn and Frances Evans of Nashville, Tenn., for the academic year 1953-54 was announced yesterday by Dean Lorna F. McGuire. Miss Kirshenbaum will be a senior this year and Miss Evans a junior.
MILWAUKEE, Sept. 16 (AP) -- Eddie Mathews lined a fast ball over the right field fence with Johnny Logan aboard today for his forty-sixth home run of the season as the Braves beat Pittsburgh, 7 -- 3.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- A thirteen-year decline in the purchasing power of the dollar has been halted, George M. Humphrey, Secretary of the Treasury, asserted here today.

The possibilities for the growth of industrial advertising in Canada are probably brighter today than anywhere else in the world, according to Arthur W. Cowles, advertising manager of the Carborundum Company, Niagara Falls, N. Y. He spoke yesterday at a meeting of the Montreal Chapter of the National Industrial Advertisers Association in that city.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- The American Bar Association has informed Attorney General Herbert Brownell Jr. that former Senator John A. Danaher, Republican of Connecticut, is "well qualified to fill one of the vacancies in the [Federal] Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- Stephen J. Spingarn, whose term as a member of the Federal Trade Commission expires on Sept. 25, assailed fellow members of the cammission today for approving budget cuts that he said would curb anti-monopoly activities of the commission the 1955 fiscal year beginning next July 1.

Mrs. Doris Walters Powell, a civilian clerk for the Army who was called "a 100 per cent Communist" last week by Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, has been suspended from her job, where she had access to classified information about food shipments to Korea, Indo-China and other overseas points.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- The appointment of a Secretary of Labor to succeed Martin P. Durkin, who resigned last week, may be delayed until the American Federation of Labor convention adjourns, informed sources said today.

HONG KONG, Sept. 16 -- The Peiping People's Daily, in an editorial on the Soviet agreement to give long-term aid to Communist China, said today that four immediate tasks faced the Chinese people in their reconstruction work.

ATLANTA., Sept. 16 -- The South, in the last four years, has increased the number of its worsted spindles approximately 10 per cent, a Southern Conference of Woolen and Worsted Manufacturers was told today.

The one-story taxpayer and theatre building at 42-14 to 42-26 Greenpoint Avenue in Long Island City, Queens, has been sold by the Celtic Realty Corporation to the Kop-Lain Realty Corporation, which plans to convert the lobby section into stores. Tentative plans call for the conversion of the auditorium and mezzanine sections for congregational or factory purposes.

C. V. Whitney's 2-year-old colt Fisherman, the favorite at a bit more than even money, gave a top-quality performance at Aqueduct yesterday in winning the thirty-first running of the Cowdin Stakes He raced six and a half furlongs in 1:17 and was only two-fifths of a second away from the track record set by the famous Hill Prince in the '49 Cowdin.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- The Jewish War Veterans charged today that Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, was "endangering" the fight against Communism by employing practices "we condemn in totalitarian governments."
WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 (UP) -- The Air Force said today that married men, accompanied by their families, would serve longer tours of duty in the far east, while single men would be sent home sooner.

The results of "governmental financial collapse from within" are more to be feared than "the invasion of an enemy army from without," Senator Edward Martin, Republican of Pennsylvania, declared last night.
BOSTON, Sept. 16 (AP) -- The Tigers blasted four Boston pitchers for eighteen hits while defeating the Red Sex, 8-3, today before 2,739, Fenway Park's smallest 1953 crowd.

PARIS, Sept. 16 -- Agitation was resumed again today in the national postal, telegraph and telephone services in protest against a circular reported to have been sent by the Minister of Post Telegraph and Telephones to all department heads ordering them to draw up lists of men who would be required to work in the event of a new strike.

Dr. German Arciniegas, visiting Professor of Spanish American Literature at Columbia University and former Minister of Education for Colombia, was sent to Ellis Island late yesterday afternoon for security questioning.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Sept. 16 -- A general strike call, issued for yesterday by the Communist-led Estate Workers Union, produced a large scale walkout, reports reaching here from all over Indonesia indicated today. However, there was no response from some laborers and on many plantations work continued as usual.

Plans are being formulated for the annual tea dance and fashion show, for the benefit of the Judson Health Center, which will be held on Nov. 18 in the main ballroom of the Plaza. Mrs. Paul H. Raymer heads the benefit committee and Mrs. Eldon Harvey Jr. is president of the women's committee.

Robert E. Wagner Jr.'s resounding victory in Tuesday's primary was interpreted in many quarters yesterday as proof that the Democratic party machine in New York City has lost the last remnants of its power to control any substantial number of votes.

TEHERAN, Iran, Sept. 16 -- Iran's purge of Tudeh (Communist) party partisans and sympathizers, well advanced in civilian ministries, has been extended to the armed forces, the Government revealed today. Four air force officers, a colonel, major, captain and lieutenant, and six non-commissioned officers are under arrest on suspicion of having a connection with the illegal Tudeh party.

LONDON, Sept. 16 (UP) -- United States and Canadian sea forces sailed from the American east coast today to open a mock war for control of the North Atlantic Ocean, the English Channel and the North Sea.

State Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein will start an investigation today concerning a Brooklyn ballot box that held sixty-four more Democratic ballots than had been issued in the primary election on Tuesday. The box contained 241 ballots, whereas only 177 had been authorized for insertion. It was described as the first case of ballot-box stuffing here in twenty years.

The Estate of John Castree, Inc., sold the four-story building at 349-55 Washington Street, northeast corner of Franklin Street, in the heart of produce district, to David S. Meister, operator, through Philip Miller, broker. The property is 88 by 36 feet and is assessed at $130,000.

A 2-year-old boy dropped placidly from a fourth-story apartment window into the waiting arms of a construction foreman yesterday afternoon in a spectacular rescue that was a near-miracle of timing and speed.
ALBANY, Sept. 16 (AP) -- Among winners in thirteen upstate mayoralty nomination contests yesterday were former Representative Edwin A. Hall of Binghamton and Steven Pankow of Buffalo.

The Rev. Dr. Roy G. Ross was elected general secretary of the National Council of the Churches of Christ in the U. S. A. at the closing session of the first fall meeting of the council's general board here yesterday. The meeting was held at the Marble Collegiate Reformed Protestant Dutch Church, Fifth Avenue and twenty-ninth Street.

Brig. Gen. George W. Goddard (Ret.) has been appointed head of the military and aerial photographic division of the Bulova Research and Development Laboratories, Inc., a subsidiary of the Bulova Watch Company.

What is believed to be one of the first scientific investigations on the nature and purpose of ear wax was described here yesterday at the annual congress of the International College of Surgeons. It suggests that the material is a potent protector of the ears from fungus and bacterial infections.

SOUTHAMPTON, England, Sept. 16 -- The first shipload of British prisoners of war liberated by the Korean armistice -- 530 of them -- came home today to barrages of joyous family questions about their physical health and doubtful press question about their ideological health.

Keyed to the approaching "long winter evenings," an exhibit of a small group of lamps and a large collection of books on crafts and "do-it-yourself" occupations has been arranged by the American Craftsmen's Educational Council in the gallery of America House, 32 East Fifty-second Street.

With adequate research, cotton's dominant position in the textile industry's inter-fiber competition can be held indefinitely, according to George Buck, technical director of the National Cotton Council.

Home furnishings sales turned up sharply in the first three days of this week, officials of several local furniture stores and home furnishings chains reported yesterday. They said furniture sales had shown the greatest rise.

That the Soviet Union has scrapped its original Fifth Five-Year Plan for 1951-1955 and replaced it with a sharply different economic blueprint giving consumer needs much higher priority and heavy industrial development lower priority than originally envisaged seems the unmistakable inference to be drawn from the two major Soviet policy statements of the past five weeks by Premier Georgi M. Malenkov and Nikita S. Khrushchev, First Secretary of the Communist party.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 (UP) -- Law - enforcement officials representing 800 cities declared today that the Federal civil defense program was "very inadequate" in view of the reported Soviet possession of the hydrogen bomb.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- Cancellation of orders for jet and conventional aircraft engines that would have cost the Government between $400,000,000 and $500,000,000 this fiscal year ending June 30 was announced by the Air Force today. The effects of the move will begin to be felt next spring.

I wish to refer to the inaccurate affirmations made by former President Prio Socarras in a letter published in THE NEW YORK TIMES on Sept. 5 in connection with the editorial "Batista's Dilemma" which appeared recently in your paper, since I consider it unjust that American public opinion should be so misled and confused.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 16 -- A strike of 44,000 New Jersey truck drivers, warehousemen and helpers next April 1 was authorized today by the Teamsters Joint Council, No. 73, A. F. L., if a law that goes into effect on that day requiring the 15,000 drivers in the state of trailer-trucks and semi-trailers to obtain special licenses is not amended.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 16 -- Cookie Lavagetto, who guided the Dodgers to victory last night, no longer is a genius as a "manager," although Roy Campanella almost made him one tonight with a pinch two-run homer in the ninth inning. But that wasn't quite enough and the Cardinals beat the Dodgers, 5 -- 4, before 16,733 fans at Busch Stadium and left the Brooks still looking for their hundredth victory.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 16 -- The sixteen members of the United Nations that sent armed forces to defend South Korea agreed today to oppose any attempt by the Soviet Union to place the proposed Korean peace conference on the agenda of the General Assembly.

MANILA, Sept. 11 -- Philippine-United States relations have increasingly become a factor, apart from the issue of political interference, in the perfervid election campaign here. It is more and more apparent that the campaign itself is a wholly spontaneous test of what the electorate really thinks of the United States and its policies in this part of the world.

The Lehman Corporation, a big investment trust, plans to split its stock two-for-one. Robert Lehman, president, announced yesterday that stockholders will vote at the annual meeting on Oct. 21 on a proposal to increase the authorized stock from 2,500,000 shares to 5,000,000 shares, par value to remain unchanged at $1 a share. The corporation has 2,076,562 shares outstanding.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 16 -- A draw in twenty-two moves between two New Yorkers, Arthur B. Bisguier and Karl Burger, left their positions unchanged today after the conclusion of the fifth round of the challengers' tournament sponsored by the' United States Chess Federation at the Hotel Adelphi.

BOSTON, Sept. 16 -- A senior backfield, built around Capt. Joe Johnson, one of the best ball-carriers to wear the Maroon and Gold, and a heavy, rangy line, composed largely of sophomores, constitute as good a first team as Boston College has put on the football field in recent years.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- Senator Frank Carlson, Republican of Kansas, joined the opposition to a national sales tax today and expressed doubt that the Eisenhower Administration would even propose one. Mr. Carlson and other well-posted Congressional sources, including Representative Wilbur D. Mills, Democrat of Arkansas, voiced the conviction, moreover, that Congress would not approve such a levy even if the Administration did recommend it.

Television producers and educational agencies will conduct a one-day clinic Monday to study methods for producing the most effective educational television programs. Participating organizations will include the Metropolitan New York Coordinating Council for Educational Television, Metropolitan New York Educational Agencies Committee on Television and the Columbia Broadcasting System.

LONDON, Sept. 16 -- Mrs. Melinda MacLean, the loyal American-born wife of the missing British diplomat Donald D. MacLean, has vanished in Switzerland under circumstances as mystifying as those surrounding the disappearance of her husband, once a Communist sympathizer, twenty-eight months ago.

OTTAWA, Sept. 16 (Canadian Press) -- Marked production increases in most of Canada's leading minerals were recorded during the first half of 1953, the Bureau of Statistics reported today, Leading in the gains were crude petroleum, natural gas, iron ore, silver, lead, zinc, cement and clay products. Among those declining were asbestos, coal, nickel and salt.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- The newest Republican member of the Senate said today he was "doubtful that tax reduction can be accomplished in a large way."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, the following principal changes for the week ended Sept. 9:

There were 493,258 owners of common and preferred shares of the General Motors Corporation in the third quarter of this year, a new high, the corporation reported yesterday. This figure was 1,790 above the previous high of 491,468 set in the second quarter this year and compared with 485,984 in the third quarter of 1952.

The nervous system is a delicate object, not only at this time of year, but also at any other. It seems balanced as though on thread, prepared at the least possible provocation to come crashing down. Far too many things affect it adversely, such things as earning a living, bringing up the children or trying to forecast the immediate future of the world.

August's heat wave bleached the pink out of the chrysanthemums that Rockefeller Center planted yesterday in its Channel Gardens. Instead of yellow, pink and purple flowers, the display is yellow, white and mauve.

PARIS, Sept. 16 -- All Roman Catholic seminaries in France have been ordered to forbid their students from working in factories as means of getting closer to the working class. The order was contained in a letter published in the Religious Bulletin of Chartres, signed by Giuseppe Cardinal Pizzardo, head of the Sacred Congregation of Seminaries in Rome.

The Treasury securities market and the secondary market for corporate bonds in general put on a good show of strength yesterday, in accompaniment to the big absorption of new securities made since Monday through the nation's investment banking machinery. In the Treasury market, longer-term securities enjoyed mark-ups of 1/8 to 1/4 point, the new thirty-year 3 1/4s closing at 100 1/2 bid, a gain of 3/16 of a point.

Unionized musicians established a picket line outside the Roxy late yesterday afternoon, a few hours before the premiere of "The Robe." Al Manuti, president of Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians, A. F. L., accused the theatre of having discharged twenty-six musicians in violation of an agreement that still had a year to run.

Brown-Forman Distillers Corporation of Louisville plunged vigorously into "the battle of the bonds" here yesterday. Its chairman, W. L. Lyons Brown, asserted that other distillers were foisting "senile" whisky on consumers with labels reading successively four, five, six and, now, seven years old.

DENVER, Colo., Sept. 16 -- President Eisenhower has invited Premier Joseph Laniel to come to Washington to discuss problems of mutual interest to France and the United States and M. Laniel has accepted.

A gain last week of 637,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end supplies were 143,487,000 barrels, compared with 142,850,000 a week earlier and 117,296,000 a year ago.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 (AP) -- The Senators ruined Virgil Trucks' bid for his twentieth victory tonight, beating the White Sox, 4 -- 2, behind the six-hit pitching of Connie Marrero.

In those countries where government encroachment on business is slight, bankers have a stronger sense of social responsibility, Richard A. Booth, president of the National Association of Mutual Savings Banks, declared yesterday. Mr. Booth headed a group of savings bank executives that recently completed a tour of thrift institutions in Great Britain and Northern European countries.
NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 16 (UP) -- An array of doctors and technicians made final preparations tonight for an attempt to separate Siamese twins joined at the base of the spine.

ALBANY, Sept. 16 -- All twenty-five passengers and three crew members on an American Airlines Convair were killed this morning when the twin-engine plane hit two radio towers while circling in a fog near Albany Airport. The plane crashed into a field and exploded in flames.

BONN, Germany, Sept. 16 -- More than 2,000,000 of the 11,000,000 to 12,000,000 Germans who once lived in the Polish-occupied territories east of the Oder and Neisse Rivers have died or have been killed since 1945, according to a two-volume study of the Eastern refugee problem prepared by German scholars and published today by the Refugee Ministry in Bonn.

The economic position of the domestic trunk airlines has improved to the point where, payments to them by the Federal Government probably will be reduced to $3,600,000 in 1955, Robert B. Murray Jr., Under Secretary of Commerce, told the Wings Club yesterday in the Biltmore Hotel. He said the latest available figures showed that two years ago they received $18,900,000.

The Public Service Commission suspended yesterday, pending a public hearing, the Long Island Water Corporation's plan for increasing its rates to its 48,000 customers by an estimated total of $226,500 annually. The corporation had asked permission to make the new rates effective yesterday.

STRASBOURG, France, Sept. 16 (UP) -- France unveiled a new plan today to heal West Europe's economic plight by eliminating trade barriers. Bernard Lafay, Secretary of State for Economic Affairs, announced the project to the Council of Europe's Assembly, meeting here.

A shining needle darted every few seconds from one point on a cockpit dial to another point, sometimes a quarter circle or more away. In the blackness of 2:45 A. M. yesterday, flying 170 miles an hour 4,000 feet above Mastic Beach, L. I., Capt. John W. Wilkin and his Eastern Air Defense Force crew in a C-47 observation plane called it completely confusing -- and therefore good.

BOSTON, Sept. 16 -- Representative Jacob K. Javits, Republican of New York, called tonight for the exercise of "complete justice" in dealing with the situation between Israel and the Arab States. Asserting that the Near East well might become a major testing ground between communism and the free world, Mr. Javits said United States policy in the area should be aimed at peace, development of standards of living and regional defense against all aggression.

Trading was routine on most New York Commodity exchanges yesterday but potatoes had the best volume since Aug. 11 and world sugar since Aug. 27. Prices closed irregular, with sugar, coffee, cocoa, zinc, copper and tin higher; cottonseed oil, burlap, hides, lead and rubber lower, and potatoes, soybean oil and wool mixed.

WESTBURY, L. I., Sept. 16 -- Headed by the Hayes Fair Acres Stable's Pronto Don, the record money-winning trotter, twelve of the speediest trotters in the nation will go to the post in the seventh annual $50,000 Roosevelt Trot over the mile and one-half distance tomorrow night.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Sept. 16 -- Facts that were said to make it clear that the Australian Communist party was behind the Australian "Convention on Peace and War" were placed before the House of Representatives in Canberra tonight by Prime Minister Robert Gordon Menzies.
The problem of developing executives is "the most important issue" facing American management, it was asserted yesterday by Don G. Mitchell, chairman of the board of Sylvania Electric Products, Inc.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 16 (AP) -- Mrs. Esther duPont Weir's Royal Governor won the $30,925 American Bred Stakes and her English-bred Royal Vale was first in the $29,625 Foreign Bred Stakes at the Atlantic City Race Course today.

NO hunter exhibits greater enthusiasm for the sport than the woodcock specialist, and these are anxious days for members of this clan, for the season opens in Maine, New Brunswick and Nova Scotia on Oct. 1, and the majority like to be in the covers on opening day, providing the flight is on.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 (AP) -- Senator John M. Butler, Republican of Maryland, announced today that a three-man Senate subcommittee, of which he is the head, would leave for Europe tomorrow to study problems of the shipping industry.

MINNEAPOLIS, Sept. 16 -- Cultural isolationism is growing in the United States, with the result that the nation's prestige abroad is beginning to suffer, speakers warned today at the fourth conference of the United States National Commission for the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization.

CANANDAIGUA, N. Y., Sept. 16 (UP) -- The parents of Fred Eugene McManus, confessed slayer, wept in court today as the father told of the last few hours their "problem" child spent at home before his brief crime career that took five lives.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Sept. 16 -- Final returns today from yesterday's primary elections in Westchester County showed that candidates of entrenched Republican committees were the winners of chief contests in Mount Vernon, Yonkers, New Castle and the scattered precincts of the Third Assembly District, while "insurgent" Republican forces in New Rochelle nominated city office candidates there and gained a secure toehold in the Republican City Committee.

The Yankees spent a long and none too profitable evening at the Stadium last night as they split a double-header with the tail-end Browns before a gathering of 7,771 which included Crown Prince Akihito of Japan.

Twenty-eight Yankees and twenty-six Dodgers were certified yesterday by Baseball Commissioner Ford C. Frick as eligible to play in the world series, which is slated to open in Yankee Stadium on Wednesday, Sept. 30.

Mainbocher's fashion philosophy is more clearly defined this season than ever before. He lifts his styles above the so-called trends and demonstrates what he honestly believes women want, making the type of clothes that are adapted to everyday living.
Imported fabrics shown yesterday at McCutcheons emphasised the fashion importance of basic material with which the designer or seamstress works.

Frank E. Noel, Pulitzer Prizewinning Associated Press photographer, who was captured by the Chinese Communists in Korea on Nov. 29, 1950, returned to New York yesterday with a report that there was no love lost between the North Koreans, the Chinese Communists and the Russians.

Four special courses designed to enlarge the scope of participants in the entertainment media have been added to the American Theatre Wing's Professional Training Program. They are entitled: "Comprehensive Review of Acting," "Acting Is a Business," "Singing Is a Business" and "Work Group for the Musical Stage."

" Coming Down the Seine," written and illustrated with more than fifty wood engravings by Robert Gibbings, will be published Monday by Dutton. The author unfolds his experiences in journeying down the 400 miles of the Seine, revealing the character of France's colorful and historic water route and the vagaries and ways of life along it.

MADISON, Wis., Sept. 16 -- State Senator Arthur Padrutt, who did not commit himself for or against Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, won the Republican primary election here yesterday over five other candidates and will face Lester Johnson, the Democratic nominee, in a special election on Oct. 13 to fill the Congressional seat of the late Representative Merlin Hull.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 (AP) -David J. McDonald, president of the United Steel Workers, C. I. O., said tonight strikers at the Lackawanna, N. Y., plant of Bethlehem Steel Company had been ordered to return to work immediately to honor a "no strike" clause in their contract.

With Thule, Greenland, in the high Arctic as its keystone, a network of "powerful" bases for possible long-range retaliatory bombing of the Soviet Union, is nearing completion along the aerial approaches to northeastern United States and Canada.

Rudolph Halley, Liberal party candidate for Mayor, took exception yesterday to the statement of Stephen A. Mitchell, Democratic national chairman, that he did not regard Mr. Halley as a Democrat because Mr. Halley had accepted the nomination of the Liberals and would run against Robert F. Wagner Jr., the Democratic nominee.
PARIS, Sept. 17 -- The Government raised the wages of 400,000, or about 20 per cent of its employes today, but the unions promptly labeled the increase as "insufficient."

LONDON, Sept. 17 -- Britain intends to continue her present military commitments in Europe even after German forces are added to the defense of the Continent, and this country becomes financially responsible for four British divisions in Germany, it was learned authoritatively today.
POCONO PINES, Pa., Sept. 17 -- The New York University Glee Club will break camp here tomorrow after its seventeenth annual week of pre-season training -- physical, no less than vocal.

Commodity prices closed generally higher yesterday on the New York exchanges with coffee, sugar, wool, cottonseed oil, soybean oil, zinc, lead, copper and tin firmer. Burlap, hides, cocoa and rubber were lower, and potatoes mixed. Volume continued light except for coffee which had the most active day of the month.

ESSEX FELLS, N. J., Sept. 17 -Henry C. Hagen of Rockaway River won the New Jersey Seniors' Golf Association thirty-six-hole medal play championship today. Hagen began with a 72 yesterday and carded a 38, 40 -- 78 on the final round for a winning total of 150.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 17 -Joseph Newman, the director who announced last month that he was going into independent production, reported today the formation of Sabre Productions in association with Victor M. Orsatti, president of Orsatti Co., Inc., a talent agency here.

A syndicate headed by Henry Moskowitz has purchased the fifteenstory and penthouse apartment building with a frontage of 150 feet at 6 to 16 West Seventyseventh Street, opposite the Museum of Natural History. The Lawyers Mortgage and Title Company insured title to the property, which is assessed at $1,170,000.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Sept. 17 -- Tom C. Robbins of Winged Foot captured the Westchester seniors' golf championship for the sixth consecutive time today, posting a two-day score of 73, 74 -- 147 at the Westchester Hills Golf Club.

Any increase in cargo-handling costs, such as that implicit in the 50-cent hourly wage rise demanded by longshoremen in the Port of New York, will mean the death of the American intercoastal shipping trade, according to the last eight steamship operators remaining in the trade.
If the Board of Education were in the habit of issuing daily communiques, yesterday's report might have said:

NEWARK, Sept. 17 -- Elevenyear-old Johnny Kay said little after his pet Irish setter Tobey was killed by a Public Service bus near his home in Pompton Plains last Thursday. But on Sunday he could no longer contain his feelings.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Sept. 17 -Two college undergraduates, a former golf professional from Indianapolis and Gene Littler, 23-year-old Californian and last of the Walker Cup players, gained the semi-final round of the United States Golf Association's amateur championship at the Oklahoma Golf and Country Club today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -- During the week ended Sept. 16, member bank reserves increased $667,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Sept. 17 -- The Communists strengthened their control of peasant groups in Indonesia here yesterday. At a congress of the National Farmers' Association, the Communists succeeded in taking over exclusive control of the association's affairs and in voting out Socialist party members of the association's Central Committee, who protested the Communist move.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., Sept. 17 -Governor Dewey today appointed Archie O. Dawson, New York attorney, as a special state commissioner to investigate the cost of workmen's compensation insurance in the state.

WASHINGTON, Sept 17 -- This community, with probably more concentration than any other, is now busily engaged in its favorite guessing-game -- this time to anticipate the identity of the next Chief Justice of the United States. It doesn't cost anything, anyone can play, and if the guesses are all wrong that only makes the wind-up more exciting.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 17 -- James Barrington, Burma's permanent delegate to the United Nations, said today he expected new instructions momentarily from his Government in the light of the reported breakdown of negotiations by a four-nation committee working in Bangkok on the withdrawal of Chinese Nationalist guerrillas in Burma.

WESTBURY, L. I., Sept. 17 -- Another episode in the Cinderella story of Katie Key and her owner, Pat Tuccio of Riverhead, L. I., was completed at Roosevelt Raceway tonight when the courageous 6-year-old bay mare raced to victory in the $50,000 Roosevelt Trot before a crowd of 19,519.

Whether the effect of smoking upon the volume of blood circulating in the limbs is profound or mild appears to depend upon the degree of flexibility of the blood vessels, it was reported here yesterday at the closing session of the eighteenth annual congress of the International College of Surgeons at the Waldrof-Astoria Hotel.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Sept. 17 -- Former Gov. Thomas J. Herbert of Ohio, chairman of President Eisenhower's Subversive Activities Control Board, defended tonight the objectives of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy and the overall results of his investigations. He spoke at the annual installation dinner of the White Plains Women's Republican Club.

It is indeed disappointing to find so little constructive criticism coming from the Democratic party's meeting in Chicago. Certainly there must be much to talk about at a biennial conclave of important party members, whether that be on future candidates or on matters of policy.

INDIAN VILLAGE, Korea, Sept. 16 -- The Indian troops are astonishing United Nations and Communist observers alike here each day by the extent of their efficiency and tact in handling the Chinese no-repatriation prisoners, who riot if given the slightest chance.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 (AP) -Harvey Higley, Veterans' Administrator, said today his agency was moving "as rapidly as possible" toward wiping out segregation of whites and Negroes in veterans' hospitals.

Plans for marketing of $19,800,000 of leasehold revenue bonds were announced yesterday by the Georgia State Office Building Authority and the Georgia State Bridge Authority. The Office Building Authority is negotiating with a syndicate headed by Robinson- Humphrey Co. and Blyth Co. and Robinson-Humphrey Co., Inc., for the sale of $9,800,000 of bonds next week.

Another war of nerves against the New York City Transit Authority was started yesterday by Michael J. Quill, international president of the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., when he warned of a subway slow-down unless the authority members met with him before next Tuesday to discuss the union's demands for pay rises and improved working conditions.

Stimulated by the speedy placement of more than $400,000,000 of new corporate and local government securities, prices of United States Government securities moved upward by substantial fractions of a point yesterday.

LONDON, Sept. 17 -- Emphasizing the importance of Anglo-American economic cooperation, Ambassador Winthrop W. Aldrich said in a speech at Sheffield tonight that both the United States and Britain had much to gain from the increasing trade between them.
No need exists for a Federal sales tax and, in fact, such an impost is "politically impossible," Beardsley Ruml asserted yesterday.

NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 17 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru took a strongly worded exception today to the elimination of India from the Korean peace conference and the continued exclusion of Communist China from the United Nations. He said the United Nations vote against India for a seat at the conference "flouted" the will not only of Asia but also of Europe.

ST, LOUIS, Sept. 17 (AP) -George Meany, president of the American Federation of Labor, assailed the Eisenhower Administration today and accused the President of yielding to the influence of big business.

Before an audience that packed the ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel at the luncheon hour yesterday, the Fashion Group, an organization of experts in the field, presented a collection of French imports that highlighted the most proclaimed trends of the season.

LONDON, Sept. 17 -- The command information center for Exercise Mariner, in which the navies of nine North Atlantic Treaty Organization countries are re-enacting the Battle of the Atlantic, issued a communique today disclosing that a United States fleet had sailed from Chesapeake Bay in the first phase of the exercise and passed through an "enemy" minefield.

Merchant and commercial groups have been invited by Robert Moses, Construction Coordinator, to cooperate with the city in a new approach to providing off-street parking space. While adoption of the plan would spell the end of attempts to set up a workable parking authority it still would make Mr. Moses virtual czar of the city's parking problem and relegate the Traffic Department to a minor engineering role.

TOKYO, Friday, Sept. 18 -- Chinese and North Korean prisoners of war released into neutral custody in Korea by the United Nations Command give every indication that they will resist, perhaps forcibly, efforts by Communist representatives to get them to change their minds about returning to their homelands.
GENEVA, Sept. 17 -- The eighth session of the contracting parties to the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade opened here today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 (UP) -Selective Service headquarters announced today that the fourth series of its college qualification tests would be held Nov. 19, 1953, and April 22, 1954, at more than 900 testing centers throughout the country.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -- Department store sales in the United States for the week ended Sept 12 were 11 per cent below sales in the same period of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

TORONTO, Sept. 17 -- Canada is worried about the "dumping" of United States textiles on the Canadian market and may consider revamping the Customs Act to plug the legal loophole through which such imports are admitted.

Harold Riegelman, Republican candidate for Mayor, in a series of statements and public appearances, outlined yesterday a five-point program for eliminating "the mess" at City Hall, which he said was responsible for other "messes" in the city, and called for structural changes in the city government.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -- The Atomic Energy Commission said tonight that the Soviet announcement of testing "new-types" of atomic bombs was confirmation of an Aug. 31 United States an-
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 17 (UP) -- Jim Hegan's double, a sacrifice and Hank Majeski's run-producing pinch fly in the eighth inning gave the Indians a 5-4 victory over the Athletics.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -- The directorship of the National Park Service, long regarded as a Federal professional and career post, has been made a political job. Ralph A. Tudor, Under Secretary of the Interior, said today that it had been placed in the Eisenhower Administration's new Schedule C, or policy-making classification.

In a darkened room at the Commodore Hotel yesterday some light was shed on the subject of residential illumination. Seven experts, illustrating their talks with slides, discussed developments in home lighting before members of the national technical conference of the Illuminating Engineering Society, now in convention here.
Everything was again shipshape at the Metropolitan Opera House last night, where the Sadler's Wells Ballet gave the second performance of its excellent production of "The Sleeping Beauty."
BAGHDAD, Iraq, Sept. 17 (AP) -- Dr. Fadhil Jamali, -- Iraq's New Premier, submitted his new Cabinet list today to King Faisal. The new Cabinet includes:

Some of the standard issues made small gains yesterday and THE NEW YORK TIMES combined average rose for the third straight day, but the stock market as a whole seemed disinclined to follow. More stocks rose than fell but six of the fifteen most active issues had losses and only five had gains, with the losses far larger than the gains.

" Daphne," Thaddeus C. Suski's play that was to have arrived here Sept. 30, failed to make the grade. The five-character comedy opened Tuesday night in Boston and will be taken off tomorrow night, although it was supposed to continue there through next week.

Three three-family buildings in Brooklyn, at 75 Clifton Place, 73 Quincy Street and 59 South Sixth Street have been purchased by the Estates Securities Company, operators, in partnership with the Mayer-Sapir Realty Corporation. Clifford Barnum was the broker.

SCARSDALE, N. Y., Sept. 17 -To encourage the interchange of ideas between students of America and India, Scarsdale High School pupils have shipped 9,400 copies of the school paper to India, where it will be distributed by the United States Information Agency.

A call for a "third great pact" for the Far East, similar to the North Atlantic Treaty and the United States alliance with LatinAmerican nations, was issued yesterday by Senator Alexander Wiley, Republican of Wisconsin. The chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee also urged thoroughgoing cooperation with the free nations of the world.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., Sept. 17 (AP) -- Dr. Paul Craddock, 34 years old, of Lynchburg, Va., a former Army major, wounded Dr. Sarah Matteson, 32, of Cambridge, Mass., then shot himself fatally early today, the police said.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 (AP) -A Senate interior subcommittee announced today it will start closed-door hearings in Seattle, Wash., Monday to investigate "the dire straits" of the United States in regard to metals needed for defense.

GENEVA, Sept. 17 (UP) -- Swiss detectives said tonight two witnesses reported seeing the missing Mrs. Melinda MacLean last Friday night aboard a train east-bound from Lausanne toward the Iron Curtain.

INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 17 (AP) -- Almost twelve tons of detonator fuses exploded and scattered pieces of a transport truck for 1,200 feet today on Indiana Highway 100 near Nora, about five miles north of the Indianapolis city limits.
The cotton futures market here eased yesterday to new lows for the life of the October and December contracts as the active months showed net losses of 7 to 27 points for the day.

Significant and continuous social and economic changes which affect every home in America will be the subject of a new ad campaign by the Institute of Life Insurance beginning the week of Oct. 5. The Institute will use about 600 daily newspapers and six major farm publications, reaching an audience of more than 52,000,000. Each of the fourteen ads will be of 1,000 lines.

INDEPENDENCE, Mo., Sept. 17 (UP) -- Former President Harry S. Truman began his campaign to interest the nation's youngsters in good government today with a thirty-minute speech in his home town's high school. About 1,000 pupils and teachers heard him.
A detachment of 158 Dutch soldiers, bound for Korea as replacements, debarked here at 10 A. M., yesterday from the Navy transport Gen. R. M. Blatchford, at Pier 10, Stapleton, S. I.

F. Tennyson Jesse and H. M. Harwood have written a murder drama scrupulously. That speaks well for their ethics but it leaves the theatregoer with a tepid play. "A Pin to See the Peepshow" is the title of their drama, which was conscientiously acted at The Playhouse last evening.
A modification of service on the Putnam Division of the New York Central Railroad was authorized yesterday by the Public Service Commission.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 17 -- Following is the text of an address made today by John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, in the general debate of the United Nations General Assembly:

Sophie Tucker, the "last of the red-hot mamas," was the-recipient of unusual honors yesterday afternoon on the occasion of her fifty years' association with show business. The vocalist became the first feminine personality to be honored by the Friars Club, which gave a luncheon for her in the grand ballroom of the Park Sheraton Hotel.

For a ball club that for the president, at least, appears virtually homeless, not to mention being mired deep in last place, Marty Marion's Browns gave an astonishingly spunky performance yesterday in their farewell engagement of the year at the Stadium.

CHICAGO, Sept. 17 -- Senator Homer Ferguson of Michigan, chairman of the Senate Republican Policy Committee, charged today that Adlai E. Stevenson, the Democratic Presidential nominee of 1952, had advocated "appeasement" of communism in suggesting high level conferences with the Soviet Union "when we can."

RANGOON, Burma, Sept. 17 (Reuters) -- A Government spokesman said tonight that the fournation talks on the evacuation of Chinese Nationalist guerrillas from Burma had broken down. Burmese delegates to the conference in Bangkok, Thailand, are being recalled, he said.

LONDON, Sept. 17 -- The Bank of England announced today that the bank rate -- that is, the minimum rate at which the bank discounts approved bills of exchange -- had been reduced from 4 to 3 1/2 per cent.

Engineer officers aboard vessels of the Isthmian Steamship Lines have won additional paid vacations and premium wage increases in a contractual wage reopening, Wilbur Dickey, president of the Brotherhood of Marine Engineers, A. F. L., said yesterday. The union has a two-year contract with Isthmian expiring on Sept. 30, 1954.

GREAT NECK, L. I., Sept. 17 -Mrs. Bernard Freeman of Inwood scored a 3-over-par 40, 37 -- 77 at the Fresh Meadow course today in the second round of the women's Cross County Golf Association championship. This, with her first round of 84 at Glen Oaks yesterday for a thirty-six-hole total of 161, placed her second, five strokes behind Roslyn Swift of Glen Oaks.

When so much attention is being directed these days New York's numerous ills it may be mildly comforting to be reminded that many of them are not new. Perhaps they are bigger ills than they were, say a half-century ago, and their very size may make them seem appalling, but not a few of today's troubles are much like those that plagued the city of yesterday.

BERLIN, Sept. 17 -- Anti-Communist incendiarism has forced the near-by city of Potsdam, the headquarters of the Soviet Army in Germany, to strengthen its patrols of the People's Police, the Potsdam newspaper Maerkische Volksstimme reported today.

The Public Service Commission ordered yesterday a hearing on Oct. 5 to establish more uniform rates for the Long Island Lighting Company and suggested a tentative plan that would provide a 3 per cent increase in consumers' electric rates.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 17 -- Dag Hammarskjold, Secretary General of the United Nations, tonight submitted a report to members of the General Assembly on his communications with Communist China and North Korea regarding the composition of the proposed Korean peace conference.
BONN, Germany, Sept. 17 -- Die Welt, one of West Germany's most influential newspapers was sold by the office of the British High Commissioner in Germany today.

PARIS, Sept. 17 -- Georges Bidault, Foreign Minister, strove hard today to break the deadlock in the Cabinet on the pending European Defense Community Treaty by reaching a compromise with the former Gaullist Ministers on the European political community linked with the treaty.

A 74-year-old man lost his life yesterday in Queens when a chemical plant explosion next door apparently blew him from the roof of his house into the burning factory. Four other persons were slightly injured by the blast.

The Community Church of New York, the Stephen Wise Free Synagogue and the American Civil Liberties Union issued statements yesterday demanding that Congress adopt a code of fair procedures to prevent the publication of irresponsible testimony" before the Un-American Activities Committee of the House of Representatives.

Major Francis W. Sutherland, who is not the man to miss a cue, had his Seventh Regiment band play some Irish music after the running of the feature race at Aqueduct yesterday. Begorra won it, and Charles Albert O'Brien rode the 4-year-old colt.

The Grover Loening estate on-Crescent Beach Road in Glen Cove, L. I., has been purchased for investment by Joseph K. Alliger and Hyman Ratner, president and treasurer of the Sterling Investing Corporation. Julius Schnapper was attorney for the buyers and David C. Bennett acted for the seller.

NEWARK, Sept. 17 -- Fifteen neon - lighted signs with interchangeable legends to warn motorists of approaching traffic hazards will be installed by the New Jersey Turnpike Authority within a few days in an augmented program to minimize hazards on the northern stretch of the 118-mile express highway.
LONDON, Sept. 17 -- British Government securities soared today after the announcement that the Bank of England had reduced the bank rate from 4 to 3 1/2 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -- The Federal Civil Defense Administration made public today a list of seventy cities and localities it considers "critical target areas" The agency declared they were the "most probable targets for atomic attack."

Reflecting the record volume of sales attained by McKesson Robbins, Inc., in its fiscal year ended on June 30, the consolidated net income increased to $7,029,203 from $6,634,360 earned in the preceding fiscal year.

STRASBOURG, France, Sept. 17 (AP) -- Paul-Henri Spaak of Belgium declared today that rejection of the European Defense Comm/mity Treaty would be a tacit invitation to the Soviet Union to occupy all West Europe.

Samuel Reshevsky, United States, and Vassily Smyslov, Russia, who are running one-two in the world chess championship challengers' tournament in Zurich, both drew their respective adjourned games last night as eight unfinished matches from the ninth, tenth and eleventh rounds were played off, according to a Swiss news report.
VIENNA, Sept. 17 (AP) -- A campaign against Jews that flared throughout Communist Eastern Europe in 1952 has been secretly reopened in Rumania and Czechoslovakia, usually reliable sources said today.

Last but not least in the group of New York stores offering French and Italian imports and Americanmade copies, Ohrbach's yesterday presented a collection of twentynine originals and adaptations that far excelled both in workmanship and selection any such group previously shown by this store.

Business borrowings from New York banks registered the largest increase on record during the week ended on Wednesday, advancing $175,000,000 to reach a total of $8,559,000,000. The increase, however, followed a decline of $14,000,000 in the previous week, so that the net expansion of $161,000,000 in the two-week period compares with a gain of $228,000,000 a year ago.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -- With overnight mail deliveries throughout the country as a goal, serious Congressional study is being given to a proposal to institute a 5-cent expedited first-class mail service between cities.

Dr. German Arciniegas, writer, historian and educator, who was taken to Ellis Island for "security questioning" Wednesday evening when he arrived here from Paris, was released yesterday morning without being questioned by Immigration authorities.

Yom Kippur, or the Day of Atonement, will be observed by Jews throughout the world beginning at sundown tonight and ending at sunset tomorrow. Revered as the holiest day of the Jewish calendar, Yom Kippur closes ten days of penitence and "spiritual inventory" that began on Rosh ha-Shanah, the Jewish New Year.

These days when fearless, intelligent and kindly citizen leadership in community affairs is so much needed, it was a delight to us at Community Service Society to read your editorial of Sept. 12 in tribute to Lawson Purdy on his ninetieth birthday. For fifteen years he was the well-known and able leader of the C. S. S., serving as its general director from 1918 to 1933.

Louis Waldman, veteran labor lawyer, who quit two weeks ago as attorney for the wage policy committee of the crime-infested International Longshoremen's Association, A. F. L., urged yesterday that the American Federation of Labor adopt a code of ethics for all unions and set up a committee to interpret and enforce it.

Once more we have seen a case where the working of the reprehensible McCarran Act has injured a distinguished foreigner and humiliated all Americans who see their own traditions of democracy violated by fellow-Americans. The detention at Ellis Island on Wednesday of Prof. German Arciniegas of Columbia University was a disturbing event.
Most perishable foods rise in price this week. The return of cooler weather has revived consumer appetites and increased demand.

CHICAGO, Sept. 17 (AP) -- As livestock continued the heavy flow to market today, hogs were steady to 25 cents a hundredweight up and cattle were mostly steady. Lambs and yearling sheep, however, toppled as much as 50 cents to $1.50 from the three-week highs reached yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -- Attorney General Herbert Brownell Jr. told the eighth annual National Conference on Citizenship today that the international situation was "an impelling reminder that freedom must be safeguarded."

ROME, Sept. 17 -- Though he called attention to the "terrible physical and moral consequences of overindulgence" Pope Pius XII said that wine was "an excellent thing" and that its alimentary and hygienic qualities deserved to be underlined.

THE bluefish seem to have lingered in local waters despite the "cool snap" and the rough seas, and even the bonito and albacore are being taken in fair numbers by boats out of New Jersey and western Long Island ports.

ANKARA, Turkey, Sept. 17 -- President Celal Bayar of Turkey will make a state visit to Washington Jan. 27 to 29 at President Eisenhower's invitation, it was announced here today. Mr. Bayar's visit will be the first to the United States by a Turkish chief of state.

Both Secretary of Agriculture Benson and the White House deny, according to news dispatches from Denver, that they know anything about reports that Mr. Benson "is being forced to resign in the continuing controversy over farm policy and falling farm prices."

The fourth annual Musical Talent in Our Schools series, sponsored jointly by radio station WQXR and THE NEW YORK TIMES, will begin auditions early next month to determine the participants for the broadcast series scheduled for next April and May.

At least the New York Football Giants "is" not dead. Coach Steye Owen's refurbished squad staged an eye-popping show for 22,551 spectators at the Polo Grounds last night in downing the San Francisco Forty-Niners, 28 -- 21, in a National Football League exhibition game played for the benefit of the Hearst Milk Fund.

DENVER, Sept. 17 -- The "rights" of Communist orators in public parks are governed by the Fourteenth Amendment to the Constitution, the Convention of the American Institute of Park Executives was told today.

SUDBURY, Ont., Sept. 17 (Canadian Press) -- The International Nickel Company announced today a trail-blazing project calling for production of by-product iron ore from nickel ores mined in the Sudbury district.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 17 -- Dick Thornburg, managing editor of Scripps-Howard Newspaper Alliance in Washington since 1945, has been appointed editor of The Cincinnati Post, a Scripps-Howard afternoon paper.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -- Feminine backing is massing behind Miss Mary H. Donlon, chairman of the New York State Workmen's Compensation Board, for the post of Secretary of Labor, made vacant by the resignation of Martin P. Durkin.

Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein's investigation into the alleged stuffing of a Brooklyn ballot box in the Impellitteri-Wagner Democratic primary contest on Tuesday night began yesterday with the questioning of four witnesses.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 (AP) -Bob Porterfield became the first Washington pitcher in twenty years to twenty-one games tonight when the Senators defeated the White Sox, 3 -- 2. The victory was Porterfield's eleventh in his last twelve starts.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 17 -- The General Assembly took the first step today toward planning for possible revision of the United Nations Charter adopted at San Francisco eight years ago.
MOSCOW, Friday, Sept. 18 -- The Soviet Union announced today that it had successfully tested some "new types" of atomic bombs in recent weeks.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 17 -Continuing his forceful tactics, Arthur B. Bisguier of New York defeated Dr. Ariel Mengarini, New York, former national amateur champion, in the challengers' tournament of the United States Chess Federation at the Hotel Adelphia, today, and thereby kept his lead over the field of twenty-three.

BOSTON, Sept. 17 (UP) -- Ted William hit a two-run homer, his thirteenth circuit drive of the season and his team's 100th, as the Red Sox beat the Tigers, 2 -- 1, to close their final series of the year today before Fenway Park's smallest crowd of the season, 2,272.

In Peter Kihss' articles about New York City he emphasized the shameful neglect of buildings and properties. As he said, New York is spending millions of dollars a year for new capital improvements, yet it fails to provide for even the bare essentials of maintenance.
A classic collection of custom made clothes, marked by feminine allure, was presented to the press yesterday by Oldric Royce in his custom salon at 16 East Fifty-second Street.

Any industrial and stock market recession in this country is apt to last longer but to cut less deeply than most observers expect, Ragnar D. Naess, investment counsel, said yesterday before the New York Society of Security Analysts.

The senseless slaughter in Korea has ceased and there is now quiet on the Korean front. If it is to have any meaning for the hopes of the plain millions of the world, the hates and fears deliberately promoted by those remote from the dangers of the battlefield for the purpose of creating a war psychosis must be displaced by returning sanity and reason.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 17 -- No representatives of the Soviet bloc, not even of the Soviet Union, whose newly appointed Ambassador has been here more than a month, have been invited to attend Yugoslavia's biggest postwar military maneuvers, whose opening phase began in the Zagreb area today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon disclosed today that the fundamental purpose of his forthcoming mission through the Far East was "to discover, to anticipate and to reduce" points of latent friction with the United States.
Secretary of State John Foster Dulles, in a dinner address in honor of Crown Prince Akihito of Japan, pressed once again last night for greater Japanese efforts to build defense forces.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., Sept. 17 -Governor Dewey declared tonight that the election of President Eisenhower had marked the turning point in the "cold war" against communism and had "probably saved the world from catastrophes which I hesitate even to contemplate."

ROGERS HORNSBY has been relieved of his duties as manager of the Cincinnati Redlegs and the suspicion grows that the finest right-handed batsman ever to play ball is through with the major leagues for keeps. Ousted by the St. Louis Browns last year and cut loose by the Redlegs this year, he obviously is too hot a potato to handle.

The arbitration award that is imminent, providing hour and wage changes for private-line bus employes as a result of the month-long strike last January, will provide a politically troublesome test for members of the Board of Estimate. Tax or fare relief or both seems an inescapable companion to fulfillment of this arbitration award.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission denied today an application by Commercial Barge Lines, Inc., of Detroit, engaged primarily in transporting automobiles by barge, for the right to carry general commodities over 5,500 miles of the Mississippi River system, its tributaries and connecting waterways.

Amid all the hosannahs of praise and thanks now emerging from Communist China over the "generous and brotherly economic aid" extended by the Soviet Union the observant reader of this material will note some strange phrases. Mao Tse-tung has declared that this aid will permit China to build up her own industry "step by step" while avoiding "twists and turns in the course of China's economic construction.''

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Sept. 17 -- The representatives of Britain and France came before the International Court of Justice here today with their amiable dispute involving the sovereignty of the two little known and hardly noticeable collections of reefs, rocks and miniscule islands in the English Channel known as Minquiers and Ecrehou.

WELL, it's over. The "live" television debut of Marilyn Monroe has come and gone, and now there's nothing left to do but go back to work. It even looks as if life and television may continue pretty much the same.

Better control of merchandising costs and greater efficiency of operations, enabled Gimbel Brothers, Inc., in the six months ended on July 31, last, to increase earnings 170 per cent over the corresponding period a year ago, although sales were only 0.5 per cent higher.

In an atmosphere heavily charged with politics, the Board of Estimate killed yesterday a resolution offered by City Council President Rudolph Halley calling for appointment of a committee, financed by a $5,000 appropriation, to study and prepare an adequate housing program for all income groups.

Today's new film is "Mission Over Korea," a Columbia war drama featuring John Hodiak, John Derek, Audrey Totter and Maureen O'Sullivan, at the Palace Theatre. Fred F. Sears directed and Robert Cohn produced, from a screen play Jesse L. Lasky Jr., Eugene Ling and Martin M. Goldsmith adapted from a story by Richard Tregaskis.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., Sept. 17 -- The peak of the attacks and criticism, leveled against the United Nations Educational, Scientific land Cultural Organization in recent years has passed in this country and elsewhere in the world, Dr. Luther H. Evans, Director General of the Organization, declared here today.

An 18-year-old part-time messenger boy with an obsession for Indian folklore and tradition was held in $2,500 bail yesterday in Felony Court Youth Term, charged with the theft of priceless Indian objects from the American Museum of Natural History.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., Sept. 17 -- Ridden by Billy Steinkraus; the Fairview Farm's 6-year-old skiebald gelding Ping Pong from Greenwich, Conn., took the top prize in the first section of the William S. Blitz Memorial Trophy event for jumpers as the forty-eighth annual Piping Rock horse show opened today.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 17 -Delegates to the fifty-second annual convention of the National Association of Supervisors of State Banks were told today that banks should be prepared to act in the event of a business recession.

The American Museum of Safety, hailing 1952 as "the best safety year in railroad history," presented last night fourteen E. H. Harriman memorial awards -- three gold medals and eleven certificates of commendation -- to fourteen railroads for their safety performances last year.

BONN, Germany, Sept. 17 -- A formal demand from trade union members of the victorious Christian Democratic Union for greater representation in the leadership of the West German Trade Union Federation was handed to Walter Freitag, the federation's president, in Duesseldorf today.

The possibility of a shutdown of the important ferry service between St George, S. I., and Sixty-ninth Street, Brooklyn, was posed this week when the Board of Estimate was informed that the operators of the line did not intend to renew their franchise with the city next year.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -- James C. Hagerty, President Eisenhower's press secretary, has made a bold and perhaps a rash move in the growing political controversy with the Democrats. He has thrown the first Shakespearean quote of the campaign, directly at Adlai E. Stevenson, himself an old acquaintance of the bard.

Bankers in this country, who have bitter arguments with their consciences whenever they are asked to finance foreign trade for terms longer than ninety days, must look with wonder on the lengths to which foreign countries are willing to go to clinch export sales.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Sept. 17 (Reuters) -- Premier Erik Eriksen of Denmark was badly shaken but otherwise uninjured today when a small plane in which he was to fly to Copenhagen from Randers, Jutland, crashed while taking off. The plane was badly damaged.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 (UP) -Roman Catholics throughout the United States will be asked Dec. 6 to help raise $8,000,000 to complete a religious edifice here.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 17 (AP) --The Wimbledon champion, Vic Seixas of Philadelphia, and Lewis Hoad of Australia gained the semifinals of the Pacific Southwest tennis tournament today.

SPRING LAKE, N. J., Sept. 17 -- Sam Kinder of Plainfield and Ed Havelka of Galloping Hill defeated Jerry Volpe of Forsgate and Jim DiStasio of Englewood, 1 up, in twenty-one holes today to gain the semi-final round of the New Jersey P. G. A. pro-pro best ball championship.

BONN, Germany, Sept. l7 -- Dr. Konrad Adenauer, West German Chancellor, has proposed to President Eisenhower that Germans and Americans should cooperate this winter in sending clothes and shoes to the East Germans, who are now receiving gifts of food from the West.

I was in prison in Czechoslovakia for over two years and I can tell you this: Living in that prison is like being buried alive. A cell there is like a tomb. And the inmate is like a man in Purgatory -- he is waiting and his problem is to get through time.
William J. Heckman has been appointed director of purchases of the Mathieson Chemical Corporation, Baltimore, Md.

Officers of the American Institute of Steel Construction and of Cooper Union unveiled yesterday a stainless steel plaque commemorating the 100th anniversary of the laying of the school's cornerstone -- wherever it is.

CHICAGO, Sept. 17 -- The present technical character of the wheat trade was shown by the sudden nosedive in prices after midday yesterday with quotations dropping as much as 5 cents a bushel in a few minutes. No news of consequence was available to explain the setback except vague talk of a proposed "two-price" system.

Julius Reiss, a United States citizen employed as a document clerk by the Polish delegation to the United Nations, was identified yesterday by Paul Crouch, former Communist functionary, as a "professional revolutionist" who had held many Communist party offices throughout this country.

New issues of public utility securities totaling more than $22,000,000 will be offered to investors today. The issuing companies, Louisiana Power and Light Company and New York State Electric and Gas Association, will use money raised by the sale to retire short-term debt and to finance construction.
CHICAGO, Sept. 17 (UP) -- The Phillies slashed eighteen hits off five Chicago pitchers today for a 16-to-4 triumph to close their season with the Cubs with seventeen victories in twenty-two games.

The largest single cauliflowergrowing area in the country flourishes almost in the backyard of NewYorkers. On the eastern end of Long Island, around Riverhead, some 5,500 acres of the prettiest member of the cabbage clan started yielding their harvest last week for vegetable lovers from Miami to Montreal and from Dallas to Winnipeg.
NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 17 (AP) -- Eight surgeons participated in an operation that separated Louisiana's Siamese twins today, and a doctor said that the odds "look good" that both would survive.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 17 -- Turkey and Poland both have announced their candidacy for a seat in the eleven-member United Nations Security Council claimed by the Soviet bloc as its political right.
ERNEST C. C. MILLER seems to be the poor man's Thomas Edison of the city.

DENVER, Sept. 17 -- The President went fishing today with Judge Orie L. Phillips, Chief Judge of the Tenth Federal Circuit Court of Appeals in Denver, who has been mentioned as one of those who are being considered for nomination as Chief Justice of the United States.

A total of $164,000 was paid in the last three and a half years to labor relations consultants who acted as "trouble-shooters" at the Yonkers Raceway, Atwood C. Wolf Sr., vice president and treasurer of the Yonkers Trotting Association, said yesterday at the opening of hearings into employment practices at the harness-racing track.

The fact that there is even a handful of American prisoners in Korea who do not wish repatriation poses some peculiar problems. We have never faced a situation of this sort before and everything that we do is, in effect, an improvisation. It is therefore desirable that we act and think with unusual caution.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -- Dr. Samuel M. Brownell, brother of the Attorney General, Herbert Brownell Jr., is likely to be appointed United States Commissioner of Education to succeed to the post left vacant by Lee M. Thurston, who took the office on July 2 and died of a heart attack Sept. 4.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 16 (UP) -Rogers Hornsby, whose record as a manager never matched his success as a hitter, lost a managerial job today for the sixth time in his turbulent career when the Redlegs dismissed him.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 17 -- A ninthinning two-run single by Wayne Belardi today gave the Dodgers that coveted one hundredth victory of the season and Carl Erskine his twentieth as the Cardinals went down to a 4-3 defeat before 9,363 fans at Busch Stadium.

Robert G. Thompson, convicted Communist party leader who was captured by Federal Bureau of Investigations agents in a California Sierra hideout several weeks ago, was brought here last night by United States marshals and lodged in the Federal House of Detention, 427 West Street.

Mayor Impellitteri said yesterday that he was "still considering" running for re-election as the candidate of the independent Experience party, on which he was elected in 1950. The concensus, even among close friends, was that difficulty in financing a campaign would bar his independent candidacy.

" Conversation With the Earth," an autobiography by the geologist Hans Cloos, will be issued Monday by Knopf. In telling of his life, Mr. Cloos describes his travels and gives details of the data he accumulated about mountains, plains, deserts, jungles and the soil and water. The publisher describes the book as "a record of the secrets of the earth."

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 17 -- Harvard football, once the finest played anywhere but in the doldrums for too many years, has been showing encouraging signs of recovery under the aegis of Coach Lloyd Jordan and Tom Bolles, athletic director.

The Public Service Commission ended hearings yesterday on a petition of the Consolidated Edison Company for permission to introduce natural gas in the Astoria and Long Island City areas of Queens, where manufactured gas is now used. The hearings were held in the commission offices at 233 Broadway.

SARANAC LAKE, N. Y., Sept. 18 -- Governor Dewey made a plea today for support by business and industry of his program for state development of the hydroelectric power resources of Niagara Falls. He said his plan for public generation and private distribution of the power would "preserve private enterprise at its best."

GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 18 -- A record $9,699,990 municipal budget, which provides for the final $35,000 payment on the town's bonded indebtedness and authorizes $3,088,350 in capital improvements, has been drafted for 1954 by the Board of Estimate and Taxation's budget committee.

LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., Sept. 18 -- The Lakelawn Farm's 5-year-old chestnut gelding Little Trip from Syracuse, scored 12 points with Ed Daniels riding to win the green working hunter championship during the second day of the forty-eighth annual Piping Rock Horse Show today.

TOKYO, Saturday, Sept. 19 -- The Communists transferred to the United Nations at Panmunjom, Korea, today twelve South Korean prisoners of war and one Turkish captive who had changed their minds about not returning to their homelands.

THE average American hunter does not seem to realize that advances have been made in hunting attire as well as in guns, for he will make a heavy investment in a new shotgun or rifle, then clump around in discomfort in clothing and boots similar in design and material to those worn by his grandfather.

OTTAWA, Sept. 18 -- A somewhat, cryptic remark by Prime Minister Louis S. St. Laurent at a press conference caused some speculation today regarding the political future of Lester B. Pearson, Secretary of State for External Affairs.

SYRACUSE, Sept. 18 -- Kid Gavilan encountered the most stubborn and unlooked-for opposition in the defense of his welterweight championship of the world against Carmen Basilio of near-by Canastota tonight. The Cuban from Camaguey gained the decision all right, after fifteen rounds of torrid battling, but the award was a split one and was unpopular with the bitterly partisan crowd.
DENVER, Sept. 18 (UP) -- The White House today announced detailed plans for President Eisenhower's visit next Monday to Springfield, Mass., and Boston.

An official of the Yonkers Raceway testified yesterday that $6,000,000 in potential mutuel bets was "lost" by the track within a three-year period owing to the slowness and inefficiency of clerks hired at the instigation of Thomas F. Lewis, the labor union leader who was slain on Aug. 28.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 (AP) -- Donald Wallace Leach, president of the Sterling Silversmiths Guild of America, announced his support today of a bill to halt forced purchasing of silver by the United States Treasury.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 18 -- Following is the text of a message the United States has requested Sweden to transmit to the Chinese Communists and North Koreans and copies of which were handed to Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold with a request that he circulate it to members of the United Nations:

The first concrete evidence on the effect of the new substitution rule will be filed today with the springing of the barrier on the 1953 college football season. There are close to 100 games on the national slate, a surprising number of which are full-blown major contests.

WASHINGTON, Sept 18 -- Craig R. Sheaffer, a key member of the "business man's team" with which Sinclair Weeks, Secretary of Commerce, has surrounded himself, has resigned as Assistant Secretary in charge of domestic affairs. Mr. Sheaffer, a fountain pen manufacturer, is expected to become chairman of the board of the company that bears his name.

ARDSLEY-ON-HUDSON, N. Y., Sept. 18 -- Mrs. Harold Masback of Sunningdale scored 41, 46 -- 87 at the Ardsley Country Club today and won the gross prize in the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association Class B tournament by a stroke.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 18 -- Top leaders of the American Federation of Labor have decided to set up a new dock union to carry on a war of extinction against the crime-enshrouded International Longshoremen's Association.

A detailed and documented study of how Jews are faring behind the Iron Curtain was published this week by the Syracuse University Press. Titled "The Jews In The Soviet Satellites," its authors are Peter Meyer, Bernard D. Weinryb, Eugene Duschinsky and Nicholas Sylvian.

DENVER, Colo., Sept. 18 -- President Eisenhower assured Dr. Ernst Reuter, Mayor of West Berlin, today that the United States was ready to explore means of alleviating unemployment in the Western sector.
PORTSMOUTH, N. H., Sept. 18 -- Textiles, the window through which most outsiders peer at the New England economy, were described today as being on the road to a new era of stability.
LIMA, Peru, Sept. 18 -- The Peruvian Government will keep its currency sound through a program of economies but will not cripple the public works program in doing so, it has assured the nation.

EDMONTON, Alberta, Sept. 18 (AP) -- A "battle royal" is going on behind the scenes to determine the price of wheat, H. G. L. Strange of Winnipeg said today. Mr. Strange is director of the research department of the Searle Grain Company.

Abraham Unger, a lawyer of 11 Park Place, was forcibly ejected yesterday from a Federal courtroom here by order of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, for "filibustering" instead of answering the Senator's questions.

Upward of 100 judges from all parts of the state have written to the Temporary State Commission on the Courts emphasizing four areas where court procedure is in need of improvement, the commission announced yesterday.

Millard L. Midonick, attorney and vice president of the New York Young Democratic Club, and Mrs. Margot Gayle, freelance writer, have been chosen by the new Democratic committeemen in the Gramercy Park section of the First Assembly District to become the Democratic leader and co-leader, respectively, of the district.

LONDON, Sept. 18 -- Combine harvesters that sift sea water may eventually crop the oceans for their valuable protein and carbohydrate sources of phytoplankton or minute plant-like marine organisms, according to biologists present here today at a symposium on the sea at the Royal Geographical Society.

The Washington Water Power Company reported yesterday for the first eight months this year. Net income of $4,421,950, equal to $1.14 a share on 2,342,41l common shares. In the corresponding period last year, the net was $2,747,088 or $1.11 a common share.

BERLIN, Sept. 18 -- In the most bellicose statement from East Germany since the inauguration of the Communists' moderate "new course" policy in June, Walter Ulbricht, first secretary of the party, has threatened West Germany with destruction if it launches a war against the East.
The country's flag manufacturing industry, with offices and showrooms on or near Fifth Avenue from Twenty-third Street south, is watching the news from Washington anxiously these days.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Sept. 18 -- Senator William F. Knowland, Republican majority leader from California, gave his full support today to the Eisenhower Administration's move to give France an additional $385,000,000 to help prosecute the war in Indo-China.

PARIS, Sept. 18 -- The meeting of American Ambassadors being held this week-end in Luxembourg is ostensibly just a routine affair. Such conferences are called from time to time to bring United States diplomats in a given area together to pool information and exchange views.

WATERTOWN, N. Y., Sept. 18 (AP) -- Clellan S. Forsythe, 58 years old, a Syracuse automobile dealer and former State assemblyman, died of a shotgun wound on a Lake Ontario island today, and a coroner's physician said his death was accidental.
The six-story building accommodating thirty families at 1815 Beverly Road in Brooklyn has been sold by Jules Tucker to an investing customer of Lane Realty, .Harry Sankin was the broker.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- Protestants and Other Americans United for Separation of Church and State reported today that Roman Catholic leaders in three South American countries had asked Dr. Milton S. Eisenhower to use his influence to "put a damper" on "propaganda and proselytizing" there by Protestant missionaries.

Prize plaques were presented yesterday to the winners of the second annual port tugboat races, held last Saturday on the Hudson River. The awards were made at the New York Towboat Exchange, 17 Battery Place, to the first three boats in each of four classes.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 18 -- Saul Wachs of Philadelphia suffered his first defeat in the challengers' tournament of the United States Chess Federation, losing to Arthur B. Bisguier of New York in the seventh round today at the Hotel Adelphia.

TRENTON, Sept. 18 -- The New Jersey Racing Commission today rejected applications that would have resulted in the establishment of a running track at Secaucus and a trotting track in Springfield Township, Burlington County. The agency advanced no reason for its action, which was taken at an otherwise routine meeting of the group at the Atlantic City track.

CHICAGO, Sept. 18 -- Erratic fluctuations prevailed in the grain markets today, especially in wheat, which had several sharp declines, but met enough support to cause a stronger tendency in the late trade. Evening-up of various spreads between September deliveries and other futures accounted for much of an active trade.

After three days of gradually diminishing gains, the stock market turned around in deliberate fashion yesterday and wiped out more than a third of the three-day gains. THE NEW YORK TIMES' combined average sank 1.14 points to 165.70 in a day that saw the rails weaker than the industrials and oils the softest section of the list.

Directors of Industrial Brownhoist Corporation yesterday turned down a proposal giving the Pennsylvania Coal and Coke Corporation permission to borrow $350,000 from the company. The directors also canceled $100,000 in yearly salaries previously authorized for four representatives of Pennsylvania Coal and Coke who had been named officers of the company.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Sept. 18 (AP) -- A retired 84-year-old Navy captain, who directed the eight-inch guns that severely damaged the old Spanish cruiser Reina Mercedes during the Spanish-American war, has finally got around to visiting his conquest of fifty-five years ago.
