Score a resounding success for Frederick Ashton, whose new ballet, "Homage to the Queen," had its New York premiere last night at the Metropolitan Opera House at the hands of the Sadler's Wells Ballet. Produced originally in celebration of the coronation of Elizabeth II, it is far more than a dutiful gesture to a newly enthroned monarch; it is an exciting work of art, sumptuous, elegant, sensitive and extraordinarily creative.

WEST ORANGE, N. J., Sept. 18 -- Stanley Calder shot a 34, 33 -- 67 on his own ball today but required help on two holes from Mrs. Philip Cudone, also of Montclair, to tie with two other teams for net honors in the Women's New Jersey Golf Association one-day best-ball tournament over the Rock Spring Club course.
DARIEN, Conn., Sept. 18 -- The successes of Ch. Blakeen Bali Ha'i in the Interstate Poodle Club specialty continued today.
Solemnly and reverently, Jews over the world began last night at sundown the sacred observance of Yom Kippur, holiest day of the Hebrew calendar.

Harris J. Klein, one of the five members of the New York City Transit Authority, yesterday accused Michael J. Quill, international president of the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., of fostering featherbedding and waste that cost the city-owned transit lines $12,000,000 a year.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 (UP) -- The Post Office Department's experiment in sending regular first class mail by air probably will start by Oct. 1, a Civil Aeronautics Board spokesman said today.

Under the Federal Refugee Relief Act of 1953 a total of 214,000 non-quota immigrants will be admitted to the United States. The Hebrew Sheltering and Immigrant Aid Society, better known as HIAS, faces a challenge soon when the immigration flow starts out of the Old World.

CHICAGO, Sept. 18 (AP) -- More than 100,000 head of livestock went through the sales alleys at the stockyards this week; yet, except for lambs, most prices were steady to higher as compared with week-ago levels.

WESTBURY, L. I., Sept. 18 -- Billy Haughton tonight became the first driver to sweep the daily double at Roosevelt Raceway this year, bringing in a 2-1 combination for a $17.70 payoff. Haughton won behind Counsel Pick at $5.40 in the first race and Peter Campbell at $5.70 in the second race.

The maritime ghost of the old Fall River Line will be revived briefly today, when the Wilson Line excursion boat Boston Belle puts into a West Forty-second Street berth after having traversed the exact route of the famous New England steamboat company through Narragansett Bay and Long Island Sound.

LONDON, Sept. 18 (AP) -- Scotland Yard arrested four men today and charged them with plotting the bizarre "Francasal affair," Britain's $1,000,000 betting fix. Detectives identified two as racehorse owners and two as bookmakers.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Sept. 18 -- Leaflets said to have been printed in Moscow and Peiping have been given to the Northern Rhodesian Government by a native African official who reported that the booklets were being distributed among natives of Northern Rhodesia. The police are investigating.

School officials, while still trying to figure out what happened to the 200 newly appointed teachers who failed to report to class on Monday, had a new problem on their hands yesterday: The famine had turned into a feast.

The State of Washington may issue up to $200,000,000 of revenue bonds over the next several years to finance the building of three bridges and a freeway, Gov. Arthur B. Langlie said yesterday at a luncheon meeting of the Municipal Forum of New York at the Lawyers Club yesterday.

Roslyn (Cookie) Swift of Glen Oaks added a one-under-par 35, 37 -- 72 yesterday to her thirty-six-hole tally of 156 for a grand total of 228 on the North Hills course to win the women's Cross County golf title for the third time.

When Arthur Kull, the New Jersey schoolteacher, resigned from his $85 a week job this summer to become a $137.50-a-week truck driver we were all given a shock of a lesson in everyday economics. Similar incidents are bound to occur until something is done about the plight of the teacher in this country.

LONDON, Sept. 18 (UP) -- The Communist radio charged today that Francis Cardinal Spellman tried during World War II to persuade the United States and Britain to join forces with Nazi Germany for an attack on Russia.

GENEVA, Sept. 18 -- Dr. Ludwig Erhard, West German Minister of Economics, urged the governments of the non-Communist world today to delay no longer in establishing an economic order consistent with freedom to govern their relations with one another.

Trading continued dull yesterday on the New York commodity exchanges. Prices closed irregular with coffee, cocoa, lead, tin and rubber higher, with potatoes, burlap, zinc and hides lower, and sugar, cottonseed oil, soybean oil, copper and wool mixed.

ROME, Sept. 17 -- Premier Giuseppe Pella's Cabinet approved today a wide amnesty for both political and non-political crimes. The bill is expected to be approved by Parliament, which meets again next week.
After a general holiday yesterday, major league baseball today will resume the process of playing out the string leading to the assured world series rematch between the Yankees and the Dodgers.

Seven counties and nine cities in the civil defense "support area" north of New York City will take part in the public participation atomic bomb exercise next Friday from 9:30 to 9:45 A. M., when sirens will sound on the "red alert," warning the public to take shelter.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Sept. 18 -- Prime Minister Daniel F. Malan embarked today on his fourth attempt to remove voters of mixed blood, called colored, from the white electoral register in Cape Province and give them limited and separate representation by white members of Parliament.

LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., Sept. 18 -- More than 200 members of the Piping Rock Club gave dinner parties this evening at the club before the horse show ball, also held at the club. Mrs. Clarence C. Pell Jr. of Old Westbury, who was chairman of the ball committee, and Mr. Pell were among the dinner hosts.

The investigation of the stuffing of a Brooklyn ballot box in Tuesday's Democratic primary election was delayed yesterday when a man described by State Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein as a "key witness" failed to appear for questioning.

The Garrett Corporation, whose operations are closely allied with those of the aviation, machine tool and hardware industries, achieved record sales and earnings in the fiscal year ended last June, the annual report disclosed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 (UP) -- Maj. Gen. Lewis B. Hershey, Selective Service director, said tonight draft calls might go as high as 50,000 or 60,000 a month after next July 1. He made the statement on the Columbia Broadcasting System's radio program "Capitol Cloakroom."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 (AP) -- Counsel for Sac and Fox Indians sought today to show that the Government had wrongfully taken land from them more than 100 years ago and should pay them a fair price for it.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 (AP) -- Fred Saigh Jr., former St. Louis Cardinals' owner jailed on tax fraud charges, has appealed in Tax Court here against back tax and penalty claims of $398,357 against him and his wife.

HILLSIDE, N. J., Sept. 18 -- An alert housewife was credited by the police here today with rescuing a 2-year-old boy and his pet dog, Taffy, from the mainline tracks of the Lehigh Valley Railroad a few minutes before a fast passenger train roared by.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- A special Senate subcommittee established to investigate juvenile delinquency announced today that public hearings to study the problem were under consideration and that twenty cities, including New York, were "possible sites."

LONDON, Sept. 18 -- The United States cruiser Macon has been "successfully attacked" by a submarine of the Orange Navy, the commander of the Blue naval force radioed today from somewhere in the Atlantic.

CHICAGO, Sept. 18 -- More than 1,200 Republican women from eighteen Midwestern and Southern states today coupled cheers for President Eisenhower's performance with a demand by 700 of them that Congress enact promptly the Bricker amendment.

The ice in a homecoming drink was all that weather-beaten Capt. Ralph R. Curry thankfully had to contend with last night after his most dangerous assignment in six years of breaking open Arctic supply lines to the nation's far northern defense bases.

Thousands of country and city churches and synagogues will be scenes of traditional harvest festivals this fall as religious expressions of the mysteries of seed, soil and harvests. In the Judaeo-Christian tradition, the practice of heralding the ripening of crops goes back for centuries, beginning in the Jewish festivals associated with agriculture.
W. Randolph Burgess, Deputy United States Treasurer, expressed the view last night that the Government was "over the hump" on deficit financing.
Among this week's art exhibitions there is one of work by contemporary printmakers at Weyhe's that maintains the high standard set by this gallery in similar shows of the past.

PARIS, Sept. 18 -- The important Paris daily Le Monde, which usually is critical of United States foreign policy, noted today the "moderate tone" of the speech by John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, to the United Nations General Assembly yesterday.
Federal Judge Harold R. Medina expects to hand down next month his decision in the anti-trust trial of seventeen investment banking houses.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 18 -- In line with the new Hollywood idea that big subjects require equally big name personalities, Paramount has signed Jennifer Jones to co-star with Bing Crosby and William Holden in "The Country Girl."

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 18 -- Burma plans to ask for more forceful action by the United Nations to push for the withdrawal of Nationalist Chinese guerrillas from Burma's border provinces, a delegation spokesman said today.

SAIGON, Vietnam, Sept. 18 -- Nationalist elements in the Indo-Chinese State of Vietnam expressed disappointment today with the limits set upon the National Congress that will shortly be held under a decree issued by Bao Dai, the Chief of State, who now is in France.

CHICAGO, Sept. 18 -- Edward T. McCormick, president of the American Stock Exchange, New York City, today assailed forecasts of a depression and described the long-term business outlook as good. He also endorsed proposals for a Federal sales tax to offset decreases in revenue that will result from scheduled cuts in income taxes.

BONN, Germany, Sept. 18 -- After an intensive six-hour discussion today the Executive Committee of the West German Trade Union Federation decided to call the leaders of the federation's sixteen constituent unions together to consider a demand from members of the republic's majority party for greater representation in the federation's management.

Stockholders of the Raytheon Manufacturing Company, at their annual meeting yesterday at Waltham, Mass., approved an increase in the authorized common stock from 3,000,000 to 4,000,000 shares. Because of stock market conditions, said Charles F. Adams Jr., president, the management has dropped its plans to issue additional shares for the time being.
LUXEMBOURG, Sept. 18 (AP) -- United States envoys in Western Europe met here today for a study of Russian tactics to slow down West European unification.

JERSEY CITY, Sept. 18 -- The failure of a City Commissioner to appear as a witness at the Superior Court inquiry into this city's financial transactions resulted in an early adjournment of today's hearing before Chief Investigator Samuel L. Larner.

The International Monetary Fund has not lived up to some of its advance billing, but it has succeeded over the past eight years in carving out a very real place for itself in the world of international finance, and with each passing year it has built on the accumulated prestige of the preceding years.
OTTAWA, Sept. 18 -- An exhibit demonstrating how small houses can be made to look like spacious homes opened here this week at the Government-sponsored Design Center.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 18 -- Two members of the British Commonwealth -- Australia and New Zealand -- urged the Soviet Union today to show the world tangible proof of a change of heart.

Dr. Marek Stanislaw Korowicz, who arrived in the United States Monday as the first alternate member of the Polish delegation to the United Nations, yesterday asked for political asylum in the United States.

When the European conflict developed into the Second World War the neat little liner Excambion brought home a load of refugees, among the last Americans to escape from the Continent in a group. Capt. William W. Kuhne, already a veteran seafarer enriched by experience, philosophized on the changing seascape.
Two member firms of the New York Stock Exchange, Greiner Co. and D. J. Manheimer Co. plan to dissolve, on Oct. 12 and Sept 30, respectively.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- Shoes for walking on water were patented this week by Ludwig A. Geiger of New York. The inventor intends them not only for recreation but for rescue work and such military operations as bridge building and assault crossings.
Six new singers, all Americans, have been engaged for the fall season of the New York City Opera Company that will open on Oct. 8 at the City Center with a performance of Rossini's "La Cenerentola."
WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- Average primary market prices increased 0.4 per cent to 110.8 per cent of the 1947-49 base level in the week ended on Tuesday, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.
LONDON, Sept. 18 (AP) -- A private British group promoting East-West trade announced tonight that East Germany had offered to buy $1,400,000 worth of cotton and wool from Britain.
LONDON, Sept. 18 -- The all-around advance in security values that followed yesterday's cut in the bank rate continued today on a broad front. British Government securities again led the advance.

READING, Pa., Sept. 18 (UP) -- Jack Burke Jr., setting a blistering pace with an unofficial course record of 63, on his own ball, combined with three amateur partners to win the pro-amateur, best-ball golf tournament today at the Berkshire Country Club. The best-ball card was 55, seventeen strokes under par.

TROY, N. Y., Sept. 18 (AP) -- With Governor Dewey's endorsement, Representative Dean P. Taylor is slated to be elected chairman of the Republican State Committee Wednesday in Albany. The Troy lawyer and a member of Congress for ten years would succeed William L. Pfeiffer of Loudonville, who has announced his resignation to devote full time to business interests.
HAMILTON, Bermuda, Sept. 18 (AP) -- Bermuda had a new hurricane scare late today while mopping up after last night's beating from hurricane Edna, but it proved to be a false alarm.
Parents interested in sharing classroom activity with their children may still enroll for special parent-child courses to be given at local institutions.
LONDON, Sept. 18 (Reuters) -- Movie experts from all over the world were on hand here today for a congress that features no big names, no awards and no ballyhoo.

HARMON, N. Y., Sept. 18 -- Five locomotives that portray a capsule history of the New York Central Railroad from 1831 to the present are lined up at the railroad's shops here preparatory to moving to Grand Central Terminal, where they will be on exhibition from Tuesday through next Saturday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 (AP) -- Republican leaders reported today that Warren L. Stephenson, central figure in a Congressional "four percenter" investigation, had been quietly stripped of all his party roles.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- President Eisenhower now has under serious consideration a plan to provide free winter clothing to East Germans through private United States relief agencies.
Rush F. Carrier has been appointed assistant general sales manager of the eastern division of Tide Water Associated Oil Company.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Sept. 18 (UP) -- Little Mississippi Southern, perennial first-game "breather" for Alabama, rose up behind speedy Lauren Pepper tonight to stun the highly-rated Crimson Tide, 25 to 19, and start off the predicted "year of upsets."

HAMILTON, Ont., Sept. 18 (AP) -- A Canadian Federal mediator continued talks with four Great Lakes shipping companies here today in an attempt to ward off a threatened strike that could affect 3,000 seamen on 276 Great Lakes vessels.

The problem of the treatment of mental diseases is of such great public interest that a comment on Dr. Manfred Sakel's Viennese lecture (as reported by William L. Laurence in THE NEW YORK TIMES, Aug. 21) and on Dr. W. Eliasberg's remarks concerning shock and insulin therapy (NEW YORK TIMES, Aug. 27) may not be superfluous.

The man who drives a rivet and the farmer picking apples would work at top efficiency if they ate five or six meals a day, according to a report on the influence of food on work production reviewed by the Nutrition Foundation.

Within the last few weeks, the Consolidated Textile Company, Inc., increased its stock ownership in the Bates Manufacturing Company to 581,000 shares or the required one-third heretofore needed to call a special meeting. However, at a special board meeting on Thursday in Lewiston, Me., directors of Bates changed the by-laws so that a 40 per cent stock interest is required to call such a meeting.

Ready and willing to roll out with the regular equipment of Hook and Ladder Company 45 yesterday was a red truck two feet long with a four-foot ladder. A toy to members of the station at 413 West 181st Street, it was, however, about as good as the real thing to its owner, 4-year-old Gabe Farkas.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 18 -- One-fourth of the 14,000 banks in this country will disappear if the present rate of mergers and voluntary liquidations continues over the next quarter century, Richard H. Barry, specialist in finance to small business, said here today.

MONTREAL, Sept. 18 -- The Canadian Congress of Labor, representing 370,000 union workers, re-elected A. R. Mosher president today for his thirteenth term. In the final session of five days of deliberation the organization also adopted resolutions condemning the Canadian Government for its "do-nothing" policies in the face of an alleged crisis in the farm implement industry.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 18 -- The Roman Catholic Near East Welfare Association has urged the United Nations General Assembly to remember its "plighted word" and carry out the internationalization of Jerusalem first recommended by the Assembly in 1947.
Bowling Green and lower Broadway echoed again yesterday to the sound of stoutly shod Dutch feet, as they did 300 years ago when the city was a village and Manhattan a pastoral outpost of Holland.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- Representative Carl T. Curtis, Republican of Nebraska, said today that his subcommittee on Social Security probably would shy away from any recommendations for changes in the Social Security Act. The subcommittee, a unit of the Ways and Means Committee of the House of Representatives, will concentrate instead on "stating the facts," the chairman added.

Governors of the New York Stock Exchange and the American Stock Exchange have voted sweeping liberalizations in their trading rules in the interest of more liquid markets. The changes will take effect on Monday.

LINDEN, N. J., Sept. 18 -- Millions of gallons of gasoline and crude oil in storage tanks at the Bayway refinery of the Standard Oil Company here were imperiled today when petroleum products in a huge separator pit suddenly blazed up in the Tremley Point tank field, a few hundred feet from the New Jersey Turnpike.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 18 (UP) -- A Davis Cup atmosphere was injected into the Pacific Southwest tennis tournament today as the semi-final bracket was filled. The two leading United States and the two leading Australian players were left in the next-to-last round.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Sept. 18 -- Perhaps the most poignant Kol Nidre service in Israel tonight on the eve of Yom Kippur, the Jewish Day of Atonement, was held in the small farming village of Gedera in southern Judea.

ANDORRA, Sept. 18 (AP) -- President Vincent Auriol of France, acting as co-prince of this tiny Pyrenees nation, told the Andorra Government today that he no longer recognized its President and Vice President.

The efforts of the Laniel Government in Paris to cope with the vast problems it faces are almost painful to watch. There are the normal brilliance, good intentions and exemplary aims, but there is neither the unity nor the power to be effective.

There is no manner of doubt that New York is a wonderful town today -- and the process of making it more wonderful goes on apace and gets a lot of notice. But a witness of the changes that process produces sometimes finds most meaning in what is missing.

NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 18 (UP) -- Louisiana's Mouton babies, born as Siamese twins but separated yesterday by surgery, "rested well" today and doctors said their chances for survival increased with every hour.

SEOUL, Korea, Sept. 17 -- During the period of a little less than two months since the armistice was signed, the streets of Seoul have become so congested that traffic policemen, both men and women, have their hands full.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 18 (UP) -- Jack Hadley raced 58 yards for one touchdown and scored another on a 2-yard plunge tonight as Temple University opened its twenty-ninth football season with a 34-0 victory over Albright before 7,500 fans.

The British importation, "A Pin to See the Peepshow," has earned for itself the dubious distinction of being the shortest-lived presentation of the new Broadway season. It opened on Thursday at the Playhouse and failed to go beyond the initial performance after Nancy Davids, the producer, decided it was futile to continue the run in the face of a poor set of critical notices.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 (UP) -- Department of Agriculture officials predicted today that over-all farm prices would average this year less than parity, the legally defined "fair" level, for the first time since 1941.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 (UP) -- Four subsidiaries of the Columbia Gas System and two pipeline companies filed with the Federal Power Commission today proposed annual rate increases totaling about $2,898,000.

The distinguished Edward Arcaro, who spent the summer at the Chicago tracks, will resume operations on the New York racing circuit today. He'll ride Mrs. Ben F. Whitaker's Grecian Queen. the top-ranking 3-year-old filly, in the $50,000 added Beldame Handicap, the main event on Aqueduct's final 1953 program.

DENVER, Sept. 18 -- President Eisenhower completed today the membership of the Commission on Intergovernmental Relations that will review all mutual Federal, state and municipal programs with the aim of achieving economy and redefining lines of authority.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- The State Department has under discussion the advisability of joining European Allies in trying to assure the Soviet Union that the West's military build-up is designed solely for defense.

KYOTO, Japan, Sept. 18 -- India, whose standard of living for her swarming population has been very low through many centuries, is putting into effect a program capable of making giant strides forward by employing atomic energy.

BOSTON, Sept. 18 -- Advice to parents for the safety of children going to and coming from school was offered today by a spokesman for the Institute for Safer Living of the American Mutual Liability Insurance Company.
Some novel objects seen at the home furnishings show now at Grand Central Palace might be of interest to home makers:
DENVER, Sept. 18 -- President Eisenhower spent a busy time on affairs of state during his six-week vacation here.

SEOUL, Korea, Sept. 18 -- Russian and American jet fighter plane pilots in unit formations clashed repeatedly in the skies over North Korea during the last two and a half years of the Korean war, with indisputable proof of the Americans' superiority, Lieut. Gen. Samuel E. Anderson, commander of the Fifth Air Force, said today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 (UP) -- The television industry informed the Federal Communications Commission today that it would be able to demonstrate its new color TV system in New York Oct. 15. The commission had asked the industry-wide National Television System Committee to stage an extensive demonstration to support its assertion that the system was feasible and should be approved for general use.
Active futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed unchanged to 4 points up yesterday.
Ilmenite, the raw material used to make titanium metal and pigments, should be more plentiful by early 1955.

JAMESBURG, N. J., Sept. 18 -- With forty-three teams shooting some torrid golf over the Forsgate Country Club course, four teams tied for the medal with 66's as the J. Foster Abeel Memorial tournament got under way today. A 2-under-par 69 was needed to qualify.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- The Federal Trade Commission reversed today a stand it took five years ago and ruled that goods given without cost on the purchase of other merchandise might be advertised as "free."

DETROIT, Sept, 18 (AP) -- Car and truck output in the United States this week will total 138,272 units, Ward's Automotive Reports said today. The agency counted 115,078 cars and 23,194 trucks in the total.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Sept. 18 -- Gene Littler, blond-haired, 23-year-old Californian from La Jolla, a storekeeper on leave from the San Diego Naval Base, and Dale Morey of Indianapolis, 32-year-old holder of the Western amateur title, moved into the final round of the United States Golf Association's amateur championship at the Oklahoma City Golf and Country Club today.

Your editorial "Mr. Dewey an Highways" supports the Governor's policy of building highways on the sound basis of pay-as-we-go by charging tolls. In addition, you are in favor of the state borrowing large sums of money to make permanent highway improvements where toll-collecting is not feasible: this to be done by raising new taxes.

Aaron Levine. realty investor and owner 0f 101-45 Avenue of the Americas, has purchased the adjoining properSy at 1047-49 Avenue of the Americas and now controis a plot of 11,200 feet at the northwest corner of Thirty-ninth Street in an area that is fast beComing a textile center.

PARIS, Sept. 18 -- The Executive Committee of the parliamentary group that once followed Gen. Charles de Gaulle and still shares his ideas, issued a statement today reiterating the opposition of the group to the European Defense Community Treaty and its twin, the Bonn peace contract with the Western Allies, which would grant sovereignty to West Germany.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 18 -- The United States served notice on Communist China and North Korea today that the General Assembly had picked the participants on the United Nations side at the proposed Korean conference and that that was all ,there was to it.

Plush and attractive, the boxes used as containers of fountain pens have usually been useless for anything else. This will be changed if the Waterman Pen Company, Inc., has its way. Robert D. Howse, executive vice president of the company, announced yesterday that Waterman will package its pens in containers that can serve a useful secondary purpose.

CHICAGO, Sept. 18 -- Armour Co. reported today a sharp increase in net earnings for the nine-month period ended Aug. 1 compared with a year earlier, although dollar sales declined and the company's income tax provision more than trebled.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 (AP) -- Senator Charles E. Potter, Republican of Michigan, announced today that a Senate Maritime subcommittee would hold hearings in San Francisco on Oct. 21-23 on problems of the shipping industry on the West Coast.

A concrete approach to an abstract subject, arithmetic, which has long been a headache to many pupils and teachers, will be emphasized this fall by Teachers College, Columbia University.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 (UP) -- The Secretary of Defense, Charles E. Wilson, announced today that K. T. Keller has quit as director of the Department's guided missiles office and will return to be chairman of the board of the Chrysler Corporation.

This week at Geneva, Switzerland, representatives of the thirty-three countries participating in "G. A. T. T." (General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade) have assembled for the eighth meeting since that organization was formed for the purpose of achieving world peace on the trade front.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Sept. 18 -- A strike of several hundred thousand workers on privately owned plantations in many parts of Indonesia was called off here today by the Communist leaders of the walkout. They acted after receiving a promise from S. M. Abidin, the Labor Minister, that the Government Labor Arbitration Board would reconsider the strikers' wage dispute with the plantations on which the board had issued a ruling two weeks ago.

In your editorial of Sept. 6 "More Aid for Indo-China" you state that the French "cannot afford to be complacent" in their fight against Communists in Indo-China, "nor can we, if they call upon us for further help." I think it is high time that this "further help" is spelled out.

The aggregate short interest in stocks listed on the New York Stock Exchange rose from 1,815,492 to 1, 935,958 shares between Aug. 14 and Sept. 15, the Exchange reported yesterday. Both totals exclude short positions in the odd-lot accounts of odd-lot dealers, which were 70,127 shares on the former and 74,540 shares on the latter date.

TIME was -- before interplanetary fantasy -- when the sea exerted an irresistible lure for boys. To walk a pitching deck awash with salty spray under a white spread of canvas was once the dream. Today the sailing ships that made men and fortunes have all but disappeared and only occasionally a full-rigged ship puts into port. and stirs nostalgia.

Some of the selling enthusiasm disappeared from the stock market last week after another jolt of selling drove prices down to the lowest levels in several years. Investors enjoyed the respite, wondering whether it meant an end to the long decline in the market which has reached a point where it is having a depressing effect on the nation's economy.

MORE than four and a half million mothers of young children work outside their own homes. Because the great majority do so because of economic necessity, statements by child-care experts urging mothers to remain at home may make them feel uneasy but will not prompt them to quit their jobs.

The drive to dislodge crime from its dominant perch in the Port of New York was clouded last week by the threat of a coast-wide dock strike. Theoretically, the two things had nothing to do with each other; practically, it was impossible to separate them.

The agreement of the United States to the restoration of the guild system in Germany, as reported in THE TIMES, is disappointingly regressive in view of the political and economic evils inherent in the system, the historic American policy against it and the support which this policy received from various elements among the Germans.

The Free Milk Fund for Babies, of which Mrs. William Randolph Hearst is founder and president, will be the beneficiary of the performance of "Il Trovatore," with Zinka Milanov, Elena Nikolaidi, Kurt Baum, Robert Merrill and Nicola Moscona in the leading roles, on the night of Dec. 2 at the Metropolitan Opera House.

Although the sugar industry generally is chary of criticizing the international agreement reached in London by the International Sugar Council a fortnight ago, B. W. Dyer Co., New York brokers and sugar economists, sounded a sharp warning last week.
ST. JOHN'S Nfld., Sept. 19 (Canadian Press)--The Spanish freighter Marte arrived here last night, ending a three-day battle to check the rise of water in her hold.

THE wide public who have depended for their knowledge of history and the philosophy of the past on the tutelage of Will Durant will welcome the appearance of "The Renaissance," fifth volume of his monumental "The Story of Civilization," upon which he has been engaged for a decade or more.

The New York Public Library's "Exploring the American Idea" program is open for registration to all adults at any branch library or in the building at Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street. The project, which offers group reading and discussion of the principles of the American heritage, was begun by the library in 1950.

News of scientific achievements from other countries might well make us hang our heads in shame. It is true that pharmaceutical laboratories are experimenting with new cures.

MINNEAPOLIS, Sept. 19 -- For the past several years the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization (UNESCO) has been under attack in various quarters. Some groups and individuals object to its "international flavor." Others feel that the organization is Communist controlled, or that it places more emphasis upon loyalty to other flags than to our own. Whatever the origin, the criticism of UNESCO has reached serious proportions.
LONDON, Sept. 19 -- Clement Attlee, leader of the Labor party, said tonight United States foreign policy was responsible for a steady deterioration of the world situation.

COLUMBIA. S. C., Sept. 19 (UP) -- Duke's Howard Pitt got on the receiving end of two important passes, one thrown by South Carolina, to lead the Blue Devils to a 20-to-7 victory over the Gamecocks tonight in the first game of the new Atlantic Coast Conference.

The State Harness Racing Commission, which is conducting hearings into employment practices at Yonkers Raceway, may extend its investigation to the seven other trotting tracks in the state, Hamilton S. Gaddis, one of the three commissioners, disclosed last night.

Profits followed the pattern of the principal phases of the economy in the first six months of this year, to build the second- highest corporate income on record for the nation's manufac turers. The final half of the year may not equal the glowing performance of the initial six months, but indications for all of 1953 point to profits exceeded only by those of the banner year 1950.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 19 -- One hundred and fifty-eight Dutch volunteers for duty in Korea were the guests here today of Dr. Joseph M. A. Luns, Foreign Minister of the Netherlands, who welcomed them to the United Nations and told them, "We fervently hope that your presence [in Korea] will ease the transition from armistice to peace."
