Hatch of 7 Gracie Square, are aiding in the arrangements for the card party and fashion show in behalf of St, Barnabas Hospital for Chronic Diseases to be held on Sept. 29 in the main bollroom of the Plaza.

ZANTE, Greece, Sept. 15 -- The grief and apathy of the people of this Ionian island and its neighbors, Cephalonia and Ithaca, have noticeably lessened in the month since the earthquake, of a magnitude not hitherto recorded in Greek history, brought death into their midst and reduced their home places to heaps of charred rubble.

MILWAUKEE, Sept. 19 (AP) -- Warren Spahn hit a bases-loaded single and set Cincinnati down with seven hits today for his twenty-first victory as the Braves beat the Redlegs, 5 -- 2, before 32,482 fans.

A youthful prowler, who said he had been drinking and did not know what he was doing, was seized early yesterday morning on the roof of the firehouse at 6 Hancock Place by members of Hook and Ladder Company 40.

MISS Lattimore's new book is a collection of warm, happy, easy-to-read little stories about a 6-year-old Negro boy who lives on Whooping Island near Charleston. Jasper's everyday adventures with his family, with his slightly older, much-admired cousin, and with his pets are told with a childlike humor.

GUATEMALA, Sept. 19 -- The Empresa Electrica, North American-owned electric power company, must grant wage increases demanded by its workers as well as reduce its present electricity rates, Interventor Alfonso Bauer Paiz has decided.

When the international system of weather observations and prediction was disrupted by the First World War, two Norwegian meteorologists, Prof. V. Bjerknes and his son, Jakob, rose to the occasion by developing air-mass analysis. Weather prediction used to be two-dimensional in the sense that observations were made on the ground.

THE most consistently successful promoter of hot music in America today (or Europe, for that matter) and, very likely, the Far East tomorrow, is a tall, blocky and somberly single-minded man of 35 named Norman Granz, who was first exposed to the art form thirteen years ago at the home of an otherwise obscure friend in Los Angeles, Granz' birthplace.

LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., Sept. 19 -- Clay Pidgeon, a 6-year-old chestnut gelding owned and ridden by Morton W. (Cappy) Smith of Middleburg, Va., won the jumper championship as the forty-eighth annual Piping Rock horse show closed before a crowd of 2,500, the largest to attend the finale in years, at the Piping Rock Club today.

JAMESBURG, N. J., Sept. 19 -- Joe Russo of West Orange and his partner, Mike Fuss of Twin Brooks, gained the semi-final round of the J. Foster Abeel Memorial best-ball golf tournament at the Forsgate Country Club today with a pair of upset victories.
PAWTUCKET, R. I., Sept. 19 (UP) -- Sailed Away and Tony De-Spirito today won the nineteenth Narragansett Special before 21,412 fans at the final day of the Narragansett Park meeting.
A possible hindrance to the transforming of human nature was suggested yesterday by Rabbi Simon Noveck as stemming from "modern institutionalized religion."

The number and tonnage of large vessels under construction or on order in private American shipyards dropped to the lowest point in twenty-six months on Sept. 1, the Shipbuilders Council of America reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- A deliberate move to discredit the workings of American justice in the eyes of citizens here has been started by the Communists, Attorney General Herbert Brownell Jr. said today. In an address at the closing session here of the National Conference on Citizenship he emphasized the need for this country to preserve its general safeguards for those put on trial before our courts.

VOYAGES have always been popular reading, whether the saga be that of a single traveler, such as Ulysses, or a group adventure, such as the journey of the Argonauts in search of the Golden Fleece. And, factual or fantastic, travel has always been one of the best ways "from outward forms to win the passion and the life that are within."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (UP) -- Senator Richard B. Russell said today that the "confusion, uncertainty and lack of direction" in the Eisenhower farm program had contributed to falling farm prices and given the Democrats a strong campaign issue for 1954.

From the outset the race for the New York Mayoralty has shaped up as one of the liveliest in years -- and one of the hardest to prognosticate. Last week a Democratic primary produced one important change in the picture -- a shattering blow to the chances of the incumbent, Vincent Impellitteri -- but the outcome of the race remained uncertain.

IN considering ways to reduce the nation's highway-accident rate, a report on driver practices issued under the sponsorship of the Highway Research Board of the National Academy of Science devotes considerable attention to the youthful driver and the problem of speeding after dark.

Chief Federal Judge Robert A. Inch of the Eastern District has designated United States Commissioners Edward E. Fay and Martin C. Epstein to sit as magistrates in a special civilian night court that will begin hearing cases next month at Fort Hamilton in Brooklyn.

A significant report prepared for the National Planning Association Committee of the South shows that in three plants of the International Harvester Company there has been "steady progress" toward integration of white and Negro employes.

AS choreographer for the Jackie Gleason television show, June Taylor puts emphasis on light entertainment, not artistic terpsichore. She loads the stage with pretty girls -- although they must be experienced in all forms of dancing -- and surrounds them with elaborate production effects.

YOUR story called "Out-growth of Porgy" in a recent Sunday's TIMES was of peculiar interest to me and to my son Richard, a private 1/C, in the Marine Corps. You see we hold the copyright of the novel "John Henry," published by Harper Bros., 1930; and of the book of the folk opera, "John Henry," published also by Harper's, 1940.
PRINCETON, N. J., Sept. 19 -- Princeton and Fordham scrimmaged for three hours today under game conditions in a closed football practice at Palmer Stadium.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- There was no answer at the Pentagon today to the question of why THE YEW YORK TIMES and the Bermuda station had received word of the crash last night before the Pentagon was notified.

BONN, Sept. 19 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer's West German Government, seen two weeks after its triumph in the general election of Sept. 6, is like one of those mammoth Diesel trucks which roll incessantly along the Autobahns, the great express highways that run through this country from one end to another.

PHILADELPHIA, Pa., Sept. 19 -- While Arthur B. Bisguier of New York drew his eighth-round game with Atillio Di Camillo of Philadelphia, a King's Indian defense, in 20 moves and continued in the lead, Hans Berliner of Washington, D. C., won from Saul Wachs of Philadelphia to take second place in the challengers' tournament of the U. S. Chess Federation at the Hotel Adelphia yesterday.

At a three-day conference on nuclear engineering held in Berkeley, Calif., K. K. Campbell, superintendent of power and maintenance at Hanford, Wash., where plutonium is produced, drew a picture of the difficulties that must be faced when the atomic power plant of the future is in operation.

Plans have been advanced at recent meetings in the Garden of the Ambassador and in private homes for the performance of "A Girl Can Tell," a new comedy, on the night of Nov. 12 at the Royale Theatre, which has been taken over to raise funds for the Kips Bay Boys Club.

I read M. Sedillot's article on why Frenchmen don't pay taxes with great interest. Having lived in France many years, I am familiar with their troubles and consider his expose a true picture of conditions.
The old and perplexing question -- How to deal with the Communists? -- confronted the free world anew last week.

Excavations during the 1953 summer by New York University on the Greek island of Samothrace have uncovered a strange structure of stones that is believed to have been used by worshipers in secret nocturnal rites seven centuries before the time of Christ.

THE opening tomorrow of an exhibit of room settings in a Fifty-seventh Street art gallery is one more indication of the increasing compatibility between the fine arts and interior design. Other evidence that there is more "art" than ever in American homes comes from our museums.

EACH visit I make to an Indian reservation strengthens in me the conviction that on no national matter is the American public more poorly informed than it is regarding the situation of its most abused minority group.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- A portion of President Eisenhower's time this week was occupied with farm policy, a problem gathering more explosive force because of a personality and a hard economic reality.

ALBUQUERQUE, N. M., Sept. 19 -- The seven-month Senate investigation of last year's Senatorial contest in New Mexico came to an end here today, without having produced any evidence that would presage an upset in the victory of Senator Dennis Chavez, Democrat, over Maj. Patrick J. Hurley (U. S. A., retired).

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 19 -- Nothing that has happened since the United Nations General Assembly started back to work this week encourages the hope that the proposed Korean peace conference will get anywhere. In fact some leading delegates are beginning to suspect that there will not be any conference at all.

Many boxes and seats have been purchased for the performance of the Sadler's Wells ballet on Thursday night at the Metropolitan Opera House for the benefit of the Child Study Association of America. Heading the benefit committee are Mrs. Nelson Doubleday, Mrs. Frank E. Karelsen and Mrs. Barney Gilbert.
A new record in gifts, grants and bequests exceeding $10,000,000 was announced yesterday by New York University for the year ended June 30. The previous high was $6,009,878, received last year.

SEATTLE, Sept. 19 (UP) -- Two second-string backs, Homer Jenkins and Emerson Wilson, led Colorado to a 21-20 victory over favored Washington today as the two teams opened their 1953 football campaigns before 31,000 fans.

GOING to the movies, means, to most New Yorkers, an evening spent in a neighborhood theatre, or a trip to one of Broadway's. glittering houses where a Hollywood film usually is on display. But, for many thousands, the same phrase means going to view a picture in a foreign language without English subtitles in one of the more than thirty movie houses which only show films from other lands.
I read with interest your excellent editorial of Sept. 15 commenting upon the survey of the stock market made by your staff correspondent A. H. Raskin.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (UP) -- The Federal Bureau of Investigation said today a major crime was committed every 4.3 minutes in the United States during the first half of 1953. The year bids fair to pile up the country's worst crime toll in history, the bureau said in making public its half-yearly collection of crime data.

More buyers were in the wholesale markets here last week than in many months, resident buying offices reported. Heavy orders were placed for holiday merchandise and for depleted fall stocks. Budgets were ample and stores are generally optimistic about fall and holiday business.

LONDON, Sept. 19 (Reuters) -- London's Arsenal Club was held to a 2-2 draw today by Manchester City, leaving the defending English League soccer champions mired in the cellar of the first division. Arsenal has registered only one victory in ten matches this season.

GANTON, England, Sept. 19 (UP) -- Max Faulkner clinched a place on Britain's Ryder Cup team today when he held off a late challenge by Dai Rees of Wales to win the 2,650 pound ($7,420) match-play golf championship, 1 up, in their 36-hole final.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- John Foster Dulles' prestige rises and falls with the tide of events and the nature and location of his public statements. Two weeks ago, when he intervened publicly in the West German election, he was down; this week-end, after an excellent speech before the General Assembly of the United Nations, he is on the rise, but next week he may be on the descent again.

ROME, Sept. 9 -- No newspapers were printed on Italian territory today and none will be tomorrow as a consequence of a strike called by the printers' and printing shop workers' union. Available to readers in Rome was the Vatican newspaper, L'Osservatore Romano, which is published in Vatican City and does not rank as an Italian newspaper.

IN her new work of fiction, actress Ruth Chatterton has labored so hard, in such an angry and earnest mood, that spontaneity is entirely missing. Stripped of some of its histrionic, "The Betrayers" is rather like one of those movie case histories about the F. B. I.

Apparently unconcerned about political charges of a "bankers' Administration" some 6,000 banking executives will descend on the nation's capital this week, presumably to rededicate themselves to a national policy of "sound money." The occasion is the seventy-ninth annual convention of the American Bankers Association, which starts its formal sessions tomorrow.

THE Chief Justiceship of the United States is the most powerful judicial office in the world. Under our system of government the Supreme Court is, as Bryce phrased it, "the living voice of the Constitution." And the Chief Justice is the living symbol of the court and of the idea of justice for which it stands.

Duke Snider warmed up for the series with the Yankees by belting two successive home runs off Robin Roberts at Ebbets Field yesterday, driving in three runs and pacing the Dodgers to a 5 -- 4 victory over the Phils. Jackie Robinson singled home the other markers.
Few shoppers have not experienced the bewildering experience of going into a store for a few items only to emerge with many, some of them not even of brands the shopper preferred.

THE automobile is of enormous importance to most Americans. As long ago as the Lynds' sociological study of Middletown, its influence on changing economic, social and sexual patterns was recognized. The super-highways it has demanded have changed the face of America.

FABIAN, Indian boy of Guatemala, is introduced with a handsome portrait on the jacket by Conrad Buff, whose colorful, posterlike illustrations are backdrops for a narrative about old versus new among people who cling to their ancient Mayan gods.

In the editorial "Stock Market Opinion" in your Sept. 15 issue you wisely observe that professional forecasts of market swings are keyed not to considerations of value but to the prior action of the prices themselves. As you indicate, the forecaster's prophecy is not based on his own findings of what should occur but on estimates of what "the crowd" thinks will occur, with its "opinion pattern" and future behavior ascertainable from esoteric signals.

An unemployed assistant laboratory photographer was booked on a charge of attempted robbery last night after he walked into the Bergen Street station in Brooklyn and confessed to attempting a hold-up that netted him nothing.

Harold Riegelman, Republican nominee for Mayor, renewed last night his contention that the voting system in the Board of Estimate should be changed to give each of the five Borough Presidents an equal vote.

NO one is more aware that a new season begins on Wednesday than a gardener, unless, perhaps, it's a farmer. The forecast from Sept. 23 to Dec. 21 is "Autumn," interpreted as brisk days, mellow sun and periodic rains.

CHICAGO, Sept. 19 (AP) -- Indian Hill, 5-year-old black stallion, was a driving winner in the $28,700 Midwest Handicap, scoring by three-quarters of a length over Pomace, at Hawthorne Park today before 20,172 fans.

WITH lengthening nights growing chilly and the leaves beginning to turn, spring may seem to be a long way off. Actually it is already upon us so far as next season's first blossoms are concerned, for autumn is the time to plant spring-flowering bulbs.

READING, Pa., Sept. 19 (UP) -- The United States Ryder Cup golf team took a 4-point lead in a race for $15,000 in prize money today by trouncing Jimmy Demaret's challengers, 4 1/2 to 1/2, in a four-ball, best-ball match.

The men's clothing industry is in the throes of a heated controversy concerning the existence of a spring season and seems to have neglected the wishes of the consumer. Manufacturers have cited production figures showing the narrowing of the spring season and retailers have ordered fewer of the regular-weight suits and concentrated on summer lines.

PRACTICAL courses for advanced amateurs and professionals in the use of the Rollei and Leica cameras are announced by Peter Gibbons, 51 West Tenth Street. Each course lasts fifteen weekly sessions, during which the students get a grounding in the techniques of the camera and its application in various fields.

THE fall planting season is an excellent time to consider starting a backyard orchard. It will not only enhance the beauty and value of a property but will provide the family table with a wide variety of delicious fruit.

MUCH as I usually admire the criticism of Robert Gorham Davis, I cannot agree with his estimate of the late Sir Desmond MacCarthy: "one of the best-loved English men of letters" as he wrote in the review of MacCarthy's "Memories."

WATKINS GLEN, N. Y., Sept. 19 (AP) -- Walter E. Hansgen of Westfield, N. J., raced to a fifteen-yard victory over George Harris 3d of Geneva, N. Y., in the 101.2-mile Grand Prix sports car road race over a new course here. His average speed was 76.1 miles per hour.

There is something to be said in favor of research concerned with dead civilizations as against most modern research -- in physics, for example. No discoveries concerning dead civilizations can possibly be regarded as destructive of modern civilization.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 19 -- A proclamation was issued today for national elections in November to name a new Parliament, whose purpose, it was stressed, will be to carry out a Socialist program and support the Government's foreign policy.

SAN DIEGO, Calif., Sept. 19 (AP) -- The San Diego Morning Union in a copyrighted story tonight said a man claiming to be Laurenti P. Beria, deposed former chief of the Soviet secret police, and three other supposed Communist leaders, reported to have escaped from the Soviet Union, are hiding in a "deep southern" country.

WEST SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Sept. 19 -- The Eastern States Exposition, a New England country fair on a metropolitan scale, opens tomorrow with a welcome to the region's six Governors touching off an eight-day program that is expected to attract 500,000 persons.

ANKARA, Turkey, Sept. 18 -- The idea of concluding a Turkish-Pakistani mutual assistance pact as the nucleus of a Middle East defense organization including Iran and Iraq has received close study here and in Karachi since the Zahedi Government came into power in Teheran.
A large subscription has been reported for the performance of the Sadler's Wells Ballet Tuesday night at the Metropolitan Opera House for the benefit of the Institute of World Affairs.

DAMASCUS, Syria, Sept. 12 -- Elections to fill eighty-two seats in Syria's revived Parliament will take place throughout the country on Oct. 9, according to a decree issued by President Adib Shishekly. In line with a Constitution promulgated in June and approved by referendum in July, the elections will be the final step in Syria's wavering course back to parliamentary life after four coups, two of them led by Colonel Shishekly.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., Sept. 19 (AP) -- Col. Arthur H. Clark of Buffalo, commander of the 174th Infantry Regiment at the New York National Guard, today was elected president of the Army and Air National Guard and Naval Militia Association of the State of New York.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 19 (UP) -- A Unitarian minister identified by a former Federal Bureau of Investigation undercover man, Herbert Philbrick, as a member of a secret Communist cell in Boston, said today he had been dissociated with the Unitarian Church headquarters there since 1947.

LIKE the peace offensive that preceded and accompanied it. Prime Minister Malenkov's claim that the Soviet Union has the hydrogen bomb was intended to divide the democracies. To the Kremlin's blandishments about peace, it adds the weapon of intimidation.

A MEETING to discuss the formation of a group of "serious photographers" whose purpose will be "to meet informally, to discuss their work and to have a place where their photographs can be shown and seen" will be held at 8 P. M. Tuesday, Sept. 29, at the Village Art Center, 42-44 West Eleventh Street.

FALL planting may be carefully planned in terms of next season's balanced color combinations and succession of bloom, but if the element of fragrance has been overlooked, one of the garden's most subtle yet compelling assets will be missing.

BELGRADE, Sept. 19 -- For Yugoslavia the Trieste dispute is basically political, not emotional. Controlling all press and radio, the Government here rarely is pushed into unwanted policy positions by popular agitation.
ART galleries hold opposing opinions on how to open up a new season. Some will launch it with an exhibition of importance while others hold back the trumps until the season really awakens.

CAIRO, Sept. 19 (AP) -- A three-member revolutionary court will open treason trials here Monday, Abdel Latif Baghdadi, the war minister, announced today. "Traitors and persons conspiring against the present regime" of President Mohammed Naguib are to be arraigned.

SEARCHERS for a full-fledged example of international commercial partnership might do well to consider the overseas film producers, whose zeal in behalf of working together recently moved one Hollywood trade paper pundit to comment that "some of the European countries are trying to gang up on Hollywood."
The relative position of tankers of United States registry in the distribution of oil is declining steadily.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 19 -- California's 1954 state election campaign may be said to have got its official start this week. That came with formalization of the candidacy for Governor of Goodwin J. Knight, Republican, Lieutenant Governor since 1947.

THE recent resignation of Secretary of Labor Martin P. Durkin focuses attention on the President's advisers. The Presidency of the United States is necessarily a joint operation -- including besides the President, himself, and his Cabinet a small coterie of friends and advisers on whom he relies for intimate help and counsel.

MASSENA, N. Y., Sept. 19 (AP) -- The chairman of the New York State Power Authority, John E. Burton, said tonight that five private utilities companies were trying "to put the snatch" on Niagara River power. He also asserted that if the companies were permitted to develop the Niagara River power potential they might ruin the plan for St. Lawrence power development by the state.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 19 (AP)--The Cubs, held hitless for six innings, matched a two-run deficit and went on to defeat the Cardinals, 5--2, tonight with a three-run, twelfth inning attach which included Ralph Kiner's bases-loaded double.

DALLAS, Sept. 19 -- Despite a return of August-like hot weather for several days during the last week, department store sales volume was moderately good. Fall and back-to-school promotions were drawing good response, merchants said.

COLUMBIA, Mo., Sept. 19 -- Chet Hanulak sped 61 yards for a touchdown in the first two minutes and Maryland tallied two more markers in the final quarter to beat Missouri's Tigers, 20 -- 6, in the football season opener for both teams.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 19 -- Vic Seixas of the United States, Wimbledon champion, and youthful Ken Rosewall of Australia won their way into final of the men's singles in the Pacific South west tennis tournament today, but tennis queen Maureen Connolly was upset in the women's play.

Rocky Marciano, heavyweight champion of the world, will defend his crown against Roland La Starza of the Bronx on Thursday night. The clash, scheduled for fifteen rounds, will be held at the Polo Grounds and is listed to begin at 10:30.

HONG KONG, Sept. 19 (Reu-ters)----The changes announced to-day by the Peiping radio involve .fifteen ministerial and other administrative posts. They include the transfer of Cheng Kuo-tung, former minister of Finance, to the post of Vice Minister of Food.

THIS is a fairly arbitrary attempt to bind together eleven situations of horrid murder and to say that each was a crime of passion. Such a gambit -- the gambit of the common bloody denominator -- is acceptable only on one or both of these terms:

Are we going to silence political criticism in America because of fear that it will be misunderstood or misinterpreted by other nations around the world? This self-conscious attitude will create an iron curtain around our political news which will render it impossible for our own people to know and understand what is going on.

BAYTOWN, Tex., Sept. 19 -- The $10,000,000 Baytown-La Porte Tunnel will be opened near here on Tuesday. The toll-free tunnel, 4,110 feet long, is under the busy Houston Ship Channel and connects the two bayshore industrial centers of Baytown and La Porte.

HONG KONG, Sept. 19 -- The Peiping Government has relieved Po Yi-po of his post as Minister of Finance and appointed in his place Teng Hsiao-ping, present Deputy Chairman of the Southwest Military and Administrative Commission.

QUANTICO, Va., Sept. 19 (UP) -- Any big war of the future may be decided by conventional, rather than atomic or hydrogen weapons, it was predicted today by Robert B. Anderson, the Secretary of the Navy.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 19 -- The heads of nineteen American Federation of Labor construction unions joined forces here today in a showdown fight to stop wildcat strikes from stalling the atomic energy program.

GLEN RIDGE, N. J., Sept. 19 -- Sal Simeone, Shackamaxon club president, and Al Fuhro, member, teamed to score a three-under-par best-ball 33, 35 -- 68 for a two-stroke lead in the opening round of the Allison Dodd Memorial member-guest golf tournament at the Glen Ridge Country Club today.
PALO ALTO, Calif., Sept. 19 -- Stubborn little College of the Pacific rallied today to upset Stanford, 25 -- 20, in a thrill-packed season opener in which the outcome was in doubt to the final gun.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Sept. 19 -- Fourteen craft, including Dick Sheehan's My Yen from Port Washington, winner of the Commodore Hinman Trophy in Group I last year, crossed the starting line off Plum Point in Manhasset Bay today in the eighth annual Stratford Shoal race of the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club.

Beginning this week, most New York auction galleries will resume full-scale activities after the summer lull. From the appearance of the leading galleries' schedules, the season now at hand promises an interesting succession of sales to an increasingly auction-minded public.

Another dramatic escape from behind the Iron Curtain has just been staged right here in New York by a man whose personality and position make his exploit a particularly telling blow against Communist pretensions and an inspiration to his oppressed nation to keep the torch of liberty alight.

CHILDREN of the future * * * may inherit the results of the present tendency to take a broader, more permissive view of imaginative fiction. Unfortunately, the opposite tendency, the desire to "improve" the minds of the young -- i.e., to jam current beliefs and attitudes into them -- is also on the increase.
I am afraid that the note attached to my letter of Sept. 6 will leave your readers with an erroneous impression of a man who has been misrepresented all too often in the American press.
SOME of the best plant food the gardener can get is the kind he can make right in his own back yard by composting garden material. Fall is the best time for any gardener to start a compost pile.

EVERYBODY talks about bad partners, but nobody ever does anything about them. (A general exception might be made for the Mrs. Bennett of Kansas City who shot and killed her husband because he misplayed four spades doubled.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept., 19 -- Ethiopia is a land of almost unimaginable agricultural riches, and could easily become the granery of the Middle East if her resources were adequately exploited, Michael W. Millar of Canada said this week on return from a mission of fourteen months there as an expert on seed improvement for the Food and Agriculture Organization.

BOSTON, Sept. 19 -- As the Yankees moved into the Hub today to begin their farewell three-game series with the Red Sox here Manager Casey Stengel looked hopefully forward to seeing his Bombers receive a good workout that would start putting them on edge for their more important world series engagement ahead.

ON a visit to New York after publication of "The Cruel Sea" Nicholas Monsarrat told this reviewer, with ill-concealed excitement, that he had a "wonderful" idea for his next novel. It was so good, he added, that he was surprised no one else had thought of it before. He preferred not to talk about it.

THIS week one of the largest fall flower shows will be presented in Westchester County. On Thursday the doors of the County Center in White Plains will open for the "Town and Country" flower show, the second annual one staged by the Ninth District of the Federated Garden Clubs of New York State.
INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 19 (AP) -- A sixty-day strike against the Indiana Bell Telephone Company, that was marked by violence and mass picketing throughout the state, was settled early today.

TEHERAN, Sept. 19 -- When Gen. Fazlollah Zahedi rode a popular uprising into the office of Premier of Iran a month ago, he took over a country which might have been compared to a feudal castle on the verge of collapse from structural defects, neglect and decay, and which, to complicate matters, was also on fire.

THERE are today more than forty science fiction magazines in existence. From sixty to 100 books are published annually in this field. It is therefore high time that a book such as this, a symposium by eleven top writers, editors and critics, was published.

THE durability of the airlines' flight equipment was demonstrated last week when a twin-engined Lockheed Lodestar, a pre-war plane, was cruised at 300 miles an hour. The airliner, operated by Lear, Inc., producer of navigational flight equipment, made speed runs over Santa Monica Bay and Catalina Island, Calif.

TWO of Prokofieff's most popular works are the pair of violin concertos he composed -- No. 1 in D major (1913), written with power, irony and exuberance at the height of his young manhood; No. 2 in G minor (1934), which dates after his return to Russia, a flowing, somewhat sentimental, altogether unproblematical piece of music.

HOLLAND is a country famed for the production of bulbs. And, therefore, the average gardener might logically assume that this is the native land of narcissus, tulips, hyacinths and other bulbs that flower in spring.

Rooting for the Pirates these days is a pointless procedure. Take a look at the standings. So, yesterday the president of the Pittsburgh Baseball Club, John W. Galbreath, went to the Aqueduct Race Track instead of the Polo Grounds. At the horse park Galbreath had an extremely pleasant and extremely profitable afternoon.

PARIS, Sept. 19 -- Edouard Herriot, venerable Speaker of the National Assembly and President for life of the Radical party, whose attack started the backfire in France against the European army treaty a year ago, said tonight he was still hostile to it but that a European defense community should be formed if negotiations with the Soviet Union should fail.

Dr. Marek Stanislaw Korowicz was in seclusion yesterday after asking for asylum in the United States on Friday, four days after having arrived from abroad as the first alternate member of the Polish delegation to, the United States.
A candy manufacturer in Brooklyn needs five trucks regularly and two more for heavier week-end deliveries.

WASHINGTON, September 19 -- The Navy Bureau of Aeronautics and the National Bureau of Standards jointly announced today that with the cooperation of half a dozen concerns they had pushed automatic mass production of electronic devices so far that the most refined skill and something that closely resembles intelligence had been transferred to machines.

PENDING the resolution of several factors still in tentative stages, there is a strong probability that the work selected for the opening of the regular season of the N. B. C. Opera Theatre Company will be "Carmen," to be presented as a color telecast from the stage of the Colonial Theatre, N. B. C.'s specially equipped video color studio in New York.

THE cool fall days are ideal for planting perennials, and the new home owner who dreams of having a colorful garden next year should start to work immediately to make them come true. A simple flower border is the best choice for a first garden.

OYSTER BAY, L. I., Sept. 19 -- John Matthews' sloop, Vim, led home a fleet of twenty-six yachts in the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club's annual cruise today. The Group I victor sailed the eighteen-mile triangular course to the American Yacht Club, Rye, then to the Indian Harbor Y. C. at Greenwich, Conn., and back home in 2:31.17.

EXCESSIVE enthusiasm often culminates in excessive folly as it does in the case of Messrs. G. Wilson Knight and Jacques Barzun, authors of the latest tomes on Lord Byron (Book Review, Aug. 9), whom they deify. I grant that the creator of Childe Harold was a poet of power and passion, a brilliant satirist and an ardent romanticist.
LINCOLN, Neb., Sept. 19 -- Two bad passes from center helped send favored Nebraska to a 20-12 defeat before Oregon today in the first nationally televised football game of the season.

The civil defense exercise starting here today and culminating on Friday with a full-scale public participation drill will be the "greatest of this kind yet to be held in the United States," the City of New York Office of Civil Defense announced yesterday. Nine counties in the city's "support area" will participate.

AUGIE MARCH, a West-Side-Chicago Tom Jones, a Wilhelm Meister of the depression years, is a handsome and intelligent young man with what he himself describes as "a weak sense of consequence." He seems primarily moved by the need for love.

THE spectacular popularity of "From Here to Eternity," which, according to well- grounded rumor, is thriving all over the land, is one of those manifestations of public interest that is causing no pain -- least of all to the theatre proprietors and to the critics who sanctioned this film.

The average starting salary of the June engineering graduate of Illinois Institute of Technology reached an all-time high of $362 a month. This was a jump of $20 over the February class average of $342.

Communist Party Secretary Nikita S. Khrushchev admitted last week that Soviet farm production had not kept pace with Russia's needs. His admission was implicit acknowledgment that a quarter of a century of Stalinist collective farm policy had failed to fulfill the original bright hopes held up before the Soviet people.

RIVERHEAD, L. I., Sept. 19 -- Eastern Suffolk's largest weekly newspaper. The News Review, marked fifty years of news coverage of the forty-odd communities in the area with the publication on Thursday of a special anniversary edition.

Room 512 at 120 Schermerhorn Street, Brooklyn, has blossomed, almost overnight, into an oasis of color. Pictures decorate the walls, magazines and paper-bound books lie at hand and, in cases, are books in bright jackets.

THE adventures of Tim, Edward Ardizzone's small sea-going hero, are taking on the proportions of a saga in miniature, but each installment is as fresh as the initial picture book. In the present volume Tim once again goes to sea, accompanied by Charlotte, in a casual fashion during a search for their friend Ginger.

INTERNAL evidence suggests that Mr. Gorham was not unmindful of last winter's tabloid headlines when he sat at a fiercely smoking typewriter and poured out this short, poisonous novel about a hundred-dollar harlot and the cafe-society procurer who master-minds her short but sensational New York career.

SOWING seeds this fall can be an exciting adventure. Gardeners who have been unsuccessful with spring sowing of the hardy perennial, shrub, tree and herb seeds have a surprise in store for them. For the fact of the matter is that these seeds need a long period of exposure to cold temperatures in order to germinate.
The market for top-grade bonds seems now to be well along in a new phase for which it reached repeatedly in the post-Korean period but never quite attained.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (UP) -- A Defense Department spokesman said today that all of the armed forces might be forced to draft men after next July 1.
NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 19 (UP) -- Tulane trampled, outweighed and outmanned The Citadel, 54 to 6, today in a football opener that was little more than a light workout for the Green Wave.

CHICAGO, Sept. 19 -- President Eisenhower told 1,200 wildly cheering Republican women today that their power for moral good must be well organized to be truly effective but warned them to shun the "kind of leadership that consists only in the clever word or sometimes bad deportment."

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 19 (AP) -- Pint-sized Logan Batcheller was the riding star today accounting for the two divisions of the Ventnor Handicap with Boncrist Farm's Better Goods in the first section and George A. Garrett's Little Flirt II in the second section of the mile-and-a-sixtenth turf course fixture.

MOSCOW, Sept. 19 (AP) -- Soviet readers who learned some time ago that "beizbol" was originally a Russian game distorted by the Americans were told today that a battle between big league club owners and broadcasters was ruining the game.

ANYONE chatting with producer Max Gordon these days is bound to detect the change. Inactive since the quick failure of "The Small Hours" during the winter of 1951, Mr. Gordon once again is high on his chances in the theatre, especially so in regard to his forth-coming sponsorship of "The Solid Gold Cadillac."

THE apartment dweller need not look longingly at bulb catalogues this year for he, too, may have his share of fall planting. There is a wide selection of bulbs that are ideal for indoor forcing and will give almost a succession of colorful bloom throughout the winter.

The latest in a long series of sporadic but fruitless pleas to preserve as a national memorial the famous Navy frigate Constellation, now a rotting hulk in the Navy Yard at Charlestown, Mass., has unwittingly aroused the ire of salt water antiquaries.

Gilbert Bailey in "The Trotting Horse Races Back Into Favor" (Aug. 30) writes that the total "handle" at the trotting tracks here is "literally half" that of the daytime-running horse tracks. Actually it is three-quarters.

CONCORD, N. H., Sept. 19 -- The nation's newest national lawmaker, Senator Robert W. Upton, Republican of New Hampshire, has returned from his first official visit to Washington and resumed the trend of his daily life as unconcernedly as if he had been no farther than Boston.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (AP) -- Secretary of Defense Charles E. Wilson was reported tonight ready to prod the new Joint Chiefs of Staff with an order to speed up an already overdue recommendation on the size and shape of military forces for the next fiscal year.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (AP) -- A former football tackle is quarterbacking one of the toughest political offensives on record -- and hoping it doesn't turn into a desperate goal line stand.
MOSCOW, Sunday, Sept. 20 -- The Soviet Union announced today that it was granting war-ravaged North Korea financial and material aid for reconstruction.

STORY-BOOK animals, as every tot knows, are likely to swing a coup in the market for papa or stage rescues from fire and flood, not to mention slighter accomplishments like speaking English. It may, therefore, surprise no one when the fisherman's big yellow cat starts fetching in a mess of fish every morning when his master is temporarily disabled.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Sept. 19 -- Gene Littler, on Navy leave, won the United States Golf Association's amateur championship in a thrilling 36-hole final at the Oklahoma City Golf and Country Club today by defeating Dale Morey of Indianapolis by 1 up.

BEFORE getting too involved in the round of fall planting, it is well to take stock of what ought to be done. Because August is a popular vacation month, any of its special garden chores have probably been postponed. And this year even stay-at-homes found it too hot and dry to go ahead with any scheduled dividing or transplanting.

In his significant opening address to the General Assembly on Thursday, Secretary Dulles presented a direct challenge to the Soviet Union to give concrete evidence of the desire to ease world tensions. He pointed out the specific points at which such evidence could be given.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- President Eisenhower returned to the capital at 7:40 o'clock tonight ending nearly six weeks of mixed work and play in Colorado. Several score of waving spec-...
WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -- A 112-page statistical guide, "Women as Workers," most comprehensive publication of its type to date, was issued this week by the Women's Bureau, Department of Labor.

Widespread construction of comparatively inexpensive passing bays on long hills and narrow roads, so that slow-moving vehicles can turn aside to allow pent up traffic and fuming drivers in the rear to proceed onward, is being urged in an effort to reduce accident potential and relieve congestion.

WEST CHESTER, Pa., Sept. 19 (AP) -- Bob Haner, Villanova captain and fullback last year, scored two touchdowns and kicked three extra points to lead the U. S. Army Engineers from Fort Belvoir, Va., to a 21-6 victory over West Chester State Teachers College here last night.

In the interest of more liquidity -- meaning a market that will take larger blocks of stock at narrower price changes -- the New York Stock Exchange has made a broad revision of its floor trading rules. The changes were approved by the governors on Thursday and go into effect tomorrow.
LONDON, Sept. 19 -- A second world air speed record within a fortnight fell today to the scarlet, arrow-shaped British jet fighter piloted by Squadron Leader Neville Duke.
PULLMAN, Wash., Sept. 19 (AP) -- Aramis Dandoy, a halfback who ran 91 yards for one touchdown and engineered two others, led Southern California to a 29-13 victory over Washington State today.

ROME -- Toward the end of September Romans start preparing for the crystal-clear days known as the Ottobrate. This is when the city's inhabitants take advantage of Italy's Indian summer, and the campagna or countryside around the capital comes into its own.

TO an old paisano, a book by Ross Santee is the odor of sagebrush in the summer rain, the clamor of kiyotes yelping from butte to butte as the desert night slowly retreats before the sun. The present volume is Santee's own story -- plus his pictures -- of life as a horsewrangler in Gila County, Ariz.
The radio room of THE NEW YORK TIMES picked up a series of four-second dashes indicating distress at sea at 1:18 A. M. yesterday.

LESS than a month from now -- on Oct. 8 to be precise -- Volume One of "The Life and Work of Sigmund Freud" will be along. Published by Basic Books for $6.75, it is written by Ernest Jones, an old friend and an old colleague, who has been given access by the Freud family to the thousands of letters, papers and records left by the master on his death in 1939.

IT may sound absurd, but it isn't: Rocky Marciano, the heavyweight champion of the world, is a lamb in lion's clothing. Dress him in slacks and polo shirt and he's the mildest of men. Put him in shorts and boxing gloves and he's a murderer. Hang around Rocky for a day or two; if the poetry you read as a schoolboy and adolescent hasn't altogether vanished, you will think of William Blake.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 19 -- Under the new Constitution being drafted in Egypt to replace that of 1953, women are to receive complete political, social and economic equality with men, Dr. Mahmoud Azmi explained this week. Approval of the Constitution in an eventual referendum will be overwhelming, he predicted, and will terminate long and vigorous, agita tion by women's organizations for enfranchisement.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 19 -- Powerful Georgia came roaring from two touchdowns behind to down Villanova, 32 -- 19, as big time one-platoon football made its 1953 debut in the East tonight.

LATEST of the numerous informational series, the True Books are designed for children in the primary grades to read to themselves. Compact, well- organized, and generously illustrated, they ease the youngest readers into the world of facts with a minimum of effort.

NEWARK, Sept. 19 -- Citing air traffic figures for the first nine months of this year, the National Air Transport Coordinating Committee disclosed today that it was having difficulty in trying to divert most of the Newark Airport traffic away from congested areas as a noise-abatement and safety Measure.
BERLIN, Sept. 19 (UP) -- Walter Ulbricht, East German Deputy Premier, told the East German people today his Government would try to abolish rationing next summer in the Soviet zone.

FAIR HILL, Md., Sept. 19 -- The Manly Steeplechase Handicap, run thirty times since it was first held at Pimlico in 1916, was revived today at the second session of the Cecil County Breeders' Fair hunts meeting.

STOCKTON, Calif. -- It has been over a hundred years since gold was discovered in California, but an occasional adventurer can still be seen down on his knees beside a stream, shifting sand from side to side in a pan, searching for the grain that is gold.

Palmer Putnam of the Atomic Energy Commission turned up at Madison, Wis., last week to tell the American Institute of Biological Sciences the now familiar story of the day when there will be no more coal, no more oil, no more gas. What shall we do then for energy ? Though an A. E. C. man, Putnam saw no salvation in atomic energy.

SPRINGERVILLE, Ariz. -- Not far from the New Mexico border, Arizona's White Mountain recreation and wildlife area in the Apache National Forest is rich in small lakes and fishing streams. These, together with the area's scenic attractions, make it worth the investigations of a leisurely tourist driving via U. S. 60 across the great Southwest.

SINCE man is the only gambling animal, it follows that he is the only hedging animal. Business men, industrialists and affluent (or seemingly affluent) home-owners are the biggest players. They wager against the vagaries of storms, the opportunism of crooks, and the carelessness of noodles with matches; then they hedge their bets by purchasing insurance.

AS customary at the middle of September each year, the art season for 1953-54 got under way last week, some twenty-five exhibitions arriving at once in local galleries along with the reopening of the Whitney Museum for its last year in the old intimate quarters on Eighth Street.

JUST about the hottest thing in locomotives in New York State in 1831 was the DeWitt Clinton, a 6,758-pound, twelve-foot-long, wood-burning toy that rolled out of Albany on Aug. 9 bound for Schenectady, seventeen miles away.

ONTONAGON, Mich., Sept. 19 -- White Pine, a new town rising from the forest and more nearly resembling a "bedroom suburb" of New York than a mining community, seems out of place in the copper country of Michigan's Upper Peninsula, an area that has seen better days.

IF Leopold Stokowski and his associates are able to raise $500,000 between now and next summer the Collegiate Orchestra of America, Inc., at that time will launch an ambitious program of study, rehearsals and concertizing at American colleges and universities.
LEXINGTON, Ky., Sept. 19 (AP) -- Texas A. and M. defeated the University of Kentucky, 7 -- 6, tonight.

Having been shunted to the sidelines early in the 1953 pennant chase, the Giants arrived at no particular station yesterday as they split a double-header with the last-place Pirates at the Polo Grounds. After taking the opener, 4 -- 1, the Polo Grounders dropped the nightcap, 6 -- 5, before a Ladies Day gathering of 2,744.

WE have a nice wooded hillside where thousands of narcissus (narcissus is the botanical name for all daffodils) bloom each spring. The area has never been fertilized or cultivated and not one single bulb has been added during the twenty years it has existed.

SAVANNAH BEACH, Ga. -- This is an all-season beach community, long familiar to Georgians as a healthful playground, but generally neglected by Northerners accustomed to the vaunted attractions of Florida. Eighteen miles from Savannah proper, Savannah Beach was known for many years simply as Tybee -- the name of the narrow island on which it is situated, at the mouth of the Savannah River.

Crown Prince Akihito of Japan, who arrived here last Wednesday on a tour, left for Boston yesterday by train after having received a polite "Banzai" from a group of his countrymen at Grand Central Terminal The Prince arrived in Boston last night and received an official reception.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Sept. 19 -- Lieut. Gen. Alexander Cameron, deputy commander of British military forces in East Africa, warned in Nairobi today that native African disturbances in Nyasaland might grow unless they were effectively and firmly countered.

AUGUSTA, Wis., Sept. 19 -- Ezra Taft Benson, Secretary of Agriculture, addressing here today a gathering of 50,000 composed mostly of farmers and members of their families, attacked "foolish and panic-provoking statements that the Department of Agriculture was neither able nor willing to carry out provisions of the law regarding price supports."
PRINCETON, N. J., Sept. 19 -- Princeton University received $4,283,663 in gifts and legacies in the last fiscal year, Dr. Harold W. Dodds, president of the university, announced today.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Sept. 19 (Reuters) -- Nearly 1,000 athletes from twenty-three countries, including the United States and Canada, will compete in the fourth Maccabiah, the Jewish Olympic games which start tomorrow.

DETROIT, Sept. 19 -- Dr. Allan Nevins, Professor of American History at Columbia University, suggested this week that the time had come to reassess -- and rewrite -- the recent history of our times. Such interpretations as those of the late Charles A. Beard are beginning to be outworn today, Professor Nevins told the annual meeting of the Society of American Archivists.

TO write a story containing nothing low or mean, to show only the better side of human character, with virtue and goodwill triumphant, and to make that story eminently readable would be quite an achievement. The Austin family of New Hampshire is a thoroughly good New England family of the Eighteen Thirties.

ROME, Sept. 19 -- Trieste does something to the emotions of Italians which makes of that city and its surrounding territory one of the most delicate and potentially dangerous problems in the world today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- For the benefit of Eastern skeptics who may not have been convinced. Seattle's Slo-mo-shun V justified all advance praise on the Potomac today.

THE "6x6" Exakta single-lens reflex camera for 2 1/4x2 1/4-inch pictures on 120 roll-film will be available some time this year, according to the importers, the Exakta Camera Company. The price will be around $300. The lens is the redesigned 80mm f/2.8 Zeiss Tessar, which has a preset diaphragm and a built-in lens hood. The lens mount is the bayonet type.

DARIEN, Conn., Sept. 19 -- A 2 1/2-year-old Doberman pinscher not yet in the flower of his full development became best in show today in his first American appearance. He was Bordo v. d. Angelburg of Westphalia, imported from Germany last December by F. F. H. Fleitmann of Plainfield, N. J.

TANGIER, Sept. 10 -- The term of the Tangier Legislative Assembly, appointed for four years, ends Oct. 11. Nearly all the old members have been reappointed by their respective consuls general, but there are a few changes.

ROME, Sept. 19 -- A committee of eight experts reported today the "complete failure" of all efforts so far to control polio and condemned the widespread and indiscriminate administration of gamma globulin.

James Earle Fraser's heroically proportioned bronze equestrian group of Theodore Roosevelt that stands outside Roosevelt Memorial Hall of the American Museum of Natural History, was an object of considerable neck-craning last week by a passerby and museum visitors.

BORN in Russia under the imperial regime, Michael Florinsky emigrated after the Bolshevik revolution. He lived, first, in London as a student and researcher in Russian history; for more than twenty years he has taught economics at Columbia University. He has written extensively on the last years of imperial Russia and on the Bolshevik revolution; impressed by these studies, Macmillan asked him in 1934 to write a history of Russia.
The American Press Institute of Columbia University will mark its eighth year with an expanded program of seven seminars for newspaper men and women beginning Nov. 30.

A boatload of New Englanders landed here at 8:40 o'clock last night in a one-night revival of the Fall River steamship line, which went out of existence in 1937 after ninety years of service between Fall River and Newport, Mass. and New York.

The fascination a match holds for practically all children led a 5-year-old boy yesterday to start a fire that killed his 11-month-old sister in her crib and destroyed a five-story tenement in Harlem.

IN CONTRAST to the many complaints concerning television standards, I would like to sound a note of acclaim for, and a vote of confidence in, the capabilities of the exceptionally high-caliber actors, from Broadway predominantly, who turn in consistently creditable -- and often memorable -- performances in TV's dramatic shows.

TRENTON, Sept. 19 -- Harold G. Hoffman, director of the New Jersey Employment Security Division, reported today that the state had $502,210,536 on deposit in the United States Treasury as of Aug. 31 to the credit of the Federal Unemployment Trust Fund.

IN one sense every book is a religious book, since each inevitably reveals its author's belief about God and man. Niall Brennan's THE MAKING OF A MORON (Sheed Ward, $2.50), which examines the condition of society and the individual under industrial capitalism, might not seem, at first glance, to be concerned with religious matters.

FORTUNATELY, "The World of Sholom Aleichem" has come back to the little Barbizon-Plaza theatre for a limited autumn engagement. The return is fortunate for several reasons. The literary material, translated out of the Yiddish, is humane, wise and delightful.

THE New York Dance Film Society, of which D. D. Livingston is director, will unite with the Katherine Dunham School in presenting a series of dance films with lecture-demonstrations at the school beginning Tuesday of this week.

A LITTLE after four every afternoon the red-coached passenger train sped through the little town of Grand Prairie, N. D., and that was the signal for hundreds of coffee pots to be taken off the backs of stoves and placed on the front burner.

Many of the most difficult problems of the liquor industry will be laid in the supposedly neutral laps of the officials of the so-called monopoly states as the National Alcoholic Beverage Control Association begins a three-day session at the New Yorker Hotel tomorrow.

MINEOLA, L. I., Sept. 19 -- Errors in navigation and strong offshore winds are causing many small land birds to overshoot Long Island in night migration flights to the South with many of them perishing in the Atlantic Ocean, according to local ornithologists.

UNITED NATIONS N. Y., Sept. 19 -- The Soviet Union demanded today that the United Nations General Assembly open a special debate on the composition of the Korean peace conference agreed to under the armistice.

LONG after the faster mountain streams have dried up in the summer's heat, canoe and foldboat enthusiasts may find good boating in the fall on many of the little rivers of New Jersey. The state abounds in streams ideal for small craft and delightful to persons who want to observe the scenery and the wildlife in peace.

The modern, one-story house on its small grounds calls for a new approach to many types of planting. One example is the most popular flower, the rose, for which a formal garden design has become traditional.

The skill and care with which railroad employes handle shipments of dangerous explosives was praised here yesterday by Lewin W. Wicks Jr., chairman of the traffic and law committee of the Eastern Railroads, as one of the principal reasons why railroads have managed for thirty-one years to carry explosives without a fatality.

MIAMI, Fla., Sept. 19 -- Nine of the sixteen Air Force men aboard a stricken B-29 hurricane-hunter plane bailed out over the Atlantic and were rescued today 200 miles east of Charleston, S. C. Seven others still were missing and may have gone down with the converted four-engined bomber.

IN the decades before and after 1900 it was the pleasant custom for historical scholars to gather together from time to time their occasional addresses and essays and for publishers to publish them and readers to read them. The custom is now obsolescent, almost antiquated.

BERKELEY, Calif., Sept. 19 (UP) -- Cotton Davidson played 59 1/2 minutes of inspired Alamo-type football today to lead Baylor to a stunning 25-0 victory over California before a crowd of 34,000 at Memorial Stadium.

While the candy industry's product is as sweet as ever, especially to the moppets fascinated by candy bars in marching rows on a television screen, the manufacturers are tasting more of the sour than the sweet.

The third annual In-Service Course for Teachers on Israel will open Wednesday at the High School of Commerce for a period of fourteen weeks, with highlights on cultural developments as expressed through music, dance and the arts. Lectures supplemented by audio-visual aids will note recent archaeological discoveries linking modern Israel with ancient Biblical days.

HICKSVILLE, L. I., Sept. 19 -- The thickly populated six square miles of Hicksville, an unincorporated section of the 100 square miles of the Town of Oyster Bay, is in the midst of controversy as to whether to become incorporated as a village or retain its present status.

THE book trade is none too flourishing in France now-adays. Many of the small publishing houses that had made a brilliant start immediately after the liberation have either collapsed altogether or been absorbed by old-established firms.

THE first museum in the world to be devoted entirely to folk art opened recently in Santa Fe, N. M. A unit of the Museum of New Mexico, it is known as the Museum of International Folk Art find is housed in a long, low building (above) set on a pinion-dotted hill two miles from the city's 300-year-old plaza.

HANOVER, N. H., Sept. 19 -- DeOrmond (Tuss) McLaughry, an elder statesman of football and a member of the rules committee, has long stood high among the coaching fraternity for his philosophical attitude toward the vagaries of fortune in his profession.

SYRACUSE, Sept. 19 (AP) -- Carmen Basilio's handlers, claiming they've got the uncrowned world welterweight champion in their camp, today demanded a return match with Cuban Kid Gavilan. But it looked as if Gavilan wouldn't be booking any more welterweight fights.

IN their mountain world of wood fires and bee trees, pine knobs and huckleberries. Peter Pocket and his Granny Messer live the pleasures and the privations of backwoods cabin folk. May Justus spins an easy-going tale of Peter's life, without dismissing the problems of clothing, food and shelter.

WESTBURY, L. I., Sept. 19 -- Cleo A. Young's Ferman Hanover, made the favorite in the eight-horse field in the $6,000 New Jersey Pace, did not disappoint his followers as he notched a length-and-a-quarter victory at Roosevelt Raceway tonight.

While the positions of Samuel Reshevsky, United States, and Vassily Smyslov, Russia, remained unchanged, with the American slightly in the lead, Miguel Najdorf of Argentina gained on them in the twelfth round of the world chess championship challengers' tournament in Zurich, last night.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 19 -- At one time or another, about twenty foreign ministers will attend this year's session of the United Nations General Assembly -- which is up to the average of recent years.
WRITING comedy, averred Selma Diamond the other day, is about as difficult as "scanning the racks at Klein's." Which, she said, isn't to imply that either task is an easy one.
The writer is a publicist operating in the purlieus of Broadway whose devotion to the legitimate drama is exceeded only by his appreciation of the Bard.

THE cold war which exists, though often unadmitted, between those whose criterion is "Is it a good film?" and those concerned only with the question "Will it make money?" has flared up more sharply than at any time in the past decade, and there has been a certain amount of shooting.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., Sept. 19 -- The thirty-fifth and penultimate regatta of the season for the Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound drew a fleet of sixty-six starters off the Larchmont Club today.

IN an empty, dusty theatre in the West Fifties, its bare stage lighted only by a single glaring bulb overhead, Mary Martin is currently preparing to become, for the first time since 1949 and some 1,300 enchanted evenings, someone other than Nellie Forbush, the Navy nurse and "cockeyed optimist" of "South Pacific."

PERHAPS one day someone will write a book entitled "Fabulous Old Romantic Creole Queen City New Orleans." Upon that happy day we will know that our New Orleans collection is at last complete. Until then they will keep coming.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- There are some signs that the executive and legislative branches of this Government, which now are unreluctantly parted, will be rather less than joyful at the reunion when Congress returns here at the turn of the year.

BY an unfortunate chronological miscue, one of the brightest periods of the American musical theatre -- the period of Jerome Kern, the Gershwins, Rodgers and Hart, the early Cole Porter -- took place before the original cast album and LP had been devised to preserve its better moments.

NOTHING provides a better armor against sneers than success, and the archers, having survived the loud laughter, amused tolerance and open disdain of the gun-bearing hunters, ran up an imposing score of big-game last year and the portents indicate that they will improve that score this fall.

DEFLATIONARY brakes in an inflationary economy can set the country back on its heels. Efforts to bring the Federal budget into balance are commendable, but if spending cuts cannot be made without harming the defense effort, additional revenue must be found.

THE second volume of Quincy Howe's story of the first half of our cataclysmic century covers the history of our times from the 1918 Armistice to the Munich surrender. It reviews two contradictory decades in which ancient empires collapsed, old orders and values vanished, strange fads attracted mass followings and new ideologies exerted global influence.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (UP) -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon appointed James B. Carey today to the Commission on Judicial and Congressional Salaries. Mr. Carey, who is secretary-treasurer of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, was one of three members named by Mr. Nixon.
The Lenox Hill Neighborhood Association will be the beneficiary of the performance of the Sadler's Wells Ballet on Wednesday night at the Metropolitan Opera House.
ONEONTA, N. Y., Sept. 19 -- Seventy years ago eight brakemen and switchmen met in a Delaware and Hudson Railroad caboose here and formed the Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen.

FALL is a season when roses are enjoyed for their display of brilliant bloom, for work on these plants does not begin until after a killing frost. Little maintenance is required by climbers, creepers and shrub roses, but hybrid teas, hybrid perpetuals and floribundas need certain care before winter.

This week is doubly endowed, for it brings both the autumn equinox and the full moon, the harvest moon which lingers in its fullness. Given reasonably clear skies, it should be a week of brilliant nights, nights which begin to lengthen beyond the days; and the turn toward autumn in the celestial almanac will be more than usually spectacular.

GARDENERS are experts at playing the waiting game. They wait for rain, they wait for sun, they wait for months to get a vine-ripened tomato. And right now they're starting the greatest waiting game of all -- fall planting. More than half a year will pass before they collect the stakes, but they're willing to wait because they know they can't lose.

ONE is apt to think of Richard and Frances Lockridge as specialists in the light humor - cum - romance mystery; but that impression is largely the result of the radio and TV adventures of Mr. and Mrs. North.
Your editorial of Sept. 13 "The 'Wetback' Scandal" will be heartily commended by all those who are concerned with the flood of illegal immigrants from Mexico into our country.

MOSCOW, Sunday, Sept. 20 (UP)--An agreement was reached yesterday providing Soviet aid for North Korean reconstruction and expansion of cultural ties between the two countries. The accord was signed by Soviet Foreig-Minister Vyacheslav M. Molotov and North Korean Foreign Minister Nam II.

RICHMOND, Sept. 19 (UP) -- L. Q. (Hadacol) Hines, 150-pound former water boy who swapped his bucket for a headgear, kicked a 17-yard field goal today to help William and Mary upset Wake Forest, 16 -- 14, before 15,000 fans.

ONE of the most interesting figures in the French theatre today is a young man of 30 -- Marcel Marceau. He brings no contribution to the legitimate stage for he has chosen the neglected art of the mime as his medium. He is earning a slow success in his own country, while abroad his art is eagerly appreciated.

Barbara Berch Jamison's "Of Mouse and Man" (Sept. 13) was a well-deserved tribute to one of Walt Disney's most eminent cartoon characters -- the pioneer of them all, indeed. There was another one, who only appeared once, as far as I know, but who is unforgettable to me.

PIONEER physician and founder of Crossnore School, Dr. Mary Martin Sloop is a dynamic and unique personality. Born on the campus at David-Son College, where her father taught science, she secretly resolved at the age of 5 to become a foreign medical missionary.

THE workmanlike historical novels of Bruce Lancaster are short on sex, long on history. It's the kind of history that goes down easily and has made books like this America's favorite way of learning about the past.

CHICAGO, Sept. 19 -- Manufacturing employment in Illinois edged upward to 1,319,900 in mid-August, the Director of Labor reported. At mid-July it had slipped to 1,314,100. A year ago a 38,500 gain was registered in the July-August period, compared with the 5,800 gain this year.

More facilities and services are needed in the Port of New York to take care of the spiritual and personal needs of German seamen, whose numbers have increased considerably with the re-establishment of German-flag ocean shipping, Dr. Hermann Brueckner, pastor of St. Matthew's Lutheran Church in Hoboken, N. J., said here yesterday.

BATON ROUGE, La., Sept. 19 (AP) -- An alert and aggressive Louisiana State University football team broke Texas' opening day record with a 20-7 upset victory tonight.

LOUIS PETERSON, like most of us, still remembers a childhood game in which someone said, "You may take a giant step," and you had to ask, "May I ?" If the someone replied, "Yes, you may," you stretched your young legs as far as they could stretch and took the biggest step you could possibly manage.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Sept. 19 -- In World War I women started the practice of working outside the home on well-paying jobs and in World War II the practice gained further momentum. Now, in this industrial city, one out of every three workers is a woman.

SOIL, sunlight, moisture and air are indispensable elements of the good lawn. Some grasses are at their best only in full, day-long sunshine; others can exist on three to five hours of direct midday sun. None can tolerate dense shade.

THE ultimate goal of every handicapped person is to become independent. At first he may be discouraged and feel "I cannot do it." But practice helps and he gradually learns to compensate for lost functions. Many disabling conditions, however, are so severe that some help is needed.

Thirty-one states are now levying a general sales tax, which is producing an income of between $20 and $35 per capita annually, Charles L. Sherwood, chief of Ohio's Sales Tax Division, told delegates to the thirty-eighth annual convention of the National Association of State Auditors, Controllers and Treasurers yesterday at the Commodore Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- Senator William E. Jenner, chairman of the Senate International Security Investigating subcommittee, said today that the employment record of Nathan Gregory Silvermaster showed that he remained in a key Government post a year after he had been cited as "a Soviet spy."

This has been the busiest summer in many years for worrying over whether some Americans owed other Americans too much for installment and credit purchases of automobiles, refrigerators, television sets and the like. For the reassuring record, one man who has more than a million Americans "on his cuff" for $1,250,000,000 says he goes home every night and sleeps with complete peace of mind.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- The Democrats had a love feast in Chicago this week which produced not only some affectionate cooing between the Northern and Southern wings of the party -- a quite notable achievement in itself -- but brought forth as well some promising strides toward effective party action in the Congressional elections of next year.

The men who turn out the nation's phonographs and records wore satisfied smiles last week. They took a long look at their sales books and found they are riding the crest of the greatest boom in the history of their industry.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 19 (UP) -- The Athletics jumped on Frank Shea for five runs in the first inning today and then went on to defeat the Senators, 6 -- 5, for their only victory in nine 1953 games the teams have played at Connie Mack Stadium.
Robert Payne says that the American is not a very good driver. It occurs to me that he compares favorably with some others.

In the Navy's time-honored way, men move from one task to another, broadening their own experience and spreading their usefulness, but often leaving behind a post that they have filled with extraordinary skill and understanding. Rear Admiral John M. Will will be transferred soon from his duties as Atlantic commander of the Military Sea Transportation Service to a sea command in the Pacific.

LUCILLE BALL is an extremely fortunate woman. Apparently her career in "I Love Lucy" is not to be affected seriously by her acknowledgement that in 1936 she had registered to vote as a Communist. Her sponsor is standing by her; the Columbia Broadcasting System has announced that her television show will continue, and many of her fans have written to make known their support.

NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 19 -- Large and important segments of the Indian reading public who are a particular target of Communist propaganda have been deprived of one of the principal United States informational services here because of Washington's drastic slash in funds and staff for this work.

THE picture of a home nestling under the friendly shade of trees seems to be forgotten in the present mass planting and building of houses. In the recent heat wave a number of these communities -- created on treeless plains -- became shimmering pools of light that reflected the sun's glare and intensified the heat.

AIRPLANES are faster and bigger than they ever were. As speed and size increase the difficulties presented by medical problems increase. The time is not far off when we shall be flying in thousand-mile-an-hour jet planes at altitudes of 50,000 feet Ross A. McFarland knows this and prepares his readers for it with what is probably the most comprehensive work on aviation medicine that has so far appeared.
PARIS, Sept. 19 -- The French Cabinet has been engaged this week in a great debate on foreign policy comparable to that provoked in the United States two years ago by the return of General MacArthur.

CHICAGO, Sept. 19 (AP) -- The American League will meet in New York Sept. 27 "to reach an understanding" regarding proposed transfer of the St. Louis Browns to another city, Will Harridge, president of the circuit, announced today.

LAST year saw still one more new festival of music, drama, and what not added to the already formidable list when the 2,000-year-old Bavarian town of Passau, on the Austrian border, inaugurated its first "Europaeische Wochen."

PIERRE, S. D. -- The five huge "main stem" dams which ultimately will control the Missouri River along its upper reaches already give travelers crossing the Great Plains areas of South Dakota and Eastern Montana a chance to see some of the most ambitious engineering operations ever attempted as well as a variety of recreational opportunities.

A New York shipping man, Howard S. Kennedy, special representative of the Moore-McCormack Lines, has been lent by the line to the United Nations to help Indonesia organize its merchant marine.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 19 -- The International Longshoremen's Association was making frantic last-minute efforts here tonight to stave off expulsion from the American Federation of Labor.

WE are all lamentably used to the short story of assembly-line manufacture, complete with reversible plot and interchangeable characters. And we are all more or less accustomed to the anxious, experimental kind of story, with private meaning presumably abloom somewhere within the dark thicket of its phrases.

IN a writing life of less than twenty years D. H. Lawrence wrote something like fifty volumes of prose and verse. By now, twenty-three years after his death, probably as many volumes have been published about Lawrence.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 19 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon will address the American Federation of Labor convention here next Wednesday as personal representative of President Eisenhower.

PICTURING Miami Beach as a bonanza resort community that keeps growing and thus has to search continually for more visitors, the resort's newly elected Mayor Harold Shapiro last week said here that his two major efforts to that end would be development of winter package vacations and stimulation of convention business.

A lawn seed mixture of good quality grasses has never been the lowest-priced item in any seed catalogue. It has always seemed expensive in comparison with the price of a package of bean or marigold seed. This fall it is not inflation which pushes the average price of a pound of lawn seed from about $1.50 to the neighborhood of $1.80.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- The Maritime Administration reported this week that the active United States ocean-going merchant fleet of vessels measuring 1,000 gross tons or more had decreased by four vessels to 1,481 during the month ended Sept. 1.

THE Post Office Department's announcement that postage on an ordinary letter to foreign countries (except Canada and Mexico) is to he advanced to 8 cents, from 5, effective Nov. 1, will affect the postal paper of the United Nations in 1954.

HAGERSTOWN, Md., Sept. 19 (UP) -- Senator Olin D. Johnston, Democrat of South Carolina, assailed President Eisenhower today as "Resourceful Alibi Ike" who knew no more about farm problems than "Little Bo Peep."

Butler University (Indianapolis, Ind.) will confer the Specialist in Education degree upon graduate students who successfully complete the second year of graduate work in specialized areas of education. The new degree is viewed as a step above and beyond the master's degree in the professional preparation for education, and not as a terminal degree.

Many persons who have been discharged from hospitals after lengthy illnesses are confronted with the serious problems of making social and economic readjustments. For men and women who have been patients in mental institutions, the situation is even more serious and complex because of the public suspicion, doubt and rejection that they often encounter.

Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt's Native Dancer, the 3-year-old gray colt with the eighteen-for-nineteen record, will do no more racing this year. Vanderbilt, with his trainer, William C. Winfrey, visited the Aqueduct press box yesterday and made that announcement.

BOSTON, Sept. 19 (AP) -- Boston's Wilbur Wilson and Gerald Dreyer of South Africa battled to a bruising draw in their return nationally televised ten-round bout tonight at the Boston Garden. Wilson weighed 145 3/4 pounds, Dreyer 147 1/4.

BOTH of the American premieres on this week's schedule of the Sadler's Wells Ballet at the Metropolitan will be by Frederick Ashton The first will be "Don Juan" on Thursday, and the second "Daphnis and Chloe" on Friday.

IN the course of its fall season, running from Oct. 8 to Nov. 8, the New York City Opera will produce an opera new to America -- Gottfried von Einem's "The Trial," based on the novel by Kafka. This opera has been hailed by some of the German critics who heard it at its world premiere in Salzburg last month, and it won a less enthusiastic reaction from some American observers.

SOME years ago readers of the magazine Astounding Science Fiction were delighted with the publication of the warm and unique "In Hiding": an intuitive study of children mutated into moppet geniuses by exposure of their mother during pregnancy to atom radiations.

JACK WATSON was the man in the middle at the first fight between Rocky Marciano and Roland La Starza. He was the referee. As a matter of fact, he was the man in the middle in more ways than one. At the end of a close, rugged fight, the ring officials handed their scorecards to the announcer, Johnny Addie. He blinked when he saw them.

PROBABLY this is the last life of the acid, stubborn and haughty Senator from Massachusetts. For any who might be puzzled over why it has been written, John A. Garraty explains that two earlier biographers were over-friendly to Henry Cabot Lodge (1850-1924).

WE speak of a tender, juicy steak; the words sum up an appetizing meal. But there are also the tough steaks, not so immediately appealing but, under the ministrations of a good cook, worthy of being set before a gastronome.

MANCHESTER, Vt. -- The New England autumn used to be something people read about, with nostalgia, in the poems of Robert Frost. But in recent years more and more city people have shaken themselves loose to drive long distances for the sake of these warm days of golden haze and the cool crisp nights.

A FLICK of a hurricane not long ago sent a Panamanian freighter, the Evgenia, skipping - over a sand bar off Cape Cod and stranded her.
