Before the gale had subsided, the veteran salvage vessel Curb plowed out into the Atlantic from her Staten Island berth, and, as this is written, was still trying to pull her back into the water.

The arrival of cooler weather was a major help to retail trade last week. The temperature averaged five degrees below the same 1952 week. This fact, coupled with the post-Labor Day seasonal gain, was enough to give most stores small gains over 1952, even though the religious holidays were a deterrent.

Prof. Joseph L. Tynan, who is 71 years old, has retired from the faculty of City College, thereby bringing to a close a career of more than half a century as a student and teacher in the institution. He had been a member of the English Department since 1906.

A kiwi, a bird that cannot fly under its own power, paused in New York last night on its 11,000-mile airplane flight from Auckland, N. Z., to London. This specimen, a male 11 months old and named Ngapuhi by the Maori children of Auckland, is being imported by the London Zoo.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (UP) -- Roger W. Lapham, former Mayor of San Francisco, has been proposed as Secretary of Labor by influental friends of President Eisenhower.

OSAKA, Japan, Sunday, Sept. 20 -- The world flyweight champion, Yoshio Shirai, badly out of condition, lost a non-title bout to the seventh-ranking contender, Leo Espinosa of the Philippines, last night on a surprising technical knockout in the seventh round.

THIS inspiriting and authoritative account rescues from misunderstanding and obscurity a gallant creative achievement. It enables the sympathetic reader to relive the saga of the heroic remnants from the concentration camps who valiantly rebuilt their lives and then helped to establish and defend a pioneer nation.

TOKYO, Sunday, Sept. 20 -- Communist authorities disclosed yesterday that they were postponing until Thursday the delivery into neutral custody of Allied prisoners of the Korean war who the enemy says refused to return to their homelands. The transfer of those prisoners was to have begun today.

LIMA, Peru, Sept. 19 -- The Peruvian Senate last night ratified the agreement on civil aviation signed last month with Brazil and hailed here by Senator Hector Boza, Vice President of the Republic, as "one more link between our countries in the political, the social, the cultural and the economic fields."

Women of society, headed by Mrs. Walted D. Fletcher, are serving on the committee for Red Cross Day which will be held on Sept. 29 at Belmont Park for the benefit of five New York chapters of the American Red Cross, the Nassau County Chapter and the national Red Cross fund.

LONDON, Sept. 20 -- While 10,000 Roman Catholics marched the Penitential mile today at Canterbury where King Henry II walked barefoot nearly 800 years ago in penance for the murder of Thomas a Becket, a descendant of the Beckets presented a relic of the martyred archbishop to St. Thomas Roman Catholic Church of Canterbury.

Two pistol shots punctuated the close of the 10 A. M. solemn high mass at St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday as Detective Mary A. Shanley, a nemesis of criminals for twenty-two years, caught a woman pickpocket suspect on the Cathedral's Fifty-first Street terrace.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 20 -- The all-powerful executive council of the American Federation of Labor voted unanimously tonight to expel the crime-infested International Longshoremen's Association and to set up a new union to battle it out for control of the docks.
To the submarine service the Thames River in Connecticut always has meant "home from the sea."

PRINCETON, N. J., Sept. 20 -- America's universities are in danger of succumbing to "projectitis" if they do not keep their research projects under control, Dr. Harold W. Dodds, president of Princeton University, said today.

WISNER, Neb., Sept. 20 -- Production and feeding of beef cattle, for the last year the weakest element in the Missouri Basin's farm economy, appeared this week to have staged a partial recovery in some phases.

Tribute was paid yesterday to the memory of the late Fiorello H. La Guardia, former Mayor of New York, as the La Guardia Memorial Association held its sixth annual service at his grave in Woodlawn Cemetery, the Bronx.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 20 -- Adolph Zukor, board chairman of Paramount Pictures and a fifty-year veteran of the movie industry, said today he was convinced that motion pictures, for many years to come, would be made in a variety of techniques, with individual stories using the one best suited to it.

TOKYO, Monday, Sept. 21 (AP) -- A Japanese educator who won the $25,000 Stalin Peace Prize last year reported from Moscow yesterday that the Soviet Union was "prepared to cooperate" in the return of Japanese prisoners of World War II still held by the Russians.

The long-predicted dissolution of the National Federation of American Shipping, which has been the maritime industry's voice in the nation's capital for the last nine years, will become a fact on Sept. 30.

GROSSINGER, N. Y., Sept. 20 -- "This guy don't need a doctor. He's in the finest condition of his career." Dr. Vincent A. Nardiello, physician for the New York State Athletic Commission, had to lapse into the argot to emphasize the excellence of Rocky Marciano's physical condition, after examining the heavyweight champion of the world today.

The "device" of landlords of using a commercial-lease agreement to obtain more than the maximum rent for an apartment brought a ruling yesterday by Joseph D. McGoldrick, State Rent Administrator, in favor of the tenants.

TOKYO, Monday, Sept. 21 -- Akahata (Red Flag), the official organ of the Japanese Communist party, today branded Ritsu Ito, one of seven missing Japanese Communist party leaders a "traitor" and announced that he had been ousted from influential party positions.

LONDON, Sept. 20 -- The National Airlines of the United States is negotiating for the purchase of Britain's new jet-powered Comet II and her, as yet, untested Comet III airliners, Robert E. Weiland, vice president of the line, said tonight.

There are times when the standard Communist double-talk gets beyond the realm of the menacing and into the world of the fantastic and ridiculous. The "black is white" and "war is peace" technique of the Kremlin and its stooges is fairly well known by this time among most rational persons, but some of its manifestations still come, now and then, as a shock.

A large undeveloped plot at Tuckahoe and Bronxville Roads near Central Avenue in the Tuckahoe neighborhood of northeast Yonkers, N. Y., has been sold by Hertha Moser to investing clients of Travis S. Levy, lawyer, of New York City.

BOSTON, Sept. 20 -- The Yankees finally regained their winning touch today as they brought down Lou Boudreau's Red Sox, 10 -- 8, to the keen disappointment of 29,188 onlookers. On several other counts, as might be indicated by the size of the score, the day was still a bit of a bust for Casey Stengel.

In his recent letter, Hyman Abosh, in support of his conclusion that teachers' salaries compare favorably with those received by truck drivers and industrial workers, cited certain figures which may have left casual readers with erroneous impressions.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 20 (AP) -- Shortstop Joe DeMaestri's single scored Tommy Giordano from second with the winning run as the Athletics beat the Senators, 4 -- 3, in eleven innings in the second game of a double-header today.

CHICAGO, Sept. 20 (AP) -- The White Sox won a double-header from the Browns today, 4 -- 0 and 5 -- 2, as Virgil Trucks became the first twenty-game winner for the Chicago club since Thornton Lee in 1941. In the second game Ferris Fain, Sox first baseman, made his 1,000th major league hit, a line single to left center.

Robert G. Burke, announced independent candidate for Manhattan Borough President, proposed yesterday that all non-Civil Service appointees in the city government be required to pass scrutiny by panels of professional men. He likened his plan to bar association examination of candidates for judiciary posts.

A sold-out house greeted the Quartetto Italiano last night in the Kaufmann Auditorium of the Lexington Avenue "Y." This was the first of six concerts, in two series, that the Italian organization will give through Oct. 10.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -- The small business administration, which on Friday was prepared to announce a new loan policy, modified its stand on interest rates today.

LONDON, Sept. 20 -- Harold Wilson, a member of the House of Commons who was President of the Board of Trade in the former Labor regime, assailed the Government today for having done nothing since the Korean armistice to lift the restrictions "paralyzing" East-West trade.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -- United States agricultural exports dropped 31 per cent in value in the last year, to the lowest point since 1944-45, prompting Secretary of Agriculture Ezra Taft Benson to reiterate today that the situation showed sharply the need for more effective farm programs and foreign trade policies.

The Publication Corporation announced yesterday that its new "Alco Process," method of gravure printing with Dupont Ortho Roto-film, will soon be available at its Hoboken and Los Angeles plants, as it already is at the Chicago plant for magazines, newspaper supplements, books, calendars, cards and packaging, as well as on fabrics and plastics.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 20 -- Arthur B. Bisguier of New York, former holder of the national open title and twice champion of the Manhattan Chess Club, won the challengers' tournament of the United States Chess Federation tonight, with a score of 8 1/2 -- 1 1/2, after defeating Koit Tullus of Seabrook, N. J., in the tenth and final round.

The lives of Navy jet pilots and the complex and costly aircraft they fly are being safeguarded by a new electronic device that "clocks" an approaching plane and indicates whether or not it is coming in at a safe landing speed.

CHICAGO, Sept. 20 -- Grain futures markets underwent erratic and extensive price moves last week, with a late-week slump in wheat. While the bread grain was under pressure there was considerable buying of corn, which held comparatively well, and somewhat better support in rye and oats on the setbacks in spite of sizable receipts of Canadian grain.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 20 -- Steel-making operations for the past week were scheduled at 90 per cent of rated capacity, up one point from the previous week's rate. Based on performance to date, September output will probably be close to 91 per cent of capacity.

Only slightly more than three years after the ratification of the North Atlantic Pact NATO's Navy and its allied forces conducted their first exercises on the northern flank of Europe last year. "Operation Main Brace" was an operation in which the navies of the

TORRINGTON, Conn., Sept. 20 -- Best in show in the annual event of the Northwestern Connecticut Dog Club today went to a pug, Ch. Pugville's Mighty Jim, owned by Pugville Kennels, Croton-on-Hudson, and handled by Walter Foster. The placement was made by Lewis S. Worden.
WESTBURY, L. I., Sept. 20 -- A couple of Smiths stole the show today in the second match of the thirty-seventh national open polo championship on International Field at the Meadow Brook Club.

POINT LOOKOUT, L. I., Sept. 20 -- Two men and a 12-year-old boy negotiated the treacherous currents of Jones Inlet in a four-teen-foot outboard motorboat here early this morning only to be dumped into the Atlantic by heavy surf 500 feet from the shore.

A "compartmentalized view of living," which places religion and daily work on autonomous levels, is the "spiritual subversive" of our time, the Rev. Dr. J. Gordon Chamberlin declared yesterday at Riverside Church.

Woodrow Wyatt, an Oxford graduate and active member of the British Labor party, presents a picture of international affairs in his book "Into the Dangerous World," which Roy Publishers will issue next Monday. In this autobiographical approach to the problem of defending Asia from communism he illumines from his travels the relationships between East and West.

Scientists and engineers employed by the Arma Corporation, producer of precision equipment for the Armed Forces and the Atomic Energy Commission, voted last night to join striking electricians in a united labor front.

CHICAGO, Sept. 20 -- Wheat futures on the Board of Trade showed great increase in activity last week, purchases being 114,899,000 bushels against 69,243,000 the previous week and only 31,916,000 a year ago. Trade in the bread grain was accelerated by sharp declines, which reflected heavy long liquidation.

LONDON, Sept. 20 -- Although for some weeks past the City has been talking fairly optimistically about the chances of a reduction in bank rate some time this fall, it was nevertheless taken completely and, of course, very pleasantly by surprise when the Bank. of England announced the change from 4 to 3 1/2 per cent on Thursday.

George Pokanson of Westwood, N. J., and Ed Giampoli of the Bronx won the one-hour team race, the specialty feature, by one lap in the Flushing bicycle festival on the Flushing Meadows bike track in Corona yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -- A task force of the Senate Internal Security subcommittee urged Congress today to enact a law designed either to halt the continuing flow of tons of Communist propaganda into and within the United States or force the propagandists to declare the nature of their material.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 20 -- Andrei Y. Vishinsky will take the center of the stage at the United Nations tomorrow to push the Soviet demand for reopening of debate on the composition of the Korean peace conference, a demand that the United States believes it can defeat for the time being.
Love of God, "the central commandment" for Christians and Jews, should be "vitally active" and not a sentiment locked within the heart, the Rev. Harry J. Wolff declared yesterday.

The New York State Fire Fighters Association in convention assembled has adopted a resolution demanding repeal of the Condon-Wadlin law, which forbids strikes on the part of civil service employes in this state. Nothing could be better calculated to fortify public opinion behind the law, and keeping it, than to have firemen -- of all people -- come out against it.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 20 (AP) -- The Cardinals pounded five Cub pitchers for fifteen hits, including three triples and two home runs, to defeat the Cubs today, 11 -- 6, and Gerry Staley won his eighteenth victory of the year.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Sept. 19 -- A Congressional investigation of meat prices appeared possible today because of the increasing spread between prices paid by consumers and prices paid to farmers for live cattle.

A memorial exhibition of paintings by the well-known teacher and painter, Kenneth Hayes Miller, opening at the National Academy on Wednesday; Thursday's reopening of the Metropolitan Museum's galleries of Egyptian art, repainted and rearranged, and an exhibition, opening tomorrow at the American Museum of Natural History, of contemporary arts and crafts of India are three of the more important art events of this week.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 20 (AP) -- Ken Rosewall of Australia defeated Victor Seixas of the United States in the final round of the Pacific Southwest tennis tournament today. Rosewall came through by scores of 6 -- 4, 1 -- 6, 3 -- 6, 6 -- 1, 6 -- 4.

PARIS, Sept. 20 -- The existing European Coal and Steel Community, an embodiment of supranational power, would be endangered by any watering down of the supranational character of the proposed Europea political community, experts on the treaties for these organizations said today.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Sept. 20 -- Emil R. Capita's Hi Q from the Port Washington Yacht Club finished with a corrected time of 6:18.43 to win the trophy in Group 3 in the eighth annual Manhasset Bay Yacht Club cruise to Stratford Shoal today.

BAKER, Calif., Sept. 20 (AP) -- Ten persons including a wedding-bound young couple were killed today in a collision on the desert highway to Las Vegas, Nev. A sedan carrying nine persons crashed head-on with a big truck-trailer.

During the past week the foreign exchange market passed through a period of extreme irregularity. The British pound sterling moved back and forth never seeming able to steady itself while the Canadian dollar displayed a very strong undertone. Business was reported to have picked up considerably over the previous week.

In the Sept. 7 issue of THE NEW YORK TIMES I read the letter by John L. Lewine commenting on some opinions by Prof. Theodore Andersson of Yale University on the subject of linguistics, particularly Esperanto.

More and more school bells are ringing out this year for homemakers who want to learn about interior decorating and antiques, or how to become more adept in the arts and crafts. Registration for courses in specialized schools, universities, museums, libraries and other centers in the metropolitan area will begin today.

ALBANY, Sept. 20 -- The State Board of Law Examiners announced today the names of 1,025 persons who passed the examination for admission to the bar held June 25 and 26. A total of 1,960 applicants took the test.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -- Initial thinking at the Defense Department held that the pilot who landed the MIG-15 jet at Kimpo airfield was eligible for the $100,000 reward offered last spring by General Clark.

Former President Truman, in his first commercial appearance on television, told the children of the country yesterday that their duty was to work by deed and example "to bring, the nations of the world together." He urged that they dedicate themselves "unswervingly to honest, democratic principles."

A bewildered 34-year-old Brooklyn Post Office clerk was arraigned yesterday in Brooklyn Felony Court as a fugitive from New Jersey on an assault and robbery charge that stemmed, the defendant declared, from a traffic dispute last Friday night on Route 1 near New Brunswick, N. J.
Seven new films, including imports from Britain, Switzerland and the Soviet Union, will open in first-run theatres this week. The schedule is:

CAIRO, Sept. 20 -- Gen. Sir Brian Robertson returned here from London aboard a jet airliner early today to resume negotiations with the Egyptian Government over the disputed title to the huge Suez Canal military base. Secret informal talks were interrupted a fortnight ago when General Robertson flew to London to confer with Prime Minister Sir Winston Churchill and the British Cabinet on disagreements remaining in the way of a settlement.

TOKYO, Monday, Sept. 21 -- The joint Korean Military Armistice Commission has scheduled a meeting this afternoon, at the request of the Communists, for an undisclosed reason. It was considered possible the Reds might be prepared to give a report on the list of missing Allied personnel who the United Nations Command says were at one time in Communist custody.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., Sept. 20 -- Only forty-three skippers turned out for the final Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound regatta today. Those who failed to appear missed some fine sailing. There was a steady fifteen-knot southerly breeze and all hands were kept busy as the craft skimmed over the windward and leeward courses.

HONG KONG, Sept. 20 -- Meetings of the Central People's Government Executive Council (Cabinet), which lasted all last week in Peiping, have emphasized a new trend in Chinese policy that the truce in Korea has reinforced.

DURBAN, South Africa, Sept. 20 (Reuters) -- African mobs set fire to eight Indian-owned stores and damaged and looted at least six others tonight in a wave of rioting in Cato Manor, a native shanty area near Durban, after an Indian bus had killed an African boy.

CAIRO, Monday, Sept. 21 -- Army trucks loaded with troops carrying rifles and fixed bayonets raced through dark, deserted streets into fashionable residential districts early today to rouse and arrest officials and politicians of the former monarchial regime.

A gallery of drawing styles is on view in the new collection of patterned decorative fabrics at J. H. Thorp Co. Along with a group of new textured upholstery materials, the fabrics are available through decorators in that concern's luxuriously refurbished showroom at 250 Park Avenue.
One thousand persons attended an annual ceremony in Brooklyn's Prospect Park yesterday honoring the memory of 400 Maryland soldiers who fought in the Battle of Long Island on Aug. 27, 1776.
Ever-increasing air traffic in the sub-Arctic regions has led to the establishment of a traffic control system for keeping track of criss-crossing airplanes and for weather and rescue operations.

CHARLESTON, S. C., Sept. 20 (AP) -- Three survivors of the stricken B-29 hurricane-hunter plane, who were rescued from an eighteen-hour ordeal at sea, said today that their craft had burst into flames without warning before going into the sea Friday night. Two of the airmen said they had fought off a shark before being saved.

Prince River, an 8-year-old brown gelding owned by Fred Blum of Brooklyn and ridden by Johnny Bell, won the open jumper championship and his stablemate, Stray Star, a bay gelding, took reserve at the Kings County horse show on Kimball Field, Brooklyn, yesterday.

The seventy-second annual convention of the American Federation of Labor, which opens in St. Louis today, faces a nation and a world whose multifold problems affect all wage-earners. This parliament of labor will have the task of preparing policies to advance peace, progress and general prosperity.

Herbert A. O'Brien, City Civil Defense Director, urged yesterday that in the public participation air raid drill on Friday at 9:30 A. M. all motorists draw up to curbs and park their automobiles before going to shelters. This would apply particularly where automobiles happened to be halted in the middle of the streets at red traffic lights, when the city's 579 air raid sirens sounded the "Red Alert."

There was a little of everything at Ebbets Field yesterday as the Dodgers beat the Phils, 5 -- 4, in a rather slow first game, and the Phils won, 2 -- 1, in the second game, which the umpires called at the end of five innings because of darkness.

BERLIN, Sept. 20 -- After six months of negotiation the United States, Britain, France and the Soviet Union were reliably reported today to have reached agreement in principle on a system of signaling between planes designed to eliminate air incidents over Germany.

Last week's events demonstrated conclusively that the issue of national agricultural policy is now major. The Democratic attacks on Secretary of Agriculture Benson at Chicago have been followed by the Secretary's rejoinder last Saturday, a rejoinder marked by an unusually defensive note.

DETROIT, Sept. 20 (AP) -- Mike Garcia won his eighteenth game of the season today, hurling the Indians to a 6 -- 3 victory over the Tigers in the second game of a doubleheader. Detroit slammed four homers -- two by Steve Souchock -- in taking the opener, 8 -- 6.

PARIS, Sept. 20 -- It is difficult for an American in Paris at this moment to pay much attention to anything but the remarkable debate going on inside the Cabinet on whether or not France will join the Western Defense Community.

Seventy-five new second lieutenants, graduates of the New York National Guard's Officer Candidate School, were sworn into the guard at commencement exercises held yesterday in the 165th Regiment Armory, Lexington Avenue and Twenty-sixth Street.

Belmont Park's fall race meeting, which will run for three weeks, will open today. Seven stakes races are scheduled this week, and the first-day feature will be the fortieth running of the Fall Highweight Handicap, for $20,000 in added money.
A program to build 312 new school buildings in the city at a cost of $500,000,000 was urged yesterday by Charles J. Bensley of the Board of Education to eliminate "overcrowding and obsolescence."
Rudolph Halley, the Liberal party's nominee for Mayor, condemned yesterday the action of the State Harness Racing Commission in holding secret hearings in its investigation of the Yonkers Raceway.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -- Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway, Army Chief of Staff, said today our treasured American liberties were "challenged" and that "no price would be too high to pay" to keep them.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -- Confronted with a British demand to pay up or buy elsewhere, Brazil has asked the International Monetary Fund for a $28,000,000 sterling loan with which to make a down payment on arrearages of about $180,000,000 in her trade account with Britain.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -- The next slice of United States aid from the $45,000,000 granted to impoverished Iran three weeks ago will probably be in the form of about $12,000,000 worth of sugar.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 20 (UP) -- Rookie fullback Buck McPhail kicked three field goals to give the Baltimore Colts a 9-3 victory over the Washington Redskins at Memorial Stadium today in the Colts' home exhibition opener before 22,800.

The Giants did not leave 'em laughing, as the curtain was rung down on 1953 baseball activities at the Polo Grounds yesterday. To put it bluntly, if any of the 4,717 fans did any laughing at all, it was at, not with the Giants, who dropped an 8-4 decision to Bob Friend and the eighth-place Pirates.
Dramatized versions of historic incidents in downtown Manhattan since New Amsterdam was incorporated 300 years ago will be presented weekly over WNYC beginning Thursday at 6:30 P. M.

Stripes, plaids and checks take an important place in the fashion picture, with stripes leading in popularity. Gay and diversified shades in two-tone or in multi-color combinations make interesting patterns in a variety of fabrics.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -- The way Lou Fageol drives a super-powered speed boat, admittedly a dangerous sport, makes it look so simple and easy. This was especially true today when he was in the cockpit of Slo-mo-shun V, which became the twenty-second winner of the President's Cup, even if a rival captured the third and final heat.

An independent, non-commercial agency, the Kansas Agricultural Experiment Station, has done a technical study on the effectiveness of a meat tenderizer on beef steaks and roasts. The results are reported in a recent issue of the monthly publication, Food Technology.

OYSTER BAY, L. I., Sept. 20 -- J. M. Mathews' Vim won the twenty-mile race for the twelve-meter craft and took the Robert Center Memorial Trophy as the annual three-day cruise of the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club ended today.

It was a great week-end for "Swan Lake" at the Metropolitan Opera House, where the Sadler's Wells Ballet presented each of its four ballerinas in turn in the leading role. Margot Fonteyn, who danced it last night, and Violetta Elvin, who did it the night before, have both been seen in it earlier this season, but for Rowena Jackson and Nadia Nerina it was a first time, as far as New York is concerned.
Three men were killed and two injured in early morning accidents yesterday in Brooklyn. One of the dead was the victim of a hit-and-run driver.
PARIS, Sept. 20 -- A controversy has arisen in high financial circles over the lowering of the discount rate last Thursday by the Bank of France at the request of Edgar Faure, Minister of Finance.

CHICAGO, Sept. 20 (AP) -- Stephen A. Mitchell, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, suggested today that prizes be awarded to members of Congressional committees who "do the best job." He voiced the idea in a question-and-answer session on the National Broadcasting Company's television program "American Forum of the Air."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -- A plea for greater independence for the Federal Trade Commission, particularly freedom from domination by the Executive Branch of the Government, was made today by Stephen J. Spingarn, retiring Democratic member of the quasi-judicial Government agency.

In the first definitive economic study of traffic congestion in twenty-nine years, the Citizens Traffic Safety Board reported yesterday that traffic blights cost business and the motoring public here an estimated $1,082,200,000 annually.

The Eastern College Athletic Conference issued a ruling yesterday applying to servicemen returning to school after military duty. The edict permits veterans returning to college to continue their athletic careers at the approximate point where they were interrupted.

Leo Pap in his letter published Sept. 12 maintains that the United States must not complain about the employment of American Communists at the United Nations, because these people were hired "as 'private individuals,' i. e., as international civil servants."

At the annual dinner of the American Museum of Safety our two major forms of public passenger travel, rail and air, were honored for their constant and successful efforts toward greater safety. The famous Harriman Gold Medals were presented to Class I Railroads in three groups differentiated by a yardstick of locomotive-miles operated during the preceding year.

The fight against so-called "fake charities" is a never-ending one in a state and city the size of ours. Committees of the City Council have explored the situation in the city without so far attempting any remedial action. Now the New York State Joint Legislative Committee on Charitable and Philanthropic Agencies and Organizations has opened a full-scale drive to eliminate charity chiselers in the state.

Two Bronx boys, who sought escape from Sunday boredom by rampaging through their grammar school, wreaked a bigger mischief than they had bargained for when their depredations reached the fourth floor, which is used as an annex for the Bronx High School of Science.

SEOUL, Korea, Monday, Sept. 21 -- A Communist pilot landed his Russian-built MIG-15 fighter plane at Kimpo Airfield near Seoul at 9:24 A. M. today [8:24 P. M., Sunday, Eastern daylight time] and surrendered to the United States Fifth Air Force.

THERE was something almost symbolic about the fact that Buck Herzog died at the approximate time Carl Furillo had his fight with Leo Durocher in the most headlined baseball Donnybrook of the season. Buck's main claim to fame, you see, was his famous fight with Ty Cobb, perhaps the most celebrated brawl the diamond ever produced.

Three-dimensional motion pictures may lead to the discovery of visional defects in children that might otherwise remain unnoticed for some time, acording to Dr. T. R. Murroughs, associate professor of psychology at the Northern Illinois College of Optometry.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -- President Eisenhower began working today on the most fateful series of decisions to confront him since he moved into the White House precisely eight months ago.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 20 (AP) -- The great repatriation of American war prisoners neared an end today when the naval transport Gen. A. W. Brewster slid into her berth with 301 former captives, including a Medal of Honor winner.

PARIS, Sept. 20 -- The Radical party, whose members are included in the present governmental majority, called today for the regulating of the right to strike to avert the disruption of France's public services that occurred during the nation-wide walkouts in August.

The Port of New York Authority has announced the consolidation of its trade promotion and protection activities, as well as its research and statistics unit, into a single division in its port development department. The new section is to be known as the trade promotion and protection division, and it will handle the activities formerly dealt with in two separate offices.

Three weeks ago today it was hinted in this column that Jose Ferrer's drama season at the City Center might be advanced several weeks from the scheduled starting date of Dec. 11. That much is now correct, the new opening date having been fixed for the week of Nov. 9, probably on Nov. 13.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -- What the United States Government considers the completed drafts of bilateral military and economic agreements that would give it the right to use Spanish naval and air bases are reported today to be awaiting Generalissimo Francisco Franco's final decision.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 20 -- Former President Truman was revealed today to be an added speaker for the American Federation of Labor convention opening here tomorrow.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Sept. 20 -- A torch lit in Modin, the birthplace of Maccabeans, who successfully revolted in the second century B. C. against a Hellenic attempt to enforce the Olympian culture upon the Hebrews of Palestine, started the Maccabiah Games, the modern Jewish counterpart of the Olympic Games today in Ramat Gan, outside Tel Aviv.

WAY up on Broadway, where shoulder-high weeds grow in vacant lots and a wide strip of grass separates the sidewalk and the curb, New York's most persevering, most optimistic man hacks away daily at a mistake he made in 1926.

KYOTO, Japan, Monday, Sept. 21 (AP) -- A theory envisaging as many as six dimensions in an attempt to unravel the secret of the atom was the chief topic of discussion today among physicists in session here.
The ship charter market pursued its mediocre course last week, if anything worse than the week before.

For the first time in history "we are witnessing fear on a global scale," the Rev. Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell, minister of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, at Fifty-fifth Street, declared yesterday.

THE inspired juxtaposition of a quietly moving talk by former President Harry S. Truman and a modest play on the spirit of the pioneers in pre-Revolutionary days contributed yesterday to an unusually fine half-hour of television (3:30 P. M. on N. B. C.).

A mass blood donation will be made by military and civilian employes at Fort Totten, Bayside, Queens, today, when a Red Cross bloodmobile sets up in the Young Men's Christian Association building on the post.

The prices of cotton futures last week registered moderate but steady declines. At Friday's close active contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange were 31 to 44 points from the level of the previous week. The three nearer deliveries dropped to new life-of-contract lows in the final day's session.

MILWAUKEE, Sept. 20 (AP) -- The fans of the Braves shattered the National League's home attendance record today as 36,011 paid their way into County Stadium to set a season's mark of 1,826,397. The old record, set in Brooklyn's Ebbets Field in 1947, was 1,807,526.

Memories of the old Fall River Steamship Line, which plied between Fall River, Mass., and New York for ninety years before it went out of existence in 1937, were revived yesterday at a luncheon at the New Yorker Hotel.

JAMESBURG, N. J., Sept. 20 -- Joe Russo of West Orange and Mike Fuss, Twin Brooks, continued their steady golf of the past three days to take the J. Foster Abeel memorial tourney with a 2-and-1 victory over Gus Siciliano, Jumping Brook, and Donald Housen, Lakewood, at the Forsgate Country Club today.

A march up Fifth Avenue and a mass meeting at Manhattan Center yesterday marked the twentieth "Memorial Manifestation" of that dark hour in the history of the Ukraine when 6,000,000 inhabitants of the Russian "granary" were starved to quell the resistance of an independent people to the Soviet regime.
Small apartments and private homes accounted for most of the activity in Bronx real estate reported over the weekend.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Sept. 20 -- Sweden staged a series of anti-invasion maneuvers along the shores of the Baltic last week, and military authorities expressed satisfaction with the results.

SEOUL, Korea, Sept. 20 -- Two Chinese Communist armies with a combined strength of about 70,000 men are returning to China from North Korea. Two more Chinese armies with approximately the same number of men are expected to take the same route soon.

NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 20 -- Senator William F. Knowland, Republican of California, arrived here at 5 o'clock this morning, and before noon was deep in a "briefing session" on the exotic complexities of India. Those who took part included Ambassador George W. Allen and other top echelon officials of the United States Embassy, and the heads of Technical Cooperation Administration here, the United States Information Agency and the Ford Foundation.

The American Jewish Committee declared yesterday that information received from on-the-spot observers indicated that the Communists in East Germany had secretly renewed their anti-Semitic campaign and had purged the last few Government officials of Jewish origin.

I hope your readers will not take too seriously the letter of Salvador de Madariaga which you published in your issue of Sept. 16, warning us that if our Government concludes any agreement with General Franco the Spanish people will be insulted and will repudiate it when the General's regime falls, "as fall it must."
Congressional inquiries that assertedly cast suspicion on the loyalty of the Protestant ministry were criticized yesterday by two prominent Congregational clergymen.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -- A high Government source said tonight that the Central Intelligence Agency had been at work for weeks checking a flood of tips from individuals who said they knew the whereabouts of Lavrenti P. Beria, deposed Soviet Minister of Internal Affairs, and how he could be reached.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -- The president of the American Bankers Association is "unconcerned" about the business outlook and fears only that the nation may have learned to inflate too well."

In an effort to make Jerusalem a new industrial center in the Middle East, a special allocation of $5,000,000 in proceeds of State of Israel bonds has been set aside for the economic development of that city.

A five-play program, including revivals, opening the week of Oct. 19 at the Theatre de Lys in Greenwich Village, was announced yesterday by a team of ambitious feminine managers, Miranda d'Ancona and Audrey Milliard. The initial offering will be "Back to Methuselah," but it was not specified which of the three divisions of Shaw's marathon philosophical fantasy would be given.
Petitions to put Mayor Impellitteri on the voting machines as the candidate of the independent Experience party have been printed and are being circulated, close friends of the Mayor said yesterday.

An industrial plot of 4,100 square feet on the east side of Fifty-eighth Street, 50 feet south of Forty-first Drive, in Woodside, Queens, has been purchased by Anthony Lembo from Lester McArdle for the erection of a one-story factory building.

Net sales of the May Department Stores in the six months ended on July 31 were $205,349 000, against $193,959,000 a year ago, the company reported yesterday. Net income rose to $4,220,000 or 62 cents a common share, after preferred dividends, against $3,655,000, or 52 cents, a year ago.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 (UP) -- Two Democratic Senators, Richard B. Russell of Georgia, and Estes Kefauver of Tennessee, joined two Republicans today in opposing the idea of a national sales tax to replace levies that expire in January.

RYE, N. Y., Sept. 20 -- Armed with hammers, chisels, hatchets, crowbars, pinch bars and other tools suitable for wrecking houses, a squad of Rye citizens demolished the interior walls on the second floor of an old stone house here over the week-end -- in a worthy cause.

WILL DURANT, who takes all knowledge for his province and writes with as disillusioned elegance and worldly a wit as Bacon himself, has completed Volume V of his monumental and magnificent "The Story of Civilization." Less than three years ago his "The Age of Faith" was published. That enormous volume of 1,100 pages provided more information about the Middle Ages in clearer and more interesting form than any other book I have ever read.

Some day somebody must gather all the pages printed in the last century about the effect of changing money rates on the flow of funds and the business cycle. They would make a lovely bonfire by which to read "The Volume of Corporate Bond Financing Since 1900"* by W. Braddock Hickman of the National Bureau of Economic Research.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- The Air Force announced today that the North Korean pilot who had flown a Soviet-built MIG-15 to a United Nations airstrip near Seoul, Korea, would be paid the $100,000 reward offered during hostilities by Gen. Mark W. Clark, United States Far East commander. Whether the plane would be kept remained in doubt, however.

You could watch the races for a lifetime, care for horses personally, make friends with them, and still not have the slightest idea why the great ones run the way they do -- why at times they will even strain themselves to the point of death to finish first. In fact, you probably couldn't even come up with an explanation of why horses tolerate men on their backs to begin with.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Sept. 21 -- New warnings against the Communist danger in Indonesia were voiced in sessions held yesterday at Bandung by the Indonesian Moslem Association. Two thousand delegates convened for the congress of the association, which is one of the principal national Islamic groups in the country.

Vice President Richard M. Nixon said here yesterday that the "great majority" of the American people, including himself and President Eisenhower, had "faith and hope" in the United Nations. Mr. Nixon plans to make his first visit to the world organization's headquarters today.

Contract talks between the International Longshoremen's Union, which up to now is an affiliate of the American Federation of Labor, and the New York Shipping Association will be resumed at 10:30 A. M. today at the Governor Clinton Hotel, the employer group said yesterday.

The suit of the Federal Trade Commission against the Book-of-the-Month Club is still before the United States Supreme Court, where a petition for a writ of certiorari was filed on Aug. 18. This was disclosed yesterday by George Wolfson of Wolfson, Caton Moguel, attorneys for the club.

LONDON, Sept. 21 -- The internal conflict in the British Labor party was emphasized today by Aneurin Bevan in the reference to "our row" and the "awful noise" that would be made by millions of Socialists while settling it.

An application for a temporary injunction was filed in State Supreme Court yesterday seeking to restrain WOV, an independent radio station, from broadcasting a running account of the Rocky Marciano-Roland La Starza fight.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 21 (AP) -- Harvey Haddix hurled his nineteenth victory for the Cardinals this year, an impressive four-hit, 4-0, triumph over the Cubs tonight. Haddix also drove in one of the Redbird runs with a triple and scored another.

GENEVA, Sept. 21 -- The British opened their case today for freedom to impose customs duties on certain agricultural imports from continental Europe and immediately ran into a storm of protest from the Netherlands, Belgium and Denmark.

SEATTLE, Sept. 21 -- The Eisenhower Administration will never place any consideration ahead of the nation's security, Arthur S. Flemming, director of the Office of Defense Mobilization, pledged here today in an address to the annual convention of the American Mining Congress.

Congressman Reed announces that the sales tax has little chance of enactment. Even with economies achieved and in sight the budget cannot be balanced with the 1954 scheduled tax reductions. The sound dollar is essential to the safety of the nation and so is an adequate defense.

Spokesmen for the village of Freeport, L. I., and representatives of the Long Island Rail Road engaged in a wrangle yesterday at a Public Service Commission hearing on the question of whether additional grade crossing protection was necessary at that community's Brookside Avenue crossing.

Various ways in which art may be incorporated in the house and in a business office are shown at the second annual Art in Interiors exhibit opening today at the Midtown Galleries, 17 East Fifty-seventh Street. Five room settings, and a vignette arranged by six designers, make up the display.

MELBOURNE, Sept. 21 -- The village to house the visiting athletes and officials at the 1956 Olympic Games will be built at Heidelberg, a Melbourne suburb, by the Victorian Housing Commission with a four and quarter million dollar advance from the Australian Government. John Cain, the Prime Minister of Victoria, revealed this decision tonight.

TORONTO, Sept. 21 (Canadian Press) -- Noel Brunet of Montreal, one of Canada's best-known violinists, was named today as soloist in one of the major works to be played next month at a concert of Canadian music at New York's Carnegie Hall.

RIDGEWOOD, N. J., Sept. 21 -- Paul L. Troast, Republican candidate for Governor of New Jersey, charged New York State officials tonight with apathy and inaction in attacking the problem of providing better commuting facilities between New Jersey and New York.

BOSTON, Sept. 21 -- Their final game of the year in Boston wiped out by rain, the Yankees today headed back to New York where they will play out their remaining American League engagements before tackling the Dodgers in their bid for a fifth straight world series title.

The "oriental influence," an expression that has been bandied about a good deal in the last week, came to the fore again yesterday morning in a discussion at the National Home Furnishings Show at Grand Central Palace.

KIAMESHA LAKE, N. Y., Sept. 21 (AP) -- Mrs. Oveta Culp Hobby, Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, said tonight that the Eisenhower Administration had made "a good start" on overhauling the Government.
Five students who held jobs while attending high school and now are about to enter college each received a $200 Horatio Alger cash award yesterday at a ceremony in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 21 (AP) -- The United States Trotting Association today suspended one of the nation's leading harness race drivers for an infraction of a rule against administering a medicant to a horse before a race.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Sept. 21 (UP) -- Governor Johnston Murray today urged the University of Oklahoma Regents to consider disregarding the National Collegiate Athletic Association's television rules if the N. C. A. A. refused to permit state-wide telecasting of the Oklahoma-Notre Dame football game.
PRINCETON, N. J., Sept. 21 -Under the astute leadership of Charlie Caldwell, Princeton has been enjoying its happiest period on the gridiron since the regime of Fritz Crisler.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- Among the problems awaiting the President for settlement is the question of amending the Atomic Energy Act to legalize the exchange of much more atomic information with the allies of the United States than at present. And a very important part of the problem concerns making available to the armed forces associated with us in the collective security of the West our new atomic weapons and the technique of using them.

The New York City Housing Authority announced yesterday that it would receive bids on Sept. 29 on $48,658,000 of loan notes of two series for the temporary financing of the Stephen Foster Houses and the Governor Smith Houses, both low-rent state-aided projects.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (UP) -The Commodity Exchange Authority said today it proposed to raise from 1,000,000 to 2,000,000 bushels the daily speculative trading limit in the soybean futures market.

DETROIT, Sept. 21 -- Benjamin F. Fairless, board chairman of the United States Steel Corporation, told the Economic Club of Detroit today that talk of a recession was not justified by the facts. There was, however, a chance that the country might "predict" itself into a recession, he declared.

JOHANNES BURG, South Africa, Sept. 21 -- The war veterans organization Torch Commando has called on all regions of the Commando to "rally in face of the new crisis caused by Prime Minister Daniel F. Malan's move to create a so-called Constitutional Court of Appeal.

It has been made clear for some weeks now that the long-negotiated military and economic agreement with Franco Spain is about to be signed. The Pentagon felt it was sufficiently important for the defense of Western Europe to have an agreement with Spain and, while our Government is not run by the Pentagon, there was enough support in Congress and not enough opposition in general to override military requirements.

Governor Dewey has ordered the State Harness Racing Commission to report to him at 10 A. M. today on its investigation of labor racketeering at Yonkers Raceway, and there were indications that the Governor would call for a full inquiry into unsavory labor practices at all seven harness tracks in the state.

CHICAGO, Sept. 21 -- Business is in a flattening-out area at the top of a boom, Henry B. Arthur, economist of Swift Co., meat packers, said today at the annual meeting of the Association of National Advertisers.

Twenty detectives and uniformed patrolmen began yesterday a search of the swamp areas of Ozone Park near Jamaica Bay, Queens, for the body of John (Chappie) Mazziotta, chief suspect in the killing of Arnold Schuster, the Brooklyn clothing salesman whose tip led to the capture of William Sutton, the bank robber.

TOKYO, Tuesday, Sept. 22 -- Communist correspondent Wilfred Burchett told Allied newsmen today twenty-three Americans and one Briton were among Allied war prisoners who have decided to stay with the Communists.

" At Home With Ethel Waters," a one-woman revue with Miss Waters appearing and singing in twenty-two numbers, will make its Broadway debut this evening at 8 o'clock at the Forty-eighth Street Theatre. Charles Bowden and Richard Barr are co-sponsors of the attraction, which has a single setting by Oliver Smith depicting a living room. Mr. Barr has directed the revue and the costumes are by Robert Mackintosh.
Judge Samuel S. Leibowitz in Kings County Court yesterday disposed of four cases stemming from the Brooklyn investigation into police-gambler tie-ups.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- Closed sessions by the Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations today were followed by charges by Senator Joseph R. McCarthy that material written by Russian authors -- some of it containing "calculated misinformation" -- had been used by the United States Army in its indoctrination courses for specialized officers.

BONN, Germany, Sept. 21 -- Christian Democratic trade unionists are asking for increased representation in the leadership of the West German Trade Union Federation not only at the federal level but also in the various states and in individual unions.

OYSTER BAY, L. I., Sept. 21 -- Code Flags "N" and "W" were hoisted on a yard-arm of the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club today to signify a New World victory over the Old in a brand new international sailing competition.

GREENWOOD LAKE, N. Y., Sept. 21 -- As Roland La Starza comes down the path to greet you at his Long Pond Inn training camp a couple of jet fighter-bombers streak over a near-by mountain top and you can't help comparing the planes and the man with the lumbering four-engine bombers of early World War II days and the huge hulks who fought for the world heavyweight championship in another era.

Stephen Wang, 51 years old, a Chinese importer and head of the Nanking Company, an oriental goods store at 423 Second Avenue, was found shot dead in the rear of his shop at 10 A. M. yesterday. The police are searching for a seaman, whose name they did not reveal, for questioning.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- The Air Force said today that rescue procedures, including the dispatch of an aircraft and emergency messages to ships at sea, had started Friday night one hour after the B-29 had been overdue at the Kindley base.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Sept. 21 -- Israel, with 50 points, led in track and field at the Maccabiah Games today and the United States contingent was a close second with 45. Great Britain was third, with 26 and South Africa fourth, with 23.

MONTREAL, Sept. 21 -- More than 800 delegates at the joint meeting of the United States Conference of Mayors and the Canadian Federation of Mayors and Municipalities today heard Alben W. Barkley, former United States Vice President, express the hope that the Governments of Canada and the United States would eventually join in building the St. Lawrence seaway.

Boris Sklar, 68-year-old editor of Russky Golos, a Russian-language newspaper, was arrested in his office, 130 East Sixteenth Street, yesterday morning by agents of the Department of Justice and taken to Ellis Island to await deportation proceedings

Germany sends preserved strawberries berries bigger than one's thumb, Israel a bitter orange marmalade, England a lemon marmalade and Switzerland a juniper berry preserve. These are new jams to great gourmets on their rounds of delicacy shops.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (AP) -- The Department of Commerce reported today that net receipts of American companies from international transportation in 1952 were one-third less than the year before and would be even less this year.

WESTBURY, L. I., Sept. 21 -- Circling the field from the seventh position at the end of the first half, Mr. and Mrs. C. T. Black's Uhleen Fingo, a 3-year-old brown filly by Calumet Fingo, scored a one-length victory over Reyno Worthy in the $4,000-Colorado mile and one-sixteenth pace at Roosevelt Raceway tonight.

The Fall Highweight Handicap, the $23,850 event that topped the opening day's program of the Westchester Racing Association's meeting at Belmont Park yesterday, produced a real surprise. Kaster, a 4-year-old gelding competing in the colors of C. Mahlon Kline, captured the six-furlong burst, beating the Marlboro Stud Farm's Jet Master by more than a length on the Widener Course.

Glore, Forgan Co. and the Stone Webster Securities Corporation announced yesterday that they had arranged for the private placement of $34,125,000 of first- mortgage bonds of the Permian Basin Pipeline Company with institutional investors. The bonds bear 4 1/2 per cent interest and will come due on June 1, 1973.

PARIS, Sept. 21 -- The first stage of an impassionate debate in the Cabinet on France's European policy, which began a week ago and continued during the weekend, ended today with the Government split about as wide as ever.

Women headed by Mrs. Henry C. Flower Jr., chairman, and Mrs. Lucius D. Clay, co-chairman, and including Mrs. Messmore Kendall are serving on the women's committee that is aiding in plans for two events in the near future that have been arranged to raise funds for the Children's Village.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- Top Government officials and leading banking executives reminded the 6,000 delegates to the seventy-ninth annual convention of the American Bankers Association here today that bankers were "on trial" in the new Administration and had a pressing responsibility to explain the basis of the Government's "sound money" policy at the community level.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, said tonight that neither he nor any salaried agent of his Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations had established direct contact with a man who said he was Lavrenti P. Beria, ousted chief of the Soviet secret police.

ROME, Sept. 21 -- Efforts to establish a European political community will be resumed in Rome tomorrow when delegates of Italy, France, West Germany, Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg will meet to draft a treaty embodying the constitution of a European federation of states.

Randy Turpin, middleweight champion of Europe, arrived from England on the Cunard liner Queen Mary yesterday for his world title bout with Carl (Bobo) Olson at Madison Square Garden on Wednesday night, Oct. 21, Turpin, who trained for the bout for two and a half weeks before boarding the ship, will resume his drills after witnessing Thursday's heavyweight encounter between Rocky Marciano and Roland La Starza at the Polo Grounds.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- The Senate Subcommittee on Privileges and Elections has ended its investigation of the 1952 Senatorial election in New Mexico where, it had been charged, Senator Dennis Chavez, the Democratic incumbent, had benefited from wholesale violation of the election laws.
The youth of Nassau County drink nicely and mostly at home.

LONDON, Sept. 21 -- The stock markets here started the new week with irregular price movements in a session chiefly notable for the fact that the volume of business was the largest since February, 1952.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- A budget reform plan that was put forward by Beardsley Ruml of New York, an economist and business man, was assailed today by Senator Harry F. Byrd as "budgetary legerdemain."

PARIS, Sept. 21 -- Sidi Mohammed el Amin Pasha, Bey of Tunis, asked today for an end of terrorism in the protectorate before the arrival of Pierre Voizard, new French Resident General M. Voizard is scheduled to leave Paris for Tunis at the end of this week.

CHICAGO, Sept. 21 -- Activity in the grain markets today was concentrated in the outgoing contract. It was the last day of trading in the September delivery. Most of the interest was in September corn, which was bought actively by shorts and sold freely by several commercial interests who were long.
Color and whimsy in design are the keynote of the new collection of decorative accessories, ranging from lamps to ice buckets, now on view at Americraft, 903 First Avenue.
STRASBOURG, France, Sept. 21 (AP) -- The Council of Europe's Consultative Assembly today confirmed Leon Marchal of France as the new Secretary General.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 21 -- George Meany, president of the American Federation of Labor, charged today that the Eisenhower Administration was running the Government for the benefit of "the greedy few." He asserted that he had recently received a bulletin of the National Association of Manufacturers, mailed in a White House envelope under Government frank.

The story of how the Federal Trade Commission has failed, over the years, to enforce its orders was recounted yesterday by Edward F. Howrey, chairman of the Commission. Mr. Howrey said he had "locked the stable door," and had appointed a committee to see that "no more horses are stolen."

Dr. Marek Stanislaw Korowicz, who is seeking asylum in the United States after having deserted the Polish delegation to the United Nations, announced yesterday that he would testify in Washington Thursday before a special meeting of the House Committee on Un-American Activities.

ANDOVER, Mass., Sept. 21 -Steve Sorota, the one-time Fordham back who played under Maj. Frank Cavanaugh and Sleepy Jim Crowley when Ram football rated highly in the national spotlight, finds himself on the spot at Phillips Academy, Andover, this season.
Six chastened baseball fans were adjudged guilty of disorderly conduct by City Magistrate Vernon C. Riddick yesterday for dumping beer on fellow fans at a Dodger-Curbs twi-night game July 22.

Aircraft carriers, now the principal type of ship in the world's leading navies, vary in size and functions, but the trend in recent years has been toward larger, heavier, more complicated and costly ships.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (AP) -N. Baxter Maddox, vice president and trust officer of the First National Bank of Atlanta, Ga., was elected president of the trust division of the American Bankers Association today. George C. Barclay, vice president of the City Bank Farmers Trust Company, New York, succeeded him as vice president.

School started the other day, and after the election of officers for the Home Room and the Safety Patrol everyone was sent home early, bearing books. The instructions this time dealt not with home work, which will be taken up later, but with the physical preservation of the books themselves.

Elegance characterizes a series of room settings now on view at the new shop of Kagan-Dreyfuss, 125 East Fifty-seventh Street. Rounded, contoured lines rich marble and brass, the use of inlaid sterling silver with rosewood all add to the lush atmosphere.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 22 -- The Soviet Union was blamed today for obstructing a two-and-a-half-year effort by a United Nations Commission to learn the fate of missing German, Japanese and other war prisoners who have been unaccounted for since World War II and are believed held on Soviet soil.

CHICAGO, Sept. 21 (AP) -- The Cuneo Press, Inc., said today that it had filed revised statements of earnings for 1950, 1951 and 1952 with the Securities and Exchange Commission, as the S. E. C. had requested.

JERSEY CITY, Sept. 21 -- City Commissioner Frank Hague Eggers questioned today the legality of the investigation of city finances begun this morning by the majority bloc on the City Commission. He did not give testimony until seventy minutes after he had been called as the first witness.

Dr. Arthur I. Holleb has been named medical producer-director of color television for the American Cancer Society, which is planning a series of closed circuit television programs for the medical profession.

Fashion is interwoven with the lore and customs of Ireland in a fascinating manner in the Sybil Connolly collection brought by the young designer from Ireland for presentation in the United States. It was shown yesterday morning at Lord Taylor.
William N. Oatis, Associated Press correspondent, and Frank E. Noel, A. P. photographer, were guests of honor at last night's benefit premiere of Paramount's "Little Boy Lost," at the Rivoli Theatre.

The Cosden Petroleum Corporation, whose fiscal year ends on April 30, reported yesterday that its net earnings for the four months ended on last Aug. 31 rose to $1,024,109 from $538,978 in the corresponding period last year. The figures are equivalent to $1.26 and 67 cents a share, respectively, for the four months' periods.

Six bloodmobiles will collect for the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program today. One call will be at the Masonic Temple, 71 West Twenty-third Street, for the beginning of a city-wide Masonic drive that will continue through November.

Many "blue chip" American corporations report that the recent rise in interest rates will have no effect on their proposed capital expenditures, the National Industrial Conference Board declared yesterday. The board based its contention on a survey of 159 manufacturing companies.
HAVANA, Sept. 21 -- The trial of 100 persons accused of participation in a revolt July 26 in Santiago de Cuba began this morning in the Urgency Court of that city.

In first place after winning his adjounred game from the twelfth round, last night, Vassily Smyslov of Russia again led Samuel Reshevsky, United States, by half a poin in the world chess championship challengers' tournament in Zurich, according to a Swiss news report.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- Dave Beck, general president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, Chauffeurs, Warehousemen and Helpers of America, A. F. L., announced today a change in union policy calling for the negotiation of national, rather than simply local and regional, agreements with employers.

Pledging himself to give the city a clean independent administration, Rudolph Halley, President of the City Council and Liberal party candidate for Mayor, told the voters last night that they were now paying the penalty for eight years of bad municipal government in the form of high crime rates, spreading slums, traffic snarls, jammed subways and a 15-cent fare.

BRONXVILLE, N. Y., Sept. 21 -- Young women from thirty-two states and nine foreign countries arrived today at the campus of Sarah Lawrence College for the new school year to find porters, janitors and other custodial employes carrying picket signs at the gates instead of rushing forward with helpful hands on trunks, suitcases and stacks of clothing.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 21 -- Andrei Y. Vishinsky, Soviet representative in the United Nations, revived today a five-year-old Soviet proposal for a one-third cut in the armed forces of the Big Five and a Soviet charge that the United States aimed at "world domination."

Average market value of New York Stock Exchange stocks on Aug. 31 was $38.34, against $40.21 at the end of July. The figure was the lowest for a month-end since Oct. 31, 1950, when the average was $38.68.

LONDON, Sept. 21 -- The British Overseas Airways Corporation in its annual report said profits during the fiscal year ended last March 31 had been 103,875 ($290,850) before payment of interest on issued capital. Its profits the year before were 1,233,722.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Sept. 21 -- The sentences of ten of the thirteen terrorists jailed by a military tribunal in the Sarafand Camp Aug. 25 were reduced in Jerusalem today by Pinhas Lavon, acting Defense Minister.

Eleven women, who were arrested while picketing the United Nations in protest against alleged American "imperialism" in Puerto Rico, were found guilty of disorderly conduct yesterday in Lower Manhattan Court.

NEW DELHI, Sept. 21 -- Senator William F. Knowland went far off the beaten tracks today to assess the use of United States financial and technical assistance in attacking India's ancient problems of poverty and hunger. The Republican majority leader was enthusiastic about what he saw in a part of the country that few visitors see and told gatherings of farm extension workers that among them was to be found "the real basis of democracy."

WEST SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Sept. 21 -- President Eisenhower matched smiles with the farm children of the Northeast states today, but urged them in all seriousness to leave the land and the American system of government in better condition than they had received it.

THE surfcaster is gradually coming into his own. The striped bass run seems to have started at several points on the New Jersey coast, the vanguard of the migration is showing at Cape Cod and the channel bass are moving in on the Hatteras, Ocracoke and Nags Head beaches in North Carolina.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt accepted yesterday from a group of boys and girls from the Pleasantville Cottage School at Pleasantville, Westchester, a check for $1,560 for the United Jewish Appeal, for which she served as chairman during June.
An opportunity to visit New York, delayed for seven years by the Soviet Government, was realized yesterday by Mrs. Robert C. Tucker, Russian-born wife of a United States diplomat.
Is there room in your Letters column for one who was deeply moved by A. M. Rosenthal's article entitled "One World Wonder" in THE TIMES of Aug. 30?
WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 Negotiators for the United States and Chile began a formal search for terms by which this country would agree to buy nearly 100,000 tons of surplus copper.

ALBANY, Sept. 21 (AP) -- The Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen anonunced today it would demand a 37 1/2-cent-an-hour wage increase from every carrier in the United States when current contracts expire.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 21 -- Following are excerpts from the translation of an address in Russian today by Andrei Y. Vishinsky, Soviet delegate, before the United Nations General Assembly:

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Sept. 21(AP) -- Harvey Harman, the head football coach of Rutgers -- miffed because one of his players was declared ineligible -- handed in his resignation, changed his mind and withdrew it. He pulled his reverse last week, but the university didn't make it public until today.

Volume increased substantially yesterday on many of the New York commodity exchanges following several weeks of inactivity. Zinc registered the heaviest trading since May 27, the No. 4 sugar contract since July 29 and cocoa since Aug. 28.

The low morale of the Voice of America staff survivors and the general curtailment of the activities and personnel of the United States Information Agency testify that neither the American people nor their Government has a proper appreciation of the critical importance of our nation's informational services.

SEOUL, Korea, Tuesday, Sept. 22 -- A North Korean captain who landed a prized Communist jet fighter at Kimpo Airfield near Seoul yesterday said today he had not known of the Allied offer of a reward of $100,000 for a MIG in combat condition.

NICHOLAS MONSARRAT'S new novel, "The Story of Esther Costello,"* seems as if it were written by an English James M. Cain instead of by the author of "The Cruel Sea." This means that his book is short, lurid and morbidly readable; but it also means that it is revolting. Mr. Monsarrat is a gifted writer who, by some perverse fate, remains a continually disappointing one.

The Executive Council of the American Federation of Labor is to be commended for speeding up its plan to help clean up the New York and New Jersey waterfront. Instead of taking the slower road to reform by suspending the racketeer-dominated International Longshoremen's Union, the Council is urging the delegates to the annual convention in St. Louis to cut the ground from under the union's present bosses by following a shorter cut.

Public and private Utility leaders from every state in the nation, opening a four-day convention at the Roosevelt Hotel, were told yesterday that President Eisenhower's Administration was giving "every indication" that it would encourage free enterprise in the utility industry.

Cesar Romero will be the master of ceremonies for a weekly variety program, "Chevrolet Showroom," beginning on Friday from 10:30 to 11 P. M. over Channel 7. Guests on the premiere performance will include George Jessel, Herb Shriner, the Debonairs, a dancing and singing act; Toni Arden, singer; Elaine Dunn, dancer, and Stan Kenton and his orchestra.

Walter T. Shirley, who managed Mayor Impellitteri's campaign in 1950, visited City Hall yesterday for the avowed purpose of prevailing upon the Mayor to seek re-election as an independent candidate under the Experience party label.

THE perfect pugilistic pairing, the experts tell us, pits a boxer against a slugger. It seems to supply more ingredients of drama and suspense than any other type of matchmaking. That's why there is such inherent appeal to Thursday's heavyweight championship fight at the Polo Grounds, which brings together the heavy-handed Rocky Marciano, the slugger, against the artful Roland La Starza, the boxer.

JOPPA, Ill., Sept. 21 -- About 2,500 American Federation of Labor construction workers defied orders by union officials today to cross picket lines of iron workers striking against the Joppa power project of the Atomic Energy Commission and an A. F. of L. spokesman announced that the striking local would be deprived of its jurisdiction in the area.

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, Sept. 21 -- The principal features of next year's budget, presented by Finance Minister Johan van de Kieft last week, are the high level of expenditures, the high deficit, the drastic cut in income taxes and the partial abolition of dividend limitation.

TORONTO, Sept. 21 (AP) -- The coming ability of the United States to use the oceans as bomber bases "promises one of the most startling changes in military strategy since the invention of the atomic bomb," a report to the American Association of Port Authorities said today.

In its long history, stretching back more than a decade, the House Committee on Un-American Activities has frequently and with justice been criticized for itself engaging in the un-American activity of playing fast and loose with the reputation of citizens whose views on social and economic matters differed from its own.

LONDON, Sept. 21 (Reuters) -- An increasing number of Britons took pen in hand today to join a letters-to-the-editor controversy on a problem every man in Britain must face: Does he want his mail addressed to him as "Esquire" or just plain "Mister?"

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 21 -- A sharp attack on raiding within the American Federation of Labor was made here today by George Meany, A. F. L. president. Many of the 700 delegates who heard his remarks at the opening of the federation's seventy-second convention interpreted them as a slap at Dave Beck.

BERLIN, Sept. 21 (Reuters) -- Eight former leaders of the coal industry in East Germany went on trial before a Communist court today on charges of having sunk unproductive shafts and having sabotaged existing mines on instructions from the United States and West Germany.

With aircrafts firm, rails steady and motors and oils weak -- the last apparently reflecting the 50-cent slash in Pennsylvania crude prices -- the stock market went through a mixed session yesterday. THE NEW YORK TIMES combined average closed virtually unchanged, down 0.08 at 165.62. The rail average gained 0.07 and the industrial average slipped 0.24 to 270.78.

The annual economic loss because of undue traffic congestion in New York City's streets is estimated conservatively at more than one billion dollars in the first rounded study of this phase of the problem in a quarter of a century. The survey was made by the Citizens Traffic Safety Board, headed by Percy C. Magnus, which questioned a cross section of New York's business and industry.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- A ground-water discovery in the desert of Western India that will enable India to develop Kandla, a new Indian seaport on the Gulf of Cutch, and relieve shipping congestion at Bombay has been reported to the Department of the Interior.
Following is the text of President Eisenhower's address last night at a Republican dinner at the Boston Garden as recorded by THE NEW YORK TIMES:

Two new films open today at first run theatres. At the Normandie is "The Village," a Swiss-made drama starring John Justin and Eva Dahlbeck. The supporting cast is headed by Sigfrit Steiner, Mary Hinton and W. Woytecki. The Lazar Wechsler Production was directed by Leopold Lindtberg from an original story by David Wechsler and Kurt Fruh and an adaptation by Elizabeth Montagu and Leopold Lindtberg.

Vice President Richard M. Nixon revealed here yesterday that he had known for "thirty days" about the story that a man who said he was Lavrenti P. Beria, deposed former Soviet Minister of Internal Affairs, had escaped from the Soviet Union and was willing to trade his secrets for sanctuary in the United States.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 21 -- The Galveston flood of 1900 will serve Metro - Goldwyn - Mayer as background for a romantic adventure spectacle to be filmed next year. "Galveston Flood" is the title being used on the project, which is engaging the attention of Herman Hoffman and Christopher Knopf, who are plotting the story details.

LAKE PLACID, N. Y., Sept. 21 (AP) -- "Durable peace can come only through a workable form of world federation with powers adequate for the prevention of war," Grove Patterson, editor in chief of The Toledo Blade, declared here today.

Scoring with left hooks, Orlando Zulueta, 134 3/4 pounds, Havana, won a split decision over Paddy De Marco, 139, Brooklyn, in the main bout of ten rounds at the Eastern Parkway Arena, Brooklyn, last night. A crowd of 2,000 saw the Cuban upset the Brooklynite.

Under close questioning yesterday as to his accuracy as a newspaper man, Walter Winchell denied that he had waged a two-month campaign to drive James A. Wechsler, editor of The New York Post, out of the newspaper business.

The steel industry's operating rate, which had declined moderately in the three preceding weeks, rose 2.2 points last week to 91.4 per cent of theoretical capacity and is scheduled to make a further gain of 2.7 points this week, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute.

BREST, France, Sept. 21 -- A Liberian vessel broke up during a vicious mid-Atlantic storm today, but lifeboat crews from the French liner Ile de France braved thirty-five-foot waves and gale winds to rescue twenty-four of the twenty-six men aboard.

Two Air Force men described yesterday how they beat off swarming sharks with their fists after parachuting from the B-29 hurricane-hunter that burned and exploded off the Atlantic Coast Friday night. The fliers were kept afloat by their "Mae West" lifejackets and tied together with a nylon cord.

Under this challenging title there appears elsewhere in this newspaper today a full-page advertisement on behalf of the American Korean Foundation, soliciting contributions for the rehabilitation of the gallant little nation that has fought itself to the edge of ruin resisting Communist aggression.
The subscription period opened yesterday for Pacific Gas and Electric Company's offering of 1,946,829 new shares of common stock to the company's stockholders.

TEHERAN, Iran, Sept. 21 -- Abdullah Entezam, Iranian career diplomat who served both the usted Premier Mohammed Mossalegh and his predecessors, was named Foreign Minister in the Cabinet of Premier Fazlollah Zahedi today.

The New York City Transit Authority gave a sharp warning yesterday to Michael J. Quill and his Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., that it would not surrender to the union any of its powers, including the right to establish new operating schedules on the city-owned transit lines to save $1,250,000 a year.

TORONTO, Sept. 21 -- The Massey-Harris Company, Ltd., became one of the world's biggest farm implement manufacturers today as shareholders voted without dissent to amalgamate with Harry Ferguson, Inc., of Great Britain.

While expressing the belief that the Local Law fixing the age of 63 for retirement in the Police Department "was unwise in its results," Supreme Court Justice Joseph A. Cox, nevertheless yesterday upheld the validity of the act, because the 241 former policemen had failed to establish that the law was "arbitrary, unreasonable, discriminatory or contrary to public policy."
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 21 (AP) -- Elmer A. Schroeder, 53 years old, a lawyer and one time "czar" of professional soccer in this country, was found slain today in his West Philadelphia apartment.

The telegram sent yesterday to Michael Quill, international president of the Transport Workers Union, and Matthew Guinan, president of the union's Local 100 by the New York City Transit Authority follows:
The text of City Council President Rudolph Halley's keynote address given last night at the Halley headquarters in the McAlpin Hotel follows:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- The Democratic national organization and a leading Southern Democrat in Congress, Senator Richard B. Russell of Georgia, are drawing closely together against the coming election-year session of the Republican Congress.

Arts of India, by modern miniaturists, metal and leather craftsmen and other artists and artisans, will be on exhibition today at the American Museum of Natural History in the last show of a tour of the United States that began in January.

The aims of the National Issues Committee, formed last month in Washington, were described yesterday at the group's first regional luncheon in the Commodore Hotel. Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, national chairman who presided, said it was not the committee's intention to support or attack any political candidate or party, but to work for the dissemination of factual reports in the interest of social progress.

BOSTON, Sept. 21 -- President Eisenhower pledged his Administration tonight to defend the dignity and freedom of the individual -- "the supreme belief of our society" -- and declared that no material sacrifice was too great to guard such an ideal.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 21 (AP) -- Elmer A. Schroeder, 53 years old, a lawyer and one time "czar" of professional soccer in this country, was found slain today in his West Philadelphia apartment.

The telegram sent yesterday to Michael Quill, international president of the Transport Workers Union, and Matthew Guinan, president of the union's Local 100 by the New York City Transit Authority follows:
