The text of City Council President Rudolph Halley's keynote address given last night at the Halley headquarters in the McAlpin Hotel follows:

RYE, N. Y., Sept. 22 -- Mrs. Donald O'Brien, the ladies' club champion at Winged Foot, and Mrs. Sophie Untermeyer of Century, the Fairfield-Westchester Wheeler Cup holder, both had rounds of 80 over the wind-swept Apawamis Club layout today to divide honors while heading their respective divisions in the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association gross tournament for Class A players.
DIGNIFIED, gray-haired Marshall Cassidy, son of the late but unforgettable Mars Cassidy, is, in the language of their world, a horse of a different color from his irascible father.

LAKE PLACID, N. Y., Sept. 22 (AP) -- President Eisenhower is expected to issue soon a new order concerning release of Government information to newspaper men and it will "recognize the basic principles of freedom of information," New York's newspaper publishers heard today.
Famous Peacock Alley, that symbolic carry-over from the days of the old Waldorf-Astoria to the twin-towered home of today, has emerged almost overnight, it seems, with a new personality.

Manhattan Borough President Robert F. Wagner Jr. and Harold Riegelman, Democratic and Republican nominees for Mayor, respectively, made derisive replies yesterday to Monday's "keynote" campaign speech of their Liberal party rival, Rudolph Halley, President of the City Council.
CHICAGO, Sept. 22 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

Clarence Francis, national chairman for the United Community Campaigns, announced yesterday that civic leaders throughout the country would aid Community Chest and United Fund campaigns to raise $280,000,000 this fall for health and welfare agencies.

SUMMIT, N. J., Sept. 22 -- The Women's New Jersey Golf Association's twenty-eighth annual state match-play championship started today and Mrs. Philip Cudone of Montclair and Mrs. Marge Mason of Ridgewood tied for the medal at 78 over the south course of the Canoe Brook Country Club.

WEST SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Sept. 22 -- The farm youth of the Northeast resumed today the implementing of President Eisenhower's advice to preserve the land by pitting their cattle and barn animals against each other in the judging contests at the Eastern States Exposition.

As spokesman for the United Nations side in the arrangements for a political conference on Korea the United States won an important decision yesterday when both the Steering Committee of the General Assembly and the Assembly itself voted to stand by the U. N. resolution of Aug. 28.
Large flocks of migratory birds blundered into the Empire State Building on their way south during the dark hours yesterday morning, and several hundred dashed themselves to death.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 22 -- Martin P. Durkin, who resigned twelve days ago as Secretary of Labor, asserted today that President Eisenhower himself had reneged on a promise to send Congress a list of nineteen amendments to the Taft-Hartley Act.

John P. Maguire and E. Stanley Klein of John P. Maguire Co. and other Eastern financial interests have set up a new corporation and bought Fieldcrest Mills, the textile manufacturing division of Marshall Field Co., Inc., it was announced yesterday.

As attorney for Stephen Stanley Ragan, also known as Michael Patrick O'Brien, may I thank and commend you for your fair and informative recent editorial concerning this "wanderer" of our century. Both your editorial and the news reports from your correspondent Henry R. Lieberman have been accurate and unbiased.

A move for immediate action on a resolution calling for a reduction in fares on city-operated buses from 15 to 10 cents, with a reduced 5-cent fare for transfers from one city bus line to another, was blocked yesterday in the City Council.

LONDON, Sept. 22 -- British Government securities led a decline on the stock markets today, in which part of last week's gains were wiped out. Business was less active, but when selling dried up British funds rallied to cut losses to 3/16th per cent.

The Maritime Administration, in a further move toward the eventual sale of additional speedy Mariner-type freighters to private industry, has decided to offer nine of these craft for operation under bareboat charter.
Alfred J. Bohlinger, New York state Superintendent of Insurance, yesterday recommended adoption of compulsory automobile liability insurance in New York State.

An expert for the Atomic Energy Commission proposed yesterday that Government restrictions be eased and industrial capital be invested in research to bring nearer the day when atomic power would light American homes and turn wheels in factories.

The liquor industry took a look at itself yesterday at a meeting of the National Alcoholic Beverage Control Association -- the liquor authorities of the sixteen states that handle liquor as a state monopoly -- and found that the twenty years since repeal had been good and that the prospect for the long-term future was even better.

NORMAN, Okla., Sept. 22 (UP) -- The University of Oklahoma Regents will hold a special meeting tomorrow to decide whether to flout the N. C. A. A.'s rule prohibiting state-wide telecasting of Saturday's Oklahoma-Notre Dame football game.

THE late George Orwell's novel, "1984," concerning life in the totalitarian world of tomorrow, was brought to the television screen on Monday evening by "Studio One" over C. B. S. It was a masterly adaptation that depicted with power, poignancy and terrifying beauty the end result of thought control -- the disintegration of the human mind and soul.

A luncheon fashion show was given yesterday by Jane Engel at Longchamps, Madison Avenue and Seventy-ninth Street, to introduce her new department, "The Show-Room," that will feature designers clothes priced from $50 to $175.
LAWRENCE, Mass., Sept. 22 (AP) -- A Navy fighter pilot tried to take off today with his wings still folded up over his cockpit. The plane was wrecked but the pilot escaped unhurt.

To open its second week at the Metropolitan Opera House, the Sadler's Wells Ballet last night presented its third performance of "The Sleeping Beauty" with a third ballerina, Nadia Nerina, and it was another of their enchanted evenings.

TEHERAN, Iran, Sept. 22 -- The newspaper Kayhan reported today that a hundred persons had been arrested on charges of being Tudek (Communist) party members and partisans of ousted Premier Mohammed Mossadegh and were to be sent tonight into banishment in the extreme southern part of Iran.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 22 -- The Soviet Union's attempt to place the proposed Korean peace conference on the agenda of the United Nations General Assembly was decisively rejected today. The Soviet proposal would have forced another debate on the question of the participants in the conference.

Charley Goldman and Dan Florio can breathe easily now. All they have to do is wait for the bell to sound tomorrow night at the Polo Grounds to signal the start of the fifteen-round fight for the heavyweight championship of the world.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Sept. 22 -- With Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll officiating, ground was broken today for the new $4,000,000 library at Rutgers University. The ceremony was held in connection with the fall convocation for the men's colleges.

HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Wednesday, Sept. 23 -- Lawrence W. McKeown, a 46-year-old maritime lawyer of Baldwin, L. I., was elected early today chairman of the Nassau County Democratic party after one of the liveliest Democratic contests since 1933 in this Republican stronghold.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 22 -- Elsewhere fans are asking, "Who's going to win the world series?" But here the big question is, "Who's going to finish third -- the Phillies or the Cardinals?"

BERKELEY, Calif., Sept. 22 (AP) -- Torben Ulrich of Denmark lost in the third round of the Pacific Coast tennis championship today to Bill Hoepner, San Francisco, 11 -- 9, 4 -- 1, 30 -- 15, default. Ulrich walked off the court after objecting to Hoepner's style of alternating lob and smash shots.

Concern has been previously expressed in these columns that in its zeal to straighten out admitted anomalies of the federal civil service (and incidentally to provide a few jobs for Republicans) the Administration may do some real damage to the theory and practice of making a career of Government work.

The thirty-ninth annual show of the American Dahlia Society, presented in cooperation with the Horticural Society of New York, opened in the Colonnades Ballroom of Essex House, 160 Central Park South, at 4 P. M. yesterday. All the exhibits can be seen again today from 10 A. M. to 10 P. M.

CAMP KILMER, N. J., Sept. 22 (AP) -- Pvt. John Galasso, 21 years old, who said he broke out of a Korean stockade rather than face an Army court-martial, will be sent back to Korea tomorrow, Army authorities announced today. Galasso gave himself up here Sept. 8 and told a story of hitchhiking 8,000 miles from the Korean front lines to his home in Plainfield, N. J.

OYSTER BAY, L. I., Sept. 22 -- The Old World team evened the score with the New at one victory apiece in the international six-meter sailing competition today. Four triumphs are needed for the cup put up this year by Sir Alfred Bossom of the House of Commons Yacht Club.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 22 -- William L. McFetridge, president of the Building Service Employes International Union, A. F. L., said it was "impractical" to carry out Governor Dewey's demand that the charter of Local 32-E be revoked. However, he promised that the parent union would see to it that the local functioned honestly or not at all.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 (AP) -- The Department of Commerce said today that foreign nations during the second quarter of this year paid off $440,000,000 of debt to the United States and at the same time earned enough to increase their gold and dollar reserves by $450,000.000.
Columbia University's Alma Mater enthroned on the steps of the Low Memorial Library and gazing over 116th Street, her arms raised in welcome, is 50 years old today.

The trucking terminal at 1039 Paterson Plant Road in Secaucus, N. J., has been leased by the Akers Alotor Lines, Inc., of Gastonia, N. C., from William Buessing. The deal was negotiated by the James lUl. Burns Company of New York as broker.
SEOUL, Korea, Wednesday, Sept. 23 -- Lieut. Gen. Samuel E. Anderson, Fifth Air Force commander, said today that the Communists had broken the Korean armistice by bringing warplanes into North Korea.

SAIGON, Vietnam, Sept. 22 -- Declaring that reinforcement in men and materiel had been accorded him, General Henri-Eugene Navarre, French commander in Indo-China, told his men today to seize and gain the initiative every-where from the Communist-led Vietminh.

The deadline for applications for the annual Blanche Thebom Scholarship, open to singers between the ages of 25 and 30, has been extended from Sept. 30 to Oct. 15. Inquiries should be addressed to the Blanche Thebom Foundation, 711 Fifth Avenue.

HIGH BRIDGE, N. J., Sept. 22 -- Sale of the Taylor-Wharton Iron and Steel Company's assets, including its name, was approved by the stockholders at a meeting here this afternoon. The sale, subject to approval by the Bureau of Internal Revenue, was made for a reported $6,000,000 to an unidentified investment group, represented by Fred W. Richmond of New York City.

In the letter of Carl Landauer and Gerhart H. Seger the "need for bipartisan basis in anti-Soviet policy" in Germany is emphasized. All right. But the role and character of the Social Democratic party are misinterpreted. In some way the letter makes us believe that in Western Germany two big parties have crystallized out of many, following the old course in the United States.

KANSAS CITY, Sept. 22 -- The spiritual and material plight of the rural people was strongly underlined by declarations and resolutions made in the first two days of the National Catholic Rural Conference here this week.

Department of Labor investigators have uncovered violations of Federal child labor regulations on fifteen of thirty New Jersey farms inspected during the last two weeks, a department spokesman reported yesterday. During the same period, he said, no violations were discovered in New York.

ROME, Sept. 22 -- A six-power conference to draft a constitution for a "European community of supranational character" or, in other words, for a European political community or federation of European states, was solemnly inaugurated by Giuseppe Pella, Premier and Foreign Minister of Italy, in Rome this morning.
Senator Byrd is abundantly justified, it seems to us, in the impatience he expressed with the so-called budgetary "reforms" proposed before the Ways and Means Committee by Beardsley Ruml.

A Brooklyn Red Cross official appealed yesterday to parents to give blood now for processing into gamma globulin saying that "the time to stockpile gamma globulin for the 1954 polio season is now, not next summer."
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Sept. 22 -- After years of wandering in the wilderness, Navy returned to a place among the football powers of the East last fall with its first winning season since 1945.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 22 -- Shortly after he had been unanimously elected chairman of the Credentials Committee of the United Nations General Assembly, Leslie Knox Munro of New Zealand ruled today that any discussion of Chinese Communist representation in the world organization was out of order at this time.

Manufacturers should offer druggists greater discounts from list prices and more special promotions to help ease the squeeze caused by higher operating costs, according to Prof. S. B. Jeffries of the Brooklyn College of Pharmacy of Long Island University.
An investment banking group headed by Blyth Co., Inc., has placed $3,200,000 of school revenue bonds of the East Penn Union School District Authority Emmaus, Lehigh County, Pa.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 (AP) -- Business activity continued high in August, the Department of Commerce said today, although there were some soft spots.

WESTBURY, L. I., Sept. 22 -- Roslyn (Cookie) Swift of Glen Oaks scored 39, 37 -- 76 to tie with Mrs. Bernard Freeman, Inwood, 39, 37 -- 76 during the first round of the Women's Long Island Golf Association 54-hole medal play championship tournament at the Meadow Brook Club today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- The economic health of this country as well as that of friendly nations depends "in good measure" on the success of the work undertaken by the Commission on Foreign Economic Policy, President Eisenhower told the group today.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, Sept. 22 -- The International Confederation of Free Trade Unions has issued a "hands off" warning to Dr. Frank Buchman and his Moral Rearmament Movement.

TOKYO, Wednesday, Sept. 23 -- The United Nations Command completed today its transfer of the Chinese and North Korean prisoners of the Korean war who have refused to be returned to communism to the custody of the Neutral Nations Repatriation Commission.

The pleasures of sixteenth-century music for voices were offered last evening by the Randolph Singers, David Randolph conducting, as another of Norman J. Seaman's "Interval Concerts" at Carnegie Recital Hall.

BONN, Germany, Sept. 22 -- For the first time since the end of World War II an exhibition of German military equipment, exclusive of arms, will open here tomorrow behind the guarded doors of a former Wehrmacht barracks.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 22 -- The end of one of the bitterest inter-union feuds in the history of the American Federation of Labor appeared to be in the making tonight.

At Boston President Eisenhower was speaking to an exclusively Republican audience, assembled for Republican fund-raising purposes, and as is traditionally the case on such occasions, whether Republican or Democratic, this was an address directed largely to a review of party achievements, past, present and prospective.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., Sept. 22 -- A fresh-water crew from Lake Ontario, skippered by Jerry Castle of Rochester, N. Y., won two of today's three races on Long Island Sound to take the lead in the eight-race series for the North American sailing championship.

CHAMPAIGN, Ill., Sept. 22 (UP) -- A "Russian" flier wearing a hammer and sickle insignia surrendered to state police today and created wild confusion until it was disclosed he was a United States Air Force man testing the alertness of authorities.

HARTFORD Sept. 22 -- Associate Justice John A. Cornell of the Connecticut Supreme Court of Errors resigned today because of ill health. Justice Cornell, who is 64 years of age and lives in Bridgeport, was named to the state's highest court on May 12 of this year by Gov. John Davis Lodge.

NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 22 -- An economic survey mission of the Japanese Government has arrived here for exploratory talks with Indian leaders on matters concerning expansion of trade between the two countries.
Three distinguished meteorologists settled down at New York University yesterday for a leisurely interview that very definitely could not have taken place a few years ago.

North Carolina, and the speaker of Sibnath Banerjee, president of the Hind Mazdoor Sabha, the Indian Socialist Trade Union Federation which claims 800,000 members, yesterday warmly praised the Moral Rearmament Movement, in a speech before the Assembly at Caux, according to a message received here.

A strong influence of the Empire period predominated the collection of designs created in this country by Jacques Fath for Joseph Halpert and presented yesterday by Gunther Jaeckel at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. It was reflected both for day and evening in silhouettes that placed emphasis on the bosom, flowing in a beltless unbroken molding line into skirts with low all-around or back flare.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- The latest bit of Government jargon to come out of the White House is "Operation Candor" -- a slogan for a real whing-ding of a television series in which President Eisenhower and "seven Cabinet members (7)" were to "tell all" about the atom bomb.

Since she calls her show "At Home With Ethel Water," it may sound flippant to say that she is best in the theatre. But that may help to explain a feeling of disappointment about Miss Waters' recapitulation of past song successes in a one-woman show which opened at the Forty-eighth Street last evening.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- Auto manufacturers will produce 6,000,000 passenger cars this year and in 1954 will produce 5,500,000 to 6,000,000 vehicles, Arthur O. Dietz, president of the C. I. T. Financial Corporation, told news men here today.

New Yorkers will have their first opportunity today to view a selection of the objects cited by the Museum of Modern Art for good design in 1953. A display of museum approved home furnishings has been on view at Chicago's Merchandise Mart (co-sponsor of the project) since January of this year, and additions were made to it last June.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 22 -- Following are excerpts from the translation of remarks in Russian by Andrei Y. Vishinsky, Soviet delegate, and the text of remarks by Henry Cabot Lodge Jr., United States delegate, made today in the United Nations General Assembly's General Committee on the Soviet request to include the Korean peace conference on the agenda:
WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- Net public and private debt of the nation rose 6 per cent through 1952 and seems headed toward a similar increase this year, the Department of Commerce reported today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- President Eisenhower will entertain at another of his dinners tomorrow night at the white House. The twenty-two guests, business men and Government officials, will discuss the American Heritage Foundation's crusade for freedom.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 22 (UP) -- Eddie Mathews and Johnny Logan collapsed defensively to give the Cardinals a 10-7 victory over the Braves and a split in a twilight-night double-header tonight after St. Louis had dropped the first game, 4 -- 3.

CHICAGO, Sept. 22 -- A speaker at the annual convention of the Association of National Advertisers today appraised the value of television as an advertising medium and called it "inexpensive and resultful" and asserted that it "packs the greatest wallop of any medium today."

Operations of the Detroit Edison Company and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on Aug. 31 resulted in earnings of $20,522,465, equal to $1.93 each on 10,617,883 capital shares, it was announced yesterday. This compares with $16,025,505, or $1.63 each on 9,830,603 shares, in the previous twelve months.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 (AP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board proposed a 25 per cent increase in air freight rates today. The board said the increase appeared necessary to enable airlines to meet cost increases since present minimum rates were established in June, 1948.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 22 -- The racket-riddled International Longshoremen's Association was expelled today from the ranks of legitimate trade unions. By an overwhelming vote, the American Federation of Labor convention revoked the pier union's charter and authorized the establishment of a new union to drive it from the docks.

Premiums are playing a bigger part in advertising and selling than they have in twenty years, it was emphasized yesterday by speakers at a premium advertising conference held in conjunction with the New York Premium Show at the Astor Hotel.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 22 -- The Soviet Union's perennial "package" proposal calling for prohibition of atomic weapons, arms cuts and a ban on war propaganda was added today to the agenda of the United Nations General Assembly without opposition and with little debate.

A new device for measuring the dose of radiation that a single living cell receives when radioactive material is within the cell itself has been developed at Columbia University's College of Physicians and Surgeons after two years of work, it became known yesterday.

Federal Judge Sylvester Ryan dismissed yesterday a $13,000,000 damage suit by which the Alleghany Corporation and two subsidiary corporations had sought to force the James Foundation of New York, Inc., to sell its controlling interest in the Western Pacific Railroad Company.

SEOUL, Korea, Sept. 22 -- The Communists in North Korea believe the war will begin again and are preparing for it, the North Korean pilot who flew a Russian-built MIG-15 fighter plane to surrender here said today in an interview.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- President Eisenhower was advised today by his Senate leader on labor matters to withhold his nomination of a successor to Martin P. Durkin as Secretary of Labor to a date approaching the time of Congress' return here in January.

MAUCH CHUNK, Pa., Sept. 22 (AP) -- You can't get much for a nickel any more, but for the towns of nch Chunk arid East /V[auch Chunk the lowly %ickel may buy a new industry to revitalize their economic life.

Some progress was made yesterday in negotiations between the New York Shipping Association and the International Longshoremen's Association, when the employers offered an increase of 7 cents an hour, covering wages and welfare benefits.

The time of the equinox makes a convenient occasion to reflect on Dr. Johnson's sage observation that "whatever makes the past, the distant or the future predominate over the present, advances us in the dignity of thinking beings." We have been thinking about -the fact that now there is one thing we can share in complete harmony with everyone on earth.

A Government official, a business man and a bank economist agreed yesterday that there was little or no danger of a major depression in the foreseeable future. They explained "Why I Am Not Afraid" at a luncheon meeting of the Sales Executives Club of New York in the Roosevelt Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- The State Department today denounced the trial and sentencing of Bishop Czeslaw Kaczmarek and other Roman Catholic clergymen by the Polish Government as "a mockery of justice" reminiscent of "the religious persecution which existed in Stalin's day."

CHICAGO, Sept. 22 -- The wheat market displayed a firmer undertone after early easiness today and rallied more than 2 cents from the low points. Export news continued to be discouraging, with reports telling of another postponement in the German buying scheduled for today.

MONTREAL, Sept. 22 (Canadian Press) -- The United States Civil Aeronautics Administrator told United States Mayors today that most United States cities at present served by airlines could expect to see air passenger traffic double by 1960.
Ovens built into kitchen walls at eye level are equipment features of several displays at the fifth annual National Home Furnishings Show this week at Grand Central Palace.

NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 22 -- Senator William F. Knowland expressed himself today as favorable to continued United States technical aid for India but he was uncertain as to further assistance in the purely economic sphere in view of the expensive defense needs of the Western Allies.
SEATTLE, Sept. 22 -- Discussion of the proposed controversial "sliding-scale import tax" for lead and zinc highlighted sessions of the annual convention of the American Mining Congress here today.

Allie Reynolds, who spent a good part of the year on relief during the Yanks' big drive to a fifth straight pennant, served notice at the Stadium last night that he was ready to return to his old familiar role of world series starter.
Public offering will be made today of $25,000,000 of 5 1/2 per cent cumulative preferred stock, par value $100, of the Northern Natural Gas Company. The issue is priced at $100.

Commodity prices closed irregular yesterday with volume somewhat smaller. Cottonseed oil, soybean oil, zinc, tin and lead closed higher; coffee, cocoa, hides, burlap and rubber lower, with sugar and potatoes mixed.

A broad rally developed in the stock market yesterday and prices made their widest gains since mid-June. Led by the railroads, which had been under steady pressure the last few weeks, gains of a point or more were numerous. Final prices were at or near the best for the session.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 22 (AP) -- Following is the text of an address by former Labor Secretary Martin P. Durkin before the American Federation of Labor convention here today:

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 22 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon combined business and pleasure today on his first visit to the headquarters of the United Nations, which he hailed as "a living, vital organization by which nobody could fail to be deeply impressed."
TEHERAN, Iran, Sept. 22 -- Abdullah Entezam, Iran's new Foreign Minister, is enough of a diplomat to evade all the hard questions, at least on his first day in office.

WESTBURY, L. I., Sept. 22 (AP) -- Stuart Hanover, owned by the Blue Hill Farm of Jericho, closed with a rush on the outside to win the California Trot by a neck tonight at Roosevelt Raceway. Sam Caton drove the 6-year-old son of His Excellency down the middle of the track to nip Great Colby, with Dutch Boy third.

NOW is the time to begin preparations for the fall hunting, in both the big game and the upland categories and in addition to plans on "where" and "when," a preliminary check on equipment and clothing is in order.

PARIS, Sept. 22 -- One reason among many for French stalling on the European Defense Community is that the Government is waiting anxiously for the Russian reply to the Western Powers' invitation to a four-Power conference. Since the date set for the meeting was Oct. 15, an answer from Moscow must be forthcoming in the next week or two.

ELIZABETH, N. J., Sept. 22 -- Death ended nineteen years' effort by John Pipala of 107 Third Street to bring his wife and son from Poland to America. A letter was sent today to his kinsmen abroad, telling them that Mr. Pipala had died here Sunday.
Futures market closed steady on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday and final prices were 1 to 8 points net higher on the day.

The Federal Government's antitrust suit against seventeen leading investment banking houses was dismissed yesterday by Federal Judge Harold R. Medina. An opinion to be filed later is expected to uphold the syndicate system of floating securities as one of the main elements in the country's economic rise.

Commercial and industrial failures turned sharply upward in the week ended on last Thursday, according to figures reported yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc. There were 182 casualties in the latest week, against 131 the week before, which included the Labor Day holiday, 145 in the 1952 week and 239 in the comparable pre-war week of 1939.

LAKE PLACID, N. Y., Sept. 22 (AP) -- A Long Island police justice, Alexander Berman of Hempstead, said today that while radar detection of speeders might be easy, it might lead to accidents. He added that the devices did the job more efficiently than police patroling in ears or motorcycles but he said that motorists generally slowed down quickly when they spotted the electronic devices and accidents might result.

Jackie Robinson, at his request, played shortstop at Ebbets Field yesterday for the first time since he was with the Kansas City Monarchs eight years ago and performed with his usual competence as the Dodgers closed their home stand with a 5-4 victory over the last-place Pirates.

ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L. I., Sept. 22 -- Otto Greiner a 34-year-old professional from the Knicker-bocker Country Club of Tonafly, N. J., and a former Deputy Collector of Internal Revenue in his native city of Baltimore before he decided to make golf his livelihood, took the lead in the first round of the Metropolitan open championship today.

There is ground for encouragement in the reports from Ankara, published in this newspaper, that Turkey and Pakistan are quietly effecting a considerable rapprochement. This can be of vital importance to the peace and stability of the entire Middle East. It can form the basis for an area of strength in what has been a region of critical weakness.

NEWARK, Sept. 22 -- Robert B. Meyner, Democratic candidate for Governor of New Jersey, today characterized the development of highway authorities as "undemocratic and a violation of the spirit of the constitution."

A plot about 174 by 110 feet on the east side of Ocean Avenue, between Avenues M and N, in the Midwood section of Brooklyn has been assembled for the Coleridge Building Company for improvement with a six-story apartment building to contain seventy-two suites and a sixty-eight-car garage.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 22 -- Andrei Y. Vishinsky, permanent representative of the Soviet Union at the United Nations, deposited today with Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold his country's instrument of accession to the Convention on the Privileges and Immunities of the United Nations.

RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, Sept. 22 -- The continued failure of India and Pakistan to settle the Kashmir issue leaves force as the only solution of the six-year-old dispute, high Pakistani military officials in the headquarters area here said today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- Secretary of Commerce Sinclair Weeks lauded the President's Committee on Employment of the Handicapped today for national, state and local leadership in placing disabled persons.

BRONXVILLE, N. Y., Sept. 22 -- Two companies from the Yonkers Fire Department were called to Sarah Lawrence College at 6:40 o'clock tonight to investigate a suspicious fire in the cellar under the college dining room, as the strike of service employes continued for the second day.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- Representative Emanuel Celler, Democrat of Brooklyn, urged the Un-American Activities Committee of the House of Representatives today to permit persons who were close to two prominent deceased rabbis whose names were linked in testimony with Communist party collaboration to reply to charges made after their deaths.

Celeste Holm, who has been shying away from scripts lately, is about to make a decision in favor of "His and Hers." Rooting for her to do so is the new firm of Albert Selden Morton Gottlieb. They feel certain everything will be arranged for the comedy, written by Michael and Fay Kanin, to go into rehearsal in November, with Mr. Kanin delegated to stage the offering.

CALDWELL, N. J., Sept. 22 -- Paul L. Troast, Republican candidate for Governor, charged here tonight that his Democratic opponent, Robert B. Meyner, was "bent on returning to a politically controlled judiciary."

ACCORDING to Messrs. Rocky Marciano and Roland LaStarza -- and you don't have to believe them if you don't want to -- neither will enter tomorrow night's fight at the Polo Grounds for the world heavyweight championship with any plans or blueprints regarding strategy.

" You should remember," said Rudolph Halley in the keynote address opening his campaign as Liberal party candidate for Mayor, "that some candidates will promise anything before election." He was speaking of others, not himself, of course. Mr. Halley's program is ambitious and there is hardly a plausible reform that he has not supported.
The Philharmonic-Symphony Society of New Yofk will open its 112th season Thursday evening, Oct. 8, with Dimitri Mitropoulos, musical director, conducting the orchestra.

WARSAW, Sept. 22 (AP) --A Polish military court today sentenced the Most Rev. Czeslaw Kaczmarek, Bishop of Kielce, and three other Roman Catholic priests to prison terms ranging up to twelve years on charges of spying for the Vatican and the United States.

ALBANY, Sept. 22 -- After a two-hour conference this morning with Governor Dewey, the State Harness Racing Commission suspended indefinitely the license of the Yonkers Raceway for failure to comply with state laws requiring affidavits by all trotting track employes.

The seventh major sale of public housing bonds backed by subsidy contracts of the Public Housing Administration was held yesterday, swelling the total outstanding supply of such bonds to $1,007,464,000.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Wednesday, Sept. 23 -- The Danish election for a new unicameral parliament held yesterday produced little change in the relative strengths of the country s many political parties. The general trend was that the two leading parties, the Social Democrats and the Agrarian Liberals, gained while the lesser parties either barely held their own or lost so much as to be removed from the political picture.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- The national board of the League of Women Voters, meeting here this week, has been making plans to start a country-wide community campaign against a go-it-alone philosophy in the field of international relations.

Thieves ransacked yesterday the Astor Hotel suite of General of the Army Omar N. Bradley, retired chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, and Mrs. Bradley. They took furs, jewelry and a portable radio, with a total value of more than $3,100, the police said last night.
ATHENS, Sept. 22 -- The Greek Government announced today it looked with favor upon a Bulgarian suggestion to resume normal diplomatic relations between Sofia and Athens.

A draw in nineteen moves in a Sicilian defense enabled Vassily Smyslov of Russia, leader in the world chess championship challengers' tournament in Zurich, to make a further gain in the thirteenth round last night, according to a Swiss news report.

DETROIT, Sept. 22 (AP) -- Satchel Paige celebrated his forty-sixth birthday -- that's according to the record books -- by winning his third game of the season tonight as the Browns defeated the Tigers, 7 -- 3.

Meyer J. Kaplan's Sunshine Nell celebrated her return to the races after a two-and-a-half-month vacation by leading a classy band of fillies and mares in the first running of the $24,750 Step Lightly Handicap at Belmont Park yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today authorized the Isbrandtsen Company, a round-the-world steamship company, to wind up its voyages by transporting cargo inter-coastally from West Coast ports to Atlantic Coast ports, Norfolk and north.

LONDON, Sept. 22 -- Faced with irreconcilable differences between the African and European delegates called here to reform the Constitution of Northern Rhodesia, the Colonial Office ended the discussions and dictated a series of Government amendments to the Constitution today.

CHICAGO, Sept. 22 (AP) -- The Indians, paced by Al Rosen's forty-first home run of the year, virtually clinched second place in the American League tonight by defeating the White Sox, 8 to 3. The victory put Cleveland three games ahead of the Sox with four games remaining.

Representative Jacob K. Javits, Republican of New York, predicted last night that the Eisenhower Administration "will find it necessary" to present to Congress a national health program as an "alternative to the National Health Insurance plan advocated by the previous administration."

THE NEW YORK TIMES (Sept. 13, Page 30) reports that Reginald Maudling, Economic Secretary to the British Treasury, "announced Britain's determination * * * to look toward intensive developments within the sterling area if assistance in her drive for convertibility were not provided."

To encourage more ad agency people to report examples of objectionable advertising they may see or hear, the American Association of Advertising Agencies has released a new series of poster reminders for agencies participating in its Interchange on Objectionable Advertising.

Millinery has a fresh slant in the hands of Lilly Dache. In her excellent fall and winter collection, seen yesterday morning in her East Fifty-sixth Street establishment, the hats, whether pillboxes, turbans or toques, all were worn well forward on the forehead.

THE HAGUE, Sept. 22 -- World production of tin concentrates and metal rose sharply in July, the International Tin Study Group reported here today. Output of concentrates was 16,100 long tons compared with 13,900 in June. Metal production was 16,400 tons against 13,500 in June.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- Philip Young, chairman of the Civil Service Commission, asserted today that he saw no cause for jitters among Federal workers over job security, and that rumors about a Republican "threat to the merit system" ought to be spiked.

GENEVA, Sept. 22 -- The Moral Rearmament Assembly, which is held every year at Caux, a mountain resort above Montreux on the Lake of Geneva, has attracted more than 6,000 persons from sixty-eight countries during this summer's session.
The newest cruiser of the British Navy, the 8,000-ton Superb, arrived here yesterday for an eight-day visit, docking at Pier 92, Hudson River at Fifty-second Street.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 22 (AP) -- Splitting a double-header with the Cubs tonight, the Redlegs maintained their two-and-a-half-game lead over Chicago, which had hopes of supplanting Cincinnati in sixth place. The Redlegs took the twilight game, 1 -- 0, and the Cubs won the second contest. 4 -- 1.

I would like to offer some interpretations of Adlai Stevenson's report to the nation which differ from those in your editorial of Sept. 17. These differences may suggest a platform for debate on foreign policy in the 1954 and 1956 elections.

Two books about the mystery of the flying saucers have been scheduled for publication next month. On Oct. 5 Henry Holt will issue "Flying Saucers From Outer Space," by Maj. Donald E. Keyhoe, Marine Corps (retired), a work based on material gathered by an Air Force agency that investigated the saucers.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 (AP) -- The Army apparently has changed. The Adjutant General's office has come up with a survey, that says that today's soldier, (1) is satisfied with his job, (2) thinks he is doing the work for which he was trained and (3) believes his chores are necessary.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- George M. Humphrey, Secretary of the Treasury, told the American Bankers Association today that "the excess profits tax will expire on Dec. 31, and there will be no request for renewal." At the same time, a 10 per cent reduction on individual income taxes is scheduled to go into effect, "and it will become effective," he said.
CLEVELAND, Sept. 22 -- Representative Alvin F. Weichel criticized the Government and American business men today for what he termed a failure to support a strong American-flag merchant marine.

The second major purge in the Georgian Communist party within the last two months is apparently aimed at removing the highest figures in both the Georgian Government and the Georgian Communist party who were installed last April when Mr. Beria was still one of the chief figures in the Soviet Union.

DELAWARE, Ohio, Sept. 22 (UP) -- Grand Circuit racing opened today at the Delaware County Fairgrounds with the 2-year-old pacing fillies racing off with the honors from the older harness horses as one world rercord was set and another tied.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- Senator Guy Cordon, Republican of Oregon, predicted today that "something will happen to change someone's mind" and thus make it possible to report the Hawaiian statehood bill in the Senate early in the next session of Congress.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Wednesday, Sept. 23 (UP) -- A Moslem separatist revolt broke out in the Atjeh area of North Sumatra Tuesday, Government reports said today.

Sooner or later the test of strength has to be made on whether Michael J. Quill or the public, through its appointed representatives, is managing the New York City transit system. This test may now be at hand, with the Transport Workers Union international president threatening an illegal slowdown in violation of his union's memorandum of understanding, which runs to Jan. 1.

TEL AVIV, Sept. 22 -- Israel and the United States remained in a close struggle for top honors in the track and field events at the Maccabiah Games, and at the close of the second day of competition tonight the home athletes were ahead, 138 points to 124.

Seven civic groups announced yesterday they had sent a joint questionnaire to the candidates for Mayor asking for their views on five leading city problems. The answers to the questions are to be made public well in advance of election to help voters make a choice among the contenders.

The Yonkers Trotting Association was the captive operator of Yonkers Raceway with all track labor and hiring policies fixed by agreement between a racket-ridden union and the Algam Corporation owners of the property, according to testimony offered last week at closed hearings of the State Harness Racing Commission and made public yesterday by order of Governor Dewey.
The New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program received 346 pints of blood on Monday. Of that total, 164 pints were donated at Fort Totten, Bayside, Queens.

CONCORD, N. H., Sept. 22 (AP) -- Gov. Hugh Gregg said today he has received several protests because the late Senator Charles W. Tobey, Republican of New Hampshire, was not included in a moment of silent homage to the late Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio at list night's Republican dinner in Boston.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- The White House said today the envelope George Meany, president of the American Federation of Labor, received, with a bulletin of The National Association of Manufacturers in it, was sent to all Presidential appointees as possible speech material.

A drastic shortage of horseradish, a result of the recent drought, has sent the wholesale price of this condiment sharply upward. A restaurateur told us yesterday he now pays 70 cents a pound compared with 30 cents a year ago.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 22 -- Humphrey Bogart and Warner Brothers today terminated an association of seventeen years when the star asked to be released from serving out the balance of one of the most fabulous contracts in film history.

LONDON, Sept. 22 -- A new purge, the third major one in eighteen months, hit the Soviet Republic of Georgia today. The two top leaders were dismissed in a shake-up, possibly mirroring a fresh struggle in the Kremlin for political control of Georgia, homeland of Stalin and Lavrenti P. Beria, deposed Soviet Minister of Internal Affairs.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- State Department officials disclaimed any knowledge tonight of a formal proposal by Yugoslavia that Austria take part in the suggested internationalization of the City of Trieste.

MONTREAL, Sept. 22 -- The United states Conference of Mayors, in annual meeting here, asked today in various resolutions for increased Federal expenditures on a wide range of projects and deplored the fact that Congress appeared not to consider the civil defense program of "major importance."

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 22 -- The Yugoslav Government has advised the Western Allies of its desire to bring Austria into the administration of the port city of Trieste under the internationalization plan proposed by Marshal Tito, Yugoslav President.

New Yorkers bade farewell yesterday to one of the hottest summers on record. At 4:07 o'clock this morning, the earth passed a point in its orbit that marked the autumnal equinox and the official arrival of fall.

EXETER, N. H., Sept., 22 -- It may be that the football picture is about to brighten at Phillips Exeter Academy. At least that's the way it seemed this afternoon as Bill Clark, the Big Red's capable coach, sent a squad of forty-nine players through a session more in keeping with a mid-season workout.

DETROIT, Sept. 23 -- An Air Force Reserve lieutenant, whose loyalty has not been questioned, said today, he faces dismissal from the service because his father and his sister have been accused of Communist associations.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 23 -- Taxes and the price of electricity could be reduced if power systems owned by governmental agencies and their customers were made to pay their fair share of taxes, Walter Sammis, president of the Edison Electric Institute, said here today.

When a one-month-old boxer puppy named Polly went to live with Richard Fowler three years ago, Richard, then 4 years old, was able to romp with the dog. He can't anymore. Polly seems to understand, and is gentle with the boy.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 23 -- Shipping industry management and maritime labor were urged today by Senator Charles E. Potter, Republican of Michigan, to adopt what he called a more realistic attitude toward costs and expenses to reduce Government subsidy aid to the lowest possible amount.

Emphasizing that Communist China continued to hold American fliers assertedly shot down over Manchuria during the Korean war, Senator Joseph R. McCarthy demanded in a speech here yesterday that United States aid to Great Britain and other Allies be cut off as long as they traded with the Chinese Communists.

Range ponies, ten-gallon hats, "levis" (tight-fitting dungarees) and six-shooters were part of the New York scene as the twenty-eighth annual world championship rodeo opened last night at Madison Square Garden. Fourteen thousand persons attended the first performance.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 23 -- Maj. Gen. William F. Dean, Medal of Honor winner and highest ranking American officer to fall captive to the Communists in the Korean fighting, sought the privacy of his family in vain here today.
Columbia University will open its 200th academic year today as 25,000 students begin to attend classes in the university's twenty major units and affiliates.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -- High Army generals, including the Chief of Staff and all his deputies, are about to be called before an impartial Pentagon study group seeking to learn their ideas for meeting President Eisenhower's call for "badly needed" reforms in the armed services.

OTTAWA, Sept. 23 (Canadian Press) -- Canada's imports continued at a high pace during July while exports lagged, widening the country's trade gap to a deficit of $206,200,000 for the first seven months of the year.
